122: 
123: PRELUDE.
124: 
125: 
126: Who that cares much to know the history of man, and how the mysterious
127: mixture behaves under the varying experiments of Time, has not dwelt,
128: at least briefly, on the life of Saint Theresa, has not smiled with
129: some gentleness at the thought of the little girl walking forth one
130: morning hand-in-hand with her still smaller brother, to go and seek
131: martyrdom in the country of the Moors? Out they toddled from rugged
132: Avila, wide-eyed and helpless-looking as two fawns, but with human
133: hearts, already beating to a national idea; until domestic reality met
134: them in the shape of uncles, and turned them back from their great
135: resolve. That child-pilgrimage was a fit beginning. Theresa’s
136: passionate, ideal nature demanded an epic life: what were many-volumed
137: romances of chivalry and the social conquests of a brilliant girl to
138: her? Her flame quickly burned up that light fuel; and, fed from within,
139: soared after some illimitable satisfaction, some object which would
140: never justify weariness, which would reconcile self-despair with the
141: rapturous consciousness of life beyond self. She found her epos in the
142: reform of a religious order.
143: 
144: That Spanish woman who lived three hundred years ago, was certainly not
145: the last of her kind. Many Theresas have been born who found for
146: themselves no epic life wherein there was a constant unfolding of
147: far-resonant action; perhaps only a life of mistakes, the offspring of
148: a certain spiritual grandeur ill-matched with the meanness of
149: opportunity; perhaps a tragic failure which found no sacred poet and
150: sank unwept into oblivion. With dim lights and tangled circumstance
151: they tried to shape their thought and deed in noble agreement; but
152: after all, to common eyes their struggles seemed mere inconsistency and
153: formlessness; for these later-born Theresas were helped by no coherent
154: social faith and order which could perform the function of knowledge
155: for the ardently willing soul. Their ardor alternated between a vague
156: ideal and the common yearning of womanhood; so that the one was
157: disapproved as extravagance, and the other condemned as a lapse.
158: 
159: Some have felt that these blundering lives are due to the inconvenient
160: indefiniteness with which the Supreme Power has fashioned the natures
161: of women: if there were one level of feminine incompetence as strict as
162: the ability to count three and no more, the social lot of women might
163: be treated with scientific certitude. Meanwhile the indefiniteness
164: remains, and the limits of variation are really much wider than any one
165: would imagine from the sameness of women’s coiffure and the favorite
166: love-stories in prose and verse. Here and there a cygnet is reared
167: uneasily among the ducklings in the brown pond, and never finds the
168: living stream in fellowship with its own oary-footed kind. Here and
169: there is born a Saint Theresa, foundress of nothing, whose loving
170: heart-beats and sobs after an unattained goodness tremble off and are
171: dispersed among hindrances, instead of centring in some
172: long-recognizable deed.
173: 
174: 
175: 
176: 
177: BOOK I.
178: MISS BROOKE.
179: 
180: 
181: 
182: 
183: CHAPTER I.
184: 
185: Since I can do no good because a woman,
186: Reach constantly at something that is near it.
187:                     —_The Maid’s Tragedy:_ BEAUMONT AND FLETCHER.
188: 
189: 
190: Miss Brooke had that kind of beauty which seems to be thrown into
191: relief by poor dress. Her hand and wrist were so finely formed that she
192: could wear sleeves not less bare of style than those in which the
193: Blessed Virgin appeared to Italian painters; and her profile as well as
194: her stature and bearing seemed to gain the more dignity from her plain
195: garments, which by the side of provincial fashion gave her the
196: impressiveness of a fine quotation from the Bible,—or from one of our
197: elder poets,—in a paragraph of to-day’s newspaper. She was usually
198: spoken of as being remarkably clever, but with the addition that her
199: sister Celia had more common-sense. Nevertheless, Celia wore scarcely
200: more trimmings; and it was only to close observers that her dress
201: differed from her sister’s, and had a shade of coquetry in its
202: arrangements; for Miss Brooke’s plain dressing was due to mixed
203: conditions, in most of which her sister shared. The pride of being
204: ladies had something to do with it: the Brooke connections, though not
205: exactly aristocratic, were unquestionably “good:” if you inquired
206: backward for a generation or two, you would not find any yard-measuring
207: or parcel-tying forefathers—anything lower than an admiral or a
208: clergyman; and there was even an ancestor discernible as a Puritan
209: gentleman who served under Cromwell, but afterwards conformed, and
210: managed to come out of all political troubles as the proprietor of a
211: respectable family estate. Young women of such birth, living in a quiet
212: country-house, and attending a village church hardly larger than a
213: parlor, naturally regarded frippery as the ambition of a huckster’s
214: daughter. Then there was well-bred economy, which in those days made
215: show in dress the first item to be deducted from, when any margin was
216: required for expenses more distinctive of rank. Such reasons would have
217: been enough to account for plain dress, quite apart from religious
218: feeling; but in Miss Brooke’s case, religion alone would have
219: determined it; and Celia mildly acquiesced in all her sister’s
220: sentiments, only infusing them with that common-sense which is able to
221: accept momentous doctrines without any eccentric agitation. Dorothea
222: knew many passages of Pascal’s Pensees and of Jeremy Taylor by heart;
223: and to her the destinies of mankind, seen by the light of Christianity,
224: made the solicitudes of feminine fashion appear an occupation for
225: Bedlam. She could not reconcile the anxieties of a spiritual life
226: involving eternal consequences, with a keen interest in gimp and
227: artificial protrusions of drapery. Her mind was theoretic, and yearned
228: by its nature after some lofty conception of the world which might
229: frankly include the parish of Tipton and her own rule of conduct there;
230: she was enamoured of intensity and greatness, and rash in embracing
231: whatever seemed to her to have those aspects; likely to seek martyrdom,
232: to make retractations, and then to incur martyrdom after all in a
233: quarter where she had not sought it. Certainly such elements in the
234: character of a marriageable girl tended to interfere with her lot, and
235: hinder it from being decided according to custom, by good looks,
236: vanity, and merely canine affection. With all this, she, the elder of
237: the sisters, was not yet twenty, and they had both been educated, since
238: they were about twelve years old and had lost their parents, on plans
239: at once narrow and promiscuous, first in an English family and
240: afterwards in a Swiss family at Lausanne, their bachelor uncle and
241: guardian trying in this way to remedy the disadvantages of their
242: orphaned condition.
243: 
244: It was hardly a year since they had come to live at Tipton Grange with
245: their uncle, a man nearly sixty, of acquiescent temper, miscellaneous
246: opinions, and uncertain vote. He had travelled in his younger years,
247: and was held in this part of the county to have contracted a too
248: rambling habit of mind. Mr. Brooke’s conclusions were as difficult to
249: predict as the weather: it was only safe to say that he would act with
250: benevolent intentions, and that he would spend as little money as
251: possible in carrying them out. For the most glutinously indefinite
252: minds enclose some hard grains of habit; and a man has been seen lax
253: about all his own interests except the retention of his snuff-box,
254: concerning which he was watchful, suspicious, and greedy of clutch.
255: 
256: In Mr. Brooke the hereditary strain of Puritan energy was clearly in
257: abeyance; but in his niece Dorothea it glowed alike through faults and
258: virtues, turning sometimes into impatience of her uncle’s talk or his
259: way of “letting things be” on his estate, and making her long all the
260: more for the time when she would be of age and have some command of
261: money for generous schemes. She was regarded as an heiress; for not
262: only had the sisters seven hundred a-year each from their parents, but
263: if Dorothea married and had a son, that son would inherit Mr. Brooke’s
264: estate, presumably worth about three thousand a-year—a rental which
265: seemed wealth to provincial families, still discussing Mr. Peel’s late
266: conduct on the Catholic question, innocent of future gold-fields, and
267: of that gorgeous plutocracy which has so nobly exalted the necessities
268: of genteel life.
269: 
270: And how should Dorothea not marry?—a girl so handsome and with such
271: prospects? Nothing could hinder it but her love of extremes, and her
272: insistence on regulating life according to notions which might cause a
273: wary man to hesitate before he made her an offer, or even might lead
274: her at last to refuse all offers. A young lady of some birth and
275: fortune, who knelt suddenly down on a brick floor by the side of a sick
276: laborer and prayed fervidly as if she thought herself living in the
277: time of the Apostles—who had strange whims of fasting like a Papist,
278: and of sitting up at night to read old theological books! Such a wife
279: might awaken you some fine morning with a new scheme for the
280: application of her income which would interfere with political economy
281: and the keeping of saddle-horses: a man would naturally think twice
282: before he risked himself in such fellowship. Women were expected to
283: have weak opinions; but the great safeguard of society and of domestic
284: life was, that opinions were not acted on. Sane people did what their
285: neighbors did, so that if any lunatics were at large, one might know
286: and avoid them.
287: 
288: The rural opinion about the new young ladies, even among the cottagers,
289: was generally in favor of Celia, as being so amiable and
290: innocent-looking, while Miss Brooke’s large eyes seemed, like her
291: religion, too unusual and striking. Poor Dorothea! compared with her,
292: the innocent-looking Celia was knowing and worldly-wise; so much
293: subtler is a human mind than the outside tissues which make a sort of
294: blazonry or clock-face for it.
295: 
296: Yet those who approached Dorothea, though prejudiced against her by
297: this alarming hearsay, found that she had a charm unaccountably
298: reconcilable with it. Most men thought her bewitching when she was on
299: horseback. She loved the fresh air and the various aspects of the
300: country, and when her eyes and cheeks glowed with mingled pleasure she
301: looked very little like a devotee. Riding was an indulgence which she
302: allowed herself in spite of conscientious qualms; she felt that she
303: enjoyed it in a pagan sensuous way, and always looked forward to
304: renouncing it.
305: 
306: She was open, ardent, and not in the least self-admiring; indeed, it
307: was pretty to see how her imagination adorned her sister Celia with
308: attractions altogether superior to her own, and if any gentleman
309: appeared to come to the Grange from some other motive than that of
310: seeing Mr. Brooke, she concluded that he must be in love with Celia:
311: Sir James Chettam, for example, whom she constantly considered from
312: Celia’s point of view, inwardly debating whether it would be good for
313: Celia to accept him. That he should be regarded as a suitor to herself
314: would have seemed to her a ridiculous irrelevance. Dorothea, with all
315: her eagerness to know the truths of life, retained very childlike ideas
316: about marriage. She felt sure that she would have accepted the
317: judicious Hooker, if she had been born in time to save him from that
318: wretched mistake he made in matrimony; or John Milton when his
319: blindness had come on; or any of the other great men whose odd habits
320: it would have been glorious piety to endure; but an amiable handsome
321: baronet, who said “Exactly” to her remarks even when she expressed
322: uncertainty,—how could he affect her as a lover? The really delightful
323: marriage must be that where your husband was a sort of father, and
324: could teach you even Hebrew, if you wished it.
325: 
326: These peculiarities of Dorothea’s character caused Mr. Brooke to be all
327: the more blamed in neighboring families for not securing some
328: middle-aged lady as guide and companion to his nieces. But he himself
329: dreaded so much the sort of superior woman likely to be available for
330: such a position, that he allowed himself to be dissuaded by Dorothea’s
331: objections, and was in this case brave enough to defy the world—that is
332: to say, Mrs. Cadwallader the Rector’s wife, and the small group of
333: gentry with whom he visited in the northeast corner of Loamshire. So
334: Miss Brooke presided in her uncle’s household, and did not at all
335: dislike her new authority, with the homage that belonged to it.
336: 
337: Sir James Chettam was going to dine at the Grange to-day with another
338: gentleman whom the girls had never seen, and about whom Dorothea felt
339: some venerating expectation. This was the Reverend Edward Casaubon,
340: noted in the county as a man of profound learning, understood for many
341: years to be engaged on a great work concerning religious history; also
342: as a man of wealth enough to give lustre to his piety, and having views
343: of his own which were to be more clearly ascertained on the publication
344: of his book. His very name carried an impressiveness hardly to be
345: measured without a precise chronology of scholarship.
346: 
347: Early in the day Dorothea had returned from the infant school which she
348: had set going in the village, and was taking her usual place in the
349: pretty sitting-room which divided the bedrooms of the sisters, bent on
350: finishing a plan for some buildings (a kind of work which she delighted
351: in), when Celia, who had been watching her with a hesitating desire to
352: propose something, said—
353: 
354: “Dorothea, dear, if you don’t mind—if you are not very busy—suppose we
355: looked at mamma’s jewels to-day, and divided them? It is exactly six
356: months to-day since uncle gave them to you, and you have not looked at
357: them yet.”
358: 
359: Celia’s face had the shadow of a pouting expression in it, the full
360: presence of the pout being kept back by an habitual awe of Dorothea and
361: principle; two associated facts which might show a mysterious
362: electricity if you touched them incautiously. To her relief, Dorothea’s
363: eyes were full of laughter as she looked up.
364: 
365: “What a wonderful little almanac you are, Celia! Is it six calendar or
366: six lunar months?”
367: 
368: “It is the last day of September now, and it was the first of April
369: when uncle gave them to you. You know, he said that he had forgotten
370: them till then. I believe you have never thought of them since you
371: locked them up in the cabinet here.”
372: 
373: “Well, dear, we should never wear them, you know.” Dorothea spoke in a
374: full cordial tone, half caressing, half explanatory. She had her pencil
375: in her hand, and was making tiny side-plans on a margin.
376: 
377: Celia colored, and looked very grave. “I think, dear, we are wanting in
378: respect to mamma’s memory, to put them by and take no notice of them.
379: And,” she added, after hesitating a little, with a rising sob of
380: mortification, “necklaces are quite usual now; and Madame Poincon, who
381: was stricter in some things even than you are, used to wear ornaments.
382: And Christians generally—surely there are women in heaven now who wore
383: jewels.” Celia was conscious of some mental strength when she really
384: applied herself to argument.
385: 
386: “You would like to wear them?” exclaimed Dorothea, an air of astonished
387: discovery animating her whole person with a dramatic action which she
388: had caught from that very Madame Poincon who wore the ornaments. “Of
389: course, then, let us have them out. Why did you not tell me before? But
390: the keys, the keys!” She pressed her hands against the sides of her
391: head and seemed to despair of her memory.
392: 
393: “They are here,” said Celia, with whom this explanation had been long
394: meditated and prearranged.
395: 
396: “Pray open the large drawer of the cabinet and get out the jewel-box.”
397: 
398: The casket was soon open before them, and the various jewels spread
399: out, making a bright parterre on the table. It was no great collection,
400: but a few of the ornaments were really of remarkable beauty, the finest
401: that was obvious at first being a necklace of purple amethysts set in
402: exquisite gold work, and a pearl cross with five brilliants in it.
403: Dorothea immediately took up the necklace and fastened it round her
404: sister’s neck, where it fitted almost as closely as a bracelet; but the
405: circle suited the Henrietta-Maria style of Celia’s head and neck, and
406: she could see that it did, in the pier-glass opposite.
407: 
408: “There, Celia! you can wear that with your Indian muslin. But this
409: cross you must wear with your dark dresses.”
410: 
411: Celia was trying not to smile with pleasure. “O Dodo, you must keep the
412: cross yourself.”
413: 
414: “No, no, dear, no,” said Dorothea, putting up her hand with careless
415: deprecation.
416: 
417: “Yes, indeed you must; it would suit you—in your black dress, now,”
418: said Celia, insistingly. “You _might_ wear that.”
419: 
420: “Not for the world, not for the world. A cross is the last thing I
421: would wear as a trinket.” Dorothea shuddered slightly.
422: 
423: “Then you will think it wicked in me to wear it,” said Celia, uneasily.
424: 
425: “No, dear, no,” said Dorothea, stroking her sister’s cheek. “Souls have
426: complexions too: what will suit one will not suit another.”
427: 
428: “But you might like to keep it for mamma’s sake.”
429: 
430: “No, I have other things of mamma’s—her sandal-wood box which I am so
431: fond of—plenty of things. In fact, they are all yours, dear. We need
432: discuss them no longer. There—take away your property.”
433: 
434: Celia felt a little hurt. There was a strong assumption of superiority
435: in this Puritanic toleration, hardly less trying to the blond flesh of
436: an unenthusiastic sister than a Puritanic persecution.
437: 
438: “But how can I wear ornaments if you, who are the elder sister, will
439: never wear them?”
440: 
441: “Nay, Celia, that is too much to ask, that I should wear trinkets to
442: keep you in countenance. If I were to put on such a necklace as that, I
443: should feel as if I had been pirouetting. The world would go round with
444: me, and I should not know how to walk.”
445: 
446: Celia had unclasped the necklace and drawn it off. “It would be a
447: little tight for your neck; something to lie down and hang would suit
448: you better,” she said, with some satisfaction. The complete unfitness
449: of the necklace from all points of view for Dorothea, made Celia
450: happier in taking it. She was opening some ring-boxes, which disclosed
451: a fine emerald with diamonds, and just then the sun passing beyond a
452: cloud sent a bright gleam over the table.
453: 
454: “How very beautiful these gems are!” said Dorothea, under a new current
455: of feeling, as sudden as the gleam. “It is strange how deeply colors
456: seem to penetrate one, like scent. I suppose that is the reason why
457: gems are used as spiritual emblems in the Revelation of St. John. They
458: look like fragments of heaven. I think that emerald is more beautiful
459: than any of them.”
460: 
461: “And there is a bracelet to match it,” said Celia. “We did not notice
462: this at first.”
463: 
464: “They are lovely,” said Dorothea, slipping the ring and bracelet on her
465: finely turned finger and wrist, and holding them towards the window on
466: a level with her eyes. All the while her thought was trying to justify
467: her delight in the colors by merging them in her mystic religious joy.
468: 
469: “You _would_ like those, Dorothea,” said Celia, rather falteringly,
470: beginning to think with wonder that her sister showed some weakness,
471: and also that emeralds would suit her own complexion even better than
472: purple amethysts. “You must keep that ring and bracelet—if nothing
473: else. But see, these agates are very pretty and quiet.”
474: 
475: “Yes! I will keep these—this ring and bracelet,” said Dorothea. Then,
476: letting her hand fall on the table, she said in another tone—“Yet what
477: miserable men find such things, and work at them, and sell them!” She
478: paused again, and Celia thought that her sister was going to renounce
479: the ornaments, as in consistency she ought to do.
480: 
481: “Yes, dear, I will keep these,” said Dorothea, decidedly. “But take all
482: the rest away, and the casket.”
483: 
484: She took up her pencil without removing the jewels, and still looking
485: at them. She thought of often having them by her, to feed her eye at
486: these little fountains of pure color.
487: 
488: “Shall you wear them in company?” said Celia, who was watching her with
489: real curiosity as to what she would do.
490: 
491: Dorothea glanced quickly at her sister. Across all her imaginative
492: adornment of those whom she loved, there darted now and then a keen
493: discernment, which was not without a scorching quality. If Miss Brooke
494: ever attained perfect meekness, it would not be for lack of inward
495: fire.
496: 
497: “Perhaps,” she said, rather haughtily. “I cannot tell to what level I
498: may sink.”
499: 
500: Celia blushed, and was unhappy: she saw that she had offended her
501: sister, and dared not say even anything pretty about the gift of the
502: ornaments which she put back into the box and carried away. Dorothea
503: too was unhappy, as she went on with her plan-drawing, questioning the
504: purity of her own feeling and speech in the scene which had ended with
505: that little explosion.
506: 
507: Celia’s consciousness told her that she had not been at all in the
508: wrong: it was quite natural and justifiable that she should have asked
509: that question, and she repeated to herself that Dorothea was
510: inconsistent: either she should have taken her full share of the
511: jewels, or, after what she had said, she should have renounced them
512: altogether.
513: 
514: “I am sure—at least, I trust,” thought Celia, “that the wearing of a
515: necklace will not interfere with my prayers. And I do not see that I
516: should be bound by Dorothea’s opinions now we are going into society,
517: though of course she herself ought to be bound by them. But Dorothea is
518: not always consistent.”
519: 
520: Thus Celia, mutely bending over her tapestry, until she heard her
521: sister calling her.
522: 
523: “Here, Kitty, come and look at my plan; I shall think I am a great
524: architect, if I have not got incompatible stairs and fireplaces.”
525: 
526: As Celia bent over the paper, Dorothea put her cheek against her
527: sister’s arm caressingly. Celia understood the action. Dorothea saw
528: that she had been in the wrong, and Celia pardoned her. Since they
529: could remember, there had been a mixture of criticism and awe in the
530: attitude of Celia’s mind towards her elder sister. The younger had
531: always worn a yoke; but is there any yoked creature without its private
532: opinions?
533: 
534: 
535: 
536: 
537: CHAPTER II.
538: 
539: “‘Dime; no ves aquel caballero que hacia nosotros viene sobre un
540: caballo rucio rodado que trae puesto en la cabeza un yelmo de oro?’ ‘Lo
541: que veo y columbro,’ respondio Sancho, ‘no es sino un hombre sobre un
542: as no pardo como el mio, que trae sobre la cabeza una cosa que
543: relumbra.’ ‘Pues ese es el yelmo de Mambrino,’ dijo Don
544: Quijote.”—CERVANTES.
545: 
546: 
547: “‘Seest thou not yon cavalier who cometh toward us on a dapple-gray
548: steed, and weareth a golden helmet?’ ‘What I see,’ answered Sancho, ‘is
549: nothing but a man on a gray ass like my own, who carries something
550: shiny on his head.’ ‘Just so,’ answered Don Quixote: ‘and that
551: resplendent object is the helmet of Mambrino.’”
552: 
553: 
554: “Sir Humphry Davy?” said Mr. Brooke, over the soup, in his easy smiling
555: way, taking up Sir James Chettam’s remark that he was studying Davy’s
556: Agricultural Chemistry. “Well, now, Sir Humphry Davy; I dined with him
557: years ago at Cartwright’s, and Wordsworth was there too—the poet
558: Wordsworth, you know. Now there was something singular. I was at
559: Cambridge when Wordsworth was there, and I never met him—and I dined
560: with him twenty years afterwards at Cartwright’s. There’s an oddity in
561: things, now. But Davy was there: he was a poet too. Or, as I may say,
562: Wordsworth was poet one, and Davy was poet two. That was true in every
563: sense, you know.”
564: 
565: Dorothea felt a little more uneasy than usual. In the beginning of
566: dinner, the party being small and the room still, these motes from the
567: mass of a magistrate’s mind fell too noticeably. She wondered how a man
568: like Mr. Casaubon would support such triviality. His manners, she
569: thought, were very dignified; the set of his iron-gray hair and his
570: deep eye-sockets made him resemble the portrait of Locke. He had the
571: spare form and the pale complexion which became a student; as different
572: as possible from the blooming Englishman of the red-whiskered type
573: represented by Sir James Chettam.
574: 
575: “I am reading the Agricultural Chemistry,” said this excellent baronet,
576: “because I am going to take one of the farms into my own hands, and see
577: if something cannot be done in setting a good pattern of farming among
578: my tenants. Do you approve of that, Miss Brooke?”
579: 
580: “A great mistake, Chettam,” interposed Mr. Brooke, “going into
581: electrifying your land and that kind of thing, and making a parlor of
582: your cow-house. It won’t do. I went into science a great deal myself at
583: one time; but I saw it would not do. It leads to everything; you can
584: let nothing alone. No, no—see that your tenants don’t sell their straw,
585: and that kind of thing; and give them draining-tiles, you know. But
586: your fancy farming will not do—the most expensive sort of whistle you
587: can buy: you may as well keep a pack of hounds.”
588: 
589: “Surely,” said Dorothea, “it is better to spend money in finding out
590: how men can make the most of the land which supports them all, than in
591: keeping dogs and horses only to gallop over it. It is not a sin to make
592: yourself poor in performing experiments for the good of all.”
593: 
594: She spoke with more energy than is expected of so young a lady, but Sir
595: James had appealed to her. He was accustomed to do so, and she had
596: often thought that she could urge him to many good actions when he was
597: her brother-in-law.
598: 
599: Mr. Casaubon turned his eyes very markedly on Dorothea while she was
600: speaking, and seemed to observe her newly.
601: 
602: “Young ladies don’t understand political economy, you know,” said Mr.
603: Brooke, smiling towards Mr. Casaubon. “I remember when we were all
604: reading Adam Smith. _There_ is a book, now. I took in all the new ideas
605: at one time—human perfectibility, now. But some say, history moves in
606: circles; and that may be very well argued; I have argued it myself. The
607: fact is, human reason may carry you a little too far—over the hedge, in
608: fact. It carried me a good way at one time; but I saw it would not do.
609: I pulled up; I pulled up in time. But not too hard. I have always been
610: in favor of a little theory: we must have Thought; else we shall be
611: landed back in the dark ages. But talking of books, there is Southey’s
612: ‘Peninsular War.’ I am reading that of a morning. You know Southey?”
613: 
614: “No,” said Mr. Casaubon, not keeping pace with Mr. Brooke’s impetuous
615: reason, and thinking of the book only. “I have little leisure for such
616: literature just now. I have been using up my eyesight on old characters
617: lately; the fact is, I want a reader for my evenings; but I am
618: fastidious in voices, and I cannot endure listening to an imperfect
619: reader. It is a misfortune, in some senses: I feed too much on the
620: inward sources; I live too much with the dead. My mind is something
621: like the ghost of an ancient, wandering about the world and trying
622: mentally to construct it as it used to be, in spite of ruin and
623: confusing changes. But I find it necessary to use the utmost caution
624: about my eyesight.”
625: 
626: This was the first time that Mr. Casaubon had spoken at any length. He
627: delivered himself with precision, as if he had been called upon to make
628: a public statement; and the balanced sing-song neatness of his speech,
629: occasionally corresponded to by a movement of his head, was the more
630: conspicuous from its contrast with good Mr. Brooke’s scrappy
631: slovenliness. Dorothea said to herself that Mr. Casaubon was the most
632: interesting man she had ever seen, not excepting even Monsieur Liret,
633: the Vaudois clergyman who had given conferences on the history of the
634: Waldenses. To reconstruct a past world, doubtless with a view to the
635: highest purposes of truth—what a work to be in any way present at, to
636: assist in, though only as a lamp-holder! This elevating thought lifted
637: her above her annoyance at being twitted with her ignorance of
638: political economy, that never-explained science which was thrust as an
639: extinguisher over all her lights.
640: 
641: “But you are fond of riding, Miss Brooke,” Sir James presently took an
642: opportunity of saying. “I should have thought you would enter a little
643: into the pleasures of hunting. I wish you would let me send over a
644: chestnut horse for you to try. It has been trained for a lady. I saw
645: you on Saturday cantering over the hill on a nag not worthy of you. My
646: groom shall bring Corydon for you every day, if you will only mention
647: the time.”
648: 
649: “Thank you, you are very good. I mean to give up riding. I shall not
650: ride any more,” said Dorothea, urged to this brusque resolution by a
651: little annoyance that Sir James would be soliciting her attention when
652: she wanted to give it all to Mr. Casaubon.
653: 
654: “No, that is too hard,” said Sir James, in a tone of reproach that
655: showed strong interest. “Your sister is given to self-mortification, is
656: she not?” he continued, turning to Celia, who sat at his right hand.
657: 
658: “I think she is,” said Celia, feeling afraid lest she should say
659: something that would not please her sister, and blushing as prettily as
660: possible above her necklace. “She likes giving up.”
661: 
662: “If that were true, Celia, my giving-up would be self-indulgence, not
663: self-mortification. But there may be good reasons for choosing not to
664: do what is very agreeable,” said Dorothea.
665: 
666: Mr. Brooke was speaking at the same time, but it was evident that Mr.
667: Casaubon was observing Dorothea, and she was aware of it.
668: 
669: “Exactly,” said Sir James. “You give up from some high, generous
670: motive.”
671: 
672: “No, indeed, not exactly. I did not say that of myself,” answered
673: Dorothea, reddening. Unlike Celia, she rarely blushed, and only from
674: high delight or anger. At this moment she felt angry with the perverse
675: Sir James. Why did he not pay attention to Celia, and leave her to
676: listen to Mr. Casaubon?—if that learned man would only talk, instead of
677: allowing himself to be talked to by Mr. Brooke, who was just then
678: informing him that the Reformation either meant something or it did
679: not, that he himself was a Protestant to the core, but that Catholicism
680: was a fact; and as to refusing an acre of your ground for a Romanist
681: chapel, all men needed the bridle of religion, which, properly
682: speaking, was the dread of a Hereafter.
683: 
684: “I made a great study of theology at one time,” said Mr. Brooke, as if
685: to explain the insight just manifested. “I know something of all
686: schools. I knew Wilberforce in his best days. Do you know Wilberforce?”
687: 
688: Mr. Casaubon said, “No.”
689: 
690: “Well, Wilberforce was perhaps not enough of a thinker; but if I went
691: into Parliament, as I have been asked to do, I should sit on the
692: independent bench, as Wilberforce did, and work at philanthropy.”
693: 
694: Mr. Casaubon bowed, and observed that it was a wide field.
695: 
696: “Yes,” said Mr. Brooke, with an easy smile, “but I have documents. I
697: began a long while ago to collect documents. They want arranging, but
698: when a question has struck me, I have written to somebody and got an
699: answer. I have documents at my back. But now, how do you arrange your
700: documents?”
701: 
702: “In pigeon-holes partly,” said Mr. Casaubon, with rather a startled air
703: of effort.
704: 
705: “Ah, pigeon-holes will not do. I have tried pigeon-holes, but
706: everything gets mixed in pigeon-holes: I never know whether a paper is
707: in A or Z.”
708: 
709: “I wish you would let me sort your papers for you, uncle,” said
710: Dorothea. “I would letter them all, and then make a list of subjects
711: under each letter.”
712: 
713: Mr. Casaubon gravely smiled approval, and said to Mr. Brooke, “You have
714: an excellent secretary at hand, you perceive.”
715: 
716: “No, no,” said Mr. Brooke, shaking his head; “I cannot let young ladies
717: meddle with my documents. Young ladies are too flighty.”
718: 
719: Dorothea felt hurt. Mr. Casaubon would think that her uncle had some
720: special reason for delivering this opinion, whereas the remark lay in
721: his mind as lightly as the broken wing of an insect among all the other
722: fragments there, and a chance current had sent it alighting on _her_.
723: 
724: When the two girls were in the drawing-room alone, Celia said—
725: 
726: “How very ugly Mr. Casaubon is!”
727: 
728: “Celia! He is one of the most distinguished-looking men I ever saw. He
729: is remarkably like the portrait of Locke. He has the same deep
730: eye-sockets.”
731: 
732: “Had Locke those two white moles with hairs on them?”
733: 
734: “Oh, I dare say! when people of a certain sort looked at him,” said
735: Dorothea, walking away a little.
736: 
737: “Mr. Casaubon is so sallow.”
738: 
739: “All the better. I suppose you admire a man with the complexion of a
740: _cochon de lait_.”
741: 
742: “Dodo!” exclaimed Celia, looking after her in surprise. “I never heard
743: you make such a comparison before.”
744: 
745: “Why should I make it before the occasion came? It is a good
746: comparison: the match is perfect.”
747: 
748: Miss Brooke was clearly forgetting herself, and Celia thought so.
749: 
750: “I wonder you show temper, Dorothea.”
751: 
752: “It is so painful in you, Celia, that you will look at human beings as
753: if they were merely animals with a toilet, and never see the great soul
754: in a man’s face.”
755: 
756: “Has Mr. Casaubon a great soul?” Celia was not without a touch of naive
757: malice.
758: 
759: “Yes, I believe he has,” said Dorothea, with the full voice of
760: decision. “Everything I see in him corresponds to his pamphlet on
761: Biblical Cosmology.”
762: 
763: “He talks very little,” said Celia
764: 
765: “There is no one for him to talk to.”
766: 
767: Celia thought privately, “Dorothea quite despises Sir James Chettam; I
768: believe she would not accept him.” Celia felt that this was a pity. She
769: had never been deceived as to the object of the baronet’s interest.
770: Sometimes, indeed, she had reflected that Dodo would perhaps not make a
771: husband happy who had not her way of looking at things; and stifled in
772: the depths of her heart was the feeling that her sister was too
773: religious for family comfort. Notions and scruples were like spilt
774: needles, making one afraid of treading, or sitting down, or even
775: eating.
776: 
777: When Miss Brooke was at the tea-table, Sir James came to sit down by
778: her, not having felt her mode of answering him at all offensive. Why
779: should he? He thought it probable that Miss Brooke liked him, and
780: manners must be very marked indeed before they cease to be interpreted
781: by preconceptions either confident or distrustful. She was thoroughly
782: charming to him, but of course he theorized a little about his
783: attachment. He was made of excellent human dough, and had the rare
784: merit of knowing that his talents, even if let loose, would not set the
785: smallest stream in the county on fire: hence he liked the prospect of a
786: wife to whom he could say, “What shall we do?” about this or that; who
787: could help her husband out with reasons, and would also have the
788: property qualification for doing so. As to the excessive religiousness
789: alleged against Miss Brooke, he had a very indefinite notion of what it
790: consisted in, and thought that it would die out with marriage. In
791: short, he felt himself to be in love in the right place, and was ready
792: to endure a great deal of predominance, which, after all, a man could
793: always put down when he liked. Sir James had no idea that he should
794: ever like to put down the predominance of this handsome girl, in whose
795: cleverness he delighted. Why not? A man’s mind—what there is of it—has
796: always the advantage of being masculine,—as the smallest birch-tree is
797: of a higher kind than the most soaring palm,—and even his ignorance is
798: of a sounder quality. Sir James might not have originated this
799: estimate; but a kind Providence furnishes the limpest personality with
800: a little gum or starch in the form of tradition.
801: 
802: “Let me hope that you will rescind that resolution about the horse,
803: Miss Brooke,” said the persevering admirer. “I assure you, riding is
804: the most healthy of exercises.”
805: 
806: “I am aware of it,” said Dorothea, coldly. “I think it would do Celia
807: good—if she would take to it.”
808: 
809: “But you are such a perfect horsewoman.”
810: 
811: “Excuse me; I have had very little practice, and I should be easily
812: thrown.”
813: 
814: “Then that is a reason for more practice. Every lady ought to be a
815: perfect horsewoman, that she may accompany her husband.”
816: 
817: “You see how widely we differ, Sir James. I have made up my mind that I
818: ought not to be a perfect horsewoman, and so I should never correspond
819: to your pattern of a lady.” Dorothea looked straight before her, and
820: spoke with cold brusquerie, very much with the air of a handsome boy,
821: in amusing contrast with the solicitous amiability of her admirer.
822: 
823: “I should like to know your reasons for this cruel resolution. It is
824: not possible that you should think horsemanship wrong.”
825: 
826: “It is quite possible that I should think it wrong for me.”
827: 
828: “Oh, why?” said Sir James, in a tender tone of remonstrance.
829: 
830: Mr. Casaubon had come up to the table, teacup in hand, and was
831: listening.
832: 
833: “We must not inquire too curiously into motives,” he interposed, in his
834: measured way. “Miss Brooke knows that they are apt to become feeble in
835: the utterance: the aroma is mixed with the grosser air. We must keep
836: the germinating grain away from the light.”
837: 
838: Dorothea colored with pleasure, and looked up gratefully to the
839: speaker. Here was a man who could understand the higher inward life,
840: and with whom there could be some spiritual communion; nay, who could
841: illuminate principle with the widest knowledge: a man whose learning
842: almost amounted to a proof of whatever he believed!
843: 
844: Dorothea’s inferences may seem large; but really life could never have
845: gone on at any period but for this liberal allowance of conclusions,
846: which has facilitated marriage under the difficulties of civilization.
847: Has any one ever pinched into its pilulous smallness the cobweb of
848: pre-matrimonial acquaintanceship?
849: 
850: “Certainly,” said good Sir James. “Miss Brooke shall not be urged to
851: tell reasons she would rather be silent upon. I am sure her reasons
852: would do her honor.”
853: 
854: He was not in the least jealous of the interest with which Dorothea had
855: looked up at Mr. Casaubon: it never occurred to him that a girl to whom
856: he was meditating an offer of marriage could care for a dried bookworm
857: towards fifty, except, indeed, in a religious sort of way, as for a
858: clergyman of some distinction.
859: 
860: However, since Miss Brooke had become engaged in a conversation with
861: Mr. Casaubon about the Vaudois clergy, Sir James betook himself to
862: Celia, and talked to her about her sister; spoke of a house in town,
863: and asked whether Miss Brooke disliked London. Away from her sister,
864: Celia talked quite easily, and Sir James said to himself that the
865: second Miss Brooke was certainly very agreeable as well as pretty,
866: though not, as some people pretended, more clever and sensible than the
867: elder sister. He felt that he had chosen the one who was in all
868: respects the superior; and a man naturally likes to look forward to
869: having the best. He would be the very Mawworm of bachelors who
870: pretended not to expect it.
871: 
872: 
873: 
874: 
875: CHAPTER III.
876: 
877: “Say, goddess, what ensued, when Raphael,
878: The affable archangel . . .
879:                     Eve
880: The story heard attentive, and was filled
881: With admiration, and deep muse, to hear
882: Of things so high and strange.”
883: —_Paradise Lost_, B. vii.
884: 
885: 
886: If it had really occurred to Mr. Casaubon to think of Miss Brooke as a
887: suitable wife for him, the reasons that might induce her to accept him
888: were already planted in her mind, and by the evening of the next day
889: the reasons had budded and bloomed. For they had had a long
890: conversation in the morning, while Celia, who did not like the company
891: of Mr. Casaubon’s moles and sallowness, had escaped to the vicarage to
892: play with the curate’s ill-shod but merry children.
893: 
894: Dorothea by this time had looked deep into the ungauged reservoir of
895: Mr. Casaubon’s mind, seeing reflected there in vague labyrinthine
896: extension every quality she herself brought; had opened much of her own
897: experience to him, and had understood from him the scope of his great
898: work, also of attractively labyrinthine extent. For he had been as
899: instructive as Milton’s “affable archangel;” and with something of the
900: archangelic manner he told her how he had undertaken to show (what
901: indeed had been attempted before, but not with that thoroughness,
902: justice of comparison, and effectiveness of arrangement at which Mr.
903: Casaubon aimed) that all the mythical systems or erratic mythical
904: fragments in the world were corruptions of a tradition originally
905: revealed. Having once mastered the true position and taken a firm
906: footing there, the vast field of mythical constructions became
907: intelligible, nay, luminous with the reflected light of
908: correspondences. But to gather in this great harvest of truth was no
909: light or speedy work. His notes already made a formidable range of
910: volumes, but the crowning task would be to condense these voluminous
911: still-accumulating results and bring them, like the earlier vintage of
912: Hippocratic books, to fit a little shelf. In explaining this to
913: Dorothea, Mr. Casaubon expressed himself nearly as he would have done
914: to a fellow-student, for he had not two styles of talking at command:
915: it is true that when he used a Greek or Latin phrase he always gave the
916: English with scrupulous care, but he would probably have done this in
917: any case. A learned provincial clergyman is accustomed to think of his
918: acquaintances as of “lords, knyghtes, and other noble and worthi men,
919: that conne Latyn but lytille.”
920: 
921: Dorothea was altogether captivated by the wide embrace of this
922: conception. Here was something beyond the shallows of ladies’ school
923: literature: here was a living Bossuet, whose work would reconcile
924: complete knowledge with devoted piety; here was a modern Augustine who
925: united the glories of doctor and saint.
926: 
927: The sanctity seemed no less clearly marked than the learning, for when
928: Dorothea was impelled to open her mind on certain themes which she
929: could speak of to no one whom she had before seen at Tipton, especially
930: on the secondary importance of ecclesiastical forms and articles of
931: belief compared with that spiritual religion, that submergence of self
932: in communion with Divine perfection which seemed to her to be expressed
933: in the best Christian books of widely distant ages, she found in Mr.
934: Casaubon a listener who understood her at once, who could assure her of
935: his own agreement with that view when duly tempered with wise
936: conformity, and could mention historical examples before unknown to
937: her.
938: 
939: “He thinks with me,” said Dorothea to herself, “or rather, he thinks a
940: whole world of which my thought is but a poor twopenny mirror. And his
941: feelings too, his whole experience—what a lake compared with my little
942: pool!”
943: 
944: Miss Brooke argued from words and dispositions not less unhesitatingly
945: than other young ladies of her age. Signs are small measurable things,
946: but interpretations are illimitable, and in girls of sweet, ardent
947: nature, every sign is apt to conjure up wonder, hope, belief, vast as a
948: sky, and colored by a diffused thimbleful of matter in the shape of
949: knowledge. They are not always too grossly deceived; for Sinbad himself
950: may have fallen by good-luck on a true description, and wrong reasoning
951: sometimes lands poor mortals in right conclusions: starting a long way
952: off the true point, and proceeding by loops and zigzags, we now and
953: then arrive just where we ought to be. Because Miss Brooke was hasty in
954: her trust, it is not therefore clear that Mr. Casaubon was unworthy of
955: it.
956: 
957: He stayed a little longer than he had intended, on a slight pressure of
958: invitation from Mr. Brooke, who offered no bait except his own
959: documents on machine-breaking and rick-burning. Mr. Casaubon was called
960: into the library to look at these in a heap, while his host picked up
961: first one and then the other to read aloud from in a skipping and
962: uncertain way, passing from one unfinished passage to another with a
963: “Yes, now, but here!” and finally pushing them all aside to open the
964: journal of his youthful Continental travels.
965: 
966: “Look here—here is all about Greece. Rhamnus, the ruins of Rhamnus—you
967: are a great Grecian, now. I don’t know whether you have given much
968: study to the topography. I spent no end of time in making out these
969: things—Helicon, now. Here, now!—‘We started the next morning for
970: Parnassus, the double-peaked Parnassus.’ All this volume is about
971: Greece, you know,” Mr. Brooke wound up, rubbing his thumb transversely
972: along the edges of the leaves as he held the book forward.
973: 
974: Mr. Casaubon made a dignified though somewhat sad audience; bowed in
975: the right place, and avoided looking at anything documentary as far as
976: possible, without showing disregard or impatience; mindful that this
977: desultoriness was associated with the institutions of the country, and
978: that the man who took him on this severe mental scamper was not only an
979: amiable host, but a landholder and custos rotulorum. Was his endurance
980: aided also by the reflection that Mr. Brooke was the uncle of Dorothea?
981: 
982: Certainly he seemed more and more bent on making her talk to him, on
983: drawing her out, as Celia remarked to herself; and in looking at her
984: his face was often lit up by a smile like pale wintry sunshine. Before
985: he left the next morning, while taking a pleasant walk with Miss Brooke
986: along the gravelled terrace, he had mentioned to her that he felt the
987: disadvantage of loneliness, the need of that cheerful companionship
988: with which the presence of youth can lighten or vary the serious toils
989: of maturity. And he delivered this statement with as much careful
990: precision as if he had been a diplomatic envoy whose words would be
991: attended with results. Indeed, Mr. Casaubon was not used to expect that
992: he should have to repeat or revise his communications of a practical or
993: personal kind. The inclinations which he had deliberately stated on the
994: 2d of October he would think it enough to refer to by the mention of
995: that date; judging by the standard of his own memory, which was a
996: volume where a vide supra could serve instead of repetitions, and not
997: the ordinary long-used blotting-book which only tells of forgotten
998: writing. But in this case Mr. Casaubon’s confidence was not likely to
999: be falsified, for Dorothea heard and retained what he said with the
1000: eager interest of a fresh young nature to which every variety in
1001: experience is an epoch.
1002: 
1003: It was three o’clock in the beautiful breezy autumn day when Mr.
1004: Casaubon drove off to his Rectory at Lowick, only five miles from
1005: Tipton; and Dorothea, who had on her bonnet and shawl, hurried along
1006: the shrubbery and across the park that she might wander through the
1007: bordering wood with no other visible companionship than that of Monk,
1008: the Great St. Bernard dog, who always took care of the young ladies in
1009: their walks. There had risen before her the girl’s vision of a possible
1010: future for herself to which she looked forward with trembling hope, and
1011: she wanted to wander on in that visionary future without interruption.
1012: She walked briskly in the brisk air, the color rose in her cheeks, and
1013: her straw bonnet (which our contemporaries might look at with
1014: conjectural curiosity as at an obsolete form of basket) fell a little
1015: backward. She would perhaps be hardly characterized enough if it were
1016: omitted that she wore her brown hair flatly braided and coiled behind
1017: so as to expose the outline of her head in a daring manner at a time
1018: when public feeling required the meagreness of nature to be
1019: dissimulated by tall barricades of frizzed curls and bows, never
1020: surpassed by any great race except the Feejeean. This was a trait of
1021: Miss Brooke’s asceticism. But there was nothing of an ascetic’s
1022: expression in her bright full eyes, as she looked before her, not
1023: consciously seeing, but absorbing into the intensity of her mood, the
1024: solemn glory of the afternoon with its long swathes of light between
1025: the far-off rows of limes, whose shadows touched each other.
1026: 
1027: All people, young or old (that is, all people in those ante-reform
1028: times), would have thought her an interesting object if they had
1029: referred the glow in her eyes and cheeks to the newly awakened ordinary
1030: images of young love: the illusions of Chloe about Strephon have been
1031: sufficiently consecrated in poetry, as the pathetic loveliness of all
1032: spontaneous trust ought to be. Miss Pippin adoring young Pumpkin, and
1033: dreaming along endless vistas of unwearying companionship, was a little
1034: drama which never tired our fathers and mothers, and had been put into
1035: all costumes. Let but Pumpkin have a figure which would sustain the
1036: disadvantages of the shortwaisted swallow-tail, and everybody felt it
1037: not only natural but necessary to the perfection of womanhood, that a
1038: sweet girl should be at once convinced of his virtue, his exceptional
1039: ability, and above all, his perfect sincerity. But perhaps no persons
1040: then living—certainly none in the neighborhood of Tipton—would have had
1041: a sympathetic understanding for the dreams of a girl whose notions
1042: about marriage took their color entirely from an exalted enthusiasm
1043: about the ends of life, an enthusiasm which was lit chiefly by its own
1044: fire, and included neither the niceties of the trousseau, the pattern
1045: of plate, nor even the honors and sweet joys of the blooming matron.
1046: 
1047: It had now entered Dorothea’s mind that Mr. Casaubon might wish to make
1048: her his wife, and the idea that he would do so touched her with a sort
1049: of reverential gratitude. How good of him—nay, it would be almost as if
1050: a winged messenger had suddenly stood beside her path and held out his
1051: hand towards her! For a long while she had been oppressed by the
1052: indefiniteness which hung in her mind, like a thick summer haze, over
1053: all her desire to make her life greatly effective. What could she do,
1054: what ought she to do?—she, hardly more than a budding woman, but yet
1055: with an active conscience and a great mental need, not to be satisfied
1056: by a girlish instruction comparable to the nibblings and judgments of a
1057: discursive mouse. With some endowment of stupidity and conceit, she
1058: might have thought that a Christian young lady of fortune should find
1059: her ideal of life in village charities, patronage of the humbler
1060: clergy, the perusal of “Female Scripture Characters,” unfolding the
1061: private experience of Sara under the Old Dispensation, and Dorcas under
1062: the New, and the care of her soul over her embroidery in her own
1063: boudoir—with a background of prospective marriage to a man who, if less
1064: strict than herself, as being involved in affairs religiously
1065: inexplicable, might be prayed for and seasonably exhorted. From such
1066: contentment poor Dorothea was shut out. The intensity of her religious
1067: disposition, the coercion it exercised over her life, was but one
1068: aspect of a nature altogether ardent, theoretic, and intellectually
1069: consequent: and with such a nature struggling in the bands of a narrow
1070: teaching, hemmed in by a social life which seemed nothing but a
1071: labyrinth of petty courses, a walled-in maze of small paths that led no
1072: whither, the outcome was sure to strike others as at once exaggeration
1073: and inconsistency. The thing which seemed to her best, she wanted to
1074: justify by the completest knowledge; and not to live in a pretended
1075: admission of rules which were never acted on. Into this soul-hunger as
1076: yet all her youthful passion was poured; the union which attracted her
1077: was one that would deliver her from her girlish subjection to her own
1078: ignorance, and give her the freedom of voluntary submission to a guide
1079: who would take her along the grandest path.
1080: 
1081: “I should learn everything then,” she said to herself, still walking
1082: quickly along the bridle road through the wood. “It would be my duty to
1083: study that I might help him the better in his great works. There would
1084: be nothing trivial about our lives. Every-day things with us would mean
1085: the greatest things. It would be like marrying Pascal. I should learn
1086: to see the truth by the same light as great men have seen it by. And
1087: then I should know what to do, when I got older: I should see how it
1088: was possible to lead a grand life here—now—in England. I don’t feel
1089: sure about doing good in any way now: everything seems like going on a
1090: mission to a people whose language I don’t know;—unless it were
1091: building good cottages—there can be no doubt about that. Oh, I hope I
1092: should be able to get the people well housed in Lowick! I will draw
1093: plenty of plans while I have time.”
1094: 
1095: Dorothea checked herself suddenly with self-rebuke for the presumptuous
1096: way in which she was reckoning on uncertain events, but she was spared
1097: any inward effort to change the direction of her thoughts by the
1098: appearance of a cantering horseman round a turning of the road. The
1099: well-groomed chestnut horse and two beautiful setters could leave no
1100: doubt that the rider was Sir James Chettam. He discerned Dorothea,
1101: jumped off his horse at once, and, having delivered it to his groom,
1102: advanced towards her with something white on his arm, at which the two
1103: setters were barking in an excited manner.
1104: 
1105: “How delightful to meet you, Miss Brooke,” he said, raising his hat and
1106: showing his sleekly waving blond hair. “It has hastened the pleasure I
1107: was looking forward to.”
1108: 
1109: Miss Brooke was annoyed at the interruption. This amiable baronet,
1110: really a suitable husband for Celia, exaggerated the necessity of
1111: making himself agreeable to the elder sister. Even a prospective
1112: brother-in-law may be an oppression if he will always be presupposing
1113: too good an understanding with you, and agreeing with you even when you
1114: contradict him. The thought that he had made the mistake of paying his
1115: addresses to herself could not take shape: all her mental activity was
1116: used up in persuasions of another kind. But he was positively obtrusive
1117: at this moment, and his dimpled hands were quite disagreeable. Her
1118: roused temper made her color deeply, as she returned his greeting with
1119: some haughtiness.
1120: 
1121: Sir James interpreted the heightened color in the way most gratifying
1122: to himself, and thought he never saw Miss Brooke looking so handsome.
1123: 
1124: “I have brought a little petitioner,” he said, “or rather, I have
1125: brought him to see if he will be approved before his petition is
1126: offered.” He showed the white object under his arm, which was a tiny
1127: Maltese puppy, one of nature’s most naive toys.
1128: 
1129: “It is painful to me to see these creatures that are bred merely as
1130: pets,” said Dorothea, whose opinion was forming itself that very moment
1131: (as opinions will) under the heat of irritation.
1132: 
1133: “Oh, why?” said Sir James, as they walked forward.
1134: 
1135: “I believe all the petting that is given them does not make them happy.
1136: They are too helpless: their lives are too frail. A weasel or a mouse
1137: that gets its own living is more interesting. I like to think that the
1138: animals about us have souls something like our own, and either carry on
1139: their own little affairs or can be companions to us, like Monk here.
1140: Those creatures are parasitic.”
1141: 
1142: “I am so glad I know that you do not like them,” said good Sir James.
1143: “I should never keep them for myself, but ladies usually are fond of
1144: these Maltese dogs. Here, John, take this dog, will you?”
1145: 
1146: The objectionable puppy, whose nose and eyes were equally black and
1147: expressive, was thus got rid of, since Miss Brooke decided that it had
1148: better not have been born. But she felt it necessary to explain.
1149: 
1150: “You must not judge of Celia’s feeling from mine. I think she likes
1151: these small pets. She had a tiny terrier once, which she was very fond
1152: of. It made me unhappy, because I was afraid of treading on it. I am
1153: rather short-sighted.”
1154: 
1155: “You have your own opinion about everything, Miss Brooke, and it is
1156: always a good opinion.”
1157: 
1158: What answer was possible to such stupid complimenting?
1159: 
1160: “Do you know, I envy you that,” Sir James said, as they continued
1161: walking at the rather brisk pace set by Dorothea.
1162: 
1163: “I don’t quite understand what you mean.”
1164: 
1165: “Your power of forming an opinion. I can form an opinion of persons. I
1166: know when I like people. But about other matters, do you know, I have
1167: often a difficulty in deciding. One hears very sensible things said on
1168: opposite sides.”
1169: 
1170: “Or that seem sensible. Perhaps we don’t always discriminate between
1171: sense and nonsense.”
1172: 
1173: Dorothea felt that she was rather rude.
1174: 
1175: “Exactly,” said Sir James. “But you seem to have the power of
1176: discrimination.”
1177: 
1178: “On the contrary, I am often unable to decide. But that is from
1179: ignorance. The right conclusion is there all the same, though I am
1180: unable to see it.”
1181: 
1182: “I think there are few who would see it more readily. Do you know,
1183: Lovegood was telling me yesterday that you had the best notion in the
1184: world of a plan for cottages—quite wonderful for a young lady, he
1185: thought. You had a real _genus_, to use his expression. He said you
1186: wanted Mr. Brooke to build a new set of cottages, but he seemed to
1187: think it hardly probable that your uncle would consent. Do you know,
1188: that is one of the things I wish to do—I mean, on my own estate. I
1189: should be so glad to carry out that plan of yours, if you would let me
1190: see it. Of course, it is sinking money; that is why people object to
1191: it. Laborers can never pay rent to make it answer. But, after all, it
1192: is worth doing.”
1193: 
1194: “Worth doing! yes, indeed,” said Dorothea, energetically, forgetting
1195: her previous small vexations. “I think we deserve to be beaten out of
1196: our beautiful houses with a scourge of small cords—all of us who let
1197: tenants live in such sties as we see round us. Life in cottages might
1198: be happier than ours, if they were real houses fit for human beings
1199: from whom we expect duties and affections.”
1200: 
1201: “Will you show me your plan?”
1202: 
1203: “Yes, certainly. I dare say it is very faulty. But I have been
1204: examining all the plans for cottages in Loudon’s book, and picked out
1205: what seem the best things. Oh what a happiness it would be to set the
1206: pattern about here! I think instead of Lazarus at the gate, we should
1207: put the pigsty cottages outside the park-gate.”
1208: 
1209: Dorothea was in the best temper now. Sir James, as brother in-law,
1210: building model cottages on his estate, and then, perhaps, others being
1211: built at Lowick, and more and more elsewhere in imitation—it would be
1212: as if the spirit of Oberlin had passed over the parishes to make the
1213: life of poverty beautiful!
1214: 
1215: Sir James saw all the plans, and took one away to consult upon with
1216: Lovegood. He also took away a complacent sense that he was making great
1217: progress in Miss Brooke’s good opinion. The Maltese puppy was not
1218: offered to Celia; an omission which Dorothea afterwards thought of with
1219: surprise; but she blamed herself for it. She had been engrossing Sir
1220: James. After all, it was a relief that there was no puppy to tread
1221: upon.
1222: 
1223: Celia was present while the plans were being examined, and observed Sir
1224: James’s illusion. “He thinks that Dodo cares about him, and she only
1225: cares about her plans. Yet I am not certain that she would refuse him
1226: if she thought he would let her manage everything and carry out all her
1227: notions. And how very uncomfortable Sir James would be! I cannot bear
1228: notions.”
1229: 
1230: It was Celia’s private luxury to indulge in this dislike. She dared not
1231: confess it to her sister in any direct statement, for that would be
1232: laying herself open to a demonstration that she was somehow or other at
1233: war with all goodness. But on safe opportunities, she had an indirect
1234: mode of making her negative wisdom tell upon Dorothea, and calling her
1235: down from her rhapsodic mood by reminding her that people were staring,
1236: not listening. Celia was not impulsive: what she had to say could wait,
1237: and came from her always with the same quiet staccato evenness. When
1238: people talked with energy and emphasis she watched their faces and
1239: features merely. She never could understand how well-bred persons
1240: consented to sing and open their mouths in the ridiculous manner
1241: requisite for that vocal exercise.
1242: 
1243: It was not many days before Mr. Casaubon paid a morning visit, on which
1244: he was invited again for the following week to dine and stay the night.
1245: Thus Dorothea had three more conversations with him, and was convinced
1246: that her first impressions had been just. He was all she had at first
1247: imagined him to be: almost everything he had said seemed like a
1248: specimen from a mine, or the inscription on the door of a museum which
1249: might open on the treasures of past ages; and this trust in his mental
1250: wealth was all the deeper and more effective on her inclination because
1251: it was now obvious that his visits were made for her sake. This
1252: accomplished man condescended to think of a young girl, and take the
1253: pains to talk to her, not with absurd compliment, but with an appeal to
1254: her understanding, and sometimes with instructive correction. What
1255: delightful companionship! Mr. Casaubon seemed even unconscious that
1256: trivialities existed, and never handed round that small-talk of heavy
1257: men which is as acceptable as stale bride-cake brought forth with an
1258: odor of cupboard. He talked of what he was interested in, or else he
1259: was silent and bowed with sad civility. To Dorothea this was adorable
1260: genuineness, and religious abstinence from that artificiality which
1261: uses up the soul in the efforts of pretence. For she looked as
1262: reverently at Mr. Casaubon’s religious elevation above herself as she
1263: did at his intellect and learning. He assented to her expressions of
1264: devout feeling, and usually with an appropriate quotation; he allowed
1265: himself to say that he had gone through some spiritual conflicts in his
1266: youth; in short, Dorothea saw that here she might reckon on
1267: understanding, sympathy, and guidance. On one—only one—of her favorite
1268: themes she was disappointed. Mr. Casaubon apparently did not care about
1269: building cottages, and diverted the talk to the extremely narrow
1270: accommodation which was to be had in the dwellings of the ancient
1271: Egyptians, as if to check a too high standard. After he was gone,
1272: Dorothea dwelt with some agitation on this indifference of his; and her
1273: mind was much exercised with arguments drawn from the varying
1274: conditions of climate which modify human needs, and from the admitted
1275: wickedness of pagan despots. Should she not urge these arguments on Mr.
1276: Casaubon when he came again? But further reflection told her that she
1277: was presumptuous in demanding his attention to such a subject; he would
1278: not disapprove of her occupying herself with it in leisure moments, as
1279: other women expected to occupy themselves with their dress and
1280: embroidery—would not forbid it when—Dorothea felt rather ashamed as she
1281: detected herself in these speculations. But her uncle had been invited
1282: to go to Lowick to stay a couple of days: was it reasonable to suppose
1283: that Mr. Casaubon delighted in Mr. Brooke’s society for its own sake,
1284: either with or without documents?
1285: 
1286: Meanwhile that little disappointment made her delight the more in Sir
1287: James Chettam’s readiness to set on foot the desired improvements. He
1288: came much oftener than Mr. Casaubon, and Dorothea ceased to find him
1289: disagreeable since he showed himself so entirely in earnest; for he had
1290: already entered with much practical ability into Lovegood’s estimates,
1291: and was charmingly docile. She proposed to build a couple of cottages,
1292: and transfer two families from their old cabins, which could then be
1293: pulled down, so that new ones could be built on the old sites. Sir
1294: James said “Exactly,” and she bore the word remarkably well.
1295: 
1296: Certainly these men who had so few spontaneous ideas might be very
1297: useful members of society under good feminine direction, if they were
1298: fortunate in choosing their sisters-in-law! It is difficult to say
1299: whether there was or was not a little wilfulness in her continuing
1300: blind to the possibility that another sort of choice was in question in
1301: relation to her. But her life was just now full of hope and action: she
1302: was not only thinking of her plans, but getting down learned books from
1303: the library and reading many things hastily (that she might be a little
1304: less ignorant in talking to Mr. Casaubon), all the while being visited
1305: with conscientious questionings whether she were not exalting these
1306: poor doings above measure and contemplating them with that
1307: self-satisfaction which was the last doom of ignorance and folly.
1308: 
1309: 
1310: 
1311: 
1312: CHAPTER IV.
1313: 
1314: 1_st Gent_. Our deeds are fetters that we forge ourselves.
1315: 
1316: 2_d Gent._ Ay, truly: but I think it is the world
1317: That brings the iron.
1318: 
1319: 
1320: “Sir James seems determined to do everything you wish,” said Celia, as
1321: they were driving home from an inspection of the new building-site.
1322: 
1323: “He is a good creature, and more sensible than any one would imagine,”
1324: said Dorothea, inconsiderately.
1325: 
1326: “You mean that he appears silly.”
1327: 
1328: “No, no,” said Dorothea, recollecting herself, and laying her hand on
1329: her sister’s a moment, “but he does not talk equally well on all
1330: subjects.”
1331: 
1332: “I should think none but disagreeable people do,” said Celia, in her
1333: usual purring way. “They must be very dreadful to live with. Only
1334: think! at breakfast, and always.”
1335: 
1336: Dorothea laughed. “O Kitty, you are a wonderful creature!” She pinched
1337: Celia’s chin, being in the mood now to think her very winning and
1338: lovely—fit hereafter to be an eternal cherub, and if it were not
1339: doctrinally wrong to say so, hardly more in need of salvation than a
1340: squirrel. “Of course people need not be always talking well. Only one
1341: tells the quality of their minds when they try to talk well.”
1342: 
1343: “You mean that Sir James tries and fails.”
1344: 
1345: “I was speaking generally. Why do you catechise me about Sir James? It
1346: is not the object of his life to please me.”
1347: 
1348: “Now, Dodo, can you really believe that?”
1349: 
1350: “Certainly. He thinks of me as a future sister—that is all.” Dorothea
1351: had never hinted this before, waiting, from a certain shyness on such
1352: subjects which was mutual between the sisters, until it should be
1353: introduced by some decisive event. Celia blushed, but said at once—
1354: 
1355: “Pray do not make that mistake any longer, Dodo. When Tantripp was
1356: brushing my hair the other day, she said that Sir James’s man knew from
1357: Mrs. Cadwallader’s maid that Sir James was to marry the eldest Miss
1358: Brooke.”
1359: 
1360: “How can you let Tantripp talk such gossip to you, Celia?” said
1361: Dorothea, indignantly, not the less angry because details asleep in her
1362: memory were now awakened to confirm the unwelcome revelation. “You must
1363: have asked her questions. It is degrading.”
1364: 
1365: “I see no harm at all in Tantripp’s talking to me. It is better to hear
1366: what people say. You see what mistakes you make by taking up notions. I
1367: am quite sure that Sir James means to make you an offer; and he
1368: believes that you will accept him, especially since you have been so
1369: pleased with him about the plans. And uncle too—I know he expects it.
1370: Every one can see that Sir James is very much in love with you.”
1371: 
1372: The revulsion was so strong and painful in Dorothea’s mind that the
1373: tears welled up and flowed abundantly. All her dear plans were
1374: embittered, and she thought with disgust of Sir James’s conceiving that
1375: she recognized him as her lover. There was vexation too on account of
1376: Celia.
1377: 
1378: “How could he expect it?” she burst forth in her most impetuous manner.
1379: “I have never agreed with him about anything but the cottages: I was
1380: barely polite to him before.”
1381: 
1382: “But you have been so pleased with him since then; he has begun to feel
1383: quite sure that you are fond of him.”
1384: 
1385: “Fond of him, Celia! How can you choose such odious expressions?” said
1386: Dorothea, passionately.
1387: 
1388: “Dear me, Dorothea, I suppose it would be right for you to be fond of a
1389: man whom you accepted for a husband.”
1390: 
1391: “It is offensive to me to say that Sir James could think I was fond of
1392: him. Besides, it is not the right word for the feeling I must have
1393: towards the man I would accept as a husband.”
1394: 
1395: “Well, I am sorry for Sir James. I thought it right to tell you,
1396: because you went on as you always do, never looking just where you are,
1397: and treading in the wrong place. You always see what nobody else sees;
1398: it is impossible to satisfy you; yet you never see what is quite plain.
1399: That’s your way, Dodo.” Something certainly gave Celia unusual courage;
1400: and she was not sparing the sister of whom she was occasionally in awe.
1401: Who can tell what just criticisms Murr the Cat may be passing on us
1402: beings of wider speculation?
1403: 
1404: “It is very painful,” said Dorothea, feeling scourged. “I can have no
1405: more to do with the cottages. I must be uncivil to him. I must tell him
1406: I will have nothing to do with them. It is very painful.” Her eyes
1407: filled again with tears.
1408: 
1409: “Wait a little. Think about it. You know he is going away for a day or
1410: two to see his sister. There will be nobody besides Lovegood.” Celia
1411: could not help relenting. “Poor Dodo,” she went on, in an amiable
1412: staccato. “It is very hard: it is your favorite _fad_ to draw plans.”
1413: 
1414: “_Fad_ to draw plans! Do you think I only care about my
1415: fellow-creatures’ houses in that childish way? I may well make
1416: mistakes. How can one ever do anything nobly Christian, living among
1417: people with such petty thoughts?”
1418: 
1419: No more was said; Dorothea was too much jarred to recover her temper
1420: and behave so as to show that she admitted any error in herself. She
1421: was disposed rather to accuse the intolerable narrowness and the
1422: purblind conscience of the society around her: and Celia was no longer
1423: the eternal cherub, but a thorn in her spirit, a pink-and-white
1424: nullifidian, worse than any discouraging presence in the “Pilgrim’s
1425: Progress.” The _fad_ of drawing plans! What was life worth—what great
1426: faith was possible when the whole effect of one’s actions could be
1427: withered up into such parched rubbish as that? When she got out of the
1428: carriage, her cheeks were pale and her eyelids red. She was an image of
1429: sorrow, and her uncle who met her in the hall would have been alarmed,
1430: if Celia had not been close to her looking so pretty and composed, that
1431: he at once concluded Dorothea’s tears to have their origin in her
1432: excessive religiousness. He had returned, during their absence, from a
1433: journey to the county town, about a petition for the pardon of some
1434: criminal.
1435: 
1436: “Well, my dears,” he said, kindly, as they went up to kiss him, “I hope
1437: nothing disagreeable has happened while I have been away.”
1438: 
1439: “No, uncle,” said Celia, “we have been to Freshitt to look at the
1440: cottages. We thought you would have been at home to lunch.”
1441: 
1442: “I came by Lowick to lunch—you didn’t know I came by Lowick. And I have
1443: brought a couple of pamphlets for you, Dorothea—in the library, you
1444: know; they lie on the table in the library.”
1445: 
1446: It seemed as if an electric stream went through Dorothea, thrilling her
1447: from despair into expectation. They were pamphlets about the early
1448: Church. The oppression of Celia, Tantripp, and Sir James was shaken
1449: off, and she walked straight to the library. Celia went up-stairs. Mr.
1450: Brooke was detained by a message, but when he re-entered the library,
1451: he found Dorothea seated and already deep in one of the pamphlets which
1452: had some marginal manuscript of Mr. Casaubon’s,—taking it in as eagerly
1453: as she might have taken in the scent of a fresh bouquet after a dry,
1454: hot, dreary walk.
1455: 
1456: She was getting away from Tipton and Freshitt, and her own sad
1457: liability to tread in the wrong places on her way to the New Jerusalem.
1458: 
1459: Mr. Brooke sat down in his arm-chair, stretched his legs towards the
1460: wood-fire, which had fallen into a wondrous mass of glowing dice
1461: between the dogs, and rubbed his hands gently, looking very mildly
1462: towards Dorothea, but with a neutral leisurely air, as if he had
1463: nothing particular to say. Dorothea closed her pamphlet, as soon as she
1464: was aware of her uncle’s presence, and rose as if to go. Usually she
1465: would have been interested about her uncle’s merciful errand on behalf
1466: of the criminal, but her late agitation had made her absent-minded.
1467: 
1468: “I came back by Lowick, you know,” said Mr. Brooke, not as if with any
1469: intention to arrest her departure, but apparently from his usual
1470: tendency to say what he had said before. This fundamental principle of
1471: human speech was markedly exhibited in Mr. Brooke. “I lunched there and
1472: saw Casaubon’s library, and that kind of thing. There’s a sharp air,
1473: driving. Won’t you sit down, my dear? You look cold.”
1474: 
1475: Dorothea felt quite inclined to accept the invitation. Some times, when
1476: her uncle’s easy way of taking things did not happen to be
1477: exasperating, it was rather soothing. She threw off her mantle and
1478: bonnet, and sat down opposite to him, enjoying the glow, but lifting up
1479: her beautiful hands for a screen. They were not thin hands, or small
1480: hands; but powerful, feminine, maternal hands. She seemed to be holding
1481: them up in propitiation for her passionate desire to know and to think,
1482: which in the unfriendly mediums of Tipton and Freshitt had issued in
1483: crying and red eyelids.
1484: 
1485: She bethought herself now of the condemned criminal. “What news have
1486: you brought about the sheep-stealer, uncle?”
1487: 
1488: “What, poor Bunch?—well, it seems we can’t get him off—he is to be
1489: hanged.”
1490: 
1491: Dorothea’s brow took an expression of reprobation and pity.
1492: 
1493: “Hanged, you know,” said Mr. Brooke, with a quiet nod. “Poor Romilly!
1494: he would have helped us. I knew Romilly. Casaubon didn’t know Romilly.
1495: He is a little buried in books, you know, Casaubon is.”
1496: 
1497: “When a man has great studies and is writing a great work, he must of
1498: course give up seeing much of the world. How can he go about making
1499: acquaintances?”
1500: 
1501: “That’s true. But a man mopes, you know. I have always been a bachelor
