1502: too, but I have that sort of disposition that I never moped; it was my
1503: way to go about everywhere and take in everything. I never moped: but I
1504: can see that Casaubon does, you know. He wants a companion—a companion,
1505: you know.”
1506: 
1507: “It would be a great honor to any one to be his companion,” said
1508: Dorothea, energetically.
1509: 
1510: “You like him, eh?” said Mr. Brooke, without showing any surprise, or
1511: other emotion. “Well, now, I’ve known Casaubon ten years, ever since he
1512: came to Lowick. But I never got anything out of him—any ideas, you
1513: know. However, he is a tiptop man and may be a bishop—that kind of
1514: thing, you know, if Peel stays in. And he has a very high opinion of
1515: you, my dear.”
1516: 
1517: Dorothea could not speak.
1518: 
1519: “The fact is, he has a very high opinion indeed of you. And he speaks
1520: uncommonly well—does Casaubon. He has deferred to me, you not being of
1521: age. In short, I have promised to speak to you, though I told him I
1522: thought there was not much chance. I was bound to tell him that. I
1523: said, my niece is very young, and that kind of thing. But I didn’t
1524: think it necessary to go into everything. However, the long and the
1525: short of it is, that he has asked my permission to make you an offer of
1526: marriage—of marriage, you know,” said Mr. Brooke, with his explanatory
1527: nod. “I thought it better to tell you, my dear.”
1528: 
1529: No one could have detected any anxiety in Mr. Brooke’s manner, but he
1530: did really wish to know something of his niece’s mind, that, if there
1531: were any need for advice, he might give it in time. What feeling he, as
1532: a magistrate who had taken in so many ideas, could make room for, was
1533: unmixedly kind. Since Dorothea did not speak immediately, he repeated,
1534: “I thought it better to tell you, my dear.”
1535: 
1536: “Thank you, uncle,” said Dorothea, in a clear unwavering tone. “I am
1537: very grateful to Mr. Casaubon. If he makes me an offer, I shall accept
1538: him. I admire and honor him more than any man I ever saw.”
1539: 
1540: Mr. Brooke paused a little, and then said in a lingering low tone, “Ah?
1541: … Well! He is a good match in some respects. But now, Chettam is a good
1542: match. And our land lies together. I shall never interfere against your
1543: wishes, my dear. People should have their own way in marriage, and that
1544: sort of thing—up to a certain point, you know. I have always said that,
1545: up to a certain point. I wish you to marry well; and I have good reason
1546: to believe that Chettam wishes to marry you. I mention it, you know.”
1547: 
1548: “It is impossible that I should ever marry Sir James Chettam,” said
1549: Dorothea. “If he thinks of marrying me, he has made a great mistake.”
1550: 
1551: “That is it, you see. One never knows. I should have thought Chettam
1552: was just the sort of man a woman would like, now.”
1553: 
1554: “Pray do not mention him in that light again, uncle,” said Dorothea,
1555: feeling some of her late irritation revive.
1556: 
1557: Mr. Brooke wondered, and felt that women were an inexhaustible subject
1558: of study, since even he at his age was not in a perfect state of
1559: scientific prediction about them. Here was a fellow like Chettam with
1560: no chance at all.
1561: 
1562: “Well, but Casaubon, now. There is no hurry—I mean for you. It’s true,
1563: every year will tell upon him. He is over five-and-forty, you know. I
1564: should say a good seven-and-twenty years older than you. To be sure,—if
1565: you like learning and standing, and that sort of thing, we can’t have
1566: everything. And his income is good—he has a handsome property
1567: independent of the Church—his income is good. Still he is not young,
1568: and I must not conceal from you, my dear, that I think his health is
1569: not over-strong. I know nothing else against him.”
1570: 
1571: “I should not wish to have a husband very near my own age,” said
1572: Dorothea, with grave decision. “I should wish to have a husband who was
1573: above me in judgment and in all knowledge.”
1574: 
1575: Mr. Brooke repeated his subdued, “Ah?—I thought you had more of your
1576: own opinion than most girls. I thought you liked your own opinion—liked
1577: it, you know.”
1578: 
1579: “I cannot imagine myself living without some opinions, but I should
1580: wish to have good reasons for them, and a wise man could help me to see
1581: which opinions had the best foundation, and would help me to live
1582: according to them.”
1583: 
1584: “Very true. You couldn’t put the thing better—couldn’t put it better,
1585: beforehand, you know. But there are oddities in things,” continued Mr.
1586: Brooke, whose conscience was really roused to do the best he could for
1587: his niece on this occasion. “Life isn’t cast in a mould—not cut out by
1588: rule and line, and that sort of thing. I never married myself, and it
1589: will be the better for you and yours. The fact is, I never loved any
1590: one well enough to put myself into a noose for them. It _is_ a noose,
1591: you know. Temper, now. There is temper. And a husband likes to be
1592: master.”
1593: 
1594: “I know that I must expect trials, uncle. Marriage is a state of higher
1595: duties. I never thought of it as mere personal ease,” said poor
1596: Dorothea.
1597: 
1598: “Well, you are not fond of show, a great establishment, balls, dinners,
1599: that kind of thing. I can see that Casaubon’s ways might suit you
1600: better than Chettam’s. And you shall do as you like, my dear. I would
1601: not hinder Casaubon; I said so at once; for there is no knowing how
1602: anything may turn out. You have not the same tastes as every young
1603: lady; and a clergyman and scholar—who may be a bishop—that kind of
1604: thing—may suit you better than Chettam. Chettam is a good fellow, a
1605: good sound-hearted fellow, you know; but he doesn’t go much into ideas.
1606: I did, when I was his age. But Casaubon’s eyes, now. I think he has
1607: hurt them a little with too much reading.”
1608: 
1609: “I should be all the happier, uncle, the more room there was for me to
1610: help him,” said Dorothea, ardently.
1611: 
1612: “You have quite made up your mind, I see. Well, my dear, the fact is, I
1613: have a letter for you in my pocket.” Mr. Brooke handed the letter to
1614: Dorothea, but as she rose to go away, he added, “There is not too much
1615: hurry, my dear. Think about it, you know.”
1616: 
1617: When Dorothea had left him, he reflected that he had certainly spoken
1618: strongly: he had put the risks of marriage before her in a striking
1619: manner. It was his duty to do so. But as to pretending to be wise for
1620: young people,—no uncle, however much he had travelled in his youth,
1621: absorbed the new ideas, and dined with celebrities now deceased, could
1622: pretend to judge what sort of marriage would turn out well for a young
1623: girl who preferred Casaubon to Chettam. In short, woman was a problem
1624: which, since Mr. Brooke’s mind felt blank before it, could be hardly
1625: less complicated than the revolutions of an irregular solid.
1626: 
1627: 
1628: 
1629: 
1630: CHAPTER V.
1631: 
1632: “Hard students are commonly troubled with gowts, catarrhs, rheums,
1633: cachexia, bradypepsia, bad eyes, stone, and collick, crudities,
1634: oppilations, vertigo, winds, consumptions, and all such diseases as
1635: come by over-much sitting: they are most part lean, dry, ill-colored …
1636: and all through immoderate pains and extraordinary studies. If you will
1637: not believe the truth of this, look upon great Tostatus and Thomas
1638: Aquainas’ works; and tell me whether those men took pains.”—BURTON’S
1639: _Anatomy of Melancholy_, P. I, s. 2.
1640: 
1641: 
1642: This was Mr. Casaubon’s letter.
1643: 
1644: MY DEAR MISS BROOKE,—I have your guardian’s permission to address you
1645: on a subject than which I have none more at heart. I am not, I trust,
1646: mistaken in the recognition of some deeper correspondence than that of
1647: date in the fact that a consciousness of need in my own life had arisen
1648: contemporaneously with the possibility of my becoming acquainted with
1649: you. For in the first hour of meeting you, I had an impression of your
1650: eminent and perhaps exclusive fitness to supply that need (connected, I
1651: may say, with such activity of the affections as even the
1652: preoccupations of a work too special to be abdicated could not
1653: uninterruptedly dissimulate); and each succeeding opportunity for
1654: observation has given the impression an added depth by convincing me
1655: more emphatically of that fitness which I had preconceived, and thus
1656: evoking more decisively those affections to which I have but now
1657: referred. Our conversations have, I think, made sufficiently clear to
1658: you the tenor of my life and purposes: a tenor unsuited, I am aware, to
1659: the commoner order of minds. But I have discerned in you an elevation
1660: of thought and a capability of devotedness, which I had hitherto not
1661: conceived to be compatible either with the early bloom of youth or with
1662: those graces of sex that may be said at once to win and to confer
1663: distinction when combined, as they notably are in you, with the mental
1664: qualities above indicated. It was, I confess, beyond my hope to meet
1665: with this rare combination of elements both solid and attractive,
1666: adapted to supply aid in graver labors and to cast a charm over vacant
1667: hours; and but for the event of my introduction to you (which, let me
1668: again say, I trust not to be superficially coincident with
1669: foreshadowing needs, but providentially related thereto as stages
1670: towards the completion of a life’s plan), I should presumably have gone
1671: on to the last without any attempt to lighten my solitariness by a
1672: matrimonial union.
1673:     Such, my dear Miss Brooke, is the accurate statement of my
1674:     feelings; and I rely on your kind indulgence in venturing now to
1675:     ask you how far your own are of a nature to confirm my happy
1676:     presentiment. To be accepted by you as your husband and the earthly
1677:     guardian of your welfare, I should regard as the highest of
1678:     providential gifts. In return I can at least offer you an affection
1679:     hitherto unwasted, and the faithful consecration of a life which,
1680:     however short in the sequel, has no backward pages whereon, if you
1681:     choose to turn them, you will find records such as might justly
1682:     cause you either bitterness or shame. I await the expression of
1683:     your sentiments with an anxiety which it would be the part of
1684:     wisdom (were it possible) to divert by a more arduous labor than
1685:     usual. But in this order of experience I am still young, and in
1686:     looking forward to an unfavorable possibility I cannot but feel
1687:     that resignation to solitude will be more difficult after the
1688:     temporary illumination of hope.
1689: 
1690: 
1691: In any case, I shall remain,
1692:     Yours with sincere devotion,
1693:         EDWARD CASAUBON.
1694: 
1695: 
1696: Dorothea trembled while she read this letter; then she fell on her
1697: knees, buried her face, and sobbed. She could not pray: under the rush
1698: of solemn emotion in which thoughts became vague and images floated
1699: uncertainly, she could but cast herself, with a childlike sense of
1700: reclining, in the lap of a divine consciousness which sustained her
1701: own. She remained in that attitude till it was time to dress for
1702: dinner.
1703: 
1704: How could it occur to her to examine the letter, to look at it
1705: critically as a profession of love? Her whole soul was possessed by the
1706: fact that a fuller life was opening before her: she was a neophyte
1707: about to enter on a higher grade of initiation. She was going to have
1708: room for the energies which stirred uneasily under the dimness and
1709: pressure of her own ignorance and the petty peremptoriness of the
1710: world’s habits.
1711: 
1712: Now she would be able to devote herself to large yet definite duties;
1713: now she would be allowed to live continually in the light of a mind
1714: that she could reverence. This hope was not unmixed with the glow of
1715: proud delight—the joyous maiden surprise that she was chosen by the man
1716: whom her admiration had chosen. All Dorothea’s passion was transfused
1717: through a mind struggling towards an ideal life; the radiance of her
1718: transfigured girlhood fell on the first object that came within its
1719: level. The impetus with which inclination became resolution was
1720: heightened by those little events of the day which had roused her
1721: discontent with the actual conditions of her life.
1722: 
1723: After dinner, when Celia was playing an “air, with variations,” a small
1724: kind of tinkling which symbolized the aesthetic part of the young
1725: ladies’ education, Dorothea went up to her room to answer Mr.
1726: Casaubon’s letter. Why should she defer the answer? She wrote it over
1727: three times, not because she wished to change the wording, but because
1728: her hand was unusually uncertain, and she could not bear that Mr.
1729: Casaubon should think her handwriting bad and illegible. She piqued
1730: herself on writing a hand in which each letter was distinguishable
1731: without any large range of conjecture, and she meant to make much use
1732: of this accomplishment, to save Mr. Casaubon’s eyes. Three times she
1733: wrote.
1734: 
1735: MY DEAR MR. CASAUBON,—I am very grateful to you for loving me, and
1736: thinking me worthy to be your wife. I can look forward to no better
1737: happiness than that which would be one with yours. If I said more, it
1738: would only be the same thing written out at greater length, for I
1739: cannot now dwell on any other thought than that I may be through life
1740: 
1741: 
1742: Yours devotedly,
1743:     DOROTHEA BROOKE.
1744: 
1745: 
1746: Later in the evening she followed her uncle into the library to give
1747: him the letter, that he might send it in the morning. He was surprised,
1748: but his surprise only issued in a few moments’ silence, during which he
1749: pushed about various objects on his writing-table, and finally stood
1750: with his back to the fire, his glasses on his nose, looking at the
1751: address of Dorothea’s letter.
1752: 
1753: “Have you thought enough about this, my dear?” he said at last.
1754: 
1755: “There was no need to think long, uncle. I know of nothing to make me
1756: vacillate. If I changed my mind, it must be because of something
1757: important and entirely new to me.”
1758: 
1759: “Ah!—then you have accepted him? Then Chettam has no chance? Has
1760: Chettam offended you—offended you, you know? What is it you don’t like
1761: in Chettam?”
1762: 
1763: “There is nothing that I like in him,” said Dorothea, rather
1764: impetuously.
1765: 
1766: Mr. Brooke threw his head and shoulders backward as if some one had
1767: thrown a light missile at him. Dorothea immediately felt some
1768: self-rebuke, and said—
1769: 
1770: “I mean in the light of a husband. He is very kind, I think—really very
1771: good about the cottages. A well-meaning man.”
1772: 
1773: “But you must have a scholar, and that sort of thing? Well, it lies a
1774: little in our family. I had it myself—that love of knowledge, and going
1775: into everything—a little too much—it took me too far; though that sort
1776: of thing doesn’t often run in the female-line; or it runs underground
1777: like the rivers in Greece, you know—it comes out in the sons. Clever
1778: sons, clever mothers. I went a good deal into that, at one time.
1779: However, my dear, I have always said that people should do as they like
1780: in these things, up to a certain point. I couldn’t, as your guardian,
1781: have consented to a bad match. But Casaubon stands well: his position
1782: is good. I am afraid Chettam will be hurt, though, and Mrs. Cadwallader
1783: will blame me.”
1784: 
1785: That evening, of course, Celia knew nothing of what had happened. She
1786: attributed Dorothea’s abstracted manner, and the evidence of further
1787: crying since they had got home, to the temper she had been in about Sir
1788: James Chettam and the buildings, and was careful not to give further
1789: offence: having once said what she wanted to say, Celia had no
1790: disposition to recur to disagreeable subjects. It had been her nature
1791: when a child never to quarrel with any one—only to observe with wonder
1792: that they quarrelled with her, and looked like turkey-cocks; whereupon
1793: she was ready to play at cat’s cradle with them whenever they recovered
1794: themselves. And as to Dorothea, it had always been her way to find
1795: something wrong in her sister’s words, though Celia inwardly protested
1796: that she always said just how things were, and nothing else: she never
1797: did and never could put words together out of her own head. But the
1798: best of Dodo was, that she did not keep angry for long together. Now,
1799: though they had hardly spoken to each other all the evening, yet when
1800: Celia put by her work, intending to go to bed, a proceeding in which
1801: she was always much the earlier, Dorothea, who was seated on a low
1802: stool, unable to occupy herself except in meditation, said, with the
1803: musical intonation which in moments of deep but quiet feeling made her
1804: speech like a fine bit of recitative—
1805: 
1806: “Celia, dear, come and kiss me,” holding her arms open as she spoke.
1807: 
1808: Celia knelt down to get the right level and gave her little butterfly
1809: kiss, while Dorothea encircled her with gentle arms and pressed her
1810: lips gravely on each cheek in turn.
1811: 
1812: “Don’t sit up, Dodo, you are so pale to-night: go to bed soon,” said
1813: Celia, in a comfortable way, without any touch of pathos.
1814: 
1815: “No, dear, I am very, very happy,” said Dorothea, fervently.
1816: 
1817: “So much the better,” thought Celia. “But how strangely Dodo goes from
1818: one extreme to the other.”
1819: 
1820: The next day, at luncheon, the butler, handing something to Mr. Brooke,
1821: said, “Jonas is come back, sir, and has brought this letter.”
1822: 
1823: Mr. Brooke read the letter, and then, nodding toward Dorothea, said,
1824: “Casaubon, my dear: he will be here to dinner; he didn’t wait to write
1825: more—didn’t wait, you know.”
1826: 
1827: It could not seem remarkable to Celia that a dinner guest should be
1828: announced to her sister beforehand, but, her eyes following the same
1829: direction as her uncle’s, she was struck with the peculiar effect of
1830: the announcement on Dorothea. It seemed as if something like the
1831: reflection of a white sunlit wing had passed across her features,
1832: ending in one of her rare blushes. For the first time it entered into
1833: Celia’s mind that there might be something more between Mr. Casaubon
1834: and her sister than his delight in bookish talk and her delight in
1835: listening. Hitherto she had classed the admiration for this “ugly” and
1836: learned acquaintance with the admiration for Monsieur Liret at
1837: Lausanne, also ugly and learned. Dorothea had never been tired of
1838: listening to old Monsieur Liret when Celia’s feet were as cold as
1839: possible, and when it had really become dreadful to see the skin of his
1840: bald head moving about. Why then should her enthusiasm not extend to
1841: Mr. Casaubon simply in the same way as to Monsieur Liret? And it seemed
1842: probable that all learned men had a sort of schoolmaster’s view of
1843: young people.
1844: 
1845: But now Celia was really startled at the suspicion which had darted
1846: into her mind. She was seldom taken by surprise in this way, her
1847: marvellous quickness in observing a certain order of signs generally
1848: preparing her to expect such outward events as she had an interest in.
1849: Not that she now imagined Mr. Casaubon to be already an accepted lover:
1850: she had only begun to feel disgust at the possibility that anything in
1851: Dorothea’s mind could tend towards such an issue. Here was something
1852: really to vex her about Dodo: it was all very well not to accept Sir
1853: James Chettam, but the idea of marrying Mr. Casaubon! Celia felt a sort
1854: of shame mingled with a sense of the ludicrous. But perhaps Dodo, if
1855: she were really bordering on such an extravagance, might be turned away
1856: from it: experience had often shown that her impressibility might be
1857: calculated on. The day was damp, and they were not going to walk out,
1858: so they both went up to their sitting-room; and there Celia observed
1859: that Dorothea, instead of settling down with her usual diligent
1860: interest to some occupation, simply leaned her elbow on an open book
1861: and looked out of the window at the great cedar silvered with the damp.
1862: She herself had taken up the making of a toy for the curate’s children,
1863: and was not going to enter on any subject too precipitately.
1864: 
1865: Dorothea was in fact thinking that it was desirable for Celia to know
1866: of the momentous change in Mr. Casaubon’s position since he had last
1867: been in the house: it did not seem fair to leave her in ignorance of
1868: what would necessarily affect her attitude towards him; but it was
1869: impossible not to shrink from telling her. Dorothea accused herself of
1870: some meanness in this timidity: it was always odious to her to have any
1871: small fears or contrivances about her actions, but at this moment she
1872: was seeking the highest aid possible that she might not dread the
1873: corrosiveness of Celia’s pretty carnally minded prose. Her reverie was
1874: broken, and the difficulty of decision banished, by Celia’s small and
1875: rather guttural voice speaking in its usual tone, of a remark aside or
1876: a “by the bye.”
1877: 
1878: “Is any one else coming to dine besides Mr. Casaubon?”
1879: 
1880: “Not that I know of.”
1881: 
1882: “I hope there is some one else. Then I shall not hear him eat his soup
1883: so.”
1884: 
1885: “What is there remarkable about his soup-eating?”
1886: 
1887: “Really, Dodo, can’t you hear how he scrapes his spoon? And he always
1888: blinks before he speaks. I don’t know whether Locke blinked, but I’m
1889: sure I am sorry for those who sat opposite to him if he did.”
1890: 
1891: “Celia,” said Dorothea, with emphatic gravity, “pray don’t make any
1892: more observations of that kind.”
1893: 
1894: “Why not? They are quite true,” returned Celia, who had her reasons for
1895: persevering, though she was beginning to be a little afraid.
1896: 
1897: “Many things are true which only the commonest minds observe.”
1898: 
1899: “Then I think the commonest minds must be rather useful. I think it is
1900: a pity Mr. Casaubon’s mother had not a commoner mind: she might have
1901: taught him better.” Celia was inwardly frightened, and ready to run
1902: away, now she had hurled this light javelin.
1903: 
1904: Dorothea’s feelings had gathered to an avalanche, and there could be no
1905: further preparation.
1906: 
1907: “It is right to tell you, Celia, that I am engaged to marry Mr.
1908: Casaubon.”
1909: 
1910: Perhaps Celia had never turned so pale before. The paper man she was
1911: making would have had his leg injured, but for her habitual care of
1912: whatever she held in her hands. She laid the fragile figure down at
1913: once, and sat perfectly still for a few moments. When she spoke there
1914: was a tear gathering.
1915: 
1916: “Oh, Dodo, I hope you will be happy.” Her sisterly tenderness could not
1917: but surmount other feelings at this moment, and her fears were the
1918: fears of affection.
1919: 
1920: Dorothea was still hurt and agitated.
1921: 
1922: “It is quite decided, then?” said Celia, in an awed under tone. “And
1923: uncle knows?”
1924: 
1925: “I have accepted Mr. Casaubon’s offer. My uncle brought me the letter
1926: that contained it; he knew about it beforehand.”
1927: 
1928: “I beg your pardon, if I have said anything to hurt you, Dodo,” said
1929: Celia, with a slight sob. She never could have thought that she should
1930: feel as she did. There was something funereal in the whole affair, and
1931: Mr. Casaubon seemed to be the officiating clergyman, about whom it
1932: would be indecent to make remarks.
1933: 
1934: “Never mind, Kitty, do not grieve. We should never admire the same
1935: people. I often offend in something of the same way; I am apt to speak
1936: too strongly of those who don’t please me.”
1937: 
1938: In spite of this magnanimity Dorothea was still smarting: perhaps as
1939: much from Celia’s subdued astonishment as from her small criticisms. Of
1940: course all the world round Tipton would be out of sympathy with this
1941: marriage. Dorothea knew of no one who thought as she did about life and
1942: its best objects.
1943: 
1944: Nevertheless before the evening was at an end she was very happy. In an
1945: hour’s _tête-à-tête_ with Mr. Casaubon she talked to him with more
1946: freedom than she had ever felt before, even pouring out her joy at the
1947: thought of devoting herself to him, and of learning how she might best
1948: share and further all his great ends. Mr. Casaubon was touched with an
1949: unknown delight (what man would not have been?) at this childlike
1950: unrestrained ardor: he was not surprised (what lover would have been?)
1951: that he should be the object of it.
1952: 
1953: “My dear young lady—Miss Brooke—Dorothea!” he said, pressing her hand
1954: between his hands, “this is a happiness greater than I had ever
1955: imagined to be in reserve for me. That I should ever meet with a mind
1956: and person so rich in the mingled graces which could render marriage
1957: desirable, was far indeed from my conception. You have all—nay, more
1958: than all—those qualities which I have ever regarded as the
1959: characteristic excellences of womanhood. The great charm of your sex is
1960: its capability of an ardent self-sacrificing affection, and herein we
1961: see its fitness to round and complete the existence of our own.
1962: Hitherto I have known few pleasures save of the severer kind: my
1963: satisfactions have been those of the solitary student. I have been
1964: little disposed to gather flowers that would wither in my hand, but now
1965: I shall pluck them with eagerness, to place them in your bosom.”
1966: 
1967: No speech could have been more thoroughly honest in its intention: the
1968: frigid rhetoric at the end was as sincere as the bark of a dog, or the
1969: cawing of an amorous rook. Would it not be rash to conclude that there
1970: was no passion behind those sonnets to Delia which strike us as the
1971: thin music of a mandolin?
1972: 
1973: Dorothea’s faith supplied all that Mr. Casaubon’s words seemed to leave
1974: unsaid: what believer sees a disturbing omission or infelicity? The
1975: text, whether of prophet or of poet, expands for whatever we can put
1976: into it, and even his bad grammar is sublime.
1977: 
1978: “I am very ignorant—you will quite wonder at my ignorance,” said
1979: Dorothea. “I have so many thoughts that may be quite mistaken; and now
1980: I shall be able to tell them all to you, and ask you about them. But,”
1981: she added, with rapid imagination of Mr. Casaubon’s probable feeling,
1982: “I will not trouble you too much; only when you are inclined to listen
1983: to me. You must often be weary with the pursuit of subjects in your own
1984: track. I shall gain enough if you will take me with you there.”
1985: 
1986: “How should I be able now to persevere in any path without your
1987: companionship?” said Mr. Casaubon, kissing her candid brow, and feeling
1988: that heaven had vouchsafed him a blessing in every way suited to his
1989: peculiar wants. He was being unconsciously wrought upon by the charms
1990: of a nature which was entirely without hidden calculations either for
1991: immediate effects or for remoter ends. It was this which made Dorothea
1992: so childlike, and, according to some judges, so stupid, with all her
1993: reputed cleverness; as, for example, in the present case of throwing
1994: herself, metaphorically speaking, at Mr. Casaubon’s feet, and kissing
1995: his unfashionable shoe-ties as if he were a Protestant Pope. She was
1996: not in the least teaching Mr. Casaubon to ask if he were good enough
1997: for her, but merely asking herself anxiously how she could be good
1998: enough for Mr. Casaubon. Before he left the next day it had been
1999: decided that the marriage should take place within six weeks. Why not?
2000: Mr. Casaubon’s house was ready. It was not a parsonage, but a
2001: considerable mansion, with much land attached to it. The parsonage was
2002: inhabited by the curate, who did all the duty except preaching the
2003: morning sermon.
2004: 
2005:

2007: 
2008: CHAPTER VI.
2009: 
2010: My lady’s tongue is like the meadow blades,
2011: That cut you stroking them with idle hand.
2012: Nice cutting is her function: she divides
2013: With spiritual edge the millet-seed,
2014: And makes intangible savings.
2015: 
2016: 
2017: As Mr. Casaubon’s carriage was passing out of the gateway, it arrested
2018: the entrance of a pony phaeton driven by a lady with a servant seated
2019: behind. It was doubtful whether the recognition had been mutual, for
2020: Mr. Casaubon was looking absently before him; but the lady was
2021: quick-eyed, and threw a nod and a “How do you do?” in the nick of time.
2022: In spite of her shabby bonnet and very old Indian shawl, it was plain
2023: that the lodge-keeper regarded her as an important personage, from the
2024: low curtsy which was dropped on the entrance of the small phaeton.
2025: 
2026: “Well, Mrs. Fitchett, how are your fowls laying now?” said the
2027: high-colored, dark-eyed lady, with the clearest chiselled utterance.
2028: 
2029: “Pretty well for laying, madam, but they’ve ta’en to eating their eggs:
2030: I’ve no peace o’ mind with ’em at all.”
2031: 
2032: “Oh, the cannibals! Better sell them cheap at once. What will you sell
2033: them a couple? One can’t eat fowls of a bad character at a high price.”
2034: 
2035: “Well, madam, half-a-crown: I couldn’t let ’em go, not under.”
2036: 
2037: “Half-a-crown, these times! Come now—for the Rector’s chicken-broth on
2038: a Sunday. He has consumed all ours that I can spare. You are half paid
2039: with the sermon, Mrs. Fitchett, remember that. Take a pair of
2040: tumbler-pigeons for them—little beauties. You must come and see them.
2041: You have no tumblers among your pigeons.”
2042: 
2043: “Well, madam, Master Fitchett shall go and see ’em after work. He’s
2044: very hot on new sorts; to oblige you.”
2045: 
2046: “Oblige me! It will be the best bargain he ever made. A pair of church
2047: pigeons for a couple of wicked Spanish fowls that eat their own eggs!
2048: Don’t you and Fitchett boast too much, that is all!”
2049: 
2050: The phaeton was driven onwards with the last words, leaving Mrs.
2051: Fitchett laughing and shaking her head slowly, with an interjectional
2052: “Sure_ly_, sure_ly_!”—from which it might be inferred that she would
2053: have found the country-side somewhat duller if the Rector’s lady had
2054: been less free-spoken and less of a skinflint. Indeed, both the farmers
2055: and laborers in the parishes of Freshitt and Tipton would have felt a
2056: sad lack of conversation but for the stories about what Mrs.
2057: Cadwallader said and did: a lady of immeasurably high birth, descended,
2058: as it were, from unknown earls, dim as the crowd of heroic shades—who
2059: pleaded poverty, pared down prices, and cut jokes in the most
2060: companionable manner, though with a turn of tongue that let you know
2061: who she was. Such a lady gave a neighborliness to both rank and
2062: religion, and mitigated the bitterness of uncommuted tithe. A much more
2063: exemplary character with an infusion of sour dignity would not have
2064: furthered their comprehension of the Thirty-nine Articles, and would
2065: have been less socially uniting.
2066: 
2067: Mr. Brooke, seeing Mrs. Cadwallader’s merits from a different point of
2068: view, winced a little when her name was announced in the library, where
2069: he was sitting alone.
2070: 
2071: “I see you have had our Lowick Cicero here,” she said, seating herself
2072: comfortably, throwing back her wraps, and showing a thin but well-built
2073: figure. “I suspect you and he are brewing some bad polities, else you
2074: would not be seeing so much of the lively man. I shall inform against
2075: you: remember you are both suspicious characters since you took Peel’s
2076: side about the Catholic Bill. I shall tell everybody that you are going
2077: to put up for Middlemarch on the Whig side when old Pinkerton resigns,
2078: and that Casaubon is going to help you in an underhand manner: going to
2079: bribe the voters with pamphlets, and throw open the public-houses to
2080: distribute them. Come, confess!”
2081: 
2082: “Nothing of the sort,” said Mr. Brooke, smiling and rubbing his
2083: eye-glasses, but really blushing a little at the impeachment. “Casaubon
2084: and I don’t talk politics much. He doesn’t care much about the
2085: philanthropic side of things; punishments, and that kind of thing. He
2086: only cares about Church questions. That is not my line of action, you
2087: know.”
2088: 
2089: “Ra-a-ther too much, my friend. I have heard of your doings. Who was it
2090: that sold his bit of land to the Papists at Middlemarch? I believe you
2091: bought it on purpose. You are a perfect Guy Faux. See if you are not
2092: burnt in effigy this 5th of November coming. Humphrey would not come to
2093: quarrel with you about it, so I am come.”
2094: 
2095: “Very good. I was prepared to be persecuted for not persecuting—not
2096: persecuting, you know.”
2097: 
2098: “There you go! That is a piece of clap-trap you have got ready for the
2099: hustings. Now, _do not_ let them lure you to the hustings, my dear Mr.
2100: Brooke. A man always makes a fool of himself, speechifying: there’s no
2101: excuse but being on the right side, so that you can ask a blessing on
2102: your humming and hawing. You will lose yourself, I forewarn you. You
2103: will make a Saturday pie of all parties’ opinions, and be pelted by
2104: everybody.”
2105: 
2106: “That is what I expect, you know,” said Mr. Brooke, not wishing to
2107: betray how little he enjoyed this prophetic sketch—“what I expect as an
2108: independent man. As to the Whigs, a man who goes with the thinkers is
2109: not likely to be hooked on by any party. He may go with them up to a
2110: certain point—up to a certain point, you know. But that is what you
2111: ladies never understand.”
2112: 
2113: “Where your certain point is? No. I should like to be told how a man
2114: can have any certain point when he belongs to no party—leading a roving
2115: life, and never letting his friends know his address. ‘Nobody knows
2116: where Brooke will be—there’s no counting on Brooke’—that is what people
2117: say of you, to be quite frank. Now, do turn respectable. How will you
2118: like going to Sessions with everybody looking shy on you, and you with
2119: a bad conscience and an empty pocket?”
2120: 
2121: “I don’t pretend to argue with a lady on politics,” said Mr. Brooke,
2122: with an air of smiling indifference, but feeling rather unpleasantly
2123: conscious that this attack of Mrs. Cadwallader’s had opened the
2124: defensive campaign to which certain rash steps had exposed him. “Your
2125: sex are not thinkers, you know—_varium et mutabile semper_—that kind of
2126: thing. You don’t know Virgil. I knew”—Mr. Brooke reflected in time that
2127: he had not had the personal acquaintance of the Augustan poet—“I was
2128: going to say, poor Stoddart, you know. That was what _he_ said. You
2129: ladies are always against an independent attitude—a man’s caring for
2130: nothing but truth, and that sort of thing. And there is no part of the
2131: county where opinion is narrower than it is here—I don’t mean to throw
2132: stones, you know, but somebody is wanted to take the independent line;
2133: and if I don’t take it, who will?”
2134: 
2135: “Who? Why, any upstart who has got neither blood nor position. People
2136: of standing should consume their independent nonsense at home, not hawk
2137: it about. And you! who are going to marry your niece, as good as your
2138: daughter, to one of our best men. Sir James would be cruelly annoyed:
2139: it will be too hard on him if you turn round now and make yourself a
2140: Whig sign-board.”
2141: 
2142: Mr. Brooke again winced inwardly, for Dorothea’s engagement had no
2143: sooner been decided, than he had thought of Mrs. Cadwallader’s
2144: prospective taunts. It might have been easy for ignorant observers to
2145: say, “Quarrel with Mrs. Cadwallader;” but where is a country gentleman
2146: to go who quarrels with his oldest neighbors? Who could taste the fine
2147: flavor in the name of Brooke if it were delivered casually, like wine
2148: without a seal? Certainly a man can only be cosmopolitan up to a
2149: certain point.
2150: 
2151: “I hope Chettam and I shall always be good friends; but I am sorry to
2152: say there is no prospect of his marrying my niece,” said Mr. Brooke,
2153: much relieved to see through the window that Celia was coming in.
2154: 
2155: “Why not?” said Mrs. Cadwallader, with a sharp note of surprise. “It is
2156: hardly a fortnight since you and I were talking about it.”
2157: 
2158: “My niece has chosen another suitor—has chosen him, you know. I have
2159: had nothing to do with it. I should have preferred Chettam; and I
2160: should have said Chettam was the man any girl would have chosen. But
2161: there is no accounting for these things. Your sex is capricious, you
2162: know.”
2163: 
2164: “Why, whom do you mean to say that you are going to let her marry?”
2165: Mrs. Cadwallader’s mind was rapidly surveying the possibilities of
2166: choice for Dorothea.
2167: 
2168: But here Celia entered, blooming from a walk in the garden, and the
2169: greeting with her delivered Mr. Brooke from the necessity of answering
2170: immediately. He got up hastily, and saying, “By the way, I must speak
2171: to Wright about the horses,” shuffled quickly out of the room.
2172: 
2173: “My dear child, what is this?—this about your sister’s engagement?”
2174: said Mrs. Cadwallader.
2175: 
2176: “She is engaged to marry Mr. Casaubon,” said Celia, resorting, as
2177: usual, to the simplest statement of fact, and enjoying this opportunity
2178: of speaking to the Rector’s wife alone.
2179: 
2180: “This is frightful. How long has it been going on?”
2181: 
2182: “I only knew of it yesterday. They are to be married in six weeks.”
2183: 
2184: “Well, my dear, I wish you joy of your brother-in-law.”
2185: 
2186: “I am so sorry for Dorothea.”
2187: 
2188: “Sorry! It is her doing, I suppose.”
2189: 
2190: “Yes; she says Mr. Casaubon has a great soul.”
2191: 
2192: “With all my heart.”
2193: 
2194: “Oh, Mrs. Cadwallader, I don’t think it can be nice to marry a man with
2195: a great soul.”
2196: 
2197: “Well, my dear, take warning. You know the look of one now; when the
2198: next comes and wants to marry you, don’t you accept him.”
2199: 
2200: “I’m sure I never should.”
2201: 
2202: “No; one such in a family is enough. So your sister never cared about
2203: Sir James Chettam? What would you have said to _him_ for a
2204: brother-in-law?”
2205: 
2206: “I should have liked that very much. I am sure he would have been a
2207: good husband. Only,” Celia added, with a slight blush (she sometimes
2208: seemed to blush as she breathed), “I don’t think he would have suited
2209: Dorothea.”
2210: 
2211: “Not high-flown enough?”
2212: 
2213: “Dodo is very strict. She thinks so much about everything, and is so
2214: particular about what one says. Sir James never seemed to please her.”
2215: 
2216: “She must have encouraged him, I am sure. That is not very creditable.”
2217: 
2218: “Please don’t be angry with Dodo; she does not see things. She thought
2219: so much about the cottages, and she was rude to Sir James sometimes;
2220: but he is so kind, he never noticed it.”
2221: 
2222: “Well,” said Mrs. Cadwallader, putting on her shawl, and rising, as if
2223: in haste, “I must go straight to Sir James and break this to him. He
2224: will have brought his mother back by this time, and I must call. Your
2225: uncle will never tell him. We are all disappointed, my dear. Young
2226: people should think of their families in marrying. I set a bad
2227: example—married a poor clergyman, and made myself a pitiable object
2228: among the De Bracys—obliged to get my coals by stratagem, and pray to
2229: heaven for my salad oil. However, Casaubon has money enough; I must do
2230: him that justice. As to his blood, I suppose the family quarterings are
2231: three cuttle-fish sable, and a commentator rampant. By the bye, before
2232: I go, my dear, I must speak to your Mrs. Carter about pastry. I want to
2233: send my young cook to learn of her. Poor people with four children,
2234: like us, you know, can’t afford to keep a good cook. I have no doubt
2235: Mrs. Carter will oblige me. Sir James’s cook is a perfect dragon.”
2236: 
2237: In less than an hour, Mrs. Cadwallader had circumvented Mrs. Carter and
2238: driven to Freshitt Hall, which was not far from her own parsonage, her
2239: husband being resident in Freshitt and keeping a curate in Tipton.
2240: 
2241: Sir James Chettam had returned from the short journey which had kept
2242: him absent for a couple of days, and had changed his dress, intending
2243: to ride over to Tipton Grange. His horse was standing at the door when
2244: Mrs. Cadwallader drove up, and he immediately appeared there himself,
2245: whip in hand. Lady Chettam had not yet returned, but Mrs. Cadwallader’s
2246: errand could not be despatched in the presence of grooms, so she asked
2247: to be taken into the conservatory close by, to look at the new plants;
2248: and on coming to a contemplative stand, she said—
2249: 
2250: “I have a great shock for you; I hope you are not so far gone in love
2251: as you pretended to be.”
2252: 
2253: It was of no use protesting against Mrs. Cadwallader’s way of putting
2254: things. But Sir James’s countenance changed a little. He felt a vague
2255: alarm.
2256: 
2257: “I do believe Brooke is going to expose himself after all. I accused
2258: him of meaning to stand for Middlemarch on the Liberal side, and he
2259: looked silly and never denied it—talked about the independent line, and
2260: the usual nonsense.”
2261: 
2262: “Is that all?” said Sir James, much relieved.
2263: 
2264: “Why,” rejoined Mrs. Cadwallader, with a sharper note, “you don’t mean
2265: to say that you would like him to turn public man in that way—making a
2266: sort of political Cheap Jack of himself?”
2267: 
2268: “He might be dissuaded, I should think. He would not like the expense.”
2269: 
2270: “That is what I told him. He is vulnerable to reason there—always a few
2271: grains of common-sense in an ounce of miserliness. Miserliness is a
2272: capital quality to run in families; it’s the safe side for madness to
2273: dip on. And there must be a little crack in the Brooke family, else we
2274: should not see what we are to see.”
2275: 
2276: “What? Brooke standing for Middlemarch?”
2277: 
2278: “Worse than that. I really feel a little responsible. I always told you
2279: Miss Brooke would be such a fine match. I knew there was a great deal
2280: of nonsense in her—a flighty sort of Methodistical stuff. But these
2281: things wear out of girls. However, I am taken by surprise for once.”
2282: 
2283: “What do you mean, Mrs. Cadwallader?” said Sir James. His fear lest
2284: Miss Brooke should have run away to join the Moravian Brethren, or some
2285: preposterous sect unknown to good society, was a little allayed by the
2286: knowledge that Mrs. Cadwallader always made the worst of things. “What
2287: has happened to Miss Brooke? Pray speak out.”
2288: 
2289: “Very well. She is engaged to be married.” Mrs. Cadwallader paused a
2290: few moments, observing the deeply hurt expression in her friend’s face,
2291: which he was trying to conceal by a nervous smile, while he whipped his
2292: boot; but she soon added, “Engaged to Casaubon.”
2293: 
2294: Sir James let his whip fall and stooped to pick it up. Perhaps his face
2295: had never before gathered so much concentrated disgust as when he
2296: turned to Mrs. Cadwallader and repeated, “Casaubon?”
2297: 
2298: “Even so. You know my errand now.”
2299: 
2300: “Good God! It is horrible! He is no better than a mummy!” (The point of
2301: view has to be allowed for, as that of a blooming and disappointed
2302: rival.)
2303: 
2304: “She says, he is a great soul.—A great bladder for dried peas to rattle
2305: in!” said Mrs. Cadwallader.
2306: 
2307: “What business has an old bachelor like that to marry?” said Sir James.
2308: “He has one foot in the grave.”
2309: 
2310: “He means to draw it out again, I suppose.”
2311: 
2312: “Brooke ought not to allow it: he should insist on its being put off
2313: till she is of age. She would think better of it then. What is a
2314: guardian for?”
2315: 
2316: “As if you could ever squeeze a resolution out of Brooke!”
2317: 
2318: “Cadwallader might talk to him.”
2319: 
2320: “Not he! Humphrey finds everybody charming. I never can get him to
2321: abuse Casaubon. He will even speak well of the bishop, though I tell
2322: him it is unnatural in a beneficed clergyman; what can one do with a
2323: husband who attends so little to the decencies? I hide it as well as I
2324: can by abusing everybody myself. Come, come, cheer up! you are well rid
2325: of Miss Brooke, a girl who would have been requiring you to see the
2326: stars by daylight. Between ourselves, little Celia is worth two of her,
2327: and likely after all to be the better match. For this marriage to
2328: Casaubon is as good as going to a nunnery.”
2329: 
2330: “Oh, on my own account—it is for Miss Brooke’s sake I think her friends
2331: should try to use their influence.”
2332: 
2333: “Well, Humphrey doesn’t know yet. But when I tell him, you may depend
2334: on it he will say, ‘Why not? Casaubon is a good fellow—and young—young
2335: enough.’ These charitable people never know vinegar from wine till they
2336: have swallowed it and got the colic. However, if I were a man I should
2337: prefer Celia, especially when Dorothea was gone. The truth is, you have
2338: been courting one and have won the other. I can see that she admires
2339: you almost as much as a man expects to be admired. If it were any one
2340: but me who said so, you might think it exaggeration. Good-by!”
2341: 
2342: Sir James handed Mrs. Cadwallader to the phaeton, and then jumped on
2343: his horse. He was not going to renounce his ride because of his
2344: friend’s unpleasant news—only to ride the faster in some other
2345: direction than that of Tipton Grange.
2346: 
2347: Now, why on earth should Mrs. Cadwallader have been at all busy about
2348: Miss Brooke’s marriage; and why, when one match that she liked to think
2349: she had a hand in was frustrated, should she have straightway contrived
2350: the preliminaries of another? Was there any ingenious plot, any
2351: hide-and-seek course of action, which might be detected by a careful
2352: telescopic watch? Not at all: a telescope might have swept the parishes
2353: of Tipton and Freshitt, the whole area visited by Mrs. Cadwallader in
2354: her phaeton, without witnessing any interview that could excite
2355: suspicion, or any scene from which she did not return with the same
2356: unperturbed keenness of eye and the same high natural color. In fact,
2357: if that convenient vehicle had existed in the days of the Seven Sages,
2358: one of them would doubtless have remarked, that you can know little of
2359: women by following them about in their pony-phaetons. Even with a
2360: microscope directed on a water-drop we find ourselves making
2361: interpretations which turn out to be rather coarse; for whereas under a
2362: weak lens you may seem to see a creature exhibiting an active voracity
2363: into which other smaller creatures actively play as if they were so
2364: many animated tax-pennies, a stronger lens reveals to you certain
2365: tiniest hairlets which make vortices for these victims while the
2366: swallower waits passively at his receipt of custom. In this way,
2367: metaphorically speaking, a strong lens applied to Mrs. Cadwallader’s
2368: match-making will show a play of minute causes producing what may be
2369: called thought and speech vortices to bring her the sort of food she
2370: needed. Her life was rurally simple, quite free from secrets either
2371: foul, dangerous, or otherwise important, and not consciously affected
2372: by the great affairs of the world. All the more did the affairs of the
2373: great world interest her, when communicated in the letters of high-born
2374: relations: the way in which fascinating younger sons had gone to the
2375: dogs by marrying their mistresses; the fine old-blooded idiocy of young
2376: Lord Tapir, and the furious gouty humors of old Lord Megatherium; the
2377: exact crossing of genealogies which had brought a coronet into a new
2378: branch and widened the relations of scandal,—these were topics of which
2379: she retained details with the utmost accuracy, and reproduced them in
2380: an excellent pickle of epigrams, which she herself enjoyed the more
2381: because she believed as unquestionably in birth and no-birth as she did
2382: in game and vermin. She would never have disowned any one on the ground
2383: of poverty: a De Bracy reduced to take his dinner in a basin would have
2384: seemed to her an example of pathos worth exaggerating, and I fear his
2385: aristocratic vices would not have horrified her. But her feeling
2386: towards the vulgar rich was a sort of religious hatred: they had
2387: probably made all their money out of high retail prices, and Mrs.
2388: Cadwallader detested high prices for everything that was not paid in
2389: kind at the Rectory: such people were no part of God’s design in making
2390: the world; and their accent was an affliction to the ears. A town where
2391: such monsters abounded was hardly more than a sort of low comedy, which
2392: could not be taken account of in a well-bred scheme of the universe.
2393: Let any lady who is inclined to be hard on Mrs. Cadwallader inquire
2394: into the comprehensiveness of her own beautiful views, and be quite
2395: sure that they afford accommodation for all the lives which have the
2396: honor to coexist with hers.
2397: 
2398: With such a mind, active as phosphorus, biting everything that came
2399: near into the form that suited it, how could Mrs. Cadwallader feel that
2400: the Miss Brookes and their matrimonial prospects were alien to her?
2401: especially as it had been the habit of years for her to scold Mr.
2402: Brooke with the friendliest frankness, and let him know in confidence
2403: that she thought him a poor creature. From the first arrival of the
2404: young ladies in Tipton she had prearranged Dorothea’s marriage with Sir
2405: James, and if it had taken place would have been quite sure that it was
2406: her doing: that it should not take place after she had preconceived it,
2407: caused her an irritation which every thinker will sympathize with. She
2408: was the diplomatist of Tipton and Freshitt, and for anything to happen
2409: in spite of her was an offensive irregularity. As to freaks like this
2410: of Miss Brooke’s, Mrs. Cadwallader had no patience with them, and now
2411: saw that her opinion of this girl had been infected with some of her
2412: husband’s weak charitableness: those Methodistical whims, that air of
2413: being more religious than the rector and curate together, came from a
2414: deeper and more constitutional disease than she had been willing to
2415: believe.
2416: 
2417: “However,” said Mrs. Cadwallader, first to herself and afterwards to
2418: her husband, “I throw her over: there was a chance, if she had married
2419: Sir James, of her becoming a sane, sensible woman. He would never have
2420: contradicted her, and when a woman is not contradicted, she has no
2421: motive for obstinacy in her absurdities. But now I wish her joy of her
2422: hair shirt.”
2423: 
2424: It followed that Mrs. Cadwallader must decide on another match for Sir
2425: James, and having made up her mind that it was to be the younger Miss
2426: Brooke, there could not have been a more skilful move towards the
2427: success of her plan than her hint to the baronet that he had made an
2428: impression on Celia’s heart. For he was not one of those gentlemen who
2429: languish after the unattainable Sappho’s apple that laughs from the
2430: topmost bough—the charms which
2431: 
2432: “Smile like the knot of cowslips on the cliff,
2433: Not to be come at by the willing hand.”
2434: 
2435: 
2436: He had no sonnets to write, and it could not strike him agreeably that
2437: he was not an object of preference to the woman whom he had preferred.
2438: Already the knowledge that Dorothea had chosen Mr. Casaubon had bruised
2439: his attachment and relaxed its hold. Although Sir James was a
2440: sportsman, he had some other feelings towards women than towards grouse
2441: and foxes, and did not regard his future wife in the light of prey,
2442: valuable chiefly for the excitements of the chase. Neither was he so
2443: well acquainted with the habits of primitive races as to feel that an
2444: ideal combat for her, tomahawk in hand, so to speak, was necessary to
2445: the historical continuity of the marriage-tie. On the contrary, having
2446: the amiable vanity which knits us to those who are fond of us, and
2447: disinclines us to those who are indifferent, and also a good grateful
2448: nature, the mere idea that a woman had a kindness towards him spun
2449: little threads of tenderness from out his heart towards hers.
2450: 
2451: Thus it happened, that after Sir James had ridden rather fast for half
2452: an hour in a direction away from Tipton Grange, he slackened his pace,
2453: and at last turned into a road which would lead him back by a shorter
2454: cut. Various feelings wrought in him the determination after all to go
2455: to the Grange to-day as if nothing new had happened. He could not help
2456: rejoicing that he had never made the offer and been rejected; mere
2457: friendly politeness required that he should call to see Dorothea about
2458: the cottages, and now happily Mrs. Cadwallader had prepared him to
2459: offer his congratulations, if necessary, without showing too much
2460: awkwardness. He really did not like it: giving up Dorothea was very
2461: painful to him; but there was something in the resolve to make this
2462: visit forthwith and conquer all show of feeling, which was a sort of
2463: file-biting and counter-irritant. And without his distinctly
2464: recognizing the impulse, there certainly was present in him the sense
2465: that Celia would be there, and that he should pay her more attention
2466: than he had done before.
2467: 
2468: We mortals, men and women, devour many a disappointment between
2469: breakfast and dinner-time; keep back the tears and look a little pale
2470: about the lips, and in answer to inquiries say, “Oh, nothing!” Pride
2471: helps us; and pride is not a bad thing when it only urges us to hide
2472: our own hurts—not to hurt others.
2473:

2477: CHAPTER VII.
2478: 
2479: “Piacer e popone
2480: Vuol la sua stagione.”
2481: —_Italian Proverb_.
2482: 
2483: 
2484: Mr. Casaubon, as might be expected, spent a great deal of his time at
2485: the Grange in these weeks, and the hindrance which courtship occasioned
2486: to the progress of his great work—the Key to all Mythologies—naturally
2487: made him look forward the more eagerly to the happy termination of
2488: courtship. But he had deliberately incurred the hindrance, having made
2489: up his mind that it was now time for him to adorn his life with the
2490: graces of female companionship, to irradiate the gloom which fatigue
2491: was apt to hang over the intervals of studious labor with the play of
2492: female fancy, and to secure in this, his culminating age, the solace of
2493: female tendance for his declining years. Hence he determined to abandon
2494: himself to the stream of feeling, and perhaps was surprised to find
2495: what an exceedingly shallow rill it was. As in droughty regions baptism
2496: by immersion could only be performed symbolically, Mr. Casaubon found
2497: that sprinkling was the utmost approach to a plunge which his stream
2498: would afford him; and he concluded that the poets had much exaggerated
2499: the force of masculine passion. Nevertheless, he observed with pleasure
2500: that Miss Brooke showed an ardent submissive affection which promised
2501: to fulfil his most agreeable previsions of marriage. It had once or
2502: twice crossed his mind that possibly there was some deficiency in
2503: Dorothea to account for the moderation of his abandonment; but he was
2504: unable to discern the deficiency, or to figure to himself a woman who
2505: would have pleased him better; so that there was clearly no reason to
2506: fall back upon but the exaggerations of human tradition.
2507: 
2508: “Could I not be preparing myself now to be more useful?” said Dorothea
2509: to him, one morning, early in the time of courtship; “could I not learn
2510: to read Latin and Greek aloud to you, as Milton’s daughters did to
2511: their father, without understanding what they read?”
2512: 
2513: “I fear that would be wearisome to you,” said Mr. Casaubon, smiling;
2514: “and, indeed, if I remember rightly, the young women you have mentioned
2515: regarded that exercise in unknown tongues as a ground for rebellion
2516: against the poet.”
2517: 
2518: “Yes; but in the first place they were very naughty girls, else they
2519: would have been proud to minister to such a father; and in the second
2520: place they might have studied privately and taught themselves to
2521: understand what they read, and then it would have been interesting. I
2522: hope you don’t expect me to be naughty and stupid?”
2523: 
2524: “I expect you to be all that an exquisite young lady can be in every
2525: possible relation of life. Certainly it might be a great advantage if
2526: you were able to copy the Greek character, and to that end it were well
2527: to begin with a little reading.”
2528: 
2529: Dorothea seized this as a precious permission. She would not have asked
2530: Mr. Casaubon at once to teach her the languages, dreading of all things
2531: to be tiresome instead of helpful; but it was not entirely out of
2532: devotion to her future husband that she wished to know Latin and Greek.
2533: Those provinces of masculine knowledge seemed to her a standing-ground
2534: from which all truth could be seen more truly. As it was, she
2535: constantly doubted her own conclusions, because she felt her own
2536: ignorance: how could she be confident that one-roomed cottages were not
2537: for the glory of God, when men who knew the classics appeared to
2538: conciliate indifference to the cottages with zeal for the glory?
2539: Perhaps even Hebrew might be necessary—at least the alphabet and a few
2540: roots—in order to arrive at the core of things, and judge soundly on
2541: the social duties of the Christian. And she had not reached that point
2542: of renunciation at which she would have been satisfied with having a
2543: wise husband: she wished, poor child, to be wise herself. Miss Brooke
2544: was certainly very naive with all her alleged cleverness. Celia, whose
2545: mind had never been thought too powerful, saw the emptiness of other
2546: people’s pretensions much more readily. To have in general but little
2547: feeling, seems to be the only security against feeling too much on any
2548: particular occasion.
2549: 
2550: However, Mr. Casaubon consented to listen and teach for an hour
2551: together, like a schoolmaster of little boys, or rather like a lover,
2552: to whom a mistress’s elementary ignorance and difficulties have a
2553: touching fitness. Few scholars would have disliked teaching the
2554: alphabet under such circumstances. But Dorothea herself was a little
2555: shocked and discouraged at her own stupidity, and the answers she got
2556: to some timid questions about the value of the Greek accents gave her a
2557: painful suspicion that here indeed there might be secrets not capable
2558: of explanation to a woman’s reason.
2559: 
2560: Mr. Brooke had no doubt on that point, and expressed himself with his
2561: usual strength upon it one day that he came into the library while the
2562: reading was going forward.
2563: 
2564: “Well, but now, Casaubon, such deep studies, classics, mathematics,
2565: that kind of thing, are too taxing for a woman—too taxing, you know.”
2566: 
2567: “Dorothea is learning to read the characters simply,” said Mr.
2568: Casaubon, evading the question. “She had the very considerate thought
2569: of saving my eyes.”
2570: 
2571: “Ah, well, without understanding, you know—that may not be so bad. But
2572: there is a lightness about the feminine mind—a touch and go—music, the
2573: fine arts, that kind of thing—they should study those up to a certain
2574: point, women should; but in a light way, you know. A woman should be
2575: able to sit down and play you or sing you a good old English tune. That
2576: is what I like; though I have heard most things—been at the opera in
2577: Vienna: Gluck, Mozart, everything of that sort. But I’m a conservative
2578: in music—it’s not like ideas, you know. I stick to the good old tunes.”
2579: 
2580: “Mr. Casaubon is not fond of the piano, and I am very glad he is not,”
2581: said Dorothea, whose slight regard for domestic music and feminine fine
2582: art must be forgiven her, considering the small tinkling and smearing
2583: in which they chiefly consisted at that dark period. She smiled and
2584: looked up at her betrothed with grateful eyes. If he had always been
2585: asking her to play the “Last Rose of Summer,” she would have required
2586: much resignation. “He says there is only an old harpsichord at Lowick,
2587: and it is covered with books.”
2588: 
2589: “Ah, there you are behind Celia, my dear. Celia, now, plays very
2590: prettily, and is always ready to play. However, since Casaubon does not
2591: like it, you are all right. But it’s a pity you should not have little
2592: recreations of that sort, Casaubon: the bow always strung—that kind of
2593: thing, you know—will not do.”
2594: 
2595: “I never could look on it in the light of a recreation to have my ears
2596: teased with measured noises,” said Mr. Casaubon. “A tune much iterated
2597: has the ridiculous effect of making the words in my mind perform a sort
2598: of minuet to keep time—an effect hardly tolerable, I imagine, after
2599: boyhood. As to the grander forms of music, worthy to accompany solemn
2600: celebrations, and even to serve as an educating influence according to
2601: the ancient conception, I say nothing, for with these we are not
2602: immediately concerned.”
2603: 
2604: “No; but music of that sort I should enjoy,” said Dorothea. “When we
2605: were coming home from Lausanne my uncle took us to hear the great organ
2606: at Freiberg, and it made me sob.”
2607: 
2608: “That kind of thing is not healthy, my dear,” said Mr. Brooke.
2609: “Casaubon, she will be in your hands now: you must teach my niece to
2610: take things more quietly, eh, Dorothea?”
2611: 
2612: He ended with a smile, not wishing to hurt his niece, but really
2613: thinking that it was perhaps better for her to be early married to so
2614: sober a fellow as Casaubon, since she would not hear of Chettam.
2615: 
2616: “It is wonderful, though,” he said to himself as he shuffled out of the
2617: room—“it is wonderful that she should have liked him. However, the
2618: match is good. I should have been travelling out of my brief to have
2619: hindered it, let Mrs. Cadwallader say what she will. He is pretty
2620: certain to be a bishop, is Casaubon. That was a very seasonable
2621: pamphlet of his on the Catholic Question:—a deanery at least. They owe
2622: him a deanery.”
2623: 
2624: And here I must vindicate a claim to philosophical reflectiveness, by
2625: remarking that Mr. Brooke on this occasion little thought of the
2626: Radical speech which, at a later period, he was led to make on the
2627: incomes of the bishops. What elegant historian would neglect a striking
2628: opportunity for pointing out that his heroes did not foresee the
2629: history of the world, or even their own actions?—For example, that
2630: Henry of Navarre, when a Protestant baby, little thought of being a
2631: Catholic monarch; or that Alfred the Great, when he measured his
2632: laborious nights with burning candles, had no idea of future gentlemen
2633: measuring their idle days with watches. Here is a mine of truth, which,
2634: however vigorously it may be worked, is likely to outlast our coal.
2635: 
2636: But of Mr. Brooke I make a further remark perhaps less warranted by
2637: precedent—namely, that if he had foreknown his speech, it might not
2638: have made any great difference. To think with pleasure of his niece’s
2639: husband having a large ecclesiastical income was one thing—to make a
2640: Liberal speech was another thing; and it is a narrow mind which cannot
2641: look at a subject from various points of view.
2642: 
2643: 
2644: 
2645: 
2646: CHAPTER VIII.
2647: 
2648: “Oh, rescue her! I am her brother now,
2649: And you her father. Every gentle maid
2650: Should have a guardian in each gentleman.”
2651: 
2652: 
2653: It was wonderful to Sir James Chettam how well he continued to like
2654: going to the Grange after he had once encountered the difficulty of
2655: seeing Dorothea for the first time in the light of a woman who was
2656: engaged to another man. Of course the forked lightning seemed to pass
2657: through him when he first approached her, and he remained conscious
2658: throughout the interview of hiding uneasiness; but, good as he was, it
2659: must be owned that his uneasiness was less than it would have been if
2660: he had thought his rival a brilliant and desirable match. He had no
2661: sense of being eclipsed by Mr. Casaubon; he was only shocked that
2662: Dorothea was under a melancholy illusion, and his mortification lost
2663: some of its bitterness by being mingled with compassion.
2664: 
2665: Nevertheless, while Sir James said to himself that he had completely
2666: resigned her, since with the perversity of a Desdemona she had not
2667: affected a proposed match that was clearly suitable and according to
2668: nature; he could not yet be quite passive under the idea of her
2669: engagement to Mr. Casaubon. On the day when he first saw them together
2670: in the light of his present knowledge, it seemed to him that he had not
2671: taken the affair seriously enough. Brooke was really culpable; he ought
2672: to have hindered it. Who could speak to him? Something might be done
2673: perhaps even now, at least to defer the marriage. On his way home he
2674: turned into the Rectory and asked for Mr. Cadwallader. Happily, the
2675: Rector was at home, and his visitor was shown into the study, where all
2676: the fishing tackle hung. But he himself was in a little room adjoining,
2677: at work with his turning apparatus, and he called to the baronet to
2678: join him there. The two were better friends than any other landholder
2679: and clergyman in the county—a significant fact which was in agreement
2680: with the amiable expression of their faces.
2681: 
2682: Mr. Cadwallader was a large man, with full lips and a sweet smile; very
2683: plain and rough in his exterior, but with that solid imperturbable ease
2684: and good-humor which is infectious, and like great grassy hills in the
2685: sunshine, quiets even an irritated egoism, and makes it rather ashamed
2686: of itself. “Well, how are you?” he said, showing a hand not quite fit
2687: to be grasped. “Sorry I missed you before. Is there anything
2688: particular? You look vexed.”
2689: 
2690: Sir James’s brow had a little crease in it, a little depression of the
2691: eyebrow, which he seemed purposely to exaggerate as he answered.
2692: 
2693: “It is only this conduct of Brooke’s. I really think somebody should
2694: speak to him.”
2695: 
2696: “What? meaning to stand?” said Mr. Cadwallader, going on with the
2697: arrangement of the reels which he had just been turning. “I hardly
2698: think he means it. But where’s the harm, if he likes it? Any one who
2699: objects to Whiggery should be glad when the Whigs don’t put up the
2700: strongest fellow. They won’t overturn the Constitution with our friend
2701: Brooke’s head for a battering ram.”
2702: 
2703: “Oh, I don’t mean that,” said Sir James, who, after putting down his
2704: hat and throwing himself into a chair, had begun to nurse his leg and
2705: examine the sole of his boot with much bitterness. “I mean this
2706: marriage. I mean his letting that blooming young girl marry Casaubon.”
2707: 
2708: “What is the matter with Casaubon? I see no harm in him—if the girl
2709: likes him.”
2710: 
2711: “She is too young to know what she likes. Her guardian ought to
2712: interfere. He ought not to allow the thing to be done in this headlong
2713: manner. I wonder a man like you, Cadwallader—a man with daughters, can
2714: look at the affair with indifference: and with such a heart as yours!
2715: Do think seriously about it.”
2716: 
2717: “I am not joking; I am as serious as possible,” said the Rector, with a
2718: provoking little inward laugh. “You are as bad as Elinor. She has been
2719: wanting me to go and lecture Brooke; and I have reminded her that her
2720: friends had a very poor opinion of the match she made when she married
2721: me.”
2722: 
2723: “But look at Casaubon,” said Sir James, indignantly. “He must be fifty,
2724: and I don’t believe he could ever have been much more than the shadow
2725: of a man. Look at his legs!”
2726: 
2727: “Confound you handsome young fellows! you think of having it all your
2728: own way in the world. You don’t understand women. They don’t admire you
2729: half so much as you admire yourselves. Elinor used to tell her sisters
2730: that she married me for my ugliness—it was so various and amusing that
2731: it had quite conquered her prudence.”
2732: 
2733: “You! it was easy enough for a woman to love you. But this is no
2734: question of beauty. I don’t _like_ Casaubon.” This was Sir James’s
2735: strongest way of implying that he thought ill of a man’s character.
2736: 
2737: “Why? what do you know against him?” said the Rector laying down his
2738: reels, and putting his thumbs into his armholes with an air of
2739: attention.
2740: 
2741: Sir James paused. He did not usually find it easy to give his reasons:
2742: it seemed to him strange that people should not know them without being
2743: told, since he only felt what was reasonable. At last he said—
2744: 
2745: “Now, Cadwallader, has he got any heart?”
2746: 
2747: “Well, yes. I don’t mean of the melting sort, but a sound kernel,
2748: _that_ you may be sure of. He is very good to his poor relations:
2749: pensions several of the women, and is educating a young fellow at a
2750: good deal of expense. Casaubon acts up to his sense of justice. His
2751: mother’s sister made a bad match—a Pole, I think—lost herself—at any
2752: rate was disowned by her family. If it had not been for that, Casaubon
2753: would not have had so much money by half. I believe he went himself to
2754: find out his cousins, and see what he could do for them. Every man
2755: would not ring so well as that, if you tried his metal. _You_ would,
2756: Chettam; but not every man.”
2757: 
2758: “I don’t know,” said Sir James, coloring. “I am not so sure of myself.”
2759: He paused a moment, and then added, “That was a right thing for
2760: Casaubon to do. But a man may wish to do what is right, and yet be a
2761: sort of parchment code. A woman may not be happy with him. And I think
2762: when a girl is so young as Miss Brooke is, her friends ought to
2763: interfere a little to hinder her from doing anything foolish. You
2764: laugh, because you fancy I have some feeling on my own account. But
2765: upon my honor, it is not that. I should feel just the same if I were
2766: Miss Brooke’s brother or uncle.”
2767: 
2768: “Well, but what should you do?”
2769: 
2770: “I should say that the marriage must not be decided on until she was of
2771: age. And depend upon it, in that case, it would never come off. I wish
2772: you saw it as I do—I wish you would talk to Brooke about it.”
2773: 
2774: Sir James rose as he was finishing his sentence, for he saw Mrs.
2775: Cadwallader entering from the study. She held by the hand her youngest
2776: girl, about five years old, who immediately ran to papa, and was made
2777: comfortable on his knee.
2778: 
2779: “I hear what you are talking about,” said the wife. “But you will make
2780: no impression on Humphrey. As long as the fish rise to his bait,
2781: everybody is what he ought to be. Bless you, Casaubon has got a
2782: trout-stream, and does not care about fishing in it himself: could
2783: there be a better fellow?”
2784: 
2785: “Well, there is something in that,” said the Rector, with his quiet,
2786: inward laugh. “It is a very good quality in a man to have a
2787: trout-stream.”
2788: 
2789: “But seriously,” said Sir James, whose vexation had not yet spent
2790: itself, “don’t you think the Rector might do some good by speaking?”
2791: 
2792: “Oh, I told you beforehand what he would say,” answered Mrs.
2793: Cadwallader, lifting up her eyebrows. “I have done what I could: I wash
2794: my hands of the marriage.”
2795: 
2796: “In the first place,” said the Rector, looking rather grave, “it would
2797: be nonsensical to expect that I could convince Brooke, and make him act
2798: accordingly. Brooke is a very good fellow, but pulpy; he will run into
2799: any mould, but he won’t keep shape.”
2800: 
2801: “He might keep shape long enough to defer the marriage,” said Sir
2802: James.
2803: 
2804: “But, my dear Chettam, why should I use my influence to Casaubon’s
2805: disadvantage, unless I were much surer than I am that I should be
2806: acting for the advantage of Miss Brooke? I know no harm of Casaubon. I
2807: don’t care about his Xisuthrus and Fee-fo-fum and the rest; but then he
2808: doesn’t care about my fishing-tackle. As to the line he took on the
2809: Catholic Question, that was unexpected; but he has always been civil to
2810: me, and I don’t see why I should spoil his sport. For anything I can
2811: tell, Miss Brooke may be happier with him than she would be with any
2812: other man.”
2813: 
2814: “Humphrey! I have no patience with you. You know you would rather dine
2815: under the hedge than with Casaubon alone. You have nothing to say to
2816: each other.”
2817: 
2818: “What has that to do with Miss Brooke’s marrying him? She does not do
2819: it for my amusement.”
2820: 
2821: “He has got no good red blood in his body,” said Sir James.
2822: 
2823: “No. Somebody put a drop under a magnifying-glass and it was all
2824: semicolons and parentheses,” said Mrs. Cadwallader.
2825: 
2826: “Why does he not bring out his book, instead of marrying,” said Sir
2827: James, with a disgust which he held warranted by the sound feeling of
2828: an English layman.
2829: 
2830: “Oh, he dreams footnotes, and they run away with all his brains. They
2831: say, when he was a little boy, he made an abstract of ‘Hop o’ my
2832: Thumb,’ and he has been making abstracts ever since. Ugh! And that is
2833: the man Humphrey goes on saying that a woman may be happy with.”
2834: 
2835: “Well, he is what Miss Brooke likes,” said the Rector. “I don’t profess
2836: to understand every young lady’s taste.”
2837: 
2838: “But if she were your own daughter?” said Sir James.
2839: 
2840: “That would be a different affair. She is _not_ my daughter, and I
2841: don’t feel called upon to interfere. Casaubon is as good as most of us.
2842: He is a scholarly clergyman, and creditable to the cloth. Some Radical
2843: fellow speechifying at Middlemarch said Casaubon was the learned
2844: straw-chopping incumbent, and Freke was the brick-and-mortar incumbent,
2845: and I was the angling incumbent. And upon my word, I don’t see that one
2846: is worse or better than the other.” The Rector ended with his silent
2847: laugh. He always saw the joke of any satire against himself. His
2848: conscience was large and easy, like the rest of him: it did only what
2849: it could do without any trouble.
2850: 
2851: Clearly, there would be no interference with Miss Brooke’s marriage
2852: through Mr. Cadwallader; and Sir James felt with some sadness that she
2853: was to have perfect liberty of misjudgment. It was a sign of his good
2854: disposition that he did not slacken at all in his intention of carrying
2855: out Dorothea’s design of the cottages. Doubtless this persistence was
2856: the best course for his own dignity: but pride only helps us to be
2857: generous; it never makes us so, any more than vanity makes us witty.
2858: She was now enough aware of Sir James’s position with regard to her, to
2859: appreciate the rectitude of his perseverance in a landlord’s duty, to
2860: which he had at first been urged by a lover’s complaisance, and her
2861: pleasure in it was great enough to count for something even in her
2862: present happiness. Perhaps she gave to Sir James Chettam’s cottages all
2863: the interest she could spare from Mr. Casaubon, or rather from the
2864: symphony of hopeful dreams, admiring trust, and passionate self
2865: devotion which that learned gentleman had set playing in her soul.
2866: Hence it happened that in the good baronet’s succeeding visits, while
2867: he was beginning to pay small attentions to Celia, he found himself
2868: talking with more and more pleasure to Dorothea. She was perfectly
2869: unconstrained and without irritation towards him now, and he was
2870: gradually discovering the delight there is in frank kindness and
2871: companionship between a man and a woman who have no passion to hide or
2872: confess.
2873: 
2874: 
2875: 
2876: 
2877: CHAPTER IX.
2878: 
2879: 1_st Gent_. An ancient land in ancient oracles
2880:     Is called “law-thirsty”: all the struggle there
2881:     Was after order and a perfect rule.
2882:     Pray, where lie such lands now? . . .
2883: 
2884: 2_d Gent_. Why, where they lay of old—in human souls.
2885: 
2886: 
2887: Mr. Casaubon’s behavior about settlements was highly satisfactory to
2888: Mr. Brooke, and the preliminaries of marriage rolled smoothly along,
2889: shortening the weeks of courtship. The betrothed bride must see her
2890: future home, and dictate any changes that she would like to have made
2891: there. A woman dictates before marriage in order that she may have an
2892: appetite for submission afterwards. And certainly, the mistakes that we
