2893: male and female mortals make when we have our own way might fairly
2894: raise some wonder that we are so fond of it.
2895: 
2896: On a gray but dry November morning Dorothea drove to Lowick in company
2897: with her uncle and Celia. Mr. Casaubon’s home was the manor-house.
2898: Close by, visible from some parts of the garden, was the little church,
2899: with the old parsonage opposite. In the beginning of his career, Mr.
2900: Casaubon had only held the living, but the death of his brother had put
2901: him in possession of the manor also. It had a small park, with a fine
2902: old oak here and there, and an avenue of limes towards the southwest
2903: front, with a sunk fence between park and pleasure-ground, so that from
2904: the drawing-room windows the glance swept uninterruptedly along a slope
2905: of greensward till the limes ended in a level of corn and pastures,
2906: which often seemed to melt into a lake under the setting sun. This was
2907: the happy side of the house, for the south and east looked rather
2908: melancholy even under the brightest morning. The grounds here were more
2909: confined, the flower-beds showed no very careful tendance, and large
2910: clumps of trees, chiefly of sombre yews, had risen high, not ten yards
2911: from the windows. The building, of greenish stone, was in the old
2912: English style, not ugly, but small-windowed and melancholy-looking: the
2913: sort of house that must have children, many flowers, open windows, and
2914: little vistas of bright things, to make it seem a joyous home. In this
2915: latter end of autumn, with a sparse remnant of yellow leaves falling
2916: slowly athwart the dark evergreens in a stillness without sunshine, the
2917: house too had an air of autumnal decline, and Mr. Casaubon, when he
2918: presented himself, had no bloom that could be thrown into relief by
2919: that background.
2920: 
2921: “Oh dear!” Celia said to herself, “I am sure Freshitt Hall would have
2922: been pleasanter than this.” She thought of the white freestone, the
2923: pillared portico, and the terrace full of flowers, Sir James smiling
2924: above them like a prince issuing from his enchantment in a rose-bush,
2925: with a handkerchief swiftly metamorphosed from the most delicately
2926: odorous petals—Sir James, who talked so agreeably, always about things
2927: which had common-sense in them, and not about learning! Celia had those
2928: light young feminine tastes which grave and weatherworn gentlemen
2929: sometimes prefer in a wife; but happily Mr. Casaubon’s bias had been
2930: different, for he would have had no chance with Celia.
2931: 
2932: Dorothea, on the contrary, found the house and grounds all that she
2933: could wish: the dark book-shelves in the long library, the carpets and
2934: curtains with colors subdued by time, the curious old maps and
2935: bird’s-eye views on the walls of the corridor, with here and there an
2936: old vase below, had no oppression for her, and seemed more cheerful
2937: than the casts and pictures at the Grange, which her uncle had long ago
2938: brought home from his travels—they being probably among the ideas he
2939: had taken in at one time. To poor Dorothea these severe classical
2940: nudities and smirking Renaissance-Correggiosities were painfully
2941: inexplicable, staring into the midst of her Puritanic conceptions: she
2942: had never been taught how she could bring them into any sort of
2943: relevance with her life. But the owners of Lowick apparently had not
2944: been travellers, and Mr. Casaubon’s studies of the past were not
2945: carried on by means of such aids.
2946: 
2947: Dorothea walked about the house with delightful emotion. Everything
2948: seemed hallowed to her: this was to be the home of her wifehood, and
2949: she looked up with eyes full of confidence to Mr. Casaubon when he drew
2950: her attention specially to some actual arrangement and asked her if she
2951: would like an alteration. All appeals to her taste she met gratefully,
2952: but saw nothing to alter. His efforts at exact courtesy and formal
2953: tenderness had no defect for her. She filled up all blanks with
2954: unmanifested perfections, interpreting him as she interpreted the works
2955: of Providence, and accounting for seeming discords by her own deafness
2956: to the higher harmonies. And there are many blanks left in the weeks of
2957: courtship which a loving faith fills with happy assurance.
2958: 
2959: “Now, my dear Dorothea, I wish you to favor me by pointing out which
2960: room you would like to have as your boudoir,” said Mr. Casaubon,
2961: showing that his views of the womanly nature were sufficiently large to
2962: include that requirement.
2963: 
2964: “It is very kind of you to think of that,” said Dorothea, “but I assure
2965: you I would rather have all those matters decided for me. I shall be
2966: much happier to take everything as it is—just as you have been used to
2967: have it, or as you will yourself choose it to be. I have no motive for
2968: wishing anything else.”
2969: 
2970: “Oh, Dodo,” said Celia, “will you not have the bow-windowed room
2971: up-stairs?”
2972: 
2973: Mr. Casaubon led the way thither. The bow-window looked down the avenue
2974: of limes; the furniture was all of a faded blue, and there were
2975: miniatures of ladies and gentlemen with powdered hair hanging in a
2976: group. A piece of tapestry over a door also showed a blue-green world
2977: with a pale stag in it. The chairs and tables were thin-legged and easy
2978: to upset. It was a room where one might fancy the ghost of a
2979: tight-laced lady revisiting the scene of her embroidery. A light
2980: bookcase contained duodecimo volumes of polite literature in calf,
2981: completing the furniture.
2982: 
2983: “Yes,” said Mr. Brooke, “this would be a pretty room with some new
2984: hangings, sofas, and that sort of thing. A little bare now.”
2985: 
2986: “No, uncle,” said Dorothea, eagerly. “Pray do not speak of altering
2987: anything. There are so many other things in the world that want
2988: altering—I like to take these things as they are. And you like them as
2989: they are, don’t you?” she added, looking at Mr. Casaubon. “Perhaps this
2990: was your mother’s room when she was young.”
2991: 
2992: “It was,” he said, with his slow bend of the head.
2993: 
2994: “This is your mother,” said Dorothea, who had turned to examine the
2995: group of miniatures. “It is like the tiny one you brought me; only, I
2996: should think, a better portrait. And this one opposite, who is this?”
2997: 
2998: “Her elder sister. They were, like you and your sister, the only two
2999: children of their parents, who hang above them, you see.”
3000: 
3001: “The sister is pretty,” said Celia, implying that she thought less
3002: favorably of Mr. Casaubon’s mother. It was a new opening to Celia’s
3003: imagination, that he came of a family who had all been young in their
3004: time—the ladies wearing necklaces.
3005: 
3006: “It is a peculiar face,” said Dorothea, looking closely. “Those deep
3007: gray eyes rather near together—and the delicate irregular nose with a
3008: sort of ripple in it—and all the powdered curls hanging backward.
3009: Altogether it seems to me peculiar rather than pretty. There is not
3010: even a family likeness between her and your mother.”
3011: 
3012: “No. And they were not alike in their lot.”
3013: 
3014: “You did not mention her to me,” said Dorothea.
3015: 
3016: “My aunt made an unfortunate marriage. I never saw her.”
3017: 
3018: Dorothea wondered a little, but felt that it would be indelicate just
3019: then to ask for any information which Mr. Casaubon did not proffer, and
3020: she turned to the window to admire the view. The sun had lately pierced
3021: the gray, and the avenue of limes cast shadows.
3022: 
3023: “Shall we not walk in the garden now?” said Dorothea.
3024: 
3025: “And you would like to see the church, you know,” said Mr. Brooke. “It
3026: is a droll little church. And the village. It all lies in a nut-shell.
3027: By the way, it will suit you, Dorothea; for the cottages are like a row
3028: of alms-houses—little gardens, gilly-flowers, that sort of thing.”
3029: 
3030: “Yes, please,” said Dorothea, looking at Mr. Casaubon, “I should like
3031: to see all that.” She had got nothing from him more graphic about the
3032: Lowick cottages than that they were “not bad.”
3033: 
3034: They were soon on a gravel walk which led chiefly between grassy
3035: borders and clumps of trees, this being the nearest way to the church,
3036: Mr. Casaubon said. At the little gate leading into the churchyard there
3037: was a pause while Mr. Casaubon went to the parsonage close by to fetch
3038: a key. Celia, who had been hanging a little in the rear, came up
3039: presently, when she saw that Mr. Casaubon was gone away, and said in
3040: her easy staccato, which always seemed to contradict the suspicion of
3041: any malicious intent—
3042: 
3043: “Do you know, Dorothea, I saw some one quite young coming up one of the
3044: walks.”
3045: 
3046: “Is that astonishing, Celia?”
3047: 
3048: “There may be a young gardener, you know—why not?” said Mr. Brooke. “I
3049: told Casaubon he should change his gardener.”
3050: 
3051: “No, not a gardener,” said Celia; “a gentleman with a sketch-book. He
3052: had light-brown curls. I only saw his back. But he was quite young.”
3053: 
3054: “The curate’s son, perhaps,” said Mr. Brooke. “Ah, there is Casaubon
3055: again, and Tucker with him. He is going to introduce Tucker. You don’t
3056: know Tucker yet.”
3057: 
3058: Mr. Tucker was the middle-aged curate, one of the “inferior clergy,”
3059: who are usually not wanting in sons. But after the introduction, the
3060: conversation did not lead to any question about his family, and the
3061: startling apparition of youthfulness was forgotten by every one but
3062: Celia. She inwardly declined to believe that the light-brown curls and
3063: slim figure could have any relationship to Mr. Tucker, who was just as
3064: old and musty-looking as she would have expected Mr. Casaubon’s curate
3065: to be; doubtless an excellent man who would go to heaven (for Celia
3066: wished not to be unprincipled), but the corners of his mouth were so
3067: unpleasant. Celia thought with some dismalness of the time she should
3068: have to spend as bridesmaid at Lowick, while the curate had probably no
3069: pretty little children whom she could like, irrespective of principle.
3070: 
3071: Mr. Tucker was invaluable in their walk; and perhaps Mr. Casaubon had
3072: not been without foresight on this head, the curate being able to
3073: answer all Dorothea’s questions about the villagers and the other
3074: parishioners. Everybody, he assured her, was well off in Lowick: not a
3075: cottager in those double cottages at a low rent but kept a pig, and the
3076: strips of garden at the back were well tended. The small boys wore
3077: excellent corduroy, the girls went out as tidy servants, or did a
3078: little straw-plaiting at home: no looms here, no Dissent; and though
3079: the public disposition was rather towards laying by money than towards
3080: spirituality, there was not much vice. The speckled fowls were so
3081: numerous that Mr. Brooke observed, “Your farmers leave some barley for
3082: the women to glean, I see. The poor folks here might have a fowl in
3083: their pot, as the good French king used to wish for all his people. The
3084: French eat a good many fowls—skinny fowls, you know.”
3085: 
3086: “I think it was a very cheap wish of his,” said Dorothea, indignantly.
3087: “Are kings such monsters that a wish like that must be reckoned a royal
3088: virtue?”
3089: 
3090: “And if he wished them a skinny fowl,” said Celia, “that would not be
3091: nice. But perhaps he wished them to have fat fowls.”
3092: 
3093: “Yes, but the word has dropped out of the text, or perhaps was
3094: subauditum; that is, present in the king’s mind, but not uttered,” said
3095: Mr. Casaubon, smiling and bending his head towards Celia, who
3096: immediately dropped backward a little, because she could not bear Mr.
3097: Casaubon to blink at her.
3098: 
3099: Dorothea sank into silence on the way back to the house. She felt some
3100: disappointment, of which she was yet ashamed, that there was nothing
3101: for her to do in Lowick; and in the next few minutes her mind had
3102: glanced over the possibility, which she would have preferred, of
3103: finding that her home would be in a parish which had a larger share of
3104: the world’s misery, so that she might have had more active duties in
3105: it. Then, recurring to the future actually before her, she made a
3106: picture of more complete devotion to Mr. Casaubon’s aims in which she
3107: would await new duties. Many such might reveal themselves to the higher
3108: knowledge gained by her in that companionship.
3109: 
3110: Mr. Tucker soon left them, having some clerical work which would not
3111: allow him to lunch at the Hall; and as they were re-entering the garden
3112: through the little gate, Mr. Casaubon said—
3113: 
3114: “You seem a little sad, Dorothea. I trust you are pleased with what you
3115: have seen.”
3116: 
3117: “I am feeling something which is perhaps foolish and wrong,” answered
3118: Dorothea, with her usual openness—“almost wishing that the people
3119: wanted more to be done for them here. I have known so few ways of
3120: making my life good for anything. Of course, my notions of usefulness
3121: must be narrow. I must learn new ways of helping people.”
3122: 
3123: “Doubtless,” said Mr. Casaubon. “Each position has its corresponding
3124: duties. Yours, I trust, as the mistress of Lowick, will not leave any
3125: yearning unfulfilled.”
3126: 
3127: “Indeed, I believe that,” said Dorothea, earnestly. “Do not suppose
3128: that I am sad.”
3129: 
3130: “That is well. But, if you are not tired, we will take another way to
3131: the house than that by which we came.”
3132: 
3133: Dorothea was not at all tired, and a little circuit was made towards a
3134: fine yew-tree, the chief hereditary glory of the grounds on this side
3135: of the house. As they approached it, a figure, conspicuous on a dark
3136: background of evergreens, was seated on a bench, sketching the old
3137: tree. Mr. Brooke, who was walking in front with Celia, turned his head,
3138: and said—
3139: 
3140: “Who is that youngster, Casaubon?”
3141: 
3142: They had come very near when Mr. Casaubon answered—
3143: 
3144: “That is a young relative of mine, a second cousin: the grandson, in
3145: fact,” he added, looking at Dorothea, “of the lady whose portrait you
3146: have been noticing, my aunt Julia.”
3147: 
3148: The young man had laid down his sketch-book and risen. His bushy
3149: light-brown curls, as well as his youthfulness, identified him at once
3150: with Celia’s apparition.
3151: 
3152: “Dorothea, let me introduce to you my cousin, Mr. Ladislaw. Will, this
3153: is Miss Brooke.”
3154: 
3155: The cousin was so close now, that, when he lifted his hat, Dorothea
3156: could see a pair of gray eyes rather near together, a delicate
3157: irregular nose with a little ripple in it, and hair falling backward;
3158: but there was a mouth and chin of a more prominent, threatening aspect
3159: than belonged to the type of the grandmother’s miniature. Young
3160: Ladislaw did not feel it necessary to smile, as if he were charmed with
3161: this introduction to his future second cousin and her relatives; but
3162: wore rather a pouting air of discontent.
3163: 
3164: “You are an artist, I see,” said Mr. Brooke, taking up the sketch-book
3165: and turning it over in his unceremonious fashion.
3166: 
3167: “No, I only sketch a little. There is nothing fit to be seen there,”
3168: said young Ladislaw, coloring, perhaps with temper rather than modesty.
3169: 
3170: “Oh, come, this is a nice bit, now. I did a little in this way myself
3171: at one time, you know. Look here, now; this is what I call a nice
3172: thing, done with what we used to call _brio_.” Mr. Brooke held out
3173: towards the two girls a large colored sketch of stony ground and trees,
3174: with a pool.
3175: 
3176: “I am no judge of these things,” said Dorothea, not coldly, but with an
3177: eager deprecation of the appeal to her. “You know, uncle, I never see
3178: the beauty of those pictures which you say are so much praised. They
3179: are a language I do not understand. I suppose there is some relation
3180: between pictures and nature which I am too ignorant to feel—just as you
3181: see what a Greek sentence stands for which means nothing to me.”
3182: Dorothea looked up at Mr. Casaubon, who bowed his head towards her,
3183: while Mr. Brooke said, smiling nonchalantly—
3184: 
3185: “Bless me, now, how different people are! But you had a bad style of
3186: teaching, you know—else this is just the thing for girls—sketching,
3187: fine art and so on. But you took to drawing plans; you don’t understand
3188: _morbidezza_, and that kind of thing. You will come to my house, I
3189: hope, and I will show you what I did in this way,” he continued,
3190: turning to young Ladislaw, who had to be recalled from his
3191: preoccupation in observing Dorothea. Ladislaw had made up his mind that
3192: she must be an unpleasant girl, since she was going to marry Casaubon,
3193: and what she said of her stupidity about pictures would have confirmed
3194: that opinion even if he had believed her. As it was, he took her words
3195: for a covert judgment, and was certain that she thought his sketch
3196: detestable. There was too much cleverness in her apology: she was
3197: laughing both at her uncle and himself. But what a voice! It was like
3198: the voice of a soul that had once lived in an Aeolian harp. This must
3199: be one of Nature’s inconsistencies. There could be no sort of passion
3200: in a girl who would marry Casaubon. But he turned from her, and bowed
3201: his thanks for Mr. Brooke’s invitation.
3202: 
3203: “We will turn over my Italian engravings together,” continued that
3204: good-natured man. “I have no end of those things, that I have laid by
3205: for years. One gets rusty in this part of the country, you know. Not
3206: you, Casaubon; you stick to your studies; but my best ideas get
3207: undermost—out of use, you know. You clever young men must guard against
3208: indolence. I was too indolent, you know: else I might have been
3209: anywhere at one time.”
3210: 
3211: “That is a seasonable admonition,” said Mr. Casaubon; “but now we will
3212: pass on to the house, lest the young ladies should be tired of
3213: standing.”
3214: 
3215: When their backs were turned, young Ladislaw sat down to go on with his
3216: sketching, and as he did so his face broke into an expression of
3217: amusement which increased as he went on drawing, till at last he threw
3218: back his head and laughed aloud. Partly it was the reception of his own
3219: artistic production that tickled him; partly the notion of his grave
3220: cousin as the lover of that girl; and partly Mr. Brooke’s definition of
3221: the place he might have held but for the impediment of indolence. Mr.
3222: Will Ladislaw’s sense of the ludicrous lit up his features very
3223: agreeably: it was the pure enjoyment of comicality, and had no mixture
3224: of sneering and self-exaltation.
3225: 
3226: “What is your nephew going to do with himself, Casaubon?” said Mr.
3227: Brooke, as they went on.
3228: 
3229: “My cousin, you mean—not my nephew.”
3230: 
3231: “Yes, yes, cousin. But in the way of a career, you know.”
3232: 
3233: “The answer to that question is painfully doubtful. On leaving Rugby he
3234: declined to go to an English university, where I would gladly have
3235: placed him, and chose what I must consider the anomalous course of
3236: studying at Heidelberg. And now he wants to go abroad again, without
3237: any special object, save the vague purpose of what he calls culture,
3238: preparation for he knows not what. He declines to choose a profession.”
3239: 
3240: “He has no means but what you furnish, I suppose.”
3241: 
3242: “I have always given him and his friends reason to understand that I
3243: would furnish in moderation what was necessary for providing him with a
3244: scholarly education, and launching him respectably. I am therefore
3245: bound to fulfil the expectation so raised,” said Mr. Casaubon, putting
3246: his conduct in the light of mere rectitude: a trait of delicacy which
3247: Dorothea noticed with admiration.
3248: 
3249: “He has a thirst for travelling; perhaps he may turn out a Bruce or a
3250: Mungo Park,” said Mr. Brooke. “I had a notion of that myself at one
3251: time.”
3252: 
3253: “No, he has no bent towards exploration, or the enlargement of our
3254: geognosis: that would be a special purpose which I could recognize with
3255: some approbation, though without felicitating him on a career which so
3256: often ends in premature and violent death. But so far is he from having
3257: any desire for a more accurate knowledge of the earth’s surface, that
3258: he said he should prefer not to know the sources of the Nile, and that
3259: there should be some unknown regions preserved as hunting grounds for
3260: the poetic imagination.”
3261: 
3262: “Well, there is something in that, you know,” said Mr. Brooke, who had
3263: certainly an impartial mind.
3264: 
3265: “It is, I fear, nothing more than a part of his general inaccuracy and
3266: indisposition to thoroughness of all kinds, which would be a bad augury
3267: for him in any profession, civil or sacred, even were he so far
3268: submissive to ordinary rule as to choose one.”
3269: 
3270: “Perhaps he has conscientious scruples founded on his own unfitness,”
3271: said Dorothea, who was interesting herself in finding a favorable
3272: explanation. “Because the law and medicine should be very serious
3273: professions to undertake, should they not? People’s lives and fortunes
3274: depend on them.”
3275: 
3276: “Doubtless; but I fear that my young relative Will Ladislaw is chiefly
3277: determined in his aversion to these callings by a dislike to steady
3278: application, and to that kind of acquirement which is needful
3279: instrumentally, but is not charming or immediately inviting to
3280: self-indulgent taste. I have insisted to him on what Aristotle has
3281: stated with admirable brevity, that for the achievement of any work
3282: regarded as an end there must be a prior exercise of many energies or
3283: acquired facilities of a secondary order, demanding patience. I have
3284: pointed to my own manuscript volumes, which represent the toil of years
3285: preparatory to a work not yet accomplished. But in vain. To careful
3286: reasoning of this kind he replies by calling himself Pegasus, and every
3287: form of prescribed work ‘harness.’”
3288: 
3289: Celia laughed. She was surprised to find that Mr. Casaubon could say
3290: something quite amusing.
3291: 
3292: “Well, you know, he may turn out a Byron, a Chatterton, a
3293: Churchill—that sort of thing—there’s no telling,” said Mr. Brooke.
3294: “Shall you let him go to Italy, or wherever else he wants to go?”
3295: 
3296: “Yes; I have agreed to furnish him with moderate supplies for a year or
3297: so; he asks no more. I shall let him be tried by the test of freedom.”
3298: 
3299: “That is very kind of you,” said Dorothea, looking up at Mr. Casaubon
3300: with delight. “It is noble. After all, people may really have in them
3301: some vocation which is not quite plain to themselves, may they not?
3302: They may seem idle and weak because they are growing. We should be very
3303: patient with each other, I think.”
3304: 
3305: “I suppose it is being engaged to be married that has made you think
3306: patience good,” said Celia, as soon as she and Dorothea were alone
3307: together, taking off their wrappings.
3308: 
3309: “You mean that I am very impatient, Celia.”
3310: 
3311: “Yes; when people don’t do and say just what you like.” Celia had
3312: become less afraid of “saying things” to Dorothea since this
3313: engagement: cleverness seemed to her more pitiable than ever.
3314: 
3315: 
3316: 
3317: 
3318: CHAPTER X.
3319: 
3320: “He had catched a great cold, had he had no other clothes to wear than
3321: the skin of a bear not yet killed.”—FULLER.
3322: 
3323: 
3324: Young Ladislaw did not pay that visit to which Mr. Brooke had invited
3325: him, and only six days afterwards Mr. Casaubon mentioned that his young
3326: relative had started for the Continent, seeming by this cold vagueness
3327: to waive inquiry. Indeed, Will had declined to fix on any more precise
3328: destination than the entire area of Europe. Genius, he held, is
3329: necessarily intolerant of fetters: on the one hand it must have the
3330: utmost play for its spontaneity; on the other, it may confidently await
3331: those messages from the universe which summon it to its peculiar work,
3332: only placing itself in an attitude of receptivity towards all sublime
3333: chances. The attitudes of receptivity are various, and Will had
3334: sincerely tried many of them. He was not excessively fond of wine, but
3335: he had several times taken too much, simply as an experiment in that
3336: form of ecstasy; he had fasted till he was faint, and then supped on
3337: lobster; he had made himself ill with doses of opium. Nothing greatly
3338: original had resulted from these measures; and the effects of the opium
3339: had convinced him that there was an entire dissimilarity between his
3340: constitution and De Quincey’s. The superadded circumstance which would
3341: evolve the genius had not yet come; the universe had not yet beckoned.
3342: Even Caesar’s fortune at one time was but a grand presentiment. We know
3343: what a masquerade all development is, and what effective shapes may be
3344: disguised in helpless embryos. In fact, the world is full of hopeful
3345: analogies and handsome dubious eggs called possibilities. Will saw
3346: clearly enough the pitiable instances of long incubation producing no
3347: chick, and but for gratitude would have laughed at Casaubon, whose
3348: plodding application, rows of note-books, and small taper of learned
3349: theory exploring the tossed ruins of the world, seemed to enforce a
3350: moral entirely encouraging to Will’s generous reliance on the
3351: intentions of the universe with regard to himself. He held that
3352: reliance to be a mark of genius; and certainly it is no mark to the
3353: contrary; genius consisting neither in self-conceit nor in humility,
3354: but in a power to make or do, not anything in general, but something in
3355: particular. Let him start for the Continent, then, without our
3356: pronouncing on his future. Among all forms of mistake, prophecy is the
3357: most gratuitous.
3358: 
3359: But at present this caution against a too hasty judgment interests me
3360: more in relation to Mr. Casaubon than to his young cousin. If to
3361: Dorothea Mr. Casaubon had been the mere occasion which had set alight
3362: the fine inflammable material of her youthful illusions, does it follow
3363: that he was fairly represented in the minds of those less impassioned
3364: personages who have hitherto delivered their judgments concerning him?
3365: I protest against any absolute conclusion, any prejudice derived from
3366: Mrs. Cadwallader’s contempt for a neighboring clergyman’s alleged
3367: greatness of soul, or Sir James Chettam’s poor opinion of his rival’s
3368: legs,—from Mr. Brooke’s failure to elicit a companion’s ideas, or from
3369: Celia’s criticism of a middle-aged scholar’s personal appearance. I am
3370: not sure that the greatest man of his age, if ever that solitary
3371: superlative existed, could escape these unfavorable reflections of
3372: himself in various small mirrors; and even Milton, looking for his
3373: portrait in a spoon, must submit to have the facial angle of a bumpkin.
3374: Moreover, if Mr. Casaubon, speaking for himself, has rather a chilling
3375: rhetoric, it is not therefore certain that there is no good work or
3376: fine feeling in him. Did not an immortal physicist and interpreter of
3377: hieroglyphs write detestable verses? Has the theory of the solar system
3378: been advanced by graceful manners and conversational tact? Suppose we
3379: turn from outside estimates of a man, to wonder, with keener interest,
3380: what is the report of his own consciousness about his doings or
3381: capacity: with what hindrances he is carrying on his daily labors; what
3382: fading of hopes, or what deeper fixity of self-delusion the years are
3383: marking off within him; and with what spirit he wrestles against
3384: universal pressure, which will one day be too heavy for him, and bring
3385: his heart to its final pause. Doubtless his lot is important in his own
3386: eyes; and the chief reason that we think he asks too large a place in
3387: our consideration must be our want of room for him, since we refer him
3388: to the Divine regard with perfect confidence; nay, it is even held
3389: sublime for our neighbor to expect the utmost there, however little he
3390: may have got from us. Mr. Casaubon, too, was the centre of his own
3391: world; if he was liable to think that others were providentially made
3392: for him, and especially to consider them in the light of their fitness
3393: for the author of a “Key to all Mythologies,” this trait is not quite
3394: alien to us, and, like the other mendicant hopes of mortals, claims
3395: some of our pity.
3396: 
3397: Certainly this affair of his marriage with Miss Brooke touched him more
3398: nearly than it did any one of the persons who have hitherto shown their
3399: disapproval of it, and in the present stage of things I feel more
3400: tenderly towards his experience of success than towards the
3401: disappointment of the amiable Sir James. For in truth, as the day fixed
3402: for his marriage came nearer, Mr. Casaubon did not find his spirits
3403: rising; nor did the contemplation of that matrimonial garden scene,
3404: where, as all experience showed, the path was to be bordered with
3405: flowers, prove persistently more enchanting to him than the accustomed
3406: vaults where he walked taper in hand. He did not confess to himself,
3407: still less could he have breathed to another, his surprise that though
3408: he had won a lovely and noble-hearted girl he had not won
3409: delight,—which he had also regarded as an object to be found by search.
3410: It is true that he knew all the classical passages implying the
3411: contrary; but knowing classical passages, we find, is a mode of motion,
3412: which explains why they leave so little extra force for their personal
3413: application.
3414: 
3415: Poor Mr. Casaubon had imagined that his long studious bachelorhood had
3416: stored up for him a compound interest of enjoyment, and that large
3417: drafts on his affections would not fail to be honored; for we all of
3418: us, grave or light, get our thoughts entangled in metaphors, and act
3419: fatally on the strength of them. And now he was in danger of being
3420: saddened by the very conviction that his circumstances were unusually
3421: happy: there was nothing external by which he could account for a
3422: certain blankness of sensibility which came over him just when his
3423: expectant gladness should have been most lively, just when he exchanged
3424: the accustomed dulness of his Lowick library for his visits to the
3425: Grange. Here was a weary experience in which he was as utterly
3426: condemned to loneliness as in the despair which sometimes threatened
3427: him while toiling in the morass of authorship without seeming nearer to
3428: the goal. And his was that worst loneliness which would shrink from
3429: sympathy. He could not but wish that Dorothea should think him not less
3430: happy than the world would expect her successful suitor to be; and in
3431: relation to his authorship he leaned on her young trust and veneration,
3432: he liked to draw forth her fresh interest in listening, as a means of
3433: encouragement to himself: in talking to her he presented all his
3434: performance and intention with the reflected confidence of the
3435: pedagogue, and rid himself for the time of that chilling ideal audience
3436: which crowded his laborious uncreative hours with the vaporous pressure
3437: of Tartarean shades.
3438: 
3439: For to Dorothea, after that toy-box history of the world adapted to
3440: young ladies which had made the chief part of her education, Mr.
3441: Casaubon’s talk about his great book was full of new vistas; and this
3442: sense of revelation, this surprise of a nearer introduction to Stoics
3443: and Alexandrians, as people who had ideas not totally unlike her own,
3444: kept in abeyance for the time her usual eagerness for a binding theory
3445: which could bring her own life and doctrine into strict connection with
3446: that amazing past, and give the remotest sources of knowledge some
3447: bearing on her actions. That more complete teaching would come—Mr.
3448: Casaubon would tell her all that: she was looking forward to higher
3449: initiation in ideas, as she was looking forward to marriage, and
3450: blending her dim conceptions of both. It would be a great mistake to
3451: suppose that Dorothea would have cared about any share in Mr.
3452: Casaubon’s learning as mere accomplishment; for though opinion in the
3453: neighborhood of Freshitt and Tipton had pronounced her clever, that
3454: epithet would not have described her to circles in whose more precise
3455: vocabulary cleverness implies mere aptitude for knowing and doing,
3456: apart from character. All her eagerness for acquirement lay within that
3457: full current of sympathetic motive in which her ideas and impulses were
3458: habitually swept along. She did not want to deck herself with
3459: knowledge—to wear it loose from the nerves and blood that fed her
3460: action; and if she had written a book she must have done it as Saint
3461: Theresa did, under the command of an authority that constrained her
3462: conscience. But something she yearned for by which her life might be
3463: filled with action at once rational and ardent; and since the time was
3464: gone by for guiding visions and spiritual directors, since prayer
3465: heightened yearning but not instruction, what lamp was there but
3466: knowledge? Surely learned men kept the only oil; and who more learned
3467: than Mr. Casaubon?
3468: 
3469: Thus in these brief weeks Dorothea’s joyous grateful expectation was
3470: unbroken, and however her lover might occasionally be conscious of
3471: flatness, he could never refer it to any slackening of her affectionate
3472: interest.
3473: 
3474: The season was mild enough to encourage the project of extending the
3475: wedding journey as far as Rome, and Mr. Casaubon was anxious for this
3476: because he wished to inspect some manuscripts in the Vatican.
3477: 
3478: “I still regret that your sister is not to accompany us,” he said one
3479: morning, some time after it had been ascertained that Celia objected to
3480: go, and that Dorothea did not wish for her companionship. “You will
3481: have many lonely hours, Dorothea, for I shall be constrained to make
3482: the utmost use of my time during our stay in Rome, and I should feel
3483: more at liberty if you had a companion.”
3484: 
3485: The words “I should feel more at liberty” grated on Dorothea. For the
3486: first time in speaking to Mr. Casaubon she colored from annoyance.
3487: 
3488: “You must have misunderstood me very much,” she said, “if you think I
3489: should not enter into the value of your time—if you think that I should
3490: not willingly give up whatever interfered with your using it to the
3491: best purpose.”
3492: 
3493: “That is very amiable in you, my dear Dorothea,” said Mr. Casaubon, not
3494: in the least noticing that she was hurt; “but if you had a lady as your
3495: companion, I could put you both under the care of a cicerone, and we
3496: could thus achieve two purposes in the same space of time.”
3497: 
3498: “I beg you will not refer to this again,” said Dorothea, rather
3499: haughtily. But immediately she feared that she was wrong, and turning
3500: towards him she laid her hand on his, adding in a different tone, “Pray
3501: do not be anxious about me. I shall have so much to think of when I am
3502: alone. And Tantripp will be a sufficient companion, just to take care
3503: of me. I could not bear to have Celia: she would be miserable.”
3504: 
3505: It was time to dress. There was to be a dinner-party that day, the last
3506: of the parties which were held at the Grange as proper preliminaries to
3507: the wedding, and Dorothea was glad of a reason for moving away at once
3508: on the sound of the bell, as if she needed more than her usual amount
3509: of preparation. She was ashamed of being irritated from some cause she
3510: could not define even to herself; for though she had no intention to be
3511: untruthful, her reply had not touched the real hurt within her. Mr.
3512: Casaubon’s words had been quite reasonable, yet they had brought a
3513: vague instantaneous sense of aloofness on his part.
3514: 
3515: “Surely I am in a strangely selfish weak state of mind,” she said to
3516: herself. “How can I have a husband who is so much above me without
3517: knowing that he needs me less than I need him?”
3518: 
3519: Having convinced herself that Mr. Casaubon was altogether right, she
3520: recovered her equanimity, and was an agreeable image of serene dignity
3521: when she came into the drawing-room in her silver-gray dress—the simple
3522: lines of her dark-brown hair parted over her brow and coiled massively
3523: behind, in keeping with the entire absence from her manner and
3524: expression of all search after mere effect. Sometimes when Dorothea was
3525: in company, there seemed to be as complete an air of repose about her
3526: as if she had been a picture of Santa Barbara looking out from her
3527: tower into the clear air; but these intervals of quietude made the
3528: energy of her speech and emotion the more remarked when some outward
3529: appeal had touched her.
3530: 
3531: She was naturally the subject of many observations this evening, for
3532: the dinner-party was large and rather more miscellaneous as to the male
3533: portion than any which had been held at the Grange since Mr. Brooke’s
3534: nieces had resided with him, so that the talking was done in duos and
3535: trios more or less inharmonious. There was the newly elected mayor of
3536: Middlemarch, who happened to be a manufacturer; the philanthropic
3537: banker his brother-in-law, who predominated so much in the town that
3538: some called him a Methodist, others a hypocrite, according to the
3539: resources of their vocabulary; and there were various professional men.
3540: In fact, Mrs. Cadwallader said that Brooke was beginning to treat the
3541: Middlemarchers, and that she preferred the farmers at the tithe-dinner,
3542: who drank her health unpretentiously, and were not ashamed of their
3543: grandfathers’ furniture. For in that part of the country, before reform
3544: had done its notable part in developing the political consciousness,
3545: there was a clearer distinction of ranks and a dimmer distinction of
3546: parties; so that Mr. Brooke’s miscellaneous invitations seemed to
3547: belong to that general laxity which came from his inordinate travel and
3548: habit of taking too much in the form of ideas.
3549: 
3550: Already, as Miss Brooke passed out of the dining-room, opportunity was
3551: found for some interjectional “asides.”
3552: 
3553: “A fine woman, Miss Brooke! an uncommonly fine woman, by God!” said Mr.
3554: Standish, the old lawyer, who had been so long concerned with the
3555: landed gentry that he had become landed himself, and used that oath in
3556: a deep-mouthed manner as a sort of armorial bearings, stamping the
3557: speech of a man who held a good position.
3558: 
3559: Mr. Bulstrode, the banker, seemed to be addressed, but that gentleman
3560: disliked coarseness and profanity, and merely bowed. The remark was
3561: taken up by Mr. Chichely, a middle-aged bachelor and coursing
3562: celebrity, who had a complexion something like an Easter egg, a few
3563: hairs carefully arranged, and a carriage implying the consciousness of
3564: a distinguished appearance.
3565: 
3566: “Yes, but not my style of woman: I like a woman who lays herself out a
3567: little more to please us. There should be a little filigree about a
3568: woman—something of the coquette. A man likes a sort of challenge. The
3569: more of a dead set she makes at you the better.”
3570: 
3571: “There’s some truth in that,” said Mr. Standish, disposed to be genial.
3572: “And, by God, it’s usually the way with them. I suppose it answers some
3573: wise ends: Providence made them so, eh, Bulstrode?”
3574: 
3575: “I should be disposed to refer coquetry to another source,” said Mr.
3576: Bulstrode. “I should rather refer it to the devil.”
3577: 
3578: “Ay, to be sure, there should be a little devil in a woman,” said Mr.
3579: Chichely, whose study of the fair sex seemed to have been detrimental
3580: to his theology. “And I like them blond, with a certain gait, and a
3581: swan neck. Between ourselves, the mayor’s daughter is more to my taste
3582: than Miss Brooke or Miss Celia either. If I were a marrying man I
3583: should choose Miss Vincy before either of them.”
3584: 
3585: “Well, make up, make up,” said Mr. Standish, jocosely; “you see the
3586: middle-aged fellows carry the day.”
3587: 
3588: Mr. Chichely shook his head with much meaning: he was not going to
3589: incur the certainty of being accepted by the woman he would choose.
3590: 
3591: The Miss Vincy who had the honor of being Mr. Chichely’s ideal was of
3592: course not present; for Mr. Brooke, always objecting to go too far,
3593: would not have chosen that his nieces should meet the daughter of a
3594: Middlemarch manufacturer, unless it were on a public occasion. The
3595: feminine part of the company included none whom Lady Chettam or Mrs.
3596: Cadwallader could object to; for Mrs. Renfrew, the colonel’s widow, was
3597: not only unexceptionable in point of breeding, but also interesting on
3598: the ground of her complaint, which puzzled the doctors, and seemed
3599: clearly a case wherein the fulness of professional knowledge might need
3600: the supplement of quackery. Lady Chettam, who attributed her own
3601: remarkable health to home-made bitters united with constant medical
3602: attendance, entered with much exercise of the imagination into Mrs.
3603: Renfrew’s account of symptoms, and into the amazing futility in her
3604: case of all strengthening medicines.
3605: 
3606: “Where can all the strength of those medicines go, my dear?” said the
3607: mild but stately dowager, turning to Mrs. Cadwallader reflectively,
3608: when Mrs. Renfrew’s attention was called away.
3609: 
3610: “It strengthens the disease,” said the Rector’s wife, much too
3611: well-born not to be an amateur in medicine. “Everything depends on the
3612: constitution: some people make fat, some blood, and some bile—that’s my
3613: view of the matter; and whatever they take is a sort of grist to the
3614: mill.”
3615: 
3616: “Then she ought to take medicines that would reduce—reduce the disease,
3617: you know, if you are right, my dear. And I think what you say is
3618: reasonable.”
3619: 
3620: “Certainly it is reasonable. You have two sorts of potatoes, fed on the
3621: same soil. One of them grows more and more watery—”
3622: 
3623: “Ah! like this poor Mrs. Renfrew—that is what I think. Dropsy! There is
3624: no swelling yet—it is inward. I should say she ought to take drying
3625: medicines, shouldn’t you?—or a dry hot-air bath. Many things might be
3626: tried, of a drying nature.”
3627: 
3628: “Let her try a certain person’s pamphlets,” said Mrs. Cadwallader in an
3629: undertone, seeing the gentlemen enter. “He does not want drying.”
3630: 
3631: “Who, my dear?” said Lady Chettam, a charming woman, not so quick as to
3632: nullify the pleasure of explanation.
3633: 
3634: “The bridegroom—Casaubon. He has certainly been drying up faster since
3635: the engagement: the flame of passion, I suppose.”
3636: 
3637: “I should think he is far from having a good constitution,” said Lady
3638: Chettam, with a still deeper undertone. “And then his studies—so very
3639: dry, as you say.”
3640: 
3641: “Really, by the side of Sir James, he looks like a death’s head skinned
3642: over for the occasion. Mark my words: in a year from this time that
3643: girl will hate him. She looks up to him as an oracle now, and by-and-by
3644: she will be at the other extreme. All flightiness!”
3645: 
3646: “How very shocking! I fear she is headstrong. But tell me—you know all
3647: about him—is there anything very bad? What is the truth?”
3648: 
3649: “The truth? he is as bad as the wrong physic—nasty to take, and sure to
3650: disagree.”
3651: 
3652: “There could not be anything worse than that,” said Lady Chettam, with
3653: so vivid a conception of the physic that she seemed to have learned
3654: something exact about Mr. Casaubon’s disadvantages. “However, James
3655: will hear nothing against Miss Brooke. He says she is the mirror of
3656: women still.”
3657: 
3658: “That is a generous make-believe of his. Depend upon it, he likes
3659: little Celia better, and she appreciates him. I hope you like my little
3660: Celia?”
3661: 
3662: “Certainly; she is fonder of geraniums, and seems more docile, though
3663: not so fine a figure. But we were talking of physic. Tell me about this
3664: new young surgeon, Mr. Lydgate. I am told he is wonderfully clever: he
3665: certainly looks it—a fine brow indeed.”
3666: 
3667: “He is a gentleman. I heard him talking to Humphrey. He talks well.”
3668: 
3669: “Yes. Mr. Brooke says he is one of the Lydgates of Northumberland,
3670: really well connected. One does not expect it in a practitioner of that
3671: kind. For my own part, I like a medical man more on a footing with the
3672: servants; they are often all the cleverer. I assure you I found poor
3673: Hicks’s judgment unfailing; I never knew him wrong. He was coarse and
3674: butcher-like, but he knew my constitution. It was a loss to me his
3675: going off so suddenly. Dear me, what a very animated conversation Miss
3676: Brooke seems to be having with this Mr. Lydgate!”
3677: 
3678: “She is talking cottages and hospitals with him,” said Mrs.
3679: Cadwallader, whose ears and power of interpretation were quick. “I
3680: believe he is a sort of philanthropist, so Brooke is sure to take him
3681: up.”
3682: 
3683: “James,” said Lady Chettam when her son came near, “bring Mr. Lydgate
3684: and introduce him to me. I want to test him.”
3685: 
3686: The affable dowager declared herself delighted with this opportunity of
3687: making Mr. Lydgate’s acquaintance, having heard of his success in
3688: treating fever on a new plan.
3689: 
3690: Mr. Lydgate had the medical accomplishment of looking perfectly grave
3691: whatever nonsense was talked to him, and his dark steady eyes gave him
3692: impressiveness as a listener. He was as little as possible like the
3693: lamented Hicks, especially in a certain careless refinement about his
3694: toilet and utterance. Yet Lady Chettam gathered much confidence in him.
3695: He confirmed her view of her own constitution as being peculiar, by
3696: admitting that all constitutions might be called peculiar, and he did
3697: not deny that hers might be more peculiar than others. He did not
3698: approve of a too lowering system, including reckless cupping, nor, on
3699: the other hand, of incessant port wine and bark. He said “I think so”
3700: with an air of so much deference accompanying the insight of agreement,
3701: that she formed the most cordial opinion of his talents.
3702: 
3703: “I am quite pleased with your protege,” she said to Mr. Brooke before
3704: going away.
3705: 
3706: “My protege?—dear me!—who is that?” said Mr. Brooke.
3707: 
3708: “This young Lydgate, the new doctor. He seems to me to understand his
3709: profession admirably.”
3710: 
3711: “Oh, Lydgate! he is not my protege, you know; only I knew an uncle of
3712: his who sent me a letter about him. However, I think he is likely to be
3713: first-rate—has studied in Paris, knew Broussais; has ideas, you
3714: know—wants to raise the profession.”
3715: 
3716: “Lydgate has lots of ideas, quite new, about ventilation and diet, that
3717: sort of thing,” resumed Mr. Brooke, after he had handed out Lady
3718: Chettam, and had returned to be civil to a group of Middlemarchers.
3719: 
3720: “Hang it, do you think that is quite sound?—upsetting the old
3721: treatment, which has made Englishmen what they are?” said Mr. Standish.
3722: 
3723: “Medical knowledge is at a low ebb among us,” said Mr. Bulstrode, who
3724: spoke in a subdued tone, and had rather a sickly air. “I, for my part,
3725: hail the advent of Mr. Lydgate. I hope to find good reason for
3726: confiding the new hospital to his management.”
3727: 
3728: “That is all very fine,” replied Mr. Standish, who was not fond of Mr.
3729: Bulstrode; “if you like him to try experiments on your hospital
3730: patients, and kill a few people for charity I have no objection. But I
3731: am not going to hand money out of my purse to have experiments tried on
3732: me. I like treatment that has been tested a little.”
3733: 
3734: “Well, you know, Standish, every dose you take is an experiment-an
3735: experiment, you know,” said Mr. Brooke, nodding towards the lawyer.
3736: 
3737: “Oh, if you talk in that sense!” said Mr. Standish, with as much
3738: disgust at such non-legal quibbling as a man can well betray towards a
3739: valuable client.
3740: 
3741: “I should be glad of any treatment that would cure me without reducing
3742: me to a skeleton, like poor Grainger,” said Mr. Vincy, the mayor, a
3743: florid man, who would have served for a study of flesh in striking
3744: contrast with the Franciscan tints of Mr. Bulstrode. “It’s an
3745: uncommonly dangerous thing to be left without any padding against the
3746: shafts of disease, as somebody said,—and I think it a very good
3747: expression myself.”
3748: 
3749: Mr. Lydgate, of course, was out of hearing. He had quitted the party
3750: early, and would have thought it altogether tedious but for the novelty
3751: of certain introductions, especially the introduction to Miss Brooke,
3752: whose youthful bloom, with her approaching marriage to that faded
3753: scholar, and her interest in matters socially useful, gave her the
3754: piquancy of an unusual combination.
3755: 
3756: “She is a good creature—that fine girl—but a little too earnest,” he
3757: thought. “It is troublesome to talk to such women. They are always
3758: wanting reasons, yet they are too ignorant to understand the merits of
3759: any question, and usually fall back on their moral sense to settle
3760: things after their own taste.”
3761: 
3762: Evidently Miss Brooke was not Mr. Lydgate’s style of woman any more
3763: than Mr. Chichely’s. Considered, indeed, in relation to the latter,
3764: whose mind was matured, she was altogether a mistake, and calculated to
3765: shock his trust in final causes, including the adaptation of fine young
3766: women to purplefaced bachelors. But Lydgate was less ripe, and might
3767: possibly have experience before him which would modify his opinion as
3768: to the most excellent things in woman.
3769: 
3770: Miss Brooke, however, was not again seen by either of these gentlemen
3771: under her maiden name. Not long after that dinner-party she had become
3772: Mrs. Casaubon, and was on her way to Rome.
3773: 
3774: 
3775: 
3776: 
3777: CHAPTER XI.
3778: 
3779: But deeds and language such as men do use,
3780: And persons such as comedy would choose,
3781: When she would show an image of the times,
3782: And sport with human follies, not with crimes.
3783: —BEN JONSON.
3784: 
3785: 
3786: Lydgate, in fact, was already conscious of being fascinated by a woman
3787: strikingly different from Miss Brooke: he did not in the least suppose
3788: that he had lost his balance and fallen in love, but he had said of
3789: that particular woman, “She is grace itself; she is perfectly lovely
3790: and accomplished. That is what a woman ought to be: she ought to
3791: produce the effect of exquisite music.” Plain women he regarded as he
3792: did the other severe facts of life, to be faced with philosophy and
3793: investigated by science. But Rosamond Vincy seemed to have the true
3794: melodic charm; and when a man has seen the woman whom he would have
3795: chosen if he had intended to marry speedily, his remaining a bachelor
3796: will usually depend on her resolution rather than on his. Lydgate
3797: believed that he should not marry for several years: not marry until he
3798: had trodden out a good clear path for himself away from the broad road
3799: which was quite ready made. He had seen Miss Vincy above his horizon
3800: almost as long as it had taken Mr. Casaubon to become engaged and
3801: married: but this learned gentleman was possessed of a fortune; he had
3802: assembled his voluminous notes, and had made that sort of reputation
3803: which precedes performance,—often the larger part of a man’s fame. He
3804: took a wife, as we have seen, to adorn the remaining quadrant of his
3805: course, and be a little moon that would cause hardly a calculable
3806: perturbation. But Lydgate was young, poor, ambitious. He had his
3807: half-century before him instead of behind him, and he had come to
3808: Middlemarch bent on doing many things that were not directly fitted to
3809: make his fortune or even secure him a good income. To a man under such
3810: circumstances, taking a wife is something more than a question of
3811: adornment, however highly he may rate this; and Lydgate was disposed to
3812: give it the first place among wifely functions. To his taste, guided by
3813: a single conversation, here was the point on which Miss Brooke would be
3814: found wanting, notwithstanding her undeniable beauty. She did not look
3815: at things from the proper feminine angle. The society of such women was
3816: about as relaxing as going from your work to teach the second form,
3817: instead of reclining in a paradise with sweet laughs for bird-notes,
3818: and blue eyes for a heaven.
3819: 
3820: Certainly nothing at present could seem much less important to Lydgate
3821: than the turn of Miss Brooke’s mind, or to Miss Brooke than the
3822: qualities of the woman who had attracted this young surgeon. But any
3823: one watching keenly the stealthy convergence of human lots, sees a slow
3824: preparation of effects from one life on another, which tells like a
3825: calculated irony on the indifference or the frozen stare with which we
3826: look at our unintroduced neighbor. Destiny stands by sarcastic with our
3827: dramatis personae folded in her hand.
3828: 
3829: Old provincial society had its share of this subtle movement: had not
3830: only its striking downfalls, its brilliant young professional dandies
3831: who ended by living up an entry with a drab and six children for their
3832: establishment, but also those less marked vicissitudes which are
3833: constantly shifting the boundaries of social intercourse, and begetting
3834: new consciousness of interdependence. Some slipped a little downward,
3835: some got higher footing: people denied aspirates, gained wealth, and
3836: fastidious gentlemen stood for boroughs; some were caught in political
3837: currents, some in ecclesiastical, and perhaps found themselves
3838: surprisingly grouped in consequence; while a few personages or families
3839: that stood with rocky firmness amid all this fluctuation, were slowly
3840: presenting new aspects in spite of solidity, and altering with the
3841: double change of self and beholder. Municipal town and rural parish
3842: gradually made fresh threads of connection—gradually, as the old
3843: stocking gave way to the savings-bank, and the worship of the solar
3844: guinea became extinct; while squires and baronets, and even lords who
3845: had once lived blamelessly afar from the civic mind, gathered the
3846: faultiness of closer acquaintanceship. Settlers, too, came from distant
3847: counties, some with an alarming novelty of skill, others with an
3848: offensive advantage in cunning. In fact, much the same sort of movement
3849: and mixture went on in old England as we find in older Herodotus, who
3850: also, in telling what had been, thought it well to take a woman’s lot
3851: for his starting-point; though Io, as a maiden apparently beguiled by
3852: attractive merchandise, was the reverse of Miss Brooke, and in this
3853: respect perhaps bore more resemblance to Rosamond Vincy, who had
3854: excellent taste in costume, with that nymph-like figure and pure
3855: blindness which give the largest range to choice in the flow and color
3856: of drapery. But these things made only part of her charm. She was
3857: admitted to be the flower of Mrs. Lemon’s school, the chief school in
3858: the county, where the teaching included all that was demanded in the
3859: accomplished female—even to extras, such as the getting in and out of a
3860: carriage. Mrs. Lemon herself had always held up Miss Vincy as an
3861: example: no pupil, she said, exceeded that young lady for mental
3862: acquisition and propriety of speech, while her musical execution was
3863: quite exceptional. We cannot help the way in which people speak of us,
3864: and probably if Mrs. Lemon had undertaken to describe Juliet or Imogen,
3865: these heroines would not have seemed poetical. The first vision of
3866: Rosamond would have been enough with most judges to dispel any
3867: prejudice excited by Mrs. Lemon’s praise.
3868: 
3869: Lydgate could not be long in Middlemarch without having that agreeable
3870: vision, or even without making the acquaintance of the Vincy family;
3871: for though Mr. Peacock, whose practice he had paid something to enter
3872: on, had not been their doctor (Mrs. Vincy not liking the lowering
3873: system adopted by him), he had many patients among their connections
3874: and acquaintances. For who of any consequence in Middlemarch was not
3875: connected or at least acquainted with the Vincys? They were old
3876: manufacturers, and had kept a good house for three generations, in
3877: which there had naturally been much intermarrying with neighbors more
3878: or less decidedly genteel. Mr. Vincy’s sister had made a wealthy match
3879: in accepting Mr. Bulstrode, who, however, as a man not born in the
3880: town, and altogether of dimly known origin, was considered to have done
3881: well in uniting himself with a real Middlemarch family; on the other
3882: hand, Mr. Vincy had descended a little, having taken an innkeeper’s
3883: daughter. But on this side too there was a cheering sense of money; for
3884: Mrs. Vincy’s sister had been second wife to rich old Mr. Featherstone,
3885: and had died childless years ago, so that her nephews and nieces might
3886: be supposed to touch the affections of the widower. And it happened
3887: that Mr. Bulstrode and Mr. Featherstone, two of Peacock’s most
3888: important patients, had, from different causes, given an especially
3889: good reception to his successor, who had raised some partisanship as
3890: well as discussion. Mr. Wrench, medical attendant to the Vincy family,
3891: very early had grounds for thinking lightly of Lydgate’s professional
3892: discretion, and there was no report about him which was not retailed at
3893: the Vincys’, where visitors were frequent. Mr. Vincy was more inclined
3894: to general good-fellowship than to taking sides, but there was no need
3895: for him to be hasty in making any new man acquaintance. Rosamond
3896: silently wished that her father would invite Mr. Lydgate. She was tired
3897: of the faces and figures she had always been used to—the various
3898: irregular profiles and gaits and turns of phrase distinguishing those
3899: Middlemarch young men whom she had known as boys. She had been at
3900: school with girls of higher position, whose brothers, she felt sure, it
3901: would have been possible for her to be more interested in, than in
3902: these inevitable Middlemarch companions. But she would not have chosen
3903: to mention her wish to her father; and he, for his part, was in no
3904: hurry on the subject. An alderman about to be mayor must by-and-by
3905: enlarge his dinner-parties, but at present there were plenty of guests
3906: at his well-spread table.
3907: 
3908: That table often remained covered with the relics of the family
3909: breakfast long after Mr. Vincy had gone with his second son to the
3910: warehouse, and when Miss Morgan was already far on in morning lessons
3911: with the younger girls in the schoolroom. It awaited the family
3912: laggard, who found any sort of inconvenience (to others) less
3913: disagreeable than getting up when he was called. This was the case one
3914: morning of the October in which we have lately seen Mr. Casaubon
3915: visiting the Grange; and though the room was a little overheated with
3916: the fire, which had sent the spaniel panting to a remote corner,
3917: Rosamond, for some reason, continued to sit at her embroidery longer
3918: than usual, now and then giving herself a little shake, and laying her
3919: work on her knee to contemplate it with an air of hesitating weariness.
3920: Her mamma, who had returned from an excursion to the kitchen, sat on
3921: the other side of the small work-table with an air of more entire
3922: placidity, until, the clock again giving notice that it was going to
3923: strike, she looked up from the lace-mending which was occupying her
3924: plump fingers and rang the bell.
3925: 
3926: “Knock at Mr. Fred’s door again, Pritchard, and tell him it has struck
3927: half-past ten.”
3928: 
3929: This was said without any change in the radiant good-humor of Mrs.
3930: Vincy’s face, in which forty-five years had delved neither angles nor
3931: parallels; and pushing back her pink capstrings, she let her work rest
3932: on her lap, while she looked admiringly at her daughter.
3933: 
3934: “Mamma,” said Rosamond, “when Fred comes down I wish you would not let
3935: him have red herrings. I cannot bear the smell of them all over the
3936: house at this hour of the morning.”
3937: 
3938: “Oh, my dear, you are so hard on your brothers! It is the only fault I
3939: have to find with you. You are the sweetest temper in the world, but
3940: you are so tetchy with your brothers.”
3941: 
3942: “Not tetchy, mamma: you never hear me speak in an unladylike way.”
3943: 
3944: “Well, but you want to deny them things.”
3945: 
3946: “Brothers are so unpleasant.”
3947: 
3948: “Oh, my dear, you must allow for young men. Be thankful if they have
3949: good hearts. A woman must learn to put up with little things. You will
3950: be married some day.”
3951: 
3952: “Not to any one who is like Fred.”
3953: 
3954: “Don’t decry your own brother, my dear. Few young men have less against
3955: them, although he couldn’t take his degree—I’m sure I can’t understand
3956: why, for he seems to me most clever. And you know yourself he was
3957: thought equal to the best society at college. So particular as you are,
3958: my dear, I wonder you are not glad to have such a gentlemanly young man
3959: for a brother. You are always finding fault with Bob because he is not
3960: Fred.”
3961: 
3962: “Oh no, mamma, only because he is Bob.”
3963: 
3964: “Well, my dear, you will not find any Middlemarch young man who has not
3965: something against him.”
3966: 
3967: “But”—here Rosamond’s face broke into a smile which suddenly revealed
3968: two dimples. She herself thought unfavorably of these dimples and
3969: smiled little in general society. “But I shall not marry any
3970: Middlemarch young man.”
3971: 
3972: “So it seems, my love, for you have as good as refused the pick of
3973: them; and if there’s better to be had, I’m sure there’s no girl better
3974: deserves it.”
3975: 
3976: “Excuse me, mamma—I wish you would not say, ‘the pick of them.’”
3977: 
3978: “Why, what else are they?”
3979: 
3980: “I mean, mamma, it is rather a vulgar expression.”
3981: 
3982: “Very likely, my dear; I never was a good speaker. What should I say?”
3983: 
3984: “The best of them.”
3985: 
3986: “Why, that seems just as plain and common. If I had had time to think,
3987: I should have said, ‘the most superior young men.’ But with your
3988: education you must know.”
3989: 
3990: “What must Rosy know, mother?” said Mr. Fred, who had slid in
3991: unobserved through the half-open door while the ladies were bending
3992: over their work, and now going up to the fire stood with his back
3993: towards it, warming the soles of his slippers.
3994: 
3995: “Whether it’s right to say ‘superior young men,’” said Mrs. Vincy,
3996: ringing the bell.
3997: 
3998: “Oh, there are so many superior teas and sugars now. Superior is
3999: getting to be shopkeepers’ slang.”
4000: 
4001: “Are you beginning to dislike slang, then?” said Rosamond, with mild
4002: gravity.
4003: 
4004: “Only the wrong sort. All choice of words is slang. It marks a class.”
4005: 
4006: “There is correct English: that is not slang.”
4007: 
4008: “I beg your pardon: correct English is the slang of prigs who write
4009: history and essays. And the strongest slang of all is the slang of
4010: poets.”
4011: 
4012: “You will say anything, Fred, to gain your point.”
4013: 
4014: “Well, tell me whether it is slang or poetry to call an ox a
4015: _leg-plaiter_.”
4016: 
4017: “Of course you can call it poetry if you like.”
4018: 
4019: “Aha, Miss Rosy, you don’t know Homer from slang. I shall invent a new
4020: game; I shall write bits of slang and poetry on slips, and give them to
4021: you to separate.”
4022: 
4023: “Dear me, how amusing it is to hear young people talk!” said Mrs.
4024: Vincy, with cheerful admiration.
4025: 
4026: “Have you got nothing else for my breakfast, Pritchard?” said Fred, to
4027: the servant who brought in coffee and buttered toast; while he walked
4028: round the table surveying the ham, potted beef, and other cold
4029: remnants, with an air of silent rejection, and polite forbearance from
4030: signs of disgust.
4031: 
4032: “Should you like eggs, sir?”
4033: 
4034: “Eggs, no! Bring me a grilled bone.”
4035: 
4036: “Really, Fred,” said Rosamond, when the servant had left the room, “if
4037: you must have hot things for breakfast, I wish you would come down
4038: earlier. You can get up at six o’clock to go out hunting; I cannot
4039: understand why you find it so difficult to get up on other mornings.”
4040: 
4041: “That is your want of understanding, Rosy. I can get up to go hunting
4042: because I like it.”
4043: 
4044: “What would you think of me if I came down two hours after every one
4045: else and ordered grilled bone?”
4046: 
4047: “I should think you were an uncommonly fast young lady,” said Fred,
4048: eating his toast with the utmost composure.
4049: 
4050: “I cannot see why brothers are to make themselves disagreeable, any
4051: more than sisters.”
4052: 
4053: “I don’t make myself disagreeable; it is you who find me so.
4054: Disagreeable is a word that describes your feelings and not my
4055: actions.”
4056: 
4057: “I think it describes the smell of grilled bone.”
4058: 
4059: “Not at all. It describes a sensation in your little nose associated
4060: with certain finicking notions which are the classics of Mrs. Lemon’s
4061: school. Look at my mother; you don’t see her objecting to everything
4062: except what she does herself. She is my notion of a pleasant woman.”
4063: 
4064: “Bless you both, my dears, and don’t quarrel,” said Mrs. Vincy, with
4065: motherly cordiality. “Come, Fred, tell us all about the new doctor. How
4066: is your uncle pleased with him?”
4067: 
4068: “Pretty well, I think. He asks Lydgate all sorts of questions and then
4069: screws up his face while he hears the answers, as if they were pinching
4070: his toes. That’s his way. Ah, here comes my grilled bone.”
4071: 
4072: “But how came you to stay out so late, my dear? You only said you were
4073: going to your uncle’s.”
4074: 
4075: “Oh, I dined at Plymdale’s. We had whist. Lydgate was there too.”
4076: 
4077: “And what do you think of him? He is very gentlemanly, I suppose. They
4078: say he is of excellent family—his relations quite county people.”
4079: 
4080: “Yes,” said Fred. “There was a Lydgate at John’s who spent no end of
4081: money. I find this man is a second cousin of his. But rich men may have
4082: very poor devils for second cousins.”
4083: 
4084: “It always makes a difference, though, to be of good family,” said
4085: Rosamond, with a tone of decision which showed that she had thought on
4086: this subject. Rosamond felt that she might have been happier if she had
4087: not been the daughter of a Middlemarch manufacturer. She disliked
4088: anything which reminded her that her mother’s father had been an
4089: innkeeper. Certainly any one remembering the fact might think that Mrs.
4090: Vincy had the air of a very handsome good-humored landlady, accustomed
4091: to the most capricious orders of gentlemen.
4092: 
4093: “I thought it was odd his name was Tertius,” said the bright-faced
4094: matron, “but of course it’s a name in the family. But now, tell us
4095: exactly what sort of man he is.”
4096: 
4097: “Oh, tallish, dark, clever—talks well—rather a prig, I think.”
4098: 
4099: “I never can make out what you mean by a prig,” said Rosamond.
4100: 
4101: “A fellow who wants to show that he has opinions.”
4102: 
4103: “Why, my dear, doctors must have opinions,” said Mrs. Vincy. “What are
4104: they there for else?”
4105: 
4106: “Yes, mother, the opinions they are paid for. But a prig is a fellow
4107: who is always making you a present of his opinions.”
4108: 
4109: “I suppose Mary Garth admires Mr. Lydgate,” said Rosamond, not without
4110: a touch of innuendo.
4111: 
4112: “Really, I can’t say.” said Fred, rather glumly, as he left the table,
4113: and taking up a novel which he had brought down with him, threw himself
4114: into an arm-chair. “If you are jealous of her, go oftener to Stone
4115: Court yourself and eclipse her.”
4116: 
4117: “I wish you would not be so vulgar, Fred. If you have finished, pray
4118: ring the bell.”
4119: 
4120: “It is true, though—what your brother says, Rosamond,” Mrs. Vincy

4122: you haven’t patience to go and see your uncle more, so proud of you as
4123: he is, and wanted you to live with him. There’s no knowing what he
4124: might have done for you as well as for Fred. God knows, I’m fond of
4125: having you at home with me, but I can part with my children for their
4126: good. And now it stands to reason that your uncle Featherstone will do
4127: something for Mary Garth.”
4128: 
4129: “Mary Garth can bear being at Stone Court, because she likes that
4130: better than being a governess,” said Rosamond, folding up her work. “I
4131: would rather not have anything left to me if I must earn it by enduring
4132: much of my uncle’s cough and his ugly relations.”
4133: 
4134: “He can’t be long for this world, my dear; I wouldn’t hasten his end,
4135: but what with asthma and that inward complaint, let us hope there is
4136: something better for him in another. And I have no ill-will towards
4137: Mary Garth, but there’s justice to be thought of. And Mr.
4138: Featherstone’s first wife brought him no money, as my sister did. Her
4139: nieces and nephews can’t have so much claim as my sister’s. And I must
4140: say I think Mary Garth a dreadful plain girl—more fit for a governess.”
4141: 
4142: “Every one would not agree with you there, mother,” said Fred, who
4143: seemed to be able to read and listen too.
4144: 
4145: “Well, my dear,” said Mrs. Vincy, wheeling skilfully, “if she _had_
4146: some fortune left her,—a man marries his wife’s relations, and the
4147: Garths are so poor, and live in such a small way. But I shall leave you
4148: to your studies, my dear; for I must go and do some shopping.”
4149: 
4150: “Fred’s studies are not very deep,” said Rosamond, rising with her
4151: mamma, “he is only reading a novel.”
4152: 
4153: “Well, well, by-and-by he’ll go to his Latin and things,” said Mrs.
4154: Vincy, soothingly, stroking her son’s head. “There’s a fire in the
4155: smoking-room on purpose. It’s your father’s wish, you know—Fred, my
4156: dear—and I always tell him you will be good, and go to college again to
4157: take your degree.”
4158: 
4159: Fred drew his mother’s hand down to his lips, but said nothing.
4160: 
4161: “I suppose you are not going out riding to-day?” said Rosamond,
4162: lingering a little after her mamma was gone.
4163: 
4164: “No; why?”
4165: 
4166: “Papa says I may have the chestnut to ride now.”
4167: 
4168: “You can go with me to-morrow, if you like. Only I am going to Stone
4169: Court, remember.”
4170: 
4171: “I want to ride so much, it is indifferent to me where we go.” Rosamond
4172: really wished to go to Stone Court, of all other places.
4173: 
4174: “Oh, I say, Rosy,” said Fred, as she was passing out of the room, “if
4175: you are going to the piano, let me come and play some airs with you.”
4176: 
4177: “Pray do not ask me this morning.”
4178: 
4179: “Why not this morning?”
4180: 
4181: “Really, Fred, I wish you would leave off playing the flute. A man
4182: looks very silly playing the flute. And you play so out of tune.”
4183: 
4184: “When next any one makes love to you, Miss Rosamond, I will tell him

4186:

4191: 
4192: This question led to an adjustment, for Rosamond had set her mind on
4193: that particular ride.
4194:

4196: “Ye banks and braes,” and other favorite airs from his “Instructor on
4197: the Flute;” a wheezy performance, into which he threw much ambition and

4202: 
4203: CHAPTER XII.
4204: 
4205: He had more tow on his distaffe
4206: Than Gerveis knew.
4207: —CHAUCER.
4208: 
4209: 
4210: The ride to Stone Court, which Fred and Rosamond took the next morning,
4211: lay through a pretty bit of midland landscape, almost all meadows and
4212: pastures, with hedgerows still allowed to grow in bushy beauty and to
4213: spread out coral fruit for the birds. Little details gave each field a
4214: particular physiognomy, dear to the eyes that have looked on them from
4215: childhood: the pool in the corner where the grasses were dank and trees
4216: leaned whisperingly; the great oak shadowing a bare place in
4217: mid-pasture; the high bank where the ash-trees grew; the sudden slope
4218: of the old marl-pit making a red background for the burdock; the
4219: huddled roofs and ricks of the homestead without a traceable way of
4220: approach; the gray gate and fences against the depths of the bordering
4221: wood; and the stray hovel, its old, old thatch full of mossy hills and
4222: valleys with wondrous modulations of light and shadow such as we travel
4223: far to see in later life, and see larger, but not more beautiful. These
4224: are the things that make the gamut of joy in landscape to midland-bred
4225: souls—the things they toddled among, or perhaps learned by heart
4226: standing between their father’s knees while he drove leisurely.
4227: 
4228: But the road, even the byroad, was excellent; for Lowick, as we have
4229: seen, was not a parish of muddy lanes and poor tenants; and it was into
4230: Lowick parish that Fred and Rosamond entered after a couple of miles’
4231: riding. Another mile would bring them to Stone Court, and at the end of
4232: the first half, the house was already visible, looking as if it had
4233: been arrested in its growth toward a stone mansion by an unexpected
4234: budding of farm-buildings on its left flank, which had hindered it from
4235: becoming anything more than the substantial dwelling of a gentleman
4236: farmer. It was not the less agreeable an object in the distance for the
4237: cluster of pinnacled corn-ricks which balanced the fine row of walnuts
4238: on the right.
4239: 
4240: Presently it was possible to discern something that might be a gig on
4241: the circular drive before the front door.
4242: 
4243: “Dear me,” said Rosamond, “I hope none of my uncle’s horrible relations
4244: are there.”
4245: 
4246: “They are, though. That is Mrs. Waule’s gig—the last yellow gig left, I
4247: should think. When I see Mrs. Waule in it, I understand how yellow can
4248: have been worn for mourning. That gig seems to me more funereal than a
4249: hearse. But then Mrs. Waule always has black crape on. How does she
4250: manage it, Rosy? Her friends can’t always be dying.”
4251: 
4252: “I don’t know at all. And she is not in the least evangelical,” said
4253: Rosamond, reflectively, as if that religious point of view would have
4254: fully accounted for perpetual crape. “And, not poor,” she added, after
4255: a moment’s pause.
4256: 
4257: “No, by George! They are as rich as Jews, those Waules and
4258: Featherstones; I mean, for people like them, who don’t want to spend
4259: anything. And yet they hang about my uncle like vultures, and are
4260: afraid of a farthing going away from their side of the family. But I
4261: believe he hates them all.”
4262: 
4263: The Mrs. Waule who was so far from being admirable in the eyes of these
4264: distant connections, had happened to say this very morning (not at all
4265: with a defiant air, but in a low, muffled, neutral tone, as of a voice
4266: heard through cotton wool) that she did not wish “to enjoy their good
4267: opinion.” She was seated, as she observed, on her own brother’s hearth,
4268: and had been Jane Featherstone five-and-twenty years before she had
4269: been Jane Waule, which entitled her to speak when her own brother’s
4270: name had been made free with by those who had no right to it.
4271: 
4272: “What are you driving at there?” said Mr. Featherstone, holding his
4273: stick between his knees and settling his wig, while he gave her a
4274: momentary sharp glance, which seemed to react on him like a draught of
4275: cold air and set him coughing.
4276: 
4277: Mrs. Waule had to defer her answer till he was quiet again, till Mary
4278: Garth had supplied him with fresh syrup, and he had begun to rub the
4279: gold knob of his stick, looking bitterly at the fire. It was a bright
4280: fire, but it made no difference to the chill-looking purplish tint of
4281: Mrs. Waule’s face, which was as neutral as her voice; having mere
4282: chinks for eyes, and lips that hardly moved in speaking.
4283: 
4284: “The doctors can’t master that cough, brother. It’s just like what I
4285: have; for I’m your own sister, constitution and everything. But, as I
4286: was saying, it’s a pity Mrs. Vincy’s family can’t be better conducted.”
4287: 
4288: “Tchah! you said nothing o’ the sort. You said somebody had made free
4289: with my name.”
4290: 
4291: “And no more than can be proved, if what everybody says is true. My
4292: brother Solomon tells me it’s the talk up and down in Middlemarch how
4293: unsteady young Vincy is, and has been forever gambling at billiards
4294: since home he came.”
4295: 
4296: “Nonsense! What’s a game at billiards? It’s a good gentlemanly game;
