4297: and young Vincy is not a clodhopper. If your son John took to
4298: billiards, now, he’d make a fool of himself.”
4299: 
4300: “Your nephew John never took to billiards or any other game, brother,
4301: and is far from losing hundreds of pounds, which, if what everybody
4302: says is true, must be found somewhere else than out of Mr. Vincy the
4303: father’s pocket. For they say he’s been losing money for years, though
4304: nobody would think so, to see him go coursing and keeping open house as
4305: they do. And I’ve heard say Mr. Bulstrode condemns Mrs. Vincy beyond
4306: anything for her flightiness, and spoiling her children so.”
4307: 
4308: “What’s Bulstrode to me? I don’t bank with him.”
4309: 
4310: “Well, Mrs. Bulstrode is Mr. Vincy’s own sister, and they do say that
4311: Mr. Vincy mostly trades on the Bank money; and you may see yourself,
4312: brother, when a woman past forty has pink strings always flying, and
4313: that light way of laughing at everything, it’s very unbecoming. But
4314: indulging your children is one thing, and finding money to pay their
4315: debts is another. And it’s openly said that young Vincy has raised
4316: money on his expectations. I don’t say what expectations. Miss Garth
4317: hears me, and is welcome to tell again. I know young people hang
4318: together.”
4319: 
4320: “No, thank you, Mrs. Waule,” said Mary Garth. “I dislike hearing
4321: scandal too much to wish to repeat it.”
4322: 
4323: Mr. Featherstone rubbed the knob of his stick and made a brief
4324: convulsive show of laughter, which had much the same genuineness as an
4325: old whist-player’s chuckle over a bad hand. Still looking at the fire,
4326: he said—
4327: 
4328: “And who pretends to say Fred Vincy hasn’t got expectations? Such a
4329: fine, spirited fellow is like enough to have ’em.”
4330: 
4331: There was a slight pause before Mrs. Waule replied, and when she did
4332: so, her voice seemed to be slightly moistened with tears, though her
4333: face was still dry.
4334: 
4335: “Whether or no, brother, it is naturally painful to me and my brother
4336: Solomon to hear your name made free with, and your complaint being such
4337: as may carry you off sudden, and people who are no more Featherstones
4338: than the Merry-Andrew at the fair, openly reckoning on your property
4339: coming to _them_. And me your own sister, and Solomon your own brother!
4340: And if that’s to be it, what has it pleased the Almighty to make
4341: families for?” Here Mrs. Waule’s tears fell, but with moderation.
4342: 
4343: “Come, out with it, Jane!” said Mr. Featherstone, looking at her. “You
4344: mean to say, Fred Vincy has been getting somebody to advance him money
4345: on what he says he knows about my will, eh?”
4346: 
4347: “I never said so, brother” (Mrs. Waule’s voice had again become dry and
4348: unshaken). “It was told me by my brother Solomon last night when he
4349: called coming from market to give me advice about the old wheat, me
4350: being a widow, and my son John only three-and-twenty, though steady
4351: beyond anything. And he had it from most undeniable authority, and not
4352: one, but many.”
4353: 
4354: “Stuff and nonsense! I don’t believe a word of it. It’s all a got-up
4355: story. Go to the window, missy; I thought I heard a horse. See if the
4356: doctor’s coming.”
4357: 
4358: “Not got up by me, brother, nor yet by Solomon, who, whatever else he
4359: may be—and I don’t deny he has oddities—has made his will and parted
4360: his property equal between such kin as he’s friends with; though, for
4361: my part, I think there are times when some should be considered more
4362: than others. But Solomon makes it no secret what he means to do.”
4363: 
4364: “The more fool he!” said Mr. Featherstone, with some difficulty;
4365: breaking into a severe fit of coughing that required Mary Garth to
4366: stand near him, so that she did not find out whose horses they were
4367: which presently paused stamping on the gravel before the door.
4368: 
4369: Before Mr. Featherstone’s cough was quiet, Rosamond entered, bearing up
4370: her riding-habit with much grace. She bowed ceremoniously to Mrs.
4371: Waule, who said stiffly, “How do you do, miss?” smiled and nodded
4372: silently to Mary, and remained standing till the coughing should cease,
4373: and allow her uncle to notice her.
4374: 
4375: “Heyday, miss!” he said at last, “you have a fine color. Where’s Fred?”
4376: 
4377: “Seeing about the horses. He will be in presently.”
4378: 
4379: “Sit down, sit down. Mrs. Waule, you’d better go.”
4380: 
4381: Even those neighbors who had called Peter Featherstone an old fox, had
4382: never accused him of being insincerely polite, and his sister was quite
4383: used to the peculiar absence of ceremony with which he marked his sense
4384: of blood-relationship. Indeed, she herself was accustomed to think that
4385: entire freedom from the necessity of behaving agreeably was included in
4386: the Almighty’s intentions about families. She rose slowly without any
4387: sign of resentment, and said in her usual muffled monotone, “Brother, I
4388: hope the new doctor will be able to do something for you. Solomon says
4389: there’s great talk of his cleverness. I’m sure it’s my wish you should
4390: be spared. And there’s none more ready to nurse you than your own
4391: sister and your own nieces, if you’d only say the word. There’s
4392: Rebecca, and Joanna, and Elizabeth, you know.”
4393: 
4394: “Ay, ay, I remember—you’ll see I’ve remembered ’em all—all dark and
4395: ugly. They’d need have some money, eh? There never was any beauty in
4396: the women of our family; but the Featherstones have always had some
4397: money, and the Waules too. Waule had money too. A warm man was Waule.
4398: Ay, ay; money’s a good egg; and if you’ve got money to leave behind
4399: you, lay it in a warm nest. Good-by, Mrs. Waule.” Here Mr. Featherstone
4400: pulled at both sides of his wig as if he wanted to deafen himself, and
4401: his sister went away ruminating on this oracular speech of his.
4402: Notwithstanding her jealousy of the Vincys and of Mary Garth, there
4403: remained as the nethermost sediment in her mental shallows a persuasion
4404: that her brother Peter Featherstone could never leave his chief
4405: property away from his blood-relations:—else, why had the Almighty
4406: carried off his two wives both childless, after he had gained so much
4407: by manganese and things, turning up when nobody expected it?—and why
4408: was there a Lowick parish church, and the Waules and Powderells all
4409: sitting in the same pew for generations, and the Featherstone pew next
4410: to them, if, the Sunday after her brother Peter’s death, everybody was
4411: to know that the property was gone out of the family? The human mind
4412: has at no period accepted a moral chaos; and so preposterous a result
4413: was not strictly conceivable. But we are frightened at much that is not
4414: strictly conceivable.
4415: 
4416: When Fred came in the old man eyed him with a peculiar twinkle, which
4417: the younger had often had reason to interpret as pride in the
4418: satisfactory details of his appearance.
4419: 
4420: “You two misses go away,” said Mr. Featherstone. “I want to speak to
4421: Fred.”
4422: 
4423: “Come into my room, Rosamond, you will not mind the cold for a little
4424: while,” said Mary. The two girls had not only known each other in
4425: childhood, but had been at the same provincial school together (Mary as
4426: an articled pupil), so that they had many memories in common, and liked
4427: very well to talk in private. Indeed, this _tête-à-tête_ was one of
4428: Rosamond’s objects in coming to Stone Court.
4429: 
4430: Old Featherstone would not begin the dialogue till the door had been
4431: closed. He continued to look at Fred with the same twinkle and with one
4432: of his habitual grimaces, alternately screwing and widening his mouth;
4433: and when he spoke, it was in a low tone, which might be taken for that
4434: of an informer ready to be bought off, rather than for the tone of an
4435: offended senior. He was not a man to feel any strong moral indignation
4436: even on account of trespasses against himself. It was natural that
4437: others should want to get an advantage over him, but then, he was a
4438: little too cunning for them.
4439: 
4440: “So, sir, you’ve been paying ten per cent for money which you’ve
4441: promised to pay off by mortgaging my land when I’m dead and gone, eh?
4442: You put my life at a twelvemonth, say. But I can alter my will yet.”
4443: 
4444: Fred blushed. He had not borrowed money in that way, for excellent
4445: reasons. But he was conscious of having spoken with some confidence
4446: (perhaps with more than he exactly remembered) about his prospect of
4447: getting Featherstone’s land as a future means of paying present debts.
4448: 
4449: “I don’t know what you refer to, sir. I have certainly never borrowed
4450: any money on such an insecurity. Please do explain.”
4451: 
4452: “No, sir, it’s you must explain. I can alter my will yet, let me tell
4453: you. I’m of sound mind—can reckon compound interest in my head, and
4454: remember every fool’s name as well as I could twenty years ago. What
4455: the deuce? I’m under eighty. I say, you must contradict this story.”
4456: 
4457: “I have contradicted it, sir,” Fred answered, with a touch of
4458: impatience, not remembering that his uncle did not verbally
4459: discriminate contradicting from disproving, though no one was further
4460: from confounding the two ideas than old Featherstone, who often
4461: wondered that so many fools took his own assertions for proofs. “But I
4462: contradict it again. The story is a silly lie.”
4463: 
4464: “Nonsense! you must bring dockiments. It comes from authority.”
4465: 
4466: “Name the authority, and make him name the man of whom I borrowed the
4467: money, and then I can disprove the story.”
4468: 
4469: “It’s pretty good authority, I think—a man who knows most of what goes
4470: on in Middlemarch. It’s that fine, religious, charitable uncle o’
4471: yours. Come now!” Here Mr. Featherstone had his peculiar inward shake
4472: which signified merriment.
4473: 
4474: “Mr. Bulstrode?”
4475: 
4476: “Who else, eh?”
4477: 
4478: “Then the story has grown into this lie out of some sermonizing words
4479: he may have let fall about me. Do they pretend that he named the man
4480: who lent me the money?”
4481: 
4482: “If there is such a man, depend upon it Bulstrode knows him. But,
4483: supposing you only tried to get the money lent, and didn’t get
4484: it—Bulstrode ’ud know that too. You bring me a writing from Bulstrode
4485: to say he doesn’t believe you’ve ever promised to pay your debts out o’
4486: my land. Come now!”
4487: 
4488: Mr. Featherstone’s face required its whole scale of grimaces as a
4489: muscular outlet to his silent triumph in the soundness of his
4490: faculties.
4491: 
4492: Fred felt himself to be in a disgusting dilemma.
4493: 
4494: “You must be joking, sir. Mr. Bulstrode, like other men, believes
4495: scores of things that are not true, and he has a prejudice against me.
4496: I could easily get him to write that he knew no facts in proof of the
4497: report you speak of, though it might lead to unpleasantness. But I
4498: could hardly ask him to write down what he believes or does not believe
4499: about me.” Fred paused an instant, and then added, in politic appeal to
4500: his uncle’s vanity, “That is hardly a thing for a gentleman to ask.”
4501: But he was disappointed in the result.
4502: 
4503: “Ay, I know what you mean. You’d sooner offend me than Bulstrode. And
4504: what’s he?—he’s got no land hereabout that ever I heard tell of. A
4505: speckilating fellow! He may come down any day, when the devil leaves
4506: off backing him. And that’s what his religion means: he wants God
4507: A’mighty to come in. That’s nonsense! There’s one thing I made out
4508: pretty clear when I used to go to church—and it’s this: God A’mighty
4509: sticks to the land. He promises land, and He gives land, and He makes
4510: chaps rich with corn and cattle. But you take the other side. You like
4511: Bulstrode and speckilation better than Featherstone and land.”
4512: 
4513: “I beg your pardon, sir,” said Fred, rising, standing with his back to
4514: the fire and beating his boot with his whip. “I like neither Bulstrode
4515: nor speculation.” He spoke rather sulkily, feeling himself stalemated.
4516: 
4517: “Well, well, you can do without me, that’s pretty clear,” said old
4518: Featherstone, secretly disliking the possibility that Fred would show
4519: himself at all independent. “You neither want a bit of land to make a
4520: squire of you instead of a starving parson, nor a lift of a hundred
4521: pound by the way. It’s all one to me. I can make five codicils if I
4522: like, and I shall keep my bank-notes for a nest-egg. It’s all one to
4523: me.”
4524: 
4525: Fred colored again. Featherstone had rarely given him presents of
4526: money, and at this moment it seemed almost harder to part with the
4527: immediate prospect of bank-notes than with the more distant prospect of
4528: the land.
4529: 
4530: “I am not ungrateful, sir. I never meant to show disregard for any kind
4531: intentions you might have towards me. On the contrary.”
4532: 
4533: “Very good. Then prove it. You bring me a letter from Bulstrode saying
4534: he doesn’t believe you’ve been cracking and promising to pay your debts
4535: out o’ my land, and then, if there’s any scrape you’ve got into, we’ll
4536: see if I can’t back you a bit. Come now! That’s a bargain. Here, give
4537: me your arm. I’ll try and walk round the room.”
4538: 
4539: Fred, in spite of his irritation, had kindness enough in him to be a
4540: little sorry for the unloved, unvenerated old man, who with his
4541: dropsical legs looked more than usually pitiable in walking. While
4542: giving his arm, he thought that he should not himself like to be an old
4543: fellow with his constitution breaking up; and he waited
4544: good-temperedly, first before the window to hear the wonted remarks
4545: about the guinea-fowls and the weather-cock, and then before the scanty
4546: book-shelves, of which the chief glories in dark calf were Josephus,
4547: Culpepper, Klopstock’s “Messiah,” and several volumes of the
4548: “Gentleman’s Magazine.”
4549: 
4550: “Read me the names o’ the books. Come now! you’re a college man.”
4551: 
4552: Fred gave him the titles.
4553: 
4554: “What did missy want with more books? What must you be bringing her
4555: more books for?”
4556: 
4557: “They amuse her, sir. She is very fond of reading.”
4558: 
4559: “A little too fond,” said Mr. Featherstone, captiously. “She was for
4560: reading when she sat with me. But I put a stop to that. She’s got the
4561: newspaper to read out loud. That’s enough for one day, I should think.
4562: I can’t abide to see her reading to herself. You mind and not bring her
4563: any more books, do you hear?”
4564: 
4565: “Yes, sir, I hear.” Fred had received this order before, and had
4566: secretly disobeyed it. He intended to disobey it again.
4567: 
4568: “Ring the bell,” said Mr. Featherstone; “I want missy to come down.”
4569: 
4570: Rosamond and Mary had been talking faster than their male friends. They
4571: did not think of sitting down, but stood at the toilet-table near the
4572: window while Rosamond took off her hat, adjusted her veil, and applied
4573: little touches of her finger-tips to her hair—hair of infantine
4574: fairness, neither flaxen nor yellow. Mary Garth seemed all the plainer
4575: standing at an angle between the two nymphs—the one in the glass, and
4576: the one out of it, who looked at each other with eyes of heavenly blue,
4577: deep enough to hold the most exquisite meanings an ingenious beholder
4578: could put into them, and deep enough to hide the meanings of the owner
4579: if these should happen to be less exquisite. Only a few children in
4580: Middlemarch looked blond by the side of Rosamond, and the slim figure
4581: displayed by her riding-habit had delicate undulations. In fact, most
4582: men in Middlemarch, except her brothers, held that Miss Vincy was the
4583: best girl in the world, and some called her an angel. Mary Garth, on
4584: the contrary, had the aspect of an ordinary sinner: she was brown; her
4585: curly dark hair was rough and stubborn; her stature was low; and it
4586: would not be true to declare, in satisfactory antithesis, that she had
4587: all the virtues. Plainness has its peculiar temptations and vices quite
4588: as much as beauty; it is apt either to feign amiability, or, not
4589: feigning it, to show all the repulsiveness of discontent: at any rate,
4590: to be called an ugly thing in contrast with that lovely creature your
4591: companion, is apt to produce some effect beyond a sense of fine
4592: veracity and fitness in the phrase. At the age of two-and-twenty Mary
4593: had certainly not attained that perfect good sense and good principle
4594: which are usually recommended to the less fortunate girl, as if they
4595: were to be obtained in quantities ready mixed, with a flavor of
4596: resignation as required. Her shrewdness had a streak of satiric
4597: bitterness continually renewed and never carried utterly out of sight,
4598: except by a strong current of gratitude towards those who, instead of
4599: telling her that she ought to be contented, did something to make her
4600: so. Advancing womanhood had tempered her plainness, which was of a good
4601: human sort, such as the mothers of our race have very commonly worn in
4602: all latitudes under a more or less becoming headgear. Rembrandt would
4603: have painted her with pleasure, and would have made her broad features
4604: look out of the canvas with intelligent honesty. For honesty,
4605: truth-telling fairness, was Mary’s reigning virtue: she neither tried
4606: to create illusions, nor indulged in them for her own behoof, and when
4607: she was in a good mood she had humor enough in her to laugh at herself.
4608: When she and Rosamond happened both to be reflected in the glass, she
4609: said, laughingly—
4610: 
4611: “What a brown patch I am by the side of you, Rosy! You are the most
4612: unbecoming companion.”
4613: 
4614: “Oh no! No one thinks of your appearance, you are so sensible and
4615: useful, Mary. Beauty is of very little consequence in reality,” said
4616: Rosamond, turning her head towards Mary, but with eyes swerving towards
4617: the new view of her neck in the glass.
4618: 
4619: “You mean _my_ beauty,” said Mary, rather sardonically.
4620: 
4621: Rosamond thought, “Poor Mary, she takes the kindest things ill.” Aloud
4622: she said, “What have you been doing lately?”
4623: 
4624: “I? Oh, minding the house—pouring out syrup—pretending to be amiable
4625: and contented—learning to have a bad opinion of everybody.”
4626: 
4627: “It is a wretched life for you.”
4628: 
4629: “No,” said Mary, curtly, with a little toss of her head. “I think my
4630: life is pleasanter than your Miss Morgan’s.”
4631: 
4632: “Yes; but Miss Morgan is so uninteresting, and not young.”
4633: 
4634: “She is interesting to herself, I suppose; and I am not at all sure
4635: that everything gets easier as one gets older.”
4636: 
4637: “No,” said Rosamond, reflectively; “one wonders what such people do,
4638: without any prospect. To be sure, there is religion as a support. But,”
4639: she added, dimpling, “it is very different with you, Mary. You may have
4640: an offer.”
4641: 
4642: “Has any one told you he means to make me one?”
4643: 
4644: “Of course not. I mean, there is a gentleman who may fall in love with
4645: you, seeing you almost every day.”
4646: 
4647: A certain change in Mary’s face was chiefly determined by the resolve
4648: not to show any change.
4649: 
4650: “Does that always make people fall in love?” she answered, carelessly;
4651: “it seems to me quite as often a reason for detesting each other.”
4652: 
4653: “Not when they are interesting and agreeable. I hear that Mr. Lydgate
4654: is both.”
4655: 
4656: “Oh, Mr. Lydgate!” said Mary, with an unmistakable lapse into
4657: indifference. “You want to know something about him,” she added, not
4658: choosing to indulge Rosamond’s indirectness.
4659: 
4660: “Merely, how you like him.”
4661: 
4662: “There is no question of liking at present. My liking always wants some
4663: little kindness to kindle it. I am not magnanimous enough to like
4664: people who speak to me without seeming to see me.”
4665: 
4666: “Is he so haughty?” said Rosamond, with heightened satisfaction. “You
4667: know that he is of good family?”
4668: 
4669: “No; he did not give that as a reason.”
4670: 
4671: “Mary! you are the oddest girl. But what sort of looking man is he?
4672: Describe him to me.”
4673: 
4674: “How can one describe a man? I can give you an inventory: heavy
4675: eyebrows, dark eyes, a straight nose, thick dark hair, large solid
4676: white hands—and—let me see—oh, an exquisite cambric
4677: pocket-handkerchief. But you will see him. You know this is about the
4678: time of his visits.”
4679: 
4680: Rosamond blushed a little, but said, meditatively, “I rather like a
4681: haughty manner. I cannot endure a rattling young man.”
4682: 
4683: “I did not tell you that Mr. Lydgate was haughty; but _il y en a pour
4684: tous les goûts_, as little Mamselle used to say, and if any girl can
4685: choose the particular sort of conceit she would like, I should think it
4686: is you, Rosy.”
4687: 
4688: “Haughtiness is not conceit; I call Fred conceited.”
4689: 
4690: “I wish no one said any worse of him. He should be more careful. Mrs.
4691: Waule has been telling uncle that Fred is very unsteady.” Mary spoke
4692: from a girlish impulse which got the better of her judgment. There was
4693: a vague uneasiness associated with the word “unsteady” which she hoped
4694: Rosamond might say something to dissipate. But she purposely abstained
4695: from mentioning Mrs. Waule’s more special insinuation.
4696: 
4697: “Oh, Fred is horrid!” said Rosamond. She would not have allowed herself
4698: so unsuitable a word to any one but Mary.
4699: 
4700: “What do you mean by horrid?”
4701: 
4702: “He is so idle, and makes papa so angry, and says he will not take
4703: orders.”
4704: 
4705: “I think Fred is quite right.”
4706: 
4707: “How can you say he is quite right, Mary? I thought you had more sense
4708: of religion.”
4709: 
4710: “He is not fit to be a clergyman.”
4711: 
4712: “But he ought to be fit.”—“Well, then, he is not what he ought to be. I
4713: know some other people who are in the same case.”
4714: 
4715: “But no one approves of them. I should not like to marry a clergyman;
4716: but there must be clergymen.”
4717: 
4718: “It does not follow that Fred must be one.”
4719: 
4720: “But when papa has been at the expense of educating him for it! And
4721: only suppose, if he should have no fortune left him?”
4722: 
4723: “I can suppose that very well,” said Mary, dryly.
4724: 
4725: “Then I wonder you can defend Fred,” said Rosamond, inclined to push
4726: this point.
4727: 
4728: “I don’t defend him,” said Mary, laughing; “I would defend any parish
4729: from having him for a clergyman.”
4730: 
4731: “But of course if he were a clergyman, he must be different.”
4732: 
4733: “Yes, he would be a great hypocrite; and he is not that yet.”
4734: 
4735: “It is of no use saying anything to you, Mary. You always take Fred’s
4736: part.”
4737: 
4738: “Why should I not take his part?” said Mary, lighting up. “He would
4739: take mine. He is the only person who takes the least trouble to oblige
4740: me.”
4741: 
4742: “You make me feel very uncomfortable, Mary,” said Rosamond, with her
4743: gravest mildness; “I would not tell mamma for the world.”
4744: 
4745: “What would you not tell her?” said Mary, angrily.
4746: 
4747: “Pray do not go into a rage, Mary,” said Rosamond, mildly as ever.
4748: 
4749: “If your mamma is afraid that Fred will make me an offer, tell her that
4750: I would not marry him if he asked me. But he is not going to do so,
4751: that I am aware. He certainly never has asked me.”
4752: 
4753: “Mary, you are always so violent.”
4754: 
4755: “And you are always so exasperating.”
4756: 
4757: “I? What can you blame me for?”
4758: 
4759: “Oh, blameless people are always the most exasperating. There is the
4760: bell—I think we must go down.”
4761: 
4762: “I did not mean to quarrel,” said Rosamond, putting on her hat.
4763: 
4764: “Quarrel? Nonsense; we have not quarrelled. If one is not to get into a
4765: rage sometimes, what is the good of being friends?”
4766: 
4767: “Am I to repeat what you have said?”
4768: 
4769: “Just as you please. I never say what I am afraid of having repeated.
4770: But let us go down.”
4771: 
4772: Mr. Lydgate was rather late this morning, but the visitors stayed long
4773: enough to see him; for Mr. Featherstone asked Rosamond to sing to him,
4774: and she herself was so kind as to propose a second favorite song of
4775: his—“Flow on, thou shining river”—after she had sung “Home, sweet home”
4776: (which she detested). This hard-headed old Overreach approved of the
4777: sentimental song, as the suitable garnish for girls, and also as
4778: fundamentally fine, sentiment being the right thing for a song.
4779: 
4780: Mr. Featherstone was still applauding the last performance, and
4781: assuring missy that her voice was as clear as a blackbird’s, when Mr.
4782: Lydgate’s horse passed the window.
4783: 
4784: His dull expectation of the usual disagreeable routine with an aged
4785: patient—who can hardly believe that medicine would not “set him up” if
4786: the doctor were only clever enough—added to his general disbelief in
4787: Middlemarch charms, made a doubly effective background to this vision
4788: of Rosamond, whom old Featherstone made haste ostentatiously to
4789: introduce as his niece, though he had never thought it worth while to
4790: speak of Mary Garth in that light. Nothing escaped Lydgate in
4791: Rosamond’s graceful behavior: how delicately she waived the notice
4792: which the old man’s want of taste had thrust upon her by a quiet
4793: gravity, not showing her dimples on the wrong occasion, but showing
4794: them afterwards in speaking to Mary, to whom she addressed herself with
4795: so much good-natured interest, that Lydgate, after quickly examining
4796: Mary more fully than he had done before, saw an adorable kindness in
4797: Rosamond’s eyes. But Mary from some cause looked rather out of temper.
4798: 
4799: “Miss Rosy has been singing me a song—you’ve nothing to say against
4800: that, eh, doctor?” said Mr. Featherstone. “I like it better than your
4801: physic.”
4802: 
4803: “That has made me forget how the time was going,” said Rosamond, rising
4804: to reach her hat, which she had laid aside before singing, so that her
4805: flower-like head on its white stem was seen in perfection above her
4806: riding-habit. “Fred, we must really go.”
4807: 
4808: “Very good,” said Fred, who had his own reasons for not being in the
4809: best spirits, and wanted to get away.
4810: 
4811: “Miss Vincy is a musician?” said Lydgate, following her with his eyes.
4812: (Every nerve and muscle in Rosamond was adjusted to the consciousness
4813: that she was being looked at. She was by nature an actress of parts
4814: that entered into her _physique:_ she even acted her own character, and
4815: so well, that she did not know it to be precisely her own.)
4816: 
4817: “The best in Middlemarch, I’ll be bound,” said Mr. Featherstone, “let
4818: the next be who she will. Eh, Fred? Speak up for your sister.”
4819: 
4820: “I’m afraid I’m out of court, sir. My evidence would be good for
4821: nothing.”
4822: 
4823: “Middlemarch has not a very high standard, uncle,” said Rosamond, with
4824: a pretty lightness, going towards her whip, which lay at a distance.
4825: 
4826: Lydgate was quick in anticipating her. He reached the whip before she
4827: did, and turned to present it to her. She bowed and looked at him: he
4828: of course was looking at her, and their eyes met with that peculiar
4829: meeting which is never arrived at by effort, but seems like a sudden
4830: divine clearance of haze. I think Lydgate turned a little paler than
4831: usual, but Rosamond blushed deeply and felt a certain astonishment.
4832: After that, she was really anxious to go, and did not know what sort of
4833: stupidity her uncle was talking of when she went to shake hands with
4834: him.
4835: 
4836: Yet this result, which she took to be a mutual impression, called
4837: falling in love, was just what Rosamond had contemplated beforehand.
4838: Ever since that important new arrival in Middlemarch she had woven a
4839: little future, of which something like this scene was the necessary
4840: beginning. Strangers, whether wrecked and clinging to a raft, or duly
4841: escorted and accompanied by portmanteaus, have always had a
4842: circumstantial fascination for the virgin mind, against which native
4843: merit has urged itself in vain. And a stranger was absolutely necessary
4844: to Rosamond’s social romance, which had always turned on a lover and
4845: bridegroom who was not a Middlemarcher, and who had no connections at
4846: all like her own: of late, indeed, the construction seemed to demand
4847: that he should somehow be related to a baronet. Now that she and the
4848: stranger had met, reality proved much more moving than anticipation,
4849: and Rosamond could not doubt that this was the great epoch of her life.
4850: She judged of her own symptoms as those of awakening love, and she held
4851: it still more natural that Mr. Lydgate should have fallen in love at
4852: first sight of her. These things happened so often at balls, and why
4853: not by the morning light, when the complexion showed all the better for
4854: it? Rosamond, though no older than Mary, was rather used to being
4855: fallen in love with; but she, for her part, had remained indifferent
4856: and fastidiously critical towards both fresh sprig and faded bachelor.
4857: And here was Mr. Lydgate suddenly corresponding to her ideal, being
4858: altogether foreign to Middlemarch, carrying a certain air of
4859: distinction congruous with good family, and possessing connections
4860: which offered vistas of that middle-class heaven, rank; a man of
4861: talent, also, whom it would be especially delightful to enslave: in
4862: fact, a man who had touched her nature quite newly, and brought a vivid
4863: interest into her life which was better than any fancied “might-be”
4864: such as she was in the habit of opposing to the actual.
4865: 
4866: Thus, in riding home, both the brother and the sister were preoccupied
4867: and inclined to be silent. Rosamond, whose basis for her structure had
4868: the usual airy slightness, was of remarkably detailed and realistic
4869: imagination when the foundation had been once presupposed; and before
4870: they had ridden a mile she was far on in the costume and introductions
4871: of her wedded life, having determined on her house in Middlemarch, and
4872: foreseen the visits she would pay to her husband’s high-bred relatives
4873: at a distance, whose finished manners she could appropriate as
4874: thoroughly as she had done her school accomplishments, preparing
4875: herself thus for vaguer elevations which might ultimately come. There
4876: was nothing financial, still less sordid, in her previsions: she cared
4877: about what were considered refinements, and not about the money that
4878: was to pay for them.
4879: 
4880: Fred’s mind, on the other hand, was busy with an anxiety which even his
4881: ready hopefulness could not immediately quell. He saw no way of eluding
4882: Featherstone’s stupid demand without incurring consequences which he
4883: liked less even than the task of fulfilling it. His father was already
4884: out of humor with him, and would be still more so if he were the
4885: occasion of any additional coolness between his own family and the
4886: Bulstrodes. Then, he himself hated having to go and speak to his uncle
4887: Bulstrode, and perhaps after drinking wine he had said many foolish
4888: things about Featherstone’s property, and these had been magnified by
4889: report. Fred felt that he made a wretched figure as a fellow who
4890: bragged about expectations from a queer old miser like Featherstone,
4891: and went to beg for certificates at his bidding. But—those
4892: expectations! He really had them, and he saw no agreeable alternative
4893: if he gave them up; besides, he had lately made a debt which galled him
4894: extremely, and old Featherstone had almost bargained to pay it off. The
4895: whole affair was miserably small: his debts were small, even his
4896: expectations were not anything so very magnificent. Fred had known men
4897: to whom he would have been ashamed of confessing the smallness of his
4898: scrapes. Such ruminations naturally produced a streak of misanthropic
4899: bitterness. To be born the son of a Middlemarch manufacturer, and
4900: inevitable heir to nothing in particular, while such men as Mainwaring
4901: and Vyan—certainly life was a poor business, when a spirited young
4902: fellow, with a good appetite for the best of everything, had so poor an
4903: outlook.
4904: 
4905: It had not occurred to Fred that the introduction of Bulstrode’s name
4906: in the matter was a fiction of old Featherstone’s; nor could this have
4907: made any difference to his position. He saw plainly enough that the old
4908: man wanted to exercise his power by tormenting him a little, and also
4909: probably to get some satisfaction out of seeing him on unpleasant terms
4910: with Bulstrode. Fred fancied that he saw to the bottom of his uncle
4911: Featherstone’s soul, though in reality half what he saw there was no
4912: more than the reflex of his own inclinations. The difficult task of
4913: knowing another soul is not for young gentlemen whose consciousness is
4914: chiefly made up of their own wishes.
4915: 
4916: Fred’s main point of debate with himself was, whether he should tell
4917: his father, or try to get through the affair without his father’s
4918: knowledge. It was probably Mrs. Waule who had been talking about him;
4919: and if Mary Garth had repeated Mrs. Waule’s report to Rosamond, it
4920: would be sure to reach his father, who would as surely question him
4921: about it. He said to Rosamond, as they slackened their pace—
4922: 
4923: “Rosy, did Mary tell you that Mrs. Waule had said anything about me?”
4924: 
4925: “Yes, indeed, she did.”
4926: 
4927: “What?”
4928: 
4929: “That you were very unsteady.”
4930: 
4931: “Was that all?”
4932: 
4933: “I should think that was enough, Fred.”
4934: 
4935: “You are sure she said no more?”
4936: 
4937: “Mary mentioned nothing else. But really, Fred, I think you ought to be
4938: ashamed.”
4939: 
4940: “Oh, fudge! Don’t lecture me. What did Mary say about it?”
4941: 
4942: “I am not obliged to tell you. You care so very much what Mary says,
4943: and you are too rude to allow me to speak.”
4944: 
4945: “Of course I care what Mary says. She is the best girl I know.”
4946: 
4947: “I should never have thought she was a girl to fall in love with.”
4948: 
4949: “How do you know what men would fall in love with? Girls never know.”
4950: 
4951: “At least, Fred, let me advise _you_ not to fall in love with her, for
4952: she says she would not marry you if you asked her.”
4953: 
4954: “She might have waited till I did ask her.”
4955: 
4956: “I knew it would nettle you, Fred.”
4957: 
4958: “Not at all. She would not have said so if you had not provoked her.”
4959: Before reaching home, Fred concluded that he would tell the whole
4960: affair as simply as possible to his father, who might perhaps take on
4961: himself the unpleasant business of speaking to Bulstrode.
4962: 
4963: 
4964: 
4965: 
4966: BOOK II.
4967: OLD AND YOUNG.
4968: 
4969: 
4970: 
4971: 
4972: CHAPTER XIII.
4973: 
4974: 1_st Gent_. How class your man?—as better than the most,
4975:     Or, seeming better, worse beneath that cloak?
4976:     As saint or knave, pilgrim or hypocrite?
4977: 
4978: 2_d Gent_. Nay, tell me how you class your wealth of books
4979:     The drifted relics of all time.
4980:     As well sort them at once by size and livery:
4981:     Vellum, tall copies, and the common calf
4982:     Will hardly cover more diversity
4983:     Than all your labels cunningly devised
4984:     To class your unread authors.
4985: 
4986: 
4987: In consequence of what he had heard from Fred, Mr. Vincy determined to
4988: speak with Mr. Bulstrode in his private room at the Bank at half-past
4989: one, when he was usually free from other callers. But a visitor had
4990: come in at one o’clock, and Mr. Bulstrode had so much to say to him,
4991: that there was little chance of the interview being over in half an
4992: hour. The banker’s speech was fluent, but it was also copious, and he
4993: used up an appreciable amount of time in brief meditative pauses. Do
4994: not imagine his sickly aspect to have been of the yellow, black-haired
4995: sort: he had a pale blond skin, thin gray-besprinkled brown hair,
4996: light-gray eyes, and a large forehead. Loud men called his subdued tone
4997: an undertone, and sometimes implied that it was inconsistent with
4998: openness; though there seems to be no reason why a loud man should not
4999: be given to concealment of anything except his own voice, unless it can
5000: be shown that Holy Writ has placed the seat of candor in the lungs. Mr.
5001: Bulstrode had also a deferential bending attitude in listening, and an
5002: apparently fixed attentiveness in his eyes which made those persons who
5003: thought themselves worth hearing infer that he was seeking the utmost
5004: improvement from their discourse. Others, who expected to make no great
5005: figure, disliked this kind of moral lantern turned on them. If you are
5006: not proud of your cellar, there is no thrill of satisfaction in seeing
5007: your guest hold up his wine-glass to the light and look judicial. Such
5008: joys are reserved for conscious merit. Hence Mr. Bulstrode’s close
5009: attention was not agreeable to the publicans and sinners in
5010: Middlemarch; it was attributed by some to his being a Pharisee, and by
5011: others to his being Evangelical. Less superficial reasoners among them
5012: wished to know who his father and grandfather were, observing that
5013: five-and-twenty years ago nobody had ever heard of a Bulstrode in
5014: Middlemarch. To his present visitor, Lydgate, the scrutinizing look was
5015: a matter of indifference: he simply formed an unfavorable opinion of
5016: the banker’s constitution, and concluded that he had an eager inward
5017: life with little enjoyment of tangible things.
5018: 
5019: “I shall be exceedingly obliged if you will look in on me here
5020: occasionally, Mr. Lydgate,” the banker observed, after a brief pause.
5021: “If, as I dare to hope, I have the privilege of finding you a valuable
5022: coadjutor in the interesting matter of hospital management, there will
5023: be many questions which we shall need to discuss in private. As to the
5024: new hospital, which is nearly finished, I shall consider what you have
5025: said about the advantages of the special destination for fevers. The
5026: decision will rest with me, for though Lord Medlicote has given the
5027: land and timber for the building, he is not disposed to give his
5028: personal attention to the object.”
5029: 
5030: “There are few things better worth the pains in a provincial town like
5031: this,” said Lydgate. “A fine fever hospital in addition to the old
5032: infirmary might be the nucleus of a medical school here, when once we
5033: get our medical reforms; and what would do more for medical education
5034: than the spread of such schools over the country? A born provincial man
5035: who has a grain of public spirit as well as a few ideas, should do what
5036: he can to resist the rush of everything that is a little better than
5037: common towards London. Any valid professional aims may often find a
5038: freer, if not a richer field, in the provinces.”
5039: 
5040: One of Lydgate’s gifts was a voice habitually deep and sonorous, yet
5041: capable of becoming very low and gentle at the right moment. About his
5042: ordinary bearing there was a certain fling, a fearless expectation of
5043: success, a confidence in his own powers and integrity much fortified by
5044: contempt for petty obstacles or seductions of which he had had no
5045: experience. But this proud openness was made lovable by an expression
5046: of unaffected good-will. Mr. Bulstrode perhaps liked him the better for
5047: the difference between them in pitch and manners; he certainly liked
5048: him the better, as Rosamond did, for being a stranger in Middlemarch.
5049: One can begin so many things with a new person!—even begin to be a
5050: better man.
5051: 
5052: “I shall rejoice to furnish your zeal with fuller opportunities,” Mr.
5053: Bulstrode answered; “I mean, by confiding to you the superintendence of
5054: my new hospital, should a maturer knowledge favor that issue, for I am
5055: determined that so great an object shall not be shackled by our two
5056: physicians. Indeed, I am encouraged to consider your advent to this
5057: town as a gracious indication that a more manifest blessing is now to
5058: be awarded to my efforts, which have hitherto been much withstood. With
5059: regard to the old infirmary, we have gained the initial point—I mean
5060: your election. And now I hope you will not shrink from incurring a
5061: certain amount of jealousy and dislike from your professional brethren
5062: by presenting yourself as a reformer.”
5063: 
5064: “I will not profess bravery,” said Lydgate, smiling, “but I acknowledge
5065: a good deal of pleasure in fighting, and I should not care for my
5066: profession, if I did not believe that better methods were to be found
5067: and enforced there as well as everywhere else.”
5068: 
5069: “The standard of that profession is low in Middlemarch, my dear sir,”
5070: said the banker. “I mean in knowledge and skill; not in social status,
5071: for our medical men are most of them connected with respectable
5072: townspeople here. My own imperfect health has induced me to give some
5073: attention to those palliative resources which the divine mercy has
5074: placed within our reach. I have consulted eminent men in the
5075: metropolis, and I am painfully aware of the backwardness under which
5076: medical treatment labors in our provincial districts.”
5077: 
5078: “Yes;—with our present medical rules and education, one must be
5079: satisfied now and then to meet with a fair practitioner. As to all the
5080: higher questions which determine the starting-point of a diagnosis—as
5081: to the philosophy of medical evidence—any glimmering of these can only
5082: come from a scientific culture of which country practitioners have
5083: usually no more notion than the man in the moon.”
5084: 
5085: Mr. Bulstrode, bending and looking intently, found the form which
5086: Lydgate had given to his agreement not quite suited to his
5087: comprehension. Under such circumstances a judicious man changes the
5088: topic and enters on ground where his own gifts may be more useful.
5089: 
5090: “I am aware,” he said, “that the peculiar bias of medical ability is
5091: towards material means. Nevertheless, Mr. Lydgate, I hope we shall not
5092: vary in sentiment as to a measure in which you are not likely to be
5093: actively concerned, but in which your sympathetic concurrence may be an
5094: aid to me. You recognize, I hope; the existence of spiritual interests
5095: in your patients?”
5096: 
5097: “Certainly I do. But those words are apt to cover different meanings to
5098: different minds.”
5099: 
5100: “Precisely. And on such subjects wrong teaching is as fatal as no
5101: teaching. Now a point which I have much at heart to secure is a new
5102: regulation as to clerical attendance at the old infirmary. The building
5103: stands in Mr. Farebrother’s parish. You know Mr. Farebrother?”
5104: 
5105: “I have seen him. He gave me his vote. I must call to thank him. He
5106: seems a very bright pleasant little fellow. And I understand he is a
5107: naturalist.”
5108: 
5109: “Mr. Farebrother, my dear sir, is a man deeply painful to contemplate.
5110: I suppose there is not a clergyman in this country who has greater
5111: talents.” Mr. Bulstrode paused and looked meditative.
5112: 
5113: “I have not yet been pained by finding any excessive talent in
5114: Middlemarch,” said Lydgate, bluntly.
5115: 
5116: “What I desire,” Mr. Bulstrode continued, looking still more serious,
5117: “is that Mr. Farebrother’s attendance at the hospital should be
5118: superseded by the appointment of a chaplain—of Mr. Tyke, in fact—and
5119: that no other spiritual aid should be called in.”
5120: 
5121: “As a medical man I could have no opinion on such a point unless I knew
5122: Mr. Tyke, and even then I should require to know the cases in which he
5123: was applied.” Lydgate smiled, but he was bent on being circumspect.
5124: 
5125: “Of course you cannot enter fully into the merits of this measure at
5126: present. But”—here Mr. Bulstrode began to speak with a more chiselled
5127: emphasis—“the subject is likely to be referred to the medical board of
5128: the infirmary, and what I trust I may ask of you is, that in virtue of
5129: the cooperation between us which I now look forward to, you will not,
5130: so far as you are concerned, be influenced by my opponents in this
5131: matter.”
5132: 
5133: “I hope I shall have nothing to do with clerical disputes,” said
5134: Lydgate. “The path I have chosen is to work well in my own profession.”
5135: 
5136: “My responsibility, Mr. Lydgate, is of a broader kind. With me, indeed,
5137: this question is one of sacred accountableness; whereas with my
5138: opponents, I have good reason to say that it is an occasion for
5139: gratifying a spirit of worldly opposition. But I shall not therefore
5140: drop one iota of my convictions, or cease to identify myself with that
5141: truth which an evil generation hates. I have devoted myself to this
5142: object of hospital-improvement, but I will boldly confess to you, Mr.
5143: Lydgate, that I should have no interest in hospitals if I believed that
5144: nothing more was concerned therein than the cure of mortal diseases. I
5145: have another ground of action, and in the face of persecution I will
5146: not conceal it.”
5147: 
5148: Mr. Bulstrode’s voice had become a loud and agitated whisper as he said
5149: the last words.
5150: 
5151: “There we certainly differ,” said Lydgate. But he was not sorry that
5152: the door was now opened, and Mr. Vincy was announced. That florid
5153: sociable personage was become more interesting to him since he had seen
5154: Rosamond. Not that, like her, he had been weaving any future in which
5155: their lots were united; but a man naturally remembers a charming girl
5156: with pleasure, and is willing to dine where he may see her again.
5157: Before he took leave, Mr. Vincy had given that invitation which he had
5158: been “in no hurry about,” for Rosamond at breakfast had mentioned that
5159: she thought her uncle Featherstone had taken the new doctor into great
5160: favor.
5161: 
5162: Mr. Bulstrode, alone with his brother-in-law, poured himself out a
5163: glass of water, and opened a sandwich-box.
5164: 
5165: “I cannot persuade you to adopt my regimen, Vincy?”
5166: 
5167: “No, no; I’ve no opinion of that system. Life wants padding,” said Mr.
5168: Vincy, unable to omit his portable theory. “However,” he went on,
5169: accenting the word, as if to dismiss all irrelevance, “what I came here
5170: to talk about was a little affair of my young scapegrace, Fred’s.”
5171: 
5172: “That is a subject on which you and I are likely to take quite as
5173: different views as on diet, Vincy.”
5174: 
5175: “I hope not this time.” (Mr. Vincy was resolved to be good-humored.)
5176: “The fact is, it’s about a whim of old Featherstone’s. Somebody has
5177: been cooking up a story out of spite, and telling it to the old man, to
5178: try to set him against Fred. He’s very fond of Fred, and is likely to
5179: do something handsome for him; indeed he has as good as told Fred that
5180: he means to leave him his land, and that makes other people jealous.”
5181: 
5182: “Vincy, I must repeat, that you will not get any concurrence from me as
5183: to the course you have pursued with your eldest son. It was entirely
5184: from worldly vanity that you destined him for the Church: with a family
5185: of three sons and four daughters, you were not warranted in devoting
5186: money to an expensive education which has succeeded in nothing but in
5187: giving him extravagant idle habits. You are now reaping the
5188: consequences.”
5189: 
5190: To point out other people’s errors was a duty that Mr. Bulstrode rarely
5191: shrank from, but Mr. Vincy was not equally prepared to be patient. When
5192: a man has the immediate prospect of being mayor, and is ready, in the
5193: interests of commerce, to take up a firm attitude on politics
5194: generally, he has naturally a sense of his importance to the framework
5195: of things which seems to throw questions of private conduct into the
5196: background. And this particular reproof irritated him more than any
5197: other. It was eminently superfluous to him to be told that he was
5198: reaping the consequences. But he felt his neck under Bulstrode’s yoke;
5199: and though he usually enjoyed kicking, he was anxious to refrain from
5200: that relief.
5201: 
5202: “As to that, Bulstrode, it’s no use going back. I’m not one of your
5203: pattern men, and I don’t pretend to be. I couldn’t foresee everything
5204: in the trade; there wasn’t a finer business in Middlemarch than ours,
5205: and the lad was clever. My poor brother was in the Church, and would
5206: have done well—had got preferment already, but that stomach fever took
5207: him off: else he might have been a dean by this time. I think I was
5208: justified in what I tried to do for Fred. If you come to religion, it
5209: seems to me a man shouldn’t want to carve out his meat to an ounce
5210: beforehand:—one must trust a little to Providence and be generous. It’s
5211: a good British feeling to try and raise your family a little: in my
5212: opinion, it’s a father’s duty to give his sons a fine chance.”
5213: 
5214: “I don’t wish to act otherwise than as your best friend, Vincy, when I
5215: say that what you have been uttering just now is one mass of
5216: worldliness and inconsistent folly.”
5217: 
5218: “Very well,” said Mr. Vincy, kicking in spite of resolutions, “I never
5219: professed to be anything but worldly; and, what’s more, I don’t see
5220: anybody else who is not worldly. I suppose you don’t conduct business
5221: on what you call unworldly principles. The only difference I see is
5222: that one worldliness is a little bit honester than another.”
5223: 
5224: “This kind of discussion is unfruitful, Vincy,” said Mr. Bulstrode,
5225: who, finishing his sandwich, had thrown himself back in his chair, and
5226: shaded his eyes as if weary. “You had some more particular business.”
5227: 
5228: “Yes, yes. The long and short of it is, somebody has told old
5229: Featherstone, giving you as the authority, that Fred has been borrowing
5230: or trying to borrow money on the prospect of his land. Of course you
5231: never said any such nonsense. But the old fellow will insist on it that
5232: Fred should bring him a denial in your handwriting; that is, just a bit
5233: of a note saying you don’t believe a word of such stuff, either of his
5234: having borrowed or tried to borrow in such a fool’s way. I suppose you
5235: can have no objection to do that.”
5236: 
5237: “Pardon me. I have an objection. I am by no means sure that your son,
5238: in his recklessness and ignorance—I will use no severer word—has not
5239: tried to raise money by holding out his future prospects, or even that
5240: some one may not have been foolish enough to supply him on so vague a
5241: presumption: there is plenty of such lax money-lending as of other
5242: folly in the world.”
5243: 
5244: “But Fred gives me his honor that he has never borrowed money on the
5245: pretence of any understanding about his uncle’s land. He is not a liar.
5246: I don’t want to make him better than he is. I have blown him up
5247: well—nobody can say I wink at what he does. But he is not a liar. And I
5248: should have thought—but I may be wrong—that there was no religion to
5249: hinder a man from believing the best of a young fellow, when you don’t
5250: know worse. It seems to me it would be a poor sort of religion to put a
5251: spoke in his wheel by refusing to say you don’t believe such harm of
5252: him as you’ve got no good reason to believe.”
5253: 
5254: “I am not at all sure that I should be befriending your son by
5255: smoothing his way to the future possession of Featherstone’s property.
5256: I cannot regard wealth as a blessing to those who use it simply as a
5257: harvest for this world. You do not like to hear these things, Vincy,
5258: but on this occasion I feel called upon to tell you that I have no
5259: motive for furthering such a disposition of property as that which you
5260: refer to. I do not shrink from saying that it will not tend to your
5261: son’s eternal welfare or to the glory of God. Why then should you
5262: expect me to pen this kind of affidavit, which has no object but to
5263: keep up a foolish partiality and secure a foolish bequest?”
5264: 
5265: “If you mean to hinder everybody from having money but saints and
5266: evangelists, you must give up some profitable partnerships, that’s all
5267: I can say,” Mr. Vincy burst out very bluntly. “It may be for the glory
5268: of God, but it is not for the glory of the Middlemarch trade, that
5269: Plymdale’s house uses those blue and green dyes it gets from the
5270: Brassing manufactory; they rot the silk, that’s all I know about it.
5271: Perhaps if other people knew so much of the profit went to the glory of
5272: God, they might like it better. But I don’t mind so much about that—I
5273: could get up a pretty row, if I chose.”
5274: 
5275: Mr. Bulstrode paused a little before he answered. “You pain me very
5276: much by speaking in this way, Vincy. I do not expect you to understand
5277: my grounds of action—it is not an easy thing even to thread a path for
5278: principles in the intricacies of the world—still less to make the
5279: thread clear for the careless and the scoffing. You must remember, if
5280: you please, that I stretch my tolerance towards you as my wife’s
5281: brother, and that it little becomes you to complain of me as
5282: withholding material help towards the worldly position of your family.
5283: I must remind you that it is not your own prudence or judgment that has
5284: enabled you to keep your place in the trade.”
5285: 
5286: “Very likely not; but you have been no loser by my trade yet,” said Mr.
5287: Vincy, thoroughly nettled (a result which was seldom much retarded by
5288: previous resolutions). “And when you married Harriet, I don’t see how
5289: you could expect that our families should not hang by the same nail. If
5290: you’ve changed your mind, and want my family to come down in the world,
5291: you’d better say so. I’ve never changed; I’m a plain Churchman now,
5292: just as I used to be before doctrines came up. I take the world as I
5293: find it, in trade and everything else. I’m contented to be no worse
5294: than my neighbors. But if you want us to come down in the world, say
5295: so. I shall know better what to do then.”
5296: 
5297: “You talk unreasonably. Shall you come down in the world for want of
5298: this letter about your son?”
5299: 
5300: “Well, whether or not, I consider it very unhandsome of you to refuse
5301: it. Such doings may be lined with religion, but outside they have a
5302: nasty, dog-in-the-manger look. You might as well slander Fred: it comes
5303: pretty near to it when you refuse to say you didn’t set a slander
5304: going. It’s this sort of thing—this tyrannical spirit, wanting to play
5305: bishop and banker everywhere—it’s this sort of thing makes a man’s name
5306: stink.”
5307: 
5308: “Vincy, if you insist on quarrelling with me, it will be exceedingly
5309: painful to Harriet as well as myself,” said Mr. Bulstrode, with a
5310: trifle more eagerness and paleness than usual.
5311: 
5312: “I don’t want to quarrel. It’s for my interest—and perhaps for yours
5313: too—that we should be friends. I bear you no grudge; I think no worse
5314: of you than I do of other people. A man who half starves himself, and
5315: goes the length in family prayers, and so on, that you do, believes in
5316: his religion whatever it may be: you could turn over your capital just
5317: as fast with cursing and swearing:—plenty of fellows do. You like to be
5318: master, there’s no denying that; you must be first chop in heaven, else
5319: you won’t like it much. But you’re my sister’s husband, and we ought to
5320: stick together; and if I know Harriet, she’ll consider it your fault if
5321: we quarrel because you strain at a gnat in this way, and refuse to do
5322: Fred a good turn. And I don’t mean to say I shall bear it well. I
5323: consider it unhandsome.”
5324: 
5325: Mr. Vincy rose, began to button his great-coat, and looked steadily at
5326: his brother-in-law, meaning to imply a demand for a decisive answer.
5327: 
5328: This was not the first time that Mr. Bulstrode had begun by admonishing
5329: Mr. Vincy, and had ended by seeing a very unsatisfactory reflection of
5330: himself in the coarse unflattering mirror which that manufacturer’s
5331: mind presented to the subtler lights and shadows of his fellow-men; and
5332: perhaps his experience ought to have warned him how the scene would
5333: end. But a full-fed fountain will be generous with its waters even in
5334: the rain, when they are worse than useless; and a fine fount of
5335: admonition is apt to be equally irrepressible.
5336: 
5337: It was not in Mr. Bulstrode’s nature to comply directly in consequence
5338: of uncomfortable suggestions. Before changing his course, he always
5339: needed to shape his motives and bring them into accordance with his
5340: habitual standard. He said, at last—
5341: 
5342: “I will reflect a little, Vincy. I will mention the subject to Harriet.
5343: I shall probably send you a letter.”
5344: 
5345: “Very well. As soon as you can, please. I hope it will all be settled
5346: before I see you to-morrow.”
5347: 
5348: 
5349: 
5350: 
5351: CHAPTER XIV.
5352: 
5353: “Follows here the strict receipt
5354: For that sauce to dainty meat,
5355: Named Idleness, which many eat
5356: By preference, and call it sweet:
5357: _First watch for morsels, like a hound
5358: Mix well with buffets, stir them round
5359: With good thick oil of flatteries, And froth with mean self-lauding
5360: lies.
5361: Serve warm: the vessels you must choose
5362: To keep it in are dead men’s shoes._”
5363: 
5364: 
5365: Mr. Bulstrode’s consultation of Harriet seemed to have had the effect
5366: desired by Mr. Vincy, for early the next morning a letter came which
5367: Fred could carry to Mr. Featherstone as the required testimony.
5368: 
5369: The old gentleman was staying in bed on account of the cold weather,
5370: and as Mary Garth was not to be seen in the sitting-room, Fred went
5371: up-stairs immediately and presented the letter to his uncle, who,
5372: propped up comfortably on a bed-rest, was not less able than usual to
5373: enjoy his consciousness of wisdom in distrusting and frustrating
5374: mankind. He put on his spectacles to read the letter, pursing up his
5375: lips and drawing down their corners.
5376: 
5377: “_Under the circumstances I will not decline to state my
5378: conviction_—tchah! what fine words the fellow puts! He’s as fine as an
5379: auctioneer—_that your son Frederic has not obtained any advance of
5380: money on bequests promised by Mr. Featherstone_—promised? who said I
5381: had ever promised? I promise nothing—I shall make codicils as long as I
5382: like—_and that considering the nature of such a proceeding, it is
5383: unreasonable to presume that a young man of sense and character would
5384: attempt it_—ah, but the gentleman doesn’t say you are a young man of
5385: sense and character, mark you that, sir!—_As to my own concern with any
5386: report of such a nature, I distinctly affirm that I never made any
5387: statement to the effect that your son had borrowed money on any
5388: property that might accrue to him on Mr. Featherstone’s demise_—bless
5389: my heart! ‘property’—accrue—demise! Lawyer Standish is nothing to him.
5390: He couldn’t speak finer if he wanted to borrow. Well,” Mr. Featherstone
5391: here looked over his spectacles at Fred, while he handed back the
5392: letter to him with a contemptuous gesture, “you don’t suppose I believe
5393: a thing because Bulstrode writes it out fine, eh?”
5394: 
5395: Fred colored. “You wished to have the letter, sir. I should think it
5396: very likely that Mr. Bulstrode’s denial is as good as the authority
5397: which told you what he denies.”
5398: 
5399: “Every bit. I never said I believed either one or the other. And now
5400: what d’ you expect?” said Mr. Featherstone, curtly, keeping on his
5401: spectacles, but withdrawing his hands under his wraps.
5402: 
5403: “I expect nothing, sir.” Fred with difficulty restrained himself from
5404: venting his irritation. “I came to bring you the letter. If you like I
5405: will bid you good morning.”
5406: 
5407: “Not yet, not yet. Ring the bell; I want missy to come.”
5408: 
5409: It was a servant who came in answer to the bell.
5410: 
5411: “Tell missy to come!” said Mr. Featherstone, impatiently. “What
5412: business had she to go away?” He spoke in the same tone when Mary came.
5413: 
5414: “Why couldn’t you sit still here till I told you to go? I want my
5415: waistcoat now. I told you always to put it on the bed.”
5416: 
5417: Mary’s eyes looked rather red, as if she had been crying. It was clear
5418: that Mr. Featherstone was in one of his most snappish humors this
5419: morning, and though Fred had now the prospect of receiving the
5420: much-needed present of money, he would have preferred being free to
5421: turn round on the old tyrant and tell him that Mary Garth was too good
5422: to be at his beck. Though Fred had risen as she entered the room, she
5423: had barely noticed him, and looked as if her nerves were quivering with
5424: the expectation that something would be thrown at her. But she never
5425: had anything worse than words to dread. When she went to reach the
5426: waistcoat from a peg, Fred went up to her and said, “Allow me.”
5427: 
5428: “Let it alone! You bring it, missy, and lay it down here,” said Mr.
5429: Featherstone. “Now you go away again till I call you,” he added, when
5430: the waistcoat was laid down by him. It was usual with him to season his
5431: pleasure in showing favor to one person by being especially
5432: disagreeable to another, and Mary was always at hand to furnish the
5433: condiment. When his own relatives came she was treated better. Slowly
5434: he took out a bunch of keys from the waistcoat pocket, and slowly he
5435: drew forth a tin box which was under the bed-clothes.
5436: 
5437: “You expect I am going to give you a little fortune, eh?” he said,
5438: looking above his spectacles and pausing in the act of opening the lid.
5439: 
5440: “Not at all, sir. You were good enough to speak of making me a present
5441: the other day, else, of course, I should not have thought of the
5442: matter.” But Fred was of a hopeful disposition, and a vision had
5443: presented itself of a sum just large enough to deliver him from a
5444: certain anxiety. When Fred got into debt, it always seemed to him
5445: highly probable that something or other—he did not necessarily conceive
5446: what—would come to pass enabling him to pay in due time. And now that
5447: the providential occurrence was apparently close at hand, it would have
5448: been sheer absurdity to think that the supply would be short of the
5449: need: as absurd as a faith that believed in half a miracle for want of
5450: strength to believe in a whole one.
5451: 
5452: The deep-veined hands fingered many bank-notes one after the other,
5453: laying them down flat again, while Fred leaned back in his chair,
5454: scorning to look eager. He held himself to be a gentleman at heart, and
5455: did not like courting an old fellow for his money. At last, Mr.
5456: Featherstone eyed him again over his spectacles and presented him with
5457: a little sheaf of notes: Fred could see distinctly that there were but
5458: five, as the less significant edges gaped towards him. But then, each
5459: might mean fifty pounds. He took them, saying—
5460: 
5461: “I am very much obliged to you, sir,” and was going to roll them up
5462: without seeming to think of their value. But this did not suit Mr.
5463: Featherstone, who was eying him intently.
5464: 
5465: “Come, don’t you think it worth your while to count ’em? You take money
5466: like a lord; I suppose you lose it like one.”
5467: 
5468: “I thought I was not to look a gift-horse in the mouth, sir. But I
5469: shall be very happy to count them.”
5470: 
5471: Fred was not so happy, however, after he had counted them. For they
5472: actually presented the absurdity of being less than his hopefulness had
5473: decided that they must be. What can the fitness of things mean, if not
5474: their fitness to a man’s expectations? Failing this, absurdity and
5475: atheism gape behind him. The collapse for Fred was severe when he found
5476: that he held no more than five twenties, and his share in the higher
5477: education of this country did not seem to help him. Nevertheless he
5478: said, with rapid changes in his fair complexion—
5479: 
5480: “It is very handsome of you, sir.”
5481: 
5482: “I should think it is,” said Mr. Featherstone, locking his box and
5483: replacing it, then taking off his spectacles deliberately, and at
5484: length, as if his inward meditation had more deeply convinced him,
5485: repeating, “I should think it handsome.”
5486: 
5487: “I assure you, sir, I am very grateful,” said Fred, who had had time to
5488: recover his cheerful air.
5489: 
5490: “So you ought to be. You want to cut a figure in the world, and I
5491: reckon Peter Featherstone is the only one you’ve got to trust to.” Here
5492: the old man’s eyes gleamed with a curiously mingled satisfaction in the
5493: consciousness that this smart young fellow relied upon him, and that
5494: the smart young fellow was rather a fool for doing so.
5495: 
5496: “Yes, indeed: I was not born to very splendid chances. Few men have
5497: been more cramped than I have been,” said Fred, with some sense of
5498: surprise at his own virtue, considering how hardly he was dealt with.
5499: “It really seems a little too bad to have to ride a broken-winded
5500: hunter, and see men, who, are not half such good judges as yourself,
5501: able to throw away any amount of money on buying bad bargains.”
5502: 
5503: “Well, you can buy yourself a fine hunter now. Eighty pound is enough
5504: for that, I reckon—and you’ll have twenty pound over to get yourself
5505: out of any little scrape,” said Mr. Featherstone, chuckling slightly.
5506: 
5507: “You are very good, sir,” said Fred, with a fine sense of contrast
5508: between the words and his feeling.
5509: 
5510: “Ay, rather a better uncle than your fine uncle Bulstrode. You won’t
5511: get much out of his spekilations, I think. He’s got a pretty strong
5512: string round your father’s leg, by what I hear, eh?”
5513: 
5514: “My father never tells me anything about his affairs, sir.”
5515: 
5516: “Well, he shows some sense there. But other people find ’em out without
5517: his telling. _He’ll_ never have much to leave you: he’ll most-like die
5518: without a will—he’s the sort of man to do it—let ’em make him mayor of
5519: Middlemarch as much as they like. But you won’t get much by his dying
5520: without a will, though you _are_ the eldest son.”
5521: 
5522: Fred thought that Mr. Featherstone had never been so disagreeable
5523: before. True, he had never before given him quite so much money at
5524: once.
5525: 
5526: “Shall I destroy this letter of Mr. Bulstrode’s, sir?” said Fred,
5527: rising with the letter as if he would put it in the fire.
5528: 
5529: “Ay, ay, I don’t want it. It’s worth no money to me.”
5530: 
5531: Fred carried the letter to the fire, and thrust the poker through it
5532: with much zest. He longed to get out of the room, but he was a little
5533: ashamed before his inner self, as well as before his uncle, to run away
5534: immediately after pocketing the money. Presently, the farm-bailiff came
5535: up to give his master a report, and Fred, to his unspeakable relief,
5536: was dismissed with the injunction to come again soon.
5537: 
5538: He had longed not only to be set free from his uncle, but also to find
5539: Mary Garth. She was now in her usual place by the fire, with sewing in
5540: her hands and a book open on the little table by her side. Her eyelids
5541: had lost some of their redness now, and she had her usual air of
5542: self-command.
5543: 
5544: “Am I wanted up-stairs?” she said, half rising as Fred entered.
5545: 
5546: “No; I am only dismissed, because Simmons is gone up.”
5547: 
5548: Mary sat down again, and resumed her work. She was certainly treating
5549: him with more indifference than usual: she did not know how
5550: affectionately indignant he had felt on her behalf up-stairs.
5551: 
5552: “May I stay here a little, Mary, or shall I bore you?”
5553: 
5554: “Pray sit down,” said Mary; “you will not be so heavy a bore as Mr.
5555: John Waule, who was here yesterday, and he sat down without asking my
5556: leave.”
5557: 
5558: “Poor fellow! I think he is in love with you.”
5559: 
5560: “I am not aware of it. And to me it is one of the most odious things in
5561: a girl’s life, that there must always be some supposition of falling in
5562: love coming between her and any man who is kind to her, and to whom she
5563: is grateful. I should have thought that I, at least, might have been
5564: safe from all that. I have no ground for the nonsensical vanity of
5565: fancying everybody who comes near me is in love with me.”
5566: 
5567: Mary did not mean to betray any feeling, but in spite of herself she
5568: ended in a tremulous tone of vexation.
5569: 
5570: “Confound John Waule! I did not mean to make you angry. I didn’t know
5571: you had any reason for being grateful to me. I forgot what a great
5572: service you think it if any one snuffs a candle for you.” Fred also had
5573: his pride, and was not going to show that he knew what had called forth
5574: this outburst of Mary’s.
5575: 
5576: “Oh, I am not angry, except with the ways of the world. I do like to be
5577: spoken to as if I had common-sense. I really often feel as if I could
5578: understand a little more than I ever hear even from young gentlemen who
5579: have been to college.” Mary had recovered, and she spoke with a
5580: suppressed rippling under-current of laughter pleasant to hear.
5581: 
5582: “I don’t care how merry you are at my expense this morning,” said Fred,
5583: “I thought you looked so sad when you came up-stairs. It is a shame you
5584: should stay here to be bullied in that way.”
5585: 
5586: “Oh, I have an easy life—by comparison. I have tried being a teacher,
5587: and I am not fit for that: my mind is too fond of wandering on its own
5588: way. I think any hardship is better than pretending to do what one is
5589: paid for, and never really doing it. Everything here I can do as well
5590: as any one else could; perhaps better than some—Rosy, for example.
5591: Though she is just the sort of beautiful creature that is imprisoned
5592: with ogres in fairy tales.”
5593: 
5594: “_Rosy!_” cried Fred, in a tone of profound brotherly scepticism.
5595: 
5596: “Come, Fred!” said Mary, emphatically; “you have no right to be so
5597: critical.”
5598: 
5599: “Do you mean anything particular—just now?”
5600: 
5601: “No, I mean something general—always.”
5602: 
5603: “Oh, that I am idle and extravagant. Well, I am not fit to be a poor
5604: man. I should not have made a bad fellow if I had been rich.”
5605: 
5606: “You would have done your duty in that state of life to which it has
5607: not pleased God to call you,” said Mary, laughing.
5608: 
5609: “Well, I couldn’t do my duty as a clergyman, any more than you could do
5610: yours as a governess. You ought to have a little fellow-feeling there,
5611: Mary.”
5612: 
5613: “I never said you ought to be a clergyman. There are other sorts of
5614: work. It seems to me very miserable not to resolve on some course and
5615: act accordingly.”
5616: 
5617: “So I could, if—” Fred broke off, and stood up, leaning against the
5618: mantel-piece.
5619: 
5620: “If you were sure you should not have a fortune?”
5621: 
5622: “I did not say that. You want to quarrel with me. It is too bad of you
5623: to be guided by what other people say about me.”
5624: 
5625: “How can I want to quarrel with you? I should be quarrelling with all
5626: my new books,” said Mary, lifting the volume on the table. “However
5627: naughty you may be to other people, you are good to me.”
5628: 
5629: “Because I like you better than any one else. But I know you despise
5630: me.”
5631: 
5632: “Yes, I do—a little,” said Mary, nodding, with a smile.
5633: 
5634: “You would admire a stupendous fellow, who would have wise opinions
5635: about everything.”
5636: 
5637: “Yes, I should.” Mary was sewing swiftly, and seemed provokingly
5638: mistress of the situation. When a conversation has taken a wrong turn
5639: for us, we only get farther and farther into the swamp of awkwardness.
5640: This was what Fred Vincy felt.
5641: 
5642: “I suppose a woman is never in love with any one she has always
5643: known—ever since she can remember; as a man often is. It is always some
5644: new fellow who strikes a girl.”
5645: 
5646: “Let me see,” said Mary, the corners of her mouth curling archly; “I
5647: must go back on my experience. There is Juliet—she seems an example of
5648: what you say. But then Ophelia had probably known Hamlet a long while;
5649: and Brenda Troil—she had known Mordaunt Merton ever since they were
5650: children; but then he seems to have been an estimable young man; and
5651: Minna was still more deeply in love with Cleveland, who was a stranger.
5652: Waverley was new to Flora MacIvor; but then she did not fall in love
5653: with him. And there are Olivia and Sophia Primrose, and Corinne—they
5654: may be said to have fallen in love with new men. Altogether, my
5655: experience is rather mixed.”
5656: 
5657: Mary looked up with some roguishness at Fred, and that look of hers was
5658: very dear to him, though the eyes were nothing more than clear windows
5659: where observation sat laughingly. He was certainly an affectionate
5660: fellow, and as he had grown from boy to man, he had grown in love with
5661: his old playmate, notwithstanding that share in the higher education of
5662: the country which had exalted his views of rank and income.
5663: 
5664: “When a man is not loved, it is no use for him to say that he could be
5665: a better fellow—could do anything—I mean, if he were sure of being
5666: loved in return.”
5667: 
5668: “Not of the least use in the world for him to say he _could_ be better.
5669: Might, could, would—they are contemptible auxiliaries.”
5670: 
5671: “I don’t see how a man is to be good for much unless he has some one
5672: woman to love him dearly.”
5673: 
5674: “I think the goodness should come before he expects that.”
5675: 
5676: “You know better, Mary. Women don’t love men for their goodness.”
5677: 
5678: “Perhaps not. But if they love them, they never think them bad.”
5679: 
5680: “It is hardly fair to say I am bad.”
5681: 
5682: “I said nothing at all about you.”
5683: 
5684: “I never shall be good for anything, Mary, if you will not say that you
5685: love me—if you will not promise to marry me—I mean, when I am able to
5686: marry.”
5687: 
5688: “If I did love you, I would not marry you: I would certainly not
5689: promise ever to marry you.”
5690: 
5691: “I think that is quite wicked, Mary. If you love me, you ought to
5692: promise to marry me.”
5693: 
5694: “On the contrary, I think it would be wicked in me to marry you even if
5695: I did love you.”
5696: 
5697: “You mean, just as I am, without any means of maintaining a wife. Of
5698: course: I am but three-and-twenty.”
5699: 
5700: “In that last point you will alter. But I am not so sure of any other
5701: alteration. My father says an idle man ought not to exist, much less,
5702: be married.”
5703: 
5704: “Then I am to blow my brains out?”
5705: 
5706: “No; on the whole I should think you would do better to pass your
5707: examination. I have heard Mr. Farebrother say it is disgracefully
5708: easy.”
5709: 
5710: “That is all very fine. Anything is easy to him. Not that cleverness
5711: has anything to do with it. I am ten times cleverer than many men who
5712: pass.”
5713: 
5714: “Dear me!” said Mary, unable to repress her sarcasm; “that accounts for
5715: the curates like Mr. Crowse. Divide your cleverness by ten, and the
5716: quotient—dear me!—is able to take a degree. But that only shows you are
5717: ten times more idle than the others.”
5718: 
5719: “Well, if I did pass, you would not want me to go into the Church?”
5720: 
5721: “That is not the question—what I want you to do. You have a conscience
5722: of your own, I suppose. There! there is Mr. Lydgate. I must go and tell
5723: my uncle.”
5724: 
5725: “Mary,” said Fred, seizing her hand as she rose; “if you will not give
5726: me some encouragement, I shall get worse instead of better.”
5727: 
5728: “I will not give you any encouragement,” said Mary, reddening. “Your
5729: friends would dislike it, and so would mine. My father would think it a
5730: disgrace to me if I accepted a man who got into debt, and would not
5731: work!”
5732: 
5733: Fred was stung, and released her hand. She walked to the door, but
5734: there she turned and said: “Fred, you have always been so good, so
5735: generous to me. I am not ungrateful. But never speak to me in that way
5736: again.”
5737: 
5738: “Very well,” said Fred, sulkily, taking up his hat and whip. His
5739: complexion showed patches of pale pink and dead white. Like many a
5740: plucked idle young gentleman, he was thoroughly in love, and with a
5741: plain girl, who had no money! But having Mr. Featherstone’s land in the
5742: background, and a persuasion that, let Mary say what she would, she
5743: really did care for him, Fred was not utterly in despair.
5744: 
5745: When he got home, he gave four of the twenties to his mother, asking
5746: her to keep them for him. “I don’t want to spend that money, mother. I
5747: want it to pay a debt with. So keep it safe away from my fingers.”
5748: 
5749: “Bless you, my dear,” said Mrs. Vincy. She doted on her eldest son and
