5750: her youngest girl (a child of six), whom others thought her two
5751: naughtiest children. The mother’s eyes are not always deceived in their
5752: partiality: she at least can best judge who is the tender,
5753: filial-hearted child. And Fred was certainly very fond of his mother.
5754: Perhaps it was his fondness for another person also that made him
5755: particularly anxious to take some security against his own liability to
5756: spend the hundred pounds. For the creditor to whom he owed a hundred
5757: and sixty held a firmer security in the shape of a bill signed by
5758: Mary’s father.
5759: 
5760: 
5761: 
5762: 
5763: CHAPTER XV.
5764: 
5765: “Black eyes you have left, you say,
5766:     Blue eyes fail to draw you;
5767: Yet you seem more rapt to-day,
5768:     Than of old we saw you.
5769: 
5770: “Oh, I track the fairest fair
5771:     Through new haunts of pleasure;
5772: Footprints here and echoes there
5773:     Guide me to my treasure:
5774: 
5775: “Lo! she turns—immortal youth
5776:     Wrought to mortal stature,
5777: Fresh as starlight’s aged truth—
5778:     Many-namèd Nature!”
5779: 
5780: 
5781: A great historian, as he insisted on calling himself, who had the
5782: happiness to be dead a hundred and twenty years ago, and so to take his
5783: place among the colossi whose huge legs our living pettiness is
5784: observed to walk under, glories in his copious remarks and digressions
5785: as the least imitable part of his work, and especially in those initial
5786: chapters to the successive books of his history, where he seems to
5787: bring his armchair to the proscenium and chat with us in all the lusty
5788: ease of his fine English. But Fielding lived when the days were longer
5789: (for time, like money, is measured by our needs), when summer
5790: afternoons were spacious, and the clock ticked slowly in the winter
5791: evenings. We belated historians must not linger after his example; and
5792: if we did so, it is probable that our chat would be thin and eager, as
5793: if delivered from a campstool in a parrot-house. I at least have so
5794: much to do in unraveling certain human lots, and seeing how they were
5795: woven and interwoven, that all the light I can command must be
5796: concentrated on this particular web, and not dispersed over that
5797: tempting range of relevancies called the universe.
5798: 
5799: At present I have to make the new settler Lydgate better known to any
5800: one interested in him than he could possibly be even to those who had
5801: seen the most of him since his arrival in Middlemarch. For surely all
5802: must admit that a man may be puffed and belauded, envied, ridiculed,
5803: counted upon as a tool and fallen in love with, or at least selected as
5804: a future husband, and yet remain virtually unknown—known merely as a
5805: cluster of signs for his neighbors’ false suppositions. There was a
5806: general impression, however, that Lydgate was not altogether a common
5807: country doctor, and in Middlemarch at that time such an impression was
5808: significant of great things being expected from him. For everybody’s
5809: family doctor was remarkably clever, and was understood to have
5810: immeasurable skill in the management and training of the most skittish
5811: or vicious diseases. The evidence of his cleverness was of the higher
5812: intuitive order, lying in his lady-patients’ immovable conviction, and
5813: was unassailable by any objection except that their intuitions were
5814: opposed by others equally strong; each lady who saw medical truth in
5815: Wrench and “the strengthening treatment” regarding Toller and “the
5816: lowering system” as medical perdition. For the heroic times of copious
5817: bleeding and blistering had not yet departed, still less the times of
5818: thorough-going theory, when disease in general was called by some bad
5819: name, and treated accordingly without shilly-shally—as if, for example,
5820: it were to be called insurrection, which must not be fired on with
5821: blank-cartridge, but have its blood drawn at once. The strengtheners
5822: and the lowerers were all “clever” men in somebody’s opinion, which is
5823: really as much as can be said for any living talents. Nobody’s
5824: imagination had gone so far as to conjecture that Mr. Lydgate could
5825: know as much as Dr. Sprague and Dr. Minchin, the two physicians, who
5826: alone could offer any hope when danger was extreme, and when the
5827: smallest hope was worth a guinea. Still, I repeat, there was a general
5828: impression that Lydgate was something rather more uncommon than any
5829: general practitioner in Middlemarch. And this was true. He was but
5830: seven-and-twenty, an age at which many men are not quite common—at
5831: which they are hopeful of achievement, resolute in avoidance, thinking
5832: that Mammon shall never put a bit in their mouths and get astride their
5833: backs, but rather that Mammon, if they have anything to do with him,
5834: shall draw their chariot.
5835: 
5836: He had been left an orphan when he was fresh from a public school. His
5837: father, a military man, had made but little provision for three
5838: children, and when the boy Tertius asked to have a medical education,
5839: it seemed easier to his guardians to grant his request by apprenticing
5840: him to a country practitioner than to make any objections on the score
5841: of family dignity. He was one of the rarer lads who early get a decided
5842: bent and make up their minds that there is something particular in life
5843: which they would like to do for its own sake, and not because their
5844: fathers did it. Most of us who turn to any subject with love remember
5845: some morning or evening hour when we got on a high stool to reach down
5846: an untried volume, or sat with parted lips listening to a new talker,
5847: or for very lack of books began to listen to the voices within, as the
5848: first traceable beginning of our love. Something of that sort happened
5849: to Lydgate. He was a quick fellow, and when hot from play, would toss
5850: himself in a corner, and in five minutes be deep in any sort of book
5851: that he could lay his hands on: if it were Rasselas or Gulliver, so
5852: much the better, but Bailey’s Dictionary would do, or the Bible with
5853: the Apocrypha in it. Something he must read, when he was not riding the
5854: pony, or running and hunting, or listening to the talk of men. All this
5855: was true of him at ten years of age; he had then read through “Chrysal,
5856: or the Adventures of a Guinea,” which was neither milk for babes, nor
5857: any chalky mixture meant to pass for milk, and it had already occurred
5858: to him that books were stuff, and that life was stupid. His school
5859: studies had not much modified that opinion, for though he “did” his
5860: classics and mathematics, he was not pre-eminent in them. It was said
5861: of him, that Lydgate could do anything he liked, but he had certainly
5862: not yet liked to do anything remarkable. He was a vigorous animal with
5863: a ready understanding, but no spark had yet kindled in him an
5864: intellectual passion; knowledge seemed to him a very superficial
5865: affair, easily mastered: judging from the conversation of his elders,
5866: he had apparently got already more than was necessary for mature life.
5867: Probably this was not an exceptional result of expensive teaching at
5868: that period of short-waisted coats, and other fashions which have not
5869: yet recurred. But, one vacation, a wet day sent him to the small home
5870: library to hunt once more for a book which might have some freshness
5871: for him: in vain! unless, indeed, he took down a dusty row of volumes
5872: with gray-paper backs and dingy labels—the volumes of an old
5873: Cyclopaedia which he had never disturbed. It would at least be a
5874: novelty to disturb them. They were on the highest shelf, and he stood
5875: on a chair to get them down. But he opened the volume which he first
5876: took from the shelf: somehow, one is apt to read in a makeshift
5877: attitude, just where it might seem inconvenient to do so. The page he
5878: opened on was under the head of Anatomy, and the first passage that
5879: drew his eyes was on the valves of the heart. He was not much
5880: acquainted with valves of any sort, but he knew that valvae were
5881: folding-doors, and through this crevice came a sudden light startling
5882: him with his first vivid notion of finely adjusted mechanism in the
5883: human frame. A liberal education had of course left him free to read
5884: the indecent passages in the school classics, but beyond a general
5885: sense of secrecy and obscenity in connection with his internal
5886: structure, had left his imagination quite unbiassed, so that for
5887: anything he knew his brains lay in small bags at his temples, and he
5888: had no more thought of representing to himself how his blood circulated
5889: than how paper served instead of gold. But the moment of vocation had
5890: come, and before he got down from his chair, the world was made new to
5891: him by a presentiment of endless processes filling the vast spaces
5892: planked out of his sight by that wordy ignorance which he had supposed
5893: to be knowledge. From that hour Lydgate felt the growth of an
5894: intellectual passion.
5895: 
5896: We are not afraid of telling over and over again how a man comes to
5897: fall in love with a woman and be wedded to her, or else be fatally
5898: parted from her. Is it due to excess of poetry or of stupidity that we
5899: are never weary of describing what King James called a woman’s “makdom
5900: and her fairnesse,” never weary of listening to the twanging of the old
5901: Troubadour strings, and are comparatively uninterested in that other
5902: kind of “makdom and fairnesse” which must be wooed with industrious
5903: thought and patient renunciation of small desires? In the story of this
5904: passion, too, the development varies: sometimes it is the glorious
5905: marriage, sometimes frustration and final parting. And not seldom the
5906: catastrophe is bound up with the other passion, sung by the
5907: Troubadours. For in the multitude of middle-aged men who go about their
5908: vocations in a daily course determined for them much in the same way as
5909: the tie of their cravats, there is always a good number who once meant
5910: to shape their own deeds and alter the world a little. The story of
5911: their coming to be shapen after the average and fit to be packed by the
5912: gross, is hardly ever told even in their consciousness; for perhaps
5913: their ardor in generous unpaid toil cooled as imperceptibly as the
5914: ardor of other youthful loves, till one day their earlier self walked
5915: like a ghost in its old home and made the new furniture ghastly.
5916: Nothing in the world more subtle than the process of their gradual
5917: change! In the beginning they inhaled it unknowingly: you and I may
5918: have sent some of our breath towards infecting them, when we uttered
5919: our conforming falsities or drew our silly conclusions: or perhaps it
5920: came with the vibrations from a woman’s glance.
5921: 
5922: Lydgate did not mean to be one of those failures, and there was the
5923: better hope of him because his scientific interest soon took the form
5924: of a professional enthusiasm: he had a youthful belief in his
5925: bread-winning work, not to be stifled by that initiation in makeshift
5926: called his ’prentice days; and he carried to his studies in London,
5927: Edinburgh, and Paris, the conviction that the medical profession as it
5928: might be was the finest in the world; presenting the most perfect
5929: interchange between science and art; offering the most direct alliance
5930: between intellectual conquest and the social good. Lydgate’s nature
5931: demanded this combination: he was an emotional creature, with a
5932: flesh-and-blood sense of fellowship which withstood all the
5933: abstractions of special study. He cared not only for “cases,” but for
5934: John and Elizabeth, especially Elizabeth.
5935: 
5936: There was another attraction in his profession: it wanted reform, and
5937: gave a man an opportunity for some indignant resolve to reject its
5938: venal decorations and other humbug, and to be the possessor of genuine
5939: though undemanded qualifications. He went to study in Paris with the
5940: determination that when he came home again he would settle in some
5941: provincial town as a general practitioner, and resist the irrational
5942: severance between medical and surgical knowledge in the interest of his
5943: own scientific pursuits, as well as of the general advance: he would
5944: keep away from the range of London intrigues, jealousies, and social
5945: truckling, and win celebrity, however slowly, as Jenner had done, by
5946: the independent value of his work. For it must be remembered that this
5947: was a dark period; and in spite of venerable colleges which used great
5948: efforts to secure purity of knowledge by making it scarce, and to
5949: exclude error by a rigid exclusiveness in relation to fees and
5950: appointments, it happened that very ignorant young gentlemen were
5951: promoted in town, and many more got a legal right to practise over
5952: large areas in the country. Also, the high standard held up to the
5953: public mind by the College of Physicians, which gave its peculiar
5954: sanction to the expensive and highly rarefied medical instruction
5955: obtained by graduates of Oxford and Cambridge, did not hinder quackery
5956: from having an excellent time of it; for since professional practice
5957: chiefly consisted in giving a great many drugs, the public inferred
5958: that it might be better off with more drugs still, if they could only
5959: be got cheaply, and hence swallowed large cubic measures of physic
5960: prescribed by unscrupulous ignorance which had taken no degrees.
5961: Considering that statistics had not yet embraced a calculation as to
5962: the number of ignorant or canting doctors which absolutely must exist
5963: in the teeth of all changes, it seemed to Lydgate that a change in the
5964: units was the most direct mode of changing the numbers. He meant to be
5965: a unit who would make a certain amount of difference towards that
5966: spreading change which would one day tell appreciably upon the
5967: averages, and in the mean time have the pleasure of making an
5968: advantageous difference to the viscera of his own patients. But he did
5969: not simply aim at a more genuine kind of practice than was common. He
5970: was ambitious of a wider effect: he was fired with the possibility that
5971: he might work out the proof of an anatomical conception and make a link
5972: in the chain of discovery.
5973: 
5974: Does it seem incongruous to you that a Middlemarch surgeon should dream
5975: of himself as a discoverer? Most of us, indeed, know little of the
5976: great originators until they have been lifted up among the
5977: constellations and already rule our fates. But that Herschel, for
5978: example, who “broke the barriers of the heavens”—did he not once play a
5979: provincial church-organ, and give music-lessons to stumbling pianists?
5980: Each of those Shining Ones had to walk on the earth among neighbors who
5981: perhaps thought much more of his gait and his garments than of anything
5982: which was to give him a title to everlasting fame: each of them had his
5983: little local personal history sprinkled with small temptations and
5984: sordid cares, which made the retarding friction of his course towards
5985: final companionship with the immortals. Lydgate was not blind to the
5986: dangers of such friction, but he had plenty of confidence in his
5987: resolution to avoid it as far as possible: being seven-and-twenty, he
5988: felt himself experienced. And he was not going to have his vanities
5989: provoked by contact with the showy worldly successes of the capital,
5990: but to live among people who could hold no rivalry with that pursuit of
5991: a great idea which was to be a twin object with the assiduous practice
5992: of his profession. There was fascination in the hope that the two
5993: purposes would illuminate each other: the careful observation and
5994: inference which was his daily work, the use of the lens to further his
5995: judgment in special cases, would further his thought as an instrument
5996: of larger inquiry. Was not this the typical pre-eminence of his
5997: profession? He would be a good Middlemarch doctor, and by that very
5998: means keep himself in the track of far-reaching investigation. On one
5999: point he may fairly claim approval at this particular stage of his
6000: career: he did not mean to imitate those philanthropic models who make
6001: a profit out of poisonous pickles to support themselves while they are
6002: exposing adulteration, or hold shares in a gambling-hell that they may
6003: have leisure to represent the cause of public morality. He intended to
6004: begin in his own case some particular reforms which were quite
6005: certainly within his reach, and much less of a problem than the
6006: demonstrating of an anatomical conception. One of these reforms was to
6007: act stoutly on the strength of a recent legal decision, and simply
6008: prescribe, without dispensing drugs or taking percentage from
6009: druggists. This was an innovation for one who had chosen to adopt the
6010: style of general practitioner in a country town, and would be felt as
6011: offensive criticism by his professional brethren. But Lydgate meant to
6012: innovate in his treatment also, and he was wise enough to see that the
6013: best security for his practising honestly according to his belief was
6014: to get rid of systematic temptations to the contrary.
6015: 
6016: Perhaps that was a more cheerful time for observers and theorizers than
6017: the present; we are apt to think it the finest era of the world when
6018: America was beginning to be discovered, when a bold sailor, even if he
6019: were wrecked, might alight on a new kingdom; and about 1829 the dark
6020: territories of Pathology were a fine America for a spirited young
6021: adventurer. Lydgate was ambitious above all to contribute towards
6022: enlarging the scientific, rational basis of his profession. The more he
6023: became interested in special questions of disease, such as the nature
6024: of fever or fevers, the more keenly he felt the need for that
6025: fundamental knowledge of structure which just at the beginning of the
6026: century had been illuminated by the brief and glorious career of
6027: Bichat, who died when he was only one-and-thirty, but, like another
6028: Alexander, left a realm large enough for many heirs. That great
6029: Frenchman first carried out the conception that living bodies,
6030: fundamentally considered, are not associations of organs which can be
6031: understood by studying them first apart, and then as it were federally;
6032: but must be regarded as consisting of certain primary webs or tissues,
6033: out of which the various organs—brain, heart, lungs, and so on—are
6034: compacted, as the various accommodations of a house are built up in
6035: various proportions of wood, iron, stone, brick, zinc, and the rest,
6036: each material having its peculiar composition and proportions. No man,
6037: one sees, can understand and estimate the entire structure or its
6038: parts—what are its frailties and what its repairs, without knowing the
6039: nature of the materials. And the conception wrought out by Bichat, with
6040: his detailed study of the different tissues, acted necessarily on
6041: medical questions as the turning of gas-light would act on a dim,
6042: oil-lit street, showing new connections and hitherto hidden facts of
6043: structure which must be taken into account in considering the symptoms
6044: of maladies and the action of medicaments. But results which depend on
6045: human conscience and intelligence work slowly, and now at the end of
6046: 1829, most medical practice was still strutting or shambling along the
6047: old paths, and there was still scientific work to be done which might
6048: have seemed to be a direct sequence of Bichat’s. This great seer did
6049: not go beyond the consideration of the tissues as ultimate facts in the
6050: living organism, marking the limit of anatomical analysis; but it was
6051: open to another mind to say, have not these structures some common
6052: basis from which they have all started, as your sarsnet, gauze, net,
6053: satin, and velvet from the raw cocoon? Here would be another light, as
6054: of oxy-hydrogen, showing the very grain of things, and revising all
6055: former explanations. Of this sequence to Bichat’s work, already
6056: vibrating along many currents of the European mind, Lydgate was
6057: enamoured; he longed to demonstrate the more intimate relations of
6058: living structure, and help to define men’s thought more accurately
6059: after the true order. The work had not yet been done, but only prepared
6060: for those who knew how to use the preparation. What was the primitive
6061: tissue? In that way Lydgate put the question—not quite in the way
6062: required by the awaiting answer; but such missing of the right word
6063: befalls many seekers. And he counted on quiet intervals to be
6064: watchfully seized, for taking up the threads of investigation—on many
6065: hints to be won from diligent application, not only of the scalpel, but
6066: of the microscope, which research had begun to use again with new
6067: enthusiasm of reliance. Such was Lydgate’s plan of his future: to do
6068: good small work for Middlemarch, and great work for the world.
6069: 
6070: He was certainly a happy fellow at this time: to be seven-and-twenty,
6071: without any fixed vices, with a generous resolution that his action
6072: should be beneficent, and with ideas in his brain that made life
6073: interesting quite apart from the cultus of horseflesh and other mystic
6074: rites of costly observance, which the eight hundred pounds left him
6075: after buying his practice would certainly not have gone far in paying
6076: for. He was at a starting-point which makes many a man’s career a fine
6077: subject for betting, if there were any gentlemen given to that
6078: amusement who could appreciate the complicated probabilities of an
6079: arduous purpose, with all the possible thwartings and furtherings of
6080: circumstance, all the niceties of inward balance, by which a man swims
6081: and makes his point or else is carried headlong. The risk would remain
6082: even with close knowledge of Lydgate’s character; for character too is
6083: a process and an unfolding. The man was still in the making, as much as
6084: the Middlemarch doctor and immortal discoverer, and there were both
6085: virtues and faults capable of shrinking or expanding. The faults will
6086: not, I hope, be a reason for the withdrawal of your interest in him.
6087: Among our valued friends is there not some one or other who is a little
6088: too self-confident and disdainful; whose distinguished mind is a little
6089: spotted with commonness; who is a little pinched here and protuberant
6090: there with native prejudices; or whose better energies are liable to
6091: lapse down the wrong channel under the influence of transient
6092: solicitations? All these things might be alleged against Lydgate, but
6093: then, they are the periphrases of a polite preacher, who talks of Adam,
6094: and would not like to mention anything painful to the pew-renters. The
6095: particular faults from which these delicate generalities are distilled
6096: have distinguishable physiognomies, diction, accent, and grimaces;
6097: filling up parts in very various dramas. Our vanities differ as our
6098: noses do: all conceit is not the same conceit, but varies in
6099: correspondence with the minutiae of mental make in which one of us
6100: differs from another. Lydgate’s conceit was of the arrogant sort, never
6101: simpering, never impertinent, but massive in its claims and
6102: benevolently contemptuous. He would do a great deal for noodles, being
6103: sorry for them, and feeling quite sure that they could have no power
6104: over him: he had thought of joining the Saint Simonians when he was in
6105: Paris, in order to turn them against some of their own doctrines. All
6106: his faults were marked by kindred traits, and were those of a man who
6107: had a fine baritone, whose clothes hung well upon him, and who even in
6108: his ordinary gestures had an air of inbred distinction. Where then lay
6109: the spots of commonness? says a young lady enamoured of that careless
6110: grace. How could there be any commonness in a man so well-bred, so
6111: ambitious of social distinction, so generous and unusual in his views
6112: of social duty? As easily as there may be stupidity in a man of genius
6113: if you take him unawares on the wrong subject, or as many a man who has
6114: the best will to advance the social millennium might be ill-inspired in
6115: imagining its lighter pleasures; unable to go beyond Offenbach’s music,
6116: or the brilliant punning in the last burlesque. Lydgate’s spots of
6117: commonness lay in the complexion of his prejudices, which, in spite of
6118: noble intention and sympathy, were half of them such as are found in
6119: ordinary men of the world: that distinction of mind which belonged to
6120: his intellectual ardor, did not penetrate his feeling and judgment
6121: about furniture, or women, or the desirability of its being known
6122: (without his telling) that he was better born than other country
6123: surgeons. He did not mean to think of furniture at present; but
6124: whenever he did so it was to be feared that neither biology nor schemes
6125: of reform would lift him above the vulgarity of feeling that there
6126: would be an incompatibility in his furniture not being of the best.
6127: 
6128: As to women, he had once already been drawn headlong by impetuous
6129: folly, which he meant to be final, since marriage at some distant
6130: period would of course not be impetuous. For those who want to be
6131: acquainted with Lydgate it will be good to know what was that case of
6132: impetuous folly, for it may stand as an example of the fitful swerving
6133: of passion to which he was prone, together with the chivalrous kindness
6134: which helped to make him morally lovable. The story can be told without
6135: many words. It happened when he was studying in Paris, and just at the
6136: time when, over and above his other work, he was occupied with some
6137: galvanic experiments. One evening, tired with his experimenting, and
6138: not being able to elicit the facts he needed, he left his frogs and
6139: rabbits to some repose under their trying and mysterious dispensation
6140: of unexplained shocks, and went to finish his evening at the theatre of
6141: the Porte Saint Martin, where there was a melodrama which he had
6142: already seen several times; attracted, not by the ingenious work of the
6143: collaborating authors, but by an actress whose part it was to stab her
6144: lover, mistaking him for the evil-designing duke of the piece. Lydgate
6145: was in love with this actress, as a man is in love with a woman whom he
6146: never expects to speak to. She was a Provencale, with dark eyes, a
6147: Greek profile, and rounded majestic form, having that sort of beauty
6148: which carries a sweet matronliness even in youth, and her voice was a
6149: soft cooing. She had but lately come to Paris, and bore a virtuous
6150: reputation, her husband acting with her as the unfortunate lover. It
6151: was her acting which was “no better than it should be,” but the public
6152: was satisfied. Lydgate’s only relaxation now was to go and look at this
6153: woman, just as he might have thrown himself under the breath of the
6154: sweet south on a bank of violets for a while, without prejudice to his
6155: galvanism, to which he would presently return. But this evening the old
6156: drama had a new catastrophe. At the moment when the heroine was to act
6157: the stabbing of her lover, and he was to fall gracefully, the wife
6158: veritably stabbed her husband, who fell as death willed. A wild shriek
6159: pierced the house, and the Provencale fell swooning: a shriek and a
6160: swoon were demanded by the play, but the swooning too was real this
6161: time. Lydgate leaped and climbed, he hardly knew how, on to the stage,
6162: and was active in help, making the acquaintance of his heroine by
6163: finding a contusion on her head and lifting her gently in his arms.
6164: Paris rang with the story of this death:—was it a murder? Some of the
6165: actress’s warmest admirers were inclined to believe in her guilt, and
6166: liked her the better for it (such was the taste of those times); but
6167: Lydgate was not one of these. He vehemently contended for her
6168: innocence, and the remote impersonal passion for her beauty which he
6169: had felt before, had passed now into personal devotion, and tender
6170: thought of her lot. The notion of murder was absurd: no motive was
6171: discoverable, the young couple being understood to dote on each other;
6172: and it was not unprecedented that an accidental slip of the foot should
6173: have brought these grave consequences. The legal investigation ended in
6174: Madame Laure’s release. Lydgate by this time had had many interviews
6175: with her, and found her more and more adorable. She talked little; but
6176: that was an additional charm. She was melancholy, and seemed grateful;
6177: her presence was enough, like that of the evening light. Lydgate was
6178: madly anxious about her affection, and jealous lest any other man than
6179: himself should win it and ask her to marry him. But instead of
6180: reopening her engagement at the Porte Saint Martin, where she would
6181: have been all the more popular for the fatal episode, she left Paris
6182: without warning, forsaking her little court of admirers. Perhaps no one
6183: carried inquiry far except Lydgate, who felt that all science had come
6184: to a stand-still while he imagined the unhappy Laure, stricken by
6185: ever-wandering sorrow, herself wandering, and finding no faithful
6186: comforter. Hidden actresses, however, are not so difficult to find as
6187: some other hidden facts, and it was not long before Lydgate gathered
6188: indications that Laure had taken the route to Lyons. He found her at
6189: last acting with great success at Avignon under the same name, looking
6190: more majestic than ever as a forsaken wife carrying her child in her
6191: arms. He spoke to her after the play, was received with the usual
6192: quietude which seemed to him beautiful as clear depths of water, and
6193: obtained leave to visit her the next day; when he was bent on telling
6194: her that he adored her, and on asking her to marry him. He knew that
6195: this was like the sudden impulse of a madman—incongruous even with his
6196: habitual foibles. No matter! It was the one thing which he was resolved
6197: to do. He had two selves within him apparently, and they must learn to
6198: accommodate each other and bear reciprocal impediments. Strange, that
6199: some of us, with quick alternate vision, see beyond our infatuations,
6200: and even while we rave on the heights, behold the wide plain where our
6201: persistent self pauses and awaits us.
6202: 
6203: To have approached Laure with any suit that was not reverentially
6204: tender would have been simply a contradiction of his whole feeling
6205: towards her.
6206: 
6207: “You have come all the way from Paris to find me?” she said to him the
6208: next day, sitting before him with folded arms, and looking at him with
6209: eyes that seemed to wonder as an untamed ruminating animal wonders.
6210: “Are all Englishmen like that?”
6211: 
6212: “I came because I could not live without trying to see you. You are
6213: lonely; I love you; I want you to consent to be my wife; I will wait,
6214: but I want you to promise that you will marry me—no one else.”
6215: 
6216: Laure looked at him in silence with a melancholy radiance from under
6217: her grand eyelids, until he was full of rapturous certainty, and knelt
6218: close to her knees.
6219: 
6220: “I will tell you something,” she said, in her cooing way, keeping her
6221: arms folded. “My foot really slipped.”
6222: 
6223: “I know, I know,” said Lydgate, deprecatingly. “It was a fatal
6224: accident—a dreadful stroke of calamity that bound me to you the more.”
6225: 
6226: Again Laure paused a little and then said, slowly, “_I meant to do
6227: it._”
6228: 
6229: Lydgate, strong man as he was, turned pale and trembled: moments seemed
6230: to pass before he rose and stood at a distance from her.
6231: 
6232: “There was a secret, then,” he said at last, even vehemently. “He was
6233: brutal to you: you hated him.”
6234: 
6235: “No! he wearied me; he was too fond: he would live in Paris, and not in
6236: my country; that was not agreeable to me.”
6237: 
6238: “Great God!” said Lydgate, in a groan of horror. “And you planned to
6239: murder him?”
6240: 
6241: “I did not plan: it came to me in the play—_I meant to do it._”
6242: 
6243: Lydgate stood mute, and unconsciously pressed his hat on while he
6244: looked at her. He saw this woman—the first to whom he had given his
6245: young adoration—amid the throng of stupid criminals.
6246: 
6247: “You are a good young man,” she said. “But I do not like husbands. I
6248: will never have another.”
6249: 
6250: Three days afterwards Lydgate was at his galvanism again in his Paris
6251: chambers, believing that illusions were at an end for him. He was saved
6252: from hardening effects by the abundant kindness of his heart and his
6253: belief that human life might be made better. But he had more reason
6254: than ever for trusting his judgment, now that it was so experienced;
6255: and henceforth he would take a strictly scientific view of woman,
6256: entertaining no expectations but such as were justified beforehand.
6257: 
6258: No one in Middlemarch was likely to have such a notion of Lydgate’s
6259: past as has here been faintly shadowed, and indeed the respectable
6260: townsfolk there were not more given than mortals generally to any eager
6261: attempt at exactness in the representation to themselves of what did
6262: not come under their own senses. Not only young virgins of that town,
6263: but gray-bearded men also, were often in haste to conjecture how a new
6264: acquaintance might be wrought into their purposes, contented with very
6265: vague knowledge as to the way in which life had been shaping him for
6266: that instrumentality. Middlemarch, in fact, counted on swallowing
6267: Lydgate and assimilating him very comfortably.
6268: 
6269: 
6270: 
6271: 
6272: CHAPTER XVI.
6273: 
6274: “All that in woman is adored
6275:     In thy fair self I find—
6276: For the whole sex can but afford
6277:     The handsome and the kind.”
6278: —SIR CHARLES SEDLEY.
6279: 
6280: 
6281: The question whether Mr. Tyke should be appointed as salaried chaplain
6282: to the hospital was an exciting topic to the Middlemarchers; and
6283: Lydgate heard it discussed in a way that threw much light on the power
6284: exercised in the town by Mr. Bulstrode. The banker was evidently a
6285: ruler, but there was an opposition party, and even among his supporters
6286: there were some who allowed it to be seen that their support was a
6287: compromise, and who frankly stated their impression that the general
6288: scheme of things, and especially the casualties of trade, required you
6289: to hold a candle to the devil.
6290: 
6291: Mr. Bulstrode’s power was not due simply to his being a country banker,
6292: who knew the financial secrets of most traders in the town and could
6293: touch the springs of their credit; it was fortified by a beneficence
6294: that was at once ready and severe—ready to confer obligations, and
6295: severe in watching the result. He had gathered, as an industrious man
6296: always at his post, a chief share in administering the town charities,
6297: and his private charities were both minute and abundant. He would take
6298: a great deal of pains about apprenticing Tegg the shoemaker’s son, and
6299: he would watch over Tegg’s church-going; he would defend Mrs. Strype
6300: the washerwoman against Stubbs’s unjust exaction on the score of her
6301: drying-ground, and he would himself scrutinize a calumny against Mrs.
6302: Strype. His private minor loans were numerous, but he would inquire
6303: strictly into the circumstances both before and after. In this way a
6304: man gathers a domain in his neighbors’ hope and fear as well as
6305: gratitude; and power, when once it has got into that subtle region,
6306: propagates itself, spreading out of all proportion to its external
6307: means. It was a principle with Mr. Bulstrode to gain as much power as
6308: possible, that he might use it for the glory of God. He went through a
6309: great deal of spiritual conflict and inward argument in order to adjust
6310: his motives, and make clear to himself what God’s glory required. But,
6311: as we have seen, his motives were not always rightly appreciated. There
6312: were many crass minds in Middlemarch whose reflective scales could only
6313: weigh things in the lump; and they had a strong suspicion that since
6314: Mr. Bulstrode could not enjoy life in their fashion, eating and
6315: drinking so little as he did, and worreting himself about everything,
6316: he must have a sort of vampire’s feast in the sense of mastery.
6317: 
6318: The subject of the chaplaincy came up at Mr. Vincy’s table when Lydgate
6319: was dining there, and the family connection with Mr. Bulstrode did not,
6320: he observed, prevent some freedom of remark even on the part of the
6321: host himself, though his reasons against the proposed arrangement
6322: turned entirely on his objection to Mr. Tyke’s sermons, which were all
6323: doctrine, and his preference for Mr. Farebrother, whose sermons were
6324: free from that taint. Mr. Vincy liked well enough the notion of the
6325: chaplain’s having a salary, supposing it were given to Farebrother, who
6326: was as good a little fellow as ever breathed, and the best preacher
6327: anywhere, and companionable too.
6328: 
6329: “What line shall you take, then?” said Mr. Chichely, the coroner, a
6330: great coursing comrade of Mr. Vincy’s.
6331: 
6332: “Oh, I’m precious glad I’m not one of the Directors now. I shall vote
6333: for referring the matter to the Directors and the Medical Board
6334: together. I shall roll some of my responsibility on your shoulders,
6335: Doctor,” said Mr. Vincy, glancing first at Dr. Sprague, the senior
6336: physician of the town, and then at Lydgate who sat opposite. “You
6337: medical gentlemen must consult which sort of black draught you will
6338: prescribe, eh, Mr. Lydgate?”
6339: 
6340: “I know little of either,” said Lydgate; “but in general, appointments
6341: are apt to be made too much a question of personal liking. The fittest
6342: man for a particular post is not always the best fellow or the most
6343: agreeable. Sometimes, if you wanted to get a reform, your only way
6344: would be to pension off the good fellows whom everybody is fond of, and
6345: put them out of the question.”
6346: 
6347: Dr. Sprague, who was considered the physician of most “weight,” though
6348: Dr. Minchin was usually said to have more “penetration,” divested his
6349: large heavy face of all expression, and looked at his wine-glass while
6350: Lydgate was speaking. Whatever was not problematical and suspected
6351: about this young man—for example, a certain showiness as to foreign
6352: ideas, and a disposition to unsettle what had been settled and
6353: forgotten by his elders—was positively unwelcome to a physician whose
6354: standing had been fixed thirty years before by a treatise on
6355: Meningitis, of which at least one copy marked “own” was bound in calf.
6356: For my part I have some fellow-feeling with Dr. Sprague: one’s
6357: self-satisfaction is an untaxed kind of property which it is very
6358: unpleasant to find deprecated.
6359: 
6360: Lydgate’s remark, however, did not meet the sense of the company. Mr.
6361: Vincy said, that if he could have _his_ way, he would not put
6362: disagreeable fellows anywhere.
6363: 
6364: “Hang your reforms!” said Mr. Chichely. “There’s no greater humbug in
6365: the world. You never hear of a reform, but it means some trick to put
6366: in new men. I hope you are not one of the ‘Lancet’s’ men, Mr.
6367: Lydgate—wanting to take the coronership out of the hands of the legal
6368: profession: your words appear to point that way.”
6369: 
6370: “I disapprove of Wakley,” interposed Dr. Sprague, “no man more: he is
6371: an ill-intentioned fellow, who would sacrifice the respectability of
6372: the profession, which everybody knows depends on the London Colleges,
6373: for the sake of getting some notoriety for himself. There are men who
6374: don’t mind about being kicked blue if they can only get talked about.
6375: But Wakley is right sometimes,” the Doctor added, judicially. “I could
6376: mention one or two points in which Wakley is in the right.”
6377: 
6378: “Oh, well,” said Mr. Chichely, “I blame no man for standing up in favor
6379: of his own cloth; but, coming to argument, I should like to know how a
6380: coroner is to judge of evidence if he has not had a legal training?”
6381: 
6382: “In my opinion,” said Lydgate, “legal training only makes a man more
6383: incompetent in questions that require knowledge of another kind. People
6384: talk about evidence as if it could really be weighed in scales by a
6385: blind Justice. No man can judge what is good evidence on any particular
6386: subject, unless he knows that subject well. A lawyer is no better than
6387: an old woman at a post-mortem examination. How is he to know the action
6388: of a poison? You might as well say that scanning verse will teach you
6389: to scan the potato crops.”
6390: 
6391: “You are aware, I suppose, that it is not the coroner’s business to
6392: conduct the _post-mortem_, but only to take the evidence of the medical
6393: witness?” said Mr. Chichely, with some scorn.
6394: 
6395: “Who is often almost as ignorant as the coroner himself,” said Lydgate.
6396: “Questions of medical jurisprudence ought not to be left to the chance
6397: of decent knowledge in a medical witness, and the coroner ought not to
6398: be a man who will believe that strychnine will destroy the coats of the
6399: stomach if an ignorant practitioner happens to tell him so.”
6400: 
6401: Lydgate had really lost sight of the fact that Mr. Chichely was his
6402: Majesty’s coroner, and ended innocently with the question, “Don’t you
6403: agree with me, Dr. Sprague?”
6404: 
6405: “To a certain extent—with regard to populous districts, and in the
6406: metropolis,” said the Doctor. “But I hope it will be long before this
6407: part of the country loses the services of my friend Chichely, even
6408: though it might get the best man in our profession to succeed him. I am
6409: sure Vincy will agree with me.”
6410: 
6411: “Yes, yes, give me a coroner who is a good coursing man,” said Mr.
6412: Vincy, jovially. “And in my opinion, you’re safest with a lawyer.
6413: Nobody can know everything. Most things are ‘visitation of God.’ And as
6414: to poisoning, why, what you want to know is the law. Come, shall we
6415: join the ladies?”
6416: 
6417: Lydgate’s private opinion was that Mr. Chichely might be the very
6418: coroner without bias as to the coats of the stomach, but he had not
6419: meant to be personal. This was one of the difficulties of moving in
6420: good Middlemarch society: it was dangerous to insist on knowledge as a
6421: qualification for any salaried office. Fred Vincy had called Lydgate a
6422: prig, and now Mr. Chichely was inclined to call him prick-eared;
6423: especially when, in the drawing-room, he seemed to be making himself
6424: eminently agreeable to Rosamond, whom he had easily monopolized in a
6425: _tête-à-tête_, since Mrs. Vincy herself sat at the tea-table. She
6426: resigned no domestic function to her daughter; and the matron’s
6427: blooming good-natured face, with the two volatile pink strings floating
6428: from her fine throat, and her cheery manners to husband and children,
6429: was certainly among the great attractions of the Vincy
6430: house—attractions which made it all the easier to fall in love with the
6431: daughter. The tinge of unpretentious, inoffensive vulgarity in Mrs.
6432: Vincy gave more effect to Rosamond’s refinement, which was beyond what
6433: Lydgate had expected.
6434: 
6435: Certainly, small feet and perfectly turned shoulders aid the impression
6436: of refined manners, and the right thing said seems quite astonishingly
6437: right when it is accompanied with exquisite curves of lip and eyelid.
6438: And Rosamond could say the right thing; for she was clever with that
6439: sort of cleverness which catches every tone except the humorous.
6440: Happily she never attempted to joke, and this perhaps was the most
6441: decisive mark of her cleverness.
6442: 
6443: She and Lydgate readily got into conversation. He regretted that he had
6444: not heard her sing the other day at Stone Court. The only pleasure he
6445: allowed himself during the latter part of his stay in Paris was to go
6446: and hear music.
6447: 
6448: “You have studied music, probably?” said Rosamond.
6449: 
6450: “No, I know the notes of many birds, and I know many melodies by ear;
6451: but the music that I don’t know at all, and have no notion about,
6452: delights me—affects me. How stupid the world is that it does not make
6453: more use of such a pleasure within its reach!”
6454: 
6455: “Yes, and you will find Middlemarch very tuneless. There are hardly any
6456: good musicians. I only know two gentlemen who sing at all well.”
6457: 
6458: “I suppose it is the fashion to sing comic songs in a rhythmic way,
6459: leaving you to fancy the tune—very much as if it were tapped on a
6460: drum?”
6461: 
6462: “Ah, you have heard Mr. Bowyer,” said Rosamond, with one of her rare
6463: smiles. “But we are speaking very ill of our neighbors.”
6464: 
6465: Lydgate was almost forgetting that he must carry on the conversation,
6466: in thinking how lovely this creature was, her garment seeming to be
6467: made out of the faintest blue sky, herself so immaculately blond, as if
6468: the petals of some gigantic flower had just opened and disclosed her;
6469: and yet with this infantine blondness showing so much ready,
6470: self-possessed grace. Since he had had the memory of Laure, Lydgate had
6471: lost all taste for large-eyed silence: the divine cow no longer
6472: attracted him, and Rosamond was her very opposite. But he recalled
6473: himself.
6474: 
6475: “You will let me hear some music to-night, I hope.”
6476: 
6477: “I will let you hear my attempts, if you like,” said Rosamond. “Papa is
6478: sure to insist on my singing. But I shall tremble before you, who have
6479: heard the best singers in Paris. I have heard very little: I have only
6480: once been to London. But our organist at St. Peter’s is a good
6481: musician, and I go on studying with him.”
6482: 
6483: “Tell me what you saw in London.”
6484: 
6485: “Very little.” (A more naive girl would have said, “Oh, everything!”
6486: But Rosamond knew better.) “A few of the ordinary sights, such as raw
6487: country girls are always taken to.”
6488: 
6489: “Do you call yourself a raw country girl?” said Lydgate, looking at her
6490: with an involuntary emphasis of admiration, which made Rosamond blush
6491: with pleasure. But she remained simply serious, turned her long neck a
6492: little, and put up her hand to touch her wondrous hair-plaits—an
6493: habitual gesture with her as pretty as any movements of a kitten’s paw.
6494: Not that Rosamond was in the least like a kitten: she was a sylph
6495: caught young and educated at Mrs. Lemon’s.
6496: 
6497: “I assure you my mind is raw,” she said immediately; “I pass at
6498: Middlemarch. I am not afraid of talking to our old neighbors. But I am
6499: really afraid of you.”
6500: 
6501: “An accomplished woman almost always knows more than we men, though her
6502: knowledge is of a different sort. I am sure you could teach me a
6503: thousand things—as an exquisite bird could teach a bear if there were
6504: any common language between them. Happily, there is a common language
6505: between women and men, and so the bears can get taught.”
6506: 
6507: “Ah, there is Fred beginning to strum! I must go and hinder him from
6508: jarring all your nerves,” said Rosamond, moving to the other side of
6509: the room, where Fred having opened the piano, at his father’s desire,
6510: that Rosamond might give them some music, was parenthetically
6511: performing “Cherry Ripe!” with one hand. Able men who have passed their
6512: examinations will do these things sometimes, not less than the plucked
6513: Fred.
6514: 
6515: “Fred, pray defer your practising till to-morrow; you will make Mr.
6516: Lydgate ill,” said Rosamond. “He has an ear.”
6517: 
6518: Fred laughed, and went on with his tune to the end.
6519: 
6520: Rosamond turned to Lydgate, smiling gently, and said, “You perceive,
6521: the bears will not always be taught.”
6522: 
6523: “Now then, Rosy!” said Fred, springing from the stool and twisting it
6524: upward for her, with a hearty expectation of enjoyment. “Some good
6525: rousing tunes first.”
6526: 
6527: Rosamond played admirably. Her master at Mrs. Lemon’s school (close to
6528: a county town with a memorable history that had its relics in church
6529: and castle) was one of those excellent musicians here and there to be
6530: found in our provinces, worthy to compare with many a noted
6531: Kapellmeister in a country which offers more plentiful conditions of
6532: musical celebrity. Rosamond, with the executant’s instinct, had seized
6533: his manner of playing, and gave forth his large rendering of noble
6534: music with the precision of an echo. It was almost startling, heard for
6535: the first time. A hidden soul seemed to be flowing forth from
6536: Rosamond’s fingers; and so indeed it was, since souls live on in
6537: perpetual echoes, and to all fine expression there goes somewhere an
6538: originating activity, if it be only that of an interpreter. Lydgate was
6539: taken possession of, and began to believe in her as something
6540: exceptional. After all, he thought, one need not be surprised to find
6541: the rare conjunctions of nature under circumstances apparently
6542: unfavorable: come where they may, they always depend on conditions that
6543: are not obvious. He sat looking at her, and did not rise to pay her any
6544: compliments, leaving that to others, now that his admiration was
6545: deepened.
6546: 
6547: Her singing was less remarkable, but also well trained, and sweet to
6548: hear as a chime perfectly in tune. It is true she sang “Meet me by
6549: moonlight,” and “I’ve been roaming”; for mortals must share the
6550: fashions of their time, and none but the ancients can be always
6551: classical. But Rosamond could also sing “Black-eyed Susan” with effect,
6552: or Haydn’s canzonets, or “Voi, che sapete,” or “Batti, batti”—she only
6553: wanted to know what her audience liked.
6554: 
6555: Her father looked round at the company, delighting in their admiration.
6556: Her mother sat, like a Niobe before her troubles, with her youngest
6557: little girl on her lap, softly beating the child’s hand up and down in
6558: time to the music. And Fred, notwithstanding his general scepticism
6559: about Rosy, listened to her music with perfect allegiance, wishing he
6560: could do the same thing on his flute. It was the pleasantest family
6561: party that Lydgate had seen since he came to Middlemarch. The Vincys
6562: had the readiness to enjoy, the rejection of all anxiety, and the
6563: belief in life as a merry lot, which made a house exceptional in most
6564: county towns at that time, when Evangelicalism had cast a certain
6565: suspicion as of plague-infection over the few amusements which survived
6566: in the provinces. At the Vincys’ there was always whist, and the
6567: card-tables stood ready now, making some of the company secretly
6568: impatient of the music. Before it ceased Mr. Farebrother came in—a
6569: handsome, broad-chested but otherwise small man, about forty, whose
6570: black was very threadbare: the brilliancy was all in his quick gray
6571: eyes. He came like a pleasant change in the light, arresting little
6572: Louisa with fatherly nonsense as she was being led out of the room by
6573: Miss Morgan, greeting everybody with some special word, and seeming to
6574: condense more talk into ten minutes than had been held all through the
6575: evening. He claimed from Lydgate the fulfilment of a promise to come
6576: and see him. “I can’t let you off, you know, because I have some
6577: beetles to show you. We collectors feel an interest in every new man
6578: till he has seen all we have to show him.”
6579: 
6580: But soon he swerved to the whist-table, rubbing his hands and saying,
6581: “Come now, let us be serious! Mr. Lydgate? not play? Ah! you are too
6582: young and light for this kind of thing.”
6583: 
6584: Lydgate said to himself that the clergyman whose abilities were so
6585: painful to Mr. Bulstrode, appeared to have found an agreeable resort in
6586: this certainly not erudite household. He could half understand it: the
6587: good-humor, the good looks of elder and younger, and the provision for
6588: passing the time without any labor of intelligence, might make the
6589: house beguiling to people who had no particular use for their odd
6590: hours.
6591: 
6592: Everything looked blooming and joyous except Miss Morgan, who was
6593: brown, dull, and resigned, and altogether, as Mrs. Vincy often said,
6594: just the sort of person for a governess. Lydgate did not mean to pay
6595: many such visits himself. They were a wretched waste of the evenings;
6596: and now, when he had talked a little more to Rosamond, he meant to
6597: excuse himself and go.
6598: 
6599: “You will not like us at Middlemarch, I feel sure,” she said, when the
6600: whist-players were settled. “We are very stupid, and you have been used
6601: to something quite different.”
6602: 
6603: “I suppose all country towns are pretty much alike,” said Lydgate. “But
6604: I have noticed that one always believes one’s own town to be more
6605: stupid than any other. I have made up my mind to take Middlemarch as it
6606: comes, and shall be much obliged if the town will take me in the same
6607: way. I have certainly found some charms in it which are much greater
6608: than I had expected.”
6609: 
6610: “You mean the rides towards Tipton and Lowick; every one is pleased
6611: with those,” said Rosamond, with simplicity.
6612: 
6613: “No, I mean something much nearer to me.”
6614: 
6615: Rosamond rose and reached her netting, and then said, “Do you care
6616: about dancing at all? I am not quite sure whether clever men ever
6617: dance.”
6618: 
6619: “I would dance with you if you would allow me.”
6620: 
6621: “Oh!” said Rosamond, with a slight deprecatory laugh. “I was only going
6622: to say that we sometimes have dancing, and I wanted to know whether you
6623: would feel insulted if you were asked to come.”
6624: 
6625: “Not on the condition I mentioned.”
6626: 
6627: After this chat Lydgate thought that he was going, but on moving
6628: towards the whist-tables, he got interested in watching Mr.
6629: Farebrother’s play, which was masterly, and also his face, which was a
6630: striking mixture of the shrewd and the mild. At ten o’clock supper was
6631: brought in (such were the customs of Middlemarch) and there was
6632: punch-drinking; but Mr. Farebrother had only a glass of water. He was
6633: winning, but there seemed to be no reason why the renewal of rubbers
6634: should end, and Lydgate at last took his leave.
6635: 
6636: But as it was not eleven o’clock, he chose to walk in the brisk air
6637: towards the tower of St. Botolph’s, Mr. Farebrother’s church, which
6638: stood out dark, square, and massive against the starlight. It was the
6639: oldest church in Middlemarch; the living, however, was but a vicarage
6640: worth barely four hundred a-year. Lydgate had heard that, and he
6641: wondered now whether Mr. Farebrother cared about the money he won at
6642: cards; thinking, “He seems a very pleasant fellow, but Bulstrode may
6643: have his good reasons.” Many things would be easier to Lydgate if it
6644: should turn out that Mr. Bulstrode was generally justifiable. “What is
6645: his religious doctrine to me, if he carries some good notions along
6646: with it? One must use such brains as are to be found.”
6647: 
6648: These were actually Lydgate’s first meditations as he walked away from
6649: Mr. Vincy’s, and on this ground I fear that many ladies will consider
6650: him hardly worthy of their attention. He thought of Rosamond and her
6651: music only in the second place; and though, when her turn came, he
6652: dwelt on the image of her for the rest of his walk, he felt no
6653: agitation, and had no sense that any new current had set into his life.
6654: He could not marry yet; he wished not to marry for several years; and
6655: therefore he was not ready to entertain the notion of being in love
6656: with a girl whom he happened to admire. He did admire Rosamond
6657: exceedingly; but that madness which had once beset him about Laure was
6658: not, he thought, likely to recur in relation to any other woman.
6659: Certainly, if falling in love had been at all in question, it would
6660: have been quite safe with a creature like this Miss Vincy, who had just
6661: the kind of intelligence one would desire in a woman—polished, refined,
6662: docile, lending itself to finish in all the delicacies of life, and
6663: enshrined in a body which expressed this with a force of demonstration
6664: that excluded the need for other evidence. Lydgate felt sure that if
6665: ever he married, his wife would have that feminine radiance, that
6666: distinctive womanhood which must be classed with flowers and music,
6667: that sort of beauty which by its very nature was virtuous, being
6668: moulded only for pure and delicate joys.
6669: 
6670: But since he did not mean to marry for the next five years—his more
6671: pressing business was to look into Louis’ new book on Fever, which he
6672: was specially interested in, because he had known Louis in Paris, and
6673: had followed many anatomical demonstrations in order to ascertain the
6674: specific differences of typhus and typhoid. He went home and read far
6675: into the smallest hour, bringing a much more testing vision of details
6676: and relations into this pathological study than he had ever thought it
6677: necessary to apply to the complexities of love and marriage, these
6678: being subjects on which he felt himself amply informed by literature,
6679: and that traditional wisdom which is handed down in the genial
6680: conversation of men. Whereas Fever had obscure conditions, and gave him
6681: that delightful labor of the imagination which is not mere
6682: arbitrariness, but the exercise of disciplined power—combining and
6683: constructing with the clearest eye for probabilities and the fullest
6684: obedience to knowledge; and then, in yet more energetic alliance with
6685: impartial Nature, standing aloof to invent tests by which to try its
6686: own work.
6687: 
6688: Many men have been praised as vividly imaginative on the strength of
6689: their profuseness in indifferent drawing or cheap narration:—reports of
6690: very poor talk going on in distant orbs; or portraits of Lucifer coming
6691: down on his bad errands as a large ugly man with bat’s wings and spurts
6692: of phosphorescence; or exaggerations of wantonness that seem to reflect
6693: life in a diseased dream. But these kinds of inspiration Lydgate
6694: regarded as rather vulgar and vinous compared with the imagination that
6695: reveals subtle actions inaccessible by any sort of lens, but tracked in
6696: that outer darkness through long pathways of necessary sequence by the
6697: inward light which is the last refinement of Energy, capable of bathing
6698: even the ethereal atoms in its ideally illuminated space. He for his
6699: part had tossed away all cheap inventions where ignorance finds itself
6700: able and at ease: he was enamoured of that arduous invention which is
6701: the very eye of research, provisionally framing its object and
6702: correcting it to more and more exactness of relation; he wanted to
6703: pierce the obscurity of those minute processes which prepare human
6704: misery and joy, those invisible thoroughfares which are the first
6705: lurking-places of anguish, mania, and crime, that delicate poise and
6706: transition which determine the growth of happy or unhappy
6707: consciousness.
6708: 
6709: As he threw down his book, stretched his legs towards the embers in the
6710: grate, and clasped his hands at the back of his head, in that agreeable
6711: afterglow of excitement when thought lapses from examination of a
6712: specific object into a suffusive sense of its connections with all the
6713: rest of our existence—seems, as it were, to throw itself on its back
6714: after vigorous swimming and float with the repose of unexhausted
6715: strength—Lydgate felt a triumphant delight in his studies, and
6716: something like pity for those less lucky men who were not of his
6717: profession.
6718: 
6719: “If I had not taken that turn when I was a lad,” he thought, “I might
6720: have got into some stupid draught-horse work or other, and lived always
6721: in blinkers. I should never have been happy in any profession that did
6722: not call forth the highest intellectual strain, and yet keep me in good
6723: warm contact with my neighbors. There is nothing like the medical
6724: profession for that: one can have the exclusive scientific life that
6725: touches the distance and befriend the old fogies in the parish too. It
6726: is rather harder for a clergyman: Farebrother seems to be an anomaly.”
6727: 
6728: This last thought brought back the Vincys and all the pictures of the
6729: evening. They floated in his mind agreeably enough, and as he took up
6730: his bed-candle his lips were curled with that incipient smile which is
6731: apt to accompany agreeable recollections. He was an ardent fellow, but
6732: at present his ardor was absorbed in love of his work and in the
6733: ambition of making his life recognized as a factor in the better life
6734: of mankind—like other heroes of science who had nothing but an obscure
6735: country practice to begin with.
6736: 
6737: Poor Lydgate! or shall I say, Poor Rosamond! Each lived in a world of
6738: which the other knew nothing. It had not occurred to Lydgate that he
6739: had been a subject of eager meditation to Rosamond, who had neither any
6740: reason for throwing her marriage into distant perspective, nor any
6741: pathological studies to divert her mind from that ruminating habit,
6742: that inward repetition of looks, words, and phrases, which makes a
6743: large part in the lives of most girls. He had not meant to look at her
6744: or speak to her with more than the inevitable amount of admiration and
6745: compliment which a man must give to a beautiful girl; indeed, it seemed
6746: to him that his enjoyment of her music had remained almost silent, for
6747: he feared falling into the rudeness of telling her his great surprise
6748: at her possession of such accomplishment. But Rosamond had registered
6749: every look and word, and estimated them as the opening incidents of a
6750: preconceived romance—incidents which gather value from the foreseen
6751: development and climax. In Rosamond’s romance it was not necessary to
6752: imagine much about the inward life of the hero, or of his serious
6753: business in the world: of course, he had a profession and was clever,
6754: as well as sufficiently handsome; but the piquant fact about Lydgate
6755: was his good birth, which distinguished him from all Middlemarch
6756: admirers, and presented marriage as a prospect of rising in rank and
6757: getting a little nearer to that celestial condition on earth in which
6758: she would have nothing to do with vulgar people, and perhaps at last
6759: associate with relatives quite equal to the county people who looked
6760: down on the Middlemarchers. It was part of Rosamond’s cleverness to
6761: discern very subtly the faintest aroma of rank, and once when she had
6762: seen the Miss Brookes accompanying their uncle at the county assizes,
6763: and seated among the aristocracy, she had envied them, notwithstanding
6764: their plain dress.
6765: 
6766: If you think it incredible that to imagine Lydgate as a man of family
6767: could cause thrills of satisfaction which had anything to do with the
6768: sense that she was in love with him, I will ask you to use your power
6769: of comparison a little more effectively, and consider whether red cloth
6770: and epaulets have never had an influence of that sort. Our passions do
6771: not live apart in locked chambers, but, dressed in their small wardrobe
6772: of notions, bring their provisions to a common table and mess together,
6773: feeding out of the common store according to their appetite.
6774: 
6775: Rosamond, in fact, was entirely occupied not exactly with Tertius
6776: Lydgate as he was in himself, but with his relation to her; and it was
6777: excusable in a girl who was accustomed to hear that all young men
6778: might, could, would be, or actually were in love with her, to believe
6779: at once that Lydgate could be no exception. His looks and words meant
6780: more to her than other men’s, because she cared more for them: she
6781: thought of them diligently, and diligently attended to that perfection
6782: of appearance, behavior, sentiments, and all other elegancies, which
6783: would find in Lydgate a more adequate admirer than she had yet been
6784: conscious of.
6785: 
6786: For Rosamond, though she would never do anything that was disagreeable
6787: to her, was industrious; and now more than ever she was active in
6788: sketching her landscapes and market-carts and portraits of friends, in
6789: practising her music, and in being from morning till night her own
6790: standard of a perfect lady, having always an audience in her own
6791: consciousness, with sometimes the not unwelcome addition of a more
6792: variable external audience in the numerous visitors of the house. She
6793: found time also to read the best novels, and even the second best, and
6794: she knew much poetry by heart. Her favorite poem was “Lalla Rookh.”
6795: 
6796: “The best girl in the world! He will be a happy fellow who gets her!”
6797: was the sentiment of the elderly gentlemen who visited the Vincys; and
6798: the rejected young men thought of trying again, as is the fashion in
6799: country towns where the horizon is not thick with coming rivals. But
6800: Mrs. Plymdale thought that Rosamond had been educated to a ridiculous
6801: pitch, for what was the use of accomplishments which would be all laid
6802: aside as soon as she was married? While her aunt Bulstrode, who had a
6803: sisterly faithfulness towards her brother’s family, had two sincere
6804: wishes for Rosamond—that she might show a more serious turn of mind,
6805: and that she might meet with a husband whose wealth corresponded to her
6806: habits.
6807: 
6808: 
6809: 
6810: 
6811: CHAPTER XVII.
6812: 
6813: “The clerkly person smiled and said
6814: Promise was a pretty maid,
6815: But being poor she died unwed.”
6816: 
6817: 
6818: The Rev. Camden Farebrother, whom Lydgate went to see the next evening,
6819: lived in an old parsonage, built of stone, venerable enough to match
6820: the church which it looked out upon. All the furniture too in the house
6821: was old, but with another grade of age—that of Mr. Farebrother’s father
6822: and grandfather. There were painted white chairs, with gilding and
6823: wreaths on them, and some lingering red silk damask with slits in it.
6824: There were engraved portraits of Lord Chancellors and other celebrated
6825: lawyers of the last century; and there were old pier-glasses to reflect
6826: them, as well as the little satin-wood tables and the sofas resembling
6827: a prolongation of uneasy chairs, all standing in relief against the
6828: dark wainscot. This was the physiognomy of the drawing-room into which
6829: Lydgate was shown; and there were three ladies to receive him, who were
6830: also old-fashioned, and of a faded but genuine respectability: Mrs.
6831: Farebrother, the Vicar’s white-haired mother, befrilled and kerchiefed
6832: with dainty cleanliness, upright, quick-eyed, and still under seventy;
6833: Miss Noble, her sister, a tiny old lady of meeker aspect, with frills
6834: and kerchief decidedly more worn and mended; and Miss Winifred
6835: Farebrother, the Vicar’s elder sister, well-looking like himself, but
6836: nipped and subdued as single women are apt to be who spend their lives
6837: in uninterrupted subjection to their elders. Lydgate had not expected
6838: to see so quaint a group: knowing simply that Mr. Farebrother was a
6839: bachelor, he had thought of being ushered into a snuggery where the
6840: chief furniture would probably be books and collections of natural
6841: objects. The Vicar himself seemed to wear rather a changed aspect, as
6842: most men do when acquaintances made elsewhere see them for the first
6843: time in their own homes; some indeed showing like an actor of genial
6844: parts disadvantageously cast for the curmudgeon in a new piece. This
6845: was not the case with Mr. Farebrother: he seemed a trifle milder and
6846: more silent, the chief talker being his mother, while he only put in a
6847: good-humored moderating remark here and there. The old lady was
6848: evidently accustomed to tell her company what they ought to think, and
6849: to regard no subject as quite safe without her steering. She was
6850: afforded leisure for this function by having all her little wants
6851: attended to by Miss Winifred. Meanwhile tiny Miss Noble carried on her
6852: arm a small basket, into which she diverted a bit of sugar, which she
6853: had first dropped in her saucer as if by mistake; looking round
6854: furtively afterwards, and reverting to her teacup with a small innocent
6855: noise as of a tiny timid quadruped. Pray think no ill of Miss Noble.
6856: That basket held small savings from her more portable food, destined
6857: for the children of her poor friends among whom she trotted on fine
6858: mornings; fostering and petting all needy creatures being so
6859: spontaneous a delight to her, that she regarded it much as if it had
6860: been a pleasant vice that she was addicted to. Perhaps she was
6861: conscious of being tempted to steal from those who had much that she
6862: might give to those who had nothing, and carried in her conscience the
6863: guilt of that repressed desire. One must be poor to know the luxury of
6864: giving!
6865: 
6866: Mrs. Farebrother welcomed the guest with a lively formality and
6867: precision. She presently informed him that they were not often in want
6868: of medical aid in that house. She had brought up her children to wear
6869: flannel and not to over-eat themselves, which last habit she considered
6870: the chief reason why people needed doctors. Lydgate pleaded for those
6871: whose fathers and mothers had over-eaten themselves, but Mrs.
6872: Farebrother held that view of things dangerous: Nature was more just
6873: than that; it would be easy for any felon to say that his ancestors
6874: ought to have been hanged instead of him. If those who had bad fathers
6875: and mothers were bad themselves, they were hanged for that. There was
6876: no need to go back on what you couldn’t see.
6877: 
6878: “My mother is like old George the Third,” said the Vicar, “she objects
6879: to metaphysics.”
6880: 
6881: “I object to what is wrong, Camden. I say, keep hold of a few plain
6882: truths, and make everything square with them. When I was young, Mr.
6883: Lydgate, there never was any question about right and wrong. We knew
6884: our catechism, and that was enough; we learned our creed and our duty.
6885: Every respectable Church person had the same opinions. But now, if you
6886: speak out of the Prayer-book itself, you are liable to be
6887: contradicted.”
6888: 
6889: “That makes rather a pleasant time of it for those who like to maintain
6890: their own point,” said Lydgate.
6891: 
6892: “But my mother always gives way,” said the Vicar, slyly.
6893: 
6894: “No, no, Camden, you must not lead Mr. Lydgate into a mistake about
6895: _me_. I shall never show that disrespect to my parents, to give up what
6896: they taught me. Any one may see what comes of turning. If you change
6897: once, why not twenty times?”
6898: 
6899: “A man might see good arguments for changing once, and not see them for
6900: changing again,” said Lydgate, amused with the decisive old lady.
6901: 
6902: “Excuse me there. If you go upon arguments, they are never wanting,
6903: when a man has no constancy of mind. My father never changed, and he
6904: preached plain moral sermons without arguments, and was a good man—few
6905: better. When you get me a good man made out of arguments, I will get
6906: you a good dinner with reading you the cookery-book. That’s my opinion,
6907: and I think anybody’s stomach will bear me out.”
6908: 
6909: “About the dinner certainly, mother,” said Mr. Farebrother.
6910: 
6911: “It is the same thing, the dinner or the man. I am nearly seventy, Mr.
6912: Lydgate, and I go upon experience. I am not likely to follow new
6913: lights, though there are plenty of them here as elsewhere. I say, they
6914: came in with the mixed stuffs that will neither wash nor wear. It was
6915: not so in my youth: a Churchman was a Churchman, and a clergyman, you
6916: might be pretty sure, was a gentleman, if nothing else. But now he may
6917: be no better than a Dissenter, and want to push aside my son on
6918: pretence of doctrine. But whoever may wish to push him aside, I am
6919: proud to say, Mr. Lydgate, that he will compare with any preacher in
6920: this kingdom, not to speak of this town, which is but a low standard to
6921: go by; at least, to my thinking, for I was born and bred at Exeter.”
6922: 
6923: “A mother is never partial,” said Mr. Farebrother, smiling. “What do
6924: you think Tyke’s mother says about him?”
6925: 
6926: “Ah, poor creature! what indeed?” said Mrs. Farebrother, her sharpness
6927: blunted for the moment by her confidence in maternal judgments. “She
6928: says the truth to herself, depend upon it.”
6929: 
6930: “And what is the truth?” said Lydgate. “I am curious to know.”
6931: 
6932: “Oh, nothing bad at all,” said Mr. Farebrother. “He is a zealous
6933: fellow: not very learned, and not very wise, I think—because I don’t
6934: agree with him.”
6935: 
6936: “Why, Camden!” said Miss Winifred, “Griffin and his wife told me only
6937: to-day, that Mr. Tyke said they should have no more coals if they came
6938: to hear you preach.”
6939: 
6940: Mrs. Farebrother laid down her knitting, which she had resumed after
6941: her small allowance of tea and toast, and looked at her son as if to
6942: say “You hear that?” Miss Noble said, “Oh poor things! poor things!” in
6943: reference, probably, to the double loss of preaching and coal. But the
6944: Vicar answered quietly—
6945: 
6946: “That is because they are not my parishioners. And I don’t think my
6947: sermons are worth a load of coals to them.”
6948: 
6949: “Mr. Lydgate,” said Mrs. Farebrother, who could not let this pass, “you
6950: don’t know my son: he always undervalues himself. I tell him he is
6951: undervaluing the God who made him, and made him a most excellent
6952: preacher.”
6953: 
6954: “That must be a hint for me to take Mr. Lydgate away to my study,
6955: mother,” said the Vicar, laughing. “I promised to show you my
6956: collection,” he added, turning to Lydgate; “shall we go?”
6957: 
6958: All three ladies remonstrated. Mr. Lydgate ought not to be hurried away
6959: without being allowed to accept another cup of tea: Miss Winifred had
6960: abundance of good tea in the pot. Why was Camden in such haste to take
6961: a visitor to his den? There was nothing but pickled vermin, and drawers
6962: full of blue-bottles and moths, with no carpet on the floor. Mr.
6963: Lydgate must excuse it. A game at cribbage would be far better. In
6964: short, it was plain that a vicar might be adored by his womankind as
6965: the king of men and preachers, and yet be held by them to stand in much
6966: need of their direction. Lydgate, with the usual shallowness of a young
6967: bachelor, wondered that Mr. Farebrother had not taught them better.
6968: 
6969: “My mother is not used to my having visitors who can take any interest
6970: in my hobbies,” said the Vicar, as he opened the door of his study,
6971: which was indeed as bare of luxuries for the body as the ladies had
6972: implied, unless a short porcelain pipe and a tobacco-box were to be
6973: excepted.
6974: 
6975: “Men of your profession don’t generally smoke,” he said. Lydgate smiled
6976: and shook his head. “Nor of mine either, properly, I suppose. You will
6977: hear that pipe alleged against me by Bulstrode and Company. They don’t
6978: know how pleased the devil would be if I gave it up.”
6979: 
6980: “I understand. You are of an excitable temper and want a sedative. I am
6981: heavier, and should get idle with it. I should rush into idleness, and
6982: stagnate there with all my might.”
6983: 
6984: “And you mean to give it all to your work. I am some ten or twelve
6985: years older than you, and have come to a compromise. I feed a weakness
6986: or two lest they should get clamorous. See,” continued the Vicar,
6987: opening several small drawers, “I fancy I have made an exhaustive study
6988: of the entomology of this district. I am going on both with the fauna
6989: and flora; but I have at least done my insects well. We are singularly
6990: rich in orthoptera: I don’t know whether—Ah! you have got hold of that
6991: glass jar—you are looking into that instead of my drawers. You don’t
6992: really care about these things?”
6993: 
6994: “Not by the side of this lovely anencephalous monster. I have never had
6995: time to give myself much to natural history. I was early bitten with an
6996: interest in structure, and it is what lies most directly in my
6997: profession. I have no hobby besides. I have the sea to swim in there.”
6998: 
6999: “Ah! you are a happy fellow,” said Mr. Farebrother, turning on his heel
7000: and beginning to fill his pipe. “You don’t know what it is to want
7001: spiritual tobacco—bad emendations of old texts, or small items about a
7002: variety of Aphis Brassicae, with the well-known signature of
7003: Philomicron, for the ‘Twaddler’s Magazine;’ or a learned treatise on
7004: the entomology of the Pentateuch, including all the insects not
