7005: mentioned, but probably met with by the Israelites in their passage
7006: through the desert; with a monograph on the Ant, as treated by Solomon,
7007: showing the harmony of the Book of Proverbs with the results of modern
7008: research. You don’t mind my fumigating you?”
7009: 
7010: Lydgate was more surprised at the openness of this talk than at its
7011: implied meaning—that the Vicar felt himself not altogether in the right
7012: vocation. The neat fitting-up of drawers and shelves, and the bookcase
7013: filled with expensive illustrated books on Natural History, made him
7014: think again of the winnings at cards and their destination. But he was
7015: beginning to wish that the very best construction of everything that
7016: Mr. Farebrother did should be the true one. The Vicar’s frankness
7017: seemed not of the repulsive sort that comes from an uneasy
7018: consciousness seeking to forestall the judgment of others, but simply
7019: the relief of a desire to do with as little pretence as possible.
7020: Apparently he was not without a sense that his freedom of speech might
7021: seem premature, for he presently said—
7022: 
7023: “I have not yet told you that I have the advantage of you, Mr. Lydgate,
7024: and know you better than you know me. You remember Trawley who shared
7025: your apartment at Paris for some time? I was a correspondent of his,
7026: and he told me a good deal about you. I was not quite sure when you
7027: first came that you were the same man. I was very glad when I found
7028: that you were. Only I don’t forget that you have not had the like
7029: prologue about me.”
7030: 
7031: Lydgate divined some delicacy of feeling here, but did not half
7032: understand it. “By the way,” he said, “what has become of Trawley? I
7033: have quite lost sight of him. He was hot on the French social systems,
7034: and talked of going to the Backwoods to found a sort of Pythagorean
7035: community. Is he gone?”
7036: 
7037: “Not at all. He is practising at a German bath, and has married a rich
7038: patient.”
7039: 
7040: “Then my notions wear the best, so far,” said Lydgate, with a short
7041: scornful laugh. “He would have it, the medical profession was an
7042: inevitable system of humbug. I said, the fault was in the men—men who
7043: truckle to lies and folly. Instead of preaching against humbug outside
7044: the walls, it might be better to set up a disinfecting apparatus
7045: within. In short—I am reporting my own conversation—you may be sure I
7046: had all the good sense on my side.”
7047: 
7048: “Your scheme is a good deal more difficult to carry out than the
7049: Pythagorean community, though. You have not only got the old Adam in
7050: yourself against you, but you have got all those descendants of the
7051: original Adam who form the society around you. You see, I have paid
7052: twelve or thirteen years more than you for my knowledge of
7053: difficulties. But”—Mr. Farebrother broke off a moment, and then added,
7054: “you are eying that glass vase again. Do you want to make an exchange?
7055: You shall not have it without a fair barter.”
7056: 
7057: “I have some sea-mice—fine specimens—in spirits. And I will throw in
7058: Robert Brown’s new thing—‘Microscopic Observations on the Pollen of
7059: Plants’—if you don’t happen to have it already.”
7060: 
7061: “Why, seeing how you long for the monster, I might ask a higher price.
7062: Suppose I ask you to look through my drawers and agree with me about
7063: all my new species?” The Vicar, while he talked in this way,
7064: alternately moved about with his pipe in his mouth, and returned to
7065: hang rather fondly over his drawers. “That would be good discipline,
7066: you know, for a young doctor who has to please his patients in
7067: Middlemarch. You must learn to be bored, remember. However, you shall
7068: have the monster on your own terms.”
7069: 
7070: “Don’t you think men overrate the necessity for humoring everybody’s
7071: nonsense, till they get despised by the very fools they humor?” said
7072: Lydgate, moving to Mr. Farebrother’s side, and looking rather absently
7073: at the insects ranged in fine gradation, with names subscribed in
7074: exquisite writing. “The shortest way is to make your value felt, so
7075: that people must put up with you whether you flatter them or not.”
7076: 
7077: “With all my heart. But then you must be sure of having the value, and
7078: you must keep yourself independent. Very few men can do that. Either
7079: you slip out of service altogether, and become good for nothing, or you
7080: wear the harness and draw a good deal where your yoke-fellows pull you.
7081: But do look at these delicate orthoptera!”
7082: 
7083: Lydgate had after all to give some scrutiny to each drawer, the Vicar
7084: laughing at himself, and yet persisting in the exhibition.
7085: 
7086: “Apropos of what you said about wearing harness,” Lydgate began, after
7087: they had sat down, “I made up my mind some time ago to do with as
7088: little of it as possible. That was why I determined not to try anything
7089: in London, for a good many years at least. I didn’t like what I saw
7090: when I was studying there—so much empty bigwiggism, and obstructive
7091: trickery. In the country, people have less pretension to knowledge, and
7092: are less of companions, but for that reason they affect one’s
7093: amour-propre less: one makes less bad blood, and can follow one’s own
7094: course more quietly.”
7095: 
7096: “Yes—well—you have got a good start; you are in the right profession,
7097: the work you feel yourself most fit for. Some people miss that, and
7098: repent too late. But you must not be too sure of keeping your
7099: independence.”
7100: 
7101: “You mean of family ties?” said Lydgate, conceiving that these might
7102: press rather tightly on Mr. Farebrother.
7103: 
7104: “Not altogether. Of course they make many things more difficult. But a
7105: good wife—a good unworldly woman—may really help a man, and keep him
7106: more independent. There’s a parishioner of mine—a fine fellow, but who
7107: would hardly have pulled through as he has done without his wife. Do
7108: you know the Garths? I think they were not Peacock’s patients.”
7109: 
7110: “No; but there is a Miss Garth at old Featherstone’s, at Lowick.”
7111: 
7112: “Their daughter: an excellent girl.”
7113: 
7114: “She is very quiet—I have hardly noticed her.”
7115: 
7116: “She has taken notice of you, though, depend upon it.”
7117: 
7118: “I don’t understand,” said Lydgate; he could hardly say “Of course.”
7119: 
7120: “Oh, she gauges everybody. I prepared her for confirmation—she is a
7121: favorite of mine.”
7122: 
7123: Mr. Farebrother puffed a few moments in silence, Lydgate not caring to
7124: know more about the Garths. At last the Vicar laid down his pipe,
7125: stretched out his legs, and turned his bright eyes with a smile towards
7126: Lydgate, saying—
7127: 
7128: “But we Middlemarchers are not so tame as you take us to be. We have
7129: our intrigues and our parties. I am a party man, for example, and
7130: Bulstrode is another. If you vote for me you will offend Bulstrode.”
7131: 
7132: “What is there against Bulstrode?” said Lydgate, emphatically.
7133: 
7134: “I did not say there was anything against him except that. If you vote
7135: against him you will make him your enemy.”
7136: 
7137: “I don’t know that I need mind about that,” said Lydgate, rather
7138: proudly; “but he seems to have good ideas about hospitals, and he
7139: spends large sums on useful public objects. He might help me a good
7140: deal in carrying out my ideas. As to his religious notions—why, as
7141: Voltaire said, incantations will destroy a flock of sheep if
7142: administered with a certain quantity of arsenic. I look for the man who
7143: will bring the arsenic, and don’t mind about his incantations.”
7144: 
7145: “Very good. But then you must not offend your arsenic-man. You will not
7146: offend me, you know,” said Mr. Farebrother, quite unaffectedly. “I
7147: don’t translate my own convenience into other people’s duties. I am
7148: opposed to Bulstrode in many ways. I don’t like the set he belongs to:
7149: they are a narrow ignorant set, and do more to make their neighbors
7150: uncomfortable than to make them better. Their system is a sort of
7151: worldly-spiritual cliqueism: they really look on the rest of mankind as
7152: a doomed carcass which is to nourish them for heaven. But,” he added,
7153: smilingly, “I don’t say that Bulstrode’s new hospital is a bad thing;
7154: and as to his wanting to oust me from the old one—why, if he thinks me
7155: a mischievous fellow, he is only returning a compliment. And I am not a
7156: model clergyman—only a decent makeshift.”
7157: 
7158: Lydgate was not at all sure that the Vicar maligned himself. A model
7159: clergyman, like a model doctor, ought to think his own profession the
7160: finest in the world, and take all knowledge as mere nourishment to his
7161: moral pathology and therapeutics. He only said, “What reason does
7162: Bulstrode give for superseding you?”
7163: 
7164: “That I don’t teach his opinions—which he calls spiritual religion; and
7165: that I have no time to spare. Both statements are true. But then I
7166: could make time, and I should be glad of the forty pounds. That is the
7167: plain fact of the case. But let us dismiss it. I only wanted to tell
7168: you that if you vote for your arsenic-man, you are not to cut me in
7169: consequence. I can’t spare you. You are a sort of circumnavigator come
7170: to settle among us, and will keep up my belief in the antipodes. Now
7171: tell me all about them in Paris.”
7172: 
7173: 
7174: 
7175: 
7176: CHAPTER XVIII.
7177: 
7178: “Oh, sir, the loftiest hopes on earth
7179: Draw lots with meaner hopes: heroic breasts,
7180: Breathing bad air, run risk of pestilence;
7181: Or, lacking lime-juice when they cross the Line,
7182: May languish with the scurvy.”
7183: 
7184: 
7185: Some weeks passed after this conversation before the question of the
7186: chaplaincy gathered any practical import for Lydgate, and without
7187: telling himself the reason, he deferred the predetermination on which
7188: side he should give his vote. It would really have been a matter of
7189: total indifference to him—that is to say, he would have taken the more
7190: convenient side, and given his vote for the appointment of Tyke without
7191: any hesitation—if he had not cared personally for Mr. Farebrother.
7192: 
7193: But his liking for the Vicar of St. Botolph’s grew with growing
7194: acquaintanceship. That, entering into Lydgate’s position as a new-comer
7195: who had his own professional objects to secure, Mr. Farebrother should
7196: have taken pains rather to warn off than to obtain his interest, showed
7197: an unusual delicacy and generosity, which Lydgate’s nature was keenly
7198: alive to. It went along with other points of conduct in Mr. Farebrother
7199: which were exceptionally fine, and made his character resemble those
7200: southern landscapes which seem divided between natural grandeur and
7201: social slovenliness. Very few men could have been as filial and
7202: chivalrous as he was to the mother, aunt, and sister, whose dependence
7203: on him had in many ways shaped his life rather uneasily for himself;
7204: few men who feel the pressure of small needs are so nobly resolute not
7205: to dress up their inevitably self-interested desires in a pretext of
7206: better motives. In these matters he was conscious that his life would
7207: bear the closest scrutiny; and perhaps the consciousness encouraged a
7208: little defiance towards the critical strictness of persons whose
7209: celestial intimacies seemed not to improve their domestic manners, and
7210: whose lofty aims were not needed to account for their actions. Then,
7211: his preaching was ingenious and pithy, like the preaching of the
7212: English Church in its robust age, and his sermons were delivered
7213: without book. People outside his parish went to hear him; and, since to
7214: fill the church was always the most difficult part of a clergyman’s
7215: function, here was another ground for a careless sense of superiority.
7216: Besides, he was a likable man: sweet-tempered, ready-witted, frank,
7217: without grins of suppressed bitterness or other conversational flavors
7218: which make half of us an affliction to our friends. Lydgate liked him
7219: heartily, and wished for his friendship.
7220: 
7221: With this feeling uppermost, he continued to waive the question of the
7222: chaplaincy, and to persuade himself that it was not only no proper
7223: business of his, but likely enough never to vex him with a demand for
7224: his vote. Lydgate, at Mr. Bulstrode’s request, was laying down plans
7225: for the internal arrangements of the new hospital, and the two were
7226: often in consultation. The banker was always presupposing that he could
7227: count in general on Lydgate as a coadjutor, but made no special
7228: recurrence to the coming decision between Tyke and Farebrother. When
7229: the General Board of the Infirmary had met, however, and Lydgate had
7230: notice that the question of the chaplaincy was thrown on a council of
7231: the directors and medical men, to meet on the following Friday, he had
7232: a vexed sense that he must make up his mind on this trivial Middlemarch
7233: business. He could not help hearing within him the distinct declaration
7234: that Bulstrode was prime minister, and that the Tyke affair was a
7235: question of office or no office; and he could not help an equally
7236: pronounced dislike to giving up the prospect of office. For his
7237: observation was constantly confirming Mr. Farebrother’s assurance that
7238: the banker would not overlook opposition. “Confound their petty
7239: politics!” was one of his thoughts for three mornings in the meditative
7240: process of shaving, when he had begun to feel that he must really hold
7241: a court of conscience on this matter. Certainly there were valid things
7242: to be said against the election of Mr. Farebrother: he had too much on
7243: his hands already, especially considering how much time he spent on
7244: non-clerical occupations. Then again it was a continually repeated
7245: shock, disturbing Lydgate’s esteem, that the Vicar should obviously
7246: play for the sake of money, liking the play indeed, but evidently
7247: liking some end which it served. Mr. Farebrother contended on theory
7248: for the desirability of all games, and said that Englishmen’s wit was
7249: stagnant for want of them; but Lydgate felt certain that he would have
7250: played very much less but for the money. There was a billiard-room at
7251: the Green Dragon, which some anxious mothers and wives regarded as the
7252: chief temptation in Middlemarch. The Vicar was a first-rate
7253: billiard-player, and though he did not frequent the Green Dragon, there
7254: were reports that he had sometimes been there in the daytime and had
7255: won money. And as to the chaplaincy, he did not pretend that he cared
7256: for it, except for the sake of the forty pounds. Lydgate was no
7257: Puritan, but he did not care for play, and winning money at it had
7258: always seemed a meanness to him; besides, he had an ideal of life which
7259: made this subservience of conduct to the gaining of small sums
7260: thoroughly hateful to him. Hitherto in his own life his wants had been
7261: supplied without any trouble to himself, and his first impulse was
7262: always to be liberal with half-crowns as matters of no importance to a
7263: gentleman; it had never occurred to him to devise a plan for getting
7264: half-crowns. He had always known in a general way that he was not rich,
7265: but he had never felt poor, and he had no power of imagining the part
7266: which the want of money plays in determining the actions of men. Money
7267: had never been a motive to him. Hence he was not ready to frame excuses
7268: for this deliberate pursuit of small gains. It was altogether repulsive
7269: to him, and he never entered into any calculation of the ratio between
7270: the Vicar’s income and his more or less necessary expenditure. It was
7271: possible that he would not have made such a calculation in his own
7272: case.
7273: 
7274: And now, when the question of voting had come, this repulsive fact told
7275: more strongly against Mr. Farebrother than it had done before. One
7276: would know much better what to do if men’s characters were more
7277: consistent, and especially if one’s friends were invariably fit for any
7278: function they desired to undertake! Lydgate was convinced that if there
7279: had been no valid objection to Mr. Farebrother, he would have voted for
7280: him, whatever Bulstrode might have felt on the subject: he did not
7281: intend to be a vassal of Bulstrode’s. On the other hand, there was
7282: Tyke, a man entirely given to his clerical office, who was simply
7283: curate at a chapel of ease in St. Peter’s parish, and had time for
7284: extra duty. Nobody had anything to say against Mr. Tyke, except that
7285: they could not bear him, and suspected him of cant. Really, from his
7286: point of view, Bulstrode was thoroughly justified.
7287: 
7288: But whichever way Lydgate began to incline, there was something to make
7289: him wince; and being a proud man, he was a little exasperated at being
7290: obliged to wince. He did not like frustrating his own best purposes by
7291: getting on bad terms with Bulstrode; he did not like voting against
7292: Farebrother, and helping to deprive him of function and salary; and the
7293: question occurred whether the additional forty pounds might not leave
7294: the Vicar free from that ignoble care about winning at cards. Moreover,
7295: Lydgate did not like the consciousness that in voting for Tyke he
7296: should be voting on the side obviously convenient for himself. But
7297: would the end really be his own convenience? Other people would say so,
7298: and would allege that he was currying favor with Bulstrode for the sake
7299: of making himself important and getting on in the world. What then? He
7300: for his own part knew that if his personal prospects simply had been
7301: concerned, he would not have cared a rotten nut for the banker’s
7302: friendship or enmity. What he really cared for was a medium for his
7303: work, a vehicle for his ideas; and after all, was he not bound to
7304: prefer the object of getting a good hospital, where he could
7305: demonstrate the specific distinctions of fever and test therapeutic
7306: results, before anything else connected with this chaplaincy? For the
7307: first time Lydgate was feeling the hampering threadlike pressure of
7308: small social conditions, and their frustrating complexity. At the end
7309: of his inward debate, when he set out for the hospital, his hope was
7310: really in the chance that discussion might somehow give a new aspect to
7311: the question, and make the scale dip so as to exclude the necessity for
7312: voting. I think he trusted a little also to the energy which is
7313: begotten by circumstances—some feeling rushing warmly and making
7314: resolve easy, while debate in cool blood had only made it more
7315: difficult. However it was, he did not distinctly say to himself on
7316: which side he would vote; and all the while he was inwardly resenting
7317: the subjection which had been forced upon him. It would have seemed
7318: beforehand like a ridiculous piece of bad logic that he, with his
7319: unmixed resolutions of independence and his select purposes, would find
7320: himself at the very outset in the grasp of petty alternatives, each of
7321: which was repugnant to him. In his student’s chambers, he had
7322: prearranged his social action quite differently.
7323: 
7324: Lydgate was late in setting out, but Dr. Sprague, the two other
7325: surgeons, and several of the directors had arrived early; Mr.
7326: Bulstrode, treasurer and chairman, being among those who were still
7327: absent. The conversation seemed to imply that the issue was
7328: problematical, and that a majority for Tyke was not so certain as had
7329: been generally supposed. The two physicians, for a wonder, turned out
7330: to be unanimous, or rather, though of different minds, they concurred
7331: in action. Dr. Sprague, the rugged and weighty, was, as every one had
7332: foreseen, an adherent of Mr. Farebrother. The Doctor was more than
7333: suspected of having no religion, but somehow Middlemarch tolerated this
7334: deficiency in him as if he had been a Lord Chancellor; indeed it is
7335: probable that his professional weight was the more believed in, the
7336: world-old association of cleverness with the evil principle being still
7337: potent in the minds even of lady-patients who had the strictest ideas
7338: of frilling and sentiment. It was perhaps this negation in the Doctor
7339: which made his neighbors call him hard-headed and dry-witted;
7340: conditions of texture which were also held favorable to the storing of
7341: judgments connected with drugs. At all events, it is certain that if
7342: any medical man had come to Middlemarch with the reputation of having
7343: very definite religious views, of being given to prayer, and of
7344: otherwise showing an active piety, there would have been a general
7345: presumption against his medical skill.
7346: 
7347: On this ground it was (professionally speaking) fortunate for Dr.
7348: Minchin that his religious sympathies were of a general kind, and such
7349: as gave a distant medical sanction to all serious sentiment, whether of
7350: Church or Dissent, rather than any adhesion to particular tenets. If
7351: Mr. Bulstrode insisted, as he was apt to do, on the Lutheran doctrine
7352: of justification, as that by which a Church must stand or fall, Dr.
7353: Minchin in return was quite sure that man was not a mere machine or a
7354: fortuitous conjunction of atoms; if Mrs. Wimple insisted on a
7355: particular providence in relation to her stomach complaint, Dr. Minchin
7356: for his part liked to keep the mental windows open and objected to
7357: fixed limits; if the Unitarian brewer jested about the Athanasian
7358: Creed, Dr. Minchin quoted Pope’s “Essay on Man.” He objected to the
7359: rather free style of anecdote in which Dr. Sprague indulged, preferring
7360: well-sanctioned quotations, and liking refinement of all kinds: it was
7361: generally known that he had some kinship to a bishop, and sometimes
7362: spent his holidays at “the palace.”
7363: 
7364: Dr. Minchin was soft-handed, pale-complexioned, and of rounded outline,
7365: not to be distinguished from a mild clergyman in appearance: whereas
7366: Dr. Sprague was superfluously tall; his trousers got creased at the
7367: knees, and showed an excess of boot at a time when straps seemed
7368: necessary to any dignity of bearing; you heard him go in and out, and
7369: up and down, as if he had come to see after the roofing. In short, he
7370: had weight, and might be expected to grapple with a disease and throw
7371: it; while Dr. Minchin might be better able to detect it lurking and to
7372: circumvent it. They enjoyed about equally the mysterious privilege of
7373: medical reputation, and concealed with much etiquette their contempt
7374: for each other’s skill. Regarding themselves as Middlemarch
7375: institutions, they were ready to combine against all innovators, and
7376: against non-professionals given to interference. On this ground they
7377: were both in their hearts equally averse to Mr. Bulstrode, though Dr.
7378: Minchin had never been in open hostility with him, and never differed
7379: from him without elaborate explanation to Mrs. Bulstrode, who had found
7380: that Dr. Minchin alone understood her constitution. A layman who pried
7381: into the professional conduct of medical men, and was always obtruding
7382: his reforms,—though he was less directly embarrassing to the two
7383: physicians than to the surgeon-apothecaries who attended paupers by
7384: contract, was nevertheless offensive to the professional nostril as
7385: such; and Dr. Minchin shared fully in the new pique against Bulstrode,
7386: excited by his apparent determination to patronize Lydgate. The
7387: long-established practitioners, Mr. Wrench and Mr. Toller; were just
7388: now standing apart and having a friendly colloquy, in which they agreed
7389: that Lydgate was a jackanapes, just made to serve Bulstrode’s purpose.
7390: To non-medical friends they had already concurred in praising the other
7391: young practitioner, who had come into the town on Mr. Peacock’s
7392: retirement without further recommendation than his own merits and such
7393: argument for solid professional acquirement as might be gathered from
7394: his having apparently wasted no time on other branches of knowledge. It
7395: was clear that Lydgate, by not dispensing drugs, intended to cast
7396: imputations on his equals, and also to obscure the limit between his
7397: own rank as a general practitioner and that of the physicians, who, in
7398: the interest of the profession, felt bound to maintain its various
7399: grades,—especially against a man who had not been to either of the
7400: English universities and enjoyed the absence of anatomical and bedside
7401: study there, but came with a libellous pretension to experience in
7402: Edinburgh and Paris, where observation might be abundant indeed, but
7403: hardly sound.
7404: 
7405: Thus it happened that on this occasion Bulstrode became identified with
7406: Lydgate, and Lydgate with Tyke; and owing to this variety of
7407: interchangeable names for the chaplaincy question, diverse minds were
7408: enabled to form the same judgment concerning it.
7409: 
7410: Dr. Sprague said at once bluntly to the group assembled when he
7411: entered, “I go for Farebrother. A salary, with all my heart. But why
7412: take it from the Vicar? He has none too much—has to insure his life,
7413: besides keeping house, and doing a vicar’s charities. Put forty pounds
7414: in his pocket and you’ll do no harm. He’s a good fellow, is
7415: Farebrother, with as little of the parson about him as will serve to
7416: carry orders.”
7417: 
7418: “Ho, ho! Doctor,” said old Mr. Powderell, a retired iron-monger of some
7419: standing—his interjection being something between a laugh and a
7420: Parliamentary disapproval; “we must let you have your say. But what we
7421: have to consider is not anybody’s income—it’s the souls of the poor
7422: sick people”—here Mr. Powderell’s voice and face had a sincere pathos
7423: in them. “He is a real Gospel preacher, is Mr. Tyke. I should vote
7424: against my conscience if I voted against Mr. Tyke—I should indeed.”
7425: 
7426: “Mr. Tyke’s opponents have not asked any one to vote against his
7427: conscience, I believe,” said Mr. Hackbutt, a rich tanner of fluent
7428: speech, whose glittering spectacles and erect hair were turned with
7429: some severity towards innocent Mr. Powderell. “But in my judgment it
7430: behoves us, as Directors, to consider whether we will regard it as our
7431: whole business to carry out propositions emanating from a single
7432: quarter. Will any member of the committee aver that he would have
7433: entertained the idea of displacing the gentleman who has always
7434: discharged the function of chaplain here, if it had not been suggested
7435: to him by parties whose disposition it is to regard every institution
7436: of this town as a machinery for carrying out their own views? I tax no
7437: man’s motives: let them lie between himself and a higher Power; but I
7438: do say, that there are influences at work here which are incompatible
7439: with genuine independence, and that a crawling servility is usually
7440: dictated by circumstances which gentlemen so conducting themselves
7441: could not afford either morally or financially to avow. I myself am a
7442: layman, but I have given no inconsiderable attention to the divisions
7443: in the Church and—”
7444: 
7445: “Oh, damn the divisions!” burst in Mr. Frank Hawley, lawyer and
7446: town-clerk, who rarely presented himself at the board, but now looked
7447: in hurriedly, whip in hand. “We have nothing to do with them here.
7448: Farebrother has been doing the work—what there was—without pay, and if
7449: pay is to be given, it should be given to him. I call it a confounded
7450: job to take the thing away from Farebrother.”
7451: 
7452: “I think it would be as well for gentlemen not to give their remarks a
7453: personal bearing,” said Mr. Plymdale. “I shall vote for the appointment
7454: of Mr. Tyke, but I should not have known, if Mr. Hackbutt hadn’t hinted
7455: it, that I was a Servile Crawler.”
7456: 
7457: “I disclaim any personalities. I expressly said, if I may be allowed to
7458: repeat, or even to conclude what I was about to say—”
7459: 
7460: “Ah, here’s Minchin!” said Mr. Frank Hawley; at which everybody turned
7461: away from Mr. Hackbutt, leaving him to feel the uselessness of superior
7462: gifts in Middlemarch. “Come, Doctor, I must have you on the right side,
7463: eh?”
7464: 
7465: “I hope so,” said Dr. Minchin, nodding and shaking hands here and
7466: there; “at whatever cost to my feelings.”
7467: 
7468: “If there’s any feeling here, it should be feeling for the man who is
7469: turned out, I think,” said Mr. Frank Hawley.
7470: 
7471: “I confess I have feelings on the other side also. I have a divided
7472: esteem,” said Dr. Minchin, rubbing his hands. “I consider Mr. Tyke an
7473: exemplary man—none more so—and I believe him to be proposed from
7474: unimpeachable motives. I, for my part, wish that I could give him my
7475: vote. But I am constrained to take a view of the case which gives the
7476: preponderance to Mr. Farebrother’s claims. He is an amiable man, an
7477: able preacher, and has been longer among us.”
7478: 
7479: Old Mr. Powderell looked on, sad and silent. Mr. Plymdale settled his
7480: cravat, uneasily.
7481: 
7482: “You don’t set up Farebrother as a pattern of what a clergyman ought to
7483: be, I hope,” said Mr. Larcher, the eminent carrier, who had just come
7484: in. “I have no ill-will towards him, but I think we owe something to
7485: the public, not to speak of anything higher, in these appointments. In
7486: my opinion Farebrother is too lax for a clergyman. I don’t wish to
7487: bring up particulars against him; but he will make a little attendance
7488: here go as far as he can.”
7489: 
7490: “And a devilish deal better than too much,” said Mr. Hawley, whose bad
7491: language was notorious in that part of the county. “Sick people can’t
7492: bear so much praying and preaching. And that methodistical sort of
7493: religion is bad for the spirits—bad for the inside, eh?” he added,
7494: turning quickly round to the four medical men who were assembled.
7495: 
7496: But any answer was dispensed with by the entrance of three gentlemen,
7497: with whom there were greetings more or less cordial. These were the
7498: Reverend Edward Thesiger, Rector of St. Peter’s, Mr. Bulstrode, and our
7499: friend Mr. Brooke of Tipton, who had lately allowed himself to be put
7500: on the board of directors in his turn, but had never before attended,
7501: his attendance now being due to Mr. Bulstrode’s exertions. Lydgate was
7502: the only person still expected.
7503: 
7504: Every one now sat down, Mr. Bulstrode presiding, pale and
7505: self-restrained as usual. Mr. Thesiger, a moderate evangelical, wished
7506: for the appointment of his friend Mr. Tyke, a zealous able man, who,
7507: officiating at a chapel of ease, had not a cure of souls too extensive
7508: to leave him ample time for the new duty. It was desirable that
7509: chaplaincies of this kind should be entered on with a fervent
7510: intention: they were peculiar opportunities for spiritual influence;
7511: and while it was good that a salary should be allotted, there was the
7512: more need for scrupulous watching lest the office should be perverted
7513: into a mere question of salary. Mr. Thesiger’s manner had so much quiet
7514: propriety that objectors could only simmer in silence.
7515: 
7516: Mr. Brooke believed that everybody meant well in the matter. He had not
7517: himself attended to the affairs of the Infirmary, though he had a
7518: strong interest in whatever was for the benefit of Middlemarch, and was
7519: most happy to meet the gentlemen present on any public question—“any
7520: public question, you know,” Mr. Brooke repeated, with his nod of
7521: perfect understanding. “I am a good deal occupied as a magistrate, and
7522: in the collection of documentary evidence, but I regard my time as
7523: being at the disposal of the public—and, in short, my friends have
7524: convinced me that a chaplain with a salary—a salary, you know—is a very
7525: good thing, and I am happy to be able to come here and vote for the
7526: appointment of Mr. Tyke, who, I understand, is an unexceptionable man,
7527: apostolic and eloquent and everything of that kind—and I am the last
7528: man to withhold my vote—under the circumstances, you know.”
7529: 
7530: “It seems to me that you have been crammed with one side of the
7531: question, Mr. Brooke,” said Mr. Frank Hawley, who was afraid of nobody,
7532: and was a Tory suspicious of electioneering intentions. “You don’t seem
7533: to know that one of the worthiest men we have has been doing duty as
7534: chaplain here for years without pay, and that Mr. Tyke is proposed to
7535: supersede him.”
7536: 
7537: “Excuse me, Mr. Hawley,” said Mr. Bulstrode. “Mr. Brooke has been fully
7538: informed of Mr. Farebrother’s character and position.”
7539: 
7540: “By his enemies,” flashed out Mr. Hawley.
7541: 
7542: “I trust there is no personal hostility concerned here,” said Mr.
7543: Thesiger.
7544: 
7545: “I’ll swear there is, though,” retorted Mr. Hawley.
7546: 
7547: “Gentlemen,” said Mr. Bulstrode, in a subdued tone, “the merits of the
7548: question may be very briefly stated, and if any one present doubts that
7549: every gentleman who is about to give his vote has not been fully
7550: informed, I can now recapitulate the considerations that should weigh
7551: on either side.”
7552: 
7553: “I don’t see the good of that,” said Mr. Hawley. “I suppose we all know
7554: whom we mean to vote for. Any man who wants to do justice does not wait
7555: till the last minute to hear both sides of the question. I have no time
7556: to lose, and I propose that the matter be put to the vote at once.”
7557: 
7558: A brief but still hot discussion followed before each person wrote
7559: “Tyke” or “Farebrother” on a piece of paper and slipped it into a glass
7560: tumbler; and in the mean time Mr. Bulstrode saw Lydgate enter.
7561: 
7562: “I perceive that the votes are equally divided at present,” said Mr.
7563: Bulstrode, in a clear biting voice. Then, looking up at Lydgate—
7564: 
7565: “There is a casting-vote still to be given. It is yours, Mr. Lydgate:
7566: will you be good enough to write?”
7567: 
7568: “The thing is settled now,” said Mr. Wrench, rising. “We all know how
7569: Mr. Lydgate will vote.”
7570: 
7571: “You seem to speak with some peculiar meaning, sir,” said Lydgate,
7572: rather defiantly, and keeping his pencil suspended.
7573: 
7574: “I merely mean that you are expected to vote with Mr. Bulstrode. Do you
7575: regard that meaning as offensive?”
7576: 
7577: “It may be offensive to others. But I shall not desist from voting with
7578: him on that account.” Lydgate immediately wrote down “Tyke.”
7579: 
7580: So the Rev. Walter Tyke became chaplain to the Infirmary, and Lydgate
7581: continued to work with Mr. Bulstrode. He was really uncertain whether
7582: Tyke were not the more suitable candidate, and yet his consciousness
7583: told him that if he had been quite free from indirect bias he should
7584: have voted for Mr. Farebrother. The affair of the chaplaincy remained a
7585: sore point in his memory as a case in which this petty medium of
7586: Middlemarch had been too strong for him. How could a man be satisfied
7587: with a decision between such alternatives and under such circumstances?
7588: No more than he can be satisfied with his hat, which he has chosen from
7589: among such shapes as the resources of the age offer him, wearing it at
7590: best with a resignation which is chiefly supported by comparison.
7591: 
7592: But Mr. Farebrother met him with the same friendliness as before. The
7593: character of the publican and sinner is not always practically
7594: incompatible with that of the modern Pharisee, for the majority of us
7595: scarcely see more distinctly the faultiness of our own conduct than the
7596: faultiness of our own arguments, or the dulness of our own jokes. But
7597: the Vicar of St. Botolph’s had certainly escaped the slightest tincture
7598: of the Pharisee, and by dint of admitting to himself that he was too
7599: much as other men were, he had become remarkably unlike them in
7600: this—that he could excuse others for thinking slightly of him, and
7601: could judge impartially of their conduct even when it told against him.
7602: 
7603: “The world has been too strong for _me_, I know,” he said one day to
7604: Lydgate. “But then I am not a mighty man—I shall never be a man of
7605: renown. The choice of Hercules is a pretty fable; but Prodicus makes it
7606: easy work for the hero, as if the first resolves were enough. Another
7607: story says that he came to hold the distaff, and at last wore the
7608: Nessus shirt. I suppose one good resolve might keep a man right if
7609: everybody else’s resolve helped him.”
7610: 
7611: The Vicar’s talk was not always inspiriting: he had escaped being a
7612: Pharisee, but he had not escaped that low estimate of possibilities
7613: which we rather hastily arrive at as an inference from our own failure.
7614: Lydgate thought that there was a pitiable infirmity of will in Mr.
7615: Farebrother.
7616: 
7617: 
7618: 
7619: 
7620: CHAPTER XIX.
7621: 
7622: “L’ altra vedete ch’ha fatto alla guancia
7623: Della sua palma, sospirando, letto.”
7624: —_Purgatorio_, vii.
7625: 
7626: 
7627: When George the Fourth was still reigning over the privacies of
7628: Windsor, when the Duke of Wellington was Prime Minister, and Mr. Vincy
7629: was mayor of the old corporation in Middlemarch, Mrs. Casaubon, born
7630: Dorothea Brooke, had taken her wedding journey to Rome. In those days
7631: the world in general was more ignorant of good and evil by forty years
7632: than it is at present. Travellers did not often carry full information
7633: on Christian art either in their heads or their pockets; and even the
7634: most brilliant English critic of the day mistook the flower-flushed
7635: tomb of the ascended Virgin for an ornamental vase due to the painter’s
7636: fancy. Romanticism, which has helped to fill some dull blanks with love
7637: and knowledge, had not yet penetrated the times with its leaven and
7638: entered into everybody’s food; it was fermenting still as a
7639: distinguishable vigorous enthusiasm in certain long-haired German
7640: artists at Rome, and the youth of other nations who worked or idled
7641: near them were sometimes caught in the spreading movement.
7642: 
7643: One fine morning a young man whose hair was not immoderately long, but
7644: abundant and curly, and who was otherwise English in his equipment, had
7645: just turned his back on the Belvedere Torso in the Vatican and was
7646: looking out on the magnificent view of the mountains from the adjoining
7647: round vestibule. He was sufficiently absorbed not to notice the
7648: approach of a dark-eyed, animated German who came up to him and placing
7649: a hand on his shoulder, said with a strong accent, “Come here, quick!
7650: else she will have changed her pose.”
7651: 
7652: Quickness was ready at the call, and the two figures passed lightly
7653: along by the Meleager, towards the hall where the reclining Ariadne,
7654: then called the Cleopatra, lies in the marble voluptuousness of her
7655: beauty, the drapery folding around her with a petal-like ease and
7656: tenderness. They were just in time to see another figure standing
7657: against a pedestal near the reclining marble: a breathing blooming
7658: girl, whose form, not shamed by the Ariadne, was clad in Quakerish gray
7659: drapery; her long cloak, fastened at the neck, was thrown backward from
7660: her arms, and one beautiful ungloved hand pillowed her cheek, pushing
7661: somewhat backward the white beaver bonnet which made a sort of halo to
7662: her face around the simply braided dark-brown hair. She was not looking
7663: at the sculpture, probably not thinking of it: her large eyes were
7664: fixed dreamily on a streak of sunlight which fell across the floor. But
7665: she became conscious of the two strangers who suddenly paused as if to
7666: contemplate the Cleopatra, and, without looking at them, immediately
7667: turned away to join a maid-servant and courier who were loitering along
7668: the hall at a little distance off.
7669: 
7670: “What do you think of that for a fine bit of antithesis?” said the
7671: German, searching in his friend’s face for responding admiration, but
7672: going on volubly without waiting for any other answer. “There lies
7673: antique beauty, not corpse-like even in death, but arrested in the
7674: complete contentment of its sensuous perfection: and here stands beauty
7675: in its breathing life, with the consciousness of Christian centuries in
7676: its bosom. But she should be dressed as a nun; I think she looks almost
7677: what you call a Quaker; I would dress her as a nun in my picture.
7678: However, she is married; I saw her wedding-ring on that wonderful left
7679: hand, otherwise I should have thought the sallow _Geistlicher_ was her
7680: father. I saw him parting from her a good while ago, and just now I
7681: found her in that magnificent pose. Only think! he is perhaps rich, and
7682: would like to have her portrait taken. Ah! it is no use looking after
7683: her—there she goes! Let us follow her home!”
7684: 
7685: “No, no,” said his companion, with a little frown.
7686: 
7687: “You are singular, Ladislaw. You look struck together. Do you know
7688: her?”
7689: 
7690: “I know that she is married to my cousin,” said Will Ladislaw,
7691: sauntering down the hall with a preoccupied air, while his German
7692: friend kept at his side and watched him eagerly.
7693: 
7694: “What! the _Geistlicher_? He looks more like an uncle—a more useful
7695: sort of relation.”
7696: 
7697: “He is not my uncle. I tell you he is my second cousin,” said Ladislaw,
7698: with some irritation.
7699: 
7700: “Schön, schön. Don’t be snappish. You are not angry with me for
7701: thinking Mrs. Second-Cousin the most perfect young Madonna I ever saw?”
7702: 
7703: “Angry? nonsense. I have only seen her once before, for a couple of
7704: minutes, when my cousin introduced her to me, just before I left
7705: England. They were not married then. I didn’t know they were coming to
7706: Rome.”
7707: 
7708: “But you will go to see them now—you will find out what they have for
7709: an address—since you know the name. Shall we go to the post? And you
7710: could speak about the portrait.”
7711: 
7712: “Confound you, Naumann! I don’t know what I shall do. I am not so
7713: brazen as you.”
7714: 
7715: “Bah! that is because you are dilettantish and amateurish. If you were
7716: an artist, you would think of Mistress Second-Cousin as antique form
7717: animated by Christian sentiment—a sort of Christian Antigone—sensuous
7718: force controlled by spiritual passion.”
7719: 
7720: “Yes, and that your painting her was the chief outcome of her
7721: existence—the divinity passing into higher completeness and all but
7722: exhausted in the act of covering your bit of canvas. I am amateurish if
7723: you like: I do _not_ think that all the universe is straining towards
7724: the obscure significance of your pictures.”
7725: 
7726: “But it is, my dear!—so far as it is straining through me, Adolf
7727: Naumann: that stands firm,” said the good-natured painter, putting a
7728: hand on Ladislaw’s shoulder, and not in the least disturbed by the
7729: unaccountable touch of ill-humor in his tone. “See now! My existence
7730: presupposes the existence of the whole universe—does it _not?_ and my
7731: function is to paint—and as a painter I have a conception which is
7732: altogether _genialisch_, of your great-aunt or second grandmother as a
7733: subject for a picture; therefore, the universe is straining towards
7734: that picture through that particular hook or claw which it puts forth
7735: in the shape of me—not true?”
7736: 
7737: “But how if another claw in the shape of me is straining to thwart
7738: it?—the case is a little less simple then.”
7739: 
7740: “Not at all: the result of the struggle is the same thing—picture or no
7741: picture—logically.”
7742: 
7743: Will could not resist this imperturbable temper, and the cloud in his
7744: face broke into sunshiny laughter.
7745: 
7746: “Come now, my friend—you will help?” said Naumann, in a hopeful tone.
7747: 
7748: “No; nonsense, Naumann! English ladies are not at everybody’s service
7749: as models. And you want to express too much with your painting. You
7750: would only have made a better or worse portrait with a background which
7751: every connoisseur would give a different reason for or against. And
7752: what is a portrait of a woman? Your painting and Plastik are poor stuff
7753: after all. They perturb and dull conceptions instead of raising them.
7754: Language is a finer medium.”
7755: 
7756: “Yes, for those who can’t paint,” said Naumann. “There you have perfect
7757: right. I did not recommend you to paint, my friend.”
7758: 
7759: The amiable artist carried his sting, but Ladislaw did not choose to
7760: appear stung. He went on as if he had not heard.
7761: 
7762: “Language gives a fuller image, which is all the better for being
7763: vague. After all, the true seeing is within; and painting stares at you
7764: with an insistent imperfection. I feel that especially about
7765: representations of women. As if a woman were a mere colored
7766: superficies! You must wait for movement and tone. There is a difference
7767: in their very breathing: they change from moment to moment.—This woman
7768: whom you have just seen, for example: how would you paint her voice,
7769: pray? But her voice is much diviner than anything you have seen of
7770: her.”
7771: 
7772: “I see, I see. You are jealous. No man must presume to think that he
7773: can paint your ideal. This is serious, my friend! Your great-aunt! ‘Der
7774: Neffe als Onkel’ in a tragic sense—_ungeheuer!_”
7775: 
7776: “You and I shall quarrel, Naumann, if you call that lady my aunt
7777: again.”
7778: 
7779: “How is she to be called then?”
7780: 
7781: “Mrs. Casaubon.”
7782: 
7783: “Good. Suppose I get acquainted with her in spite of you, and find that
7784: she very much wishes to be painted?”
7785: 
7786: “Yes, suppose!” said Will Ladislaw, in a contemptuous undertone,
7787: intended to dismiss the subject. He was conscious of being irritated by
7788: ridiculously small causes, which were half of his own creation. Why was
7789: he making any fuss about Mrs. Casaubon? And yet he felt as if something
7790: had happened to him with regard to her. There are characters which are
7791: continually creating collisions and nodes for themselves in dramas
7792: which nobody is prepared to act with them. Their susceptibilities will
7793: clash against objects that remain innocently quiet.
7794: 
7795: 
7796: 
7797: 
7798: CHAPTER XX.
7799: 
7800: “A child forsaken, waking suddenly,
7801: Whose gaze afeard on all things round doth rove,
7802: And seeth only that it cannot see
7803:     The meeting eyes of love.”
7804: 
7805: 
7806: Two hours later, Dorothea was seated in an inner room or boudoir of a
7807: handsome apartment in the Via Sistina.
7808: 
7809: I am sorry to add that she was sobbing bitterly, with such abandonment
7810: to this relief of an oppressed heart as a woman habitually controlled
7811: by pride on her own account and thoughtfulness for others will
7812: sometimes allow herself when she feels securely alone. And Mr. Casaubon
7813: was certain to remain away for some time at the Vatican.
7814: 
7815: Yet Dorothea had no distinctly shapen grievance that she could state
7816: even to herself; and in the midst of her confused thought and passion,
7817: the mental act that was struggling forth into clearness was a
7818: self-accusing cry that her feeling of desolation was the fault of her
7819: own spiritual poverty. She had married the man of her choice, and with
7820: the advantage over most girls that she had contemplated her marriage
7821: chiefly as the beginning of new duties: from the very first she had
7822: thought of Mr. Casaubon as having a mind so much above her own, that he
7823: must often be claimed by studies which she could not entirely share;
7824: moreover, after the brief narrow experience of her girlhood she was
7825: beholding Rome, the city of visible history, where the past of a whole
7826: hemisphere seems moving in funeral procession with strange ancestral
7827: images and trophies gathered from afar.
7828: 
7829: But this stupendous fragmentariness heightened the dreamlike
7830: strangeness of her bridal life. Dorothea had now been five weeks in
7831: Rome, and in the kindly mornings when autumn and winter seemed to go
7832: hand in hand like a happy aged couple one of whom would presently
7833: survive in chiller loneliness, she had driven about at first with Mr.
7834: Casaubon, but of late chiefly with Tantripp and their experienced
7835: courier. She had been led through the best galleries, had been taken to
7836: the chief points of view, had been shown the grandest ruins and the
7837: most glorious churches, and she had ended by oftenest choosing to drive
7838: out to the Campagna where she could feel alone with the earth and sky,
7839: away-from the oppressive masquerade of ages, in which her own life too
7840: seemed to become a masque with enigmatical costumes.
7841: 
7842: To those who have looked at Rome with the quickening power of a
7843: knowledge which breathes a growing soul into all historic shapes, and
7844: traces out the suppressed transitions which unite all contrasts, Rome
7845: may still be the spiritual centre and interpreter of the world. But let
7846: them conceive one more historical contrast: the gigantic broken
7847: revelations of that Imperial and Papal city thrust abruptly on the
7848: notions of a girl who had been brought up in English and Swiss
7849: Puritanism, fed on meagre Protestant histories and on art chiefly of
7850: the hand-screen sort; a girl whose ardent nature turned all her small
7851: allowance of knowledge into principles, fusing her actions into their
7852: mould, and whose quick emotions gave the most abstract things the
7853: quality of a pleasure or a pain; a girl who had lately become a wife,
7854: and from the enthusiastic acceptance of untried duty found herself
7855: plunged in tumultuous preoccupation with her personal lot. The weight
7856: of unintelligible Rome might lie easily on bright nymphs to whom it
7857: formed a background for the brilliant picnic of Anglo-foreign society;
7858: but Dorothea had no such defence against deep impressions. Ruins and
7859: basilicas, palaces and colossi, set in the midst of a sordid present,
7860: where all that was living and warm-blooded seemed sunk in the deep
7861: degeneracy of a superstition divorced from reverence; the dimmer but
7862: yet eager Titanic life gazing and struggling on walls and ceilings; the
7863: long vistas of white forms whose marble eyes seemed to hold the
7864: monotonous light of an alien world: all this vast wreck of ambitious
7865: ideals, sensuous and spiritual, mixed confusedly with the signs of
7866: breathing forgetfulness and degradation, at first jarred her as with an
7867: electric shock, and then urged themselves on her with that ache
7868: belonging to a glut of confused ideas which check the flow of emotion.
7869: Forms both pale and glowing took possession of her young sense, and
7870: fixed themselves in her memory even when she was not thinking of them,
7871: preparing strange associations which remained through her after-years.
7872: Our moods are apt to bring with them images which succeed each other
7873: like the magic-lantern pictures of a doze; and in certain states of
7874: dull forlornness Dorothea all her life continued to see the vastness of
7875: St. Peter’s, the huge bronze canopy, the excited intention in the
7876: attitudes and garments of the prophets and evangelists in the mosaics
7877: above, and the red drapery which was being hung for Christmas spreading
7878: itself everywhere like a disease of the retina.
7879: 
7880: Not that this inward amazement of Dorothea’s was anything very
7881: exceptional: many souls in their young nudity are tumbled out among
7882: incongruities and left to “find their feet” among them, while their
7883: elders go about their business. Nor can I suppose that when Mrs.
7884: Casaubon is discovered in a fit of weeping six weeks after her wedding,
7885: the situation will be regarded as tragic. Some discouragement, some
7886: faintness of heart at the new real future which replaces the imaginary,
7887: is not unusual, and we do not expect people to be deeply moved by what
7888: is not unusual. That element of tragedy which lies in the very fact of
7889: frequency, has not yet wrought itself into the coarse emotion of
7890: mankind; and perhaps our frames could hardly bear much of it. If we had
7891: a keen vision and feeling of all ordinary human life, it would be like
7892: hearing the grass grow and the squirrel’s heart beat, and we should die
7893: of that roar which lies on the other side of silence. As it is, the
7894: quickest of us walk about well wadded with stupidity.
7895: 
7896: However, Dorothea was crying, and if she had been required to state the
7897: cause, she could only have done so in some such general words as I have
7898: already used: to have been driven to be more particular would have been
7899: like trying to give a history of the lights and shadows, for that new
7900: real future which was replacing the imaginary drew its material from
7901: the endless minutiae by which her view of Mr. Casaubon and her wifely
7902: relation, now that she was married to him, was gradually changing with
7903: the secret motion of a watch-hand from what it had been in her maiden
7904: dream. It was too early yet for her fully to recognize or at least
7905: admit the change, still more for her to have readjusted that
7906: devotedness which was so necessary a part of her mental life that she
7907: was almost sure sooner or later to recover it. Permanent rebellion, the
7908: disorder of a life without some loving reverent resolve, was not
7909: possible to her; but she was now in an interval when the very force of
7910: her nature heightened its confusion. In this way, the early months of
7911: marriage often are times of critical tumult—whether that of a
7912: shrimp-pool or of deeper waters—which afterwards subsides into cheerful
7913: peace.
7914: 
7915: But was not Mr. Casaubon just as learned as before? Had his forms of
7916: expression changed, or his sentiments become less laudable? Oh
7917: waywardness of womanhood! did his chronology fail him, or his ability
7918: to state not only a theory but the names of those who held it; or his
7919: provision for giving the heads of any subject on demand? And was not
7920: Rome the place in all the world to give free play to such
7921: accomplishments? Besides, had not Dorothea’s enthusiasm especially
7922: dwelt on the prospect of relieving the weight and perhaps the sadness
7923: with which great tasks lie on him who has to achieve them?— And that
7924: such weight pressed on Mr. Casaubon was only plainer than before.
7925: 
7926: All these are crushing questions; but whatever else remained the same,
7927: the light had changed, and you cannot find the pearly dawn at noonday.
7928: The fact is unalterable, that a fellow-mortal with whose nature you are
7929: acquainted solely through the brief entrances and exits of a few
7930: imaginative weeks called courtship, may, when seen in the continuity of
7931: married companionship, be disclosed as something better or worse than
7932: what you have preconceived, but will certainly not appear altogether
7933: the same. And it would be astonishing to find how soon the change is
7934: felt if we had no kindred changes to compare with it. To share lodgings
7935: with a brilliant dinner-companion, or to see your favorite politician
7936: in the Ministry, may bring about changes quite as rapid: in these cases
7937: too we begin by knowing little and believing much, and we sometimes end
7938: by inverting the quantities.
7939: 
7940: Still, such comparisons might mislead, for no man was more incapable of
7941: flashy make-believe than Mr. Casaubon: he was as genuine a character as
7942: any ruminant animal, and he had not actively assisted in creating any
7943: illusions about himself. How was it that in the weeks since her
7944: marriage, Dorothea had not distinctly observed but felt with a stifling
7945: depression, that the large vistas and wide fresh air which she had
7946: dreamed of finding in her husband’s mind were replaced by anterooms and
7947: winding passages which seemed to lead nowhither? I suppose it was that
7948: in courtship everything is regarded as provisional and preliminary, and
7949: the smallest sample of virtue or accomplishment is taken to guarantee
7950: delightful stores which the broad leisure of marriage will reveal. But
7951: the door-sill of marriage once crossed, expectation is concentrated on
7952: the present. Having once embarked on your marital voyage, it is
7953: impossible not to be aware that you make no way and that the sea is not
7954: within sight—that, in fact, you are exploring an enclosed basin.
7955: 
7956: In their conversation before marriage, Mr. Casaubon had often dwelt on
7957: some explanation or questionable detail of which Dorothea did not see
7958: the bearing; but such imperfect coherence seemed due to the brokenness
7959: of their intercourse, and, supported by her faith in their future, she
7960: had listened with fervid patience to a recitation of possible arguments
7961: to be brought against Mr. Casaubon’s entirely new view of the
7962: Philistine god Dagon and other fish-deities, thinking that hereafter
7963: she should see this subject which touched him so nearly from the same
7964: high ground whence doubtless it had become so important to him. Again,
7965: the matter-of-course statement and tone of dismissal with which he
7966: treated what to her were the most stirring thoughts, was easily
7967: accounted for as belonging to the sense of haste and preoccupation in
7968: which she herself shared during their engagement. But now, since they
7969: had been in Rome, with all the depths of her emotion roused to
7970: tumultuous activity, and with life made a new problem by new elements,
7971: she had been becoming more and more aware, with a certain terror, that
7972: her mind was continually sliding into inward fits of anger and
7973: repulsion, or else into forlorn weariness. How far the judicious Hooker
7974: or any other hero of erudition would have been the same at Mr.
7975: Casaubon’s time of life, she had no means of knowing, so that he could
7976: not have the advantage of comparison; but her husband’s way of
7977: commenting on the strangely impressive objects around them had begun to
7978: affect her with a sort of mental shiver: he had perhaps the best
7979: intention of acquitting himself worthily, but only of acquitting
7980: himself. What was fresh to her mind was worn out to his; and such
7981: capacity of thought and feeling as had ever been stimulated in him by
7982: the general life of mankind had long shrunk to a sort of dried
7983: preparation, a lifeless embalmment of knowledge.
7984: 
7985: When he said, “Does this interest you, Dorothea? Shall we stay a little
7986: longer? I am ready to stay if you wish it,”—it seemed to her as if
7987: going or staying were alike dreary. Or, “Should you like to go to the
7988: Farnesina, Dorothea? It contains celebrated frescos designed or painted
7989: by Raphael, which most persons think it worth while to visit.”
7990: 
7991: “But do you care about them?” was always Dorothea’s question.
7992: 
7993: “They are, I believe, highly esteemed. Some of them represent the fable
7994: of Cupid and Psyche, which is probably the romantic invention of a
7995: literary period, and cannot, I think, be reckoned as a genuine mythical
7996: product. But if you like these wall-paintings we can easily drive
7997: thither; and you will then, I think, have seen the chief works of
7998: Raphael, any of which it were a pity to omit in a visit to Rome. He is
7999: the painter who has been held to combine the most complete grace of
8000: form with sublimity of expression. Such at least I have gathered to be
8001: the opinion of cognoscenti.”
8002: 
8003: This kind of answer given in a measured official tone, as of a
8004: clergyman reading according to the rubric, did not help to justify the
8005: glories of the Eternal City, or to give her the hope that if she knew
8006: more about them the world would be joyously illuminated for her. There
8007: is hardly any contact more depressing to a young ardent creature than
8008: that of a mind in which years full of knowledge seem to have issued in
8009: a blank absence of interest or sympathy.
8010: 
8011: On other subjects indeed Mr. Casaubon showed a tenacity of occupation
8012: and an eagerness which are usually regarded as the effect of
8013: enthusiasm, and Dorothea was anxious to follow this spontaneous
8014: direction of his thoughts, instead of being made to feel that she
8015: dragged him away from it. But she was gradually ceasing to expect with
8016: her former delightful confidence that she should see any wide opening
8017: where she followed him. Poor Mr. Casaubon himself was lost among small
8018: closets and winding stairs, and in an agitated dimness about the
8019: Cabeiri, or in an exposure of other mythologists’ ill-considered
8020: parallels, easily lost sight of any purpose which had prompted him to
8021: these labors. With his taper stuck before him he forgot the absence of
8022: windows, and in bitter manuscript remarks on other men’s notions about
8023: the solar deities, he had become indifferent to the sunlight.
8024: 
8025: These characteristics, fixed and unchangeable as bone in Mr. Casaubon,
8026: might have remained longer unfelt by Dorothea if she had been
8027: encouraged to pour forth her girlish and womanly feeling—if he would
8028: have held her hands between his and listened with the delight of
8029: tenderness and understanding to all the little histories which made up
8030: her experience, and would have given her the same sort of intimacy in
8031: return, so that the past life of each could be included in their mutual
8032: knowledge and affection—or if she could have fed her affection with
8033: those childlike caresses which are the bent of every sweet woman, who
8034: has begun by showering kisses on the hard pate of her bald doll,
8035: creating a happy soul within that woodenness from the wealth of her own
8036: love. That was Dorothea’s bent. With all her yearning to know what was
8037: afar from her and to be widely benignant, she had ardor enough for what
8038: was near, to have kissed Mr. Casaubon’s coat-sleeve, or to have
8039: caressed his shoe-latchet, if he would have made any other sign of
8040: acceptance than pronouncing her, with his unfailing propriety, to be of
8041: a most affectionate and truly feminine nature, indicating at the same
8042: time by politely reaching a chair for her that he regarded these
8043: manifestations as rather crude and startling. Having made his clerical
8044: toilet with due care in the morning, he was prepared only for those
8045: amenities of life which were suited to the well-adjusted stiff cravat
8046: of the period, and to a mind weighted with unpublished matter.
8047: 
8048: And by a sad contradiction Dorothea’s ideas and resolves seemed like
8049: melting ice floating and lost in the warm flood of which they had been
8050: but another form. She was humiliated to find herself a mere victim of
8051: feeling, as if she could know nothing except through that medium: all
8052: her strength was scattered in fits of agitation, of struggle, of
8053: despondency, and then again in visions of more complete renunciation,
8054: transforming all hard conditions into duty. Poor Dorothea! she was
8055: certainly troublesome—to herself chiefly; but this morning for the
8056: first time she had been troublesome to Mr. Casaubon.
8057: 
8058: She had begun, while they were taking coffee, with a determination to
8059: shake off what she inwardly called her selfishness, and turned a face
8060: all cheerful attention to her husband when he said, “My dear Dorothea,
8061: we must now think of all that is yet left undone, as a preliminary to
8062: our departure. I would fain have returned home earlier that we might
8063: have been at Lowick for the Christmas; but my inquiries here have been
8064: protracted beyond their anticipated period. I trust, however, that the
8065: time here has not been passed unpleasantly to you. Among the sights of
8066: Europe, that of Rome has ever been held one of the most striking and in
8067: some respects edifying. I well remember that I considered it an epoch
8068: in my life when I visited it for the first time; after the fall of
8069: Napoleon, an event which opened the Continent to travellers. Indeed I
8070: think it is one among several cities to which an extreme hyperbole has
8071: been applied—‘See Rome and die:’ but in your case I would propose an
8072: emendation and say, See Rome as a bride, and live henceforth as a happy
8073: wife.”
8074: 
8075: Mr. Casaubon pronounced this little speech with the most conscientious
8076: intention, blinking a little and swaying his head up and down, and
8077: concluding with a smile. He had not found marriage a rapturous state,
8078: but he had no idea of being anything else than an irreproachable
8079: husband, who would make a charming young woman as happy as she deserved
8080: to be.
8081: 
8082: “I hope you are thoroughly satisfied with our stay—I mean, with the
8083: result so far as your studies are concerned,” said Dorothea, trying to
8084: keep her mind fixed on what most affected her husband.
8085: 
8086: “Yes,” said Mr. Casaubon, with that peculiar pitch of voice which makes
8087: the word half a negative. “I have been led farther than I had foreseen,
8088: and various subjects for annotation have presented themselves which,
8089: though I have no direct need of them, I could not pretermit. The task,
8090: notwithstanding the assistance of my amanuensis, has been a somewhat
8091: laborious one, but your society has happily prevented me from that too
8092: continuous prosecution of thought beyond the hours of study which has
8093: been the snare of my solitary life.”
8094: 
8095: “I am very glad that my presence has made any difference to you,” said
8096: Dorothea, who had a vivid memory of evenings in which she had supposed
8097: that Mr. Casaubon’s mind had gone too deep during the day to be able to
8098: get to the surface again. I fear there was a little temper in her
8099: reply. “I hope when we get to Lowick, I shall be more useful to you,
8100: and be able to enter a little more into what interests you.”
8101: 
8102: “Doubtless, my dear,” said Mr. Casaubon, with a slight bow. “The notes
8103: I have here made will want sifting, and you can, if you please, extract
8104: them under my direction.”
8105: 
8106: “And all your notes,” said Dorothea, whose heart had already burned
8107: within her on this subject, so that now she could not help speaking
8108: with her tongue. “All those rows of volumes—will you not now do what
8109: you used to speak of?—will you not make up your mind what part of them
8110: you will use, and begin to write the book which will make your vast
8111: knowledge useful to the world? I will write to your dictation, or I
8112: will copy and extract what you tell me: I can be of no other use.”
8113: Dorothea, in a most unaccountable, darkly feminine manner, ended with a
8114: slight sob and eyes full of tears.
8115: 
8116: The excessive feeling manifested would alone have been highly
8117: disturbing to Mr. Casaubon, but there were other reasons why Dorothea’s
8118: words were among the most cutting and irritating to him that she could
8119: have been impelled to use. She was as blind to his inward troubles as
8120: he to hers: she had not yet learned those hidden conflicts in her
8121: husband which claim our pity. She had not yet listened patiently to his
8122: heartbeats, but only felt that her own was beating violently. In Mr.
8123: Casaubon’s ear, Dorothea’s voice gave loud emphatic iteration to those
8124: muffled suggestions of consciousness which it was possible to explain
8125: as mere fancy, the illusion of exaggerated sensitiveness: always when
8126: such suggestions are unmistakably repeated from without, they are
8127: resisted as cruel and unjust. We are angered even by the full
8128: acceptance of our humiliating confessions—how much more by hearing in
8129: hard distinct syllables from the lips of a near observer, those
8130: confused murmurs which we try to call morbid, and strive against as if
8131: they were the oncoming of numbness! And this cruel outward accuser was
8132: there in the shape of a wife—nay, of a young bride, who, instead of
8133: observing his abundant pen-scratches and amplitude of paper with the
8134: uncritical awe of an elegant-minded canary-bird, seemed to present
8135: herself as a spy watching everything with a malign power of inference.
8136: Here, towards this particular point of the compass, Mr. Casaubon had a
8137: sensitiveness to match Dorothea’s, and an equal quickness to imagine
8138: more than the fact. He had formerly observed with approbation her
8139: capacity for worshipping the right object; he now foresaw with sudden
8140: terror that this capacity might be replaced by presumption, this
8141: worship by the most exasperating of all criticism,—that which sees
8142: vaguely a great many fine ends, and has not the least notion what it
8143: costs to reach them.
8144: 
8145: For the first time since Dorothea had known him, Mr. Casaubon’s face
8146: had a quick angry flush upon it.
8147: 
8148: “My love,” he said, with irritation reined in by propriety, “you may
8149: rely upon me for knowing the times and the seasons, adapted to the
8150: different stages of a work which is not to be measured by the facile
8151: conjectures of ignorant onlookers. It had been easy for me to gain a
8152: temporary effect by a mirage of baseless opinion; but it is ever the
8153: trial of the scrupulous explorer to be saluted with the impatient scorn
8154: of chatterers who attempt only the smallest achievements, being indeed
8155: equipped for no other. And it were well if all such could be admonished
8156: to discriminate judgments of which the true subject-matter lies
8157: entirely beyond their reach, from those of which the elements may be
8158: compassed by a narrow and superficial survey.”
8159: 
8160: This speech was delivered with an energy and readiness quite unusual
8161: with Mr. Casaubon. It was not indeed entirely an improvisation, but had
8162: taken shape in inward colloquy, and rushed out like the round grains
8163: from a fruit when sudden heat cracks it. Dorothea was not only his
8164: wife: she was a personification of that shallow world which surrounds
8165: the appreciated or desponding author.
8166: 
8167: Dorothea was indignant in her turn. Had she not been repressing
8168: everything in herself except the desire to enter into some fellowship
8169: with her husband’s chief interests?
8170: 
8171: “My judgment _was_ a very superficial one—such as I am capable of
8172: forming,” she answered, with a prompt resentment, that needed no
8173: rehearsal. “You showed me the rows of notebooks—you have often spoken
8174: of them—you have often said that they wanted digesting. But I never
8175: heard you speak of the writing that is to be published. Those were very
8176: simple facts, and my judgment went no farther. I only begged you to let
8177: me be of some good to you.”
8178: 
8179: Dorothea rose to leave the table and Mr. Casaubon made no reply, taking
8180: up a letter which lay beside him as if to reperuse it. Both were
8181: shocked at their mutual situation—that each should have betrayed anger
8182: towards the other. If they had been at home, settled at Lowick in
8183: ordinary life among their neighbors, the clash would have been less
8184: embarrassing: but on a wedding journey, the express object of which is
8185: to isolate two people on the ground that they are all the world to each
8186: other, the sense of disagreement is, to say the least, confounding and
8187: stultifying. To have changed your longitude extensively and placed
8188: yourselves in a moral solitude in order to have small explosions, to
8189: find conversation difficult and to hand a glass of water without
8190: looking, can hardly be regarded as satisfactory fulfilment even to the
8191: toughest minds. To Dorothea’s inexperienced sensitiveness, it seemed
8192: like a catastrophe, changing all prospects; and to Mr. Casaubon it was
8193: a new pain, he never having been on a wedding journey before, or found
8194: himself in that close union which was more of a subjection than he had
8195: been able to imagine, since this charming young bride not only obliged
8196: him to much consideration on her behalf (which he had sedulously
8197: given), but turned out to be capable of agitating him cruelly just
8198: where he most needed soothing. Instead of getting a soft fence against
8199: the cold, shadowy, unapplausive audience of his life, had he only given
8200: it a more substantial presence?
8201: 
8202: Neither of them felt it possible to speak again at present. To have
8203: reversed a previous arrangement and declined to go out would have been
8204: a show of persistent anger which Dorothea’s conscience shrank from,
8205: seeing that she already began to feel herself guilty. However just her
8206: indignation might be, her ideal was not to claim justice, but to give
8207: tenderness. So when the carriage came to the door, she drove with Mr.
8208: Casaubon to the Vatican, walked with him through the stony avenue of
8209: inscriptions, and when she parted with him at the entrance to the
8210: Library, went on through the Museum out of mere listlessness as to what
8211: was around her. She had not spirit to turn round and say that she would
8212: drive anywhere. It was when Mr. Casaubon was quitting her that Naumann
8213: had first seen her, and he had entered the long gallery of sculpture at
8214: the same time with her; but here Naumann had to await Ladislaw with
8215: whom he was to settle a bet of champagne about an enigmatical
8216: mediaeval-looking figure there. After they had examined the figure, and
8217: had walked on finishing their dispute, they had parted, Ladislaw
8218: lingering behind while Naumann had gone into the Hall of Statues where
8219: he again saw Dorothea, and saw her in that brooding abstraction which
8220: made her pose remarkable. She did not really see the streak of sunlight
8221: on the floor more than she saw the statues: she was inwardly seeing the
8222: light of years to come in her own home and over the English fields and
8223: elms and hedge-bordered highroads; and feeling that the way in which
8224: they might be filled with joyful devotedness was not so clear to her as
8225: it had been. But in Dorothea’s mind there was a current into which all
8226: thought and feeling were apt sooner or later to flow—the reaching
8227: forward of the whole consciousness towards the fullest truth, the least
8228: partial good. There was clearly something better than anger and
8229: despondency.
8230: 
8231: 
8232: 
8233: 
8234: CHAPTER XXI.
8235: 
8236: “Hire facounde eke full womanly and plain,
8237: No contrefeted termes had she
8238: To semen wise.”
8239: —CHAUCER.
8240: 
8241: 
8242: It was in that way Dorothea came to be sobbing as soon as she was
8243: securely alone. But she was presently roused by a knock at the door,
8244: which made her hastily dry her eyes before saying, “Come in.” Tantripp
8245: had brought a card, and said that there was a gentleman waiting in the
8246: lobby. The courier had told him that only Mrs. Casaubon was at home,
8247: but he said he was a relation of Mr. Casaubon’s: would she see him?
8248: 
8249: “Yes,” said Dorothea, without pause; “show him into the salon.” Her
8250: chief impressions about young Ladislaw were that when she had seen him
8251: at Lowick she had been made aware of Mr. Casaubon’s generosity towards
8252: him, and also that she had been interested in his own hesitation about
8253: his career. She was alive to anything that gave her an opportunity for
8254: active sympathy, and at this moment it seemed as if the visit had come
8255: to shake her out of her self-absorbed discontent—to remind her of her
8256: husband’s goodness, and make her feel that she had now the right to be
8257: his helpmate in all kind deeds. She waited a minute or two, but when
8258: she passed into the next room there were just signs enough that she had
8259: been crying to make her open face look more youthful and appealing than
8260: usual. She met Ladislaw with that exquisite smile of good-will which is
8261: unmixed with vanity, and held out her hand to him. He was the elder by
8262: several years, but at that moment he looked much the younger, for his
8263: transparent complexion flushed suddenly, and he spoke with a shyness
8264: extremely unlike the ready indifference of his manner with his male
8265: companion, while Dorothea became all the calmer with a wondering desire
8266: to put him at ease.
8267: 
8268: “I was not aware that you and Mr. Casaubon were in Rome, until this
8269: morning, when I saw you in the Vatican Museum,” he said. “I knew you at
8270: once—but—I mean, that I concluded Mr. Casaubon’s address would be found
8271: at the Poste Restante, and I was anxious to pay my respects to him and
8272: you as early as possible.”
8273: 
8274: “Pray sit down. He is not here now, but he will be glad to hear of you,
8275: I am sure,” said Dorothea, seating herself unthinkingly between the
8276: fire and the light of the tall window, and pointing to a chair
8277: opposite, with the quietude of a benignant matron. The signs of girlish
8278: sorrow in her face were only the more striking. “Mr. Casaubon is much
8279: engaged; but you will leave your address—will you not?—and he will
8280: write to you.”
8281: 
8282: “You are very good,” said Ladislaw, beginning to lose his diffidence in
8283: the interest with which he was observing the signs of weeping which had
8284: altered her face. “My address is on my card. But if you will allow me I
