8285: will call again to-morrow at an hour when Mr. Casaubon is likely to be
8286: at home.”
8287: 
8288: “He goes to read in the Library of the Vatican every day, and you can
8289: hardly see him except by an appointment. Especially now. We are about
8290: to leave Rome, and he is very busy. He is usually away almost from
8291: breakfast till dinner. But I am sure he will wish you to dine with us.”
8292: 
8293: Will Ladislaw was struck mute for a few moments. He had never been fond
8294: of Mr. Casaubon, and if it had not been for the sense of obligation,
8295: would have laughed at him as a Bat of erudition. But the idea of this
8296: dried-up pedant, this elaborator of small explanations about as
8297: important as the surplus stock of false antiquities kept in a vendor’s
8298: back chamber, having first got this adorable young creature to marry
8299: him, and then passing his honeymoon away from her, groping after his
8300: mouldy futilities (Will was given to hyperbole)—this sudden picture
8301: stirred him with a sort of comic disgust: he was divided between the
8302: impulse to laugh aloud and the equally unseasonable impulse to burst
8303: into scornful invective.
8304: 
8305: For an instant he felt that the struggle was causing a queer contortion
8306: of his mobile features, but with a good effort he resolved it into
8307: nothing more offensive than a merry smile.
8308: 
8309: Dorothea wondered; but the smile was irresistible, and shone back from
8310: her face too. Will Ladislaw’s smile was delightful, unless you were
8311: angry with him beforehand: it was a gush of inward light illuminating
8312: the transparent skin as well as the eyes, and playing about every curve
8313: and line as if some Ariel were touching them with a new charm, and
8314: banishing forever the traces of moodiness. The reflection of that smile
8315: could not but have a little merriment in it too, even under dark
8316: eyelashes still moist, as Dorothea said inquiringly, “Something amuses
8317: you?”
8318: 
8319: “Yes,” said Will, quick in finding resources. “I am thinking of the
8320: sort of figure I cut the first time I saw you, when you annihilated my
8321: poor sketch with your criticism.”
8322: 
8323: “My criticism?” said Dorothea, wondering still more. “Surely not. I
8324: always feel particularly ignorant about painting.”
8325: 
8326: “I suspected you of knowing so much, that you knew how to say just what
8327: was most cutting. You said—I dare say you don’t remember it as I
8328: do—that the relation of my sketch to nature was quite hidden from you.
8329: At least, you implied that.” Will could laugh now as well as smile.
8330: 
8331: “That was really my ignorance,” said Dorothea, admiring Will’s
8332: good-humor. “I must have said so only because I never could see any
8333: beauty in the pictures which my uncle told me all judges thought very
8334: fine. And I have gone about with just the same ignorance in Rome. There
8335: are comparatively few paintings that I can really enjoy. At first when
8336: I enter a room where the walls are covered with frescos, or with rare
8337: pictures, I feel a kind of awe—like a child present at great ceremonies
8338: where there are grand robes and processions; I feel myself in the
8339: presence of some higher life than my own. But when I begin to examine
8340: the pictures one by one the life goes out of them, or else is something
8341: violent and strange to me. It must be my own dulness. I am seeing so
8342: much all at once, and not understanding half of it. That always makes
8343: one feel stupid. It is painful to be told that anything is very fine
8344: and not be able to feel that it is fine—something like being blind,
8345: while people talk of the sky.”
8346: 
8347: “Oh, there is a great deal in the feeling for art which must be
8348: acquired,” said Will. (It was impossible now to doubt the directness of
8349: Dorothea’s confession.) “Art is an old language with a great many
8350: artificial affected styles, and sometimes the chief pleasure one gets
8351: out of knowing them is the mere sense of knowing. I enjoy the art of
8352: all sorts here immensely; but I suppose if I could pick my enjoyment to
8353: pieces I should find it made up of many different threads. There is
8354: something in daubing a little one’s self, and having an idea of the
8355: process.”
8356: 
8357: “You mean perhaps to be a painter?” said Dorothea, with a new direction
8358: of interest. “You mean to make painting your profession? Mr. Casaubon
8359: will like to hear that you have chosen a profession.”
8360: 
8361: “No, oh no,” said Will, with some coldness. “I have quite made up my
8362: mind against it. It is too one-sided a life. I have been seeing a great
8363: deal of the German artists here: I travelled from Frankfort with one of
8364: them. Some are fine, even brilliant fellows—but I should not like to
8365: get into their way of looking at the world entirely from the studio
8366: point of view.”
8367: 
8368: “That I can understand,” said Dorothea, cordially. “And in Rome it
8369: seems as if there were so many things which are more wanted in the
8370: world than pictures. But if you have a genius for painting, would it
8371: not be right to take that as a guide? Perhaps you might do better
8372: things than these—or different, so that there might not be so many
8373: pictures almost all alike in the same place.”
8374: 
8375: There was no mistaking this simplicity, and Will was won by it into
8376: frankness. “A man must have a very rare genius to make changes of that
8377: sort. I am afraid mine would not carry me even to the pitch of doing
8378: well what has been done already, at least not so well as to make it
8379: worth while. And I should never succeed in anything by dint of
8380: drudgery. If things don’t come easily to me I never get them.”
8381: 
8382: “I have heard Mr. Casaubon say that he regrets your want of patience,”
8383: said Dorothea, gently. She was rather shocked at this mode of taking
8384: all life as a holiday.
8385: 
8386: “Yes, I know Mr. Casaubon’s opinion. He and I differ.”
8387: 
8388: The slight streak of contempt in this hasty reply offended Dorothea.
8389: She was all the more susceptible about Mr. Casaubon because of her
8390: morning’s trouble.
8391: 
8392: “Certainly you differ,” she said, rather proudly. “I did not think of
8393: comparing you: such power of persevering devoted labor as Mr.
8394: Casaubon’s is not common.”
8395: 
8396: Will saw that she was offended, but this only gave an additional
8397: impulse to the new irritation of his latent dislike towards Mr.
8398: Casaubon. It was too intolerable that Dorothea should be worshipping
8399: this husband: such weakness in a woman is pleasant to no man but the
8400: husband in question. Mortals are easily tempted to pinch the life out
8401: of their neighbor’s buzzing glory, and think that such killing is no
8402: murder.
8403: 
8404: “No, indeed,” he answered, promptly. “And therefore it is a pity that
8405: it should be thrown away, as so much English scholarship is, for want
8406: of knowing what is being done by the rest of the world. If Mr. Casaubon
8407: read German he would save himself a great deal of trouble.”
8408: 
8409: “I do not understand you,” said Dorothea, startled and anxious.
8410: 
8411: “I merely mean,” said Will, in an offhand way, “that the Germans have
8412: taken the lead in historical inquiries, and they laugh at results which
8413: are got by groping about in woods with a pocket-compass while they have
8414: made good roads. When I was with Mr. Casaubon I saw that he deafened
8415: himself in that direction: it was almost against his will that he read
8416: a Latin treatise written by a German. I was very sorry.”
8417: 
8418: Will only thought of giving a good pinch that would annihilate that
8419: vaunted laboriousness, and was unable to imagine the mode in which
8420: Dorothea would be wounded. Young Mr. Ladislaw was not at all deep
8421: himself in German writers; but very little achievement is required in
8422: order to pity another man’s shortcomings.
8423: 
8424: Poor Dorothea felt a pang at the thought that the labor of her
8425: husband’s life might be void, which left her no energy to spare for the
8426: question whether this young relative who was so much obliged to him
8427: ought not to have repressed his observation. She did not even speak,
8428: but sat looking at her hands, absorbed in the piteousness of that
8429: thought.
8430: 
8431: Will, however, having given that annihilating pinch, was rather
8432: ashamed, imagining from Dorothea’s silence that he had offended her
8433: still more; and having also a conscience about plucking the
8434: tail-feathers from a benefactor.
8435: 
8436: “I regretted it especially,” he resumed, taking the usual course from
8437: detraction to insincere eulogy, “because of my gratitude and respect
8438: towards my cousin. It would not signify so much in a man whose talents
8439: and character were less distinguished.”
8440: 
8441: Dorothea raised her eyes, brighter than usual with excited feeling, and
8442: said in her saddest recitative, “How I wish I had learned German when I
8443: was at Lausanne! There were plenty of German teachers. But now I can be
8444: of no use.”
8445: 
8446: There was a new light, but still a mysterious light, for Will in
8447: Dorothea’s last words. The question how she had come to accept Mr.
8448: Casaubon—which he had dismissed when he first saw her by saying that
8449: she must be disagreeable in spite of appearances—was not now to be
8450: answered on any such short and easy method. Whatever else she might be,
8451: she was not disagreeable. She was not coldly clever and indirectly
8452: satirical, but adorably simple and full of feeling. She was an angel
8453: beguiled. It would be a unique delight to wait and watch for the
8454: melodious fragments in which her heart and soul came forth so directly
8455: and ingenuously. The Aeolian harp again came into his mind.
8456: 
8457: She must have made some original romance for herself in this marriage.
8458: And if Mr. Casaubon had been a dragon who had carried her off to his
8459: lair with his talons simply and without legal forms, it would have been
8460: an unavoidable feat of heroism to release her and fall at her feet. But
8461: he was something more unmanageable than a dragon: he was a benefactor
8462: with collective society at his back, and he was at that moment entering
8463: the room in all the unimpeachable correctness of his demeanor, while
8464: Dorothea was looking animated with a newly roused alarm and regret, and
8465: Will was looking animated with his admiring speculation about her
8466: feelings.
8467: 
8468: Mr. Casaubon felt a surprise which was quite unmixed with pleasure, but
8469: he did not swerve from his usual politeness of greeting, when Will rose
8470: and explained his presence. Mr. Casaubon was less happy than usual, and
8471: this perhaps made him look all the dimmer and more faded; else, the
8472: effect might easily have been produced by the contrast of his young
8473: cousin’s appearance. The first impression on seeing Will was one of
8474: sunny brightness, which added to the uncertainty of his changing
8475: expression. Surely, his very features changed their form, his jaw
8476: looked sometimes large and sometimes small; and the little ripple in
8477: his nose was a preparation for metamorphosis. When he turned his head
8478: quickly his hair seemed to shake out light, and some persons thought
8479: they saw decided genius in this coruscation. Mr. Casaubon, on the
8480: contrary, stood rayless.
8481: 
8482: As Dorothea’s eyes were turned anxiously on her husband she was perhaps
8483: not insensible to the contrast, but it was only mingled with other
8484: causes in making her more conscious of that new alarm on his behalf
8485: which was the first stirring of a pitying tenderness fed by the
8486: realities of his lot and not by her own dreams. Yet it was a source of
8487: greater freedom to her that Will was there; his young equality was
8488: agreeable, and also perhaps his openness to conviction. She felt an
8489: immense need of some one to speak to, and she had never before seen any
8490: one who seemed so quick and pliable, so likely to understand
8491: everything.
8492: 
8493: Mr. Casaubon gravely hoped that Will was passing his time profitably as
8494: well as pleasantly in Rome—had thought his intention was to remain in
8495: South Germany—but begged him to come and dine to-morrow, when he could
8496: converse more at large: at present he was somewhat weary. Ladislaw
8497: understood, and accepting the invitation immediately took his leave.
8498: 
8499: Dorothea’s eyes followed her husband anxiously, while he sank down
8500: wearily at the end of a sofa, and resting his elbow supported his head
8501: and looked on the floor. A little flushed, and with bright eyes, she
8502: seated herself beside him, and said—
8503: 
8504: “Forgive me for speaking so hastily to you this morning. I was wrong. I
8505: fear I hurt you and made the day more burdensome.”
8506: 
8507: “I am glad that you feel that, my dear,” said Mr. Casaubon. He spoke
8508: quietly and bowed his head a little, but there was still an uneasy
8509: feeling in his eyes as he looked at her.
8510: 
8511: “But you do forgive me?” said Dorothea, with a quick sob. In her need
8512: for some manifestation of feeling she was ready to exaggerate her own
8513: fault. Would not love see returning penitence afar off, and fall on its
8514: neck and kiss it?
8515: 
8516: “My dear Dorothea—‘who with repentance is not satisfied, is not of
8517: heaven nor earth:’—you do not think me worthy to be banished by that
8518: severe sentence,” said Mr. Casaubon, exerting himself to make a strong
8519: statement, and also to smile faintly.
8520: 
8521: Dorothea was silent, but a tear which had come up with the sob would
8522: insist on falling.
8523: 
8524: “You are excited, my dear. And I also am feeling some unpleasant
8525: consequences of too much mental disturbance,” said Mr. Casaubon. In
8526: fact, he had it in his thought to tell her that she ought not to have
8527: received young Ladislaw in his absence: but he abstained, partly from
8528: the sense that it would be ungracious to bring a new complaint in the
8529: moment of her penitent acknowledgment, partly because he wanted to
8530: avoid further agitation of himself by speech, and partly because he was
8531: too proud to betray that jealousy of disposition which was not so
8532: exhausted on his scholarly compeers that there was none to spare in
8533: other directions. There is a sort of jealousy which needs very little
8534: fire: it is hardly a passion, but a blight bred in the cloudy, damp
8535: despondency of uneasy egoism.
8536: 
8537: “I think it is time for us to dress,” he added, looking at his watch.
8538: They both rose, and there was never any further allusion between them
8539: to what had passed on this day.
8540: 
8541: But Dorothea remembered it to the last with the vividness with which we
8542: all remember epochs in our experience when some dear expectation dies,
8543: or some new motive is born. Today she had begun to see that she had
8544: been under a wild illusion in expecting a response to her feeling from
8545: Mr. Casaubon, and she had felt the waking of a presentiment that there
8546: might be a sad consciousness in his life which made as great a need on
8547: his side as on her own.
8548: 
8549: We are all of us born in moral stupidity, taking the world as an udder
8550: to feed our supreme selves: Dorothea had early begun to emerge from
8551: that stupidity, but yet it had been easier to her to imagine how she
8552: would devote herself to Mr. Casaubon, and become wise and strong in his
8553: strength and wisdom, than to conceive with that distinctness which is
8554: no longer reflection but feeling—an idea wrought back to the directness
8555: of sense, like the solidity of objects—that he had an equivalent centre
8556: of self, whence the lights and shadows must always fall with a certain
8557: difference.
8558: 
8559: 
8560: 
8561: 
8562: CHAPTER XXII.
8563: 
8564: “Nous câusames longtemps; elle était simple et bonne.
8565: Ne sachant pas le mal, elle faisait le bien;
8566: Des richesses du coeur elle me fit l’aumône,
8567: Et tout en écoutant comme le coeur se donne,
8568: Sans oser y penser je lui donnai le mien;
8569: Elle emporta ma vie, et n’en sut jamais rien.”
8570: —ALFRED DE MUSSET.
8571: 
8572: 
8573: Will Ladislaw was delightfully agreeable at dinner the next day, and
8574: gave no opportunity for Mr. Casaubon to show disapprobation. On the
8575: contrary it seemed to Dorothea that Will had a happier way of drawing
8576: her husband into conversation and of deferentially listening to him
8577: than she had ever observed in any one before. To be sure, the listeners
8578: about Tipton were not highly gifted! Will talked a good deal himself,
8579: but what he said was thrown in with such rapidity, and with such an
8580: unimportant air of saying something by the way, that it seemed a gay
8581: little chime after the great bell. If Will was not always perfect, this
8582: was certainly one of his good days. He described touches of incident
8583: among the poor people in Rome, only to be seen by one who could move
8584: about freely; he found himself in agreement with Mr. Casaubon as to the
8585: unsound opinions of Middleton concerning the relations of Judaism and
8586: Catholicism; and passed easily to a half-enthusiastic half-playful
8587: picture of the enjoyment he got out of the very miscellaneousness of
8588: Rome, which made the mind flexible with constant comparison, and saved
8589: you from seeing the world’s ages as a set of box-like partitions
8590: without vital connection. Mr. Casaubon’s studies, Will observed, had
8591: always been of too broad a kind for that, and he had perhaps never felt
8592: any such sudden effect, but for himself he confessed that Rome had
8593: given him quite a new sense of history as a whole: the fragments
8594: stimulated his imagination and made him constructive. Then
8595: occasionally, but not too often, he appealed to Dorothea, and discussed
8596: what she said, as if her sentiment were an item to be considered in the
8597: final judgment even of the Madonna di Foligno or the Laocoon. A sense
8598: of contributing to form the world’s opinion makes conversation
8599: particularly cheerful; and Mr. Casaubon too was not without his pride
8600: in his young wife, who spoke better than most women, as indeed he had
8601: perceived in choosing her.
8602: 
8603: Since things were going on so pleasantly, Mr. Casaubon’s statement that
8604: his labors in the Library would be suspended for a couple of days, and
8605: that after a brief renewal he should have no further reason for staying
8606: in Rome, encouraged Will to urge that Mrs. Casaubon should not go away
8607: without seeing a studio or two. Would not Mr. Casaubon take her? That
8608: sort of thing ought not to be missed: it was quite special: it was a
8609: form of life that grew like a small fresh vegetation with its
8610: population of insects on huge fossils. Will would be happy to conduct
8611: them—not to anything wearisome, only to a few examples.
8612: 
8613: Mr. Casaubon, seeing Dorothea look earnestly towards him, could not but
8614: ask her if she would be interested in such visits: he was now at her
8615: service during the whole day; and it was agreed that Will should come
8616: on the morrow and drive with them.
8617: 
8618: Will could not omit Thorwaldsen, a living celebrity about whom even Mr.
8619: Casaubon inquired, but before the day was far advanced he led the way
8620: to the studio of his friend Adolf Naumann, whom he mentioned as one of
8621: the chief renovators of Christian art, one of those who had not only
8622: revived but expanded that grand conception of supreme events as
8623: mysteries at which the successive ages were spectators, and in relation
8624: to which the great souls of all periods became as it were
8625: contemporaries. Will added that he had made himself Naumann’s pupil for
8626: the nonce.
8627: 
8628: “I have been making some oil-sketches under him,” said Will. “I hate
8629: copying. I must put something of my own in. Naumann has been painting
8630: the Saints drawing the Car of the Church, and I have been making a
8631: sketch of Marlowe’s Tamburlaine Driving the Conquered Kings in his
8632: Chariot. I am not so ecclesiastical as Naumann, and I sometimes twit
8633: him with his excess of meaning. But this time I mean to outdo him in
8634: breadth of intention. I take Tamburlaine in his chariot for the
8635: tremendous course of the world’s physical history lashing on the
8636: harnessed dynasties. In my opinion, that is a good mythical
8637: interpretation.” Will here looked at Mr. Casaubon, who received this
8638: offhand treatment of symbolism very uneasily, and bowed with a neutral
8639: air.
8640: 
8641: “The sketch must be very grand, if it conveys so much,” said Dorothea.
8642: “I should need some explanation even of the meaning you give. Do you
8643: intend Tamburlaine to represent earthquakes and volcanoes?”
8644: 
8645: “Oh yes,” said Will, laughing, “and migrations of races and clearings
8646: of forests—and America and the steam-engine. Everything you can
8647: imagine!”
8648: 
8649: “What a difficult kind of shorthand!” said Dorothea, smiling towards
8650: her husband. “It would require all your knowledge to be able to read
8651: it.”
8652: 
8653: Mr. Casaubon blinked furtively at Will. He had a suspicion that he was
8654: being laughed at. But it was not possible to include Dorothea in the
8655: suspicion.
8656: 
8657: They found Naumann painting industriously, but no model was present;
8658: his pictures were advantageously arranged, and his own plain vivacious
8659: person set off by a dove-colored blouse and a maroon velvet cap, so
8660: that everything was as fortunate as if he had expected the beautiful
8661: young English lady exactly at that time.
8662: 
8663: The painter in his confident English gave little dissertations on his
8664: finished and unfinished subjects, seeming to observe Mr. Casaubon as
8665: much as he did Dorothea. Will burst in here and there with ardent words
8666: of praise, marking out particular merits in his friend’s work; and
8667: Dorothea felt that she was getting quite new notions as to the
8668: significance of Madonnas seated under inexplicable canopied thrones
8669: with the simple country as a background, and of saints with
8670: architectural models in their hands, or knives accidentally wedged in
8671: their skulls. Some things which had seemed monstrous to her were
8672: gathering intelligibility and even a natural meaning: but all this was
8673: apparently a branch of knowledge in which Mr. Casaubon had not
8674: interested himself.
8675: 
8676: “I think I would rather feel that painting is beautiful than have to
8677: read it as an enigma; but I should learn to understand these pictures
8678: sooner than yours with the very wide meaning,” said Dorothea, speaking
8679: to Will.
8680: 
8681: “Don’t speak of my painting before Naumann,” said Will. “He will tell
8682: you, it is all _pfuscherei_, which is his most opprobrious word!”
8683: 
8684: “Is that true?” said Dorothea, turning her sincere eyes on Naumann, who
8685: made a slight grimace and said—
8686: 
8687: “Oh, he does not mean it seriously with painting. His walk must be
8688: _belles-lettres_. That is wi-ide.”
8689: 
8690: Naumann’s pronunciation of the vowel seemed to stretch the word
8691: satirically. Will did not half like it, but managed to laugh: and Mr.
8692: Casaubon, while he felt some disgust at the artist’s German accent,
8693: began to entertain a little respect for his judicious severity.
8694: 
8695: The respect was not diminished when Naumann, after drawing Will aside
8696: for a moment and looking, first at a large canvas, then at Mr.
8697: Casaubon, came forward again and said—
8698: 
8699: “My friend Ladislaw thinks you will pardon me, sir, if I say that a
8700: sketch of your head would be invaluable to me for the St. Thomas
8701: Aquinas in my picture there. It is too much to ask; but I so seldom see
8702: just what I want—the idealistic in the real.”
8703: 
8704: “You astonish me greatly, sir,” said Mr. Casaubon, his looks improved
8705: with a glow of delight; “but if my poor physiognomy, which I have been
8706: accustomed to regard as of the commonest order, can be of any use to
8707: you in furnishing some traits for the angelical doctor, I shall feel
8708: honored. That is to say, if the operation will not be a lengthy one;
8709: and if Mrs. Casaubon will not object to the delay.”
8710: 
8711: As for Dorothea, nothing could have pleased her more, unless it had
8712: been a miraculous voice pronouncing Mr. Casaubon the wisest and
8713: worthiest among the sons of men. In that case her tottering faith would
8714: have become firm again.
8715: 
8716: Naumann’s apparatus was at hand in wonderful completeness, and the
8717: sketch went on at once as well as the conversation. Dorothea sat down
8718: and subsided into calm silence, feeling happier than she had done for a
8719: long while before. Every one about her seemed good, and she said to
8720: herself that Rome, if she had only been less ignorant, would have been
8721: full of beauty: its sadness would have been winged with hope. No nature
8722: could be less suspicious than hers: when she was a child she believed
8723: in the gratitude of wasps and the honorable susceptibility of sparrows,
8724: and was proportionately indignant when their baseness was made
8725: manifest.
8726: 
8727: The adroit artist was asking Mr. Casaubon questions about English
8728: polities, which brought long answers, and, Will meanwhile had perched
8729: himself on some steps in the background overlooking all.
8730: 
8731: Presently Naumann said—“Now if I could lay this by for half an hour and
8732: take it up again—come and look, Ladislaw—I think it is perfect so far.”
8733: 
8734: Will vented those adjuring interjections which imply that admiration is
8735: too strong for syntax; and Naumann said in a tone of piteous regret—
8736: 
8737: “Ah—now—if I could but have had more—but you have other engagements—I
8738: could not ask it—or even to come again to-morrow.”
8739: 
8740: “Oh, let us stay!” said Dorothea. “We have nothing to do to-day except
8741: go about, have we?” she added, looking entreatingly at Mr. Casaubon.
8742: “It would be a pity not to make the head as good as possible.”
8743: 
8744: “I am at your service, sir, in the matter,” said Mr. Casaubon, with
8745: polite condescension. “Having given up the interior of my head to
8746: idleness, it is as well that the exterior should work in this way.”
8747: 
8748: “You are unspeakably good—now I am happy!” said Naumann, and then went
8749: on in German to Will, pointing here and there to the sketch as if he
8750: were considering that. Putting it aside for a moment, he looked round
8751: vaguely, as if seeking some occupation for his visitors, and afterwards
8752: turning to Mr. Casaubon, said—
8753: 
8754: “Perhaps the beautiful bride, the gracious lady, would not be unwilling
8755: to let me fill up the time by trying to make a slight sketch of
8756: her—not, of course, as you see, for that picture—only as a single
8757: study.”
8758: 
8759: Mr. Casaubon, bowing, doubted not that Mrs. Casaubon would oblige him,
8760: and Dorothea said, at once, “Where shall I put myself?”
8761: 
8762: Naumann was all apologies in asking her to stand, and allow him to
8763: adjust her attitude, to which she submitted without any of the affected
8764: airs and laughs frequently thought necessary on such occasions, when
8765: the painter said, “It is as Santa Clara that I want you to
8766: stand—leaning so, with your cheek against your hand—so—looking at that
8767: stool, please, so!”
8768: 
8769: Will was divided between the inclination to fall at the Saint’s feet
8770: and kiss her robe, and the temptation to knock Naumann down while he
8771: was adjusting her arm. All this was impudence and desecration, and he
8772: repented that he had brought her.
8773: 
8774: The artist was diligent, and Will recovering himself moved about and
8775: occupied Mr. Casaubon as ingeniously as he could; but he did not in the
8776: end prevent the time from seeming long to that gentleman, as was clear
8777: from his expressing a fear that Mrs. Casaubon would be tired. Naumann
8778: took the hint and said—
8779: 
8780: “Now, sir, if you can oblige me again; I will release the lady-wife.”
8781: 
8782: So Mr. Casaubon’s patience held out further, and when after all it
8783: turned out that the head of Saint Thomas Aquinas would be more perfect
8784: if another sitting could be had, it was granted for the morrow. On the
8785: morrow Santa Clara too was retouched more than once. The result of all
8786: was so far from displeasing to Mr. Casaubon, that he arranged for the
8787: purchase of the picture in which Saint Thomas Aquinas sat among the
8788: doctors of the Church in a disputation too abstract to be represented,
8789: but listened to with more or less attention by an audience above. The
8790: Santa Clara, which was spoken of in the second place, Naumann declared
8791: himself to be dissatisfied with—he could not, in conscience, engage to
8792: make a worthy picture of it; so about the Santa Clara the arrangement
8793: was conditional.
8794: 
8795: I will not dwell on Naumann’s jokes at the expense of Mr. Casaubon that
8796: evening, or on his dithyrambs about Dorothea’s charm, in all which Will
8797: joined, but with a difference. No sooner did Naumann mention any detail
8798: of Dorothea’s beauty, than Will got exasperated at his presumption:
8799: there was grossness in his choice of the most ordinary words, and what
8800: business had he to talk of her lips? She was not a woman to be spoken
8801: of as other women were. Will could not say just what he thought, but he
8802: became irritable. And yet, when after some resistance he had consented
8803: to take the Casaubons to his friend’s studio, he had been allured by
8804: the gratification of his pride in being the person who could grant
8805: Naumann such an opportunity of studying her loveliness—or rather her
8806: divineness, for the ordinary phrases which might apply to mere bodily
8807: prettiness were not applicable to her. (Certainly all Tipton and its
8808: neighborhood, as well as Dorothea herself, would have been surprised at
8809: her beauty being made so much of. In that part of the world Miss Brooke
8810: had been only a “fine young woman.”)
8811: 
8812: “Oblige me by letting the subject drop, Naumann. Mrs. Casaubon is not
8813: to be talked of as if she were a model,” said Will. Naumann stared at
8814: him.
8815: 
8816: “Schön! I will talk of my Aquinas. The head is not a bad type, after
8817: all. I dare say the great scholastic himself would have been flattered
8818: to have his portrait asked for. Nothing like these starchy doctors for
8819: vanity! It was as I thought: he cared much less for her portrait than
8820: his own.”
8821: 
8822: “He’s a cursed white-blooded pedantic coxcomb,” said Will, with
8823: gnashing impetuosity. His obligations to Mr. Casaubon were not known to
8824: his hearer, but Will himself was thinking of them, and wishing that he
8825: could discharge them all by a check.
8826: 
8827: Naumann gave a shrug and said, “It is good they go away soon, my dear.
8828: They are spoiling your fine temper.”
8829: 
8830: All Will’s hope and contrivance were now concentrated on seeing
8831: Dorothea when she was alone. He only wanted her to take more emphatic
8832: notice of him; he only wanted to be something more special in her
8833: remembrance than he could yet believe himself likely to be. He was
8834: rather impatient under that open ardent good-will, which he saw was her
8835: usual state of feeling. The remote worship of a woman throned out of
8836: their reach plays a great part in men’s lives, but in most cases the
8837: worshipper longs for some queenly recognition, some approving sign by
8838: which his soul’s sovereign may cheer him without descending from her
8839: high place. That was precisely what Will wanted. But there were plenty
8840: of contradictions in his imaginative demands. It was beautiful to see
8841: how Dorothea’s eyes turned with wifely anxiety and beseeching to Mr.
8842: Casaubon: she would have lost some of her halo if she had been without
8843: that duteous preoccupation; and yet at the next moment the husband’s
8844: sandy absorption of such nectar was too intolerable; and Will’s longing
8845: to say damaging things about him was perhaps not the less tormenting
8846: because he felt the strongest reasons for restraining it.
8847: 
8848: Will had not been invited to dine the next day. Hence he persuaded
8849: himself that he was bound to call, and that the only eligible time was
8850: the middle of the day, when Mr. Casaubon would not be at home.
8851: 
8852: Dorothea, who had not been made aware that her former reception of Will
8853: had displeased her husband, had no hesitation about seeing him,
8854: especially as he might be come to pay a farewell visit. When he entered
8855: she was looking at some cameos which she had been buying for Celia. She
8856: greeted Will as if his visit were quite a matter of course, and said at
8857: once, having a cameo bracelet in her hand—
8858: 
8859: “I am so glad you are come. Perhaps you understand all about cameos,
8860: and can tell me if these are really good. I wished to have you with us
8861: in choosing them, but Mr. Casaubon objected: he thought there was not
8862: time. He will finish his work to-morrow, and we shall go away in three
8863: days. I have been uneasy about these cameos. Pray sit down and look at
8864: them.”
8865: 
8866: “I am not particularly knowing, but there can be no great mistake about
8867: these little Homeric bits: they are exquisitely neat. And the color is
8868: fine: it will just suit you.”
8869: 
8870: “Oh, they are for my sister, who has quite a different complexion. You
8871: saw her with me at Lowick: she is light-haired and very pretty—at least
8872: I think so. We were never so long away from each other in our lives
8873: before. She is a great pet and never was naughty in her life. I found
8874: out before I came away that she wanted me to buy her some cameos, and I
8875: should be sorry for them not to be good—after their kind.” Dorothea
8876: added the last words with a smile.
8877: 
8878: “You seem not to care about cameos,” said Will, seating himself at some
8879: distance from her, and observing her while she closed the cases.
8880: 
8881: “No, frankly, I don’t think them a great object in life,” said
8882: Dorothea.
8883: 
8884: “I fear you are a heretic about art generally. How is that? I should
8885: have expected you to be very sensitive to the beautiful everywhere.”
8886: 
8887: “I suppose I am dull about many things,” said Dorothea, simply. “I
8888: should like to make life beautiful—I mean everybody’s life. And then
8889: all this immense expense of art, that seems somehow to lie outside life
8890: and make it no better for the world, pains one. It spoils my enjoyment
8891: of anything when I am made to think that most people are shut out from
8892: it.”
8893: 
8894: “I call that the fanaticism of sympathy,” said Will, impetuously. “You
8895: might say the same of landscape, of poetry, of all refinement. If you
8896: carried it out you ought to be miserable in your own goodness, and turn
8897: evil that you might have no advantage over others. The best piety is to
8898: enjoy—when you can. You are doing the most then to save the earth’s
8899: character as an agreeable planet. And enjoyment radiates. It is of no
8900: use to try and take care of all the world; that is being taken care of
8901: when you feel delight—in art or in anything else. Would you turn all
8902: the youth of the world into a tragic chorus, wailing and moralizing
8903: over misery? I suspect that you have some false belief in the virtues
8904: of misery, and want to make your life a martyrdom.” Will had gone
8905: further than he intended, and checked himself. But Dorothea’s thought
8906: was not taking just the same direction as his own, and she answered
8907: without any special emotion—
8908: 
8909: “Indeed you mistake me. I am not a sad, melancholy creature. I am never
8910: unhappy long together. I am angry and naughty—not like Celia: I have a
8911: great outburst, and then all seems glorious again. I cannot help
8912: believing in glorious things in a blind sort of way. I should be quite
8913: willing to enjoy the art here, but there is so much that I don’t know
8914: the reason of—so much that seems to me a consecration of ugliness
8915: rather than beauty. The painting and sculpture may be wonderful, but
8916: the feeling is often low and brutal, and sometimes even ridiculous.
8917: Here and there I see what takes me at once as noble—something that I
8918: might compare with the Alban Mountains or the sunset from the Pincian
8919: Hill; but that makes it the greater pity that there is so little of the
8920: best kind among all that mass of things over which men have toiled so.”
8921: 
8922: “Of course there is always a great deal of poor work: the rarer things
8923: want that soil to grow in.”
8924: 
8925: “Oh dear,” said Dorothea, taking up that thought into the chief current
8926: of her anxiety; “I see it must be very difficult to do anything good. I
8927: have often felt since I have been in Rome that most of our lives would
8928: look much uglier and more bungling than the pictures, if they could be
8929: put on the wall.”
8930: 
8931: Dorothea parted her lips again as if she were going to say more, but
8932: changed her mind and paused.
8933: 
8934: “You are too young—it is an anachronism for you to have such thoughts,”
8935: said Will, energetically, with a quick shake of the head habitual to
8936: him. “You talk as if you had never known any youth. It is monstrous—as
8937: if you had had a vision of Hades in your childhood, like the boy in the
8938: legend. You have been brought up in some of those horrible notions that
8939: choose the sweetest women to devour—like Minotaurs. And now you will go
8940: and be shut up in that stone prison at Lowick: you will be buried
8941: alive. It makes me savage to think of it! I would rather never have
8942: seen you than think of you with such a prospect.”
8943: 
8944: Will again feared that he had gone too far; but the meaning we attach
8945: to words depends on our feeling, and his tone of angry regret had so
8946: much kindness in it for Dorothea’s heart, which had always been giving
8947: out ardor and had never been fed with much from the living beings
8948: around her, that she felt a new sense of gratitude and answered with a
8949: gentle smile—
8950: 
8951: “It is very good of you to be anxious about me. It is because you did
8952: not like Lowick yourself: you had set your heart on another kind of
8953: life. But Lowick is my chosen home.”
8954: 
8955: The last sentence was spoken with an almost solemn cadence, and Will
8956: did not know what to say, since it would not be useful for him to
8957: embrace her slippers, and tell her that he would die for her: it was
8958: clear that she required nothing of the sort; and they were both silent
8959: for a moment or two, when Dorothea began again with an air of saying at
8960: last what had been in her mind beforehand.
8961: 
8962: “I wanted to ask you again about something you said the other day.
8963: Perhaps it was half of it your lively way of speaking: I notice that
8964: you like to put things strongly; I myself often exaggerate when I speak
8965: hastily.”
8966: 
8967: “What was it?” said Will, observing that she spoke with a timidity
8968: quite new in her. “I have a hyperbolical tongue: it catches fire as it
8969: goes. I dare say I shall have to retract.”
8970: 
8971: “I mean what you said about the necessity of knowing German—I mean, for
8972: the subjects that Mr. Casaubon is engaged in. I have been thinking
8973: about it; and it seems to me that with Mr. Casaubon’s learning he must
8974: have before him the same materials as German scholars—has he not?”
8975: Dorothea’s timidity was due to an indistinct consciousness that she was
8976: in the strange situation of consulting a third person about the
8977: adequacy of Mr. Casaubon’s learning.
8978: 
8979: “Not exactly the same materials,” said Will, thinking that he would be
8980: duly reserved. “He is not an Orientalist, you know. He does not profess
8981: to have more than second-hand knowledge there.”
8982: 
8983: “But there are very valuable books about antiquities which were written
8984: a long while ago by scholars who knew nothing about these modern
8985: things; and they are still used. Why should Mr. Casaubon’s not be
8986: valuable, like theirs?” said Dorothea, with more remonstrant energy.
8987: She was impelled to have the argument aloud, which she had been having
8988: in her own mind.
8989: 
8990: “That depends on the line of study taken,” said Will, also getting a
8991: tone of rejoinder. “The subject Mr. Casaubon has chosen is as changing
8992: as chemistry: new discoveries are constantly making new points of view.
8993: Who wants a system on the basis of the four elements, or a book to
8994: refute Paracelsus? Do you not see that it is no use now to be crawling
8995: a little way after men of the last century—men like Bryant—and
8996: correcting their mistakes?—living in a lumber-room and furbishing up
8997: broken-legged theories about Chus and Mizraim?”
8998: 
8999: “How can you bear to speak so lightly?” said Dorothea, with a look
9000: between sorrow and anger. “If it were as you say, what could be sadder
9001: than so much ardent labor all in vain? I wonder it does not affect you
9002: more painfully, if you really think that a man like Mr. Casaubon, of so
9003: much goodness, power, and learning, should in any way fail in what has
9004: been the labor of his best years.” She was beginning to be shocked that
9005: she had got to such a point of supposition, and indignant with Will for
9006: having led her to it.
9007: 
9008: “You questioned me about the matter of fact, not of feeling,” said
9009: Will. “But if you wish to punish me for the fact, I submit. I am not in
9010: a position to express my feeling toward Mr. Casaubon: it would be at
9011: best a pensioner’s eulogy.”
9012: 
9013: “Pray excuse me,” said Dorothea, coloring deeply. “I am aware, as you
9014: say, that I am in fault in having introduced the subject. Indeed, I am
9015: wrong altogether. Failure after long perseverance is much grander than
9016: never to have a striving good enough to be called a failure.”
9017: 
9018: “I quite agree with you,” said Will, determined to change the
9019: situation—“so much so that I have made up my mind not to run that risk
9020: of never attaining a failure. Mr. Casaubon’s generosity has perhaps
9021: been dangerous to me, and I mean to renounce the liberty it has given
9022: me. I mean to go back to England shortly and work my own way—depend on
9023: nobody else than myself.”
9024: 
9025: “That is fine—I respect that feeling,” said Dorothea, with returning
9026: kindness. “But Mr. Casaubon, I am sure, has never thought of anything
9027: in the matter except what was most for your welfare.”
9028: 
9029: “She has obstinacy and pride enough to serve instead of love, now she
9030: has married him,” said Will to himself. Aloud he said, rising—
9031: 
9032: “I shall not see you again.”
9033: 
9034: “Oh, stay till Mr. Casaubon comes,” said Dorothea, earnestly. “I am so
9035: glad we met in Rome. I wanted to know you.”
9036: 
9037: “And I have made you angry,” said Will. “I have made you think ill of
9038: me.”
9039: 
9040: “Oh no. My sister tells me I am always angry with people who do not say
9041: just what I like. But I hope I am not given to think ill of them. In
9042: the end I am usually obliged to think ill of myself for being so
9043: impatient.”
9044: 
9045: “Still, you don’t like me; I have made myself an unpleasant thought to
9046: you.”
9047: 
9048: “Not at all,” said Dorothea, with the most open kindness. “I like you
9049: very much.”
9050: 
9051: Will was not quite contented, thinking that he would apparently have
9052: been of more importance if he had been disliked. He said nothing, but
9053: looked dull, not to say sulky.
9054: 
9055: “And I am quite interested to see what you will do,” Dorothea went on
9056: cheerfully. “I believe devoutly in a natural difference of vocation. If
9057: it were not for that belief, I suppose I should be very narrow—there
9058: are so many things, besides painting, that I am quite ignorant of. You
9059: would hardly believe how little I have taken in of music and
9060: literature, which you know so much of. I wonder what your vocation will
9061: turn out to be: perhaps you will be a poet?”
9062: 
9063: “That depends. To be a poet is to have a soul so quick to discern that
9064: no shade of quality escapes it, and so quick to feel, that discernment
9065: is but a hand playing with finely ordered variety on the chords of
9066: emotion—a soul in which knowledge passes instantaneously into feeling,
9067: and feeling flashes back as a new organ of knowledge. One may have that
9068: condition by fits only.”
9069: 
9070: “But you leave out the poems,” said Dorothea. “I think they are wanted
9071: to complete the poet. I understand what you mean about knowledge
9072: passing into feeling, for that seems to be just what I experience. But
9073: I am sure I could never produce a poem.”
9074: 
9075: “You _are_ a poem—and that is to be the best part of a poet—what makes
9076: up the poet’s consciousness in his best moods,” said Will, showing such
9077: originality as we all share with the morning and the spring-time and
9078: other endless renewals.
9079: 
9080: “I am very glad to hear it,” said Dorothea, laughing out her words in a
9081: bird-like modulation, and looking at Will with playful gratitude in her
9082: eyes. “What very kind things you say to me!”
9083: 
9084: “I wish I could ever do anything that would be what you call kind—that
9085: I could ever be of the slightest service to you. I fear I shall never
9086: have the opportunity.” Will spoke with fervor.
9087: 
9088: “Oh yes,” said Dorothea, cordially. “It will come; and I shall remember
9089: how well you wish me. I quite hoped that we should be friends when I
9090: first saw you—because of your relationship to Mr. Casaubon.” There was
9091: a certain liquid brightness in her eyes, and Will was conscious that
9092: his own were obeying a law of nature and filling too. The allusion to
9093: Mr. Casaubon would have spoiled all if anything at that moment could
9094: have spoiled the subduing power, the sweet dignity, of her noble
9095: unsuspicious inexperience.
9096: 
9097: “And there is one thing even now that you can do,” said Dorothea,
9098: rising and walking a little way under the strength of a recurring
9099: impulse. “Promise me that you will not again, to any one, speak of that
9100: subject—I mean about Mr. Casaubon’s writings—I mean in that kind of
9101: way. It was I who led to it. It was my fault. But promise me.”
9102: 
9103: She had returned from her brief pacing and stood opposite Will, looking
9104: gravely at him.
9105: 
9106: “Certainly, I will promise you,” said Will, reddening however. If he
9107: never said a cutting word about Mr. Casaubon again and left off
9108: receiving favors from him, it would clearly be permissible to hate him
9109: the more. The poet must know how to hate, says Goethe; and Will was at
9110: least ready with that accomplishment. He said that he must go now
9111: without waiting for Mr. Casaubon, whom he would come to take leave of
9112: at the last moment. Dorothea gave him her hand, and they exchanged a
9113: simple “Good-by.”
9114: 
9115: But going out of the _porte cochere_ he met Mr. Casaubon, and that
9116: gentleman, expressing the best wishes for his cousin, politely waived
9117: the pleasure of any further leave-taking on the morrow, which would be
9118: sufficiently crowded with the preparations for departure.
9119: 
9120: “I have something to tell you about our cousin Mr. Ladislaw, which I
9121: think will heighten your opinion of him,” said Dorothea to her husband
9122: in the course of the evening. She had mentioned immediately on his
9123: entering that Will had just gone away, and would come again, but Mr.
9124: Casaubon had said, “I met him outside, and we made our final adieux, I
9125: believe,” saying this with the air and tone by which we imply that any
9126: subject, whether private or public, does not interest us enough to wish
9127: for a further remark upon it. So Dorothea had waited.
9128: 
9129: “What is that, my love?” said Mr Casaubon (he always said “my love”
9130: when his manner was the coldest).
9131: 
9132: “He has made up his mind to leave off wandering at once, and to give up
9133: his dependence on your generosity. He means soon to go back to England,
9134: and work his own way. I thought you would consider that a good sign,”
9135: said Dorothea, with an appealing look into her husband’s neutral face.
9136: 
9137: “Did he mention the precise order of occupation to which he would
9138: addict himself?”
9139: 
9140: “No. But he said that he felt the danger which lay for him in your
9141: generosity. Of course he will write to you about it. Do you not think
9142: better of him for his resolve?”
9143: 
9144: “I shall await his communication on the subject,” said Mr. Casaubon.
9145: 
9146: “I told him I was sure that the thing you considered in all you did for
9147: him was his own welfare. I remembered your goodness in what you said
9148: about him when I first saw him at Lowick,” said Dorothea, putting her
9149: hand on her husband’s.
9150: 
9151: “I had a duty towards him,” said Mr. Casaubon, laying his other hand on
9152: Dorothea’s in conscientious acceptance of her caress, but with a glance
9153: which he could not hinder from being uneasy. “The young man, I confess,
9154: is not otherwise an object of interest to me, nor need we, I think,
9155: discuss his future course, which it is not ours to determine beyond the
9156: limits which I have sufficiently indicated.” Dorothea did not mention
9157: Will again.
9158: 
9159: 
9160: 
9161: 
9162: BOOK III.
9163: WAITING FOR DEATH.
9164: 
9165: 
9166: 
9167: 
9168: CHAPTER XXIII.
9169: 
9170: “Your horses of the Sun,” he said,
9171:     “And first-rate whip Apollo!
9172: Whate’er they be, I’ll eat my head,
9173:     But I will beat them hollow.”
9174: 
9175: 
9176: Fred Vincy, we have seen, had a debt on his mind, and though no such
9177: immaterial burthen could depress that buoyant-hearted young gentleman
9178: for many hours together, there were circumstances connected with this
9179: debt which made the thought of it unusually importunate. The creditor
9180: was Mr. Bambridge, a horse-dealer of the neighborhood, whose company
9181: was much sought in Middlemarch by young men understood to be “addicted
9182: to pleasure.” During the vacations Fred had naturally required more
9183: amusements than he had ready money for, and Mr. Bambridge had been
9184: accommodating enough not only to trust him for the hire of horses and
9185: the accidental expense of ruining a fine hunter, but also to make a
9186: small advance by which he might be able to meet some losses at
9187: billiards. The total debt was a hundred and sixty pounds. Bambridge was
9188: in no alarm about his money, being sure that young Vincy had backers;
9189: but he had required something to show for it, and Fred had at first
9190: given a bill with his own signature. Three months later he had renewed
9191: this bill with the signature of Caleb Garth. On both occasions Fred had
9192: felt confident that he should meet the bill himself, having ample funds
9193: at disposal in his own hopefulness. You will hardly demand that his
9194: confidence should have a basis in external facts; such confidence, we
9195: know, is something less coarse and materialistic: it is a comfortable
9196: disposition leading us to expect that the wisdom of providence or the
9197: folly of our friends, the mysteries of luck or the still greater
9198: mystery of our high individual value in the universe, will bring about
9199: agreeable issues, such as are consistent with our good taste in
9200: costume, and our general preference for the best style of thing. Fred
9201: felt sure that he should have a present from his uncle, that he should
9202: have a run of luck, that by dint of “swapping” he should gradually
9203: metamorphose a horse worth forty pounds into a horse that would fetch a
9204: hundred at any moment—“judgment” being always equivalent to an
9205: unspecified sum in hard cash. And in any case, even supposing negations
9206: which only a morbid distrust could imagine, Fred had always (at that
9207: time) his father’s pocket as a last resource, so that his assets of
9208: hopefulness had a sort of gorgeous superfluity about them. Of what
9209: might be the capacity of his father’s pocket, Fred had only a vague
9210: notion: was not trade elastic? And would not the deficiencies of one
9211: year be made up for by the surplus of another? The Vincys lived in an
9212: easy profuse way, not with any new ostentation, but according to the
9213: family habits and traditions, so that the children had no standard of
9214: economy, and the elder ones retained some of their infantine notion
9215: that their father might pay for anything if he would. Mr. Vincy himself
9216: had expensive Middlemarch habits—spent money on coursing, on his
9217: cellar, and on dinner-giving, while mamma had those running accounts
9218: with tradespeople, which give a cheerful sense of getting everything
9219: one wants without any question of payment. But it was in the nature of
9220: fathers, Fred knew, to bully one about expenses: there was always a
9221: little storm over his extravagance if he had to disclose a debt, and
9222: Fred disliked bad weather within doors. He was too filial to be
9223: disrespectful to his father, and he bore the thunder with the certainty
9224: that it was transient; but in the mean time it was disagreeable to see
9225: his mother cry, and also to be obliged to look sulky instead of having
9226: fun; for Fred was so good-tempered that if he looked glum under
9227: scolding, it was chiefly for propriety’s sake. The easier course
9228: plainly, was to renew the bill with a friend’s signature. Why not? With
9229: the superfluous securities of hope at his command, there was no reason
9230: why he should not have increased other people’s liabilities to any
9231: extent, but for the fact that men whose names were good for anything
9232: were usually pessimists, indisposed to believe that the universal order
9233: of things would necessarily be agreeable to an agreeable young
9234: gentleman.
9235: 
9236: With a favor to ask we review our list of friends, do justice to their
9237: more amiable qualities, forgive their little offenses, and concerning
9238: each in turn, try to arrive at the conclusion that he will be eager to
9239: oblige us, our own eagerness to be obliged being as communicable as
9240: other warmth. Still there is always a certain number who are dismissed
9241: as but moderately eager until the others have refused; and it happened
9242: that Fred checked off all his friends but one, on the ground that
9243: applying to them would be disagreeable; being implicitly convinced that
9244: he at least (whatever might be maintained about mankind generally) had
9245: a right to be free from anything disagreeable. That he should ever fall
9246: into a thoroughly unpleasant position—wear trousers shrunk with
9247: washing, eat cold mutton, have to walk for want of a horse, or to “duck
9248: under” in any sort of way—was an absurdity irreconcilable with those
9249: cheerful intuitions implanted in him by nature. And Fred winced under
9250: the idea of being looked down upon as wanting funds for small debts.
9251: Thus it came to pass that the friend whom he chose to apply to was at
9252: once the poorest and the kindest—namely, Caleb Garth.
9253: 
9254: The Garths were very fond of Fred, as he was of them; for when he and
9255: Rosamond were little ones, and the Garths were better off, the slight
9256: connection between the two families through Mr. Featherstone’s double
9257: marriage (the first to Mr. Garth’s sister, and the second to Mrs.
9258: Vincy’s) had led to an acquaintance which was carried on between the
9259: children rather than the parents: the children drank tea together out
9260: of their toy teacups, and spent whole days together in play. Mary was a
9261: little hoyden, and Fred at six years old thought her the nicest girl in
9262: the world, making her his wife with a brass ring which he had cut from
9263: an umbrella. Through all the stages of his education he had kept his
9264: affection for the Garths, and his habit of going to their house as a
9265: second home, though any intercourse between them and the elders of his
9266: family had long ceased. Even when Caleb Garth was prosperous, the
9267: Vincys were on condescending terms with him and his wife, for there
9268: were nice distinctions of rank in Middlemarch; and though old
9269: manufacturers could not any more than dukes be connected with none but
9270: equals, they were conscious of an inherent social superiority which was
9271: defined with great nicety in practice, though hardly expressible
9272: theoretically. Since then Mr. Garth had failed in the building
9273: business, which he had unfortunately added to his other avocations of
9274: surveyor, valuer, and agent, had conducted that business for a time
9275: entirely for the benefit of his assignees, and had been living
9276: narrowly, exerting himself to the utmost that he might after all pay
9277: twenty shillings in the pound. He had now achieved this, and from all
9278: who did not think it a bad precedent, his honorable exertions had won
9279: him due esteem; but in no part of the world is genteel visiting founded
9280: on esteem, in the absence of suitable furniture and complete
9281: dinner-service. Mrs. Vincy had never been at her ease with Mrs. Garth,
9282: and frequently spoke of her as a woman who had had to work for her
9283: bread—meaning that Mrs. Garth had been a teacher before her marriage;
9284: in which case an intimacy with Lindley Murray and Mangnall’s Questions
9285: was something like a draper’s discrimination of calico trademarks, or a
9286: courier’s acquaintance with foreign countries: no woman who was better
9287: off needed that sort of thing. And since Mary had been keeping Mr.
9288: Featherstone’s house, Mrs. Vincy’s want of liking for the Garths had
9289: been converted into something more positive, by alarm lest Fred should
9290: engage himself to this plain girl, whose parents “lived in such a small
9291: way.” Fred, being aware of this, never spoke at home of his visits to
9292: Mrs. Garth, which had of late become more frequent, the increasing
9293: ardor of his affection for Mary inclining him the more towards those
9294: who belonged to her.
9295: 
9296: Mr. Garth had a small office in the town, and to this Fred went with
9297: his request. He obtained it without much difficulty, for a large amount
9298: of painful experience had not sufficed to make Caleb Garth cautious
9299: about his own affairs, or distrustful of his fellow-men when they had
9300: not proved themselves untrustworthy; and he had the highest opinion of
9301: Fred, was “sure the lad would turn out well—an open affectionate
9302: fellow, with a good bottom to his character—you might trust him for
9303: anything.” Such was Caleb’s psychological argument. He was one of those
9304: rare men who are rigid to themselves and indulgent to others. He had a
9305: certain shame about his neighbors’ errors, and never spoke of them
9306: willingly; hence he was not likely to divert his mind from the best
9307: mode of hardening timber and other ingenious devices in order to
9308: preconceive those errors. If he had to blame any one, it was necessary
9309: for him to move all the papers within his reach, or describe various
9310: diagrams with his stick, or make calculations with the odd money in his
9311: pocket, before he could begin; and he would rather do other men’s work
9312: than find fault with their doing. I fear he was a bad disciplinarian.
9313: 
9314: When Fred stated the circumstances of his debt, his wish to meet it
9315: without troubling his father, and the certainty that the money would be
9316: forthcoming so as to cause no one any inconvenience, Caleb pushed his
9317: spectacles upward, listened, looked into his favorite’s clear young
9318: eyes, and believed him, not distinguishing confidence about the future
9319: from veracity about the past; but he felt that it was an occasion for a
9320: friendly hint as to conduct, and that before giving his signature he
9321: must give a rather strong admonition. Accordingly, he took the paper
9322: and lowered his spectacles, measured the space at his command, reached
9323: his pen and examined it, dipped it in the ink and examined it again,
9324: then pushed the paper a little way from him, lifted up his spectacles
9325: again, showed a deepened depression in the outer angle of his bushy
9326: eyebrows, which gave his face a peculiar mildness (pardon these details
9327: for once—you would have learned to love them if you had known Caleb
9328: Garth), and said in a comfortable tone,—
9329: 
9330: “It was a misfortune, eh, that breaking the horse’s knees? And then,
9331: these exchanges, they don’t answer when you have ’cute jockeys to deal
9332: with. You’ll be wiser another time, my boy.”
9333: 
9334: Whereupon Caleb drew down his spectacles, and proceeded to write his
9335: signature with the care which he always gave to that performance; for
9336: whatever he did in the way of business he did well. He contemplated the
9337: large well-proportioned letters and final flourish, with his head a
9338: trifle on one side for an instant, then handed it to Fred, said
9339: “Good-by,” and returned forthwith to his absorption in a plan for Sir
9340: James Chettam’s new farm-buildings.
9341: 
9342: Either because his interest in this work thrust the incident of the
9343: signature from his memory, or for some reason of which Caleb was more
9344: conscious, Mrs. Garth remained ignorant of the affair.
9345: 
9346: Since it occurred, a change had come over Fred’s sky, which altered his
9347: view of the distance, and was the reason why his uncle Featherstone’s
9348: present of money was of importance enough to make his color come and
9349: go, first with a too definite expectation, and afterwards with a
9350: proportionate disappointment. His failure in passing his examination,
9351: had made his accumulation of college debts the more unpardonable by his
9352: father, and there had been an unprecedented storm at home. Mr. Vincy
9353: had sworn that if he had anything more of that sort to put up with,
9354: Fred should turn out and get his living how he could; and he had never
9355: yet quite recovered his good-humored tone to his son, who had
9356: especially enraged him by saying at this stage of things that he did
9357: not want to be a clergyman, and would rather not “go on with that.”
9358: Fred was conscious that he would have been yet more severely dealt with
9359: if his family as well as himself had not secretly regarded him as Mr.
9360: Featherstone’s heir; that old gentleman’s pride in him, and apparent
9361: fondness for him, serving in the stead of more exemplary conduct—just
9362: as when a youthful nobleman steals jewellery we call the act
9363: kleptomania, speak of it with a philosophical smile, and never think of
9364: his being sent to the house of correction as if he were a ragged boy
9365: who had stolen turnips. In fact, tacit expectations of what would be
9366: done for him by uncle Featherstone determined the angle at which most
9367: people viewed Fred Vincy in Middlemarch; and in his own consciousness,
9368: what uncle Featherstone would do for him in an emergency, or what he
9369: would do simply as an incorporated luck, formed always an immeasurable
9370: depth of aerial perspective. But that present of bank-notes, once made,
9371: was measurable, and being applied to the amount of the debt, showed a
9372: deficit which had still to be filled up either by Fred’s “judgment” or
9373: by luck in some other shape. For that little episode of the alleged
9374: borrowing, in which he had made his father the agent in getting the
9375: Bulstrode certificate, was a new reason against going to his father for
9376: money towards meeting his actual debt. Fred was keen enough to foresee
9377: that anger would confuse distinctions, and that his denial of having
9378: borrowed expressly on the strength of his uncle’s will would be taken
9379: as a falsehood. He had gone to his father and told him one vexatious
9380: affair, and he had left another untold: in such cases the complete
9381: revelation always produces the impression of a previous duplicity. Now
9382: Fred piqued himself on keeping clear of lies, and even fibs; he often
9383: shrugged his shoulders and made a significant grimace at what he called
9384: Rosamond’s fibs (it is only brothers who can associate such ideas with
9385: a lovely girl); and rather than incur the accusation of falsehood he
9386: would even incur some trouble and self-restraint. It was under strong
9387: inward pressure of this kind that Fred had taken the wise step of
9388: depositing the eighty pounds with his mother. It was a pity that he had
9389: not at once given them to Mr. Garth; but he meant to make the sum
9390: complete with another sixty, and with a view to this, he had kept
9391: twenty pounds in his own pocket as a sort of seed-corn, which, planted
9392: by judgment, and watered by luck, might yield more than threefold—a
9393: very poor rate of multiplication when the field is a young gentleman’s
9394: infinite soul, with all the numerals at command.
9395: 
9396: Fred was not a gambler: he had not that specific disease in which the
9397: suspension of the whole nervous energy on a chance or risk becomes as
9398: necessary as the dram to the drunkard; he had only the tendency to that
9399: diffusive form of gambling which has no alcoholic intensity, but is
9400: carried on with the healthiest chyle-fed blood, keeping up a joyous
9401: imaginative activity which fashions events according to desire, and
9402: having no fears about its own weather, only sees the advantage there
9403: must be to others in going aboard with it. Hopefulness has a pleasure
9404: in making a throw of any kind, because the prospect of success is
9405: certain; and only a more generous pleasure in offering as many as
9406: possible a share in the stake. Fred liked play, especially billiards,
9407: as he liked hunting or riding a steeple-chase; and he only liked it the
9408: better because he wanted money and hoped to win. But the twenty pounds’
9409: worth of seed-corn had been planted in vain in the seductive green
9410: plot—all of it at least which had not been dispersed by the
9411: roadside—and Fred found himself close upon the term of payment with no
9412: money at command beyond the eighty pounds which he had deposited with
9413: his mother. The broken-winded horse which he rode represented a present
9414: which had been made to him a long while ago by his uncle Featherstone:
9415: his father always allowed him to keep a horse, Mr. Vincy’s own habits
9416: making him regard this as a reasonable demand even for a son who was
9417: rather exasperating. This horse, then, was Fred’s property, and in his
9418: anxiety to meet the imminent bill he determined to sacrifice a
9419: possession without which life would certainly be worth little. He made
9420: the resolution with a sense of heroism—heroism forced on him by the
9421: dread of breaking his word to Mr. Garth, by his love for Mary and awe
9422: of her opinion. He would start for Houndsley horse-fair which was to be
9423: held the next morning, and—simply sell his horse, bringing back the
9424: money by coach?—Well, the horse would hardly fetch more than thirty
9425: pounds, and there was no knowing what might happen; it would be folly
9426: to balk himself of luck beforehand. It was a hundred to one that some
9427: good chance would fall in his way; the longer he thought of it, the
9428: less possible it seemed that he should not have a good chance, and the
9429: less reasonable that he should not equip himself with the powder and
9430: shot for bringing it down. He would ride to Houndsley with Bambridge
9431: and with Horrock “the vet,” and without asking them anything expressly,
9432: he should virtually get the benefit of their opinion. Before he set
9433: out, Fred got the eighty pounds from his mother.
9434: 
9435: Most of those who saw Fred riding out of Middlemarch in company with
9436: Bambridge and Horrock, on his way of course to Houndsley horse-fair,
9437: thought that young Vincy was pleasure-seeking as usual; and but for an
9438: unwonted consciousness of grave matters on hand, he himself would have
9439: had a sense of dissipation, and of doing what might be expected of a
9440: gay young fellow. Considering that Fred was not at all coarse, that he
9441: rather looked down on the manners and speech of young men who had not
9442: been to the university, and that he had written stanzas as pastoral and
9443: unvoluptuous as his flute-playing, his attraction towards Bambridge and
9444: Horrock was an interesting fact which even the love of horse-flesh
9445: would not wholly account for without that mysterious influence of
9446: Naming which determinates so much of mortal choice. Under any other
9447: name than “pleasure” the society of Messieurs Bambridge and Horrock
9448: must certainly have been regarded as monotonous; and to arrive with
9449: them at Houndsley on a drizzling afternoon, to get down at the Red Lion
9450: in a street shaded with coal-dust, and dine in a room furnished with a
9451: dirt-enamelled map of the county, a bad portrait of an anonymous horse
9452: in a stable, His Majesty George the Fourth with legs and cravat, and
9453: various leaden spittoons, might have seemed a hard business, but for
9454: the sustaining power of nomenclature which determined that the pursuit
9455: of these things was “gay.”
9456: 
9457: In Mr. Horrock there was certainly an apparent unfathomableness which
9458: offered play to the imagination. Costume, at a glance, gave him a
9459: thrilling association with horses (enough to specify the hat-brim which
9460: took the slightest upward angle just to escape the suspicion of bending
9461: downwards), and nature had given him a face which by dint of Mongolian
9462: eyes, and a nose, mouth, and chin seeming to follow his hat-brim in a
9463: moderate inclination upwards, gave the effect of a subdued unchangeable
9464: sceptical smile, of all expressions the most tyrannous over a
9465: susceptible mind, and, when accompanied by adequate silence, likely to
9466: create the reputation of an invincible understanding, an infinite fund
9467: of humor—too dry to flow, and probably in a state of immovable
9468: crust,—and a critical judgment which, if you could ever be fortunate
9469: enough to know it, would be _the_ thing and no other. It is a
9470: physiognomy seen in all vocations, but perhaps it has never been more
9471: powerful over the youth of England than in a judge of horses.
9472: 
9473: Mr. Horrock, at a question from Fred about his horse’s fetlock, turned
9474: sideways in his saddle, and watched the horse’s action for the space of
9475: three minutes, then turned forward, twitched his own bridle, and
9476: remained silent with a profile neither more nor less sceptical than it
9477: had been.
9478: 
9479: The part thus played in dialogue by Mr. Horrock was terribly effective.
9480: A mixture of passions was excited in Fred—a mad desire to thrash
9481: Horrock’s opinion into utterance, restrained by anxiety to retain the
9482: advantage of his friendship. There was always the chance that Horrock
9483: might say something quite invaluable at the right moment.
9484: 
9485: Mr. Bambridge had more open manners, and appeared to give forth his
9486: ideas without economy. He was loud, robust, and was sometimes spoken of
9487: as being “given to indulgence”—chiefly in swearing, drinking, and
9488: beating his wife. Some people who had lost by him called him a vicious
9489: man; but he regarded horse-dealing as the finest of the arts, and might
9490: have argued plausibly that it had nothing to do with morality. He was
9491: undeniably a prosperous man, bore his drinking better than others bore
9492: their moderation, and, on the whole, flourished like the green
9493: bay-tree. But his range of conversation was limited, and like the fine
9494: old tune, “Drops of brandy,” gave you after a while a sense of
9495: returning upon itself in a way that might make weak heads dizzy. But a
9496: slight infusion of Mr. Bambridge was felt to give tone and character to
9497: several circles in Middlemarch; and he was a distinguished figure in
9498: the bar and billiard-room at the Green Dragon. He knew some anecdotes
9499: about the heroes of the turf, and various clever tricks of Marquesses
9500: and Viscounts which seemed to prove that blood asserted its
9501: pre-eminence even among black-legs; but the minute retentiveness of his
9502: memory was chiefly shown about the horses he had himself bought and
9503: sold; the number of miles they would trot you in no time without
9504: turning a hair being, after the lapse of years, still a subject of
9505: passionate asseveration, in which he would assist the imagination of
9506: his hearers by solemnly swearing that they never saw anything like it.
9507: In short, Mr. Bambridge was a man of pleasure and a gay companion.
9508: 
9509: Fred was subtle, and did not tell his friends that he was going to
9510: Houndsley bent on selling his horse: he wished to get indirectly at
9511: their genuine opinion of its value, not being aware that a genuine
9512: opinion was the last thing likely to be extracted from such eminent
9513: critics. It was not Mr. Bambridge’s weakness to be a gratuitous
9514: flatterer. He had never before been so much struck with the fact that
9515: this unfortunate bay was a roarer to a degree which required the
9516: roundest word for perdition to give you any idea of it.
9517: 
9518: “You made a bad hand at swapping when you went to anybody but me,
9519: Vincy! Why, you never threw your leg across a finer horse than that
9520: chestnut, and you gave him for this brute. If you set him cantering, he
9521: goes on like twenty sawyers. I never heard but one worse roarer in my
9522: life, and that was a roan: it belonged to Pegwell, the corn-factor; he
9523: used to drive him in his gig seven years ago, and he wanted me to take
9524: him, but I said, ‘Thank you, Peg, I don’t deal in wind-instruments.’
9525: That was what I said. It went the round of the country, that joke did.
9526: But, what the hell! the horse was a penny trumpet to that roarer of
9527: yours.”
9528: 
9529: “Why, you said just now his was worse than mine,” said Fred, more
9530: irritable than usual.
9531: 
9532: “I said a lie, then,” said Mr. Bambridge, emphatically. “There wasn’t a
9533: penny to choose between ’em.”
9534: 
9535: Fred spurred his horse, and they trotted on a little way. When they
9536: slackened again, Mr. Bambridge said—
9537: 
9538: “Not but what the roan was a better trotter than yours.”
9539: 
9540: “I’m quite satisfied with his paces, I know,” said Fred, who required
9541: all the consciousness of being in gay company to support him; “I say
9542: his trot is an uncommonly clean one, eh, Horrock?”
9543: 
9544: Mr. Horrock looked before him with as complete a neutrality as if he
9545: had been a portrait by a great master.
9546: 
9547: Fred gave up the fallacious hope of getting a genuine opinion; but on
9548: reflection he saw that Bambridge’s depreciation and Horrock’s silence
9549: were both virtually encouraging, and indicated that they thought better
9550: of the horse than they chose to say.
9551: 
9552: That very evening, indeed, before the fair had set in, Fred thought he
9553: saw a favorable opening for disposing advantageously of his horse, but
9554: an opening which made him congratulate himself on his foresight in
9555: bringing with him his eighty pounds. A young farmer, acquainted with
9556: Mr. Bambridge, came into the Red Lion, and entered into conversation
9557: about parting with a hunter, which he introduced at once as Diamond,
9558: implying that it was a public character. For himself he only wanted a
9559: useful hack, which would draw upon occasion; being about to marry and
9560: to give up hunting. The hunter was in a friend’s stable at some little
9561: distance; there was still time for gentlemen to see it before dark. The
9562: friend’s stable had to be reached through a back street where you might
9563: as easily have been poisoned without expense of drugs as in any grim
9564: street of that unsanitary period. Fred was not fortified against
9565: disgust by brandy, as his companions were, but the hope of having at
9566: last seen the horse that would enable him to make money was
9567: exhilarating enough to lead him over the same ground again the first
9568: thing in the morning. He felt sure that if he did not come to a bargain
9569: with the farmer, Bambridge would; for the stress of circumstances, Fred
9570: felt, was sharpening his acuteness and endowing him with all the
9571: constructive power of suspicion. Bambridge had run down Diamond in a
9572: way that he never would have done (the horse being a friend’s) if he
9573: had not thought of buying it; every one who looked at the animal—even
9574: Horrock—was evidently impressed with its merit. To get all the
9575: advantage of being with men of this sort, you must know how to draw
9576: your inferences, and not be a spoon who takes things literally. The
9577: color of the horse was a dappled gray, and Fred happened to know that
9578: Lord Medlicote’s man was on the look-out for just such a horse. After
9579: all his running down, Bambridge let it out in the course of the
9580: evening, when the farmer was absent, that he had seen worse horses go
9581: for eighty pounds. Of course he contradicted himself twenty times over,
9582: but when you know what is likely to be true you can test a man’s
9583: admissions. And Fred could not but reckon his own judgment of a horse
9584: as worth something. The farmer had paused over Fred’s respectable
9585: though broken-winded steed long enough to show that he thought it worth
9586: consideration, and it seemed probable that he would take it, with
9587: five-and-twenty pounds in addition, as the equivalent of Diamond. In
9588: that case Fred, when he had parted with his new horse for at least
9589: eighty pounds, would be fifty-five pounds in pocket by the transaction,
