9590: and would have a hundred and thirty-five pounds towards meeting the
9591: bill; so that the deficit temporarily thrown on Mr. Garth would at the
9592: utmost be twenty-five pounds. By the time he was hurrying on his
9593: clothes in the morning, he saw so clearly the importance of not losing
9594: this rare chance, that if Bambridge and Horrock had both dissuaded him,
9595: he would not have been deluded into a direct interpretation of their
9596: purpose: he would have been aware that those deep hands held something
9597: else than a young fellow’s interest. With regard to horses, distrust
9598: was your only clew. But scepticism, as we know, can never be thoroughly
9599: applied, else life would come to a standstill: something we must
9600: believe in and do, and whatever that something may be called, it is
9601: virtually our own judgment, even when it seems like the most slavish
9602: reliance on another. Fred believed in the excellence of his bargain,
9603: and even before the fair had well set in, had got possession of the
9604: dappled gray, at the price of his old horse and thirty pounds in
9605: addition—only five pounds more than he had expected to give.
9606: 
9607: But he felt a little worried and wearied, perhaps with mental debate,
9608: and without waiting for the further gayeties of the horse-fair, he set
9609: out alone on his fourteen miles’ journey, meaning to take it very
9610: quietly and keep his horse fresh.
9611: 
9612: 
9613: 
9614: 
9615: CHAPTER XXIV.
9616: 
9617: “The offender’s sorrow brings but small relief
9618: To him who wears the strong offence’s cross.”
9619: —SHAKESPEARE: _Sonnets_.
9620: 
9621: 
9622: I am sorry to say that only the third day after the propitious events
9623: at Houndsley Fred Vincy had fallen into worse spirits than he had known
9624: in his life before. Not that he had been disappointed as to the
9625: possible market for his horse, but that before the bargain could be
9626: concluded with Lord Medlicote’s man, this Diamond, in which hope to the
9627: amount of eighty pounds had been invested, had without the slightest
9628: warning exhibited in the stable a most vicious energy in kicking, had
9629: just missed killing the groom, and had ended in laming himself severely
9630: by catching his leg in a rope that overhung the stable-board. There was
9631: no more redress for this than for the discovery of bad temper after
9632: marriage—which of course old companions were aware of before the
9633: ceremony. For some reason or other, Fred had none of his usual
9634: elasticity under this stroke of ill-fortune: he was simply aware that
9635: he had only fifty pounds, that there was no chance of his getting any
9636: more at present, and that the bill for a hundred and sixty would be
9637: presented in five days. Even if he had applied to his father on the
9638: plea that Mr. Garth should be saved from loss, Fred felt smartingly
9639: that his father would angrily refuse to rescue Mr. Garth from the
9640: consequence of what he would call encouraging extravagance and deceit.
9641: He was so utterly downcast that he could frame no other project than to
9642: go straight to Mr. Garth and tell him the sad truth, carrying with him
9643: the fifty pounds, and getting that sum at least safely out of his own
9644: hands. His father, being at the warehouse, did not yet know of the
9645: accident: when he did, he would storm about the vicious brute being
9646: brought into his stable; and before meeting that lesser annoyance Fred
9647: wanted to get away with all his courage to face the greater. He took
9648: his father’s nag, for he had made up his mind that when he had told Mr.
9649: Garth, he would ride to Stone Court and confess all to Mary. In fact,
9650: it is probable that but for Mary’s existence and Fred’s love for her,
9651: his conscience would have been much less active both in previously
9652: urging the debt on his thought and impelling him not to spare himself
9653: after his usual fashion by deferring an unpleasant task, but to act as
9654: directly and simply as he could. Even much stronger mortals than Fred
9655: Vincy hold half their rectitude in the mind of the being they love
9656: best. “The theatre of all my actions is fallen,” said an antique
9657: personage when his chief friend was dead; and they are fortunate who
9658: get a theatre where the audience demands their best. Certainly it would
9659: have made a considerable difference to Fred at that time if Mary Garth
9660: had had no decided notions as to what was admirable in character.
9661: 
9662: Mr. Garth was not at the office, and Fred rode on to his house, which
9663: was a little way outside the town—a homely place with an orchard in
9664: front of it, a rambling, old-fashioned, half-timbered building, which
9665: before the town had spread had been a farm-house, but was now
9666: surrounded with the private gardens of the townsmen. We get the fonder
9667: of our houses if they have a physiognomy of their own, as our friends
9668: have. The Garth family, which was rather a large one, for Mary had four
9669: brothers and one sister, were very fond of their old house, from which
9670: all the best furniture had long been sold. Fred liked it too, knowing
9671: it by heart even to the attic which smelt deliciously of apples and
9672: quinces, and until to-day he had never come to it without pleasant
9673: expectations; but his heart beat uneasily now with the sense that he
9674: should probably have to make his confession before Mrs. Garth, of whom
9675: he was rather more in awe than of her husband. Not that she was
9676: inclined to sarcasm and to impulsive sallies, as Mary was. In her
9677: present matronly age at least, Mrs. Garth never committed herself by
9678: over-hasty speech; having, as she said, borne the yoke in her youth,
9679: and learned self-control. She had that rare sense which discerns what
9680: is unalterable, and submits to it without murmuring. Adoring her
9681: husband’s virtues, she had very early made up her mind to his
9682: incapacity of minding his own interests, and had met the consequences
9683: cheerfully. She had been magnanimous enough to renounce all pride in
9684: teapots or children’s frilling, and had never poured any pathetic
9685: confidences into the ears of her feminine neighbors concerning Mr.
9686: Garth’s want of prudence and the sums he might have had if he had been
9687: like other men. Hence these fair neighbors thought her either proud or
9688: eccentric, and sometimes spoke of her to their husbands as “your fine
9689: Mrs. Garth.” She was not without her criticism of them in return, being
9690: more accurately instructed than most matrons in Middlemarch, and—where
9691: is the blameless woman?—apt to be a little severe towards her own sex,
9692: which in her opinion was framed to be entirely subordinate. On the
9693: other hand, she was disproportionately indulgent towards the failings
9694: of men, and was often heard to say that these were natural. Also, it
9695: must be admitted that Mrs. Garth was a trifle too emphatic in her
9696: resistance to what she held to be follies: the passage from governess
9697: into housewife had wrought itself a little too strongly into her
9698: consciousness, and she rarely forgot that while her grammar and accent
9699: were above the town standard, she wore a plain cap, cooked the family
9700: dinner, and darned all the stockings. She had sometimes taken pupils in
9701: a peripatetic fashion, making them follow her about in the kitchen with
9702: their book or slate. She thought it good for them to see that she could
9703: make an excellent lather while she corrected their blunders “without
9704: looking,”—that a woman with her sleeves tucked up above her elbows
9705: might know all about the Subjunctive Mood or the Torrid Zone—that, in
9706: short, she might possess “education” and other good things ending in
9707: “tion,” and worthy to be pronounced emphatically, without being a
9708: useless doll. When she made remarks to this edifying effect, she had a
9709: firm little frown on her brow, which yet did not hinder her face from
9710: looking benevolent, and her words which came forth like a procession
9711: were uttered in a fervid agreeable contralto. Certainly, the exemplary
9712: Mrs. Garth had her droll aspects, but her character sustained her
9713: oddities, as a very fine wine sustains a flavor of skin.
9714: 
9715: Towards Fred Vincy she had a motherly feeling, and had always been
9716: disposed to excuse his errors, though she would probably not have
9717: excused Mary for engaging herself to him, her daughter being included
9718: in that more rigorous judgment which she applied to her own sex. But
9719: this very fact of her exceptional indulgence towards him made it the
9720: harder to Fred that he must now inevitably sink in her opinion. And the
9721: circumstances of his visit turned out to be still more unpleasant than
9722: he had expected; for Caleb Garth had gone out early to look at some
9723: repairs not far off. Mrs. Garth at certain hours was always in the
9724: kitchen, and this morning she was carrying on several occupations at
9725: once there—making her pies at the well-scoured deal table on one side
9726: of that airy room, observing Sally’s movements at the oven and
9727: dough-tub through an open door, and giving lessons to her youngest boy
9728: and girl, who were standing opposite to her at the table with their
9729: books and slates before them. A tub and a clothes-horse at the other
9730: end of the kitchen indicated an intermittent wash of small things also
9731: going on.
9732: 
9733: Mrs. Garth, with her sleeves turned above her elbows, deftly handling
9734: her pastry—applying her rolling-pin and giving ornamental pinches,
9735: while she expounded with grammatical fervor what were the right views
9736: about the concord of verbs and pronouns with “nouns of multitude or
9737: signifying many,” was a sight agreeably amusing. She was of the same
9738: curly-haired, square-faced type as Mary, but handsomer, with more
9739: delicacy of feature, a pale skin, a solid matronly figure, and a
9740: remarkable firmness of glance. In her snowy-frilled cap she reminded
9741: one of that delightful Frenchwoman whom we have all seen marketing,
9742: basket on arm. Looking at the mother, you might hope that the daughter
9743: would become like her, which is a prospective advantage equal to a
9744: dowry—the mother too often standing behind the daughter like a
9745: malignant prophecy—“Such as I am, she will shortly be.”
9746: 
9747: “Now let us go through that once more,” said Mrs. Garth, pinching an
9748: apple-puff which seemed to distract Ben, an energetic young male with a
9749: heavy brow, from due attention to the lesson. “‘Not without regard to
9750: the import of the word as conveying unity or plurality of idea’—tell me
9751: again what that means, Ben.”
9752: 
9753: (Mrs. Garth, like more celebrated educators, had her favorite ancient
9754: paths, and in a general wreck of society would have tried to hold her
9755: “Lindley Murray” above the waves.)
9756: 
9757: “Oh—it means—you must think what you mean,” said Ben, rather peevishly.
9758: “I hate grammar. What’s the use of it?”
9759: 
9760: “To teach you to speak and write correctly, so that you can be
9761: understood,” said Mrs. Garth, with severe precision. “Should you like
9762: to speak as old Job does?”
9763: 
9764: “Yes,” said Ben, stoutly; “it’s funnier. He says, ‘Yo goo’—that’s just
9765: as good as ‘You go.’”
9766: 
9767: “But he says, ‘A ship’s in the garden,’ instead of ‘a sheep,’” said
9768: Letty, with an air of superiority. “You might think he meant a ship off
9769: the sea.”
9770: 
9771: “No, you mightn’t, if you weren’t silly,” said Ben. “How could a ship
9772: off the sea come there?”
9773: 
9774: “These things belong only to pronunciation, which is the least part of
9775: grammar,” said Mrs. Garth. “That apple-peel is to be eaten by the pigs,
9776: Ben; if you eat it, I must give them your piece of pasty. Job has only
9777: to speak about very plain things. How do you think you would write or
9778: speak about anything more difficult, if you knew no more of grammar
9779: than he does? You would use wrong words, and put words in the wrong
9780: places, and instead of making people understand you, they would turn
9781: away from you as a tiresome person. What would you do then?”
9782: 
9783: “I shouldn’t care, I should leave off,” said Ben, with a sense that
9784: this was an agreeable issue where grammar was concerned.
9785: 
9786: “I see you are getting tired and stupid, Ben,” said Mrs. Garth,
9787: accustomed to these obstructive arguments from her male offspring.
9788: Having finished her pies, she moved towards the clothes-horse, and
9789: said, “Come here and tell me the story I told you on Wednesday, about
9790: Cincinnatus.”
9791: 
9792: “I know! he was a farmer,” said Ben.
9793: 
9794: “Now, Ben, he was a Roman—let _me_ tell,” said Letty, using her elbow
9795: contentiously.
9796: 
9797: “You silly thing, he was a Roman farmer, and he was ploughing.”
9798: 
9799: “Yes, but before that—that didn’t come first—people wanted him,” said
9800: Letty.
9801: 
9802: “Well, but you must say what sort of a man he was first,” insisted Ben.
9803: “He was a wise man, like my father, and that made the people want his
9804: advice. And he was a brave man, and could fight. And so could my
9805: father—couldn’t he, mother?”
9806: 
9807: “Now, Ben, let me tell the story straight on, as mother told it us,”
9808: said Letty, frowning. “Please, mother, tell Ben not to speak.”
9809: 
9810: “Letty, I am ashamed of you,” said her mother, wringing out the caps
9811: from the tub. “When your brother began, you ought to have waited to see
9812: if he could not tell the story. How rude you look, pushing and
9813: frowning, as if you wanted to conquer with your elbows! Cincinnatus, I
9814: am sure, would have been sorry to see his daughter behave so.” (Mrs.
9815: Garth delivered this awful sentence with much majesty of enunciation,
9816: and Letty felt that between repressed volubility and general disesteem,
9817: that of the Romans inclusive, life was already a painful affair.) “Now,
9818: Ben.”
9819: 
9820: “Well—oh—well—why, there was a great deal of fighting, and they were
9821: all blockheads, and—I can’t tell it just how you told it—but they
9822: wanted a man to be captain and king and everything—”
9823: 
9824: “Dictator, now,” said Letty, with injured looks, and not without a wish
9825: to make her mother repent.
9826: 
9827: “Very well, dictator!” said Ben, contemptuously. “But that isn’t a good
9828: word: he didn’t tell them to write on slates.”
9829: 
9830: “Come, come, Ben, you are not so ignorant as that,” said Mrs. Garth,
9831: carefully serious. “Hark, there is a knock at the door! Run, Letty, and
9832: open it.”
9833: 
9834: The knock was Fred’s; and when Letty said that her father was not in
9835: yet, but that her mother was in the kitchen, Fred had no alternative.
9836: He could not depart from his usual practice of going to see Mrs. Garth
9837: in the kitchen if she happened to be at work there. He put his arm
9838: round Letty’s neck silently, and led her into the kitchen without his
9839: usual jokes and caresses.
9840: 
9841: Mrs. Garth was surprised to see Fred at this hour, but surprise was not
9842: a feeling that she was given to express, and she only said, quietly
9843: continuing her work—
9844: 
9845: “You, Fred, so early in the day? You look quite pale. Has anything
9846: happened?”
9847: 
9848: “I want to speak to Mr. Garth,” said Fred, not yet ready to say
9849: more—“and to you also,” he added, after a little pause, for he had no
9850: doubt that Mrs. Garth knew everything about the bill, and he must in
9851: the end speak of it before her, if not to her solely.
9852: 
9853: “Caleb will be in again in a few minutes,” said Mrs. Garth, who
9854: imagined some trouble between Fred and his father. “He is sure not to
9855: be long, because he has some work at his desk that must be done this
9856: morning. Do you mind staying with me, while I finish my matters here?”
9857: 
9858: “But we needn’t go on about Cincinnatus, need we?” said Ben, who had
9859: taken Fred’s whip out of his hand, and was trying its efficiency on the
9860: cat.
9861: 
9862: “No, go out now. But put that whip down. How very mean of you to whip
9863: poor old Tortoise! Pray take the whip from him, Fred.”
9864: 
9865: “Come, old boy, give it me,” said Fred, putting out his hand.
9866: 
9867: “Will you let me ride on your horse to-day?” said Ben, rendering up the
9868: whip, with an air of not being obliged to do it.
9869: 
9870: “Not to-day—another time. I am not riding my own horse.”
9871: 
9872: “Shall you see Mary to-day?”
9873: 
9874: “Yes, I think so,” said Fred, with an unpleasant twinge.
9875: 
9876: “Tell her to come home soon, and play at forfeits, and make fun.”
9877: 
9878: “Enough, enough, Ben! run away,” said Mrs. Garth, seeing that Fred was
9879: teased.
9880: 
9881: “Are Letty and Ben your only pupils now, Mrs. Garth?” said Fred, when
9882: the children were gone and it was needful to say something that would
9883: pass the time. He was not yet sure whether he should wait for Mr.
9884: Garth, or use any good opportunity in conversation to confess to Mrs.
9885: Garth herself, give her the money and ride away.
9886: 
9887: “One—only one. Fanny Hackbutt comes at half past eleven. I am not
9888: getting a great income now,” said Mrs. Garth, smiling. “I am at a low
9889: ebb with pupils. But I have saved my little purse for Alfred’s premium:
9890: I have ninety-two pounds. He can go to Mr. Hanmer’s now; he is just at
9891: the right age.”
9892: 
9893: This did not lead well towards the news that Mr. Garth was on the brink
9894: of losing ninety-two pounds and more. Fred was silent. “Young gentlemen
9895: who go to college are rather more costly than that,” Mrs. Garth
9896: innocently continued, pulling out the edging on a cap-border. “And
9897: Caleb thinks that Alfred will turn out a distinguished engineer: he
9898: wants to give the boy a good chance. There he is! I hear him coming in.
9899: We will go to him in the parlor, shall we?”
9900: 
9901: When they entered the parlor Caleb had thrown down his hat and was
9902: seated at his desk.
9903: 
9904: “What! Fred, my boy!” he said, in a tone of mild surprise, holding his
9905: pen still undipped; “you are here betimes.” But missing the usual
9906: expression of cheerful greeting in Fred’s face, he immediately added,
9907: “Is there anything up at home?—anything the matter?”
9908: 
9909: “Yes, Mr. Garth, I am come to tell something that I am afraid will give
9910: you a bad opinion of me. I am come to tell you and Mrs. Garth that I
9911: can’t keep my word. I can’t find the money to meet the bill after all.
9912: I have been unfortunate; I have only got these fifty pounds towards the
9913: hundred and sixty.”
9914: 
9915: While Fred was speaking, he had taken out the notes and laid them on
9916: the desk before Mr. Garth. He had burst forth at once with the plain
9917: fact, feeling boyishly miserable and without verbal resources. Mrs.
9918: Garth was mutely astonished, and looked at her husband for an
9919: explanation. Caleb blushed, and after a little pause said—
9920: 
9921: “Oh, I didn’t tell you, Susan: I put my name to a bill for Fred; it was
9922: for a hundred and sixty pounds. He made sure he could meet it himself.”
9923: 
9924: There was an evident change in Mrs. Garth’s face, but it was like a
9925: change below the surface of water which remains smooth. She fixed her
9926: eyes on Fred, saying—
9927: 
9928: “I suppose you have asked your father for the rest of the money and he
9929: has refused you.”
9930: 
9931: “No,” said Fred, biting his lip, and speaking with more difficulty;
9932: “but I know it will be of no use to ask him; and unless it were of use,
9933: I should not like to mention Mr. Garth’s name in the matter.”
9934: 
9935: “It has come at an unfortunate time,” said Caleb, in his hesitating
9936: way, looking down at the notes and nervously fingering the paper,
9937: “Christmas upon us—I’m rather hard up just now. You see, I have to cut
9938: out everything like a tailor with short measure. What can we do, Susan?
9939: I shall want every farthing we have in the bank. It’s a hundred and ten
9940: pounds, the deuce take it!”
9941: 
9942: “I must give you the ninety-two pounds that I have put by for Alfred’s
9943: premium,” said Mrs. Garth, gravely and decisively, though a nice ear
9944: might have discerned a slight tremor in some of the words. “And I have
9945: no doubt that Mary has twenty pounds saved from her salary by this
9946: time. She will advance it.”
9947: 
9948: Mrs. Garth had not again looked at Fred, and was not in the least
9949: calculating what words she should use to cut him the most effectively.
9950: Like the eccentric woman she was, she was at present absorbed in
9951: considering what was to be done, and did not fancy that the end could
9952: be better achieved by bitter remarks or explosions. But she had made
9953: Fred feel for the first time something like the tooth of remorse.
9954: Curiously enough, his pain in the affair beforehand had consisted
9955: almost entirely in the sense that he must seem dishonorable, and sink
9956: in the opinion of the Garths: he had not occupied himself with the
9957: inconvenience and possible injury that his breach might occasion them,
9958: for this exercise of the imagination on other people’s needs is not
9959: common with hopeful young gentlemen. Indeed we are most of us brought
9960: up in the notion that the highest motive for not doing a wrong is
9961: something irrespective of the beings who would suffer the wrong. But at
9962: this moment he suddenly saw himself as a pitiful rascal who was robbing
9963: two women of their savings.
9964: 
9965: “I shall certainly pay it all, Mrs. Garth—ultimately,” he stammered
9966: out.
9967: 
9968: “Yes, ultimately,” said Mrs. Garth, who having a special dislike to
9969: fine words on ugly occasions, could not now repress an epigram. “But
9970: boys cannot well be apprenticed ultimately: they should be apprenticed
9971: at fifteen.” She had never been so little inclined to make excuses for
9972: Fred.
9973: 
9974: “I was the most in the wrong, Susan,” said Caleb. “Fred made sure of
9975: finding the money. But I’d no business to be fingering bills. I suppose
9976: you have looked all round and tried all honest means?” he added, fixing
9977: his merciful gray eyes on Fred. Caleb was too delicate to specify Mr.
9978: Featherstone.
9979: 
9980: “Yes, I have tried everything—I really have. I should have had a
9981: hundred and thirty pounds ready but for a misfortune with a horse which
9982: I was about to sell. My uncle had given me eighty pounds, and I paid
9983: away thirty with my old horse in order to get another which I was going
9984: to sell for eighty or more—I meant to go without a horse—but now it has
9985: turned out vicious and lamed itself. I wish I and the horses too had
9986: been at the devil, before I had brought this on you. There’s no one
9987: else I care so much for: you and Mrs. Garth have always been so kind to
9988: me. However, it’s no use saying that. You will always think me a rascal
9989: now.”
9990: 
9991: Fred turned round and hurried out of the room, conscious that he was
9992: getting rather womanish, and feeling confusedly that his being sorry
9993: was not of much use to the Garths. They could see him mount, and
9994: quickly pass through the gate.
9995: 
9996: “I am disappointed in Fred Vincy,” said Mrs. Garth. “I would not have
9997: believed beforehand that he would have drawn you into his debts. I knew
9998: he was extravagant, but I did not think that he would be so mean as to
9999: hang his risks on his oldest friend, who could the least afford to
10000: lose.”
10001: 
10002: “I was a fool, Susan.”
10003: 
10004: “That you were,” said the wife, nodding and smiling. “But I should not
10005: have gone to publish it in the market-place. Why should you keep such
10006: things from me? It is just so with your buttons: you let them burst off
10007: without telling me, and go out with your wristband hanging. If I had
10008: only known I might have been ready with some better plan.”
10009: 
10010: “You are sadly cut up, I know, Susan,” said Caleb, looking feelingly at
10011: her. “I can’t abide your losing the money you’ve scraped together for
10012: Alfred.”
10013: 
10014: “It is very well that I _had_ scraped it together; and it is you who
10015: will have to suffer, for you must teach the boy yourself. You must give
10016: up your bad habits. Some men take to drinking, and you have taken to
10017: working without pay. You must indulge yourself a little less in that.
10018: And you must ride over to Mary, and ask the child what money she has.”
10019: 
10020: Caleb had pushed his chair back, and was leaning forward, shaking his
10021: head slowly, and fitting his finger-tips together with much nicety.
10022: 
10023: “Poor Mary!” he said. “Susan,” he went on in a lowered tone, “I’m
10024: afraid she may be fond of Fred.”
10025: 
10026: “Oh no! She always laughs at him; and he is not likely to think of her
10027: in any other than a brotherly way.”
10028: 
10029: Caleb made no rejoinder, but presently lowered his spectacles, drew up
10030: his chair to the desk, and said, “Deuce take the bill—I wish it was at
10031: Hanover! These things are a sad interruption to business!”
10032: 
10033: The first part of this speech comprised his whole store of maledictory
10034: expression, and was uttered with a slight snarl easy to imagine. But it
10035: would be difficult to convey to those who never heard him utter the
10036: word “business,” the peculiar tone of fervid veneration, of religious
10037: regard, in which he wrapped it, as a consecrated symbol is wrapped in
10038: its gold-fringed linen.
10039: 
10040: Caleb Garth often shook his head in meditation on the value, the
10041: indispensable might of that myriad-headed, myriad-handed labor by which
10042: the social body is fed, clothed, and housed. It had laid hold of his
10043: imagination in boyhood. The echoes of the great hammer where roof or
10044: keel were a-making, the signal-shouts of the workmen, the roar of the
10045: furnace, the thunder and plash of the engine, were a sublime music to
10046: him; the felling and lading of timber, and the huge trunk vibrating
10047: star-like in the distance along the highway, the crane at work on the
10048: wharf, the piled-up produce in warehouses, the precision and variety of
10049: muscular effort wherever exact work had to be turned out,—all these
10050: sights of his youth had acted on him as poetry without the aid of the
10051: poets, had made a philosophy for him without the aid of philosophers, a
10052: religion without the aid of theology. His early ambition had been to
10053: have as effective a share as possible in this sublime labor, which was
10054: peculiarly dignified by him with the name of “business;” and though he
10055: had only been a short time under a surveyor, and had been chiefly his
10056: own teacher, he knew more of land, building, and mining than most of
10057: the special men in the county.
10058: 
10059: His classification of human employments was rather crude, and, like the
10060: categories of more celebrated men, would not be acceptable in these
10061: advanced times. He divided them into “business, politics, preaching,
10062: learning, and amusement.” He had nothing to say against the last four;
10063: but he regarded them as a reverential pagan regarded other gods than
10064: his own. In the same way, he thought very well of all ranks, but he
10065: would not himself have liked to be of any rank in which he had not such
10066: close contact with “business” as to get often honorably decorated with
10067: marks of dust and mortar, the damp of the engine, or the sweet soil of
10068: the woods and fields. Though he had never regarded himself as other
10069: than an orthodox Christian, and would argue on prevenient grace if the
10070: subject were proposed to him, I think his virtual divinities were good
10071: practical schemes, accurate work, and the faithful completion of
10072: undertakings: his prince of darkness was a slack workman. But there was
10073: no spirit of denial in Caleb, and the world seemed so wondrous to him
10074: that he was ready to accept any number of systems, like any number of
10075: firmaments, if they did not obviously interfere with the best
10076: land-drainage, solid building, correct measuring, and judicious boring
10077: (for coal). In fact, he had a reverential soul with a strong practical
10078: intelligence. But he could not manage finance: he knew values well, but
10079: he had no keenness of imagination for monetary results in the shape of
10080: profit and loss: and having ascertained this to his cost, he determined
10081: to give up all forms of his beloved “business” which required that
10082: talent. He gave himself up entirely to the many kinds of work which he
10083: could do without handling capital, and was one of those precious men
10084: within his own district whom everybody would choose to work for them,
10085: because he did his work well, charged very little, and often declined
10086: to charge at all. It is no wonder, then, that the Garths were poor, and
10087: “lived in a small way.” However, they did not mind it.
10088: 
10089: 
10090: 
10091: 
10092: CHAPTER XXV.
10093: 
10094: “Love seeketh not itself to please,
10095:     Nor for itself hath any care
10096: But for another gives its ease
10097:     And builds a heaven in hell’s despair.
10098: . . . . . . .
10099: Love seeketh only self to please,
10100:     To bind another to its delight,
10101: Joys in another’s loss of ease,
10102:     And builds a hell in heaven’s despite.”
10103: —W. BLAKE: _Songs of Experience_.
10104: 
10105: 
10106: Fred Vincy wanted to arrive at Stone Court when Mary could not expect
10107: him, and when his uncle was not downstairs: in that case she might be
10108: sitting alone in the wainscoted parlor. He left his horse in the yard
10109: to avoid making a noise on the gravel in front, and entered the parlor
10110: without other notice than the noise of the door-handle. Mary was in her
10111: usual corner, laughing over Mrs. Piozzi’s recollections of Johnson, and
10112: looked up with the fun still in her face. It gradually faded as she saw
10113: Fred approach her without speaking, and stand before her with his elbow
10114: on the mantel-piece, looking ill. She too was silent, only raising her
10115: eyes to him inquiringly.
10116: 
10117: “Mary,” he began, “I am a good-for-nothing blackguard.”
10118: 
10119: “I should think one of those epithets would do at a time,” said Mary,
10120: trying to smile, but feeling alarmed.
10121: 
10122: “I know you will never think well of me any more. You will think me a
10123: liar. You will think me dishonest. You will think I didn’t care for
10124: you, or your father and mother. You always do make the worst of me, I
10125: know.”
10126: 
10127: “I cannot deny that I shall think all that of you, Fred, if you give me
10128: good reasons. But please to tell me at once what you have done. I would
10129: rather know the painful truth than imagine it.”
10130: 
10131: “I owed money—a hundred and sixty pounds. I asked your father to put
10132: his name to a bill. I thought it would not signify to him. I made sure
10133: of paying the money myself, and I have tried as hard as I could. And
10134: now, I have been so unlucky—a horse has turned out badly—I can only pay
10135: fifty pounds. And I can’t ask my father for the money: he would not
10136: give me a farthing. And my uncle gave me a hundred a little while ago.
10137: So what can I do? And now your father has no ready money to spare, and
10138: your mother will have to pay away her ninety-two pounds that she has
10139: saved, and she says your savings must go too. You see what a—”
10140: 
10141: “Oh, poor mother, poor father!” said Mary, her eyes filling with tears,
10142: and a little sob rising which she tried to repress. She looked straight
10143: before her and took no notice of Fred, all the consequences at home
10144: becoming present to her. He too remained silent for some moments,
10145: feeling more miserable than ever. “I wouldn’t have hurt you for the
10146: world, Mary,” he said at last. “You can never forgive me.”
10147: 
10148: “What does it matter whether I forgive you?” said Mary, passionately.
10149: “Would that make it any better for my mother to lose the money she has
10150: been earning by lessons for four years, that she might send Alfred to
10151: Mr. Hanmer’s? Should you think all that pleasant enough if I forgave
10152: you?”
10153: 
10154: “Say what you like, Mary. I deserve it all.”
10155: 
10156: “I don’t want to say anything,” said Mary, more quietly, “and my anger
10157: is of no use.” She dried her eyes, threw aside her book, rose and
10158: fetched her sewing.
10159: 
10160: Fred followed her with his eyes, hoping that they would meet hers, and
10161: in that way find access for his imploring penitence. But no! Mary could
10162: easily avoid looking upward.
10163: 
10164: “I do care about your mother’s money going,” he said, when she was
10165: seated again and sewing quickly. “I wanted to ask you, Mary—don’t you
10166: think that Mr. Featherstone—if you were to tell him—tell him, I mean,
10167: about apprenticing Alfred—would advance the money?”
10168: 
10169: “My family is not fond of begging, Fred. We would rather work for our
10170: money. Besides, you say that Mr. Featherstone has lately given you a
10171: hundred pounds. He rarely makes presents; he has never made presents to
10172: us. I am sure my father will not ask him for anything; and even if I
10173: chose to beg of him, it would be of no use.”
10174: 
10175: “I am so miserable, Mary—if you knew how miserable I am, you would be
10176: sorry for me.”
10177: 
10178: “There are other things to be more sorry for than that. But selfish
10179: people always think their own discomfort of more importance than
10180: anything else in the world. I see enough of that every day.”
10181: 
10182: “It is hardly fair to call me selfish. If you knew what things other
10183: young men do, you would think me a good way off the worst.”
10184: 
10185: “I know that people who spend a great deal of money on themselves
10186: without knowing how they shall pay, must be selfish. They are always
10187: thinking of what they can get for themselves, and not of what other
10188: people may lose.”
10189: 
10190: “Any man may be unfortunate, Mary, and find himself unable to pay when
10191: he meant it. There is not a better man in the world than your father,
10192: and yet he got into trouble.”
10193: 
10194: “How dare you make any comparison between my father and you, Fred?”
10195: said Mary, in a deep tone of indignation. “He never got into trouble by
10196: thinking of his own idle pleasures, but because he was always thinking
10197: of the work he was doing for other people. And he has fared hard, and
10198: worked hard to make good everybody’s loss.”
10199: 
10200: “And you think that I shall never try to make good anything, Mary. It
10201: is not generous to believe the worst of a man. When you have got any
10202: power over him, I think you might try and use it to make him better;
10203: but that is what you never do. However, I’m going,” Fred ended,
10204: languidly. “I shall never speak to you about anything again. I’m very
10205: sorry for all the trouble I’ve caused—that’s all.”
10206: 
10207: Mary had dropped her work out of her hand and looked up. There is often
10208: something maternal even in a girlish love, and Mary’s hard experience
10209: had wrought her nature to an impressibility very different from that
10210: hard slight thing which we call girlishness. At Fred’s last words she
10211: felt an instantaneous pang, something like what a mother feels at the
10212: imagined sobs or cries of her naughty truant child, which may lose
10213: itself and get harm. And when, looking up, her eyes met his dull
10214: despairing glance, her pity for him surmounted her anger and all her
10215: other anxieties.
10216: 
10217: “Oh, Fred, how ill you look! Sit down a moment. Don’t go yet. Let me
10218: tell uncle that you are here. He has been wondering that he has not
10219: seen you for a whole week.” Mary spoke hurriedly, saying the words that
10220: came first without knowing very well what they were, but saying them in
10221: a half-soothing half-beseeching tone, and rising as if to go away to
10222: Mr. Featherstone. Of course Fred felt as if the clouds had parted and a
10223: gleam had come: he moved and stood in her way.
10224: 
10225: “Say one word, Mary, and I will do anything. Say you will not think the
10226: worst of me—will not give me up altogether.”
10227: 
10228: “As if it were any pleasure to me to think ill of you,” said Mary, in a
10229: mournful tone. “As if it were not very painful to me to see you an idle
10230: frivolous creature. How can you bear to be so contemptible, when others
10231: are working and striving, and there are so many things to be done—how
10232: can you bear to be fit for nothing in the world that is useful? And
10233: with so much good in your disposition, Fred,—you might be worth a great
10234: deal.”
10235: 
10236: “I will try to be anything you like, Mary, if you will say that you
10237: love me.”
10238: 
10239: “I should be ashamed to say that I loved a man who must always be
10240: hanging on others, and reckoning on what they would do for him. What
10241: will you be when you are forty? Like Mr. Bowyer, I suppose—just as
10242: idle, living in Mrs. Beck’s front parlor—fat and shabby, hoping
10243: somebody will invite you to dinner—spending your morning in learning a
10244: comic song—oh no! learning a tune on the flute.”
10245: 
10246: Mary’s lips had begun to curl with a smile as soon as she had asked
10247: that question about Fred’s future (young souls are mobile), and before
10248: she ended, her face had its full illumination of fun. To him it was
10249: like the cessation of an ache that Mary could laugh at him, and with a
10250: passive sort of smile he tried to reach her hand; but she slipped away
10251: quickly towards the door and said, “I shall tell uncle. You _must_ see
10252: him for a moment or two.”
10253: 
10254: Fred secretly felt that his future was guaranteed against the
10255: fulfilment of Mary’s sarcastic prophecies, apart from that “anything”
10256: which he was ready to do if she would define it. He never dared in
10257: Mary’s presence to approach the subject of his expectations from Mr.
10258: Featherstone, and she always ignored them, as if everything depended on
10259: himself. But if ever he actually came into the property, she must
10260: recognize the change in his position. All this passed through his mind
10261: somewhat languidly, before he went up to see his uncle. He stayed but a
10262: little while, excusing himself on the ground that he had a cold; and
10263: Mary did not reappear before he left the house. But as he rode home, he
10264: began to be more conscious of being ill, than of being melancholy.
10265: 
10266: When Caleb Garth arrived at Stone Court soon after dusk, Mary was not
10267: surprised, although he seldom had leisure for paying her a visit, and
10268: was not at all fond of having to talk with Mr. Featherstone. The old
10269: man, on the other hand, felt himself ill at ease with a brother-in-law
10270: whom he could not annoy, who did not mind about being considered poor,
10271: had nothing to ask of him, and understood all kinds of farming and
10272: mining business better than he did. But Mary had felt sure that her
10273: parents would want to see her, and if her father had not come, she
10274: would have obtained leave to go home for an hour or two the next day.
10275: After discussing prices during tea with Mr. Featherstone, Caleb rose to
10276: bid him good-by, and said, “I want to speak to you, Mary.”
10277: 
10278: She took a candle into another large parlor, where there was no fire,
10279: and setting down the feeble light on the dark mahogany table, turned
10280: round to her father, and putting her arms round his neck kissed him
10281: with childish kisses which he delighted in,—the expression of his large
10282: brows softening as the expression of a great beautiful dog softens when
10283: it is caressed. Mary was his favorite child, and whatever Susan might
10284: say, and right as she was on all other subjects, Caleb thought it
10285: natural that Fred or any one else should think Mary more lovable than
10286: other girls.
10287: 
10288: “I’ve got something to tell you, my dear,” said Caleb in his hesitating
10289: way. “No very good news; but then it might be worse.”
10290: 
10291: “About money, father? I think I know what it is.”
10292: 
10293: “Ay? how can that be? You see, I’ve been a bit of a fool again, and put
10294: my name to a bill, and now it comes to paying; and your mother has got
10295: to part with her savings, that’s the worst of it, and even they won’t
10296: quite make things even. We wanted a hundred and ten pounds: your mother
10297: has ninety-two, and I have none to spare in the bank; and she thinks
10298: that you have some savings.”
10299: 
10300: “Oh yes; I have more than four-and-twenty pounds. I thought you would
10301: come, father, so I put it in my bag. See! beautiful white notes and
10302: gold.”
10303: 
10304: Mary took out the folded money from her reticule and put it into her
10305: father’s hand.
10306: 
10307: “Well, but how—we only want eighteen—here, put the rest back,
10308: child,—but how did you know about it?” said Caleb, who, in his
10309: unconquerable indifference to money, was beginning to be chiefly
10310: concerned about the relation the affair might have to Mary’s
10311: affections.
10312: 
10313: “Fred told me this morning.”
10314: 
10315: “Ah! Did he come on purpose?”
10316: 
10317: “Yes, I think so. He was a good deal distressed.”
10318: 
10319: “I’m afraid Fred is not to be trusted, Mary,” said the father, with
10320: hesitating tenderness. “He means better than he acts, perhaps. But I
10321: should think it a pity for any body’s happiness to be wrapped up in
10322: him, and so would your mother.”
10323: 
10324: “And so should I, father,” said Mary, not looking up, but putting the
10325: back of her father’s hand against her cheek.
10326: 
10327: “I don’t want to pry, my dear. But I was afraid there might be
10328: something between you and Fred, and I wanted to caution you. You see,
10329: Mary”—here Caleb’s voice became more tender; he had been pushing his
10330: hat about on the table and looking at it, but finally he turned his
10331: eyes on his daughter—“a woman, let her be as good as she may, has got
10332: to put up with the life her husband makes for her. Your mother has had
10333: to put up with a good deal because of me.”
10334: 
10335: Mary turned the back of her father’s hand to her lips and smiled at
10336: him.
10337: 
10338: “Well, well, nobody’s perfect, but”—here Mr. Garth shook his head to
10339: help out the inadequacy of words—“what I am thinking of is—what it must
10340: be for a wife when she’s never sure of her husband, when he hasn’t got
10341: a principle in him to make him more afraid of doing the wrong thing by
10342: others than of getting his own toes pinched. That’s the long and the
10343: short of it, Mary. Young folks may get fond of each other before they
10344: know what life is, and they may think it all holiday if they can only
10345: get together; but it soon turns into working day, my dear. However, you
10346: have more sense than most, and you haven’t been kept in cotton-wool:
10347: there may be no occasion for me to say this, but a father trembles for
10348: his daughter, and you are all by yourself here.”
10349: 
10350: “Don’t fear for me, father,” said Mary, gravely meeting her father’s
10351: eyes; “Fred has always been very good to me; he is kind-hearted and
10352: affectionate, and not false, I think, with all his self-indulgence. But
10353: I will never engage myself to one who has no manly independence, and
10354: who goes on loitering away his time on the chance that others will
10355: provide for him. You and my mother have taught me too much pride for
10356: that.”
10357: 
10358: “That’s right—that’s right. Then I am easy,” said Mr. Garth, taking up
10359: his hat. “But it’s hard to run away with your earnings, eh child.”
10360: 
10361: “Father!” said Mary, in her deepest tone of remonstrance. “Take
10362: pocketfuls of love besides to them all at home,” was her last word
10363: before he closed the outer door on himself.
10364: 
10365: “I suppose your father wanted your earnings,” said old Mr.
10366: Featherstone, with his usual power of unpleasant surmise, when Mary
10367: returned to him. “He makes but a tight fit, I reckon. You’re of age
10368: now; you ought to be saving for yourself.”
10369: 
10370: “I consider my father and mother the best part of myself, sir,” said
10371: Mary, coldly.
10372: 
10373: Mr. Featherstone grunted: he could not deny that an ordinary sort of
10374: girl like her might be expected to be useful, so he thought of another
10375: rejoinder, disagreeable enough to be always apropos. “If Fred Vincy
10376: comes to-morrow, now, don’t you keep him chattering: let him come up to
10377: me.”
10378: 
10379: 
10380: 
10381: 
10382: CHAPTER XXVI.
10383: 
10384: He beats me and I rail at him: O worthy satisfaction! would it were
10385: otherwise—that I could beat him while he railed at me.—_Troilus and
10386: Cressida_.
10387: 
10388: 
10389: But Fred did not go to Stone Court the next day, for reasons that were
10390: quite peremptory. From those visits to unsanitary Houndsley streets in
10391: search of Diamond, he had brought back not only a bad bargain in
10392: horse-flesh, but the further misfortune of some ailment which for a day
10393: or two had deemed mere depression and headache, but which got so much
10394: worse when he returned from his visit to Stone Court that, going into
10395: the dining-room, he threw himself on the sofa, and in answer to his
10396: mother’s anxious question, said, “I feel very ill: I think you must
10397: send for Wrench.”
10398: 
10399: Wrench came, but did not apprehend anything serious, spoke of a “slight
10400: derangement,” and did not speak of coming again on the morrow. He had a
10401: due value for the Vincys’ house, but the wariest men are apt to be
10402: dulled by routine, and on worried mornings will sometimes go through
10403: their business with the zest of the daily bell-ringer. Mr. Wrench was a
10404: small, neat, bilious man, with a well-dressed wig: he had a laborious
10405: practice, an irascible temper, a lymphatic wife and seven children; and
10406: he was already rather late before setting out on a four-miles drive to
10407: meet Dr. Minchin on the other side of Tipton, the decease of Hicks, a
10408: rural practitioner, having increased Middlemarch practice in that
10409: direction. Great statesmen err, and why not small medical men? Mr.
10410: Wrench did not neglect sending the usual white parcels, which this time
10411: had black and drastic contents. Their effect was not alleviating to
10412: poor Fred, who, however, unwilling as he said to believe that he was
10413: “in for an illness,” rose at his usual easy hour the next morning and
10414: went down-stairs meaning to breakfast, but succeeded in nothing but in
10415: sitting and shivering by the fire. Mr. Wrench was again sent for, but
10416: was gone on his rounds, and Mrs. Vincy seeing her darling’s changed
10417: looks and general misery, began to cry and said she would send for Dr.
10418: Sprague.
10419: 
10420: “Oh, nonsense, mother! It’s nothing,” said Fred, putting out his hot
10421: dry hand to her, “I shall soon be all right. I must have taken cold in
10422: that nasty damp ride.”
10423: 
10424: “Mamma!” said Rosamond, who was seated near the window (the dining-room
10425: windows looked on that highly respectable street called Lowick Gate),
10426: “there is Mr. Lydgate, stopping to speak to some one. If I were you I
10427: would call him in. He has cured Ellen Bulstrode. They say he cures
10428: every one.”
10429: 
10430: Mrs. Vincy sprang to the window and opened it in an instant, thinking
10431: only of Fred and not of medical etiquette. Lydgate was only two yards
10432: off on the other side of some iron palisading, and turned round at the
10433: sudden sound of the sash, before she called to him. In two minutes he
10434: was in the room, and Rosamond went out, after waiting just long enough
10435: to show a pretty anxiety conflicting with her sense of what was
10436: becoming.
10437: 
10438: Lydgate had to hear a narrative in which Mrs. Vincy’s mind insisted
10439: with remarkable instinct on every point of minor importance, especially
10440: on what Mr. Wrench had said and had not said about coming again. That
10441: there might be an awkward affair with Wrench, Lydgate saw at once; but
10442: the case was serious enough to make him dismiss that consideration: he
10443: was convinced that Fred was in the pink-skinned stage of typhoid fever,
10444: and that he had taken just the wrong medicines. He must go to bed
10445: immediately, must have a regular nurse, and various appliances and
10446: precautions must be used, about which Lydgate was particular. Poor Mrs.
10447: Vincy’s terror at these indications of danger found vent in such words
10448: as came most easily. She thought it “very ill usage on the part of Mr.
10449: Wrench, who had attended their house so many years in preference to Mr.
10450: Peacock, though Mr. Peacock was equally a friend. Why Mr. Wrench should
10451: neglect her children more than others, she could not for the life of
10452: her understand. He had not neglected Mrs. Larcher’s when they had the
10453: measles, nor indeed would Mrs. Vincy have wished that he should. And if
10454: anything should happen—”
10455: 
10456: Here poor Mrs. Vincy’s spirit quite broke down, and her Niobe throat
10457: and good-humored face were sadly convulsed. This was in the hall out of
10458: Fred’s hearing, but Rosamond had opened the drawing-room door, and now
10459: came forward anxiously. Lydgate apologized for Mr. Wrench, said that
10460: the symptoms yesterday might have been disguising, and that this form
10461: of fever was very equivocal in its beginnings: he would go immediately
10462: to the druggist’s and have a prescription made up in order to lose no
10463: time, but he would write to Mr. Wrench and tell him what had been done.
10464: 
10465: “But you must come again—you must go on attending Fred. I can’t have my
10466: boy left to anybody who may come or not. I bear nobody ill-will, thank
10467: God, and Mr. Wrench saved me in the pleurisy, but he’d better have let
10468: me die—if—if—”
10469: 
10470: “I will meet Mr. Wrench here, then, shall I?” said Lydgate, really
10471: believing that Wrench was not well prepared to deal wisely with a case
10472: of this kind.
10473: 
10474: “Pray make that arrangement, Mr. Lydgate,” said Rosamond, coming to her
10475: mother’s aid, and supporting her arm to lead her away.
10476: 
10477: When Mr. Vincy came home he was very angry with Wrench, and did not
10478: care if he never came into his house again. Lydgate should go on now,
10479: whether Wrench liked it or not. It was no joke to have fever in the
10480: house. Everybody must be sent to now, not to come to dinner on
10481: Thursday. And Pritchard needn’t get up any wine: brandy was the best
10482: thing against infection. “I shall drink brandy,” added Mr. Vincy,
10483: emphatically—as much as to say, this was not an occasion for firing
10484: with blank-cartridges. “He’s an uncommonly unfortunate lad, is Fred.
10485: He’d need have some luck by and by to make up for all this—else I don’t
10486: know who’d have an eldest son.”
10487: 
10488: “Don’t say so, Vincy,” said the mother, with a quivering lip, “if you
10489: don’t want him to be taken from me.”
10490: 
10491: “It will worret you to death, Lucy; _that_ I can see,” said Mr. Vincy,
10492: more mildly. “However, Wrench shall know what I think of the matter.”
10493: (What Mr. Vincy thought confusedly was, that the fever might somehow
10494: have been hindered if Wrench had shown the proper solicitude about
10495: his—the Mayor’s—family.) “I’m the last man to give in to the cry about
10496: new doctors, or new parsons either—whether they’re Bulstrode’s men or
10497: not. But Wrench shall know what I think, take it as he will.”
10498: 
10499: Wrench did not take it at all well. Lydgate was as polite as he could
10500: be in his offhand way, but politeness in a man who has placed you at a
10501: disadvantage is only an additional exasperation, especially if he
10502: happens to have been an object of dislike beforehand. Country
10503: practitioners used to be an irritable species, susceptible on the point
10504: of honor; and Mr. Wrench was one of the most irritable among them. He
10505: did not refuse to meet Lydgate in the evening, but his temper was
10506: somewhat tried on the occasion. He had to hear Mrs. Vincy say—
10507: 
10508: “Oh, Mr. Wrench, what have I ever done that you should use me so?— To
10509: go away, and never to come again! And my boy might have been stretched
10510: a corpse!”
10511: 
10512: Mr. Vincy, who had been keeping up a sharp fire on the enemy Infection,
10513: and was a good deal heated in consequence, started up when he heard
10514: Wrench come in, and went into the hall to let him know what he thought.
10515: 
10516: “I’ll tell you what, Wrench, this is beyond a joke,” said the Mayor,
10517: who of late had had to rebuke offenders with an official air, and now
10518: broadened himself by putting his thumbs in his armholes. “To let fever
10519: get unawares into a house like this. There are some things that ought
10520: to be actionable, and are not so— that’s my opinion.”
10521: 
10522: But irrational reproaches were easier to bear than the sense of being
10523: instructed, or rather the sense that a younger man, like Lydgate,
10524: inwardly considered him in need of instruction, for “in point of fact,”
10525: Mr. Wrench afterwards said, Lydgate paraded flighty, foreign notions,
10526: which would not wear. He swallowed his ire for the moment, but he
10527: afterwards wrote to decline further attendance in the case. The house
10528: might be a good one, but Mr. Wrench was not going to truckle to anybody
10529: on a professional matter. He reflected, with much probability on his
10530: side, that Lydgate would by-and-by be caught tripping too, and that his
10531: ungentlemanly attempts to discredit the sale of drugs by his
10532: professional brethren, would by-and-by recoil on himself. He threw out
10533: biting remarks on Lydgate’s tricks, worthy only of a quack, to get
10534: himself a factitious reputation with credulous people. That cant about
10535: cures was never got up by sound practitioners.
10536: 
10537: This was a point on which Lydgate smarted as much as Wrench could
10538: desire. To be puffed by ignorance was not only humiliating, but
10539: perilous, and not more enviable than the reputation of the
10540: weather-prophet. He was impatient of the foolish expectations amidst
10541: which all work must be carried on, and likely enough to damage himself
10542: as much as Mr. Wrench could wish, by an unprofessional openness.
10543: 
10544: However, Lydgate was installed as medical attendant on the Vincys, and
10545: the event was a subject of general conversation in Middlemarch. Some
10546: said, that the Vincys had behaved scandalously, that Mr. Vincy had
10547: threatened Wrench, and that Mrs. Vincy had accused him of poisoning her
10548: son. Others were of opinion that Mr. Lydgate’s passing by was
10549: providential, that he was wonderfully clever in fevers, and that
10550: Bulstrode was in the right to bring him forward. Many people believed
10551: that Lydgate’s coming to the town at all was really due to Bulstrode;
10552: and Mrs. Taft, who was always counting stitches and gathered her
10553: information in misleading fragments caught between the rows of her
10554: knitting, had got it into her head that Mr. Lydgate was a natural son
10555: of Bulstrode’s, a fact which seemed to justify her suspicions of
10556: evangelical laymen.
10557: 
10558: She one day communicated this piece of knowledge to Mrs. Farebrother,
10559: who did not fail to tell her son of it, observing—
10560: 
10561: “I should not be surprised at anything in Bulstrode, but I should be
10562: sorry to think it of Mr. Lydgate.”
10563: 
10564: “Why, mother,” said Mr. Farebrother, after an explosive laugh, “you
10565: know very well that Lydgate is of a good family in the North. He never
10566: heard of Bulstrode before he came here.”
10567: 
10568: “That is satisfactory so far as Mr. Lydgate is concerned, Camden,” said
10569: the old lady, with an air of precision.—“But as to Bulstrode—the report
10570: may be true of some other son.”
10571: 
10572: 
10573: 
10574: 
10575: CHAPTER XXVII.
10576: 
10577: Let the high Muse chant loves Olympian:
10578: We are but mortals, and must sing of man.
10579: 
10580: 
10581: An eminent philosopher among my friends, who can dignify even your ugly
10582: furniture by lifting it into the serene light of science, has shown me
10583: this pregnant little fact. Your pier-glass or extensive surface of
10584: polished steel made to be rubbed by a housemaid, will be minutely and
10585: multitudinously scratched in all directions; but place now against it a
10586: lighted candle as a centre of illumination, and lo! the scratches will
10587: seem to arrange themselves in a fine series of concentric circles round
10588: that little sun. It is demonstrable that the scratches are going
10589: everywhere impartially and it is only your candle which produces the
10590: flattering illusion of a concentric arrangement, its light falling with
10591: an exclusive optical selection. These things are a parable. The
10592: scratches are events, and the candle is the egoism of any person now
10593: absent—of Miss Vincy, for example. Rosamond had a Providence of her own
10594: who had kindly made her more charming than other girls, and who seemed
10595: to have arranged Fred’s illness and Mr. Wrench’s mistake in order to
10596: bring her and Lydgate within effective proximity. It would have been to
10597: contravene these arrangements if Rosamond had consented to go away to
10598: Stone Court or elsewhere, as her parents wished her to do, especially
10599: since Mr. Lydgate thought the precaution needless. Therefore, while
10600: Miss Morgan and the children were sent away to a farmhouse the morning
10601: after Fred’s illness had declared itself, Rosamond refused to leave
10602: papa and mamma.
10603: 
10604: Poor mamma indeed was an object to touch any creature born of woman;
10605: and Mr. Vincy, who doted on his wife, was more alarmed on her account
10606: than on Fred’s. But for his insistence she would have taken no rest:
10607: her brightness was all bedimmed; unconscious of her costume which had
10608: always been so fresh and gay, she was like a sick bird with languid eye
10609: and plumage ruffled, her senses dulled to the sights and sounds that
10610: used most to interest her. Fred’s delirium, in which he seemed to be
10611: wandering out of her reach, tore her heart. After her first outburst
10612: against Mr. Wrench she went about very quietly: her one low cry was to
10613: Lydgate. She would follow him out of the room and put her hand on his
10614: arm moaning out, “Save my boy.” Once she pleaded, “He has always been
10615: good to me, Mr. Lydgate: he never had a hard word for his mother,”—as
10616: if poor Fred’s suffering were an accusation against him. All the
10617: deepest fibres of the mother’s memory were stirred, and the young man
10618: whose voice took a gentler tone when he spoke to her, was one with the
10619: babe whom she had loved, with a love new to her, before he was born.
10620: 
10621: “I have good hope, Mrs. Vincy,” Lydgate would say. “Come down with me
10622: and let us talk about the food.” In that way he led her to the parlor
10623: where Rosamond was, and made a change for her, surprising her into
10624: taking some tea or broth which had been prepared for her. There was a
10625: constant understanding between him and Rosamond on these matters. He
10626: almost always saw her before going to the sickroom, and she appealed to
10627: him as to what she could do for mamma. Her presence of mind and
10628: adroitness in carrying out his hints were admirable, and it is not
10629: wonderful that the idea of seeing Rosamond began to mingle itself with
10630: his interest in the case. Especially when the critical stage was
10631: passed, and he began to feel confident of Fred’s recovery. In the more
10632: doubtful time, he had advised calling in Dr. Sprague (who, if he could,
10633: would rather have remained neutral on Wrench’s account); but after two
10634: consultations, the conduct of the case was left to Lydgate, and there
10635: was every reason to make him assiduous. Morning and evening he was at
10636: Mr. Vincy’s, and gradually the visits became cheerful as Fred became
10637: simply feeble, and lay not only in need of the utmost petting but
10638: conscious of it, so that Mrs. Vincy felt as if, after all, the illness
10639: had made a festival for her tenderness.
10640: 
10641: Both father and mother held it an added reason for good spirits, when
10642: old Mr. Featherstone sent messages by Lydgate, saying that Fred must
10643: make haste and get well, as he, Peter Featherstone, could not do
10644: without him, and missed his visits sadly. The old man himself was
10645: getting bedridden. Mrs. Vincy told these messages to Fred when he could
10646: listen, and he turned towards her his delicate, pinched face, from
10647: which all the thick blond hair had been cut away, and in which the eyes
10648: seemed to have got larger, yearning for some word about Mary—wondering
10649: what she felt about his illness. No word passed his lips; but “to hear
10650: with eyes belongs to love’s rare wit,” and the mother in the fulness of
10651: her heart not only divined Fred’s longing, but felt ready for any
10652: sacrifice in order to satisfy him.
10653: 
10654: “If I can only see my boy strong again,” she said, in her loving folly;
10655: “and who knows?—perhaps master of Stone Court! and he can marry anybody
10656: he likes then.”
10657: 
10658: “Not if they won’t have me, mother,” said Fred. The illness had made
10659: him childish, and tears came as he spoke.
10660: 
10661: “Oh, take a bit of jelly, my dear,” said Mrs. Vincy, secretly
10662: incredulous of any such refusal.
10663: 
10664: She never left Fred’s side when her husband was not in the house, and
10665: thus Rosamond was in the unusual position of being much alone. Lydgate,
10666: naturally, never thought of staying long with her, yet it seemed that
10667: the brief impersonal conversations they had together were creating that
10668: peculiar intimacy which consists in shyness. They were obliged to look
10669: at each other in speaking, and somehow the looking could not be carried
10670: through as the matter of course which it really was. Lydgate began to
10671: feel this sort of consciousness unpleasant and one day looked down, or
10672: anywhere, like an ill-worked puppet. But this turned out badly: the
10673: next day, Rosamond looked down, and the consequence was that when their
10674: eyes met again, both were more conscious than before. There was no help
10675: for this in science, and as Lydgate did not want to flirt, there seemed
10676: to be no help for it in folly. It was therefore a relief when neighbors
10677: no longer considered the house in quarantine, and when the chances of
10678: seeing Rosamond alone were very much reduced.
10679: 
10680: But that intimacy of mutual embarrassment, in which each feels that the
10681: other is feeling something, having once existed, its effect is not to
10682: be done away with. Talk about the weather and other well-bred topics is
10683: apt to seem a hollow device, and behavior can hardly become easy unless
10684: it frankly recognizes a mutual fascination—which of course need not
10685: mean anything deep or serious. This was the way in which Rosamond and
10686: Lydgate slid gracefully into ease, and made their intercourse lively
10687: again. Visitors came and went as usual, there was once more music in
10688: the drawing-room, and all the extra hospitality of Mr. Vincy’s
10689: mayoralty returned. Lydgate, whenever he could, took his seat by
10690: Rosamond’s side, and lingered to hear her music, calling himself her
10691: captive—meaning, all the while, not to be her captive. The
10692: preposterousness of the notion that he could at once set up a
10693: satisfactory establishment as a married man was a sufficient guarantee
10694: against danger. This play at being a little in love was agreeable, and
10695: did not interfere with graver pursuits. Flirtation, after all, was not
10696: necessarily a singeing process. Rosamond, for her part, had never
10697: enjoyed the days so much in her life before: she was sure of being
10698: admired by some one worth captivating, and she did not distinguish
10699: flirtation from love, either in herself or in another. She seemed to be
10700: sailing with a fair wind just whither she would go, and her thoughts
10701: were much occupied with a handsome house in Lowick Gate which she hoped
10702: would by-and-by be vacant. She was quite determined, when she was
10703: married, to rid herself adroitly of all the visitors who were not
10704: agreeable to her at her father’s; and she imagined the drawing-room in
10705: her favorite house with various styles of furniture.
10706: 
10707: Certainly her thoughts were much occupied with Lydgate himself; he
10708: seemed to her almost perfect: if he had known his notes so that his
10709: enchantment under her music had been less like an emotional elephant’s,
10710: and if he had been able to discriminate better the refinements of her
10711: taste in dress, she could hardly have mentioned a deficiency in him.
10712: How different he was from young Plymdale or Mr. Caius Larcher! Those
10713: young men had not a notion of French, and could speak on no subject
10714: with striking knowledge, except perhaps the dyeing and carrying trades,
10715: which of course they were ashamed to mention; they were Middlemarch
10716: gentry, elated with their silver-headed whips and satin stocks, but
10717: embarrassed in their manners, and timidly jocose: even Fred was above
10718: them, having at least the accent and manner of a university man.
10719: Whereas Lydgate was always listened to, bore himself with the careless
10720: politeness of conscious superiority, and seemed to have the right
10721: clothes on by a certain natural affinity, without ever having to think
10722: about them. Rosamond was proud when he entered the room, and when he
10723: approached her with a distinguishing smile, she had a delicious sense
10724: that she was the object of enviable homage. If Lydgate had been aware
10725: of all the pride he excited in that delicate bosom, he might have been
10726: just as well pleased as any other man, even the most densely ignorant
10727: of humoral pathology or fibrous tissue: he held it one of the prettiest
10728: attitudes of the feminine mind to adore a man’s pre-eminence without
10729: too precise a knowledge of what it consisted in. But Rosamond was not
10730: one of those helpless girls who betray themselves unawares, and whose
10731: behavior is awkwardly driven by their impulses, instead of being
10732: steered by wary grace and propriety. Do you imagine that her rapid
10733: forecast and rumination concerning house-furniture and society were
10734: ever discernible in her conversation, even with her mamma? On the
10735: contrary, she would have expressed the prettiest surprise and
10736: disapprobation if she had heard that another young lady had been
10737: detected in that immodest prematureness—indeed, would probably have
10738: disbelieved in its possibility. For Rosamond never showed any
10739: unbecoming knowledge, and was always that combination of correct
10740: sentiments, music, dancing, drawing, elegant note-writing, private
10741: album for extracted verse, and perfect blond loveliness, which made the
10742: irresistible woman for the doomed man of that date. Think no unfair
10743: evil of her, pray: she had no wicked plots, nothing sordid or
10744: mercenary; in fact, she never thought of money except as something
10745: necessary which other people would always provide. She was not in the
10746: habit of devising falsehoods, and if her statements were no direct clew
10747: to fact, why, they were not intended in that light—they were among her
10748: elegant accomplishments, intended to please. Nature had inspired many
10749: arts in finishing Mrs. Lemon’s favorite pupil, who by general consent
10750: (Fred’s excepted) was a rare compound of beauty, cleverness, and
10751: amiability.
10752: 
10753: Lydgate found it more and more agreeable to be with her, and there was
10754: no constraint now, there was a delightful interchange of influence in
10755: their eyes, and what they said had that superfluity of meaning for
10756: them, which is observable with some sense of flatness by a third
10757: person; still they had no interviews or asides from which a third
10758: person need have been excluded. In fact, they flirted; and Lydgate was
10759: secure in the belief that they did nothing else. If a man could not
10760: love and be wise, surely he could flirt and be wise at the same time?
10761: Really, the men in Middlemarch, except Mr. Farebrother, were great
10762: bores, and Lydgate did not care about commercial politics or cards:
10763: what was he to do for relaxation? He was often invited to the
10764: Bulstrodes’; but the girls there were hardly out of the schoolroom; and
10765: Mrs. Bulstrode’s _naive_ way of conciliating piety and worldliness, the
10766: nothingness of this life and the desirability of cut glass, the
10767: consciousness at once of filthy rags and the best damask, was not a
10768: sufficient relief from the weight of her husband’s invariable
10769: seriousness. The Vincys’ house, with all its faults, was the pleasanter
10770: by contrast; besides, it nourished Rosamond—sweet to look at as a
10771: half-opened blush-rose, and adorned with accomplishments for the
10772: refined amusement of man.
10773: 
10774: But he made some enemies, other than medical, by his success with Miss
10775: Vincy. One evening he came into the drawing-room rather late, when
10776: several other visitors were there. The card-table had drawn off the
10777: elders, and Mr. Ned Plymdale (one of the good matches in Middlemarch,
10778: though not one of its leading minds) was in _tête-à-tête_ with
10779: Rosamond. He had brought the last “Keepsake,” the gorgeous watered-silk
10780: publication which marked modern progress at that time; and he
10781: considered himself very fortunate that he could be the first to look
10782: over it with her, dwelling on the ladies and gentlemen with shiny
10783: copper-plate cheeks and copper-plate smiles, and pointing to comic
10784: verses as capital and sentimental stories as interesting. Rosamond was
10785: gracious, and Mr. Ned was satisfied that he had the very best thing in
10786: art and literature as a medium for “paying addresses”—the very thing to
10787: please a nice girl. He had also reasons, deep rather than ostensible,
10788: for being satisfied with his own appearance. To superficial observers
10789: his chin had too vanishing an aspect, looking as if it were being
10790: gradually reabsorbed. And it did indeed cause him some difficulty about
10791: the fit of his satin stocks, for which chins were at that time useful.
10792: 
10793: “I think the Honorable Mrs. S. is something like you,” said Mr. Ned. He
10794: kept the book open at the bewitching portrait, and looked at it rather
10795: languishingly.
10796: 
10797: “Her back is very large; she seems to have sat for that,” said
10798: Rosamond, not meaning any satire, but thinking how red young Plymdale’s
10799: hands were, and wondering why Lydgate did not come. She went on with
10800: her tatting all the while.
10801: 
10802: “I did not say she was as beautiful as you are,” said Mr. Ned,
10803: venturing to look from the portrait to its rival.
10804: 
10805: “I suspect you of being an adroit flatterer,” said Rosamond, feeling
10806: sure that she should have to reject this young gentleman a second time.
10807: 
10808: But now Lydgate came in; the book was closed before he reached
10809: Rosamond’s corner, and as he took his seat with easy confidence on the
10810: other side of her, young Plymdale’s jaw fell like a barometer towards
10811: the cheerless side of change. Rosamond enjoyed not only Lydgate’s
10812: presence but its effect: she liked to excite jealousy.
10813: 
10814: “What a late comer you are!” she said, as they shook hands. “Mamma had
10815: given you up a little while ago. How do you find Fred?”
10816: 
10817: “As usual; going on well, but slowly. I want him to go away—to Stone
10818: Court, for example. But your mamma seems to have some objection.”
10819: 
10820: “Poor fellow!” said Rosamond, prettily. “You will see Fred so changed,”
10821: she added, turning to the other suitor; “we have looked to Mr. Lydgate
10822: as our guardian angel during this illness.”
10823: 
10824: Mr. Ned smiled nervously, while Lydgate, drawing the “Keepsake” towards
10825: him and opening it, gave a short scornful laugh and tossed up his chin,
10826: as if in wonderment at human folly.
10827: 
10828: “What are you laughing at so profanely?” said Rosamond, with bland
10829: neutrality.
10830: 
10831: “I wonder which would turn out to be the silliest—the engravings or the
10832: writing here,” said Lydgate, in his most convinced tone, while he
10833: turned over the pages quickly, seeming to see all through the book in
10834: no time, and showing his large white hands to much advantage, as
10835: Rosamond thought. “Do look at this bridegroom coming out of church: did
10836: you ever see such a ‘sugared invention’—as the Elizabethans used to
10837: say? Did any haberdasher ever look so smirking? Yet I will answer for
10838: it the story makes him one of the first gentlemen in the land.”
10839: 
10840: “You are so severe, I am frightened at you,” said Rosamond, keeping her
10841: amusement duly moderate. Poor young Plymdale had lingered with
10842: admiration over this very engraving, and his spirit was stirred.
10843: 
10844: “There are a great many celebrated people writing in the ‘Keepsake,’ at
10845: all events,” he said, in a tone at once piqued and timid. “This is the
10846: first time I have heard it called silly.”
10847: 
10848: “I think I shall turn round on you and accuse you of being a Goth,”
10849: said Rosamond, looking at Lydgate with a smile. “I suspect you know
10850: nothing about Lady Blessington and L. E. L.” Rosamond herself was not
10851: without relish for these writers, but she did not readily commit
10852: herself by admiration, and was alive to the slightest hint that
10853: anything was not, according to Lydgate, in the very highest taste.
10854: 
10855: “But Sir Walter Scott—I suppose Mr. Lydgate knows him,” said young
10856: Plymdale, a little cheered by this advantage.
10857: 
10858: “Oh, I read no literature now,” said Lydgate, shutting the book, and
10859: pushing it away. “I read so much when I was a lad, that I suppose it
10860: will last me all my life. I used to know Scott’s poems by heart.”
10861: 
10862: “I should like to know when you left off,” said Rosamond, “because then
10863: I might be sure that I knew something which you did not know.”
10864: 
10865: “Mr. Lydgate would say that was not worth knowing,” said Mr. Ned,
10866: purposely caustic.
10867: 
10868: “On the contrary,” said Lydgate, showing no smart; but smiling with
10869: exasperating confidence at Rosamond. “It would be worth knowing by the
10870: fact that Miss Vincy could tell it me.”
10871: 
10872: Young Plymdale soon went to look at the whist-playing, thinking that
10873: Lydgate was one of the most conceited, unpleasant fellows it had ever
10874: been his ill-fortune to meet.
10875: 
10876: “How rash you are!” said Rosamond, inwardly delighted. “Do you see that
10877: you have given offence?”
10878: 
10879: “What! is it Mr. Plymdale’s book? I am sorry. I didn’t think about it.”
10880: 
10881: “I shall begin to admit what you said of yourself when you first came
10882: here—that you are a bear, and want teaching by the birds.”
10883: 
10884: “Well, there is a bird who can teach me what she will. Don’t I listen
10885: to her willingly?”
10886: 
10887: To Rosamond it seemed as if she and Lydgate were as good as engaged.
10888: That they were some time to be engaged had long been an idea in her
10889: mind; and ideas, we know, tend to a more solid kind of existence, the
10890: necessary materials being at hand. It is true, Lydgate had the
10891: counter-idea of remaining unengaged; but this was a mere negative, a
10892: shadow cast by other resolves which themselves were capable of
10893: shrinking. Circumstance was almost sure to be on the side of Rosamond’s
10894: idea, which had a shaping activity and looked through watchful blue
10895: eyes, whereas Lydgate’s lay blind and unconcerned as a jelly-fish which
10896: gets melted without knowing it.
10897: 
10898: That evening when he went home, he looked at his phials to see how a
10899: process of maceration was going on, with undisturbed interest; and he
10900: wrote out his daily notes with as much precision as usual. The reveries
10901: from which it was difficult for him to detach himself were ideal
10902: constructions of something else than Rosamond’s virtues, and the
10903: primitive tissue was still his fair unknown. Moreover, he was beginning
10904: to feel some zest for the growing though half-suppressed feud between
10905: him and the other medical men, which was likely to become more
10906: manifest, now that Bulstrode’s method of managing the new hospital was
10907: about to be declared; and there were various inspiriting signs that his
10908: non-acceptance by some of Peacock’s patients might be counterbalanced
10909: by the impression he had produced in other quarters. Only a few days
10910: later, when he had happened to overtake Rosamond on the Lowick road and
10911: had got down from his horse to walk by her side until he had quite
10912: protected her from a passing drove, he had been stopped by a servant on
10913: horseback with a message calling him in to a house of some importance
10914: where Peacock had never attended; and it was the second instance of
10915: this kind. The servant was Sir James Chettam’s, and the house was
10916: Lowick Manor.
10917: 
10918: 
10919: 
10920: 
10921: CHAPTER XXVIII.
10922:
