10923: 1_st Gent_. All times are good to seek your wedded home
10924:     Bringing a mutual delight.
10925: 
10926: 2_d Gent_. Why, true.
10927:     The calendar hath not an evil day
10928:     For souls made one by love, and even death
10929:     Were sweetness, if it came like rolling waves
10930:     While they two clasped each other, and foresaw
10931:     No life apart.
10932: 
10933: 
10934: Mr. and Mrs. Casaubon, returning from their wedding journey, arrived at
10935: Lowick Manor in the middle of January. A light snow was falling as they
10936: descended at the door, and in the morning, when Dorothea passed from
10937: her dressing-room into the blue-green boudoir that we know of, she saw
10938: the long avenue of limes lifting their trunks from a white earth, and
10939: spreading white branches against the dun and motionless sky. The
10940: distant flat shrank in uniform whiteness and low-hanging uniformity of
10941: cloud. The very furniture in the room seemed to have shrunk since she
10942: saw it before: the stag in the tapestry looked more like a ghost in his
10943: ghostly blue-green world; the volumes of polite literature in the
10944: bookcase looked more like immovable imitations of books. The bright
10945: fire of dry oak-boughs burning on the logs seemed an incongruous
10946: renewal of life and glow—like the figure of Dorothea herself as she
10947: entered carrying the red-leather cases containing the cameos for Celia.
10948: 
10949: She was glowing from her morning toilet as only healthful youth can
10950: glow: there was gem-like brightness on her coiled hair and in her hazel
10951: eyes; there was warm red life in her lips; her throat had a breathing
10952: whiteness above the differing white of the fur which itself seemed to
10953: wind about her neck and cling down her blue-gray pelisse with a
10954: tenderness gathered from her own, a sentient commingled innocence which
10955: kept its loveliness against the crystalline purity of the outdoor snow.
10956: As she laid the cameo-cases on the table in the bow-window, she
10957: unconsciously kept her hands on them, immediately absorbed in looking
10958: out on the still, white enclosure which made her visible world.
10959: 
10960: Mr. Casaubon, who had risen early complaining of palpitation, was in
10961: the library giving audience to his curate Mr. Tucker. By-and-by Celia
10962: would come in her quality of bridesmaid as well as sister, and through
10963: the next weeks there would be wedding visits received and given; all in
10964: continuance of that transitional life understood to correspond with the
10965: excitement of bridal felicity, and keeping up the sense of busy
10966: ineffectiveness, as of a dream which the dreamer begins to suspect. The
10967: duties of her married life, contemplated as so great beforehand, seemed
10968: to be shrinking with the furniture and the white vapor-walled
10969: landscape. The clear heights where she expected to walk in full
10970: communion had become difficult to see even in her imagination; the
10971: delicious repose of the soul on a complete superior had been shaken
10972: into uneasy effort and alarmed with dim presentiment. When would the
10973: days begin of that active wifely devotion which was to strengthen her
10974: husband’s life and exalt her own? Never perhaps, as she had
10975: preconceived them; but somehow—still somehow. In this solemnly pledged
10976: union of her life, duty would present itself in some new form of
10977: inspiration and give a new meaning to wifely love.
10978: 
10979: Meanwhile there was the snow and the low arch of dun vapor—there was
10980: the stifling oppression of that gentlewoman’s world, where everything
10981: was done for her and none asked for her aid—where the sense of
10982: connection with a manifold pregnant existence had to be kept up
10983: painfully as an inward vision, instead of coming from without in claims
10984: that would have shaped her energies.— “What shall I do?” “Whatever you
10985: please, my dear:” that had been her brief history since she had left
10986: off learning morning lessons and practising silly rhythms on the hated
10987: piano. Marriage, which was to bring guidance into worthy and imperative
10988: occupation, had not yet freed her from the gentlewoman’s oppressive
10989: liberty: it had not even filled her leisure with the ruminant joy of
10990: unchecked tenderness. Her blooming full-pulsed youth stood there in a
10991: moral imprisonment which made itself one with the chill, colorless,
10992: narrowed landscape, with the shrunken furniture, the never-read books,
10993: and the ghostly stag in a pale fantastic world that seemed to be
10994: vanishing from the daylight.
10995: 
10996: In the first minutes when Dorothea looked out she felt nothing but the
10997: dreary oppression; then came a keen remembrance, and turning away from
10998: the window she walked round the room. The ideas and hopes which were
10999: living in her mind when she first saw this room nearly three months
11000: before were present now only as memories: she judged them as we judge
11001: transient and departed things. All existence seemed to beat with a
11002: lower pulse than her own, and her religious faith was a solitary cry,
11003: the struggle out of a nightmare in which every object was withering and
11004: shrinking away from her. Each remembered thing in the room was
11005: disenchanted, was deadened as an unlit transparency, till her wandering
11006: gaze came to the group of miniatures, and there at last she saw
11007: something which had gathered new breath and meaning: it was the
11008: miniature of Mr. Casaubon’s aunt Julia, who had made the unfortunate
11009: marriage—of Will Ladislaw’s grandmother. Dorothea could fancy that it
11010: was alive now—the delicate woman’s face which yet had a headstrong
11011: look, a peculiarity difficult to interpret. Was it only her friends who
11012: thought her marriage unfortunate? or did she herself find it out to be
11013: a mistake, and taste the salt bitterness of her tears in the merciful
11014: silence of the night? What breadths of experience Dorothea seemed to
11015: have passed over since she first looked at this miniature! She felt a
11016: new companionship with it, as if it had an ear for her and could see
11017: how she was looking at it. Here was a woman who had known some
11018: difficulty about marriage. Nay, the colors deepened, the lips and chin
11019: seemed to get larger, the hair and eyes seemed to be sending out light,
11020: the face was masculine and beamed on her with that full gaze which
11021: tells her on whom it falls that she is too interesting for the
11022: slightest movement of her eyelid to pass unnoticed and uninterpreted.
11023: The vivid presentation came like a pleasant glow to Dorothea: she felt
11024: herself smiling, and turning from the miniature sat down and looked up
11025: as if she were again talking to a figure in front of her. But the smile
11026: disappeared as she went on meditating, and at last she said aloud—
11027: 
11028: “Oh, it was cruel to speak so! How sad—how dreadful!”
11029: 
11030: She rose quickly and went out of the room, hurrying along the corridor,
11031: with the irresistible impulse to go and see her husband and inquire if
11032: she could do anything for him. Perhaps Mr. Tucker was gone and Mr.
11033: Casaubon was alone in the library. She felt as if all her morning’s
11034: gloom would vanish if she could see her husband glad because of her
11035: presence.
11036: 
11037: But when she reached the head of the dark oak there was Celia coming
11038: up, and below there was Mr. Brooke, exchanging welcomes and
11039: congratulations with Mr. Casaubon.
11040: 
11041: “Dodo!” said Celia, in her quiet staccato; then kissed her sister,
11042: whose arms encircled her, and said no more. I think they both cried a
11043: little in a furtive manner, while Dorothea ran down-stairs to greet her
11044: uncle.
11045: 
11046: “I need not ask how you are, my dear,” said Mr. Brooke, after kissing
11047: her forehead. “Rome has agreed with you, I see—happiness, frescos, the
11048: antique—that sort of thing. Well, it’s very pleasant to have you back
11049: again, and you understand all about art now, eh? But Casaubon is a
11050: little pale, I tell him—a little pale, you know. Studying hard in his
11051: holidays is carrying it rather too far. I overdid it at one time”—Mr.
11052: Brooke still held Dorothea’s hand, but had turned his face to Mr.
11053: Casaubon—“about topography, ruins, temples—I thought I had a clew, but
11054: I saw it would carry me too far, and nothing might come of it. You may
11055: go any length in that sort of thing, and nothing may come of it, you
11056: know.”
11057: 
11058: Dorothea’s eyes also were turned up to her husband’s face with some
11059: anxiety at the idea that those who saw him afresh after absence might
11060: be aware of signs which she had not noticed.
11061: 
11062: “Nothing to alarm you, my dear,” said Mr. Brooke, observing her
11063: expression. “A little English beef and mutton will soon make a
11064: difference. It was all very well to look pale, sitting for the portrait
11065: of Aquinas, you know—we got your letter just in time. But Aquinas,
11066: now—he was a little too subtle, wasn’t he? Does anybody read Aquinas?”
11067: 
11068: “He is not indeed an author adapted to superficial minds,” said Mr.
11069: Casaubon, meeting these timely questions with dignified patience.
11070: 
11071: “You would like coffee in your own room, uncle?” said Dorothea, coming
11072: to the rescue.
11073: 
11074: “Yes; and you must go to Celia: she has great news to tell you, you
11075: know. I leave it all to her.”
11076: 
11077: The blue-green boudoir looked much more cheerful when Celia was seated
11078: there in a pelisse exactly like her sister’s, surveying the cameos with
11079: a placid satisfaction, while the conversation passed on to other
11080: topics.
11081: 
11082: “Do you think it nice to go to Rome on a wedding journey?” said Celia,
11083: with her ready delicate blush which Dorothea was used to on the
11084: smallest occasions.
11085: 
11086: “It would not suit all—not you, dear, for example,” said Dorothea,
11087: quietly. No one would ever know what she thought of a wedding journey
11088: to Rome.
11089: 
11090: “Mrs. Cadwallader says it is nonsense, people going a long journey when
11091: they are married. She says they get tired to death of each other, and
11092: can’t quarrel comfortably, as they would at home. And Lady Chettam says
11093: she went to Bath.” Celia’s color changed again and again—seemed
11094: 
11095: “To come and go with tidings from the heart,
11096: As it a running messenger had been.”
11097: 
11098: 
11099: It must mean more than Celia’s blushing usually did.
11100: 
11101: “Celia! has something happened?” said Dorothea, in a tone full of
11102: sisterly feeling. “Have you really any great news to tell me?”
11103: 
11104: “It was because you went away, Dodo. Then there was nobody but me for
11105: Sir James to talk to,” said Celia, with a certain roguishness in her
11106: eyes.
11107: 
11108: “I understand. It is as I used to hope and believe,” said Dorothea,
11109: taking her sister’s face between her hands, and looking at her half
11110: anxiously. Celia’s marriage seemed more serious than it used to do.
11111: 
11112: “It was only three days ago,” said Celia. “And Lady Chettam is very
11113: kind.”
11114: 
11115: “And you are very happy?”
11116: 
11117: “Yes. We are not going to be married yet. Because every thing is to be
11118: got ready. And I don’t want to be married so very soon, because I think
11119: it is nice to be engaged. And we shall be married all our lives after.”
11120: 
11121: “I do believe you could not marry better, Kitty. Sir James is a good,
11122: honorable man,” said Dorothea, warmly.
11123: 
11124: “He has gone on with the cottages, Dodo. He will tell you about them
11125: when he comes. Shall you be glad to see him?”
11126: 
11127: “Of course I shall. How can you ask me?”
11128: 
11129: “Only I was afraid you would be getting so learned,” said Celia,
11130: regarding Mr. Casaubon’s learning as a kind of damp which might in due
11131: time saturate a neighboring body.
11132: 
11133: 
11134: 
11135: 
11136: CHAPTER XXIX.
11137: 
11138: I found that no genius in another could please me. My unfortunate
11139: paradoxes had entirely dried up that source of comfort.—GOLDSMITH.
11140: 
11141: 
11142: One morning, some weeks after her arrival at Lowick, Dorothea—but why
11143: always Dorothea? Was her point of view the only possible one with
11144: regard to this marriage? I protest against all our interest, all our
11145: effort at understanding being given to the young skins that look
11146: blooming in spite of trouble; for these too will get faded, and will
11147: know the older and more eating griefs which we are helping to neglect.
11148: In spite of the blinking eyes and white moles objectionable to Celia,
11149: and the want of muscular curve which was morally painful to Sir James,
11150: Mr. Casaubon had an intense consciousness within him, and was
11151: spiritually a-hungered like the rest of us. He had done nothing
11152: exceptional in marrying—nothing but what society sanctions, and
11153: considers an occasion for wreaths and bouquets. It had occurred to him
11154: that he must not any longer defer his intention of matrimony, and he
11155: had reflected that in taking a wife, a man of good position should
11156: expect and carefully choose a blooming young lady—the younger the
11157: better, because more educable and submissive—of a rank equal to his
11158: own, of religious principles, virtuous disposition, and good
11159: understanding. On such a young lady he would make handsome settlements,
11160: and he would neglect no arrangement for her happiness: in return, he
11161: should receive family pleasures and leave behind him that copy of
11162: himself which seemed so urgently required of a man—to the sonneteers of
11163: the sixteenth century. Times had altered since then, and no sonneteer
11164: had insisted on Mr. Casaubon’s leaving a copy of himself; moreover, he
11165: had not yet succeeded in issuing copies of his mythological key; but he
11166: had always intended to acquit himself by marriage, and the sense that
11167: he was fast leaving the years behind him, that the world was getting
11168: dimmer and that he felt lonely, was a reason to him for losing no more
11169: time in overtaking domestic delights before they too were left behind
11170: by the years.
11171: 
11172: And when he had seen Dorothea he believed that he had found even more
11173: than he demanded: she might really be such a helpmate to him as would
11174: enable him to dispense with a hired secretary, an aid which Mr.
11175: Casaubon had never yet employed and had a suspicious dread of. (Mr.
11176: Casaubon was nervously conscious that he was expected to manifest a
11177: powerful mind.) Providence, in its kindness, had supplied him with the
11178: wife he needed. A wife, a modest young lady, with the purely
11179: appreciative, unambitious abilities of her sex, is sure to think her
11180: husband’s mind powerful. Whether Providence had taken equal care of
11181: Miss Brooke in presenting her with Mr. Casaubon was an idea which could
11182: hardly occur to him. Society never made the preposterous demand that a
11183: man should think as much about his own qualifications for making a
11184: charming girl happy as he thinks of hers for making himself happy. As
11185: if a man could choose not only his wife but his wife’s husband! Or as
11186: if he were bound to provide charms for his posterity in his own
11187: person!— When Dorothea accepted him with effusion, that was only
11188: natural; and Mr. Casaubon believed that his happiness was going to
11189: begin.
11190: 
11191: He had not had much foretaste of happiness in his previous life. To
11192: know intense joy without a strong bodily frame, one must have an
11193: enthusiastic soul. Mr. Casaubon had never had a strong bodily frame,
11194: and his soul was sensitive without being enthusiastic: it was too
11195: languid to thrill out of self-consciousness into passionate delight; it
11196: went on fluttering in the swampy ground where it was hatched, thinking
11197: of its wings and never flying. His experience was of that pitiable kind
11198: which shrinks from pity, and fears most of all that it should be known:
11199: it was that proud narrow sensitiveness which has not mass enough to
11200: spare for transformation into sympathy, and quivers thread-like in
11201: small currents of self-preoccupation or at best of an egoistic
11202: scrupulosity. And Mr. Casaubon had many scruples: he was capable of a
11203: severe self-restraint; he was resolute in being a man of honor
11204: according to the code; he would be unimpeachable by any recognized
11205: opinion. In conduct these ends had been attained; but the difficulty of
11206: making his Key to all Mythologies unimpeachable weighed like lead upon
11207: his mind; and the pamphlets—or “Parerga” as he called them—by which he
11208: tested his public and deposited small monumental records of his march,
11209: were far from having been seen in all their significance. He suspected
11210: the Archdeacon of not having read them; he was in painful doubt as to
11211: what was really thought of them by the leading minds of Brasenose, and
11212: bitterly convinced that his old acquaintance Carp had been the writer
11213: of that depreciatory recension which was kept locked in a small drawer
11214: of Mr. Casaubon’s desk, and also in a dark closet of his verbal memory.
11215: These were heavy impressions to struggle against, and brought that
11216: melancholy embitterment which is the consequence of all excessive
11217: claim: even his religious faith wavered with his wavering trust in his
11218: own authorship, and the consolations of the Christian hope in
11219: immortality seemed to lean on the immortality of the still unwritten
11220: Key to all Mythologies. For my part I am very sorry for him. It is an
11221: uneasy lot at best, to be what we call highly taught and yet not to
11222: enjoy: to be present at this great spectacle of life and never to be
11223: liberated from a small hungry shivering self—never to be fully
11224: possessed by the glory we behold, never to have our consciousness
11225: rapturously transformed into the vividness of a thought, the ardor of a
11226: passion, the energy of an action, but always to be scholarly and
11227: uninspired, ambitious and timid, scrupulous and dim-sighted. Becoming a
11228: dean or even a bishop would make little difference, I fear, to Mr.
11229: Casaubon’s uneasiness. Doubtless some ancient Greek has observed that
11230: behind the big mask and the speaking-trumpet, there must always be our
11231: poor little eyes peeping as usual and our timorous lips more or less
11232: under anxious control.
11233: 
11234: To this mental estate mapped out a quarter of a century before, to
11235: sensibilities thus fenced in, Mr. Casaubon had thought of annexing
11236: happiness with a lovely young bride; but even before marriage, as we
11237: have seen, he found himself under a new depression in the consciousness
11238: that the new bliss was not blissful to him. Inclination yearned back to
11239: its old, easier custom. And the deeper he went in domesticity the more
11240: did the sense of acquitting himself and acting with propriety
11241: predominate over any other satisfaction. Marriage, like religion and
11242: erudition, nay, like authorship itself, was fated to become an outward
11243: requirement, and Edward Casaubon was bent on fulfilling unimpeachably
11244: all requirements. Even drawing Dorothea into use in his study,
11245: according to his own intention before marriage, was an effort which he
11246: was always tempted to defer, and but for her pleading insistence it
11247: might never have begun. But she had succeeded in making it a matter of
11248: course that she should take her place at an early hour in the library
11249: and have work either of reading aloud or copying assigned her. The work
11250: had been easier to define because Mr. Casaubon had adopted an immediate
11251: intention: there was to be a new Parergon, a small monograph on some
11252: lately traced indications concerning the Egyptian mysteries whereby
11253: certain assertions of Warburton’s could be corrected. References were
11254: extensive even here, but not altogether shoreless; and sentences were
11255: actually to be written in the shape wherein they would be scanned by
11256: Brasenose and a less formidable posterity. These minor monumental
11257: productions were always exciting to Mr. Casaubon; digestion was made
11258: difficult by the interference of citations, or by the rivalry of
11259: dialectical phrases ringing against each other in his brain. And from
11260: the first there was to be a Latin dedication about which everything was
11261: uncertain except that it was not to be addressed to Carp: it was a
11262: poisonous regret to Mr. Casaubon that he had once addressed a
11263: dedication to Carp in which he had numbered that member of the animal
11264: kingdom among the _viros nullo ævo perituros_, a mistake which would
11265: infallibly lay the dedicator open to ridicule in the next age, and
11266: might even be chuckled over by Pike and Tench in the present.
11267: 
11268: Thus Mr. Casaubon was in one of his busiest epochs, and as I began to
11269: say a little while ago, Dorothea joined him early in the library where
11270: he had breakfasted alone. Celia at this time was on a second visit to
11271: Lowick, probably the last before her marriage, and was in the
11272: drawing-room expecting Sir James.
11273: 
11274: Dorothea had learned to read the signs of her husband’s mood, and she
11275: saw that the morning had become more foggy there during the last hour.
11276: She was going silently to her desk when he said, in that distant tone
11277: which implied that he was discharging a disagreeable duty—
11278: 
11279: “Dorothea, here is a letter for you, which was enclosed in one
11280: addressed to me.”
11281: 
11282: It was a letter of two pages, and she immediately looked at the
11283: signature.
11284: 
11285: “Mr. Ladislaw! What can he have to say to me?” she exclaimed, in a tone
11286: of pleased surprise. “But,” she added, looking at Mr. Casaubon, “I can
11287: imagine what he has written to you about.”
11288: 
11289: “You can, if you please, read the letter,” said Mr. Casaubon, severely
11290: pointing to it with his pen, and not looking at her. “But I may as well
11291: say beforehand, that I must decline the proposal it contains to pay a
11292: visit here. I trust I may be excused for desiring an interval of
11293: complete freedom from such distractions as have been hitherto
11294: inevitable, and especially from guests whose desultory vivacity makes
11295: their presence a fatigue.”
11296: 
11297: There had been no clashing of temper between Dorothea and her husband
11298: since that little explosion in Rome, which had left such strong traces
11299: in her mind that it had been easier ever since to quell emotion than to
11300: incur the consequence of venting it. But this ill-tempered anticipation
11301: that she could desire visits which might be disagreeable to her
11302: husband, this gratuitous defence of himself against selfish complaint
11303: on her part, was too sharp a sting to be meditated on until after it
11304: had been resented. Dorothea had thought that she could have been
11305: patient with John Milton, but she had never imagined him behaving in
11306: this way; and for a moment Mr. Casaubon seemed to be stupidly
11307: undiscerning and odiously unjust. Pity, that “new-born babe” which was
11308: by-and-by to rule many a storm within her, did not “stride the blast”
11309: on this occasion. With her first words, uttered in a tone that shook
11310: him, she startled Mr. Casaubon into looking at her, and meeting the
11311: flash of her eyes.
11312: 
11313: “Why do you attribute to me a wish for anything that would annoy you?
11314: You speak to me as if I were something you had to contend against. Wait
11315: at least till I appear to consult my own pleasure apart from yours.”
11316: 
11317: “Dorothea, you are hasty,” answered Mr. Casaubon, nervously.
11318: 
11319: Decidedly, this woman was too young to be on the formidable level of
11320: wifehood—unless she had been pale and featureless and taken everything
11321: for granted.
11322: 
11323: “I think it was you who were first hasty in your false suppositions
11324: about my feeling,” said Dorothea, in the same tone. The fire was not
11325: dissipated yet, and she thought it was ignoble in her husband not to
11326: apologize to her.
11327: 
11328: “We will, if you please, say no more on this subject, Dorothea. I have
11329: neither leisure nor energy for this kind of debate.”
11330: 
11331: Here Mr. Casaubon dipped his pen and made as if he would return to his
11332: writing, though his hand trembled so much that the words seemed to be
11333: written in an unknown character. There are answers which, in turning
11334: away wrath, only send it to the other end of the room, and to have a
11335: discussion coolly waived when you feel that justice is all on your own
11336: side is even more exasperating in marriage than in philosophy.
11337: 
11338: Dorothea left Ladislaw’s two letters unread on her husband’s
11339: writing-table and went to her own place, the scorn and indignation
11340: within her rejecting the reading of these letters, just as we hurl away
11341: any trash towards which we seem to have been suspected of mean
11342: cupidity. She did not in the least divine the subtle sources of her
11343: husband’s bad temper about these letters: she only knew that they had
11344: caused him to offend her. She began to work at once, and her hand did
11345: not tremble; on the contrary, in writing out the quotations which had
11346: been given to her the day before, she felt that she was forming her
11347: letters beautifully, and it seemed to her that she saw the construction
11348: of the Latin she was copying, and which she was beginning to
11349: understand, more clearly than usual. In her indignation there was a
11350: sense of superiority, but it went out for the present in firmness of
11351: stroke, and did not compress itself into an inward articulate voice
11352: pronouncing the once “affable archangel” a poor creature.
11353: 
11354: There had been this apparent quiet for half an hour, and Dorothea had
11355: not looked away from her own table, when she heard the loud bang of a
11356: book on the floor, and turning quickly saw Mr. Casaubon on the library
11357: steps clinging forward as if he were in some bodily distress. She
11358: started up and bounded towards him in an instant: he was evidently in
11359: great straits for breath. Jumping on a stool she got close to his elbow
11360: and said with her whole soul melted into tender alarm—
11361: 
11362: “Can you lean on me, dear?”
11363: 
11364: He was still for two or three minutes, which seemed endless to her,
11365: unable to speak or move, gasping for breath. When at last he descended
11366: the three steps and fell backward in the large chair which Dorothea had
11367: drawn close to the foot of the ladder, he no longer gasped but seemed
11368: helpless and about to faint. Dorothea rang the bell violently, and
11369: presently Mr. Casaubon was helped to the couch: he did not faint, and
11370: was gradually reviving, when Sir James Chettam came in, having been met
11371: in the hall with the news that Mr. Casaubon had “had a fit in the
11372: library.”
11373: 
11374: “Good God! this is just what might have been expected,” was his
11375: immediate thought. If his prophetic soul had been urged to
11376: particularize, it seemed to him that “fits” would have been the
11377: definite expression alighted upon. He asked his informant, the butler,
11378: whether the doctor had been sent for. The butler never knew his master
11379: to want the doctor before; but would it not be right to send for a
11380: physician?
11381: 
11382: When Sir James entered the library, however, Mr. Casaubon could make
11383: some signs of his usual politeness, and Dorothea, who in the reaction
11384: from her first terror had been kneeling and sobbing by his side now
11385: rose and herself proposed that some one should ride off for a medical
11386: man.
11387: 
11388: “I recommend you to send for Lydgate,” said Sir James. “My mother has
11389: called him in, and she has found him uncommonly clever. She has had a
11390: poor opinion of the physicians since my father’s death.”
11391: 
11392: Dorothea appealed to her husband, and he made a silent sign of
11393: approval. So Mr. Lydgate was sent for and he came wonderfully soon, for
11394: the messenger, who was Sir James Chettam’s man and knew Mr. Lydgate,
11395: met him leading his horse along the Lowick road and giving his arm to
11396: Miss Vincy.
11397: 
11398: Celia, in the drawing-room, had known nothing of the trouble till Sir
11399: James told her of it. After Dorothea’s account, he no longer considered
11400: the illness a fit, but still something “of that nature.”
11401: 
11402: “Poor dear Dodo—how dreadful!” said Celia, feeling as much grieved as
11403: her own perfect happiness would allow. Her little hands were clasped,
11404: and enclosed by Sir James’s as a bud is enfolded by a liberal calyx.
11405: “It is very shocking that Mr. Casaubon should be ill; but I never did
11406: like him. And I think he is not half fond enough of Dorothea; and he
11407: ought to be, for I am sure no one else would have had him—do you think
11408: they would?”
11409: 
11410: “I always thought it a horrible sacrifice of your sister,” said Sir
11411: James.
11412: 
11413: “Yes. But poor Dodo never did do what other people do, and I think she
11414: never will.”
11415: 
11416: “She is a noble creature,” said the loyal-hearted Sir James. He had
11417: just had a fresh impression of this kind, as he had seen Dorothea
11418: stretching her tender arm under her husband’s neck and looking at him
11419: with unspeakable sorrow. He did not know how much penitence there was
11420: in the sorrow.
11421: 
11422: “Yes,” said Celia, thinking it was very well for Sir James to say so,
11423: but _he_ would not have been comfortable with Dodo. “Shall I go to her?
11424: Could I help her, do you think?”
11425: 
11426: “I think it would be well for you just to go and see her before Lydgate
11427: comes,” said Sir James, magnanimously. “Only don’t stay long.”
11428: 
11429: While Celia was gone he walked up and down remembering what he had
11430: originally felt about Dorothea’s engagement, and feeling a revival of
11431: his disgust at Mr. Brooke’s indifference. If Cadwallader—if every one
11432: else had regarded the affair as he, Sir James, had done, the marriage
11433: might have been hindered. It was wicked to let a young girl blindly
11434: decide her fate in that way, without any effort to save her. Sir James
11435: had long ceased to have any regrets on his own account: his heart was
11436: satisfied with his engagement to Celia. But he had a chivalrous nature
11437: (was not the disinterested service of woman among the ideal glories of
11438: old chivalry?): his disregarded love had not turned to bitterness; its
11439: death had made sweet odors—floating memories that clung with a
11440: consecrating effect to Dorothea. He could remain her brotherly friend,
11441: interpreting her actions with generous trustfulness.
11442: 
11443: 
11444: 
11445: 
11446: CHAPTER XXX.
11447: 
11448: Qui veut délasser hors de propos, lasse.—PASCAL.
11449: 
11450: 
11451: Mr. Casaubon had no second attack of equal severity with the first, and
11452: in a few days began to recover his usual condition. But Lydgate seemed
11453: to think the case worth a great deal of attention. He not only used his
11454: stethoscope (which had not become a matter of course in practice at
11455: that time), but sat quietly by his patient and watched him. To Mr.
11456: Casaubon’s questions about himself, he replied that the source of the
11457: illness was the common error of intellectual men—a too eager and
11458: monotonous application: the remedy was, to be satisfied with moderate
11459: work, and to seek variety of relaxation. Mr. Brooke, who sat by on one
11460: occasion, suggested that Mr. Casaubon should go fishing, as Cadwallader
11461: did, and have a turning-room, make toys, table-legs, and that kind of
11462: thing.
11463: 
11464: “In short, you recommend me to anticipate the arrival of my second
11465: childhood,” said poor Mr. Casaubon, with some bitterness. “These
11466: things,” he added, looking at Lydgate, “would be to me such relaxation
11467: as tow-picking is to prisoners in a house of correction.”
11468: 
11469: “I confess,” said Lydgate, smiling, “amusement is rather an
11470: unsatisfactory prescription. It is something like telling people to
11471: keep up their spirits. Perhaps I had better say, that you must submit
11472: to be mildly bored rather than to go on working.”
11473: 
11474: “Yes, yes,” said Mr. Brooke. “Get Dorothea to play backgammon with you
11475: in the evenings. And shuttlecock, now—I don’t know a finer game than
11476: shuttlecock for the daytime. I remember it all the fashion. To be sure,
11477: your eyes might not stand that, Casaubon. But you must unbend, you
11478: know. Why, you might take to some light study: conchology, now: I
11479: always think that must be a light study. Or get Dorothea to read you
11480: light things, Smollett—‘Roderick Random,’ ‘Humphrey Clinker:’ they are
11481: a little broad, but she may read anything now she’s married, you know.
11482: I remember they made me laugh uncommonly—there’s a droll bit about a
11483: postilion’s breeches. We have no such humor now. I have gone through
11484: all these things, but they might be rather new to you.”
11485: 
11486: “As new as eating thistles,” would have been an answer to represent Mr.
11487: Casaubon’s feelings. But he only bowed resignedly, with due respect to
11488: his wife’s uncle, and observed that doubtless the works he mentioned
11489: had “served as a resource to a certain order of minds.”
11490: 
11491: “You see,” said the able magistrate to Lydgate, when they were outside
11492: the door, “Casaubon has been a little narrow: it leaves him rather at a
11493: loss when you forbid him his particular work, which I believe is
11494: something very deep indeed—in the line of research, you know. I would
11495: never give way to that; I was always versatile. But a clergyman is tied
11496: a little tight. If they would make him a bishop, now!—he did a very
11497: good pamphlet for Peel. He would have more movement then, more show; he
11498: might get a little flesh. But I recommend you to talk to Mrs. Casaubon.
11499: She is clever enough for anything, is my niece. Tell her, her husband
11500: wants liveliness, diversion: put her on amusing tactics.”
11501: 
11502: Without Mr. Brooke’s advice, Lydgate had determined on speaking to
11503: Dorothea. She had not been present while her uncle was throwing out his
11504: pleasant suggestions as to the mode in which life at Lowick might be
11505: enlivened, but she was usually by her husband’s side, and the
11506: unaffected signs of intense anxiety in her face and voice about
11507: whatever touched his mind or health, made a drama which Lydgate was
11508: inclined to watch. He said to himself that he was only doing right in
11509: telling her the truth about her husband’s probable future, but he
11510: certainly thought also that it would be interesting to talk
11511: confidentially with her. A medical man likes to make psychological
11512: observations, and sometimes in the pursuit of such studies is too
11513: easily tempted into momentous prophecy which life and death easily set
11514: at nought. Lydgate had often been satirical on this gratuitous
11515: prediction, and he meant now to be guarded.
11516: 
11517: He asked for Mrs. Casaubon, but being told that she was out walking, he
11518: was going away, when Dorothea and Celia appeared, both glowing from
11519: their struggle with the March wind. When Lydgate begged to speak with
11520: her alone, Dorothea opened the library door which happened to be the
11521: nearest, thinking of nothing at the moment but what he might have to
11522: say about Mr. Casaubon. It was the first time she had entered this room
11523: since her husband had been taken ill, and the servant had chosen not to
11524: open the shutters. But there was light enough to read by from the
11525: narrow upper panes of the windows.
11526: 
11527: “You will not mind this sombre light,” said Dorothea, standing in the
11528: middle of the room. “Since you forbade books, the library has been out
11529: of the question. But Mr. Casaubon will soon be here again, I hope. Is
11530: he not making progress?”
11531: 
11532: “Yes, much more rapid progress than I at first expected. Indeed, he is
11533: already nearly in his usual state of health.”
11534: 
11535: “You do not fear that the illness will return?” said Dorothea, whose
11536: quick ear had detected some significance in Lydgate’s tone.
11537: 
11538: “Such cases are peculiarly difficult to pronounce upon,” said Lydgate.
11539: “The only point on which I can be confident is that it will be
11540: desirable to be very watchful on Mr. Casaubon’s account, lest he should
11541: in any way strain his nervous power.”
11542: 
11543: “I beseech you to speak quite plainly,” said Dorothea, in an imploring
11544: tone. “I cannot bear to think that there might be something which I did
11545: not know, and which, if I had known it, would have made me act
11546: differently.” The words came out like a cry: it was evident that they
11547: were the voice of some mental experience which lay not very far off.
11548: 
11549: “Sit down,” she added, placing herself on the nearest chair, and
11550: throwing off her bonnet and gloves, with an instinctive discarding of
11551: formality where a great question of destiny was concerned.
11552: 
11553: “What you say now justifies my own view,” said Lydgate. “I think it is
11554: one’s function as a medical man to hinder regrets of that sort as far
11555: as possible. But I beg you to observe that Mr. Casaubon’s case is
11556: precisely of the kind in which the issue is most difficult to pronounce
11557: upon. He may possibly live for fifteen years or more, without much
11558: worse health than he has had hitherto.”
11559: 
11560: Dorothea had turned very pale, and when Lydgate paused she said in a
11561: low voice, “You mean if we are very careful.”
11562: 
11563: “Yes—careful against mental agitation of all kinds, and against
11564: excessive application.”
11565: 
11566: “He would be miserable, if he had to give up his work,” said Dorothea,
11567: with a quick prevision of that wretchedness.
11568: 
11569: “I am aware of that. The only course is to try by all means, direct and
11570: indirect, to moderate and vary his occupations. With a happy
11571: concurrence of circumstances, there is, as I said, no immediate danger
11572: from that affection of the heart, which I believe to have been the
11573: cause of his late attack. On the other hand, it is possible that the
11574: disease may develop itself more rapidly: it is one of those cases in
11575: which death is sometimes sudden. Nothing should be neglected which
11576: might be affected by such an issue.”
11577: 
11578: There was silence for a few moments, while Dorothea sat as if she had
11579: been turned to marble, though the life within her was so intense that
11580: her mind had never before swept in brief time over an equal range of
11581: scenes and motives.
11582: 
11583: “Help me, pray,” she said, at last, in the same low voice as before.
11584: “Tell me what I can do.”
11585: 
11586: “What do you think of foreign travel? You have been lately in Rome, I
11587: think.”
11588: 
11589: The memories which made this resource utterly hopeless were a new
11590: current that shook Dorothea out of her pallid immobility.
11591: 
11592: “Oh, that would not do—that would be worse than anything,” she said
11593: with a more childlike despondency, while the tears rolled down.
11594: “Nothing will be of any use that he does not enjoy.”
11595: 
11596: “I wish that I could have spared you this pain,” said Lydgate, deeply
11597: touched, yet wondering about her marriage. Women just like Dorothea had
11598: not entered into his traditions.
11599: 
11600: “It was right of you to tell me. I thank you for telling me the truth.”
11601: 
11602: “I wish you to understand that I shall not say anything to enlighten
11603: Mr. Casaubon himself. I think it desirable for him to know nothing more
11604: than that he must not overwork himself, and must observe certain rules.
11605: Anxiety of any kind would be precisely the most unfavorable condition
11606: for him.”
11607: 
11608: Lydgate rose, and Dorothea mechanically rose at the same time,
11609: unclasping her cloak and throwing it off as if it stifled her. He was
11610: bowing and quitting her, when an impulse which if she had been alone
11611: would have turned into a prayer, made her say with a sob in her voice—
11612: 
11613: “Oh, you are a wise man, are you not? You know all about life and
11614: death. Advise me. Think what I can do. He has been laboring all his
11615: life and looking forward. He minds about nothing else.— And I mind
11616: about nothing else—”
11617: 
11618: For years after Lydgate remembered the impression produced in him by
11619: this involuntary appeal—this cry from soul to soul, without other
11620: consciousness than their moving with kindred natures in the same
11621: embroiled medium, the same troublous fitfully illuminated life. But
11622: what could he say now except that he should see Mr. Casaubon again
11623: to-morrow?
11624: 
11625: When he was gone, Dorothea’s tears gushed forth, and relieved her
11626: stifling oppression. Then she dried her eyes, reminded that her
11627: distress must not be betrayed to her husband; and looked round the room
11628: thinking that she must order the servant to attend to it as usual,
11629: since Mr. Casaubon might now at any moment wish to enter. On his
11630: writing-table there were letters which had lain untouched since the
11631: morning when he was taken ill, and among them, as Dorothea well
11632: remembered, there were young Ladislaw’s letters, the one addressed to
11633: her still unopened. The associations of these letters had been made the
11634: more painful by that sudden attack of illness which she felt that the
11635: agitation caused by her anger might have helped to bring on: it would
11636: be time enough to read them when they were again thrust upon her, and
11637: she had had no inclination to fetch them from the library. But now it
11638: occurred to her that they should be put out of her husband’s sight:
11639: whatever might have been the sources of his annoyance about them, he
11640: must, if possible, not be annoyed again; and she ran her eyes first
11641: over the letter addressed to him to assure herself whether or not it
11642: would be necessary to write in order to hinder the offensive visit.
11643: 
11644: Will wrote from Rome, and began by saying that his obligations to Mr.
11645: Casaubon were too deep for all thanks not to seem impertinent. It was
11646: plain that if he were not grateful, he must be the poorest-spirited
11647: rascal who had ever found a generous friend. To expand in wordy thanks
11648: would be like saying, “I am honest.” But Will had come to perceive that
11649: his defects—defects which Mr. Casaubon had himself often pointed
11650: to—needed for their correction that more strenuous position which his
11651: relative’s generosity had hitherto prevented from being inevitable. He
11652: trusted that he should make the best return, if return were possible,
11653: by showing the effectiveness of the education for which he was
11654: indebted, and by ceasing in future to need any diversion towards
11655: himself of funds on which others might have a better claim. He was
11656: coming to England, to try his fortune, as many other young men were
11657: obliged to do whose only capital was in their brains. His friend
11658: Naumann had desired him to take charge of the “Dispute”—the picture
11659: painted for Mr. Casaubon, with whose permission, and Mrs. Casaubon’s,
11660: Will would convey it to Lowick in person. A letter addressed to the
11661: Poste Restante in Paris within the fortnight would hinder him, if
11662: necessary, from arriving at an inconvenient moment. He enclosed a
11663: letter to Mrs. Casaubon in which he continued a discussion about art,
11664: begun with her in Rome.
11665: 
11666: Opening her own letter Dorothea saw that it was a lively continuation
11667: of his remonstrance with her fanatical sympathy and her want of sturdy
11668: neutral delight in things as they were—an outpouring of his young
11669: vivacity which it was impossible to read just now. She had immediately
11670: to consider what was to be done about the other letter: there was still
11671: time perhaps to prevent Will from coming to Lowick. Dorothea ended by
11672: giving the letter to her uncle, who was still in the house, and begging
11673: him to let Will know that Mr. Casaubon had been ill, and that his
11674: health would not allow the reception of any visitors.
11675: 
11676: No one more ready than Mr. Brooke to write a letter: his only
11677: difficulty was to write a short one, and his ideas in this case
11678: expanded over the three large pages and the inward foldings. He had
11679: simply said to Dorothea—
11680: 
11681: “To be sure, I will write, my dear. He’s a very clever young
11682: fellow—this young Ladislaw—I dare say will be a rising young man. It’s
11683: a good letter—marks his sense of things, you know. However, I will tell
11684: him about Casaubon.”
11685: 
11686: But the end of Mr. Brooke’s pen was a thinking organ, evolving
11687: sentences, especially of a benevolent kind, before the rest of his mind
11688: could well overtake them. It expressed regrets and proposed remedies,
11689: which, when Mr. Brooke read them, seemed felicitously
11690: worded—surprisingly the right thing, and determined a sequel which he
11691: had never before thought of. In this case, his pen found it such a pity
11692: young Ladislaw should not have come into the neighborhood just at that
11693: time, in order that Mr. Brooke might make his acquaintance more fully,
11694: and that they might go over the long-neglected Italian drawings
11695: together—it also felt such an interest in a young man who was starting
11696: in life with a stock of ideas—that by the end of the second page it had
11697: persuaded Mr. Brooke to invite young Ladislaw, since he could not be
11698: received at Lowick, to come to Tipton Grange. Why not? They could find
11699: a great many things to do together, and this was a period of peculiar
11700: growth—the political horizon was expanding, and—in short, Mr. Brooke’s
11701: pen went off into a little speech which it had lately reported for that
11702: imperfectly edited organ the “Middlemarch Pioneer.” While Mr. Brooke
11703: was sealing this letter, he felt elated with an influx of dim
11704: projects:—a young man capable of putting ideas into form, the “Pioneer”
11705: purchased to clear the pathway for a new candidate, documents
11706: utilized—who knew what might come of it all? Since Celia was going to
11707: marry immediately, it would be very pleasant to have a young fellow at
11708: table with him, at least for a time.
11709: 
11710: But he went away without telling Dorothea what he had put into the
11711: letter, for she was engaged with her husband, and—in fact, these things
11712: were of no importance to her.
11713: 
11714: 
11715: 
11716: 
11717: CHAPTER XXXI.
11718: 
11719: How will you know the pitch of that great bell
11720: Too large for you to stir? Let but a flute
11721: Play ’neath the fine-mixed metal: listen close
11722: Till the right note flows forth, a silvery rill:
11723: Then shall the huge bell tremble—then the mass
11724: With myriad waves concurrent shall respond
11725: In low soft unison.
11726: 
11727: 
11728: Lydgate that evening spoke to Miss Vincy of Mrs. Casaubon, and laid
11729: some emphasis on the strong feeling she appeared to have for that
11730: formal studious man thirty years older than herself.
11731: 
11732: “Of course she is devoted to her husband,” said Rosamond, implying a
11733: notion of necessary sequence which the scientific man regarded as the
11734: prettiest possible for a woman; but she was thinking at the same time
11735: that it was not so very melancholy to be mistress of Lowick Manor with
11736: a husband likely to die soon. “Do you think her very handsome?”
11737: 
11738: “She certainly is handsome, but I have not thought about it,” said
11739: Lydgate.
11740: 
11741: “I suppose it would be unprofessional,” said Rosamond, dimpling. “But
11742: how your practice is spreading! You were called in before to the
11743: Chettams, I think; and now, the Casaubons.”
11744: 
11745: “Yes,” said Lydgate, in a tone of compulsory admission. “But I don’t
11746: really like attending such people so well as the poor. The cases are
11747: more monotonous, and one has to go through more fuss and listen more
11748: deferentially to nonsense.”
11749: 
11750: “Not more than in Middlemarch,” said Rosamond. “And at least you go
11751: through wide corridors and have the scent of rose-leaves everywhere.”
11752: 
11753: “That is true, Mademoiselle de Montmorenci,” said Lydgate, just bending
11754: his head to the table and lifting with his fourth finger her delicate
11755: handkerchief which lay at the mouth of her reticule, as if to enjoy its
11756: scent, while he looked at her with a smile.
11757: 
11758: But this agreeable holiday freedom with which Lydgate hovered about the
11759: flower of Middlemarch, could not continue indefinitely. It was not more
11760: possible to find social isolation in that town than elsewhere, and two
11761: people persistently flirting could by no means escape from “the various
11762: entanglements, weights, blows, clashings, motions, by which things
11763: severally go on.” Whatever Miss Vincy did must be remarked, and she was
11764: perhaps the more conspicuous to admirers and critics because just now
11765: Mrs. Vincy, after some struggle, had gone with Fred to stay a little
11766: while at Stone Court, there being no other way of at once gratifying
11767: old Featherstone and keeping watch against Mary Garth, who appeared a
11768: less tolerable daughter-in-law in proportion as Fred’s illness
11769: disappeared.
11770: 
11771: Aunt Bulstrode, for example, came a little oftener into Lowick Gate to
11772: see Rosamond, now she was alone. For Mrs. Bulstrode had a true sisterly
11773: feeling for her brother; always thinking that he might have married
11774: better, but wishing well to the children. Now Mrs. Bulstrode had a
11775: long-standing intimacy with Mrs. Plymdale. They had nearly the same
11776: preferences in silks, patterns for underclothing, china-ware, and
11777: clergymen; they confided their little troubles of health and household
11778: management to each other, and various little points of superiority on
11779: Mrs. Bulstrode’s side, namely, more decided seriousness, more
11780: admiration for mind, and a house outside the town, sometimes served to
11781: give color to their conversation without dividing them—well-meaning
11782: women both, knowing very little of their own motives.
11783: 
11784: Mrs. Bulstrode, paying a morning visit to Mrs. Plymdale, happened to
11785: say that she could not stay longer, because she was going to see poor
11786: Rosamond.
11787: 
11788: “Why do you say ‘poor Rosamond’?” said Mrs. Plymdale, a round-eyed
11789: sharp little woman, like a tamed falcon.
11790: 
11791: “She is so pretty, and has been brought up in such thoughtlessness. The
11792: mother, you know, had always that levity about her, which makes me
11793: anxious for the children.”
11794: 
11795: “Well, Harriet, if I am to speak my mind,” said Mrs. Plymdale, with
11796: emphasis, “I must say, anybody would suppose you and Mr. Bulstrode
11797: would be delighted with what has happened, for you have done everything
11798: to put Mr. Lydgate forward.”
11799: 
11800: “Selina, what do you mean?” said Mrs. Bulstrode, in genuine surprise.
11801: 
11802: “Not but what I am truly thankful for Ned’s sake,” said Mrs. Plymdale.
11803: “He could certainly better afford to keep such a wife than some people
11804: can; but I should wish him to look elsewhere. Still a mother has
11805: anxieties, and some young men would take to a bad life in consequence.
11806: Besides, if I was obliged to speak, I should say I was not fond of
11807: strangers coming into a town.”
11808: 
11809: “I don’t know, Selina,” said Mrs. Bulstrode, with a little emphasis in
11810: her turn. “Mr. Bulstrode was a stranger here at one time. Abraham and
11811: Moses were strangers in the land, and we are told to entertain
11812: strangers. And especially,” she added, after a slight pause, “when they
11813: are unexceptionable.”
11814: 
11815: “I was not speaking in a religious sense, Harriet. I spoke as a
11816: mother.”
11817: 
11818: “Selina, I am sure you have never heard me say anything against a niece
11819: of mine marrying your son.”
11820: 
11821: “Oh, it is pride in Miss Vincy—I am sure it is nothing else,” said Mrs.
11822: Plymdale, who had never before given all her confidence to “Harriet” on
11823: this subject. “No young man in Middlemarch was good enough for her: I
11824: have heard her mother say as much. That is not a Christian spirit, I
11825: think. But now, from all I hear, she has found a man as proud as
11826: herself.”
11827: 
11828: “You don’t mean that there is anything between Rosamond and Mr.
11829: Lydgate?” said Mrs. Bulstrode, rather mortified at finding out her own
11830: ignorance.
11831: 
11832: “Is it possible you don’t know, Harriet?”
11833: 
11834: “Oh, I go about so little; and I am not fond of gossip; I really never
11835: hear any. You see so many people that I don’t see. Your circle is
11836: rather different from ours.”
11837: 
11838: “Well, but your own niece and Mr. Bulstrode’s great favorite—and yours
11839: too, I am sure, Harriet! I thought, at one time, you meant him for
11840: Kate, when she is a little older.”
11841: 
11842: “I don’t believe there can be anything serious at present,” said Mrs.
11843: Bulstrode. “My brother would certainly have told me.”
11844: 
11845: “Well, people have different ways, but I understand that nobody can see
11846: Miss Vincy and Mr. Lydgate together without taking them to be engaged.
11847: However, it is not my business. Shall I put up the pattern of mittens?”
11848: 
11849: After this Mrs. Bulstrode drove to her niece with a mind newly
11850: weighted. She was herself handsomely dressed, but she noticed with a
11851: little more regret than usual that Rosamond, who was just come in and
11852: met her in walking-dress, was almost as expensively equipped. Mrs.
11853: Bulstrode was a feminine smaller edition of her brother, and had none
11854: of her husband’s low-toned pallor. She had a good honest glance and
11855: used no circumlocution.
11856: 
11857: “You are alone, I see, my dear,” she said, as they entered the
11858: drawing-room together, looking round gravely. Rosamond felt sure that
11859: her aunt had something particular to say, and they sat down near each
11860: other. Nevertheless, the quilling inside Rosamond’s bonnet was so
11861: charming that it was impossible not to desire the same kind of thing
11862: for Kate, and Mrs. Bulstrode’s eyes, which were rather fine, rolled
11863: round that ample quilled circuit, while she spoke.
11864: 
11865: “I have just heard something about you that has surprised me very much,
11866: Rosamond.”
11867: 
11868: “What is that, aunt?” Rosamond’s eyes also were roaming over her aunt’s
11869: large embroidered collar.
11870: 
11871: “I can hardly believe it—that you should be engaged without my knowing
11872: it—without your father’s telling me.” Here Mrs. Bulstrode’s eyes
11873: finally rested on Rosamond’s, who blushed deeply, and said—
11874: 
11875: “I am not engaged, aunt.”
11876: 
11877: “How is it that every one says so, then—that it is the town’s talk?”
11878: 
11879: “The town’s talk is of very little consequence, I think,” said
11880: Rosamond, inwardly gratified.
11881: 
11882: “Oh, my dear, be more thoughtful; don’t despise your neighbors so.
11883: Remember you are turned twenty-two now, and you will have no fortune:
11884: your father, I am sure, will not be able to spare you anything. Mr.
11885: Lydgate is very intellectual and clever; I know there is an attraction
11886: in that. I like talking to such men myself; and your uncle finds him
11887: very useful. But the profession is a poor one here. To be sure, this
11888: life is not everything; but it is seldom a medical man has true
11889: religious views—there is too much pride of intellect. And you are not
11890: fit to marry a poor man.
11891: 
11892: “Mr. Lydgate is not a poor man, aunt. He has very high connections.”
11893: 
11894: “He told me himself he was poor.”
11895: 
11896: “That is because he is used to people who have a high style of living.”
11897: 
11898: “My dear Rosamond, _you_ must not think of living in high style.”
11899: 
11900: Rosamond looked down and played with her reticule. She was not a fiery
11901: young lady and had no sharp answers, but she meant to live as she
11902: pleased.
11903: 
11904: “Then it is really true?” said Mrs. Bulstrode, looking very earnestly
11905: at her niece. “You are thinking of Mr. Lydgate—there is some
11906: understanding between you, though your father doesn’t know. Be open, my
11907: dear Rosamond: Mr. Lydgate has really made you an offer?”
11908: 
11909: Poor Rosamond’s feelings were very unpleasant. She had been quite easy
11910: as to Lydgate’s feeling and intention, but now when her aunt put this
11911: question she did not like being unable to say Yes. Her pride was hurt,
11912: but her habitual control of manner helped her.
11913: 
11914: “Pray excuse me, aunt. I would rather not speak on the subject.”
11915: 
11916: “You would not give your heart to a man without a decided prospect, I
11917: trust, my dear. And think of the two excellent offers I know of that
11918: you have refused!—and one still within your reach, if you will not
11919: throw it away. I knew a very great beauty who married badly at last, by
11920: doing so. Mr. Ned Plymdale is a nice young man—some might think
11921: good-looking; and an only son; and a large business of that kind is
11922: better than a profession. Not that marrying is everything. I would have
11923: you seek first the kingdom of God. But a girl should keep her heart
11924: within her own power.”
11925: 
11926: “I should never give it to Mr. Ned Plymdale, if it were. I have already
11927: refused him. If I loved, I should love at once and without change,”
11928: said Rosamond, with a great sense of being a romantic heroine, and
11929: playing the part prettily.
11930: 
11931: “I see how it is, my dear,” said Mrs. Bulstrode, in a melancholy voice,
11932: rising to go. “You have allowed your affections to be engaged without
11933: return.”
11934: 
11935: “No, indeed, aunt,” said Rosamond, with emphasis.
11936: 
11937: “Then you are quite confident that Mr. Lydgate has a serious attachment
11938: to you?”
11939: 
11940: Rosamond’s cheeks by this time were persistently burning, and she felt
11941: much mortification. She chose to be silent, and her aunt went away all
11942: the more convinced.
11943: 
11944: Mr. Bulstrode in things worldly and indifferent was disposed to do what
11945: his wife bade him, and she now, without telling her reasons, desired
11946: him on the next opportunity to find out in conversation with Mr.
11947: Lydgate whether he had any intention of marrying soon. The result was a
11948: decided negative. Mr. Bulstrode, on being cross-questioned, showed that
11949: Lydgate had spoken as no man would who had any attachment that could
11950: issue in matrimony. Mrs. Bulstrode now felt that she had a serious duty
11951: before her, and she soon managed to arrange a _tête-à-tête_ with
11952: Lydgate, in which she passed from inquiries about Fred Vincy’s health,
11953: and expressions of her sincere anxiety for her brother’s large family,
11954: to general remarks on the dangers which lay before young people with
11955: regard to their settlement in life. Young men were often wild and
11956: disappointing, making little return for the money spent on them, and a
11957: girl was exposed to many circumstances which might interfere with her
11958: prospects.
11959: 
11960: “Especially when she has great attractions, and her parents see much
11961: company,” said Mrs. Bulstrode. “Gentlemen pay her attention, and
11962: engross her all to themselves, for the mere pleasure of the moment, and
11963: that drives off others. I think it is a heavy responsibility, Mr.
11964: Lydgate, to interfere with the prospects of any girl.” Here Mrs.
11965: Bulstrode fixed her eyes on him, with an unmistakable purpose of
11966: warning, if not of rebuke.
11967: 
11968: “Clearly,” said Lydgate, looking at her—perhaps even staring a little
11969: in return. “On the other hand, a man must be a great coxcomb to go
11970: about with a notion that he must not pay attention to a young lady lest
11971: she should fall in love with him, or lest others should think she
11972: must.”
11973: 
11974: “Oh, Mr. Lydgate, you know well what your advantages are. You know that
11975: our young men here cannot cope with you. Where you frequent a house it
11976: may militate very much against a girl’s making a desirable settlement
11977: in life, and prevent her from accepting offers even if they are made.”
11978: 
11979: Lydgate was less flattered by his advantage over the Middlemarch
11980: Orlandos than he was annoyed by the perception of Mrs. Bulstrode’s
11981: meaning. She felt that she had spoken as impressively as it was
11982: necessary to do, and that in using the superior word “militate” she had
11983: thrown a noble drapery over a mass of particulars which were still
11984: evident enough.
11985: 
11986: Lydgate was fuming a little, pushed his hair back with one hand, felt
11987: curiously in his waistcoat-pocket with the other, and then stooped to
11988: beckon the tiny black spaniel, which had the insight to decline his
11989: hollow caresses. It would not have been decent to go away, because he
11990: had been dining with other guests, and had just taken tea. But Mrs.
11991: Bulstrode, having no doubt that she had been understood, turned the
11992: conversation.
11993: 
11994: Solomon’s Proverbs, I think, have omitted to say, that as the sore
11995: palate findeth grit, so an uneasy consciousness heareth innuendoes. The
11996: next day Mr. Farebrother, parting from Lydgate in the street, supposed
11997: that they should meet at Vincy’s in the evening. Lydgate answered
11998: curtly, no—he had work to do—he must give up going out in the evening.
11999: 
12000: “What! you are going to get lashed to the mast, eh, and are stopping
12001: your ears?” said the Vicar. “Well, if you don’t mean to be won by the
12002: sirens, you are right to take precautions in time.”
12003: 
12004: A few days before, Lydgate would have taken no notice of these words as
12005: anything more than the Vicar’s usual way of putting things. They seemed
12006: now to convey an innuendo which confirmed the impression that he had
12007: been making a fool of himself and behaving so as to be misunderstood:
12008: not, he believed, by Rosamond herself; she, he felt sure, took
12009: everything as lightly as he intended it. She had an exquisite tact and
12010: insight in relation to all points of manners; but the people she lived
12011: among were blunderers and busybodies. However, the mistake should go no
12012: farther. He resolved—and kept his resolution—that he would not go to
12013: Mr. Vincy’s except on business.
12014: 
12015: Rosamond became very unhappy. The uneasiness first stirred by her
12016: aunt’s questions grew and grew till at the end of ten days that she had
12017: not seen Lydgate, it grew into terror at the blank that might possibly
12018: come—into foreboding of that ready, fatal sponge which so cheaply wipes
12019: out the hopes of mortals. The world would have a new dreariness for
12020: her, as a wilderness that a magician’s spells had turned for a little
12021: while into a garden. She felt that she was beginning to know the pang
12022: of disappointed love, and that no other man could be the occasion of
12023: such delightful aerial building as she had been enjoying for the last
12024: six months. Poor Rosamond lost her appetite and felt as forlorn as
12025: Ariadne—as a charming stage Ariadne left behind with all her boxes full
12026: of costumes and no hope of a coach.
12027: 
12028: There are many wonderful mixtures in the world which are all alike
12029: called love, and claim the privileges of a sublime rage which is an
12030: apology for everything (in literature and the drama). Happily Rosamond
12031: did not think of committing any desperate act: she plaited her fair
12032: hair as beautifully as usual, and kept herself proudly calm. Her most
12033: cheerful supposition was that her aunt Bulstrode had interfered in some
12034: way to hinder Lydgate’s visits: everything was better than a
12035: spontaneous indifference in him. Any one who imagines ten days too
12036: short a time—not for falling into leanness, lightness, or other
12037: measurable effects of passion, but—for the whole spiritual circuit of
12038: alarmed conjecture and disappointment, is ignorant of what can go on in
12039: the elegant leisure of a young lady’s mind.
12040: 
12041: On the eleventh day, however, Lydgate when leaving Stone Court was
12042: requested by Mrs. Vincy to let her husband know that there was a marked
12043: change in Mr. Featherstone’s health, and that she wished him to come to
12044: Stone Court on that day. Now Lydgate might have called at the
12045: warehouse, or might have written a message on a leaf of his pocket-book
12046: and left it at the door. Yet these simple devices apparently did not
12047: occur to him, from which we may conclude that he had no strong
12048: objection to calling at the house at an hour when Mr. Vincy was not at
12049: home, and leaving the message with Miss Vincy. A man may, from various
12050: motives, decline to give his company, but perhaps not even a sage would
12051: be gratified that nobody missed him. It would be a graceful, easy way
12052: of piecing on the new habits to the old, to have a few playful words
12053: with Rosamond about his resistance to dissipation, and his firm resolve
12054: to take long fasts even from sweet sounds. It must be confessed, also,
12055: that momentary speculations as to all the possible grounds for Mrs.
12056: Bulstrode’s hints had managed to get woven like slight clinging hairs
12057: into the more substantial web of his thoughts.
12058: 
12059: Miss Vincy was alone, and blushed so deeply when Lydgate came in that
12060: he felt a corresponding embarrassment, and instead of any playfulness,
12061: he began at once to speak of his reason for calling, and to beg her,
12062: almost formally, to deliver the message to her father. Rosamond, who at
12063: the first moment felt as if her happiness were returning, was keenly
12064: hurt by Lydgate’s manner; her blush had departed, and she assented
12065: coldly, without adding an unnecessary word, some trivial chain-work
12066: which she had in her hands enabling her to avoid looking at Lydgate
12067: higher than his chin. In all failures, the beginning is certainly the
12068: half of the whole. After sitting two long moments while he moved his
12069: whip and could say nothing, Lydgate rose to go, and Rosamond, made
12070: nervous by her struggle between mortification and the wish not to
12071: betray it, dropped her chain as if startled, and rose too,
12072: mechanically. Lydgate instantaneously stooped to pick up the chain.
12073: When he rose he was very near to a lovely little face set on a fair
12074: long neck which he had been used to see turning about under the most
12075: perfect management of self-contented grace. But as he raised his eyes
12076: now he saw a certain helpless quivering which touched him quite newly,
12077: and made him look at Rosamond with a questioning flash. At this moment
12078: she was as natural as she had ever been when she was five years old:
12079: she felt that her tears had risen, and it was no use to try to do
12080: anything else than let them stay like water on a blue flower or let
12081: them fall over her cheeks, even as they would.
12082: 
12083: That moment of naturalness was the crystallizing feather-touch: it
12084: shook flirtation into love. Remember that the ambitious man who was
12085: looking at those Forget-me-nots under the water was very warm-hearted
12086: and rash. He did not know where the chain went; an idea had thrilled
12087: through the recesses within him which had a miraculous effect in
12088: raising the power of passionate love lying buried there in no sealed
12089: sepulchre, but under the lightest, easily pierced mould. His words were
12090: quite abrupt and awkward; but the tone made them sound like an ardent,
12091: appealing avowal.
12092: 
12093: “What is the matter? you are distressed. Tell me, pray.”
12094: 
12095: Rosamond had never been spoken to in such tones before. I am not sure
12096: that she knew what the words were: but she looked at Lydgate and the
12097: tears fell over her cheeks. There could have been no more complete
12098: answer than that silence, and Lydgate, forgetting everything else,
12099: completely mastered by the outrush of tenderness at the sudden belief
12100: that this sweet young creature depended on him for her joy, actually
12101: put his arms round her, folding her gently and protectingly—he was used
12102: to being gentle with the weak and suffering—and kissed each of the two
12103: large tears. This was a strange way of arriving at an understanding,
12104: but it was a short way. Rosamond was not angry, but she moved backward
12105: a little in timid happiness, and Lydgate could now sit near her and
12106: speak less incompletely. Rosamond had to make her little confession,
12107: and he poured out words of gratitude and tenderness with impulsive
12108: lavishment. In half an hour he left the house an engaged man, whose
12109: soul was not his own, but the woman’s to whom he had bound himself.
12110: 
12111: He came again in the evening to speak with Mr. Vincy, who, just
12112: returned from Stone Court, was feeling sure that it would not be long
12113: before he heard of Mr. Featherstone’s demise. The felicitous word
12114: “demise,” which had seasonably occurred to him, had raised his spirits
12115: even above their usual evening pitch. The right word is always a power,
12116: and communicates its definiteness to our action. Considered as a
12117: demise, old Featherstone’s death assumed a merely legal aspect, so that
12118: Mr. Vincy could tap his snuff-box over it and be jovial, without even
12119: an intermittent affectation of solemnity; and Mr. Vincy hated both
12120: solemnity and affectation. Who was ever awe struck about a testator, or
12121: sang a hymn on the title to real property? Mr. Vincy was inclined to
12122: take a jovial view of all things that evening: he even observed to
12123: Lydgate that Fred had got the family constitution after all, and would
12124: soon be as fine a fellow as ever again; and when his approbation of
12125: Rosamond’s engagement was asked for, he gave it with astonishing
12126: facility, passing at once to general remarks on the desirableness of
12127: matrimony for young men and maidens, and apparently deducing from the
12128: whole the appropriateness of a little more punch.
12129: 
12130: 
12131: 
12132: 
12133: CHAPTER XXXII.
12134: 
12135: They’ll take suggestion as a cat laps milk.
12136: —SHAKESPEARE: _Tempest_.
12137: 
12138: 
12139: The triumphant confidence of the Mayor founded on Mr. Featherstone’s
12140: insistent demand that Fred and his mother should not leave him, was a
12141: feeble emotion compared with all that was agitating the breasts of the
12142: old man’s blood-relations, who naturally manifested more their sense of
12143: the family tie and were more visibly numerous now that he had become
12144: bedridden. Naturally: for when “poor Peter” had occupied his arm-chair
12145: in the wainscoted parlor, no assiduous beetles for whom the cook
12146: prepares boiling water could have been less welcome on a hearth which
12147: they had reasons for preferring, than those persons whose Featherstone
12148: blood was ill-nourished, not from penuriousness on their part, but from
12149: poverty. Brother Solomon and Sister Jane were rich, and the family
12150: candor and total abstinence from false politeness with which they were
12151: always received seemed to them no argument that their brother in the
12152: solemn act of making his will would overlook the superior claims of
12153: wealth. Themselves at least he had never been unnatural enough to
12154: banish from his house, and it seemed hardly eccentric that he should
12155: have kept away Brother Jonah, Sister Martha, and the rest, who had no
12156: shadow of such claims. They knew Peter’s maxim, that money was a good
12157: egg, and should be laid in a warm nest.
12158: 
12159: But Brother Jonah, Sister Martha, and all the needy exiles, held a
12160: different point of view. Probabilities are as various as the faces to
12161: be seen at will in fretwork or paper-hangings: every form is there,
12162: from Jupiter to Judy, if you only look with creative inclination. To
12163: the poorer and least favored it seemed likely that since Peter had done
12164: nothing for them in his life, he would remember them at the last. Jonah
12165: argued that men liked to make a surprise of their wills, while Martha
12166: said that nobody need be surprised if he left the best part of his
12167: money to those who least expected it. Also it was not to be thought but
12168: that an own brother “lying there” with dropsy in his legs must come to
12169: feel that blood was thicker than water, and if he didn’t alter his
12170: will, he might have money by him. At any rate some blood-relations
12171: should be on the premises and on the watch against those who were
12172: hardly relations at all. Such things had been known as forged wills and
12173: disputed wills, which seemed to have the golden-hazy advantage of
12174: somehow enabling non-legatees to live out of them. Again, those who
12175: were no blood-relations might be caught making away with things—and
12176: poor Peter “lying there” helpless! Somebody should be on the watch. But
12177: in this conclusion they were at one with Solomon and Jane; also, some
12178: nephews, nieces, and cousins, arguing with still greater subtilty as to
12179: what might be done by a man able to “will away” his property and give
12180: himself large treats of oddity, felt in a handsome sort of way that
12181: there was a family interest to be attended to, and thought of Stone
12182: Court as a place which it would be nothing but right for them to visit.
12183: Sister Martha, otherwise Mrs. Cranch, living with some wheeziness in
12184: the Chalky Flats, could not undertake the journey; but her son, as
12185: being poor Peter’s own nephew, could represent her advantageously, and
12186: watch lest his uncle Jonah should make an unfair use of the improbable
12187: things which seemed likely to happen. In fact there was a general sense
12188: running in the Featherstone blood that everybody must watch everybody
12189: else, and that it would be well for everybody else to reflect that the
12190: Almighty was watching him.
12191: 
12192: Thus Stone Court continually saw one or other blood-relation alighting
12193: or departing, and Mary Garth had the unpleasant task of carrying their
12194: messages to Mr. Featherstone, who would see none of them, and sent her
12195: down with the still more unpleasant task of telling them so. As manager
12196: of the household she felt bound to ask them in good provincial fashion
12197: to stay and eat; but she chose to consult Mrs. Vincy on the point of
12198: extra down-stairs consumption now that Mr. Featherstone was laid up.
12199: 
12200: “Oh, my dear, you must do things handsomely where there’s last illness
12201: and a property. God knows, I don’t grudge them every ham in the
12202: house—only, save the best for the funeral. Have some stuffed veal
12203: always, and a fine cheese in cut. You must expect to keep open house in
12204: these last illnesses,” said liberal Mrs. Vincy, once more of cheerful
12205: note and bright plumage.
12206: 
12207: But some of the visitors alighted and did not depart after the handsome
12208: treating to veal and ham. Brother Jonah, for example (there are such
12209: unpleasant people in most families; perhaps even in the highest
12210: aristocracy there are Brobdingnag specimens, gigantically in debt and
12211: bloated at greater expense)—Brother Jonah, I say, having come down in
12212: the world, was mainly supported by a calling which he was modest enough
12213: not to boast of, though it was much better than swindling either on
12214: exchange or turf, but which did not require his presence at Brassing so
12215: long as he had a good corner to sit in and a supply of food. He chose
12216: the kitchen-corner, partly because he liked it best, and partly because
12217: he did not want to sit with Solomon, concerning whom he had a strong
12218: brotherly opinion. Seated in a famous arm-chair and in his best suit,
12219: constantly within sight of good cheer, he had a comfortable
12220: consciousness of being on the premises, mingled with fleeting
12221: suggestions of Sunday and the bar at the Green Man; and he informed
12222: Mary Garth that he should not go out of reach of his brother Peter
12223: while that poor fellow was above ground. The troublesome ones in a
12224: family are usually either the wits or the idiots. Jonah was the wit
12225: among the Featherstones, and joked with the maid-servants when they
12226: came about the hearth, but seemed to consider Miss Garth a suspicious
12227: character, and followed her with cold eyes.
12228: 
12229: Mary would have borne this one pair of eyes with comparative ease, but
12230: unfortunately there was young Cranch, who, having come all the way from
12231: the Chalky Flats to represent his mother and watch his uncle Jonah,
12232: also felt it his duty to stay and to sit chiefly in the kitchen to give
12233: his uncle company. Young Cranch was not exactly the balancing point
12234: between the wit and the idiot,—verging slightly towards the latter
12235: type, and squinting so as to leave everything in doubt about his
