12236: sentiments except that they were not of a forcible character. When Mary
12237: Garth entered the kitchen and Mr. Jonah Featherstone began to follow
12238: her with his cold detective eyes, young Cranch turning his head in the
12239: same direction seemed to insist on it that she should remark how he was
12240: squinting, as if he did it with design, like the gypsies when Borrow
12241: read the New Testament to them. This was rather too much for poor Mary;
12242: sometimes it made her bilious, sometimes it upset her gravity. One day
12243: that she had an opportunity she could not resist describing the kitchen
12244: scene to Fred, who would not be hindered from immediately going to see
12245: it, affecting simply to pass through. But no sooner did he face the
12246: four eyes than he had to rush through the nearest door which happened
12247: to lead to the dairy, and there under the high roof and among the pans
12248: he gave way to laughter which made a hollow resonance perfectly audible
12249: in the kitchen. He fled by another doorway, but Mr. Jonah, who had not
12250: before seen Fred’s white complexion, long legs, and pinched delicacy of
12251: face, prepared many sarcasms in which these points of appearance were
12252: wittily combined with the lowest moral attributes.
12253: 
12254: “Why, Tom, _you_ don’t wear such gentlemanly trousers—you haven’t got
12255: half such fine long legs,” said Jonah to his nephew, winking at the
12256: same time, to imply that there was something more in these statements
12257: than their undeniableness. Tom looked at his legs, but left it
12258: uncertain whether he preferred his moral advantages to a more vicious
12259: length of limb and reprehensible gentility of trouser.
12260: 
12261: In the large wainscoted parlor too there were constantly pairs of eyes
12262: on the watch, and own relatives eager to be “sitters-up.” Many came,
12263: lunched, and departed, but Brother Solomon and the lady who had been
12264: Jane Featherstone for twenty-five years before she was Mrs. Waule found
12265: it good to be there every day for hours, without other calculable
12266: occupation than that of observing the cunning Mary Garth (who was so
12267: deep that she could be found out in nothing) and giving occasional dry
12268: wrinkly indications of crying—as if capable of torrents in a wetter
12269: season—at the thought that they were not allowed to go into Mr.
12270: Featherstone’s room. For the old man’s dislike of his own family seemed
12271: to get stronger as he got less able to amuse himself by saying biting
12272: things to them. Too languid to sting, he had the more venom refluent in
12273: his blood.
12274: 
12275: Not fully believing the message sent through Mary Garth, they had
12276: presented themselves together within the door of the bedroom, both in
12277: black—Mrs. Waule having a white handkerchief partially unfolded in her
12278: hand—and both with faces in a sort of half-mourning purple; while Mrs.
12279: Vincy with her pink cheeks and pink ribbons flying was actually
12280: administering a cordial to their own brother, and the
12281: light-complexioned Fred, his short hair curling as might be expected in
12282: a gambler’s, was lolling at his ease in a large chair.
12283: 
12284: Old Featherstone no sooner caught sight of these funereal figures
12285: appearing in spite of his orders than rage came to strengthen him more
12286: successfully than the cordial. He was propped up on a bed-rest, and
12287: always had his gold-headed stick lying by him. He seized it now and
12288: swept it backwards and forwards in as large an area as he could,
12289: apparently to ban these ugly spectres, crying in a hoarse sort of
12290: screech—
12291: 
12292: “Back, back, Mrs. Waule! Back, Solomon!”
12293: 
12294: “Oh, Brother. Peter,” Mrs. Waule began—but Solomon put his hand before
12295: her repressingly. He was a large-cheeked man, nearly seventy, with
12296: small furtive eyes, and was not only of much blander temper but thought
12297: himself much deeper than his brother Peter; indeed not likely to be
12298: deceived in any of his fellow-men, inasmuch as they could not well be
12299: more greedy and deceitful than he suspected them of being. Even the
12300: invisible powers, he thought, were likely to be soothed by a bland
12301: parenthesis here and there—coming from a man of property, who might
12302: have been as impious as others.
12303: 
12304: “Brother Peter,” he said, in a wheedling yet gravely official tone,
12305: “It’s nothing but right I should speak to you about the Three Crofts
12306: and the Manganese. The Almighty knows what I’ve got on my mind—”
12307: 
12308: “Then he knows more than I want to know,” said Peter, laying down his
12309: stick with a show of truce which had a threat in it too, for he
12310: reversed the stick so as to make the gold handle a club in case of
12311: closer fighting, and looked hard at Solomon’s bald head.
12312: 
12313: “There’s things you might repent of, Brother, for want of speaking to
12314: me,” said Solomon, not advancing, however. “I could sit up with you
12315: to-night, and Jane with me, willingly, and you might take your own time
12316: to speak, or let me speak.”
12317: 
12318: “Yes, I shall take my own time—you needn’t offer me yours,” said Peter.
12319: 
12320: “But you can’t take your own time to die in, Brother,” began Mrs.
12321: Waule, with her usual woolly tone. “And when you lie speechless you may
12322: be tired of having strangers about you, and you may think of me and my
12323: children”—but here her voice broke under the touching thought which she
12324: was attributing to her speechless brother; the mention of ourselves
12325: being naturally affecting.
12326: 
12327: “No, I shan’t,” said old Featherstone, contradictiously. “I shan’t
12328: think of any of you. I’ve made my will, I tell you, I’ve made my will.”
12329: Here he turned his head towards Mrs. Vincy, and swallowed some more of
12330: his cordial.
12331: 
12332: “Some people would be ashamed to fill up a place belonging by rights to
12333: others,” said Mrs. Waule, turning her narrow eyes in the same
12334: direction.
12335: 
12336: “Oh, sister,” said Solomon, with ironical softness, “you and me are not
12337: fine, and handsome, and clever enough: we must be humble and let smart
12338: people push themselves before us.”
12339: 
12340: Fred’s spirit could not bear this: rising and looking at Mr.
12341: Featherstone, he said, “Shall my mother and I leave the room, sir, that
12342: you may be alone with your friends?”
12343: 
12344: “Sit down, I tell you,” said old Featherstone, snappishly. “Stop where
12345: you are. Good-by, Solomon,” he added, trying to wield his stick again,
12346: but failing now that he had reversed the handle. “Good-by, Mrs. Waule.
12347: Don’t you come again.”
12348: 
12349: “I shall be down-stairs, Brother, whether or no,” said Solomon. “I
12350: shall do my duty, and it remains to be seen what the Almighty will
12351: allow.”
12352: 
12353: “Yes, in property going out of families,” said Mrs. Waule, in
12354: continuation,—“and where there’s steady young men to carry on. But I
12355: pity them who are not such, and I pity their mothers. Good-by, Brother
12356: Peter.”
12357: 
12358: “Remember, I’m the eldest after you, Brother, and prospered from the
12359: first, just as you did, and have got land already by the name of
12360: Featherstone,” said Solomon, relying much on that reflection, as one
12361: which might be suggested in the watches of the night. “But I bid you
12362: good-by for the present.”
12363: 
12364: Their exit was hastened by their seeing old Mr. Featherstone pull his
12365: wig on each side and shut his eyes with his mouth-widening grimace, as
12366: if he were determined to be deaf and blind.
12367: 
12368: None the less they came to Stone Court daily and sat below at the post
12369: of duty, sometimes carrying on a slow dialogue in an undertone in which
12370: the observation and response were so far apart, that any one hearing
12371: them might have imagined himself listening to speaking automata, in
12372: some doubt whether the ingenious mechanism would really work, or wind
12373: itself up for a long time in order to stick and be silent. Solomon and
12374: Jane would have been sorry to be quick: what that led to might be seen
12375: on the other side of the wall in the person of Brother Jonah.
12376: 
12377: But their watch in the wainscoted parlor was sometimes varied by the
12378: presence of other guests from far or near. Now that Peter Featherstone
12379: was up-stairs, his property could be discussed with all that local
12380: enlightenment to be found on the spot: some rural and Middlemarch
12381: neighbors expressed much agreement with the family and sympathy with
12382: their interest against the Vincys, and feminine visitors were even
12383: moved to tears, in conversation with Mrs. Waule, when they recalled the
12384: fact that they themselves had been disappointed in times past by
12385: codicils and marriages for spite on the part of ungrateful elderly
12386: gentlemen, who, it might have been supposed, had been spared for
12387: something better. Such conversation paused suddenly, like an organ when
12388: the bellows are let drop, if Mary Garth came into the room; and all
12389: eyes were turned on her as a possible legatee, or one who might get
12390: access to iron chests.
12391: 
12392: But the younger men who were relatives or connections of the family,
12393: were disposed to admire her in this problematic light, as a girl who
12394: showed much conduct, and who among all the chances that were flying
12395: might turn out to be at least a moderate prize. Hence she had her share
12396: of compliments and polite attentions.
12397: 
12398: Especially from Mr. Borthrop Trumbull, a distinguished bachelor and
12399: auctioneer of those parts, much concerned in the sale of land and
12400: cattle: a public character, indeed, whose name was seen on widely
12401: distributed placards, and who might reasonably be sorry for those who
12402: did not know of him. He was second cousin to Peter Featherstone, and
12403: had been treated by him with more amenity than any other relative,
12404: being useful in matters of business; and in that programme of his
12405: funeral which the old man had himself dictated, he had been named as a
12406: Bearer. There was no odious cupidity in Mr. Borthrop Trumbull—nothing
12407: more than a sincere sense of his own merit, which, he was aware, in
12408: case of rivalry might tell against competitors; so that if Peter
12409: Featherstone, who so far as he, Trumbull, was concerned, had behaved
12410: like as good a soul as ever breathed, should have done anything
12411: handsome by him, all he could say was, that he had never fished and
12412: fawned, but had advised him to the best of his experience, which now
12413: extended over twenty years from the time of his apprenticeship at
12414: fifteen, and was likely to yield a knowledge of no surreptitious kind.
12415: His admiration was far from being confined to himself, but was
12416: accustomed professionally as well as privately to delight in estimating
12417: things at a high rate. He was an amateur of superior phrases, and never
12418: used poor language without immediately correcting himself—which was
12419: fortunate, as he was rather loud, and given to predominate, standing or
12420: walking about frequently, pulling down his waistcoat with the air of a
12421: man who is very much of his own opinion, trimming himself rapidly with
12422: his fore-finger, and marking each new series in these movements by a
12423: busy play with his large seals. There was occasionally a little
12424: fierceness in his demeanor, but it was directed chiefly against false
12425: opinion, of which there is so much to correct in the world that a man
12426: of some reading and experience necessarily has his patience tried. He
12427: felt that the Featherstone family generally was of limited
12428: understanding, but being a man of the world and a public character,
12429: took everything as a matter of course, and even went to converse with
12430: Mr. Jonah and young Cranch in the kitchen, not doubting that he had
12431: impressed the latter greatly by his leading questions concerning the
12432: Chalky Flats. If anybody had observed that Mr. Borthrop Trumbull, being
12433: an auctioneer, was bound to know the nature of everything, he would
12434: have smiled and trimmed himself silently with the sense that he came
12435: pretty near that. On the whole, in an auctioneering way, he was an
12436: honorable man, not ashamed of his business, and feeling that “the
12437: celebrated Peel, now Sir Robert,” if introduced to him, would not fail
12438: to recognize his importance.
12439: 
12440: “I don’t mind if I have a slice of that ham, and a glass of that ale,
12441: Miss Garth, if you will allow me,” he said, coming into the parlor at
12442: half-past eleven, after having had the exceptional privilege of seeing
12443: old Featherstone, and standing with his back to the fire between Mrs.
12444: Waule and Solomon.
12445: 
12446: “It’s not necessary for you to go out;—let me ring the bell.”
12447: 
12448: “Thank you,” said Mary, “I have an errand.”
12449: 
12450: “Well, Mr. Trumbull, you’re highly favored,” said Mrs. Waule.
12451: 
12452: “What! seeing the old man?” said the auctioneer, playing with his seals
12453: dispassionately. “Ah, you see he has relied on me considerably.” Here
12454: he pressed his lips together, and frowned meditatively.
12455: 
12456: “Might anybody ask what their brother has been saying?” said Solomon,
12457: in a soft tone of humility, in which he had a sense of luxurious
12458: cunning, he being a rich man and not in need of it.
12459: 
12460: “Oh yes, anybody may ask,” said Mr. Trumbull, with loud and
12461: good-humored though cutting sarcasm. “Anybody may interrogate. Any one
12462: may give their remarks an interrogative turn,” he continued, his
12463: sonorousness rising with his style. “This is constantly done by good
12464: speakers, even when they anticipate no answer. It is what we call a
12465: figure of speech—speech at a high figure, as one may say.” The eloquent
12466: auctioneer smiled at his own ingenuity.
12467: 
12468: “I shouldn’t be sorry to hear he’d remembered you, Mr. Trumbull,” said
12469: Solomon. “I never was against the deserving. It’s the undeserving I’m
12470: against.”
12471: 
12472: “Ah, there it is, you see, there it is,” said Mr. Trumbull,
12473: significantly. “It can’t be denied that undeserving people have been
12474: legatees, and even residuary legatees. It is so, with testamentary
12475: dispositions.” Again he pursed up his lips and frowned a little.
12476: 
12477: “Do you mean to say for certain, Mr. Trumbull, that my brother has left
12478: his land away from our family?” said Mrs. Waule, on whom, as an
12479: unhopeful woman, those long words had a depressing effect.
12480: 
12481: “A man might as well turn his land into charity land at once as leave
12482: it to some people,” observed Solomon, his sister’s question having
12483: drawn no answer.
12484: 
12485: “What, Blue-Coat land?” said Mrs. Waule, again. “Oh, Mr. Trumbull, you
12486: never can mean to say that. It would be flying in the face of the
12487: Almighty that’s prospered him.”
12488: 
12489: While Mrs. Waule was speaking, Mr. Borthrop Trumbull walked away from
12490: the fireplace towards the window, patrolling with his fore-finger round
12491: the inside of his stock, then along his whiskers and the curves of his
12492: hair. He now walked to Miss Garth’s work-table, opened a book which lay
12493: there and read the title aloud with pompous emphasis as if he were
12494: offering it for sale:
12495: 
12496: “‘Anne of Geierstein’ (pronounced Jeersteen) or the ‘Maiden of the
12497: Mist, by the author of Waverley.’” Then turning the page, he began
12498: sonorously—“The course of four centuries has well-nigh elapsed since
12499: the series of events which are related in the following chapters took
12500: place on the Continent.” He pronounced the last truly admirable word
12501: with the accent on the last syllable, not as unaware of vulgar usage,
12502: but feeling that this novel delivery enhanced the sonorous beauty which
12503: his reading had given to the whole.
12504: 
12505: And now the servant came in with the tray, so that the moments for
12506: answering Mrs. Waule’s question had gone by safely, while she and
12507: Solomon, watching Mr. Trumbull’s movements, were thinking that high
12508: learning interfered sadly with serious affairs. Mr. Borthrop Trumbull
12509: really knew nothing about old Featherstone’s will; but he could hardly
12510: have been brought to declare any ignorance unless he had been arrested
12511: for misprision of treason.
12512: 
12513: “I shall take a mere mouthful of ham and a glass of ale,” he said,
12514: reassuringly. “As a man with public business, I take a snack when I
12515: can. I will back this ham,” he added, after swallowing some morsels
12516: with alarming haste, “against any ham in the three kingdoms. In my
12517: opinion it is better than the hams at Freshitt Hall—and I think I am a
12518: tolerable judge.”
12519: 
12520: “Some don’t like so much sugar in their hams,” said Mrs. Waule. “But my
12521: poor brother would always have sugar.”
12522: 
12523: “If any person demands better, he is at liberty to do so; but, God
12524: bless me, what an aroma! I should be glad to buy in that quality, I
12525: know. There is some gratification to a gentleman”—here Mr. Trumbull’s
12526: voice conveyed an emotional remonstrance—“in having this kind of ham
12527: set on his table.”
12528: 
12529: He pushed aside his plate, poured out his glass of ale and drew his
12530: chair a little forward, profiting by the occasion to look at the inner
12531: side of his legs, which he stroked approvingly—Mr. Trumbull having all
12532: those less frivolous airs and gestures which distinguish the
12533: predominant races of the north.
12534: 
12535: “You have an interesting work there, I see, Miss Garth,” he observed,
12536: when Mary re-entered. “It is by the author of ‘Waverley’: that is Sir
12537: Walter Scott. I have bought one of his works myself—a very nice thing,
12538: a very superior publication, entitled ‘Ivanhoe.’ You will not get any
12539: writer to beat him in a hurry, I think—he will not, in my opinion, be
12540: speedily surpassed. I have just been reading a portion at the
12541: commencement of ‘Anne of Jeersteen.’ It commences well.” (Things never
12542: began with Mr. Borthrop Trumbull: they always commenced, both in
12543: private life and on his handbills.) “You are a reader, I see. Do you
12544: subscribe to our Middlemarch library?”
12545: 
12546: “No,” said Mary. “Mr. Fred Vincy brought this book.”
12547: 
12548: “I am a great bookman myself,” returned Mr. Trumbull. “I have no less
12549: than two hundred volumes in calf, and I flatter myself they are well
12550: selected. Also pictures by Murillo, Rubens, Teniers, Titian, Vandyck,
12551: and others. I shall be happy to lend you any work you like to mention,
12552: Miss Garth.”
12553: 
12554: “I am much obliged,” said Mary, hastening away again, “but I have
12555: little time for reading.”
12556: 
12557: “I should say my brother has done something for _her_ in his will,”
12558: said Mr. Solomon, in a very low undertone, when she had shut the door
12559: behind her, pointing with his head towards the absent Mary.
12560: 
12561: “His first wife was a poor match for him, though,” said Mrs. Waule.
12562: “She brought him nothing: and this young woman is only her niece,—and
12563: very proud. And my brother has always paid her wage.”
12564: 
12565: “A sensible girl though, in my opinion,” said Mr. Trumbull, finishing
12566: his ale and starting up with an emphatic adjustment of his waistcoat.
12567: “I have observed her when she has been mixing medicine in drops. She
12568: minds what she is doing, sir. That is a great point in a woman, and a
12569: great point for our friend up-stairs, poor dear old soul. A man whose
12570: life is of any value should think of his wife as a nurse: that is what
12571: I should do, if I married; and I believe I have lived single long
12572: enough not to make a mistake in that line. Some men must marry to
12573: elevate themselves a little, but when I am in need of that, I hope some
12574: one will tell me so—I hope some individual will apprise me of the fact.
12575: I wish you good morning, Mrs. Waule. Good morning, Mr. Solomon. I trust
12576: we shall meet under less melancholy auspices.”
12577: 
12578: When Mr. Trumbull had departed with a fine bow, Solomon, leaning
12579: forward, observed to his sister, “You may depend, Jane, my brother has
12580: left that girl a lumping sum.”
12581: 
12582: “Anybody would think so, from the way Mr. Trumbull talks,” said Jane.
12583: Then, after a pause, “He talks as if my daughters wasn’t to be trusted
12584: to give drops.”
12585: 
12586: “Auctioneers talk wild,” said Solomon. “Not but what Trumbull has made
12587: money.”
12588: 
12589: 
12590: 
12591: 
12592: CHAPTER XXXIII.
12593: 
12594: “Close up his eyes and draw the curtain close;
12595: And let us all to meditation.”
12596: —2 _Henry VI_.
12597: 
12598: 
12599: That night after twelve o’clock Mary Garth relieved the watch in Mr.
12600: Featherstone’s room, and sat there alone through the small hours. She
12601: often chose this task, in which she found some pleasure,
12602: notwithstanding the old man’s testiness whenever he demanded her
12603: attentions. There were intervals in which she could sit perfectly
12604: still, enjoying the outer stillness and the subdued light. The red fire
12605: with its gently audible movement seemed like a solemn existence calmly
12606: independent of the petty passions, the imbecile desires, the straining
12607: after worthless uncertainties, which were daily moving her contempt.
12608: Mary was fond of her own thoughts, and could amuse herself well sitting
12609: in twilight with her hands in her lap; for, having early had strong
12610: reason to believe that things were not likely to be arranged for her
12611: peculiar satisfaction, she wasted no time in astonishment and annoyance
12612: at that fact. And she had already come to take life very much as a
12613: comedy in which she had a proud, nay, a generous resolution not to act
12614: the mean or treacherous part. Mary might have become cynical if she had
12615: not had parents whom she honored, and a well of affectionate gratitude
12616: within her, which was all the fuller because she had learned to make no
12617: unreasonable claims.
12618: 
12619: She sat to-night revolving, as she was wont, the scenes of the day, her
12620: lips often curling with amusement at the oddities to which her fancy
12621: added fresh drollery: people were so ridiculous with their illusions,
12622: carrying their fool’s caps unawares, thinking their own lies opaque
12623: while everybody else’s were transparent, making themselves exceptions
12624: to everything, as if when all the world looked yellow under a lamp they
12625: alone were rosy. Yet there were some illusions under Mary’s eyes which
12626: were not quite comic to her. She was secretly convinced, though she had
12627: no other grounds than her close observation of old Featherstone’s
12628: nature, that in spite of his fondness for having the Vincys about him,
12629: they were as likely to be disappointed as any of the relations whom he
12630: kept at a distance. She had a good deal of disdain for Mrs. Vincy’s
12631: evident alarm lest she and Fred should be alone together, but it did
12632: not hinder her from thinking anxiously of the way in which Fred would
12633: be affected, if it should turn out that his uncle had left him as poor
12634: as ever. She could make a butt of Fred when he was present, but she did
12635: not enjoy his follies when he was absent.
12636: 
12637: Yet she liked her thoughts: a vigorous young mind not overbalanced by
12638: passion, finds a good in making acquaintance with life, and watches its
12639: own powers with interest. Mary had plenty of merriment within.
12640: 
12641: Her thought was not veined by any solemnity or pathos about the old man
12642: on the bed: such sentiments are easier to affect than to feel about an
12643: aged creature whose life is not visibly anything but a remnant of
12644: vices. She had always seen the most disagreeable side of Mr.
12645: Featherstone: he was not proud of her, and she was only useful to him.
12646: To be anxious about a soul that is always snapping at you must be left
12647: to the saints of the earth; and Mary was not one of them. She had never
12648: returned him a harsh word, and had waited on him faithfully: that was
12649: her utmost. Old Featherstone himself was not in the least anxious about
12650: his soul, and had declined to see Mr. Tucker on the subject.
12651: 
12652: To-night he had not snapped, and for the first hour or two he lay
12653: remarkably still, until at last Mary heard him rattling his bunch of
12654: keys against the tin box which he always kept in the bed beside him.
12655: About three o’clock he said, with remarkable distinctness, “Missy, come
12656: here!”
12657: 
12658: Mary obeyed, and found that he had already drawn the tin box from under
12659: the clothes, though he usually asked to have this done for him; and he
12660: had selected the key. He now unlocked the box, and, drawing from it
12661: another key, looked straight at her with eyes that seemed to have
12662: recovered all their sharpness and said, “How many of ’em are in the
12663: house?”
12664: 
12665: “You mean of your own relations, sir,” said Mary, well used to the old
12666: man’s way of speech. He nodded slightly and she went on.
12667: 
12668: “Mr. Jonah Featherstone and young Cranch are sleeping here.”
12669: 
12670: “Oh ay, they stick, do they? and the rest—they come every day, I’ll
12671: warrant—Solomon and Jane, and all the young uns? They come peeping, and
12672: counting and casting up?”
12673: 
12674: “Not all of them every day. Mr. Solomon and Mrs. Waule are here every
12675: day, and the others come often.”
12676: 
12677: The old man listened with a grimace while she spoke, and then said,
12678: relaxing his face, “The more fools they. You hearken, missy. It’s three
12679: o’clock in the morning, and I’ve got all my faculties as well as ever I
12680: had in my life. I know all my property, and where the money’s put out,
12681: and everything. And I’ve made everything ready to change my mind, and
12682: do as I like at the last. Do you hear, missy? I’ve got my faculties.”
12683: 
12684: “Well, sir?” said Mary, quietly.
12685: 
12686: He now lowered his tone with an air of deeper cunning. “I’ve made two
12687: wills, and I’m going to burn one. Now you do as I tell you. This is the
12688: key of my iron chest, in the closet there. You push well at the side of
12689: the brass plate at the top, till it goes like a bolt: then you can put
12690: the key in the front lock and turn it. See and do that; and take out
12691: the topmost paper—Last Will and Testament—big printed.”
12692: 
12693: “No, sir,” said Mary, in a firm voice, “I cannot do that.”
12694: 
12695: “Not do it? I tell you, you must,” said the old man, his voice
12696: beginning to shake under the shock of this resistance.
12697: 
12698: “I cannot touch your iron chest or your will. I must refuse to do
12699: anything that might lay me open to suspicion.”
12700: 
12701: “I tell you, I’m in my right mind. Shan’t I do as I like at the last? I
12702: made two wills on purpose. Take the key, I say.”
12703: 
12704: “No, sir, I will not,” said Mary, more resolutely still. Her repulsion
12705: was getting stronger.
12706: 
12707: “I tell you, there’s no time to lose.”
12708: 
12709: “I cannot help that, sir. I will not let the close of your life soil
12710: the beginning of mine. I will not touch your iron chest or your will.”
12711: She moved to a little distance from the bedside.
12712: 
12713: The old man paused with a blank stare for a little while, holding the
12714: one key erect on the ring; then with an agitated jerk he began to work
12715: with his bony left hand at emptying the tin box before him.
12716: 
12717: “Missy,” he began to say, hurriedly, “look here! take the money—the
12718: notes and gold—look here—take it—you shall have it all—do as I tell
12719: you.”
12720: 
12721: He made an effort to stretch out the key towards her as far as
12722: possible, and Mary again retreated.
12723: 
12724: “I will not touch your key or your money, sir. Pray don’t ask me to do
12725: it again. If you do, I must go and call your brother.”
12726: 
12727: He let his hand fall, and for the first time in her life Mary saw old
12728: Peter Featherstone begin to cry childishly. She said, in as gentle a
12729: tone as she could command, “Pray put up your money, sir;” and then went
12730: away to her seat by the fire, hoping this would help to convince him
12731: that it was useless to say more. Presently he rallied and said eagerly—
12732: 
12733: “Look here, then. Call the young chap. Call Fred Vincy.”
12734: 
12735: Mary’s heart began to beat more quickly. Various ideas rushed through
12736: her mind as to what the burning of a second will might imply. She had
12737: to make a difficult decision in a hurry.
12738: 
12739: “I will call him, if you will let me call Mr. Jonah and others with
12740: him.”
12741: 
12742: “Nobody else, I say. The young chap. I shall do as I like.”
12743: 
12744: “Wait till broad daylight, sir, when every one is stirring. Or let me
12745: call Simmons now, to go and fetch the lawyer? He can be here in less
12746: than two hours.”
12747: 
12748: “Lawyer? What do I want with the lawyer? Nobody shall know—I say,
12749: nobody shall know. I shall do as I like.”
12750: 
12751: “Let me call some one else, sir,” said Mary, persuasively. She did not
12752: like her position—alone with the old man, who seemed to show a strange
12753: flaring of nervous energy which enabled him to speak again and again
12754: without falling into his usual cough; yet she desired not to push
12755: unnecessarily the contradiction which agitated him. “Let me, pray, call
12756: some one else.”
12757: 
12758: “You let me alone, I say. Look here, missy. Take the money. You’ll
12759: never have the chance again. It’s pretty nigh two hundred—there’s more
12760: in the box, and nobody knows how much there was. Take it and do as I
12761: tell you.”
12762: 
12763: Mary, standing by the fire, saw its red light falling on the old man,
12764: propped up on his pillows and bed-rest, with his bony hand holding out
12765: the key, and the money lying on the quilt before him. She never forgot
12766: that vision of a man wanting to do as he liked at the last. But the way
12767: in which he had put the offer of the money urged her to speak with
12768: harder resolution than ever.
12769: 
12770: “It is of no use, sir. I will not do it. Put up your money. I will not
12771: touch your money. I will do anything else I can to comfort you; but I
12772: will not touch your keys or your money.”
12773: 
12774: “Anything else—anything else!” said old Featherstone, with hoarse rage,
12775: which, as if in a nightmare, tried to be loud, and yet was only just
12776: audible. “I want nothing else. You come here—you come here.”
12777: 
12778: Mary approached him cautiously, knowing him too well. She saw him
12779: dropping his keys and trying to grasp his stick, while he looked at her
12780: like an aged hyena, the muscles of his face getting distorted with the
12781: effort of his hand. She paused at a safe distance.
12782: 
12783: “Let me give you some cordial,” she said, quietly, “and try to compose
12784: yourself. You will perhaps go to sleep. And to-morrow by daylight you
12785: can do as you like.”
12786: 
12787: He lifted the stick, in spite of her being beyond his reach, and threw
12788: it with a hard effort which was but impotence. It fell, slipping over
12789: the foot of the bed. Mary let it lie, and retreated to her chair by the
12790: fire. By-and-by she would go to him with the cordial. Fatigue would
12791: make him passive. It was getting towards the chillest moment of the
12792: morning, the fire had got low, and she could see through the chink
12793: between the moreen window-curtains the light whitened by the blind.
12794: Having put some wood on the fire and thrown a shawl over her, she sat
12795: down, hoping that Mr. Featherstone might now fall asleep. If she went
12796: near him the irritation might be kept up. He had said nothing after
12797: throwing the stick, but she had seen him taking his keys again and
12798: laying his right hand on the money. He did not put it up, however, and
12799: she thought that he was dropping off to sleep.
12800: 
12801: But Mary herself began to be more agitated by the remembrance of what
12802: she had gone through, than she had been by the reality—questioning
12803: those acts of hers which had come imperatively and excluded all
12804: question in the critical moment.
12805: 
12806: Presently the dry wood sent out a flame which illuminated every
12807: crevice, and Mary saw that the old man was lying quietly with his head
12808: turned a little on one side. She went towards him with inaudible steps,
12809: and thought that his face looked strangely motionless; but the next
12810: moment the movement of the flame communicating itself to all objects
12811: made her uncertain. The violent beating of her heart rendered her
12812: perceptions so doubtful that even when she touched him and listened for
12813: his breathing, she could not trust her conclusions. She went to the
12814: window and gently propped aside the curtain and blind, so that the
12815: still light of the sky fell on the bed.
12816: 
12817: The next moment she ran to the bell and rang it energetically. In a
12818: very little while there was no longer any doubt that Peter Featherstone
12819: was dead, with his right hand clasping the keys, and his left hand
12820: lying on the heap of notes and gold.
12821: 
12822: 
12823: 
12824: 
12825: BOOK IV.
12826: THREE LOVE PROBLEMS.
12827: 
12828: 
12829: 
12830: 
12831: CHAPTER XXXIV.
12832: 
12833: “1_st Gent_. Such men as this are feathers, chips, and straws,
12834:     Carry no weight, no force.
12835: 
12836: 2_d Gent_. But levity
12837:     Is causal too, and makes the sum of weight.
12838:     For power finds its place in lack of power;
12839:     Advance is cession, and the driven ship
12840:     May run aground because the helmsman’s thought
12841:     Lacked force to balance opposites.”
12842: 
12843: 
12844: It was on a morning of May that Peter Featherstone was buried. In the
12845: prosaic neighborhood of Middlemarch, May was not always warm and sunny,
12846: and on this particular morning a chill wind was blowing the blossoms
12847: from the surrounding gardens on to the green mounds of Lowick
12848: churchyard. Swiftly moving clouds only now and then allowed a gleam to
12849: light up any object, whether ugly or beautiful, that happened to stand
12850: within its golden shower. In the churchyard the objects were remarkably
12851: various, for there was a little country crowd waiting to see the
12852: funeral. The news had spread that it was to be a “big burying;” the old
12853: gentleman had left written directions about everything and meant to
12854: have a funeral “beyond his betters.” This was true; for old
12855: Featherstone had not been a Harpagon whose passions had all been
12856: devoured by the ever-lean and ever-hungry passion of saving, and who
12857: would drive a bargain with his undertaker beforehand. He loved money,
12858: but he also loved to spend it in gratifying his peculiar tastes, and
12859: perhaps he loved it best of all as a means of making others feel his
12860: power more or less uncomfortably. If any one will here contend that
12861: there must have been traits of goodness in old Featherstone, I will not
12862: presume to deny this; but I must observe that goodness is of a modest
12863: nature, easily discouraged, and when much privacy, elbowed in early
12864: life by unabashed vices, is apt to retire into extreme privacy, so that
12865: it is more easily believed in by those who construct a selfish old
12866: gentleman theoretically, than by those who form the narrower judgments
12867: based on his personal acquaintance. In any case, he had been bent on
12868: having a handsome funeral, and on having persons “bid” to it who would
12869: rather have stayed at home. He had even desired that female relatives
12870: should follow him to the grave, and poor sister Martha had taken a
12871: difficult journey for this purpose from the Chalky Flats. She and Jane
12872: would have been altogether cheered (in a tearful manner) by this sign
12873: that a brother who disliked seeing them while he was living had been
12874: prospectively fond of their presence when he should have become a
12875: testator, if the sign had not been made equivocal by being extended to
12876: Mrs. Vincy, whose expense in handsome crape seemed to imply the most
12877: presumptuous hopes, aggravated by a bloom of complexion which told
12878: pretty plainly that she was not a blood-relation, but of that generally
12879: objectionable class called wife’s kin.
12880: 
12881: We are all of us imaginative in some form or other, for images are the
12882: brood of desire; and poor old Featherstone, who laughed much at the way
12883: in which others cajoled themselves, did not escape the fellowship of
12884: illusion. In writing the programme for his burial he certainly did not
12885: make clear to himself that his pleasure in the little drama of which it
12886: formed a part was confined to anticipation. In chuckling over the
12887: vexations he could inflict by the rigid clutch of his dead hand, he
12888: inevitably mingled his consciousness with that livid stagnant presence,
12889: and so far as he was preoccupied with a future life, it was with one of
12890: gratification inside his coffin. Thus old Featherstone was imaginative,
12891: after his fashion.
12892: 
12893: However, the three mourning-coaches were filled according to the
12894: written orders of the deceased. There were pall-bearers on horseback,
12895: with the richest scarfs and hatbands, and even the under-bearers had
12896: trappings of woe which were of a good well-priced quality. The black
12897: procession, when dismounted, looked the larger for the smallness of the
12898: churchyard; the heavy human faces and the black draperies shivering in
12899: the wind seemed to tell of a world strangely incongruous with the
12900: lightly dropping blossoms and the gleams of sunshine on the daisies.
12901: The clergyman who met the procession was Mr. Cadwallader—also according
12902: to the request of Peter Featherstone, prompted as usual by peculiar
12903: reasons. Having a contempt for curates, whom he always called
12904: understrappers, he was resolved to be buried by a beneficed clergyman.
12905: Mr. Casaubon was out of the question, not merely because he declined
12906: duty of this sort, but because Featherstone had an especial dislike to
12907: him as the rector of his own parish, who had a lien on the land in the
12908: shape of tithe, also as the deliverer of morning sermons, which the old
12909: man, being in his pew and not at all sleepy, had been obliged to sit
12910: through with an inward snarl. He had an objection to a parson stuck up
12911: above his head preaching to him. But his relations with Mr. Cadwallader
12912: had been of a different kind: the trout-stream which ran through Mr.
12913: Casaubon’s land took its course through Featherstone’s also, so that
12914: Mr. Cadwallader was a parson who had had to ask a favor instead of
12915: preaching. Moreover, he was one of the high gentry living four miles
12916: away from Lowick, and was thus exalted to an equal sky with the sheriff
12917: of the county and other dignities vaguely regarded as necessary to the
12918: system of things. There would be a satisfaction in being buried by Mr.
12919: Cadwallader, whose very name offered a fine opportunity for pronouncing
12920: wrongly if you liked.
12921: 
12922: This distinction conferred on the Rector of Tipton and Freshitt was the
12923: reason why Mrs. Cadwallader made one of the group that watched old
12924: Featherstone’s funeral from an upper window of the manor. She was not
12925: fond of visiting that house, but she liked, as she said, to see
12926: collections of strange animals such as there would be at this funeral;
12927: and she had persuaded Sir James and the young Lady Chettam to drive the
12928: Rector and herself to Lowick in order that the visit might be
12929: altogether pleasant.
12930: 
12931: “I will go anywhere with you, Mrs. Cadwallader,” Celia had said; “but I
12932: don’t like funerals.”
12933: 
12934: “Oh, my dear, when you have a clergyman in your family you must
12935: accommodate your tastes: I did that very early. When I married Humphrey
12936: I made up my mind to like sermons, and I set out by liking the end very
12937: much. That soon spread to the middle and the beginning, because I
12938: couldn’t have the end without them.”
12939: 
12940: “No, to be sure not,” said the Dowager Lady Chettam, with stately
12941: emphasis.
12942: 
12943: The upper window from which the funeral could be well seen was in the
12944: room occupied by Mr. Casaubon when he had been forbidden to work; but
12945: he had resumed nearly his habitual style of life now in spite of
12946: warnings and prescriptions, and after politely welcoming Mrs.
12947: Cadwallader had slipped again into the library to chew a cud of erudite
12948: mistake about Cush and Mizraim.
12949: 
12950: But for her visitors Dorothea too might have been shut up in the
12951: library, and would not have witnessed this scene of old Featherstone’s
12952: funeral, which, aloof as it seemed to be from the tenor of her life,
12953: always afterwards came back to her at the touch of certain sensitive
12954: points in memory, just as the vision of St. Peter’s at Rome was inwoven
12955: with moods of despondency. Scenes which make vital changes in our
12956: neighbors’ lot are but the background of our own, yet, like a
12957: particular aspect of the fields and trees, they become associated for
12958: us with the epochs of our own history, and make a part of that unity
12959: which lies in the selection of our keenest consciousness.
12960: 
12961: The dream-like association of something alien and ill-understood with
12962: the deepest secrets of her experience seemed to mirror that sense of
12963: loneliness which was due to the very ardor of Dorothea’s nature. The
12964: country gentry of old time lived in a rarefied social air: dotted apart
12965: on their stations up the mountain they looked down with imperfect
12966: discrimination on the belts of thicker life below. And Dorothea was not
12967: at ease in the perspective and chilliness of that height.
12968: 
12969: “I shall not look any more,” said Celia, after the train had entered
12970: the church, placing herself a little behind her husband’s elbow so that
12971: she could slyly touch his coat with her cheek. “I dare say Dodo likes
12972: it: she is fond of melancholy things and ugly people.”
12973: 
12974: “I am fond of knowing something about the people I live among,” said
12975: Dorothea, who had been watching everything with the interest of a monk
12976: on his holiday tour. “It seems to me we know nothing of our neighbors,
12977: unless they are cottagers. One is constantly wondering what sort of
12978: lives other people lead, and how they take things. I am quite obliged
12979: to Mrs. Cadwallader for coming and calling me out of the library.”
12980: 
12981: “Quite right to feel obliged to me,” said Mrs. Cadwallader. “Your rich
12982: Lowick farmers are as curious as any buffaloes or bisons, and I dare
12983: say you don’t half see them at church. They are quite different from
12984: your uncle’s tenants or Sir James’s—monsters—farmers without
12985: landlords—one can’t tell how to class them.”
12986: 
12987: “Most of these followers are not Lowick people,” said Sir James; “I
12988: suppose they are legatees from a distance, or from Middlemarch.
12989: Lovegood tells me the old fellow has left a good deal of money as well
12990: as land.”
12991: 
12992: “Think of that now! when so many younger sons can’t dine at their own
12993: expense,” said Mrs. Cadwallader. “Ah,” turning round at the sound of
12994: the opening door, “here is Mr. Brooke. I felt that we were incomplete
12995: before, and here is the explanation. You are come to see this odd
12996: funeral, of course?”
12997: 
12998: “No, I came to look after Casaubon—to see how he goes on, you know. And
12999: to bring a little news—a little news, my dear,” said Mr. Brooke,
13000: nodding at Dorothea as she came towards him. “I looked into the
13001: library, and I saw Casaubon over his books. I told him it wouldn’t do:
13002: I said, ‘This will never do, you know: think of your wife, Casaubon.’
13003: And he promised me to come up. I didn’t tell him my news: I said, he
13004: must come up.”
13005: 
13006: “Ah, now they are coming out of church,” Mrs. Cadwallader exclaimed.
13007: “Dear me, what a wonderfully mixed set! Mr. Lydgate as doctor, I
13008: suppose. But that is really a good looking woman, and the fair young
13009: man must be her son. Who are they, Sir James, do you know?”
13010: 
13011: “I see Vincy, the Mayor of Middlemarch; they are probably his wife and
13012: son,” said Sir James, looking interrogatively at Mr. Brooke, who nodded
13013: and said—
13014: 
13015: “Yes, a very decent family—a very good fellow is Vincy; a credit to the
13016: manufacturing interest. You have seen him at my house, you know.”
13017: 
13018: “Ah, yes: one of your secret committee,” said Mrs. Cadwallader,
13019: provokingly.
13020: 
13021: “A coursing fellow, though,” said Sir James, with a fox-hunter’s
13022: disgust.
13023: 
13024: “And one of those who suck the life out of the wretched handloom
13025: weavers in Tipton and Freshitt. That is how his family look so fair and
13026: sleek,” said Mrs. Cadwallader. “Those dark, purple-faced people are an
13027: excellent foil. Dear me, they are like a set of jugs! Do look at
13028: Humphrey: one might fancy him an ugly archangel towering above them in
13029: his white surplice.”
13030: 
13031: “It’s a solemn thing, though, a funeral,” said Mr. Brooke, “if you take
13032: it in that light, you know.”
13033: 
13034: “But I am not taking it in that light. I can’t wear my solemnity too
13035: often, else it will go to rags. It was time the old man died, and none
13036: of these people are sorry.”
13037: 
13038: “How piteous!” said Dorothea. “This funeral seems to me the most dismal
13039: thing I ever saw. It is a blot on the morning. I cannot bear to think
13040: that any one should die and leave no love behind.”
13041: 
13042: She was going to say more, but she saw her husband enter and seat
13043: himself a little in the background. The difference his presence made to
13044: her was not always a happy one: she felt that he often inwardly
13045: objected to her speech.
13046: 
13047: “Positively,” exclaimed Mrs. Cadwallader, “there is a new face come out
13048: from behind that broad man queerer than any of them: a little round
13049: head with bulging eyes—a sort of frog-face—do look. He must be of
13050: another blood, I think.”
13051: 
13052: “Let me see!” said Celia, with awakened curiosity, standing behind Mrs.
13053: Cadwallader and leaning forward over her head. “Oh, what an odd face!”
13054: Then with a quick change to another sort of surprised expression, she
13055: added, “Why, Dodo, you never told me that Mr. Ladislaw was come again!”
13056: 
13057: Dorothea felt a shock of alarm: every one noticed her sudden paleness
13058: as she looked up immediately at her uncle, while Mr. Casaubon looked at
13059: her.
13060: 
13061: “He came with me, you know; he is my guest—puts up with me at the
13062: Grange,” said Mr. Brooke, in his easiest tone, nodding at Dorothea, as
13063: if the announcement were just what she might have expected. “And we
13064: have brought the picture at the top of the carriage. I knew you would
13065: be pleased with the surprise, Casaubon. There you are to the very
13066: life—as Aquinas, you know. Quite the right sort of thing. And you will
13067: hear young Ladislaw talk about it. He talks uncommonly well—points out
13068: this, that, and the other—knows art and everything of that
13069: kind—companionable, you know—is up with you in any track—what I’ve been
13070: wanting a long while.”
13071: 
13072: Mr. Casaubon bowed with cold politeness, mastering his irritation, but
13073: only so far as to be silent. He remembered Will’s letter quite as well
13074: as Dorothea did; he had noticed that it was not among the letters which
13075: had been reserved for him on his recovery, and secretly concluding that
13076: Dorothea had sent word to Will not to come to Lowick, he had shrunk
13077: with proud sensitiveness from ever recurring to the subject. He now
13078: inferred that she had asked her uncle to invite Will to the Grange; and
13079: she felt it impossible at that moment to enter into any explanation.
13080: 
13081: Mrs. Cadwallader’s eyes, diverted from the churchyard, saw a good deal
13082: of dumb show which was not so intelligible to her as she could have
13083: desired, and could not repress the question, “Who is Mr. Ladislaw?”
13084: 
13085: “A young relative of Mr. Casaubon’s,” said Sir James, promptly. His
13086: good-nature often made him quick and clear-seeing in personal matters,
13087: and he had divined from Dorothea’s glance at her husband that there was
13088: some alarm in her mind.
13089: 
13090: “A very nice young fellow—Casaubon has done everything for him,”
13091: explained Mr. Brooke. “He repays your expense in him, Casaubon,” he
13092: went on, nodding encouragingly. “I hope he will stay with me a long
13093: while and we shall make something of my documents. I have plenty of
13094: ideas and facts, you know, and I can see he is just the man to put them
13095: into shape—remembers what the right quotations are, _omne tulit
13096: punctum_, and that sort of thing—gives subjects a kind of turn. I
13097: invited him some time ago when you were ill, Casaubon; Dorothea said
13098: you couldn’t have anybody in the house, you know, and she asked me to
13099: write.”
13100: 
13101: Poor Dorothea felt that every word of her uncle’s was about as pleasant
13102: as a grain of sand in the eye to Mr. Casaubon. It would be altogether
13103: unfitting now to explain that she had not wished her uncle to invite
13104: Will Ladislaw. She could not in the least make clear to herself the
13105: reasons for her husband’s dislike to his presence—a dislike painfully
13106: impressed on her by the scene in the library; but she felt the
13107: unbecomingness of saying anything that might convey a notion of it to
13108: others. Mr. Casaubon, indeed, had not thoroughly represented those
13109: mixed reasons to himself; irritated feeling with him, as with all of
13110: us, seeking rather for justification than for self-knowledge. But he
13111: wished to repress outward signs, and only Dorothea could discern the
13112: changes in her husband’s face before he observed with more of dignified
13113: bending and sing-song than usual—
13114: 
13115: “You are exceedingly hospitable, my dear sir; and I owe you
13116: acknowledgments for exercising your hospitality towards a relative of
13117: mine.”
13118: 
13119: The funeral was ended now, and the churchyard was being cleared.
13120: 
13121: “Now you can see him, Mrs. Cadwallader,” said Celia. “He is just like a
13122: miniature of Mr. Casaubon’s aunt that hangs in Dorothea’s boudoir—quite
13123: nice-looking.”
13124: 
13125: “A very pretty sprig,” said Mrs. Cadwallader, dryly. “What is your
13126: nephew to be, Mr. Casaubon?”
13127: 
13128: “Pardon me, he is not my nephew. He is my cousin.”
13129: 
13130: “Well, you know,” interposed Mr. Brooke, “he is trying his wings. He is
13131: just the sort of young fellow to rise. I should be glad to give him an
13132: opportunity. He would make a good secretary, now, like Hobbes, Milton,
13133: Swift—that sort of man.”
13134: 
13135: “I understand,” said Mrs. Cadwallader. “One who can write speeches.”
13136: 
13137: “I’ll fetch him in now, eh, Casaubon?” said Mr. Brooke. “He wouldn’t
13138: come in till I had announced him, you know. And we’ll go down and look
13139: at the picture. There you are to the life: a deep subtle sort of
13140: thinker with his fore-finger on the page, while Saint Bonaventure or
13141: somebody else, rather fat and florid, is looking up at the Trinity.
13142: Everything is symbolical, you know—the higher style of art: I like that
13143: up to a certain point, but not too far—it’s rather straining to keep up
13144: with, you know. But you are at home in that, Casaubon. And your
13145: painter’s flesh is good—solidity, transparency, everything of that
13146: sort. I went into that a great deal at one time. However, I’ll go and
13147: fetch Ladislaw.”
13148: 
13149: 
13150: 
13151: 
13152: CHAPTER XXXV.
13153: 
13154: “Non, je ne comprends pas de plus charmant plaisir
13155: Que de voir d’héritiers une troupe affligée
13156: Le maintien interdit, et la mine allongée,
13157: Lire un long testament où pales, étonnés
13158: On leur laisse un bonsoir avec un pied de nez.
13159: Pour voir au naturel leur tristesse profonde
13160: Je reviendrais, je crois, exprès de l’autre monde.”
13161: —REGNARD: _Le Légataire Universel_.
13162: 
13163: 
13164: When the animals entered the Ark in pairs, one may imagine that allied
13165: species made much private remark on each other, and were tempted to
13166: think that so many forms feeding on the same store of fodder were
13167: eminently superfluous, as tending to diminish the rations. (I fear the
13168: part played by the vultures on that occasion would be too painful for
13169: art to represent, those birds being disadvantageously naked about the
13170: gullet, and apparently without rites and ceremonies.)
13171: 
13172: The same sort of temptation befell the Christian Carnivora who formed
13173: Peter Featherstone’s funeral procession; most of them having their
13174: minds bent on a limited store which each would have liked to get the
13175: most of. The long-recognized blood-relations and connections by
13176: marriage made already a goodly number, which, multiplied by
13177: possibilities, presented a fine range for jealous conjecture and
13178: pathetic hopefulness. Jealousy of the Vincys had created a fellowship
13179: in hostility among all persons of the Featherstone blood, so that in
13180: the absence of any decided indication that one of themselves was to
13181: have more than the rest, the dread lest that long-legged Fred Vincy
13182: should have the land was necessarily dominant, though it left abundant
13183: feeling and leisure for vaguer jealousies, such as were entertained
13184: towards Mary Garth. Solomon found time to reflect that Jonah was
13185: undeserving, and Jonah to abuse Solomon as greedy; Jane, the elder
13186: sister, held that Martha’s children ought not to expect so much as the
13187: young Waules; and Martha, more lax on the subject of primogeniture, was
13188: sorry to think that Jane was so “having.” These nearest of kin were
13189: naturally impressed with the unreasonableness of expectations in
13190: cousins and second cousins, and used their arithmetic in reckoning the
13191: large sums that small legacies might mount to, if there were too many
13192: of them. Two cousins were present to hear the will, and a second cousin
13193: besides Mr. Trumbull. This second cousin was a Middlemarch mercer of
13194: polite manners and superfluous aspirates. The two cousins were elderly
13195: men from Brassing, one of them conscious of claims on the score of
13196: inconvenient expense sustained by him in presents of oysters and other
13197: eatables to his rich cousin Peter; the other entirely saturnine,
13198: leaning his hands and chin on a stick, and conscious of claims based on
13199: no narrow performance but on merit generally: both blameless citizens
13200: of Brassing, who wished that Jonah Featherstone did not live there. The
13201: wit of a family is usually best received among strangers.
13202: 
13203: “Why, Trumbull himself is pretty sure of five hundred—_that_ you may
13204: depend,—I shouldn’t wonder if my brother promised him,” said Solomon,
13205: musing aloud with his sisters, the evening before the funeral.
13206: 
13207: “Dear, dear!” said poor sister Martha, whose imagination of hundreds
13208: had been habitually narrowed to the amount of her unpaid rent.
13209: 
13210: But in the morning all the ordinary currents of conjecture were
13211: disturbed by the presence of a strange mourner who had plashed among
13212: them as if from the moon. This was the stranger described by Mrs.
13213: Cadwallader as frog-faced: a man perhaps about two or three and thirty,
13214: whose prominent eyes, thin-lipped, downward-curved mouth, and hair
13215: sleekly brushed away from a forehead that sank suddenly above the ridge
13216: of the eyebrows, certainly gave his face a batrachian unchangeableness
13217: of expression. Here, clearly, was a new legatee; else why was he bidden
13218: as a mourner? Here were new possibilities, raising a new uncertainty,
13219: which almost checked remark in the mourning-coaches. We are all
13220: humiliated by the sudden discovery of a fact which has existed very
13221: comfortably and perhaps been staring at us in private while we have
13222: been making up our world entirely without it. No one had seen this
13223: questionable stranger before except Mary Garth, and she knew nothing
13224: more of him than that he had twice been to Stone Court when Mr.
13225: Featherstone was down-stairs, and had sat alone with him for several
13226: hours. She had found an opportunity of mentioning this to her father,
13227: and perhaps Caleb’s were the only eyes, except the lawyer’s, which
13228: examined the stranger with more of inquiry than of disgust or
13229: suspicion. Caleb Garth, having little expectation and less cupidity,
13230: was interested in the verification of his own guesses, and the calmness
13231: with which he half smilingly rubbed his chin and shot intelligent
13232: glances much as if he were valuing a tree, made a fine contrast with
13233: the alarm or scorn visible in other faces when the unknown mourner,
13234: whose name was understood to be Rigg, entered the wainscoted parlor and
13235: took his seat near the door to make part of the audience when the will
13236: should be read. Just then Mr. Solomon and Mr. Jonah were gone up-stairs
13237: with the lawyer to search for the will; and Mrs. Waule, seeing two
13238: vacant seats between herself and Mr. Borthrop Trumbull, had the spirit
13239: to move next to that great authority, who was handling his watch-seals
13240: and trimming his outlines with a determination not to show anything so
13241: compromising to a man of ability as wonder or surprise.
13242: 
13243: “I suppose you know everything about what my poor brother’s done, Mr.
13244: Trumbull,” said Mrs. Waule, in the lowest of her woolly tones, while
13245: she turned her crape-shadowed bonnet towards Mr. Trumbull’s ear.
13246: 
13247: “My good lady, whatever was told me was told in confidence,” said the
13248: auctioneer, putting his hand up to screen that secret.
13249: 
13250: “Them who’ve made sure of their good-luck may be disappointed yet,”
13251: Mrs. Waule continued, finding some relief in this communication.
13252: 
13253: “Hopes are often delusive,” said Mr. Trumbull, still in confidence.
13254: 
13255: “Ah!” said Mrs. Waule, looking across at the Vincys, and then moving
13256: back to the side of her sister Martha.
13257: 
13258: “It’s wonderful how close poor Peter was,” she said, in the same
13259: undertones. “We none of us know what he might have had on his mind. I
13260: only hope and trust he wasn’t a worse liver than we think of, Martha.”
13261: 
13262: Poor Mrs. Cranch was bulky, and, breathing asthmatically, had the
13263: additional motive for making her remarks unexceptionable and giving
13264: them a general bearing, that even her whispers were loud and liable to
13265: sudden bursts like those of a deranged barrel-organ.
13266: 
13267: “I never _was_ covetous, Jane,” she replied; “but I have six children
13268: and have buried three, and I didn’t marry into money. The eldest, that
13269: sits there, is but nineteen—so I leave you to guess. And stock always
13270: short, and land most awkward. But if ever I’ve begged and prayed; it’s
13271: been to God above; though where there’s one brother a bachelor and the
13272: other childless after twice marrying—anybody might think!”
13273: 
13274: Meanwhile, Mr. Vincy had glanced at the passive face of Mr. Rigg, and
13275: had taken out his snuff-box and tapped it, but had put it again
13276: unopened as an indulgence which, however clarifying to the judgment,
13277: was unsuited to the occasion. “I shouldn’t wonder if Featherstone had
13278: better feelings than any of us gave him credit for,” he observed, in
13279: the ear of his wife. “This funeral shows a thought about everybody: it
13280: looks well when a man wants to be followed by his friends, and if they
13281: are humble, not to be ashamed of them. I should be all the better
13282: pleased if he’d left lots of small legacies. They may be uncommonly
13283: useful to fellows in a small way.”
13284: 
13285: “Everything is as handsome as could be, crape and silk and everything,”
13286: said Mrs. Vincy, contentedly.
13287: 
13288: But I am sorry to say that Fred was under some difficulty in repressing
13289: a laugh, which would have been more unsuitable than his father’s
13290: snuff-box. Fred had overheard Mr. Jonah suggesting something about a
13291: “love-child,” and with this thought in his mind, the stranger’s face,
13292: which happened to be opposite him, affected him too ludicrously. Mary
13293: Garth, discerning his distress in the twitchings of his mouth, and his
13294: recourse to a cough, came cleverly to his rescue by asking him to
13295: change seats with her, so that he got into a shadowy corner. Fred was
13296: feeling as good-naturedly as possible towards everybody, including
13297: Rigg; and having some relenting towards all these people who were less
13298: lucky than he was aware of being himself, he would not for the world
13299: have behaved amiss; still, it was particularly easy to laugh.
13300: 
13301: But the entrance of the lawyer and the two brothers drew every one’s
13302: attention. The lawyer was Mr. Standish, and he had come to Stone Court
13303: this morning believing that he knew thoroughly well who would be
13304: pleased and who disappointed before the day was over. The will he
13305: expected to read was the last of three which he had drawn up for Mr.
13306: Featherstone. Mr. Standish was not a man who varied his manners: he
13307: behaved with the same deep-voiced, off-hand civility to everybody, as
13308: if he saw no difference in them, and talked chiefly of the hay-crop,
13309: which would be “very fine, by God!” of the last bulletins concerning
13310: the King, and of the Duke of Clarence, who was a sailor every inch of
13311: him, and just the man to rule over an island like Britain.
13312: 
13313: Old Featherstone had often reflected as he sat looking at the fire that
13314: Standish would be surprised some day: it is true that if he had done as
13315: he liked at the last, and burnt the will drawn up by another lawyer, he
13316: would not have secured that minor end; still he had had his pleasure in
13317: ruminating on it. And certainly Mr. Standish was surprised, but not at
13318: all sorry; on the contrary, he rather enjoyed the zest of a little
13319: curiosity in his own mind, which the discovery of a second will added
13320: to the prospective amazement on the part of the Featherstone family.
13321: 
13322: As to the sentiments of Solomon and Jonah, they were held in utter
13323: suspense: it seemed to them that the old will would have a certain
13324: validity, and that there might be such an interlacement of poor Peter’s
13325: former and latter intentions as to create endless “lawing” before
13326: anybody came by their own—an inconvenience which would have at least
13327: the advantage of going all round. Hence the brothers showed a
13328: thoroughly neutral gravity as they re-entered with Mr. Standish; but
13329: Solomon took out his white handkerchief again with a sense that in any
13330: case there would be affecting passages, and crying at funerals, however
13331: dry, was customarily served up in lawn.
13332: 
13333: Perhaps the person who felt the most throbbing excitement at this
13334: moment was Mary Garth, in the consciousness that it was she who had
13335: virtually determined the production of this second will, which might
13336: have momentous effects on the lot of some persons present. No soul
13337: except herself knew what had passed on that final night.
13338: 
13339: “The will I hold in my hand,” said Mr. Standish, who, seated at the
13340: table in the middle of the room, took his time about everything,
13341: including the coughs with which he showed a disposition to clear his
13342: voice, “was drawn up by myself and executed by our deceased friend on
13343: the 9th of August, 1825. But I find that there is a subsequent
13344: instrument hitherto unknown to me, bearing date the 20th of July, 1826,
13345: hardly a year later than the previous one. And there is farther, I
13346: see”—Mr. Standish was cautiously travelling over the document with his
13347: spectacles—“a codicil to this latter will, bearing date March 1, 1828.”
13348: 
13349: “Dear, dear!” said sister Martha, not meaning to be audible, but driven
13350: to some articulation under this pressure of dates.
13351: 
13352: “I shall begin by reading the earlier will,” continued Mr. Standish,
13353: “since such, as appears by his not having destroyed the document, was
13354: the intention of deceased.”
13355: 
13356: The preamble was felt to be rather long, and several besides Solomon
13357: shook their heads pathetically, looking on the ground: all eyes avoided
13358: meeting other eyes, and were chiefly fixed either on the spots in the
13359: table-cloth or on Mr. Standish’s bald head; excepting Mary Garth’s.
13360: When all the rest were trying to look nowhere in particular, it was
13361: safe for her to look at them. And at the sound of the first “give and
13362: bequeath” she could see all complexions changing subtly, as if some
13363: faint vibration were passing through them, save that of Mr. Rigg. He
13364: sat in unaltered calm, and, in fact, the company, preoccupied with more
13365: important problems, and with the complication of listening to bequests
13366: which might or might not be revoked, had ceased to think of him. Fred
13367: blushed, and Mr. Vincy found it impossible to do without his snuff-box
13368: in his hand, though he kept it closed.
13369: 
13370: The small bequests came first, and even the recollection that there was
13371: another will and that poor Peter might have thought better of it, could
13372: not quell the rising disgust and indignation. One likes to be done well
13373: by in every tense, past, present, and future. And here was Peter
13374: capable five years ago of leaving only two hundred apiece to his own
13375: brothers and sisters, and only a hundred apiece to his own nephews and
13376: nieces: the Garths were not mentioned, but Mrs. Vincy and Rosamond were
13377: each to have a hundred. Mr. Trumbull was to have the gold-headed cane
13378: and fifty pounds; the other second cousins and the cousins present were
13379: each to have the like handsome sum, which, as the saturnine cousin
13380: observed, was a sort of legacy that left a man nowhere; and there was
13381: much more of such offensive dribbling in favor of persons not
13382: present—problematical, and, it was to be feared, low connections.
13383: Altogether, reckoning hastily, here were about three thousand disposed
13384: of. Where then had Peter meant the rest of the money to go—and where
13385: the land? and what was revoked and what not revoked—and was the
13386: revocation for better or for worse? All emotion must be conditional,
13387: and might turn out to be the wrong thing. The men were strong enough to
13388: bear up and keep quiet under this confused suspense; some letting their
13389: lower lip fall, others pursing it up, according to the habit of their
13390: muscles. But Jane and Martha sank under the rush of questions, and
13391: began to cry; poor Mrs. Cranch being half moved with the consolation of
13392: getting any hundreds at all without working for them, and half aware
13393: that her share was scanty; whereas Mrs. Waule’s mind was entirely
13394: flooded with the sense of being an own sister and getting little, while
13395: somebody else was to have much. The general expectation now was that
13396: the “much” would fall to Fred Vincy, but the Vincys themselves were
13397: surprised when ten thousand pounds in specified investments were
13398: declared to be bequeathed to him:—was the land coming too? Fred bit his
13399: lips: it was difficult to help smiling, and Mrs. Vincy felt herself the
13400: happiest of women—possible revocation shrinking out of sight in this
13401: dazzling vision.
13402: 
13403: There was still a residue of personal property as well as the land, but
13404: the whole was left to one person, and that person was—O possibilities!
13405: O expectations founded on the favor of “close” old gentlemen! O endless
13406: vocatives that would still leave expression slipping helpless from the
13407: measurement of mortal folly!—that residuary legatee was Joshua Rigg,
13408: who was also sole executor, and who was to take thenceforth the name of
13409: Featherstone.
13410: 
13411: There was a rustling which seemed like a shudder running round the
13412: room. Every one stared afresh at Mr. Rigg, who apparently experienced
13413: no surprise.
13414: 
13415: “A most singular testamentary disposition!” exclaimed Mr. Trumbull,
13416: preferring for once that he should be considered ignorant in the past.
13417: “But there is a second will—there is a further document. We have not
13418: yet heard the final wishes of the deceased.”
13419: 
13420: Mary Garth was feeling that what they had yet to hear were not the
13421: final wishes. The second will revoked everything except the legacies to
13422: the low persons before mentioned (some alterations in these being the
13423: occasion of the codicil), and the bequest of all the land lying in
13424: Lowick parish with all the stock and household furniture, to Joshua
13425: Rigg. The residue of the property was to be devoted to the erection and
13426: endowment of almshouses for old men, to be called Featherstone’s
13427: Alms-Houses, and to be built on a piece of land near Middlemarch
13428: already bought for the purpose by the testator, he wishing—so the
13429: document declared—to please God Almighty. Nobody present had a
13430: farthing; but Mr. Trumbull had the gold-headed cane. It took some time
13431: for the company to recover the power of expression. Mary dared not look
13432: at Fred.
13433: 
13434: Mr. Vincy was the first to speak—after using his snuff-box
13435: energetically—and he spoke with loud indignation. “The most
13436: unaccountable will I ever heard! I should say he was not in his right
13437: mind when he made it. I should say this last will was void,” added Mr.
13438: Vincy, feeling that this expression put the thing in the true light.
13439: “Eh Standish?”
13440: 
13441: “Our deceased friend always knew what he was about, I think,” said Mr.
13442: Standish. “Everything is quite regular. Here is a letter from Clemmens
13443: of Brassing tied with the will. He drew it up. A very respectable
13444: solicitor.”
13445: 
13446: “I never noticed any alienation of mind—any aberration of intellect in
13447: the late Mr. Featherstone,” said Borthrop Trumbull, “but I call this
13448: will eccentric. I was always willingly of service to the old soul; and
13449: he intimated pretty plainly a sense of obligation which would show
13450: itself in his will. The gold-headed cane is farcical considered as an
13451: acknowledgment to me; but happily I am above mercenary considerations.”
13452: 
13453: “There’s nothing very surprising in the matter that I can see,” said
13454: Caleb Garth. “Anybody might have had more reason for wondering if the
13455: will had been what you might expect from an open-minded straightforward
13456: man. For my part, I wish there was no such thing as a will.”
13457: 
13458: “That’s a strange sentiment to come from a Christian man, by God!” said
13459: the lawyer. “I should like to know how you will back that up, Garth!”
13460: 
13461: “Oh,” said Caleb, leaning forward, adjusting his finger-tips with
13462: nicety and looking meditatively on the ground. It always seemed to him
13463: that words were the hardest part of “business.”
13464: 
13465: But here Mr. Jonah Featherstone made himself heard. “Well, he always
13466: was a fine hypocrite, was my brother Peter. But this will cuts out
13467: everything. If I’d known, a wagon and six horses shouldn’t have drawn
13468: me from Brassing. I’ll put a white hat and drab coat on to-morrow.”
13469: 
13470: “Dear, dear,” wept Mrs. Cranch, “and we’ve been at the expense of
13471: travelling, and that poor lad sitting idle here so long! It’s the first
13472: time I ever heard my brother Peter was so wishful to please God
13473: Almighty; but if I was to be struck helpless I must say it’s hard—I can
13474: think no other.”
13475: 
13476: “It’ll do him no good where he’s gone, that’s my belief,” said Solomon,
13477: with a bitterness which was remarkably genuine, though his tone could
13478: not help being sly. “Peter was a bad liver, and almshouses won’t cover
13479: it, when he’s had the impudence to show it at the last.”
13480: 
13481: “And all the while had got his own lawful family—brothers and sisters
13482: and nephews and nieces—and has sat in church with ’em whenever he
13483: thought well to come,” said Mrs. Waule. “And might have left his
13484: property so respectable, to them that’s never been used to extravagance
13485: or unsteadiness in no manner of way—and not so poor but what they could
13486: have saved every penny and made more of it. And me—the trouble I’ve
13487: been at, times and times, to come here and be sisterly—and him with
13488: things on his mind all the while that might make anybody’s flesh creep.
13489: But if the Almighty’s allowed it, he means to punish him for it.
13490: Brother Solomon, I shall be going, if you’ll drive me.”
13491: 
13492: “I’ve no desire to put my foot on the premises again,” said Solomon.
13493: “I’ve got land of my own and property of my own to will away.”
13494: 
13495: “It’s a poor tale how luck goes in the world,” said Jonah. “It never
13496: answers to have a bit of spirit in you. You’d better be a dog in the
13497: manger. But those above ground might learn a lesson. One fool’s will is
13498: enough in a family.”
13499: 
13500: “There’s more ways than one of being a fool,” said Solomon. “I shan’t
13501: leave my money to be poured down the sink, and I shan’t leave it to
13502: foundlings from Africay. I like Featherstones that were brewed such,
13503: and not turned Featherstones with sticking the name on ’em.”
13504: 
13505: Solomon addressed these remarks in a loud aside to Mrs. Waule as he
13506: rose to accompany her. Brother Jonah felt himself capable of much more
13507: stinging wit than this, but he reflected that there was no use in
13508: offending the new proprietor of Stone Court, until you were certain
13509: that he was quite without intentions of hospitality towards witty men
13510: whose name he was about to bear.
13511: 
13512: Mr. Joshua Rigg, in fact, appeared to trouble himself little about any
13513: innuendoes, but showed a notable change of manner, walking coolly up to
13514: Mr. Standish and putting business questions with much coolness. He had
13515: a high chirping voice and a vile accent. Fred, whom he no longer moved
13516: to laughter, thought him the lowest monster he had ever seen. But Fred
13517: was feeling rather sick. The Middlemarch mercer waited for an
13518: opportunity of engaging Mr. Rigg in conversation: there was no knowing
13519: how many pairs of legs the new proprietor might require hose for, and
13520: profits were more to be relied on than legacies. Also, the mercer, as a
13521: second cousin, was dispassionate enough to feel curiosity.
13522: 
13523: Mr. Vincy, after his one outburst, had remained proudly silent, though
13524: too much preoccupied with unpleasant feelings to think of moving, till
13525: he observed that his wife had gone to Fred’s side and was crying
13526: silently while she held her darling’s hand. He rose immediately, and
13527: turning his back on the company while he said to her in an
13528: undertone,—“Don’t give way, Lucy; don’t make a fool of yourself, my
13529: dear, before these people,” he added in his usual loud voice—“Go and
13530: order the phaeton, Fred; I have no time to waste.”
13531: 
13532: Mary Garth had before this been getting ready to go home with her
13533: father. She met Fred in the hall, and now for the first time had the
13534: courage to look at him. He had that withered sort of paleness which
13535: will sometimes come on young faces, and his hand was very cold when she
13536: shook it. Mary too was agitated; she was conscious that fatally,
13537: without will of her own, she had perhaps made a great difference to
13538: Fred’s lot.
13539: 
13540: “Good-by,” she said, with affectionate sadness. “Be brave, Fred. I do
13541: believe you are better without the money. What was the good of it to
13542: Mr. Featherstone?”
13543: 
13544: “That’s all very fine,” said Fred, pettishly. “What is a fellow to do?
13545: I must go into the Church now.” (He knew that this would vex Mary: very
13546: well; then she must tell him what else he could do.) “And I thought I
13547: should be able to pay your father at once and make everything right.
13548: And you have not even a hundred pounds left you. What shall you do now,
13549: Mary?”
13550: 
13551: “Take another situation, of course, as soon as I can get one. My father
13552: has enough to do to keep the rest, without me. Good-by.”
13553: 
13554: In a very short time Stone Court was cleared of well-brewed
13555: Featherstones and other long-accustomed visitors. Another stranger had
13556: been brought to settle in the neighborhood of Middlemarch, but in the
13557: case of Mr. Rigg Featherstone there was more discontent with immediate
13558: visible consequences than speculation as to the effect which his
13559: presence might have in the future. No soul was prophetic enough to have
13560: any foreboding as to what might appear on the trial of Joshua Rigg.
13561:
