13562: And here I am naturally led to reflect on the means of elevating a low
13563: subject. Historical parallels are remarkably efficient in this way. The
13564: chief objection to them is, that the diligent narrator may lack space,
13565: or (what is often the same thing) may not be able to think of them with
13566: any degree of particularity, though he may have a philosophical
13567: confidence that if known they would be illustrative. It seems an easier
13568: and shorter way to dignity, to observe that—since there never was a
13569: true story which could not be told in parables, where you might put a
13570: monkey for a margrave, and vice versa—whatever has been or is to be
13571: narrated by me about low people, may be ennobled by being considered a
13572: parable; so that if any bad habits and ugly consequences are brought
13573: into view, the reader may have the relief of regarding them as not more
13574: than figuratively ungenteel, and may feel himself virtually in company
13575: with persons of some style. Thus while I tell the truth about loobies,
13576: my reader’s imagination need not be entirely excluded from an
13577: occupation with lords; and the petty sums which any bankrupt of high
13578: standing would be sorry to retire upon, may be lifted to the level of
13579: high commercial transactions by the inexpensive addition of
13580: proportional ciphers.
13581: 
13582: As to any provincial history in which the agents are all of high moral
13583: rank, that must be of a date long posterior to the first Reform Bill,
13584: and Peter Featherstone, you perceive, was dead and buried some months
13585: before Lord Grey came into office.
13586: 
13587: 
13588: 
13589: 
13590: CHAPTER XXXVI.
13591: 
13592: ’T is strange to see the humors of these men,
13593: These great aspiring spirits, that should be wise:
13594: . . . . . . . .
13595: For being the nature of great spirits to love
13596: To be where they may be most eminent;
13597: They, rating of themselves so farre above
13598: Us in conceit, with whom they do frequent,
13599: Imagine how we wonder and esteeme
13600: All that they do or say; which makes them strive
13601: To make our admiration more extreme,
13602: Which they suppose they cannot, ’less they give
13603: Notice of their extreme and highest thoughts.
13604: —DANIEL: _Tragedy of Philotas_.
13605: 
13606: 
13607: Mr. Vincy went home from the reading of the will with his point of view
13608: considerably changed in relation to many subjects. He was an
13609: open-minded man, but given to indirect modes of expressing himself:
13610: when he was disappointed in a market for his silk braids, he swore at
13611: the groom; when his brother-in-law Bulstrode had vexed him, he made
13612: cutting remarks on Methodism; and it was now apparent that he regarded
13613: Fred’s idleness with a sudden increase of severity, by his throwing an
13614: embroidered cap out of the smoking-room on to the hall-floor.
13615: 
13616: “Well, sir,” he observed, when that young gentleman was moving off to
13617: bed, “I hope you’ve made up your mind now to go up next term and pass
13618: your examination. I’ve taken my resolution, so I advise you to lose no
13619: time in taking yours.”
13620: 
13621: Fred made no answer: he was too utterly depressed. Twenty-four hours
13622: ago he had thought that instead of needing to know what he should do,
13623: he should by this time know that he needed to do nothing: that he
13624: should hunt in pink, have a first-rate hunter, ride to cover on a fine
13625: hack, and be generally respected for doing so; moreover, that he should
13626: be able at once to pay Mr. Garth, and that Mary could no longer have
13627: any reason for not marrying him. And all this was to have come without
13628: study or other inconvenience, purely by the favor of providence in the
13629: shape of an old gentleman’s caprice. But now, at the end of the
13630: twenty-four hours, all those firm expectations were upset. It was
13631: “rather hard lines” that while he was smarting under this
13632: disappointment he should be treated as if he could have helped it. But
13633: he went away silently and his mother pleaded for him.
13634: 
13635: “Don’t be hard on the poor boy, Vincy. He’ll turn out well yet, though
13636: that wicked man has deceived him. I feel as sure as I sit here, Fred
13637: will turn out well—else why was he brought back from the brink of the
13638: grave? And I call it a robbery: it was like giving him the land, to
13639: promise it; and what is promising, if making everybody believe is not
13640: promising? And you see he did leave him ten thousand pounds, and then
13641: took it away again.”
13642: 
13643: “Took it away again!” said Mr. Vincy, pettishly. “I tell you the lad’s
13644: an unlucky lad, Lucy. And you’ve always spoiled him.”
13645: 
13646: “Well, Vincy, he was my first, and you made a fine fuss with him when
13647: he came. You were as proud as proud,” said Mrs. Vincy, easily
13648: recovering her cheerful smile.
13649: 
13650: “Who knows what babies will turn to? I was fool enough, I dare say,”
13651: said the husband—more mildly, however.
13652: 
13653: “But who has handsomer, better children than ours? Fred is far beyond
13654: other people’s sons: you may hear it in his speech, that he has kept
13655: college company. And Rosamond—where is there a girl like her? She might
13656: stand beside any lady in the land, and only look the better for it. You
13657: see—Mr. Lydgate has kept the highest company and been everywhere, and
13658: he fell in love with her at once. Not but what I could have wished
13659: Rosamond had not engaged herself. She might have met somebody on a
13660: visit who would have been a far better match; I mean at her
13661: schoolfellow Miss Willoughby’s. There are relations in that family
13662: quite as high as Mr. Lydgate’s.”
13663: 
13664: “Damn relations!” said Mr. Vincy; “I’ve had enough of them. I don’t
13665: want a son-in-law who has got nothing but his relations to recommend
13666: him.”
13667: 
13668: “Why, my dear,” said Mrs. Vincy, “you seemed as pleased as could be
13669: about it. It’s true, I wasn’t at home; but Rosamond told me you hadn’t
13670: a word to say against the engagement. And she has begun to buy in the
13671: best linen and cambric for her underclothing.”
13672: 
13673: “Not by my will,” said Mr. Vincy. “I shall have enough to do this year,
13674: with an idle scamp of a son, without paying for wedding-clothes. The
13675: times are as tight as can be; everybody is being ruined; and I don’t
13676: believe Lydgate has got a farthing. I shan’t give my consent to their
13677: marrying. Let ’em wait, as their elders have done before ’em.”
13678: 
13679: “Rosamond will take it hard, Vincy, and you know you never could bear
13680: to cross her.”
13681: 
13682: “Yes, I could. The sooner the engagement’s off, the better. I don’t
13683: believe he’ll ever make an income, the way he goes on. He makes
13684: enemies; that’s all I hear of his making.”
13685: 
13686: “But he stands very high with Mr. Bulstrode, my dear. The marriage
13687: would please _him_, I should think.”
13688: 
13689: “Please the deuce!” said Mr. Vincy. “Bulstrode won’t pay for their
13690: keep. And if Lydgate thinks I’m going to give money for them to set up
13691: housekeeping, he’s mistaken, that’s all. I expect I shall have to put
13692: down my horses soon. You’d better tell Rosy what I say.”
13693: 
13694: This was a not infrequent procedure with Mr. Vincy—to be rash in jovial
13695: assent, and on becoming subsequently conscious that he had been rash,
13696: to employ others in making the offensive retractation. However, Mrs.
13697: Vincy, who never willingly opposed her husband, lost no time the next
13698: morning in letting Rosamond know what he had said. Rosamond, examining
13699: some muslin-work, listened in silence, and at the end gave a certain
13700: turn of her graceful neck, of which only long experience could teach
13701: you that it meant perfect obstinacy.
13702: 
13703: “What do you say, my dear?” said her mother, with affectionate
13704: deference.
13705: 
13706: “Papa does not mean anything of the kind,” said Rosamond, quite calmly.
13707: “He has always said that he wished me to marry the man I loved. And I
13708: shall marry Mr. Lydgate. It is seven weeks now since papa gave his
13709: consent. And I hope we shall have Mrs. Bretton’s house.”
13710: 
13711: “Well, my dear, I shall leave you to manage your papa. You always do
13712: manage everybody. But if we ever do go and get damask, Sadler’s is the
13713: place—far better than Hopkins’s. Mrs. Bretton’s is very large, though:
13714: I should love you to have such a house; but it will take a great deal
13715: of furniture—carpeting and everything, besides plate and glass. And you
13716: hear, your papa says he will give no money. Do you think Mr. Lydgate
13717: expects it?”
13718: 
13719: “You cannot imagine that I should ask him, mamma. Of course he
13720: understands his own affairs.”
13721: 
13722: “But he may have been looking for money, my dear, and we all thought of
13723: your having a pretty legacy as well as Fred;—and now everything is so
13724: dreadful—there’s no pleasure in thinking of anything, with that poor
13725: boy disappointed as he is.”
13726: 
13727: “That has nothing to do with my marriage, mamma. Fred must leave off
13728: being idle. I am going up-stairs to take this work to Miss Morgan: she
13729: does the open hemming very well. Mary Garth might do some work for me
13730: now, I should think. Her sewing is exquisite; it is the nicest thing I
13731: know about Mary. I should so like to have all my cambric frilling
13732: double-hemmed. And it takes a long time.”
13733: 
13734: Mrs. Vincy’s belief that Rosamond could manage her papa was well
13735: founded. Apart from his dinners and his coursing, Mr. Vincy, blustering
13736: as he was, had as little of his own way as if he had been a prime
13737: minister: the force of circumstances was easily too much for him, as it
13738: is for most pleasure-loving florid men; and the circumstance called
13739: Rosamond was particularly forcible by means of that mild persistence
13740: which, as we know, enables a white soft living substance to make its
13741: way in spite of opposing rock. Papa was not a rock: he had no other
13742: fixity than that fixity of alternating impulses sometimes called habit,
13743: and this was altogether unfavorable to his taking the only decisive
13744: line of conduct in relation to his daughter’s engagement—namely, to
13745: inquire thoroughly into Lydgate’s circumstances, declare his own
13746: inability to furnish money, and forbid alike either a speedy marriage
13747: or an engagement which must be too lengthy. That seems very simple and
13748: easy in the statement; but a disagreeable resolve formed in the chill
13749: hours of the morning had as many conditions against it as the early
13750: frost, and rarely persisted under the warming influences of the day.
13751: The indirect though emphatic expression of opinion to which Mr. Vincy
13752: was prone suffered much restraint in this case: Lydgate was a proud man
13753: towards whom innuendoes were obviously unsafe, and throwing his hat on
13754: the floor was out of the question. Mr. Vincy was a little in awe of
13755: him, a little vain that he wanted to marry Rosamond, a little
13756: indisposed to raise a question of money in which his own position was
13757: not advantageous, a little afraid of being worsted in dialogue with a
13758: man better educated and more highly bred than himself, and a little
13759: afraid of doing what his daughter would not like. The part Mr. Vincy
13760: preferred playing was that of the generous host whom nobody criticises.
13761: In the earlier half of the day there was business to hinder any formal
13762: communication of an adverse resolve; in the later there was dinner,
13763: wine, whist, and general satisfaction. And in the mean while the hours
13764: were each leaving their little deposit and gradually forming the final
13765: reason for inaction, namely, that action was too late. The accepted
13766: lover spent most of his evenings in Lowick Gate, and a love-making not
13767: at all dependent on money-advances from fathers-in-law, or prospective
13768: income from a profession, went on flourishingly under Mr. Vincy’s own
13769: eyes. Young love-making—that gossamer web! Even the points it clings
13770: to—the things whence its subtle interlacings are swung—are scarcely
13771: perceptible: momentary touches of fingertips, meetings of rays from
13772: blue and dark orbs, unfinished phrases, lightest changes of cheek and
13773: lip, faintest tremors. The web itself is made of spontaneous beliefs
13774: and indefinable joys, yearnings of one life towards another, visions of
13775: completeness, indefinite trust. And Lydgate fell to spinning that web
13776: from his inward self with wonderful rapidity, in spite of experience
13777: supposed to be finished off with the drama of Laure—in spite too of
13778: medicine and biology; for the inspection of macerated muscle or of eyes
13779: presented in a dish (like Santa Lucia’s), and other incidents of
13780: scientific inquiry, are observed to be less incompatible with poetic
13781: love than a native dulness or a lively addiction to the lowest prose.
13782: As for Rosamond, she was in the water-lily’s expanding wonderment at
13783: its own fuller life, and she too was spinning industriously at the
13784: mutual web. All this went on in the corner of the drawing-room where
13785: the piano stood, and subtle as it was, the light made it a sort of
13786: rainbow visible to many observers besides Mr. Farebrother. The
13787: certainty that Miss Vincy and Mr. Lydgate were engaged became general
13788: in Middlemarch without the aid of formal announcement.
13789: 
13790: Aunt Bulstrode was again stirred to anxiety; but this time she
13791: addressed herself to her brother, going to the warehouse expressly to
13792: avoid Mrs. Vincy’s volatility. His replies were not satisfactory.
13793: 
13794: “Walter, you never mean to tell me that you have allowed all this to go
13795: on without inquiry into Mr. Lydgate’s prospects?” said Mrs. Bulstrode,
13796: opening her eyes with wider gravity at her brother, who was in his
13797: peevish warehouse humor. “Think of this girl brought up in luxury—in
13798: too worldly a way, I am sorry to say—what will she do on a small
13799: income?”
13800: 
13801: “Oh, confound it, Harriet! What can I do when men come into the town
13802: without any asking of mine? Did you shut your house up against Lydgate?
13803: Bulstrode has pushed him forward more than anybody. I never made any
13804: fuss about the young fellow. You should go and talk to your husband
13805: about it, not me.”
13806: 
13807: “Well, really, Walter, how can Mr. Bulstrode be to blame? I am sure he
13808: did not wish for the engagement.”
13809: 
13810: “Oh, if Bulstrode had not taken him by the hand, I should never have
13811: invited him.”
13812: 
13813: “But you called him in to attend on Fred, and I am sure that was a
13814: mercy,” said Mrs. Bulstrode, losing her clew in the intricacies of the
13815: subject.
13816: 
13817: “I don’t know about mercy,” said Mr. Vincy, testily. “I know I am
13818: worried more than I like with my family. I was a good brother to you,
13819: Harriet, before you married Bulstrode, and I must say he doesn’t always
13820: show that friendly spirit towards your family that might have been
13821: expected of him.” Mr. Vincy was very little like a Jesuit, but no
13822: accomplished Jesuit could have turned a question more adroitly. Harriet
13823: had to defend her husband instead of blaming her brother, and the
13824: conversation ended at a point as far from the beginning as some recent
13825: sparring between the brothers-in-law at a vestry meeting.
13826: 
13827: Mrs. Bulstrode did not repeat her brother’s complaints to her husband,
13828: but in the evening she spoke to him of Lydgate and Rosamond. He did not
13829: share her warm interest, however; and only spoke with resignation of
13830: the risks attendant on the beginning of medical practice and the
13831: desirability of prudence.
13832: 
13833: “I am sure we are bound to pray for that thoughtless girl—brought up as
13834: she has been,” said Mrs. Bulstrode, wishing to rouse her husband’s
13835: feelings.
13836: 
13837: “Truly, my dear,” said Mr. Bulstrode, assentingly. “Those who are not
13838: of this world can do little else to arrest the errors of the
13839: obstinately worldly. That is what we must accustom ourselves to
13840: recognize with regard to your brother’s family. I could have wished
13841: that Mr. Lydgate had not entered into such a union; but my relations
13842: with him are limited to that use of his gifts for God’s purposes which
13843: is taught us by the divine government under each dispensation.”
13844: 
13845: Mrs. Bulstrode said no more, attributing some dissatisfaction which she
13846: felt to her own want of spirituality. She believed that her husband was
13847: one of those men whose memoirs should be written when they died.
13848: 
13849: As to Lydgate himself, having been accepted, he was prepared to accept
13850: all the consequences which he believed himself to foresee with perfect
13851: clearness. Of course he must be married in a year—perhaps even in half
13852: a year. This was not what he had intended; but other schemes would not
13853: be hindered: they would simply adjust themselves anew. Marriage, of
13854: course, must be prepared for in the usual way. A house must be taken
13855: instead of the rooms he at present occupied; and Lydgate, having heard
13856: Rosamond speak with admiration of old Mrs. Bretton’s house (situated in
13857: Lowick Gate), took notice when it fell vacant after the old lady’s
13858: death, and immediately entered into treaty for it.
13859: 
13860: He did this in an episodic way, very much as he gave orders to his
13861: tailor for every requisite of perfect dress, without any notion of
13862: being extravagant. On the contrary, he would have despised any
13863: ostentation of expense; his profession had familiarized him with all
13864: grades of poverty, and he cared much for those who suffered hardships.
13865: He would have behaved perfectly at a table where the sauce was served
13866: in a jug with the handle off, and he would have remembered nothing
13867: about a grand dinner except that a man was there who talked well. But
13868: it had never occurred to him that he should live in any other than what
13869: he would have called an ordinary way, with green glasses for hock, and
13870: excellent waiting at table. In warming himself at French social
13871: theories he had brought away no smell of scorching. We may handle even
13872: extreme opinions with impunity while our furniture, our dinner-giving,
13873: and preference for armorial bearings in our own case, link us
13874: indissolubly with the established order. And Lydgate’s tendency was not
13875: towards extreme opinions: he would have liked no barefooted doctrines,
13876: being particular about his boots: he was no radical in relation to
13877: anything but medical reform and the prosecution of discovery. In the
13878: rest of practical life he walked by hereditary habit; half from that
13879: personal pride and unreflecting egoism which I have already called
13880: commonness, and half from that naivete which belonged to preoccupation
13881: with favorite ideas.
13882: 
13883: Any inward debate Lydgate had as to the consequences of this engagement
13884: which had stolen upon him, turned on the paucity of time rather than of
13885: money. Certainly, being in love and being expected continually by some
13886: one who always turned out to be prettier than memory could represent
13887: her to be, did interfere with the diligent use of spare hours which
13888: might serve some “plodding fellow of a German” to make the great,
13889: imminent discovery. This was really an argument for not deferring the
13890: marriage too long, as he implied to Mr. Farebrother, one day that the
13891: Vicar came to his room with some pond-products which he wanted to
13892: examine under a better microscope than his own, and, finding Lydgate’s
13893: tableful of apparatus and specimens in confusion, said sarcastically—
13894: 
13895: “Eros has degenerated; he began by introducing order and harmony, and
13896: now he brings back chaos.”
13897: 
13898: “Yes, at some stages,” said Lydgate, lifting his brows and smiling,
13899: while he began to arrange his microscope. “But a better order will
13900: begin after.”
13901: 
13902: “Soon?” said the Vicar.
13903: 
13904: “I hope so, really. This unsettled state of affairs uses up the time,
13905: and when one has notions in science, every moment is an opportunity. I
13906: feel sure that marriage must be the best thing for a man who wants to
13907: work steadily. He has everything at home then—no teasing with personal
13908: speculations—he can get calmness and freedom.”
13909: 
13910: “You are an enviable dog,” said the Vicar, “to have such a
13911: prospect—Rosamond, calmness and freedom, all to your share. Here am I
13912: with nothing but my pipe and pond-animalcules. Now, are you ready?”
13913: 
13914: Lydgate did not mention to the Vicar another reason he had for wishing
13915: to shorten the period of courtship. It was rather irritating to him,
13916: even with the wine of love in his veins, to be obliged to mingle so
13917: often with the family party at the Vincys’, and to enter so much into
13918: Middlemarch gossip, protracted good cheer, whist-playing, and general
13919: futility. He had to be deferential when Mr. Vincy decided questions
13920: with trenchant ignorance, especially as to those liquors which were the
13921: best inward pickle, preserving you from the effects of bad air. Mrs.
13922: Vincy’s openness and simplicity were quite unstreaked with suspicion as
13923: to the subtle offence she might give to the taste of her intended
13924: son-in-law; and altogether Lydgate had to confess to himself that he
13925: was descending a little in relation to Rosamond’s family. But that
13926: exquisite creature herself suffered in the same sort of way:—it was at
13927: least one delightful thought that in marrying her, he could give her a
13928: much-needed transplantation.
13929: 
13930: “Dear!” he said to her one evening, in his gentlest tone, as he sat
13931: down by her and looked closely at her face—
13932: 
13933: But I must first say that he had found her alone in the drawing-room,
13934: where the great old-fashioned window, almost as large as the side of
13935: the room, was opened to the summer scents of the garden at the back of
13936: the house. Her father and mother were gone to a party, and the rest
13937: were all out with the butterflies.
13938: 
13939: “Dear! your eyelids are red.”
13940: 
13941: “Are they?” said Rosamond. “I wonder why.” It was not in her nature to
13942: pour forth wishes or grievances. They only came forth gracefully on
13943: solicitation.
13944: 
13945: “As if you could hide it from me!” said Lydgate, laying his hand
13946: tenderly on both of hers. “Don’t I see a tiny drop on one of the
13947: lashes? Things trouble you, and you don’t tell me. That is unloving.”
13948: 
13949: “Why should I tell you what you cannot alter? They are every-day
13950: things:—perhaps they have been a little worse lately.”
13951: 
13952: “Family annoyances. Don’t fear speaking. I guess them.”
13953: 
13954: “Papa has been more irritable lately. Fred makes him angry, and this
13955: morning there was a fresh quarrel because Fred threatens to throw his
13956: whole education away, and do something quite beneath him. And besides—”
13957: 
13958: Rosamond hesitated, and her cheeks were gathering a slight flush.
13959: Lydgate had never seen her in trouble since the morning of their
13960: engagement, and he had never felt so passionately towards her as at
13961: this moment. He kissed the hesitating lips gently, as if to encourage
13962: them.
13963: 
13964: “I feel that papa is not quite pleased about our engagement,” Rosamond
13965: continued, almost in a whisper; “and he said last night that he should
13966: certainly speak to you and say it must be given up.”
13967: 
13968: “Will you give it up?” said Lydgate, with quick energy—almost angrily.
13969: 
13970: “I never give up anything that I choose to do,” said Rosamond,
13971: recovering her calmness at the touching of this chord.
13972: 
13973: “God bless you!” said Lydgate, kissing her again. This constancy of
13974: purpose in the right place was adorable. He went on:—
13975: 
13976: “It is too late now for your father to say that our engagement must be
13977: given up. You are of age, and I claim you as mine. If anything is done
13978: to make you unhappy,—that is a reason for hastening our marriage.”
13979: 
13980: An unmistakable delight shone forth from the blue eyes that met his,
13981: and the radiance seemed to light up all his future with mild sunshine.
13982: Ideal happiness (of the kind known in the Arabian Nights, in which you
13983: are invited to step from the labor and discord of the street into a
13984: paradise where everything is given to you and nothing claimed) seemed
13985: to be an affair of a few weeks’ waiting, more or less.
13986: 
13987: “Why should we defer it?” he said, with ardent insistence. “I have
13988: taken the house now: everything else can soon be got ready—can it not?
13989: You will not mind about new clothes. Those can be bought afterwards.”
13990: 
13991: “What original notions you clever men have!” said Rosamond, dimpling
13992: with more thorough laughter than usual at this humorous incongruity.
13993: “This is the first time I ever heard of wedding-clothes being bought
13994: after marriage.”
13995: 
13996: “But you don’t mean to say you would insist on my waiting months for
13997: the sake of clothes?” said Lydgate, half thinking that Rosamond was
13998: tormenting him prettily, and half fearing that she really shrank from
13999: speedy marriage. “Remember, we are looking forward to a better sort of
14000: happiness even than this—being continually together, independent of
14001: others, and ordering our lives as we will. Come, dear, tell me how soon
14002: you can be altogether mine.”
14003: 
14004: There was a serious pleading in Lydgate’s tone, as if he felt that she
14005: would be injuring him by any fantastic delays. Rosamond became serious
14006: too, and slightly meditative; in fact, she was going through many
14007: intricacies of lace-edging and hosiery and petticoat-tucking, in order
14008: to give an answer that would at least be approximative.
14009: 
14010: “Six weeks would be ample—say so, Rosamond,” insisted Lydgate,
14011: releasing her hands to put his arm gently round her.
14012: 
14013: One little hand immediately went to pat her hair, while she gave her
14014: neck a meditative turn, and then said seriously—
14015: 
14016: “There would be the house-linen and the furniture to be prepared.
14017: Still, mamma could see to those while we were away.”
14018: 
14019: “Yes, to be sure. We must be away a week or so.”
14020: 
14021: “Oh, more than that!” said Rosamond, earnestly. She was thinking of her
14022: evening dresses for the visit to Sir Godwin Lydgate’s, which she had
14023: long been secretly hoping for as a delightful employment of at least
14024: one quarter of the honeymoon, even if she deferred her introduction to
14025: the uncle who was a doctor of divinity (also a pleasing though sober
14026: kind of rank, when sustained by blood). She looked at her lover with
14027: some wondering remonstrance as she spoke, and he readily understood
14028: that she might wish to lengthen the sweet time of double solitude.
14029: 
14030: “Whatever you wish, my darling, when the day is fixed. But let us take
14031: a decided course, and put an end to any discomfort you may be
14032: suffering. Six weeks!—I am sure they would be ample.”
14033: 
14034: “I could certainly hasten the work,” said Rosamond. “Will you, then,
14035: mention it to papa?—I think it would be better to write to him.” She
14036: blushed and looked at him as the garden flowers look at us when we walk
14037: forth happily among them in the transcendent evening light: is there
14038: not a soul beyond utterance, half nymph, half child, in those delicate
14039: petals which glow and breathe about the centres of deep color?
14040: 
14041: He touched her ear and a little bit of neck under it with his lips, and
14042: they sat quite still for many minutes which flowed by them like a small
14043: gurgling brook with the kisses of the sun upon it. Rosamond thought
14044: that no one could be more in love than she was; and Lydgate thought
14045: that after all his wild mistakes and absurd credulity, he had found
14046: perfect womanhood—felt as if already breathed upon by exquisite wedded
14047: affection such as would be bestowed by an accomplished creature who
14048: venerated his high musings and momentous labors and would never
14049: interfere with them; who would create order in the home and accounts
14050: with still magic, yet keep her fingers ready to touch the lute and
14051: transform life into romance at any moment; who was instructed to the
14052: true womanly limit and not a hair’s-breadth beyond—docile, therefore,
14053: and ready to carry out behests which came from that limit. It was
14054: plainer now than ever that his notion of remaining much longer a
14055: bachelor had been a mistake: marriage would not be an obstruction but a
14056: furtherance. And happening the next day to accompany a patient to
14057: Brassing, he saw a dinner-service there which struck him as so exactly
14058: the right thing that he bought it at once. It saved time to do these
14059: things just when you thought of them, and Lydgate hated ugly crockery.
14060: The dinner-service in question was expensive, but that might be in the
14061: nature of dinner-services. Furnishing was necessarily expensive; but
14062: then it had to be done only once.
14063: 
14064: “It must be lovely,” said Mrs. Vincy, when Lydgate mentioned his
14065: purchase with some descriptive touches. “Just what Rosy ought to have.
14066: I trust in heaven it won’t be broken!”
14067: 
14068: “One must hire servants who will not break things,” said Lydgate.
14069: (Certainly, this was reasoning with an imperfect vision of sequences.
14070: But at that period there was no sort of reasoning which was not more or
14071: less sanctioned by men of science.)
14072: 
14073: Of course it was unnecessary to defer the mention of anything to mamma,
14074: who did not readily take views that were not cheerful, and being a
14075: happy wife herself, had hardly any feeling but pride in her daughter’s
14076: marriage. But Rosamond had good reasons for suggesting to Lydgate that
14077: papa should be appealed to in writing. She prepared for the arrival of
14078: the letter by walking with her papa to the warehouse the next morning,
14079: and telling him on the way that Mr. Lydgate wished to be married soon.
14080: 
14081: “Nonsense, my dear!” said Mr. Vincy. “What has he got to marry on?
14082: You’d much better give up the engagement. I’ve told you so pretty
14083: plainly before this. What have you had such an education for, if you
14084: are to go and marry a poor man? It’s a cruel thing for a father to
14085: see.”
14086: 
14087: “Mr. Lydgate is not poor, papa. He bought Mr. Peacock’s practice,
14088: which, they say, is worth eight or nine hundred a-year.”
14089: 
14090: “Stuff and nonsense! What’s buying a practice? He might as well buy
14091: next year’s swallows. It’ll all slip through his fingers.”
14092: 
14093: “On the contrary, papa, he will increase the practice. See how he has
14094: been called in by the Chettams and Casaubons.”
14095: 
14096: “I hope he knows I shan’t give anything—with this disappointment about
14097: Fred, and Parliament going to be dissolved, and machine-breaking
14098: everywhere, and an election coming on—”
14099: 
14100: “Dear papa! what can that have to do with my marriage?”
14101: 
14102: “A pretty deal to do with it! We may all be ruined for what I know—the
14103: country’s in that state! Some say it’s the end of the world, and be
14104: hanged if I don’t think it looks like it! Anyhow, it’s not a time for
14105: me to be drawing money out of my business, and I should wish Lydgate to
14106: know that.”
14107: 
14108: “I am sure he expects nothing, papa. And he has such very high
14109: connections: he is sure to rise in one way or another. He is engaged in
14110: making scientific discoveries.”
14111: 
14112: Mr. Vincy was silent.
14113: 
14114: “I cannot give up my only prospect of happiness, papa. Mr. Lydgate is a
14115: gentleman. I could never love any one who was not a perfect gentleman.
14116: You would not like me to go into a consumption, as Arabella Hawley did.
14117: And you know that I never change my mind.”
14118: 
14119: Again papa was silent.
14120: 
14121: “Promise me, papa, that you will consent to what we wish. We shall
14122: never give each other up; and you know that you have always objected to
14123: long courtships and late marriages.”
14124: 
14125: There was a little more urgency of this kind, till Mr. Vincy said,
14126: “Well, well, child, he must write to me first before I can answer
14127: him,”—and Rosamond was certain that she had gained her point.
14128: 
14129: Mr. Vincy’s answer consisted chiefly in a demand that Lydgate should
14130: insure his life—a demand immediately conceded. This was a delightfully
14131: reassuring idea supposing that Lydgate died, but in the mean time not a
14132: self-supporting idea. However, it seemed to make everything comfortable
14133: about Rosamond’s marriage; and the necessary purchases went on with
14134: much spirit. Not without prudential considerations, however. A bride
14135: (who is going to visit at a baronet’s) must have a few first-rate
14136: pocket-handkerchiefs; but beyond the absolutely necessary half-dozen,
14137: Rosamond contented herself without the very highest style of embroidery
14138: and Valenciennes. Lydgate also, finding that his sum of eight hundred
14139: pounds had been considerably reduced since he had come to Middlemarch,
14140: restrained his inclination for some plate of an old pattern which was
14141: shown to him when he went into Kibble’s establishment at Brassing to
14142: buy forks and spoons. He was too proud to act as if he presupposed that
14143: Mr. Vincy would advance money to provide furniture; and though, since
14144: it would not be necessary to pay for everything at once, some bills
14145: would be left standing over, he did not waste time in conjecturing how
14146: much his father-in-law would give in the form of dowry, to make payment
14147: easy. He was not going to do anything extravagant, but the requisite
14148: things must be bought, and it would be bad economy to buy them of a
14149: poor quality. All these matters were by the bye. Lydgate foresaw that
14150: science and his profession were the objects he should alone pursue
14151: enthusiastically; but he could not imagine himself pursuing them in
14152: such a home as Wrench had—the doors all open, the oil-cloth worn, the
14153: children in soiled pinafores, and lunch lingering in the form of bones,
14154: black-handled knives, and willow-pattern. But Wrench had a wretched
14155: lymphatic wife who made a mummy of herself indoors in a large shawl;
14156: and he must have altogether begun with an ill-chosen domestic
14157: apparatus.
14158: 
14159: Rosamond, however, was on her side much occupied with conjectures,
14160: though her quick imitative perception warned her against betraying them
14161: too crudely.
14162: 
14163: “I shall like so much to know your family,” she said one day, when the
14164: wedding journey was being discussed. “We might perhaps take a direction
14165: that would allow us to see them as we returned. Which of your uncles do
14166: you like best?”
14167: 
14168: “Oh,—my uncle Godwin, I think. He is a good-natured old fellow.”
14169: 
14170: “You were constantly at his house at Quallingham, when you were a boy,
14171: were you not? I should so like to see the old spot and everything you
14172: were used to. Does he know you are going to be married?”
14173: 
14174: “No,” said Lydgate, carelessly, turning in his chair and rubbing his
14175: hair up.
14176: 
14177: “Do send him word of it, you naughty undutiful nephew. He will perhaps
14178: ask you to take me to Quallingham; and then you could show me about the
14179: grounds, and I could imagine you there when you were a boy. Remember,
14180: you see me in my home, just as it has been since I was a child. It is
14181: not fair that I should be so ignorant of yours. But perhaps you would
14182: be a little ashamed of me. I forgot that.”
14183: 
14184: Lydgate smiled at her tenderly, and really accepted the suggestion that
14185: the proud pleasure of showing so charming a bride was worth some
14186: trouble. And now he came to think of it, he would like to see the old
14187: spots with Rosamond.
14188: 
14189: “I will write to him, then. But my cousins are bores.”
14190: 
14191: It seemed magnificent to Rosamond to be able to speak so slightingly of
14192: a baronet’s family, and she felt much contentment in the prospect of
14193: being able to estimate them contemptuously on her own account.
14194: 
14195: But mamma was near spoiling all, a day or two later, by saying—
14196: 
14197: “I hope your uncle Sir Godwin will not look down on Rosy, Mr. Lydgate.
14198: I should think he would do something handsome. A thousand or two can be
14199: nothing to a baronet.”
14200: 
14201: “Mamma!” said Rosamond, blushing deeply; and Lydgate pitied her so much
14202: that he remained silent and went to the other end of the room to
14203: examine a print curiously, as if he had been absent-minded. Mamma had a
14204: little filial lecture afterwards, and was docile as usual. But Rosamond
14205: reflected that if any of those high-bred cousins who were bores, should
14206: be induced to visit Middlemarch, they would see many things in her own
14207: family which might shock them. Hence it seemed desirable that Lydgate
14208: should by-and-by get some first-rate position elsewhere than in
14209: Middlemarch; and this could hardly be difficult in the case of a man
14210: who had a titled uncle and could make discoveries. Lydgate, you
14211: perceive, had talked fervidly to Rosamond of his hopes as to the
14212: highest uses of his life, and had found it delightful to be listened to
14213: by a creature who would bring him the sweet furtherance of satisfying
14214: affection—beauty—repose—such help as our thoughts get from the summer
14215: sky and the flower-fringed meadows.
14216: 
14217: Lydgate relied much on the psychological difference between what for
14218: the sake of variety I will call goose and gander: especially on the
14219: innate submissiveness of the goose as beautifully corresponding to the
14220: strength of the gander.
14221: 
14222: 
14223: 
14224: 
14225: CHAPTER XXXVII.
14226: 
14227: Thrice happy she that is so well assured
14228: Unto herself and settled so in heart
14229: That neither will for better be allured
14230: Ne fears to worse with any chance to start,
14231: But like a steddy ship doth strongly part
14232: The raging waves and keeps her course aright;
14233: Ne aught for tempest doth from it depart,
14234: Ne aught for fairer weather’s false delight.
14235: Such self-assurance need not fear the spight
14236: Of grudging foes; ne favour seek of friends;
14237: But in the stay of her own stedfast might
14238: Neither to one herself nor other bends.
14239:     Most happy she that most assured doth rest,
14240:     But he most happy who such one loves best.
14241: —SPENSER.
14242: 
14243: 
14244: The doubt hinted by Mr. Vincy whether it were only the general election
14245: or the end of the world that was coming on, now that George the Fourth
14246: was dead, Parliament dissolved, Wellington and Peel generally
14247: depreciated and the new King apologetic, was a feeble type of the
14248: uncertainties in provincial opinion at that time. With the glow-worm
14249: lights of country places, how could men see which were their own
14250: thoughts in the confusion of a Tory Ministry passing Liberal measures,
14251: of Tory nobles and electors being anxious to return Liberals rather
14252: than friends of the recreant Ministers, and of outcries for remedies
14253: which seemed to have a mysteriously remote bearing on private interest,
14254: and were made suspicious by the advocacy of disagreeable neighbors?
14255: Buyers of the Middlemarch newspapers found themselves in an anomalous
14256: position: during the agitation on the Catholic Question many had given
14257: up the “Pioneer”—which had a motto from Charles James Fox and was in
14258: the van of progress—because it had taken Peel’s side about the Papists,
14259: and had thus blotted its Liberalism with a toleration of Jesuitry and
14260: Baal; but they were ill-satisfied with the “Trumpet,” which—since its
14261: blasts against Rome, and in the general flaccidity of the public mind
14262: (nobody knowing who would support whom)—had become feeble in its
14263: blowing.
14264: 
14265: It was a time, according to a noticeable article in the “Pioneer,” when
14266: the crying needs of the country might well counteract a reluctance to
14267: public action on the part of men whose minds had from long experience
14268: acquired breadth as well as concentration, decision of judgment as well
14269: as tolerance, dispassionateness as well as energy—in fact, all those
14270: qualities which in the melancholy experience of mankind have been the
14271: least disposed to share lodgings.
14272: 
14273: Mr. Hackbutt, whose fluent speech was at that time floating more widely
14274: than usual, and leaving much uncertainty as to its ultimate channel,
14275: was heard to say in Mr. Hawley’s office that the article in question
14276: “emanated” from Brooke of Tipton, and that Brooke had secretly bought
14277: the “Pioneer” some months ago.
14278: 
14279: “That means mischief, eh?” said Mr. Hawley. “He’s got the freak of
14280: being a popular man now, after dangling about like a stray tortoise. So
14281: much the worse for him. I’ve had my eye on him for some time. He shall
14282: be prettily pumped upon. He’s a damned bad landlord. What business has
14283: an old county man to come currying favor with a low set of dark-blue
14284: freemen? As to his paper, I only hope he may do the writing himself. It
14285: would be worth our paying for.”
14286: 
14287: “I understand he has got a very brilliant young fellow to edit it, who
14288: can write the highest style of leading article, quite equal to anything
14289: in the London papers. And he means to take very high ground on Reform.”
14290: 
14291: “Let Brooke reform his rent-roll. He’s a cursed old screw, and the
14292: buildings all over his estate are going to rack. I suppose this young
14293: fellow is some loose fish from London.”
14294: 
14295: “His name is Ladislaw. He is said to be of foreign extraction.”
14296: 
14297: “I know the sort,” said Mr. Hawley; “some emissary. He’ll begin with
14298: flourishing about the Rights of Man and end with murdering a wench.
14299: That’s the style.”
14300: 
14301: “You must concede that there are abuses, Hawley,” said Mr. Hackbutt,
14302: foreseeing some political disagreement with his family lawyer. “I
14303: myself should never favor immoderate views—in fact I take my stand with
14304: Huskisson—but I cannot blind myself to the consideration that the
14305: non-representation of large towns—”
14306: 
14307: “Large towns be damned!” said Mr. Hawley, impatient of exposition. “I
14308: know a little too much about Middlemarch elections. Let ’em quash every
14309: pocket borough to-morrow, and bring in every mushroom town in the
14310: kingdom—they’ll only increase the expense of getting into Parliament. I
14311: go upon facts.”
14312: 
14313: Mr. Hawley’s disgust at the notion of the “Pioneer” being edited by an
14314: emissary, and of Brooke becoming actively political—as if a tortoise of
14315: desultory pursuits should protrude its small head ambitiously and
14316: become rampant—was hardly equal to the annoyance felt by some members
14317: of Mr. Brooke’s own family. The result had oozed forth gradually, like
14318: the discovery that your neighbor has set up an unpleasant kind of
14319: manufacture which will be permanently under your nostrils without legal
14320: remedy. The “Pioneer” had been secretly bought even before Will
14321: Ladislaw’s arrival, the expected opportunity having offered itself in
14322: the readiness of the proprietor to part with a valuable property which
14323: did not pay; and in the interval since Mr. Brooke had written his
14324: invitation, those germinal ideas of making his mind tell upon the world
14325: at large which had been present in him from his younger years, but had
14326: hitherto lain in some obstruction, had been sprouting under cover.
14327: 
14328: The development was much furthered by a delight in his guest which
14329: proved greater even than he had anticipated. For it seemed that Will
14330: was not only at home in all those artistic and literary subjects which
14331: Mr. Brooke had gone into at one time, but that he was strikingly ready
14332: at seizing the points of the political situation, and dealing with them
14333: in that large spirit which, aided by adequate memory, lends itself to
14334: quotation and general effectiveness of treatment.
14335: 
14336: “He seems to me a kind of Shelley, you know,” Mr. Brooke took an
14337: opportunity of saying, for the gratification of Mr. Casaubon. “I don’t
14338: mean as to anything objectionable—laxities or atheism, or anything of
14339: that kind, you know—Ladislaw’s sentiments in every way I am sure are
14340: good—indeed, we were talking a great deal together last night. But he
14341: has the same sort of enthusiasm for liberty, freedom, emancipation—a
14342: fine thing under guidance—under guidance, you know. I think I shall be
14343: able to put him on the right tack; and I am the more pleased because he
14344: is a relation of yours, Casaubon.”
14345: 
14346: If the right tack implied anything more precise than the rest of Mr.
14347: Brooke’s speech, Mr. Casaubon silently hoped that it referred to some
14348: occupation at a great distance from Lowick. He had disliked Will while
14349: he helped him, but he had begun to dislike him still more now that Will
14350: had declined his help. That is the way with us when we have any uneasy
14351: jealousy in our disposition: if our talents are chiefly of the
14352: burrowing kind, our honey-sipping cousin (whom we have grave reasons
14353: for objecting to) is likely to have a secret contempt for us, and any
14354: one who admires him passes an oblique criticism on ourselves. Having
14355: the scruples of rectitude in our souls, we are above the meanness of
14356: injuring him—rather we meet all his claims on us by active benefits;
14357: and the drawing of cheques for him, being a superiority which he must
14358: recognize, gives our bitterness a milder infusion. Now Mr. Casaubon had
14359: been deprived of that superiority (as anything more than a remembrance)
14360: in a sudden, capricious manner. His antipathy to Will did not spring
14361: from the common jealousy of a winter-worn husband: it was something
14362: deeper, bred by his lifelong claims and discontents; but Dorothea, now
14363: that she was present—Dorothea, as a young wife who herself had shown an
14364: offensive capability of criticism, necessarily gave concentration to
14365: the uneasiness which had before been vague.
14366: 
14367: Will Ladislaw on his side felt that his dislike was flourishing at the
14368: expense of his gratitude, and spent much inward discourse in justifying
14369: the dislike. Casaubon hated him—he knew that very well; on his first
14370: entrance he could discern a bitterness in the mouth and a venom in the
14371: glance which would almost justify declaring war in spite of past
14372: benefits. He was much obliged to Casaubon in the past, but really the
14373: act of marrying this wife was a set-off against the obligation. It was
14374: a question whether gratitude which refers to what is done for one’s
14375: self ought not to give way to indignation at what is done against
14376: another. And Casaubon had done a wrong to Dorothea in marrying her. A
14377: man was bound to know himself better than that, and if he chose to grow
14378: gray crunching bones in a cavern, he had no business to be luring a
14379: girl into his companionship. “It is the most horrible of
14380: virgin-sacrifices,” said Will; and he painted to himself what were
14381: Dorothea’s inward sorrows as if he had been writing a choric wail. But
14382: he would never lose sight of her: he would watch over her—if he gave up
14383: everything else in life he would watch over her, and she should know
14384: that she had one slave in the world. Will had—to use Sir Thomas
14385: Browne’s phrase—a “passionate prodigality” of statement both to himself
14386: and others. The simple truth was that nothing then invited him so
14387: strongly as the presence of Dorothea.
14388: 
14389: Invitations of the formal kind had been wanting, however, for Will had
14390: never been asked to go to Lowick. Mr. Brooke, indeed, confident of
14391: doing everything agreeable which Casaubon, poor fellow, was too much
14392: absorbed to think of, had arranged to bring Ladislaw to Lowick several
14393: times (not neglecting meanwhile to introduce him elsewhere on every
14394: opportunity as “a young relative of Casaubon’s”). And though Will had
14395: not seen Dorothea alone, their interviews had been enough to restore
14396: her former sense of young companionship with one who was cleverer than
14397: herself, yet seemed ready to be swayed by her. Poor Dorothea before her
14398: marriage had never found much room in other minds for what she cared
14399: most to say; and she had not, as we know, enjoyed her husband’s
14400: superior instruction so much as she had expected. If she spoke with any
14401: keenness of interest to Mr. Casaubon, he heard her with an air of
14402: patience as if she had given a quotation from the Delectus familiar to
14403: him from his tender years, and sometimes mentioned curtly what ancient
14404: sects or personages had held similar ideas, as if there were too much
14405: of that sort in stock already; at other times he would inform her that
14406: she was mistaken, and reassert what her remark had questioned.
14407: 
14408: But Will Ladislaw always seemed to see more in what she said than she
14409: herself saw. Dorothea had little vanity, but she had the ardent woman’s
14410: need to rule beneficently by making the joy of another soul. Hence the
14411: mere chance of seeing Will occasionally was like a lunette opened in
14412: the wall of her prison, giving her a glimpse of the sunny air; and this
14413: pleasure began to nullify her original alarm at what her husband might
14414: think about the introduction of Will as her uncle’s guest. On this
14415: subject Mr. Casaubon had remained dumb.
14416: 
14417: But Will wanted to talk with Dorothea alone, and was impatient of slow
14418: circumstance. However slight the terrestrial intercourse between Dante
14419: and Beatrice or Petrarch and Laura, time changes the proportion of
14420: things, and in later days it is preferable to have fewer sonnets and
14421: more conversation. Necessity excused stratagem, but stratagem was
14422: limited by the dread of offending Dorothea. He found out at last that
14423: he wanted to take a particular sketch at Lowick; and one morning when
14424: Mr. Brooke had to drive along the Lowick road on his way to the county
14425: town, Will asked to be set down with his sketch-book and camp-stool at
14426: Lowick, and without announcing himself at the Manor settled himself to
14427: sketch in a position where he must see Dorothea if she came out to
14428: walk—and he knew that she usually walked an hour in the morning.
14429: 
14430: But the stratagem was defeated by the weather. Clouds gathered with
14431: treacherous quickness, the rain came down, and Will was obliged to take
14432: shelter in the house. He intended, on the strength of relationship, to
14433: go into the drawing-room and wait there without being announced; and
14434: seeing his old acquaintance the butler in the hall, he said, “Don’t
14435: mention that I am here, Pratt; I will wait till luncheon; I know Mr.
14436: Casaubon does not like to be disturbed when he is in the library.”
14437: 
14438: “Master is out, sir; there’s only Mrs. Casaubon in the library. I’d
14439: better tell her you’re here, sir,” said Pratt, a red-cheeked man given
14440: to lively converse with Tantripp, and often agreeing with her that it
14441: must be dull for Madam.
14442: 
14443: “Oh, very well; this confounded rain has hindered me from sketching,”
14444: said Will, feeling so happy that he affected indifference with
14445: delightful ease.
14446: 
14447: In another minute he was in the library, and Dorothea was meeting him
14448: with her sweet unconstrained smile.
14449: 
14450: “Mr. Casaubon has gone to the Archdeacon’s,” she said, at once. “I
14451: don’t know whether he will be at home again long before dinner. He was
14452: uncertain how long he should be. Did you want to say anything
14453: particular to him?”
14454: 
14455: “No; I came to sketch, but the rain drove me in. Else I would not have
14456: disturbed you yet. I supposed that Mr. Casaubon was here, and I know he
14457: dislikes interruption at this hour.”
14458: 
14459: “I am indebted to the rain, then. I am so glad to see you.” Dorothea
14460: uttered these common words with the simple sincerity of an unhappy
14461: child, visited at school.
14462: 
14463: “I really came for the chance of seeing you alone,” said Will,
14464: mysteriously forced to be just as simple as she was. He could not stay
14465: to ask himself, why not? “I wanted to talk about things, as we did in
14466: Rome. It always makes a difference when other people are present.”
14467: 
14468: “Yes,” said Dorothea, in her clear full tone of assent. “Sit down.” She
14469: seated herself on a dark ottoman with the brown books behind her,
14470: looking in her plain dress of some thin woollen-white material, without
14471: a single ornament on her besides her wedding-ring, as if she were under
14472: a vow to be different from all other women; and Will sat down opposite
14473: her at two yards’ distance, the light falling on his bright curls and
14474: delicate but rather petulant profile, with its defiant curves of lip
14475: and chin. Each looked at the other as if they had been two flowers
14476: which had opened then and there. Dorothea for the moment forgot her
14477: husband’s mysterious irritation against Will: it seemed fresh water at
14478: her thirsty lips to speak without fear to the one person whom she had
14479: found receptive; for in looking backward through sadness she
14480: exaggerated a past solace.
14481: 
14482: “I have often thought that I should like to talk to you again,” she
14483: said, immediately. “It seems strange to me how many things I said to
14484: you.”
14485: 
14486: “I remember them all,” said Will, with the unspeakable content in his
14487: soul of feeling that he was in the presence of a creature worthy to be
14488: perfectly loved. I think his own feelings at that moment were perfect,
14489: for we mortals have our divine moments, when love is satisfied in the
14490: completeness of the beloved object.
14491: 
14492: “I have tried to learn a great deal since we were in Rome,” said
14493: Dorothea. “I can read Latin a little, and I am beginning to understand
14494: just a little Greek. I can help Mr. Casaubon better now. I can find out
14495: references for him and save his eyes in many ways. But it is very
14496: difficult to be learned; it seems as if people were worn out on the way
14497: to great thoughts, and can never enjoy them because they are too
14498: tired.”
14499: 
14500: “If a man has a capacity for great thoughts, he is likely to overtake
14501: them before he is decrepit,” said Will, with irrepressible quickness.
14502: But through certain sensibilities Dorothea was as quick as he, and
14503: seeing her face change, he added, immediately, “But it is quite true
14504: that the best minds have been sometimes overstrained in working out
14505: their ideas.”
14506: 
14507: “You correct me,” said Dorothea. “I expressed myself ill. I should have
14508: said that those who have great thoughts get too much worn in working
14509: them out. I used to feel about that, even when I was a little girl; and
14510: it always seemed to me that the use I should like to make of my life
14511: would be to help some one who did great works, so that his burthen
14512: might be lighter.”
14513: 
14514: Dorothea was led on to this bit of autobiography without any sense of
14515: making a revelation. But she had never before said anything to Will
14516: which threw so strong a light on her marriage. He did not shrug his
14517: shoulders; and for want of that muscular outlet he thought the more
14518: irritably of beautiful lips kissing holy skulls and other emptinesses
14519: ecclesiastically enshrined. Also he had to take care that his speech
14520: should not betray that thought.
14521: 
14522: “But you may easily carry the help too far,” he said, “and get
14523: over-wrought yourself. Are you not too much shut up? You already look
14524: paler. It would be better for Mr. Casaubon to have a secretary; he
14525: could easily get a man who would do half his work for him. It would
14526: save him more effectually, and you need only help him in lighter ways.”
14527: 
14528: “How can you think of that?” said Dorothea, in a tone of earnest
14529: remonstrance. “I should have no happiness if I did not help him in his
14530: work. What could I do? There is no good to be done in Lowick. The only
14531: thing I desire is to help him more. And he objects to a secretary:
14532: please not to mention that again.”
14533: 
14534: “Certainly not, now I know your feeling. But I have heard both Mr.
14535: Brooke and Sir James Chettam express the same wish.”
14536: 
14537: “Yes,” said Dorothea, “but they don’t understand—they want me to be a
14538: great deal on horseback, and have the garden altered and new
14539: conservatories, to fill up my days. I thought you could understand that
14540: one’s mind has other wants,” she added, rather impatiently—“besides,
14541: Mr. Casaubon cannot bear to hear of a secretary.”
14542: 
14543: “My mistake is excusable,” said Will. “In old days I used to hear Mr.
14544: Casaubon speak as if he looked forward to having a secretary. Indeed he
14545: held out the prospect of that office to me. But I turned out to be—not
14546: good enough for it.”
14547: 
14548: Dorothea was trying to extract out of this an excuse for her husband’s
14549: evident repulsion, as she said, with a playful smile, “You were not a
14550: steady worker enough.”
14551: 
14552: “No,” said Will, shaking his head backward somewhat after the manner of
14553: a spirited horse. And then, the old irritable demon prompting him to
14554: give another good pinch at the moth-wings of poor Mr. Casaubon’s glory,
14555: he went on, “And I have seen since that Mr. Casaubon does not like any
14556: one to overlook his work and know thoroughly what he is doing. He is
14557: too doubtful—too uncertain of himself. I may not be good for much, but
14558: he dislikes me because I disagree with him.”
14559: 
14560: Will was not without his intentions to be always generous, but our
14561: tongues are little triggers which have usually been pulled before
14562: general intentions can be brought to bear. And it was too intolerable
14563: that Casaubon’s dislike of him should not be fairly accounted for to
14564: Dorothea. Yet when he had spoken he was rather uneasy as to the effect
14565: on her.
14566: 
14567: But Dorothea was strangely quiet—not immediately indignant, as she had
14568: been on a like occasion in Rome. And the cause lay deep. She was no
14569: longer struggling against the perception of facts, but adjusting
14570: herself to their clearest perception; and now when she looked steadily
14571: at her husband’s failure, still more at his possible consciousness of
14572: failure, she seemed to be looking along the one track where duty became
14573: tenderness. Will’s want of reticence might have been met with more
14574: severity, if he had not already been recommended to her mercy by her
14575: husband’s dislike, which must seem hard to her till she saw better
14576: reason for it.
14577: 
14578: She did not answer at once, but after looking down ruminatingly she
14579: said, with some earnestness, “Mr. Casaubon must have overcome his
14580: dislike of you so far as his actions were concerned: and that is
14581: admirable.”
14582: 
14583: “Yes; he has shown a sense of justice in family matters. It was an
14584: abominable thing that my grandmother should have been disinherited
14585: because she made what they called a _mesalliance_, though there was
14586: nothing to be said against her husband except that he was a Polish
14587: refugee who gave lessons for his bread.”
14588: 
14589: “I wish I knew all about her!” said Dorothea. “I wonder how she bore
14590: the change from wealth to poverty: I wonder whether she was happy with
14591: her husband! Do you know much about them?”
14592: 
14593: “No; only that my grandfather was a patriot—a bright fellow—could speak
14594: many languages—musical—got his bread by teaching all sorts of things.
14595: They both died rather early. And I never knew much of my father, beyond
14596: what my mother told me; but he inherited the musical talents. I
14597: remember his slow walk and his long thin hands; and one day remains
14598: with me when he was lying ill, and I was very hungry, and had only a
14599: little bit of bread.”
14600: 
14601: “Ah, what a different life from mine!” said Dorothea, with keen
14602: interest, clasping her hands on her lap. “I have always had too much of
14603: everything. But tell me how it was—Mr. Casaubon could not have known
14604: about you then.”
14605: 
14606: “No; but my father had made himself known to Mr. Casaubon, and that was
14607: my last hungry day. My father died soon after, and my mother and I were
14608: well taken care of. Mr. Casaubon always expressly recognized it as his
14609: duty to take care of us because of the harsh injustice which had been
14610: shown to his mother’s sister. But now I am telling you what is not new
14611: to you.”
14612: 
14613: In his inmost soul Will was conscious of wishing to tell Dorothea what
14614: was rather new even in his own construction of things—namely, that Mr.
14615: Casaubon had never done more than pay a debt towards him. Will was much
14616: too good a fellow to be easy under the sense of being ungrateful. And
14617: when gratitude has become a matter of reasoning there are many ways of
14618: escaping from its bonds.
14619: 
14620: “No,” answered Dorothea; “Mr. Casaubon has always avoided dwelling on
14621: his own honorable actions.” She did not feel that her husband’s conduct
14622: was depreciated; but this notion of what justice had required in his
14623: relations with Will Ladislaw took strong hold on her mind. After a
14624: moment’s pause, she added, “He had never told me that he supported your
14625: mother. Is she still living?”
14626: 
14627: “No; she died by an accident—a fall—four years ago. It is curious that
14628: my mother, too, ran away from her family, but not for the sake of her
14629: husband. She never would tell me anything about her family, except that
14630: she forsook them to get her own living—went on the stage, in fact. She
14631: was a dark-eyed creature, with crisp ringlets, and never seemed to be
14632: getting old. You see I come of rebellious blood on both sides,” Will
14633: ended, smiling brightly at Dorothea, while she was still looking with
14634: serious intentness before her, like a child seeing a drama for the
14635: first time.
14636: 
14637: But her face, too, broke into a smile as she said, “That is your
14638: apology, I suppose, for having yourself been rather rebellious; I mean,
14639: to Mr. Casaubon’s wishes. You must remember that you have not done what
14640: he thought best for you. And if he dislikes you—you were speaking of
14641: dislike a little while ago—but I should rather say, if he has shown any
14642: painful feelings towards you, you must consider how sensitive he has
14643: become from the wearing effect of study. Perhaps,” she continued,
14644: getting into a pleading tone, “my uncle has not told you how serious
14645: Mr. Casaubon’s illness was. It would be very petty of us who are well
14646: and can bear things, to think much of small offences from those who
14647: carry a weight of trial.”
14648: 
14649: “You teach me better,” said Will. “I will never grumble on that subject
14650: again.” There was a gentleness in his tone which came from the
14651: unutterable contentment of perceiving—what Dorothea was hardly
14652: conscious of—that she was travelling into the remoteness of pure pity
14653: and loyalty towards her husband. Will was ready to adore her pity and
14654: loyalty, if she would associate himself with her in manifesting them.
14655: “I have really sometimes been a perverse fellow,” he went on, “but I
14656: will never again, if I can help it, do or say what you would
14657: disapprove.”
14658: 
14659: “That is very good of you,” said Dorothea, with another open smile. “I
14660: shall have a little kingdom then, where I shall give laws. But you will
14661: soon go away, out of my rule, I imagine. You will soon be tired of
14662: staying at the Grange.”
14663: 
14664: “That is a point I wanted to mention to you—one of the reasons why I
14665: wished to speak to you alone. Mr. Brooke proposes that I should stay in
14666: this neighborhood. He has bought one of the Middlemarch newspapers, and
14667: he wishes me to conduct that, and also to help him in other ways.”
14668: 
14669: “Would not that be a sacrifice of higher prospects for you?” said
14670: Dorothea.
14671: 
14672: “Perhaps; but I have always been blamed for thinking of prospects, and
14673: not settling to anything. And here is something offered to me. If you
14674: would not like me to accept it, I will give it up. Otherwise I would
14675: rather stay in this part of the country than go away. I belong to
14676: nobody anywhere else.”
14677: 
14678: “I should like you to stay very much,” said Dorothea, at once, as
14679: simply and readily as she had spoken at Rome. There was not the shadow
14680: of a reason in her mind at the moment why she should not say so.
14681: 
14682: “Then I _will_ stay,” said Ladislaw, shaking his head backward, rising
14683: and going towards the window, as if to see whether the rain had ceased.
14684: 
14685: But the next moment, Dorothea, according to a habit which was getting
14686: continually stronger, began to reflect that her husband felt
14687: differently from herself, and she colored deeply under the double
14688: embarrassment of having expressed what might be in opposition to her
14689: husband’s feeling, and of having to suggest this opposition to Will.
14690: His face was not turned towards her, and this made it easier to say—
14691: 
14692: “But my opinion is of little consequence on such a subject. I think you
14693: should be guided by Mr. Casaubon. I spoke without thinking of anything
14694: else than my own feeling, which has nothing to do with the real
14695: question. But it now occurs to me—perhaps Mr. Casaubon might see that
14696: the proposal was not wise. Can you not wait now and mention it to him?”
14697: 
14698: “I can’t wait to-day,” said Will, inwardly seared by the possibility
14699: that Mr. Casaubon would enter. “The rain is quite over now. I told Mr.
14700: Brooke not to call for me: I would rather walk the five miles. I shall
14701: strike across Halsell Common, and see the gleams on the wet grass. I
14702: like that.”
14703: 
14704: He approached her to shake hands quite hurriedly, longing but not
14705: daring to say, “Don’t mention the subject to Mr. Casaubon.” No, he
14706: dared not, could not say it. To ask her to be less simple and direct
14707: would be like breathing on the crystal that you want to see the light
14708: through. And there was always the other great dread—of himself becoming
14709: dimmed and forever ray-shorn in her eyes.
14710: 
14711: “I wish you could have stayed,” said Dorothea, with a touch of
14712: mournfulness, as she rose and put out her hand. She also had her
14713: thought which she did not like to express:—Will certainly ought to lose
14714: no time in consulting Mr. Casaubon’s wishes, but for her to urge this
14715: might seem an undue dictation.
14716: 
14717: So they only said “Good-by,” and Will quitted the house, striking
14718: across the fields so as not to run any risk of encountering Mr.
14719: Casaubon’s carriage, which, however, did not appear at the gate until
14720: four o’clock. That was an unpropitious hour for coming home: it was too
14721: early to gain the moral support under ennui of dressing his person for
14722: dinner, and too late to undress his mind of the day’s frivolous
14723: ceremony and affairs, so as to be prepared for a good plunge into the
14724: serious business of study. On such occasions he usually threw into an
14725: easy-chair in the library, and allowed Dorothea to read the London
14726: papers to him, closing his eyes the while. To-day, however, he declined
14727: that relief, observing that he had already had too many public details
14728: urged upon him; but he spoke more cheerfully than usual, when Dorothea
14729: asked about his fatigue, and added with that air of formal effort which
14730: never forsook him even when he spoke without his waistcoat and cravat—
14731: 
14732: “I have had the gratification of meeting my former acquaintance, Dr.
14733: Spanning, to-day, and of being praised by one who is himself a worthy
14734: recipient of praise. He spoke very handsomely of my late tractate on
14735: the Egyptian Mysteries,—using, in fact, terms which it would not become
14736: me to repeat.” In uttering the last clause, Mr. Casaubon leaned over
14737: the elbow of his chair, and swayed his head up and down, apparently as
14738: a muscular outlet instead of that recapitulation which would not have
14739: been becoming.
14740: 
14741: “I am very glad you have had that pleasure,” said Dorothea, delighted
14742: to see her husband less weary than usual at this hour. “Before you came
14743: I had been regretting that you happened to be out to-day.”
14744: 
14745: “Why so, my dear?” said Mr. Casaubon, throwing himself backward again.
14746: 
14747: “Because Mr. Ladislaw has been here; and he has mentioned a proposal of
14748: my uncle’s which I should like to know your opinion of.” Her husband
14749: she felt was really concerned in this question. Even with her ignorance
14750: of the world she had a vague impression that the position offered to
14751: Will was out of keeping with his family connections, and certainly Mr.
14752: Casaubon had a claim to be consulted. He did not speak, but merely
14753: bowed.
14754: 
14755: “Dear uncle, you know, has many projects. It appears that he has bought
14756: one of the Middlemarch newspapers, and he has asked Mr. Ladislaw to
14757: stay in this neighborhood and conduct the paper for him, besides
14758: helping him in other ways.”
14759: 
14760: Dorothea looked at her husband while she spoke, but he had at first
14761: blinked and finally closed his eyes, as if to save them; while his lips
14762: became more tense. “What is your opinion?” she added, rather timidly,
14763: after a slight pause.
14764: 
14765: “Did Mr. Ladislaw come on purpose to ask my opinion?” said Mr.
14766: Casaubon, opening his eyes narrowly with a knife-edged look at
14767: Dorothea. She was really uncomfortable on the point he inquired about,
14768: but she only became a little more serious, and her eyes did not swerve.
14769: 
14770: “No,” she answered immediately, “he did not say that he came to ask
14771: your opinion. But when he mentioned the proposal, he of course expected
14772: me to tell you of it.”
14773: 
14774: Mr. Casaubon was silent.
14775: 
14776: “I feared that you might feel some objection. But certainly a young man
14777: with so much talent might be very useful to my uncle—might help him to
14778: do good in a better way. And Mr. Ladislaw wishes to have some fixed
14779: occupation. He has been blamed, he says, for not seeking something of
14780: that kind, and he would like to stay in this neighborhood because no
14781: one cares for him elsewhere.”
14782: 
14783: Dorothea felt that this was a consideration to soften her husband.
14784: However, he did not speak, and she presently recurred to Dr. Spanning
14785: and the Archdeacon’s breakfast. But there was no longer sunshine on
14786: these subjects.
14787: 
14788: The next morning, without Dorothea’s knowledge, Mr. Casaubon despatched
14789: the following letter, beginning “Dear Mr. Ladislaw” (he had always
14790: before addressed him as “Will”):—
14791: 
14792: “Mrs. Casaubon informs me that a proposal has been made to you, and
14793: (according to an inference by no means stretched) has on your part been
14794: in some degree entertained, which involves your residence in this
14795: neighborhood in a capacity which I am justified in saying touches my
14796: own position in such a way as renders it not only natural and
14797: warrantable in me when that effect is viewed under the influence of
14798: legitimate feeling, but incumbent on me when the same effect is
14799: considered in the light of my responsibilities, to state at once that
14800: your acceptance of the proposal above indicated would be highly
14801: offensive to me. That I have some claim to the exercise of a veto here,
14802: would not, I believe, be denied by any reasonable person cognizant of
14803: the relations between us: relations which, though thrown into the past
14804: by your recent procedure, are not thereby annulled in their character
14805: of determining antecedents. I will not here make reflections on any
14806: person’s judgment. It is enough for me to point out to yourself that
14807: there are certain social fitnesses and proprieties which should hinder
14808: a somewhat near relative of mine from becoming any wise conspicuous in
14809: this vicinity in a status not only much beneath my own, but associated
14810: at best with the sciolism of literary or political adventurers. At any
14811: rate, the contrary issue must exclude you from further reception at my
14812: house.
14813: 
14814: 
14815: Yours faithfully,
14816: “EDWARD CASAUBON.”
14817: 
14818: 
14819: Meanwhile Dorothea’s mind was innocently at work towards the further
14820: embitterment of her husband; dwelling, with a sympathy that grew to
14821: agitation, on what Will had told her about his parents and
14822: grandparents. Any private hours in her day were usually spent in her
14823: blue-green boudoir, and she had come to be very fond of its pallid
14824: quaintness. Nothing had been outwardly altered there; but while the
14825: summer had gradually advanced over the western fields beyond the avenue
14826: of elms, the bare room had gathered within it those memories of an
14827: inward life which fill the air as with a cloud of good or bad angels,
14828: the invisible yet active forms of our spiritual triumphs or our
14829: spiritual falls. She had been so used to struggle for and to find
14830: resolve in looking along the avenue towards the arch of western light
14831: that the vision itself had gained a communicating power. Even the pale
14832: stag seemed to have reminding glances and to mean mutely, “Yes, we
14833: know.” And the group of delicately touched miniatures had made an
14834: audience as of beings no longer disturbed about their own earthly lot,
14835: but still humanly interested. Especially the mysterious “Aunt Julia”
14836: about whom Dorothea had never found it easy to question her husband.
14837: 
14838: And now, since her conversation with Will, many fresh images had
14839: gathered round that Aunt Julia who was Will’s grandmother; the presence
14840: of that delicate miniature, so like a living face that she knew,
14841: helping to concentrate her feelings. What a wrong, to cut off the girl
14842: from the family protection and inheritance only because she had chosen
14843: a man who was poor! Dorothea, early troubling her elders with questions
14844: about the facts around her, had wrought herself into some independent
14845: clearness as to the historical, political reasons why eldest sons had
14846: superior rights, and why land should be entailed: those reasons,
14847: impressing her with a certain awe, might be weightier than she knew,
14848: but here was a question of ties which left them uninfringed. Here was a
14849: daughter whose child—even according to the ordinary aping of
14850: aristocratic institutions by people who are no more aristocratic than
14851: retired grocers, and who have no more land to “keep together” than a
14852: lawn and a paddock—would have a prior claim. Was inheritance a question
14853: of liking or of responsibility? All the energy of Dorothea’s nature
14854: went on the side of responsibility—the fulfilment of claims founded on
14855: our own deeds, such as marriage and parentage.
14856: 
14857: It was true, she said to herself, that Mr. Casaubon had a debt to the
14858: Ladislaws—that he had to pay back what the Ladislaws had been wronged
14859: of. And now she began to think of her husband’s will, which had been
14860: made at the time of their marriage, leaving the bulk of his property to
14861: her, with proviso in case of her having children. That ought to be
14862: altered; and no time ought to be lost. This very question which had
14863: just arisen about Will Ladislaw’s occupation, was the occasion for
14864: placing things on a new, right footing. Her husband, she felt sure,
14865: according to all his previous conduct, would be ready to take the just
14866: view, if she proposed it—she, in whose interest an unfair concentration
14867: of the property had been urged. His sense of right had surmounted and
14868: would continue to surmount anything that might be called antipathy. She
14869: suspected that her uncle’s scheme was disapproved by Mr. Casaubon, and
14870: this made it seem all the more opportune that a fresh understanding
14871: should be begun, so that instead of Will’s starting penniless and
14872: accepting the first function that offered itself, he should find
14873: himself in possession of a rightful income which should be paid by her
14874: husband during his life, and, by an immediate alteration of the will,
14875: should be secured at his death. The vision of all this as what ought to
