14876: be done seemed to Dorothea like a sudden letting in of daylight, waking
14877: her from her previous stupidity and incurious self-absorbed ignorance
14878: about her husband’s relation to others. Will Ladislaw had refused Mr.
14879: Casaubon’s future aid on a ground that no longer appeared right to her;
14880: and Mr. Casaubon had never himself seen fully what was the claim upon
14881: him. “But he will!” said Dorothea. “The great strength of his character
14882: lies here. And what are we doing with our money? We make no use of half
14883: of our income. My own money buys me nothing but an uneasy conscience.”
14884: 
14885: There was a peculiar fascination for Dorothea in this division of
14886: property intended for herself, and always regarded by her as excessive.
14887: She was blind, you see, to many things obvious to others—likely to
14888: tread in the wrong places, as Celia had warned her; yet her blindness
14889: to whatever did not lie in her own pure purpose carried her safely by
14890: the side of precipices where vision would have been perilous with fear.
14891: 
14892: The thoughts which had gathered vividness in the solitude of her
14893: boudoir occupied her incessantly through the day on which Mr. Casaubon
14894: had sent his letter to Will. Everything seemed hindrance to her till
14895: she could find an opportunity of opening her heart to her husband. To
14896: his preoccupied mind all subjects were to be approached gently, and she
14897: had never since his illness lost from her consciousness the dread of
14898: agitating him. But when young ardor is set brooding over the conception
14899: of a prompt deed, the deed itself seems to start forth with independent
14900: life, mastering ideal obstacles. The day passed in a sombre fashion,
14901: not unusual, though Mr. Casaubon was perhaps unusually silent; but
14902: there were hours of the night which might be counted on as
14903: opportunities of conversation; for Dorothea, when aware of her
14904: husband’s sleeplessness, had established a habit of rising, lighting a
14905: candle, and reading him to sleep again. And this night she was from the
14906: beginning sleepless, excited by resolves. He slept as usual for a few
14907: hours, but she had risen softly and had sat in the darkness for nearly
14908: an hour before he said—
14909: 
14910: “Dorothea, since you are up, will you light a candle?”
14911: 
14912: “Do you feel ill, dear?” was her first question, as she obeyed him.
14913: 
14914: “No, not at all; but I shall be obliged, since you are up, if you will
14915: read me a few pages of Lowth.”
14916: 
14917: “May I talk to you a little instead?” said Dorothea.
14918: 
14919: “Certainly.”
14920: 
14921: “I have been thinking about money all day—that I have always had too
14922: much, and especially the prospect of too much.”
14923: 
14924: “These, my dear Dorothea, are providential arrangements.”
14925: 
14926: “But if one has too much in consequence of others being wronged, it
14927: seems to me that the divine voice which tells us to set that wrong
14928: right must be obeyed.”
14929: 
14930: “What, my love, is the bearing of your remark?”
14931: 
14932: “That you have been too liberal in arrangements for me—I mean, with
14933: regard to property; and that makes me unhappy.”
14934: 
14935: “How so? I have none but comparatively distant connections.”
14936: 
14937: “I have been led to think about your aunt Julia, and how she was left
14938: in poverty only because she married a poor man, an act which was not
14939: disgraceful, since he was not unworthy. It was on that ground, I know,
14940: that you educated Mr. Ladislaw and provided for his mother.”
14941: 
14942: Dorothea waited a few moments for some answer that would help her
14943: onward. None came, and her next words seemed the more forcible to her,
14944: falling clear upon the dark silence.
14945: 
14946: “But surely we should regard his claim as a much greater one, even to
14947: the half of that property which I know that you have destined for me.
14948: And I think he ought at once to be provided for on that understanding.
14949: It is not right that he should be in the dependence of poverty while we
14950: are rich. And if there is any objection to the proposal he mentioned,
14951: the giving him his true place and his true share would set aside any
14952: motive for his accepting it.”
14953: 
14954: “Mr. Ladislaw has probably been speaking to you on this subject?” said
14955: Mr. Casaubon, with a certain biting quickness not habitual to him.
14956: 
14957: “Indeed, no!” said Dorothea, earnestly. “How can you imagine it, since
14958: he has so lately declined everything from you? I fear you think too
14959: hardly of him, dear. He only told me a little about his parents and
14960: grandparents, and almost all in answer to my questions. You are so
14961: good, so just—you have done everything you thought to be right. But it
14962: seems to me clear that more than that is right; and I must speak about
14963: it, since I am the person who would get what is called benefit by that
14964: ‘more’ not being done.”
14965: 
14966: There was a perceptible pause before Mr. Casaubon replied, not quickly
14967: as before, but with a still more biting emphasis.
14968: 
14969: “Dorothea, my love, this is not the first occasion, but it were well
14970: that it should be the last, on which you have assumed a judgment on
14971: subjects beyond your scope. Into the question how far conduct,
14972: especially in the matter of alliances, constitutes a forfeiture of
14973: family claims, I do not now enter. Suffice it, that you are not here
14974: qualified to discriminate. What I now wish you to understand is, that I
14975: accept no revision, still less dictation within that range of affairs
14976: which I have deliberated upon as distinctly and properly mine. It is
14977: not for you to interfere between me and Mr. Ladislaw, and still less to
14978: encourage communications from him to you which constitute a criticism
14979: on my procedure.”
14980: 
14981: Poor Dorothea, shrouded in the darkness, was in a tumult of conflicting
14982: emotions. Alarm at the possible effect on himself of her husband’s
14983: strongly manifested anger, would have checked any expression of her own
14984: resentment, even if she had been quite free from doubt and compunction
14985: under the consciousness that there might be some justice in his last
14986: insinuation. Hearing him breathe quickly after he had spoken, she sat
14987: listening, frightened, wretched—with a dumb inward cry for help to bear
14988: this nightmare of a life in which every energy was arrested by dread.
14989: But nothing else happened, except that they both remained a long while
14990: sleepless, without speaking again.
14991: 
14992: The next day, Mr. Casaubon received the following answer from Will
14993: Ladislaw:—
14994: 
14995: “DEAR MR. CASAUBON,—I have given all due consideration to your letter
14996: of yesterday, but I am unable to take precisely your view of our mutual
14997: position. With the fullest acknowledgment of your generous conduct to
14998: me in the past, I must still maintain that an obligation of this kind
14999: cannot fairly fetter me as you appear to expect that it should. Granted
15000: that a benefactor’s wishes may constitute a claim; there must always be
15001: a reservation as to the quality of those wishes. They may possibly
15002: clash with more imperative considerations. Or a benefactor’s veto might
15003: impose such a negation on a man’s life that the consequent blank might
15004: be more cruel than the benefaction was generous. I am merely using
15005: strong illustrations. In the present case I am unable to take your view
15006: of the bearing which my acceptance of occupation—not enriching
15007: certainly, but not dishonorable—will have on your own position which
15008: seems to me too substantial to be affected in that shadowy manner. And
15009: though I do not believe that any change in our relations will occur
15010: (certainly none has yet occurred) which can nullify the obligations
15011: imposed on me by the past, pardon me for not seeing that those
15012: obligations should restrain me from using the ordinary freedom of
15013: living where I choose, and maintaining myself by any lawful occupation
15014: I may choose. Regretting that there exists this difference between us
15015: as to a relation in which the conferring of benefits has been entirely
15016: on your side—
15017: 
15018: 
15019: I remain, yours with persistent obligation,
15020: WILL LADISLAW.”
15021: 
15022: 
15023: Poor Mr. Casaubon felt (and must not we, being impartial, feel with him
15024: a little?) that no man had juster cause for disgust and suspicion than
15025: he. Young Ladislaw, he was sure, meant to defy and annoy him, meant to
15026: win Dorothea’s confidence and sow her mind with disrespect, and perhaps
15027: aversion, towards her husband. Some motive beneath the surface had been
15028: needed to account for Will’s sudden change of course in rejecting Mr.
15029: Casaubon’s aid and quitting his travels; and this defiant determination
15030: to fix himself in the neighborhood by taking up something so much at
15031: variance with his former choice as Mr. Brooke’s Middlemarch projects,
15032: revealed clearly enough that the undeclared motive had relation to
15033: Dorothea. Not for one moment did Mr. Casaubon suspect Dorothea of any
15034: doubleness: he had no suspicions of her, but he had (what was little
15035: less uncomfortable) the positive knowledge that her tendency to form
15036: opinions about her husband’s conduct was accompanied with a disposition
15037: to regard Will Ladislaw favorably and be influenced by what he said.
15038: His own proud reticence had prevented him from ever being undeceived in
15039: the supposition that Dorothea had originally asked her uncle to invite
15040: Will to his house.
15041: 
15042: And now, on receiving Will’s letter, Mr. Casaubon had to consider his
15043: duty. He would never have been easy to call his action anything else
15044: than duty; but in this case, contending motives thrust him back into
15045: negations.
15046: 
15047: Should he apply directly to Mr. Brooke, and demand of that troublesome
15048: gentleman to revoke his proposal? Or should he consult Sir James
15049: Chettam, and get him to concur in remonstrance against a step which
15050: touched the whole family? In either case Mr. Casaubon was aware that
15051: failure was just as probable as success. It was impossible for him to
15052: mention Dorothea’s name in the matter, and without some alarming
15053: urgency Mr. Brooke was as likely as not, after meeting all
15054: representations with apparent assent, to wind up by saying, “Never
15055: fear, Casaubon! Depend upon it, young Ladislaw will do you credit.
15056: Depend upon it, I have put my finger on the right thing.” And Mr.
15057: Casaubon shrank nervously from communicating on the subject with Sir
15058: James Chettam, between whom and himself there had never been any
15059: cordiality, and who would immediately think of Dorothea without any
15060: mention of her.
15061: 
15062: Poor Mr. Casaubon was distrustful of everybody’s feeling towards him,
15063: especially as a husband. To let any one suppose that he was jealous
15064: would be to admit their (suspected) view of his disadvantages: to let
15065: them know that he did not find marriage particularly blissful would
15066: imply his conversion to their (probably) earlier disapproval. It would
15067: be as bad as letting Carp, and Brasenose generally, know how backward
15068: he was in organizing the matter for his “Key to all Mythologies.” All
15069: through his life Mr. Casaubon had been trying not to admit even to
15070: himself the inward sores of self-doubt and jealousy. And on the most
15071: delicate of all personal subjects, the habit of proud suspicious
15072: reticence told doubly.
15073: 
15074: Thus Mr. Casaubon remained proudly, bitterly silent. But he had
15075: forbidden Will to come to Lowick Manor, and he was mentally preparing
15076: other measures of frustration.
15077: 
15078: 
15079: 
15080: 
15081: CHAPTER XXXVIII.
15082: 
15083: “C’est beaucoup que le jugement des hommes sur les actions humaines;
15084: tôt ou tard il devient efficace.”—GUIZOT.
15085: 
15086: 
15087: Sir James Chettam could not look with any satisfaction on Mr. Brooke’s
15088: new courses; but it was easier to object than to hinder. Sir James
15089: accounted for his having come in alone one day to lunch with the
15090: Cadwalladers by saying—
15091: 
15092: “I can’t talk to you as I want, before Celia: it might hurt her.
15093: Indeed, it would not be right.”
15094: 
15095: “I know what you mean—the ‘Pioneer’ at the Grange!” darted in Mrs.
15096: Cadwallader, almost before the last word was off her friend’s tongue.
15097: “It is frightful—this taking to buying whistles and blowing them in
15098: everybody’s hearing. Lying in bed all day and playing at dominoes, like
15099: poor Lord Plessy, would be more private and bearable.”
15100: 
15101: “I see they are beginning to attack our friend Brooke in the
15102: ‘Trumpet,’” said the Rector, lounging back and smiling easily, as he
15103: would have done if he had been attacked himself. “There are tremendous
15104: sarcasms against a landlord not a hundred miles from Middlemarch, who
15105: receives his own rents, and makes no returns.”
15106: 
15107: “I do wish Brooke would leave that off,” said Sir James, with his
15108: little frown of annoyance.
15109: 
15110: “Is he really going to be put in nomination, though?” said Mr.
15111: Cadwallader. “I saw Farebrother yesterday—he’s Whiggish himself, hoists
15112: Brougham and Useful Knowledge; that’s the worst I know of him;—and he
15113: says that Brooke is getting up a pretty strong party. Bulstrode, the
15114: banker, is his foremost man. But he thinks Brooke would come off badly
15115: at a nomination.”
15116: 
15117: “Exactly,” said Sir James, with earnestness. “I have been inquiring
15118: into the thing, for I’ve never known anything about Middlemarch
15119: politics before—the county being my business. What Brooke trusts to, is
15120: that they are going to turn out Oliver because he is a Peelite. But
15121: Hawley tells me that if they send up a Whig at all it is sure to be
15122: Bagster, one of those candidates who come from heaven knows where, but
15123: dead against Ministers, and an experienced Parliamentary man. Hawley’s
15124: rather rough: he forgot that he was speaking to me. He said if Brooke
15125: wanted a pelting, he could get it cheaper than by going to the
15126: hustings.”
15127: 
15128: “I warned you all of it,” said Mrs. Cadwallader, waving her hands
15129: outward. “I said to Humphrey long ago, Mr. Brooke is going to make a
15130: splash in the mud. And now he has done it.”
15131: 
15132: “Well, he might have taken it into his head to marry,” said the Rector.
15133: “That would have been a graver mess than a little flirtation with
15134: politics.”
15135: 
15136: “He may do that afterwards,” said Mrs. Cadwallader—“when he has come
15137: out on the other side of the mud with an ague.”
15138: 
15139: “What I care for most is his own dignity,” said Sir James. “Of course I
15140: care the more because of the family. But he’s getting on in life now,
15141: and I don’t like to think of his exposing himself. They will be raking
15142: up everything against him.”
15143: 
15144: “I suppose it’s no use trying any persuasion,” said the Rector.
15145: “There’s such an odd mixture of obstinacy and changeableness in Brooke.
15146: Have you tried him on the subject?”
15147: 
15148: “Well, no,” said Sir James; “I feel a delicacy in appearing to dictate.
15149: But I have been talking to this young Ladislaw that Brooke is making a
15150: factotum of. Ladislaw seems clever enough for anything. I thought it as
15151: well to hear what he had to say; and he is against Brooke’s standing
15152: this time. I think he’ll turn him round: I think the nomination may be
15153: staved off.”
15154: 
15155: “I know,” said Mrs. Cadwallader, nodding. “The independent member
15156: hasn’t got his speeches well enough by heart.”
15157: 
15158: “But this Ladislaw—there again is a vexatious business,” said Sir
15159: James. “We have had him two or three times to dine at the Hall (you
15160: have met him, by the bye) as Brooke’s guest and a relation of
15161: Casaubon’s, thinking he was only on a flying visit. And now I find he’s
15162: in everybody’s mouth in Middlemarch as the editor of the ‘Pioneer.’
15163: There are stories going about him as a quill-driving alien, a foreign
15164: emissary, and what not.”
15165: 
15166: “Casaubon won’t like that,” said the Rector.
15167: 
15168: “There _is_ some foreign blood in Ladislaw,” returned Sir James. “I
15169: hope he won’t go into extreme opinions and carry Brooke on.”
15170: 
15171: “Oh, he’s a dangerous young sprig, that Mr. Ladislaw,” said Mrs.
15172: Cadwallader, “with his opera songs and his ready tongue. A sort of
15173: Byronic hero—an amorous conspirator, it strikes me. And Thomas Aquinas
15174: is not fond of him. I could see that, the day the picture was brought.”
15175: 
15176: “I don’t like to begin on the subject with Casaubon,” said Sir James.
15177: “He has more right to interfere than I. But it’s a disagreeable affair
15178: all round. What a character for anybody with decent connections to show
15179: himself in!—one of those newspaper fellows! You have only to look at
15180: Keck, who manages the ‘Trumpet.’ I saw him the other day with Hawley.
15181: His writing is sound enough, I believe, but he’s such a low fellow,
15182: that I wished he had been on the wrong side.”
15183: 
15184: “What can you expect with these peddling Middlemarch papers?” said the
15185: Rector. “I don’t suppose you could get a high style of man anywhere to
15186: be writing up interests he doesn’t really care about, and for pay that
15187: hardly keeps him in at elbows.”
15188: 
15189: “Exactly: that makes it so annoying that Brooke should have put a man
15190: who has a sort of connection with the family in a position of that
15191: kind. For my part, I think Ladislaw is rather a fool for accepting.”
15192: 
15193: “It is Aquinas’s fault,” said Mrs. Cadwallader. “Why didn’t he use his
15194: interest to get Ladislaw made an _attache_ or sent to India? That is
15195: how families get rid of troublesome sprigs.”
15196: 
15197: “There is no knowing to what lengths the mischief may go,” said Sir
15198: James, anxiously. “But if Casaubon says nothing, what can I do?”
15199: 
15200: “Oh my dear Sir James,” said the Rector, “don’t let us make too much of
15201: all this. It is likely enough to end in mere smoke. After a month or
15202: two Brooke and this Master Ladislaw will get tired of each other;
15203: Ladislaw will take wing; Brooke will sell the ‘Pioneer,’ and everything
15204: will settle down again as usual.”
15205: 
15206: “There is one good chance—that he will not like to feel his money
15207: oozing away,” said Mrs. Cadwallader. “If I knew the items of election
15208: expenses I could scare him. It’s no use plying him with wide words like
15209: Expenditure: I wouldn’t talk of phlebotomy, I would empty a pot of
15210: leeches upon him. What we good stingy people don’t like, is having our
15211: sixpences sucked away from us.”
15212: 
15213: “And he will not like having things raked up against him,” said Sir
15214: James. “There is the management of his estate. They have begun upon
15215: that already. And it really is painful for me to see. It is a nuisance
15216: under one’s very nose. I do think one is bound to do the best for one’s
15217: land and tenants, especially in these hard times.”
15218: 
15219: “Perhaps the ‘Trumpet’ may rouse him to make a change, and some good
15220: may come of it all,” said the Rector. “I know I should be glad. I
15221: should hear less grumbling when my tithe is paid. I don’t know what I
15222: should do if there were not a modus in Tipton.”
15223: 
15224: “I want him to have a proper man to look after things—I want him to
15225: take on Garth again,” said Sir James. “He got rid of Garth twelve years
15226: ago, and everything has been going wrong since. I think of getting
15227: Garth to manage for me—he has made such a capital plan for my
15228: buildings; and Lovegood is hardly up to the mark. But Garth would not
15229: undertake the Tipton estate again unless Brooke left it entirely to
15230: him.”
15231: 
15232: “In the right of it too,” said the Rector. “Garth is an independent
15233: fellow: an original, simple-minded fellow. One day, when he was doing
15234: some valuation for me, he told me point-blank that clergymen seldom
15235: understood anything about business, and did mischief when they meddled;
15236: but he said it as quietly and respectfully as if he had been talking to
15237: me about sailors. He would make a different parish of Tipton, if Brooke
15238: would let him manage. I wish, by the help of the ‘Trumpet,’ you could
15239: bring that round.”
15240: 
15241: “If Dorothea had kept near her uncle, there would have been some
15242: chance,” said Sir James. “She might have got some power over him in
15243: time, and she was always uneasy about the estate. She had wonderfully
15244: good notions about such things. But now Casaubon takes her up entirely.
15245: Celia complains a good deal. We can hardly get her to dine with us,
15246: since he had that fit.” Sir James ended with a look of pitying disgust,
15247: and Mrs. Cadwallader shrugged her shoulders as much as to say that
15248: _she_ was not likely to see anything new in that direction.
15249: 
15250: “Poor Casaubon!” the Rector said. “That was a nasty attack. I thought
15251: he looked shattered the other day at the Archdeacon’s.”
15252: 
15253: “In point of fact,” resumed Sir James, not choosing to dwell on “fits,”
15254: “Brooke doesn’t mean badly by his tenants or any one else, but he has
15255: got that way of paring and clipping at expenses.”
15256: 
15257: “Come, that’s a blessing,” said Mrs. Cadwallader. “That helps him to
15258: find himself in a morning. He may not know his own opinions, but he
15259: does know his own pocket.”
15260: 
15261: “I don’t believe a man is in pocket by stinginess on his land,” said
15262: Sir James.
15263: 
15264: “Oh, stinginess may be abused like other virtues: it will not do to
15265: keep one’s own pigs lean,” said Mrs. Cadwallader, who had risen to look
15266: out of the window. “But talk of an independent politician and he will
15267: appear.”
15268: 
15269: “What! Brooke?” said her husband.
15270: 
15271: “Yes. Now, you ply him with the ‘Trumpet,’ Humphrey; and I will put the
15272: leeches on him. What will you do, Sir James?”
15273: 
15274: “The fact is, I don’t like to begin about it with Brooke, in our mutual
15275: position; the whole thing is so unpleasant. I do wish people would
15276: behave like gentlemen,” said the good baronet, feeling that this was a
15277: simple and comprehensive programme for social well-being.
15278: 
15279: “Here you all are, eh?” said Mr. Brooke, shuffling round and shaking
15280: hands. “I was going up to the Hall by-and-by, Chettam. But it’s
15281: pleasant to find everybody, you know. Well, what do you think of
15282: things?—going on a little fast! It was true enough, what Lafitte
15283: said—‘Since yesterday, a century has passed away:’—they’re in the next
15284: century, you know, on the other side of the water. Going on faster than
15285: we are.”
15286: 
15287: “Why, yes,” said the Rector, taking up the newspaper. “Here is the
15288: ‘Trumpet’ accusing you of lagging behind—did you see?”
15289: 
15290: “Eh? no,” said Mr. Brooke, dropping his gloves into his hat and hastily
15291: adjusting his eye-glass. But Mr. Cadwallader kept the paper in his
15292: hand, saying, with a smile in his eyes—
15293: 
15294: “Look here! all this is about a landlord not a hundred miles from
15295: Middlemarch, who receives his own rents. They say he is the most
15296: retrogressive man in the county. I think you must have taught them that
15297: word in the ‘Pioneer.’”
15298: 
15299: “Oh, that is Keck—an illiterate fellow, you know. Retrogressive, now!
15300: Come, that’s capital. He thinks it means destructive: they want to make
15301: me out a destructive, you know,” said Mr. Brooke, with that
15302: cheerfulness which is usually sustained by an adversary’s ignorance.
15303: 
15304: “I think he knows the meaning of the word. Here is a sharp stroke or
15305: two. _If we had to describe a man who is retrogressive in the most evil
15306: sense of the word—we should say, he is one who would dub himself a
15307: reformer of our constitution, while every interest for which he is
15308: immediately responsible is going to decay: a philanthropist who cannot
15309: bear one rogue to be hanged, but does not mind five honest tenants
15310: being half-starved: a man who shrieks at corruption, and keeps his
15311: farms at rack-rent: who roars himself red at rotten boroughs, and does
15312: not mind if every field on his farms has a rotten gate: a man very
15313: open-hearted to Leeds and Manchester, no doubt; he would give any
15314: number of representatives who will pay for their seats out of their own
15315: pockets: what he objects to giving, is a little return on rent-days to
15316: help a tenant to buy stock, or an outlay on repairs to keep the weather
15317: out at a tenant’s barn-door or make his house look a little less like
15318: an Irish cottier’s. But we all know the wag’s definition of a
15319: philanthropist: a man whose charity increases directly as the square of
15320: the distance._ And so on. All the rest is to show what sort of
15321: legislator a philanthropist is likely to make,” ended the Rector,
15322: throwing down the paper, and clasping his hands at the back of his
15323: head, while he looked at Mr. Brooke with an air of amused neutrality.
15324: 
15325: “Come, that’s rather good, you know,” said Mr. Brooke, taking up the
15326: paper and trying to bear the attack as easily as his neighbor did, but
15327: coloring and smiling rather nervously; “that about roaring himself red
15328: at rotten boroughs—I never made a speech about rotten boroughs in my
15329: life. And as to roaring myself red and that kind of thing—these men
15330: never understand what is good satire. Satire, you know, should be true
15331: up to a certain point. I recollect they said that in ‘The Edinburgh’
15332: somewhere—it must be true up to a certain point.”
15333: 
15334: “Well, that is really a hit about the gates,” said Sir James, anxious
15335: to tread carefully. “Dagley complained to me the other day that he
15336: hadn’t got a decent gate on his farm. Garth has invented a new pattern
15337: of gate—I wish you would try it. One ought to use some of one’s timber
15338: in that way.”
15339: 
15340: “You go in for fancy farming, you know, Chettam,” said Mr. Brooke,
15341: appearing to glance over the columns of the “Trumpet.” “That’s your
15342: hobby, and you don’t mind the expense.”
15343: 
15344: “I thought the most expensive hobby in the world was standing for
15345: Parliament,” said Mrs. Cadwallader. “They said the last unsuccessful
15346: candidate at Middlemarch—Giles, wasn’t his name?—spent ten thousand
15347: pounds and failed because he did not bribe enough. What a bitter
15348: reflection for a man!”
15349: 
15350: “Somebody was saying,” said the Rector, laughingly, “that East Retford
15351: was nothing to Middlemarch, for bribery.”
15352: 
15353: “Nothing of the kind,” said Mr. Brooke. “The Tories bribe, you know:
15354: Hawley and his set bribe with treating, hot codlings, and that sort of
15355: thing; and they bring the voters drunk to the poll. But they are not
15356: going to have it their own way in future—not in future, you know.
15357: Middlemarch is a little backward, I admit—the freemen are a little
15358: backward. But we shall educate them—we shall bring them on, you know.
15359: The best people there are on our side.”
15360: 
15361: “Hawley says you have men on your side who will do you harm,” remarked
15362: Sir James. “He says Bulstrode the banker will do you harm.”
15363: 
15364: “And that if you got pelted,” interposed Mrs. Cadwallader, “half the
15365: rotten eggs would mean hatred of your committee-man. Good heavens!
15366: Think what it must be to be pelted for wrong opinions. And I seem to
15367: remember a story of a man they pretended to chair and let him fall into
15368: a dust-heap on purpose!”
15369: 
15370: “Pelting is nothing to their finding holes in one’s coat,” said the
15371: Rector. “I confess that’s what I should be afraid of, if we parsons had
15372: to stand at the hustings for preferment. I should be afraid of their
15373: reckoning up all my fishing days. Upon my word, I think the truth is
15374: the hardest missile one can be pelted with.”
15375: 
15376: “The fact is,” said Sir James, “if a man goes into public life he must
15377: be prepared for the consequences. He must make himself proof against
15378: calumny.”
15379: 
15380: “My dear Chettam, that is all very fine, you know,” said Mr. Brooke.
15381: “But how will you make yourself proof against calumny? You should read
15382: history—look at ostracism, persecution, martyrdom, and that kind of
15383: thing. They always happen to the best men, you know. But what is that
15384: in Horace?—_fiat justitia, ruat_ … something or other.”
15385: 
15386: “Exactly,” said Sir James, with a little more heat than usual. “What I
15387: mean by being proof against calumny is being able to point to the fact
15388: as a contradiction.”
15389: 
15390: “And it is not martyrdom to pay bills that one has run into one’s
15391: self,” said Mrs. Cadwallader.
15392: 
15393: But it was Sir James’s evident annoyance that most stirred Mr. Brooke.
15394: “Well, you know, Chettam,” he said, rising, taking up his hat and
15395: leaning on his stick, “you and I have a different system. You are all
15396: for outlay with your farms. I don’t want to make out that my system is
15397: good under all circumstances—under all circumstances, you know.”
15398: 
15399: “There ought to be a new valuation made from time to time,” said Sir
15400: James. “Returns are very well occasionally, but I like a fair
15401: valuation. What do you say, Cadwallader?”
15402: 
15403: “I agree with you. If I were Brooke, I would choke the ‘Trumpet’ at
15404: once by getting Garth to make a new valuation of the farms, and giving
15405: him _carte blanche_ about gates and repairs: that’s my view of the
15406: political situation,” said the Rector, broadening himself by sticking
15407: his thumbs in his armholes, and laughing towards Mr. Brooke.
15408: 
15409: “That’s a showy sort of thing to do, you know,” said Mr. Brooke. “But I
15410: should like you to tell me of another landlord who has distressed his
15411: tenants for arrears as little as I have. I let the old tenants stay on.
15412: I’m uncommonly easy, let me tell you, uncommonly easy. I have my own
15413: ideas, and I take my stand on them, you know. A man who does that is
15414: always charged with eccentricity, inconsistency, and that kind of
15415: thing. When I change my line of action, I shall follow my own ideas.”
15416: 
15417: After that, Mr. Brooke remembered that there was a packet which he had
15418: omitted to send off from the Grange, and he bade everybody hurriedly
15419: good-by.
15420: 
15421: “I didn’t want to take a liberty with Brooke,” said Sir James; “I see
15422: he is nettled. But as to what he says about old tenants, in point of
15423: fact no new tenant would take the farms on the present terms.”
15424: 
15425: “I have a notion that he will be brought round in time,” said the
15426: Rector. “But you were pulling one way, Elinor, and we were pulling
15427: another. You wanted to frighten him away from expense, and we want to
15428: frighten him into it. Better let him try to be popular and see that his
15429: character as a landlord stands in his way. I don’t think it signifies
15430: two straws about the ‘Pioneer,’ or Ladislaw, or Brooke’s speechifying
15431: to the Middlemarchers. But it does signify about the parishioners in
15432: Tipton being comfortable.”
15433: 
15434: “Excuse me, it is you two who are on the wrong tack,” said Mrs.
15435: Cadwallader. “You should have proved to him that he loses money by bad
15436: management, and then we should all have pulled together. If you put him
15437: a-horseback on politics, I warn you of the consequences. It was all
15438: very well to ride on sticks at home and call them ideas.”
15439: 
15440: 
15441: 
15442: 
15443: CHAPTER XXXIX.
15444: 
15445: “If, as I have, you also doe,
15446:     Vertue attired in woman see,
15447: And dare love that, and say so too,
15448:     And forget the He and She;
15449: 
15450: And if this love, though placed so,
15451:     From prophane men you hide,
15452: Which will no faith on this bestow,
15453:     Or, if they doe, deride:
15454: 
15455: Then you have done a braver thing
15456:     Than all the Worthies did,
15457: And a braver thence will spring,
15458:     Which is, to keep that hid.”
15459: —DR. DONNE.
15460: 
15461: 
15462: Sir James Chettam’s mind was not fruitful in devices, but his growing
15463: anxiety to “act on Brooke,” once brought close to his constant belief
15464: in Dorothea’s capacity for influence, became formative, and issued in a
15465: little plan; namely, to plead Celia’s indisposition as a reason for
15466: fetching Dorothea by herself to the Hall, and to leave her at the
15467: Grange with the carriage on the way, after making her fully aware of
15468: the situation concerning the management of the estate.
15469: 
15470: In this way it happened that one day near four o’clock, when Mr. Brooke
15471: and Ladislaw were seated in the library, the door opened and Mrs.
15472: Casaubon was announced.
15473: 
15474: Will, the moment before, had been low in the depths of boredom, and,
15475: obliged to help Mr. Brooke in arranging “documents” about hanging
15476: sheep-stealers, was exemplifying the power our minds have of riding
15477: several horses at once by inwardly arranging measures towards getting a
15478: lodging for himself in Middlemarch and cutting short his constant
15479: residence at the Grange; while there flitted through all these steadier
15480: images a tickling vision of a sheep-stealing epic written with Homeric
15481: particularity. When Mrs. Casaubon was announced he started up as from
15482: an electric shock, and felt a tingling at his finger-ends. Any one
15483: observing him would have seen a change in his complexion, in the
15484: adjustment of his facial muscles, in the vividness of his glance, which
15485: might have made them imagine that every molecule in his body had passed
15486: the message of a magic touch. And so it had. For effective magic is
15487: transcendent nature; and who shall measure the subtlety of those
15488: touches which convey the quality of soul as well as body, and make a
15489: man’s passion for one woman differ from his passion for another as joy
15490: in the morning light over valley and river and white mountain-top
15491: differs from joy among Chinese lanterns and glass panels? Will, too,
15492: was made of very impressible stuff. The bow of a violin drawn near him
15493: cleverly, would at one stroke change the aspect of the world for him,
15494: and his point of view shifted as easily as his mood. Dorothea’s
15495: entrance was the freshness of morning.
15496: 
15497: “Well, my dear, this is pleasant, now,” said Mr. Brooke, meeting and
15498: kissing her. “You have left Casaubon with his books, I suppose. That’s
15499: right. We must not have you getting too learned for a woman, you know.”
15500: 
15501: “There is no fear of that, uncle,” said Dorothea, turning to Will and
15502: shaking hands with open cheerfulness, while she made no other form of
15503: greeting, but went on answering her uncle. “I am very slow. When I want
15504: to be busy with books, I am often playing truant among my thoughts. I
15505: find it is not so easy to be learned as to plan cottages.”
15506: 
15507: She seated herself beside her uncle opposite to Will, and was evidently
15508: preoccupied with something that made her almost unmindful of him. He
15509: was ridiculously disappointed, as if he had imagined that her coming
15510: had anything to do with him.
15511: 
15512: “Why, yes, my dear, it was quite your hobby to draw plans. But it was
15513: good to break that off a little. Hobbies are apt to run away with us,
15514: you know; it doesn’t do to be run away with. We must keep the reins. I
15515: have never let myself be run away with; I always pulled up. That is
15516: what I tell Ladislaw. He and I are alike, you know: he likes to go into
15517: everything. We are working at capital punishment. We shall do a great
15518: deal together, Ladislaw and I.”
15519: 
15520: “Yes,” said Dorothea, with characteristic directness, “Sir James has
15521: been telling me that he is in hope of seeing a great change made soon
15522: in your management of the estate—that you are thinking of having the
15523: farms valued, and repairs made, and the cottages improved, so that
15524: Tipton may look quite another place. Oh, how happy!”—she went on,
15525: clasping her hands, with a return to that more childlike impetuous
15526: manner, which had been subdued since her marriage. “If I were at home
15527: still, I should take to riding again, that I might go about with you
15528: and see all that! And you are going to engage Mr. Garth, who praised my
15529: cottages, Sir James says.”
15530: 
15531: “Chettam is a little hasty, my dear,” said Mr. Brooke, coloring
15532: slightly; “a little hasty, you know. I never said I should do anything
15533: of the kind. I never said I should _not_ do it, you know.”
15534: 
15535: “He only feels confident that you will do it,” said Dorothea, in a
15536: voice as clear and unhesitating as that of a young chorister chanting a
15537: credo, “because you mean to enter Parliament as a member who cares for
15538: the improvement of the people, and one of the first things to be made
15539: better is the state of the land and the laborers. Think of Kit Downes,
15540: uncle, who lives with his wife and seven children in a house with one
15541: sitting room and one bedroom hardly larger than this table!—and those
15542: poor Dagleys, in their tumble-down farmhouse, where they live in the
15543: back kitchen and leave the other rooms to the rats! That is one reason
15544: why I did not like the pictures here, dear uncle—which you think me
15545: stupid about. I used to come from the village with all that dirt and
15546: coarse ugliness like a pain within me, and the simpering pictures in
15547: the drawing-room seemed to me like a wicked attempt to find delight in
15548: what is false, while we don’t mind how hard the truth is for the
15549: neighbors outside our walls. I think we have no right to come forward
15550: and urge wider changes for good, until we have tried to alter the evils
15551: which lie under our own hands.”
15552: 
15553: Dorothea had gathered emotion as she went on, and had forgotten
15554: everything except the relief of pouring forth her feelings, unchecked:
15555: an experience once habitual with her, but hardly ever present since her
15556: marriage, which had been a perpetual struggle of energy with fear. For
15557: the moment, Will’s admiration was accompanied with a chilling sense of
15558: remoteness. A man is seldom ashamed of feeling that he cannot love a
15559: woman so well when he sees a certain greatness in her: nature having
15560: intended greatness for men. But nature has sometimes made sad
15561: oversights in carrying out her intention; as in the case of good Mr.
15562: Brooke, whose masculine consciousness was at this moment in rather a
15563: stammering condition under the eloquence of his niece. He could not
15564: immediately find any other mode of expressing himself than that of
15565: rising, fixing his eye-glass, and fingering the papers before him. At
15566: last he said—
15567: 
15568: “There is something in what you say, my dear, something in what you
15569: say—but not everything—eh, Ladislaw? You and I don’t like our pictures
15570: and statues being found fault with. Young ladies are a little ardent,
15571: you know—a little one-sided, my dear. Fine art, poetry, that kind of
15572: thing, elevates a nation—_emollit mores_—you understand a little Latin
15573: now. But—eh? what?”
15574: 
15575: These interrogatives were addressed to the footman who had come in to
15576: say that the keeper had found one of Dagley’s boys with a leveret in
15577: his hand just killed.
15578: 
15579: “I’ll come, I’ll come. I shall let him off easily, you know,” said Mr.
15580: Brooke aside to Dorothea, shuffling away very cheerfully.
15581: 
15582: “I hope you feel how right this change is that I—that Sir James wishes
15583: for,” said Dorothea to Will, as soon as her uncle was gone.
15584: 
15585: “I do, now I have heard you speak about it. I shall not forget what you
15586: have said. But can you think of something else at this moment? I may
15587: not have another opportunity of speaking to you about what has
15588: occurred,” said Will, rising with a movement of impatience, and holding
15589: the back of his chair with both hands.
15590: 
15591: “Pray tell me what it is,” said Dorothea, anxiously, also rising and
15592: going to the open window, where Monk was looking in, panting and
15593: wagging his tail. She leaned her back against the window-frame, and
15594: laid her hand on the dog’s head; for though, as we know, she was not
15595: fond of pets that must be held in the hands or trodden on, she was
15596: always attentive to the feelings of dogs, and very polite if she had to
15597: decline their advances.
15598: 
15599: Will followed her only with his eyes and said, “I presume you know that
15600: Mr. Casaubon has forbidden me to go to his house.”
15601: 
15602: “No, I did not,” said Dorothea, after a moment’s pause. She was
15603: evidently much moved. “I am very, very sorry,” she added, mournfully.
15604: She was thinking of what Will had no knowledge of—the conversation
15605: between her and her husband in the darkness; and she was anew smitten
15606: with hopelessness that she could influence Mr. Casaubon’s action. But
15607: the marked expression of her sorrow convinced Will that it was not all
15608: given to him personally, and that Dorothea had not been visited by the
15609: idea that Mr. Casaubon’s dislike and jealousy of him turned upon
15610: herself. He felt an odd mixture of delight and vexation: of delight
15611: that he could dwell and be cherished in her thought as in a pure home,
15612: without suspicion and without stint—of vexation because he was of too
15613: little account with her, was not formidable enough, was treated with an
15614: unhesitating benevolence which did not flatter him. But his dread of
15615: any change in Dorothea was stronger than his discontent, and he began
15616: to speak again in a tone of mere explanation.
15617: 
15618: “Mr. Casaubon’s reason is, his displeasure at my taking a position here
15619: which he considers unsuited to my rank as his cousin. I have told him
15620: that I cannot give way on this point. It is a little too hard on me to
15621: expect that my course in life is to be hampered by prejudices which I
15622: think ridiculous. Obligation may be stretched till it is no better than
15623: a brand of slavery stamped on us when we were too young to know its
15624: meaning. I would not have accepted the position if I had not meant to
15625: make it useful and honorable. I am not bound to regard family dignity
15626: in any other light.”
15627: 
15628: Dorothea felt wretched. She thought her husband altogether in the
15629: wrong, on more grounds than Will had mentioned.
15630: 
15631: “It is better for us not to speak on the subject,” she said, with a
15632: tremulousness not common in her voice, “since you and Mr. Casaubon
15633: disagree. You intend to remain?” She was looking out on the lawn, with
15634: melancholy meditation.
15635: 
15636: “Yes; but I shall hardly ever see you now,” said Will, in a tone of
15637: almost boyish complaint.
15638: 
15639: “No,” said Dorothea, turning her eyes full upon him, “hardly ever. But
15640: I shall hear of you. I shall know what you are doing for my uncle.”
15641: 
15642: “I shall know hardly anything about you,” said Will. “No one will tell
15643: me anything.”
15644: 
15645: “Oh, my life is very simple,” said Dorothea, her lips curling with an
15646: exquisite smile, which irradiated her melancholy. “I am always at
15647: Lowick.”
15648: 
15649: “That is a dreadful imprisonment,” said Will, impetuously.
15650: 
15651: “No, don’t think that,” said Dorothea. “I have no longings.”
15652: 
15653: He did not speak, but she replied to some change in his expression. “I
15654: mean, for myself. Except that I should like not to have so much more
15655: than my share without doing anything for others. But I have a belief of
15656: my own, and it comforts me.”
15657: 
15658: “What is that?” said Will, rather jealous of the belief.
15659: 
15660: “That by desiring what is perfectly good, even when we don’t quite know
15661: what it is and cannot do what we would, we are part of the divine power
15662: against evil—widening the skirts of light and making the struggle with
15663: darkness narrower.”
15664: 
15665: “That is a beautiful mysticism—it is a—”
15666: 
15667: “Please not to call it by any name,” said Dorothea, putting out her
15668: hands entreatingly. “You will say it is Persian, or something else
15669: geographical. It is my life. I have found it out, and cannot part with
15670: it. I have always been finding out my religion since I was a little
15671: girl. I used to pray so much—now I hardly ever pray. I try not to have
15672: desires merely for myself, because they may not be good for others, and
15673: I have too much already. I only told you, that you might know quite
15674: well how my days go at Lowick.”
15675: 
15676: “God bless you for telling me!” said Will, ardently, and rather
15677: wondering at himself. They were looking at each other like two fond
15678: children who were talking confidentially of birds.
15679: 
15680: “What is _your_ religion?” said Dorothea. “I mean—not what you know
15681: about religion, but the belief that helps you most?”
15682: 
15683: “To love what is good and beautiful when I see it,” said Will. “But I
15684: am a rebel: I don’t feel bound, as you do, to submit to what I don’t
15685: like.”
15686: 
15687: “But if you like what is good, that comes to the same thing,” said
15688: Dorothea, smiling.
15689: 
15690: “Now you are subtle,” said Will.
15691: 
15692: “Yes; Mr. Casaubon often says I am too subtle. I don’t feel as if I
15693: were subtle,” said Dorothea, playfully. “But how long my uncle is! I
15694: must go and look for him. I must really go on to the Hall. Celia is
15695: expecting me.”
15696: 
15697: Will offered to tell Mr. Brooke, who presently came and said that he
15698: would step into the carriage and go with Dorothea as far as Dagley’s,
15699: to speak about the small delinquent who had been caught with the
15700: leveret. Dorothea renewed the subject of the estate as they drove
15701: along, but Mr. Brooke, not being taken unawares, got the talk under his
15702: own control.
15703: 
15704: “Chettam, now,” he replied; “he finds fault with me, my dear; but I
15705: should not preserve my game if it were not for Chettam, and he can’t
15706: say that that expense is for the sake of the tenants, you know. It’s a
15707: little against my feeling:—poaching, now, if you come to look into it—I
15708: have often thought of getting up the subject. Not long ago, Flavell,
15709: the Methodist preacher, was brought up for knocking down a hare that
15710: came across his path when he and his wife were walking out together. He
15711: was pretty quick, and knocked it on the neck.”
15712: 
15713: “That was very brutal, I think,” said Dorothea.
15714: 
15715: “Well, now, it seemed rather black to me, I confess, in a Methodist
15716: preacher, you know. And Johnson said, ‘You may judge what a hypo_crite_
15717: he is.’ And upon my word, I thought Flavell looked very little like
15718: ‘the highest style of man’—as somebody calls the Christian—Young, the
15719: poet Young, I think—you know Young? Well, now, Flavell in his shabby
15720: black gaiters, pleading that he thought the Lord had sent him and his
15721: wife a good dinner, and he had a right to knock it down, though not a
15722: mighty hunter before the Lord, as Nimrod was—I assure you it was rather
15723: comic: Fielding would have made something of it—or Scott, now—Scott
15724: might have worked it up. But really, when I came to think of it, I
15725: couldn’t help liking that the fellow should have a bit of hare to say
15726: grace over. It’s all a matter of prejudice—prejudice with the law on
15727: its side, you know—about the stick and the gaiters, and so on. However,
15728: it doesn’t do to reason about things; and law is law. But I got Johnson
15729: to be quiet, and I hushed the matter up. I doubt whether Chettam would
15730: not have been more severe, and yet he comes down on me as if I were the
15731: hardest man in the county. But here we are at Dagley’s.”
15732: 
15733: Mr. Brooke got down at a farmyard-gate, and Dorothea drove on. It is
15734: wonderful how much uglier things will look when we only suspect that we
15735: are blamed for them. Even our own persons in the glass are apt to
15736: change their aspect for us after we have heard some frank remark on
15737: their less admirable points; and on the other hand it is astonishing
15738: how pleasantly conscience takes our encroachments on those who never
15739: complain or have nobody to complain for them. Dagley’s homestead never
15740: before looked so dismal to Mr. Brooke as it did today, with his mind
15741: thus sore about the fault-finding of the “Trumpet,” echoed by Sir
15742: James.
15743: 
15744: It is true that an observer, under that softening influence of the fine
15745: arts which makes other people’s hardships picturesque, might have been
15746: delighted with this homestead called Freeman’s End: the old house had
15747: dormer-windows in the dark red roof, two of the chimneys were choked
15748: with ivy, the large porch was blocked up with bundles of sticks, and
15749: half the windows were closed with gray worm-eaten shutters about which
15750: the jasmine-boughs grew in wild luxuriance; the mouldering garden wall
15751: with hollyhocks peeping over it was a perfect study of highly mingled
15752: subdued color, and there was an aged goat (kept doubtless on
15753: interesting superstitious grounds) lying against the open back-kitchen
15754: door. The mossy thatch of the cow-shed, the broken gray barn-doors, the
15755: pauper laborers in ragged breeches who had nearly finished unloading a
15756: wagon of corn into the barn ready for early thrashing; the scanty dairy
15757: of cows being tethered for milking and leaving one half of the shed in
15758: brown emptiness; the very pigs and white ducks seeming to wander about
15759: the uneven neglected yard as if in low spirits from feeding on a too
15760: meagre quality of rinsings,—all these objects under the quiet light of
15761: a sky marbled with high clouds would have made a sort of picture which
15762: we have all paused over as a “charming bit,” touching other
15763: sensibilities than those which are stirred by the depression of the
15764: agricultural interest, with the sad lack of farming capital, as seen
15765: constantly in the newspapers of that time. But these troublesome
15766: associations were just now strongly present to Mr. Brooke, and spoiled
15767: the scene for him. Mr. Dagley himself made a figure in the landscape,
15768: carrying a pitchfork and wearing his milking-hat—a very old beaver
15769: flattened in front. His coat and breeches were the best he had, and he
15770: would not have been wearing them on this weekday occasion if he had not
15771: been to market and returned later than usual, having given himself the
15772: rare treat of dining at the public table of the Blue Bull. How he came
15773: to fall into this extravagance would perhaps be matter of wonderment to
15774: himself on the morrow; but before dinner something in the state of the
15775: country, a slight pause in the harvest before the Far Dips were cut,
15776: the stories about the new King and the numerous handbills on the walls,
15777: had seemed to warrant a little recklessness. It was a maxim about
15778: Middlemarch, and regarded as self-evident, that good meat should have
15779: good drink, which last Dagley interpreted as plenty of table ale well
15780: followed up by rum-and-water. These liquors have so far truth in them
15781: that they were not false enough to make poor Dagley seem merry: they
15782: only made his discontent less tongue-tied than usual. He had also taken
15783: too much in the shape of muddy political talk, a stimulant dangerously
15784: disturbing to his farming conservatism, which consisted in holding that
15785: whatever is, is bad, and any change is likely to be worse. He was
15786: flushed, and his eyes had a decidedly quarrelsome stare as he stood
15787: still grasping his pitchfork, while the landlord approached with his
15788: easy shuffling walk, one hand in his trouser-pocket and the other
15789: swinging round a thin walking-stick.
15790: 
15791: “Dagley, my good fellow,” began Mr. Brooke, conscious that he was going
15792: to be very friendly about the boy.
15793: 
15794: “Oh, ay, I’m a good feller, am I? Thank ye, sir, thank ye,” said
15795: Dagley, with a loud snarling irony which made Fag the sheep-dog stir
15796: from his seat and prick his ears; but seeing Monk enter the yard after
15797: some outside loitering, Fag seated himself again in an attitude of
15798: observation. “I’m glad to hear I’m a good feller.”
15799: 
15800: Mr. Brooke reflected that it was market-day, and that his worthy tenant
15801: had probably been dining, but saw no reason why he should not go on,
15802: since he could take the precaution of repeating what he had to say to
15803: Mrs. Dagley.
15804: 
15805: “Your little lad Jacob has been caught killing a leveret, Dagley: I
15806: have told Johnson to lock him up in the empty stable an hour or two,
15807: just to frighten him, you know. But he will be brought home by-and-by,
15808: before night: and you’ll just look after him, will you, and give him a
15809: reprimand, you know?”
15810: 
15811: “No, I woon’t: I’ll be dee’d if I’ll leather my boy to please you or
15812: anybody else, not if you was twenty landlords istid o’ one, and that a
15813: bad un.”
15814: 
15815: Dagley’s words were loud enough to summon his wife to the back-kitchen
15816: door—the only entrance ever used, and one always open except in bad
15817: weather—and Mr. Brooke, saying soothingly, “Well, well, I’ll speak to
15818: your wife—I didn’t mean beating, you know,” turned to walk to the
15819: house. But Dagley, only the more inclined to “have his say” with a
15820: gentleman who walked away from him, followed at once, with Fag
15821: slouching at his heels and sullenly evading some small and probably
15822: charitable advances on the part of Monk.
15823: 
15824: “How do you do, Mrs. Dagley?” said Mr. Brooke, making some haste. “I
15825: came to tell you about your boy: I don’t want you to give him the
15826: stick, you know.” He was careful to speak quite plainly this time.
15827: 
15828: Overworked Mrs. Dagley—a thin, worn woman, from whose life pleasure had
15829: so entirely vanished that she had not even any Sunday clothes which
15830: could give her satisfaction in preparing for church—had already had a
15831: misunderstanding with her husband since he had come home, and was in
15832: low spirits, expecting the worst. But her husband was beforehand in
15833: answering.
15834: 
15835: “No, nor he woon’t hev the stick, whether you want it or no,” pursued
15836: Dagley, throwing out his voice, as if he wanted it to hit hard. “You’ve
15837: got no call to come an’ talk about sticks o’ these primises, as you
15838: woon’t give a stick tow’rt mending. Go to Middlemarch to ax for _your_
15839: charrickter.”
15840: 
15841: “You’d far better hold your tongue, Dagley,” said the wife, “and not
15842: kick your own trough over. When a man as is father of a family has been
15843: an’ spent money at market and made himself the worse for liquor, he’s
15844: done enough mischief for one day. But I should like to know what my
15845: boy’s done, sir.”
15846: 
15847: “Niver do you mind what he’s done,” said Dagley, more fiercely, “it’s
15848: my business to speak, an’ not yourn. An’ I wull speak, too. I’ll hev my
15849: say—supper or no. An’ what I say is, as I’ve lived upo’ your ground
15850: from my father and grandfather afore me, an’ hev dropped our money
15851: into’t, an’ me an’ my children might lie an’ rot on the ground for
15852: top-dressin’ as we can’t find the money to buy, if the King wasn’t to
15853: put a stop.”
15854: 
15855: “My good fellow, you’re drunk, you know,” said Mr. Brooke,
15856: confidentially but not judiciously. “Another day, another day,” he
15857: added, turning as if to go.
15858: 
15859: But Dagley immediately fronted him, and Fag at his heels growled low,
15860: as his master’s voice grew louder and more insulting, while Monk also
15861: drew close in silent dignified watch. The laborers on the wagon were
15862: pausing to listen, and it seemed wiser to be quite passive than to
15863: attempt a ridiculous flight pursued by a bawling man.
15864: 
15865: “I’m no more drunk nor you are, nor so much,” said Dagley. “I can carry
15866: my liquor, an’ I know what I meean. An’ I meean as the King ’ull put a
15867: stop to ’t, for them say it as knows it, as there’s to be a Rinform,
15868: and them landlords as never done the right thing by their tenants ’ull
15869: be treated i’ that way as they’ll hev to scuttle off. An’ there’s them
15870: i’ Middlemarch knows what the Rinform is—an’ as knows who’ll hev to
15871: scuttle. Says they, ‘I know who _your_ landlord is.’ An’ says I, ‘I
15872: hope you’re the better for knowin’ him, I arn’t.’ Says they, ‘He’s a
15873: close-fisted un.’ ‘Ay ay,’ says I. ‘He’s a man for the Rinform,’ says
15874: they. That’s what they says. An’ I made out what the Rinform were—an’
15875: it were to send you an’ your likes a-scuttlin’ an’ wi’ pretty
15876: strong-smellin’ things too. An’ you may do as you like now, for I’m
15877: none afeard on you. An’ you’d better let my boy aloan, an’ look to
15878: yoursen, afore the Rinform has got upo’ your back. That’s what I’n got
15879: to say,” concluded Mr. Dagley, striking his fork into the ground with a
15880: firmness which proved inconvenient as he tried to draw it up again.
15881: 
15882: At this last action Monk began to bark loudly, and it was a moment for
15883: Mr. Brooke to escape. He walked out of the yard as quickly as he could,
15884: in some amazement at the novelty of his situation. He had never been
15885: insulted on his own land before, and had been inclined to regard
15886: himself as a general favorite (we are all apt to do so, when we think
15887: of our own amiability more than of what other people are likely to want
15888: of us). When he had quarrelled with Caleb Garth twelve years before he
15889: had thought that the tenants would be pleased at the landlord’s taking
15890: everything into his own hands.
15891: 
15892: Some who follow the narrative of his experience may wonder at the
15893: midnight darkness of Mr. Dagley; but nothing was easier in those times
15894: than for an hereditary farmer of his grade to be ignorant, in spite
15895: somehow of having a rector in the twin parish who was a gentleman to
15896: the backbone, a curate nearer at hand who preached more learnedly than
15897: the rector, a landlord who had gone into everything, especially fine
15898: art and social improvement, and all the lights of Middlemarch only
15899: three miles off. As to the facility with which mortals escape
15900: knowledge, try an average acquaintance in the intellectual blaze of
15901: London, and consider what that eligible person for a dinner-party would
15902: have been if he had learned scant skill in “summing” from the
15903: parish-clerk of Tipton, and read a chapter in the Bible with immense
15904: difficulty, because such names as Isaiah or Apollos remained
15905: unmanageable after twice spelling. Poor Dagley read a few verses
15906: sometimes on a Sunday evening, and the world was at least not darker to
15907: him than it had been before. Some things he knew thoroughly, namely,
15908: the slovenly habits of farming, and the awkwardness of weather, stock
15909: and crops, at Freeman’s End—so called apparently by way of sarcasm, to
15910: imply that a man was free to quit it if he chose, but that there was no
15911: earthly “beyond” open to him.
15912: 
15913: 
15914: 
15915: 
15916: CHAPTER XL.
15917: 
15918: Wise in his daily work was he:
15919:     To fruits of diligence,
15920: And not to faiths or polity,
15921:     He plied his utmost sense.
15922: These perfect in their little parts,
15923:     Whose work is all their prize—
15924: Without them how could laws, or arts,
15925:     Or towered cities rise?
15926: 
15927: 
15928: In watching effects, if only of an electric battery, it is often
15929: necessary to change our place and examine a particular mixture or group
15930: at some distance from the point where the movement we are interested in
15931: was set up. The group I am moving towards is at Caleb Garth’s
15932: breakfast-table in the large parlor where the maps and desk were:
15933: father, mother, and five of the children. Mary was just now at home
15934: waiting for a situation, while Christy, the boy next to her, was
15935: getting cheap learning and cheap fare in Scotland, having to his
15936: father’s disappointment taken to books instead of that sacred calling
15937: “business.”
15938: 
15939: The letters had come—nine costly letters, for which the postman had
15940: been paid three and twopence, and Mr. Garth was forgetting his tea and
15941: toast while he read his letters and laid them open one above the other,
15942: sometimes swaying his head slowly, sometimes screwing up his mouth in
15943: inward debate, but not forgetting to cut off a large red seal unbroken,
15944: which Letty snatched up like an eager terrier.
15945: 
15946: The talk among the rest went on unrestrainedly, for nothing disturbed
15947: Caleb’s absorption except shaking the table when he was writing.
15948: 
15949: Two letters of the nine had been for Mary. After reading them, she had
15950: passed them to her mother, and sat playing with her tea-spoon absently,
15951: till with a sudden recollection she returned to her sewing, which she
15952: had kept on her lap during breakfast.
15953: 
15954: “Oh, don’t sew, Mary!” said Ben, pulling her arm down. “Make me a
15955: peacock with this bread-crumb.” He had been kneading a small mass for
15956: the purpose.
15957: 
15958: “No, no, Mischief!” said Mary, good-humoredly, while she pricked his
15959: hand lightly with her needle. “Try and mould it yourself: you have seen
15960: me do it often enough. I must get this sewing done. It is for Rosamond
15961: Vincy: she is to be married next week, and she can’t be married without
15962: this handkerchief.” Mary ended merrily, amused with the last notion.
15963: 
15964: “Why can’t she, Mary?” said Letty, seriously interested in this
15965: mystery, and pushing her head so close to her sister that Mary now
15966: turned the threatening needle towards Letty’s nose.
15967: 
15968: “Because this is one of a dozen, and without it there would only be
15969: eleven,” said Mary, with a grave air of explanation, so that Letty sank
15970: back with a sense of knowledge.
15971: 
15972: “Have you made up your mind, my dear?” said Mrs. Garth, laying the
15973: letters down.
15974: 
15975: “I shall go to the school at York,” said Mary. “I am less unfit to
15976: teach in a school than in a family. I like to teach classes best. And,
15977: you see, I must teach: there is nothing else to be done.”
15978: 
15979: “Teaching seems to me the most delightful work in the world,” said Mrs.
15980: Garth, with a touch of rebuke in her tone. “I could understand your
15981: objection to it if you had not knowledge enough, Mary, or if you
15982: disliked children.”
15983: 
15984: “I suppose we never quite understand why another dislikes what we like,
15985: mother,” said Mary, rather curtly. “I am not fond of a schoolroom: I
15986: like the outside world better. It is a very inconvenient fault of
15987: mine.”
15988: 
15989: “It must be very stupid to be always in a girls’ school,” said Alfred.
15990: “Such a set of nincompoops, like Mrs. Ballard’s pupils walking two and
15991: two.”
15992: 
15993: “And they have no games worth playing at,” said Jim. “They can neither
15994: throw nor leap. I don’t wonder at Mary’s not liking it.”
15995: 
15996: “What is that Mary doesn’t like, eh?” said the father, looking over his
15997: spectacles and pausing before he opened his next letter.
15998: 
15999: “Being among a lot of nincompoop girls,” said Alfred.
16000: 
16001: “Is it the situation you had heard of, Mary?” said Caleb, gently,
16002: looking at his daughter.
16003: 
16004: “Yes, father: the school at York. I have determined to take it. It is
16005: quite the best. Thirty-five pounds a-year, and extra pay for teaching
16006: the smallest strummers at the piano.”
16007: 
16008: “Poor child! I wish she could stay at home with us, Susan,” said Caleb,
16009: looking plaintively at his wife.
16010: 
16011: “Mary would not be happy without doing her duty,” said Mrs. Garth,
16012: magisterially, conscious of having done her own.
16013: 
16014: “It wouldn’t make me happy to do such a nasty duty as that,” said
16015: Alfred—at which Mary and her father laughed silently, but Mrs. Garth
16016: said, gravely—
16017: 
16018: “Do find a fitter word than nasty, my dear Alfred, for everything that
16019: you think disagreeable. And suppose that Mary could help you to go to
16020: Mr. Hanmer’s with the money she gets?”
16021: 
16022: “That seems to me a great shame. But she’s an old brick,” said Alfred,
16023: rising from his chair, and pulling Mary’s head backward to kiss her.
16024: 
16025: Mary colored and laughed, but could not conceal that the tears were
16026: coming. Caleb, looking on over his spectacles, with the angles of his
16027: eyebrows falling, had an expression of mingled delight and sorrow as he
16028: returned to the opening of his letter; and even Mrs. Garth, her lips
16029: curling with a calm contentment, allowed that inappropriate language to
16030: pass without correction, although Ben immediately took it up, and sang,
16031: “She’s an old brick, old brick, old brick!” to a cantering measure,
16032: which he beat out with his fist on Mary’s arm.
16033: 
16034: But Mrs. Garth’s eyes were now drawn towards her husband, who was
16035: already deep in the letter he was reading. His face had an expression
16036: of grave surprise, which alarmed her a little, but he did not like to
16037: be questioned while he was reading, and she remained anxiously watching
16038: till she saw him suddenly shaken by a little joyous laugh as he turned
16039: back to the beginning of the letter, and looking at her above his
16040: spectacles, said, in a low tone, “What do you think, Susan?”
16041: 
16042: She went and stood behind him, putting her hand on his shoulder, while
16043: they read the letter together. It was from Sir James Chettam, offering
16044: to Mr. Garth the management of the family estates at Freshitt and
16045: elsewhere, and adding that Sir James had been requested by Mr. Brooke
16046: of Tipton to ascertain whether Mr. Garth would be disposed at the same
16047: time to resume the agency of the Tipton property. The Baronet added in
16048: very obliging words that he himself was particularly desirous of seeing
16049: the Freshitt and Tipton estates under the same management, and he hoped
16050: to be able to show that the double agency might be held on terms
16051: agreeable to Mr. Garth, whom he would be glad to see at the Hall at
16052: twelve o’clock on the following day.
16053: 
16054: “He writes handsomely, doesn’t he, Susan?” said Caleb, turning his eyes
16055: upward to his wife, who raised her hand from his shoulder to his ear,
16056: while she rested her chin on his head. “Brooke didn’t like to ask me
16057: himself, I can see,” he continued, laughing silently.
16058: 
16059: “Here is an honor to your father, children,” said Mrs. Garth, looking
16060: round at the five pair of eyes, all fixed on the parents. “He is asked
16061: to take a post again by those who dismissed him long ago. That shows
16062: that he did his work well, so that they feel the want of him.”
16063: 
16064: “Like Cincinnatus—hooray!” said Ben, riding on his chair, with a
16065: pleasant confidence that discipline was relaxed.
16066: 
16067: “Will they come to fetch him, mother?” said Letty, thinking of the
16068: Mayor and Corporation in their robes.
16069: 
16070: Mrs. Garth patted Letty’s head and smiled, but seeing that her husband
16071: was gathering up his letters and likely soon to be out of reach in that
16072: sanctuary “business,” she pressed his shoulder and said emphatically—
16073: 
16074: “Now, mind you ask fair pay, Caleb.”
16075: 
16076: “Oh yes,” said Caleb, in a deep voice of assent, as if it would be
16077: unreasonable to suppose anything else of him. “It’ll come to between
16078: four and five hundred, the two together.” Then with a little start of
16079: remembrance he said, “Mary, write and give up that school. Stay and
16080: help your mother. I’m as pleased as Punch, now I’ve thought of that.”
16081: 
16082: No manner could have been less like that of Punch triumphant than
16083: Caleb’s, but his talents did not lie in finding phrases, though he was
16084: very particular about his letter-writing, and regarded his wife as a
16085: treasury of correct language.
16086: 
16087: There was almost an uproar among the children now, and Mary held up the
16088: cambric embroidery towards her mother entreatingly, that it might be
16089: put out of reach while the boys dragged her into a dance. Mrs. Garth,
16090: in placid joy, began to put the cups and plates together, while Caleb
16091: pushing his chair from the table, as if he were going to move to the
16092: desk, still sat holding his letters in his hand and looking on the
16093: ground meditatively, stretching out the fingers of his left hand,
16094: according to a mute language of his own. At last he said—
16095: 
16096: “It’s a thousand pities Christy didn’t take to business, Susan. I shall
16097: want help by-and-by. And Alfred must go off to the engineering—I’ve
16098: made up my mind to that.” He fell into meditation and finger-rhetoric
16099: again for a little while, and then continued: “I shall make Brooke have
16100: new agreements with the tenants, and I shall draw up a rotation of
16101: crops. And I’ll lay a wager we can get fine bricks out of the clay at
16102: Bott’s corner. I must look into that: it would cheapen the repairs.
16103: It’s a fine bit of work, Susan! A man without a family would be glad to
16104: do it for nothing.”
16105: 
16106: “Mind you don’t, though,” said his wife, lifting up her finger.
16107: 
16108: “No, no; but it’s a fine thing to come to a man when he’s seen into the
16109: nature of business: to have the chance of getting a bit of the country
16110: into good fettle, as they say, and putting men into the right way with
16111: their farming, and getting a bit of good contriving and solid building
16112: done—that those who are living and those who come after will be the
16113: better for. I’d sooner have it than a fortune. I hold it the most
16114: honorable work that is.” Here Caleb laid down his letters, thrust his
16115: fingers between the buttons of his waistcoat, and sat upright, but
16116: presently proceeded with some awe in his voice and moving his head
16117: slowly aside—“It’s a great gift of God, Susan.”
16118: 
16119: “That it is, Caleb,” said his wife, with answering fervor. “And it will
16120: be a blessing to your children to have had a father who did such work:
16121: a father whose good work remains though his name may be forgotten.” She
16122: could not say any more to him then about the pay.
16123: 
16124: In the evening, when Caleb, rather tired with his day’s work, was
16125: seated in silence with his pocket-book open on his knee, while Mrs.
16126: Garth and Mary were at their sewing, and Letty in a corner was
16127: whispering a dialogue with her doll, Mr. Farebrother came up the
16128: orchard walk, dividing the bright August lights and shadows with the
16129: tufted grass and the apple-tree boughs. We know that he was fond of his
16130: parishioners the Garths, and had thought Mary worth mentioning to
16131: Lydgate. He used to the full the clergyman’s privilege of disregarding
16132: the Middlemarch discrimination of ranks, and always told his mother
16133: that Mrs. Garth was more of a lady than any matron in the town. Still,
16134: you see, he spent his evenings at the Vincys’, where the matron, though
16135: less of a lady, presided over a well-lit drawing-room and whist. In
16136: those days human intercourse was not determined solely by respect. But
16137: the Vicar did heartily respect the Garths, and a visit from him was no
16138: surprise to that family. Nevertheless he accounted for it even while he
16139: was shaking hands, by saying, “I come as an envoy, Mrs. Garth: I have
16140: something to say to you and Garth on behalf of Fred Vincy. The fact is,
16141: poor fellow,” he continued, as he seated himself and looked round with
16142: his bright glance at the three who were listening to him, “he has taken
16143: me into his confidence.”
16144: 
16145: Mary’s heart beat rather quickly: she wondered how far Fred’s
16146: confidence had gone.
16147: 
16148: “We haven’t seen the lad for months,” said Caleb. “I couldn’t think
16149: what was become of him.”
16150: 
16151: “He has been away on a visit,” said the Vicar, “because home was a
16152: little too hot for him, and Lydgate told his mother that the poor
16153: fellow must not begin to study yet. But yesterday he came and poured
16154: himself out to me. I am very glad he did, because I have seen him grow
16155: up from a youngster of fourteen, and I am so much at home in the house
16156: that the children are like nephews and nieces to me. But it is a
16157: difficult case to advise upon. However, he has asked me to come and
16158: tell you that he is going away, and that he is so miserable about his
16159: debt to you, and his inability to pay, that he can’t bear to come
16160: himself even to bid you good by.”
16161: 
16162: “Tell him it doesn’t signify a farthing,” said Caleb, waving his hand.
16163: “We’ve had the pinch and have got over it. And now I’m going to be as
16164: rich as a Jew.”
16165: 
16166: “Which means,” said Mrs. Garth, smiling at the Vicar, “that we are
16167: going to have enough to bring up the boys well and to keep Mary at
16168: home.”
16169: 
16170: “What is the treasure-trove?” said Mr. Farebrother.
16171: 
16172: “I’m going to be agent for two estates, Freshitt and Tipton; and
16173: perhaps for a pretty little bit of land in Lowick besides: it’s all the
16174: same family connection, and employment spreads like water if it’s once
16175: set going. It makes me very happy, Mr. Farebrother”—here Caleb threw
16176: back his head a little, and spread his arms on the elbows of his
16177: chair—“that I’ve got an opportunity again with the letting of the land,
16178: and carrying out a notion or two with improvements. It’s a most
16179: uncommonly cramping thing, as I’ve often told Susan, to sit on
16180: horseback and look over the hedges at the wrong thing, and not be able
16181: to put your hand to it to make it right. What people do who go into
16182: politics I can’t think: it drives me almost mad to see mismanagement
16183: over only a few hundred acres.”
16184: 
16185: It was seldom that Caleb volunteered so long a speech, but his
16186: happiness had the effect of mountain air: his eyes were bright, and the
16187: words came without effort.
16188: 
16189: “I congratulate you heartily, Garth,” said the Vicar. “This is the best
16190: sort of news I could have had to carry to Fred Vincy, for he dwelt a
16191: good deal on the injury he had done you in causing you to part with
16192: money—robbing you of it, he said—which you wanted for other purposes. I
16193: wish Fred were not such an idle dog; he has some very good points, and
16194: his father is a little hard upon him.”
16195: 
16196: “Where is he going?” said Mrs. Garth, rather coldly.
16197: 
16198: “He means to try again for his degree, and he is going up to study
16199: before term. I have advised him to do that. I don’t urge him to enter
16200: the Church—on the contrary. But if he will go and work so as to pass,
16201: that will be some guarantee that he has energy and a will; and he is
16202: quite at sea; he doesn’t know what else to do. So far he will please
16203: his father, and I have promised in the mean time to try and reconcile
16204: Vincy to his son’s adopting some other line of life. Fred says frankly
16205: he is not fit for a clergyman, and I would do anything I could to
16206: hinder a man from the fatal step of choosing the wrong profession. He
16207: quoted to me what you said, Miss Garth—do you remember it?” (Mr.
16208: Farebrother used to say “Mary” instead of “Miss Garth,” but it was part
16209: of his delicacy to treat her with the more deference because, according
16210: to Mrs. Vincy’s phrase, she worked for her bread.)
16211: 
16212: Mary felt uncomfortable, but, determined to take the matter lightly,
16213: answered at once, “I have said so many impertinent things to Fred—we
16214: are such old playfellows.”
16215: 
16216: “You said, according to him, that he would be one of those ridiculous
16217: clergymen who help to make the whole clergy ridiculous. Really, that
16218: was so cutting that I felt a little cut myself.”
16219: 
16220: Caleb laughed. “She gets her tongue from you, Susan,” he said, with
16221: some enjoyment.
16222: 
16223: “Not its flippancy, father,” said Mary, quickly, fearing that her
16224: mother would be displeased. “It is rather too bad of Fred to repeat my
16225: flippant speeches to Mr. Farebrother.”
16226: 
16227: “It was certainly a hasty speech, my dear,” said Mrs. Garth, with whom
16228: speaking evil of dignities was a high misdemeanor. “We should not value
16229: our Vicar the less because there was a ridiculous curate in the next
16230: parish.”
16231: 
16232: “There’s something in what she says, though,” said Caleb, not disposed
16233: to have Mary’s sharpness undervalued. “A bad workman of any sort makes
16234: his fellows mistrusted. Things hang together,” he added, looking on the
16235: floor and moving his feet uneasily with a sense that words were
