16236: scantier than thoughts.
16237: 
16238: “Clearly,” said the Vicar, amused. “By being contemptible we set men’s
16239: minds to the tune of contempt. I certainly agree with Miss Garth’s view
16240: of the matter, whether I am condemned by it or not. But as to Fred
16241: Vincy, it is only fair he should be excused a little: old
16242: Featherstone’s delusive behavior did help to spoil him. There was
16243: something quite diabolical in not leaving him a farthing after all. But
16244: Fred has the good taste not to dwell on that. And what he cares most
16245: about is having offended you, Mrs. Garth; he supposes you will never
16246: think well of him again.”
16247: 
16248: “I have been disappointed in Fred,” said Mrs. Garth, with decision.
16249: “But I shall be ready to think well of him again when he gives me good
16250: reason to do so.”
16251: 
16252: At this point Mary went out of the room, taking Letty with her.
16253: 
16254: “Oh, we must forgive young people when they’re sorry,” said Caleb,
16255: watching Mary close the door. “And as you say, Mr. Farebrother, there
16256: was the very devil in that old man. Now Mary’s gone out, I must tell
16257: you a thing—it’s only known to Susan and me, and you’ll not tell it
16258: again. The old scoundrel wanted Mary to burn one of the wills the very
16259: night he died, when she was sitting up with him by herself, and he
16260: offered her a sum of money that he had in the box by him if she would
16261: do it. But Mary, you understand, could do no such thing—would not be
16262: handling his iron chest, and so on. Now, you see, the will he wanted
16263: burnt was this last, so that if Mary had done what he wanted, Fred
16264: Vincy would have had ten thousand pounds. The old man did turn to him
16265: at the last. That touches poor Mary close; she couldn’t help it—she was
16266: in the right to do what she did, but she feels, as she says, much as if
16267: she had knocked down somebody’s property and broken it against her
16268: will, when she was rightfully defending herself. I feel with her,
16269: somehow, and if I could make any amends to the poor lad, instead of
16270: bearing him a grudge for the harm he did us, I should be glad to do it.
16271: Now, what is your opinion, sir? Susan doesn’t agree with me; she
16272: says—tell what you say, Susan.”
16273: 
16274: “Mary could not have acted otherwise, even if she had known what would
16275: be the effect on Fred,” said Mrs. Garth, pausing from her work, and
16276: looking at Mr. Farebrother.
16277: 
16278: “And she was quite ignorant of it. It seems to me, a loss which falls
16279: on another because we have done right is not to lie upon our
16280: conscience.”
16281: 
16282: The Vicar did not answer immediately, and Caleb said, “It’s the
16283: feeling. The child feels in that way, and I feel with her. You don’t
16284: mean your horse to tread on a dog when you’re backing out of the way;
16285: but it goes through you, when it’s done.”
16286: 
16287: “I am sure Mrs. Garth would agree with you there,” said Mr.
16288: Farebrother, who for some reason seemed more inclined to ruminate than
16289: to speak. “One could hardly say that the feeling you mention about Fred
16290: is wrong—or rather, mistaken—though no man ought to make a claim on
16291: such feeling.”
16292: 
16293: “Well, well,” said Caleb, “it’s a secret. You will not tell Fred.”
16294: 
16295: “Certainly not. But I shall carry the other good news—that you can
16296: afford the loss he caused you.”
16297: 
16298: Mr. Farebrother left the house soon after, and seeing Mary in the
16299: orchard with Letty, went to say good-by to her. They made a pretty
16300: picture in the western light which brought out the brightness of the
16301: apples on the old scant-leaved boughs—Mary in her lavender gingham and
16302: black ribbons holding a basket, while Letty in her well-worn nankin
16303: picked up the fallen apples. If you want to know more particularly how
16304: Mary looked, ten to one you will see a face like hers in the crowded
16305: street to-morrow, if you are there on the watch: she will not be among
16306: those daughters of Zion who are haughty, and walk with stretched-out
16307: necks and wanton eyes, mincing as they go: let all those pass, and fix
16308: your eyes on some small plump brownish person of firm but quiet
16309: carriage, who looks about her, but does not suppose that anybody is
16310: looking at her. If she has a broad face and square brow, well-marked
16311: eyebrows and curly dark hair, a certain expression of amusement in her
16312: glance which her mouth keeps the secret of, and for the rest features
16313: entirely insignificant—take that ordinary but not disagreeable person
16314: for a portrait of Mary Garth. If you made her smile, she would show you
16315: perfect little teeth; if you made her angry, she would not raise her
16316: voice, but would probably say one of the bitterest things you have ever
16317: tasted the flavor of; if you did her a kindness, she would never forget
16318: it. Mary admired the keen-faced handsome little Vicar in his
16319: well-brushed threadbare clothes more than any man she had had the
16320: opportunity of knowing. She had never heard him say a foolish thing,
16321: though she knew that he did unwise ones; and perhaps foolish sayings
16322: were more objectionable to her than any of Mr. Farebrother’s unwise
16323: doings. At least, it was remarkable that the actual imperfections of
16324: the Vicar’s clerical character never seemed to call forth the same
16325: scorn and dislike which she showed beforehand for the predicted
16326: imperfections of the clerical character sustained by Fred Vincy. These
16327: irregularities of judgment, I imagine, are found even in riper minds
16328: than Mary Garth’s: our impartiality is kept for abstract merit and
16329: demerit, which none of us ever saw. Will any one guess towards which of
16330: those widely different men Mary had the peculiar woman’s
16331: tenderness?—the one she was most inclined to be severe on, or the
16332: contrary?
16333: 
16334: “Have you any message for your old playfellow, Miss Garth?” said the
16335: Vicar, as he took a fragrant apple from the basket which she held
16336: towards him, and put it in his pocket. “Something to soften down that
16337: harsh judgment? I am going straight to see him.”
16338: 
16339: “No,” said Mary, shaking her head, and smiling. “If I were to say that
16340: he would not be ridiculous as a clergyman, I must say that he would be
16341: something worse than ridiculous. But I am very glad to hear that he is
16342: going away to work.”
16343: 
16344: “On the other hand, I am very glad to hear that _you_ are not going
16345: away to work. My mother, I am sure, will be all the happier if you will
16346: come to see her at the vicarage: you know she is fond of having young
16347: people to talk to, and she has a great deal to tell about old times.
16348: You will really be doing a kindness.”
16349: 
16350: “I should like it very much, if I may,” said Mary. “Everything seems
16351: too happy for me all at once. I thought it would always be part of my
16352: life to long for home, and losing that grievance makes me feel rather
16353: empty: I suppose it served instead of sense to fill up my mind?”
16354: 
16355: “May I go with you, Mary?” whispered Letty—a most inconvenient child,
16356: who listened to everything. But she was made exultant by having her
16357: chin pinched and her cheek kissed by Mr. Farebrother—an incident which
16358: she narrated to her mother and father.
16359: 
16360: As the Vicar walked to Lowick, any one watching him closely might have
16361: seen him twice shrug his shoulders. I think that the rare Englishmen
16362: who have this gesture are never of the heavy type—for fear of any
16363: lumbering instance to the contrary, I will say, hardly ever; they have
16364: usually a fine temperament and much tolerance towards the smaller
16365: errors of men (themselves inclusive). The Vicar was holding an inward
16366: dialogue in which he told himself that there was probably something
16367: more between Fred and Mary Garth than the regard of old playfellows,
16368: and replied with a question whether that bit of womanhood were not a
16369: great deal too choice for that crude young gentleman. The rejoinder to
16370: this was the first shrug. Then he laughed at himself for being likely
16371: to have felt jealous, as if he had been a man able to marry, which,
16372: added he, it is as clear as any balance-sheet that I am not. Whereupon
16373: followed the second shrug.
16374: 
16375: What could two men, so different from each other, see in this “brown
16376: patch,” as Mary called herself? It was certainly not her plainness that
16377: attracted them (and let all plain young ladies be warned against the
16378: dangerous encouragement given them by Society to confide in their want
16379: of beauty). A human being in this aged nation of ours is a very
16380: wonderful whole, the slow creation of long interchanging influences:
16381: and charm is a result of two such wholes, the one loving and the one
16382: loved.
16383: 
16384: When Mr. and Mrs. Garth were sitting alone, Caleb said, “Susan, guess
16385: what I’m thinking of.”
16386: 
16387: “The rotation of crops,” said Mrs. Garth, smiling at him, above her
16388: knitting, “or else the back-doors of the Tipton cottages.”
16389: 
16390: “No,” said Caleb, gravely; “I am thinking that I could do a great turn
16391: for Fred Vincy. Christy’s gone, Alfred will be gone soon, and it will
16392: be five years before Jim is ready to take to business. I shall want
16393: help, and Fred might come in and learn the nature of things and act
16394: under me, and it might be the making of him into a useful man, if he
16395: gives up being a parson. What do you think?”
16396: 
16397: “I think, there is hardly anything honest that his family would object
16398: to more,” said Mrs. Garth, decidedly.
16399: 
16400: “What care I about their objecting?” said Caleb, with a sturdiness
16401: which he was apt to show when he had an opinion. “The lad is of age and
16402: must get his bread. He has sense enough and quickness enough; he likes
16403: being on the land, and it’s my belief that he could learn business well
16404: if he gave his mind to it.”
16405: 
16406: “But would he? His father and mother wanted him to be a fine gentleman,
16407: and I think he has the same sort of feeling himself. They all think us
16408: beneath them. And if the proposal came from you, I am sure Mrs. Vincy
16409: would say that we wanted Fred for Mary.”
16410: 
16411: “Life is a poor tale, if it is to be settled by nonsense of that sort,”
16412: said Caleb, with disgust.
16413: 
16414: “Yes, but there is a certain pride which is proper, Caleb.”
16415: 
16416: “I call it improper pride to let fools’ notions hinder you from doing a
16417: good action. There’s no sort of work,” said Caleb, with fervor, putting
16418: out his hand and moving it up and down to mark his emphasis, “that
16419: could ever be done well, if you minded what fools say. You must have it
16420: inside you that your plan is right, and that plan you must follow.”
16421: 
16422: “I will not oppose any plan you have set your mind on, Caleb,” said
16423: Mrs. Garth, who was a firm woman, but knew that there were some points
16424: on which her mild husband was yet firmer. “Still, it seems to be fixed
16425: that Fred is to go back to college: will it not be better to wait and
16426: see what he will choose to do after that? It is not easy to keep people
16427: against their will. And you are not yet quite sure enough of your own
16428: position, or what you will want.”
16429: 
16430: “Well, it may be better to wait a bit. But as to my getting plenty of
16431: work for two, I’m pretty sure of that. I’ve always had my hands full
16432: with scattered things, and there’s always something fresh turning up.
16433: Why, only yesterday—bless me, I don’t think I told you!—it was rather
16434: odd that two men should have been at me on different sides to do the
16435: same bit of valuing. And who do you think they were?” said Caleb,
16436: taking a pinch of snuff and holding it up between his fingers, as if it
16437: were a part of his exposition. He was fond of a pinch when it occurred
16438: to him, but he usually forgot that this indulgence was at his command.
16439: 
16440: His wife held down her knitting and looked attentive.
16441: 
16442: “Why, that Rigg, or Rigg Featherstone, was one. But Bulstrode was
16443: before him, so I’m going to do it for Bulstrode. Whether it’s mortgage
16444: or purchase they’re going for, I can’t tell yet.”
16445: 
16446: “Can that man be going to sell the land just left him—which he has
16447: taken the name for?” said Mrs. Garth.
16448: 
16449: “Deuce knows,” said Caleb, who never referred the knowledge of
16450: discreditable doings to any higher power than the deuce. “But Bulstrode
16451: has long been wanting to get a handsome bit of land under his
16452: fingers—that I know. And it’s a difficult matter to get, in this part
16453: of the country.”
16454: 
16455: Caleb scattered his snuff carefully instead of taking it, and then
16456: added, “The ins and outs of things are curious. Here is the land
16457: they’ve been all along expecting for Fred, which it seems the old man
16458: never meant to leave him a foot of, but left it to this side-slip of a
16459: son that he kept in the dark, and thought of his sticking there and
16460: vexing everybody as well as he could have vexed ’em himself if he could
16461: have kept alive. I say, it would be curious if it got into Bulstrode’s
16462: hands after all. The old man hated him, and never would bank with him.”
16463: 
16464: “What reason could the miserable creature have for hating a man whom he
16465: had nothing to do with?” said Mrs. Garth.
16466: 
16467: “Pooh! where’s the use of asking for such fellows’ reasons? The soul of
16468: man,” said Caleb, with the deep tone and grave shake of the head which
16469: always came when he used this phrase—“The soul of man, when it gets
16470: fairly rotten, will bear you all sorts of poisonous toad-stools, and no
16471: eye can see whence came the seed thereof.”
16472: 
16473: It was one of Caleb’s quaintnesses, that in his difficulty of finding
16474: speech for his thought, he caught, as it were, snatches of diction
16475: which he associated with various points of view or states of mind; and
16476: whenever he had a feeling of awe, he was haunted by a sense of Biblical
16477: phraseology, though he could hardly have given a strict quotation.
16478: 
16479: 
16480: 
16481: 
16482: CHAPTER XLI.
16483: 
16484: By swaggering could I never thrive,
16485: For the rain it raineth every day.
16486: —_Twelfth Night_.
16487: 
16488: 
16489: The transactions referred to by Caleb Garth as having gone forward
16490: between Mr. Bulstrode and Mr. Joshua Rigg Featherstone concerning the
16491: land attached to Stone Court, had occasioned the interchange of a
16492: letter or two between these personages.
16493: 
16494: Who shall tell what may be the effect of writing? If it happens to have
16495: been cut in stone, though it lie face down-most for ages on a forsaken
16496: beach, or “rest quietly under the drums and tramplings of many
16497: conquests,” it may end by letting us into the secret of usurpations and
16498: other scandals gossiped about long empires ago:—this world being
16499: apparently a huge whispering-gallery. Such conditions are often
16500: minutely represented in our petty lifetimes. As the stone which has
16501: been kicked by generations of clowns may come by curious little links
16502: of effect under the eyes of a scholar, through whose labors it may at
16503: last fix the date of invasions and unlock religions, so a bit of ink
16504: and paper which has long been an innocent wrapping or stop-gap may at
16505: last be laid open under the one pair of eyes which have knowledge
16506: enough to turn it into the opening of a catastrophe. To Uriel watching
16507: the progress of planetary history from the sun, the one result would be
16508: just as much of a coincidence as the other.
16509: 
16510: Having made this rather lofty comparison I am less uneasy in calling
16511: attention to the existence of low people by whose interference, however
16512: little we may like it, the course of the world is very much determined.
16513: It would be well, certainly, if we could help to reduce their number,
16514: and something might perhaps be done by not lightly giving occasion to
16515: their existence. Socially speaking, Joshua Rigg would have been
16516: generally pronounced a superfluity. But those who like Peter
16517: Featherstone never had a copy of themselves demanded, are the very last
16518: to wait for such a request either in prose or verse. The copy in this
16519: case bore more of outside resemblance to the mother, in whose sex
16520: frog-features, accompanied with fresh-colored cheeks and a well-rounded
16521: figure, are compatible with much charm for a certain order of admirers.
16522: The result is sometimes a frog-faced male, desirable, surely, to no
16523: order of intelligent beings. Especially when he is suddenly brought
16524: into evidence to frustrate other people’s expectations—the very lowest
16525: aspect in which a social superfluity can present himself.
16526: 
16527: But Mr. Rigg Featherstone’s low characteristics were all of the sober,
16528: water-drinking kind. From the earliest to the latest hour of the day he
16529: was always as sleek, neat, and cool as the frog he resembled, and old
16530: Peter had secretly chuckled over an offshoot almost more calculating,
16531: and far more imperturbable, than himself. I will add that his
16532: finger-nails were scrupulously attended to, and that he meant to marry
16533: a well-educated young lady (as yet unspecified) whose person was good,
16534: and whose connections, in a solid middle-class way, were undeniable.
16535: Thus his nails and modesty were comparable to those of most gentlemen;
16536: though his ambition had been educated only by the opportunities of a
16537: clerk and accountant in the smaller commercial houses of a seaport. He
16538: thought the rural Featherstones very simple absurd people, and they in
16539: their turn regarded his “bringing up” in a seaport town as an
16540: exaggeration of the monstrosity that their brother Peter, and still
16541: more Peter’s property, should have had such belongings.
16542: 
16543: The garden and gravel approach, as seen from the two windows of the
16544: wainscoted parlor at Stone Court, were never in better trim than now,
16545: when Mr. Rigg Featherstone stood, with his hands behind him, looking
16546: out on these grounds as their master. But it seemed doubtful whether he
16547: looked out for the sake of contemplation or of turning his back to a
16548: person who stood in the middle of the room, with his legs considerably
16549: apart and his hands in his trouser-pockets: a person in all respects a
16550: contrast to the sleek and cool Rigg. He was a man obviously on the way
16551: towards sixty, very florid and hairy, with much gray in his bushy
16552: whiskers and thick curly hair, a stoutish body which showed to
16553: disadvantage the somewhat worn joinings of his clothes, and the air of
16554: a swaggerer, who would aim at being noticeable even at a show of
16555: fireworks, regarding his own remarks on any other person’s performance
16556: as likely to be more interesting than the performance itself.
16557: 
16558: His name was John Raffles, and he sometimes wrote jocosely W.A.G. after
16559: his signature, observing when he did so, that he was once taught by
16560: Leonard Lamb of Finsbury who wrote B.A. after his name, and that he,
16561: Raffles, originated the witticism of calling that celebrated principal
16562: Ba-Lamb. Such were the appearance and mental flavor of Mr. Raffles,
16563: both of which seemed to have a stale odor of travellers’ rooms in the
16564: commercial hotels of that period.
16565: 
16566: “Come, now, Josh,” he was saying, in a full rumbling tone, “look at it
16567: in this light: here is your poor mother going into the vale of years,
16568: and you could afford something handsome now to make her comfortable.”
16569: 
16570: “Not while you live. Nothing would make her comfortable while you
16571: live,” returned Rigg, in his cool high voice. “What I give her, you’ll
16572: take.”
16573: 
16574: “You bear me a grudge, Josh, that I know. But come, now—as between man
16575: and man—without humbug—a little capital might enable me to make a
16576: first-rate thing of the shop. The tobacco trade is growing. I should
16577: cut my own nose off in not doing the best I could at it. I should stick
16578: to it like a flea to a fleece for my own sake. I should always be on
16579: the spot. And nothing would make your poor mother so happy. I’ve pretty
16580: well done with my wild oats—turned fifty-five. I want to settle down in
16581: my chimney-corner. And if I once buckled to the tobacco trade, I could
16582: bring an amount of brains and experience to bear on it that would not
16583: be found elsewhere in a hurry. I don’t want to be bothering you one
16584: time after another, but to get things once for all into the right
16585: channel. Consider that, Josh—as between man and man—and with your poor
16586: mother to be made easy for her life. I was always fond of the old
16587: woman, by Jove!”
16588: 
16589: “Have you done?” said Mr. Rigg, quietly, without looking away from the
16590: window.
16591: 
16592: “Yes, _I_’ve done,” said Raffles, taking hold of his hat which stood
16593: before him on the table, and giving it a sort of oratorical push.
16594: 
16595: “Then just listen to me. The more you say anything, the less I shall
16596: believe it. The more you want me to do a thing, the more reason I shall
16597: have for never doing it. Do you think I mean to forget your kicking me
16598: when I was a lad, and eating all the best victual away from me and my
16599: mother? Do you think I forget your always coming home to sell and
16600: pocket everything, and going off again leaving us in the lurch? I
16601: should be glad to see you whipped at the cart-tail. My mother was a
16602: fool to you: she’d no right to give me a father-in-law, and she’s been
16603: punished for it. She shall have her weekly allowance paid and no more:
16604: and that shall be stopped if you dare to come on to these premises
16605: again, or to come into this country after me again. The next time you
16606: show yourself inside the gates here, you shall be driven off with the
16607: dogs and the wagoner’s whip.”
16608: 
16609: As Rigg pronounced the last words he turned round and looked at Raffles
16610: with his prominent frozen eyes. The contrast was as striking as it
16611: could have been eighteen years before, when Rigg was a most unengaging
16612: kickable boy, and Raffles was the rather thick-set Adonis of bar-rooms
16613: and back-parlors. But the advantage now was on the side of Rigg, and
16614: auditors of this conversation might probably have expected that Raffles
16615: would retire with the air of a defeated dog. Not at all. He made a
16616: grimace which was habitual with him whenever he was “out” in a game;
16617: then subsided into a laugh, and drew a brandy-flask from his pocket.
16618: 
16619: “Come, Josh,” he said, in a cajoling tone, “give us a spoonful of
16620: brandy, and a sovereign to pay the way back, and I’ll go. Honor bright!
16621: I’ll go like a bullet, _by_ Jove!”
16622: 
16623: “Mind,” said Rigg, drawing out a bunch of keys, “if I ever see you
16624: again, I shan’t speak to you. I don’t own you any more than if I saw a
16625: crow; and if you want to own me you’ll get nothing by it but a
16626: character for being what you are—a spiteful, brassy, bullying rogue.”
16627: 
16628: “That’s a pity, now, Josh,” said Raffles, affecting to scratch his head
16629: and wrinkle his brows upward as if he were nonplussed. “I’m very fond
16630: of you; _by_ Jove, I am! There’s nothing I like better than plaguing
16631: you—you’re so like your mother, and I must do without it. But the
16632: brandy and the sovereign’s a bargain.”
16633: 
16634: He jerked forward the flask and Rigg went to a fine old oaken bureau
16635: with his keys. But Raffles had reminded himself by his movement with
16636: the flask that it had become dangerously loose from its leather
16637: covering, and catching sight of a folded paper which had fallen within
16638: the fender, he took it up and shoved it under the leather so as to make
16639: the glass firm.
16640: 
16641: By that time Rigg came forward with a brandy-bottle, filled the flask,
16642: and handed Raffles a sovereign, neither looking at him nor speaking to
16643: him. After locking up the bureau again, he walked to the window and
16644: gazed out as impassibly as he had done at the beginning of the
16645: interview, while Raffles took a small allowance from the flask, screwed
16646: it up, and deposited it in his side-pocket, with provoking slowness,
16647: making a grimace at his stepson’s back.
16648: 
16649: “Farewell, Josh—and if forever!” said Raffles, turning back his head as
16650: he opened the door.
16651: 
16652: Rigg saw him leave the grounds and enter the lane. The gray day had
16653: turned to a light drizzling rain, which freshened the hedgerows and the
16654: grassy borders of the by-roads, and hastened the laborers who were
16655: loading the last shocks of corn. Raffles, walking with the uneasy gait
16656: of a town loiterer obliged to do a bit of country journeying on foot,
16657: looked as incongruous amid this moist rural quiet and industry as if he
16658: had been a baboon escaped from a menagerie. But there were none to
16659: stare at him except the long-weaned calves, and none to show dislike of
16660: his appearance except the little water-rats which rustled away at his
16661: approach.
16662: 
16663: He was fortunate enough when he got on to the highroad to be overtaken
16664: by the stage-coach, which carried him to Brassing; and there he took
16665: the new-made railway, observing to his fellow-passengers that he
16666: considered it pretty well seasoned now it had done for Huskisson. Mr.
16667: Raffles on most occasions kept up the sense of having been educated at
16668: an academy, and being able, if he chose, to pass well everywhere;
16669: indeed, there was not one of his fellow-men whom he did not feel
16670: himself in a position to ridicule and torment, confident of the
16671: entertainment which he thus gave to all the rest of the company.
16672: 
16673: He played this part now with as much spirit as if his journey had been
16674: entirely successful, resorting at frequent intervals to his flask. The
16675: paper with which he had wedged it was a letter signed _Nicholas
16676: Bulstrode_, but Raffles was not likely to disturb it from its present
16677: useful position.
16678: 
16679: 
16680: 
16681: 
16682: CHAPTER XLII.
16683: 
16684: How much, methinks, I could despise this man
16685: Were I not bound in charity against it!
16686: —SHAKESPEARE: _Henry VIII_.
16687: 
16688: 
16689: One of the professional calls made by Lydgate soon after his return
16690: from his wedding-journey was to Lowick Manor, in consequence of a
16691: letter which had requested him to fix a time for his visit.
16692: 
16693: Mr. Casaubon had never put any question concerning the nature of his
16694: illness to Lydgate, nor had he even to Dorothea betrayed any anxiety as
16695: to how far it might be likely to cut short his labors or his life. On
16696: this point, as on all others, he shrank from pity; and if the suspicion
16697: of being pitied for anything in his lot surmised or known in spite of
16698: himself was embittering, the idea of calling forth a show of compassion
16699: by frankly admitting an alarm or a sorrow was necessarily intolerable
16700: to him. Every proud mind knows something of this experience, and
16701: perhaps it is only to be overcome by a sense of fellowship deep enough
16702: to make all efforts at isolation seem mean and petty instead of
16703: exalting.
16704: 
16705: But Mr. Casaubon was now brooding over something through which the
16706: question of his health and life haunted his silence with a more
16707: harassing importunity even than through the autumnal unripeness of his
16708: authorship. It is true that this last might be called his central
16709: ambition; but there are some kinds of authorship in which by far the
16710: largest result is the uneasy susceptibility accumulated in the
16711: consciousness of the author—one knows of the river by a few streaks
16712: amid a long-gathered deposit of uncomfortable mud. That was the way
16713: with Mr. Casaubon’s hard intellectual labors. Their most characteristic
16714: result was not the “Key to all Mythologies,” but a morbid consciousness
16715: that others did not give him the place which he had not demonstrably
16716: merited—a perpetual suspicious conjecture that the views entertained of
16717: him were not to his advantage—a melancholy absence of passion in his
16718: efforts at achievement, and a passionate resistance to the confession
16719: that he had achieved nothing.
16720: 
16721: Thus his intellectual ambition which seemed to others to have absorbed
16722: and dried him, was really no security against wounds, least of all
16723: against those which came from Dorothea. And he had begun now to frame
16724: possibilities for the future which were somehow more embittering to him
16725: than anything his mind had dwelt on before.
16726: 
16727: Against certain facts he was helpless: against Will Ladislaw’s
16728: existence, his defiant stay in the neighborhood of Lowick, and his
16729: flippant state of mind with regard to the possessors of authentic,
16730: well-stamped erudition: against Dorothea’s nature, always taking on
16731: some new shape of ardent activity, and even in submission and silence
16732: covering fervid reasons which it was an irritation to think of: against
16733: certain notions and likings which had taken possession of her mind in
16734: relation to subjects that he could not possibly discuss with her. There
16735: was no denying that Dorothea was as virtuous and lovely a young lady as
16736: he could have obtained for a wife; but a young lady turned out to be
16737: something more troublesome than he had conceived. She nursed him, she
16738: read to him, she anticipated his wants, and was solicitous about his
16739: feelings; but there had entered into the husband’s mind the certainty
16740: that she judged him, and that her wifely devotedness was like a
16741: penitential expiation of unbelieving thoughts—was accompanied with a
16742: power of comparison by which himself and his doings were seen too
16743: luminously as a part of things in general. His discontent passed
16744: vapor-like through all her gentle loving manifestations, and clung to
16745: that inappreciative world which she had only brought nearer to him.
16746: 
16747: Poor Mr. Casaubon! This suffering was the harder to bear because it
16748: seemed like a betrayal: the young creature who had worshipped him with
16749: perfect trust had quickly turned into the critical wife; and early
16750: instances of criticism and resentment had made an impression which no
16751: tenderness and submission afterwards could remove. To his suspicious
16752: interpretation Dorothea’s silence now was a suppressed rebellion; a
16753: remark from her which he had not in any way anticipated was an
16754: assertion of conscious superiority; her gentle answers had an
16755: irritating cautiousness in them; and when she acquiesced it was a
16756: self-approved effort of forbearance. The tenacity with which he strove
16757: to hide this inward drama made it the more vivid for him; as we hear
16758: with the more keenness what we wish others not to hear.
16759: 
16760: Instead of wondering at this result of misery in Mr. Casaubon, I think
16761: it quite ordinary. Will not a tiny speck very close to our vision blot
16762: out the glory of the world, and leave only a margin by which we see the
16763: blot? I know no speck so troublesome as self. And who, if Mr. Casaubon
16764: had chosen to expound his discontents—his suspicions that he was not
16765: any longer adored without criticism—could have denied that they were
16766: founded on good reasons? On the contrary, there was a strong reason to
16767: be added, which he had not himself taken explicitly into
16768: account—namely, that he was not unmixedly adorable. He suspected this,
16769: however, as he suspected other things, without confessing it, and like
16770: the rest of us, felt how soothing it would have been to have a
16771: companion who would never find it out.
16772: 
16773: This sore susceptibility in relation to Dorothea was thoroughly
16774: prepared before Will Ladislaw had returned to Lowick, and what had
16775: occurred since then had brought Mr. Casaubon’s power of suspicious
16776: construction into exasperated activity. To all the facts which he knew,
16777: he added imaginary facts both present and future which became more real
16778: to him than those because they called up a stronger dislike, a more
16779: predominating bitterness. Suspicion and jealousy of Will Ladislaw’s
16780: intentions, suspicion and jealousy of Dorothea’s impressions, were
16781: constantly at their weaving work. It would be quite unjust to him to
16782: suppose that he could have entered into any coarse misinterpretation of
16783: Dorothea: his own habits of mind and conduct, quite as much as the open
16784: elevation of her nature, saved him from any such mistake. What he was
16785: jealous of was her opinion, the sway that might be given to her ardent
16786: mind in its judgments, and the future possibilities to which these
16787: might lead her. As to Will, though until his last defiant letter he had
16788: nothing definite which he would choose formally to allege against him,
16789: he felt himself warranted in believing that he was capable of any
16790: design which could fascinate a rebellious temper and an undisciplined
16791: impulsiveness. He was quite sure that Dorothea was the cause of Will’s
16792: return from Rome, and his determination to settle in the neighborhood;
16793: and he was penetrating enough to imagine that Dorothea had innocently
16794: encouraged this course. It was as clear as possible that she was ready
16795: to be attached to Will and to be pliant to his suggestions: they had
16796: never had a _tête-à-tête_ without her bringing away from it some new
16797: troublesome impression, and the last interview that Mr. Casaubon was
16798: aware of (Dorothea, on returning from Freshitt Hall, had for the first
16799: time been silent about having seen Will) had led to a scene which
16800: roused an angrier feeling against them both than he had ever known
16801: before. Dorothea’s outpouring of her notions about money, in the
16802: darkness of the night, had done nothing but bring a mixture of more
16803: odious foreboding into her husband’s mind.
16804: 
16805: And there was the shock lately given to his health always sadly present
16806: with him. He was certainly much revived; he had recovered all his usual
16807: power of work: the illness might have been mere fatigue, and there
16808: might still be twenty years of achievement before him, which would
16809: justify the thirty years of preparation. That prospect was made the
16810: sweeter by a flavor of vengeance against the hasty sneers of Carp &
16811: Company; for even when Mr. Casaubon was carrying his taper among the
16812: tombs of the past, those modern figures came athwart the dim light, and
16813: interrupted his diligent exploration. To convince Carp of his mistake,
16814: so that he would have to eat his own words with a good deal of
16815: indigestion, would be an agreeable accident of triumphant authorship,
16816: which the prospect of living to future ages on earth and to all
16817: eternity in heaven could not exclude from contemplation. Since, thus,
16818: the prevision of his own unending bliss could not nullify the bitter
16819: savors of irritated jealousy and vindictiveness, it is the less
16820: surprising that the probability of a transient earthly bliss for other
16821: persons, when he himself should have entered into glory, had not a
16822: potently sweetening effect. If the truth should be that some
16823: undermining disease was at work within him, there might be large
16824: opportunity for some people to be the happier when he was gone; and if
16825: one of those people should be Will Ladislaw, Mr. Casaubon objected so
16826: strongly that it seemed as if the annoyance would make part of his
16827: disembodied existence.
16828: 
16829: This is a very bare and therefore a very incomplete way of putting the
16830: case. The human soul moves in many channels, and Mr. Casaubon, we know,
16831: had a sense of rectitude and an honorable pride in satisfying the
16832: requirements of honor, which compelled him to find other reasons for
16833: his conduct than those of jealousy and vindictiveness. The way in which
16834: Mr. Casaubon put the case was this:—“In marrying Dorothea Brooke I had
16835: to care for her well-being in case of my death. But well-being is not
16836: to be secured by ample, independent possession of property; on the
16837: contrary, occasions might arise in which such possession might expose
16838: her to the more danger. She is ready prey to any man who knows how to
16839: play adroitly either on her affectionate ardor or her Quixotic
16840: enthusiasm; and a man stands by with that very intention in his mind—a
16841: man with no other principle than transient caprice, and who has a
16842: personal animosity towards me—I am sure of it—an animosity which is fed
16843: by the consciousness of his ingratitude, and which he has constantly
16844: vented in ridicule of which I am as well assured as if I had heard it.
16845: Even if I live I shall not be without uneasiness as to what he may
16846: attempt through indirect influence. This man has gained Dorothea’s ear:
16847: he has fascinated her attention; he has evidently tried to impress her
16848: mind with the notion that he has claims beyond anything I have done for
16849: him. If I die—and he is waiting here on the watch for that—he will
16850: persuade her to marry him. That would be calamity for her and success
16851: for him. _She_ would not think it calamity: he would make her believe
16852: anything; she has a tendency to immoderate attachment which she
16853: inwardly reproaches me for not responding to, and already her mind is
16854: occupied with his fortunes. He thinks of an easy conquest and of
16855: entering into my nest. That I will hinder! Such a marriage would be
16856: fatal to Dorothea. Has he ever persisted in anything except from
16857: contradiction? In knowledge he has always tried to be showy at small
16858: cost. In religion he could be, as long as it suited him, the facile
16859: echo of Dorothea’s vagaries. When was sciolism ever dissociated from
16860: laxity? I utterly distrust his morals, and it is my duty to hinder to
16861: the utmost the fulfilment of his designs.”
16862: 
16863: The arrangements made by Mr. Casaubon on his marriage left strong
16864: measures open to him, but in ruminating on them his mind inevitably
16865: dwelt so much on the probabilities of his own life that the longing to
16866: get the nearest possible calculation had at last overcome his proud
16867: reticence, and had determined him to ask Lydgate’s opinion as to the
16868: nature of his illness.
16869: 
16870: He had mentioned to Dorothea that Lydgate was coming by appointment at
16871: half-past three, and in answer to her anxious question, whether he had
16872: felt ill, replied,—“No, I merely wish to have his opinion concerning
16873: some habitual symptoms. You need not see him, my dear. I shall give
16874: orders that he may be sent to me in the Yew-tree Walk, where I shall be
16875: taking my usual exercise.”
16876: 
16877: When Lydgate entered the Yew-tree Walk he saw Mr. Casaubon slowly
16878: receding with his hands behind him according to his habit, and his head
16879: bent forward. It was a lovely afternoon; the leaves from the lofty
16880: limes were falling silently across the sombre evergreens, while the
16881: lights and shadows slept side by side: there was no sound but the
16882: cawing of the rooks, which to the accustomed ear is a lullaby, or that
16883: last solemn lullaby, a dirge. Lydgate, conscious of an energetic frame
16884: in its prime, felt some compassion when the figure which he was likely
16885: soon to overtake turned round, and in advancing towards him showed more
16886: markedly than ever the signs of premature age—the student’s bent
16887: shoulders, the emaciated limbs, and the melancholy lines of the mouth.
16888: “Poor fellow,” he thought, “some men with his years are like lions; one
16889: can tell nothing of their age except that they are full grown.”
16890: 
16891: “Mr. Lydgate,” said Mr. Casaubon, with his invariably polite air, “I am
16892: exceedingly obliged to you for your punctuality. We will, if you
16893: please, carry on our conversation in walking to and fro.”
16894: 
16895: “I hope your wish to see me is not due to the return of unpleasant
16896: symptoms,” said Lydgate, filling up a pause.
16897: 
16898: “Not immediately—no. In order to account for that wish I must
16899: mention—what it were otherwise needless to refer to—that my life, on
16900: all collateral accounts insignificant, derives a possible importance
16901: from the incompleteness of labors which have extended through all its
16902: best years. In short, I have long had on hand a work which I would fain
16903: leave behind me in such a state, at least, that it might be committed
16904: to the press by—others. Were I assured that this is the utmost I can
16905: reasonably expect, that assurance would be a useful circumscription of
16906: my attempts, and a guide in both the positive and negative
16907: determination of my course.”
16908: 
16909: Here Mr. Casaubon paused, removed one hand from his back and thrust it
16910: between the buttons of his single-breasted coat. To a mind largely
16911: instructed in the human destiny hardly anything could be more
16912: interesting than the inward conflict implied in his formal measured
16913: address, delivered with the usual sing-song and motion of the head.
16914: Nay, are there many situations more sublimely tragic than the struggle
16915: of the soul with the demand to renounce a work which has been all the
16916: significance of its life—a significance which is to vanish as the
16917: waters which come and go where no man has need of them? But there was
16918: nothing to strike others as sublime about Mr. Casaubon, and Lydgate,
16919: who had some contempt at hand for futile scholarship, felt a little
16920: amusement mingling with his pity. He was at present too ill acquainted
16921: with disaster to enter into the pathos of a lot where everything is
16922: below the level of tragedy except the passionate egoism of the
16923: sufferer.
16924: 
16925: “You refer to the possible hindrances from want of health?” he said,
16926: wishing to help forward Mr. Casaubon’s purpose, which seemed to be
16927: clogged by some hesitation.
16928: 
16929: “I do. You have not implied to me that the symptoms which—I am bound to
16930: testify—you watched with scrupulous care, were those of a fatal
16931: disease. But were it so, Mr. Lydgate, I should desire to know the truth
16932: without reservation, and I appeal to you for an exact statement of your
16933: conclusions: I request it as a friendly service. If you can tell me
16934: that my life is not threatened by anything else than ordinary
16935: casualties, I shall rejoice, on grounds which I have already indicated.
16936: If not, knowledge of the truth is even more important to me.”
16937: 
16938: “Then I can no longer hesitate as to my course,” said Lydgate; “but the
16939: first thing I must impress on you is that my conclusions are doubly
16940: uncertain—uncertain not only because of my fallibility, but because
16941: diseases of the heart are eminently difficult to found predictions on.
16942: In any case, one can hardly increase appreciably the tremendous
16943: uncertainty of life.”
16944: 
16945: Mr. Casaubon winced perceptibly, but bowed.
16946: 
16947: “I believe that you are suffering from what is called fatty
16948: degeneration of the heart, a disease which was first divined and
16949: explored by Laennec, the man who gave us the stethoscope, not so very
16950: many years ago. A good deal of experience—a more lengthened
16951: observation—is wanting on the subject. But after what you have said, it
16952: is my duty to tell you that death from this disease is often sudden. At
16953: the same time, no such result can be predicted. Your condition may be
16954: consistent with a tolerably comfortable life for another fifteen years,
16955: or even more. I could add no information to this beyond anatomical or
16956: medical details, which would leave expectation at precisely the same
16957: point.” Lydgate’s instinct was fine enough to tell him that plain
16958: speech, quite free from ostentatious caution, would be felt by Mr.
16959: Casaubon as a tribute of respect.
16960: 
16961: “I thank you, Mr. Lydgate,” said Mr. Casaubon, after a moment’s pause.
16962: “One thing more I have still to ask: did you communicate what you have
16963: now told me to Mrs. Casaubon?”
16964: 
16965: “Partly—I mean, as to the possible issues.” Lydgate was going to
16966: explain why he had told Dorothea, but Mr. Casaubon, with an
16967: unmistakable desire to end the conversation, waved his hand slightly,
16968: and said again, “I thank you,” proceeding to remark on the rare beauty
16969: of the day.
16970: 
16971: Lydgate, certain that his patient wished to be alone, soon left him;
16972: and the black figure with hands behind and head bent forward continued
16973: to pace the walk where the dark yew-trees gave him a mute companionship
16974: in melancholy, and the little shadows of bird or leaf that fleeted
16975: across the isles of sunlight, stole along in silence as in the presence
16976: of a sorrow. Here was a man who now for the first time found himself
16977: looking into the eyes of death—who was passing through one of those
16978: rare moments of experience when we feel the truth of a commonplace,
16979: which is as different from what we call knowing it, as the vision of
16980: waters upon the earth is different from the delirious vision of the
16981: water which cannot be had to cool the burning tongue. When the
16982: commonplace “We must all die” transforms itself suddenly into the acute
16983: consciousness “I must die—and soon,” then death grapples us, and his
16984: fingers are cruel; afterwards, he may come to fold us in his arms as
16985: our mother did, and our last moment of dim earthly discerning may be
16986: like the first. To Mr. Casaubon now, it was as if he suddenly found
16987: himself on the dark river-brink and heard the plash of the oncoming
16988: oar, not discerning the forms, but expecting the summons. In such an
16989: hour the mind does not change its lifelong bias, but carries it onward
16990: in imagination to the other side of death, gazing backward—perhaps with
16991: the divine calm of beneficence, perhaps with the petty anxieties of
16992: self-assertion. What was Mr. Casaubon’s bias his acts will give us a
16993: clew to. He held himself to be, with some private scholarly
16994: reservations, a believing Christian, as to estimates of the present and
16995: hopes of the future. But what we strive to gratify, though we may call
16996: it a distant hope, is an immediate desire: the future estate for which
16997: men drudge up city alleys exists already in their imagination and love.
16998: And Mr. Casaubon’s immediate desire was not for divine communion and
16999: light divested of earthly conditions; his passionate longings, poor
17000: man, clung low and mist-like in very shady places.
17001: 
17002: Dorothea had been aware when Lydgate had ridden away, and she had
17003: stepped into the garden, with the impulse to go at once to her husband.
17004: But she hesitated, fearing to offend him by obtruding herself; for her
17005: ardor, continually repulsed, served, with her intense memory, to
17006: heighten her dread, as thwarted energy subsides into a shudder; and she
17007: wandered slowly round the nearer clumps of trees until she saw him
17008: advancing. Then she went towards him, and might have represented a
17009: heaven-sent angel coming with a promise that the short hours remaining
17010: should yet be filled with that faithful love which clings the closer to
17011: a comprehended grief. His glance in reply to hers was so chill that she
17012: felt her timidity increased; yet she turned and passed her hand through
17013: his arm.
17014: 
17015: Mr. Casaubon kept his hands behind him and allowed her pliant arm to
17016: cling with difficulty against his rigid arm.
17017: 
17018: There was something horrible to Dorothea in the sensation which this
17019: unresponsive hardness inflicted on her. That is a strong word, but not
17020: too strong: it is in these acts called trivialities that the seeds of
17021: joy are forever wasted, until men and women look round with haggard
17022: faces at the devastation their own waste has made, and say, the earth
17023: bears no harvest of sweetness—calling their denial knowledge. You may
17024: ask why, in the name of manliness, Mr. Casaubon should have behaved in
17025: that way. Consider that his was a mind which shrank from pity: have you
17026: ever watched in such a mind the effect of a suspicion that what is
17027: pressing it as a grief may be really a source of contentment, either
17028: actual or future, to the being who already offends by pitying? Besides,
17029: he knew little of Dorothea’s sensations, and had not reflected that on
17030: such an occasion as the present they were comparable in strength to his
17031: own sensibilities about Carp’s criticisms.
17032: 
17033: Dorothea did not withdraw her arm, but she could not venture to speak.
17034: Mr. Casaubon did not say, “I wish to be alone,” but he directed his
17035: steps in silence towards the house, and as they entered by the glass
17036: door on this eastern side, Dorothea withdrew her arm and lingered on
17037: the matting, that she might leave her husband quite free. He entered
17038: the library and shut himself in, alone with his sorrow.
17039: 
17040: She went up to her boudoir. The open bow-window let in the serene glory
17041: of the afternoon lying in the avenue, where the lime-trees cast long
17042: shadows. But Dorothea knew nothing of the scene. She threw herself on a
17043: chair, not heeding that she was in the dazzling sun-rays: if there were
17044: discomfort in that, how could she tell that it was not part of her
17045: inward misery?
17046: 
17047: She was in the reaction of a rebellious anger stronger than any she had
17048: felt since her marriage. Instead of tears there came words:—
17049: 
17050: “What have I done—what am I—that he should treat me so? He never knows
17051: what is in my mind—he never cares. What is the use of anything I do? He
17052: wishes he had never married me.”
17053: 
17054: She began to hear herself, and was checked into stillness. Like one who
17055: has lost his way and is weary, she sat and saw as in one glance all the
17056: paths of her young hope which she should never find again. And just as
17057: clearly in the miserable light she saw her own and her husband’s
17058: solitude—how they walked apart so that she was obliged to survey him.
17059: If he had drawn her towards him, she would never have surveyed
17060: him—never have said, “Is he worth living for?” but would have felt him
17061: simply a part of her own life. Now she said bitterly, “It is his fault,
17062: not mine.” In the jar of her whole being, Pity was overthrown. Was it
17063: her fault that she had believed in him—had believed in his
17064: worthiness?—And what, exactly, was he?— She was able enough to estimate
17065: him—she who waited on his glances with trembling, and shut her best
17066: soul in prison, paying it only hidden visits, that she might be petty
17067: enough to please him. In such a crisis as this, some women begin to
17068: hate.
17069: 
17070: The sun was low when Dorothea was thinking that she would not go down
17071: again, but would send a message to her husband saying that she was not
17072: well and preferred remaining up-stairs. She had never deliberately
17073: allowed her resentment to govern her in this way before, but she
17074: believed now that she could not see him again without telling him the
17075: truth about her feeling, and she must wait till she could do it without
17076: interruption. He might wonder and be hurt at her message. It was good
17077: that he should wonder and be hurt. Her anger said, as anger is apt to
17078: say, that God was with her—that all heaven, though it were crowded with
17079: spirits watching them, must be on her side. She had determined to ring
17080: her bell, when there came a rap at the door.
17081: 
17082: Mr. Casaubon had sent to say that he would have his dinner in the
17083: library. He wished to be quite alone this evening, being much occupied.
17084: 
17085: “I shall not dine, then, Tantripp.”
17086: 
17087: “Oh, madam, let me bring you a little something?”
17088: 
17089: “No; I am not well. Get everything ready in my dressing room, but pray
17090: do not disturb me again.”
17091: 
17092: Dorothea sat almost motionless in her meditative struggle, while the
17093: evening slowly deepened into night. But the struggle changed
17094: continually, as that of a man who begins with a movement towards
17095: striking and ends with conquering his desire to strike. The energy that
17096: would animate a crime is not more than is wanted to inspire a resolved
17097: submission, when the noble habit of the soul reasserts itself. That
17098: thought with which Dorothea had gone out to meet her husband—her
17099: conviction that he had been asking about the possible arrest of all his
17100: work, and that the answer must have wrung his heart, could not be long
17101: without rising beside the image of him, like a shadowy monitor looking
17102: at her anger with sad remonstrance. It cost her a litany of pictured
17103: sorrows and of silent cries that she might be the mercy for those
17104: sorrows—but the resolved submission did come; and when the house was
17105: still, and she knew that it was near the time when Mr. Casaubon
17106: habitually went to rest, she opened her door gently and stood outside
17107: in the darkness waiting for his coming up-stairs with a light in his
17108: hand. If he did not come soon she thought that she would go down and
17109: even risk incurring another pang. She would never again expect anything
17110: else. But she did hear the library door open, and slowly the light
17111: advanced up the staircase without noise from the footsteps on the
17112: carpet. When her husband stood opposite to her, she saw that his face
17113: was more haggard. He started slightly on seeing her, and she looked up
17114: at him beseechingly, without speaking.
17115: 
17116: “Dorothea!” he said, with a gentle surprise in his tone. “Were you
17117: waiting for me?”
17118: 
17119: “Yes, I did not like to disturb you.”
17120: 
17121: “Come, my dear, come. You are young, and need not to extend your life
17122: by watching.”
17123: 
17124: When the kind quiet melancholy of that speech fell on Dorothea’s ears,
17125: she felt something like the thankfulness that might well up in us if we
17126: had narrowly escaped hurting a lamed creature. She put her hand into
17127: her husband’s, and they went along the broad corridor together.
17128: 
17129: 
17130: 
17131: 
17132: BOOK V.
17133: THE DEAD HAND.
17134: 
17135: 
17136: 
17137: 
17138: CHAPTER XLIII.
17139: 
17140: “This figure hath high price: ’t was wrought with love
17141: Ages ago in finest ivory;
17142: Nought modish in it, pure and noble lines
17143: Of generous womanhood that fits all time
17144: That too is costly ware; majolica
17145: Of deft design, to please a lordly eye:
17146: The smile, you see, is perfect—wonderful
17147: As mere Faience! a table ornament
17148: To suit the richest mounting.”
17149: 
17150: 
17151: Dorothea seldom left home without her husband, but she did occasionally
17152: drive into Middlemarch alone, on little errands of shopping or charity
17153: such as occur to every lady of any wealth when she lives within three
17154: miles of a town. Two days after that scene in the Yew-tree Walk, she
17155: determined to use such an opportunity in order if possible to see
17156: Lydgate, and learn from him whether her husband had really felt any
17157: depressing change of symptoms which he was concealing from her, and
17158: whether he had insisted on knowing the utmost about himself. She felt
17159: almost guilty in asking for knowledge about him from another, but the
17160: dread of being without it—the dread of that ignorance which would make
17161: her unjust or hard—overcame every scruple. That there had been some
17162: crisis in her husband’s mind she was certain: he had the very next day
17163: begun a new method of arranging his notes, and had associated her quite
17164: newly in carrying out his plan. Poor Dorothea needed to lay up stores
17165: of patience.
17166: 
17167: It was about four o’clock when she drove to Lydgate’s house in Lowick
17168: Gate, wishing, in her immediate doubt of finding him at home, that she
17169: had written beforehand. And he was not at home.
17170: 
17171: “Is Mrs. Lydgate at home?” said Dorothea, who had never, that she knew
17172: of, seen Rosamond, but now remembered the fact of the marriage. Yes,
17173: Mrs. Lydgate was at home.
17174: 
17175: “I will go in and speak to her, if she will allow me. Will you ask her
17176: if she can see me—see Mrs. Casaubon, for a few minutes?”
17177: 
17178: When the servant had gone to deliver that message, Dorothea could hear
17179: sounds of music through an open window—a few notes from a man’s voice
17180: and then a piano bursting into roulades. But the roulades broke off
17181: suddenly, and then the servant came back saying that Mrs. Lydgate would
17182: be happy to see Mrs. Casaubon.
17183: 
17184: When the drawing-room door opened and Dorothea entered, there was a
17185: sort of contrast not infrequent in country life when the habits of the
17186: different ranks were less blent than now. Let those who know, tell us
17187: exactly what stuff it was that Dorothea wore in those days of mild
17188: autumn—that thin white woollen stuff soft to the touch and soft to the
17189: eye. It always seemed to have been lately washed, and to smell of the
17190: sweet hedges—was always in the shape of a pelisse with sleeves hanging
17191: all out of the fashion. Yet if she had entered before a still audience
17192: as Imogene or Cato’s daughter, the dress might have seemed right
17193: enough: the grace and dignity were in her limbs and neck; and about her
17194: simply parted hair and candid eyes the large round poke which was then
17195: in the fate of women, seemed no more odd as a head-dress than the gold
17196: trencher we call a halo. By the present audience of two persons, no
17197: dramatic heroine could have been expected with more interest than Mrs.
17198: Casaubon. To Rosamond she was one of those county divinities not mixing
17199: with Middlemarch mortality, whose slightest marks of manner or
17200: appearance were worthy of her study; moreover, Rosamond was not without
17201: satisfaction that Mrs. Casaubon should have an opportunity of studying
17202: _her_. What is the use of being exquisite if you are not seen by the
17203: best judges? and since Rosamond had received the highest compliments at
17204: Sir Godwin Lydgate’s, she felt quite confident of the impression she
17205: must make on people of good birth. Dorothea put out her hand with her
17206: usual simple kindness, and looked admiringly at Lydgate’s lovely
17207: bride—aware that there was a gentleman standing at a distance, but
17208: seeing him merely as a coated figure at a wide angle. The gentleman was
17209: too much occupied with the presence of the one woman to reflect on the
17210: contrast between the two—a contrast that would certainly have been
17211: striking to a calm observer. They were both tall, and their eyes were
17212: on a level; but imagine Rosamond’s infantine blondness and wondrous
17213: crown of hair-plaits, with her pale-blue dress of a fit and fashion so
17214: perfect that no dressmaker could look at it without emotion, a large
17215: embroidered collar which it was to be hoped all beholders would know
17216: the price of, her small hands duly set off with rings, and that
17217: controlled self-consciousness of manner which is the expensive
17218: substitute for simplicity.
17219: 
17220: “Thank you very much for allowing me to interrupt you,” said Dorothea,
17221: immediately. “I am anxious to see Mr. Lydgate, if possible, before I go
17222: home, and I hoped that you might possibly tell me where I could find
17223: him, or even allow me to wait for him, if you expect him soon.”
17224: 
17225: “He is at the New Hospital,” said Rosamond; “I am not sure how soon he
17226: will come home. But I can send for him.”
17227: 
17228: “Will you let me go and fetch him?” said Will Ladislaw, coming forward.
17229: He had already taken up his hat before Dorothea entered. She colored
17230: with surprise, but put out her hand with a smile of unmistakable
17231: pleasure, saying—
17232: 
17233: “I did not know it was you: I had no thought of seeing you here.”
17234: 
17235: “May I go to the Hospital and tell Mr. Lydgate that you wish to see
17236: him?” said Will.
17237: 
17238: “It would be quicker to send the carriage for him,” said Dorothea, “if
17239: you will be kind enough to give the message to the coachman.”
17240: 
17241: Will was moving to the door when Dorothea, whose mind had flashed in an
17242: instant over many connected memories, turned quickly and said, “I will
17243: go myself, thank you. I wish to lose no time before getting home again.
17244: I will drive to the Hospital and see Mr. Lydgate there. Pray excuse me,
17245: Mrs. Lydgate. I am very much obliged to you.”
17246: 
17247: Her mind was evidently arrested by some sudden thought, and she left
17248: the room hardly conscious of what was immediately around her—hardly
17249: conscious that Will opened the door for her and offered her his arm to
17250: lead her to the carriage. She took the arm but said nothing. Will was
17251: feeling rather vexed and miserable, and found nothing to say on his
17252: side. He handed her into the carriage in silence, they said good-by,
17253: and Dorothea drove away.
17254: 
17255: In the five minutes’ drive to the Hospital she had time for some
17256: reflections that were quite new to her. Her decision to go, and her
17257: preoccupation in leaving the room, had come from the sudden sense that
17258: there would be a sort of deception in her voluntarily allowing any
17259: further intercourse between herself and Will which she was unable to
17260: mention to her husband, and already her errand in seeking Lydgate was a
17261: matter of concealment. That was all that had been explicitly in her
17262: mind; but she had been urged also by a vague discomfort. Now that she
17263: was alone in her drive, she heard the notes of the man’s voice and the
17264: accompanying piano, which she had not noted much at the time, returning
17265: on her inward sense; and she found herself thinking with some wonder
17266: that Will Ladislaw was passing his time with Mrs. Lydgate in her
17267: husband’s absence. And then she could not help remembering that he had
17268: passed some time with her under like circumstances, so why should there
17269: be any unfitness in the fact? But Will was Mr. Casaubon’s relative, and
17270: one towards whom she was bound to show kindness. Still there had been
17271: signs which perhaps she ought to have understood as implying that Mr.
17272: Casaubon did not like his cousin’s visits during his own absence.
17273: “Perhaps I have been mistaken in many things,” said poor Dorothea to
17274: herself, while the tears came rolling and she had to dry them quickly.
17275: She felt confusedly unhappy, and the image of Will which had been so
17276: clear to her before was mysteriously spoiled. But the carriage stopped
17277: at the gate of the Hospital. She was soon walking round the grass plots
17278: with Lydgate, and her feelings recovered the strong bent which had made
17279: her seek for this interview.
17280: 
17281: Will Ladislaw, meanwhile, was mortified, and knew the reason of it
17282: clearly enough. His chances of meeting Dorothea were rare; and here for
17283: the first time there had come a chance which had set him at a
17284: disadvantage. It was not only, as it had been hitherto, that she was
17285: not supremely occupied with him, but that she had seen him under
17286: circumstances in which he might appear not to be supremely occupied
17287: with her. He felt thrust to a new distance from her, amongst the
17288: circles of Middlemarchers who made no part of her life. But that was
17289: not his fault: of course, since he had taken his lodgings in the town,
17290: he had been making as many acquaintances as he could, his position
17291: requiring that he should know everybody and everything. Lydgate was
17292: really better worth knowing than any one else in the neighborhood, and
17293: he happened to have a wife who was musical and altogether worth calling
17294: upon. Here was the whole history of the situation in which Diana had
17295: descended too unexpectedly on her worshipper. It was mortifying. Will
17296: was conscious that he should not have been at Middlemarch but for
17297: Dorothea; and yet his position there was threatening to divide him from
17298: her with those barriers of habitual sentiment which are more fatal to
17299: the persistence of mutual interest than all the distance between Rome
17300: and Britain. Prejudices about rank and status were easy enough to defy
17301: in the form of a tyrannical letter from Mr. Casaubon; but prejudices,
17302: like odorous bodies, have a double existence both solid and
17303: subtle—solid as the pyramids, subtle as the twentieth echo of an echo,
17304: or as the memory of hyacinths which once scented the darkness. And Will
17305: was of a temperament to feel keenly the presence of subtleties: a man
17306: of clumsier perceptions would not have felt, as he did, that for the
17307: first time some sense of unfitness in perfect freedom with him had
17308: sprung up in Dorothea’s mind, and that their silence, as he conducted
17309: her to the carriage, had had a chill in it. Perhaps Casaubon, in his
17310: hatred and jealousy, had been insisting to Dorothea that Will had slid
17311: below her socially. Confound Casaubon!
17312: 
17313: Will re-entered the drawing-room, took up his hat, and looking
17314: irritated as he advanced towards Mrs. Lydgate, who had seated herself
17315: at her work-table, said—
17316: 
17317: “It is always fatal to have music or poetry interrupted. May I come
17318: another day and just finish about the rendering of ‘Lungi dal caro
17319: bene’?”
17320: 
17321: “I shall be happy to be taught,” said Rosamond. “But I am sure you
17322: admit that the interruption was a very beautiful one. I quite envy your
17323: acquaintance with Mrs. Casaubon. Is she very clever? She looks as if
17324: she were.”
17325: 
17326: “Really, I never thought about it,” said Will, sulkily.
17327: 
17328: “That is just the answer Tertius gave me, when I first asked him if she
17329: were handsome. What is it that you gentlemen are thinking of when you
17330: are with Mrs. Casaubon?”
17331: 
17332: “Herself,” said Will, not indisposed to provoke the charming Mrs.
17333: Lydgate. “When one sees a perfect woman, one never thinks of her
17334: attributes—one is conscious of her presence.”
17335: 
17336: “I shall be jealous when Tertius goes to Lowick,” said Rosamond,
17337: dimpling, and speaking with aery lightness. “He will come back and
17338: think nothing of me.”
17339: 
17340: “That does not seem to have been the effect on Lydgate hitherto. Mrs.
17341: Casaubon is too unlike other women for them to be compared with her.”
17342: 
17343: “You are a devout worshipper, I perceive. You often see her, I
17344: suppose.”
17345: 
17346: “No,” said Will, almost pettishly. “Worship is usually a matter of
17347: theory rather than of practice. But I am practising it to excess just
17348: at this moment—I must really tear myself away.”
17349: 
17350: “Pray come again some evening: Mr. Lydgate will like to hear the music,
17351: and I cannot enjoy it so well without him.”
17352: 
17353: When her husband was at home again, Rosamond said, standing in front of
17354: him and holding his coat-collar with both her hands, “Mr. Ladislaw was
17355: here singing with me when Mrs. Casaubon came in. He seemed vexed. Do
17356: you think he disliked her seeing him at our house? Surely your position
17357: is more than equal to his—whatever may be his relation to the
17358: Casaubons.”
17359: 
17360: “No, no; it must be something else if he were really vexed. Ladislaw is
17361: a sort of gypsy; he thinks nothing of leather and prunella.”
17362: 
17363: “Music apart, he is not always very agreeable. Do you like him?”
17364: 
17365: “Yes: I think he is a good fellow: rather miscellaneous and
17366: bric-a-brac, but likable.”
17367: 
17368: “Do you know, I think he adores Mrs. Casaubon.”
17369: 
17370: “Poor devil!” said Lydgate, smiling and pinching his wife’s ears.
17371: 
17372: Rosamond felt herself beginning to know a great deal of the world,
17373: especially in discovering what when she was in her unmarried girlhood
17374: had been inconceivable to her except as a dim tragedy in by-gone
17375: costumes—that women, even after marriage, might make conquests and
17376: enslave men. At that time young ladies in the country, even when
17377: educated at Mrs. Lemon’s, read little French literature later than
17378: Racine, and public prints had not cast their present magnificent
17379: illumination over the scandals of life. Still, vanity, with a woman’s
17380: whole mind and day to work in, can construct abundantly on slight
17381: hints, especially on such a hint as the possibility of indefinite
17382: conquests. How delightful to make captives from the throne of marriage
17383: with a husband as crown-prince by your side—himself in fact a
17384: subject—while the captives look up forever hopeless, losing their rest
17385: probably, and if their appetite too, so much the better! But Rosamond’s
17386: romance turned at present chiefly on her crown-prince, and it was
17387: enough to enjoy his assured subjection. When he said, “Poor devil!” she
17388: asked, with playful curiosity—
17389: 
17390: “Why so?”
17391: 
17392: “Why, what can a man do when he takes to adoring one of you mermaids?
17393: He only neglects his work and runs up bills.”
17394: 
17395: “I am sure you do not neglect your work. You are always at the
17396: Hospital, or seeing poor patients, or thinking about some doctor’s
17397: quarrel; and then at home you always want to pore over your microscope
17398: and phials. Confess you like those things better than me.”
17399: 
17400: “Haven’t you ambition enough to wish that your husband should be
17401: something better than a Middlemarch doctor?” said Lydgate, letting his
17402: hands fall on to his wife’s shoulders, and looking at her with
17403: affectionate gravity. “I shall make you learn my favorite bit from an
17404: old poet—
17405: 
17406: ‘Why should our pride make such a stir to be
17407: And be forgot? What good is like to this,
17408: To do worthy the writing, and to write
17409: Worthy the reading and the worlds delight?’
17410: 
17411: 
17412: What I want, Rosy, is to do worthy the writing,—and to write out myself
17413: what I have done. A man must work, to do that, my pet.”
17414: 
17415: “Of course, I wish you to make discoveries: no one could more wish you
17416: to attain a high position in some better place than Middlemarch. You
17417: cannot say that I have ever tried to hinder you from working. But we
17418: cannot live like hermits. You are not discontented with me, Tertius?”
17419: 
17420: “No, dear, no. I am too entirely contented.”
17421: 
17422: “But what did Mrs. Casaubon want to say to you?”
17423: 
17424: “Merely to ask about her husband’s health. But I think she is going to
17425: be splendid to our New Hospital: I think she will give us two hundred
17426: a-year.”
17427: 
17428: 
17429: 
17430: 
17431: CHAPTER XLIV.
17432: 
17433: I would not creep along the coast but steer
17434: Out in mid-sea, by guidance of the stars.
17435: 
17436: 
17437: When Dorothea, walking round the laurel-planted plots of the New
17438: Hospital with Lydgate, had learned from him that there were no signs of
17439: change in Mr. Casaubon’s bodily condition beyond the mental sign of
17440: anxiety to know the truth about his illness, she was silent for a few
17441: moments, wondering whether she had said or done anything to rouse this
17442: new anxiety. Lydgate, not willing to let slip an opportunity of
17443: furthering a favorite purpose, ventured to say—
17444: 
17445: “I don’t know whether your or Mr. Casaubon’s attention has been drawn
17446: to the needs of our New Hospital. Circumstances have made it seem
17447: rather egotistic in me to urge the subject; but that is not my fault:
17448: it is because there is a fight being made against it by the other
17449: medical men. I think you are generally interested in such things, for I
17450: remember that when I first had the pleasure of seeing you at Tipton
17451: Grange before your marriage, you were asking me some questions about
17452: the way in which the health of the poor was affected by their miserable
17453: housing.”
17454: 
17455: “Yes, indeed,” said Dorothea, brightening. “I shall be quite grateful
17456: to you if you will tell me how I can help to make things a little
17457: better. Everything of that sort has slipped away from me since I have
17458: been married. I mean,” she said, after a moment’s hesitation, “that the
17459: people in our village are tolerably comfortable, and my mind has been
17460: too much taken up for me to inquire further. But here—in such a place
17461: as Middlemarch—there must be a great deal to be done.”
17462: 
17463: “There is everything to be done,” said Lydgate, with abrupt energy.
17464: “And this Hospital is a capital piece of work, due entirely to Mr.
17465: Bulstrode’s exertions, and in a great degree to his money. But one man
17466: can’t do everything in a scheme of this sort. Of course he looked
17467: forward to help. And now there’s a mean, petty feud set up against the
17468: thing in the town, by certain persons who want to make it a failure.”
17469: 
17470: “What can be their reasons?” said Dorothea, with naive surprise.
17471: 
17472: “Chiefly Mr. Bulstrode’s unpopularity, to begin with. Half the town
17473: would almost take trouble for the sake of thwarting him. In this stupid
17474: world most people never consider that a thing is good to be done unless
17475: it is done by their own set. I had no connection with Bulstrode before
17476: I came here. I look at him quite impartially, and I see that he has
17477: some notions—that he has set things on foot—which I can turn to good
17478: public purpose. If a fair number of the better educated men went to
17479: work with the belief that their observations might contribute to the
17480: reform of medical doctrine and practice, we should soon see a change
17481: for the better. That’s my point of view. I hold that by refusing to
17482: work with Mr. Bulstrode I should be turning my back on an opportunity
17483: of making my profession more generally serviceable.”
17484: 
17485: “I quite agree with you,” said Dorothea, at once fascinated by the
17486: situation sketched in Lydgate’s words. “But what is there against Mr.
17487: Bulstrode? I know that my uncle is friendly with him.”
17488: 
17489: “People don’t like his religious tone,” said Lydgate, breaking off
17490: there.
17491: 
17492: “That is all the stronger reason for despising such an opposition,”
17493: said Dorothea, looking at the affairs of Middlemarch by the light of
17494: the great persecutions.
17495: 
17496: “To put the matter quite fairly, they have other objections to him:—he
17497: is masterful and rather unsociable, and he is concerned with trade,
17498: which has complaints of its own that I know nothing about. But what has
17499: that to do with the question whether it would not be a fine thing to
17500: establish here a more valuable hospital than any they have in the
17501: county? The immediate motive to the opposition, however, is the fact
17502: that Bulstrode has put the medical direction into my hands. Of course I
17503: am glad of that. It gives me an opportunity of doing some good
17504: work,—and I am aware that I have to justify his choice of me. But the
17505: consequence is, that the whole profession in Middlemarch have set
17506: themselves tooth and nail against the Hospital, and not only refuse to
17507: cooperate themselves, but try to blacken the whole affair and hinder
17508: subscriptions.”
17509: 
17510: “How very petty!” exclaimed Dorothea, indignantly.
17511: 
17512: “I suppose one must expect to fight one’s way: there is hardly anything
17513: to be done without it. And the ignorance of people about here is
17514: stupendous. I don’t lay claim to anything else than having used some
17515: opportunities which have not come within everybody’s reach; but there
17516: is no stifling the offence of being young, and a new-comer, and
17517: happening to know something more than the old inhabitants. Still, if I
17518: believe that I can set going a better method of treatment—if I believe
17519: that I can pursue certain observations and inquiries which may be a
17520: lasting benefit to medical practice, I should be a base truckler if I
17521: allowed any consideration of personal comfort to hinder me. And the
17522: course is all the clearer from there being no salary in question to put
17523: my persistence in an equivocal light.”
17524: 
17525: “I am glad you have told me this, Mr. Lydgate,” said Dorothea,
17526: cordially. “I feel sure I can help a little. I have some money, and
17527: don’t know what to do with it—that is often an uncomfortable thought to
17528: me. I am sure I can spare two hundred a-year for a grand purpose like
17529: this. How happy you must be, to know things that you feel sure will do
17530: great good! I wish I could awake with that knowledge every morning.
17531: There seems to be so much trouble taken that one can hardly see the
17532: good of!”
17533:
