17534: There was a melancholy cadence in Dorothea’s voice as she spoke these
17535: last words. But she presently added, more cheerfully, “Pray come to
17536: Lowick and tell us more of this. I will mention the subject to Mr.
17537: Casaubon. I must hasten home now.”
17538: 
17539: She did mention it that evening, and said that she should like to
17540: subscribe two hundred a-year—she had seven hundred a-year as the
17541: equivalent of her own fortune, settled on her at her marriage. Mr.
17542: Casaubon made no objection beyond a passing remark that the sum might
17543: be disproportionate in relation to other good objects, but when
17544: Dorothea in her ignorance resisted that suggestion, he acquiesced. He
17545: did not care himself about spending money, and was not reluctant to
17546: give it. If he ever felt keenly any question of money it was through
17547: the medium of another passion than the love of material property.
17548: 
17549: Dorothea told him that she had seen Lydgate, and recited the gist of
17550: her conversation with him about the Hospital. Mr. Casaubon did not
17551: question her further, but he felt sure that she had wished to know what
17552: had passed between Lydgate and himself. “She knows that I know,” said
17553: the ever-restless voice within; but that increase of tacit knowledge
17554: only thrust further off any confidence between them. He distrusted her
17555: affection; and what loneliness is more lonely than distrust?
17556: 
17557: 
17558: 
17559: 
17560: CHAPTER XLV.
17561: 
17562: It is the humor of many heads to extol the days of their forefathers,
17563: and declaim against the wickedness of times present. Which
17564: notwithstanding they cannot handsomely do, without the borrowed help
17565: and satire of times past; condemning the vices of their own times, by
17566: the expressions of vices in times which they commend, which cannot but
17567: argue the community of vice in both. Horace, therefore, Juvenal, and
17568: Persius, were no prophets, although their lines did seem to indigitate
17569: and point at our times.—SIR THOMAS BROWNE: _Pseudodoxia Epidemica_.
17570: 
17571: 
17572: That opposition to the New Fever Hospital which Lydgate had sketched to
17573: Dorothea was, like other oppositions, to be viewed in many different
17574: lights. He regarded it as a mixture of jealousy and dunderheaded
17575: prejudice. Mr. Bulstrode saw in it not only medical jealousy but a
17576: determination to thwart himself, prompted mainly by a hatred of that
17577: vital religion of which he had striven to be an effectual lay
17578: representative—a hatred which certainly found pretexts apart from
17579: religion such as were only too easy to find in the entanglements of
17580: human action. These might be called the ministerial views. But
17581: oppositions have the illimitable range of objections at command, which
17582: need never stop short at the boundary of knowledge, but can draw
17583: forever on the vasts of ignorance. What the opposition in Middlemarch
17584: said about the New Hospital and its administration had certainly a
17585: great deal of echo in it, for heaven has taken care that everybody
17586: shall not be an originator; but there were differences which
17587: represented every social shade between the polished moderation of Dr.
17588: Minchin and the trenchant assertion of Mrs. Dollop, the landlady of the
17589: Tankard in Slaughter Lane.
17590: 
17591: Mrs. Dollop became more and more convinced by her own asseveration,
17592: that Dr. Lydgate meant to let the people die in the Hospital, if not to
17593: poison them, for the sake of cutting them up without saying by your
17594: leave or with your leave; for it was a known “fac” that he had wanted
17595: to cut up Mrs. Goby, as respectable a woman as any in Parley Street,
17596: who had money in trust before her marriage—a poor tale for a doctor,
17597: who if he was good for anything should know what was the matter with
17598: you before you died, and not want to pry into your inside after you
17599: were gone. If that was not reason, Mrs. Dollop wished to know what was;
17600: but there was a prevalent feeling in her audience that her opinion was
17601: a bulwark, and that if it were overthrown there would be no limits to
17602: the cutting-up of bodies, as had been well seen in Burke and Hare with
17603: their pitch-plaisters—such a hanging business as that was not wanted in
17604: Middlemarch!
17605: 
17606: And let it not be supposed that opinion at the Tankard in Slaughter
17607: Lane was unimportant to the medical profession: that old authentic
17608: public-house—the original Tankard, known by the name of Dollop’s—was
17609: the resort of a great Benefit Club, which had some months before put to
17610: the vote whether its long-standing medical man, “Doctor Gambit,” should
17611: not be cashiered in favor of “this Doctor Lydgate,” who was capable of
17612: performing the most astonishing cures, and rescuing people altogether
17613: given up by other practitioners. But the balance had been turned
17614: against Lydgate by two members, who for some private reasons held that
17615: this power of resuscitating persons as good as dead was an equivocal
17616: recommendation, and might interfere with providential favors. In the
17617: course of the year, however, there had been a change in the public
17618: sentiment, of which the unanimity at Dollop’s was an index.
17619: 
17620: A good deal more than a year ago, before anything was known of
17621: Lydgate’s skill, the judgments on it had naturally been divided,
17622: depending on a sense of likelihood, situated perhaps in the pit of the
17623: stomach or in the pineal gland, and differing in its verdicts, but not
17624: the less valuable as a guide in the total deficit of evidence. Patients
17625: who had chronic diseases or whose lives had long been worn threadbare,
17626: like old Featherstone’s, had been at once inclined to try him; also,
17627: many who did not like paying their doctor’s bills, thought agreeably of
17628: opening an account with a new doctor and sending for him without stint
17629: if the children’s temper wanted a dose, occasions when the old
17630: practitioners were often crusty; and all persons thus inclined to
17631: employ Lydgate held it likely that he was clever. Some considered that
17632: he might do more than others “where there was liver;”—at least there
17633: would be no harm in getting a few bottles of “stuff” from him, since if
17634: these proved useless it would still be possible to return to the
17635: Purifying Pills, which kept you alive if they did not remove the
17636: yellowness. But these were people of minor importance. Good Middlemarch
17637: families were of course not going to change their doctor without reason
17638: shown; and everybody who had employed Mr. Peacock did not feel obliged
17639: to accept a new man merely in the character of his successor, objecting
17640: that he was “not likely to be equal to Peacock.”
17641: 
17642: But Lydgate had not been long in the town before there were particulars
17643: enough reported of him to breed much more specific expectations and to
17644: intensify differences into partisanship; some of the particulars being
17645: of that impressive order of which the significance is entirely hidden,
17646: like a statistical amount without a standard of comparison, but with a
17647: note of exclamation at the end. The cubic feet of oxygen yearly
17648: swallowed by a full-grown man—what a shudder they might have created in
17649: some Middlemarch circles! “Oxygen! nobody knows what that may be—is it
17650: any wonder the cholera has got to Dantzic? And yet there are people who
17651: say quarantine is no good!”
17652: 
17653: One of the facts quickly rumored was that Lydgate did not dispense
17654: drugs. This was offensive both to the physicians whose exclusive
17655: distinction seemed infringed on, and to the surgeon-apothecaries with
17656: whom he ranged himself; and only a little while before, they might have
17657: counted on having the law on their side against a man who without
17658: calling himself a London-made M.D. dared to ask for pay except as a
17659: charge on drugs. But Lydgate had not been experienced enough to foresee
17660: that his new course would be even more offensive to the laity; and to
17661: Mr. Mawmsey, an important grocer in the Top Market, who, though not one
17662: of his patients, questioned him in an affable manner on the subject, he
17663: was injudicious enough to give a hasty popular explanation of his
17664: reasons, pointing out to Mr. Mawmsey that it must lower the character
17665: of practitioners, and be a constant injury to the public, if their only
17666: mode of getting paid for their work was by their making out long bills
17667: for draughts, boluses, and mixtures.
17668: 
17669: “It is in that way that hard-working medical men may come to be almost
17670: as mischievous as quacks,” said Lydgate, rather thoughtlessly. “To get
17671: their own bread they must overdose the king’s lieges; and that’s a bad
17672: sort of treason, Mr. Mawmsey—undermines the constitution in a fatal
17673: way.”
17674: 
17675: Mr. Mawmsey was not only an overseer (it was about a question of
17676: outdoor pay that he was having an interview with Lydgate), he was also
17677: asthmatic and had an increasing family: thus, from a medical point of
17678: view, as well as from his own, he was an important man; indeed, an
17679: exceptional grocer, whose hair was arranged in a flame-like pyramid,
17680: and whose retail deference was of the cordial, encouraging
17681: kind—jocosely complimentary, and with a certain considerate abstinence
17682: from letting out the full force of his mind. It was Mr. Mawmsey’s
17683: friendly jocoseness in questioning him which had set the tone of
17684: Lydgate’s reply. But let the wise be warned against too great readiness
17685: at explanation: it multiplies the sources of mistake, lengthening the
17686: sum for reckoners sure to go wrong.
17687: 
17688: Lydgate smiled as he ended his speech, putting his foot into the
17689: stirrup, and Mr. Mawmsey laughed more than he would have done if he had
17690: known who the king’s lieges were, giving his “Good morning, sir,
17691: good-morning, sir,” with the air of one who saw everything clearly
17692: enough. But in truth his views were perturbed. For years he had been
17693: paying bills with strictly made items, so that for every half-crown and
17694: eighteen-pence he was certain something measurable had been delivered.
17695: He had done this with satisfaction, including it among his
17696: responsibilities as a husband and father, and regarding a longer bill
17697: than usual as a dignity worth mentioning. Moreover, in addition to the
17698: massive benefit of the drugs to “self and family,” he had enjoyed the
17699: pleasure of forming an acute judgment as to their immediate effects, so
17700: as to give an intelligent statement for the guidance of Mr. Gambit—a
17701: practitioner just a little lower in status than Wrench or Toller, and
17702: especially esteemed as an accoucheur, of whose ability Mr. Mawmsey had
17703: the poorest opinion on all other points, but in doctoring, he was wont
17704: to say in an undertone, he placed Gambit above any of them.
17705: 
17706: Here were deeper reasons than the superficial talk of a new man, which
17707: appeared still flimsier in the drawing-room over the shop, when they
17708: were recited to Mrs. Mawmsey, a woman accustomed to be made much of as
17709: a fertile mother,—generally under attendance more or less frequent from
17710: Mr. Gambit, and occasionally having attacks which required Dr. Minchin.
17711: 
17712: “Does this Mr. Lydgate mean to say there is no use in taking medicine?”
17713: said Mrs. Mawmsey, who was slightly given to drawling. “I should like
17714: him to tell me how I could bear up at Fair time, if I didn’t take
17715: strengthening medicine for a month beforehand. Think of what I have to
17716: provide for calling customers, my dear!”—here Mrs. Mawmsey turned to an
17717: intimate female friend who sat by—“a large veal pie—a stuffed fillet—a
17718: round of beef—ham, tongue, et cetera, et cetera! But what keeps me up
17719: best is the pink mixture, not the brown. I wonder, Mr. Mawmsey, with
17720: _your_ experience, you could have patience to listen. I should have
17721: told him at once that I knew a little better than that.”
17722: 
17723: “No, no, no,” said Mr. Mawmsey; “I was not going to tell him my
17724: opinion. Hear everything and judge for yourself is my motto. But he
17725: didn’t know who he was talking to. I was not to be turned on _his_
17726: finger. People often pretend to tell me things, when they might as well
17727: say, ‘Mawmsey, you’re a fool.’ But I smile at it: I humor everybody’s
17728: weak place. If physic had done harm to self and family, I should have
17729: found it out by this time.”
17730: 
17731: The next day Mr. Gambit was told that Lydgate went about saying physic
17732: was of no use.
17733: 
17734: “Indeed!” said he, lifting his eyebrows with cautious surprise. (He was
17735: a stout husky man with a large ring on his fourth finger.) “How will he
17736: cure his patients, then?”
17737: 
17738: “That is what I say,” returned Mrs. Mawmsey, who habitually gave weight
17739: to her speech by loading her pronouns. “Does _he_ suppose that people
17740: will pay him only to come and sit with them and go away again?”
17741: 
17742: Mrs. Mawmsey had had a great deal of sitting from Mr. Gambit, including
17743: very full accounts of his own habits of body and other affairs; but of
17744: course he knew there was no innuendo in her remark, since his spare
17745: time and personal narrative had never been charged for. So he replied,
17746: humorously—
17747: 
17748: “Well, Lydgate is a good-looking young fellow, you know.”
17749: 
17750: “Not one that _I_ would employ,” said Mrs. Mawmsey. “_Others_ may do as
17751: they please.”
17752: 
17753: Hence Mr. Gambit could go away from the chief grocer’s without fear of
17754: rivalry, but not without a sense that Lydgate was one of those
17755: hypocrites who try to discredit others by advertising their own
17756: honesty, and that it might be worth some people’s while to show him up.
17757: Mr. Gambit, however, had a satisfactory practice, much pervaded by the
17758: smells of retail trading which suggested the reduction of cash payments
17759: to a balance. And he did not think it worth his while to show Lydgate
17760: up until he knew how. He had not indeed great resources of education,
17761: and had had to work his own way against a good deal of professional
17762: contempt; but he made none the worse accoucheur for calling the
17763: breathing apparatus “longs.”
17764: 
17765: Other medical men felt themselves more capable. Mr. Toller shared the
17766: highest practice in the town and belonged to an old Middlemarch family:
17767: there were Tollers in the law and everything else above the line of
17768: retail trade. Unlike our irascible friend Wrench, he had the easiest
17769: way in the world of taking things which might be supposed to annoy him,
17770: being a well-bred, quietly facetious man, who kept a good house, was
17771: very fond of a little sporting when he could get it, very friendly with
17772: Mr. Hawley, and hostile to Mr. Bulstrode. It may seem odd that with
17773: such pleasant habits he should have been given to the heroic treatment,
17774: bleeding and blistering and starving his patients, with a dispassionate
17775: disregard to his personal example; but the incongruity favored the
17776: opinion of his ability among his patients, who commonly observed that
17777: Mr. Toller had lazy manners, but his treatment was as active as you
17778: could desire: no man, said they, carried more seriousness into his
17779: profession: he was a little slow in coming, but when he came, he _did_
17780: something. He was a great favorite in his own circle, and whatever he
17781: implied to any one’s disadvantage told doubly from his careless
17782: ironical tone.
17783: 
17784: He naturally got tired of smiling and saying, “Ah!” when he was told
17785: that Mr. Peacock’s successor did not mean to dispense medicines; and
17786: Mr. Hackbutt one day mentioning it over the wine at a dinner-party, Mr.
17787: Toller said, laughingly, “Dibbitts will get rid of his stale drugs,
17788: then. I’m fond of little Dibbitts—I’m glad he’s in luck.”
17789: 
17790: “I see your meaning, Toller,” said Mr. Hackbutt, “and I am entirely of
17791: your opinion. I shall take an opportunity of expressing myself to that
17792: effect. A medical man should be responsible for the quality of the
17793: drugs consumed by his patients. That is the rationale of the system of
17794: charging which has hitherto obtained; and nothing is more offensive
17795: than this ostentation of reform, where there is no real amelioration.”
17796: 
17797: “Ostentation, Hackbutt?” said Mr. Toller, ironically. “I don’t see
17798: that. A man can’t very well be ostentatious of what nobody believes in.
17799: There’s no reform in the matter: the question is, whether the profit on
17800: the drugs is paid to the medical man by the druggist or by the patient,
17801: and whether there shall be extra pay under the name of attendance.”
17802: 
17803: “Ah, to be sure; one of your damned new versions of old humbug,” said
17804: Mr. Hawley, passing the decanter to Mr. Wrench.
17805: 
17806: Mr. Wrench, generally abstemious, often drank wine rather freely at a
17807: party, getting the more irritable in consequence.
17808: 
17809: “As to humbug, Hawley,” he said, “that’s a word easy to fling about.
17810: But what I contend against is the way medical men are fouling their own
17811: nest, and setting up a cry about the country as if a general
17812: practitioner who dispenses drugs couldn’t be a gentleman. I throw back
17813: the imputation with scorn. I say, the most ungentlemanly trick a man
17814: can be guilty of is to come among the members of his profession with
17815: innovations which are a libel on their time-honored procedure. That is
17816: my opinion, and I am ready to maintain it against any one who
17817: contradicts me.” Mr. Wrench’s voice had become exceedingly sharp.
17818: 
17819: “I can’t oblige you there, Wrench,” said Mr. Hawley, thrusting his
17820: hands into his trouser-pockets.
17821: 
17822: “My dear fellow,” said Mr. Toller, striking in pacifically, and looking
17823: at Mr. Wrench, “the physicians have their toes trodden on more than we
17824: have. If you come to dignity it is a question for Minchin and Sprague.”
17825: 
17826: “Does medical jurisprudence provide nothing against these
17827: infringements?” said Mr. Hackbutt, with a disinterested desire to offer
17828: his lights. “How does the law stand, eh, Hawley?”
17829: 
17830: “Nothing to be done there,” said Mr. Hawley. “I looked into it for
17831: Sprague. You’d only break your nose against a damned judge’s decision.”
17832: 
17833: “Pooh! no need of law,” said Mr. Toller. “So far as practice is
17834: concerned the attempt is an absurdity. No patient will like
17835: it—certainly not Peacock’s, who have been used to depletion. Pass the
17836: wine.”
17837: 
17838: Mr. Toller’s prediction was partly verified. If Mr. and Mrs. Mawmsey,
17839: who had no idea of employing Lydgate, were made uneasy by his supposed
17840: declaration against drugs, it was inevitable that those who called him
17841: in should watch a little anxiously to see whether he did “use all the
17842: means he might use” in the case. Even good Mr. Powderell, who in his
17843: constant charity of interpretation was inclined to esteem Lydgate the
17844: more for what seemed a conscientious pursuit of a better plan, had his
17845: mind disturbed with doubts during his wife’s attack of erysipelas, and
17846: could not abstain from mentioning to Lydgate that Mr. Peacock on a
17847: similar occasion had administered a series of boluses which were not
17848: otherwise definable than by their remarkable effect in bringing Mrs.
17849: Powderell round before Michaelmas from an illness which had begun in a
17850: remarkably hot August. At last, indeed, in the conflict between his
17851: desire not to hurt Lydgate and his anxiety that no “means” should be
17852: lacking, he induced his wife privately to take Widgeon’s Purifying
17853: Pills, an esteemed Middlemarch medicine, which arrested every disease
17854: at the fountain by setting to work at once upon the blood. This
17855: co-operative measure was not to be mentioned to Lydgate, and Mr.
17856: Powderell himself had no certain reliance on it, only hoping that it
17857: might be attended with a blessing.
17858: 
17859: But in this doubtful stage of Lydgate’s introduction he was helped by
17860: what we mortals rashly call good fortune. I suppose no doctor ever came
17861: newly to a place without making cures that surprised somebody—cures
17862: which may be called fortune’s testimonials, and deserve as much credit
17863: as the written or printed kind. Various patients got well while Lydgate
17864: was attending them, some even of dangerous illnesses; and it was
17865: remarked that the new doctor with his new ways had at least the merit
17866: of bringing people back from the brink of death. The trash talked on
17867: such occasions was the more vexatious to Lydgate, because it gave
17868: precisely the sort of prestige which an incompetent and unscrupulous
17869: man would desire, and was sure to be imputed to him by the simmering
17870: dislike of the other medical men as an encouragement on his own part of
17871: ignorant puffing. But even his proud outspokenness was checked by the
17872: discernment that it was as useless to fight against the interpretations
17873: of ignorance as to whip the fog; and “good fortune” insisted on using
17874: those interpretations.
17875: 
17876: Mrs. Larcher having just become charitably concerned about alarming
17877: symptoms in her charwoman, when Dr. Minchin called, asked him to see
17878: her then and there, and to give her a certificate for the Infirmary;
17879: whereupon after examination he wrote a statement of the case as one of
17880: tumor, and recommended the bearer Nancy Nash as an out-patient. Nancy,
17881: calling at home on her way to the Infirmary, allowed the stay maker and
17882: his wife, in whose attic she lodged, to read Dr. Minchin’s paper, and
17883: by this means became a subject of compassionate conversation in the
17884: neighboring shops of Churchyard Lane as being afflicted with a tumor at
17885: first declared to be as large and hard as a duck’s egg, but later in
17886: the day to be about the size of “your fist.” Most hearers agreed that
17887: it would have to be cut out, but one had known of oil and another of
17888: “squitchineal” as adequate to soften and reduce any lump in the body
17889: when taken enough of into the inside—the oil by gradually “soopling,”
17890: the squitchineal by eating away.
17891: 
17892: Meanwhile when Nancy presented herself at the Infirmary, it happened to
17893: be one of Lydgate’s days there. After questioning and examining her,
17894: Lydgate said to the house-surgeon in an undertone, “It’s not tumor:
17895: it’s cramp.” He ordered her a blister and some steel mixture, and told
17896: her to go home and rest, giving her at the same time a note to Mrs.
17897: Larcher, who, she said, was her best employer, to testify that she was
17898: in need of good food.
17899: 
17900: But by-and-by Nancy, in her attic, became portentously worse, the
17901: supposed tumor having indeed given way to the blister, but only
17902: wandered to another region with angrier pain. The staymaker’s wife went
17903: to fetch Lydgate, and he continued for a fortnight to attend Nancy in
17904: her own home, until under his treatment she got quite well and went to
17905: work again. But the case continued to be described as one of tumor in
17906: Churchyard Lane and other streets—nay, by Mrs. Larcher also; for when
17907: Lydgate’s remarkable cure was mentioned to Dr. Minchin, he naturally
17908: did not like to say, “The case was not one of tumor, and I was mistaken
17909: in describing it as such,” but answered, “Indeed! ah! I saw it was a
17910: surgical case, not of a fatal kind.” He had been inwardly annoyed,
17911: however, when he had asked at the Infirmary about the woman he had
17912: recommended two days before, to hear from the house-surgeon, a
17913: youngster who was not sorry to vex Minchin with impunity, exactly what
17914: had occurred: he privately pronounced that it was indecent in a general
17915: practitioner to contradict a physician’s diagnosis in that open manner,
17916: and afterwards agreed with Wrench that Lydgate was disagreeably
17917: inattentive to etiquette. Lydgate did not make the affair a ground for
17918: valuing himself or (very particularly) despising Minchin, such
17919: rectification of misjudgments often happening among men of equal
17920: qualifications. But report took up this amazing case of tumor, not
17921: clearly distinguished from cancer, and considered the more awful for
17922: being of the wandering sort; till much prejudice against Lydgate’s
17923: method as to drugs was overcome by the proof of his marvellous skill in
17924: the speedy restoration of Nancy Nash after she had been rolling and
17925: rolling in agonies from the presence of a tumor both hard and
17926: obstinate, but nevertheless compelled to yield.
17927: 
17928: How could Lydgate help himself? It is offensive to tell a lady when she
17929: is expressing her amazement at your skill, that she is altogether
17930: mistaken and rather foolish in her amazement. And to have entered into
17931: the nature of diseases would only have added to his breaches of medical
17932: propriety. Thus he had to wince under a promise of success given by
17933: that ignorant praise which misses every valid quality.
17934: 
17935: In the case of a more conspicuous patient, Mr. Borthrop Trumbull,
17936: Lydgate was conscious of having shown himself something better than an
17937: every-day doctor, though here too it was an equivocal advantage that he
17938: won. The eloquent auctioneer was seized with pneumonia, and having been
17939: a patient of Mr. Peacock’s, sent for Lydgate, whom he had expressed his
17940: intention to patronize. Mr Trumbull was a robust man, a good subject
17941: for trying the expectant theory upon—watching the course of an
17942: interesting disease when left as much as possible to itself, so that
17943: the stages might be noted for future guidance; and from the air with
17944: which he described his sensations Lydgate surmised that he would like
17945: to be taken into his medical man’s confidence, and be represented as a
17946: partner in his own cure. The auctioneer heard, without much surprise,
17947: that his was a constitution which (always with due watching) might be
17948: left to itself, so as to offer a beautiful example of a disease with
17949: all its phases seen in clear delineation, and that he probably had the
17950: rare strength of mind voluntarily to become the test of a rational
17951: procedure, and thus make the disorder of his pulmonary functions a
17952: general benefit to society.
17953: 
17954: Mr. Trumbull acquiesced at once, and entered strongly into the view
17955: that an illness of his was no ordinary occasion for medical science.
17956: 
17957: “Never fear, sir; you are not speaking to one who is altogether
17958: ignorant of the _vis medicatrix_,” said he, with his usual superiority
17959: of expression, made rather pathetic by difficulty of breathing. And he
17960: went without shrinking through his abstinence from drugs, much
17961: sustained by application of the thermometer which implied the
17962: importance of his temperature, by the sense that he furnished objects
17963: for the microscope, and by learning many new words which seemed suited
17964: to the dignity of his secretions. For Lydgate was acute enough to
17965: indulge him with a little technical talk.
17966: 
17967: It may be imagined that Mr. Trumbull rose from his couch with a
17968: disposition to speak of an illness in which he had manifested the
17969: strength of his mind as well as constitution; and he was not backward
17970: in awarding credit to the medical man who had discerned the quality of
17971: patient he had to deal with. The auctioneer was not an ungenerous man,
17972: and liked to give others their due, feeling that he could afford it. He
17973: had caught the words “expectant method,” and rang chimes on this and
17974: other learned phrases to accompany the assurance that Lydgate “knew a
17975: thing or two more than the rest of the doctors—was far better versed in
17976: the secrets of his profession than the majority of his compeers.”
17977: 
17978: This had happened before the affair of Fred Vincy’s illness had given
17979: to Mr. Wrench’s enmity towards Lydgate more definite personal ground.
17980: The new-comer already threatened to be a nuisance in the shape of
17981: rivalry, and was certainly a nuisance in the shape of practical
17982: criticism or reflections on his hard-driven elders, who had had
17983: something else to do than to busy themselves with untried notions. His
17984: practice had spread in one or two quarters, and from the first the
17985: report of his high family had led to his being pretty generally
17986: invited, so that the other medical men had to meet him at dinner in the
17987: best houses; and having to meet a man whom you dislike is not observed
17988: always to end in a mutual attachment. There was hardly ever so much
17989: unanimity among them as in the opinion that Lydgate was an arrogant
17990: young fellow, and yet ready for the sake of ultimately predominating to
17991: show a crawling subservience to Bulstrode. That Mr. Farebrother, whose
17992: name was a chief flag of the anti-Bulstrode party, always defended
17993: Lydgate and made a friend of him, was referred to Farebrother’s
17994: unaccountable way of fighting on both sides.
17995: 
17996: Here was plenty of preparation for the outburst of professional disgust
17997: at the announcement of the laws Mr. Bulstrode was laying down for the
17998: direction of the New Hospital, which were the more exasperating because
17999: there was no present possibility of interfering with his will and
18000: pleasure, everybody except Lord Medlicote having refused help towards
18001: the building, on the ground that they preferred giving to the Old
18002: Infirmary. Mr. Bulstrode met all the expenses, and had ceased to be
18003: sorry that he was purchasing the right to carry out his notions of
18004: improvement without hindrance from prejudiced coadjutors; but he had
18005: had to spend large sums, and the building had lingered. Caleb Garth had
18006: undertaken it, had failed during its progress, and before the interior
18007: fittings were begun had retired from the management of the business;
18008: and when referring to the Hospital he often said that however Bulstrode
18009: might ring if you tried him, he liked good solid carpentry and masonry,
18010: and had a notion both of drains and chimneys. In fact, the Hospital had
18011: become an object of intense interest to Bulstrode, and he would
18012: willingly have continued to spare a large yearly sum that he might rule
18013: it dictatorially without any Board; but he had another favorite object
18014: which also required money for its accomplishment: he wished to buy some
18015: land in the neighborhood of Middlemarch, and therefore he wished to get
18016: considerable contributions towards maintaining the Hospital. Meanwhile
18017: he framed his plan of management. The Hospital was to be reserved for
18018: fever in all its forms; Lydgate was to be chief medical superintendent,
18019: that he might have free authority to pursue all comparative
18020: investigations which his studies, particularly in Paris, had shown him
18021: the importance of, the other medical visitors having a consultative
18022: influence, but no power to contravene Lydgate’s ultimate decisions; and
18023: the general management was to be lodged exclusively in the hands of
18024: five directors associated with Mr. Bulstrode, who were to have votes in
18025: the ratio of their contributions, the Board itself filling up any
18026: vacancy in its numbers, and no mob of small contributors being admitted
18027: to a share of government.
18028: 
18029: There was an immediate refusal on the part of every medical man in the
18030: town to become a visitor at the Fever Hospital.
18031: 
18032: “Very well,” said Lydgate to Mr. Bulstrode, “we have a capital
18033: house-surgeon and dispenser, a clear-headed, neat-handed fellow; we’ll
18034: get Webbe from Crabsley, as good a country practitioner as any of them,
18035: to come over twice a-week, and in case of any exceptional operation,
18036: Protheroe will come from Brassing. I must work the harder, that’s all,
18037: and I have given up my post at the Infirmary. The plan will flourish in
18038: spite of them, and then they’ll be glad to come in. Things can’t last
18039: as they are: there must be all sorts of reform soon, and then young
18040: fellows may be glad to come and study here.” Lydgate was in high
18041: spirits.
18042: 
18043: “I shall not flinch, you may depend upon it, Mr. Lydgate,” said Mr.
18044: Bulstrode. “While I see you carrying out high intentions with vigor,
18045: you shall have my unfailing support. And I have humble confidence that
18046: the blessing which has hitherto attended my efforts against the spirit
18047: of evil in this town will not be withdrawn. Suitable directors to
18048: assist me I have no doubt of securing. Mr. Brooke of Tipton has already
18049: given me his concurrence, and a pledge to contribute yearly: he has not
18050: specified the sum—probably not a great one. But he will be a useful
18051: member of the board.”
18052: 
18053: A useful member was perhaps to be defined as one who would originate
18054: nothing, and always vote with Mr. Bulstrode.
18055: 
18056: The medical aversion to Lydgate was hardly disguised now. Neither Dr.
18057: Sprague nor Dr. Minchin said that he disliked Lydgate’s knowledge, or
18058: his disposition to improve treatment: what they disliked was his
18059: arrogance, which nobody felt to be altogether deniable. They implied
18060: that he was insolent, pretentious, and given to that reckless
18061: innovation for the sake of noise and show which was the essence of the
18062: charlatan.
18063: 
18064: The word charlatan once thrown on the air could not be let drop. In
18065: those days the world was agitated about the wondrous doings of Mr. St.
18066: John Long, “noblemen and gentlemen” attesting his extraction of a fluid
18067: like mercury from the temples of a patient.
18068: 
18069: Mr. Toller remarked one day, smilingly, to Mrs. Taft, that “Bulstrode
18070: had found a man to suit him in Lydgate; a charlatan in religion is sure
18071: to like other sorts of charlatans.”
18072: 
18073: “Yes, indeed, I can imagine,” said Mrs. Taft, keeping the number of
18074: thirty stitches carefully in her mind all the while; “there are so many
18075: of that sort. I remember Mr. Cheshire, with his irons, trying to make
18076: people straight when the Almighty had made them crooked.”
18077: 
18078: “No, no,” said Mr. Toller, “Cheshire was all right—all fair and above
18079: board. But there’s St. John Long—that’s the kind of fellow we call a
18080: charlatan, advertising cures in ways nobody knows anything about: a
18081: fellow who wants to make a noise by pretending to go deeper than other
18082: people. The other day he was pretending to tap a man’s brain and get
18083: quicksilver out of it.”
18084: 
18085: “Good gracious! what dreadful trifling with people’s constitutions!”
18086: said Mrs. Taft.
18087: 
18088: After this, it came to be held in various quarters that Lydgate played
18089: even with respectable constitutions for his own purposes, and how much
18090: more likely that in his flighty experimenting he should make sixes and
18091: sevens of hospital patients. Especially it was to be expected, as the
18092: landlady of the Tankard had said, that he would recklessly cut up their
18093: dead bodies. For Lydgate having attended Mrs. Goby, who died apparently
18094: of a heart-disease not very clearly expressed in the symptoms, too
18095: daringly asked leave of her relatives to open the body, and thus gave
18096: an offence quickly spreading beyond Parley Street, where that lady had
18097: long resided on an income such as made this association of her body
18098: with the victims of Burke and Hare a flagrant insult to her memory.
18099: 
18100: Affairs were in this stage when Lydgate opened the subject of the
18101: Hospital to Dorothea. We see that he was bearing enmity and silly
18102: misconception with much spirit, aware that they were partly created by
18103: his good share of success.
18104: 
18105: “They will not drive me away,” he said, talking confidentially in Mr.
18106: Farebrother’s study. “I have got a good opportunity here, for the ends
18107: I care most about; and I am pretty sure to get income enough for our
18108: wants. By-and-by I shall go on as quietly as possible: I have no
18109: seductions now away from home and work. And I am more and more
18110: convinced that it will be possible to demonstrate the homogeneous
18111: origin of all the tissues. Raspail and others are on the same track,
18112: and I have been losing time.”
18113: 
18114: “I have no power of prophecy there,” said Mr. Farebrother, who had been
18115: puffing at his pipe thoughtfully while Lydgate talked; “but as to the
18116: hostility in the town, you’ll weather it if you are prudent.”
18117: 
18118: “How am I to be prudent?” said Lydgate, “I just do what comes before me
18119: to do. I can’t help people’s ignorance and spite, any more than
18120: Vesalius could. It isn’t possible to square one’s conduct to silly
18121: conclusions which nobody can foresee.”
18122: 
18123: “Quite true; I didn’t mean that. I meant only two things. One is, keep
18124: yourself as separable from Bulstrode as you can: of course, you can go
18125: on doing good work of your own by his help; but don’t get tied. Perhaps
18126: it seems like personal feeling in me to say so—and there’s a good deal
18127: of that, I own—but personal feeling is not always in the wrong if you
18128: boil it down to the impressions which make it simply an opinion.”
18129: 
18130: “Bulstrode is nothing to me,” said Lydgate, carelessly, “except on
18131: public grounds. As to getting very closely united to him, I am not fond
18132: enough of him for that. But what was the other thing you meant?” said
18133: Lydgate, who was nursing his leg as comfortably as possible, and
18134: feeling in no great need of advice.
18135: 
18136: “Why, this. Take care—_experto crede_—take care not to get hampered
18137: about money matters. I know, by a word you let fall one day, that you
18138: don’t like my playing at cards so much for money. You are right enough
18139: there. But try and keep clear of wanting small sums that you haven’t
18140: got. I am perhaps talking rather superfluously; but a man likes to
18141: assume superiority over himself, by holding up his bad example and
18142: sermonizing on it.”
18143: 
18144: Lydgate took Mr. Farebrother’s hints very cordially, though he would
18145: hardly have borne them from another man. He could not help remembering
18146: that he had lately made some debts, but these had seemed inevitable,
18147: and he had no intention now to do more than keep house in a simple way.
18148: The furniture for which he owed would not want renewing; nor even the
18149: stock of wine for a long while.
18150: 
18151: Many thoughts cheered him at that time—and justly. A man conscious of
18152: enthusiasm for worthy aims is sustained under petty hostilities by the
18153: memory of great workers who had to fight their way not without wounds,
18154: and who hover in his mind as patron saints, invisibly helping. At home,
18155: that same evening when he had been chatting with Mr. Farebrother, he
18156: had his long legs stretched on the sofa, his head thrown back, and his
18157: hands clasped behind it according to his favorite ruminating attitude,
18158: while Rosamond sat at the piano, and played one tune after another, of
18159: which her husband only knew (like the emotional elephant he was!) that
18160: they fell in with his mood as if they had been melodious sea-breezes.
18161: 
18162: There was something very fine in Lydgate’s look just then, and any one
18163: might have been encouraged to bet on his achievement. In his dark eyes
18164: and on his mouth and brow there was that placidity which comes from the
18165: fulness of contemplative thought—the mind not searching, but beholding,
18166: and the glance seeming to be filled with what is behind it.
18167: 
18168: Presently Rosamond left the piano and seated herself on a chair close
18169: to the sofa and opposite her husband’s face.
18170: 
18171: “Is that enough music for you, my lord?” she said, folding her hands
18172: before her and putting on a little air of meekness.
18173: 
18174: “Yes, dear, if you are tired,” said Lydgate, gently, turning his eyes
18175: and resting them on her, but not otherwise moving. Rosamond’s presence
18176: at that moment was perhaps no more than a spoonful brought to the lake,
18177: and her woman’s instinct in this matter was not dull.
18178: 
18179: “What is absorbing you?” she said, leaning forward and bringing her
18180: face nearer to his.
18181: 
18182: He moved his hands and placed them gently behind her shoulders.
18183: 
18184: “I am thinking of a great fellow, who was about as old as I am three
18185: hundred years ago, and had already begun a new era in anatomy.”
18186: 
18187: “I can’t guess,” said Rosamond, shaking her head. “We used to play at
18188: guessing historical characters at Mrs. Lemon’s, but not anatomists.”
18189: 
18190: “I’ll tell you. His name was Vesalius. And the only way he could get to
18191: know anatomy as he did, was by going to snatch bodies at night, from
18192: graveyards and places of execution.”
18193: 
18194: “Oh!” said Rosamond, with a look of disgust on her pretty face, “I am
18195: very glad you are not Vesalius. I should have thought he might find
18196: some less horrible way than that.”
18197: 
18198: “No, he couldn’t,” said Lydgate, going on too earnestly to take much
18199: notice of her answer. “He could only get a complete skeleton by
18200: snatching the whitened bones of a criminal from the gallows, and
18201: burying them, and fetching them away by bits secretly, in the dead of
18202: night.”
18203: 
18204: “I hope he is not one of your great heroes,” said Rosamond, half
18205: playfully, half anxiously, “else I shall have you getting up in the
18206: night to go to St. Peter’s churchyard. You know how angry you told me
18207: the people were about Mrs. Goby. You have enemies enough already.”
18208: 
18209: “So had Vesalius, Rosy. No wonder the medical fogies in Middlemarch are
18210: jealous, when some of the greatest doctors living were fierce upon
18211: Vesalius because they had believed in Galen, and he showed that Galen
18212: was wrong. They called him a liar and a poisonous monster. But the
18213: facts of the human frame were on his side; and so he got the better of
18214: them.”
18215: 
18216: “And what happened to him afterwards?” said Rosamond, with some
18217: interest.
18218: 
18219: “Oh, he had a good deal of fighting to the last. And they did
18220: exasperate him enough at one time to make him burn a good deal of his
18221: work. Then he got shipwrecked just as he was coming from Jerusalem to
18222: take a great chair at Padua. He died rather miserably.”
18223: 
18224: There was a moment’s pause before Rosamond said, “Do you know, Tertius,
18225: I often wish you had not been a medical man.”
18226: 
18227: “Nay, Rosy, don’t say that,” said Lydgate, drawing her closer to him.
18228: “That is like saying you wish you had married another man.”
18229: 
18230: “Not at all; you are clever enough for anything: you might easily have
18231: been something else. And your cousins at Quallingham all think that you
18232: have sunk below them in your choice of a profession.”
18233: 
18234: “The cousins at Quallingham may go to the devil!” said Lydgate, with
18235: scorn. “It was like their impudence if they said anything of the sort
18236: to you.”
18237: 
18238: “Still,” said Rosamond, “I do _not_ think it is a nice profession,
18239: dear.” We know that she had much quiet perseverance in her opinion.
18240: 
18241: “It is the grandest profession in the world, Rosamond,” said Lydgate,
18242: gravely. “And to say that you love me without loving the medical man in
18243: me, is the same sort of thing as to say that you like eating a peach
18244: but don’t like its flavor. Don’t say that again, dear, it pains me.”
18245: 
18246: “Very well, Doctor Grave-face,” said Rosy, dimpling, “I will declare in
18247: future that I dote on skeletons, and body-snatchers, and bits of things
18248: in phials, and quarrels with everybody, that end in your dying
18249: miserably.”
18250: 
18251: “No, no, not so bad as that,” said Lydgate, giving up remonstrance and
18252: petting her resignedly.
18253: 
18254: 
18255: 
18256: 
18257: CHAPTER XLVI.
18258: 
18259: Pues no podemos haber aquello que queremos, queramos aquello que
18260: podremos.
18261: 
18262: Since we cannot get what we like, let us like what we can get.—_Spanish
18263: Proverb_.
18264: 
18265: 
18266: While Lydgate, safely married and with the Hospital under his command,
18267: felt himself struggling for Medical Reform against Middlemarch,
18268: Middlemarch was becoming more and more conscious of the national
18269: struggle for another kind of Reform.
18270: 
18271: By the time that Lord John Russell’s measure was being debated in the
18272: House of Commons, there was a new political animation in Middlemarch,
18273: and a new definition of parties which might show a decided change of
18274: balance if a new election came. And there were some who already
18275: predicted this event, declaring that a Reform Bill would never be
18276: carried by the actual Parliament. This was what Will Ladislaw dwelt on
18277: to Mr. Brooke as a reason for congratulation that he had not yet tried
18278: his strength at the hustings.
18279: 
18280: “Things will grow and ripen as if it were a comet year,” said Will.
18281: “The public temper will soon get to a cometary heat, now the question
18282: of Reform has set in. There is likely to be another election before
18283: long, and by that time Middlemarch will have got more ideas into its
18284: head. What we have to work at now is the ‘Pioneer’ and political
18285: meetings.”
18286: 
18287: “Quite right, Ladislaw; we shall make a new thing of opinion here,”
18288: said Mr. Brooke. “Only I want to keep myself independent about Reform,
18289: you know; I don’t want to go too far. I want to take up Wilberforce’s
18290: and Romilly’s line, you know, and work at Negro Emancipation, Criminal
18291: Law—that kind of thing. But of course I should support Grey.”
18292: 
18293: “If you go in for the principle of Reform, you must be prepared to take
18294: what the situation offers,” said Will. “If everybody pulled for his own
18295: bit against everybody else, the whole question would go to tatters.”
18296: 
18297: “Yes, yes, I agree with you—I quite take that point of view. I should
18298: put it in that light. I should support Grey, you know. But I don’t want
18299: to change the balance of the constitution, and I don’t think Grey
18300: would.”
18301: 
18302: “But that is what the country wants,” said Will. “Else there would be
18303: no meaning in political unions or any other movement that knows what
18304: it’s about. It wants to have a House of Commons which is not weighted
18305: with nominees of the landed class, but with representatives of the
18306: other interests. And as to contending for a reform short of that, it is
18307: like asking for a bit of an avalanche which has already begun to
18308: thunder.”
18309: 
18310: “That is fine, Ladislaw: that is the way to put it. Write that down,
18311: now. We must begin to get documents about the feeling of the country,
18312: as well as the machine-breaking and general distress.”
18313: 
18314: “As to documents,” said Will, “a two-inch card will hold plenty. A few
18315: rows of figures are enough to deduce misery from, and a few more will
18316: show the rate at which the political determination of the people is
18317: growing.”
18318: 
18319: “Good: draw that out a little more at length, Ladislaw. That is an
18320: idea, now: write it out in the ‘Pioneer.’ Put the figures and deduce
18321: the misery, you know; and put the other figures and deduce—and so on.
18322: You have a way of putting things. Burke, now:—when I think of Burke, I
18323: can’t help wishing somebody had a pocket-borough to give you, Ladislaw.
18324: You’d never get elected, you know. And we shall always want talent in
18325: the House: reform as we will, we shall always want talent. That
18326: avalanche and the thunder, now, was really a little like Burke. I want
18327: that sort of thing—not ideas, you know, but a way of putting them.”
18328: 
18329: “Pocket-boroughs would be a fine thing,” said Ladislaw, “if they were
18330: always in the right pocket, and there were always a Burke at hand.”
18331: 
18332: Will was not displeased with that complimentary comparison, even from
18333: Mr. Brooke; for it is a little too trying to human flesh to be
18334: conscious of expressing one’s self better than others and never to have
18335: it noticed, and in the general dearth of admiration for the right
18336: thing, even a chance bray of applause falling exactly in time is rather
18337: fortifying. Will felt that his literary refinements were usually beyond
18338: the limits of Middlemarch perception; nevertheless, he was beginning
18339: thoroughly to like the work of which when he began he had said to
18340: himself rather languidly, “Why not?”—and he studied the political
18341: situation with as ardent an interest as he had ever given to poetic
18342: metres or mediaevalism. It is undeniable that but for the desire to be
18343: where Dorothea was, and perhaps the want of knowing what else to do,
18344: Will would not at this time have been meditating on the needs of the
18345: English people or criticising English statesmanship: he would probably
18346: have been rambling in Italy sketching plans for several dramas, trying
18347: prose and finding it too jejune, trying verse and finding it too
18348: artificial, beginning to copy “bits” from old pictures, leaving off
18349: because they were “no good,” and observing that, after all,
18350: self-culture was the principal point; while in politics he would have
18351: been sympathizing warmly with liberty and progress in general. Our
18352: sense of duty must often wait for some work which shall take the place
18353: of dilettanteism and make us feel that the quality of our action is not
18354: a matter of indifference.
18355: 
18356: Ladislaw had now accepted his bit of work, though it was not that
18357: indeterminate loftiest thing which he had once dreamed of as alone
18358: worthy of continuous effort. His nature warmed easily in the presence
18359: of subjects which were visibly mixed with life and action, and the
18360: easily stirred rebellion in him helped the glow of public spirit. In
18361: spite of Mr. Casaubon and the banishment from Lowick, he was rather
18362: happy; getting a great deal of fresh knowledge in a vivid way and for
18363: practical purposes, and making the “Pioneer” celebrated as far as
18364: Brassing (never mind the smallness of the area; the writing was not
18365: worse than much that reaches the four corners of the earth).
18366: 
18367: Mr. Brooke was occasionally irritating; but Will’s impatience was
18368: relieved by the division of his time between visits to the Grange and
18369: retreats to his Middlemarch lodgings, which gave variety to his life.
18370: 
18371: “Shift the pegs a little,” he said to himself, “and Mr. Brooke might be
18372: in the Cabinet, while I was Under-Secretary. That is the common order
18373: of things: the little waves make the large ones and are of the same
18374: pattern. I am better here than in the sort of life Mr. Casaubon would
18375: have trained me for, where the doing would be all laid down by a
18376: precedent too rigid for me to react upon. I don’t care for prestige or
18377: high pay.”
18378: 
18379: As Lydgate had said of him, he was a sort of gypsy, rather enjoying the
18380: sense of belonging to no class; he had a feeling of romance in his
18381: position, and a pleasant consciousness of creating a little surprise
18382: wherever he went. That sort of enjoyment had been disturbed when he had
18383: felt some new distance between himself and Dorothea in their accidental
18384: meeting at Lydgate’s, and his irritation had gone out towards Mr.
18385: Casaubon, who had declared beforehand that Will would lose caste. “I
18386: never had any caste,” he would have said, if that prophecy had been
18387: uttered to him, and the quick blood would have come and gone like
18388: breath in his transparent skin. But it is one thing to like defiance,
18389: and another thing to like its consequences.
18390: 
18391: Meanwhile, the town opinion about the new editor of the “Pioneer” was
18392: tending to confirm Mr. Casaubon’s view. Will’s relationship in that
18393: distinguished quarter did not, like Lydgate’s high connections, serve
18394: as an advantageous introduction: if it was rumored that young Ladislaw
18395: was Mr. Casaubon’s nephew or cousin, it was also rumored that “Mr.
18396: Casaubon would have nothing to do with him.”
18397: 
18398: “Brooke has taken him up,” said Mr. Hawley, “because that is what no
18399: man in his senses could have expected. Casaubon has devilish good
18400: reasons, you may be sure, for turning the cold shoulder on a young
18401: fellow whose bringing-up he paid for. Just like Brooke—one of those
18402: fellows who would praise a cat to sell a horse.”
18403: 
18404: And some oddities of Will’s, more or less poetical, appeared to support
18405: Mr. Keck, the editor of the “Trumpet,” in asserting that Ladislaw, if
18406: the truth were known, was not only a Polish emissary but crack-brained,
18407: which accounted for the preternatural quickness and glibness of his
18408: speech when he got on to a platform—as he did whenever he had an
18409: opportunity, speaking with a facility which cast reflections on solid
18410: Englishmen generally. It was disgusting to Keck to see a strip of a
18411: fellow, with light curls round his head, get up and speechify by the
18412: hour against institutions “which had existed when he was in his
18413: cradle.” And in a leading article of the “Trumpet,” Keck characterized
18414: Ladislaw’s speech at a Reform meeting as “the violence of an
18415: energumen—a miserable effort to shroud in the brilliancy of fireworks
18416: the daring of irresponsible statements and the poverty of a knowledge
18417: which was of the cheapest and most recent description.”
18418: 
18419: “That was a rattling article yesterday, Keck,” said Dr. Sprague, with
18420: sarcastic intentions. “But what is an energumen?”
18421: 
18422: “Oh, a term that came up in the French Revolution,” said Keck.
18423: 
18424: This dangerous aspect of Ladislaw was strangely contrasted with other
18425: habits which became matter of remark. He had a fondness, half artistic,
18426: half affectionate, for little children—the smaller they were on
18427: tolerably active legs, and the funnier their clothing, the better Will
18428: liked to surprise and please them. We know that in Rome he was given to
18429: ramble about among the poor people, and the taste did not quit him in
18430: Middlemarch.
18431: 
18432: He had somehow picked up a troop of droll children, little hatless boys
18433: with their galligaskins much worn and scant shirting to hang out,
18434: little girls who tossed their hair out of their eyes to look at him,
18435: and guardian brothers at the mature age of seven. This troop he had led
18436: out on gypsy excursions to Halsell Wood at nutting-time, and since the
18437: cold weather had set in he had taken them on a clear day to gather
18438: sticks for a bonfire in the hollow of a hillside, where he drew out a
18439: small feast of gingerbread for them, and improvised a Punch-and-Judy
18440: drama with some private home-made puppets. Here was one oddity. Another
18441: was, that in houses where he got friendly, he was given to stretch
18442: himself at full length on the rug while he talked, and was apt to be
18443: discovered in this attitude by occasional callers for whom such an
18444: irregularity was likely to confirm the notions of his dangerously mixed
18445: blood and general laxity.
18446: 
18447: But Will’s articles and speeches naturally recommended him in families
18448: which the new strictness of party division had marked off on the side
18449: of Reform. He was invited to Mr. Bulstrode’s; but here he could not lie
18450: down on the rug, and Mrs. Bulstrode felt that his mode of talking about
18451: Catholic countries, as if there were any truce with Antichrist,
18452: illustrated the usual tendency to unsoundness in intellectual men.
18453: 
18454: At Mr. Farebrother’s, however, whom the irony of events had brought on
18455: the same side with Bulstrode in the national movement, Will became a
18456: favorite with the ladies; especially with little Miss Noble, whom it
18457: was one of his oddities to escort when he met her in the street with
18458: her little basket, giving her his arm in the eyes of the town, and
18459: insisting on going with her to pay some call where she distributed her
18460: small filchings from her own share of sweet things.
18461: 
18462: But the house where he visited oftenest and lay most on the rug was
18463: Lydgate’s. The two men were not at all alike, but they agreed none the
18464: worse. Lydgate was abrupt but not irritable, taking little notice of
18465: megrims in healthy people; and Ladislaw did not usually throw away his
18466: susceptibilities on those who took no notice of them. With Rosamond, on
18467: the other hand, he pouted and was wayward—nay, often uncomplimentary,
18468: much to her inward surprise; nevertheless he was gradually becoming
18469: necessary to her entertainment by his companionship in her music, his
18470: varied talk, and his freedom from the grave preoccupation which, with
18471: all her husband’s tenderness and indulgence, often made his manners
18472: unsatisfactory to her, and confirmed her dislike of the medical
18473: profession.
18474: 
18475: Lydgate, inclined to be sarcastic on the superstitious faith of the
18476: people in the efficacy of “the bill,” while nobody cared about the low
18477: state of pathology, sometimes assailed Will with troublesome questions.
18478: One evening in March, Rosamond in her cherry-colored dress with
18479: swansdown trimming about the throat sat at the tea-table; Lydgate,
18480: lately come in tired from his outdoor work, was seated sideways on an
18481: easy-chair by the fire with one leg over the elbow, his brow looking a
18482: little troubled as his eyes rambled over the columns of the “Pioneer,”
18483: while Rosamond, having noticed that he was perturbed, avoided looking
18484: at him, and inwardly thanked heaven that she herself had not a moody
18485: disposition. Will Ladislaw was stretched on the rug contemplating the
18486: curtain-pole abstractedly, and humming very low the notes of “When
18487: first I saw thy face;” while the house spaniel, also stretched out with
18488: small choice of room, looked from between his paws at the usurper of
18489: the rug with silent but strong objection.
18490: 
18491: Rosamond bringing Lydgate his cup of tea, he threw down the paper, and
18492: said to Will, who had started up and gone to the table—
18493: 
18494: “It’s no use your puffing Brooke as a reforming landlord, Ladislaw:
18495: they only pick the more holes in his coat in the ‘Trumpet.’”
18496: 
18497: “No matter; those who read the ‘Pioneer’ don’t read the ‘Trumpet,’”
18498: said Will, swallowing his tea and walking about. “Do you suppose the
18499: public reads with a view to its own conversion? We should have a
18500: witches’ brewing with a vengeance then—‘Mingle, mingle, mingle, mingle,
18501: You that mingle may’—and nobody would know which side he was going to
18502: take.”
18503: 
18504: “Farebrother says, he doesn’t believe Brooke would get elected if the
18505: opportunity came: the very men who profess to be for him would bring
18506: another member out of the bag at the right moment.”
18507: 
18508: “There’s no harm in trying. It’s good to have resident members.”
18509: 
18510: “Why?” said Lydgate, who was much given to use that inconvenient word
18511: in a curt tone.
18512: 
18513: “They represent the local stupidity better,” said Will, laughing, and
18514: shaking his curls; “and they are kept on their best behavior in the
18515: neighborhood. Brooke is not a bad fellow, but he has done some good
18516: things on his estate that he never would have done but for this
18517: Parliamentary bite.”
18518: 
18519: “He’s not fitted to be a public man,” said Lydgate, with contemptuous
18520: decision. “He would disappoint everybody who counted on him: I can see
18521: that at the Hospital. Only, there Bulstrode holds the reins and drives
18522: him.”
18523: 
18524: “That depends on how you fix your standard of public men,” said Will.
18525: “He’s good enough for the occasion: when the people have made up their
18526: mind as they are making it up now, they don’t want a man—they only want
18527: a vote.”
18528: 
18529: “That is the way with you political writers, Ladislaw—crying up a
18530: measure as if it were a universal cure, and crying up men who are a
18531: part of the very disease that wants curing.”
18532: 
18533: “Why not? Men may help to cure themselves off the face of the land
18534: without knowing it,” said Will, who could find reasons impromptu, when
18535: he had not thought of a question beforehand.
18536: 
18537: “That is no excuse for encouraging the superstitious exaggeration of
18538: hopes about this particular measure, helping the cry to swallow it
18539: whole and to send up voting popinjays who are good for nothing but to
18540: carry it. You go against rottenness, and there is nothing more
18541: thoroughly rotten than making people believe that society can be cured
18542: by a political hocus-pocus.”
18543: 
18544: “That’s very fine, my dear fellow. But your cure must begin somewhere,
18545: and put it that a thousand things which debase a population can never
18546: be reformed without this particular reform to begin with. Look what
18547: Stanley said the other day—that the House had been tinkering long
18548: enough at small questions of bribery, inquiring whether this or that
18549: voter has had a guinea when everybody knows that the seats have been
18550: sold wholesale. Wait for wisdom and conscience in public
18551: agents—fiddlestick! The only conscience we can trust to is the massive
18552: sense of wrong in a class, and the best wisdom that will work is the
18553: wisdom of balancing claims. That’s my text—which side is injured? I
18554: support the man who supports their claims; not the virtuous upholder of
18555: the wrong.”
18556: 
18557: “That general talk about a particular case is mere question begging,
18558: Ladislaw. When I say, I go in for the dose that cures, it doesn’t
18559: follow that I go in for opium in a given case of gout.”
18560: 
18561: “I am not begging the question we are upon—whether we are to try for
18562: nothing till we find immaculate men to work with. Should you go on that
18563: plan? If there were one man who would carry you a medical reform and
18564: another who would oppose it, should you inquire which had the better
18565: motives or even the better brains?”
18566: 
18567: “Oh, of course,” said Lydgate, seeing himself checkmated by a move
18568: which he had often used himself, “if one did not work with such men as
18569: are at hand, things must come to a dead-lock. Suppose the worst opinion
18570: in the town about Bulstrode were a true one, that would not make it
18571: less true that he has the sense and the resolution to do what I think
18572: ought to be done in the matters I know and care most about; but that is
18573: the only ground on which I go with him,” Lydgate added rather proudly,
18574: bearing in mind Mr. Farebrother’s remarks. “He is nothing to me
18575: otherwise; I would not cry him up on any personal ground—I would keep
18576: clear of that.”
18577: 
18578: “Do you mean that I cry up Brooke on any personal ground?” said Will
18579: Ladislaw, nettled, and turning sharp round. For the first time he felt
18580: offended with Lydgate; not the less so, perhaps, because he would have
18581: declined any close inquiry into the growth of his relation to Mr.
18582: Brooke.
18583: 
18584: “Not at all,” said Lydgate, “I was simply explaining my own action. I
18585: meant that a man may work for a special end with others whose motives
18586: and general course are equivocal, if he is quite sure of his personal
18587: independence, and that he is not working for his private
18588: interest—either place or money.”
18589: 
18590: “Then, why don’t you extend your liberality to others?” said Will,
18591: still nettled. “My personal independence is as important to me as yours
18592: is to you. You have no more reason to imagine that I have personal
18593: expectations from Brooke, than I have to imagine that you have personal
18594: expectations from Bulstrode. Motives are points of honor, I
18595: suppose—nobody can prove them. But as to money and place in the world,”
18596: Will ended, tossing back his head, “I think it is pretty clear that I
18597: am not determined by considerations of that sort.”
18598: 
18599: “You quite mistake me, Ladislaw,” said Lydgate, surprised. He had been
18600: preoccupied with his own vindication, and had been blind to what
18601: Ladislaw might infer on his own account. “I beg your pardon for
18602: unintentionally annoying you. In fact, I should rather attribute to you
18603: a romantic disregard of your own worldly interests. On the political
18604: question, I referred simply to intellectual bias.”
18605: 
18606: “How very unpleasant you both are this evening!” said Rosamond. “I
18607: cannot conceive why money should have been referred to. Politics and
18608: Medicine are sufficiently disagreeable to quarrel upon. You can both of
18609: you go on quarrelling with all the world and with each other on those
18610: two topics.”
18611: 
18612: Rosamond looked mildly neutral as she said this, rising to ring the
18613: bell, and then crossing to her work-table.
18614: 
18615: “Poor Rosy!” said Lydgate, putting out his hand to her as she was
18616: passing him. “Disputation is not amusing to cherubs. Have some music.
18617: Ask Ladislaw to sing with you.”
18618: 
18619: When Will was gone Rosamond said to her husband, “What put you out of
18620: temper this evening, Tertius?”
18621: 
18622: “Me? It was Ladislaw who was out of temper. He is like a bit of
18623: tinder.”
18624: 
18625: “But I mean, before that. Something had vexed you before you came in,
18626: you looked cross. And that made you begin to dispute with Mr. Ladislaw.
18627: You hurt me very much when you look so, Tertius.”
18628: 
18629: “Do I? Then I am a brute,” said Lydgate, caressing her penitently.
18630: 
18631: “What vexed you?”
18632: 
18633: “Oh, outdoor things—business.” It was really a letter insisting on the
18634: payment of a bill for furniture. But Rosamond was expecting to have a
18635: baby, and Lydgate wished to save her from any perturbation.
18636: 
18637: 
18638: 
18639: 
18640: CHAPTER XLVII.
18641: 
18642: Was never true love loved in vain,
18643: For truest love is highest gain.
18644: No art can make it: it must spring
18645: Where elements are fostering.
18646: So in heaven’s spot and hour
18647: Springs the little native flower,
18648: Downward root and upward eye,
18649: Shapen by the earth and sky.
18650: 
18651: 
18652: It happened to be on a Saturday evening that Will Ladislaw had that
18653: little discussion with Lydgate. Its effect when he went to his own
18654: rooms was to make him sit up half the night, thinking over again, under
18655: a new irritation, all that he had before thought of his having settled
18656: in Middlemarch and harnessed himself with Mr. Brooke. Hesitations
18657: before he had taken the step had since turned into susceptibility to
18658: every hint that he would have been wiser not to take it; and hence came
18659: his heat towards Lydgate—a heat which still kept him restless. Was he
18660: not making a fool of himself?—and at a time when he was more than ever
18661: conscious of being something better than a fool? And for what end?
18662: 
18663: Well, for no definite end. True, he had dreamy visions of
18664: possibilities: there is no human being who having both passions and
18665: thoughts does not think in consequence of his passions—does not find
18666: images rising in his mind which soothe the passion with hope or sting
18667: it with dread. But this, which happens to us all, happens to some with
18668: a wide difference; and Will was not one of those whose wit “keeps the
18669: roadway:” he had his bypaths where there were little joys of his own
18670: choosing, such as gentlemen cantering on the highroad might have
18671: thought rather idiotic. The way in which he made a sort of happiness
18672: for himself out of his feeling for Dorothea was an example of this. It
18673: may seem strange, but it is the fact, that the ordinary vulgar vision
18674: of which Mr. Casaubon suspected him—namely, that Dorothea might become
18675: a widow, and that the interest he had established in her mind might
18676: turn into acceptance of him as a husband—had no tempting, arresting
18677: power over him; he did not live in the scenery of such an event, and
18678: follow it out, as we all do with that imagined “otherwise” which is our
18679: practical heaven. It was not only that he was unwilling to entertain
18680: thoughts which could be accused of baseness, and was already uneasy in
18681: the sense that he had to justify himself from the charge of
18682: ingratitude—the latent consciousness of many other barriers between
18683: himself and Dorothea besides the existence of her husband, had helped
18684: to turn away his imagination from speculating on what might befall Mr.
18685: Casaubon. And there were yet other reasons. Will, we know, could not
18686: bear the thought of any flaw appearing in his crystal: he was at once
18687: exasperated and delighted by the calm freedom with which Dorothea
18688: looked at him and spoke to him, and there was something so exquisite in
18689: thinking of her just as she was, that he could not long for a change
18690: which must somehow change her. Do we not shun the street version of a
18691: fine melody?—or shrink from the news that the rarity—some bit of
18692: chiselling or engraving perhaps—which we have dwelt on even with
18693: exultation in the trouble it has cost us to snatch glimpses of it, is
18694: really not an uncommon thing, and may be obtained as an every-day
18695: possession? Our good depends on the quality and breadth of our emotion;
18696: and to Will, a creature who cared little for what are called the solid
18697: things of life and greatly for its subtler influences, to have within
18698: him such a feeling as he had towards Dorothea, was like the inheritance
18699: of a fortune. What others might have called the futility of his
18700: passion, made an additional delight for his imagination: he was
18701: conscious of a generous movement, and of verifying in his own
18702: experience that higher love-poetry which had charmed his fancy.
18703: Dorothea, he said to himself, was forever enthroned in his soul: no
18704: other woman could sit higher than her footstool; and if he could have
18705: written out in immortal syllables the effect she wrought within him, he
18706: might have boasted after the example of old Drayton, that,—
18707: 
18708: “Queens hereafter might be glad to live
18709: Upon the alms of her superfluous praise.”
18710: 
18711: 
18712: But this result was questionable. And what else could he do for
18713: Dorothea? What was his devotion worth to her? It was impossible to
18714: tell. He would not go out of her reach. He saw no creature among her
18715: friends to whom he could believe that she spoke with the same simple
18716: confidence as to him. She had once said that she would like him to
18717: stay; and stay he would, whatever fire-breathing dragons might hiss
18718: around her.
18719: 
18720: This had always been the conclusion of Will’s hesitations. But he was
18721: not without contradictoriness and rebellion even towards his own
18722: resolve. He had often got irritated, as he was on this particular
18723: night, by some outside demonstration that his public exertions with Mr.
18724: Brooke as a chief could not seem as heroic as he would like them to be,
18725: and this was always associated with the other ground of irritation—that
18726: notwithstanding his sacrifice of dignity for Dorothea’s sake, he could
18727: hardly ever see her. Whereupon, not being able to contradict these
18728: unpleasant facts, he contradicted his own strongest bias and said, “I
18729: am a fool.”
18730: 
18731: Nevertheless, since the inward debate necessarily turned on Dorothea,
18732: he ended, as he had done before, only by getting a livelier sense of
18733: what her presence would be to him; and suddenly reflecting that the
18734: morrow would be Sunday, he determined to go to Lowick Church and see
18735: her. He slept upon that idea, but when he was dressing in the rational
18736: morning light, Objection said—
18737: 
18738: “That will be a virtual defiance of Mr. Casaubon’s prohibition to visit
18739: Lowick, and Dorothea will be displeased.”
18740: 
18741: “Nonsense!” argued Inclination, “it would be too monstrous for him to
18742: hinder me from going out to a pretty country church on a spring
18743: morning. And Dorothea will be glad.”
18744: 
18745: “It will be clear to Mr. Casaubon that you have come either to annoy
18746: him or to see Dorothea.”
18747: 
18748: “It is not true that I go to annoy him, and why should I not go to see
18749: Dorothea? Is he to have everything to himself and be always
18750: comfortable? Let him smart a little, as other people are obliged to do.
18751: I have always liked the quaintness of the church and congregation;
18752: besides, I know the Tuckers: I shall go into their pew.”
18753: 
18754: Having silenced Objection by force of unreason, Will walked to Lowick
18755: as if he had been on the way to Paradise, crossing Halsell Common and
18756: skirting the wood, where the sunlight fell broadly under the budding
18757: boughs, bringing out the beauties of moss and lichen, and fresh green
18758: growths piercing the brown. Everything seemed to know that it was
18759: Sunday, and to approve of his going to Lowick Church. Will easily felt
18760: happy when nothing crossed his humor, and by this time the thought of
18761: vexing Mr. Casaubon had become rather amusing to him, making his face
18762: break into its merry smile, pleasant to see as the breaking of sunshine
18763: on the water—though the occasion was not exemplary. But most of us are
18764: apt to settle within ourselves that the man who blocks our way is
18765: odious, and not to mind causing him a little of the disgust which his
18766: personality excites in ourselves. Will went along with a small book
18767: under his arm and a hand in each side-pocket, never reading, but
18768: chanting a little, as he made scenes of what would happen in church and
18769: coming out. He was experimenting in tunes to suit some words of his
18770: own, sometimes trying a ready-made melody, sometimes improvising. The
18771: words were not exactly a hymn, but they certainly fitted his Sunday
18772: experience:—
18773: 
18774: “O me, O me, what frugal cheer
18775:     My love doth feed upon!
18776: A touch, a ray, that is not here,
18777:     A shadow that is gone:
18778: 
18779: “A dream of breath that might be near,
18780:     An inly-echoed tone,
18781: The thought that one may think me dear,
18782:     The place where one was known,
18783: 
18784: “The tremor of a banished fear,
18785:      An ill that was not done—
18786: O me, O me, what frugal cheer
18787:     My love doth feed upon!”
18788: 
18789: 
18790: Sometimes, when he took off his hat, shaking his head backward, and
18791: showing his delicate throat as he sang, he looked like an incarnation
18792: of the spring whose spirit filled the air—a bright creature, abundant
18793: in uncertain promises.
18794: 
18795: The bells were still ringing when he got to Lowick, and he went into
18796: the curate’s pew before any one else arrived there. But he was still
18797: left alone in it when the congregation had assembled. The curate’s pew
18798: was opposite the rector’s at the entrance of the small chancel, and
18799: Will had time to fear that Dorothea might not come while he looked
18800: round at the group of rural faces which made the congregation from year
18801: to year within the white-washed walls and dark old pews, hardly with
18802: more change than we see in the boughs of a tree which breaks here and
18803: there with age, but yet has young shoots. Mr. Rigg’s frog-face was
18804: something alien and unaccountable, but notwithstanding this shock to
18805: the order of things, there were still the Waules and the rural stock of
18806: the Powderells in their pews side by side; brother Samuel’s cheek had
18807: the same purple round as ever, and the three generations of decent
18808: cottagers came as of old with a sense of duty to their betters
18809: generally—the smaller children regarding Mr. Casaubon, who wore the
18810: black gown and mounted to the highest box, as probably the chief of all
18811: betters, and the one most awful if offended. Even in 1831 Lowick was at
18812: peace, not more agitated by Reform than by the solemn tenor of the
18813: Sunday sermon. The congregation had been used to seeing Will at church
18814: in former days, and no one took much note of him except the choir, who
18815: expected him to make a figure in the singing.
18816: 
18817: Dorothea did at last appear on this quaint background, walking up the
18818: short aisle in her white beaver bonnet and gray cloak—the same she had
18819: worn in the Vatican. Her face being, from her entrance, towards the
18820: chancel, even her shortsighted eyes soon discerned Will, but there was
18821: no outward show of her feeling except a slight paleness and a grave bow
18822: as she passed him. To his own surprise Will felt suddenly
