18823: uncomfortable, and dared not look at her after they had bowed to each
18824: other. Two minutes later, when Mr. Casaubon came out of the vestry,
18825: and, entering the pew, seated himself in face of Dorothea, Will felt
18826: his paralysis more complete. He could look nowhere except at the choir
18827: in the little gallery over the vestry-door: Dorothea was perhaps
18828: pained, and he had made a wretched blunder. It was no longer amusing to
18829: vex Mr. Casaubon, who had the advantage probably of watching him and
18830: seeing that he dared not turn his head. Why had he not imagined this
18831: beforehand?—but he could not expect that he should sit in that square
18832: pew alone, unrelieved by any Tuckers, who had apparently departed from
18833: Lowick altogether, for a new clergyman was in the desk. Still he called
18834: himself stupid now for not foreseeing that it would be impossible for
18835: him to look towards Dorothea—nay, that she might feel his coming an
18836: impertinence. There was no delivering himself from his cage, however;
18837: and Will found his places and looked at his book as if he had been a
18838: school-mistress, feeling that the morning service had never been so
18839: immeasurably long before, that he was utterly ridiculous, out of
18840: temper, and miserable. This was what a man got by worshipping the sight
18841: of a woman! The clerk observed with surprise that Mr. Ladislaw did not
18842: join in the tune of Hanover, and reflected that he might have a cold.
18843: 
18844: Mr. Casaubon did not preach that morning, and there was no change in
18845: Will’s situation until the blessing had been pronounced and every one
18846: rose. It was the fashion at Lowick for “the betters” to go out first.
18847: With a sudden determination to break the spell that was upon him, Will
18848: looked straight at Mr. Casaubon. But that gentleman’s eyes were on the
18849: button of the pew-door, which he opened, allowing Dorothea to pass, and
18850: following her immediately without raising his eyelids. Will’s glance
18851: had caught Dorothea’s as she turned out of the pew, and again she
18852: bowed, but this time with a look of agitation, as if she were
18853: repressing tears. Will walked out after them, but they went on towards
18854: the little gate leading out of the churchyard into the shrubbery, never
18855: looking round.
18856: 
18857: It was impossible for him to follow them, and he could only walk back
18858: sadly at mid-day along the same road which he had trodden hopefully in
18859: the morning. The lights were all changed for him both without and
18860: within.
18861: 
18862: 
18863: 
18864: 
18865: CHAPTER XLVIII.
18866: 
18867: Surely the golden hours are turning gray
18868: And dance no more, and vainly strive to run:
18869: I see their white locks streaming in the wind—
18870: Each face is haggard as it looks at me,
18871: Slow turning in the constant clasping round
18872: Storm-driven.
18873: 
18874: 
18875: Dorothea’s distress when she was leaving the church came chiefly from
18876: the perception that Mr. Casaubon was determined not to speak to his
18877: cousin, and that Will’s presence at church had served to mark more
18878: strongly the alienation between them. Will’s coming seemed to her quite
18879: excusable, nay, she thought it an amiable movement in him towards a
18880: reconciliation which she herself had been constantly wishing for. He
18881: had probably imagined, as she had, that if Mr. Casaubon and he could
18882: meet easily, they would shake hands and friendly intercourse might
18883: return. But now Dorothea felt quite robbed of that hope. Will was
18884: banished further than ever, for Mr. Casaubon must have been newly
18885: embittered by this thrusting upon him of a presence which he refused to
18886: recognize.
18887: 
18888: He had not been very well that morning, suffering from some difficulty
18889: in breathing, and had not preached in consequence; she was not
18890: surprised, therefore, that he was nearly silent at luncheon, still less
18891: that he made no allusion to Will Ladislaw. For her own part she felt
18892: that she could never again introduce that subject. They usually spent
18893: apart the hours between luncheon and dinner on a Sunday; Mr. Casaubon
18894: in the library dozing chiefly, and Dorothea in her boudoir, where she
18895: was wont to occupy herself with some of her favorite books. There was a
18896: little heap of them on the table in the bow-window—of various sorts,
18897: from Herodotus, which she was learning to read with Mr. Casaubon, to
18898: her old companion Pascal, and Keble’s “Christian Year.” But to-day she
18899: opened one after another, and could read none of them. Everything
18900: seemed dreary: the portents before the birth of Cyrus—Jewish
18901: antiquities—oh dear!—devout epigrams—the sacred chime of favorite
18902: hymns—all alike were as flat as tunes beaten on wood: even the spring
18903: flowers and the grass had a dull shiver in them under the afternoon
18904: clouds that hid the sun fitfully; even the sustaining thoughts which
18905: had become habits seemed to have in them the weariness of long future
18906: days in which she would still live with them for her sole companions.
18907: It was another or rather a fuller sort of companionship that poor
18908: Dorothea was hungering for, and the hunger had grown from the perpetual
18909: effort demanded by her married life. She was always trying to be what
18910: her husband wished, and never able to repose on his delight in what she
18911: was. The thing that she liked, that she spontaneously cared to have,
18912: seemed to be always excluded from her life; for if it was only granted
18913: and not shared by her husband it might as well have been denied. About
18914: Will Ladislaw there had been a difference between them from the first,
18915: and it had ended, since Mr. Casaubon had so severely repulsed
18916: Dorothea’s strong feeling about his claims on the family property, by
18917: her being convinced that she was in the right and her husband in the
18918: wrong, but that she was helpless. This afternoon the helplessness was
18919: more wretchedly benumbing than ever: she longed for objects who could
18920: be dear to her, and to whom she could be dear. She longed for work
18921: which would be directly beneficent like the sunshine and the rain, and
18922: now it appeared that she was to live more and more in a virtual tomb,
18923: where there was the apparatus of a ghastly labor producing what would
18924: never see the light. Today she had stood at the door of the tomb and
18925: seen Will Ladislaw receding into the distant world of warm activity and
18926: fellowship—turning his face towards her as he went.
18927: 
18928: Books were of no use. Thinking was of no use. It was Sunday, and she
18929: could not have the carriage to go to Celia, who had lately had a baby.
18930: There was no refuge now from spiritual emptiness and discontent, and
18931: Dorothea had to bear her bad mood, as she would have borne a headache.
18932: 
18933: After dinner, at the hour when she usually began to read aloud, Mr.
18934: Casaubon proposed that they should go into the library, where, he said,
18935: he had ordered a fire and lights. He seemed to have revived, and to be
18936: thinking intently.
18937: 
18938: In the library Dorothea observed that he had newly arranged a row of
18939: his note-books on a table, and now he took up and put into her hand a
18940: well-known volume, which was a table of contents to all the others.
18941: 
18942: “You will oblige me, my dear,” he said, seating himself, “if instead of
18943: other reading this evening, you will go through this aloud, pencil in
18944: hand, and at each point where I say ‘mark,’ will make a cross with your
18945: pencil. This is the first step in a sifting process which I have long
18946: had in view, and as we go on I shall be able to indicate to you certain
18947: principles of selection whereby you will, I trust, have an intelligent
18948: participation in my purpose.”
18949: 
18950: This proposal was only one more sign added to many since his memorable
18951: interview with Lydgate, that Mr. Casaubon’s original reluctance to let
18952: Dorothea work with him had given place to the contrary disposition,
18953: namely, to demand much interest and labor from her.
18954: 
18955: After she had read and marked for two hours, he said, “We will take the
18956: volume up-stairs—and the pencil, if you please—and in case of reading
18957: in the night, we can pursue this task. It is not wearisome to you, I
18958: trust, Dorothea?”
18959: 
18960: “I prefer always reading what you like best to hear,” said Dorothea,
18961: who told the simple truth; for what she dreaded was to exert herself in
18962: reading or anything else which left him as joyless as ever.
18963: 
18964: It was a proof of the force with which certain characteristics in
18965: Dorothea impressed those around her, that her husband, with all his
18966: jealousy and suspicion, had gathered implicit trust in the integrity of
18967: her promises, and her power of devoting herself to her idea of the
18968: right and best. Of late he had begun to feel that these qualities were
18969: a peculiar possession for himself, and he wanted to engross them.
18970: 
18971: The reading in the night did come. Dorothea in her young weariness had
18972: slept soon and fast: she was awakened by a sense of light, which seemed
18973: to her at first like a sudden vision of sunset after she had climbed a
18974: steep hill: she opened her eyes and saw her husband wrapped in his warm
18975: gown seating himself in the arm-chair near the fire-place where the
18976: embers were still glowing. He had lit two candles, expecting that
18977: Dorothea would awake, but not liking to rouse her by more direct means.
18978: 
18979: “Are you ill, Edward?” she said, rising immediately.
18980: 
18981: “I felt some uneasiness in a reclining posture. I will sit here for a
18982: time.” She threw wood on the fire, wrapped herself up, and said, “You
18983: would like me to read to you?”
18984: 
18985: “You would oblige me greatly by doing so, Dorothea,” said Mr. Casaubon,
18986: with a shade more meekness than usual in his polite manner. “I am
18987: wakeful: my mind is remarkably lucid.”
18988: 
18989: “I fear that the excitement may be too great for you,” said Dorothea,
18990: remembering Lydgate’s cautions.
18991: 
18992: “No, I am not conscious of undue excitement. Thought is easy.” Dorothea
18993: dared not insist, and she read for an hour or more on the same plan as
18994: she had done in the evening, but getting over the pages with more
18995: quickness. Mr. Casaubon’s mind was more alert, and he seemed to
18996: anticipate what was coming after a very slight verbal indication,
18997: saying, “That will do—mark that”—or “Pass on to the next head—I omit
18998: the second excursus on Crete.” Dorothea was amazed to think of the
18999: bird-like speed with which his mind was surveying the ground where it
19000: had been creeping for years. At last he said—
19001: 
19002: “Close the book now, my dear. We will resume our work to-morrow. I have
19003: deferred it too long, and would gladly see it completed. But you
19004: observe that the principle on which my selection is made, is to give
19005: adequate, and not disproportionate illustration to each of the theses
19006: enumerated in my introduction, as at present sketched. You have
19007: perceived that distinctly, Dorothea?”
19008: 
19009: “Yes,” said Dorothea, rather tremulously. She felt sick at heart.
19010: 
19011: “And now I think that I can take some repose,” said Mr. Casaubon. He
19012: laid down again and begged her to put out the lights. When she had lain
19013: down too, and there was a darkness only broken by a dull glow on the
19014: hearth, he said—
19015: 
19016: “Before I sleep, I have a request to make, Dorothea.”
19017: 
19018: “What is it?” said Dorothea, with dread in her mind.
19019: 
19020: “It is that you will let me know, deliberately, whether, in case of my
19021: death, you will carry out my wishes: whether you will avoid doing what
19022: I should deprecate, and apply yourself to do what I should desire.”
19023: 
19024: Dorothea was not taken by surprise: many incidents had been leading her
19025: to the conjecture of some intention on her husband’s part which might
19026: make a new yoke for her. She did not answer immediately.
19027: 
19028: “You refuse?” said Mr. Casaubon, with more edge in his tone.
19029: 
19030: “No, I do not yet refuse,” said Dorothea, in a clear voice, the need of
19031: freedom asserting itself within her; “but it is too solemn—I think it
19032: is not right—to make a promise when I am ignorant what it will bind me
19033: to. Whatever affection prompted I would do without promising.”
19034: 
19035: “But you would use your own judgment: I ask you to obey mine; you
19036: refuse.”
19037: 
19038: “No, dear, no!” said Dorothea, beseechingly, crushed by opposing fears.
19039: “But may I wait and reflect a little while? I desire with my whole soul
19040: to do what will comfort you; but I cannot give any pledge
19041: suddenly—still less a pledge to do I know not what.”
19042: 
19043: “You cannot then confide in the nature of my wishes?”
19044: 
19045: “Grant me till to-morrow,” said Dorothea, beseechingly.
19046: 
19047: “Till to-morrow then,” said Mr. Casaubon.
19048: 
19049: Soon she could hear that he was sleeping, but there was no more sleep
19050: for her. While she constrained herself to lie still lest she should
19051: disturb him, her mind was carrying on a conflict in which imagination
19052: ranged its forces first on one side and then on the other. She had no
19053: presentiment that the power which her husband wished to establish over
19054: her future action had relation to anything else than his work. But it
19055: was clear enough to her that he would expect her to devote herself to
19056: sifting those mixed heaps of material, which were to be the doubtful
19057: illustration of principles still more doubtful. The poor child had
19058: become altogether unbelieving as to the trustworthiness of that Key
19059: which had made the ambition and the labor of her husband’s life. It was
19060: not wonderful that, in spite of her small instruction, her judgment in
19061: this matter was truer than his: for she looked with unbiassed
19062: comparison and healthy sense at probabilities on which he had risked
19063: all his egoism. And now she pictured to herself the days, and months,
19064: and years which she must spend in sorting what might be called
19065: shattered mummies, and fragments of a tradition which was itself a
19066: mosaic wrought from crushed ruins—sorting them as food for a theory
19067: which was already withered in the birth like an elfin child. Doubtless
19068: a vigorous error vigorously pursued has kept the embryos of truth
19069: a-breathing: the quest of gold being at the same time a questioning of
19070: substances, the body of chemistry is prepared for its soul, and
19071: Lavoisier is born. But Mr. Casaubon’s theory of the elements which made
19072: the seed of all tradition was not likely to bruise itself unawares
19073: against discoveries: it floated among flexible conjectures no more
19074: solid than those etymologies which seemed strong because of likeness in
19075: sound until it was shown that likeness in sound made them impossible:
19076: it was a method of interpretation which was not tested by the necessity
19077: of forming anything which had sharper collisions than an elaborate
19078: notion of Gog and Magog: it was as free from interruption as a plan for
19079: threading the stars together. And Dorothea had so often had to check
19080: her weariness and impatience over this questionable riddle-guessing, as
19081: it revealed itself to her instead of the fellowship in high knowledge
19082: which was to make life worthier! She could understand well enough now
19083: why her husband had come to cling to her, as possibly the only hope
19084: left that his labors would ever take a shape in which they could be
19085: given to the world. At first it had seemed that he wished to keep even
19086: her aloof from any close knowledge of what he was doing; but gradually
19087: the terrible stringency of human need—the prospect of a too speedy
19088: death—
19089: 
19090: And here Dorothea’s pity turned from her own future to her husband’s
19091: past—nay, to his present hard struggle with a lot which had grown out
19092: of that past: the lonely labor, the ambition breathing hardly under the
19093: pressure of self-distrust; the goal receding, and the heavier limbs;
19094: and now at last the sword visibly trembling above him! And had she not
19095: wished to marry him that she might help him in his life’s labor?—But
19096: she had thought the work was to be something greater, which she could
19097: serve in devoutly for its own sake. Was it right, even to soothe his
19098: grief—would it be possible, even if she promised—to work as in a
19099: treadmill fruitlessly?
19100: 
19101: And yet, could she deny him? Could she say, “I refuse to content this
19102: pining hunger?” It would be refusing to do for him dead, what she was
19103: almost sure to do for him living. If he lived as Lydgate had said he
19104: might, for fifteen years or more, her life would certainly be spent in
19105: helping him and obeying him.
19106: 
19107: Still, there was a deep difference between that devotion to the living
19108: and that indefinite promise of devotion to the dead. While he lived, he
19109: could claim nothing that she would not still be free to remonstrate
19110: against, and even to refuse. But—the thought passed through her mind
19111: more than once, though she could not believe in it—might he not mean to
19112: demand something more from her than she had been able to imagine, since
19113: he wanted her pledge to carry out his wishes without telling her
19114: exactly what they were? No; his heart was bound up in his work only:
19115: that was the end for which his failing life was to be eked out by hers.
19116: 
19117: And now, if she were to say, “No! if you die, I will put no finger to
19118: your work“—it seemed as if she would be crushing that bruised heart.
19119: 
19120: For four hours Dorothea lay in this conflict, till she felt ill and
19121: bewildered, unable to resolve, praying mutely. Helpless as a child
19122: which has sobbed and sought too long, she fell into a late morning
19123: sleep, and when she waked Mr. Casaubon was already up. Tantripp told
19124: her that he had read prayers, breakfasted, and was in the library.
19125: 
19126: “I never saw you look so pale, madam,” said Tantripp, a solid-figured
19127: woman who had been with the sisters at Lausanne.
19128: 
19129: “Was I ever high-colored, Tantripp?” said Dorothea, smiling faintly.
19130: 
19131: “Well, not to say high-colored, but with a bloom like a Chiny rose. But
19132: always smelling those leather books, what can be expected? Do rest a
19133: little this morning, madam. Let me say you are ill and not able to go
19134: into that close library.”
19135: 
19136: “Oh no, no! let me make haste,” said Dorothea. “Mr. Casaubon wants me
19137: particularly.”
19138: 
19139: When she went down she felt sure that she should promise to fulfil his
19140: wishes; but that would be later in the day—not yet.
19141: 
19142: As Dorothea entered the library, Mr. Casaubon turned round from the
19143: table where he had been placing some books, and said—
19144: 
19145: “I was waiting for your appearance, my dear. I had hoped to set to work
19146: at once this morning, but I find myself under some indisposition,
19147: probably from too much excitement yesterday. I am going now to take a
19148: turn in the shrubbery, since the air is milder.”
19149: 
19150: “I am glad to hear that,” said Dorothea. “Your mind, I feared, was too
19151: active last night.”
19152: 
19153: “I would fain have it set at rest on the point I last spoke of,
19154: Dorothea. You can now, I hope, give me an answer.”
19155: 
19156: “May I come out to you in the garden presently?” said Dorothea, winning
19157: a little breathing space in that way.
19158: 
19159: “I shall be in the Yew-tree Walk for the next half-hour,” said Mr.
19160: Casaubon, and then he left her.
19161: 
19162: Dorothea, feeling very weary, rang and asked Tantripp to bring her some
19163: wraps. She had been sitting still for a few minutes, but not in any
19164: renewal of the former conflict: she simply felt that she was going to
19165: say “Yes” to her own doom: she was too weak, too full of dread at the
19166: thought of inflicting a keen-edged blow on her husband, to do anything
19167: but submit completely. She sat still and let Tantripp put on her bonnet
19168: and shawl, a passivity which was unusual with her, for she liked to
19169: wait on herself.
19170: 
19171: “God bless you, madam!” said Tantripp, with an irrepressible movement
19172: of love towards the beautiful, gentle creature for whom she felt unable
19173: to do anything more, now that she had finished tying the bonnet.
19174: 
19175: This was too much for Dorothea’s highly-strung feeling, and she burst
19176: into tears, sobbing against Tantripp’s arm. But soon she checked
19177: herself, dried her eyes, and went out at the glass door into the
19178: shrubbery.
19179: 
19180: “I wish every book in that library was built into a caticom for your
19181: master,” said Tantripp to Pratt, the butler, finding him in the
19182: breakfast-room. She had been at Rome, and visited the antiquities, as
19183: we know; and she always declined to call Mr. Casaubon anything but
19184: “your master,” when speaking to the other servants.
19185: 
19186: Pratt laughed. He liked his master very well, but he liked Tantripp
19187: better.
19188: 
19189: When Dorothea was out on the gravel walks, she lingered among the
19190: nearer clumps of trees, hesitating, as she had done once before, though
19191: from a different cause. Then she had feared lest her effort at
19192: fellowship should be unwelcome; now she dreaded going to the spot where
19193: she foresaw that she must bind herself to a fellowship from which she
19194: shrank. Neither law nor the world’s opinion compelled her to this—only
19195: her husband’s nature and her own compassion, only the ideal and not the
19196: real yoke of marriage. She saw clearly enough the whole situation, yet
19197: she was fettered: she could not smite the stricken soul that entreated
19198: hers. If that were weakness, Dorothea was weak. But the half-hour was
19199: passing, and she must not delay longer. When she entered the Yew-tree
19200: Walk she could not see her husband; but the walk had bends, and she
19201: went, expecting to catch sight of his figure wrapped in a blue cloak,
19202: which, with a warm velvet cap, was his outer garment on chill days for
19203: the garden. It occurred to her that he might be resting in the
19204: summer-house, towards which the path diverged a little. Turning the
19205: angle, she could see him seated on the bench, close to a stone table.
19206: His arms were resting on the table, and his brow was bowed down on
19207: them, the blue cloak being dragged forward and screening his face on
19208: each side.
19209: 
19210: “He exhausted himself last night,” Dorothea said to herself, thinking
19211: at first that he was asleep, and that the summer-house was too damp a
19212: place to rest in. But then she remembered that of late she had seen him
19213: take that attitude when she was reading to him, as if he found it
19214: easier than any other; and that he would sometimes speak, as well as
19215: listen, with his face down in that way. She went into the summerhouse
19216: and said, “I am come, Edward; I am ready.”
19217: 
19218: He took no notice, and she thought that he must be fast asleep. She
19219: laid her hand on his shoulder, and repeated, “I am ready!” Still he was
19220: motionless; and with a sudden confused fear, she leaned down to him,
19221: took off his velvet cap, and leaned her cheek close to his head, crying
19222: in a distressed tone—
19223: 
19224: “Wake, dear, wake! Listen to me. I am come to answer.” But Dorothea
19225: never gave her answer.
19226: 
19227: Later in the day, Lydgate was seated by her bedside, and she was
19228: talking deliriously, thinking aloud, and recalling what had gone
19229: through her mind the night before. She knew him, and called him by his
19230: name, but appeared to think it right that she should explain everything
19231: to him; and again, and again, begged him to explain everything to her
19232: husband.
19233: 
19234: “Tell him I shall go to him soon: I am ready to promise. Only, thinking
19235: about it was so dreadful—it has made me ill. Not very ill. I shall soon
19236: be better. Go and tell him.”
19237: 
19238: But the silence in her husband’s ear was never more to be broken.
19239: 
19240: 
19241: 
19242: 
19243: CHAPTER XLIX.
19244: 
19245: “A task too strong for wizard spells
19246: This squire had brought about;
19247: ’T is easy dropping stones in wells,
19248: But who shall get them out?”
19249: 
19250: 
19251: “I wish to God we could hinder Dorothea from knowing this,” said Sir
19252: James Chettam, with a little frown on his brow, and an expression of
19253: intense disgust about his mouth.
19254: 
19255: He was standing on the hearth-rug in the library at Lowick Grange, and
19256: speaking to Mr. Brooke. It was the day after Mr. Casaubon had been
19257: buried, and Dorothea was not yet able to leave her room.
19258: 
19259: “That would be difficult, you know, Chettam, as she is an executrix,
19260: and she likes to go into these things—property, land, that kind of
19261: thing. She has her notions, you know,” said Mr. Brooke, sticking his
19262: eye-glasses on nervously, and exploring the edges of a folded paper
19263: which he held in his hand; “and she would like to act—depend upon it,
19264: as an executrix Dorothea would want to act. And she was twenty-one last
19265: December, you know. I can hinder nothing.”
19266: 
19267: Sir James looked at the carpet for a minute in silence, and then
19268: lifting his eyes suddenly fixed them on Mr. Brooke, saying, “I will
19269: tell you what we can do. Until Dorothea is well, all business must be
19270: kept from her, and as soon as she is able to be moved she must come to
19271: us. Being with Celia and the baby will be the best thing in the world
19272: for her, and will pass away the time. And meanwhile you must get rid of
19273: Ladislaw: you must send him out of the country.” Here Sir James’s look
19274: of disgust returned in all its intensity.
19275: 
19276: Mr. Brooke put his hands behind him, walked to the window and
19277: straightened his back with a little shake before he replied.
19278: 
19279: “That is easily said, Chettam, easily said, you know.”
19280: 
19281: “My dear sir,” persisted Sir James, restraining his indignation within
19282: respectful forms, “it was you who brought him here, and you who keep
19283: him here—I mean by the occupation you give him.”
19284: 
19285: “Yes, but I can’t dismiss him in an instant without assigning reasons,
19286: my dear Chettam. Ladislaw has been invaluable, most satisfactory. I
19287: consider that I have done this part of the country a service by
19288: bringing him—by bringing him, you know.” Mr. Brooke ended with a nod,
19289: turning round to give it.
19290: 
19291: “It’s a pity this part of the country didn’t do without him, that’s all
19292: I have to say about it. At any rate, as Dorothea’s brother-in-law, I
19293: feel warranted in objecting strongly to his being kept here by any
19294: action on the part of her friends. You admit, I hope, that I have a
19295: right to speak about what concerns the dignity of my wife’s sister?”
19296: 
19297: Sir James was getting warm.
19298: 
19299: “Of course, my dear Chettam, of course. But you and I have different
19300: ideas—different—”
19301: 
19302: “Not about this action of Casaubon’s, I should hope,” interrupted Sir
19303: James. “I say that he has most unfairly compromised Dorothea. I say
19304: that there never was a meaner, more ungentlemanly action than this—a
19305: codicil of this sort to a will which he made at the time of his
19306: marriage with the knowledge and reliance of her family—a positive
19307: insult to Dorothea!”
19308: 
19309: “Well, you know, Casaubon was a little twisted about Ladislaw. Ladislaw
19310: has told me the reason—dislike of the bent he took, you know—Ladislaw
19311: didn’t think much of Casaubon’s notions, Thoth and Dagon—that sort of
19312: thing: and I fancy that Casaubon didn’t like the independent position
19313: Ladislaw had taken up. I saw the letters between them, you know. Poor
19314: Casaubon was a little buried in books—he didn’t know the world.”
19315: 
19316: “It’s all very well for Ladislaw to put that color on it,” said Sir
19317: James. “But I believe Casaubon was only jealous of him on Dorothea’s
19318: account, and the world will suppose that she gave him some reason; and
19319: that is what makes it so abominable—coupling her name with this young
19320: fellow’s.”
19321: 
19322: “My dear Chettam, it won’t lead to anything, you know,” said Mr.
19323: Brooke, seating himself and sticking on his eye-glass again. “It’s all
19324: of a piece with Casaubon’s oddity. This paper, now, ‘Synoptical
19325: Tabulation’ and so on, ‘for the use of Mrs. Casaubon,’ it was locked up
19326: in the desk with the will. I suppose he meant Dorothea to publish his
19327: researches, eh? and she’ll do it, you know; she has gone into his
19328: studies uncommonly.”
19329: 
19330: “My dear sir,” said Sir James, impatiently, “that is neither here nor
19331: there. The question is, whether you don’t see with me the propriety of
19332: sending young Ladislaw away?”
19333: 
19334: “Well, no, not the urgency of the thing. By-and-by, perhaps, it may
19335: come round. As to gossip, you know, sending him away won’t hinder
19336: gossip. People say what they like to say, not what they have chapter
19337: and verse for,” said Mr Brooke, becoming acute about the truths that
19338: lay on the side of his own wishes. “I might get rid of Ladislaw up to a
19339: certain point—take away the ‘Pioneer’ from him, and that sort of thing;
19340: but I couldn’t send him out of the country if he didn’t choose to
19341: go—didn’t choose, you know.”
19342: 
19343: Mr. Brooke, persisting as quietly as if he were only discussing the
19344: nature of last year’s weather, and nodding at the end with his usual
19345: amenity, was an exasperating form of obstinacy.
19346: 
19347: “Good God!” said Sir James, with as much passion as he ever showed,
19348: “let us get him a post; let us spend money on him. If he could go in
19349: the suite of some Colonial Governor! Grampus might take him—and I could
19350: write to Fulke about it.”
19351: 
19352: “But Ladislaw won’t be shipped off like a head of cattle, my dear
19353: fellow; Ladislaw has his ideas. It’s my opinion that if he were to part
19354: from me to-morrow, you’d only hear the more of him in the country. With
19355: his talent for speaking and drawing up documents, there are few men who
19356: could come up to him as an agitator—an agitator, you know.”
19357: 
19358: “Agitator!” said Sir James, with bitter emphasis, feeling that the
19359: syllables of this word properly repeated were a sufficient exposure of
19360: its hatefulness.
19361: 
19362: “But be reasonable, Chettam. Dorothea, now. As you say, she had better
19363: go to Celia as soon as possible. She can stay under your roof, and in
19364: the mean time things may come round quietly. Don’t let us be firing off
19365: our guns in a hurry, you know. Standish will keep our counsel, and the
19366: news will be old before it’s known. Twenty things may happen to carry
19367: off Ladislaw—without my doing anything, you know.”
19368: 
19369: “Then I am to conclude that you decline to do anything?”
19370: 
19371: “Decline, Chettam?—no—I didn’t say decline. But I really don’t see what
19372: I could do. Ladislaw is a gentleman.”
19373: 
19374: “I am glad to hear it!” said Sir James, his irritation making him
19375: forget himself a little. “I am sure Casaubon was not.”
19376: 
19377: “Well, it would have been worse if he had made the codicil to hinder
19378: her from marrying again at all, you know.”
19379: 
19380: “I don’t know that,” said Sir James. “It would have been less
19381: indelicate.”
19382: 
19383: “One of poor Casaubon’s freaks! That attack upset his brain a little.
19384: It all goes for nothing. She doesn’t _want_ to marry Ladislaw.”
19385: 
19386: “But this codicil is framed so as to make everybody believe that she
19387: did. I don’t believe anything of the sort about Dorothea,” said Sir
19388: James—then frowningly, “but I suspect Ladislaw. I tell you frankly, I
19389: suspect Ladislaw.”
19390: 
19391: “I couldn’t take any immediate action on that ground, Chettam. In fact,
19392: if it were possible to pack him off—send him to Norfolk Island—that
19393: sort of thing—it would look all the worse for Dorothea to those who
19394: knew about it. It would seem as if we distrusted her—distrusted her,
19395: you know.”
19396: 
19397: That Mr. Brooke had hit on an undeniable argument, did not tend to
19398: soothe Sir James. He put out his hand to reach his hat, implying that
19399: he did not mean to contend further, and said, still with some heat—
19400: 
19401: “Well, I can only say that I think Dorothea was sacrificed once,
19402: because her friends were too careless. I shall do what I can, as her
19403: brother, to protect her now.”
19404: 
19405: “You can’t do better than get her to Freshitt as soon as possible,
19406: Chettam. I approve that plan altogether,” said Mr. Brooke, well pleased
19407: that he had won the argument. It would have been highly inconvenient to
19408: him to part with Ladislaw at that time, when a dissolution might happen
19409: any day, and electors were to be convinced of the course by which the
19410: interests of the country would be best served. Mr. Brooke sincerely
19411: believed that this end could be secured by his own return to
19412: Parliament: he offered the forces of his mind honestly to the nation.
19413: 
19414: 
19415: 
19416: 
19417: CHAPTER L.
19418: 
19419: “This Loller here wol precilen us somewhat.”
19420: “Nay by my father’s soule! that schal he nat,”
19421: Sayde the Schipman, ‘here schal he not preche,
19422: We schal no gospel glosen here ne teche.
19423: We leven all in the gret God,’ quod he.
19424: He wolden sowen some diffcultee.”—_Canterbury Tales_.
19425: 
19426: 
19427: Dorothea had been safe at Freshitt Hall nearly a week before she had
19428: asked any dangerous questions. Every morning now she sat with Celia in
19429: the prettiest of up-stairs sitting-rooms, opening into a small
19430: conservatory—Celia all in white and lavender like a bunch of mixed
19431: violets, watching the remarkable acts of the baby, which were so
19432: dubious to her inexperienced mind that all conversation was interrupted
19433: by appeals for their interpretation made to the oracular nurse.
19434: Dorothea sat by in her widow’s dress, with an expression which rather
19435: provoked Celia, as being much too sad; for not only was baby quite
19436: well, but really when a husband had been so dull and troublesome while
19437: he lived, and besides that had—well, well! Sir James, of course, had
19438: told Celia everything, with a strong representation how important it
19439: was that Dorothea should not know it sooner than was inevitable.
19440: 
19441: But Mr. Brooke had been right in predicting that Dorothea would not
19442: long remain passive where action had been assigned to her; she knew the
19443: purport of her husband’s will made at the time of their marriage, and
19444: her mind, as soon as she was clearly conscious of her position, was
19445: silently occupied with what she ought to do as the owner of Lowick
19446: Manor with the patronage of the living attached to it.
19447: 
19448: One morning when her uncle paid his usual visit, though with an unusual
19449: alacrity in his manner which he accounted for by saying that it was now
19450: pretty certain Parliament would be dissolved forthwith, Dorothea said—
19451: 
19452: “Uncle, it is right now that I should consider who is to have the
19453: living at Lowick. After Mr. Tucker had been provided for, I never heard
19454: my husband say that he had any clergyman in his mind as a successor to
19455: himself. I think I ought to have the keys now and go to Lowick to
19456: examine all my husband’s papers. There may be something that would
19457: throw light on his wishes.”
19458: 
19459: “No hurry, my dear,” said Mr. Brooke, quietly. “By-and-by, you know,
19460: you can go, if you like. But I cast my eyes over things in the desks
19461: and drawers—there was nothing—nothing but deep subjects, you
19462: know—besides the will. Everything can be done by-and-by. As to the
19463: living, I have had an application for interest already—I should say
19464: rather good. Mr. Tyke has been strongly recommended to me—I had
19465: something to do with getting him an appointment before. An apostolic
19466: man, I believe—the sort of thing that would suit you, my dear.”
19467: 
19468: “I should like to have fuller knowledge about him, uncle, and judge for
19469: myself, if Mr. Casaubon has not left any expression of his wishes. He
19470: has perhaps made some addition to his will—there may be some
19471: instructions for me,” said Dorothea, who had all the while had this
19472: conjecture in her mind with relation to her husband’s work.
19473: 
19474: “Nothing about the rectory, my dear—nothing,” said Mr. Brooke, rising
19475: to go away, and putting out his hand to his nieces: “nor about his
19476: researches, you know. Nothing in the will.”
19477: 
19478: Dorothea’s lip quivered.
19479: 
19480: “Come, you must not think of these things yet, my dear. By-and-by, you
19481: know.”
19482: 
19483: “I am quite well now, uncle; I wish to exert myself.”
19484: 
19485: “Well, well, we shall see. But I must run away now—I have no end of
19486: work now—it’s a crisis—a political crisis, you know. And here is Celia
19487: and her little man—you are an aunt, you know, now, and I am a sort of
19488: grandfather,” said Mr. Brooke, with placid hurry, anxious to get away
19489: and tell Chettam that it would not be his (Mr. Brooke’s) fault if
19490: Dorothea insisted on looking into everything.
19491: 
19492: Dorothea sank back in her chair when her uncle had left the room, and
19493: cast her eyes down meditatively on her crossed hands.
19494: 
19495: “Look, Dodo! look at him! Did you ever see anything like that?” said
19496: Celia, in her comfortable staccato.
19497: 
19498: “What, Kitty?” said Dorothea, lifting her eyes rather absently.
19499: 
19500: “What? why, his upper lip; see how he is drawing it down, as if he
19501: meant to make a face. Isn’t it wonderful! He may have his little
19502: thoughts. I wish nurse were here. Do look at him.”
19503: 
19504: A large tear which had been for some time gathering, rolled down
19505: Dorothea’s cheek as she looked up and tried to smile.
19506: 
19507: “Don’t be sad, Dodo; kiss baby. What are you brooding over so? I am
19508: sure you did everything, and a great deal too much. You should be happy
19509: now.”
19510: 
19511: “I wonder if Sir James would drive me to Lowick. I want to look over
19512: everything—to see if there were any words written for me.”
19513: 
19514: “You are not to go till Mr. Lydgate says you may go. And he has not
19515: said so yet (here you are, nurse; take baby and walk up and down the
19516: gallery). Besides, you have got a wrong notion in your head as usual,
19517: Dodo—I can see that: it vexes me.”
19518: 
19519: “Where am I wrong, Kitty?” said Dorothea, quite meekly. She was almost
19520: ready now to think Celia wiser than herself, and was really wondering
19521: with some fear what her wrong notion was. Celia felt her advantage, and
19522: was determined to use it. None of them knew Dodo as well as she did, or
19523: knew how to manage her. Since Celia’s baby was born, she had had a new
19524: sense of her mental solidity and calm wisdom. It seemed clear that
19525: where there was a baby, things were right enough, and that error, in
19526: general, was a mere lack of that central poising force.
19527: 
19528: “I can see what you are thinking of as well as can be, Dodo,” said
19529: Celia. “You are wanting to find out if there is anything uncomfortable
19530: for you to do now, only because Mr. Casaubon wished it. As if you had
19531: not been uncomfortable enough before. And he doesn’t deserve it, and
19532: you will find that out. He has behaved very badly. James is as angry
19533: with him as can be. And I had better tell you, to prepare you.”
19534: 
19535: “Celia,” said Dorothea, entreatingly, “you distress me. Tell me at once
19536: what you mean.” It glanced through her mind that Mr. Casaubon had left
19537: the property away from her—which would not be so very distressing.
19538: 
19539: “Why, he has made a codicil to his will, to say the property was all to
19540: go away from you if you married—I mean—”
19541: 
19542: “That is of no consequence,” said Dorothea, breaking in impetuously.
19543: 
19544: “But if you married Mr. Ladislaw, not anybody else,” Celia went on with
19545: persevering quietude. “Of course that is of no consequence in one
19546: way—you never _would_ marry Mr. Ladislaw; but that only makes it worse
19547: of Mr. Casaubon.”
19548: 
19549: The blood rushed to Dorothea’s face and neck painfully. But Celia was
19550: administering what she thought a sobering dose of fact. It was taking
19551: up notions that had done Dodo’s health so much harm. So she went on in
19552: her neutral tone, as if she had been remarking on baby’s robes.
19553: 
19554: “James says so. He says it is abominable, and not like a gentleman. And
19555: there never was a better judge than James. It is as if Mr. Casaubon
19556: wanted to make people believe that you would wish to marry Mr.
19557: Ladislaw—which is ridiculous. Only James says it was to hinder Mr.
19558: Ladislaw from wanting to marry you for your money—just as if he ever
19559: would think of making you an offer. Mrs. Cadwallader said you might as
19560: well marry an Italian with white mice! But I must just go and look at
19561: baby,” Celia added, without the least change of tone, throwing a light
19562: shawl over her, and tripping away.
19563: 
19564: Dorothea by this time had turned cold again, and now threw herself back
19565: helplessly in her chair. She might have compared her experience at that
19566: moment to the vague, alarmed consciousness that her life was taking on
19567: a new form, that she was undergoing a metamorphosis in which memory
19568: would not adjust itself to the stirring of new organs. Everything was
19569: changing its aspect: her husband’s conduct, her own duteous feeling
19570: towards him, every struggle between them—and yet more, her whole
19571: relation to Will Ladislaw. Her world was in a state of convulsive
19572: change; the only thing she could say distinctly to herself was, that
19573: she must wait and think anew. One change terrified her as if it had
19574: been a sin; it was a violent shock of repulsion from her departed
19575: husband, who had had hidden thoughts, perhaps perverting everything she
19576: said and did. Then again she was conscious of another change which also
19577: made her tremulous; it was a sudden strange yearning of heart towards
19578: Will Ladislaw. It had never before entered her mind that he could,
19579: under any circumstances, be her lover: conceive the effect of the
19580: sudden revelation that another had thought of him in that light—that
19581: perhaps he himself had been conscious of such a possibility,—and this
19582: with the hurrying, crowding vision of unfitting conditions, and
19583: questions not soon to be solved.
19584: 
19585: It seemed a long while—she did not know how long—before she heard Celia
19586: saying, “That will do, nurse; he will be quiet on my lap now. You can
19587: go to lunch, and let Garratt stay in the next room. What I think,
19588: Dodo,” Celia went on, observing nothing more than that Dorothea was
19589: leaning back in her chair, and likely to be passive, “is that Mr.
19590: Casaubon was spiteful. I never did like him, and James never did. I
19591: think the corners of his mouth were dreadfully spiteful. And now he has
19592: behaved in this way, I am sure religion does not require you to make
19593: yourself uncomfortable about him. If he has been taken away, that is a
19594: mercy, and you ought to be grateful. We should not grieve, should we,
19595: baby?” said Celia confidentially to that unconscious centre and poise
19596: of the world, who had the most remarkable fists all complete even to
19597: the nails, and hair enough, really, when you took his cap off, to
19598: make—you didn’t know what:—in short, he was Bouddha in a Western form.
19599: 
19600: At this crisis Lydgate was announced, and one of the first things he
19601: said was, “I fear you are not so well as you were, Mrs. Casaubon; have
19602: you been agitated? allow me to feel your pulse.” Dorothea’s hand was of
19603: a marble coldness.
19604: 
19605: “She wants to go to Lowick, to look over papers,” said Celia. “She
19606: ought not, ought she?”
19607: 
19608: Lydgate did not speak for a few moments. Then he said, looking at
19609: Dorothea. “I hardly know. In my opinion Mrs. Casaubon should do what
19610: would give her the most repose of mind. That repose will not always
19611: come from being forbidden to act.”
19612: 
19613: “Thank you,” said Dorothea, exerting herself, “I am sure that is wise.
19614: There are so many things which I ought to attend to. Why should I sit
19615: here idle?” Then, with an effort to recall subjects not connected with
19616: her agitation, she added, abruptly, “You know every one in Middlemarch,
19617: I think, Mr. Lydgate. I shall ask you to tell me a great deal. I have
19618: serious things to do now. I have a living to give away. You know Mr.
19619: Tyke and all the—” But Dorothea’s effort was too much for her; she
19620: broke off and burst into sobs.
19621: 
19622: Lydgate made her drink a dose of sal volatile.
19623: 
19624: “Let Mrs. Casaubon do as she likes,” he said to Sir James, whom he
19625: asked to see before quitting the house. “She wants perfect freedom, I
19626: think, more than any other prescription.”
19627: 
19628: His attendance on Dorothea while her brain was excited, had enabled him
19629: to form some true conclusions concerning the trials of her life. He
19630: felt sure that she had been suffering from the strain and conflict of
19631: self-repression; and that she was likely now to feel herself only in
19632: another sort of pinfold than that from which she had been released.
19633: 
19634: Lydgate’s advice was all the easier for Sir James to follow when he
19635: found that Celia had already told Dorothea the unpleasant fact about
19636: the will. There was no help for it now—no reason for any further delay
19637: in the execution of necessary business. And the next day Sir James
19638: complied at once with her request that he would drive her to Lowick.
19639: 
19640: “I have no wish to stay there at present,” said Dorothea; “I could
19641: hardly bear it. I am much happier at Freshitt with Celia. I shall be
19642: able to think better about what should be done at Lowick by looking at
19643: it from a distance. And I should like to be at the Grange a little
19644: while with my uncle, and go about in all the old walks and among the
19645: people in the village.”
19646: 
19647: “Not yet, I think. Your uncle is having political company, and you are
19648: better out of the way of such doings,” said Sir James, who at that
19649: moment thought of the Grange chiefly as a haunt of young Ladislaw’s.
19650: But no word passed between him and Dorothea about the objectionable
19651: part of the will; indeed, both of them felt that the mention of it
19652: between them would be impossible. Sir James was shy, even with men,
19653: about disagreeable subjects; and the one thing that Dorothea would have
19654: chosen to say, if she had spoken on the matter at all, was forbidden to
19655: her at present because it seemed to be a further exposure of her
19656: husband’s injustice. Yet she did wish that Sir James could know what
19657: had passed between her and her husband about Will Ladislaw’s moral
19658: claim on the property: it would then, she thought, be apparent to him
19659: as it was to her, that her husband’s strange indelicate proviso had
19660: been chiefly urged by his bitter resistance to that idea of claim, and
19661: not merely by personal feelings more difficult to talk about. Also, it
19662: must be admitted, Dorothea wished that this could be known for Will’s
19663: sake, since her friends seemed to think of him as simply an object of
19664: Mr. Casaubon’s charity. Why should he be compared with an Italian
19665: carrying white mice? That word quoted from Mrs. Cadwallader seemed like
19666: a mocking travesty wrought in the dark by an impish finger.
19667: 
19668: At Lowick Dorothea searched desk and drawer—searched all her husband’s
19669: places of deposit for private writing, but found no paper addressed
19670: especially to her, except that “Synoptical Tabulation,” which was
19671: probably only the beginning of many intended directions for her
19672: guidance. In carrying out this bequest of labor to Dorothea, as in all
19673: else, Mr. Casaubon had been slow and hesitating, oppressed in the plan
19674: of transmitting his work, as he had been in executing it, by the sense
19675: of moving heavily in a dim and clogging medium: distrust of Dorothea’s
19676: competence to arrange what he had prepared was subdued only by distrust
19677: of any other redactor. But he had come at last to create a trust for
19678: himself out of Dorothea’s nature: she could do what she resolved to do:
19679: and he willingly imagined her toiling under the fetters of a promise to
19680: erect a tomb with his name upon it. (Not that Mr. Casaubon called the
19681: future volumes a tomb; he called them the Key to all Mythologies.) But
19682: the months gained on him and left his plans belated: he had only had
19683: time to ask for that promise by which he sought to keep his cold grasp
19684: on Dorothea’s life.
19685: 
19686: The grasp had slipped away. Bound by a pledge given from the depths of
19687: her pity, she would have been capable of undertaking a toil which her
19688: judgment whispered was vain for all uses except that consecration of
19689: faithfulness which is a supreme use. But now her judgment, instead of
19690: being controlled by duteous devotion, was made active by the
19691: imbittering discovery that in her past union there had lurked the
19692: hidden alienation of secrecy and suspicion. The living, suffering man
19693: was no longer before her to awaken her pity: there remained only the
19694: retrospect of painful subjection to a husband whose thoughts had been
19695: lower than she had believed, whose exorbitant claims for himself had
19696: even blinded his scrupulous care for his own character, and made him
19697: defeat his own pride by shocking men of ordinary honor. As for the
19698: property which was the sign of that broken tie, she would have been
19699: glad to be free from it and have nothing more than her original fortune
19700: which had been settled on her, if there had not been duties attached to
19701: ownership, which she ought not to flinch from. About this property many
19702: troublous questions insisted on rising: had she not been right in
19703: thinking that the half of it ought to go to Will Ladislaw?—but was it
19704: not impossible now for her to do that act of justice? Mr. Casaubon had
19705: taken a cruelly effective means of hindering her: even with indignation
19706: against him in her heart, any act that seemed a triumphant eluding of
19707: his purpose revolted her.
19708: 
19709: After collecting papers of business which she wished to examine, she
19710: locked up again the desks and drawers—all empty of personal words for
19711: her—empty of any sign that in her husband’s lonely brooding his heart
19712: had gone out to her in excuse or explanation; and she went back to
19713: Freshitt with the sense that around his last hard demand and his last
19714: injurious assertion of his power, the silence was unbroken.
19715: 
19716: Dorothea tried now to turn her thoughts towards immediate duties, and
19717: one of these was of a kind which others were determined to remind her
19718: of. Lydgate’s ear had caught eagerly her mention of the living, and as
19719: soon as he could, he reopened the subject, seeing here a possibility of
19720: making amends for the casting-vote he had once given with an
19721: ill-satisfied conscience. “Instead of telling you anything about Mr.
19722: Tyke,” he said, “I should like to speak of another man—Mr. Farebrother,
19723: the Vicar of St. Botolph’s. His living is a poor one, and gives him a
19724: stinted provision for himself and his family. His mother, aunt, and
19725: sister all live with him, and depend upon him. I believe he has never
19726: married because of them. I never heard such good preaching as his—such
19727: plain, easy eloquence. He would have done to preach at St. Paul’s Cross
19728: after old Latimer. His talk is just as good about all subjects:
19729: original, simple, clear. I think him a remarkable fellow: he ought to
19730: have done more than he has done.”
19731: 
19732: “Why has he not done more?” said Dorothea, interested now in all who
19733: had slipped below their own intention.
19734: 
19735: “That’s a hard question,” said Lydgate. “I find myself that it’s
19736: uncommonly difficult to make the right thing work: there are so many
19737: strings pulling at once. Farebrother often hints that he has got into
19738: the wrong profession; he wants a wider range than that of a poor
19739: clergyman, and I suppose he has no interest to help him on. He is very
19740: fond of Natural History and various scientific matters, and he is
19741: hampered in reconciling these tastes with his position. He has no money
19742: to spare—hardly enough to use; and that has led him into
19743: card-playing—Middlemarch is a great place for whist. He does play for
19744: money, and he wins a good deal. Of course that takes him into company a
19745: little beneath him, and makes him slack about some things; and yet,
19746: with all that, looking at him as a whole, I think he is one of the most
19747: blameless men I ever knew. He has neither venom nor doubleness in him,
19748: and those often go with a more correct outside.”
19749: 
19750: “I wonder whether he suffers in his conscience because of that habit,”
19751: said Dorothea; “I wonder whether he wishes he could leave it off.”
19752: 
19753: “I have no doubt he would leave it off, if he were transplanted into
19754: plenty: he would be glad of the time for other things.”
19755: 
19756: “My uncle says that Mr. Tyke is spoken of as an apostolic man,” said
19757: Dorothea, meditatively. She was wishing it were possible to restore the
19758: times of primitive zeal, and yet thinking of Mr. Farebrother with a
19759: strong desire to rescue him from his chance-gotten money.
19760: 
19761: “I don’t pretend to say that Farebrother is apostolic,” said Lydgate.
19762: “His position is not quite like that of the Apostles: he is only a
19763: parson among parishioners whose lives he has to try and make better.
19764: Practically I find that what is called being apostolic now, is an
19765: impatience of everything in which the parson doesn’t cut the principal
19766: figure. I see something of that in Mr. Tyke at the Hospital: a good
19767: deal of his doctrine is a sort of pinching hard to make people
19768: uncomfortably aware of him. Besides, an apostolic man at Lowick!—he
19769: ought to think, as St. Francis did, that it is needful to preach to the
19770: birds.”
19771: 
19772: “True,” said Dorothea. “It is hard to imagine what sort of notions our
19773: farmers and laborers get from their teaching. I have been looking into
19774: a volume of sermons by Mr. Tyke: such sermons would be of no use at
19775: Lowick—I mean, about imputed righteousness and the prophecies in the
19776: Apocalypse. I have always been thinking of the different ways in which
19777: Christianity is taught, and whenever I find one way that makes it a
19778: wider blessing than any other, I cling to that as the truest—I mean
19779: that which takes in the most good of all kinds, and brings in the most
19780: people as sharers in it. It is surely better to pardon too much, than
19781: to condemn too much. But I should like to see Mr. Farebrother and hear
19782: him preach.”
19783: 
19784: “Do,” said Lydgate; “I trust to the effect of that. He is very much
19785: beloved, but he has his enemies too: there are always people who can’t
19786: forgive an able man for differing from them. And that money-winning
19787: business is really a blot. You don’t, of course, see many Middlemarch
19788: people: but Mr. Ladislaw, who is constantly seeing Mr. Brooke, is a
19789: great friend of Mr. Farebrother’s old ladies, and would be glad to sing
19790: the Vicar’s praises. One of the old ladies—Miss Noble, the aunt—is a
19791: wonderfully quaint picture of self-forgetful goodness, and Ladislaw
19792: gallants her about sometimes. I met them one day in a back street: you
19793: know Ladislaw’s look—a sort of Daphnis in coat and waistcoat; and this
19794: little old maid reaching up to his arm—they looked like a couple
19795: dropped out of a romantic comedy. But the best evidence about
19796: Farebrother is to see him and hear him.”
19797: 
19798: Happily Dorothea was in her private sitting-room when this conversation
19799: occurred, and there was no one present to make Lydgate’s innocent
19800: introduction of Ladislaw painful to her. As was usual with him in
19801: matters of personal gossip, Lydgate had quite forgotten Rosamond’s
19802: remark that she thought Will adored Mrs. Casaubon. At that moment he
19803: was only caring for what would recommend the Farebrother family; and he
19804: had purposely given emphasis to the worst that could be said about the
19805: Vicar, in order to forestall objections. In the weeks since Mr.
19806: Casaubon’s death he had hardly seen Ladislaw, and he had heard no rumor
19807: to warn him that Mr. Brooke’s confidential secretary was a dangerous
19808: subject with Mrs. Casaubon. When he was gone, his picture of Ladislaw
19809: lingered in her mind and disputed the ground with that question of the
19810: Lowick living. What was Will Ladislaw thinking about her? Would he hear
19811: of that fact which made her cheeks burn as they never used to do? And
19812: how would he feel when he heard it?—But she could see as well as
19813: possible how he smiled down at the little old maid. An Italian with
19814: white mice!—on the contrary, he was a creature who entered into every
19815: one’s feelings, and could take the pressure of their thought instead of
19816: urging his own with iron resistance.
19817: 
19818: 
19819: 
19820: 
19821: CHAPTER LI.
19822: 
19823: Party is Nature too, and you shall see
19824: By force of Logic how they both agree:
19825: The Many in the One, the One in Many;
19826: All is not Some, nor Some the same as Any:
19827: Genus holds species, both are great or small;
19828: One genus highest, one not high at all;
19829: Each species has its differentia too,
19830: This is not That, and He was never You,
19831: Though this and that are AYES, and you and he
19832: Are like as one to one, or three to three.
19833: 
19834: 
19835: No gossip about Mr. Casaubon’s will had yet reached Ladislaw: the air
19836: seemed to be filled with the dissolution of Parliament and the coming
19837: election, as the old wakes and fairs were filled with the rival clatter
19838: of itinerant shows; and more private noises were taken little notice
19839: of. The famous “dry election” was at hand, in which the depths of
19840: public feeling might be measured by the low flood-mark of drink. Will
19841: Ladislaw was one of the busiest at this time; and though Dorothea’s
19842: widowhood was continually in his thought, he was so far from wishing to
19843: be spoken to on the subject, that when Lydgate sought him out to tell
19844: him what had passed about the Lowick living, he answered rather
19845: waspishly—
19846: 
19847: “Why should you bring me into the matter? I never see Mrs. Casaubon,
19848: and am not likely to see her, since she is at Freshitt. I never go
19849: there. It is Tory ground, where I and the ‘Pioneer’ are no more welcome
19850: than a poacher and his gun.”
19851: 
19852: The fact was that Will had been made the more susceptible by observing
19853: that Mr. Brooke, instead of wishing him, as before, to come to the
19854: Grange oftener than was quite agreeable to himself, seemed now to
19855: contrive that he should go there as little as possible. This was a
19856: shuffling concession of Mr. Brooke’s to Sir James Chettam’s indignant
19857: remonstrance; and Will, awake to the slightest hint in this direction,
19858: concluded that he was to be kept away from the Grange on Dorothea’s
19859: account. Her friends, then, regarded him with some suspicion? Their
19860: fears were quite superfluous: they were very much mistaken if they
19861: imagined that he would put himself forward as a needy adventurer trying
19862: to win the favor of a rich woman.
19863: 
19864: Until now Will had never fully seen the chasm between himself and
19865: Dorothea—until now that he was come to the brink of it, and saw her on
19866: the other side. He began, not without some inward rage, to think of
19867: going away from the neighborhood: it would be impossible for him to
19868: show any further interest in Dorothea without subjecting himself to
19869: disagreeable imputations—perhaps even in her mind, which others might
19870: try to poison.
19871: 
19872: “We are forever divided,” said Will. “I might as well be at Rome; she
19873: would be no farther from me.” But what we call our despair is often
19874: only the painful eagerness of unfed hope. There were plenty of reasons
19875: why he should not go—public reasons why he should not quit his post at
19876: this crisis, leaving Mr. Brooke in the lurch when he needed “coaching”
19877: for the election, and when there was so much canvassing, direct and
19878: indirect, to be carried on. Will could not like to leave his own
19879: chessmen in the heat of a game; and any candidate on the right side,
19880: even if his brain and marrow had been as soft as was consistent with a
19881: gentlemanly bearing, might help to turn a majority. To coach Mr. Brooke
19882: and keep him steadily to the idea that he must pledge himself to vote
19883: for the actual Reform Bill, instead of insisting on his independence
19884: and power of pulling up in time, was not an easy task. Mr.
19885: Farebrother’s prophecy of a fourth candidate “in the bag” had not yet
19886: been fulfilled, neither the Parliamentary Candidate Society nor any
19887: other power on the watch to secure a reforming majority seeing a worthy
19888: nodus for interference while there was a second reforming candidate
19889: like Mr. Brooke, who might be returned at his own expense; and the
19890: fight lay entirely between Pinkerton the old Tory member, Bagster the
19891: new Whig member returned at the last election, and Brooke the future
19892: independent member, who was to fetter himself for this occasion only.
19893: Mr. Hawley and his party would bend all their forces to the return of
19894: Pinkerton, and Mr. Brooke’s success must depend either on plumpers
19895: which would leave Bagster in the rear, or on the new minting of Tory
19896: votes into reforming votes. The latter means, of course, would be
19897: preferable.
19898: 
19899: This prospect of converting votes was a dangerous distraction to Mr.
19900: Brooke: his impression that waverers were likely to be allured by
19901: wavering statements, and also the liability of his mind to stick afresh
19902: at opposing arguments as they turned up in his memory, gave Will
19903: Ladislaw much trouble.
19904: 
19905: “You know there are tactics in these things,” said Mr. Brooke; “meeting
19906: people half-way—tempering your ideas—saying, ‘Well now, there’s
19907: something in that,’ and so on. I agree with you that this is a peculiar
19908: occasion—the country with a will of its own—political unions—that sort
19909: of thing—but we sometimes cut with rather too sharp a knife, Ladislaw.
19910: These ten-pound householders, now: why ten? Draw the line
19911: somewhere—yes: but why just at ten? That’s a difficult question, now,
19912: if you go into it.”
19913: 
19914: “Of course it is,” said Will, impatiently. “But if you are to wait till
19915: we get a logical Bill, you must put yourself forward as a
19916: revolutionist, and then Middlemarch would not elect you, I fancy. As
19917: for trimming, this is not a time for trimming.”
19918: 
19919: Mr. Brooke always ended by agreeing with Ladislaw, who still appeared
19920: to him a sort of Burke with a leaven of Shelley; but after an interval
19921: the wisdom of his own methods reasserted itself, and he was again drawn
19922: into using them with much hopefulness. At this stage of affairs he was
19923: in excellent spirits, which even supported him under large advances of
19924: money; for his powers of convincing and persuading had not yet been
19925: tested by anything more difficult than a chairman’s speech introducing
19926: other orators, or a dialogue with a Middlemarch voter, from which he
19927: came away with a sense that he was a tactician by nature, and that it
19928: was a pity he had not gone earlier into this kind of thing. He was a
19929: little conscious of defeat, however, with Mr. Mawmsey, a chief
19930: representative in Middlemarch of that great social power, the retail
19931: trader, and naturally one of the most doubtful voters in the
19932: borough—willing for his own part to supply an equal quality of teas and
19933: sugars to reformer and anti-reformer, as well as to agree impartially
19934: with both, and feeling like the burgesses of old that this necessity of
19935: electing members was a great burthen to a town; for even if there were
19936: no danger in holding out hopes to all parties beforehand, there would
19937: be the painful necessity at last of disappointing respectable people
19938: whose names were on his books. He was accustomed to receive large
19939: orders from Mr. Brooke of Tipton; but then, there were many of
19940: Pinkerton’s committee whose opinions had a great weight of grocery on
19941: their side. Mr. Mawmsey thinking that Mr. Brooke, as not too “clever in
19942: his intellects,” was the more likely to forgive a grocer who gave a
19943: hostile vote under pressure, had become confidential in his back
19944: parlor.
19945: 
19946: “As to Reform, sir, put it in a family light,” he said, rattling the
19947: small silver in his pocket, and smiling affably. “Will it support Mrs.
19948: Mawmsey, and enable her to bring up six children when I am no more? I
19949: put the question _fictiously_, knowing what must be the answer. Very
19950: well, sir. I ask you what, as a husband and a father, I am to do when
19951: gentlemen come to me and say, ‘Do as you like, Mawmsey; but if you vote
19952: against us, I shall get my groceries elsewhere: when I sugar my liquor
19953: I like to feel that I am benefiting the country by maintaining
19954: tradesmen of the right color.’ Those very words have been spoken to me,
19955: sir, in the very chair where you are now sitting. I don’t mean by your
19956: honorable self, Mr. Brooke.”
19957: 
19958: “No, no, no—that’s narrow, you know. Until my butler complains to me of
19959: your goods, Mr. Mawmsey,” said Mr. Brooke, soothingly, “until I hear
19960: that you send bad sugars, spices—that sort of thing—I shall never order
19961: him to go elsewhere.”
19962: 
19963: “Sir, I am your humble servant, and greatly obliged,” said Mr. Mawmsey,
19964: feeling that politics were clearing up a little. “There would be some
19965: pleasure in voting for a gentleman who speaks in that honorable
19966: manner.”
19967: 
19968: “Well, you know, Mr. Mawmsey, you would find it the right thing to put
19969: yourself on our side. This Reform will touch everybody by-and-by—a
19970: thoroughly popular measure—a sort of A, B, C, you know, that must come
19971: first before the rest can follow. I quite agree with you that you’ve
19972: got to look at the thing in a family light: but public spirit, now.
19973: We’re all one family, you know—it’s all one cupboard. Such a thing as a
19974: vote, now: why, it may help to make men’s fortunes at the Cape—there’s
19975: no knowing what may be the effect of a vote,” Mr. Brooke ended, with a
19976: sense of being a little out at sea, though finding it still enjoyable.
19977: But Mr. Mawmsey answered in a tone of decisive check.
19978: 
19979: “I beg your pardon, sir, but I can’t afford that. When I give a vote I
19980: must know what I am doing; I must look to what will be the effects on
19981: my till and ledger, speaking respectfully. Prices, I’ll admit, are what
19982: nobody can know the merits of; and the sudden falls after you’ve bought
19983: in currants, which are a goods that will not keep—I’ve never; myself
19984: seen into the ins and outs there; which is a rebuke to human pride. But
19985: as to one family, there’s debtor and creditor, I hope; they’re not
19986: going to reform that away; else I should vote for things staying as
19987: they are. Few men have less need to cry for change than I have,
19988: personally speaking—that is, for self and family. I am not one of those
19989: who have nothing to lose: I mean as to respectability both in parish
19990: and private business, and noways in respect of your honorable self and
19991: custom, which you was good enough to say you would not withdraw from
19992: me, vote or no vote, while the article sent in was satisfactory.”
19993: 
19994: After this conversation Mr. Mawmsey went up and boasted to his wife
19995: that he had been rather too many for Brooke of Tipton, and that he
19996: didn’t mind so much now about going to the poll.
19997: 
19998: Mr. Brooke on this occasion abstained from boasting of his tactics to
19999: Ladislaw, who for his part was glad enough to persuade himself that he
20000: had no concern with any canvassing except the purely argumentative
20001: sort, and that he worked no meaner engine than knowledge. Mr. Brooke,
20002: necessarily, had his agents, who understood the nature of the
20003: Middlemarch voter and the means of enlisting his ignorance on the side
20004: of the Bill—which were remarkably similar to the means of enlisting it
20005: on the side against the Bill. Will stopped his ears. Occasionally
20006: Parliament, like the rest of our lives, even to our eating and apparel,
20007: could hardly go on if our imaginations were too active about processes.
20008: There were plenty of dirty-handed men in the world to do dirty
20009: business; and Will protested to himself that his share in bringing Mr.
20010: Brooke through would be quite innocent.
20011: 
20012: But whether he should succeed in that mode of contributing to the
20013: majority on the right side was very doubtful to him. He had written out
20014: various speeches and memoranda for speeches, but he had begun to
20015: perceive that Mr. Brooke’s mind, if it had the burthen of remembering
20016: any train of thought, would let it drop, run away in search of it, and
20017: not easily come back again. To collect documents is one mode of serving
20018: your country, and to remember the contents of a document is another.
20019: No! the only way in which Mr. Brooke could be coerced into thinking of
20020: the right arguments at the right time was to be well plied with them
20021: till they took up all the room in his brain. But here there was the
20022: difficulty of finding room, so many things having been taken in
20023: beforehand. Mr. Brooke himself observed that his ideas stood rather in
20024: his way when he was speaking.
20025: 
20026: However, Ladislaw’s coaching was forthwith to be put to the test, for
20027: before the day of nomination Mr. Brooke was to explain himself to the
20028: worthy electors of Middlemarch from the balcony of the White Hart,
20029: which looked out advantageously at an angle of the market-place,
20030: commanding a large area in front and two converging streets. It was a
20031: fine May morning, and everything seemed hopeful: there was some
20032: prospect of an understanding between Bagster’s committee and Brooke’s,
20033: to which Mr. Bulstrode, Mr. Standish as a Liberal lawyer, and such
20034: manufacturers as Mr. Plymdale and Mr. Vincy, gave a solidity which
20035: almost counterbalanced Mr. Hawley and his associates who sat for
20036: Pinkerton at the Green Dragon. Mr. Brooke, conscious of having weakened
20037: the blasts of the “Trumpet” against him, by his reforms as a landlord
20038: in the last half year, and hearing himself cheered a little as he drove
20039: into the town, felt his heart tolerably light under his buff-colored
20040: waistcoat. But with regard to critical occasions, it often happens that
20041: all moments seem comfortably remote until the last.
20042: 
20043: “This looks well, eh?” said Mr. Brooke as the crowd gathered. “I shall
20044: have a good audience, at any rate. I like this, now—this kind of public
20045: made up of one’s own neighbors, you know.”
20046: 
20047: The weavers and tanners of Middlemarch, unlike Mr. Mawmsey, had never
20048: thought of Mr. Brooke as a neighbor, and were not more attached to him
20049: than if he had been sent in a box from London. But they listened
20050: without much disturbance to the speakers who introduced the candidate,
20051: one of them—a political personage from Brassing, who came to tell
20052: Middlemarch its duty—spoke so fully, that it was alarming to think what
20053: the candidate could find to say after him. Meanwhile the crowd became
20054: denser, and as the political personage neared the end of his speech,
20055: Mr. Brooke felt a remarkable change in his sensations while he still
20056: handled his eye-glass, trifled with documents before him, and exchanged
20057: remarks with his committee, as a man to whom the moment of summons was
20058: indifferent.
20059: 
20060: “I’ll take another glass of sherry, Ladislaw,” he said, with an easy
20061: air, to Will, who was close behind him, and presently handed him the
20062: supposed fortifier. It was ill-chosen; for Mr. Brooke was an abstemious
20063: man, and to drink a second glass of sherry quickly at no great interval
20064: from the first was a surprise to his system which tended to scatter his
20065: energies instead of collecting them. Pray pity him: so many English
20066: gentlemen make themselves miserable by speechifying on entirely private
20067: grounds! whereas Mr. Brooke wished to serve his country by standing for
20068: Parliament—which, indeed, may also be done on private grounds, but
20069: being once undertaken does absolutely demand some speechifying.
20070: 
20071: It was not about the beginning of his speech that Mr. Brooke was at all
20072: anxious; this, he felt sure, would be all right; he should have it
20073: quite pat, cut out as neatly as a set of couplets from Pope. Embarking
20074: would be easy, but the vision of open sea that might come after was
20075: alarming. “And questions, now,” hinted the demon just waking up in his
20076: stomach, “somebody may put questions about the schedules.—Ladislaw,” he
20077: continued, aloud, “just hand me the memorandum of the schedules.”
20078: 
20079: When Mr. Brooke presented himself on the balcony, the cheers were quite
20080: loud enough to counterbalance the yells, groans, brayings, and other
20081: expressions of adverse theory, which were so moderate that Mr. Standish
20082: (decidedly an old bird) observed in the ear next to him, “This looks
20083: dangerous, by God! Hawley has got some deeper plan than this.” Still,
20084: the cheers were exhilarating, and no candidate could look more amiable
20085: than Mr. Brooke, with the memorandum in his breast-pocket, his left
20086: hand on the rail of the balcony, and his right trifling with his
20087: eye-glass. The striking points in his appearance were his buff
20088: waistcoat, short-clipped blond hair, and neutral physiognomy. He began
20089: with some confidence.
20090: 
20091: “Gentlemen—Electors of Middlemarch!”
20092: 
20093: This was so much the right thing that a little pause after it seemed
20094: natural.
20095: 
20096: “I’m uncommonly glad to be here—I was never so proud and happy in my
20097: life—never so happy, you know.”
20098: 
20099: This was a bold figure of speech, but not exactly the right thing; for,
20100: unhappily, the pat opening had slipped away—even couplets from Pope may
20101: be but “fallings from us, vanishings,” when fear clutches us, and a
20102: glass of sherry is hurrying like smoke among our ideas. Ladislaw, who
20103: stood at the window behind the speaker, thought, “it’s all up now. The
20104: only chance is that, since the best thing won’t always do, floundering
20105: may answer for once.” Mr. Brooke, meanwhile, having lost other clews,
20106: fell back on himself and his qualifications—always an appropriate
20107: graceful subject for a candidate.
20108: 
20109: “I am a close neighbor of yours, my good friends—you’ve known me on the
20110: bench a good while—I’ve always gone a good deal into public
20111: questions—machinery, now, and machine-breaking—you’re many of you
20112: concerned with machinery, and I’ve been going into that lately. It
20113: won’t do, you know, breaking machines: everything must go on—trade,
20114: manufactures, commerce, interchange of staples—that kind of thing—since
20115: Adam Smith, that must go on. We must look all over the
20116: globe:—‘Observation with extensive view,’ must look everywhere, ‘from
20117: China to Peru,’ as somebody says—Johnson, I think, ‘The Rambler,’ you
20118: know. That is what I have done up to a certain point—not as far as
20119: Peru; but I’ve not always stayed at home—I saw it wouldn’t do. I’ve
20120: been in the Levant, where some of your Middlemarch goods go—and then,
20121: again, in the Baltic. The Baltic, now.”
20122: 
20123: Plying among his recollections in this way, Mr. Brooke might have got
20124: along, easily to himself, and would have come back from the remotest
20125: seas without trouble; but a diabolical procedure had been set up by the
20126: enemy. At one and the same moment there had risen above the shoulders
20127: of the crowd, nearly opposite Mr. Brooke, and within ten yards of him,
20128: the effigy of himself: buff-colored waistcoat, eye-glass, and neutral
