20129: physiognomy, painted on rag; and there had arisen, apparently in the
20130: air, like the note of the cuckoo, a parrot-like, Punch-voiced echo of
20131: his words. Everybody looked up at the open windows in the houses at the
20132: opposite angles of the converging streets; but they were either blank,
20133: or filled by laughing listeners. The most innocent echo has an impish
20134: mockery in it when it follows a gravely persistent speaker, and this
20135: echo was not at all innocent; if it did not follow with the precision
20136: of a natural echo, it had a wicked choice of the words it overtook. By
20137: the time it said, “The Baltic, now,” the laugh which had been running
20138: through the audience became a general shout, and but for the sobering
20139: effects of party and that great public cause which the entanglement of
20140: things had identified with “Brooke of Tipton,” the laugh might have
20141: caught his committee. Mr. Bulstrode asked, reprehensively, what the new
20142: police was doing; but a voice could not well be collared, and an attack
20143: on the effigy of the candidate would have been too equivocal, since
20144: Hawley probably meant it to be pelted.
20145: 
20146: Mr. Brooke himself was not in a position to be quickly conscious of
20147: anything except a general slipping away of ideas within himself: he had
20148: even a little singing in the ears, and he was the only person who had
20149: not yet taken distinct account of the echo or discerned the image of
20150: himself. Few things hold the perceptions more thoroughly captive than
20151: anxiety about what we have got to say. Mr. Brooke heard the laughter;
20152: but he had expected some Tory efforts at disturbance, and he was at
20153: this moment additionally excited by the tickling, stinging sense that
20154: his lost exordium was coming back to fetch him from the Baltic.
20155: 
20156: “That reminds me,” he went on, thrusting a hand into his side-pocket,
20157: with an easy air, “if I wanted a precedent, you know—but we never want
20158: a precedent for the right thing—but there is Chatham, now; I can’t say
20159: I should have supported Chatham, or Pitt, the younger Pitt—he was not a
20160: man of ideas, and we want ideas, you know.”
20161: 
20162: “Blast your ideas! we want the Bill,” said a loud rough voice from the
20163: crowd below.
20164: 
20165: Immediately the invisible Punch, who had hitherto followed Mr. Brooke,
20166: repeated, “Blast your ideas! we want the Bill.” The laugh was louder
20167: than ever, and for the first time Mr. Brooke being himself silent,
20168: heard distinctly the mocking echo. But it seemed to ridicule his
20169: interrupter, and in that light was encouraging; so he replied with
20170: amenity—
20171: 
20172: “There is something in what you say, my good friend, and what do we
20173: meet for but to speak our minds—freedom of opinion, freedom of the
20174: press, liberty—that kind of thing? The Bill, now—you shall have the
20175: Bill”—here Mr. Brooke paused a moment to fix on his eye-glass and take
20176: the paper from his breast-pocket, with a sense of being practical and
20177: coming to particulars. The invisible Punch followed:—
20178: 
20179: “You shall have the Bill, Mr. Brooke, per electioneering contest, and a
20180: seat outside Parliament as delivered, five thousand pounds, seven
20181: shillings, and fourpence.”
20182: 
20183: Mr. Brooke, amid the roars of laughter, turned red, let his eye-glass
20184: fall, and looking about him confusedly, saw the image of himself, which
20185: had come nearer. The next moment he saw it dolorously bespattered with
20186: eggs. His spirit rose a little, and his voice too.
20187: 
20188: “Buffoonery, tricks, ridicule the test of truth—all that is very
20189: well”—here an unpleasant egg broke on Mr. Brooke’s shoulder, as the
20190: echo said, “All that is very well;” then came a hail of eggs, chiefly
20191: aimed at the image, but occasionally hitting the original, as if by
20192: chance. There was a stream of new men pushing among the crowd;
20193: whistles, yells, bellowings, and fifes made all the greater hubbub
20194: because there was shouting and struggling to put them down. No voice
20195: would have had wing enough to rise above the uproar, and Mr. Brooke,
20196: disagreeably anointed, stood his ground no longer. The frustration
20197: would have been less exasperating if it had been less gamesome and
20198: boyish: a serious assault of which the newspaper reporter “can aver
20199: that it endangered the learned gentleman’s ribs,” or can respectfully
20200: bear witness to “the soles of that gentleman’s boots having been
20201: visible above the railing,” has perhaps more consolations attached to
20202: it.
20203: 
20204: Mr. Brooke re-entered the committee-room, saying, as carelessly as he
20205: could, “This is a little too bad, you know. I should have got the ear
20206: of the people by-and-by—but they didn’t give me time. I should have
20207: gone into the Bill by-and-by, you know,” he added, glancing at
20208: Ladislaw. “However, things will come all right at the nomination.”
20209: 
20210: But it was not resolved unanimously that things would come right; on
20211: the contrary, the committee looked rather grim, and the political
20212: personage from Brassing was writing busily, as if he were brewing new
20213: devices.
20214: 
20215: “It was Bowyer who did it,” said Mr. Standish, evasively. “I know it as
20216: well as if he had been advertised. He’s uncommonly good at
20217: ventriloquism, and he did it uncommonly well, by God! Hawley has been
20218: having him to dinner lately: there’s a fund of talent in Bowyer.”
20219: 
20220: “Well, you know, you never mentioned him to me, Standish, else I would
20221: have invited him to dine,” said poor Mr. Brooke, who had gone through a
20222: great deal of inviting for the good of his country.
20223: 
20224: “There’s not a more paltry fellow in Middlemarch than Bowyer,” said
20225: Ladislaw, indignantly, “but it seems as if the paltry fellows were
20226: always to turn the scale.”
20227: 
20228: Will was thoroughly out of temper with himself as well as with his
20229: “principal,” and he went to shut himself in his rooms with a
20230: half-formed resolve to throw up the “Pioneer” and Mr. Brooke together.
20231: Why should he stay? If the impassable gulf between himself and Dorothea
20232: were ever to be filled up, it must rather be by his going away and
20233: getting into a thoroughly different position than by staying here and
20234: slipping into deserved contempt as an understrapper of Brooke’s. Then
20235: came the young dream of wonders that he might do—in five years, for
20236: example: political writing, political speaking, would get a higher
20237: value now public life was going to be wider and more national, and they
20238: might give him such distinction that he would not seem to be asking
20239: Dorothea to step down to him. Five years:—if he could only be sure that
20240: she cared for him more than for others; if he could only make her aware
20241: that he stood aloof until he could tell his love without lowering
20242: himself—then he could go away easily, and begin a career which at
20243: five-and-twenty seemed probable enough in the inward order of things,
20244: where talent brings fame, and fame everything else which is delightful.
20245: He could speak and he could write; he could master any subject if he
20246: chose, and he meant always to take the side of reason and justice, on
20247: which he would carry all his ardor. Why should he not one day be lifted
20248: above the shoulders of the crowd, and feel that he had won that
20249: eminence well? Without doubt he would leave Middlemarch, go to town,
20250: and make himself fit for celebrity by “eating his dinners.”
20251: 
20252: But not immediately: not until some kind of sign had passed between him
20253: and Dorothea. He could not be satisfied until she knew why, even if he
20254: were the man she would choose to marry, he would not marry her. Hence
20255: he must keep his post and bear with Mr. Brooke a little longer.
20256: 
20257: But he soon had reason to suspect that Mr. Brooke had anticipated him
20258: in the wish to break up their connection. Deputations without and
20259: voices within had concurred in inducing that philanthropist to take a
20260: stronger measure than usual for the good of mankind; namely, to
20261: withdraw in favor of another candidate, to whom he left the advantages
20262: of his canvassing machinery. He himself called this a strong measure,
20263: but observed that his health was less capable of sustaining excitement
20264: than he had imagined.
20265: 
20266: “I have felt uneasy about the chest—it won’t do to carry that too far,”
20267: he said to Ladislaw in explaining the affair. “I must pull up. Poor
20268: Casaubon was a warning, you know. I’ve made some heavy advances, but
20269: I’ve dug a channel. It’s rather coarse work—this electioneering, eh,
20270: Ladislaw? dare say you are tired of it. However, we have dug a channel
20271: with the ‘Pioneer’—put things in a track, and so on. A more ordinary
20272: man than you might carry it on now—more ordinary, you know.”
20273: 
20274: “Do you wish me to give it up?” said Will, the quick color coming in
20275: his face, as he rose from the writing-table, and took a turn of three
20276: steps with his hands in his pockets. “I am ready to do so whenever you
20277: wish it.”
20278: 
20279: “As to wishing, my dear Ladislaw, I have the highest opinion of your
20280: powers, you know. But about the ‘Pioneer,’ I have been consulting a
20281: little with some of the men on our side, and they are inclined to take
20282: it into their hands—indemnify me to a certain extent—carry it on, in
20283: fact. And under the circumstances, you might like to give up—might find
20284: a better field. These people might not take that high view of you which
20285: I have always taken, as an alter ego, a right hand—though I always
20286: looked forward to your doing something else. I think of having a run
20287: into France. But I’ll write you any letters, you know—to Althorpe and
20288: people of that kind. I’ve met Althorpe.”
20289: 
20290: “I am exceedingly obliged to you,” said Ladislaw, proudly. “Since you
20291: are going to part with the ‘Pioneer,’ I need not trouble you about the
20292: steps I shall take. I may choose to continue here for the present.”
20293: 
20294: After Mr. Brooke had left him Will said to himself, “The rest of the
20295: family have been urging him to get rid of me, and he doesn’t care now
20296: about my going. I shall stay as long as I like. I shall go of my own
20297: movements and not because they are afraid of me.”
20298: 
20299: 
20300: 
20301: 
20302: CHAPTER LII.
20303: 
20304: “His heart
20305: The lowliest duties on itself did lay.”
20306: —WORDSWORTH.
20307: 
20308: 
20309: On that June evening when Mr. Farebrother knew that he was to have the
20310: Lowick living, there was joy in the old fashioned parlor, and even the
20311: portraits of the great lawyers seemed to look on with satisfaction. His
20312: mother left her tea and toast untouched, but sat with her usual pretty
20313: primness, only showing her emotion by that flush in the cheeks and
20314: brightness in the eyes which give an old woman a touching momentary
20315: identity with her far-off youthful self, and saying decisively—
20316: 
20317: “The greatest comfort, Camden, is that you have deserved it.”
20318: 
20319: “When a man gets a good berth, mother, half the deserving must come
20320: after,” said the son, brimful of pleasure, and not trying to conceal
20321: it. The gladness in his face was of that active kind which seems to
20322: have energy enough not only to flash outwardly, but to light up busy
20323: vision within: one seemed to see thoughts, as well as delight, in his
20324: glances.
20325: 
20326: “Now, aunt,” he went on, rubbing his hands and looking at Miss Noble,
20327: who was making tender little beaver-like noises, “There shall be
20328: sugar-candy always on the table for you to steal and give to the
20329: children, and you shall have a great many new stockings to make
20330: presents of, and you shall darn your own more than ever!”
20331: 
20332: Miss Noble nodded at her nephew with a subdued half-frightened laugh,
20333: conscious of having already dropped an additional lump of sugar into
20334: her basket on the strength of the new preferment.
20335: 
20336: “As for you, Winny”—the Vicar went on—“I shall make no difficulty about
20337: your marrying any Lowick bachelor—Mr. Solomon Featherstone, for
20338: example, as soon as I find you are in love with him.”
20339: 
20340: Miss Winifred, who had been looking at her brother all the while and
20341: crying heartily, which was her way of rejoicing, smiled through her
20342: tears and said, “You must set me the example, Cam: _you_ must marry
20343: now.”
20344: 
20345: “With all my heart. But who is in love with me? I am a seedy old
20346: fellow,” said the Vicar, rising, pushing his chair away and looking
20347: down at himself. “What do you say, mother?”
20348: 
20349: “You are a handsome man, Camden: though not so fine a figure of a man
20350: as your father,” said the old lady.
20351: 
20352: “I wish you would marry Miss Garth, brother,” said Miss Winifred. “She
20353: would make us so lively at Lowick.”
20354: 
20355: “Very fine! You talk as if young women were tied up to be chosen, like
20356: poultry at market; as if I had only to ask and everybody would have
20357: me,” said the Vicar, not caring to specify.
20358: 
20359: “We don’t want everybody,” said Miss Winifred. “But _you_ would like
20360: Miss Garth, mother, shouldn’t you?”
20361: 
20362: “My son’s choice shall be mine,” said Mrs. Farebrother, with majestic
20363: discretion, “and a wife would be most welcome, Camden. You will want
20364: your whist at home when we go to Lowick, and Henrietta Noble never was
20365: a whist-player.” (Mrs. Farebrother always called her tiny old sister by
20366: that magnificent name.)
20367: 
20368: “I shall do without whist now, mother.”
20369: 
20370: “Why so, Camden? In my time whist was thought an undeniable amusement
20371: for a good churchman,” said Mrs. Farebrother, innocent of the meaning
20372: that whist had for her son, and speaking rather sharply, as at some
20373: dangerous countenancing of new doctrine.
20374: 
20375: “I shall be too busy for whist; I shall have two parishes,” said the
20376: Vicar, preferring not to discuss the virtues of that game.
20377: 
20378: He had already said to Dorothea, “I don’t feel bound to give up St.
20379: Botolph’s. It is protest enough against the pluralism they want to
20380: reform if I give somebody else most of the money. The stronger thing is
20381: not to give up power, but to use it well.”
20382: 
20383: “I have thought of that,” said Dorothea. “So far as self is concerned,
20384: I think it would be easier to give up power and money than to keep
20385: them. It seems very unfitting that I should have this patronage, yet I
20386: felt that I ought not to let it be used by some one else instead of
20387: me.”
20388: 
20389: “It is I who am bound to act so that you will not regret your power,”
20390: said Mr. Farebrother.
20391: 
20392: His was one of the natures in which conscience gets the more active
20393: when the yoke of life ceases to gall them. He made no display of
20394: humility on the subject, but in his heart he felt rather ashamed that
20395: his conduct had shown laches which others who did not get benefices
20396: were free from.
20397: 
20398: “I used often to wish I had been something else than a clergyman,” he
20399: said to Lydgate, “but perhaps it will be better to try and make as good
20400: a clergyman out of myself as I can. That is the well-beneficed point of
20401: view, you perceive, from which difficulties are much simplified,” he
20402: ended, smiling.
20403: 
20404: The Vicar did feel then as if his share of duties would be easy. But
20405: Duty has a trick of behaving unexpectedly—something like a heavy friend
20406: whom we have amiably asked to visit us, and who breaks his leg within
20407: our gates.
20408: 
20409: Hardly a week later, Duty presented itself in his study under the
20410: disguise of Fred Vincy, now returned from Omnibus College with his
20411: bachelor’s degree.
20412: 
20413: “I am ashamed to trouble you, Mr. Farebrother,” said Fred, whose fair
20414: open face was propitiating, “but you are the only friend I can consult.
20415: I told you everything once before, and you were so good that I can’t
20416: help coming to you again.”
20417: 
20418: “Sit down, Fred, I’m ready to hear and do anything I can,” said the
20419: Vicar, who was busy packing some small objects for removal, and went on
20420: with his work.
20421: 
20422: “I wanted to tell you—” Fred hesitated an instant and then went on
20423: plungingly, “I might go into the Church now; and really, look where I
20424: may, I can’t see anything else to do. I don’t like it, but I know it’s
20425: uncommonly hard on my father to say so, after he has spent a good deal
20426: of money in educating me for it.” Fred paused again an instant, and
20427: then repeated, “and I can’t see anything else to do.”
20428: 
20429: “I did talk to your father about it, Fred, but I made little way with
20430: him. He said it was too late. But you have got over one bridge now:
20431: what are your other difficulties?”
20432: 
20433: “Merely that I don’t like it. I don’t like divinity, and preaching, and
20434: feeling obliged to look serious. I like riding across country, and
20435: doing as other men do. I don’t mean that I want to be a bad fellow in
20436: any way; but I’ve no taste for the sort of thing people expect of a
20437: clergyman. And yet what else am I to do? My father can’t spare me any
20438: capital, else I might go into farming. And he has no room for me in his
20439: trade. And of course I can’t begin to study for law or physic now, when
20440: my father wants me to earn something. It’s all very well to say I’m
20441: wrong to go into the Church; but those who say so might as well tell me
20442: to go into the backwoods.”
20443: 
20444: Fred’s voice had taken a tone of grumbling remonstrance, and Mr.
20445: Farebrother might have been inclined to smile if his mind had not been
20446: too busy in imagining more than Fred told him.
20447: 
20448: “Have you any difficulties about doctrines—about the Articles?” he
20449: said, trying hard to think of the question simply for Fred’s sake.
20450: 
20451: “No; I suppose the Articles are right. I am not prepared with any
20452: arguments to disprove them, and much better, cleverer fellows than I am
20453: go in for them entirely. I think it would be rather ridiculous in me to
20454: urge scruples of that sort, as if I were a judge,” said Fred, quite
20455: simply.
20456: 
20457: “I suppose, then, it has occurred to you that you might be a fair
20458: parish priest without being much of a divine?”
20459: 
20460: “Of course, if I am obliged to be a clergyman, I shall try and do my
20461: duty, though I mayn’t like it. Do you think any body ought to blame
20462: me?”
20463: 
20464: “For going into the Church under the circumstances? That depends on
20465: your conscience, Fred—how far you have counted the cost, and seen what
20466: your position will require of you. I can only tell you about myself,
20467: that I have always been too lax, and have been uneasy in consequence.”
20468: 
20469: “But there is another hindrance,” said Fred, coloring. “I did not tell
20470: you before, though perhaps I may have said things that made you guess
20471: it. There is somebody I am very fond of: I have loved her ever since we
20472: were children.”
20473: 
20474: “Miss Garth, I suppose?” said the Vicar, examining some labels very
20475: closely.
20476: 
20477: “Yes. I shouldn’t mind anything if she would have me. And I know I
20478: could be a good fellow then.”
20479: 
20480: “And you think she returns the feeling?”
20481: 
20482: “She never will say so; and a good while ago she made me promise not to
20483: speak to her about it again. And she has set her mind especially
20484: against my being a clergyman; I know that. But I can’t give her up. I
20485: do think she cares about me. I saw Mrs. Garth last night, and she said
20486: that Mary was staying at Lowick Rectory with Miss Farebrother.”
20487: 
20488: “Yes, she is very kindly helping my sister. Do you wish to go there?”
20489: 
20490: “No, I want to ask a great favor of you. I am ashamed to bother you in
20491: this way; but Mary might listen to what you said, if you mentioned the
20492: subject to her—I mean about my going into the Church.”
20493: 
20494: “That is rather a delicate task, my dear Fred. I shall have to
20495: presuppose your attachment to her; and to enter on the subject as you
20496: wish me to do, will be asking her to tell me whether she returns it.”
20497: 
20498: “That is what I want her to tell you,” said Fred, bluntly. “I don’t
20499: know what to do, unless I can get at her feeling.”
20500: 
20501: “You mean that you would be guided by that as to your going into the
20502: Church?”
20503: 
20504: “If Mary said she would never have me I might as well go wrong in one
20505: way as another.”
20506: 
20507: “That is nonsense, Fred. Men outlive their love, but they don’t outlive
20508: the consequences of their recklessness.”
20509: 
20510: “Not my sort of love: I have never been without loving Mary. If I had
20511: to give her up, it would be like beginning to live on wooden legs.”
20512: 
20513: “Will she not be hurt at my intrusion?”
20514: 
20515: “No, I feel sure she will not. She respects you more than any one, and
20516: she would not put you off with fun as she does me. Of course I could
20517: not have told any one else, or asked any one else to speak to her, but
20518: you. There is no one else who could be such a friend to both of us.”
20519: Fred paused a moment, and then said, rather complainingly, “And she
20520: ought to acknowledge that I have worked in order to pass. She ought to
20521: believe that I would exert myself for her sake.”
20522: 
20523: There was a moment’s silence before Mr. Farebrother laid down his work,
20524: and putting out his hand to Fred said—
20525: 
20526: “Very well, my boy. I will do what you wish.”
20527: 
20528: That very day Mr. Farebrother went to Lowick parsonage on the nag which
20529: he had just set up. “Decidedly I am an old stalk,” he thought, “the
20530: young growths are pushing me aside.”
20531: 
20532: He found Mary in the garden gathering roses and sprinkling the petals
20533: on a sheet. The sun was low, and tall trees sent their shadows across
20534: the grassy walks where Mary was moving without bonnet or parasol. She
20535: did not observe Mr. Farebrother’s approach along the grass, and had
20536: just stooped down to lecture a small black-and-tan terrier, which would
20537: persist in walking on the sheet and smelling at the rose-leaves as Mary
20538: sprinkled them. She took his fore-paws in one hand, and lifted up the
20539: forefinger of the other, while the dog wrinkled his brows and looked
20540: embarrassed. “Fly, Fly, I am ashamed of you,” Mary was saying in a
20541: grave contralto. “This is not becoming in a sensible dog; anybody would
20542: think you were a silly young gentleman.”
20543: 
20544: “You are unmerciful to young gentlemen, Miss Garth,” said the Vicar,
20545: within two yards of her.
20546: 
20547: Mary started up and blushed. “It always answers to reason with Fly,”
20548: she said, laughingly.
20549: 
20550: “But not with young gentlemen?”
20551: 
20552: “Oh, with some, I suppose; since some of them turn into excellent men.”
20553: 
20554: “I am glad of that admission, because I want at this very moment to
20555: interest you in a young gentleman.”
20556: 
20557: “Not a silly one, I hope,” said Mary, beginning to pluck the roses
20558: again, and feeling her heart beat uncomfortably.
20559: 
20560: “No; though perhaps wisdom is not his strong point, but rather
20561: affection and sincerity. However, wisdom lies more in those two
20562: qualities than people are apt to imagine. I hope you know by those
20563: marks what young gentleman I mean.”
20564: 
20565: “Yes, I think I do,” said Mary, bravely, her face getting more serious,
20566: and her hands cold; “it must be Fred Vincy.”
20567: 
20568: “He has asked me to consult you about his going into the Church. I hope
20569: you will not think that I consented to take a liberty in promising to
20570: do so.”
20571: 
20572: “On the contrary, Mr. Farebrother,” said Mary, giving up the roses, and
20573: folding her arms, but unable to look up, “whenever you have anything to
20574: say to me I feel honored.”
20575: 
20576: “But before I enter on that question, let me just touch a point on
20577: which your father took me into confidence; by the way, it was that very
20578: evening on which I once before fulfilled a mission from Fred, just
20579: after he had gone to college. Mr. Garth told me what happened on the
20580: night of Featherstone’s death—how you refused to burn the will; and he
20581: said that you had some heart-prickings on that subject, because you had
20582: been the innocent means of hindering Fred from getting his ten thousand
20583: pounds. I have kept that in mind, and I have heard something that may
20584: relieve you on that score—may show you that no sin-offering is demanded
20585: from you there.”
20586: 
20587: Mr. Farebrother paused a moment and looked at Mary. He meant to give
20588: Fred his full advantage, but it would be well, he thought, to clear her
20589: mind of any superstitions, such as women sometimes follow when they do
20590: a man the wrong of marrying him as an act of atonement. Mary’s cheeks
20591: had begun to burn a little, and she was mute.
20592: 
20593: “I mean, that your action made no real difference to Fred’s lot. I find
20594: that the first will would not have been legally good after the burning
20595: of the last; it would not have stood if it had been disputed, and you
20596: may be sure it would have been disputed. So, on that score, you may
20597: feel your mind free.”
20598: 
20599: “Thank you, Mr. Farebrother,” said Mary, earnestly. “I am grateful to
20600: you for remembering my feelings.”
20601: 
20602: “Well, now I may go on. Fred, you know, has taken his degree. He has
20603: worked his way so far, and now the question is, what is he to do? That
20604: question is so difficult that he is inclined to follow his father’s
20605: wishes and enter the Church, though you know better than I do that he
20606: was quite set against that formerly. I have questioned him on the
20607: subject, and I confess I see no insuperable objection to his being a
20608: clergyman, as things go. He says that he could turn his mind to doing
20609: his best in that vocation, on one condition. If that condition were
20610: fulfilled I would do my utmost in helping Fred on. After a time—not, of
20611: course, at first—he might be with me as my curate, and he would have so
20612: much to do that his stipend would be nearly what I used to get as
20613: vicar. But I repeat that there is a condition without which all this
20614: good cannot come to pass. He has opened his heart to me, Miss Garth,
20615: and asked me to plead for him. The condition lies entirely in your
20616: feeling.”
20617: 
20618: Mary looked so much moved, that he said after a moment, “Let us walk a
20619: little;” and when they were walking he added, “To speak quite plainly,
20620: Fred will not take any course which would lessen the chance that you
20621: would consent to be his wife; but with that prospect, he will try his
20622: best at anything you approve.”
20623: 
20624: “I cannot possibly say that I will ever be his wife, Mr. Farebrother:
20625: but I certainly never will be his wife if he becomes a clergyman. What
20626: you say is most generous and kind; I don’t mean for a moment to correct
20627: your judgment. It is only that I have my girlish, mocking way of
20628: looking at things,” said Mary, with a returning sparkle of playfulness
20629: in her answer which only made its modesty more charming.
20630: 
20631: “He wishes me to report exactly what you think,” said Mr. Farebrother.
20632: 
20633: “I could not love a man who is ridiculous,” said Mary, not choosing to
20634: go deeper. “Fred has sense and knowledge enough to make him
20635: respectable, if he likes, in some good worldly business, but I can
20636: never imagine him preaching and exhorting, and pronouncing blessings,
20637: and praying by the sick, without feeling as if I were looking at a
20638: caricature. His being a clergyman would be only for gentility’s sake,
20639: and I think there is nothing more contemptible than such imbecile
20640: gentility. I used to think that of Mr. Crowse, with his empty face and
20641: neat umbrella, and mincing little speeches. What right have such men to
20642: represent Christianity—as if it were an institution for getting up
20643: idiots genteelly—as if—” Mary checked herself. She had been carried
20644: along as if she had been speaking to Fred instead of Mr. Farebrother.
20645: 
20646: “Young women are severe: they don’t feel the stress of action as men
20647: do, though perhaps I ought to make you an exception there. But you
20648: don’t put Fred Vincy on so low a level as that?”
20649: 
20650: “No, indeed, he has plenty of sense, but I think he would not show it
20651: as a clergyman. He would be a piece of professional affectation.”
20652: 
20653: “Then the answer is quite decided. As a clergyman he could have no
20654: hope?”
20655: 
20656: Mary shook her head.
20657: 
20658: “But if he braved all the difficulties of getting his bread in some
20659: other way—will you give him the support of hope? May he count on
20660: winning you?”
20661: 
20662: “I think Fred ought not to need telling again what I have already said
20663: to him,” Mary answered, with a slight resentment in her manner. “I mean
20664: that he ought not to put such questions until he has done something
20665: worthy, instead of saying that he could do it.”
20666: 
20667: Mr. Farebrother was silent for a minute or more, and then, as they
20668: turned and paused under the shadow of a maple at the end of a grassy
20669: walk, said, “I understand that you resist any attempt to fetter you,
20670: but either your feeling for Fred Vincy excludes your entertaining
20671: another attachment, or it does not: either he may count on your
20672: remaining single until he shall have earned your hand, or he may in any
20673: case be disappointed. Pardon me, Mary—you know I used to catechise you
20674: under that name—but when the state of a woman’s affections touches the
20675: happiness of another life—of more lives than one—I think it would be
20676: the nobler course for her to be perfectly direct and open.”
20677: 
20678: Mary in her turn was silent, wondering not at Mr. Farebrother’s manner
20679: but at his tone, which had a grave restrained emotion in it. When the
20680: strange idea flashed across her that his words had reference to
20681: himself, she was incredulous, and ashamed of entertaining it. She had
20682: never thought that any man could love her except Fred, who had espoused
20683: her with the umbrella ring, when she wore socks and little strapped
20684: shoes; still less that she could be of any importance to Mr.
20685: Farebrother, the cleverest man in her narrow circle. She had only time
20686: to feel that all this was hazy and perhaps illusory; but one thing was
20687: clear and determined—her answer.
20688: 
20689: “Since you think it my duty, Mr. Farebrother, I will tell you that I
20690: have too strong a feeling for Fred to give him up for any one else. I
20691: should never be quite happy if I thought he was unhappy for the loss of
20692: me. It has taken such deep root in me—my gratitude to him for always
20693: loving me best, and minding so much if I hurt myself, from the time
20694: when we were very little. I cannot imagine any new feeling coming to
20695: make that weaker. I should like better than anything to see him worthy
20696: of every one’s respect. But please tell him I will not promise to marry
20697: him till then: I should shame and grieve my father and mother. He is
20698: free to choose some one else.”
20699: 
20700: “Then I have fulfilled my commission thoroughly,” said Mr. Farebrother,
20701: putting out his hand to Mary, “and I shall ride back to Middlemarch
20702: forthwith. With this prospect before him, we shall get Fred into the
20703: right niche somehow, and I hope I shall live to join your hands. God
20704: bless you!”
20705: 
20706: “Oh, please stay, and let me give you some tea,” said Mary. Her eyes
20707: filled with tears, for something indefinable, something like the
20708: resolute suppression of a pain in Mr. Farebrother’s manner, made her
20709: feel suddenly miserable, as she had once felt when she saw her father’s
20710: hands trembling in a moment of trouble.
20711: 
20712: “No, my dear, no. I must get back.”
20713: 
20714: In three minutes the Vicar was on horseback again, having gone
20715: magnanimously through a duty much harder than the renunciation of
20716: whist, or even than the writing of penitential meditations.
20717: 
20718: 
20719: 
20720: 
20721: CHAPTER LIII.
20722: 
20723: It is but a shallow haste which concludeth insincerity from what
20724: outsiders call inconsistency—putting a dead mechanism of “ifs” and
20725: “therefores” for the living myriad of hidden suckers whereby the belief
20726: and the conduct are wrought into mutual sustainment.
20727: 
20728: 
20729: Mr. Bulstrode, when he was hoping to acquire a new interest in Lowick,
20730: had naturally had an especial wish that the new clergyman should be one
20731: whom he thoroughly approved; and he believed it to be a chastisement
20732: and admonition directed to his own shortcomings and those of the nation
20733: at large, that just about the time when he came in possession of the
20734: deeds which made him the proprietor of Stone Court, Mr. Farebrother
20735: “read himself” into the quaint little church and preached his first
20736: sermon to the congregation of farmers, laborers, and village artisans.
20737: It was not that Mr. Bulstrode intended to frequent Lowick Church or to
20738: reside at Stone Court for a good while to come: he had bought the
20739: excellent farm and fine homestead simply as a retreat which he might
20740: gradually enlarge as to the land and beautify as to the dwelling, until
20741: it should be conducive to the divine glory that he should enter on it
20742: as a residence, partially withdrawing from his present exertions in the
20743: administration of business, and throwing more conspicuously on the side
20744: of Gospel truth the weight of local landed proprietorship, which
20745: Providence might increase by unforeseen occasions of purchase. A strong
20746: leading in this direction seemed to have been given in the surprising
20747: facility of getting Stone Court, when every one had expected that Mr.
20748: Rigg Featherstone would have clung to it as the Garden of Eden. That
20749: was what poor old Peter himself had expected; having often, in
20750: imagination, looked up through the sods above him, and, unobstructed by
20751: perspective, seen his frog-faced legatee enjoying the fine old place to
20752: the perpetual surprise and disappointment of other survivors.
20753: 
20754: But how little we know what would make paradise for our neighbors! We
20755: judge from our own desires, and our neighbors themselves are not always
20756: open enough even to throw out a hint of theirs. The cool and judicious
20757: Joshua Rigg had not allowed his parent to perceive that Stone Court was
20758: anything less than the chief good in his estimation, and he had
20759: certainly wished to call it his own. But as Warren Hastings looked at
20760: gold and thought of buying Daylesford, so Joshua Rigg looked at Stone
20761: Court and thought of buying gold. He had a very distinct and intense
20762: vision of his chief good, the vigorous greed which he had inherited
20763: having taken a special form by dint of circumstance: and his chief good
20764: was to be a moneychanger. From his earliest employment as an errand-boy
20765: in a seaport, he had looked through the windows of the moneychangers as
20766: other boys look through the windows of the pastry-cooks; the
20767: fascination had wrought itself gradually into a deep special passion;
20768: he meant, when he had property, to do many things, one of them being to
20769: marry a genteel young person; but these were all accidents and joys
20770: that imagination could dispense with. The one joy after which his soul
20771: thirsted was to have a money-changer’s shop on a much-frequented quay,
20772: to have locks all round him of which he held the keys, and to look
20773: sublimely cool as he handled the breeding coins of all nations, while
20774: helpless Cupidity looked at him enviously from the other side of an
20775: iron lattice. The strength of that passion had been a power enabling
20776: him to master all the knowledge necessary to gratify it. And when
20777: others were thinking that he had settled at Stone Court for life,
20778: Joshua himself was thinking that the moment now was not far off when he
20779: should settle on the North Quay with the best appointments in safes and
20780: locks.
20781: 
20782: Enough. We are concerned with looking at Joshua Rigg’s sale of his land
20783: from Mr. Bulstrode’s point of view, and he interpreted it as a cheering
20784: dispensation conveying perhaps a sanction to a purpose which he had for
20785: some time entertained without external encouragement; he interpreted it
20786: thus, but not too confidently, offering up his thanksgiving in guarded
20787: phraseology. His doubts did not arise from the possible relations of
20788: the event to Joshua Rigg’s destiny, which belonged to the unmapped
20789: regions not taken under the providential government, except perhaps in
20790: an imperfect colonial way; but they arose from reflecting that this
20791: dispensation too might be a chastisement for himself, as Mr.
20792: Farebrother’s induction to the living clearly was.
20793: 
20794: This was not what Mr. Bulstrode said to any man for the sake of
20795: deceiving him: it was what he said to himself—it was as genuinely his
20796: mode of explaining events as any theory of yours may be, if you happen
20797: to disagree with him. For the egoism which enters into our theories
20798: does not affect their sincerity; rather, the more our egoism is
20799: satisfied, the more robust is our belief.
20800: 
20801: However, whether for sanction or for chastisement, Mr. Bulstrode,
20802: hardly fifteen months after the death of Peter Featherstone, had become
20803: the proprietor of Stone Court, and what Peter would say “if he were
20804: worthy to know,” had become an inexhaustible and consolatory subject of
20805: conversation to his disappointed relatives. The tables were now turned
20806: on that dear brother departed, and to contemplate the frustration of
20807: his cunning by the superior cunning of things in general was a cud of
20808: delight to Solomon. Mrs. Waule had a melancholy triumph in the proof
20809: that it did not answer to make false Featherstones and cut off the
20810: genuine; and Sister Martha receiving the news in the Chalky Flats said,
20811: “Dear, dear! then the Almighty could have been none so pleased with the
20812: almshouses after all.”
20813: 
20814: Affectionate Mrs. Bulstrode was particularly glad of the advantage
20815: which her husband’s health was likely to get from the purchase of Stone
20816: Court. Few days passed without his riding thither and looking over some
20817: part of the farm with the bailiff, and the evenings were delicious in
20818: that quiet spot, when the new hay-ricks lately set up were sending
20819: forth odors to mingle with the breath of the rich old garden. One
20820: evening, while the sun was still above the horizon and burning in
20821: golden lamps among the great walnut boughs, Mr. Bulstrode was pausing
20822: on horseback outside the front gate waiting for Caleb Garth, who had
20823: met him by appointment to give an opinion on a question of stable
20824: drainage, and was now advising the bailiff in the rick-yard.
20825: 
20826: Mr. Bulstrode was conscious of being in a good spiritual frame and more
20827: than usually serene, under the influence of his innocent recreation. He
20828: was doctrinally convinced that there was a total absence of merit in
20829: himself; but that doctrinal conviction may be held without pain when
20830: the sense of demerit does not take a distinct shape in memory and
20831: revive the tingling of shame or the pang of remorse. Nay, it may be
20832: held with intense satisfaction when the depth of our sinning is but a
20833: measure for the depth of forgiveness, and a clenching proof that we are
20834: peculiar instruments of the divine intention. The memory has as many
20835: moods as the temper, and shifts its scenery like a diorama. At this
20836: moment Mr. Bulstrode felt as if the sunshine were all one with that of
20837: far-off evenings when he was a very young man and used to go out
20838: preaching beyond Highbury. And he would willingly have had that service
20839: of exhortation in prospect now. The texts were there still, and so was
20840: his own facility in expounding them. His brief reverie was interrupted
20841: by the return of Caleb Garth, who also was on horseback, and was just
20842: shaking his bridle before starting, when he exclaimed—
20843: 
20844: “Bless my heart! what’s this fellow in black coming along the lane?
20845: He’s like one of those men one sees about after the races.”
20846: 
20847: Mr. Bulstrode turned his horse and looked along the lane, but made no
20848: reply. The comer was our slight acquaintance Mr. Raffles, whose
20849: appearance presented no other change than such as was due to a suit of
20850: black and a crape hat-band. He was within three yards of the horseman
20851: now, and they could see the flash of recognition in his face as he
20852: whirled his stick upward, looking all the while at Mr. Bulstrode, and
20853: at last exclaiming:—
20854: 
20855: “By Jove, Nick, it’s you! I couldn’t be mistaken, though the
20856: five-and-twenty years have played old Boguy with us both! How are you,
20857: eh? you didn’t expect to see _me_ here. Come, shake us by the hand.” To
20858: say that Mr. Raffles’ manner was rather excited would be only one mode
20859: of saying that it was evening. Caleb Garth could see that there was a
20860: moment of struggle and hesitation in Mr. Bulstrode, but it ended in his
20861: putting out his hand coldly to Raffles and saying—
20862: 
20863: “I did not indeed expect to see you in this remote country place.”
20864: 
20865: “Well, it belongs to a stepson of mine,” said Raffles, adjusting
20866: himself in a swaggering attitude. “I came to see him here before. I’m
20867: not so surprised at seeing you, old fellow, because I picked up a
20868: letter—what you may call a providential thing. It’s uncommonly
20869: fortunate I met you, though; for I don’t care about seeing my stepson:
20870: he’s not affectionate, and his poor mother’s gone now. To tell the
20871: truth, I came out of love to you, Nick: I came to get your address,
20872: for—look here!” Raffles drew a crumpled paper from his pocket.
20873: 
20874: Almost any other man than Caleb Garth might have been tempted to linger
20875: on the spot for the sake of hearing all he could about a man whose
20876: acquaintance with Bulstrode seemed to imply passages in the banker’s
20877: life so unlike anything that was known of him in Middlemarch that they
20878: must have the nature of a secret to pique curiosity. But Caleb was
20879: peculiar: certain human tendencies which are commonly strong were
20880: almost absent from his mind; and one of these was curiosity about
20881: personal affairs. Especially if there was anything discreditable to be
20882: found out concerning another man, Caleb preferred not to know it; and
20883: if he had to tell anybody under him that his evil doings were
20884: discovered, he was more embarrassed than the culprit. He now spurred
20885: his horse, and saying, “I wish you good evening, Mr. Bulstrode; I must
20886: be getting home,” set off at a trot.
20887: 
20888: “You didn’t put your full address to this letter,” Raffles continued.
20889: “That was not like the first-rate man of business you used to be. ‘The
20890: Shrubs,’—they may be anywhere: you live near at hand, eh?—have cut the
20891: London concern altogether—perhaps turned country squire—have a rural
20892: mansion to invite me to. Lord, how many years it is ago! The old lady
20893: must have been dead a pretty long while—gone to glory without the pain
20894: of knowing how poor her daughter was, eh? But, by Jove! you’re very
20895: pale and pasty, Nick. Come, if you’re going home, I’ll walk by your
20896: side.”
20897: 
20898: Mr. Bulstrode’s usual paleness had in fact taken an almost deathly hue.
20899: Five minutes before, the expanse of his life had been submerged in its
20900: evening sunshine which shone backward to its remembered morning: sin
20901: seemed to be a question of doctrine and inward penitence, humiliation
20902: an exercise of the closet, the bearing of his deeds a matter of private
20903: vision adjusted solely by spiritual relations and conceptions of the
20904: divine purposes. And now, as if by some hideous magic, this loud red
20905: figure had risen before him in unmanageable solidity—an incorporate
20906: past which had not entered into his imagination of chastisements. But
20907: Mr. Bulstrode’s thought was busy, and he was not a man to act or speak
20908: rashly.
20909: 
20910: “I was going home,” he said, “but I can defer my ride a little. And you
20911: can, if you please, rest here.”
20912: 
20913: “Thank you,” said Raffles, making a grimace. “I don’t care now about
20914: seeing my stepson. I’d rather go home with you.”
20915: 
20916: “Your stepson, if Mr. Rigg Featherstone was he, is here no longer. I am
20917: master here now.”
20918: 
20919: Raffles opened wide eyes, and gave a long whistle of surprise, before
20920: he said, “Well then, I’ve no objection. I’ve had enough walking from
20921: the coach-road. I never was much of a walker, or rider either. What I
20922: like is a smart vehicle and a spirited cob. I was always a little heavy
20923: in the saddle. What a pleasant surprise it must be to you to see me,
20924: old fellow!” he continued, as they turned towards the house. “You don’t
20925: say so; but you never took your luck heartily—you were always thinking
20926: of improving the occasion—you’d such a gift for improving your luck.”
20927: 
20928: Mr. Raffles seemed greatly to enjoy his own wit, and swung his leg in a
20929: swaggering manner which was rather too much for his companion’s
20930: judicious patience.
20931: 
20932: “If I remember rightly,” Mr. Bulstrode observed, with chill anger, “our
20933: acquaintance many years ago had not the sort of intimacy which you are
20934: now assuming, Mr. Raffles. Any services you desire of me will be the
20935: more readily rendered if you will avoid a tone of familiarity which did
20936: not lie in our former intercourse, and can hardly be warranted by more
20937: than twenty years of separation.”
20938: 
20939: “You don’t like being called Nick? Why, I always called you Nick in my
20940: heart, and though lost to sight, to memory dear. By Jove! my feelings
20941: have ripened for you like fine old cognac. I hope you’ve got some in
20942: the house now. Josh filled my flask well the last time.”
20943: 
20944: Mr. Bulstrode had not yet fully learned that even the desire for cognac
20945: was not stronger in Raffles than the desire to torment, and that a hint
20946: of annoyance always served him as a fresh cue. But it was at least
20947: clear that further objection was useless, and Mr. Bulstrode, in giving
20948: orders to the housekeeper for the accommodation of the guest, had a
20949: resolute air of quietude.
20950: 
20951: There was the comfort of thinking that this housekeeper had been in the
20952: service of Rigg also, and might accept the idea that Mr. Bulstrode
20953: entertained Raffles merely as a friend of her former master.
20954: 
20955: When there was food and drink spread before his visitor in the
20956: wainscoted parlor, and no witness in the room, Mr. Bulstrode said—
20957: 
20958: “Your habits and mine are so different, Mr. Raffles, that we can hardly
20959: enjoy each other’s society. The wisest plan for both of us will
20960: therefore be to part as soon as possible. Since you say that you wished
20961: to meet me, you probably considered that you had some business to
20962: transact with me. But under the circumstances I will invite you to
20963: remain here for the night, and I will myself ride over here early
20964: to-morrow morning—before breakfast, in fact—when I can receive any
20965: communication you have to make to me.”
20966: 
20967: “With all my heart,” said Raffles; “this is a comfortable place—a
20968: little dull for a continuance; but I can put up with it for a night,
20969: with this good liquor and the prospect of seeing you again in the
20970: morning. You’re a much better host than my stepson was; but Josh owed
20971: me a bit of a grudge for marrying his mother; and between you and me
20972: there was never anything but kindness.”
20973: 
20974: Mr. Bulstrode, hoping that the peculiar mixture of joviality and
20975: sneering in Raffles’ manner was a good deal the effect of drink, had
20976: determined to wait till he was quite sober before he spent more words
20977: upon him. But he rode home with a terribly lucid vision of the
20978: difficulty there would be in arranging any result that could be
20979: permanently counted on with this man. It was inevitable that he should
20980: wish to get rid of John Raffles, though his reappearance could not be
20981: regarded as lying outside the divine plan. The spirit of evil might
20982: have sent him to threaten Mr. Bulstrode’s subversion as an instrument
20983: of good; but the threat must have been permitted, and was a
20984: chastisement of a new kind. It was an hour of anguish for him very
20985: different from the hours in which his struggle had been securely
20986: private, and which had ended with a sense that his secret misdeeds were
20987: pardoned and his services accepted. Those misdeeds even when
20988: committed—had they not been half sanctified by the singleness of his
20989: desire to devote himself and all he possessed to the furtherance of the
20990: divine scheme? And was he after all to become a mere stone of stumbling
20991: and a rock of offence? For who would understand the work within him?
20992: Who would not, when there was the pretext of casting disgrace upon him,
20993: confound his whole life and the truths he had espoused, in one heap of
20994: obloquy?
20995: 
20996: In his closest meditations the life-long habit of Mr. Bulstrode’s mind
20997: clad his most egoistic terrors in doctrinal references to superhuman
20998: ends. But even while we are talking and meditating about the earth’s
20999: orbit and the solar system, what we feel and adjust our movements to is
21000: the stable earth and the changing day. And now within all the automatic
21001: succession of theoretic phrases—distinct and inmost as the shiver and
21002: the ache of oncoming fever when we are discussing abstract pain, was
21003: the forecast of disgrace in the presence of his neighbors and of his
21004: own wife. For the pain, as well as the public estimate of disgrace,
21005: depends on the amount of previous profession. To men who only aim at
21006: escaping felony, nothing short of the prisoner’s dock is disgrace. But
21007: Mr. Bulstrode had aimed at being an eminent Christian.
21008: 
21009: It was not more than half-past seven in the morning when he again
21010: reached Stone Court. The fine old place never looked more like a
21011: delightful home than at that moment; the great white lilies were in
21012: flower, the nasturtiums, their pretty leaves all silvered with dew,
21013: were running away over the low stone wall; the very noises all around
21014: had a heart of peace within them. But everything was spoiled for the
21015: owner as he walked on the gravel in front and awaited the descent of
21016: Mr. Raffles, with whom he was condemned to breakfast.
21017: 
21018: It was not long before they were seated together in the wainscoted
21019: parlor over their tea and toast, which was as much as Raffles cared to
21020: take at that early hour. The difference between his morning and evening
21021: self was not so great as his companion had imagined that it might be;
21022: the delight in tormenting was perhaps even the stronger because his
21023: spirits were rather less highly pitched. Certainly his manners seemed
21024: more disagreeable by the morning light.
21025: 
21026: “As I have little time to spare, Mr. Raffles,” said the banker, who
21027: could hardly do more than sip his tea and break his toast without
21028: eating it, “I shall be obliged if you will mention at once the ground
21029: on which you wished to meet with me. I presume that you have a home
21030: elsewhere and will be glad to return to it.”
21031: 
21032: “Why, if a man has got any heart, doesn’t he want to see an old friend,
21033: Nick?—I must call you Nick—we always did call you young Nick when we
21034: knew you meant to marry the old widow. Some said you had a handsome
21035: family likeness to old Nick, but that was your mother’s fault, calling
21036: you Nicholas. Aren’t you glad to see me again? I expected an invite to
21037: stay with you at some pretty place. My own establishment is broken up
21038: now my wife’s dead. I’ve no particular attachment to any spot; I would
21039: as soon settle hereabout as anywhere.”
21040: 
21041: “May I ask why you returned from America? I considered that the strong
21042: wish you expressed to go there, when an adequate sum was furnished, was
21043: tantamount to an engagement that you would remain there for life.”
21044: 
21045: “Never knew that a wish to go to a place was the same thing as a wish
21046: to stay. But I did stay a matter of ten years; it didn’t suit me to
21047: stay any longer. And I’m not going again, Nick.” Here Mr. Raffles
21048: winked slowly as he looked at Mr. Bulstrode.
21049: 
21050: “Do you wish to be settled in any business? What is your calling now?”
21051: 
21052: “Thank you, my calling is to enjoy myself as much as I can. I don’t
21053: care about working any more. If I did anything it would be a little
21054: travelling in the tobacco line—or something of that sort, which takes a
21055: man into agreeable company. But not without an independence to fall
21056: back upon. That’s what I want: I’m not so strong as I was, Nick, though
21057: I’ve got more color than you. I want an independence.”
21058: 
21059: “That could be supplied to you, if you would engage to keep at a
21060: distance,” said Mr. Bulstrode, perhaps with a little too much eagerness
21061: in his undertone.
21062: 
21063: “That must be as it suits my convenience,” said Raffles coolly. “I see
21064: no reason why I shouldn’t make a few acquaintances hereabout. I’m not
21065: ashamed of myself as company for anybody. I dropped my portmanteau at
21066: the turnpike when I got down—change of linen—genuine—honor bright—more
21067: than fronts and wristbands; and with this suit of mourning, straps and
21068: everything, I should do you credit among the nobs here.” Mr. Raffles
21069: had pushed away his chair and looked down at himself, particularly at
21070: his straps. His chief intention was to annoy Bulstrode, but he really
21071: thought that his appearance now would produce a good effect, and that
21072: he was not only handsome and witty, but clad in a mourning style which
21073: implied solid connections.
21074: 
21075: “If you intend to rely on me in any way, Mr. Raffles,” said Bulstrode,
21076: after a moment’s pause, “you will expect to meet my wishes.”
21077: 
21078: “Ah, to be sure,” said Raffles, with a mocking cordiality. “Didn’t I
21079: always do it? Lord, you made a pretty thing out of me, and I got but
21080: little. I’ve often thought since, I might have done better by telling
21081: the old woman that I’d found her daughter and her grandchild: it would
21082: have suited my feelings better; I’ve got a soft place in my heart. But
21083: you’ve buried the old lady by this time, I suppose—it’s all one to her
21084: now. And you’ve got your fortune out of that profitable business which
21085: had such a blessing on it. You’ve taken to being a nob, buying land,
21086: being a country bashaw. Still in the Dissenting line, eh? Still godly?
21087: Or taken to the Church as more genteel?”
21088: 
21089: This time Mr. Raffles’ slow wink and slight protrusion of his tongue
21090: was worse than a nightmare, because it held the certitude that it was
21091: not a nightmare, but a waking misery. Mr. Bulstrode felt a shuddering
21092: nausea, and did not speak, but was considering diligently whether he
21093: should not leave Raffles to do as he would, and simply defy him as a
21094: slanderer. The man would soon show himself disreputable enough to make
21095: people disbelieve him. “But not when he tells any ugly-looking truth
21096: about _you_,” said discerning consciousness. And again: it seemed no
21097: wrong to keep Raffles at a distance, but Mr. Bulstrode shrank from the
21098: direct falsehood of denying true statements. It was one thing to look
21099: back on forgiven sins, nay, to explain questionable conformity to lax
21100: customs, and another to enter deliberately on the necessity of
21101: falsehood.
21102: 
21103: But since Bulstrode did not speak, Raffles ran on, by way of using time
21104: to the utmost.
21105: 
21106: “I’ve not had such fine luck as you, by Jove! Things went confoundedly
21107: with me in New York; those Yankees are cool hands, and a man of
21108: gentlemanly feelings has no chance with them. I married when I came
21109: back—a nice woman in the tobacco trade—very fond of me—but the trade
21110: was restricted, as we say. She had been settled there a good many years
21111: by a friend; but there was a son too much in the case. Josh and I never
21112: hit it off. However, I made the most of the position, and I’ve always
21113: taken my glass in good company. It’s been all on the square with me;
21114: I’m as open as the day. You won’t take it ill of me that I didn’t look
21115: you up before. I’ve got a complaint that makes me a little dilatory. I
21116: thought you were trading and praying away in London still, and didn’t
21117: find you there. But you see I was sent to you, Nick—perhaps for a
21118: blessing to both of us.”
21119: 
21120: Mr. Raffles ended with a jocose snuffle: no man felt his intellect more
21121: superior to religious cant. And if the cunning which calculates on the
21122: meanest feelings in men could be called intellect, he had his share,
21123: for under the blurting rallying tone with which he spoke to Bulstrode,
21124: there was an evident selection of statements, as if they had been so
21125: many moves at chess. Meanwhile Bulstrode had determined on his move,
21126: and he said, with gathered resolution—
21127: 
21128: “You will do well to reflect, Mr. Raffles, that it is possible for a
21129: man to overreach himself in the effort to secure undue advantage.
21130: Although I am not in any way bound to you, I am willing to supply you
21131: with a regular annuity—in quarterly payments—so long as you fulfil a
21132: promise to remain at a distance from this neighborhood. It is in your
21133: power to choose. If you insist on remaining here, even for a short
21134: time, you will get nothing from me. I shall decline to know you.”
21135: 
21136: “Ha, ha!” said Raffles, with an affected explosion, “that reminds me of
21137: a droll dog of a thief who declined to know the constable.”
21138: 
21139: “Your allusions are lost on me sir,” said Bulstrode, with white heat;
21140: “the law has no hold on me either through your agency or any other.”
21141: 
21142: “You can’t understand a joke, my good fellow. I only meant that I
21143: should never decline to know you. But let us be serious. Your quarterly
21144: payment won’t quite suit me. I like my freedom.”
21145: 
21146: Here Raffles rose and stalked once or twice up and down the room,
21147: swinging his leg, and assuming an air of masterly meditation. At last
21148: he stopped opposite Bulstrode, and said, “I’ll tell you what! Give us a
21149: couple of hundreds—come, that’s modest—and I’ll go away—honor
21150: bright!—pick up my portmanteau and go away. But I shall not give up my
21151: liberty for a dirty annuity. I shall come and go where I like. Perhaps
21152: it may suit me to stay away, and correspond with a friend; perhaps not.
21153: Have you the money with you?”
21154: 
21155: “No, I have one hundred,” said Bulstrode, feeling the immediate
21156: riddance too great a relief to be rejected on the ground of future
21157: uncertainties. “I will forward you the other if you will mention an
21158: address.”
21159: 
21160: “No, I’ll wait here till you bring it,” said Raffles. “I’ll take a
21161: stroll and have a snack, and you’ll be back by that time.”
21162: 
21163: Mr. Bulstrode’s sickly body, shattered by the agitations he had gone
21164: through since the last evening, made him feel abjectly in the power of
21165: this loud invulnerable man. At that moment he snatched at a temporary
21166: repose to be won on any terms. He was rising to do what Raffles
21167: suggested, when the latter said, lifting up his finger as if with a
21168: sudden recollection—
21169: 
21170: “I did have another look after Sarah again, though I didn’t tell you;
21171: I’d a tender conscience about that pretty young woman. I didn’t find
21172: her, but I found out her husband’s name, and I made a note of it. But
21173: hang it, I lost my pocketbook. However, if I heard it, I should know it
21174: again. I’ve got my faculties as if I was in my prime, but names wear
21175: out, by Jove! Sometimes I’m no better than a confounded tax-paper
21176: before the names are filled in. However, if I hear of her and her
21177: family, you shall know, Nick. You’d like to do something for her, now
21178: she’s your step-daughter.”
21179: 
21180: “Doubtless,” said Mr. Bulstrode, with the usual steady look of his
21181: light-gray eyes; “though that might reduce my power of assisting you.”
21182: 
21183: As he walked out of the room, Raffles winked slowly at his back, and
21184: then turned towards the window to watch the banker riding
21185: away—virtually at his command. His lips first curled with a smile and
21186: then opened with a short triumphant laugh.
21187: 
21188: “But what the deuce was the name?” he presently said, half aloud,
21189: scratching his head, and wrinkling his brows horizontally. He had not
21190: really cared or thought about this point of forgetfulness until it
21191: occurred to him in his invention of annoyances for Bulstrode.
21192: 
21193: “It began with L; it was almost all l’s I fancy,” he went on, with a
21194: sense that he was getting hold of the slippery name. But the hold was
21195: too slight, and he soon got tired of this mental chase; for few men
21196: were more impatient of private occupation or more in need of making
21197: themselves continually heard than Mr. Raffles. He preferred using his
21198: time in pleasant conversation with the bailiff and the housekeeper,
21199: from whom he gathered as much as he wanted to know about Mr.
21200: Bulstrode’s position in Middlemarch.
21201: 
21202: After all, however, there was a dull space of time which needed
21203: relieving with bread and cheese and ale, and when he was seated alone
21204: with these resources in the wainscoted parlor, he suddenly slapped his
21205: knee, and exclaimed, “Ladislaw!” That action of memory which he had
21206: tried to set going, and had abandoned in despair, had suddenly
21207: completed itself without conscious effort—a common experience,
21208: agreeable as a completed sneeze, even if the name remembered is of no
21209: value. Raffles immediately took out his pocket-book, and wrote down the
21210: name, not because he expected to use it, but merely for the sake of not
21211: being at a loss if he ever did happen to want it. He was not going to
21212: tell Bulstrode: there was no actual good in telling, and to a mind like
21213: that of Mr. Raffles there is always probable good in a secret.
21214: 
21215: He was satisfied with his present success, and by three o’clock that
21216: day he had taken up his portmanteau at the turnpike and mounted the
21217: coach, relieving Mr. Bulstrode’s eyes of an ugly black spot on the
21218: landscape at Stone Court, but not relieving him of the dread that the
21219: black spot might reappear and become inseparable even from the vision
21220: of his hearth.
21221: 
21222: 
21223: 
21224: 
21225: BOOK VI.
21226: THE WIDOW AND THE WIFE.
21227: 
21228: 
21229: 
21230: 
21231: CHAPTER LIV.
21232: 
21233: “Negli occhi porta la mia donna Amore;
21234: Per che si fa gentil ciò ch’ella mira:
21235: Ov’ella passa, ogni uom ver lei si gira,
21236: E cui saluta fa tremar lo core.
21237: 
21238: Sicchè, bassando il viso, tutto smore,
21239: E d’ogni suo difetto allor sospira:
21240: Fuggon dinanzi a lei Superbia ed Ira:
21241: Aiutatemi, donne, a farle onore.
21242: 
21243: Ogni dolcezza, ogni pensiero umile
21244: Nasce nel core a chi parlar la sente;
21245: Ond’è beato chi prima la vide.
21246: Quel ch’ella par quand’ un poco sorride,
21247: Non si può dicer, nè tener a mente,
21248: Si è nuovo miracolo gentile.”
21249: —DANTE: _La Vita Nuova_.
21250: 
21251: 
21252: By that delightful morning when the hay-ricks at Stone Court were
21253: scenting the air quite impartially, as if Mr. Raffles had been a guest
21254: worthy of finest incense, Dorothea had again taken up her abode at
21255: Lowick Manor. After three months Freshitt had become rather oppressive:
21256: to sit like a model for Saint Catherine looking rapturously at Celia’s
21257: baby would not do for many hours in the day, and to remain in that
21258: momentous babe’s presence with persistent disregard was a course that
21259: could not have been tolerated in a childless sister. Dorothea would
21260: have been capable of carrying baby joyfully for a mile if there had
21261: been need, and of loving it the more tenderly for that labor; but to an
21262: aunt who does not recognize her infant nephew as Bouddha, and has
21263: nothing to do for him but to admire, his behavior is apt to appear
21264: monotonous, and the interest of watching him exhaustible. This
21265: possibility was quite hidden from Celia, who felt that Dorothea’s
21266: childless widowhood fell in quite prettily with the birth of little
21267: Arthur (baby was named after Mr. Brooke).
21268: 
21269: “Dodo is just the creature not to mind about having anything of her
21270: own—children or anything!” said Celia to her husband. “And if she had
21271: had a baby, it never could have been such a dear as Arthur. Could it,
21272: James?
21273: 
21274: “Not if it had been like Casaubon,” said Sir James, conscious of some
21275: indirectness in his answer, and of holding a strictly private opinion
21276: as to the perfections of his first-born.
21277: 
21278: “No! just imagine! Really it was a mercy,” said Celia; “and I think it
21279: is very nice for Dodo to be a widow. She can be just as fond of our
21280: baby as if it were her own, and she can have as many notions of her own
21281: as she likes.”
21282: 
21283: “It is a pity she was not a queen,” said the devout Sir James.
21284: 
21285: “But what should we have been then? We must have been something else,”
21286: said Celia, objecting to so laborious a flight of imagination. “I like
21287: her better as she is.”
21288: 
21289: Hence, when she found that Dorothea was making arrangements for her
21290: final departure to Lowick, Celia raised her eyebrows with
21291: disappointment, and in her quiet unemphatic way shot a needle-arrow of
21292: sarcasm.
21293: 
21294: “What will you do at Lowick, Dodo? You say yourself there is nothing to
21295: be done there: everybody is so clean and well off, it makes you quite
21296: melancholy. And here you have been so happy going all about Tipton with
21297: Mr. Garth into the worst backyards. And now uncle is abroad, you and
21298: Mr. Garth can have it all your own way; and I am sure James does
21299: everything you tell him.”
21300: 
21301: “I shall often come here, and I shall see how baby grows all the
21302: better,” said Dorothea.
21303: 
21304: “But you will never see him washed,” said Celia; “and that is quite the
21305: best part of the day.” She was almost pouting: it did seem to her very
21306: hard in Dodo to go away from the baby when she might stay.
21307: 
21308: “Dear Kitty, I will come and stay all night on purpose,” said Dorothea;
21309: “but I want to be alone now, and in my own home. I wish to know the
21310: Farebrothers better, and to talk to Mr. Farebrother about what there is
21311: to be done in Middlemarch.”
21312: 
21313: Dorothea’s native strength of will was no longer all converted into
21314: resolute submission. She had a great yearning to be at Lowick, and was
21315: simply determined to go, not feeling bound to tell all her reasons. But
21316: every one around her disapproved. Sir James was much pained, and
21317: offered that they should all migrate to Cheltenham for a few months
21318: with the sacred ark, otherwise called a cradle: at that period a man
21319: could hardly know what to propose if Cheltenham were rejected.
21320: 
21321: The Dowager Lady Chettam, just returned from a visit to her daughter in
21322: town, wished, at least, that Mrs. Vigo should be written to, and
21323: invited to accept the office of companion to Mrs. Casaubon: it was not
21324: credible that Dorothea as a young widow would think of living alone in
21325: the house at Lowick. Mrs. Vigo had been reader and secretary to royal
21326: personages, and in point of knowledge and sentiments even Dorothea
21327: could have nothing to object to her.
21328: 
21329: Mrs. Cadwallader said, privately, “You will certainly go mad in that
21330: house alone, my dear. You will see visions. We have all got to exert
21331: ourselves a little to keep sane, and call things by the same names as
21332: other people call them by. To be sure, for younger sons and women who
21333: have no money, it is a sort of provision to go mad: they are taken care
21334: of then. But you must not run into that. I dare say you are a little
21335: bored here with our good dowager; but think what a bore you might
21336: become yourself to your fellow-creatures if you were always playing
21337: tragedy queen and taking things sublimely. Sitting alone in that
21338: library at Lowick you may fancy yourself ruling the weather; you must
21339: get a few people round you who wouldn’t believe you if you told them.
21340: That is a good lowering medicine.”
21341: 
21342: “I never called everything by the same name that all the people about
21343: me did,” said Dorothea, stoutly.
21344: 
21345: “But I suppose you have found out your mistake, my dear,” said Mrs.
21346: Cadwallader, “and that is a proof of sanity.”
21347: 
21348: Dorothea was aware of the sting, but it did not hurt her. “No,” she
21349: said, “I still think that the greater part of the world is mistaken
21350: about many things. Surely one may be sane and yet think so, since the
21351: greater part of the world has often had to come round from its
21352: opinion.”
21353: 
21354: Mrs. Cadwallader said no more on that point to Dorothea, but to her
21355: husband she remarked, “It will be well for her to marry again as soon
21356: as it is proper, if one could get her among the right people. Of course
21357: the Chettams would not wish it. But I see clearly a husband is the best
21358: thing to keep her in order. If we were not so poor I would invite Lord
21359: Triton. He will be marquis some day, and there is no denying that she
21360: would make a good marchioness: she looks handsomer than ever in her
21361: mourning.”
21362: 
21363: “My dear Elinor, do let the poor woman alone. Such contrivances are of
21364: no use,” said the easy Rector.
21365: 
21366: “No use? How are matches made, except by bringing men and women
21367: together? And it is a shame that her uncle should have run away and
21368: shut up the Grange just now. There ought to be plenty of eligible
21369: matches invited to Freshitt and the Grange. Lord Triton is precisely
21370: the man: full of plans for making the people happy in a soft-headed
21371: sort of way. That would just suit Mrs. Casaubon.”
21372: 
21373: “Let Mrs. Casaubon choose for herself, Elinor.”
21374: 
21375: “That is the nonsense you wise men talk! How can she choose if she has
21376: no variety to choose from? A woman’s choice usually means taking the
21377: only man she can get. Mark my words, Humphrey. If her friends don’t
21378: exert themselves, there will be a worse business than the Casaubon
21379: business yet.”
21380: 
21381: “For heaven’s sake don’t touch on that topic, Elinor! It is a very sore
21382: point with Sir James. He would be deeply offended if you entered on it
21383: to him unnecessarily.”
21384: 
21385: “I have never entered on it,” said Mrs Cadwallader, opening her hands.
21386: “Celia told me all about the will at the beginning, without any asking
21387: of mine.”
21388: 
21389: “Yes, yes; but they want the thing hushed up, and I understand that the
21390: young fellow is going out of the neighborhood.”
21391: 
21392: Mrs. Cadwallader said nothing, but gave her husband three significant
21393: nods, with a very sarcastic expression in her dark eyes.
21394: 
21395: Dorothea quietly persisted in spite of remonstrance and persuasion. So
21396: by the end of June the shutters were all opened at Lowick Manor, and
21397: the morning gazed calmly into the library, shining on the rows of
21398: note-books as it shines on the weary waste planted with huge stones,
21399: the mute memorial of a forgotten faith; and the evening laden with
21400: roses entered silently into the blue-green boudoir where Dorothea chose
21401: oftenest to sit. At first she walked into every room, questioning the
21402: eighteen months of her married life, and carrying on her thoughts as if
21403: they were a speech to be heard by her husband. Then, she lingered in
21404: the library and could not be at rest till she had carefully ranged all
21405: the note-books as she imagined that he would wish to see them, in
21406: orderly sequence. The pity which had been the restraining compelling
21407: motive in her life with him still clung about his image, even while she
21408: remonstrated with him in indignant thought and told him that he was
21409: unjust. One little act of hers may perhaps be smiled at as
21410: superstitious. The Synoptical Tabulation for the use of Mrs. Casaubon,
21411: she carefully enclosed and sealed, writing within the envelope, “I
21412: could not use it. Do you not see now that I could not submit my soul to
21413: yours, by working hopelessly at what I have no belief in—Dorothea?”
21414: Then she deposited the paper in her own desk.
21415: 
21416: That silent colloquy was perhaps only the more earnest because
21417: underneath and through it all there was always the deep longing which
21418: had really determined her to come to Lowick. The longing was to see
21419: Will Ladislaw. She did not know any good that could come of their
21420: meeting: she was helpless; her hands had been tied from making up to
21421: him for any unfairness in his lot. But her soul thirsted to see him.
21422: How could it be otherwise? If a princess in the days of enchantment had
21423: seen a four-footed creature from among those which live in herds come
21424: to her once and again with a human gaze which rested upon her with
21425: choice and beseeching, what would she think of in her journeying, what
21426: would she look for when the herds passed her? Surely for the gaze which
21427: had found her, and which she would know again. Life would be no better
21428: than candle-light tinsel and daylight rubbish if our spirits were not
21429: touched by what has been, to issues of longing and constancy. It was
21430: true that Dorothea wanted to know the Farebrothers better, and
21431: especially to talk to the new rector, but also true that remembering
21432: what Lydgate had told her about Will Ladislaw and little Miss Noble,
21433: she counted on Will’s coming to Lowick to see the Farebrother family.
21434: The very first Sunday, _before_ she entered the church, she saw him as
21435: she had seen him the last time she was there, alone in the clergyman’s
21436: pew; but _when_ she entered his figure was gone.
21437: 
21438: In the week-days when she went to see the ladies at the Rectory, she
21439: listened in vain for some word that they might let fall about Will; but
21440: it seemed to her that Mrs. Farebrother talked of every one else in the
21441: neighborhood and out of it.
21442: 
21443: “Probably some of Mr. Farebrother’s Middlemarch hearers may follow him
21444: to Lowick sometimes. Do you not think so?” said Dorothea, rather
21445: despising herself for having a secret motive in asking the question.
21446: 
21447: “If they are wise they will, Mrs. Casaubon,” said the old lady. “I see
21448: that you set a right value on my son’s preaching. His grandfather on my
21449: side was an excellent clergyman, but his father was in the law:—most
21450: exemplary and honest nevertheless, which is a reason for our never
21451: being rich. They say Fortune is a woman and capricious. But sometimes
21452: she is a good woman and gives to those who merit, which has been the
21453: case with you, Mrs. Casaubon, who have given a living to my son.”
21454: 
21455: Mrs. Farebrother recurred to her knitting with a dignified satisfaction
21456: in her neat little effort at oratory, but this was not what Dorothea
21457: wanted to hear. Poor thing! she did not even know whether Will Ladislaw
21458: was still at Middlemarch, and there was no one whom she dared to ask,
21459: unless it were Lydgate. But just now she could not see Lydgate without
21460: sending for him or going to seek him. Perhaps Will Ladislaw, having
21461: heard of that strange ban against him left by Mr. Casaubon, had felt it
21462: better that he and she should not meet again, and perhaps she was wrong
21463: to wish for a meeting that others might find many good reasons against.
21464: Still “I do wish it” came at the end of those wise reflections as
21465: naturally as a sob after holding the breath. And the meeting did
21466: happen, but in a formal way quite unexpected by her.
21467: 
21468: One morning, about eleven, Dorothea was seated in her boudoir with a
21469: map of the land attached to the manor and other papers before her,
