21470: which were to help her in making an exact statement for herself of her
21471: income and affairs. She had not yet applied herself to her work, but
21472: was seated with her hands folded on her lap, looking out along the
21473: avenue of limes to the distant fields. Every leaf was at rest in the
21474: sunshine, the familiar scene was changeless, and seemed to represent
21475: the prospect of her life, full of motiveless ease—motiveless, if her
21476: own energy could not seek out reasons for ardent action. The widow’s
21477: cap of those times made an oval frame for the face, and had a crown
21478: standing up; the dress was an experiment in the utmost laying on of
21479: crape; but this heavy solemnity of clothing made her face look all the
21480: younger, with its recovered bloom, and the sweet, inquiring candor of
21481: her eyes.
21482: 
21483: Her reverie was broken by Tantripp, who came to say that Mr. Ladislaw
21484: was below, and begged permission to see Madam if it were not too early.
21485: 
21486: “I will see him,” said Dorothea, rising immediately. “Let him be shown
21487: into the drawing-room.”
21488: 
21489: The drawing-room was the most neutral room in the house to her—the one
21490: least associated with the trials of her married life: the damask
21491: matched the wood-work, which was all white and gold; there were two
21492: tall mirrors and tables with nothing on them—in brief, it was a room
21493: where you had no reason for sitting in one place rather than in
21494: another. It was below the boudoir, and had also a bow-window looking
21495: out on the avenue. But when Pratt showed Will Ladislaw into it the
21496: window was open; and a winged visitor, buzzing in and out now and then
21497: without minding the furniture, made the room look less formal and
21498: uninhabited.
21499: 
21500: “Glad to see you here again, sir,” said Pratt, lingering to adjust a
21501: blind.
21502: 
21503: “I am only come to say good-by, Pratt,” said Will, who wished even the
21504: butler to know that he was too proud to hang about Mrs. Casaubon now
21505: she was a rich widow.
21506: 
21507: “Very sorry to hear it, sir,” said Pratt, retiring. Of course, as a
21508: servant who was to be told nothing, he knew the fact of which Ladislaw
21509: was still ignorant, and had drawn his inferences; indeed, had not
21510: differed from his betrothed Tantripp when she said, “Your master was as
21511: jealous as a fiend—and no reason. Madam would look higher than Mr.
21512: Ladislaw, else I don’t know her. Mrs. Cadwallader’s maid says there’s a
21513: lord coming who is to marry her when the mourning’s over.”
21514: 
21515: There were not many moments for Will to walk about with his hat in his
21516: hand before Dorothea entered. The meeting was very different from that
21517: first meeting in Rome when Will had been embarrassed and Dorothea calm.
21518: This time he felt miserable but determined, while she was in a state of
21519: agitation which could not be hidden. Just outside the door she had felt
21520: that this longed-for meeting was after all too difficult, and when she
21521: saw Will advancing towards her, the deep blush which was rare in her
21522: came with painful suddenness. Neither of them knew how it was, but
21523: neither of them spoke. She gave her hand for a moment, and then they
21524: went to sit down near the window, she on one settee and he on another
21525: opposite. Will was peculiarly uneasy: it seemed to him not like
21526: Dorothea that the mere fact of her being a widow should cause such a
21527: change in her manner of receiving him; and he knew of no other
21528: condition which could have affected their previous relation to each
21529: other—except that, as his imagination at once told him, her friends
21530: might have been poisoning her mind with their suspicions of him.
21531: 
21532: “I hope I have not presumed too much in calling,” said Will; “I could
21533: not bear to leave the neighborhood and begin a new life without seeing
21534: you to say good-by.”
21535: 
21536: “Presumed? Surely not. I should have thought it unkind if you had not
21537: wished to see me,” said Dorothea, her habit of speaking with perfect
21538: genuineness asserting itself through all her uncertainty and agitation.
21539: “Are you going away immediately?”
21540: 
21541: “Very soon, I think. I intend to go to town and eat my dinners as a
21542: barrister, since, they say, that is the preparation for all public
21543: business. There will be a great deal of political work to be done
21544: by-and-by, and I mean to try and do some of it. Other men have managed
21545: to win an honorable position for themselves without family or money.”
21546: 
21547: “And that will make it all the more honorable,” said Dorothea,
21548: ardently. “Besides, you have so many talents. I have heard from my
21549: uncle how well you speak in public, so that every one is sorry when you
21550: leave off, and how clearly you can explain things. And you care that
21551: justice should be done to every one. I am so glad. When we were in
21552: Rome, I thought you only cared for poetry and art, and the things that
21553: adorn life for us who are well off. But now I know you think about the
21554: rest of the world.”
21555: 
21556: While she was speaking Dorothea had lost her personal embarrassment,
21557: and had become like her former self. She looked at Will with a direct
21558: glance, full of delighted confidence.
21559: 
21560: “You approve of my going away for years, then, and never coming here
21561: again till I have made myself of some mark in the world?” said Will,
21562: trying hard to reconcile the utmost pride with the utmost effort to get
21563: an expression of strong feeling from Dorothea.
21564: 
21565: She was not aware how long it was before she answered. She had turned
21566: her head and was looking out of the window on the rose-bushes, which
21567: seemed to have in them the summers of all the years when Will would be
21568: away. This was not judicious behavior. But Dorothea never thought of
21569: studying her manners: she thought only of bowing to a sad necessity
21570: which divided her from Will. Those first words of his about his
21571: intentions had seemed to make everything clear to her: he knew, she
21572: supposed, all about Mr. Casaubon’s final conduct in relation to him,
21573: and it had come to him with the same sort of shock as to herself. He
21574: had never felt more than friendship for her—had never had anything in
21575: his mind to justify what she felt to be her husband’s outrage on the
21576: feelings of both: and that friendship he still felt. Something which
21577: may be called an inward silent sob had gone on in Dorothea before she
21578: said with a pure voice, just trembling in the last words as if only
21579: from its liquid flexibility—
21580: 
21581: “Yes, it must be right for you to do as you say. I shall be very happy
21582: when I hear that you have made your value felt. But you must have
21583: patience. It will perhaps be a long while.”
21584: 
21585: Will never quite knew how it was that he saved himself from falling
21586: down at her feet, when the “long while” came forth with its gentle
21587: tremor. He used to say that the horrible hue and surface of her crape
21588: dress was most likely the sufficient controlling force. He sat still,
21589: however, and only said—
21590: 
21591: “I shall never hear from you. And you will forget all about me.”
21592: 
21593: “No,” said Dorothea, “I shall never forget you. I have never forgotten
21594: any one whom I once knew. My life has never been crowded, and seems not
21595: likely to be so. And I have a great deal of space for memory at Lowick,
21596: haven’t I?” She smiled.
21597: 
21598: “Good God!” Will burst out passionately, rising, with his hat still in
21599: his hand, and walking away to a marble table, where he suddenly turned
21600: and leaned his back against it. The blood had mounted to his face and
21601: neck, and he looked almost angry. It had seemed to him as if they were
21602: like two creatures slowly turning to marble in each other’s presence,
21603: while their hearts were conscious and their eyes were yearning. But
21604: there was no help for it. It should never be true of him that in this
21605: meeting to which he had come with bitter resolution he had ended by a
21606: confession which might be interpreted into asking for her fortune.
21607: Moreover, it was actually true that he was fearful of the effect which
21608: such confessions might have on Dorothea herself.
21609: 
21610: She looked at him from that distance in some trouble, imagining that
21611: there might have been an offence in her words. But all the while there
21612: was a current of thought in her about his probable want of money, and
21613: the impossibility of her helping him. If her uncle had been at home,
21614: something might have been done through him! It was this preoccupation
21615: with the hardship of Will’s wanting money, while she had what ought to
21616: have been his share, which led her to say, seeing that he remained
21617: silent and looked away from her—
21618: 
21619: “I wonder whether you would like to have that miniature which hangs
21620: up-stairs—I mean that beautiful miniature of your grandmother. I think
21621: it is not right for me to keep it, if you would wish to have it. It is
21622: wonderfully like you.”
21623: 
21624: “You are very good,” said Will, irritably. “No; I don’t mind about it.
21625: It is not very consoling to have one’s own likeness. It would be more
21626: consoling if others wanted to have it.”
21627: 
21628: “I thought you would like to cherish her memory—I thought—” Dorothea
21629: broke off an instant, her imagination suddenly warning her away from
21630: Aunt Julia’s history—“you would surely like to have the miniature as a
21631: family memorial.”
21632: 
21633: “Why should I have that, when I have nothing else! A man with only a
21634: portmanteau for his stowage must keep his memorials in his head.”
21635: 
21636: Will spoke at random: he was merely venting his petulance; it was a
21637: little too exasperating to have his grandmother’s portrait offered him
21638: at that moment. But to Dorothea’s feeling his words had a peculiar
21639: sting. She rose and said with a touch of indignation as well as
21640: hauteur—
21641: 
21642: “You are much the happier of us two, Mr. Ladislaw, to have nothing.”
21643: 
21644: Will was startled. Whatever the words might be, the tone seemed like a
21645: dismissal; and quitting his leaning posture, he walked a little way
21646: towards her. Their eyes met, but with a strange questioning gravity.
21647: Something was keeping their minds aloof, and each was left to
21648: conjecture what was in the other. Will had really never thought of
21649: himself as having a claim of inheritance on the property which was held
21650: by Dorothea, and would have required a narrative to make him understand
21651: her present feeling.
21652: 
21653: “I never felt it a misfortune to have nothing till now,” he said. “But
21654: poverty may be as bad as leprosy, if it divides us from what we most
21655: care for.”
21656: 
21657: The words cut Dorothea to the heart, and made her relent. She answered
21658: in a tone of sad fellowship.
21659: 
21660: “Sorrow comes in so many ways. Two years ago I had no notion of that—I
21661: mean of the unexpected way in which trouble comes, and ties our hands,
21662: and makes us silent when we long to speak. I used to despise women a
21663: little for not shaping their lives more, and doing better things. I was
21664: very fond of doing as I liked, but I have almost given it up,” she
21665: ended, smiling playfully.
21666: 
21667: “I have not given up doing as I like, but I can very seldom do it,”
21668: said Will. He was standing two yards from her with his mind full of
21669: contradictory desires and resolves—desiring some unmistakable proof
21670: that she loved him, and yet dreading the position into which such a
21671: proof might bring him. “The thing one most longs for may be surrounded
21672: with conditions that would be intolerable.”
21673: 
21674: At this moment Pratt entered and said, “Sir James Chettam is in the
21675: library, madam.”
21676: 
21677: “Ask Sir James to come in here,” said Dorothea, immediately. It was as
21678: if the same electric shock had passed through her and Will. Each of
21679: them felt proudly resistant, and neither looked at the other, while
21680: they awaited Sir James’s entrance.
21681: 
21682: After shaking hands with Dorothea, he bowed as slightly as possible to
21683: Ladislaw, who repaid the slightness exactly, and then going towards
21684: Dorothea, said—
21685: 
21686: “I must say good-by, Mrs. Casaubon; and probably for a long while.”
21687: 
21688: Dorothea put out her hand and said her good-by cordially. The sense
21689: that Sir James was depreciating Will, and behaving rudely to him,
21690: roused her resolution and dignity: there was no touch of confusion in
21691: her manner. And when Will had left the room, she looked with such calm
21692: self-possession at Sir James, saying, “How is Celia?” that he was
21693: obliged to behave as if nothing had annoyed him. And what would be the
21694: use of behaving otherwise? Indeed, Sir James shrank with so much
21695: dislike from the association even in thought of Dorothea with Ladislaw
21696: as her possible lover, that he would himself have wished to avoid an
21697: outward show of displeasure which would have recognized the
21698: disagreeable possibility. If any one had asked him why he shrank in
21699: that way, I am not sure that he would at first have said anything
21700: fuller or more precise than “_That_ Ladislaw!”—though on reflection he
21701: might have urged that Mr. Casaubon’s codicil, barring Dorothea’s
21702: marriage with Will, except under a penalty, was enough to cast
21703: unfitness over any relation at all between them. His aversion was all
21704: the stronger because he felt himself unable to interfere.
21705: 
21706: But Sir James was a power in a way unguessed by himself. Entering at
21707: that moment, he was an incorporation of the strongest reasons through
21708: which Will’s pride became a repellent force, keeping him asunder from
21709: Dorothea.
21710: 
21711: 
21712:

21714: CHAPTER LV.
21715: 
21716: Hath she her faults? I would you had them too.
21717: They are the fruity must of soundest wine;
21718: Or say, they are regenerating fire
21719: Such as hath turned the dense black element
21720: Into a crystal pathway for the sun.
21721: 
21722: 
21723: If youth is the season of hope, it is often so only in the sense that
21724: our elders are hopeful about us; for no age is so apt as youth to think
21725: its emotions, partings, and resolves are the last of their kind. Each
21726: crisis seems final, simply because it is new. We are told that the
21727: oldest inhabitants in Peru do not cease to be agitated by the
21728: earthquakes, but they probably see beyond each shock, and reflect that
21729: there are plenty more to come.
21730: 
21731: To Dorothea, still in that time of youth when the eyes with their long
21732: full lashes look out after their rain of tears unsoiled and unwearied
21733: as a freshly opened passion-flower, that morning’s parting with Will
21734: Ladislaw seemed to be the close of their personal relations. He was
21735: going away into the distance of unknown years, and if ever he came back
21736: he would be another man. The actual state of his mind—his proud resolve
21737: to give the lie beforehand to any suspicion that he would play the
21738: needy adventurer seeking a rich woman—lay quite out of her imagination,
21739: and she had interpreted all his behavior easily enough by her
21740: supposition that Mr. Casaubon’s codicil seemed to him, as it did to
21741: her, a gross and cruel interdict on any active friendship between them.
21742: Their young delight in speaking to each other, and saying what no one
21743: else would care to hear, was forever ended, and become a treasure of
21744: the past. For this very reason she dwelt on it without inward check.
21745: That unique happiness too was dead, and in its shadowed silent chamber
21746: she might vent the passionate grief which she herself wondered at. For
21747: the first time she took down the miniature from the wall and kept it
21748: before her, liking to blend the woman who had been too hardly judged
21749: with the grandson whom her own heart and judgment defended. Can any one
21750: who has rejoiced in woman’s tenderness think it a reproach to her that
21751: she took the little oval picture in her palm and made a bed for it
21752: there, and leaned her cheek upon it, as if that would soothe the
21753: creatures who had suffered unjust condemnation? She did not know then
21754: that it was Love who had come to her briefly, as in a dream before
21755: awaking, with the hues of morning on his wings—that it was Love to whom
21756: she was sobbing her farewell as his image was banished by the blameless
21757: rigor of irresistible day. She only felt that there was something
21758: irrevocably amiss and lost in her lot, and her thoughts about the
21759: future were the more readily shapen into resolve. Ardent souls, ready
21760: to construct their coming lives, are apt to commit themselves to the
21761: fulfilment of their own visions.
21762: 
21763: One day that she went to Freshitt to fulfil her promise of staying all
21764: night and seeing baby washed, Mrs. Cadwallader came to dine, the Rector
21765: being gone on a fishing excursion. It was a warm evening, and even in
21766: the delightful drawing-room, where the fine old turf sloped from the
21767: open window towards a lilied pool and well-planted mounds, the heat was
21768: enough to make Celia in her white muslin and light curls reflect with
21769: pity on what Dodo must feel in her black dress and close cap. But this
21770: was not until some episodes with baby were over, and had left her mind
21771: at leisure. She had seated herself and taken up a fan for some time
21772: before she said, in her quiet guttural—
21773: 
21774: “Dear Dodo, do throw off that cap. I am sure your dress must make you
21775: feel ill.”
21776: 
21777: “I am so used to the cap—it has become a sort of shell,” said Dorothea,
21778: smiling. “I feel rather bare and exposed when it is off.”
21779: 
21780: “I must see you without it; it makes us all warm,” said Celia, throwing
21781: down her fan, and going to Dorothea. It was a pretty picture to see
21782: this little lady in white muslin unfastening the widow’s cap from her
21783: more majestic sister, and tossing it on to a chair. Just as the coils
21784: and braids of dark-brown hair had been set free, Sir James entered the
21785: room. He looked at the released head, and said, “Ah!” in a tone of
21786: satisfaction.
21787: 
21788: “It was I who did it, James,” said Celia. “Dodo need not make such a
21789: slavery of her mourning; she need not wear that cap any more among her
21790: friends.”
21791: 
21792: “My dear Celia,” said Lady Chettam, “a widow must wear her mourning at
21793: least a year.”
21794: 
21795: “Not if she marries again before the end of it,” said Mrs. Cadwallader,
21796: who had some pleasure in startling her good friend the Dowager. Sir
21797: James was annoyed, and leaned forward to play with Celia’s Maltese dog.
21798: 
21799: “That is very rare, I hope,” said Lady Chettam, in a tone intended to
21800: guard against such events. “No friend of ours ever committed herself in
21801: that way except Mrs. Beevor, and it was very painful to Lord Grinsell
21802: when she did so. Her first husband was objectionable, which made it the
21803: greater wonder. And severely she was punished for it. They said Captain
21804: Beevor dragged her about by the hair, and held up loaded pistols at
21805: her.”
21806: 
21807: “Oh, if she took the wrong man!” said Mrs. Cadwallader, who was in a
21808: decidedly wicked mood. “Marriage is always bad then, first or second.
21809: Priority is a poor recommendation in a husband if he has got no other.
21810: I would rather have a good second husband than an indifferent first.”
21811: 
21812: “My dear, your clever tongue runs away with you,” said Lady Chettam. “I
21813: am sure you would be the last woman to marry again prematurely, if our
21814: dear Rector were taken away.”
21815: 
21816: “Oh, I make no vows; it might be a necessary economy. It is lawful to
21817: marry again, I suppose; else we might as well be Hindoos instead of
21818: Christians. Of course if a woman accepts the wrong man, she must take
21819: the consequences, and one who does it twice over deserves her fate. But
21820: if she can marry blood, beauty, and bravery—the sooner the better.”
21821: 
21822: “I think the subject of our conversation is very ill-chosen,” said Sir
21823: James, with a look of disgust. “Suppose we change it.”
21824: 
21825: “Not on my account, Sir James,” said Dorothea, determined not to lose
21826: the opportunity of freeing herself from certain oblique references to
21827: excellent matches. “If you are speaking on my behalf, I can assure you
21828: that no question can be more indifferent and impersonal to me than
21829: second marriage. It is no more to me than if you talked of women going
21830: fox-hunting: whether it is admirable in them or not, I shall not follow
21831: them. Pray let Mrs. Cadwallader amuse herself on that subject as much
21832: as on any other.”
21833: 
21834: “My dear Mrs. Casaubon,” said Lady Chettam, in her stateliest way, “you
21835: do not, I hope, think there was any allusion to you in my mentioning
21836: Mrs. Beevor. It was only an instance that occurred to me. She was
21837: step-daughter to Lord Grinsell: he married Mrs. Teveroy for his second
21838: wife. There could be no possible allusion to you.”
21839: 
21840: “Oh no,” said Celia. “Nobody chose the subject; it all came out of
21841: Dodo’s cap. Mrs. Cadwallader only said what was quite true. A woman
21842: could not be married in a widow’s cap, James.”
21843: 
21844: “Hush, my dear!” said Mrs. Cadwallader. “I will not offend again. I
21845: will not even refer to Dido or Zenobia. Only what are we to talk about?
21846: I, for my part, object to the discussion of Human Nature, because that
21847: is the nature of rectors’ wives.”
21848: 
21849: Later in the evening, after Mrs. Cadwallader was gone, Celia said
21850: privately to Dorothea, “Really, Dodo, taking your cap off made you like
21851: yourself again in more ways than one. You spoke up just as you used to
21852: do, when anything was said to displease you. But I could hardly make
21853: out whether it was James that you thought wrong, or Mrs. Cadwallader.”
21854: 
21855: “Neither,” said Dorothea. “James spoke out of delicacy to me, but he
21856: was mistaken in supposing that I minded what Mrs. Cadwallader said. I
21857: should only mind if there were a law obliging me to take any piece of
21858: blood and beauty that she or anybody else recommended.”
21859: 
21860: “But you know, Dodo, if you ever did marry, it would be all the better
21861: to have blood and beauty,” said Celia, reflecting that Mr. Casaubon had
21862: not been richly endowed with those gifts, and that it would be well to
21863: caution Dorothea in time.
21864: 
21865: “Don’t be anxious, Kitty; I have quite other thoughts about my life. I
21866: shall never marry again,” said Dorothea, touching her sister’s chin,
21867: and looking at her with indulgent affection. Celia was nursing her
21868: baby, and Dorothea had come to say good-night to her.
21869: 
21870: “Really—quite?” said Celia. “Not anybody at all—if he were very
21871: wonderful indeed?”
21872: 
21873: Dorothea shook her head slowly. “Not anybody at all. I have delightful
21874: plans. I should like to take a great deal of land, and drain it, and
21875: make a little colony, where everybody should work, and all the work
21876: should be done well. I should know every one of the people and be their
21877: friend. I am going to have great consultations with Mr. Garth: he can
21878: tell me almost everything I want to know.”
21879: 
21880: “Then you _will_ be happy, if you have a plan, Dodo?” said Celia.
21881: “Perhaps little Arthur will like plans when he grows up, and then he
21882: can help you.”
21883: 
21884: Sir James was informed that same night that Dorothea was really quite
21885: set against marrying anybody at all, and was going to take to “all
21886: sorts of plans,” just like what she used to have. Sir James made no
21887: remark. To his secret feeling there was something repulsive in a
21888: woman’s second marriage, and no match would prevent him from feeling it
21889: a sort of desecration for Dorothea. He was aware that the world would
21890: regard such a sentiment as preposterous, especially in relation to a
21891: woman of one-and-twenty; the practice of “the world” being to treat of
21892: a young widow’s second marriage as certain and probably near, and to
21893: smile with meaning if the widow acts accordingly. But if Dorothea did
21894: choose to espouse her solitude, he felt that the resolution would well
21895: become her.
21896: 
21897: 
21898: 
21899: 
21900: CHAPTER LVI.
21901: 
21902: “How happy is he born and taught
21903: That serveth not another’s will;
21904: Whose armor is his honest thought,
21905: And simple truth his only skill!
21906: . . . . . . .
21907: This man is freed from servile bands
21908: Of hope to rise or fear to fall;
21909: Lord of himself though not of lands;
21910: And having nothing yet hath all.”
21911: —SIR HENRY WOTTON.
21912: 
21913: 
21914: Dorothea’s confidence in Caleb Garth’s knowledge, which had begun on
21915: her hearing that he approved of her cottages, had grown fast during her
21916: stay at Freshitt, Sir James having induced her to take rides over the
21917: two estates in company with himself and Caleb, who quite returned her
21918: admiration, and told his wife that Mrs. Casaubon had a head for
21919: business most uncommon in a woman. It must be remembered that by
21920: “business” Caleb never meant money transactions, but the skilful
21921: application of labor.
21922: 
21923: “Most uncommon!” repeated Caleb. “She said a thing I often used to
21924: think myself when I was a lad:—‘Mr. Garth, I should like to feel, if I
21925: lived to be old, that I had improved a great piece of land and built a
21926: great many good cottages, because the work is of a healthy kind while
21927: it is being done, and after it is done, men are the better for it.’
21928: Those were the very words: she sees into things in that way.”
21929: 
21930: “But womanly, I hope,” said Mrs. Garth, half suspecting that Mrs.
21931: Casaubon might not hold the true principle of subordination.
21932: 
21933: “Oh, you can’t think!” said Caleb, shaking his head. “You would like to
21934: hear her speak, Susan. She speaks in such plain words, and a voice like
21935: music. Bless me! it reminds me of bits in the ‘Messiah’—‘and
21936: straightway there appeared a multitude of the heavenly host, praising
21937: God and saying;’ it has a tone with it that satisfies your ear.”
21938: 
21939: Caleb was very fond of music, and when he could afford it went to hear
21940: an oratorio that came within his reach, returning from it with a
21941: profound reverence for this mighty structure of tones, which made him
21942: sit meditatively, looking on the floor and throwing much unutterable
21943: language into his outstretched hands.
21944: 
21945: With this good understanding between them, it was natural that Dorothea
21946: asked Mr. Garth to undertake any business connected with the three
21947: farms and the numerous tenements attached to Lowick Manor; indeed, his
21948: expectation of getting work for two was being fast fulfilled. As he
21949: said, “Business breeds.” And one form of business which was beginning
21950: to breed just then was the construction of railways. A projected line
21951: was to run through Lowick parish where the cattle had hitherto grazed
21952: in a peace unbroken by astonishment; and thus it happened that the
21953: infant struggles of the railway system entered into the affairs of
21954: Caleb Garth, and determined the course of this history with regard to
21955: two persons who were dear to him. The submarine railway may have its
21956: difficulties; but the bed of the sea is not divided among various
21957: landed proprietors with claims for damages not only measurable but
21958: sentimental. In the hundred to which Middlemarch belonged railways were
21959: as exciting a topic as the Reform Bill or the imminent horrors of
21960: Cholera, and those who held the most decided views on the subject were
21961: women and landholders. Women both old and young regarded travelling by
21962: steam as presumptuous and dangerous, and argued against it by saying
21963: that nothing should induce them to get into a railway carriage; while
21964: proprietors, differing from each other in their arguments as much as
21965: Mr. Solomon Featherstone differed from Lord Medlicote, were yet
21966: unanimous in the opinion that in selling land, whether to the Enemy of
21967: mankind or to a company obliged to purchase, these pernicious agencies
21968: must be made to pay a very high price to landowners for permission to
21969: injure mankind.
21970: 
21971: But the slower wits, such as Mr. Solomon and Mrs. Waule, who both
21972: occupied land of their own, took a long time to arrive at this
21973: conclusion, their minds halting at the vivid conception of what it
21974: would be to cut the Big Pasture in two, and turn it into three-cornered
21975: bits, which would be “nohow;” while accommodation-bridges and high
21976: payments were remote and incredible.
21977: 
21978: “The cows will all cast their calves, brother,” said Mrs. Waule, in a
21979: tone of deep melancholy, “if the railway comes across the Near Close;
21980: and I shouldn’t wonder at the mare too, if she was in foal. It’s a poor
21981: tale if a widow’s property is to be spaded away, and the law say
21982: nothing to it. What’s to hinder ’em from cutting right and left if they
21983: begin? It’s well known, _I_ can’t fight.”
21984: 
21985: “The best way would be to say nothing, and set somebody on to send ’em
21986: away with a flea in their ear, when they came spying and measuring,”
21987: said Solomon. “Folks did that about Brassing, by what I can understand.
21988: It’s all a pretence, if the truth was known, about their being forced
21989: to take one way. Let ’em go cutting in another parish. And I don’t
21990: believe in any pay to make amends for bringing a lot of ruffians to
21991: trample your crops. Where’s a company’s pocket?”
21992: 
21993: “Brother Peter, God forgive him, got money out of a company,” said Mrs.
21994: Waule. “But that was for the manganese. That wasn’t for railways to
21995: blow you to pieces right and left.”
21996: 
21997: “Well, there’s this to be said, Jane,” Mr. Solomon concluded, lowering
21998: his voice in a cautious manner—“the more spokes we put in their wheel,
21999: the more they’ll pay us to let ’em go on, if they must come whether or
22000: not.”
22001: 
22002: This reasoning of Mr. Solomon’s was perhaps less thorough than he
22003: imagined, his cunning bearing about the same relation to the course of
22004: railways as the cunning of a diplomatist bears to the general chill or
22005: catarrh of the solar system. But he set about acting on his views in a
22006: thoroughly diplomatic manner, by stimulating suspicion. His side of
22007: Lowick was the most remote from the village, and the houses of the
22008: laboring people were either lone cottages or were collected in a hamlet
22009: called Frick, where a water-mill and some stone-pits made a little
22010: centre of slow, heavy-shouldered industry.
22011: 
22012: In the absence of any precise idea as to what railways were, public
22013: opinion in Frick was against them; for the human mind in that grassy
22014: corner had not the proverbial tendency to admire the unknown, holding
22015: rather that it was likely to be against the poor man, and that
22016: suspicion was the only wise attitude with regard to it. Even the rumor
22017: of Reform had not yet excited any millennial expectations in Frick,
22018: there being no definite promise in it, as of gratuitous grains to
22019: fatten Hiram Ford’s pig, or of a publican at the “Weights and Scales”
22020: who would brew beer for nothing, or of an offer on the part of the
22021: three neighboring farmers to raise wages during winter. And without
22022: distinct good of this kind in its promises, Reform seemed on a footing
22023: with the bragging of pedlers, which was a hint for distrust to every
22024: knowing person. The men of Frick were not ill-fed, and were less given
22025: to fanaticism than to a strong muscular suspicion; less inclined to
22026: believe that they were peculiarly cared for by heaven, than to regard
22027: heaven itself as rather disposed to take them in—a disposition
22028: observable in the weather.
22029: 
22030: Thus the mind of Frick was exactly of the sort for Mr. Solomon
22031: Featherstone to work upon, he having more plenteous ideas of the same
22032: order, with a suspicion of heaven and earth which was better fed and
22033: more entirely at leisure. Solomon was overseer of the roads at that
22034: time, and on his slow-paced cob often took his rounds by Frick to look
22035: at the workmen getting the stones there, pausing with a mysterious
22036: deliberation, which might have misled you into supposing that he had
22037: some other reason for staying than the mere want of impulse to move.
22038: After looking for a long while at any work that was going on, he would
22039: raise his eyes a little and look at the horizon; finally he would shake
22040: his bridle, touch his horse with the whip, and get it to move slowly
22041: onward. The hour-hand of a clock was quick by comparison with Mr.
22042: Solomon, who had an agreeable sense that he could afford to be slow. He
22043: was in the habit of pausing for a cautious, vaguely designing chat with
22044: every hedger or ditcher on his way, and was especially willing to
22045: listen even to news which he had heard before, feeling himself at an
22046: advantage over all narrators in partially disbelieving them. One day,
22047: however, he got into a dialogue with Hiram Ford, a wagoner, in which he
22048: himself contributed information. He wished to know whether Hiram had
22049: seen fellows with staves and instruments spying about: they called
22050: themselves railroad people, but there was no telling what they were or
22051: what they meant to do. The least they pretended was that they were
22052: going to cut Lowick Parish into sixes and sevens.
22053: 
22054: “Why, there’ll be no stirrin’ from one pla-ace to another,” said Hiram,
22055: thinking of his wagon and horses.
22056: 
22057: “Not a bit,” said Mr. Solomon. “And cutting up fine land such as this
22058: parish! Let ’em go into Tipton, say I. But there’s no knowing what
22059: there is at the bottom of it. Traffic is what they put for’ard; but
22060: it’s to do harm to the land and the poor man in the long-run.”
22061: 
22062: “Why, they’re Lunnon chaps, I reckon,” said Hiram, who had a dim notion
22063: of London as a centre of hostility to the country.
22064: 
22065: “Ay, to be sure. And in some parts against Brassing, by what I’ve heard
22066: say, the folks fell on ’em when they were spying, and broke their
22067: peep-holes as they carry, and drove ’em away, so as they knew better
22068: than come again.”
22069: 
22070: “It war good foon, I’d be bound,” said Hiram, whose fun was much
22071: restricted by circumstances.
22072: 
22073: “Well, I wouldn’t meddle with ’em myself,” said Solomon. “But some say
22074: this country’s seen its best days, and the sign is, as it’s being
22075: overrun with these fellows trampling right and left, and wanting to cut
22076: it up into railways; and all for the big traffic to swallow up the
22077: little, so as there shan’t be a team left on the land, nor a whip to
22078: crack.”
22079: 
22080: “I’ll crack _my_ whip about their ear’n, afore they bring it to that,
22081: though,” said Hiram, while Mr. Solomon, shaking his bridle, moved
22082: onward.
22083: 
22084: Nettle-seed needs no digging. The ruin of this countryside by railroads
22085: was discussed, not only at the “Weights and Scales,” but in the
22086: hay-field, where the muster of working hands gave opportunities for
22087: talk such as were rarely had through the rural year.
22088: 
22089: One morning, not long after that interview between Mr. Farebrother and
22090: Mary Garth, in which she confessed to him her feeling for Fred Vincy,
22091: it happened that her father had some business which took him to
22092: Yoddrell’s farm in the direction of Frick: it was to measure and value
22093: an outlying piece of land belonging to Lowick Manor, which Caleb
22094: expected to dispose of advantageously for Dorothea (it must be
22095: confessed that his bias was towards getting the best possible terms
22096: from railroad companies). He put up his gig at Yoddrell’s, and in
22097: walking with his assistant and measuring-chain to the scene of his
22098: work, he encountered the party of the company’s agents, who were
22099: adjusting their spirit-level. After a little chat he left them,
22100: observing that by-and-by they would reach him again where he was going
22101: to measure. It was one of those gray mornings after light rains, which
22102: become delicious about twelve o’clock, when the clouds part a little,
22103: and the scent of the earth is sweet along the lanes and by the
22104: hedgerows.
22105: 
22106: The scent would have been sweeter to Fred Vincy, who was coming along
22107: the lanes on horseback, if his mind had not been worried by
22108: unsuccessful efforts to imagine what he was to do, with his father on
22109: one side expecting him straightway to enter the Church, with Mary on
22110: the other threatening to forsake him if he did enter it, and with the
22111: working-day world showing no eager need whatever of a young gentleman
22112: without capital and generally unskilled. It was the harder to Fred’s
22113: disposition because his father, satisfied that he was no longer
22114: rebellious, was in good humor with him, and had sent him on this
22115: pleasant ride to see after some greyhounds. Even when he had fixed on
22116: what he should do, there would be the task of telling his father. But
22117: it must be admitted that the fixing, which had to come first, was the
22118: more difficult task:—what secular avocation on earth was there for a
22119: young man (whose friends could not get him an “appointment”) which was
22120: at once gentlemanly, lucrative, and to be followed without special
22121: knowledge? Riding along the lanes by Frick in this mood, and slackening
22122: his pace while he reflected whether he should venture to go round by
22123: Lowick Parsonage to call on Mary, he could see over the hedges from one
22124: field to another. Suddenly a noise roused his attention, and on the far
22125: side of a field on his left hand he could see six or seven men in
22126: smock-frocks with hay-forks in their hands making an offensive approach
22127: towards the four railway agents who were facing them, while Caleb Garth
22128: and his assistant were hastening across the field to join the
22129: threatened group. Fred, delayed a few moments by having to find the
22130: gate, could not gallop up to the spot before the party in smock-frocks,
22131: whose work of turning the hay had not been too pressing after
22132: swallowing their mid-day beer, were driving the men in coats before
22133: them with their hay-forks; while Caleb Garth’s assistant, a lad of
22134: seventeen, who had snatched up the spirit-level at Caleb’s order, had
22135: been knocked down and seemed to be lying helpless. The coated men had
22136: the advantage as runners, and Fred covered their retreat by getting in
22137: front of the smock-frocks and charging them suddenly enough to throw
22138: their chase into confusion. “What do you confounded fools mean?”
22139: shouted Fred, pursuing the divided group in a zigzag, and cutting right
22140: and left with his whip. “I’ll swear to every one of you before the
22141: magistrate. You’ve knocked the lad down and killed him, for what I
22142: know. You’ll every one of you be hanged at the next assizes, if you
22143: don’t mind,” said Fred, who afterwards laughed heartily as he
22144: remembered his own phrases.
22145: 
22146: The laborers had been driven through the gate-way into their hay-field,
22147: and Fred had checked his horse, when Hiram Ford, observing himself at a
22148: safe challenging distance, turned back and shouted a defiance which he
22149: did not know to be Homeric.
22150: 
22151: “Yo’re a coward, yo are. Yo git off your horse, young measter, and I’ll
22152: have a round wi’ ye, I wull. Yo daredn’t come on wi’out your hoss an’
22153: whip. I’d soon knock the breath out on ye, I would.”
22154: 
22155: “Wait a minute, and I’ll come back presently, and have a round with you
22156: all in turn, if you like,” said Fred, who felt confidence in his power
22157: of boxing with his dearly beloved brethren. But just now he wanted to
22158: hasten back to Caleb and the prostrate youth.
22159: 
22160: The lad’s ankle was strained, and he was in much pain from it, but he
22161: was no further hurt, and Fred placed him on the horse that he might
22162: ride to Yoddrell’s and be taken care of there.
22163: 
22164: “Let them put the horse in the stable, and tell the surveyors they can
22165: come back for their traps,” said Fred. “The ground is clear now.”
22166: 
22167: “No, no,” said Caleb, “here’s a breakage. They’ll have to give up for
22168: to-day, and it will be as well. Here, take the things before you on the
22169: horse, Tom. They’ll see you coming, and they’ll turn back.”
22170: 
22171: “I’m glad I happened to be here at the right moment, Mr. Garth,” said
22172: Fred, as Tom rode away. “No knowing what might have happened if the
22173: cavalry had not come up in time.”
22174: 
22175: “Ay, ay, it was lucky,” said Caleb, speaking rather absently, and
22176: looking towards the spot where he had been at work at the moment of
22177: interruption. “But—deuce take it—this is what comes of men being
22178: fools—I’m hindered of my day’s work. I can’t get along without somebody
22179: to help me with the measuring-chain. However!” He was beginning to move
22180: towards the spot with a look of vexation, as if he had forgotten Fred’s
22181: presence, but suddenly he turned round and said quickly, “What have you
22182: got to do to-day, young fellow?”
22183: 
22184: “Nothing, Mr. Garth. I’ll help you with pleasure—can I?” said Fred,
22185: with a sense that he should be courting Mary when he was helping her
22186: father.
22187: 
22188: “Well, you mustn’t mind stooping and getting hot.”
22189: 
22190: “I don’t mind anything. Only I want to go first and have a round with
22191: that hulky fellow who turned to challenge me. It would be a good lesson
22192: for him. I shall not be five minutes.”
22193: 
22194: “Nonsense!” said Caleb, with his most peremptory intonation. “I shall
22195: go and speak to the men myself. It’s all ignorance. Somebody has been
22196: telling them lies. The poor fools don’t know any better.”
22197: 
22198: “I shall go with you, then,” said Fred.
22199: 
22200: “No, no; stay where you are. I don’t want your young blood. I can take
22201: care of myself.”
22202: 
22203: Caleb was a powerful man and knew little of any fear except the fear of
22204: hurting others and the fear of having to speechify. But he felt it his
22205: duty at this moment to try and give a little harangue. There was a
22206: striking mixture in him—which came from his having always been a
22207: hard-working man himself—of rigorous notions about workmen and
22208: practical indulgence towards them. To do a good day’s work and to do it
22209: well, he held to be part of their welfare, as it was the chief part of
22210: his own happiness; but he had a strong sense of fellowship with them.
22211: When he advanced towards the laborers they had not gone to work again,
22212: but were standing in that form of rural grouping which consists in each
22213: turning a shoulder towards the other, at a distance of two or three
22214: yards. They looked rather sulkily at Caleb, who walked quickly with one
22215: hand in his pocket and the other thrust between the buttons of his
22216: waistcoat, and had his every-day mild air when he paused among them.
22217: 
22218: “Why, my lads, how’s this?” he began, taking as usual to brief phrases,
22219: which seemed pregnant to himself, because he had many thoughts lying
22220: under them, like the abundant roots of a plant that just manages to
22221: peep above the water. “How came you to make such a mistake as this?
22222: Somebody has been telling you lies. You thought those men up there
22223: wanted to do mischief.”
22224: 
22225: “Aw!” was the answer, dropped at intervals by each according to his
22226: degree of unreadiness.
22227: 
22228: “Nonsense! No such thing! They’re looking out to see which way the
22229: railroad is to take. Now, my lads, you can’t hinder the railroad: it
22230: will be made whether you like it or not. And if you go fighting against
22231: it, you’ll get yourselves into trouble. The law gives those men leave
22232: to come here on the land. The owner has nothing to say against it, and
22233: if you meddle with them you’ll have to do with the constable and
22234: Justice Blakesley, and with the handcuffs and Middlemarch jail. And you
22235: might be in for it now, if anybody informed against you.”
22236: 
22237: Caleb paused here, and perhaps the greatest orator could not have
22238: chosen either his pause or his images better for the occasion.
22239: 
22240: “But come, you didn’t mean any harm. Somebody told you the railroad was
22241: a bad thing. That was a lie. It may do a bit of harm here and there, to
22242: this and to that; and so does the sun in heaven. But the railway’s a
22243: good thing.”
22244: 
22245: “Aw! good for the big folks to make money out on,” said old Timothy
22246: Cooper, who had stayed behind turning his hay while the others had been
22247: gone on their spree;—“I’n seen lots o’ things turn up sin’ I war a
22248: young un—the war an’ the peace, and the canells, an’ the oald King
22249: George, an’ the Regen’, an’ the new King George, an’ the new un as has
22250: got a new ne-ame—an’ it’s been all aloike to the poor mon. What’s the
22251: canells been t’ him? They’n brought him neyther me-at nor be-acon, nor
22252: wage to lay by, if he didn’t save it wi’ clemmin’ his own inside. Times
22253: ha’ got wusser for him sin’ I war a young un. An’ so it’ll be wi’ the
22254: railroads. They’ll on’y leave the poor mon furder behind. But them are
22255: fools as meddle, and so I told the chaps here. This is the big folks’s
22256: world, this is. But yo’re for the big folks, Muster Garth, yo are.”
22257: 
22258: Timothy was a wiry old laborer, of a type lingering in those times—who
22259: had his savings in a stocking-foot, lived in a lone cottage, and was
22260: not to be wrought on by any oratory, having as little of the feudal
22261: spirit, and believing as little, as if he had not been totally
22262: unacquainted with the Age of Reason and the Rights of Man. Caleb was in
22263: a difficulty known to any person attempting in dark times and
22264: unassisted by miracle to reason with rustics who are in possession of
22265: an undeniable truth which they know through a hard process of feeling,
22266: and can let it fall like a giant’s club on your neatly carved argument
22267: for a social benefit which they do not feel. Caleb had no cant at
22268: command, even if he could have chosen to use it; and he had been
22269: accustomed to meet all such difficulties in no other way than by doing
22270: his “business” faithfully. He answered—
22271: 
22272: “If you don’t think well of me, Tim, never mind; that’s neither here
22273: nor there now. Things may be bad for the poor man—bad they are; but I
22274: want the lads here not to do what will make things worse for
22275: themselves. The cattle may have a heavy load, but it won’t help ’em to
22276: throw it over into the roadside pit, when it’s partly their own
22277: fodder.”
22278: 
22279: “We war on’y for a bit o’ foon,” said Hiram, who was beginning to see
22280: consequences. “That war all we war arter.”
22281: 
22282: “Well, promise me not to meddle again, and I’ll see that nobody informs
22283: against you.”
22284: 
22285: “I’n ne’er meddled, an’ I’n no call to promise,” said Timothy.
22286: 
22287: “No, but the rest. Come, I’m as hard at work as any of you to-day, and
22288: I can’t spare much time. Say you’ll be quiet without the constable.”
22289: 
22290: “Aw, we wooant meddle—they may do as they loike for oos”—were the forms
22291: in which Caleb got his pledges; and then he hastened back to Fred, who
22292: had followed him, and watched him in the gateway.
22293: 
22294: They went to work, and Fred helped vigorously. His spirits had risen,
22295: and he heartily enjoyed a good slip in the moist earth under the
22296: hedgerow, which soiled his perfect summer trousers. Was it his
22297: successful onset which had elated him, or the satisfaction of helping
22298: Mary’s father? Something more. The accidents of the morning had helped
22299: his frustrated imagination to shape an employment for himself which had
22300: several attractions. I am not sure that certain fibres in Mr. Garth’s
22301: mind had not resumed their old vibration towards the very end which now
22302: revealed itself to Fred. For the effective accident is but the touch of
22303: fire where there is oil and tow; and it always appeared to Fred that
22304: the railway brought the needed touch. But they went on in silence
22305: except when their business demanded speech. At last, when they had
22306: finished and were walking away, Mr. Garth said—
22307: 
22308: “A young fellow needn’t be a B. A. to do this sort of work, eh, Fred?”
22309: 
22310: “I wish I had taken to it before I had thought of being a B. A.,” said
22311: Fred. He paused a moment, and then added, more hesitatingly, “Do you
22312: think I am too old to learn your business, Mr. Garth?”
22313: 
22314: “My business is of many sorts, my boy,” said Mr. Garth, smiling. “A
22315: good deal of what I know can only come from experience: you can’t learn
22316: it off as you learn things out of a book. But you are young enough to
22317: lay a foundation yet.” Caleb pronounced the last sentence emphatically,
22318: but paused in some uncertainty. He had been under the impression lately
22319: that Fred had made up his mind to enter the Church.
22320: 
22321: “You do think I could do some good at it, if I were to try?” said Fred,
22322: more eagerly.
22323: 
22324: “That depends,” said Caleb, turning his head on one side and lowering
22325: his voice, with the air of a man who felt himself to be saying
22326: something deeply religious. “You must be sure of two things: you must
22327: love your work, and not be always looking over the edge of it, wanting
22328: your play to begin. And the other is, you must not be ashamed of your
22329: work, and think it would be more honorable to you to be doing something
22330: else. You must have a pride in your own work and in learning to do it
22331: well, and not be always saying, There’s this and there’s that—if I had
22332: this or that to do, I might make something of it. No matter what a man
22333: is—I wouldn’t give twopence for him”—here Caleb’s mouth looked bitter,
22334: and he snapped his fingers—“whether he was the prime minister or the
22335: rick-thatcher, if he didn’t do well what he undertook to do.”
22336: 
22337: “I can never feel that I should do that in being a clergyman,” said
22338: Fred, meaning to take a step in argument.
22339: 
22340: “Then let it alone, my boy,” said Caleb, abruptly, “else you’ll never
22341: be easy. Or, if you _are_ easy, you’ll be a poor stick.”
22342: 
22343: “That is very nearly what Mary thinks about it,” said Fred, coloring.
22344: “I think you must know what I feel for Mary, Mr. Garth: I hope it does
22345: not displease you that I have always loved her better than any one
22346: else, and that I shall never love any one as I love her.”
22347: 
22348: The expression of Caleb’s face was visibly softening while Fred spoke.
22349: But he swung his head with a solemn slowness, and said—
22350: 
22351: “That makes things more serious, Fred, if you want to take Mary’s
22352: happiness into your keeping.”
22353: 
22354: “I know that, Mr. Garth,” said Fred, eagerly, “and I would do anything
22355: for _her_. She says she will never have me if I go into the Church; and
22356: I shall be the most miserable devil in the world if I lose all hope of
22357: Mary. Really, if I could get some other profession, business—anything
22358: that I am at all fit for, I would work hard, I would deserve your good
22359: opinion. I should like to have to do with outdoor things. I know a good
22360: deal about land and cattle already. I used to believe, you know—though
22361: you will think me rather foolish for it—that I should have land of my
22362: own. I am sure knowledge of that sort would come easily to me,
22363: especially if I could be under you in any way.”
22364: 
22365: “Softly, my boy,” said Caleb, having the image of “Susan” before his
22366: eyes. “What have you said to your father about all this?”
22367: 
22368: “Nothing, yet; but I must tell him. I am only waiting to know what I
22369: can do instead of entering the Church. I am very sorry to disappoint
22370: him, but a man ought to be allowed to judge for himself when he is
22371: four-and-twenty. How could I know when I was fifteen, what it would be
22372: right for me to do now? My education was a mistake.”
22373: 
22374: “But hearken to this, Fred,” said Caleb. “Are you sure Mary is fond of
22375: you, or would ever have you?”
22376: 
22377: “I asked Mr. Farebrother to talk to her, because she had forbidden me—I
22378: didn’t know what else to do,” said Fred, apologetically. “And he says
22379: that I have every reason to hope, if I can put myself in an honorable
22380: position—I mean, out of the Church. I dare say you think it
22381: unwarrantable in me, Mr. Garth, to be troubling you and obtruding my
22382: own wishes about Mary, before I have done anything at all for myself.
22383: Of course I have not the least claim—indeed, I have already a debt to
22384: you which will never be discharged, even when I have been able to pay
22385: it in the shape of money.”
22386: 
22387: “Yes, my boy, you have a claim,” said Caleb, with much feeling in his
22388: voice. “The young ones have always a claim on the old to help them
22389: forward. I was young myself once and had to do without much help; but
22390: help would have been welcome to me, if it had been only for the
22391: fellow-feeling’s sake. But I must consider. Come to me to-morrow at the
22392: office, at nine o’clock. At the office, mind.”
22393: 
22394: Mr. Garth would take no important step without consulting Susan, but it
22395: must be confessed that before he reached home he had taken his
22396: resolution. With regard to a large number of matters about which other
22397: men are decided or obstinate, he was the most easily manageable man in
22398: the world. He never knew what meat he would choose, and if Susan had
22399: said that they ought to live in a four-roomed cottage, in order to
22400: save, he would have said, “Let us go,” without inquiring into details.
22401: But where Caleb’s feeling and judgment strongly pronounced, he was a
22402: ruler; and in spite of his mildness and timidity in reproving, every
22403: one about him knew that on the exceptional occasions when he chose, he
22404: was absolute. He never, indeed, chose to be absolute except on some one
22405: else’s behalf. On ninety-nine points Mrs. Garth decided, but on the
22406: hundredth she was often aware that she would have to perform the
22407: singularly difficult task of carrying out her own principle, and to
22408: make herself subordinate.
22409: 
22410: “It is come round as I thought, Susan,” said Caleb, when they were
22411: seated alone in the evening. He had already narrated the adventure
22412: which had brought about Fred’s sharing in his work, but had kept back
22413: the further result. “The children _are_ fond of each other—I mean, Fred
22414: and Mary.”
22415: 
22416: Mrs. Garth laid her work on her knee, and fixed her penetrating eyes
22417: anxiously on her husband.
22418: 
22419: “After we’d done our work, Fred poured it all out to me. He can’t bear
22420: to be a clergyman, and Mary says she won’t have him if he is one; and
22421: the lad would like to be under me and give his mind to business. And
22422: I’ve determined to take him and make a man of him.”
22423: 
22424: “Caleb!” said Mrs. Garth, in a deep contralto, expressive of resigned
22425: astonishment.
22426: 
22427: “It’s a fine thing to do,” said Mr. Garth, settling himself firmly
22428: against the back of his chair, and grasping the elbows. “I shall have
22429: trouble with him, but I think I shall carry it through. The lad loves
22430: Mary, and a true love for a good woman is a great thing, Susan. It
22431: shapes many a rough fellow.”
22432: 
22433: “Has Mary spoken to you on the subject?” said Mrs Garth, secretly a
22434: little hurt that she had to be informed on it herself.
22435: 
22436: “Not a word. I asked her about Fred once; I gave her a bit of a
22437: warning. But she assured me she would never marry an idle
22438: self-indulgent man—nothing since. But it seems Fred set on Mr.
22439: Farebrother to talk to her, because she had forbidden him to speak
22440: himself, and Mr. Farebrother has found out that she is fond of Fred,
22441: but says he must not be a clergyman. Fred’s heart is fixed on Mary,
22442: that I can see: it gives me a good opinion of the lad—and we always
22443: liked him, Susan.”
22444: 
22445: “It is a pity for Mary, I think,” said Mrs. Garth.
22446: 
22447: “Why—a pity?”
22448: 
22449: “Because, Caleb, she might have had a man who is worth twenty Fred
22450: Vincy’s.”
22451: 
22452: “Ah?” said Caleb, with surprise.
22453: 
22454: “I firmly believe that Mr. Farebrother is attached to her, and meant to
22455: make her an offer; but of course, now that Fred has used him as an
22456: envoy, there is an end to that better prospect.” There was a severe
22457: precision in Mrs. Garth’s utterance. She was vexed and disappointed,
22458: but she was bent on abstaining from useless words.
22459: 
22460: Caleb was silent a few moments under a conflict of feelings. He looked
22461: at the floor and moved his head and hands in accompaniment to some
22462: inward argumentation. At last he said—
22463: 
22464: “That would have made me very proud and happy, Susan, and I should have
22465: been glad for your sake. I’ve always felt that your belongings have
22466: never been on a level with you. But you took me, though I was a plain
22467: man.”
22468: 
22469: “I took the best and cleverest man I had ever known,” said Mrs. Garth,
22470: convinced that _she_ would never have loved any one who came short of
22471: that mark.
22472: 
22473: “Well, perhaps others thought you might have done better. But it would
22474: have been worse for me. And that is what touches me close about Fred.
22475: The lad is good at bottom, and clever enough to do, if he’s put in the
22476: right way; and he loves and honors my daughter beyond anything, and she
22477: has given him a sort of promise according to what he turns out. I say,
22478: that young man’s soul is in my hand; and I’ll do the best I can for
22479: him, so help me God! It’s my duty, Susan.”
22480: 
22481: Mrs. Garth was not given to tears, but there was a large one rolling
22482: down her face before her husband had finished. It came from the
22483: pressure of various feelings, in which there was much affection and
22484: some vexation. She wiped it away quickly, saying—
22485: 
22486: “Few men besides you would think it a duty to add to their anxieties in
22487: that way, Caleb.”
22488: 
22489: “That signifies nothing—what other men would think. I’ve got a clear
22490: feeling inside me, and that I shall follow; and I hope your heart will
22491: go with me, Susan, in making everything as light as can be to Mary,
22492: poor child.”
22493: 
22494: Caleb, leaning back in his chair, looked with anxious appeal towards
22495: his wife. She rose and kissed him, saying, “God bless you, Caleb! Our
22496: children have a good father.”
22497: 
22498: But she went out and had a hearty cry to make up for the suppression of
22499: her words. She felt sure that her husband’s conduct would be
22500: misunderstood, and about Fred she was rational and unhopeful. Which
22501: would turn out to have the more foresight in it—her rationality or
22502: Caleb’s ardent generosity?
22503: 
22504: When Fred went to the office the next morning, there was a test to be
22505: gone through which he was not prepared for.
22506: 
22507: “Now Fred,” said Caleb, “you will have some desk-work. I have always
22508: done a good deal of writing myself, but I can’t do without help, and as
22509: I want you to understand the accounts and get the values into your
22510: head, I mean to do without another clerk. So you must buckle to. How
22511: are you at writing and arithmetic?”
22512: 
22513: Fred felt an awkward movement of the heart; he had not thought of
22514: desk-work; but he was in a resolute mood, and not going to shrink. “I’m
22515: not afraid of arithmetic, Mr. Garth: it always came easily to me. I
22516: think you know my writing.”
22517: 
22518: “Let us see,” said Caleb, taking up a pen, examining it carefully and
22519: handing it, well dipped, to Fred with a sheet of ruled paper. “Copy me
22520: a line or two of that valuation, with the figures at the end.”
22521: 
22522: At that time the opinion existed that it was beneath a gentleman to
22523: write legibly, or with a hand in the least suitable to a clerk. Fred
22524: wrote the lines demanded in a hand as gentlemanly as that of any
22525: viscount or bishop of the day: the vowels were all alike and the
22526: consonants only distinguishable as turning up or down, the strokes had
22527: a blotted solidity and the letters disdained to keep the line—in short,
22528: it was a manuscript of that venerable kind easy to interpret when you
22529: know beforehand what the writer means.
22530: 
22531: As Caleb looked on, his visage showed a growing depression, but when
22532: Fred handed him the paper he gave something like a snarl, and rapped
22533: the paper passionately with the back of his hand. Bad work like this
22534: dispelled all Caleb’s mildness.
22535: 
22536: “The deuce!” he exclaimed, snarlingly. “To think that this is a country
22537: where a man’s education may cost hundreds and hundreds, and it turns
22538: you out this!” Then in a more pathetic tone, pushing up his spectacles
22539: and looking at the unfortunate scribe, “The Lord have mercy on us,
22540: Fred, I can’t put up with this!”
22541: 
22542: “What can I do, Mr. Garth?” said Fred, whose spirits had sunk very low,
22543: not only at the estimate of his handwriting, but at the vision of
22544: himself as liable to be ranked with office clerks.
22545: 
22546: “Do? Why, you must learn to form your letters and keep the line. What’s
22547: the use of writing at all if nobody can understand it?” asked Caleb,
22548: energetically, quite preoccupied with the bad quality of the work. “Is
22549: there so little business in the world that you must be sending puzzles
22550: over the country? But that’s the way people are brought up. I should
22551: lose no end of time with the letters some people send me, if Susan did
22552: not make them out for me. It’s disgusting.” Here Caleb tossed the paper
22553: from him.
22554: 
22555: Any stranger peeping into the office at that moment might have wondered
22556: what was the drama between the indignant man of business, and the
22557: fine-looking young fellow whose blond complexion was getting rather
22558: patchy as he bit his lip with mortification. Fred was struggling with
22559: many thoughts. Mr. Garth had been so kind and encouraging at the
22560: beginning of their interview, that gratitude and hopefulness had been
22561: at a high pitch, and the downfall was proportionate. He had not thought
22562: of desk-work—in fact, like the majority of young gentlemen, he wanted
22563: an occupation which should be free from disagreeables. I cannot tell
22564: what might have been the consequences if he had not distinctly promised
22565: himself that he would go to Lowick to see Mary and tell her that he was
22566: engaged to work under her father. He did not like to disappoint himself
22567: there.
22568: 
22569: “I am very sorry,” were all the words that he could muster. But Mr.
22570: Garth was already relenting.
22571: 
22572: “We must make the best of it, Fred,” he began, with a return to his
22573: usual quiet tone. “Every man can learn to write. I taught myself. Go at
22574: it with a will, and sit up at night if the day-time isn’t enough. We’ll
22575: be patient, my boy. Callum shall go on with the books for a bit, while
22576: you are learning. But now I must be off,” said Caleb, rising. “You must
22577: let your father know our agreement. You’ll save me Callum’s salary, you
22578: know, when you can write; and I can afford to give you eighty pounds
22579: for the first year, and more after.”
22580: 
22581: When Fred made the necessary disclosure to his parents, the relative
22582: effect on the two was a surprise which entered very deeply into his
22583: memory. He went straight from Mr. Garth’s office to the warehouse,
22584: rightly feeling that the most respectful way in which he could behave
22585: to his father was to make the painful communication as gravely and
22586: formally as possible. Moreover, the decision would be more certainly
22587: understood to be final, if the interview took place in his father’s
22588: gravest hours, which were always those spent in his private room at the
22589: warehouse.
22590: 
22591: Fred entered on the subject directly, and declared briefly what he had
22592: done and was resolved to do, expressing at the end his regret that he
22593: should be the cause of disappointment to his father, and taking the
22594: blame on his own deficiencies. The regret was genuine, and inspired
22595: Fred with strong, simple words.
22596: 
22597: Mr. Vincy listened in profound surprise without uttering even an
22598: exclamation, a silence which in his impatient temperament was a sign of
22599: unusual emotion. He had not been in good spirits about trade that
22600: morning, and the slight bitterness in his lips grew intense as he
22601: listened. When Fred had ended, there was a pause of nearly a minute,
22602: during which Mr. Vincy replaced a book in his desk and turned the key
22603: emphatically. Then he looked at his son steadily, and said—
22604: 
22605: “So you’ve made up your mind at last, sir?”
22606: 
22607: “Yes, father.”
22608: 
22609: “Very well; stick to it. I’ve no more to say. You’ve thrown away your
22610: education, and gone down a step in life, when I had given you the means
22611: of rising, that’s all.”
22612: 
22613: “I am very sorry that we differ, father. I think I can be quite as much
22614: of a gentleman at the work I have undertaken, as if I had been a
22615: curate. But I am grateful to you for wishing to do the best for me.”
22616: 
22617: “Very well; I have no more to say. I wash my hands of you. I only hope,
22618: when you have a son of your own he will make a better return for the
22619: pains you spend on him.”
22620: 
22621: This was very cutting to Fred. His father was using that unfair
22622: advantage possessed by us all when we are in a pathetic situation and
22623: see our own past as if it were simply part of the pathos. In reality,
22624: Mr. Vincy’s wishes about his son had had a great deal of pride,
22625: inconsiderateness, and egoistic folly in them. But still the
22626: disappointed father held a strong lever; and Fred felt as if he were
22627: being banished with a malediction.
22628: 
22629: “I hope you will not object to my remaining at home, sir?” he said,
22630: after rising to go; “I shall have a sufficient salary to pay for my
22631: board, as of course I should wish to do.”
22632: 
22633: “Board be hanged!” said Mr. Vincy, recovering himself in his disgust at
22634: the notion that Fred’s keep would be missed at his table. “Of course
22635: your mother will want you to stay. But I shall keep no horse for you,
22636: you understand; and you will pay your own tailor. You will do with a
22637: suit or two less, I fancy, when you have to pay for ’em.”
22638: 
22639: Fred lingered; there was still something to be said. At last it came.
22640: 
22641: “I hope you will shake hands with me, father, and forgive me the
22642: vexation I have caused you.”
22643: 
22644: Mr. Vincy from his chair threw a quick glance upward at his son, who
22645: had advanced near to him, and then gave his hand, saying hurriedly,
22646: “Yes, yes, let us say no more.”
22647: 
22648: Fred went through much more narrative and explanation with his mother,
22649: but she was inconsolable, having before her eyes what perhaps her
22650: husband had never thought of, the certainty that Fred would marry Mary
22651: Garth, that her life would henceforth be spoiled by a perpetual
22652: infusion of Garths and their ways, and that her darling boy, with his
22653: beautiful face and stylish air “beyond anybody else’s son in
22654: Middlemarch,” would be sure to get like that family in plainness of
22655: appearance and carelessness about his clothes. To her it seemed that
22656: there was a Garth conspiracy to get possession of the desirable Fred,
22657: but she dared not enlarge on this opinion, because a slight hint of it
22658: had made him “fly out” at her as he had never done before. Her temper
22659: was too sweet for her to show any anger, but she felt that her
22660: happiness had received a bruise, and for several days merely to look at
22661: Fred made her cry a little as if he were the subject of some baleful
22662: prophecy. Perhaps she was the slower to recover her usual cheerfulness
22663: because Fred had warned her that she must not reopen the sore question
22664: with his father, who had accepted his decision and forgiven him. If her
22665: husband had been vehement against Fred, she would have been urged into
22666: defence of her darling. It was the end of the fourth day when Mr. Vincy
22667: said to her—
22668: 
22669: “Come, Lucy, my dear, don’t be so down-hearted. You always have spoiled
22670: the boy, and you must go on spoiling him.”
22671: 
22672: “Nothing ever did cut me so before, Vincy,” said the wife, her fair
22673: throat and chin beginning to tremble again, “only his illness.”
22674: 
22675: “Pooh, pooh, never mind! We must expect to have trouble with our
22676: children. Don’t make it worse by letting me see you out of spirits.”
22677: 
22678: “Well, I won’t,” said Mrs. Vincy, roused by this appeal and adjusting
22679: herself with a little shake as of a bird which lays down its ruffled
22680: plumage.
22681: 
22682: “It won’t do to begin making a fuss about one,” said Mr. Vincy, wishing
22683: to combine a little grumbling with domestic cheerfulness. “There’s
22684: Rosamond as well as Fred.”
22685: 
22686: “Yes, poor thing. I’m sure I felt for her being disappointed of her
22687: baby; but she got over it nicely.”
22688: 
22689: “Baby, pooh! I can see Lydgate is making a mess of his practice, and
22690: getting into debt too, by what I hear. I shall have Rosamond coming to
22691: me with a pretty tale one of these days. But they’ll get no money from
22692: me, I know. Let _his_ family help him. I never did like that marriage.
22693: But it’s no use talking. Ring the bell for lemons, and don’t look dull
22694: any more, Lucy. I’ll drive you and Louisa to Riverston to-morrow.”
22695: 
22696: 
22697: 
22698: 
22699: CHAPTER LVII.
22700: 
22701: They numbered scarce eight summers when a name
22702:     Rose on their souls and stirred such motions there
22703: As thrill the buds and shape their hidden frame
22704:     At penetration of the quickening air:
22705: His name who told of loyal Evan Dhu,
22706:     Of quaint Bradwardine, and Vich Ian Vor,
22707: Making the little world their childhood knew
22708:     Large with a land of mountain lake and scaur,
22709: And larger yet with wonder, love, belief
22710:     Toward Walter Scott who living far away
22711: Sent them this wealth of joy and noble grief.
22712:     The book and they must part, but day by day,
22713:         In lines that thwart like portly spiders ran
22714:         They wrote the tale, from Tully Veolan.
22715: 
22716: 
22717: The evening that Fred Vincy walked to Lowick parsonage (he had begun to
22718: see that this was a world in which even a spirited young man must
22719: sometimes walk for want of a horse to carry him) he set out at five
22720: o’clock and called on Mrs. Garth by the way, wishing to assure himself
22721: that she accepted their new relations willingly.
22722: 
22723: He found the family group, dogs and cats included, under the great
22724: apple-tree in the orchard. It was a festival with Mrs. Garth, for her
22725: eldest son, Christy, her peculiar joy and pride, had come home for a
22726: short holiday—Christy, who held it the most desirable thing in the
22727: world to be a tutor, to study all literatures and be a regenerate
22728: Porson, and who was an incorporate criticism on poor Fred, a sort of
22729: object-lesson given to him by the educational mother. Christy himself,
22730: a square-browed, broad-shouldered masculine edition of his mother not
22731: much higher than Fred’s shoulder—which made it the harder that he
22732: should be held superior—was always as simple as possible, and thought
22733: no more of Fred’s disinclination to scholarship than of a giraffe’s,
22734: wishing that he himself were more of the same height. He was lying on
22735: the ground now by his mother’s chair, with his straw hat laid flat over
22736: his eyes, while Jim on the other side was reading aloud from that
22737: beloved writer who has made a chief part in the happiness of many young
22738: lives. The volume was “Ivanhoe,” and Jim was in the great archery scene
22739: at the tournament, but suffered much interruption from Ben, who had
22740: fetched his own old bow and arrows, and was making himself dreadfully
22741: disagreeable, Letty thought, by begging all present to observe his
22742: random shots, which no one wished to do except Brownie, the
22743: active-minded but probably shallow mongrel, while the grizzled
22744: Newfoundland lying in the sun looked on with the dull-eyed neutrality
22745: of extreme old age. Letty herself, showing as to her mouth and pinafore
22746: some slight signs that she had been assisting at the gathering of the
22747: cherries which stood in a coral-heap on the tea-table, was now seated
22748: on the grass, listening open-eyed to the reading.
22749: 
22750: But the centre of interest was changed for all by the arrival of Fred
22751: Vincy. When, seating himself on a garden-stool, he said that he was on
22752: his way to Lowick Parsonage, Ben, who had thrown down his bow, and
22753: snatched up a reluctant half-grown kitten instead, strode across Fred’s
22754: outstretched leg, and said “Take me!”
22755: 
22756: “Oh, and me too,” said Letty.
22757: 
22758: “You can’t keep up with Fred and me,” said Ben.
22759: 
22760: “Yes, I can. Mother, please say that I am to go,” urged Letty, whose
22761: life was much checkered by resistance to her depreciation as a girl.
22762: 
22763: “I shall stay with Christy,” observed Jim; as much as to say that he
22764: had the advantage of those simpletons; whereupon Letty put her hand up
22765: to her head and looked with jealous indecision from the one to the
22766: other.
22767: 
22768: “Let us all go and see Mary,” said Christy, opening his arms.
22769: 
22770: “No, my dear child, we must not go in a swarm to the parsonage. And
22771: that old Glasgow suit of yours would never do. Besides, your father
22772: will come home. We must let Fred go alone. He can tell Mary that you
22773: are here, and she will come back to-morrow.”
22774: 
22775: Christy glanced at his own threadbare knees, and then at Fred’s
22776: beautiful white trousers. Certainly Fred’s tailoring suggested the
22777: advantages of an English university, and he had a graceful way even of
22778: looking warm and of pushing his hair back with his handkerchief.
22779: 
22780: “Children, run away,” said Mrs. Garth; “it is too warm to hang about
22781: your friends. Take your brother and show him the rabbits.”
22782: 
22783: The eldest understood, and led off the children immediately. Fred felt
22784: that Mrs. Garth wished to give him an opportunity of saying anything he
22785: had to say, but he could only begin by observing—
22786: 
22787: “How glad you must be to have Christy here!”
22788: 
22789: “Yes; he has come sooner than I expected. He got down from the coach at
22790: nine o’clock, just after his father went out. I am longing for Caleb to
22791: come and hear what wonderful progress Christy is making. He has paid
22792: his expenses for the last year by giving lessons, carrying on hard
22793: study at the same time. He hopes soon to get a private tutorship and go
22794: abroad.”
22795: 
22796: “He is a great fellow,” said Fred, to whom these cheerful truths had a
22797: medicinal taste, “and no trouble to anybody.” After a slight pause, he
22798: added, “But I fear you will think that I am going to be a great deal of
22799: trouble to Mr. Garth.”
22800: 
22801: “Caleb likes taking trouble: he is one of those men who always do more
22802: than any one would have thought of asking them to do,” answered Mrs.
22803: Garth. She was knitting, and could either look at Fred or not, as she
22804: chose—always an advantage when one is bent on loading speech with
22805: salutary meaning; and though Mrs. Garth intended to be duly reserved,
22806: she did wish to say something that Fred might be the better for.
22807: 
22808: “I know you think me very undeserving, Mrs. Garth, and with good
22809: reason,” said Fred, his spirit rising a little at the perception of
22810: something like a disposition to lecture him. “I happen to have behaved
22811: just the worst to the people I can’t help wishing for the most from.
22812: But while two men like Mr. Garth and Mr. Farebrother have not given me
22813: up, I don’t see why I should give myself up.” Fred thought it might be
22814: well to suggest these masculine examples to Mrs. Garth.
22815: 
22816: “Assuredly,” said she, with gathering emphasis. “A young man for whom
22817: two such elders had devoted themselves would indeed be culpable if he
22818: threw himself away and made their sacrifices vain.”
22819:
