22820: Fred wondered a little at this strong language, but only said, “I hope
22821: it will not be so with me, Mrs. Garth, since I have some encouragement
22822: to believe that I may win Mary. Mr. Garth has told you about that? You
22823: were not surprised, I dare say?” Fred ended, innocently referring only
22824: to his own love as probably evident enough.
22825: 
22826: “Not surprised that Mary has given you encouragement?” returned Mrs.
22827: Garth, who thought it would be well for Fred to be more alive to the
22828: fact that Mary’s friends could not possibly have wished this
22829: beforehand, whatever the Vincys might suppose. “Yes, I confess I was
22830: surprised.”
22831: 
22832: “She never did give me any—not the least in the world, when I talked to
22833: her myself,” said Fred, eager to vindicate Mary. “But when I asked Mr.
22834: Farebrother to speak for me, she allowed him to tell me there was a
22835: hope.”
22836: 
22837: The power of admonition which had begun to stir in Mrs. Garth had not
22838: yet discharged itself. It was a little too provoking even for _her_
22839: self-control that this blooming youngster should flourish on the
22840: disappointments of sadder and wiser people—making a meal of a
22841: nightingale and never knowing it—and that all the while his family
22842: should suppose that hers was in eager need of this sprig; and her
22843: vexation had fermented the more actively because of its total
22844: repression towards her husband. Exemplary wives will sometimes find
22845: scapegoats in this way. She now said with energetic decision, “You made
22846: a great mistake, Fred, in asking Mr. Farebrother to speak for you.”
22847: 
22848: “Did I?” said Fred, reddening instantaneously. He was alarmed, but at a
22849: loss to know what Mrs. Garth meant, and added, in an apologetic tone,
22850: “Mr. Farebrother has always been such a friend of ours; and Mary, I
22851: knew, would listen to him gravely; and he took it on himself quite
22852: readily.”
22853: 
22854: “Yes, young people are usually blind to everything but their own
22855: wishes, and seldom imagine how much those wishes cost others,” said
22856: Mrs. Garth. She did not mean to go beyond this salutary general
22857: doctrine, and threw her indignation into a needless unwinding of her
22858: worsted, knitting her brow at it with a grand air.
22859: 
22860: “I cannot conceive how it could be any pain to Mr. Farebrother,” said
22861: Fred, who nevertheless felt that surprising conceptions were beginning
22862: to form themselves.
22863: 
22864: “Precisely; you cannot conceive,” said Mrs. Garth, cutting her words as
22865: neatly as possible.
22866: 
22867: For a moment Fred looked at the horizon with a dismayed anxiety, and
22868: then turning with a quick movement said almost sharply—
22869: 
22870: “Do you mean to say, Mrs. Garth, that Mr. Farebrother is in love with
22871: Mary?”
22872: 
22873: “And if it were so, Fred, I think you are the last person who ought to
22874: be surprised,” returned Mrs. Garth, laying her knitting down beside her
22875: and folding her arms. It was an unwonted sign of emotion in her that
22876: she should put her work out of her hands. In fact her feelings were
22877: divided between the satisfaction of giving Fred his discipline and the
22878: sense of having gone a little too far. Fred took his hat and stick and
22879: rose quickly.
22880: 
22881: “Then you think I am standing in his way, and in Mary’s too?” he said,
22882: in a tone which seemed to demand an answer.
22883: 
22884: Mrs. Garth could not speak immediately. She had brought herself into
22885: the unpleasant position of being called on to say what she really felt,
22886: yet what she knew there were strong reasons for concealing. And to her
22887: the consciousness of having exceeded in words was peculiarly
22888: mortifying. Besides, Fred had given out unexpected electricity, and he
22889: now added, “Mr. Garth seemed pleased that Mary should be attached to
22890: me. He could not have known anything of this.”
22891: 
22892: Mrs. Garth felt a severe twinge at this mention of her husband, the
22893: fear that Caleb might think her in the wrong not being easily
22894: endurable. She answered, wanting to check unintended consequences—
22895: 
22896: “I spoke from inference only. I am not aware that Mary knows anything
22897: of the matter.”
22898: 
22899: But she hesitated to beg that he would keep entire silence on a subject
22900: which she had herself unnecessarily mentioned, not being used to stoop
22901: in that way; and while she was hesitating there was already a rush of
22902: unintended consequences under the apple-tree where the tea-things
22903: stood. Ben, bouncing across the grass with Brownie at his heels, and
22904: seeing the kitten dragging the knitting by a lengthening line of wool,
22905: shouted and clapped his hands; Brownie barked, the kitten, desperate,
22906: jumped on the tea-table and upset the milk, then jumped down again and
22907: swept half the cherries with it; and Ben, snatching up the half-knitted
22908: sock-top, fitted it over the kitten’s head as a new source of madness,
22909: while Letty arriving cried out to her mother against this cruelty—it
22910: was a history as full of sensation as “This is the house that Jack
22911: built.” Mrs. Garth was obliged to interfere, the other young ones came
22912: up and the _tête-à-tête_ with Fred was ended. He got away as soon as he
22913: could, and Mrs. Garth could only imply some retractation of her
22914: severity by saying “God bless you” when she shook hands with him.
22915: 
22916: She was unpleasantly conscious that she had been on the verge of
22917: speaking as “one of the foolish women speaketh”—telling first and
22918: entreating silence after. But she had not entreated silence, and to
22919: prevent Caleb’s blame she determined to blame herself and confess all
22920: to him that very night. It was curious what an awful tribunal the mild
22921: Caleb’s was to her, whenever he set it up. But she meant to point out
22922: to him that the revelation might do Fred Vincy a great deal of good.
22923: 
22924: No doubt it was having a strong effect on him as he walked to Lowick.
22925: Fred’s light hopeful nature had perhaps never had so much of a bruise
22926: as from this suggestion that if he had been out of the way Mary might
22927: have made a thoroughly good match. Also he was piqued that he had been
22928: what he called such a stupid lout as to ask that intervention from Mr.
22929: Farebrother. But it was not in a lover’s nature—it was not in Fred’s,
22930: that the new anxiety raised about Mary’s feeling should not surmount
22931: every other. Notwithstanding his trust in Mr. Farebrother’s generosity,
22932: notwithstanding what Mary had said to him, Fred could not help feeling
22933: that he had a rival: it was a new consciousness, and he objected to it
22934: extremely, not being in the least ready to give up Mary for her good,
22935: being ready rather to fight for her with any man whatsoever. But the
22936: fighting with Mr. Farebrother must be of a metaphorical kind, which was
22937: much more difficult to Fred than the muscular. Certainly this
22938: experience was a discipline for Fred hardly less sharp than his
22939: disappointment about his uncle’s will. The iron had not entered into
22940: his soul, but he had begun to imagine what the sharp edge would be. It
22941: did not once occur to Fred that Mrs. Garth might be mistaken about Mr.
22942: Farebrother, but he suspected that she might be wrong about Mary. Mary
22943: had been staying at the parsonage lately, and her mother might know
22944: very little of what had been passing in her mind.
22945: 
22946: He did not feel easier when he found her looking cheerful with the
22947: three ladies in the drawing-room. They were in animated discussion on
22948: some subject which was dropped when he entered, and Mary was copying
22949: the labels from a heap of shallow cabinet drawers, in a minute
22950: handwriting which she was skilled in. Mr. Farebrother was somewhere in
22951: the village, and the three ladies knew nothing of Fred’s peculiar
22952: relation to Mary: it was impossible for either of them to propose that
22953: they should walk round the garden, and Fred predicted to himself that
22954: he should have to go away without saying a word to her in private. He
22955: told her first of Christy’s arrival and then of his own engagement with
22956: her father; and he was comforted by seeing that this latter news
22957: touched her keenly. She said hurriedly, “I am so glad,” and then bent
22958: over her writing to hinder any one from noticing her face. But here was
22959: a subject which Mrs. Farebrother could not let pass.
22960: 
22961: “You don’t mean, my dear Miss Garth, that you are glad to hear of a
22962: young man giving up the Church for which he was educated: you only mean
22963: that things being so, you are glad that he should be under an excellent
22964: man like your father.”
22965: 
22966: “No, really, Mrs. Farebrother, I am glad of both, I fear,” said Mary,
22967: cleverly getting rid of one rebellious tear. “I have a dreadfully
22968: secular mind. I never liked any clergyman except the Vicar of Wakefield
22969: and Mr. Farebrother.”
22970: 
22971: “Now why, my dear?” said Mrs. Farebrother, pausing on her large wooden
22972: knitting-needles and looking at Mary. “You have always a good reason
22973: for your opinions, but this astonishes me. Of course I put out of the
22974: question those who preach new doctrine. But why should you dislike
22975: clergymen?”
22976: 
22977: “Oh dear,” said Mary, her face breaking into merriment as she seemed to
22978: consider a moment, “I don’t like their neckcloths.”
22979: 
22980: “Why, you don’t like Camden’s, then,” said Miss Winifred, in some
22981: anxiety.
22982: 
22983: “Yes, I do,” said Mary. “I don’t like the other clergymen’s neckcloths,
22984: because it is they who wear them.”
22985: 
22986: “How very puzzling!” said Miss Noble, feeling that her own intellect
22987: was probably deficient.
22988: 
22989: “My dear, you are joking. You would have better reasons than these for
22990: slighting so respectable a class of men,” said Mrs. Farebrother,
22991: majestically.
22992: 
22993: “Miss Garth has such severe notions of what people should be that it is
22994: difficult to satisfy her,” said Fred.
22995: 
22996: “Well, I am glad at least that she makes an exception in favor of my
22997: son,” said the old lady.
22998: 
22999: Mary was wondering at Fred’s piqued tone, when Mr. Farebrother came in
23000: and had to hear the news about the engagement under Mr. Garth. At the
23001: end he said with quiet satisfaction, “_That_ is right;” and then bent
23002: to look at Mary’s labels and praise her handwriting. Fred felt horribly
23003: jealous—was glad, of course, that Mr. Farebrother was so estimable, but
23004: wished that he had been ugly and fat as men at forty sometimes are. It
23005: was clear what the end would be, since Mary openly placed Farebrother
23006: above everybody, and these women were all evidently encouraging the
23007: affair. He was feeling sure that he should have no chance of speaking
23008: to Mary, when Mr. Farebrother said—
23009: 
23010: “Fred, help me to carry these drawers back into my study—you have never
23011: seen my fine new study. Pray come too, Miss Garth. I want you to see a
23012: stupendous spider I found this morning.”
23013: 
23014: Mary at once saw the Vicar’s intention. He had never since the
23015: memorable evening deviated from his old pastoral kindness towards her,
23016: and her momentary wonder and doubt had quite gone to sleep. Mary was
23017: accustomed to think rather rigorously of what was probable, and if a
23018: belief flattered her vanity she felt warned to dismiss it as
23019: ridiculous, having early had much exercise in such dismissals. It was
23020: as she had foreseen: when Fred had been asked to admire the fittings of
23021: the study, and she had been asked to admire the spider, Mr. Farebrother
23022: said—
23023: 
23024: “Wait here a minute or two. I am going to look out an engraving which
23025: Fred is tall enough to hang for me. I shall be back in a few minutes.”
23026: And then he went out. Nevertheless, the first word Fred said to Mary
23027: was—
23028: 
23029: “It is of no use, whatever I do, Mary. You are sure to marry
23030: Farebrother at last.” There was some rage in his tone.
23031: 
23032: “What do you mean, Fred?” Mary exclaimed indignantly, blushing deeply,
23033: and surprised out of all her readiness in reply.
23034: 
23035: “It is impossible that you should not see it all clearly enough—you who
23036: see everything.”
23037: 
23038: “I only see that you are behaving very ill, Fred, in speaking so of Mr.
23039: Farebrother after he has pleaded your cause in every way. How can you
23040: have taken up such an idea?”
23041: 
23042: Fred was rather deep, in spite of his irritation. If Mary had really
23043: been unsuspicious, there was no good in telling her what Mrs. Garth had
23044: said.
23045: 
23046: “It follows as a matter of course,” he replied. “When you are
23047: continually seeing a man who beats me in everything, and whom you set
23048: up above everybody, I can have no fair chance.”
23049: 
23050: “You are very ungrateful, Fred,” said Mary. “I wish I had never told
23051: Mr. Farebrother that I cared for you in the least.”
23052: 
23053: “No, I am not ungrateful; I should be the happiest fellow in the world
23054: if it were not for this. I told your father everything, and he was very
23055: kind; he treated me as if I were his son. I could go at the work with a
23056: will, writing and everything, if it were not for this.”
23057: 
23058: “For this? for what?” said Mary, imagining now that something specific
23059: must have been said or done.
23060: 
23061: “This dreadful certainty that I shall be bowled out by Farebrother.”
23062: Mary was appeased by her inclination to laugh.
23063: 
23064: “Fred,” she said, peeping round to catch his eyes, which were sulkily
23065: turned away from her, “you are too delightfully ridiculous. If you were
23066: not such a charming simpleton, what a temptation this would be to play
23067: the wicked coquette, and let you suppose that somebody besides you has
23068: made love to me.”
23069: 
23070: “Do you really like me best, Mary?” said Fred, turning eyes full of
23071: affection on her, and trying to take her hand.
23072: 
23073: “I don’t like you at all at this moment,” said Mary, retreating, and
23074: putting her hands behind her. “I only said that no mortal ever made
23075: love to me besides you. And that is no argument that a very wise man
23076: ever will,” she ended, merrily.
23077: 
23078: “I wish you would tell me that you could not possibly ever think of
23079: him,” said Fred.
23080: 
23081: “Never dare to mention this any more to me, Fred,” said Mary, getting
23082: serious again. “I don’t know whether it is more stupid or ungenerous in
23083: you not to see that Mr. Farebrother has left us together on purpose
23084: that we might speak freely. I am disappointed that you should be so
23085: blind to his delicate feeling.”
23086: 
23087: There was no time to say any more before Mr. Farebrother came back with
23088: the engraving; and Fred had to return to the drawing-room still with a
23089: jealous dread in his heart, but yet with comforting arguments from
23090: Mary’s words and manner. The result of the conversation was on the
23091: whole more painful to Mary: inevitably her attention had taken a new
23092: attitude, and she saw the possibility of new interpretations. She was
23093: in a position in which she seemed to herself to be slighting Mr.
23094: Farebrother, and this, in relation to a man who is much honored, is
23095: always dangerous to the firmness of a grateful woman. To have a reason
23096: for going home the next day was a relief, for Mary earnestly desired to
23097: be always clear that she loved Fred best. When a tender affection has
23098: been storing itself in us through many of our years, the idea that we
23099: could accept any exchange for it seems to be a cheapening of our lives.
23100: And we can set a watch over our affections and our constancy as we can
23101: over other treasures.
23102: 
23103: “Fred has lost all his other expectations; he must keep this,” Mary
23104: said to herself, with a smile curling her lips. It was impossible to
23105: help fleeting visions of another kind—new dignities and an acknowledged
23106: value of which she had often felt the absence. But these things with
23107: Fred outside them, Fred forsaken and looking sad for the want of her,
23108: could never tempt her deliberate thought.
23109: 
23110: 
23111: 
23112: 
23113: CHAPTER LVIII.
23114: 
23115: “For there can live no hatred in thine eye,
23116: Therefore in that I cannot know thy change:
23117: In many’s looks the false heart’s history
23118: Is writ in moods and frowns and wrinkles strange:
23119: But Heaven in thy creation did decree
23120: That in thy face sweet love should ever dwell:
23121: Whate’er thy thoughts or thy heart’s workings be
23122: Thy looks should nothing thence but sweetness tell.”
23123: —SHAKESPEARE: _Sonnets_.
23124: 
23125: 
23126: At the time when Mr. Vincy uttered that presentiment about Rosamond,
23127: she herself had never had the idea that she should be driven to make
23128: the sort of appeal which he foresaw. She had not yet had any anxiety
23129: about ways and means, although her domestic life had been expensive as
23130: well as eventful. Her baby had been born prematurely, and all the
23131: embroidered robes and caps had to be laid by in darkness. This
23132: misfortune was attributed entirely to her having persisted in going out
23133: on horseback one day when her husband had desired her not to do so; but
23134: it must not be supposed that she had shown temper on the occasion, or
23135: rudely told him that she would do as she liked.
23136: 
23137: What led her particularly to desire horse-exercise was a visit from
23138: Captain Lydgate, the baronet’s third son, who, I am sorry to say, was
23139: detested by our Tertius of that name as a vapid fop “parting his hair
23140: from brow to nape in a despicable fashion” (not followed by Tertius
23141: himself), and showing an ignorant security that he knew the proper
23142: thing to say on every topic. Lydgate inwardly cursed his own folly that
23143: he had drawn down this visit by consenting to go to his uncle’s on the
23144: wedding-tour, and he made himself rather disagreeable to Rosamond by
23145: saying so in private. For to Rosamond this visit was a source of
23146: unprecedented but gracefully concealed exultation. She was so intensely
23147: conscious of having a cousin who was a baronet’s son staying in the
23148: house, that she imagined the knowledge of what was implied by his
23149: presence to be diffused through all other minds; and when she
23150: introduced Captain Lydgate to her guests, she had a placid sense that
23151: his rank penetrated them as if it had been an odor. The satisfaction
23152: was enough for the time to melt away some disappointment in the
23153: conditions of marriage with a medical man even of good birth: it seemed
23154: now that her marriage was visibly as well as ideally floating her above
23155: the Middlemarch level, and the future looked bright with letters and
23156: visits to and from Quallingham, and vague advancement in consequence
23157: for Tertius. Especially as, probably at the Captain’s suggestion, his
23158: married sister, Mrs. Mengan, had come with her maid, and stayed two
23159: nights on her way from town. Hence it was clearly worth while for
23160: Rosamond to take pains with her music and the careful selection of her
23161: lace.
23162: 
23163: As to Captain Lydgate himself, his low brow, his aquiline nose bent on
23164: one side, and his rather heavy utterance, might have been
23165: disadvantageous in any young gentleman who had not a military bearing
23166: and mustache to give him what is doted on by some flower-like blond
23167: heads as “style.” He had, moreover, that sort of high-breeding which
23168: consists in being free from the petty solicitudes of middle-class
23169: gentility, and he was a great critic of feminine charms. Rosamond
23170: delighted in his admiration now even more than she had done at
23171: Quallingham, and he found it easy to spend several hours of the day in
23172: flirting with her. The visit altogether was one of the pleasantest
23173: larks he had ever had, not the less so perhaps because he suspected
23174: that his queer cousin Tertius wished him away: though Lydgate, who
23175: would rather (hyperbolically speaking) have died than have failed in
23176: polite hospitality, suppressed his dislike, and only pretended
23177: generally not to hear what the gallant officer said, consigning the
23178: task of answering him to Rosamond. For he was not at all a jealous
23179: husband, and preferred leaving a feather-headed young gentleman alone
23180: with his wife to bearing him company.
23181: 
23182: “I wish you would talk more to the Captain at dinner, Tertius,” said
23183: Rosamond, one evening when the important guest was gone to Loamford to
23184: see some brother officers stationed there. “You really look so absent
23185: sometimes—you seem to be seeing through his head into something behind
23186: it, instead of looking at him.”
23187: 
23188: “My dear Rosy, you don’t expect me to talk much to such a conceited ass
23189: as that, I hope,” said Lydgate, brusquely. “If he got his head broken,
23190: I might look at it with interest, not before.”
23191: 
23192: “I cannot conceive why you should speak of your cousin so
23193: contemptuously,” said Rosamond, her fingers moving at her work while
23194: she spoke with a mild gravity which had a touch of disdain in it.
23195: 
23196: “Ask Ladislaw if he doesn’t think your Captain the greatest bore he
23197: ever met with. Ladislaw has almost forsaken the house since he came.”
23198: 
23199: Rosamond thought she knew perfectly well why Mr. Ladislaw disliked the
23200: Captain: he was jealous, and she liked his being jealous.
23201: 
23202: “It is impossible to say what will suit eccentric persons,” she
23203: answered, “but in my opinion Captain Lydgate is a thorough gentleman,
23204: and I think you ought not, out of respect to Sir Godwin, to treat him
23205: with neglect.”
23206: 
23207: “No, dear; but we have had dinners for him. And he comes in and goes
23208: out as he likes. He doesn’t want me.”
23209: 
23210: “Still, when he is in the room, you might show him more attention. He
23211: may not be a phoenix of cleverness in your sense; his profession is
23212: different; but it would be all the better for you to talk a little on
23213: his subjects. _I_ think his conversation is quite agreeable. And he is
23214: anything but an unprincipled man.”
23215: 
23216: “The fact is, you would wish me to be a little more like him, Rosy,”
23217: said Lydgate, in a sort of resigned murmur, with a smile which was not
23218: exactly tender, and certainly not merry. Rosamond was silent and did
23219: not smile again; but the lovely curves of her face looked good-tempered
23220: enough without smiling.
23221: 
23222: Those words of Lydgate’s were like a sad milestone marking how far he
23223: had travelled from his old dreamland, in which Rosamond Vincy appeared
23224: to be that perfect piece of womanhood who would reverence her husband’s
23225: mind after the fashion of an accomplished mermaid, using her comb and
23226: looking-glass and singing her song for the relaxation of his adored
23227: wisdom alone. He had begun to distinguish between that imagined
23228: adoration and the attraction towards a man’s talent because it gives
23229: him prestige, and is like an order in his button-hole or an Honorable
23230: before his name.
23231: 
23232: It might have been supposed that Rosamond had travelled too, since she
23233: had found the pointless conversation of Mr. Ned Plymdale perfectly
23234: wearisome; but to most mortals there is a stupidity which is
23235: unendurable and a stupidity which is altogether acceptable—else,
23236: indeed, what would become of social bonds? Captain Lydgate’s stupidity
23237: was delicately scented, carried itself with “style,” talked with a good
23238: accent, and was closely related to Sir Godwin. Rosamond found it quite
23239: agreeable and caught many of its phrases.
23240: 
23241: Therefore since Rosamond, as we know, was fond of horseback, there were
23242: plenty of reasons why she should be tempted to resume her riding when
23243: Captain Lydgate, who had ordered his man with two horses to follow him
23244: and put up at the “Green Dragon,” begged her to go out on the gray
23245: which he warranted to be gentle and trained to carry a lady—indeed, he
23246: had bought it for his sister, and was taking it to Quallingham.
23247: Rosamond went out the first time without telling her husband, and came
23248: back before his return; but the ride had been so thorough a success,
23249: and she declared herself so much the better in consequence, that he was
23250: informed of it with full reliance on his consent that she should go
23251: riding again.
23252: 
23253: On the contrary Lydgate was more than hurt—he was utterly confounded
23254: that she had risked herself on a strange horse without referring the
23255: matter to his wish. After the first almost thundering exclamations of
23256: astonishment, which sufficiently warned Rosamond of what was coming, he
23257: was silent for some moments.
23258: 
23259: “However, you have come back safely,” he said, at last, in a decisive
23260: tone. “You will not go again, Rosy; that is understood. If it were the
23261: quietest, most familiar horse in the world, there would always be the
23262: chance of accident. And you know very well that I wished you to give up
23263: riding the roan on that account.”
23264: 
23265: “But there is the chance of accident indoors, Tertius.”
23266: 
23267: “My darling, don’t talk nonsense,” said Lydgate, in an imploring tone;
23268: “surely I am the person to judge for you. I think it is enough that I
23269: say you are not to go again.”
23270: 
23271: Rosamond was arranging her hair before dinner, and the reflection of
23272: her head in the glass showed no change in its loveliness except a
23273: little turning aside of the long neck. Lydgate had been moving about
23274: with his hands in his pockets, and now paused near her, as if he
23275: awaited some assurance.
23276: 
23277: “I wish you would fasten up my plaits, dear,” said Rosamond, letting
23278: her arms fall with a little sigh, so as to make a husband ashamed of
23279: standing there like a brute. Lydgate had often fastened the plaits
23280: before, being among the deftest of men with his large finely formed
23281: fingers. He swept up the soft festoons of plaits and fastened in the
23282: tall comb (to such uses do men come!); and what could he do then but
23283: kiss the exquisite nape which was shown in all its delicate curves? But
23284: when we do what we have done before, it is often with a difference.
23285: Lydgate was still angry, and had not forgotten his point.
23286: 
23287: “I shall tell the Captain that he ought to have known better than offer
23288: you his horse,” he said, as he moved away.
23289: 
23290: “I beg you will not do anything of the kind, Tertius,” said Rosamond,
23291: looking at him with something more marked than usual in her speech. “It
23292: will be treating me as if I were a child. Promise that you will leave
23293: the subject to me.”
23294: 
23295: There did seem to be some truth in her objection. Lydgate said, “Very
23296: well,” with a surly obedience, and thus the discussion ended with his
23297: promising Rosamond, and not with her promising him.
23298: 
23299: In fact, she had been determined not to promise. Rosamond had that
23300: victorious obstinacy which never wastes its energy in impetuous
23301: resistance. What she liked to do was to her the right thing, and all
23302: her cleverness was directed to getting the means of doing it. She meant
23303: to go out riding again on the gray, and she did go on the next
23304: opportunity of her husband’s absence, not intending that he should know
23305: until it was late enough not to signify to her. The temptation was
23306: certainly great: she was very fond of the exercise, and the
23307: gratification of riding on a fine horse, with Captain Lydgate, Sir
23308: Godwin’s son, on another fine horse by her side, and of being met in
23309: this position by any one but her husband, was something as good as her
23310: dreams before marriage: moreover she was riveting the connection with
23311: the family at Quallingham, which must be a wise thing to do.
23312: 
23313: But the gentle gray, unprepared for the crash of a tree that was being
23314: felled on the edge of Halsell wood, took fright, and caused a worse
23315: fright to Rosamond, leading finally to the loss of her baby. Lydgate
23316: could not show his anger towards her, but he was rather bearish to the
23317: Captain, whose visit naturally soon came to an end.
23318: 
23319: In all future conversations on the subject, Rosamond was mildly certain
23320: that the ride had made no difference, and that if she had stayed at
23321: home the same symptoms would have come on and would have ended in the
23322: same way, because she had felt something like them before.
23323: 
23324: Lydgate could only say, “Poor, poor darling!”—but he secretly wondered
23325: over the terrible tenacity of this mild creature. There was gathering
23326: within him an amazed sense of his powerlessness over Rosamond. His
23327: superior knowledge and mental force, instead of being, as he had
23328: imagined, a shrine to consult on all occasions, was simply set aside on
23329: every practical question. He had regarded Rosamond’s cleverness as
23330: precisely of the receptive kind which became a woman. He was now
23331: beginning to find out what that cleverness was—what was the shape into
23332: which it had run as into a close network aloof and independent. No one
23333: quicker than Rosamond to see causes and effects which lay within the
23334: track of her own tastes and interests: she had seen clearly Lydgate’s
23335: preeminence in Middlemarch society, and could go on imaginatively
23336: tracing still more agreeable social effects when his talent should have
23337: advanced him; but for her, his professional and scientific ambition had
23338: no other relation to these desirable effects than if they had been the
23339: fortunate discovery of an ill-smelling oil. And that oil apart, with
23340: which she had nothing to do, of course she believed in her own opinion
23341: more than she did in his. Lydgate was astounded to find in numberless
23342: trifling matters, as well as in this last serious case of the riding,
23343: that affection did not make her compliant. He had no doubt that the
23344: affection was there, and had no presentiment that he had done anything
23345: to repel it. For his own part he said to himself that he loved her as
23346: tenderly as ever, and could make up his mind to her negations;
23347: but—well! Lydgate was much worried, and conscious of new elements in
23348: his life as noxious to him as an inlet of mud to a creature that has
23349: been used to breathe and bathe and dart after its illuminated prey in
23350: the clearest of waters.
23351: 
23352: Rosamond was soon looking lovelier than ever at her worktable, enjoying
23353: drives in her father’s phaeton and thinking it likely that she might be
23354: invited to Quallingham. She knew that she was a much more exquisite
23355: ornament to the drawing-room there than any daughter of the family, and
23356: in reflecting that the gentlemen were aware of that, did not perhaps
23357: sufficiently consider whether the ladies would be eager to see
23358: themselves surpassed.
23359: 
23360: Lydgate, relieved from anxiety about her, relapsed into what she
23361: inwardly called his moodiness—a name which to her covered his
23362: thoughtful preoccupation with other subjects than herself, as well as
23363: that uneasy look of the brow and distaste for all ordinary things as if
23364: they were mixed with bitter herbs, which really made a sort of
23365: weather-glass to his vexation and foreboding. These latter states of
23366: mind had one cause amongst others, which he had generously but
23367: mistakenly avoided mentioning to Rosamond, lest it should affect her
23368: health and spirits. Between him and her indeed there was that total
23369: missing of each other’s mental track, which is too evidently possible
23370: even between persons who are continually thinking of each other. To
23371: Lydgate it seemed that he had been spending month after month in
23372: sacrificing more than half of his best intent and best power to his
23373: tenderness for Rosamond; bearing her little claims and interruptions
23374: without impatience, and, above all, bearing without betrayal of
23375: bitterness to look through less and less of interfering illusion at the
23376: blank unreflecting surface her mind presented to his ardor for the more
23377: impersonal ends of his profession and his scientific study, an ardor
23378: which he had fancied that the ideal wife must somehow worship as
23379: sublime, though not in the least knowing why. But his endurance was
23380: mingled with a self-discontent which, if we know how to be candid, we
23381: shall confess to make more than half our bitterness under grievances,
23382: wife or husband included. It always remains true that if we had been
23383: greater, circumstance would have been less strong against us. Lydgate
23384: was aware that his concessions to Rosamond were often little more than
23385: the lapse of slackening resolution, the creeping paralysis apt to seize
23386: an enthusiasm which is out of adjustment to a constant portion of our
23387: lives. And on Lydgate’s enthusiasm there was constantly pressing not a
23388: simple weight of sorrow, but the biting presence of a petty degrading
23389: care, such as casts the blight of irony over all higher effort.
23390: 
23391: This was the care which he had hitherto abstained from mentioning to
23392: Rosamond; and he believed, with some wonder, that it had never entered
23393: her mind, though certainly no difficulty could be less mysterious. It
23394: was an inference with a conspicuous handle to it, and had been easily
23395: drawn by indifferent observers, that Lydgate was in debt; and he could
23396: not succeed in keeping out of his mind for long together that he was
23397: every day getting deeper into that swamp, which tempts men towards it
23398: with such a pretty covering of flowers and verdure. It is wonderful how
23399: soon a man gets up to his chin there—in a condition in which, in spite
23400: of himself, he is forced to think chiefly of release, though he had a
23401: scheme of the universe in his soul.
23402: 
23403: Eighteen months ago Lydgate was poor, but had never known the eager
23404: want of small sums, and felt rather a burning contempt for any one who
23405: descended a step in order to gain them. He was now experiencing
23406: something worse than a simple deficit: he was assailed by the vulgar
23407: hateful trials of a man who has bought and used a great many things
23408: which might have been done without, and which he is unable to pay for,
23409: though the demand for payment has become pressing.
23410: 
23411: How this came about may be easily seen without much arithmetic or
23412: knowledge of prices. When a man in setting up a house and preparing for
23413: marriage finds that his furniture and other initial expenses come to
23414: between four and five hundred pounds more than he has capital to pay
23415: for; when at the end of a year it appears that his household expenses,
23416: horses and et caeteras, amount to nearly a thousand, while the proceeds
23417: of the practice reckoned from the old books to be worth eight hundred
23418: per annum have sunk like a summer pond and make hardly five hundred,
23419: chiefly in unpaid entries, the plain inference is that, whether he
23420: minds it or not, he is in debt. Those were less expensive times than
23421: our own, and provincial life was comparatively modest; but the ease
23422: with which a medical man who had lately bought a practice, who thought
23423: that he was obliged to keep two horses, whose table was supplied
23424: without stint, and who paid an insurance on his life and a high rent
23425: for house and garden, might find his expenses doubling his receipts,
23426: can be conceived by any one who does not think these details beneath
23427: his consideration. Rosamond, accustomed from her childhood to an
23428: extravagant household, thought that good housekeeping consisted simply
23429: in ordering the best of everything—nothing else “answered;” and Lydgate
23430: supposed that “if things were done at all, they must be done
23431: properly”—he did not see how they were to live otherwise. If each head
23432: of household expenditure had been mentioned to him beforehand, he would
23433: have probably observed that “it could hardly come to much,” and if any
23434: one had suggested a saving on a particular article—for example, the
23435: substitution of cheap fish for dear—it would have appeared to him
23436: simply a penny-wise, mean notion. Rosamond, even without such an
23437: occasion as Captain Lydgate’s visit, was fond of giving invitations,
23438: and Lydgate, though he often thought the guests tiresome, did not
23439: interfere. This sociability seemed a necessary part of professional
23440: prudence, and the entertainment must be suitable. It is true Lydgate
23441: was constantly visiting the homes of the poor and adjusting his
23442: prescriptions of diet to their small means; but, dear me! has it not by
23443: this time ceased to be remarkable—is it not rather that we expect in
23444: men, that they should have numerous strands of experience lying side by
23445: side and never compare them with each other? Expenditure—like ugliness
23446: and errors—becomes a totally new thing when we attach our own
23447: personality to it, and measure it by that wide difference which is
23448: manifest (in our own sensations) between ourselves and others. Lydgate
23449: believed himself to be careless about his dress, and he despised a man
23450: who calculated the effects of his costume; it seemed to him only a
23451: matter of course that he had abundance of fresh garments—such things
23452: were naturally ordered in sheaves. It must be remembered that he had
23453: never hitherto felt the check of importunate debt, and he walked by
23454: habit, not by self-criticism. But the check had come.
23455: 
23456: Its novelty made it the more irritating. He was amazed, disgusted that
23457: conditions so foreign to all his purposes, so hatefully disconnected
23458: with the objects he cared to occupy himself with, should have lain in
23459: ambush and clutched him when he was unaware. And there was not only the
23460: actual debt; there was the certainty that in his present position he
23461: must go on deepening it. Two furnishing tradesmen at Brassing, whose
23462: bills had been incurred before his marriage, and whom uncalculated
23463: current expenses had ever since prevented him from paying, had
23464: repeatedly sent him unpleasant letters which had forced themselves on
23465: his attention. This could hardly have been more galling to any
23466: disposition than to Lydgate’s, with his intense pride—his dislike of
23467: asking a favor or being under an obligation to any one. He had scorned
23468: even to form conjectures about Mr. Vincy’s intentions on money matters,
23469: and nothing but extremity could have induced him to apply to his
23470: father-in-law, even if he had not been made aware in various indirect
23471: ways since his marriage that Mr. Vincy’s own affairs were not
23472: flourishing, and that the expectation of help from him would be
23473: resented. Some men easily trust in the readiness of friends; it had
23474: never in the former part of his life occurred to Lydgate that he should
23475: need to do so: he had never thought what borrowing would be to him; but
23476: now that the idea had entered his mind, he felt that he would rather
23477: incur any other hardship. In the mean time he had no money or prospects
23478: of money; and his practice was not getting more lucrative.
23479: 
23480: No wonder that Lydgate had been unable to suppress all signs of inward
23481: trouble during the last few months, and now that Rosamond was regaining
23482: brilliant health, he meditated taking her entirely into confidence on
23483: his difficulties. New conversance with tradesmen’s bills had forced his
23484: reasoning into a new channel of comparison: he had begun to consider
23485: from a new point of view what was necessary and unnecessary in goods
23486: ordered, and to see that there must be some change of habits. How could
23487: such a change be made without Rosamond’s concurrence? The immediate
23488: occasion of opening the disagreeable fact to her was forced upon him.
23489: 
23490: Having no money, and having privately sought advice as to what security
23491: could possibly be given by a man in his position, Lydgate had offered
23492: the one good security in his power to the less peremptory creditor, who
23493: was a silversmith and jeweller, and who consented to take on himself
23494: the upholsterer’s credit also, accepting interest for a given term. The
23495: security necessary was a bill of sale on the furniture of his house,
23496: which might make a creditor easy for a reasonable time about a debt
23497: amounting to less than four hundred pounds; and the silversmith, Mr.
23498: Dover, was willing to reduce it by taking back a portion of the plate
23499: and any other article which was as good as new. “Any other article” was
23500: a phrase delicately implying jewellery, and more particularly some
23501: purple amethysts costing thirty pounds, which Lydgate had bought as a
23502: bridal present.
23503: 
23504: Opinions may be divided as to his wisdom in making this present: some
23505: may think that it was a graceful attention to be expected from a man
23506: like Lydgate, and that the fault of any troublesome consequences lay in
23507: the pinched narrowness of provincial life at that time, which offered
23508: no conveniences for professional people whose fortune was not
23509: proportioned to their tastes; also, in Lydgate’s ridiculous
23510: fastidiousness about asking his friends for money.
23511: 
23512: However, it had seemed a question of no moment to him on that fine
23513: morning when he went to give a final order for plate: in the presence
23514: of other jewels enormously expensive, and as an addition to orders of
23515: which the amount had not been exactly calculated, thirty pounds for
23516: ornaments so exquisitely suited to Rosamond’s neck and arms could
23517: hardly appear excessive when there was no ready cash for it to exceed.
23518: But at this crisis Lydgate’s imagination could not help dwelling on the
23519: possibility of letting the amethysts take their place again among Mr.
23520: Dover’s stock, though he shrank from the idea of proposing this to
23521: Rosamond. Having been roused to discern consequences which he had never
23522: been in the habit of tracing, he was preparing to act on this
23523: discernment with some of the rigor (by no means all) that he would have
23524: applied in pursuing experiment. He was nerving himself to this rigor as
23525: he rode from Brassing, and meditated on the representations he must
23526: make to Rosamond.
23527: 
23528: It was evening when he got home. He was intensely miserable, this
23529: strong man of nine-and-twenty and of many gifts. He was not saying
23530: angrily within himself that he had made a profound mistake; but the
23531: mistake was at work in him like a recognized chronic disease, mingling
23532: its uneasy importunities with every prospect, and enfeebling every
23533: thought. As he went along the passage to the drawing-room, he heard the
23534: piano and singing. Of course, Ladislaw was there. It was some weeks
23535: since Will had parted from Dorothea, yet he was still at the old post
23536: in Middlemarch. Lydgate had no objection in general to Ladislaw’s
23537: coming, but just now he was annoyed that he could not find his hearth
23538: free. When he opened the door the two singers went on towards the
23539: key-note, raising their eyes and looking at him indeed, but not
23540: regarding his entrance as an interruption. To a man galled with his
23541: harness as poor Lydgate was, it is not soothing to see two people
23542: warbling at him, as he comes in with the sense that the painful day has
23543: still pains in store. His face, already paler than usual, took on a
23544: scowl as he walked across the room and flung himself into a chair.
23545: 
23546: The singers feeling themselves excused by the fact that they had only
23547: three bars to sing, now turned round.
23548: 
23549: “How are you, Lydgate?” said Will, coming forward to shake hands.
23550: 
23551: Lydgate took his hand, but did not think it necessary to speak.
23552: 
23553: “Have you dined, Tertius? I expected you much earlier,” said Rosamond,
23554: who had already seen that her husband was in a “horrible humor.” She
23555: seated herself in her usual place as she spoke.
23556: 
23557: “I have dined. I should like some tea, please,” said Lydgate, curtly,
23558: still scowling and looking markedly at his legs stretched out before
23559: him.
23560: 
23561: Will was too quick to need more. “I shall be off,” he said, reaching
23562: his hat.
23563: 
23564: “Tea is coming,” said Rosamond; “pray don’t go.”
23565: 
23566: “Yes, Lydgate is bored,” said Will, who had more comprehension of
23567: Lydgate than Rosamond had, and was not offended by his manner, easily
23568: imagining outdoor causes of annoyance.
23569: 
23570: “There is the more need for you to stay,” said Rosamond, playfully, and
23571: in her lightest accent; “he will not speak to me all the evening.”
23572: 
23573: “Yes, Rosamond, I shall,” said Lydgate, in his strong baritone. “I have
23574: some serious business to speak to you about.”
23575: 
23576: No introduction of the business could have been less like that which
23577: Lydgate had intended; but her indifferent manner had been too
23578: provoking.
23579: 
23580: “There! you see,” said Will. “I’m going to the meeting about the
23581: Mechanics’ Institute. Good-by;” and he went quickly out of the room.
23582: 
23583: Rosamond did not look at her husband, but presently rose and took her
23584: place before the tea-tray. She was thinking that she had never seen him
23585: so disagreeable. Lydgate turned his dark eyes on her and watched her as
23586: she delicately handled the tea-service with her taper fingers, and
23587: looked at the objects immediately before her with no curve in her face
23588: disturbed, and yet with an ineffable protest in her air against all
23589: people with unpleasant manners. For the moment he lost the sense of his
23590: wound in a sudden speculation about this new form of feminine
23591: impassibility revealing itself in the sylph-like frame which he had
23592: once interpreted as the sign of a ready intelligent sensitiveness. His
23593: mind glancing back to Laure while he looked at Rosamond, he said
23594: inwardly, “Would _she_ kill me because I wearied her?” and then, “It is
23595: the way with all women.” But this power of generalizing which gives men
23596: so much the superiority in mistake over the dumb animals, was
23597: immediately thwarted by Lydgate’s memory of wondering impressions from
23598: the behavior of another woman—from Dorothea’s looks and tones of
23599: emotion about her husband when Lydgate began to attend him—from her
23600: passionate cry to be taught what would best comfort that man for whose
23601: sake it seemed as if she must quell every impulse in her except the
23602: yearnings of faithfulness and compassion. These revived impressions
23603: succeeded each other quickly and dreamily in Lydgate’s mind while the
23604: tea was being brewed. He had shut his eyes in the last instant of
23605: reverie while he heard Dorothea saying, “Advise me—think what I can
23606: do—he has been all his life laboring and looking forward. He minds
23607: about nothing else—and I mind about nothing else.”
23608: 
23609: That voice of deep-souled womanhood had remained within him as the
23610: enkindling conceptions of dead and sceptred genius had remained within
23611: him (is there not a genius for feeling nobly which also reigns over
23612: human spirits and their conclusions?); the tones were a music from
23613: which he was falling away—he had really fallen into a momentary doze,
23614: when Rosamond said in her silvery neutral way, “Here is your tea,
23615: Tertius,” setting it on the small table by his side, and then moved
23616: back to her place without looking at him. Lydgate was too hasty in
23617: attributing insensibility to her; after her own fashion, she was
23618: sensitive enough, and took lasting impressions. Her impression now was
23619: one of offence and repulsion. But then, Rosamond had no scowls and had
23620: never raised her voice: she was quite sure that no one could justly
23621: find fault with her.
23622: 
23623: Perhaps Lydgate and she had never felt so far off each other before;
23624: but there were strong reasons for not deferring his revelation, even if
23625: he had not already begun it by that abrupt announcement; indeed some of
23626: the angry desire to rouse her into more sensibility on his account
23627: which had prompted him to speak prematurely, still mingled with his
23628: pain in the prospect of her pain. But he waited till the tray was gone,
23629: the candles were lit, and the evening quiet might be counted on: the
23630: interval had left time for repelled tenderness to return into the old
23631: course. He spoke kindly.
23632: 
23633: “Dear Rosy, lay down your work and come to sit by me,” he said, gently,
23634: pushing away the table, and stretching out his arm to draw a chair near
23635: his own.
23636: 
23637: Rosamond obeyed. As she came towards him in her drapery of transparent
23638: faintly tinted muslin, her slim yet round figure never looked more
23639: graceful; as she sat down by him and laid one hand on the elbow of his
23640: chair, at last looking at him and meeting his eyes, her delicate neck
23641: and cheek and purely cut lips never had more of that untarnished beauty
23642: which touches as in spring-time and infancy and all sweet freshness. It
23643: touched Lydgate now, and mingled the early moments of his love for her
23644: with all the other memories which were stirred in this crisis of deep
23645: trouble. He laid his ample hand softly on hers, saying—
23646: 
23647: “Dear!” with the lingering utterance which affection gives to the word.
23648: Rosamond too was still under the power of that same past, and her
23649: husband was still in part the Lydgate whose approval had stirred
23650: delight. She put his hair lightly away from his forehead, then laid her
23651: other hand on his, and was conscious of forgiving him.
23652: 
23653: “I am obliged to tell you what will hurt you, Rosy. But there are
23654: things which husband and wife must think of together. I dare say it has
23655: occurred to you already that I am short of money.”
23656: 
23657: Lydgate paused; but Rosamond turned her neck and looked at a vase on
23658: the mantel-piece.
23659: 
23660: “I was not able to pay for all the things we had to get before we were
23661: married, and there have been expenses since which I have been obliged
23662: to meet. The consequence is, there is a large debt at Brassing—three
23663: hundred and eighty pounds—which has been pressing on me a good while,
23664: and in fact we are getting deeper every day, for people don’t pay me
23665: the faster because others want the money. I took pains to keep it from
23666: you while you were not well; but now we must think together about it,
23667: and you must help me.”
23668: 
23669: “What can _I_ do, Tertius?” said Rosamond, turning her eyes on him
23670: again. That little speech of four words, like so many others in all
23671: languages, is capable by varied vocal inflections of expressing all
23672: states of mind from helpless dimness to exhaustive argumentative
23673: perception, from the completest self-devoting fellowship to the most
23674: neutral aloofness. Rosamond’s thin utterance threw into the words “What
23675: can—I—do!” as much neutrality as they could hold. They fell like a
23676: mortal chill on Lydgate’s roused tenderness. He did not storm in
23677: indignation—he felt too sad a sinking of the heart. And when he spoke
23678: again it was more in the tone of a man who forces himself to fulfil a
23679: task.
23680: 
23681: “It is necessary for you to know, because I have to give security for a
23682: time, and a man must come to make an inventory of the furniture.”
23683: 
23684: Rosamond colored deeply. “Have you not asked papa for money?” she said,
23685: as soon as she could speak.
23686: 
23687: “No.”
23688: 
23689: “Then I must ask him!” she said, releasing her hands from Lydgate’s,
23690: and rising to stand at two yards’ distance from him.
23691: 
23692: “No, Rosy,” said Lydgate, decisively. “It is too late to do that. The
23693: inventory will be begun to-morrow. Remember it is a mere security: it
23694: will make no difference: it is a temporary affair. I insist upon it
23695: that your father shall not know, unless I choose to tell him,” added
23696: Lydgate, with a more peremptory emphasis.
23697: 
23698: This certainly was unkind, but Rosamond had thrown him back on evil
23699: expectation as to what she would do in the way of quiet steady
23700: disobedience. The unkindness seemed unpardonable to her: she was not
23701: given to weeping and disliked it, but now her chin and lips began to
23702: tremble and the tears welled up. Perhaps it was not possible for
23703: Lydgate, under the double stress of outward material difficulty and of
23704: his own proud resistance to humiliating consequences, to imagine fully
23705: what this sudden trial was to a young creature who had known nothing
23706: but indulgence, and whose dreams had all been of new indulgence, more
23707: exactly to her taste. But he did wish to spare her as much as he could,
23708: and her tears cut him to the heart. He could not speak again
23709: immediately; but Rosamond did not go on sobbing: she tried to conquer
23710: her agitation and wiped away her tears, continuing to look before her
23711: at the mantel-piece.
23712: 
23713: “Try not to grieve, darling,” said Lydgate, turning his eyes up towards
23714: her. That she had chosen to move away from him in this moment of her
23715: trouble made everything harder to say, but he must absolutely go on.
23716: “We must brace ourselves to do what is necessary. It is I who have been
23717: in fault: I ought to have seen that I could not afford to live in this
23718: way. But many things have told against me in my practice, and it really
23719: just now has ebbed to a low point. I may recover it, but in the mean
23720: time we must pull up—we must change our way of living. We shall weather
23721: it. When I have given this security I shall have time to look about me;
23722: and you are so clever that if you turn your mind to managing you will
23723: school me into carefulness. I have been a thoughtless rascal about
23724: squaring prices—but come, dear, sit down and forgive me.”
23725: 
23726: Lydgate was bowing his neck under the yoke like a creature who had
23727: talons, but who had Reason too, which often reduces us to meekness.
23728: When he had spoken the last words in an imploring tone, Rosamond
23729: returned to the chair by his side. His self-blame gave her some hope
23730: that he would attend to her opinion, and she said—
23731: 
23732: “Why can you not put off having the inventory made? You can send the
23733: men away to-morrow when they come.”
23734: 
23735: “I shall not send them away,” said Lydgate, the peremptoriness rising
23736: again. Was it of any use to explain?
23737: 
23738: “If we left Middlemarch? there would of course be a sale, and that
23739: would do as well.”
23740: 
23741: “But we are not going to leave Middlemarch.”
23742: 
23743: “I am sure, Tertius, it would be much better to do so. Why can we not
23744: go to London? Or near Durham, where your family is known?”
23745: 
23746: “We can go nowhere without money, Rosamond.”
23747: 
23748: “Your friends would not wish you to be without money. And surely these
23749: odious tradesmen might be made to understand that, and to wait, if you
23750: would make proper representations to them.”
23751: 
23752: “This is idle Rosamond,” said Lydgate, angrily. “You must learn to take
23753: my judgment on questions you don’t understand. I have made necessary
23754: arrangements, and they must be carried out. As to friends, I have no
23755: expectations whatever from them, and shall not ask them for anything.”
23756: 
23757: Rosamond sat perfectly still. The thought in her mind was that if she
23758: had known how Lydgate would behave, she would never have married him.
23759: 
23760: “We have no time to waste now on unnecessary words, dear,” said
23761: Lydgate, trying to be gentle again. “There are some details that I want
23762: to consider with you. Dover says he will take a good deal of the plate
23763: back again, and any of the jewellery we like. He really behaves very
23764: well.”
23765: 
23766: “Are we to go without spoons and forks then?” said Rosamond, whose very
23767: lips seemed to get thinner with the thinness of her utterance. She was
23768: determined to make no further resistance or suggestions.
23769: 
23770: “Oh no, dear!” said Lydgate. “But look here,” he continued, drawing a
23771: paper from his pocket and opening it; “here is Dover’s account. See, I
23772: have marked a number of articles, which if we returned them would
23773: reduce the amount by thirty pounds and more. I have not marked any of
23774: the jewellery.” Lydgate had really felt this point of the jewellery
23775: very bitter to himself; but he had overcome the feeling by severe
23776: argument. He could not propose to Rosamond that she should return any
23777: particular present of his, but he had told himself that he was bound to
23778: put Dover’s offer before her, and her inward prompting might make the
23779: affair easy.
23780: 
23781: “It is useless for me to look, Tertius,” said Rosamond, calmly; “you
23782: will return what you please.” She would not turn her eyes on the paper,
23783: and Lydgate, flushing up to the roots of his hair, drew it back and let
23784: it fall on his knee. Meanwhile Rosamond quietly went out of the room,
23785: leaving Lydgate helpless and wondering. Was she not coming back? It
23786: seemed that she had no more identified herself with him than if they
23787: had been creatures of different species and opposing interests. He
23788: tossed his head and thrust his hands deep into his pockets with a sort
23789: of vengeance. There was still science—there were still good objects to
23790: work for. He must give a tug still—all the stronger because other
23791: satisfactions were going.
23792: 
23793: But the door opened and Rosamond re-entered. She carried the leather
23794: box containing the amethysts, and a tiny ornamental basket which
23795: contained other boxes, and laying them on the chair where she had been
23796: sitting, she said, with perfect propriety in her air—
23797: 
23798: “This is all the jewellery you ever gave me. You can return what you
23799: like of it, and of the plate also. You will not, of course, expect me
23800: to stay at home to-morrow. I shall go to papa’s.”
23801: 
23802: To many women the look Lydgate cast at her would have been more
23803: terrible than one of anger: it had in it a despairing acceptance of the
23804: distance she was placing between them.
23805: 
23806: “And when shall you come back again?” he said, with a bitter edge on
23807: his accent.
23808: 
23809: “Oh, in the evening. Of course I shall not mention the subject to
23810: mamma.” Rosamond was convinced that no woman could behave more
23811: irreproachably than she was behaving; and she went to sit down at her
23812: work-table. Lydgate sat meditating a minute or two, and the result was
23813: that he said, with some of the old emotion in his tone—
23814: 
23815: “Now we have been united, Rosy, you should not leave me to myself in
23816: the first trouble that has come.”
23817: 
23818: “Certainly not,” said Rosamond; “I shall do everything it becomes me to
23819: do.”
23820: 
23821: “It is not right that the thing should be left to servants, or that I
23822: should have to speak to them about it. And I shall be obliged to go
23823: out—I don’t know how early. I understand your shrinking from the
23824: humiliation of these money affairs. But, my dear Rosamond, as a
23825: question of pride, which I feel just as much as you can, it is surely
23826: better to manage the thing ourselves, and let the servants see as
23827: little of it as possible; and since you are my wife, there is no
23828: hindering your share in my disgraces—if there were disgraces.”
23829: 
23830: Rosamond did not answer immediately, but at last she said, “Very well,
23831: I will stay at home.”
23832: 
23833: “I shall not touch these jewels, Rosy. Take them away again. But I will
23834: write out a list of plate that we may return, and that can be packed up
23835: and sent at once.”
23836: 
23837: “The servants will know _that_,” said Rosamond, with the slightest
23838: touch of sarcasm.
23839: 
23840: “Well, we must meet some disagreeables as necessities. Where is the
23841: ink, I wonder?” said Lydgate, rising, and throwing the account on the
23842: larger table where he meant to write.
23843: 
23844: Rosamond went to reach the inkstand, and after setting it on the table
23845: was going to turn away, when Lydgate, who was standing close by, put
23846: his arm round her and drew her towards him, saying—
23847: 
23848: “Come, darling, let us make the best of things. It will only be for a
23849: time, I hope, that we shall have to be stingy and particular. Kiss me.”
23850: 
23851: His native warm-heartedness took a great deal of quenching, and it is a
23852: part of manliness for a husband to feel keenly the fact that an
23853: inexperienced girl has got into trouble by marrying him. She received
23854: his kiss and returned it faintly, and in this way an appearance of
23855: accord was recovered for the time. But Lydgate could not help looking
23856: forward with dread to the inevitable future discussions about
23857: expenditure and the necessity for a complete change in their way of
23858: living.
23859: 
23860: 
23861: 
23862: 
23863: CHAPTER LIX.
23864: 
23865: “They said of old the Soul had human shape,
23866: But smaller, subtler than the fleshly self,
23867: So wandered forth for airing when it pleased.
23868: And see! beside her cherub-face there floats
23869: A pale-lipped form aerial whispering
23870: Its promptings in that little shell her ear.”
23871: 
23872: 
23873: News is often dispersed as thoughtlessly and effectively as that pollen
23874: which the bees carry off (having no idea how powdery they are) when
23875: they are buzzing in search of their particular nectar. This fine
23876: comparison has reference to Fred Vincy, who on that evening at Lowick
23877: Parsonage heard a lively discussion among the ladies on the news which
23878: their old servant had got from Tantripp concerning Mr. Casaubon’s
23879: strange mention of Mr. Ladislaw in a codicil to his will made not long
23880: before his death. Miss Winifred was astounded to find that her brother
23881: had known the fact before, and observed that Camden was the most
23882: wonderful man for knowing things and not telling them; whereupon Mary
23883: Garth said that the codicil had perhaps got mixed up with the habits of
23884: spiders, which Miss Winifred never would listen to. Mrs. Farebrother
23885: considered that the news had something to do with their having only
23886: once seen Mr. Ladislaw at Lowick, and Miss Noble made many small
23887: compassionate mewings.
23888: 
23889: Fred knew little and cared less about Ladislaw and the Casaubons, and
23890: his mind never recurred to that discussion till one day calling on
23891: Rosamond at his mother’s request to deliver a message as he passed, he
23892: happened to see Ladislaw going away. Fred and Rosamond had little to
23893: say to each other now that marriage had removed her from collision with
23894: the unpleasantness of brothers, and especially now that he had taken
23895: what she held the stupid and even reprehensible step of giving up the
23896: Church to take to such a business as Mr. Garth’s. Hence Fred talked by
23897: preference of what he considered indifferent news, and “a propos of
23898: that young Ladislaw” mentioned what he had heard at Lowick Parsonage.
23899: 
23900: Now Lydgate, like Mr. Farebrother, knew a great deal more than he told,
23901: and when he had once been set thinking about the relation between Will
23902: and Dorothea his conjectures had gone beyond the fact. He imagined that
23903: there was a passionate attachment on both sides, and this struck him as
23904: much too serious to gossip about. He remembered Will’s irritability
23905: when he had mentioned Mrs. Casaubon, and was the more circumspect. On
23906: the whole his surmises, in addition to what he knew of the fact,
23907: increased his friendliness and tolerance towards Ladislaw, and made him
23908: understand the vacillation which kept him at Middlemarch after he had
23909: said that he should go away. It was significant of the separateness
23910: between Lydgate’s mind and Rosamond’s that he had no impulse to speak
23911: to her on the subject; indeed, he did not quite trust her reticence
23912: towards Will. And he was right there; though he had no vision of the
23913: way in which her mind would act in urging her to speak.
23914: 
23915: When she repeated Fred’s news to Lydgate, he said, “Take care you don’t
23916: drop the faintest hint to Ladislaw, Rosy. He is likely to fly out as if
23917: you insulted him. Of course it is a painful affair.”
23918: 
23919: Rosamond turned her neck and patted her hair, looking the image of
23920: placid indifference. But the next time Will came when Lydgate was away,
23921: she spoke archly about his not going to London as he had threatened.
23922: 
23923: “I know all about it. I have a confidential little bird,” said she,
23924: showing very pretty airs of her head over the bit of work held high
23925: between her active fingers. “There is a powerful magnet in this
23926: neighborhood.”
23927: 
23928: “To be sure there is. Nobody knows that better than you,” said Will,
23929: with light gallantry, but inwardly prepared to be angry.
23930: 
23931: “It is really the most charming romance: Mr. Casaubon jealous, and
23932: foreseeing that there was no one else whom Mrs. Casaubon would so much
23933: like to marry, and no one who would so much like to marry her as a
23934: certain gentleman; and then laying a plan to spoil all by making her
23935: forfeit her property if she did marry that gentleman—and then—and
23936: then—and then—oh, I have no doubt the end will be thoroughly romantic.”
23937: 
23938: “Great God! what do you mean?” said Will, flushing over face and ears,
23939: his features seeming to change as if he had had a violent shake. “Don’t
23940: joke; tell me what you mean.”
23941: 
23942: “You don’t really know?” said Rosamond, no longer playful, and desiring
23943: nothing better than to tell in order that she might evoke effects.
23944: 
23945: “No!” he returned, impatiently.
23946: 
23947: “Don’t know that Mr. Casaubon has left it in his will that if Mrs.
23948: Casaubon marries you she is to forfeit all her property?”
23949: 
23950: “How do you know that it is true?” said Will, eagerly.
23951: 
23952: “My brother Fred heard it from the Farebrothers.” Will started up from
23953: his chair and reached his hat.
23954: 
23955: “I dare say she likes you better than the property,” said Rosamond,
23956: looking at him from a distance.
23957: 
23958: “Pray don’t say any more about it,” said Will, in a hoarse undertone
23959: extremely unlike his usual light voice. “It is a foul insult to her and
23960: to me.” Then he sat down absently, looking before him, but seeing
23961: nothing.
23962: 
23963: “Now you are angry with _me_,” said Rosamond. “It is too bad to bear
23964: _me_ malice. You ought to be obliged to me for telling you.”
23965: 
23966: “So I am,” said Will, abruptly, speaking with that kind of double soul
23967: which belongs to dreamers who answer questions.
23968: 
23969: “I expect to hear of the marriage,” said Rosamond, playfully.
23970: 
23971: “Never! You will never hear of the marriage!”
23972: 
23973: With those words uttered impetuously, Will rose, put out his hand to
23974: Rosamond, still with the air of a somnambulist, and went away.
23975: 
23976: When he was gone, Rosamond left her chair and walked to the other end
23977: of the room, leaning when she got there against a chiffonniere, and
23978: looking out of the window wearily. She was oppressed by ennui, and by
23979: that dissatisfaction which in women’s minds is continually turning into
23980: a trivial jealousy, referring to no real claims, springing from no
23981: deeper passion than the vague exactingness of egoism, and yet capable
23982: of impelling action as well as speech. “There really is nothing to care
23983: for much,” said poor Rosamond inwardly, thinking of the family at
23984: Quallingham, who did not write to her; and that perhaps Tertius when he
23985: came home would tease her about expenses. She had already secretly
23986: disobeyed him by asking her father to help them, and he had ended
23987: decisively by saying, “I am more likely to want help myself.”
23988: 
23989: 
23990: 
23991: 
23992: CHAPTER LX.
23993: 
23994: Good phrases are surely, and ever were, very commendable.
23995: —_Justice Shallow_.
23996: 
23997: 
23998: A few days afterwards—it was already the end of August—there was an
23999: occasion which caused some excitement in Middlemarch: the public, if it
24000: chose, was to have the advantage of buying, under the distinguished
24001: auspices of Mr. Borthrop Trumbull, the furniture, books, and pictures
24002: which anybody might see by the handbills to be the best in every kind,
24003: belonging to Edwin Larcher, Esq. This was not one of the sales
24004: indicating the depression of trade; on the contrary, it was due to Mr.
24005: Larcher’s great success in the carrying business, which warranted his
24006: purchase of a mansion near Riverston already furnished in high style by
24007: an illustrious Spa physician—furnished indeed with such large framefuls
24008: of expensive flesh-painting in the dining-room, that Mrs. Larcher was
24009: nervous until reassured by finding the subjects to be Scriptural. Hence
24010: the fine opportunity to purchasers which was well pointed out in the
24011: handbills of Mr. Borthrop Trumbull, whose acquaintance with the history
24012: of art enabled him to state that the hall furniture, to be sold without
24013: reserve, comprised a piece of carving by a contemporary of Gibbons.
24014: 
24015: At Middlemarch in those times a large sale was regarded as a kind of
24016: festival. There was a table spread with the best cold eatables, as at a
24017: superior funeral; and facilities were offered for that
24018: generous-drinking of cheerful glasses which might lead to generous and
24019: cheerful bidding for undesirable articles. Mr. Larcher’s sale was the
24020: more attractive in the fine weather because the house stood just at the
24021: end of the town, with a garden and stables attached, in that pleasant
24022: issue from Middlemarch called the London Road, which was also the road
24023: to the New Hospital and to Mr. Bulstrode’s retired residence, known as
24024: the Shrubs. In short, the auction was as good as a fair, and drew all
24025: classes with leisure at command: to some, who risked making bids in
24026: order simply to raise prices, it was almost equal to betting at the
24027: races. The second day, when the best furniture was to be sold,
24028: “everybody” was there; even Mr. Thesiger, the rector of St. Peter’s,
24029: had looked in for a short time, wishing to buy the carved table, and
24030: had rubbed elbows with Mr. Bambridge and Mr. Horrock. There was a
24031: wreath of Middlemarch ladies accommodated with seats round the large
24032: table in the dining-room, where Mr. Borthrop Trumbull was mounted with
24033: desk and hammer; but the rows chiefly of masculine faces behind were
24034: often varied by incomings and outgoings both from the door and the
24035: large bow-window opening on to the lawn.
24036: 
24037: “Everybody” that day did not include Mr. Bulstrode, whose health could
24038: not well endure crowds and draughts. But Mrs. Bulstrode had
24039: particularly wished to have a certain picture—a “Supper at Emmaus,”
24040: attributed in the catalogue to Guido; and at the last moment before the
24041: day of the sale Mr. Bulstrode had called at the office of the
24042: “Pioneer,” of which he was now one of the proprietors, to beg of Mr.
24043: Ladislaw as a great favor that he would obligingly use his remarkable
24044: knowledge of pictures on behalf of Mrs. Bulstrode, and judge of the
24045: value of this particular painting—“if,” added the scrupulously polite
24046: banker, “attendance at the sale would not interfere with the
24047: arrangements for your departure, which I know is imminent.”
24048: 
24049: This proviso might have sounded rather satirically in Will’s ear if he
24050: had been in a mood to care about such satire. It referred to an
24051: understanding entered into many weeks before with the proprietors of
24052: the paper, that he should be at liberty any day he pleased to hand over
24053: the management to the subeditor whom he had been training; since he
24054: wished finally to quit Middlemarch. But indefinite visions of ambition
24055: are weak against the ease of doing what is habitual or beguilingly
24056: agreeable; and we all know the difficulty of carrying out a resolve
24057: when we secretly long that it may turn out to be unnecessary. In such
24058: states of mind the most incredulous person has a private leaning
24059: towards miracle: impossible to conceive how our wish could be
24060: fulfilled, still—very wonderful things have happened! Will did not
24061: confess this weakness to himself, but he lingered. What was the use of
24062: going to London at that time of the year? The Rugby men who would
24063: remember him were not there; and so far as political writing was
24064: concerned, he would rather for a few weeks go on with the “Pioneer.” At
24065: the present moment, however, when Mr. Bulstrode was speaking to him, he
24066: had both a strengthened resolve to go and an equally strong resolve not
24067: to go till he had once more seen Dorothea. Hence he replied that he had
24068: reasons for deferring his departure a little, and would be happy to go
24069: to the sale.
24070: 
24071: Will was in a defiant mood, his consciousness being deeply stung with
24072: the thought that the people who looked at him probably knew a fact
24073: tantamount to an accusation against him as a fellow with low designs
24074: which were to be frustrated by a disposal of property. Like most people
24075: who assert their freedom with regard to conventional distinction, he
24076: was prepared to be sudden and quick at quarrel with any one who might
24077: hint that he had personal reasons for that assertion—that there was
24078: anything in his blood, his bearing, or his character to which he gave
24079: the mask of an opinion. When he was under an irritating impression of
24080: this kind he would go about for days with a defiant look, the color
24081: changing in his transparent skin as if he were on the _qui vive_,
24082: watching for something which he had to dart upon.
24083: 
24084: This expression was peculiarly noticeable in him at the sale, and those
24085: who had only seen him in his moods of gentle oddity or of bright
24086: enjoyment would have been struck with a contrast. He was not sorry to
24087: have this occasion for appearing in public before the Middlemarch
24088: tribes of Toller, Hackbutt, and the rest, who looked down on him as an
24089: adventurer, and were in a state of brutal ignorance about Dante—who
24090: sneered at his Polish blood, and were themselves of a breed very much
24091: in need of crossing. He stood in a conspicuous place not far from the
24092: auctioneer, with a fore-finger in each side-pocket and his head thrown
24093: backward, not caring to speak to anybody, though he had been cordially
24094: welcomed as a connoiss_ure_ by Mr. Trumbull, who was enjoying the
24095: utmost activity of his great faculties.
24096: 
24097: And surely among all men whose vocation requires them to exhibit their
24098: powers of speech, the happiest is a prosperous provincial auctioneer
24099: keenly alive to his own jokes and sensible of his encyclopedic
24100: knowledge. Some saturnine, sour-blooded persons might object to be
24101: constantly insisting on the merits of all articles from boot-jacks to
24102: “Berghems;” but Mr. Borthrop Trumbull had a kindly liquid in his veins;
24103: he was an admirer by nature, and would have liked to have the universe
24104: under his hammer, feeling that it would go at a higher figure for his
24105: recommendation.
24106: 
24107: Meanwhile Mrs. Larcher’s drawing-room furniture was enough for him.
24108: When Will Ladislaw had come in, a second fender, said to have been
24109: forgotten in its right place, suddenly claimed the auctioneer’s
24110: enthusiasm, which he distributed on the equitable principle of praising
24111: those things most which were most in need of praise. The fender was of
24112: polished steel, with much lancet-shaped open-work and a sharp edge.
24113: 
24114: “Now, ladies,” said he, “I shall appeal to you. Here is a fender which
24115: at any other sale would hardly be offered with out reserve, being, as I
24116: may say, for quality of steel and quaintness of design, a kind of
24117: thing”—here Mr. Trumbull dropped his voice and became slightly nasal,
24118: trimming his outlines with his left finger—“that might not fall in with
24119: ordinary tastes. Allow me to tell you that by-and-by this style of
24120: workmanship will be the only one in vogue—half-a-crown, you said? thank
24121: you—going at half-a-crown, this characteristic fender; and I have
24122: particular information that the antique style is very much sought after
24123: in high quarters. Three shillings—three-and-sixpence—hold it well up,
