24124: Joseph! Look, ladies, at the chastity of the design—I have no doubt
24125: myself that it was turned out in the last century! Four shillings, Mr.
24126: Mawmsey?—four shillings.”
24127: 
24128: “It’s not a thing I would put in _my_ drawing-room,” said Mrs. Mawmsey,
24129: audibly, for the warning of the rash husband. “I wonder _at_ Mrs.
24130: Larcher. Every blessed child’s head that fell against it would be cut
24131: in two. The edge is like a knife.”
24132: 
24133: “Quite true,” rejoined Mr. Trumbull, quickly, “and most uncommonly
24134: useful to have a fender at hand that will cut, if you have a leather
24135: shoe-tie or a bit of string that wants cutting and no knife at hand:
24136: many a man has been left hanging because there was no knife to cut him
24137: down. Gentlemen, here’s a fender that if you had the misfortune to hang
24138: yourselves would cut you down in no time—with astonishing
24139: celerity—four-and-sixpence—five—five-and-sixpence—an appropriate thing
24140: for a spare bedroom where there was a four-poster and a guest a little
24141: out of his mind—six shillings—thank you, Mr. Clintup—going at six
24142: shillings—going—gone!” The auctioneer’s glance, which had been
24143: searching round him with a preternatural susceptibility to all signs of
24144: bidding, here dropped on the paper before him, and his voice too
24145: dropped into a tone of indifferent despatch as he said, “Mr. Clintup.
24146: Be handy, Joseph.”
24147: 
24148: “It was worth six shillings to have a fender you could always tell that
24149: joke on,” said Mr. Clintup, laughing low and apologetically to his next
24150: neighbor. He was a diffident though distinguished nurseryman, and
24151: feared that the audience might regard his bid as a foolish one.
24152: 
24153: Meanwhile Joseph had brought a trayful of small articles. “Now,
24154: ladies,” said Mr. Trumbull, taking up one of the articles, “this tray
24155: contains a very recherchy lot—a collection of trifles for the
24156: drawing-room table—and trifles make the sum _of_ human things—nothing
24157: more important than trifles—(yes, Mr. Ladislaw, yes, by-and-by)—but
24158: pass the tray round, Joseph—these bijoux must be examined, ladies. This
24159: I have in my hand is an ingenious contrivance—a sort of practical
24160: rebus, I may call it: here, you see, it looks like an elegant
24161: heart-shaped box, portable—for the pocket; there, again, it becomes
24162: like a splendid double flower—an ornament for the table; and now”—Mr.
24163: Trumbull allowed the flower to fall alarmingly into strings of
24164: heart-shaped leaves—“a book of riddles! No less than five hundred
24165: printed in a beautiful red. Gentlemen, if I had less of a conscience, I
24166: should not wish you to bid high for this lot—I have a longing for it
24167: myself. What can promote innocent mirth, and I may say virtue, more
24168: than a good riddle?—it hinders profane language, and attaches a man to
24169: the society of refined females. This ingenious article itself, without
24170: the elegant domino-box, card-basket, &c., ought alone to give a high
24171: price to the lot. Carried in the pocket it might make an individual
24172: welcome in any society. Four shillings, sir?—four shillings for this
24173: remarkable collection of riddles with the et caeteras. Here is a
24174: sample: ‘How must you spell honey to make it catch lady-birds?
24175: Answer—money.’ You hear?—lady-birds—honey money. This is an amusement
24176: to sharpen the intellect; it has a sting—it has what we call satire,
24177: and wit without indecency. Four-and-sixpence—five shillings.”
24178: 
24179: The bidding ran on with warming rivalry. Mr. Bowyer was a bidder, and
24180: this was too exasperating. Bowyer couldn’t afford it, and only wanted
24181: to hinder every other man from making a figure. The current carried
24182: even Mr. Horrock with it, but this committal of himself to an opinion
24183: fell from him with so little sacrifice of his neutral expression, that
24184: the bid might not have been detected as his but for the friendly oaths
24185: of Mr. Bambridge, who wanted to know what Horrock would do with blasted
24186: stuff only fit for haberdashers given over to that state of perdition
24187: which the horse-dealer so cordially recognized in the majority of
24188: earthly existences. The lot was finally knocked down at a guinea to Mr.
24189: Spilkins, a young Slender of the neighborhood, who was reckless with
24190: his pocket-money and felt his want of memory for riddles.
24191: 
24192: “Come, Trumbull, this is too bad—you’ve been putting some old maid’s
24193: rubbish into the sale,” murmured Mr. Toller, getting close to the
24194: auctioneer. “I want to see how the prints go, and I must be off soon.”
24195: 
24196: “_Im_mediately, Mr. Toller. It was only an act of benevolence which
24197: your noble heart would approve. Joseph! quick with the prints—Lot 235.
24198: Now, gentlemen, you who are connoiss_ures_, you are going to have a
24199: treat. Here is an engraving of the Duke of Wellington surrounded by his
24200: staff on the Field of Waterloo; and notwithstanding recent events which
24201: have, as it were, enveloped our great Hero in a cloud, I will be bold
24202: to say—for a man in my line must not be blown about by political
24203: winds—that a finer subject—of the modern order, belonging to our own
24204: time and epoch—the understanding of man could hardly conceive: angels
24205: might, perhaps, but not men, sirs, not men.”
24206: 
24207: “Who painted it?” said Mr. Powderell, much impressed.
24208: 
24209: “It is a proof before the letter, Mr. Powderell—the painter is not
24210: known,” answered Trumbull, with a certain gaspingness in his last
24211: words, after which he pursed up his lips and stared round him.
24212: 
24213: “I’ll bid a pound!” said Mr. Powderell, in a tone of resolved emotion,
24214: as of a man ready to put himself in the breach. Whether from awe or
24215: pity, nobody raised the price on him.
24216: 
24217: Next came two Dutch prints which Mr. Toller had been eager for, and
24218: after he had secured them he went away. Other prints, and afterwards
24219: some paintings, were sold to leading Middlemarchers who had come with a
24220: special desire for them, and there was a more active movement of the
24221: audience in and out; some, who had bought what they wanted, going away,
24222: others coming in either quite newly or from a temporary visit to the
24223: refreshments which were spread under the marquee on the lawn. It was
24224: this marquee that Mr. Bambridge was bent on buying, and he appeared to
24225: like looking inside it frequently, as a foretaste of its possession. On
24226: the last occasion of his return from it he was observed to bring with
24227: him a new companion, a stranger to Mr. Trumbull and every one else,
24228: whose appearance, however, led to the supposition that he might be a
24229: relative of the horse-dealer’s—also “given to indulgence.” His large
24230: whiskers, imposing swagger, and swing of the leg, made him a striking
24231: figure; but his suit of black, rather shabby at the edges, caused the
24232: prejudicial inference that he was not able to afford himself as much
24233: indulgence as he liked.
24234: 
24235: “Who is it you’ve picked up, Bam?” said Mr. Horrock, aside.
24236: 
24237: “Ask him yourself,” returned Mr. Bambridge. “He said he’d just turned
24238: in from the road.”
24239: 
24240: Mr. Horrock eyed the stranger, who was leaning back against his stick
24241: with one hand, using his toothpick with the other, and looking about
24242: him with a certain restlessness apparently under the silence imposed on
24243: him by circumstances.
24244: 
24245: At length the “Supper at Emmaus” was brought forward, to Will’s immense
24246: relief, for he was getting so tired of the proceedings that he had
24247: drawn back a little and leaned his shoulder against the wall just
24248: behind the auctioneer. He now came forward again, and his eye caught
24249: the conspicuous stranger, who, rather to his surprise, was staring at
24250: him markedly. But Will was immediately appealed to by Mr. Trumbull.
24251: 
24252: “Yes, Mr. Ladislaw, yes; this interests you as a connoiss_ure_, I
24253: think. It is some pleasure,” the auctioneer went on with a rising
24254: fervor, “to have a picture like this to show to a company of ladies and
24255: gentlemen—a picture worth any sum to an individual whose means were on
24256: a level with his judgment. It is a painting of the Italian school—by
24257: the celebrated _Guydo_, the greatest painter in the world, the chief of
24258: the Old Masters, as they are called—I take it, because they were up to
24259: a thing or two beyond most of us—in possession of secrets now lost to
24260: the bulk of mankind. Let me tell you, gentlemen, I have seen a great
24261: many pictures by the Old Masters, and they are not all up to this
24262: mark—some of them are darker than you might like and not family
24263: subjects. But here is a _Guydo_—the frame alone is worth pounds—which
24264: any lady might be proud to hang up—a suitable thing for what we call a
24265: refectory in a charitable institution, if any gentleman of the
24266: Corporation wished to show his munifi_cence_. Turn it a little, sir?
24267: yes. Joseph, turn it a little towards Mr. Ladislaw—Mr. Ladislaw, having
24268: been abroad, understands the merit of these things, you observe.”
24269: 
24270: All eyes were for a moment turned towards Will, who said, coolly, “Five
24271: pounds.” The auctioneer burst out in deep remonstrance.
24272: 
24273: “Ah! Mr. Ladislaw! the frame alone is worth that. Ladies and gentlemen,
24274: for the credit of the town! Suppose it should be discovered hereafter
24275: that a gem of art has been amongst us in this town, and nobody in
24276: Middlemarch awake to it. Five guineas—five seven-six—five ten. Still,
24277: ladies, still! It is a gem, and ‘Full many a gem,’ as the poet says,
24278: has been allowed to go at a nominal price because the public knew no
24279: better, because it was offered in circles where there was—I was going
24280: to say a low feeling, but no!—Six pounds—six guineas—a _Guydo_ of the
24281: first order going at six guineas—it is an insult to religion, ladies;
24282: it touches us all as Christians, gentlemen, that a subject like this
24283: should go at such a low figure—six pounds ten—seven—”
24284: 
24285: The bidding was brisk, and Will continued to share in it, remembering
24286: that Mrs. Bulstrode had a strong wish for the picture, and thinking
24287: that he might stretch the price to twelve pounds. But it was knocked
24288: down to him at ten guineas, whereupon he pushed his way towards the
24289: bow-window and went out. He chose to go under the marquee to get a
24290: glass of water, being hot and thirsty: it was empty of other visitors,
24291: and he asked the woman in attendance to fetch him some fresh water; but
24292: before she was well gone he was annoyed to see entering the florid
24293: stranger who had stared at him. It struck Will at this moment that the
24294: man might be one of those political parasitic insects of the bloated
24295: kind who had once or twice claimed acquaintance with him as having
24296: heard him speak on the Reform question, and who might think of getting
24297: a shilling by news. In this light his person, already rather heating to
24298: behold on a summer’s day, appeared the more disagreeable; and Will,
24299: half-seated on the elbow of a garden-chair, turned his eyes carefully
24300: away from the comer. But this signified little to our acquaintance Mr.
24301: Raffles, who never hesitated to thrust himself on unwilling
24302: observation, if it suited his purpose to do so. He moved a step or two
24303: till he was in front of Will, and said with full-mouthed haste, “Excuse
24304: me, Mr. Ladislaw—was your mother’s name Sarah Dunkirk?”
24305: 
24306: Will, starting to his feet, moved backward a step, frowning, and saying
24307: with some fierceness, “Yes, sir, it was. And what is that to you?”
24308: 
24309: It was in Will’s nature that the first spark it threw out was a direct
24310: answer of the question and a challenge of the consequences. To have
24311: said, “What is that to you?” in the first instance, would have seemed
24312: like shuffling—as if he minded who knew anything about his origin!
24313: 
24314: Raffles on his side had not the same eagerness for a collision which
24315: was implied in Ladislaw’s threatening air. The slim young fellow with
24316: his girl’s complexion looked like a tiger-cat ready to spring on him.
24317: Under such circumstances Mr. Raffles’s pleasure in annoying his company
24318: was kept in abeyance.
24319: 
24320: “No offence, my good sir, no offence! I only remember your mother—knew
24321: her when she was a girl. But it is your father that you feature, sir. I
24322: had the pleasure of seeing your father too. Parents alive, Mr.
24323: Ladislaw?”
24324: 
24325: “No!” thundered Will, in the same attitude as before.
24326: 
24327: “Should be glad to do you a service, Mr. Ladislaw—by Jove, I should!
24328: Hope to meet again.”
24329: 
24330: Hereupon Raffles, who had lifted his hat with the last words, turned
24331: himself round with a swing of his leg and walked away. Will looked
24332: after him a moment, and could see that he did not re-enter the
24333: auction-room, but appeared to be walking towards the road. For an
24334: instant he thought that he had been foolish not to let the man go on
24335: talking;—but no! on the whole he preferred doing without knowledge from
24336: that source.
24337: 
24338: Later in the evening, however, Raffles overtook him in the street, and
24339: appearing either to have forgotten the roughness of his former
24340: reception or to intend avenging it by a forgiving familiarity, greeted
24341: him jovially and walked by his side, remarking at first on the
24342: pleasantness of the town and neighborhood. Will suspected that the man
24343: had been drinking and was considering how to shake him off when Raffles
24344: said—
24345: 
24346: “I’ve been abroad myself, Mr. Ladislaw—I’ve seen the world—used to
24347: parley-vous a little. It was at Boulogne I saw your father—a most
24348: uncommon likeness you are of him, by Jove! mouth—nose—eyes—hair turned
24349: off your brow just like his—a little in the foreign style. John Bull
24350: doesn’t do much of that. But your father was very ill when I saw him.
24351: Lord, lord! hands you might see through. You were a small youngster
24352: then. Did he get well?”
24353: 
24354: “No,” said Will, curtly.
24355: 
24356: “Ah! Well! I’ve often wondered what became of your mother. She ran away
24357: from her friends when she was a young lass—a proud-spirited lass, and
24358: pretty, by Jove! I knew the reason why she ran away,” said Raffles,
24359: winking slowly as he looked sideways at Will.
24360: 
24361: “You know nothing dishonorable of her, sir,” said Will, turning on him
24362: rather savagely. But Mr. Raffles just now was not sensitive to shades
24363: of manner.
24364: 
24365: “Not a bit!” said he, tossing his head decisively. “She was a little
24366: too honorable to like her friends—that was it!” Here Raffles again
24367: winked slowly. “Lord bless you, I knew all about ’em—a little in what
24368: you may call the respectable thieving line—the high style of
24369: receiving-house—none of your holes and corners—first-rate. Slap-up
24370: shop, high profits and no mistake. But Lord! Sarah would have known
24371: nothing about it—a dashing young lady she was—fine boarding-school—fit
24372: for a lord’s wife—only Archie Duncan threw it at her out of spite,
24373: because she would have nothing to do with him. And so she ran away from
24374: the whole concern. I travelled for ’em, sir, in a gentlemanly way—at a
24375: high salary. They didn’t mind her running away at first—godly folks,
24376: sir, very godly—and she was for the stage. The son was alive then, and
24377: the daughter was at a discount. Hallo! here we are at the Blue Bull.
24378: What do you say, Mr. Ladislaw?—shall we turn in and have a glass?”
24379: 
24380: “No, I must say good evening,” said Will, dashing up a passage which
24381: led into Lowick Gate, and almost running to get out of Raffles’s reach.
24382: 
24383: He walked a long while on the Lowick road away from the town, glad of
24384: the starlit darkness when it came. He felt as if he had had dirt cast
24385: on him amidst shouts of scorn. There was this to confirm the fellow’s
24386: statement—that his mother never would tell him the reason why she had
24387: run away from her family.
24388: 
24389: Well! what was he, Will Ladislaw, the worse, supposing the truth about
24390: that family to be the ugliest? His mother had braved hardship in order
24391: to separate herself from it. But if Dorothea’s friends had known this
24392: story—if the Chettams had known it—they would have had a fine color to
24393: give their suspicions a welcome ground for thinking him unfit to come
24394: near her. However, let them suspect what they pleased, they would find
24395: themselves in the wrong. They would find out that the blood in his
24396: veins was as free from the taint of meanness as theirs.
24397: 
24398: 
24399: 
24400: 
24401: CHAPTER LXI.
24402: 
24403: “Inconsistencies,” answered Imlac, “cannot both be right, but imputed
24404: to man they may both be true.”—_Rasselas_.
24405: 
24406: 
24407: The same night, when Mr. Bulstrode returned from a journey to Brassing
24408: on business, his good wife met him in the entrance-hall and drew him
24409: into his private sitting-room.
24410: 
24411: “Nicholas,” she said, fixing her honest eyes upon him anxiously, “there
24412: has been such a disagreeable man here asking for you—it has made me
24413: quite uncomfortable.”
24414: 
24415: “What kind of man, my dear,” said Mr. Bulstrode, dreadfully certain of
24416: the answer.
24417: 
24418: “A red-faced man with large whiskers, and most impudent in his manner.
24419: He declared he was an old friend of yours, and said you would be sorry
24420: not to see him. He wanted to wait for you here, but I told him he could
24421: see you at the Bank to-morrow morning. Most impudent he was!—stared at
24422: me, and said his friend Nick had luck in wives. I don’t believe he
24423: would have gone away, if Blucher had not happened to break his chain
24424: and come running round on the gravel—for I was in the garden; so I
24425: said, ‘You’d better go away—the dog is very fierce, and I can’t hold
24426: him.’ Do you really know anything of such a man?”
24427: 
24428: “I believe I know who he is, my dear,” said Mr. Bulstrode, in his usual
24429: subdued voice, “an unfortunate dissolute wretch, whom I helped too much
24430: in days gone by. However, I presume you will not be troubled by him
24431: again. He will probably come to the Bank—to beg, doubtless.”
24432: 
24433: No more was said on the subject until the next day, when Mr. Bulstrode
24434: had returned from the town and was dressing for dinner. His wife, not
24435: sure that he was come home, looked into his dressing-room and saw him
24436: with his coat and cravat off, leaning one arm on a chest of drawers and
24437: staring absently at the ground. He started nervously and looked up as
24438: she entered.
24439: 
24440: “You look very ill, Nicholas. Is there anything the matter?”
24441: 
24442: “I have a good deal of pain in my head,” said Mr. Bulstrode, who was so
24443: frequently ailing that his wife was always ready to believe in this
24444: cause of depression.
24445: 
24446: “Sit down and let me sponge it with vinegar.”
24447: 
24448: Physically Mr. Bulstrode did not want the vinegar, but morally the
24449: affectionate attention soothed him. Though always polite, it was his
24450: habit to receive such services with marital coolness, as his wife’s
24451: duty. But to-day, while she was bending over him, he said, “You are
24452: very good, Harriet,” in a tone which had something new in it to her
24453: ear; she did not know exactly what the novelty was, but her woman’s
24454: solicitude shaped itself into a darting thought that he might be going
24455: to have an illness.
24456: 
24457: “Has anything worried you?” she said. “Did that man come to you at the
24458: Bank?”
24459: 
24460: “Yes; it was as I had supposed. He is a man who at one time might have
24461: done better. But he has sunk into a drunken debauched creature.”
24462: 
24463: “Is he quite gone away?” said Mrs. Bulstrode, anxiously; but for
24464: certain reasons she refrained from adding, “It was very disagreeable to
24465: hear him calling himself a friend of yours.” At that moment she would
24466: not have liked to say anything which implied her habitual consciousness
24467: that her husband’s earlier connections were not quite on a level with
24468: her own. Not that she knew much about them. That her husband had at
24469: first been employed in a bank, that he had afterwards entered into what
24470: he called city business and gained a fortune before he was
24471: three-and-thirty, that he had married a widow who was much older than
24472: himself—a Dissenter, and in other ways probably of that disadvantageous
24473: quality usually perceptible in a first wife if inquired into with the
24474: dispassionate judgment of a second—was almost as much as she had cared
24475: to learn beyond the glimpses which Mr. Bulstrode’s narrative
24476: occasionally gave of his early bent towards religion, his inclination
24477: to be a preacher, and his association with missionary and philanthropic
24478: efforts. She believed in him as an excellent man whose piety carried a
24479: peculiar eminence in belonging to a layman, whose influence had turned
24480: her own mind toward seriousness, and whose share of perishable good had
24481: been the means of raising her own position. But she also liked to think
24482: that it was well in every sense for Mr. Bulstrode to have won the hand
24483: of Harriet Vincy; whose family was undeniable in a Middlemarch light—a
24484: better light surely than any thrown in London thoroughfares or
24485: dissenting chapel-yards. The unreformed provincial mind distrusted
24486: London; and while true religion was everywhere saving, honest Mrs.
24487: Bulstrode was convinced that to be saved in the Church was more
24488: respectable. She so much wished to ignore towards others that her
24489: husband had ever been a London Dissenter, that she liked to keep it out
24490: of sight even in talking to him. He was quite aware of this; indeed in
24491: some respects he was rather afraid of this ingenuous wife, whose
24492: imitative piety and native worldliness were equally sincere, who had
24493: nothing to be ashamed of, and whom he had married out of a thorough
24494: inclination still subsisting. But his fears were such as belong to a
24495: man who cares to maintain his recognized supremacy: the loss of high
24496: consideration from his wife, as from every one else who did not clearly
24497: hate him out of enmity to the truth, would be as the beginning of death
24498: to him. When she said—
24499: 
24500: “Is he quite gone away?”
24501: 
24502: “Oh, I trust so,” he answered, with an effort to throw as much sober
24503: unconcern into his tone as possible!
24504: 
24505: But in truth Mr. Bulstrode was very far from a state of quiet trust. In
24506: the interview at the Bank, Raffles had made it evident that his
24507: eagerness to torment was almost as strong in him as any other greed. He
24508: had frankly said that he had turned out of the way to come to
24509: Middlemarch, just to look about him and see whether the neighborhood
24510: would suit him to live in. He had certainly had a few debts to pay more
24511: than he expected, but the two hundred pounds were not gone yet: a cool
24512: five-and-twenty would suffice him to go away with for the present. What
24513: he had wanted chiefly was to see his friend Nick and family, and know
24514: all about the prosperity of a man to whom he was so much attached.
24515: By-and-by he might come back for a longer stay. This time Raffles
24516: declined to be “seen off the premises,” as he expressed it—declined to
24517: quit Middlemarch under Bulstrode’s eyes. He meant to go by coach the
24518: next day—if he chose.
24519: 
24520: Bulstrode felt himself helpless. Neither threats nor coaxing could
24521: avail: he could not count on any persistent fear nor on any promise. On
24522: the contrary, he felt a cold certainty at his heart that Raffles—unless
24523: providence sent death to hinder him—would come back to Middlemarch
24524: before long. And that certainty was a terror.
24525: 
24526: It was not that he was in danger of legal punishment or of beggary: he
24527: was in danger only of seeing disclosed to the judgment of his neighbors
24528: and the mournful perception of his wife certain facts of his past life
24529: which would render him an object of scorn and an opprobrium of the
24530: religion with which he had diligently associated himself. The terror of
24531: being judged sharpens the memory: it sends an inevitable glare over
24532: that long-unvisited past which has been habitually recalled only in
24533: general phrases. Even without memory, the life is bound into one by a
24534: zone of dependence in growth and decay; but intense memory forces a man
24535: to own his blameworthy past. With memory set smarting like a reopened
24536: wound, a man’s past is not simply a dead history, an outworn
24537: preparation of the present: it is not a repented error shaken loose
24538: from the life: it is a still quivering part of himself, bringing
24539: shudders and bitter flavors and the tinglings of a merited shame.
24540: 
24541: Into this second life Bulstrode’s past had now risen, only the
24542: pleasures of it seeming to have lost their quality. Night and day,
24543: without interruption save of brief sleep which only wove retrospect and
24544: fear into a fantastic present, he felt the scenes of his earlier life
24545: coming between him and everything else, as obstinately as when we look
24546: through the window from a lighted room, the objects we turn our backs
24547: on are still before us, instead of the grass and the trees. The
24548: successive events inward and outward were there in one view: though
24549: each might be dwelt on in turn, the rest still kept their hold in the
24550: consciousness.
24551: 
24552: Once more he saw himself the young banker’s clerk, with an agreeable
24553: person, as clever in figures as he was fluent in speech and fond of
24554: theological definition: an eminent though young member of a Calvinistic
24555: dissenting church at Highbury, having had striking experience in
24556: conviction of sin and sense of pardon. Again he heard himself called
24557: for as Brother Bulstrode in prayer meetings, speaking on religious
24558: platforms, preaching in private houses. Again he felt himself thinking
24559: of the ministry as possibly his vocation, and inclined towards
24560: missionary labor. That was the happiest time of his life: that was the
24561: spot he would have chosen now to awake in and find the rest a dream.
24562: The people among whom Brother Bulstrode was distinguished were very
24563: few, but they were very near to him, and stirred his satisfaction the
24564: more; his power stretched through a narrow space, but he felt its
24565: effect the more intensely. He believed without effort in the peculiar
24566: work of grace within him, and in the signs that God intended him for
24567: special instrumentality.
24568: 
24569: Then came the moment of transition; it was with the sense of promotion
24570: he had when he, an orphan educated at a commercial charity-school, was
24571: invited to a fine villa belonging to Mr. Dunkirk, the richest man in
24572: the congregation. Soon he became an intimate there, honored for his
24573: piety by the wife, marked out for his ability by the husband, whose
24574: wealth was due to a flourishing city and west-end trade. That was the
24575: setting-in of a new current for his ambition, directing his prospects
24576: of “instrumentality” towards the uniting of distinguished religious
24577: gifts with successful business.
24578: 
24579: By-and-by came a decided external leading: a confidential subordinate
24580: partner died, and nobody seemed to the principal so well fitted to fill
24581: the severely felt vacancy as his young friend Bulstrode, if he would
24582: become confidential accountant. The offer was accepted. The business
24583: was a pawnbroker’s, of the most magnificent sort both in extent and
24584: profits; and on a short acquaintance with it Bulstrode became aware
24585: that one source of magnificent profit was the easy reception of any
24586: goods offered, without strict inquiry as to where they came from. But
24587: there was a branch house at the west end, and no pettiness or dinginess
24588: to give suggestions of shame.
24589: 
24590: He remembered his first moments of shrinking. They were private, and
24591: were filled with arguments; some of these taking the form of prayer.
24592: The business was established and had old roots; is it not one thing to
24593: set up a new gin-palace and another to accept an investment in an old
24594: one? The profits made out of lost souls—where can the line be drawn at
24595: which they begin in human transactions? Was it not even God’s way of
24596: saving His chosen? “Thou knowest,”—the young Bulstrode had said then,
24597: as the older Bulstrode was saying now—“Thou knowest how loose my soul
24598: sits from these things—how I view them all as implements for tilling
24599: Thy garden rescued here and there from the wilderness.”
24600: 
24601: Metaphors and precedents were not wanting; peculiar spiritual
24602: experiences were not wanting which at last made the retention of his
24603: position seem a service demanded of him: the vista of a fortune had
24604: already opened itself, and Bulstrode’s shrinking remained private. Mr.
24605: Dunkirk had never expected that there would be any shrinking at all: he
24606: had never conceived that trade had anything to do with the scheme of
24607: salvation. And it was true that Bulstrode found himself carrying on two
24608: distinct lives; his religious activity could not be incompatible with
24609: his business as soon as he had argued himself into not feeling it
24610: incompatible.
24611: 
24612: Mentally surrounded with that past again, Bulstrode had the same
24613: pleas—indeed, the years had been perpetually spinning them into
24614: intricate thickness, like masses of spider-web, padding the moral
24615: sensibility; nay, as age made egoism more eager but less enjoying, his
24616: soul had become more saturated with the belief that he did everything
24617: for God’s sake, being indifferent to it for his own. And yet—if he
24618: could be back in that far-off spot with his youthful poverty—why, then
24619: he would choose to be a missionary.
24620: 
24621: But the train of causes in which he had locked himself went on. There
24622: was trouble in the fine villa at Highbury. Years before, the only
24623: daughter had run away, defied her parents, and gone on the stage; and
24624: now the only boy died, and after a short time Mr. Dunkirk died also.
24625: The wife, a simple pious woman, left with all the wealth in and out of
24626: the magnificent trade, of which she never knew the precise nature, had
24627: come to believe in Bulstrode, and innocently adore him as women often
24628: adore their priest or “man-made” minister. It was natural that after a
24629: time marriage should have been thought of between them. But Mrs.
24630: Dunkirk had qualms and yearnings about her daughter, who had long been
24631: regarded as lost both to God and her parents. It was known that the
24632: daughter had married, but she was utterly gone out of sight. The
24633: mother, having lost her boy, imagined a grandson, and wished in a
24634: double sense to reclaim her daughter. If she were found, there would be
24635: a channel for property—perhaps a wide one—in the provision for several
24636: grandchildren. Efforts to find her must be made before Mrs. Dunkirk
24637: would marry again. Bulstrode concurred; but after advertisement as well
24638: as other modes of inquiry had been tried, the mother believed that her
24639: daughter was not to be found, and consented to marry without
24640: reservation of property.
24641: 
24642: The daughter had been found; but only one man besides Bulstrode knew
24643: it, and he was paid for keeping silence and carrying himself away.
24644: 
24645: That was the bare fact which Bulstrode was now forced to see in the
24646: rigid outline with which acts present themselves to onlookers. But for
24647: himself at that distant time, and even now in burning memory, the fact
24648: was broken into little sequences, each justified as it came by
24649: reasonings which seemed to prove it righteous. Bulstrode’s course up to
24650: that time had, he thought, been sanctioned by remarkable providences,
24651: appearing to point the way for him to be the agent in making the best
24652: use of a large property and withdrawing it from perversion. Death and
24653: other striking dispositions, such as feminine trustfulness, had come;
24654: and Bulstrode would have adopted Cromwell’s words—“Do you call these
24655: bare events? The Lord pity you!” The events were comparatively small,
24656: but the essential condition was there—namely, that they were in favor
24657: of his own ends. It was easy for him to settle what was due from him to
24658: others by inquiring what were God’s intentions with regard to himself.
24659: Could it be for God’s service that this fortune should in any
24660: considerable proportion go to a young woman and her husband who were
24661: given up to the lightest pursuits, and might scatter it abroad in
24662: triviality—people who seemed to lie outside the path of remarkable
24663: providences? Bulstrode had never said to himself beforehand, “The
24664: daughter shall not be found”—nevertheless when the moment came he kept
24665: her existence hidden; and when other moments followed, he soothed the
24666: mother with consolation in the probability that the unhappy young woman
24667: might be no more.
24668: 
24669: There were hours in which Bulstrode felt that his action was
24670: unrighteous; but how could he go back? He had mental exercises, called
24671: himself nought, laid hold on redemption, and went on in his course of
24672: instrumentality. And after five years Death again came to widen his
24673: path, by taking away his wife. He did gradually withdraw his capital,
24674: but he did not make the sacrifices requisite to put an end to the
24675: business, which was carried on for thirteen years afterwards before it
24676: finally collapsed. Meanwhile Nicholas Bulstrode had used his hundred
24677: thousand discreetly, and was become provincially, solidly important—a
24678: banker, a Churchman, a public benefactor; also a sleeping partner in
24679: trading concerns, in which his ability was directed to economy in the
24680: raw material, as in the case of the dyes which rotted Mr. Vincy’s silk.
24681: And now, when this respectability had lasted undisturbed for nearly
24682: thirty years—when all that preceded it had long lain benumbed in the
24683: consciousness—that past had risen and immersed his thought as if with
24684: the terrible irruption of a new sense overburthening the feeble being.
24685: 
24686: Meanwhile, in his conversation with Raffles, he had learned something
24687: momentous, something which entered actively into the struggle of his
24688: longings and terrors. There, he thought, lay an opening towards
24689: spiritual, perhaps towards material rescue.
24690: 
24691: The spiritual kind of rescue was a genuine need with him. There may be
24692: coarse hypocrites, who consciously affect beliefs and emotions for the
24693: sake of gulling the world, but Bulstrode was not one of them. He was
24694: simply a man whose desires had been stronger than his theoretic
24695: beliefs, and who had gradually explained the gratification of his
24696: desires into satisfactory agreement with those beliefs. If this be
24697: hypocrisy, it is a process which shows itself occasionally in us all,
24698: to whatever confession we belong, and whether we believe in the future
24699: perfection of our race or in the nearest date fixed for the end of the
24700: world; whether we regard the earth as a putrefying nidus for a saved
24701: remnant, including ourselves, or have a passionate belief in the
24702: solidarity of mankind.
24703: 
24704: The service he could do to the cause of religion had been through life
24705: the ground he alleged to himself for his choice of action: it had been
24706: the motive which he had poured out in his prayers. Who would use money
24707: and position better than he meant to use them? Who could surpass him in
24708: self-abhorrence and exaltation of God’s cause? And to Mr. Bulstrode
24709: God’s cause was something distinct from his own rectitude of conduct:
24710: it enforced a discrimination of God’s enemies, who were to be used
24711: merely as instruments, and whom it would be as well if possible to keep
24712: out of money and consequent influence. Also, profitable investments in
24713: trades where the power of the prince of this world showed its most
24714: active devices, became sanctified by a right application of the profits
24715: in the hands of God’s servant.
24716: 
24717: This implicit reasoning is essentially no more peculiar to evangelical
24718: belief than the use of wide phrases for narrow motives is peculiar to
24719: Englishmen. There is no general doctrine which is not capable of eating
24720: out our morality if unchecked by the deep-seated habit of direct
24721: fellow-feeling with individual fellow-men.
24722: 
24723: But a man who believes in something else than his own greed, has
24724: necessarily a conscience or standard to which he more or less adapts
24725: himself. Bulstrode’s standard had been his serviceableness to God’s
24726: cause: “I am sinful and nought—a vessel to be consecrated by use—but
24727: use me!”—had been the mould into which he had constrained his immense
24728: need of being something important and predominating. And now had come a
24729: moment in which that mould seemed in danger of being broken and utterly
24730: cast away.
24731: 
24732: What if the acts he had reconciled himself to because they made him a
24733: stronger instrument of the divine glory, were to become the pretext of
24734: the scoffer, and a darkening of that glory? If this were to be the
24735: ruling of Providence, he was cast out from the temple as one who had
24736: brought unclean offerings.
24737: 
24738: He had long poured out utterances of repentance. But today a repentance
24739: had come which was of a bitterer flavor, and a threatening Providence
24740: urged him to a kind of propitiation which was not simply a doctrinal
24741: transaction. The divine tribunal had changed its aspect for him;
24742: self-prostration was no longer enough, and he must bring restitution in
24743: his hand. It was really before his God that Bulstrode was about to
24744: attempt such restitution as seemed possible: a great dread had seized
24745: his susceptible frame, and the scorching approach of shame wrought in
24746: him a new spiritual need. Night and day, while the resurgent
24747: threatening past was making a conscience within him, he was thinking by
24748: what means he could recover peace and trust—by what sacrifice he could
24749: stay the rod. His belief in these moments of dread was, that if he
24750: spontaneously did something right, God would save him from the
24751: consequences of wrong-doing. For religion can only change when the
24752: emotions which fill it are changed; and the religion of personal fear
24753: remains nearly at the level of the savage.
24754: 
24755: He had seen Raffles actually going away on the Brassing coach, and this
24756: was a temporary relief; it removed the pressure of an immediate dread,
24757: but did not put an end to the spiritual conflict and the need to win
24758: protection. At last he came to a difficult resolve, and wrote a letter
24759: to Will Ladislaw, begging him to be at the Shrubs that evening for a
24760: private interview at nine o’clock. Will had felt no particular surprise
24761: at the request, and connected it with some new notions about the
24762: “Pioneer;” but when he was shown into Mr. Bulstrode’s private room, he
24763: was struck with the painfully worn look on the banker’s face, and was
24764: going to say, “Are you ill?” when, checking himself in that abruptness,
24765: he only inquired after Mrs. Bulstrode, and her satisfaction with the
24766: picture bought for her.
24767: 
24768: “Thank you, she is quite satisfied; she has gone out with her daughters
24769: this evening. I begged you to come, Mr. Ladislaw, because I have a
24770: communication of a very private—indeed, I will say, of a sacredly
24771: confidential nature, which I desire to make to you. Nothing, I dare
24772: say, has been farther from your thoughts than that there had been
24773: important ties in the past which could connect your history with mine.”
24774: 
24775: Will felt something like an electric shock. He was already in a state
24776: of keen sensitiveness and hardly allayed agitation on the subject of
24777: ties in the past, and his presentiments were not agreeable. It seemed
24778: like the fluctuations of a dream—as if the action begun by that loud
24779: bloated stranger were being carried on by this pale-eyed sickly looking
24780: piece of respectability, whose subdued tone and glib formality of
24781: speech were at this moment almost as repulsive to him as their
24782: remembered contrast. He answered, with a marked change of color—
24783: 
24784: “No, indeed, nothing.”
24785: 
24786: “You see before you, Mr. Ladislaw, a man who is deeply stricken. But
24787: for the urgency of conscience and the knowledge that I am before the
24788: bar of One who seeth not as man seeth, I should be under no compulsion
24789: to make the disclosure which has been my object in asking you to come
24790: here to-night. So far as human laws go, you have no claim on me
24791: whatever.”
24792: 
24793: Will was even more uncomfortable than wondering. Mr. Bulstrode had
24794: paused, leaning his head on his hand, and looking at the floor. But he
24795: now fixed his examining glance on Will and said—
24796: 
24797: “I am told that your mother’s name was Sarah Dunkirk, and that she ran
24798: away from her friends to go on the stage. Also, that your father was at
24799: one time much emaciated by illness. May I ask if you can confirm these
24800: statements?”
24801: 
24802: “Yes, they are all true,” said Will, struck with the order in which an
24803: inquiry had come, that might have been expected to be preliminary to
24804: the banker’s previous hints. But Mr. Bulstrode had to-night followed
24805: the order of his emotions; he entertained no doubt that the opportunity
24806: for restitution had come, and he had an overpowering impulse towards
24807: the penitential expression by which he was deprecating chastisement.
24808: 
24809: “Do you know any particulars of your mother’s family?” he continued.
24810: 
24811: “No; she never liked to speak of them. She was a very generous,
24812: honorable woman,” said Will, almost angrily.
24813: 
24814: “I do not wish to allege anything against her. Did she never mention
24815: her mother to you at all?”
24816: 
24817: “I have heard her say that she thought her mother did not know the
24818: reason of her running away. She said ‘poor mother’ in a pitying tone.”
24819: 
24820: “That mother became my wife,” said Bulstrode, and then paused a moment
24821: before he added, “you have a claim on me, Mr. Ladislaw: as I said
24822: before, not a legal claim, but one which my conscience recognizes. I
24823: was enriched by that marriage—a result which would probably not have
24824: taken place—certainly not to the same extent—if your grandmother could
24825: have discovered her daughter. That daughter, I gather, is no longer
24826: living!”
24827: 
24828: “No,” said Will, feeling suspicion and repugnance rising so strongly
24829: within him, that without quite knowing what he did, he took his hat
24830: from the floor and stood up. The impulse within him was to reject the
24831: disclosed connection.
24832: 
24833: “Pray be seated, Mr. Ladislaw,” said Bulstrode, anxiously. “Doubtless
24834: you are startled by the suddenness of this discovery. But I entreat
24835: your patience with one who is already bowed down by inward trial.”
24836: 
24837: Will reseated himself, feeling some pity which was half contempt for
24838: this voluntary self-abasement of an elderly man.
24839: 
24840: “It is my wish, Mr. Ladislaw, to make amends for the deprivation which
24841: befell your mother. I know that you are without fortune, and I wish to
24842: supply you adequately from a store which would have probably already
24843: been yours had your grandmother been certain of your mother’s existence
24844: and been able to find her.”
24845: 
24846: Mr. Bulstrode paused. He felt that he was performing a striking piece
24847: of scrupulosity in the judgment of his auditor, and a penitential act
24848: in the eyes of God. He had no clew to the state of Will Ladislaw’s
24849: mind, smarting as it was from the clear hints of Raffles, and with its
24850: natural quickness in construction stimulated by the expectation of
24851: discoveries which he would have been glad to conjure back into
24852: darkness. Will made no answer for several moments, till Mr. Bulstrode,
24853: who at the end of his speech had cast his eyes on the floor, now raised
24854: them with an examining glance, which Will met fully, saying—
24855: 
24856: “I suppose you did know of my mother’s existence, and knew where she
24857: might have been found.”
24858: 
24859: Bulstrode shrank—there was a visible quivering in his face and hands.
24860: He was totally unprepared to have his advances met in this way, or to
24861: find himself urged into more revelation than he had beforehand set down
24862: as needful. But at that moment he dared not tell a lie, and he felt
24863: suddenly uncertain of his ground which he had trodden with some
24864: confidence before.
24865: 
24866: “I will not deny that you conjecture rightly,” he answered, with a
24867: faltering in his tone. “And I wish to make atonement to you as the one
24868: still remaining who has suffered a loss through me. You enter, I trust,
24869: into my purpose, Mr. Ladislaw, which has a reference to higher than
24870: merely human claims, and as I have already said, is entirely
24871: independent of any legal compulsion. I am ready to narrow my own
24872: resources and the prospects of my family by binding myself to allow you
24873: five hundred pounds yearly during my life, and to leave you a
24874: proportional capital at my death—nay, to do still more, if more should
24875: be definitely necessary to any laudable project on your part.” Mr.
24876: Bulstrode had gone on to particulars in the expectation that these
24877: would work strongly on Ladislaw, and merge other feelings in grateful
24878: acceptance.
24879: 
24880: But Will was looking as stubborn as possible, with his lip pouting and
24881: his fingers in his side-pockets. He was not in the least touched, and
24882: said firmly,—
24883: 
24884: “Before I make any reply to your proposition, Mr. Bulstrode, I must beg
24885: you to answer a question or two. Were you connected with the business
24886: by which that fortune you speak of was originally made?”
24887: 
24888: Mr. Bulstrode’s thought was, “Raffles has told him.” How could he
24889: refuse to answer when he had volunteered what drew forth the question?
24890: He answered, “Yes.”
24891: 
24892: “And was that business—or was it not—a thoroughly dishonorable one—nay,
24893: one that, if its nature had been made public, might have ranked those
24894: concerned in it with thieves and convicts?”
24895: 
24896: Will’s tone had a cutting bitterness: he was moved to put his question
24897: as nakedly as he could.
24898: 
24899: Bulstrode reddened with irrepressible anger. He had been prepared for a
24900: scene of self-abasement, but his intense pride and his habit of
24901: supremacy overpowered penitence, and even dread, when this young man,
24902: whom he had meant to benefit, turned on him with the air of a judge.
24903: 
24904: “The business was established before I became connected with it, sir;
24905: nor is it for you to institute an inquiry of that kind,” he answered,
24906: not raising his voice, but speaking with quick defiantness.
24907: 
24908: “Yes, it is,” said Will, starting up again with his hat in his hand.
24909: “It is eminently mine to ask such questions, when I have to decide
24910: whether I will have transactions with you and accept your money. My
24911: unblemished honor is important to me. It is important to me to have no
24912: stain on my birth and connections. And now I find there is a stain
24913: which I can’t help. My mother felt it, and tried to keep as clear of it
24914: as she could, and so will I. You shall keep your ill-gotten money. If I
24915: had any fortune of my own, I would willingly pay it to any one who
24916: could disprove what you have told me. What I have to thank you for is
24917: that you kept the money till now, when I can refuse it. It ought to lie
24918: with a man’s self that he is a gentleman. Good-night, sir.”
24919: 
24920: Bulstrode was going to speak, but Will, with determined quickness, was
24921: out of the room in an instant, and in another the hall-door had closed
24922: behind him. He was too strongly possessed with passionate rebellion
24923: against this inherited blot which had been thrust on his knowledge to
24924: reflect at present whether he had not been too hard on Bulstrode—too
24925: arrogantly merciless towards a man of sixty, who was making efforts at
24926: retrieval when time had rendered them vain.
24927: 
24928: No third person listening could have thoroughly understood the
24929: impetuosity of Will’s repulse or the bitterness of his words. No one
24930: but himself then knew how everything connected with the sentiment of
24931: his own dignity had an immediate bearing for him on his relation to
24932: Dorothea and to Mr. Casaubon’s treatment of him. And in the rush of
24933: impulses by which he flung back that offer of Bulstrode’s there was
24934: mingled the sense that it would have been impossible for him ever to
24935: tell Dorothea that he had accepted it.
24936: 
24937: As for Bulstrode—when Will was gone he suffered a violent reaction, and
24938: wept like a woman. It was the first time he had encountered an open
24939: expression of scorn from any man higher than Raffles; and with that
24940: scorn hurrying like venom through his system, there was no sensibility
24941: left to consolations. But the relief of weeping had to be checked. His
24942: wife and daughters soon came home from hearing the address of an
24943: Oriental missionary, and were full of regret that papa had not heard,
24944: in the first instance, the interesting things which they tried to
24945: repeat to him.
24946: 
24947: Perhaps, through all other hidden thoughts, the one that breathed most
24948: comfort was, that Will Ladislaw at least was not likely to publish what
24949: had taken place that evening.
24950: 
24951: 
24952: 
24953: 
24954: CHAPTER LXII.
24955: 
24956: He was a squyer of lowe degre,
24957: That loved the king’s daughter of Hungrie.
24958: —_Old Romance_.
24959: 
24960: 
24961: Will Ladislaw’s mind was now wholly bent on seeing Dorothea again, and
24962: forthwith quitting Middlemarch. The morning after his agitating scene
24963: with Bulstrode he wrote a brief letter to her, saying that various
24964: causes had detained him in the neighborhood longer than he had
24965: expected, and asking her permission to call again at Lowick at some
24966: hour which she would mention on the earliest possible day, he being
24967: anxious to depart, but unwilling to do so until she had granted him an
24968: interview. He left the letter at the office, ordering the messenger to
24969: carry it to Lowick Manor, and wait for an answer.
24970: 
24971: Ladislaw felt the awkwardness of asking for more last words. His former
24972: farewell had been made in the hearing of Sir James Chettam, and had
24973: been announced as final even to the butler. It is certainly trying to a
24974: man’s dignity to reappear when he is not expected to do so: a first
24975: farewell has pathos in it, but to come back for a second lends an
24976: opening to comedy, and it was possible even that there might be bitter
24977: sneers afloat about Will’s motives for lingering. Still it was on the
24978: whole more satisfactory to his feeling to take the directest means of
24979: seeing Dorothea, than to use any device which might give an air of
24980: chance to a meeting of which he wished her to understand that it was
24981: what he earnestly sought. When he had parted from her before, he had
24982: been in ignorance of facts which gave a new aspect to the relation
24983: between them, and made a more absolute severance than he had then
24984: believed in. He knew nothing of Dorothea’s private fortune, and being
24985: little used to reflect on such matters, took it for granted that
24986: according to Mr. Casaubon’s arrangement marriage to him, Will Ladislaw,
24987: would mean that she consented to be penniless. That was not what he
24988: could wish for even in his secret heart, or even if she had been ready
24989: to meet such hard contrast for his sake. And then, too, there was the
24990: fresh smart of that disclosure about his mother’s family, which if
24991: known would be an added reason why Dorothea’s friends should look down
24992: upon him as utterly below her. The secret hope that after some years he
24993: might come back with the sense that he had at least a personal value
24994: equal to her wealth, seemed now the dreamy continuation of a dream.
24995: This change would surely justify him in asking Dorothea to receive him
24996: once more.
24997: 
24998: But Dorothea on that morning was not at home to receive Will’s note. In
24999: consequence of a letter from her uncle announcing his intention to be
25000: at home in a week, she had driven first to Freshitt to carry the news,
25001: meaning to go on to the Grange to deliver some orders with which her
25002: uncle had intrusted her—thinking, as he said, “a little mental
25003: occupation of this sort good for a widow.”
25004: 
25005: If Will Ladislaw could have overheard some of the talk at Freshitt that
25006: morning, he would have felt all his suppositions confirmed as to the
25007: readiness of certain people to sneer at his lingering in the
25008: neighborhood. Sir James, indeed, though much relieved concerning
25009: Dorothea, had been on the watch to learn Ladislaw’s movements, and had
25010: an instructed informant in Mr. Standish, who was necessarily in his
25011: confidence on this matter. That Ladislaw had stayed in Middlemarch
25012: nearly two months after he had declared that he was going immediately,
25013: was a fact to embitter Sir James’s suspicions, or at least to justify
25014: his aversion to a “young fellow” whom he represented to himself as
25015: slight, volatile, and likely enough to show such recklessness as
25016: naturally went along with a position unriveted by family ties or a
25017: strict profession. But he had just heard something from Standish which,
25018: while it justified these surmises about Will, offered a means of
25019: nullifying all danger with regard to Dorothea.
25020: 
25021: Unwonted circumstances may make us all rather unlike ourselves: there
25022: are conditions under which the most majestic person is obliged to
25023: sneeze, and our emotions are liable to be acted on in the same
25024: incongruous manner. Good Sir James was this morning so far unlike
25025: himself that he was irritably anxious to say something to Dorothea on a
25026: subject which he usually avoided as if it had been a matter of shame to
25027: them both. He could not use Celia as a medium, because he did not
25028: choose that she should know the kind of gossip he had in his mind; and
25029: before Dorothea happened to arrive he had been trying to imagine how,
25030: with his shyness and unready tongue, he could ever manage to introduce
25031: his communication. Her unexpected presence brought him to utter
25032: hopelessness in his own power of saying anything unpleasant; but
25033: desperation suggested a resource; he sent the groom on an unsaddled
25034: horse across the park with a pencilled note to Mrs. Cadwallader, who
25035: already knew the gossip, and would think it no compromise of herself to
25036: repeat it as often as required.
25037: 
25038: Dorothea was detained on the good pretext that Mr. Garth, whom she
25039: wanted to see, was expected at the hall within the hour, and she was
25040: still talking to Caleb on the gravel when Sir James, on the watch for
25041: the rector’s wife, saw her coming and met her with the needful hints.
25042: 
25043: “Enough! I understand,”—said Mrs. Cadwallader. “You shall be innocent.
25044: I am such a blackamoor that I cannot smirch myself.”
25045: 
25046: “I don’t mean that it’s of any consequence,” said Sir James, disliking
25047: that Mrs. Cadwallader should understand too much. “Only it is desirable
25048: that Dorothea should know there are reasons why she should not receive
25049: him again; and I really can’t say so to her. It will come lightly from
25050: you.”
25051: 
25052: It came very lightly indeed. When Dorothea quitted Caleb and turned to
25053: meet them, it appeared that Mrs. Cadwallader had stepped across the
25054: park by the merest chance in the world, just to chat with Celia in a
25055: matronly way about the baby. And so Mr. Brooke was coming back?
25056: Delightful!—coming back, it was to be hoped, quite cured of
25057: Parliamentary fever and pioneering. Apropos of the “Pioneer”—somebody
25058: had prophesied that it would soon be like a dying dolphin, and turn all
25059: colors for want of knowing how to help itself, because Mr. Brooke’s
25060: protege, the brilliant young Ladislaw, was gone or going. Had Sir James
25061: heard that?
25062: 
25063: The three were walking along the gravel slowly, and Sir James, turning
25064: aside to whip a shrub, said he had heard something of that sort.
25065: 
25066: “All false!” said Mrs. Cadwallader. “He is not gone, or going,
25067: apparently; the ‘Pioneer’ keeps its color, and Mr. Orlando Ladislaw is
25068: making a sad dark-blue scandal by warbling continually with your Mr.
25069: Lydgate’s wife, who they tell me is as pretty as pretty can be. It
25070: seems nobody ever goes into the house without finding this young
25071: gentleman lying on the rug or warbling at the piano. But the people in
25072: manufacturing towns are always disreputable.”
25073: 
25074: “You began by saying that one report was false, Mrs. Cadwallader, and I
25075: believe this is false too,” said Dorothea, with indignant energy; “at
25076: least, I feel sure it is a misrepresentation. I will not hear any evil
25077: spoken of Mr. Ladislaw; he has already suffered too much injustice.”
25078: 
25079: Dorothea when thoroughly moved cared little what any one thought of her
25080: feelings; and even if she had been able to reflect, she would have held
25081: it petty to keep silence at injurious words about Will from fear of
25082: being herself misunderstood. Her face was flushed and her lip trembled.
25083: 
25084: Sir James, glancing at her, repented of his stratagem; but Mrs.
25085: Cadwallader, equal to all occasions, spread the palms of her hands
25086: outward and said—“Heaven grant it, my dear!—I mean that all bad tales
25087: about anybody may be false. But it is a pity that young Lydgate should
25088: have married one of these Middlemarch girls. Considering he’s a son of
25089: somebody, he might have got a woman with good blood in her veins, and
25090: not too young, who would have put up with his profession. There’s Clara
25091: Harfager, for instance, whose friends don’t know what to do with her;
25092: and she has a portion. Then we might have had her among us.
25093: However!—it’s no use being wise for other people. Where is Celia? Pray
25094: let us go in.”
25095: 
25096: “I am going on immediately to Tipton,” said Dorothea, rather haughtily.
25097: “Good-by.”
25098: 
25099: Sir James could say nothing as he accompanied her to the carriage. He
25100: was altogether discontented with the result of a contrivance which had
25101: cost him some secret humiliation beforehand.
25102: 
25103: Dorothea drove along between the berried hedgerows and the shorn
25104: corn-fields, not seeing or hearing anything around. The tears came and
25105: rolled down her cheeks, but she did not know it. The world, it seemed,
25106: was turning ugly and hateful, and there was no place for her
25107: trustfulness. “It is not true—it is not true!” was the voice within her
25108: that she listened to; but all the while a remembrance to which there
25109: had always clung a vague uneasiness would thrust itself on her
25110: attention—the remembrance of that day when she had found Will Ladislaw
25111: with Mrs. Lydgate, and had heard his voice accompanied by the piano.
25112: 
25113: “He said he would never do anything that I disapproved—I wish I could
25114: have told him that I disapproved of that,” said poor Dorothea,
25115: inwardly, feeling a strange alternation between anger with Will and the
25116: passionate defence of him. “They all try to blacken him before me; but
25117: I will care for no pain, if he is not to blame. I always believed he
25118: was good.”—These were her last thoughts before she felt that the
25119: carriage was passing under the archway of the lodge-gate at the Grange,
25120: when she hurriedly pressed her handkerchief to her face and began to
25121: think of her errands. The coachman begged leave to take out the horses
25122: for half an hour as there was something wrong with a shoe; and
25123: Dorothea, having the sense that she was going to rest, took off her
25124: gloves and bonnet, while she was leaning against a statue in the
25125: entrance-hall, and talking to the housekeeper. At last she said—
25126: 
25127: “I must stay here a little, Mrs. Kell. I will go into the library and
25128: write you some memoranda from my uncle’s letter, if you will open the
25129: shutters for me.”
25130: 
25131: “The shutters are open, madam,” said Mrs. Kell, following Dorothea, who
25132: had walked along as she spoke. “Mr. Ladislaw is there, looking for
25133: something.”
25134: 
25135: (Will had come to fetch a portfolio of his own sketches which he had
25136: missed in the act of packing his movables, and did not choose to leave
25137: behind.)
25138: 
25139: Dorothea’s heart seemed to turn over as if it had had a blow, but she
25140: was not perceptibly checked: in truth, the sense that Will was there
25141: was for the moment all-satisfying to her, like the sight of something
25142: precious that one has lost. When she reached the door she said to Mrs.
25143: Kell—
25144: 
25145: “Go in first, and tell him that I am here.”
25146: 
25147: Will had found his portfolio, and had laid it on the table at the far
25148: end of the room, to turn over the sketches and please himself by
25149: looking at the memorable piece of art which had a relation to nature
25150: too mysterious for Dorothea. He was smiling at it still, and shaking
25151: the sketches into order with the thought that he might find a letter
25152: from her awaiting him at Middlemarch, when Mrs. Kell close to his elbow
25153: said—
25154: 
25155: “Mrs. Casaubon is coming in, sir.”
25156: 
25157: Will turned round quickly, and the next moment Dorothea was entering.
25158: As Mrs. Kell closed the door behind her they met: each was looking at
25159: the other, and consciousness was overflowed by something that
25160: suppressed utterance. It was not confusion that kept them silent, for
25161: they both felt that parting was near, and there is no shamefacedness in
25162: a sad parting.
25163: 
25164: She moved automatically towards her uncle’s chair against the
25165: writing-table, and Will, after drawing it out a little for her, went a
25166: few paces off and stood opposite to her.
25167: 
25168: “Pray sit down,” said Dorothea, crossing her hands on her lap; “I am
25169: very glad you were here.” Will thought that her face looked just as it
25170: did when she first shook hands with him in Rome; for her widow’s cap,
25171: fixed in her bonnet, had gone off with it, and he could see that she
25172: had lately been shedding tears. But the mixture of anger in her
25173: agitation had vanished at the sight of him; she had been used, when
25174: they were face to face, always to feel confidence and the happy freedom
25175: which comes with mutual understanding, and how could other people’s
25176: words hinder that effect on a sudden? Let the music which can take
25177: possession of our frame and fill the air with joy for us, sound once
25178: more—what does it signify that we heard it found fault with in its
25179: absence?
25180: 
25181: “I have sent a letter to Lowick Manor to-day, asking leave to see you,”
25182: said Will, seating himself opposite to her. “I am going away
25183: immediately, and I could not go without speaking to you again.”
25184: 
25185: “I thought we had parted when you came to Lowick many weeks ago—you
25186: thought you were going then,” said Dorothea, her voice trembling a
25187: little.
25188: 
25189: “Yes; but I was in ignorance then of things which I know now—things
25190: which have altered my feelings about the future. When I saw you before,
25191: I was dreaming that I might come back some day. I don’t think I ever
25192: shall—now.” Will paused here.
25193: 
25194: “You wished me to know the reasons?” said Dorothea, timidly.
25195: 
25196: “Yes,” said Will, impetuously, shaking his head backward, and looking
25197: away from her with irritation in his face. “Of course I must wish it. I
25198: have been grossly insulted in your eyes and in the eyes of others.
25199: There has been a mean implication against my character. I wish you to
25200: know that under no circumstances would I have lowered myself by—under
25201: no circumstances would I have given men the chance of saying that I
25202: sought money under the pretext of seeking—something else. There was no
25203: need of other safeguard against me—the safeguard of wealth was enough.”
25204: 
25205: Will rose from his chair with the last word and went—he hardly knew
25206: where; but it was to the projecting window nearest him, which had been
25207: open as now about the same season a year ago, when he and Dorothea had
25208: stood within it and talked together. Her whole heart was going out at
25209: this moment in sympathy with Will’s indignation: she only wanted to
25210: convince him that she had never done him injustice, and he seemed to
25211: have turned away from her as if she too had been part of the unfriendly
25212: world.
25213: 
25214: “It would be very unkind of you to suppose that I ever attributed any
25215: meanness to you,” she began. Then in her ardent way, wanting to plead
25216: with him, she moved from her chair and went in front of him to her old
25217: place in the window, saying, “Do you suppose that I ever disbelieved in
25218: you?”
25219: 
25220: When Will saw her there, he gave a start and moved backward out of the
25221: window, without meeting her glance. Dorothea was hurt by this movement
25222: following up the previous anger of his tone. She was ready to say that
25223: it was as hard on her as on him, and that she was helpless; but those
25224: strange particulars of their relation which neither of them could
25225: explicitly mention kept her always in dread of saying too much. At this
25226: moment she had no belief that Will would in any case have wanted to
25227: marry her, and she feared using words which might imply such a belief.
25228: She only said earnestly, recurring to his last word—
25229: 
25230: “I am sure no safeguard was ever needed against you.”
25231: 
25232: Will did not answer. In the stormy fluctuation of his feelings these
25233: words of hers seemed to him cruelly neutral, and he looked pale and
25234: miserable after his angry outburst. He went to the table and fastened
25235: up his portfolio, while Dorothea looked at him from the distance. They
25236: were wasting these last moments together in wretched silence. What
25237: could he say, since what had got obstinately uppermost in his mind was
25238: the passionate love for her which he forbade himself to utter? What
25239: could she say, since she might offer him no help—since she was forced
25240: to keep the money that ought to have been his?—since to-day he seemed
25241: not to respond as he used to do to her thorough trust and liking?
25242: 
25243: But Will at last turned away from his portfolio and approached the
25244: window again.
25245: 
25246: “I must go,” he said, with that peculiar look of the eyes which
25247: sometimes accompanies bitter feeling, as if they had been tired and
25248: burned with gazing too close at a light.
25249: 
25250: “What shall you do in life?” said Dorothea, timidly. “Have your
25251: intentions remained just the same as when we said good-by before?”
25252: 
25253: “Yes,” said Will, in a tone that seemed to waive the subject as
25254: uninteresting. “I shall work away at the first thing that offers. I
25255: suppose one gets a habit of doing without happiness or hope.”
25256: 
25257: “Oh, what sad words!” said Dorothea, with a dangerous tendency to sob.
25258: Then trying to smile, she added, “We used to agree that we were alike
25259: in speaking too strongly.”
25260: 
25261: “I have not spoken too strongly now,” said Will, leaning back against
25262: the angle of the wall. “There are certain things which a man can only
25263: go through once in his life; and he must know some time or other that
25264: the best is over with him. This experience has happened to me while I
25265: am very young—that is all. What I care more for than I can ever care
25266: for anything else is absolutely forbidden to me—I don’t mean merely by
25267: being out of my reach, but forbidden me, even if it were within my
25268: reach, by my own pride and honor—by everything I respect myself for. Of
25269: course I shall go on living as a man might do who had seen heaven in a
25270: trance.”
25271: 
25272: Will paused, imagining that it would be impossible for Dorothea to
25273: misunderstand this; indeed he felt that he was contradicting himself
25274: and offending against his self-approval in speaking to her so plainly;
25275: but still—it could not be fairly called wooing a woman to tell her that
25276: he would never woo her. It must be admitted to be a ghostly kind of
25277: wooing.
25278: 
25279: But Dorothea’s mind was rapidly going over the past with quite another
25280: vision than his. The thought that she herself might be what Will most
25281: cared for did throb through her an instant, but then came doubt: the
25282: memory of the little they had lived through together turned pale and
25283: shrank before the memory which suggested how much fuller might have
25284: been the intercourse between Will and some one else with whom he had
25285: had constant companionship. Everything he had said might refer to that
25286: other relation, and whatever had passed between him and herself was
25287: thoroughly explained by what she had always regarded as their simple
25288: friendship and the cruel obstruction thrust upon it by her husband’s
25289: injurious act. Dorothea stood silent, with her eyes cast down dreamily,
25290: while images crowded upon her which left the sickening certainty that
25291: Will was referring to Mrs. Lydgate. But why sickening? He wanted her to
25292: know that here too his conduct should be above suspicion.
25293: 
25294: Will was not surprised at her silence. His mind also was tumultuously
25295: busy while he watched her, and he was feeling rather wildly that
25296: something must happen to hinder their parting—some miracle, clearly
25297: nothing in their own deliberate speech. Yet, after all, had she any
25298: love for him?—he could not pretend to himself that he would rather
25299: believe her to be without that pain. He could not deny that a secret
25300: longing for the assurance that she loved him was at the root of all his
25301: words.
25302: 
25303: Neither of them knew how long they stood in that way. Dorothea was
25304: raising her eyes, and was about to speak, when the door opened and her
25305: footman came to say—
25306: 
25307: “The horses are ready, madam, whenever you like to start.”
25308: 
25309: “Presently,” said Dorothea. Then turning to Will, she said, “I have
25310: some memoranda to write for the housekeeper.”
25311: 
25312: “I must go,” said Will, when the door had closed again—advancing
25313: towards her. “The day after to-morrow I shall leave Middlemarch.”
25314: 
25315: “You have acted in every way rightly,” said Dorothea, in a low tone,
25316: feeling a pressure at her heart which made it difficult to speak.
25317: 
25318: She put out her hand, and Will took it for an instant without speaking,
25319: for her words had seemed to him cruelly cold and unlike herself. Their
25320: eyes met, but there was discontent in his, and in hers there was only
25321: sadness. He turned away and took his portfolio under his arm.
25322: 
25323: “I have never done you injustice. Please remember me,” said Dorothea,
25324: repressing a rising sob.
25325: 
25326: “Why should you say that?” said Will, with irritation. “As if I were
25327: not in danger of forgetting everything else.”
25328: 
25329: He had really a movement of anger against her at that moment, and it
25330: impelled him to go away without pause. It was all one flash to
25331: Dorothea—his last words—his distant bow to her as he reached the
25332: door—the sense that he was no longer there. She sank into the chair,
25333: and for a few moments sat like a statue, while images and emotions were
25334: hurrying upon her. Joy came first, in spite of the threatening train
25335: behind it—joy in the impression that it was really herself whom Will
25336: loved and was renouncing, that there was really no other love less
25337: permissible, more blameworthy, which honor was hurrying him away from.
25338: They were parted all the same, but—Dorothea drew a deep breath and felt
25339: her strength return—she could think of him unrestrainedly. At that
25340: moment the parting was easy to bear: the first sense of loving and
25341: being loved excluded sorrow. It was as if some hard icy pressure had
25342: melted, and her consciousness had room to expand: her past was come
25343: back to her with larger interpretation. The joy was not the
25344: less—perhaps it was the more complete just then—because of the
25345: irrevocable parting; for there was no reproach, no contemptuous wonder
25346: to imagine in any eye or from any lips. He had acted so as to defy
25347: reproach, and make wonder respectful.
25348: 
25349: Any one watching her might have seen that there was a fortifying
25350: thought within her. Just as when inventive power is working with glad
25351: ease some small claim on the attention is fully met as if it were only
25352: a cranny opened to the sunlight, it was easy now for Dorothea to write
25353: her memoranda. She spoke her last words to the housekeeper in cheerful
25354: tones, and when she seated herself in the carriage her eyes were bright
25355: and her cheeks blooming under the dismal bonnet. She threw back the
25356: heavy “weepers,” and looked before her, wondering which road Will had
25357: taken. It was in her nature to be proud that he was blameless, and
25358: through all her feelings there ran this vein—“I was right to defend
25359: him.”
25360: 
25361: The coachman was used to drive his grays at a good pace, Mr. Casaubon
25362: being unenjoying and impatient in everything away from his desk, and
25363: wanting to get to the end of all journeys; and Dorothea was now bowled
25364: along quickly. Driving was pleasant, for rain in the night had laid the
25365: dust, and the blue sky looked far off, away from the region of the
25366: great clouds that sailed in masses. The earth looked like a happy place
25367: under the vast heavens, and Dorothea was wishing that she might
25368: overtake Will and see him once more.
25369: 
25370: After a turn of the road, there he was with the portfolio under his
25371: arm; but the next moment she was passing him while he raised his hat,
25372: and she felt a pang at being seated there in a sort of exaltation,
25373: leaving him behind. She could not look back at him. It was as if a
25374: crowd of indifferent objects had thrust them asunder, and forced them
25375: along different paths, taking them farther and farther away from each
25376: other, and making it useless to look back. She could no more make any
25377: sign that would seem to say, “Need we part?” than she could stop the
25378: carriage to wait for him. Nay, what a world of reasons crowded upon her
25379: against any movement of her thought towards a future that might reverse
25380: the decision of this day!
25381: 
25382: “I only wish I had known before—I wish he knew—then we could be quite
25383: happy in thinking of each other, though we are forever parted. And if I
25384: could but have given him the money, and made things easier for
25385: him!”—were the longings that came back the most persistently. And yet,
25386: so heavily did the world weigh on her in spite of her independent
25387: energy, that with this idea of Will as in need of such help and at a
25388: disadvantage with the world, there came always the vision of that
25389: unfittingness of any closer relation between them which lay in the
25390: opinion of every one connected with her. She felt to the full all the
25391: imperativeness of the motives which urged Will’s conduct. How could he
25392: dream of her defying the barrier that her husband had placed between
25393: them?—how could she ever say to herself that she would defy it?
25394: 
25395: Will’s certainty as the carriage grew smaller in the distance, had much
25396: more bitterness in it. Very slight matters were enough to gall him in
25397: his sensitive mood, and the sight of Dorothea driving past him while he
25398: felt himself plodding along as a poor devil seeking a position in a
25399: world which in his present temper offered him little that he coveted,
25400: made his conduct seem a mere matter of necessity, and took away the
25401: sustainment of resolve. After all, he had no assurance that she loved
25402: him: could any man pretend that he was simply glad in such a case to
25403: have the suffering all on his own side?
25404:
