25405: That evening Will spent with the Lydgates; the next evening he was
25406: gone.
25407: 
25408: 
25409: 
25410: 
25411: BOOK VII.
25412: TWO TEMPTATIONS.
25413: 
25414: 
25415: 
25416: 
25417: CHAPTER LXIII.
25418: 
25419: These little things are great to little man.—GOLDSMITH.
25420: 
25421: 
25422: “Have you seen much of your scientific phoenix, Lydgate, lately?” said
25423: Mr. Toller at one of his Christmas dinner-parties, speaking to Mr.
25424: Farebrother on his right hand.
25425: 
25426: “Not much, I am sorry to say,” answered the Vicar, accustomed to parry
25427: Mr. Toller’s banter about his belief in the new medical light. “I am
25428: out of the way and he is too busy.”
25429: 
25430: “Is he? I am glad to hear it,” said Dr. Minchin, with mingled suavity
25431: and surprise.
25432: 
25433: “He gives a great deal of time to the New Hospital,” said Mr.
25434: Farebrother, who had his reasons for continuing the subject: “I hear of
25435: that from my neighbor, Mrs. Casaubon, who goes there often. She says
25436: Lydgate is indefatigable, and is making a fine thing of Bulstrode’s
25437: institution. He is preparing a new ward in case of the cholera coming
25438: to us.”
25439: 
25440: “And preparing theories of treatment to try on the patients, I
25441: suppose,” said Mr. Toller.
25442: 
25443: “Come, Toller, be candid,” said Mr. Farebrother. “You are too clever
25444: not to see the good of a bold fresh mind in medicine, as well as in
25445: everything else; and as to cholera, I fancy, none of you are very sure
25446: what you ought to do. If a man goes a little too far along a new road,
25447: it is usually himself that he harms more than any one else.”
25448: 
25449: “I am sure you and Wrench ought to be obliged to him,” said Dr.
25450: Minchin, looking towards Toller, “for he has sent you the cream of
25451: Peacock’s patients.”
25452: 
25453: “Lydgate has been living at a great rate for a young beginner,” said
25454: Mr. Harry Toller, the brewer. “I suppose his relations in the North
25455: back him up.”
25456: 
25457: “I hope so,” said Mr. Chichely, “else he ought not to have married that
25458: nice girl we were all so fond of. Hang it, one has a grudge against a
25459: man who carries off the prettiest girl in the town.”
25460: 
25461: “Ay, by God! and the best too,” said Mr. Standish.
25462: 
25463: “My friend Vincy didn’t half like the marriage, I know that,” said Mr.
25464: Chichely. “_He_ wouldn’t do much. How the relations on the other side
25465: may have come down I can’t say.” There was an emphatic kind of
25466: reticence in Mr. Chichely’s manner of speaking.
25467: 
25468: “Oh, I shouldn’t think Lydgate ever looked to practice for a living,”
25469: said Mr. Toller, with a slight touch of sarcasm, and there the subject
25470: was dropped.
25471: 
25472: This was not the first time that Mr. Farebrother had heard hints of
25473: Lydgate’s expenses being obviously too great to be met by his practice,
25474: but he thought it not unlikely that there were resources or
25475: expectations which excused the large outlay at the time of Lydgate’s
25476: marriage, and which might hinder any bad consequences from the
25477: disappointment in his practice. One evening, when he took the pains to
25478: go to Middlemarch on purpose to have a chat with Lydgate as of old, he
25479: noticed in him an air of excited effort quite unlike his usual easy way
25480: of keeping silence or breaking it with abrupt energy whenever he had
25481: anything to say. Lydgate talked persistently when they were in his
25482: work-room, putting arguments for and against the probability of certain
25483: biological views; but he had none of those definite things to say or to
25484: show which give the waymarks of a patient uninterrupted pursuit, such
25485: as he used himself to insist on, saying that “there must be a systole
25486: and diastole in all inquiry,” and that “a man’s mind must be
25487: continually expanding and shrinking between the whole human horizon and
25488: the horizon of an object-glass.” That evening he seemed to be talking
25489: widely for the sake of resisting any personal bearing; and before long
25490: they went into the drawing room, where Lydgate, having asked Rosamond
25491: to give them music, sank back in his chair in silence, but with a
25492: strange light in his eyes. “He may have been taking an opiate,” was a
25493: thought that crossed Mr. Farebrother’s mind—“tic-douloureux perhaps—or
25494: medical worries.”
25495: 
25496: It did not occur to him that Lydgate’s marriage was not delightful: he
25497: believed, as the rest did, that Rosamond was an amiable, docile
25498: creature, though he had always thought her rather uninteresting—a
25499: little too much the pattern-card of the finishing-school; and his
25500: mother could not forgive Rosamond because she never seemed to see that
25501: Henrietta Noble was in the room. “However, Lydgate fell in love with
25502: her,” said the Vicar to himself, “and she must be to his taste.”
25503: 
25504: Mr. Farebrother was aware that Lydgate was a proud man, but having very
25505: little corresponding fibre in himself, and perhaps too little care
25506: about personal dignity, except the dignity of not being mean or
25507: foolish, he could hardly allow enough for the way in which Lydgate
25508: shrank, as from a burn, from the utterance of any word about his
25509: private affairs. And soon after that conversation at Mr. Toller’s, the
25510: Vicar learned something which made him watch the more eagerly for an
25511: opportunity of indirectly letting Lydgate know that if he wanted to
25512: open himself about any difficulty there was a friendly ear ready.
25513: 
25514: The opportunity came at Mr. Vincy’s, where, on New Year’s Day, there
25515: was a party, to which Mr. Farebrother was irresistibly invited, on the
25516: plea that he must not forsake his old friends on the first new year of
25517: his being a greater man, and Rector as well as Vicar. And this party
25518: was thoroughly friendly: all the ladies of the Farebrother family were
25519: present; the Vincy children all dined at the table, and Fred had
25520: persuaded his mother that if she did not invite Mary Garth, the
25521: Farebrothers would regard it as a slight to themselves, Mary being
25522: their particular friend. Mary came, and Fred was in high spirits,
25523: though his enjoyment was of a checkered kind—triumph that his mother
25524: should see Mary’s importance with the chief personages in the party
25525: being much streaked with jealousy when Mr. Farebrother sat down by her.
25526: Fred used to be much more easy about his own accomplishments in the
25527: days when he had not begun to dread being “bowled out by Farebrother,”
25528: and this terror was still before him. Mrs. Vincy, in her fullest
25529: matronly bloom, looked at Mary’s little figure, rough wavy hair, and
25530: visage quite without lilies and roses, and wondered; trying
25531: unsuccessfully to fancy herself caring about Mary’s appearance in
25532: wedding clothes, or feeling complacency in grandchildren who would
25533: “feature” the Garths. However, the party was a merry one, and Mary was
25534: particularly bright; being glad, for Fred’s sake, that his friends were
25535: getting kinder to her, and being also quite willing that they should
25536: see how much she was valued by others whom they must admit to be
25537: judges.
25538: 
25539: Mr. Farebrother noticed that Lydgate seemed bored, and that Mr. Vincy
25540: spoke as little as possible to his son-in-law. Rosamond was perfectly
25541: graceful and calm, and only a subtle observation such as the Vicar had
25542: not been roused to bestow on her would have perceived the total absence
25543: of that interest in her husband’s presence which a loving wife is sure
25544: to betray, even if etiquette keeps her aloof from him. When Lydgate was
25545: taking part in the conversation, she never looked towards him any more
25546: than if she had been a sculptured Psyche modelled to look another way:
25547: and when, after being called out for an hour or two, he re-entered the
25548: room, she seemed unconscious of the fact, which eighteen months before
25549: would have had the effect of a numeral before ciphers. In reality,
25550: however, she was intensely aware of Lydgate’s voice and movements; and
25551: her pretty good-tempered air of unconsciousness was a studied negation
25552: by which she satisfied her inward opposition to him without compromise
25553: of propriety. When the ladies were in the drawing-room after Lydgate
25554: had been called away from the dessert, Mrs. Farebrother, when Rosamond
25555: happened to be near her, said—“You have to give up a great deal of your
25556: husband’s society, Mrs. Lydgate.”
25557: 
25558: “Yes, the life of a medical man is very arduous: especially when he is
25559: so devoted to his profession as Mr. Lydgate is,” said Rosamond, who was
25560: standing, and moved easily away at the end of this correct little
25561: speech.
25562: 
25563: “It is dreadfully dull for her when there is no company,” said Mrs.
25564: Vincy, who was seated at the old lady’s side. “I am sure I thought so
25565: when Rosamond was ill, and I was staying with her. You know, Mrs.
25566: Farebrother, ours is a cheerful house. I am of a cheerful disposition
25567: myself, and Mr. Vincy always likes something to be going on. That is
25568: what Rosamond has been used to. Very different from a husband out at
25569: odd hours, and never knowing when he will come home, and of a close,
25570: proud disposition, _I_ think”—indiscreet Mrs. Vincy did lower her tone
25571: slightly with this parenthesis. “But Rosamond always had an angel of a
25572: temper; her brothers used very often not to please her, but she was
25573: never the girl to show temper; from a baby she was always as good as
25574: good, and with a complexion beyond anything. But my children are all
25575: good-tempered, thank God.”
25576: 
25577: This was easily credible to any one looking at Mrs. Vincy as she threw
25578: back her broad cap-strings, and smiled towards her three little girls,
25579: aged from seven to eleven. But in that smiling glance she was obliged
25580: to include Mary Garth, whom the three girls had got into a corner to
25581: make her tell them stories. Mary was just finishing the delicious tale
25582: of Rumpelstiltskin, which she had well by heart, because Letty was
25583: never tired of communicating it to her ignorant elders from a favorite
25584: red volume. Louisa, Mrs. Vincy’s darling, now ran to her with wide-eyed
25585: serious excitement, crying, “Oh mamma, mamma, the little man stamped so
25586: hard on the floor he couldn’t get his leg out again!”
25587: 
25588: “Bless you, my cherub!” said mamma; “you shall tell me all about it
25589: to-morrow. Go and listen!” and then, as her eyes followed Louisa back
25590: towards the attractive corner, she thought that if Fred wished her to
25591: invite Mary again she would make no objection, the children being so
25592: pleased with her.
25593: 
25594: But presently the corner became still more animated, for Mr.
25595: Farebrother came in, and seating himself behind Louisa, took her on his
25596: lap; whereupon the girls all insisted that he must hear
25597: Rumpelstiltskin, and Mary must tell it over again. He insisted too, and
25598: Mary, without fuss, began again in her neat fashion, with precisely the
25599: same words as before. Fred, who had also seated himself near, would
25600: have felt unmixed triumph in Mary’s effectiveness if Mr. Farebrother
25601: had not been looking at her with evident admiration, while he
25602: dramatized an intense interest in the tale to please the children.
25603: 
25604: “You will never care any more about my one-eyed giant, Loo,” said Fred
25605: at the end.
25606: 
25607: “Yes, I shall. Tell about him now,” said Louisa.
25608: 
25609: “Oh, I dare say; I am quite cut out. Ask Mr. Farebrother.”
25610: 
25611: “Yes,” added Mary; “ask Mr. Farebrother to tell you about the ants
25612: whose beautiful house was knocked down by a giant named Tom, and he
25613: thought they didn’t mind because he couldn’t hear them cry, or see them
25614: use their pocket-handkerchiefs.”
25615: 
25616: “Please,” said Louisa, looking up at the Vicar.
25617: 
25618: “No, no, I am a grave old parson. If I try to draw a story out of my
25619: bag a sermon comes instead. Shall I preach you a sermon?” said he,
25620: putting on his short-sighted glasses, and pursing up his lips.
25621: 
25622: “Yes,” said Louisa, falteringly.
25623: 
25624: “Let me see, then. Against cakes: how cakes are bad things, especially
25625: if they are sweet and have plums in them.”
25626: 
25627: Louisa took the affair rather seriously, and got down from the Vicar’s
25628: knee to go to Fred.
25629: 
25630: “Ah, I see it will not do to preach on New Year’s Day,” said Mr.
25631: Farebrother, rising and walking away. He had discovered of late that
25632: Fred had become jealous of him, and also that he himself was not losing
25633: his preference for Mary above all other women.
25634: 
25635: “A delightful young person is Miss Garth,” said Mrs. Farebrother, who
25636: had been watching her son’s movements.
25637: 
25638: “Yes,” said Mrs. Vincy, obliged to reply, as the old lady turned to her
25639: expectantly. “It is a pity she is not better-looking.”
25640: 
25641: “I cannot say that,” said Mrs. Farebrother, decisively. “I like her
25642: countenance. We must not always ask for beauty, when a good God has
25643: seen fit to make an excellent young woman without it. I put good
25644: manners first, and Miss Garth will know how to conduct herself in any
25645: station.”
25646: 
25647: The old lady was a little sharp in her tone, having a prospective
25648: reference to Mary’s becoming her daughter-in-law; for there was this
25649: inconvenience in Mary’s position with regard to Fred, that it was not
25650: suitable to be made public, and hence the three ladies at Lowick
25651: Parsonage were still hoping that Camden would choose Miss Garth.
25652: 
25653: New visitors entered, and the drawing-room was given up to music and
25654: games, while whist-tables were prepared in the quiet room on the other
25655: side of the hall. Mr. Farebrother played a rubber to satisfy his
25656: mother, who regarded her occasional whist as a protest against scandal
25657: and novelty of opinion, in which light even a revoke had its dignity.
25658: But at the end he got Mr. Chichely to take his place, and left the
25659: room. As he crossed the hall, Lydgate had just come in and was taking
25660: off his great-coat.
25661: 
25662: “You are the man I was going to look for,” said the Vicar; and instead
25663: of entering the drawing-room, they walked along the hall and stood
25664: against the fireplace, where the frosty air helped to make a glowing
25665: bank. “You see, I can leave the whist-table easily enough,” he went on,
25666: smiling at Lydgate, “now I don’t play for money. I owe that to you,
25667: Mrs. Casaubon says.”
25668: 
25669: “How?” said Lydgate, coldly.
25670: 
25671: “Ah, you didn’t mean me to know it; I call that ungenerous reticence.
25672: You should let a man have the pleasure of feeling that you have done
25673: him a good turn. I don’t enter into some people’s dislike of being
25674: under an obligation: upon my word, I prefer being under an obligation
25675: to everybody for behaving well to me.”
25676: 
25677: “I can’t tell what you mean,” said Lydgate, “unless it is that I once
25678: spoke of you to Mrs. Casaubon. But I did not think that she would break
25679: her promise not to mention that I had done so,” said Lydgate, leaning
25680: his back against the corner of the mantel-piece, and showing no
25681: radiance in his face.
25682: 
25683: “It was Brooke who let it out, only the other day. He paid me the
25684: compliment of saying that he was very glad I had the living though you
25685: had come across his tactics, and had praised me up as a Ken and a
25686: Tillotson, and that sort of thing, till Mrs. Casaubon would hear of no
25687: one else.”
25688: 
25689: “Oh, Brooke is such a leaky-minded fool,” said Lydgate, contemptuously.
25690: 
25691: “Well, I was glad of the leakiness then. I don’t see why you shouldn’t
25692: like me to know that you wished to do me a service, my dear fellow. And
25693: you certainly have done me one. It’s rather a strong check to one’s
25694: self-complacency to find how much of one’s right doing depends on not
25695: being in want of money. A man will not be tempted to say the Lord’s
25696: Prayer backward to please the devil, if he doesn’t want the devil’s
25697: services. I have no need to hang on the smiles of chance now.”
25698: 
25699: “I don’t see that there’s any money-getting without chance,” said
25700: Lydgate; “if a man gets it in a profession, it’s pretty sure to come by
25701: chance.”
25702: 
25703: Mr. Farebrother thought he could account for this speech, in striking
25704: contrast with Lydgate’s former way of talking, as the perversity which
25705: will often spring from the moodiness of a man ill at ease in his
25706: affairs. He answered in a tone of good-humored admission—
25707: 
25708: “Ah, there’s enormous patience wanted with the way of the world. But it
25709: is the easier for a man to wait patiently when he has friends who love
25710: him, and ask for nothing better than to help him through, so far as it
25711: lies in their power.”
25712: 
25713: “Oh yes,” said Lydgate, in a careless tone, changing his attitude and
25714: looking at his watch. “People make much more of their difficulties than
25715: they need to do.”
25716: 
25717: He knew as distinctly as possible that this was an offer of help to
25718: himself from Mr. Farebrother, and he could not bear it. So strangely
25719: determined are we mortals, that, after having been long gratified with
25720: the sense that he had privately done the Vicar a service, the
25721: suggestion that the Vicar discerned his need of a service in return
25722: made him shrink into unconquerable reticence. Besides, behind all
25723: making of such offers what else must come?—that he should “mention his
25724: case,” imply that he wanted specific things. At that moment, suicide
25725: seemed easier.
25726: 
25727: Mr. Farebrother was too keen a man not to know the meaning of that
25728: reply, and there was a certain massiveness in Lydgate’s manner and
25729: tone, corresponding with his physique, which if he repelled your
25730: advances in the first instance seemed to put persuasive devices out of
25731: question.
25732: 
25733: “What time are you?” said the Vicar, devouring his wounded feeling.
25734: 
25735: “After eleven,” said Lydgate. And they went into the drawing-room.
25736: 
25737: 
25738: 
25739: 
25740: CHAPTER LXIV.
25741: 
25742: 1_st Gent_. Where lies the power, there let the blame lie too.
25743: 
25744: 2_d Gent_. Nay, power is relative; you cannot fright
25745:     The coming pest with border fortresses,
25746:     Or catch your carp with subtle argument.
25747:     All force is twain in one: cause is not cause
25748:     Unless effect be there; and action’s self
25749:     Must needs contain a passive. So command
25750:     Exists but with obedience.
25751: 
25752: 
25753: Even if Lydgate had been inclined to be quite open about his affairs,
25754: he knew that it would have hardly been in Mr. Farebrother’s power to
25755: give him the help he immediately wanted. With the year’s bills coming
25756: in from his tradesmen, with Dover’s threatening hold on his furniture,
25757: and with nothing to depend on but slow dribbling payments from patients
25758: who must not be offended—for the handsome fees he had had from Freshitt
25759: Hall and Lowick Manor had been easily absorbed—nothing less than a
25760: thousand pounds would have freed him from actual embarrassment, and
25761: left a residue which, according to the favorite phrase of hopefulness
25762: in such circumstances, would have given him “time to look about him.”
25763: 
25764: Naturally, the merry Christmas bringing the happy New Year, when
25765: fellow-citizens expect to be paid for the trouble and goods they have
25766: smilingly bestowed on their neighbors, had so tightened the pressure of
25767: sordid cares on Lydgate’s mind that it was hardly possible for him to
25768: think unbrokenly of any other subject, even the most habitual and
25769: soliciting. He was not an ill-tempered man; his intellectual activity,
25770: the ardent kindness of his heart, as well as his strong frame, would
25771: always, under tolerably easy conditions, have kept him above the petty
25772: uncontrolled susceptibilities which make bad temper. But he was now a
25773: prey to that worst irritation which arises not simply from annoyances,
25774: but from the second consciousness underlying those annoyances, of
25775: wasted energy and a degrading preoccupation, which was the reverse of
25776: all his former purposes. “_This_ is what I am thinking of; and _that_
25777: is what I might have been thinking of,” was the bitter incessant murmur
25778: within him, making every difficulty a double goad to impatience.
25779: 
25780: Some gentlemen have made an amazing figure in literature by general
25781: discontent with the universe as a trap of dulness into which their
25782: great souls have fallen by mistake; but the sense of a stupendous self
25783: and an insignificant world may have its consolations. Lydgate’s
25784: discontent was much harder to bear: it was the sense that there was a
25785: grand existence in thought and effective action lying around him, while
25786: his self was being narrowed into the miserable isolation of egoistic
25787: fears, and vulgar anxieties for events that might allay such fears. His
25788: troubles will perhaps appear miserably sordid, and beneath the
25789: attention of lofty persons who can know nothing of debt except on a
25790: magnificent scale. Doubtless they were sordid; and for the majority,
25791: who are not lofty, there is no escape from sordidness but by being free
25792: from money-craving, with all its base hopes and temptations, its
25793: watching for death, its hinted requests, its horse-dealer’s desire to
25794: make bad work pass for good, its seeking for function which ought to be
25795: another’s, its compulsion often to long for Luck in the shape of a wide
25796: calamity.
25797: 
25798: It was because Lydgate writhed under the idea of getting his neck
25799: beneath this vile yoke that he had fallen into a bitter moody state
25800: which was continually widening Rosamond’s alienation from him. After
25801: the first disclosure about the bill of sale, he had made many efforts
25802: to draw her into sympathy with him about possible measures for
25803: narrowing their expenses, and with the threatening approach of
25804: Christmas his propositions grew more and more definite. “We two can do
25805: with only one servant, and live on very little,” he said, “and I shall
25806: manage with one horse.” For Lydgate, as we have seen, had begun to
25807: reason, with a more distinct vision, about the expenses of living, and
25808: any share of pride he had given to appearances of that sort was meagre
25809: compared with the pride which made him revolt from exposure as a
25810: debtor, or from asking men to help him with their money.
25811: 
25812: “Of course you can dismiss the other two servants, if you like,” said
25813: Rosamond; “but I should have thought it would be very injurious to your
25814: position for us to live in a poor way. You must expect your practice to
25815: be lowered.”
25816: 
25817: “My dear Rosamond, it is not a question of choice. We have begun too
25818: expensively. Peacock, you know, lived in a much smaller house than
25819: this. It is my fault: I ought to have known better, and I deserve a
25820: thrashing—if there were anybody who had a right to give it me—for
25821: bringing you into the necessity of living in a poorer way than you have
25822: been used to. But we married because we loved each other, I suppose.
25823: And that may help us to pull along till things get better. Come, dear,
25824: put down that work and come to me.”
25825: 
25826: He was really in chill gloom about her at that moment, but he dreaded a
25827: future without affection, and was determined to resist the oncoming of
25828: division between them. Rosamond obeyed him, and he took her on his
25829: knee, but in her secret soul she was utterly aloof from him. The poor
25830: thing saw only that the world was not ordered to her liking, and
25831: Lydgate was part of that world. But he held her waist with one hand and
25832: laid the other gently on both of hers; for this rather abrupt man had
25833: much tenderness in his manners towards women, seeming to have always
25834: present in his imagination the weakness of their frames and the
25835: delicate poise of their health both in body and mind. And he began
25836: again to speak persuasively.
25837: 
25838: “I find, now I look into things a little, Rosy, that it is wonderful
25839: what an amount of money slips away in our housekeeping. I suppose the
25840: servants are careless, and we have had a great many people coming. But
25841: there must be many in our rank who manage with much less: they must do
25842: with commoner things, I suppose, and look after the scraps. It seems,
25843: money goes but a little way in these matters, for Wrench has everything
25844: as plain as possible, and he has a very large practice.”
25845: 
25846: “Oh, if you think of living as the Wrenches do!” said Rosamond, with a
25847: little turn of her neck. “But I have heard you express your disgust at
25848: that way of living.”
25849: 
25850: “Yes, they have bad taste in everything—they make economy look ugly. We
25851: needn’t do that. I only meant that they avoid expenses, although Wrench
25852: has a capital practice.”
25853: 
25854: “Why should not you have a good practice, Tertius? Mr. Peacock had. You
25855: should be more careful not to offend people, and you should send out
25856: medicines as the others do. I am sure you began well, and you got
25857: several good houses. It cannot answer to be eccentric; you should think
25858: what will be generally liked,” said Rosamond, in a decided little tone
25859: of admonition.
25860: 
25861: Lydgate’s anger rose: he was prepared to be indulgent towards feminine
25862: weakness, but not towards feminine dictation. The shallowness of a
25863: waternixie’s soul may have a charm until she becomes didactic. But he
25864: controlled himself, and only said, with a touch of despotic firmness—
25865: 
25866: “What I am to do in my practice, Rosy, it is for me to judge. That is
25867: not the question between us. It is enough for you to know that our
25868: income is likely to be a very narrow one—hardly four hundred, perhaps
25869: less, for a long time to come, and we must try to re-arrange our lives
25870: in accordance with that fact.”
25871: 
25872: Rosamond was silent for a moment or two, looking before her, and then
25873: said, “My uncle Bulstrode ought to allow you a salary for the time you
25874: give to the Hospital: it is not right that you should work for
25875: nothing.”
25876: 
25877: “It was understood from the beginning that my services would be
25878: gratuitous. That, again, need not enter into our discussion. I have
25879: pointed out what is the only probability,” said Lydgate, impatiently.
25880: Then checking himself, he went on more quietly—
25881: 
25882: “I think I see one resource which would free us from a good deal of the
25883: present difficulty. I hear that young Ned Plymdale is going to be
25884: married to Miss Sophy Toller. They are rich, and it is not often that a
25885: good house is vacant in Middlemarch. I feel sure that they would be
25886: glad to take this house from us with most of our furniture, and they
25887: would be willing to pay handsomely for the lease. I can employ Trumbull
25888: to speak to Plymdale about it.”
25889: 
25890: Rosamond left her husband’s knee and walked slowly to the other end of
25891: the room; when she turned round and walked towards him it was evident
25892: that the tears had come, and that she was biting her under-lip and
25893: clasping her hands to keep herself from crying. Lydgate was
25894: wretched—shaken with anger and yet feeling that it would be unmanly to
25895: vent the anger just now.
25896: 
25897: “I am very sorry, Rosamond; I know this is painful.”
25898: 
25899: “I thought, at least, when I had borne to send the plate back and have
25900: that man taking an inventory of the furniture—I should have thought
25901: _that_ would suffice.”
25902: 
25903: “I explained it to you at the time, dear. That was only a security and
25904: behind that security there is a debt. And that debt must be paid within
25905: the next few months, else we shall have our furniture sold. If young
25906: Plymdale will take our house and most of our furniture, we shall be
25907: able to pay that debt, and some others too, and we shall be quit of a
25908: place too expensive for us. We might take a smaller house: Trumbull, I
25909: know, has a very decent one to let at thirty pounds a-year, and this is
25910: ninety.” Lydgate uttered this speech in the curt hammering way with
25911: which we usually try to nail down a vague mind to imperative facts.
25912: Tears rolled silently down Rosamond’s cheeks; she just pressed her
25913: handkerchief against them, and stood looking at the large vase on the
25914: mantel-piece. It was a moment of more intense bitterness than she had
25915: ever felt before. At last she said, without hurry and with careful
25916: emphasis—
25917: 
25918: “I never could have believed that you would like to act in that way.”
25919: 
25920: “Like it?” burst out Lydgate, rising from his chair, thrusting his
25921: hands in his pockets and stalking away from the hearth; “it’s not a
25922: question of liking. Of course, I don’t like it; it’s the only thing I
25923: can do.” He wheeled round there, and turned towards her.
25924: 
25925: “I should have thought there were many other means than that,” said
25926: Rosamond. “Let us have a sale and leave Middlemarch altogether.”
25927: 
25928: “To do what? What is the use of my leaving my work in Middlemarch to go
25929: where I have none? We should be just as penniless elsewhere as we are
25930: here,” said Lydgate still more angrily.
25931: 
25932: “If we are to be in that position it will be entirely your own doing,
25933: Tertius,” said Rosamond, turning round to speak with the fullest
25934: conviction. “You will not behave as you ought to do to your own family.
25935: You offended Captain Lydgate. Sir Godwin was very kind to me when we
25936: were at Quallingham, and I am sure if you showed proper regard to him
25937: and told him your affairs, he would do anything for you. But rather
25938: than that, you like giving up our house and furniture to Mr. Ned
25939: Plymdale.”
25940: 
25941: There was something like fierceness in Lydgate’s eyes, as he answered
25942: with new violence, “Well, then, if you will have it so, I do like it. I
25943: admit that I like it better than making a fool of myself by going to
25944: beg where it’s of no use. Understand then, that it is what I _like to
25945: do._”
25946: 
25947: There was a tone in the last sentence which was equivalent to the
25948: clutch of his strong hand on Rosamond’s delicate arm. But for all that,
25949: his will was not a whit stronger than hers. She immediately walked out
25950: of the room in silence, but with an intense determination to hinder
25951: what Lydgate liked to do.
25952: 
25953: He went out of the house, but as his blood cooled he felt that the
25954: chief result of the discussion was a deposit of dread within him at the
25955: idea of opening with his wife in future subjects which might again urge
25956: him to violent speech. It was as if a fracture in delicate crystal had
25957: begun, and he was afraid of any movement that might make it fatal. His
25958: marriage would be a mere piece of bitter irony if they could not go on
25959: loving each other. He had long ago made up his mind to what he thought
25960: was her negative character—her want of sensibility, which showed itself
25961: in disregard both of his specific wishes and of his general aims. The
25962: first great disappointment had been borne: the tender devotedness and
25963: docile adoration of the ideal wife must be renounced, and life must be
25964: taken up on a lower stage of expectation, as it is by men who have lost
25965: their limbs. But the real wife had not only her claims, she had still a
25966: hold on his heart, and it was his intense desire that the hold should
25967: remain strong. In marriage, the certainty, “She will never love me
25968: much,” is easier to bear than the fear, “I shall love her no more.”
25969: Hence, after that outburst, his inward effort was entirely to excuse
25970: her, and to blame the hard circumstances which were partly his fault.
25971: He tried that evening, by petting her, to heal the wound he had made in
25972: the morning, and it was not in Rosamond’s nature to be repellent or
25973: sulky; indeed, she welcomed the signs that her husband loved her and
25974: was under control. But this was something quite distinct from loving
25975: _him_. Lydgate would not have chosen soon to recur to the plan of
25976: parting with the house; he was resolved to carry it out, and say as
25977: little more about it as possible. But Rosamond herself touched on it at
25978: breakfast by saying, mildly—
25979: 
25980: “Have you spoken to Trumbull yet?”
25981: 
25982: “No,” said Lydgate, “but I shall call on him as I go by this morning.
25983: No time must be lost.” He took Rosamond’s question as a sign that she
25984: withdrew her inward opposition, and kissed her head caressingly when he
25985: got up to go away.
25986: 
25987: As soon as it was late enough to make a call, Rosamond went to Mrs.
25988: Plymdale, Mr. Ned’s mother, and entered with pretty congratulations
25989: into the subject of the coming marriage. Mrs. Plymdale’s maternal view
25990: was, that Rosamond might possibly now have retrospective glimpses of
25991: her own folly; and feeling the advantages to be at present all on the
25992: side of her son, was too kind a woman not to behave graciously.
25993: 
25994: “Yes, Ned is most happy, I must say. And Sophy Toller is all I could
25995: desire in a daughter-in-law. Of course her father is able to do
25996: something handsome for her—that is only what would be expected with a
25997: brewery like his. And the connection is everything we should desire.
25998: But that is not what I look at. She is such a very nice girl—no airs,
25999: no pretensions, though on a level with the first. I don’t mean with the
26000: titled aristocracy. I see very little good in people aiming out of
26001: their own sphere. I mean that Sophy is equal to the best in the town,
26002: and she is contented with that.”
26003: 
26004: “I have always thought her very agreeable,” said Rosamond.
26005: 
26006: “I look upon it as a reward for Ned, who never held his head too high,
26007: that he should have got into the very best connection,” continued Mrs.
26008: Plymdale, her native sharpness softened by a fervid sense that she was
26009: taking a correct view. “And such particular people as the Tollers are,
26010: they might have objected because some of our friends are not theirs. It
26011: is well known that your aunt Bulstrode and I have been intimate from
26012: our youth, and Mr. Plymdale has been always on Mr. Bulstrode’s side.
26013: And I myself prefer serious opinions. But the Tollers have welcomed Ned
26014: all the same.”
26015: 
26016: “I am sure he is a very deserving, well-principled young man,” said
26017: Rosamond, with a neat air of patronage in return for Mrs. Plymdale’s
26018: wholesome corrections.
26019: 
26020: “Oh, he has not the style of a captain in the army, or that sort of
26021: carriage as if everybody was beneath him, or that showy kind of
26022: talking, and singing, and intellectual talent. But I am thankful he has
26023: not. It is a poor preparation both for here and Hereafter.”
26024: 
26025: “Oh dear, yes; appearances have very little to do with happiness,” said
26026: Rosamond. “I think there is every prospect of their being a happy
26027: couple. What house will they take?”
26028: 
26029: “Oh, as for that, they must put up with what they can get. They have
26030: been looking at the house in St. Peter’s Place, next to Mr. Hackbutt’s;
26031: it belongs to him, and he is putting it nicely in repair. I suppose
26032: they are not likely to hear of a better. Indeed, I think Ned will
26033: decide the matter to-day.”
26034: 
26035: “I should think it is a nice house; I like St. Peter’s Place.”
26036: 
26037: “Well, it is near the Church, and a genteel situation. But the windows
26038: are narrow, and it is all ups and downs. You don’t happen to know of
26039: any other that would be at liberty?” said Mrs. Plymdale, fixing her
26040: round black eyes on Rosamond with the animation of a sudden thought in
26041: them.
26042: 
26043: “Oh no; I hear so little of those things.”
26044: 
26045: Rosamond had not foreseen that question and answer in setting out to
26046: pay her visit; she had simply meant to gather any information which
26047: would help her to avert the parting with her own house under
26048: circumstances thoroughly disagreeable to her. As to the untruth in her
26049: reply, she no more reflected on it than she did on the untruth there
26050: was in her saying that appearances had very little to do with
26051: happiness. Her object, she was convinced, was thoroughly justifiable:
26052: it was Lydgate whose intention was inexcusable; and there was a plan in
26053: her mind which, when she had carried it out fully, would prove how very
26054: false a step it would have been for him to have descended from his
26055: position.
26056: 
26057: She returned home by Mr. Borthrop Trumbull’s office, meaning to call
26058: there. It was the first time in her life that Rosamond had thought of
26059: doing anything in the form of business, but she felt equal to the
26060: occasion. That she should be obliged to do what she intensely disliked,
26061: was an idea which turned her quiet tenacity into active invention. Here
26062: was a case in which it could not be enough simply to disobey and be
26063: serenely, placidly obstinate: she must act according to her judgment,
26064: and she said to herself that her judgment was right—“indeed, if it had
26065: not been, she would not have wished to act on it.”
26066: 
26067: Mr. Trumbull was in the back-room of his office, and received Rosamond
26068: with his finest manners, not only because he had much sensibility to
26069: her charms, but because the good-natured fibre in him was stirred by
26070: his certainty that Lydgate was in difficulties, and that this
26071: uncommonly pretty woman—this young lady with the highest personal
26072: attractions—was likely to feel the pinch of trouble—to find herself
26073: involved in circumstances beyond her control. He begged her to do him
26074: the honor to take a seat, and stood before her trimming and comporting
26075: himself with an eager solicitude, which was chiefly benevolent.
26076: Rosamond’s first question was, whether her husband had called on Mr.
26077: Trumbull that morning, to speak about disposing of their house.
26078: 
26079: “Yes, ma’am, yes, he did; he did so,” said the good auctioneer, trying
26080: to throw something soothing into his iteration. “I was about to fulfil
26081: his order, if possible, this afternoon. He wished me not to
26082: procrastinate.”
26083: 
26084: “I called to tell you not to go any further, Mr. Trumbull; and I beg of
26085: you not to mention what has been said on the subject. Will you oblige
26086: me?”
26087: 
26088: “Certainly I will, Mrs. Lydgate, certainly. Confidence is sacred with
26089: me on business or any other topic. I am then to consider the commission
26090: withdrawn?” said Mr. Trumbull, adjusting the long ends of his blue
26091: cravat with both hands, and looking at Rosamond deferentially.
26092: 
26093: “Yes, if you please. I find that Mr. Ned Plymdale has taken a house—the
26094: one in St. Peter’s Place next to Mr. Hackbutt’s. Mr. Lydgate would be
26095: annoyed that his orders should be fulfilled uselessly. And besides
26096: that, there are other circumstances which render the proposal
26097: unnecessary.”
26098: 
26099: “Very good, Mrs. Lydgate, very good. I am at your commands, whenever
26100: you require any service of me,” said Mr. Trumbull, who felt pleasure in
26101: conjecturing that some new resources had been opened. “Rely on me, I
26102: beg. The affair shall go no further.”
26103: 
26104: That evening Lydgate was a little comforted by observing that Rosamond
26105: was more lively than she had usually been of late, and even seemed
26106: interested in doing what would please him without being asked. He
26107: thought, “If she will be happy and I can rub through, what does it all
26108: signify? It is only a narrow swamp that we have to pass in a long
26109: journey. If I can get my mind clear again, I shall do.”
26110: 
26111: He was so much cheered that he began to search for an account of
26112: experiments which he had long ago meant to look up, and had neglected
26113: out of that creeping self-despair which comes in the train of petty
26114: anxieties. He felt again some of the old delightful absorption in a
26115: far-reaching inquiry, while Rosamond played the quiet music which was
26116: as helpful to his meditation as the plash of an oar on the evening
26117: lake. It was rather late; he had pushed away all the books, and was
26118: looking at the fire with his hands clasped behind his head in
26119: forgetfulness of everything except the construction of a new
26120: controlling experiment, when Rosamond, who had left the piano and was
26121: leaning back in her chair watching him, said—
26122: 
26123: “Mr. Ned Plymdale has taken a house already.”
26124: 
26125: Lydgate, startled and jarred, looked up in silence for a moment, like a
26126: man who has been disturbed in his sleep. Then flushing with an
26127: unpleasant consciousness, he asked—
26128: 
26129: “How do you know?”
26130: 
26131: “I called at Mrs. Plymdale’s this morning, and she told me that he had
26132: taken the house in St. Peter’s Place, next to Mr. Hackbutt’s.”
26133: 
26134: Lydgate was silent. He drew his hands from behind his head and pressed
26135: them against the hair which was hanging, as it was apt to do, in a mass
26136: on his forehead, while he rested his elbows on his knees. He was
26137: feeling bitter disappointment, as if he had opened a door out of a
26138: suffocating place and had found it walled up; but he also felt sure
26139: that Rosamond was pleased with the cause of his disappointment. He
26140: preferred not looking at her and not speaking, until he had got over
26141: the first spasm of vexation. After all, he said in his bitterness, what
26142: can a woman care about so much as house and furniture? a husband
26143: without them is an absurdity. When he looked up and pushed his hair
26144: aside, his dark eyes had a miserable blank non-expectance of sympathy
26145: in them, but he only said, coolly—
26146: 
26147: “Perhaps some one else may turn up. I told Trumbull to be on the
26148: look-out if he failed with Plymdale.”
26149: 
26150: Rosamond made no remark. She trusted to the chance that nothing more
26151: would pass between her husband and the auctioneer until some issue
26152: should have justified her interference; at any rate, she had hindered
26153: the event which she immediately dreaded. After a pause, she said—
26154: 
26155: “How much money is it that those disagreeable people want?”
26156: 
26157: “What disagreeable people?”
26158: 
26159: “Those who took the list—and the others. I mean, how much money would
26160: satisfy them so that you need not be troubled any more?”
26161: 
26162: Lydgate surveyed her for a moment, as if he were looking for symptoms,
26163: and then said, “Oh, if I could have got six hundred from Plymdale for
26164: furniture and as premium, I might have managed. I could have paid off
26165: Dover, and given enough on account to the others to make them wait
26166: patiently, if we contracted our expenses.”
26167: 
26168: “But I mean how much should you want if we stayed in this house?”
26169: 
26170: “More than I am likely to get anywhere,” said Lydgate, with rather a
26171: grating sarcasm in his tone. It angered him to perceive that Rosamond’s
26172: mind was wandering over impracticable wishes instead of facing possible
26173: efforts.
26174: 
26175: “Why should you not mention the sum?” said Rosamond, with a mild
26176: indication that she did not like his manners.
26177: 
26178: “Well,” said Lydgate in a guessing tone, “it would take at least a
26179: thousand to set me at ease. But,” he added, incisively, “I have to
26180: consider what I shall do without it, not with it.”
26181: 
26182: Rosamond said no more.
26183: 
26184: But the next day she carried out her plan of writing to Sir Godwin
26185: Lydgate. Since the Captain’s visit, she had received a letter from him,
26186: and also one from Mrs. Mengan, his married sister, condoling with her
26187: on the loss of her baby, and expressing vaguely the hope that they
26188: should see her again at Quallingham. Lydgate had told her that this
26189: politeness meant nothing; but she was secretly convinced that any
26190: backwardness in Lydgate’s family towards him was due to his cold and
26191: contemptuous behavior, and she had answered the letters in her most
26192: charming manner, feeling some confidence that a specific invitation
26193: would follow. But there had been total silence. The Captain evidently
26194: was not a great penman, and Rosamond reflected that the sisters might
26195: have been abroad. However, the season was come for thinking of friends
26196: at home, and at any rate Sir Godwin, who had chucked her under the
26197: chin, and pronounced her to be like the celebrated beauty, Mrs. Croly,
26198: who had made a conquest of him in 1790, would be touched by any appeal
26199: from her, and would find it pleasant for her sake to behave as he ought
26200: to do towards his nephew. Rosamond was naively convinced of what an old
26201: gentleman ought to do to prevent her from suffering annoyance. And she
26202: wrote what she considered the most judicious letter possible—one which
26203: would strike Sir Godwin as a proof of her excellent sense—pointing out
26204: how desirable it was that Tertius should quit such a place as
26205: Middlemarch for one more fitted to his talents, how the unpleasant
26206: character of the inhabitants had hindered his professional success, and
26207: how in consequence he was in money difficulties, from which it would
26208: require a thousand pounds thoroughly to extricate him. She did not say
26209: that Tertius was unaware of her intention to write; for she had the
26210: idea that his supposed sanction of her letter would be in accordance
26211: with what she did say of his great regard for his uncle Godwin as the
26212: relative who had always been his best friend. Such was the force of
26213: Poor Rosamond’s tactics now she applied them to affairs.
26214: 
26215: This had happened before the party on New Year’s Day, and no answer had
26216: yet come from Sir Godwin. But on the morning of that day Lydgate had to
26217: learn that Rosamond had revoked his order to Borthrop Trumbull. Feeling
26218: it necessary that she should be gradually accustomed to the idea of
26219: their quitting the house in Lowick Gate, he overcame his reluctance to
26220: speak to her again on the subject, and when they were breakfasting
26221: said—
26222: 
26223: “I shall try to see Trumbull this morning, and tell him to advertise
26224: the house in the ‘Pioneer’ and the ‘Trumpet.’ If the thing were
26225: advertised, some one might be inclined to take it who would not
26226: otherwise have thought of a change. In these country places many people
26227: go on in their old houses when their families are too large for them,
26228: for want of knowing where they can find another. And Trumbull seems to
26229: have got no bite at all.”
26230: 
26231: Rosamond knew that the inevitable moment was come. “I ordered Trumbull
26232: not to inquire further,” she said, with a careful calmness which was
26233: evidently defensive.
26234: 
26235: Lydgate stared at her in mute amazement. Only half an hour before he
26236: had been fastening up her plaits for her, and talking the “little
26237: language” of affection, which Rosamond, though not returning it,
26238: accepted as if she had been a serene and lovely image, now and then
26239: miraculously dimpling towards her votary. With such fibres still astir
26240: in him, the shock he received could not at once be distinctly anger; it
26241: was confused pain. He laid down the knife and fork with which he was
26242: carving, and throwing himself back in his chair, said at last, with a
26243: cool irony in his tone—
26244: 
26245: “May I ask when and why you did so?”
26246: 
26247: “When I knew that the Plymdales had taken a house, I called to tell him
26248: not to mention ours to them; and at the same time I told him not to let
26249: the affair go on any further. I knew that it would be very injurious to
26250: you if it were known that you wished to part with your house and
26251: furniture, and I had a very strong objection to it. I think that was
26252: reason enough.”
26253: 
26254: “It was of no consequence then that I had told you imperative reasons
26255: of another kind; of no consequence that I had come to a different
26256: conclusion, and given an order accordingly?” said Lydgate, bitingly,
26257: the thunder and lightning gathering about his brow and eyes.
26258: 
26259: The effect of any one’s anger on Rosamond had always been to make her
26260: shrink in cold dislike, and to become all the more calmly correct, in
26261: the conviction that she was not the person to misbehave whatever others
26262: might do. She replied—
26263: 
26264: “I think I had a perfect right to speak on a subject which concerns me
26265: at least as much as you.”
26266: 
26267: “Clearly—you had a right to speak, but only to me. You had no right to
26268: contradict my orders secretly, and treat me as if I were a fool,” said
26269: Lydgate, in the same tone as before. Then with some added scorn, “Is it
26270: possible to make you understand what the consequences will be? Is it of
26271: any use for me to tell you again why we must try to part with the
26272: house?”
26273: 
26274: “It is not necessary for you to tell me again,” said Rosamond, in a
26275: voice that fell and trickled like cold water-drops. “I remembered what
26276: you said. You spoke just as violently as you do now. But that does not
26277: alter my opinion that you ought to try every other means rather than
26278: take a step which is so painful to me. And as to advertising the house,
26279: I think it would be perfectly degrading to you.”
26280: 
26281: “And suppose I disregard your opinion as you disregard mine?”
26282: 
26283: “You can do so, of course. But I think you ought to have told me before
26284: we were married that you would place me in the worst position, rather
26285: than give up your own will.”
26286: 
26287: Lydgate did not speak, but tossed his head on one side, and twitched
26288: the corners of his mouth in despair. Rosamond, seeing that he was not
26289: looking at her, rose and set his cup of coffee before him; but he took
26290: no notice of it, and went on with an inward drama and argument,
26291: occasionally moving in his seat, resting one arm on the table, and
26292: rubbing his hand against his hair. There was a conflux of emotions and
26293: thoughts in him that would not let him either give thorough way to his
26294: anger or persevere with simple rigidity of resolve. Rosamond took
26295: advantage of his silence.
26296: 
26297: “When we were married everyone felt that your position was very high. I
26298: could not have imagined then that you would want to sell our furniture,
26299: and take a house in Bride Street, where the rooms are like cages. If we
26300: are to live in that way let us at least leave Middlemarch.”
26301: 
26302: “These would be very strong considerations,” said Lydgate, half
26303: ironically—still there was a withered paleness about his lips as he
26304: looked at his coffee, and did not drink—“these would be very strong
26305: considerations if I did not happen to be in debt.”
26306: 
26307: “Many persons must have been in debt in the same way, but if they are
26308: respectable, people trust them. I am sure I have heard papa say that
26309: the Torbits were in debt, and they went on very well. It cannot be good
26310: to act rashly,” said Rosamond, with serene wisdom.
26311: 
26312: Lydgate sat paralyzed by opposing impulses: since no reasoning he could
26313: apply to Rosamond seemed likely to conquer her assent, he wanted to
26314: smash and grind some object on which he could at least produce an
26315: impression, or else to tell her brutally that he was master, and she
26316: must obey. But he not only dreaded the effect of such extremities on
26317: their mutual life—he had a growing dread of Rosamond’s quiet elusive
26318: obstinacy, which would not allow any assertion of power to be final;
26319: and again, she had touched him in a spot of keenest feeling by implying
26320: that she had been deluded with a false vision of happiness in marrying
26321: him. As to saying that he was master, it was not the fact. The very
26322: resolution to which he had wrought himself by dint of logic and
26323: honorable pride was beginning to relax under her torpedo contact. He
26324: swallowed half his cup of coffee, and then rose to go.
26325: 
26326: “I may at least request that you will not go to Trumbull at
26327: present—until it has been seen that there are no other means,” said
26328: Rosamond. Although she was not subject to much fear, she felt it safer
26329: not to betray that she had written to Sir Godwin. “Promise me that you
26330: will not go to him for a few weeks, or without telling me.”
26331: 
26332: Lydgate gave a short laugh. “I think it is I who should exact a promise
26333: that you will do nothing without telling me,” he said, turning his eyes
26334: sharply upon her, and then moving to the door.
26335: 
26336: “You remember that we are going to dine at papa’s,” said Rosamond,
26337: wishing that he should turn and make a more thorough concession to her.
26338: But he only said “Oh yes,” impatiently, and went away. She held it to
26339: be very odious in him that he did not think the painful propositions he
26340: had had to make to her were enough, without showing so unpleasant a
26341: temper. And when she put the moderate request that he would defer going
26342: to Trumbull again, it was cruel in him not to assure her of what he
26343: meant to do. She was convinced of her having acted in every way for the
26344: best; and each grating or angry speech of Lydgate’s served only as an
26345: addition to the register of offences in her mind. Poor Rosamond for
26346: months had begun to associate her husband with feelings of
26347: disappointment, and the terribly inflexible relation of marriage had
26348: lost its charm of encouraging delightful dreams. It had freed her from
26349: the disagreeables of her father’s house, but it had not given her
26350: everything that she had wished and hoped. The Lydgate with whom she had
26351: been in love had been a group of airy conditions for her, most of which
26352: had disappeared, while their place had been taken by every-day details
26353: which must be lived through slowly from hour to hour, not floated
26354: through with a rapid selection of favorable aspects. The habits of
26355: Lydgate’s profession, his home preoccupation with scientific subjects,
26356: which seemed to her almost like a morbid vampire’s taste, his peculiar
26357: views of things which had never entered into the dialogue of
26358: courtship—all these continually alienating influences, even without the
26359: fact of his having placed himself at a disadvantage in the town, and
26360: without that first shock of revelation about Dover’s debt, would have
26361: made his presence dull to her. There was another presence which ever
26362: since the early days of her marriage, until four months ago, had been
26363: an agreeable excitement, but that was gone: Rosamond would not confess
26364: to herself how much the consequent blank had to do with her utter
26365: ennui; and it seemed to her (perhaps she was right) that an invitation
26366: to Quallingham, and an opening for Lydgate to settle elsewhere than in
26367: Middlemarch—in London, or somewhere likely to be free from
26368: unpleasantness—would satisfy her quite well, and make her indifferent
26369: to the absence of Will Ladislaw, towards whom she felt some resentment
26370: for his exaltation of Mrs. Casaubon.
26371: 
26372: That was the state of things with Lydgate and Rosamond on the New
26373: Year’s Day when they dined at her father’s, she looking mildly neutral
26374: towards him in remembrance of his ill-tempered behavior at breakfast,
26375: and he carrying a much deeper effect from the inward conflict in which
26376: that morning scene was only one of many epochs. His flushed effort
26377: while talking to Mr. Farebrother—his effort after the cynical pretence
26378: that all ways of getting money are essentially the same, and that
26379: chance has an empire which reduces choice to a fool’s illusion—was but
26380: the symptom of a wavering resolve, a benumbed response to the old
26381: stimuli of enthusiasm.
26382: 
26383: What was he to do? He saw even more keenly than Rosamond did the
26384: dreariness of taking her into the small house in Bride Street, where
26385: she would have scanty furniture around her and discontent within: a
26386: life of privation and life with Rosamond were two images which had
26387: become more and more irreconcilable ever since the threat of privation
26388: had disclosed itself. But even if his resolves had forced the two
26389: images into combination, the useful preliminaries to that hard change
26390: were not visibly within reach. And though he had not given the promise
26391: which his wife had asked for, he did not go again to Trumbull. He even
26392: began to think of taking a rapid journey to the North and seeing Sir
26393: Godwin. He had once believed that nothing would urge him into making an
26394: application for money to his uncle, but he had not then known the full
26395: pressure of alternatives yet more disagreeable. He could not depend on
26396: the effect of a letter; it was only in an interview, however
26397: disagreeable this might be to himself, that he could give a thorough
26398: explanation and could test the effectiveness of kinship. No sooner had
26399: Lydgate begun to represent this step to himself as the easiest than
26400: there was a reaction of anger that he—he who had long ago determined to
26401: live aloof from such abject calculations, such self-interested anxiety
26402: about the inclinations and the pockets of men with whom he had been
26403: proud to have no aims in common—should have fallen not simply to their
26404: level, but to the level of soliciting them.
26405: 
26406: 
26407: 
26408: 
26409: CHAPTER LXV.
26410: 
26411: One of us two must bowen douteless,
26412: And, sith a man is more reasonable
26413: Than woman is, ye [men] moste be suffrable.
26414: —CHAUCER: _Canterbury Tales_.
26415: 
26416: 
26417: The bias of human nature to be slow in correspondence triumphs even
26418: over the present quickening in the general pace of things: what wonder
26419: then that in 1832 old Sir Godwin Lydgate was slow to write a letter
26420: which was of consequence to others rather than to himself? Nearly three
26421: weeks of the new year were gone, and Rosamond, awaiting an answer to
26422: her winning appeal, was every day disappointed. Lydgate, in total
26423: ignorance of her expectations, was seeing the bills come in, and
26424: feeling that Dover’s use of his advantage over other creditors was
26425: imminent. He had never mentioned to Rosamond his brooding purpose of
26426: going to Quallingham: he did not want to admit what would appear to her
26427: a concession to her wishes after indignant refusal, until the last
26428: moment; but he was really expecting to set off soon. A slice of the
26429: railway would enable him to manage the whole journey and back in four
26430: days.
26431: 
26432: But one morning after Lydgate had gone out, a letter came addressed to
26433: him, which Rosamond saw clearly to be from Sir Godwin. She was full of
26434: hope. Perhaps there might be a particular note to her enclosed; but
26435: Lydgate was naturally addressed on the question of money or other aid,
26436: and the fact that he was written to, nay, the very delay in writing at
26437: all, seemed to certify that the answer was thoroughly compliant. She
26438: was too much excited by these thoughts to do anything but light
26439: stitching in a warm corner of the dining-room, with the outside of this
26440: momentous letter lying on the table before her. About twelve she heard
26441: her husband’s step in the passage, and tripping to open the door, she
26442: said in her lightest tones, “Tertius, come in here—here is a letter for
26443: you.”
26444: 
26445: “Ah?” he said, not taking off his hat, but just turning her round
26446: within his arm to walk towards the spot where the letter lay. “My uncle
26447: Godwin!” he exclaimed, while Rosamond reseated herself, and watched him
26448: as he opened the letter. She had expected him to be surprised.
26449: 
26450: While Lydgate’s eyes glanced rapidly over the brief letter, she saw his
26451: face, usually of a pale brown, taking on a dry whiteness; with nostrils
26452: and lips quivering he tossed down the letter before her, and said
26453: violently—
26454: 
26455: “It will be impossible to endure life with you, if you will always be
26456: acting secretly—acting in opposition to me and hiding your actions.”
26457: 
26458: He checked his speech and turned his back on her—then wheeled round and
26459: walked about, sat down, and got up again restlessly, grasping hard the
26460: objects deep down in his pockets. He was afraid of saying something
26461: irremediably cruel.
26462: 
26463: Rosamond too had changed color as she read. The letter ran in this
26464: way:—
26465: 
26466: “DEAR TERTIUS,—Don’t set your wife to write to me when you have
26467: anything to ask. It is a roundabout wheedling sort of thing which I
26468: should not have credited you with. I never choose to write to a woman
26469: on matters of business. As to my supplying you with a thousand pounds,
26470: or only half that sum, I can do nothing of the sort. My own family
26471: drains me to the last penny. With two younger sons and three daughters,
26472: I am not likely to have cash to spare. You seem to have got through
26473: your own money pretty quickly, and to have made a mess where you are;
26474: the sooner you go somewhere else the better. But I have nothing to do
26475: with men of your profession, and can’t help you there. I did the best I
26476: could for you as guardian, and let you have your own way in taking to
26477: medicine. You might have gone into the army or the Church. Your money
26478: would have held out for that, and there would have been a surer ladder
26479: before you. Your uncle Charles has had a grudge against you for not
26480: going into his profession, but not I. I have always wished you well,
26481: but you must consider yourself on your own legs entirely now.
26482: 
26483: 
26484: Your affectionate uncle,
26485: GODWIN LYDGATE.”
26486: 
26487: 
26488: When Rosamond had finished reading the letter she sat quite still, with
26489: her hands folded before her, restraining any show of her keen
26490: disappointment, and intrenching herself in quiet passivity under her
26491: husband’s wrath. Lydgate paused in his movements, looked at her again,
26492: and said, with biting severity—
26493: 
26494: “Will this be enough to convince you of the harm you may do by secret
26495: meddling? Have you sense enough to recognize now your incompetence to
26496: judge and act for me—to interfere with your ignorance in affairs which
26497: it belongs to me to decide on?”
26498: 
26499: The words were hard; but this was not the first time that Lydgate had
26500: been frustrated by her. She did not look at him, and made no reply.
26501: 
26502: “I had nearly resolved on going to Quallingham. It would have cost me
26503: pain enough to do it, yet it might have been of some use. But it has
26504: been of no use for me to think of anything. You have always been
26505: counteracting me secretly. You delude me with a false assent, and then
26506: I am at the mercy of your devices. If you mean to resist every wish I
26507: express, say so and defy me. I shall at least know what I am doing
26508: then.”
26509: 
26510: It is a terrible moment in young lives when the closeness of love’s
26511: bond has turned to this power of galling. In spite of Rosamond’s
26512: self-control a tear fell silently and rolled over her lips. She still
26513: said nothing; but under that quietude was hidden an intense effect: she
26514: was in such entire disgust with her husband that she wished she had
26515: never seen him. Sir Godwin’s rudeness towards her and utter want of
26516: feeling ranged him with Dover and all other creditors—disagreeable
26517: people who only thought of themselves, and did not mind how annoying
26518: they were to her. Even her father was unkind, and might have done more
26519: for them. In fact there was but one person in Rosamond’s world whom she
26520: did not regard as blameworthy, and that was the graceful creature with
26521: blond plaits and with little hands crossed before her, who had never
26522: expressed herself unbecomingly, and had always acted for the best—the
26523: best naturally being what she best liked.
26524: 
26525: Lydgate pausing and looking at her began to feel that half-maddening
26526: sense of helplessness which comes over passionate people when their
26527: passion is met by an innocent-looking silence whose meek victimized air
26528: seems to put them in the wrong, and at last infects even the justest
26529: indignation with a doubt of its justice. He needed to recover the full
26530: sense that he was in the right by moderating his words.
26531: 
26532: “Can you not see, Rosamond,” he began again, trying to be simply grave
26533: and not bitter, “that nothing can be so fatal as a want of openness and
26534: confidence between us? It has happened again and again that I have
26535: expressed a decided wish, and you have seemed to assent, yet after that
26536: you have secretly disobeyed my wish. In that way I can never know what
26537: I have to trust to. There would be some hope for us if you would admit
26538: this. Am I such an unreasonable, furious brute? Why should you not be
26539: open with me?” Still silence.
26540: 
26541: “Will you only say that you have been mistaken, and that I may depend
26542: on your not acting secretly in future?” said Lydgate, urgently, but
26543: with something of request in his tone which Rosamond was quick to
26544: perceive. She spoke with coolness.
26545: 
26546: “I cannot possibly make admissions or promises in answer to such words
26547: as you have used towards me. I have not been accustomed to language of
26548: that kind. You have spoken of my ‘secret meddling,’ and my ‘interfering
26549: ignorance,’ and my ‘false assent.’ I have never expressed myself in
26550: that way to you, and I think that you ought to apologize. You spoke of
26551: its being impossible to live with me. Certainly you have not made my
26552: life pleasant to me of late. I think it was to be expected that I
26553: should try to avert some of the hardships which our marriage has
26554: brought on me.” Another tear fell as Rosamond ceased speaking, and she
26555: pressed it away as quietly as the first.
26556: 
26557: Lydgate flung himself into a chair, feeling checkmated. What place was
26558: there in her mind for a remonstrance to lodge in? He laid down his hat,
26559: flung an arm over the back of his chair, and looked down for some
26560: moments without speaking. Rosamond had the double purchase over him of
26561: insensibility to the point of justice in his reproach, and of
26562: sensibility to the undeniable hardships now present in her married
26563: life. Although her duplicity in the affair of the house had exceeded
26564: what he knew, and had really hindered the Plymdales from knowing of it,
26565: she had no consciousness that her action could rightly be called false.
26566: We are not obliged to identify our own acts according to a strict
26567: classification, any more than the materials of our grocery and clothes.
26568: Rosamond felt that she was aggrieved, and that this was what Lydgate
26569: had to recognize.
26570: 
26571: As for him, the need of accommodating himself to her nature, which was
26572: inflexible in proportion to its negations, held him as with pincers. He
26573: had begun to have an alarmed foresight of her irrevocable loss of love
26574: for him, and the consequent dreariness of their life. The ready fulness
26575: of his emotions made this dread alternate quickly with the first
26576: violent movements of his anger. It would assuredly have been a vain
26577: boast in him to say that he was her master.
26578: 
26579: “You have not made my life pleasant to me of late”—“the hardships which
26580: our marriage has brought on me”—these words were stinging his
26581: imagination as a pain makes an exaggerated dream. If he were not only
26582: to sink from his highest resolve, but to sink into the hideous
26583: fettering of domestic hate?
26584: 
26585: “Rosamond,” he said, turning his eyes on her with a melancholy look,
26586: “you should allow for a man’s words when he is disappointed and
26587: provoked. You and I cannot have opposite interests. I cannot part my
26588: happiness from yours. If I am angry with you, it is that you seem not
26589: to see how any concealment divides us. How could I wish to make
26590: anything hard to you either by my words or conduct? When I hurt you, I
26591: hurt part of my own life. I should never be angry with you if you would
26592: be quite open with me.”
26593: 
26594: “I have only wished to prevent you from hurrying us into wretchedness
26595: without any necessity,” said Rosamond, the tears coming again from a
26596: softened feeling now that her husband had softened. “It is so very hard
26597: to be disgraced here among all the people we know, and to live in such
26598: a miserable way. I wish I had died with the baby.”
26599: 
26600: She spoke and wept with that gentleness which makes such words and
26601: tears omnipotent over a loving-hearted man. Lydgate drew his chair near
26602: to hers and pressed her delicate head against his cheek with his
26603: powerful tender hand. He only caressed her; he did not say anything;
26604: for what was there to say? He could not promise to shield her from the
26605: dreaded wretchedness, for he could see no sure means of doing so. When
26606: he left her to go out again, he told himself that it was ten times
26607: harder for her than for him: he had a life away from home, and constant
26608: appeals to his activity on behalf of others. He wished to excuse
26609: everything in her if he could—but it was inevitable that in that
26610: excusing mood he should think of her as if she were an animal of
26611: another and feebler species. Nevertheless she had mastered him.
26612: 
26613: 
26614: 
26615: 
26616: CHAPTER LXVI.
26617: 
26618: ’Tis one thing to be tempted, Escalus,
26619: Another thing to fall.
26620: —_Measure for Measure_.
26621: 
26622: 
26623: Lydgate certainly had good reason to reflect on the service his
26624: practice did him in counteracting his personal cares. He had no longer
26625: free energy enough for spontaneous research and speculative thinking,
26626: but by the bedside of patients, the direct external calls on his
26627: judgment and sympathies brought the added impulse needed to draw him
26628: out of himself. It was not simply that beneficent harness of routine
26629: which enables silly men to live respectably and unhappy men to live
26630: calmly—it was a perpetual claim on the immediate fresh application of
26631: thought, and on the consideration of another’s need and trial. Many of
26632: us looking back through life would say that the kindest man we have
26633: ever known has been a medical man, or perhaps that surgeon whose fine
26634: tact, directed by deeply informed perception, has come to us in our
26635: need with a more sublime beneficence than that of miracle-workers. Some
26636: of that twice-blessed mercy was always with Lydgate in his work at the
26637: Hospital or in private houses, serving better than any opiate to quiet
26638: and sustain him under his anxieties and his sense of mental degeneracy.
26639: 
26640: Mr. Farebrother’s suspicion as to the opiate was true, however. Under
26641: the first galling pressure of foreseen difficulties, and the first
26642: perception that his marriage, if it were not to be a yoked loneliness,
26643: must be a state of effort to go on loving without too much care about
26644: being loved, he had once or twice tried a dose of opium. But he had no
26645: hereditary constitutional craving after such transient escapes from the
26646: hauntings of misery. He was strong, could drink a great deal of wine,
26647: but did not care about it; and when the men round him were drinking
26648: spirits, he took sugar and water, having a contemptuous pity even for
26649: the earliest stages of excitement from drink. It was the same with
26650: gambling. He had looked on at a great deal of gambling in Paris,
26651: watching it as if it had been a disease. He was no more tempted by such
26652: winning than he was by drink. He had said to himself that the only
26653: winning he cared for must be attained by a conscious process of high,
26654: difficult combination tending towards a beneficent result. The power he
26655: longed for could not be represented by agitated fingers clutching a
26656: heap of coin, or by the half-barbarous, half-idiotic triumph in the
26657: eyes of a man who sweeps within his arms the ventures of twenty
26658: chapfallen companions.
26659: 
26660: But just as he had tried opium, so his thought now began to turn upon
26661: gambling—not with appetite for its excitement, but with a sort of
26662: wistful inward gaze after that easy way of getting money, which implied
26663: no asking and brought no responsibility. If he had been in London or
26664: Paris at that time, it is probable that such thoughts, seconded by
26665: opportunity, would have taken him into a gambling-house, no longer to
26666: watch the gamblers, but to watch with them in kindred eagerness.
26667: Repugnance would have been surmounted by the immense need to win, if
26668: chance would be kind enough to let him. An incident which happened not
26669: very long after that airy notion of getting aid from his uncle had been
26670: excluded, was a strong sign of the effect that might have followed any
26671: extant opportunity of gambling.
26672: 
26673: The billiard-room at the Green Dragon was the constant resort of a
26674: certain set, most of whom, like our acquaintance Mr. Bambridge, were
26675: regarded as men of pleasure. It was here that poor Fred Vincy had made
26676: part of his memorable debt, having lost money in betting, and been
26677: obliged to borrow of that gay companion. It was generally known in
26678: Middlemarch that a good deal of money was lost and won in this way; and
26679: the consequent repute of the Green Dragon as a place of dissipation
26680: naturally heightened in some quarters the temptation to go there.
26681: Probably its regular visitants, like the initiates of freemasonry,
26682: wished that there were something a little more tremendous to keep to
26683: themselves concerning it; but they were not a closed community, and
26684: many decent seniors as well as juniors occasionally turned into the
26685: billiard-room to see what was going on. Lydgate, who had the muscular
26686: aptitude for billiards, and was fond of the game, had once or twice in
26687: the early days after his arrival in Middlemarch taken his turn with the
26688: cue at the Green Dragon; but afterwards he had no leisure for the game,
26689: and no inclination for the socialities there. One evening, however, he
26690: had occasion to seek Mr. Bambridge at that resort. The horsedealer had
26691: engaged to get him a customer for his remaining good horse, for which
26692: Lydgate had determined to substitute a cheap hack, hoping by this
26693: reduction of style to get perhaps twenty pounds; and he cared now for
26694: every small sum, as a help towards feeding the patience of his
26695: tradesmen. To run up to the billiard-room, as he was passing, would
26696: save time.
26697: 
26698: Mr. Bambridge was not yet come, but would be sure to arrive by-and-by,
26699: said his friend Mr. Horrock; and Lydgate stayed, playing a game for the
26700: sake of passing the time. That evening he had the peculiar light in the
26701: eyes and the unusual vivacity which had been once noticed in him by Mr.
26702: Farebrother. The exceptional fact of his presence was much noticed in
26703: the room, where there was a good deal of Middlemarch company; and
26704: several lookers-on, as well as some of the players, were betting with
26705: animation. Lydgate was playing well, and felt confident; the bets were
26706: dropping round him, and with a swift glancing thought of the probable
26707: gain which might double the sum he was saving from his horse, he began
26708: to bet on his own play, and won again and again. Mr. Bambridge had come
26709: in, but Lydgate did not notice him. He was not only excited with his
26710: play, but visions were gleaming on him of going the next day to
26711: Brassing, where there was gambling on a grander scale to be had, and
26712: where, by one powerful snatch at the devil’s bait, he might carry it
26713: off without the hook, and buy his rescue from his daily solicitings.
26714: 
26715: He was still winning when two new visitors entered. One of them was a
26716: young Hawley, just come from his law studies in town, and the other was
26717: Fred Vincy, who had spent several evenings of late at this old haunt of
26718: his. Young Hawley, an accomplished billiard-player, brought a cool
26719: fresh hand to the cue. But Fred Vincy, startled at seeing Lydgate, and
26720: astonished to see him betting with an excited air, stood aside, and
26721: kept out of the circle round the table.
26722: 
26723: Fred had been rewarding resolution by a little laxity of late. He had
