26724: been working heartily for six months at all outdoor occupations under
26725: Mr. Garth, and by dint of severe practice had nearly mastered the
26726: defects of his handwriting, this practice being, perhaps, a little the
26727: less severe that it was often carried on in the evening at Mr. Garth’s
26728: under the eyes of Mary. But the last fortnight Mary had been staying at
26729: Lowick Parsonage with the ladies there, during Mr. Farebrother’s
26730: residence in Middlemarch, where he was carrying out some parochial
26731: plans; and Fred, not seeing anything more agreeable to do, had turned
26732: into the Green Dragon, partly to play at billiards, partly to taste the
26733: old flavor of discourse about horses, sport, and things in general,
26734: considered from a point of view which was not strenuously correct. He
26735: had not been out hunting once this season, had had no horse of his own
26736: to ride, and had gone from place to place chiefly with Mr. Garth in his
26737: gig, or on the sober cob which Mr. Garth could lend him. It was a
26738: little too bad, Fred began to think, that he should be kept in the
26739: traces with more severity than if he had been a clergyman. “I will tell
26740: you what, Mistress Mary—it will be rather harder work to learn
26741: surveying and drawing plans than it would have been to write sermons,”
26742: he had said, wishing her to appreciate what he went through for her
26743: sake; “and as to Hercules and Theseus, they were nothing to me. They
26744: had sport, and never learned to write a bookkeeping hand.” And now,
26745: Mary being out of the way for a little while, Fred, like any other
26746: strong dog who cannot slip his collar, had pulled up the staple of his
26747: chain and made a small escape, not of course meaning to go fast or far.
26748: There could be no reason why he should not play at billiards, but he
26749: was determined not to bet. As to money just now, Fred had in his mind
26750: the heroic project of saving almost all of the eighty pounds that Mr.
26751: Garth offered him, and returning it, which he could easily do by giving
26752: up all futile money-spending, since he had a superfluous stock of
26753: clothes, and no expense in his board. In that way he could, in one
26754: year, go a good way towards repaying the ninety pounds of which he had
26755: deprived Mrs. Garth, unhappily at a time when she needed that sum more
26756: than she did now. Nevertheless, it must be acknowledged that on this
26757: evening, which was the fifth of his recent visits to the billiard-room,
26758: Fred had, not in his pocket, but in his mind, the ten pounds which he
26759: meant to reserve for himself from his half-year’s salary (having before
26760: him the pleasure of carrying thirty to Mrs. Garth when Mary was likely
26761: to be come home again)—he had those ten pounds in his mind as a fund
26762: from which he might risk something, if there were a chance of a good
26763: bet. Why? Well, when sovereigns were flying about, why shouldn’t he
26764: catch a few? He would never go far along that road again; but a man
26765: likes to assure himself, and men of pleasure generally, what he could
26766: do in the way of mischief if he chose, and that if he abstains from
26767: making himself ill, or beggaring himself, or talking with the utmost
26768: looseness which the narrow limits of human capacity will allow, it is
26769: not because he is a spooney. Fred did not enter into formal reasons,
26770: which are a very artificial, inexact way of representing the tingling
26771: returns of old habit, and the caprices of young blood: but there was
26772: lurking in him a prophetic sense that evening, that when he began to
26773: play he should also begin to bet—that he should enjoy some
26774: punch-drinking, and in general prepare himself for feeling “rather
26775: seedy” in the morning. It is in such indefinable movements that action
26776: often begins.
26777: 
26778: But the last thing likely to have entered Fred’s expectation was that
26779: he should see his brother-in-law Lydgate—of whom he had never quite
26780: dropped the old opinion that he was a prig, and tremendously conscious
26781: of his superiority—looking excited and betting, just as he himself
26782: might have done. Fred felt a shock greater than he could quite account
26783: for by the vague knowledge that Lydgate was in debt, and that his
26784: father had refused to help him; and his own inclination to enter into
26785: the play was suddenly checked. It was a strange reversal of attitudes:
26786: Fred’s blond face and blue eyes, usually bright and careless, ready to
26787: give attention to anything that held out a promise of amusement,
26788: looking involuntarily grave and almost embarrassed as if by the sight
26789: of something unfitting; while Lydgate, who had habitually an air of
26790: self-possessed strength, and a certain meditativeness that seemed to
26791: lie behind his most observant attention, was acting, watching, speaking
26792: with that excited narrow consciousness which reminds one of an animal
26793: with fierce eyes and retractile claws.
26794: 
26795: Lydgate, by betting on his own strokes, had won sixteen pounds; but
26796: young Hawley’s arrival had changed the poise of things. He made
26797: first-rate strokes himself, and began to bet against Lydgate’s strokes,
26798: the strain of whose nerves was thus changed from simple confidence in
26799: his own movements to defying another person’s doubt in them. The
26800: defiance was more exciting than the confidence, but it was less sure.
26801: He continued to bet on his own play, but began often to fail. Still he
26802: went on, for his mind was as utterly narrowed into that precipitous
26803: crevice of play as if he had been the most ignorant lounger there. Fred
26804: observed that Lydgate was losing fast, and found himself in the new
26805: situation of puzzling his brains to think of some device by which,
26806: without being offensive, he could withdraw Lydgate’s attention, and
26807: perhaps suggest to him a reason for quitting the room. He saw that
26808: others were observing Lydgate’s strange unlikeness to himself, and it
26809: occurred to him that merely to touch his elbow and call him aside for a
26810: moment might rouse him from his absorption. He could think of nothing
26811: cleverer than the daring improbability of saying that he wanted to see
26812: Rosy, and wished to know if she were at home this evening; and he was
26813: going desperately to carry out this weak device, when a waiter came up
26814: to him with a message, saying that Mr. Farebrother was below, and
26815: begged to speak with him.
26816: 
26817: Fred was surprised, not quite comfortably, but sending word that he
26818: would be down immediately, he went with a new impulse up to Lydgate,
26819: said, “Can I speak to you a moment?” and drew him aside.
26820: 
26821: “Farebrother has just sent up a message to say that he wants to speak
26822: to me. He is below. I thought you might like to know he was there, if
26823: you had anything to say to him.”
26824: 
26825: Fred had simply snatched up this pretext for speaking, because he could
26826: not say, “You are losing confoundedly, and are making everybody stare
26827: at you; you had better come away.” But inspiration could hardly have
26828: served him better. Lydgate had not before seen that Fred was present,
26829: and his sudden appearance with an announcement of Mr. Farebrother had
26830: the effect of a sharp concussion.
26831: 
26832: “No, no,” said Lydgate; “I have nothing particular to say to him.
26833: But—the game is up—I must be going—I came in just to see Bambridge.”
26834: 
26835: “Bambridge is over there, but he is making a row—I don’t think he’s
26836: ready for business. Come down with me to Farebrother. I expect he is
26837: going to blow me up, and you will shield me,” said Fred, with some
26838: adroitness.
26839: 
26840: Lydgate felt shame, but could not bear to act as if he felt it, by
26841: refusing to see Mr. Farebrother; and he went down. They merely shook
26842: hands, however, and spoke of the frost; and when all three had turned
26843: into the street, the Vicar seemed quite willing to say good-by to
26844: Lydgate. His present purpose was clearly to talk with Fred alone, and
26845: he said, kindly, “I disturbed you, young gentleman, because I have some
26846: pressing business with you. Walk with me to St. Botolph’s, will you?”
26847: 
26848: It was a fine night, the sky thick with stars, and Mr. Farebrother
26849: proposed that they should make a circuit to the old church by the
26850: London road. The next thing he said was—
26851: 
26852: “I thought Lydgate never went to the Green Dragon?”
26853: 
26854: “So did I,” said Fred. “But he said that he went to see Bambridge.”
26855: 
26856: “He was not playing, then?”
26857: 
26858: Fred had not meant to tell this, but he was obliged now to say, “Yes,
26859: he was. But I suppose it was an accidental thing. I have never seen him
26860: there before.”
26861: 
26862: “You have been going often yourself, then, lately?”
26863: 
26864: “Oh, about five or six times.”
26865: 
26866: “I think you had some good reason for giving up the habit of going
26867: there?”
26868: 
26869: “Yes. You know all about it,” said Fred, not liking to be catechised in
26870: this way. “I made a clean breast to you.”
26871: 
26872: “I suppose that gives me a warrant to speak about the matter now. It is
26873: understood between us, is it not?—that we are on a footing of open
26874: friendship: I have listened to you, and you will be willing to listen
26875: to me. I may take my turn in talking a little about myself?”
26876: 
26877: “I am under the deepest obligation to you, Mr. Farebrother,” said Fred,
26878: in a state of uncomfortable surmise.
26879: 
26880: “I will not affect to deny that you are under some obligation to me.
26881: But I am going to confess to you, Fred, that I have been tempted to
26882: reverse all that by keeping silence with you just now. When somebody
26883: said to me, ‘Young Vincy has taken to being at the billiard-table every
26884: night again—he won’t bear the curb long;’ I was tempted to do the
26885: opposite of what I am doing—to hold my tongue and wait while you went
26886: down the ladder again, betting first and then—”
26887: 
26888: “I have not made any bets,” said Fred, hastily.
26889: 
26890: “Glad to hear it. But I say, my prompting was to look on and see you
26891: take the wrong turning, wear out Garth’s patience, and lose the best
26892: opportunity of your life—the opportunity which you made some rather
26893: difficult effort to secure. You can guess the feeling which raised that
26894: temptation in me—I am sure you know it. I am sure you know that the
26895: satisfaction of your affections stands in the way of mine.”
26896: 
26897: There was a pause. Mr. Farebrother seemed to wait for a recognition of
26898: the fact; and the emotion perceptible in the tones of his fine voice
26899: gave solemnity to his words. But no feeling could quell Fred’s alarm.
26900: 
26901: “I could not be expected to give her up,” he said, after a moment’s
26902: hesitation: it was not a case for any pretence of generosity.
26903: 
26904: “Clearly not, when her affection met yours. But relations of this sort,
26905: even when they are of long standing, are always liable to change. I can
26906: easily conceive that you might act in a way to loosen the tie she feels
26907: towards you—it must be remembered that she is only conditionally bound
26908: to you—and that in that case, another man, who may flatter himself that
26909: he has a hold on her regard, might succeed in winning that firm place
26910: in her love as well as respect which you had let slip. I can easily
26911: conceive such a result,” repeated Mr. Farebrother, emphatically. “There
26912: is a companionship of ready sympathy, which might get the advantage
26913: even over the longest associations.” It seemed to Fred that if Mr.
26914: Farebrother had had a beak and talons instead of his very capable
26915: tongue, his mode of attack could hardly be more cruel. He had a
26916: horrible conviction that behind all this hypothetic statement there was
26917: a knowledge of some actual change in Mary’s feeling.
26918: 
26919: “Of course I know it might easily be all up with me,” he said, in a
26920: troubled voice. “If she is beginning to compare—” He broke off, not
26921: liking to betray all he felt, and then said, by the help of a little
26922: bitterness, “But I thought you were friendly to me.”
26923: 
26924: “So I am; that is why we are here. But I have had a strong disposition
26925: to be otherwise. I have said to myself, ‘If there is a likelihood of
26926: that youngster doing himself harm, why should you interfere? Aren’t you
26927: worth as much as he is, and don’t your sixteen years over and above
26928: his, in which you have gone rather hungry, give you more right to
26929: satisfaction than he has? If there’s a chance of his going to the dogs,
26930: let him—perhaps you could nohow hinder it—and do you take the
26931: benefit.’”
26932: 
26933: There was a pause, in which Fred was seized by a most uncomfortable
26934: chill. What was coming next? He dreaded to hear that something had been
26935: said to Mary—he felt as if he were listening to a threat rather than a
26936: warning. When the Vicar began again there was a change in his tone like
26937: the encouraging transition to a major key.
26938: 
26939: “But I had once meant better than that, and I am come back to my old
26940: intention. I thought that I could hardly _secure myself_ in it better,
26941: Fred, than by telling you just what had gone on in me. And now, do you
26942: understand me? I want you to make the happiness of her life and your
26943: own, and if there is any chance that a word of warning from me may turn
26944: aside any risk to the contrary—well, I have uttered it.”
26945: 
26946: There was a drop in the Vicar’s voice when he spoke the last words. He
26947: paused—they were standing on a patch of green where the road diverged
26948: towards St. Botolph’s, and he put out his hand, as if to imply that the
26949: conversation was closed. Fred was moved quite newly. Some one highly
26950: susceptible to the contemplation of a fine act has said, that it
26951: produces a sort of regenerating shudder through the frame, and makes
26952: one feel ready to begin a new life. A good degree of that effect was
26953: just then present in Fred Vincy.
26954: 
26955: “I will try to be worthy,” he said, breaking off before he could say
26956: “of you as well as of her.” And meanwhile Mr. Farebrother had gathered
26957: the impulse to say something more.
26958: 
26959: “You must not imagine that I believe there is at present any decline in
26960: her preference of you, Fred. Set your heart at rest, that if you keep
26961: right, other things will keep right.”
26962: 
26963: “I shall never forget what you have done,” Fred answered. “I can’t say
26964: anything that seems worth saying—only I will try that your goodness
26965: shall not be thrown away.”
26966: 
26967: “That’s enough. Good-by, and God bless you.”
26968: 
26969: In that way they parted. But both of them walked about a long while
26970: before they went out of the starlight. Much of Fred’s rumination might
26971: be summed up in the words, “It certainly would have been a fine thing
26972: for her to marry Farebrother—but if she loves me best and I am a good
26973: husband?”
26974: 
26975: Perhaps Mr. Farebrother’s might be concentrated into a single shrug and
26976: one little speech. “To think of the part one little woman can play in
26977: the life of a man, so that to renounce her may be a very good imitation
26978: of heroism, and to win her may be a discipline!”
26979: 
26980: 
26981: 
26982: 
26983: CHAPTER LXVII.
26984: 
26985: Now is there civil war within the soul:
26986: Resolve is thrust from off the sacred throne
26987: By clamorous Needs, and Pride the grand-vizier
26988: Makes humble compact, plays the supple part
26989: Of envoy and deft-tongued apologist
26990: For hungry rebels.
26991: 
26992: 
26993: Happily Lydgate had ended by losing in the billiard-room, and brought
26994: away no encouragement to make a raid on luck. On the contrary, he felt
26995: unmixed disgust with himself the next day when he had to pay four or
26996: five pounds over and above his gains, and he carried about with him a
26997: most unpleasant vision of the figure he had made, not only rubbing
26998: elbows with the men at the Green Dragon but behaving just as they did.
26999: A philosopher fallen to betting is hardly distinguishable from a
27000: Philistine under the same circumstances: the difference will chiefly be
27001: found in his subsequent reflections, and Lydgate chewed a very
27002: disagreeable cud in that way. His reason told him how the affair might
27003: have been magnified into ruin by a slight change of scenery—if it had
27004: been a gambling-house that he had turned into, where chance could be
27005: clutched with both hands instead of being picked up with thumb and
27006: fore-finger. Nevertheless, though reason strangled the desire to
27007: gamble, there remained the feeling that, with an assurance of luck to
27008: the needful amount, he would have liked to gamble, rather than take the
27009: alternative which was beginning to urge itself as inevitable.
27010: 
27011: That alternative was to apply to Mr. Bulstrode. Lydgate had so many
27012: times boasted both to himself and others that he was totally
27013: independent of Bulstrode, to whose plans he had lent himself solely
27014: because they enabled him to carry out his own ideas of professional
27015: work and public benefit—he had so constantly in their personal
27016: intercourse had his pride sustained by the sense that he was making a
27017: good social use of this predominating banker, whose opinions he thought
27018: contemptible and whose motives often seemed to him an absurd mixture of
27019: contradictory impressions—that he had been creating for himself strong
27020: ideal obstacles to the proffering of any considerable request to him on
27021: his own account.
27022: 
27023: Still, early in March his affairs were at that pass in which men begin
27024: to say that their oaths were delivered in ignorance, and to perceive
27025: that the act which they had called impossible to them is becoming
27026: manifestly possible. With Dover’s ugly security soon to be put in
27027: force, with the proceeds of his practice immediately absorbed in paying
27028: back debts, and with the chance, if the worst were known, of daily
27029: supplies being refused on credit, above all with the vision of
27030: Rosamond’s hopeless discontent continually haunting him, Lydgate had
27031: begun to see that he should inevitably bend himself to ask help from
27032: somebody or other. At first he had considered whether he should write
27033: to Mr. Vincy; but on questioning Rosamond he found that, as he had
27034: suspected, she had already applied twice to her father, the last time
27035: being since the disappointment from Sir Godwin; and papa had said that
27036: Lydgate must look out for himself. “Papa said he had come, with one bad
27037: year after another, to trade more and more on borrowed capital, and had
27038: had to give up many indulgences; he could not spare a single hundred
27039: from the charges of his family. He said, let Lydgate ask Bulstrode:
27040: they have always been hand and glove.”
27041: 
27042: Indeed, Lydgate himself had come to the conclusion that if he must end
27043: by asking for a free loan, his relations with Bulstrode, more at least
27044: than with any other man, might take the shape of a claim which was not
27045: purely personal. Bulstrode had indirectly helped to cause the failure
27046: of his practice, and had also been highly gratified by getting a
27047: medical partner in his plans:—but who among us ever reduced himself to
27048: the sort of dependence in which Lydgate now stood, without trying to
27049: believe that he had claims which diminished the humiliation of asking?
27050: It was true that of late there had seemed to be a new languor of
27051: interest in Bulstrode about the Hospital; but his health had got worse,
27052: and showed signs of a deep-seated nervous affection. In other respects
27053: he did not appear to be changed: he had always been highly polite, but
27054: Lydgate had observed in him from the first a marked coldness about his
27055: marriage and other private circumstances, a coldness which he had
27056: hitherto preferred to any warmth of familiarity between them. He
27057: deferred the intention from day to day, his habit of acting on his
27058: conclusions being made infirm by his repugnance to every possible
27059: conclusion and its consequent act. He saw Mr. Bulstrode often, but he
27060: did not try to use any occasion for his private purpose. At one moment
27061: he thought, “I will write a letter: I prefer that to any circuitous
27062: talk;” at another he thought, “No; if I were talking to him, I could
27063: make a retreat before any signs of disinclination.”
27064: 
27065: Still the days passed and no letter was written, no special interview
27066: sought. In his shrinking from the humiliation of a dependent attitude
27067: towards Bulstrode, he began to familiarize his imagination with another
27068: step even more unlike his remembered self. He began spontaneously to
27069: consider whether it would be possible to carry out that puerile notion
27070: of Rosamond’s which had often made him angry, namely, that they should
27071: quit Middlemarch without seeing anything beyond that preface. The
27072: question came—“Would any man buy the practice of me even now, for as
27073: little as it is worth? Then the sale might happen as a necessary
27074: preparation for going away.”
27075: 
27076: But against his taking this step, which he still felt to be a
27077: contemptible relinquishment of present work, a guilty turning aside
27078: from what was a real and might be a widening channel for worthy
27079: activity, to start again without any justified destination, there was
27080: this obstacle, that the purchaser, if procurable at all, might not be
27081: quickly forthcoming. And afterwards? Rosamond in a poor lodging, though
27082: in the largest city or most distant town, would not find the life that
27083: could save her from gloom, and save him from the reproach of having
27084: plunged her into it. For when a man is at the foot of the hill in his
27085: fortunes, he may stay a long while there in spite of professional
27086: accomplishment. In the British climate there is no incompatibility
27087: between scientific insight and furnished lodgings: the incompatibility
27088: is chiefly between scientific ambition and a wife who objects to that
27089: kind of residence.
27090: 
27091: But in the midst of his hesitation, opportunity came to decide him. A
27092: note from Mr. Bulstrode requested Lydgate to call on him at the Bank. A
27093: hypochondriacal tendency had shown itself in the banker’s constitution
27094: of late; and a lack of sleep, which was really only a slight
27095: exaggeration of an habitual dyspeptic symptom, had been dwelt on by him
27096: as a sign of threatening insanity. He wanted to consult Lydgate without
27097: delay on that particular morning, although he had nothing to tell
27098: beyond what he had told before. He listened eagerly to what Lydgate had
27099: to say in dissipation of his fears, though this too was only
27100: repetition; and this moment in which Bulstrode was receiving a medical
27101: opinion with a sense of comfort, seemed to make the communication of a
27102: personal need to him easier than it had been in Lydgate’s contemplation
27103: beforehand. He had been insisting that it would be well for Mr.
27104: Bulstrode to relax his attention to business.
27105: 
27106: “One sees how any mental strain, however slight, may affect a delicate
27107: frame,” said Lydgate at that stage of the consultation when the remarks
27108: tend to pass from the personal to the general, “by the deep stamp which
27109: anxiety will make for a time even on the young and vigorous. I am
27110: naturally very strong; yet I have been thoroughly shaken lately by an
27111: accumulation of trouble.”
27112: 
27113: “I presume that a constitution in the susceptible state in which mine
27114: at present is, would be especially liable to fall a victim to cholera,
27115: if it visited our district. And since its appearance near London, we
27116: may well besiege the Mercy-seat for our protection,” said Mr.
27117: Bulstrode, not intending to evade Lydgate’s allusion, but really
27118: preoccupied with alarms about himself.
27119: 
27120: “You have at all events taken your share in using good practical
27121: precautions for the town, and that is the best mode of asking for
27122: protection,” said Lydgate, with a strong distaste for the broken
27123: metaphor and bad logic of the banker’s religion, somewhat increased by
27124: the apparent deafness of his sympathy. But his mind had taken up its
27125: long-prepared movement towards getting help, and was not yet arrested.
27126: He added, “The town has done well in the way of cleansing, and finding
27127: appliances; and I think that if the cholera should come, even our
27128: enemies will admit that the arrangements in the Hospital are a public
27129: good.”
27130: 
27131: “Truly,” said Mr. Bulstrode, with some coldness. “With regard to what
27132: you say, Mr. Lydgate, about the relaxation of my mental labor, I have
27133: for some time been entertaining a purpose to that effect—a purpose of a
27134: very decided character. I contemplate at least a temporary withdrawal
27135: from the management of much business, whether benevolent or commercial.
27136: Also I think of changing my residence for a time: probably I shall
27137: close or let ‘The Shrubs,’ and take some place near the coast—under
27138: advice of course as to salubrity. That would be a measure which you
27139: would recommend?”
27140: 
27141: “Oh yes,” said Lydgate, falling backward in his chair, with
27142: ill-repressed impatience under the banker’s pale earnest eyes and
27143: intense preoccupation with himself.
27144: 
27145: “I have for some time felt that I should open this subject with you in
27146: relation to our Hospital,” continued Bulstrode. “Under the
27147: circumstances I have indicated, of course I must cease to have any
27148: personal share in the management, and it is contrary to my views of
27149: responsibility to continue a large application of means to an
27150: institution which I cannot watch over and to some extent regulate. I
27151: shall therefore, in case of my ultimate decision to leave Middlemarch,
27152: consider that I withdraw other support to the New Hospital than that
27153: which will subsist in the fact that I chiefly supplied the expenses of
27154: building it, and have contributed further large sums to its successful
27155: working.”
27156: 
27157: Lydgate’s thought, when Bulstrode paused according to his wont, was,
27158: “He has perhaps been losing a good deal of money.” This was the most
27159: plausible explanation of a speech which had caused rather a startling
27160: change in his expectations. He said in reply—
27161: 
27162: “The loss to the Hospital can hardly be made up, I fear.”
27163: 
27164: “Hardly,” returned Bulstrode, in the same deliberate, silvery tone;
27165: “except by some changes of plan. The only person who may be certainly
27166: counted on as willing to increase her contributions is Mrs. Casaubon. I
27167: have had an interview with her on the subject, and I have pointed out
27168: to her, as I am about to do to you, that it will be desirable to win a
27169: more general support to the New Hospital by a change of system.”
27170: Another pause, but Lydgate did not speak.
27171: 
27172: “The change I mean is an amalgamation with the Infirmary, so that the
27173: New Hospital shall be regarded as a special addition to the elder
27174: institution, having the same directing board. It will be necessary,
27175: also, that the medical management of the two shall be combined. In this
27176: way any difficulty as to the adequate maintenance of our new
27177: establishment will be removed; the benevolent interests of the town
27178: will cease to be divided.”
27179: 
27180: Mr. Bulstrode had lowered his eyes from Lydgate’s face to the buttons
27181: of his coat as he again paused.
27182: 
27183: “No doubt that is a good device as to ways and means,” said Lydgate,
27184: with an edge of irony in his tone. “But I can’t be expected to rejoice
27185: in it at once, since one of the first results will be that the other
27186: medical men will upset or interrupt my methods, if it were only because
27187: they are mine.”
27188: 
27189: “I myself, as you know, Mr. Lydgate, highly valued the opportunity of
27190: new and independent procedure which you have diligently employed: the
27191: original plan, I confess, was one which I had much at heart, under
27192: submission to the Divine Will. But since providential indications
27193: demand a renunciation from me, I renounce.”
27194: 
27195: Bulstrode showed a rather exasperating ability in this conversation.
27196: The broken metaphor and bad logic of motive which had stirred his
27197: hearer’s contempt were quite consistent with a mode of putting the
27198: facts which made it difficult for Lydgate to vent his own indignation
27199: and disappointment. After some rapid reflection, he only asked—
27200: 
27201: “What did Mrs. Casaubon say?”
27202: 
27203: “That was the further statement which I wished to make to you,” said
27204: Bulstrode, who had thoroughly prepared his ministerial explanation.
27205: “She is, you are aware, a woman of most munificent disposition, and
27206: happily in possession—not I presume of great wealth, but of funds which
27207: she can well spare. She has informed me that though she has destined
27208: the chief part of those funds to another purpose, she is willing to
27209: consider whether she cannot fully take my place in relation to the
27210: Hospital. But she wishes for ample time to mature her thoughts on the
27211: subject, and I have told her that there is no need for haste—that, in
27212: fact, my own plans are not yet absolute.”
27213: 
27214: Lydgate was ready to say, “If Mrs. Casaubon would take your place,
27215: there would be gain, instead of loss.” But there was still a weight on
27216: his mind which arrested this cheerful candor. He replied, “I suppose,
27217: then, that I may enter into the subject with Mrs. Casaubon.”
27218: 
27219: “Precisely; that is what she expressly desires. Her decision, she says,
27220: will much depend on what you can tell her. But not at present: she is,
27221: I believe, just setting out on a journey. I have her letter here,” said
27222: Mr. Bulstrode, drawing it out, and reading from it. “‘I am immediately
27223: otherwise engaged,’ she says. ‘I am going into Yorkshire with Sir James
27224: and Lady Chettam; and the conclusions I come to about some land which I
27225: am to see there may affect my power of contributing to the Hospital.’
27226: Thus, Mr. Lydgate, there is no haste necessary in this matter; but I
27227: wished to apprise you beforehand of what may possibly occur.”
27228: 
27229: Mr. Bulstrode returned the letter to his side-pocket, and changed his
27230: attitude as if his business were closed. Lydgate, whose renewed hope
27231: about the Hospital only made him more conscious of the facts which
27232: poisoned his hope, felt that his effort after help, if made at all,
27233: must be made now and vigorously.
27234: 
27235: “I am much obliged to you for giving me full notice,” he said, with a
27236: firm intention in his tone, yet with an interruptedness in his delivery
27237: which showed that he spoke unwillingly. “The highest object to me is my
27238: profession, and I had identified the Hospital with the best use I can
27239: at present make of my profession. But the best use is not always the
27240: same with monetary success. Everything which has made the Hospital
27241: unpopular has helped with other causes—I think they are all connected
27242: with my professional zeal—to make me unpopular as a practitioner. I get
27243: chiefly patients who can’t pay me. I should like them best, if I had
27244: nobody to pay on my own side.” Lydgate waited a little, but Bulstrode
27245: only bowed, looking at him fixedly, and he went on with the same
27246: interrupted enunciation—as if he were biting an objectional leek.
27247: 
27248: “I have slipped into money difficulties which I can see no way out of,
27249: unless some one who trusts me and my future will advance me a sum
27250: without other security. I had very little fortune left when I came
27251: here. I have no prospects of money from my own family. My expenses, in
27252: consequence of my marriage, have been very much greater than I had
27253: expected. The result at this moment is that it would take a thousand
27254: pounds to clear me. I mean, to free me from the risk of having all my
27255: goods sold in security of my largest debt—as well as to pay my other
27256: debts—and leave anything to keep us a little beforehand with our small
27257: income. I find that it is out of the question that my wife’s father
27258: should make such an advance. That is why I mention my position to—to
27259: the only other man who may be held to have some personal connection
27260: with my prosperity or ruin.”
27261: 
27262: Lydgate hated to hear himself. But he had spoken now, and had spoken
27263: with unmistakable directness. Mr. Bulstrode replied without haste, but
27264: also without hesitation.
27265: 
27266: “I am grieved, though, I confess, not surprised by this information,
27267: Mr. Lydgate. For my own part, I regretted your alliance with my
27268: brother-in-law’s family, which has always been of prodigal habits, and
27269: which has already been much indebted to me for sustainment in its
27270: present position. My advice to you, Mr. Lydgate, would be, that instead
27271: of involving yourself in further obligations, and continuing a doubtful
27272: struggle, you should simply become a bankrupt.”
27273: 
27274: “That would not improve my prospect,” said Lydgate, rising and speaking
27275: bitterly, “even if it were a more agreeable thing in itself.”
27276: 
27277: “It is always a trial,” said Mr. Bulstrode; “but trial, my dear sir, is
27278: our portion here, and is a needed corrective. I recommend you to weigh
27279: the advice I have given.”
27280: 
27281: “Thank you,” said Lydgate, not quite knowing what he said. “I have
27282: occupied you too long. Good-day.”
27283: 
27284: 
27285: 
27286: 
27287: CHAPTER LXVIII.
27288: 
27289: What suit of grace hath Virtue to put on
27290: If Vice shall wear as good, and do as well?
27291: If Wrong, if Craft, if Indiscretion
27292: Act as fair parts with ends as laudable?
27293: Which all this mighty volume of events
27294: The world, the universal map of deeds,
27295: Strongly controls, and proves from all descents,
27296: That the directest course still best succeeds.
27297: For should not grave and learn’d Experience
27298: That looks with the eyes of all the world beside,
27299: And with all ages holds intelligence,
27300: Go safer than Deceit without a guide!
27301: —DANIEL: _Musophilus_.
27302: 
27303: 
27304: That change of plan and shifting of interest which Bulstrode stated or
27305: betrayed in his conversation with Lydgate, had been determined in him
27306: by some severe experience which he had gone through since the epoch of
27307: Mr. Larcher’s sale, when Raffles had recognized Will Ladislaw, and when
27308: the banker had in vain attempted an act of restitution which might move
27309: Divine Providence to arrest painful consequences.
27310: 
27311: His certainty that Raffles, unless he were dead, would return to
27312: Middlemarch before long, had been justified. On Christmas Eve he had
27313: reappeared at The Shrubs. Bulstrode was at home to receive him, and
27314: hinder his communication with the rest of the family, but he could not
27315: altogether hinder the circumstances of the visit from compromising
27316: himself and alarming his wife. Raffles proved more unmanageable than he
27317: had shown himself to be in his former appearances, his chronic state of
27318: mental restlessness, the growing effect of habitual intemperance,
27319: quickly shaking off every impression from what was said to him. He
27320: insisted on staying in the house, and Bulstrode, weighing two sets of
27321: evils, felt that this was at least not a worse alternative than his
27322: going into the town. He kept him in his own room for the evening and
27323: saw him to bed, Raffles all the while amusing himself with the
27324: annoyance he was causing this decent and highly prosperous
27325: fellow-sinner, an amusement which he facetiously expressed as sympathy
27326: with his friend’s pleasure in entertaining a man who had been
27327: serviceable to him, and who had not had all his earnings. There was a
27328: cunning calculation under this noisy joking—a cool resolve to extract
27329: something the handsomer from Bulstrode as payment for release from this
27330: new application of torture. But his cunning had a little overcast its
27331: mark.
27332: 
27333: Bulstrode was indeed more tortured than the coarse fibre of Raffles
27334: could enable him to imagine. He had told his wife that he was simply
27335: taking care of this wretched creature, the victim of vice, who might
27336: otherwise injure himself; he implied, without the direct form of
27337: falsehood, that there was a family tie which bound him to this care,
27338: and that there were signs of mental alienation in Raffles which urged
27339: caution. He would himself drive the unfortunate being away the next
27340: morning. In these hints he felt that he was supplying Mrs. Bulstrode
27341: with precautionary information for his daughters and servants, and
27342: accounting for his allowing no one but himself to enter the room even
27343: with food and drink. But he sat in an agony of fear lest Raffles should
27344: be overheard in his loud and plain references to past facts—lest Mrs.
27345: Bulstrode should be even tempted to listen at the door. How could he
27346: hinder her, how betray his terror by opening the door to detect her?
27347: She was a woman of honest direct habits, and little likely to take so
27348: low a course in order to arrive at painful knowledge; but fear was
27349: stronger than the calculation of probabilities.
27350: 
27351: In this way Raffles had pushed the torture too far, and produced an
27352: effect which had not been in his plan. By showing himself hopelessly
27353: unmanageable he had made Bulstrode feel that a strong defiance was the
27354: only resource left. After taking Raffles to bed that night the banker
27355: ordered his closed carriage to be ready at half-past seven the next
27356: morning. At six o’clock he had already been long dressed, and had spent
27357: some of his wretchedness in prayer, pleading his motives for averting
27358: the worst evil if in anything he had used falsity and spoken what was
27359: not true before God. For Bulstrode shrank from a direct lie with an
27360: intensity disproportionate to the number of his more indirect misdeeds.
27361: But many of these misdeeds were like the subtle muscular movements
27362: which are not taken account of in the consciousness, though they bring
27363: about the end that we fix our mind on and desire. And it is only what
27364: we are vividly conscious of that we can vividly imagine to be seen by
27365: Omniscience.
27366: 
27367: Bulstrode carried his candle to the bedside of Raffles, who was
27368: apparently in a painful dream. He stood silent, hoping that the
27369: presence of the light would serve to waken the sleeper gradually and
27370: gently, for he feared some noise as the consequence of a too sudden
27371: awakening. He had watched for a couple of minutes or more the
27372: shudderings and pantings which seemed likely to end in waking, when
27373: Raffles, with a long half-stifled moan, started up and stared round him
27374: in terror, trembling and gasping. But he made no further noise, and
27375: Bulstrode, setting down the candle, awaited his recovery.
27376: 
27377: It was a quarter of an hour later before Bulstrode, with a cold
27378: peremptoriness of manner which he had not before shown, said, “I came
27379: to call you thus early, Mr. Raffles, because I have ordered the
27380: carriage to be ready at half-past seven, and intend myself to conduct
27381: you as far as Ilsely, where you can either take the railway or await a
27382: coach.” Raffles was about to speak, but Bulstrode anticipated him
27383: imperiously with the words, “Be silent, sir, and hear what I have to
27384: say. I shall supply you with money now, and I will furnish you with a
27385: reasonable sum from time to time, on your application to me by letter;
27386: but if you choose to present yourself here again, if you return to
27387: Middlemarch, if you use your tongue in a manner injurious to me, you
27388: will have to live on such fruits as your malice can bring you, without
27389: help from me. Nobody will pay you well for blasting my name: I know the
27390: worst you can do against me, and I shall brave it if you dare to thrust
27391: yourself upon me again. Get up, sir, and do as I order you, without
27392: noise, or I will send for a policeman to take you off my premises, and
27393: you may carry your stories into every pothouse in the town, but you
27394: shall have no sixpence from me to pay your expenses there.”
27395: 
27396: Bulstrode had rarely in his life spoken with such nervous energy: he
27397: had been deliberating on this speech and its probable effects through a
27398: large part of the night; and though he did not trust to its ultimately
27399: saving him from any return of Raffles, he had concluded that it was the
27400: best throw he could make. It succeeded in enforcing submission from the
27401: jaded man this morning: his empoisoned system at this moment quailed
27402: before Bulstrode’s cold, resolute bearing, and he was taken off quietly
27403: in the carriage before the family breakfast time. The servants imagined
27404: him to be a poor relation, and were not surprised that a strict man
27405: like their master, who held his head high in the world, should be
27406: ashamed of such a cousin and want to get rid of him. The banker’s drive
27407: of ten miles with his hated companion was a dreary beginning of the
27408: Christmas day; but at the end of the drive, Raffles had recovered his
27409: spirits, and parted in a contentment for which there was the good
27410: reason that the banker had given him a hundred pounds. Various motives
27411: urged Bulstrode to this open-handedness, but he did not himself inquire
27412: closely into all of them. As he had stood watching Raffles in his
27413: uneasy sleep, it had certainly entered his mind that the man had been
27414: much shattered since the first gift of two hundred pounds.
27415: 
27416: He had taken care to repeat the incisive statement of his resolve not
27417: to be played on any more; and had tried to penetrate Raffles with the
27418: fact that he had shown the risks of bribing him to be quite equal to
27419: the risks of defying him. But when, freed from his repulsive presence,
27420: Bulstrode returned to his quiet home, he brought with him no confidence
27421: that he had secured more than a respite. It was as if he had had a
27422: loathsome dream, and could not shake off its images with their hateful
27423: kindred of sensations—as if on all the pleasant surroundings of his
27424: life a dangerous reptile had left his slimy traces.
27425: 
27426: Who can know how much of his most inward life is made up of the
27427: thoughts he believes other men to have about him, until that fabric of
27428: opinion is threatened with ruin?
27429: 
27430: Bulstrode was only the more conscious that there was a deposit of
27431: uneasy presentiment in his wife’s mind, because she carefully avoided
27432: any allusion to it. He had been used every day to taste the flavor of
27433: supremacy and the tribute of complete deference: and the certainty that
27434: he was watched or measured with a hidden suspicion of his having some
27435: discreditable secret, made his voice totter when he was speaking to
27436: edification. Foreseeing, to men of Bulstrode’s anxious temperament, is
27437: often worse than seeing; and his imagination continually heightened the
27438: anguish of an imminent disgrace. Yes, imminent; for if his defiance of
27439: Raffles did not keep the man away—and though he prayed for this result
27440: he hardly hoped for it—the disgrace was certain. In vain he said to
27441: himself that, if permitted, it would be a divine visitation, a
27442: chastisement, a preparation; he recoiled from the imagined burning; and
27443: he judged that it must be more for the Divine glory that he should
27444: escape dishonor. That recoil had at last urged him to make preparations
27445: for quitting Middlemarch. If evil truth must be reported of him, he
27446: would then be at a less scorching distance from the contempt of his old
27447: neighbors; and in a new scene, where his life would not have gathered
27448: the same wide sensibility, the tormentor, if he pursued him, would be
27449: less formidable. To leave the place finally would, he knew, be
27450: extremely painful to his wife, and on other grounds he would have
27451: preferred to stay where he had struck root. Hence he made his
27452: preparations at first in a conditional way, wishing to leave on all
27453: sides an opening for his return after brief absence, if any favorable
27454: intervention of Providence should dissipate his fears. He was preparing
27455: to transfer his management of the Bank, and to give up any active
27456: control of other commercial affairs in the neighborhood, on the ground
27457: of his failing health, but without excluding his future resumption of
27458: such work. The measure would cause him some added expense and some
27459: diminution of income beyond what he had already undergone from the
27460: general depression of trade; and the Hospital presented itself as a
27461: principal object of outlay on which he could fairly economize.
27462: 
27463: This was the experience which had determined his conversation with
27464: Lydgate. But at this time his arrangements had most of them gone no
27465: farther than a stage at which he could recall them if they proved to be
27466: unnecessary. He continually deferred the final steps; in the midst of
27467: his fears, like many a man who is in danger of shipwreck or of being
27468: dashed from his carriage by runaway horses, he had a clinging
27469: impression that something would happen to hinder the worst, and that to
27470: spoil his life by a late transplantation might be over-hasty—especially
27471: since it was difficult to account satisfactorily to his wife for the
27472: project of their indefinite exile from the only place where she would
27473: like to live.
27474: 
27475: Among the affairs Bulstrode had to care for, was the management of the
27476: farm at Stone Court in case of his absence; and on this as well as on
27477: all other matters connected with any houses and land he possessed in or
27478: about Middlemarch, he had consulted Caleb Garth. Like every one else
27479: who had business of that sort, he wanted to get the agent who was more
27480: anxious for his employer’s interests than his own. With regard to Stone
27481: Court, since Bulstrode wished to retain his hold on the stock, and to
27482: have an arrangement by which he himself could, if he chose, resume his
27483: favorite recreation of superintendence, Caleb had advised him not to
27484: trust to a mere bailiff, but to let the land, stock, and implements
27485: yearly, and take a proportionate share of the proceeds.
27486: 
27487: “May I trust to you to find me a tenant on these terms, Mr. Garth?”
27488: said Bulstrode. “And will you mention to me the yearly sum which would
27489: repay you for managing these affairs which we have discussed together?”
27490: 
27491: “I’ll think about it,” said Caleb, in his blunt way. “I’ll see how I
27492: can make it out.”
27493: 
27494: If it had not been that he had to consider Fred Vincy’s future, Mr.
27495: Garth would not probably have been glad of any addition to his work, of
27496: which his wife was always fearing an excess for him as he grew older.
27497: But on quitting Bulstrode after that conversation, a very alluring idea
27498: occurred to him about this said letting of Stone Court. What if
27499: Bulstrode would agree to his placing Fred Vincy there on the
27500: understanding that he, Caleb Garth, should be responsible for the
27501: management? It would be an excellent schooling for Fred; he might make
27502: a modest income there, and still have time left to get knowledge by
27503: helping in other business. He mentioned his notion to Mrs. Garth with
27504: such evident delight that she could not bear to chill his pleasure by
27505: expressing her constant fear of his undertaking too much.
27506: 
27507: “The lad would be as happy as two,” he said, throwing himself back in
27508: his chair, and looking radiant, “if I could tell him it was all
27509: settled. Think; Susan! His mind had been running on that place for
27510: years before old Featherstone died. And it would be as pretty a turn of
27511: things as could be that he should hold the place in a good industrious
27512: way after all—by his taking to business. For it’s likely enough
27513: Bulstrode might let him go on, and gradually buy the stock. He hasn’t
27514: made up his mind, I can see, whether or not he shall settle somewhere
27515: else as a lasting thing. I never was better pleased with a notion in my
27516: life. And then the children might be married by-and-by, Susan.”
27517: 
27518: “You will not give any hint of the plan to Fred, until you are sure
27519: that Bulstrode would agree to the plan?” said Mrs. Garth, in a tone of
27520: gentle caution. “And as to marriage, Caleb, we old people need not help
27521: to hasten it.”
27522: 
27523: “Oh, I don’t know,” said Caleb, swinging his head aside. “Marriage is a
27524: taming thing. Fred would want less of my bit and bridle. However, I
27525: shall say nothing till I know the ground I’m treading on. I shall speak
27526: to Bulstrode again.”
27527: 
27528: He took his earliest opportunity of doing so. Bulstrode had anything
27529: but a warm interest in his nephew Fred Vincy, but he had a strong wish
27530: to secure Mr. Garth’s services on many scattered points of business at
27531: which he was sure to be a considerable loser, if they were under less
27532: conscientious management. On that ground he made no objection to Mr.
27533: Garth’s proposal; and there was also another reason why he was not
27534: sorry to give a consent which was to benefit one of the Vincy family.
27535: It was that Mrs. Bulstrode, having heard of Lydgate’s debts, had been
27536: anxious to know whether her husband could not do something for poor
27537: Rosamond, and had been much troubled on learning from him that
27538: Lydgate’s affairs were not easily remediable, and that the wisest plan
27539: was to let them “take their course.” Mrs. Bulstrode had then said for
27540: the first time, “I think you are always a little hard towards my
27541: family, Nicholas. And I am sure I have no reason to deny any of my
27542: relatives. Too worldly they may be, but no one ever had to say that
27543: they were not respectable.”
27544: 
27545: “My dear Harriet,” said Mr. Bulstrode, wincing under his wife’s eyes,
27546: which were filling with tears, “I have supplied your brother with a
27547: great deal of capital. I cannot be expected to take care of his married
27548: children.”
27549: 
27550: That seemed to be true, and Mrs. Bulstrode’s remonstrance subsided into
27551: pity for poor Rosamond, whose extravagant education she had always
27552: foreseen the fruits of.
27553: 
27554: But remembering that dialogue, Mr. Bulstrode felt that when he had to
27555: talk to his wife fully about his plan of quitting Middlemarch, he
27556: should be glad to tell her that he had made an arrangement which might
27557: be for the good of her nephew Fred. At present he had merely mentioned
27558: to her that he thought of shutting up The Shrubs for a few months, and
27559: taking a house on the Southern Coast.
27560: 
27561: Hence Mr. Garth got the assurance he desired, namely, that in case of
27562: Bulstrode’s departure from Middlemarch for an indefinite time, Fred
27563: Vincy should be allowed to have the tenancy of Stone Court on the terms
27564: proposed.
27565: 
27566: Caleb was so elated with his hope of this “neat turn” being given to
27567: things, that if his self-control had not been braced by a little
27568: affectionate wifely scolding, he would have betrayed everything to
27569: Mary, wanting “to give the child comfort.” However, he restrained
27570: himself, and kept in strict privacy from Fred certain visits which he
27571: was making to Stone Court, in order to look more thoroughly into the
27572: state of the land and stock, and take a preliminary estimate. He was
27573: certainly more eager in these visits than the probable speed of events
27574: required him to be; but he was stimulated by a fatherly delight in
27575: occupying his mind with this bit of probable happiness which he held in
27576: store like a hidden birthday gift for Fred and Mary.
27577: 
27578: “But suppose the whole scheme should turn out to be a castle in the
27579: air?” said Mrs. Garth.
27580: 
27581: “Well, well,” replied Caleb; “the castle will tumble about nobody’s
27582: head.”
27583: 
27584: 
27585: 
27586: 
27587: CHAPTER LXIX.
27588: 
27589: “If thou hast heard a word, let it die with thee.”
27590: —_Ecclesiasticus_.
27591: 
27592: 
27593: Mr. Bulstrode was still seated in his manager’s room at the Bank, about
27594: three o’clock of the same day on which he had received Lydgate there,
27595: when the clerk entered to say that his horse was waiting, and also that
27596: Mr. Garth was outside and begged to speak with him.
27597: 
27598: “By all means,” said Bulstrode; and Caleb entered. “Pray sit down, Mr.
27599: Garth,” continued the banker, in his suavest tone.
27600: 
27601: “I am glad that you arrived just in time to find me here. I know you
27602: count your minutes.”
27603: 
27604: “Oh,” said Caleb, gently, with a slow swing of his head on one side, as
27605: he seated himself and laid his hat on the floor.
27606: 
27607: He looked at the ground, leaning forward and letting his long fingers
27608: droop between his legs, while each finger moved in succession, as if it
27609: were sharing some thought which filled his large quiet brow.
27610: 
27611: Mr. Bulstrode, like every one else who knew Caleb, was used to his
27612: slowness in beginning to speak on any topic which he felt to be
27613: important, and rather expected that he was about to recur to the buying
27614: of some houses in Blindman’s Court, for the sake of pulling them down,
27615: as a sacrifice of property which would be well repaid by the influx of
27616: air and light on that spot. It was by propositions of this kind that
27617: Caleb was sometimes troublesome to his employers; but he had usually
27618: found Bulstrode ready to meet him in projects of improvement, and they
27619: had got on well together. When he spoke again, however, it was to say,
27620: in rather a subdued voice—
27621: 
27622: “I have just come away from Stone Court, Mr. Bulstrode.”
27623: 
27624: “You found nothing wrong there, I hope,” said the banker; “I was there
27625: myself yesterday. Abel has done well with the lambs this year.”
27626: 
27627: “Why, yes,” said Caleb, looking up gravely, “there is something wrong—a
27628: stranger, who is very ill, I think. He wants a doctor, and I came to
27629: tell you of that. His name is Raffles.”
27630: 
27631: He saw the shock of his words passing through Bulstrode’s frame. On
27632: this subject the banker had thought that his fears were too constantly
27633: on the watch to be taken by surprise; but he had been mistaken.
27634: 
27635: “Poor wretch!” he said in a compassionate tone, though his lips
27636: trembled a little. “Do you know how he came there?”
27637: 
27638: “I took him myself,” said Caleb, quietly—“took him up in my gig. He had
27639: got down from the coach, and was walking a little beyond the turning
27640: from the toll-house, and I overtook him. He remembered seeing me with
27641: you once before, at Stone Court, and he asked me to take him on. I saw
27642: he was ill: it seemed to me the right thing to do, to carry him under
27643: shelter. And now I think you should lose no time in getting advice for
27644: him.” Caleb took up his hat from the floor as he ended, and rose slowly
27645: from his seat.
27646: 
27647: “Certainly,” said Bulstrode, whose mind was very active at this moment.
27648: “Perhaps you will yourself oblige me, Mr. Garth, by calling at Mr.
27649: Lydgate’s as you pass—or stay! he may at this hour probably be at the
27650: Hospital. I will first send my man on the horse there with a note this
27651: instant, and then I will myself ride to Stone Court.”
27652: 
27653: Bulstrode quickly wrote a note, and went out himself to give the
27654: commission to his man. When he returned, Caleb was standing as before
27655: with one hand on the back of the chair, holding his hat with the other.
27656: In Bulstrode’s mind the dominant thought was, “Perhaps Raffles only
27657: spoke to Garth of his illness. Garth may wonder, as he must have done
27658: before, at this disreputable fellow’s claiming intimacy with me; but he
27659: will know nothing. And he is friendly to me—I can be of use to him.”
27660: 
27661: He longed for some confirmation of this hopeful conjecture, but to have
27662: asked any question as to what Raffles had said or done would have been
27663: to betray fear.
27664: 
27665: “I am exceedingly obliged to you, Mr. Garth,” he said, in his usual
27666: tone of politeness. “My servant will be back in a few minutes, and I
27667: shall then go myself to see what can be done for this unfortunate man.
27668: Perhaps you had some other business with me? If so, pray be seated.”
27669: 
27670: “Thank you,” said Caleb, making a slight gesture with his right hand to
27671: waive the invitation. “I wish to say, Mr. Bulstrode, that I must
27672: request you to put your business into some other hands than mine. I am
27673: obliged to you for your handsome way of meeting me—about the letting of
27674: Stone Court, and all other business. But I must give it up.” A sharp
27675: certainty entered like a stab into Bulstrode’s soul.
27676: 
27677: “This is sudden, Mr. Garth,” was all he could say at first.
27678: 
27679: “It is,” said Caleb; “but it is quite fixed. I must give it up.”
27680: 
27681: He spoke with a firmness which was very gentle, and yet he could see
27682: that Bulstrode seemed to cower under that gentleness, his face looking
27683: dried and his eyes swerving away from the glance which rested on him.
27684: Caleb felt a deep pity for him, but he could have used no pretexts to
27685: account for his resolve, even if they would have been of any use.
27686: 
27687: “You have been led to this, I apprehend, by some slanders concerning me
27688: uttered by that unhappy creature,” said Bulstrode, anxious now to know
27689: the utmost.
27690: 
27691: “That is true. I can’t deny that I act upon what I heard from him.”
27692: 
27693: “You are a conscientious man, Mr. Garth—a man, I trust, who feels
27694: himself accountable to God. You would not wish to injure me by being
27695: too ready to believe a slander,” said Bulstrode, casting about for
27696: pleas that might be adapted to his hearer’s mind. “That is a poor
27697: reason for giving up a connection which I think I may say will be
27698: mutually beneficial.”
27699: 
27700: “I would injure no man if I could help it,” said Caleb; “even if I
27701: thought God winked at it. I hope I should have a feeling for my
27702: fellow-creature. But, sir—I am obliged to believe that this Raffles has
27703: told me the truth. And I can’t be happy in working with you, or
27704: profiting by you. It hurts my mind. I must beg you to seek another
27705: agent.”
27706: 
27707: “Very well, Mr. Garth. But I must at least claim to know the worst that
27708: he has told you. I must know what is the foul speech that I am liable
27709: to be the victim of,” said Bulstrode, a certain amount of anger
27710: beginning to mingle with his humiliation before this quiet man who
27711: renounced his benefits.
27712: 
27713: “That’s needless,” said Caleb, waving his hand, bowing his head
27714: slightly, and not swerving from the tone which had in it the merciful
27715: intention to spare this pitiable man. “What he has said to me will
27716: never pass from my lips, unless something now unknown forces it from
27717: me. If you led a harmful life for gain, and kept others out of their
27718: rights by deceit, to get the more for yourself, I dare say you
27719: repent—you would like to go back, and can’t: that must be a bitter
27720: thing”—Caleb paused a moment and shook his head—“it is not for me to
27721: make your life harder to you.”
27722: 
27723: “But you do—you do make it harder to me,” said Bulstrode constrained
27724: into a genuine, pleading cry. “You make it harder to me by turning your
27725: back on me.”
27726: 
27727: “That I’m forced to do,” said Caleb, still more gently, lifting up his
27728: hand. “I am sorry. I don’t judge you and say, he is wicked, and I am
27729: righteous. God forbid. I don’t know everything. A man may do wrong, and
27730: his will may rise clear out of it, though he can’t get his life clear.
27731: That’s a bad punishment. If it is so with you,—well, I’m very sorry for
27732: you. But I have that feeling inside me, that I can’t go on working with
27733: you. That’s all, Mr. Bulstrode. Everything else is buried, so far as my
27734: will goes. And I wish you good-day.”
27735: 
27736: “One moment, Mr. Garth!” said Bulstrode, hurriedly. “I may trust then
27737: to your solemn assurance that you will not repeat either to man or
27738: woman what—even if it have any degree of truth in it—is yet a malicious
27739: representation?” Caleb’s wrath was stirred, and he said, indignantly—
27740: 
27741: “Why should I have said it if I didn’t mean it? I am in no fear of you.
27742: Such tales as that will never tempt my tongue.”
27743: 
27744: “Excuse me—I am agitated—I am the victim of this abandoned man.”
27745: 
27746: “Stop a bit! you have got to consider whether you didn’t help to make
27747: him worse, when you profited by his vices.”
27748: 
27749: “You are wronging me by too readily believing him,” said Bulstrode,
27750: oppressed, as by a nightmare, with the inability to deny flatly what
27751: Raffles might have said; and yet feeling it an escape that Caleb had
27752: not so stated it to him as to ask for that flat denial.
27753: 
27754: “No,” said Caleb, lifting his hand deprecatingly; “I am ready to
27755: believe better, when better is proved. I rob you of no good chance. As
27756: to speaking, I hold it a crime to expose a man’s sin unless I’m clear
27757: it must be done to save the innocent. That is my way of thinking, Mr.
27758: Bulstrode, and what I say, I’ve no need to swear. I wish you good-day.”
27759: 
27760: Some hours later, when he was at home, Caleb said to his wife,
27761: incidentally, that he had had some little differences with Bulstrode,
27762: and that in consequence, he had given up all notion of taking Stone
27763: Court, and indeed had resigned doing further business for him.
27764: 
27765: “He was disposed to interfere too much, was he?” said Mrs. Garth,
27766: imagining that her husband had been touched on his sensitive point, and
27767: not been allowed to do what he thought right as to materials and modes
27768: of work.
27769: 
27770: “Oh,” said Caleb, bowing his head and waving his hand gravely. And Mrs.
27771: Garth knew that this was a sign of his not intending to speak further
27772: on the subject.
27773: 
27774: As for Bulstrode, he had almost immediately mounted his horse and set
27775: off for Stone Court, being anxious to arrive there before Lydgate.
27776: 
27777: His mind was crowded with images and conjectures, which were a language
27778: to his hopes and fears, just as we hear tones from the vibrations which
27779: shake our whole system. The deep humiliation with which he had winced
27780: under Caleb Garth’s knowledge of his past and rejection of his
27781: patronage, alternated with and almost gave way to the sense of safety
27782: in the fact that Garth, and no other, had been the man to whom Raffles
27783: had spoken. It seemed to him a sort of earnest that Providence intended
27784: his rescue from worse consequences; the way being thus left open for
27785: the hope of secrecy. That Raffles should be afflicted with illness,
27786: that he should have been led to Stone Court rather than
27787: elsewhere—Bulstrode’s heart fluttered at the vision of probabilities
27788: which these events conjured up. If it should turn out that he was freed
27789: from all danger of disgrace—if he could breathe in perfect liberty—his
27790: life should be more consecrated than it had ever been before. He
27791: mentally lifted up this vow as if it would urge the result he longed
27792: for—he tried to believe in the potency of that prayerful resolution—its
27793: potency to determine death. He knew that he ought to say, “Thy will be
27794: done;” and he said it often. But the intense desire remained that the
27795: will of God might be the death of that hated man.
27796: 
27797: Yet when he arrived at Stone Court he could not see the change in
27798: Raffles without a shock. But for his pallor and feebleness, Bulstrode
27799: would have called the change in him entirely mental. Instead of his
27800: loud tormenting mood, he showed an intense, vague terror, and seemed to
27801: deprecate Bulstrode’s anger, because the money was all gone—he had been
27802: robbed—it had half of it been taken from him. He had only come here
27803: because he was ill and somebody was hunting him—somebody was after him,
27804: he had told nobody anything, he had kept his mouth shut. Bulstrode, not
27805: knowing the significance of these symptoms, interpreted this new
27806: nervous susceptibility into a means of alarming Raffles into true
27807: confessions, and taxed him with falsehood in saying that he had not
27808: told anything, since he had just told the man who took him up in his
27809: gig and brought him to Stone Court. Raffles denied this with solemn
27810: adjurations; the fact being that the links of consciousness were
27811: interrupted in him, and that his minute terror-stricken narrative to
27812: Caleb Garth had been delivered under a set of visionary impulses which
27813: had dropped back into darkness.
27814: 
27815: Bulstrode’s heart sank again at this sign that he could get no grasp
27816: over the wretched man’s mind, and that no word of Raffles could be
27817: trusted as to the fact which he most wanted to know, namely, whether or
27818: not he had really kept silence to every one in the neighborhood except
27819: Caleb Garth. The housekeeper had told him without the least constraint
27820: of manner that since Mr. Garth left, Raffles had asked her for beer,
27821: and after that had not spoken, seeming very ill. On that side it might
27822: be concluded that there had been no betrayal. Mrs. Abel thought, like
27823: the servants at The Shrubs, that the strange man belonged to the
27824: unpleasant “kin” who are among the troubles of the rich; she had at
27825: first referred the kinship to Mr. Rigg, and where there was property
27826: left, the buzzing presence of such large blue-bottles seemed natural
27827: enough. How he could be “kin” to Bulstrode as well was not so clear,
27828: but Mrs. Abel agreed with her husband that there was “no knowing,” a
27829: proposition which had a great deal of mental food for her, so that she
27830: shook her head over it without further speculation.
27831: 
27832: In less than an hour Lydgate arrived. Bulstrode met him outside the
27833: wainscoted parlor, where Raffles was, and said—
27834: 
27835: “I have called you in, Mr. Lydgate, to an unfortunate man who was once
27836: in my employment, many years ago. Afterwards he went to America, and
27837: returned I fear to an idle dissolute life. Being destitute, he has a
27838: claim on me. He was slightly connected with Rigg, the former owner of
27839: this place, and in consequence found his way here. I believe he is
27840: seriously ill: apparently his mind is affected. I feel bound to do the
27841: utmost for him.”
27842: 
27843: Lydgate, who had the remembrance of his last conversation with
27844: Bulstrode strongly upon him, was not disposed to say an unnecessary
27845: word to him, and bowed slightly in answer to this account; but just
27846: before entering the room he turned automatically and said, “What is his
27847: name?”—to know names being as much a part of the medical man’s
27848: accomplishment as of the practical politician’s.
27849: 
27850: “Raffles, John Raffles,” said Bulstrode, who hoped that whatever became
27851: of Raffles, Lydgate would never know any more of him.
27852: 
27853: When he had thoroughly examined and considered the patient, Lydgate
27854: ordered that he should go to bed, and be kept there in as complete
27855: quiet as possible, and then went with Bulstrode into another room.
27856: 
27857: “It is a serious case, I apprehend,” said the banker, before Lydgate
27858: began to speak.
27859: 
27860: “No—and yes,” said Lydgate, half dubiously. “It is difficult to decide
27861: as to the possible effect of long-standing complications; but the man
27862: had a robust constitution to begin with. I should not expect this
27863: attack to be fatal, though of course the system is in a ticklish state.
27864: He should be well watched and attended to.”
27865: 
27866: “I will remain here myself,” said Bulstrode. “Mrs. Abel and her husband
27867: are inexperienced. I can easily remain here for the night, if you will
27868: oblige me by taking a note for Mrs. Bulstrode.”
27869: 
27870: “I should think that is hardly necessary,” said Lydgate. “He seems tame
27871: and terrified enough. He might become more unmanageable. But there is a
27872: man here—is there not?”
27873: 
27874: “I have more than once stayed here a few nights for the sake of
27875: seclusion,” said Bulstrode, indifferently; “I am quite disposed to do
27876: so now. Mrs. Abel and her husband can relieve or aid me, if necessary.”
27877: 
27878: “Very well. Then I need give my directions only to you,” said Lydgate,
27879: not feeling surprised at a little peculiarity in Bulstrode.
27880: 
27881: “You think, then, that the case is hopeful?” said Bulstrode, when
27882: Lydgate had ended giving his orders.
27883: 
27884: “Unless there turn out to be further complications, such as I have not
27885: at present detected—yes,” said Lydgate. “He may pass on to a worse
27886: stage; but I should not wonder if he got better in a few days, by
27887: adhering to the treatment I have prescribed. There must be firmness.
27888: Remember, if he calls for liquors of any sort, not to give them to him.
27889: In my opinion, men in his condition are oftener killed by treatment
27890: than by the disease. Still, new symptoms may arise. I shall come again
27891: to-morrow morning.”
27892: 
27893: After waiting for the note to be carried to Mrs. Bulstrode, Lydgate
27894: rode away, forming no conjectures, in the first instance, about the
27895: history of Raffles, but rehearsing the whole argument, which had lately
27896: been much stirred by the publication of Dr. Ware’s abundant experience
27897: in America, as to the right way of treating cases of alcoholic
27898: poisoning such as this. Lydgate, when abroad, had already been
27899: interested in this question: he was strongly convinced against the
27900: prevalent practice of allowing alcohol and persistently administering
27901: large doses of opium; and he had repeatedly acted on this conviction
27902: with a favorable result.
27903: 
27904: “The man is in a diseased state,” he thought, “but there’s a good deal
27905: of wear in him still. I suppose he is an object of charity to
27906: Bulstrode. It is curious what patches of hardness and tenderness lie
27907: side by side in men’s dispositions. Bulstrode seems the most
27908: unsympathetic fellow I ever saw about some people, and yet he has taken
27909: no end of trouble, and spent a great deal of money, on benevolent
27910: objects. I suppose he has some test by which he finds out whom Heaven
27911: cares for—he has made up his mind that it doesn’t care for me.”
27912: 
27913: This streak of bitterness came from a plenteous source, and kept
27914: widening in the current of his thought as he neared Lowick Gate. He had
27915: not been there since his first interview with Bulstrode in the morning,
27916: having been found at the Hospital by the banker’s messenger; and for
27917: the first time he was returning to his home without the vision of any
27918: expedient in the background which left him a hope of raising money
27919: enough to deliver him from the coming destitution of everything which
27920: made his married life tolerable—everything which saved him and Rosamond
27921: from that bare isolation in which they would be forced to recognize how
27922: little of a comfort they could be to each other. It was more bearable
27923: to do without tenderness for himself than to see that his own
27924: tenderness could make no amends for the lack of other things to her.
27925: The sufferings of his own pride from humiliations past and to come were
27926: keen enough, yet they were hardly distinguishable to himself from that
27927: more acute pain which dominated them—the pain of foreseeing that
27928: Rosamond would come to regard him chiefly as the cause of
27929: disappointment and unhappiness to her. He had never liked the
27930: makeshifts of poverty, and they had never before entered into his
27931: prospects for himself; but he was beginning now to imagine how two
27932: creatures who loved each other, and had a stock of thoughts in common,
27933: might laugh over their shabby furniture, and their calculations how far
27934: they could afford butter and eggs. But the glimpse of that poetry
27935: seemed as far off from him as the carelessness of the golden age; in
27936: poor Rosamond’s mind there was not room enough for luxuries to look
27937: small in. He got down from his horse in a very sad mood, and went into
27938: the house, not expecting to be cheered except by his dinner, and
27939: reflecting that before the evening closed it would be wise to tell
27940: Rosamond of his application to Bulstrode and its failure. It would be
27941: well not to lose time in preparing her for the worst.
27942: 
27943: But his dinner waited long for him before he was able to eat it. For on
27944: entering he found that Dover’s agent had already put a man in the
27945: house, and when he asked where Mrs. Lydgate was, he was told that she
27946: was in her bedroom. He went up and found her stretched on the bed pale
27947: and silent, without an answer even in her face to any word or look of
27948: his. He sat down by the bed and leaning over her said with almost a cry
27949: of prayer—
27950: 
27951: “Forgive me for this misery, my poor Rosamond! Let us only love one
27952: another.”
27953: 
27954: She looked at him silently, still with the blank despair on her face;
27955: but then the tears began to fill her blue eyes, and her lip trembled.
27956: The strong man had had too much to bear that day. He let his head fall
27957: beside hers and sobbed.
27958: 
27959: He did not hinder her from going to her father early in the morning—it
27960: seemed now that he ought not to hinder her from doing as she pleased.
27961: In half an hour she came back, and said that papa and mamma wished her
27962: to go and stay with them while things were in this miserable state.
27963: Papa said he could do nothing about the debt—if he paid this, there
27964: would be half-a-dozen more. She had better come back home again till
27965: Lydgate had got a comfortable home for her. “Do you object, Tertius?”
27966: 
27967: “Do as you like,” said Lydgate. “But things are not coming to a crisis
27968: immediately. There is no hurry.”
27969: 
27970: “I should not go till to-morrow,” said Rosamond; “I shall want to pack
27971: my clothes.”
27972: 
27973: “Oh, I would wait a little longer than to-morrow—there is no knowing
27974: what may happen,” said Lydgate, with bitter irony. “I may get my neck
27975: broken, and that may make things easier to you.”
27976: 
27977: It was Lydgate’s misfortune and Rosamond’s too, that his tenderness
27978: towards her, which was both an emotional prompting and a
27979: well-considered resolve, was inevitably interrupted by these outbursts
27980: of indignation either ironical or remonstrant. She thought them totally
27981: unwarranted, and the repulsion which this exceptional severity excited
27982: in her was in danger of making the more persistent tenderness
27983: unacceptable.
27984: 
27985: “I see you do not wish me to go,” she said, with chill mildness; “why
27986: can you not say so, without that kind of violence? I shall stay until
27987: you request me to do otherwise.”
27988: 
27989: Lydgate said no more, but went out on his rounds. He felt bruised and
27990: shattered, and there was a dark line under his eyes which Rosamond had
27991: not seen before. She could not bear to look at him. Tertius had a way
27992: of taking things which made them a great deal worse for her.
27993: 
27994: 
27995: 
27996: 
27997: CHAPTER LXX.
27998: 
27999: “Our deeds still travel with us from afar,
28000: And what we have been makes us what we are.”
28001: 
28002: 
28003: Bulstrode’s first object after Lydgate had left Stone Court was to
28004: examine Raffles’s pockets, which he imagined were sure to carry signs
28005: in the shape of hotel-bills of the places he had stopped in, if he had
28006: not told the truth in saying that he had come straight from Liverpool
28007: because he was ill and had no money. There were various bills crammed
28008: into his pocketbook, but none of a later date than Christmas at any
28009: other place, except one, which bore date that morning. This was
28010: crumpled up with a hand-bill about a horse-fair in one of his
28011: tail-pockets, and represented the cost of three days’ stay at an inn at
28012: Bilkley, where the fair was held—a town at least forty miles from
28013: Middlemarch. The bill was heavy, and since Raffles had no luggage with
28014: him, it seemed probable that he had left his portmanteau behind in
