28015: payment, in order to save money for his travelling fare; for his purse
28016: was empty, and he had only a couple of sixpences and some loose pence
28017: in his pockets.
28018: 
28019: Bulstrode gathered a sense of safety from these indications that
28020: Raffles had really kept at a distance from Middlemarch since his
28021: memorable visit at Christmas. At a distance and among people who were
28022: strangers to Bulstrode, what satisfaction could there be to Raffles’s
28023: tormenting, self-magnifying vein in telling old scandalous stories
28024: about a Middlemarch banker? And what harm if he did talk? The chief
28025: point now was to keep watch over him as long as there was any danger of
28026: that intelligible raving, that unaccountable impulse to tell, which
28027: seemed to have acted towards Caleb Garth; and Bulstrode felt much
28028: anxiety lest some such impulse should come over him at the sight of
28029: Lydgate. He sat up alone with him through the night, only ordering the
28030: housekeeper to lie down in her clothes, so as to be ready when he
28031: called her, alleging his own indisposition to sleep, and his anxiety to
28032: carry out the doctor’s orders. He did carry them out faithfully,
28033: although Raffles was incessantly asking for brandy, and declaring that
28034: he was sinking away—that the earth was sinking away from under him. He
28035: was restless and sleepless, but still quailing and manageable. On the
28036: offer of the food ordered by Lydgate, which he refused, and the denial
28037: of other things which he demanded, he seemed to concentrate all his
28038: terror on Bulstrode, imploringly deprecating his anger, his revenge on
28039: him by starvation, and declaring with strong oaths that he had never
28040: told any mortal a word against him. Even this Bulstrode felt that he
28041: would not have liked Lydgate to hear; but a more alarming sign of
28042: fitful alternation in his delirium was, that in-the morning twilight
28043: Raffles suddenly seemed to imagine a doctor present, addressing him and
28044: declaring that Bulstrode wanted to starve him to death out of revenge
28045: for telling, when he never had told.
28046: 
28047: Bulstrode’s native imperiousness and strength of determination served
28048: him well. This delicate-looking man, himself nervously perturbed, found
28049: the needed stimulus in his strenuous circumstances, and through that
28050: difficult night and morning, while he had the air of an animated corpse
28051: returned to movement without warmth, holding the mastery by its chill
28052: impassibility, his mind was intensely at work thinking of what he had
28053: to guard against and what would win him security. Whatever prayers he
28054: might lift up, whatever statements he might inwardly make of this man’s
28055: wretched spiritual condition, and the duty he himself was under to
28056: submit to the punishment divinely appointed for him rather than to wish
28057: for evil to another—through all this effort to condense words into a
28058: solid mental state, there pierced and spread with irresistible
28059: vividness the images of the events he desired. And in the train of
28060: those images came their apology. He could not but see the death of
28061: Raffles, and see in it his own deliverance. What was the removal of
28062: this wretched creature? He was impenitent—but were not public criminals
28063: impenitent?—yet the law decided on their fate. Should Providence in
28064: this case award death, there was no sin in contemplating death as the
28065: desirable issue—if he kept his hands from hastening it—if he
28066: scrupulously did what was prescribed. Even here there might be a
28067: mistake: human prescriptions were fallible things: Lydgate had said
28068: that treatment had hastened death,—why not his own method of treatment?
28069: But of course intention was everything in the question of right and
28070: wrong.
28071: 
28072: And Bulstrode set himself to keep his intention separate from his
28073: desire. He inwardly declared that he intended to obey orders. Why
28074: should he have got into any argument about the validity of these
28075: orders? It was only the common trick of desire—which avails itself of
28076: any irrelevant scepticism, finding larger room for itself in all
28077: uncertainty about effects, in every obscurity that looks like the
28078: absence of law. Still, he did obey the orders.
28079: 
28080: His anxieties continually glanced towards Lydgate, and his remembrance
28081: of what had taken place between them the morning before was accompanied
28082: with sensibilities which had not been roused at all during the actual
28083: scene. He had then cared but little about Lydgate’s painful impressions
28084: with regard to the suggested change in the Hospital, or about the
28085: disposition towards himself which what he held to be his justifiable
28086: refusal of a rather exorbitant request might call forth. He recurred to
28087: the scene now with a perception that he had probably made Lydgate his
28088: enemy, and with an awakened desire to propitiate him, or rather to
28089: create in him a strong sense of personal obligation. He regretted that
28090: he had not at once made even an unreasonable money-sacrifice. For in
28091: case of unpleasant suspicions, or even knowledge gathered from the
28092: raving of Raffles, Bulstrode would have felt that he had a defence in
28093: Lydgate’s mind by having conferred a momentous benefit on him. But the
28094: regret had perhaps come too late.
28095: 
28096: Strange, piteous conflict in the soul of this unhappy man, who had
28097: longed for years to be better than he was—who had taken his selfish
28098: passions into discipline and clad them in severe robes, so that he had
28099: walked with them as a devout choir, till now that a terror had risen
28100: among them, and they could chant no longer, but threw out their common
28101: cries for safety.
28102: 
28103: It was nearly the middle of the day before Lydgate arrived: he had
28104: meant to come earlier, but had been detained, he said; and his
28105: shattered looks were noticed by Balstrode. But he immediately threw
28106: himself into the consideration of the patient, and inquired strictly
28107: into all that had occurred. Raffles was worse, would take hardly any
28108: food, was persistently wakeful and restlessly raving; but still not
28109: violent. Contrary to Bulstrode’s alarmed expectation, he took little
28110: notice of Lydgate’s presence, and continued to talk or murmur
28111: incoherently.
28112: 
28113: “What do you think of him?” said Bulstrode, in private.
28114: 
28115: “The symptoms are worse.”
28116: 
28117: “You are less hopeful?”
28118: 
28119: “No; I still think he may come round. Are you going to stay here
28120: yourself?” said Lydgate, looking at Bulstrode with an abrupt question,
28121: which made him uneasy, though in reality it was not due to any
28122: suspicious conjecture.
28123: 
28124: “Yes, I think so,” said Bulstrode, governing himself and speaking with
28125: deliberation. “Mrs. Bulstrode is advised of the reasons which detain
28126: me. Mrs. Abel and her husband are not experienced enough to be left
28127: quite alone, and this kind of responsibility is scarcely included in
28128: their service of me. You have some fresh instructions, I presume.”
28129: 
28130: The chief new instruction that Lydgate had to give was on the
28131: administration of extremely moderate doses of opium, in case of the
28132: sleeplessness continuing after several hours. He had taken the
28133: precaution of bringing opium in his pocket, and he gave minute
28134: directions to Bulstrode as to the doses, and the point at which they
28135: should cease. He insisted on the risk of not ceasing; and repeated his
28136: order that no alcohol should be given.
28137: 
28138: “From what I see of the case,” he ended, “narcotism is the only thing I
28139: should be much afraid of. He may wear through even without much food.
28140: There’s a good deal of strength in him.”
28141: 
28142: “You look ill yourself, Mr. Lydgate—a most unusual, I may say
28143: unprecedented thing in my knowledge of you,” said Bulstrode, showing a
28144: solicitude as unlike his indifference the day before, as his present
28145: recklessness about his own fatigue was unlike his habitual
28146: self-cherishing anxiety. “I fear you are harassed.”
28147: 
28148: “Yes, I am,” said Lydgate, brusquely, holding his hat, and ready to go.
28149: 
28150: “Something new, I fear,” said Bulstrode, inquiringly. “Pray be seated.”
28151: 
28152: “No, thank you,” said Lydgate, with some hauteur. “I mentioned to you
28153: yesterday what was the state of my affairs. There is nothing to add,
28154: except that the execution has since then been actually put into my
28155: house. One can tell a good deal of trouble in a short sentence. I will
28156: say good morning.”
28157: 
28158: “Stay, Mr. Lydgate, stay,” said Bulstrode; “I have been reconsidering
28159: this subject. I was yesterday taken by surprise, and saw it
28160: superficially. Mrs. Bulstrode is anxious for her niece, and I myself
28161: should grieve at a calamitous change in your position. Claims on me are
28162: numerous, but on reconsideration, I esteem it right that I should incur
28163: a small sacrifice rather than leave you unaided. You said, I think,
28164: that a thousand pounds would suffice entirely to free you from your
28165: burthens, and enable you to recover a firm stand?”
28166: 
28167: “Yes,” said Lydgate, a great leap of joy within him surmounting every
28168: other feeling; “that would pay all my debts, and leave me a little on
28169: hand. I could set about economizing in our way of living. And by-and-by
28170: my practice might look up.”
28171: 
28172: “If you will wait a moment, Mr. Lydgate, I will draw a check to that
28173: amount. I am aware that help, to be effectual in these cases, should be
28174: thorough.”
28175: 
28176: While Bulstrode wrote, Lydgate turned to the window thinking of his
28177: home—thinking of his life with its good start saved from frustration,
28178: its good purposes still unbroken.
28179: 
28180: “You can give me a note of hand for this, Mr. Lydgate,” said the
28181: banker, advancing towards him with the check. “And by-and-by, I hope,
28182: you may be in circumstances gradually to repay me. Meanwhile, I have
28183: pleasure in thinking that you will be released from further
28184: difficulty.”
28185: 
28186: “I am deeply obliged to you,” said Lydgate. “You have restored to me
28187: the prospect of working with some happiness and some chance of good.”
28188: 
28189: It appeared to him a very natural movement in Bulstrode that he should
28190: have reconsidered his refusal: it corresponded with the more munificent
28191: side of his character. But as he put his hack into a canter, that he
28192: might get the sooner home, and tell the good news to Rosamond, and get
28193: cash at the bank to pay over to Dover’s agent, there crossed his mind,
28194: with an unpleasant impression, as from a dark-winged flight of evil
28195: augury across his vision, the thought of that contrast in himself which
28196: a few months had brought—that he should be overjoyed at being under a
28197: strong personal obligation—that he should be overjoyed at getting money
28198: for himself from Bulstrode.
28199: 
28200: The banker felt that he had done something to nullify one cause of
28201: uneasiness, and yet he was scarcely the easier. He did not measure the
28202: quantity of diseased motive which had made him wish for Lydgate’s
28203: good-will, but the quantity was none the less actively there, like an
28204: irritating agent in his blood. A man vows, and yet will not cast away
28205: the means of breaking his vow. Is it that he distinctly means to break
28206: it? Not at all; but the desires which tend to break it are at work in
28207: him dimly, and make their way into his imagination, and relax his
28208: muscles in the very moments when he is telling himself over again the
28209: reasons for his vow. Raffles, recovering quickly, returning to the free
28210: use of his odious powers—how could Bulstrode wish for that? Raffles
28211: dead was the image that brought release, and indirectly he prayed for
28212: that way of release, beseeching that, if it were possible, the rest of
28213: his days here below might be freed from the threat of an ignominy which
28214: would break him utterly as an instrument of God’s service. Lydgate’s
28215: opinion was not on the side of promise that this prayer would be
28216: fulfilled; and as the day advanced, Bulstrode felt himself getting
28217: irritated at the persistent life in this man, whom he would fain have
28218: seen sinking into the silence of death: imperious will stirred
28219: murderous impulses towards this brute life, over which will, by itself,
28220: had no power. He said inwardly that he was getting too much worn; he
28221: would not sit up with the patient to-night, but leave him to Mrs. Abel,
28222: who, if necessary, could call her husband.
28223: 
28224: At six o’clock, Raffles, having had only fitful perturbed snatches of
28225: sleep, from which he waked with fresh restlessness and perpetual cries
28226: that he was sinking away, Bulstrode began to administer the opium
28227: according to Lydgate’s directions. At the end of half an hour or more
28228: he called Mrs. Abel and told her that he found himself unfit for
28229: further watching. He must now consign the patient to her care; and he
28230: proceeded to repeat to her Lydgate’s directions as to the quantity of
28231: each dose. Mrs. Abel had not before known anything of Lydgate’s
28232: prescriptions; she had simply prepared and brought whatever Bulstrode
28233: ordered, and had done what he pointed out to her. She began now to ask
28234: what else she should do besides administering the opium.
28235: 
28236: “Nothing at present, except the offer of the soup or the soda-water:
28237: you can come to me for further directions. Unless there is any
28238: important change, I shall not come into the room again to-night. You
28239: will ask your husband for help if necessary. I must go to bed early.”
28240: 
28241: “You’ve much need, sir, I’m sure,” said Mrs. Abel, “and to take
28242: something more strengthening than what you’ve done.”
28243: 
28244: Bulstrode went away now without anxiety as to what Raffles might say in
28245: his raving, which had taken on a muttering incoherence not likely to
28246: create any dangerous belief. At any rate he must risk this. He went
28247: down into the wainscoted parlor first, and began to consider whether he
28248: would not have his horse saddled and go home by the moonlight, and give
28249: up caring for earthly consequences. Then, he wished that he had begged
28250: Lydgate to come again that evening. Perhaps he might deliver a
28251: different opinion, and think that Raffles was getting into a less
28252: hopeful state. Should he send for Lydgate? If Raffles were really
28253: getting worse, and slowly dying, Bulstrode felt that he could go to bed
28254: and sleep in gratitude to Providence. But was he worse? Lydgate might
28255: come and simply say that he was going on as he expected, and predict
28256: that he would by-and-by fall into a good sleep, and get well. What was
28257: the use of sending for him? Bulstrode shrank from that result. No ideas
28258: or opinions could hinder him from seeing the one probability to be,
28259: that Raffles recovered would be just the same man as before, with his
28260: strength as a tormentor renewed, obliging him to drag away his wife to
28261: spend her years apart from her friends and native place, carrying an
28262: alienating suspicion against him in her heart.
28263: 
28264: He had sat an hour and a half in this conflict by the firelight only,
28265: when a sudden thought made him rise and light the bed-candle, which he
28266: had brought down with him. The thought was, that he had not told Mrs.
28267: Abel when the doses of opium must cease.
28268: 
28269: He took hold of the candlestick, but stood motionless for a long while.
28270: She might already have given him more than Lydgate had prescribed. But
28271: it was excusable in him, that he should forget part of an order, in his
28272: present wearied condition. He walked up-stairs, candle in hand, not
28273: knowing whether he should straightway enter his own room and go to bed,
28274: or turn to the patient’s room and rectify his omission. He paused in
28275: the passage, with his face turned towards Raffles’s room, and he could
28276: hear him moaning and murmuring. He was not asleep, then. Who could know
28277: that Lydgate’s prescription would not be better disobeyed than
28278: followed, since there was still no sleep?
28279: 
28280: He turned into his own room. Before he had quite undressed, Mrs. Abel
28281: rapped at the door; he opened it an inch, so that he could hear her
28282: speak low.
28283: 
28284: “If you please, sir, should I have no brandy nor nothing to give the
28285: poor creetur? He feels sinking away, and nothing else will he
28286: swaller—and but little strength in it, if he did—only the opium. And he
28287: says more and more he’s sinking down through the earth.”
28288: 
28289: To her surprise, Mr. Bulstrode did not answer. A struggle was going on
28290: within him.
28291: 
28292: “I think he must die for want o’ support, if he goes on in that way.
28293: When I nursed my poor master, Mr. Robisson, I had to give him port-wine
28294: and brandy constant, and a big glass at a time,” added Mrs. Abel, with
28295: a touch of remonstrance in her tone.
28296: 
28297: But again Mr. Bulstrode did not answer immediately, and she continued,
28298: “It’s not a time to spare when people are at death’s door, nor would
28299: you wish it, sir, I’m sure. Else I should give him our own bottle o’
28300: rum as we keep by us. But a sitter-up so as you’ve been, and doing
28301: everything as laid in your power—”
28302: 
28303: Here a key was thrust through the inch of doorway, and Mr. Bulstrode
28304: said huskily, “That is the key of the wine-cooler. You will find plenty
28305: of brandy there.”
28306: 
28307: Early in the morning—about six—Mr. Bulstrode rose and spent some time
28308: in prayer. Does any one suppose that private prayer is necessarily
28309: candid—necessarily goes to the roots of action? Private prayer is
28310: inaudible speech, and speech is representative: who can represent
28311: himself just as he is, even in his own reflections? Bulstrode had not
28312: yet unravelled in his thought the confused promptings of the last
28313: four-and-twenty hours.
28314: 
28315: He listened in the passage, and could hear hard stertorous breathing.
28316: Then he walked out in the garden, and looked at the early rime on the
28317: grass and fresh spring leaves. When he re-entered the house, he felt
28318: startled at the sight of Mrs. Abel.
28319: 
28320: “How is your patient—asleep, I think?” he said, with an attempt at
28321: cheerfulness in his tone.
28322: 
28323: “He’s gone very deep, sir,” said Mrs. Abel. “He went off gradual
28324: between three and four o’clock. Would you please to go and look at him?
28325: I thought it no harm to leave him. My man’s gone afield, and the little
28326: girl’s seeing to the kettles.”
28327: 
28328: Bulstrode went up. At a glance he knew that Raffles was not in the
28329: sleep which brings revival, but in the sleep which streams deeper and
28330: deeper into the gulf of death.
28331: 
28332: He looked round the room and saw a bottle with some brandy in it, and
28333: the almost empty opium phial. He put the phial out of sight, and
28334: carried the brandy-bottle down-stairs with him, locking it again in the
28335: wine-cooler.
28336: 
28337: While breakfasting he considered whether he should ride to Middlemarch
28338: at once, or wait for Lydgate’s arrival. He decided to wait, and told
28339: Mrs. Abel that she might go about her work—he could watch in the
28340: bed-chamber.
28341: 
28342: As he sat there and beheld the enemy of his peace going irrevocably
28343: into silence, he felt more at rest than he had done for many months.
28344: His conscience was soothed by the enfolding wing of secrecy, which
28345: seemed just then like an angel sent down for his relief. He drew out
28346: his pocket-book to review various memoranda there as to the
28347: arrangements he had projected and partly carried out in the prospect of
28348: quitting Middlemarch, and considered how far he would let them stand or
28349: recall them, now that his absence would be brief. Some economies which
28350: he felt desirable might still find a suitable occasion in his temporary
28351: withdrawal from management, and he hoped still that Mrs. Casaubon would
28352: take a large share in the expenses of the Hospital. In that way the
28353: moments passed, until a change in the stertorous breathing was marked
28354: enough to draw his attention wholly to the bed, and forced him to think
28355: of the departing life, which had once been subservient to his own—which
28356: he had once been glad to find base enough for him to act on as he
28357: would. It was his gladness then which impelled him now to be glad that
28358: the life was at an end.
28359: 
28360: And who could say that the death of Raffles had been hastened? Who knew
28361: what would have saved him?
28362: 
28363: Lydgate arrived at half-past ten, in time to witness the final pause of
28364: the breath. When he entered the room Bulstrode observed a sudden
28365: expression in his face, which was not so much surprise as a recognition
28366: that he had not judged correctly. He stood by the bed in silence for
28367: some time, with his eyes turned on the dying man, but with that subdued
28368: activity of expression which showed that he was carrying on an inward
28369: debate.
28370: 
28371: “When did this change begin?” said he, looking at Bulstrode.
28372: 
28373: “I did not watch by him last night,” said Bulstrode. “I was over-worn,
28374: and left him under Mrs. Abel’s care. She said that he sank into sleep
28375: between three and four o’clock. When I came in before eight he was
28376: nearly in this condition.”
28377: 
28378: Lydgate did not ask another question, but watched in silence until he
28379: said, “It’s all over.”
28380: 
28381: This morning Lydgate was in a state of recovered hope and freedom. He
28382: had set out on his work with all his old animation, and felt himself
28383: strong enough to bear all the deficiencies of his married life. And he
28384: was conscious that Bulstrode had been a benefactor to him. But he was
28385: uneasy about this case. He had not expected it to terminate as it had
28386: done. Yet he hardly knew how to put a question on the subject to
28387: Bulstrode without appearing to insult him; and if he examined the
28388: housekeeper—why, the man was dead. There seemed to be no use in
28389: implying that somebody’s ignorance or imprudence had killed him. And
28390: after all, he himself might be wrong.
28391: 
28392: He and Bulstrode rode back to Middlemarch together, talking of many
28393: things—chiefly cholera and the chances of the Reform Bill in the House
28394: of Lords, and the firm resolve of the political Unions. Nothing was
28395: said about Raffles, except that Bulstrode mentioned the necessity of
28396: having a grave for him in Lowick churchyard, and observed that, so far
28397: as he knew, the poor man had no connections, except Rigg, whom he had
28398: stated to be unfriendly towards him.
28399: 
28400: On returning home Lydgate had a visit from Mr. Farebrother. The Vicar
28401: had not been in the town the day before, but the news that there was an
28402: execution in Lydgate’s house had got to Lowick by the evening, having
28403: been carried by Mr. Spicer, shoemaker and parish-clerk, who had it from
28404: his brother, the respectable bell-hanger in Lowick Gate. Since that
28405: evening when Lydgate had come down from the billiard room with Fred
28406: Vincy, Mr. Farebrother’s thoughts about him had been rather gloomy.
28407: Playing at the Green Dragon once or oftener might have been a trifle in
28408: another man; but in Lydgate it was one of several signs that he was
28409: getting unlike his former self. He was beginning to do things for which
28410: he had formerly even an excessive scorn. Whatever certain
28411: dissatisfactions in marriage, which some silly tinklings of gossip had
28412: given him hints of, might have to do with this change, Mr. Farebrother
28413: felt sure that it was chiefly connected with the debts which were being
28414: more and more distinctly reported, and he began to fear that any notion
28415: of Lydgate’s having resources or friends in the background must be
28416: quite illusory. The rebuff he had met with in his first attempt to win
28417: Lydgate’s confidence, disinclined him to a second; but this news of the
28418: execution being actually in the house, determined the Vicar to overcome
28419: his reluctance.
28420: 
28421: Lydgate had just dismissed a poor patient, in whom he was much
28422: interested, and he came forward to put out his hand—with an open
28423: cheerfulness which surprised Mr. Farebrother. Could this too be a proud
28424: rejection of sympathy and help? Never mind; the sympathy and help
28425: should be offered.
28426: 
28427: “How are you, Lydgate? I came to see you because I had heard something
28428: which made me anxious about you,” said the Vicar, in the tone of a good
28429: brother, only that there was no reproach in it. They were both seated
28430: by this time, and Lydgate answered immediately—
28431: 
28432: “I think I know what you mean. You had heard that there was an
28433: execution in the house?”
28434: 
28435: “Yes; is it true?”
28436: 
28437: “It was true,” said Lydgate, with an air of freedom, as if he did not
28438: mind talking about the affair now. “But the danger is over; the debt is
28439: paid. I am out of my difficulties now: I shall be freed from debts, and
28440: able, I hope, to start afresh on a better plan.”
28441: 
28442: “I am very thankful to hear it,” said the Vicar, falling back in his
28443: chair, and speaking with that low-toned quickness which often follows
28444: the removal of a load. “I like that better than all the news in the
28445: ‘Times.’ I confess I came to you with a heavy heart.”
28446: 
28447: “Thank you for coming,” said Lydgate, cordially. “I can enjoy the
28448: kindness all the more because I am happier. I have certainly been a
28449: good deal crushed. I’m afraid I shall find the bruises still painful
28450: by-and by,” he added, smiling rather sadly; “but just now I can only
28451: feel that the torture-screw is off.”
28452: 
28453: Mr. Farebrother was silent for a moment, and then said earnestly, “My
28454: dear fellow, let me ask you one question. Forgive me if I take a
28455: liberty.”
28456: 
28457: “I don’t believe you will ask anything that ought to offend me.”
28458: 
28459: “Then—this is necessary to set my heart quite at rest—you have not—have
28460: you?—in order to pay your debts, incurred another debt which may harass
28461: you worse hereafter?”
28462: 
28463: “No,” said Lydgate, coloring slightly. “There is no reason why I should
28464: not tell you—since the fact is so—that the person to whom I am indebted
28465: is Bulstrode. He has made me a very handsome advance—a thousand
28466: pounds—and he can afford to wait for repayment.”
28467: 
28468: “Well, that is generous,” said Mr. Farebrother, compelling himself to
28469: approve of the man whom he disliked. His delicate feeling shrank from
28470: dwelling even in his thought on the fact that he had always urged
28471: Lydgate to avoid any personal entanglement with Bulstrode. He added
28472: immediately, “And Bulstrode must naturally feel an interest in your
28473: welfare, after you have worked with him in a way which has probably
28474: reduced your income instead of adding to it. I am glad to think that he
28475: has acted accordingly.”
28476: 
28477: Lydgate felt uncomfortable under these kindly suppositions. They made
28478: more distinct within him the uneasy consciousness which had shown its
28479: first dim stirrings only a few hours before, that Bulstrode’s motives
28480: for his sudden beneficence following close upon the chillest
28481: indifference might be merely selfish. He let the kindly suppositions
28482: pass. He could not tell the history of the loan, but it was more
28483: vividly present with him than ever, as well as the fact which the Vicar
28484: delicately ignored—that this relation of personal indebtedness to
28485: Bulstrode was what he had once been most resolved to avoid.
28486: 
28487: He began, instead of answering, to speak of his projected economies,
28488: and of his having come to look at his life from a different point of
28489: view.
28490: 
28491: “I shall set up a surgery,” he said. “I really think I made a mistaken
28492: effort in that respect. And if Rosamond will not mind, I shall take an
28493: apprentice. I don’t like these things, but if one carries them out
28494: faithfully they are not really lowering. I have had a severe galling to
28495: begin with: that will make the small rubs seem easy.”
28496: 
28497: Poor Lydgate! the “if Rosamond will not mind,” which had fallen from
28498: him involuntarily as part of his thought, was a significant mark of the
28499: yoke he bore. But Mr. Farebrother, whose hopes entered strongly into
28500: the same current with Lydgate’s, and who knew nothing about him that
28501: could now raise a melancholy presentiment, left him with affectionate
28502: congratulation.
28503: 
28504: 
28505: 
28506: 
28507: CHAPTER LXXI.
28508: 
28509: _Clown_. . . . ’Twas in the Bunch of Grapes, where, indeed,
28510: you have a delight to sit, have you not?
28511: _Froth_. I have so: because it is an open room, and good for winter.
28512: _Clo_. Why, very well then: I hope here be truths.
28513: —_Measure for Measure_.
28514: 
28515: 
28516: Five days after the death of Raffles, Mr. Bambridge was standing at his
28517: leisure under the large archway leading into the yard of the Green
28518: Dragon. He was not fond of solitary contemplation, but he had only just
28519: come out of the house, and any human figure standing at ease under the
28520: archway in the early afternoon was as certain to attract companionship
28521: as a pigeon which has found something worth pecking at. In this case
28522: there was no material object to feed upon, but the eye of reason saw a
28523: probability of mental sustenance in the shape of gossip. Mr. Hopkins,
28524: the meek-mannered draper opposite, was the first to act on this inward
28525: vision, being the more ambitious of a little masculine talk because his
28526: customers were chiefly women. Mr. Bambridge was rather curt to the
28527: draper, feeling that Hopkins was of course glad to talk to _him_, but
28528: that he was not going to waste much of his talk on Hopkins. Soon,
28529: however, there was a small cluster of more important listeners, who
28530: were either deposited from the passers-by, or had sauntered to the spot
28531: expressly to see if there were anything going on at the Green Dragon;
28532: and Mr. Bambridge was finding it worth his while to say many impressive
28533: things about the fine studs he had been seeing and the purchases he had
28534: made on a journey in the north from which he had just returned.
28535: Gentlemen present were assured that when they could show him anything
28536: to cut out a blood mare, a bay, rising four, which was to be seen at
28537: Doncaster if they chose to go and look at it, Mr. Bambridge would
28538: gratify them by being shot “from here to Hereford.” Also, a pair of
28539: blacks which he was going to put into the break recalled vividly to his
28540: mind a pair which he had sold to Faulkner in ’19, for a hundred
28541: guineas, and which Faulkner had sold for a hundred and sixty two months
28542: later—any gent who could disprove this statement being offered the
28543: privilege of calling Mr. Bambridge by a very ugly name until the
28544: exercise made his throat dry.
28545: 
28546: When the discourse was at this point of animation, came up Mr. Frank
28547: Hawley. He was not a man to compromise his dignity by lounging at the
28548: Green Dragon, but happening to pass along the High Street and seeing
28549: Bambridge on the other side, he took some of his long strides across to
28550: ask the horsedealer whether he had found the first-rate gig-horse which
28551: he had engaged to look for. Mr. Hawley was requested to wait until he
28552: had seen a gray selected at Bilkley: if that did not meet his wishes to
28553: a hair, Bambridge did not know a horse when he saw it, which seemed to
28554: be the highest conceivable unlikelihood. Mr. Hawley, standing with his
28555: back to the street, was fixing a time for looking at the gray and
28556: seeing it tried, when a horseman passed slowly by.
28557: 
28558: “Bulstrode!” said two or three voices at once in a low tone, one of
28559: them, which was the draper’s, respectfully prefixing the “Mr.;” but
28560: nobody having more intention in this interjectural naming than if they
28561: had said “the Riverston coach” when that vehicle appeared in the
28562: distance. Mr. Hawley gave a careless glance round at Bulstrode’s back,
28563: but as Bambridge’s eyes followed it he made a sarcastic grimace.
28564: 
28565: “By jingo! that reminds me,” he began, lowering his voice a little, “I
28566: picked up something else at Bilkley besides your gig-horse, Mr. Hawley.
28567: I picked up a fine story about Bulstrode. Do you know how he came by
28568: his fortune? Any gentleman wanting a bit of curious information, I can
28569: give it him free of expense. If everybody got their deserts, Bulstrode
28570: might have had to say his prayers at Botany Bay.”
28571: 
28572: “What do you mean?” said Mr. Hawley, thrusting his hands into his
28573: pockets, and pushing a little forward under the archway. If Bulstrode
28574: should turn out to be a rascal, Frank Hawley had a prophetic soul.
28575: 
28576: “I had it from a party who was an old chum of Bulstrode’s. I’ll tell
28577: you where I first picked him up,” said Bambridge, with a sudden gesture
28578: of his fore-finger. “He was at Larcher’s sale, but I knew nothing of
28579: him then—he slipped through my fingers—was after Bulstrode, no doubt.
28580: He tells me he can tap Bulstrode to any amount, knows all his secrets.
28581: However, he blabbed to me at Bilkley: he takes a stiff glass. Damme if
28582: I think he meant to turn king’s evidence; but he’s that sort of
28583: bragging fellow, the bragging runs over hedge and ditch with him, till
28584: he’d brag of a spavin as if it ’ud fetch money. A man should know when
28585: to pull up.” Mr. Bambridge made this remark with an air of disgust,
28586: satisfied that his own bragging showed a fine sense of the marketable.
28587: 
28588: “What’s the man’s name? Where can he be found?” said Mr. Hawley.
28589: 
28590: “As to where he is to be found, I left him to it at the Saracen’s Head;
28591: but his name is Raffles.”
28592: 
28593: “Raffles!” exclaimed Mr. Hopkins. “I furnished his funeral yesterday.
28594: He was buried at Lowick. Mr. Bulstrode followed him. A very decent
28595: funeral.” There was a strong sensation among the listeners. Mr.
28596: Bambridge gave an ejaculation in which “brimstone” was the mildest
28597: word, and Mr. Hawley, knitting his brows and bending his head forward,
28598: exclaimed, “What?—where did the man die?”
28599: 
28600: “At Stone Court,” said the draper. “The housekeeper said he was a
28601: relation of the master’s. He came there ill on Friday.”
28602: 
28603: “Why, it was on Wednesday I took a glass with him,” interposed
28604: Bambridge.
28605: 
28606: “Did any doctor attend him?” said Mr. Hawley
28607: 
28608: “Yes. Mr. Lydgate. Mr. Bulstrode sat up with him one night. He died the
28609: third morning.”
28610: 
28611: “Go on, Bambridge,” said Mr. Hawley, insistently. “What did this fellow
28612: say about Bulstrode?”
28613: 
28614: The group had already become larger, the town-clerk’s presence being a
28615: guarantee that something worth listening to was going on there; and Mr.
28616: Bambridge delivered his narrative in the hearing of seven. It was
28617: mainly what we know, including the fact about Will Ladislaw, with some
28618: local color and circumstance added: it was what Bulstrode had dreaded
28619: the betrayal of—and hoped to have buried forever with the corpse of
28620: Raffles—it was that haunting ghost of his earlier life which as he rode
28621: past the archway of the Green Dragon he was trusting that Providence
28622: had delivered him from. Yes, Providence. He had not confessed to
28623: himself yet that he had done anything in the way of contrivance to this
28624: end; he had accepted what seemed to have been offered. It was
28625: impossible to prove that he had done anything which hastened the
28626: departure of that man’s soul.
28627: 
28628: But this gossip about Bulstrode spread through Middlemarch like the
28629: smell of fire. Mr. Frank Hawley followed up his information by sending
28630: a clerk whom he could trust to Stone Court on a pretext of inquiring
28631: about hay, but really to gather all that could be learned about Raffles
28632: and his illness from Mrs. Abel. In this way it came to his knowledge
28633: that Mr. Garth had carried the man to Stone Court in his gig; and Mr.
28634: Hawley in consequence took an opportunity of seeing Caleb, calling at
28635: his office to ask whether he had time to undertake an arbitration if it
28636: were required, and then asking him incidentally about Raffles. Caleb
28637: was betrayed into no word injurious to Bulstrode beyond the fact which
28638: he was forced to admit, that he had given up acting for him within the
28639: last week. Mr Hawley drew his inferences, and feeling convinced that
28640: Raffles had told his story to Garth, and that Garth had given up
28641: Bulstrode’s affairs in consequence, said so a few hours later to Mr.
28642: Toller. The statement was passed on until it had quite lost the stamp
28643: of an inference, and was taken as information coming straight from
28644: Garth, so that even a diligent historian might have concluded Caleb to
28645: be the chief publisher of Bulstrode’s misdemeanors.
28646: 
28647: Mr. Hawley was not slow to perceive that there was no handle for the
28648: law either in the revelations made by Raffles or in the circumstances
28649: of his death. He had himself ridden to Lowick village that he might
28650: look at the register and talk over the whole matter with Mr.
28651: Farebrother, who was not more surprised than the lawyer that an ugly
28652: secret should have come to light about Bulstrode, though he had always
28653: had justice enough in him to hinder his antipathy from turning into
28654: conclusions. But while they were talking another combination was
28655: silently going forward in Mr. Farebrother’s mind, which foreshadowed
28656: what was soon to be loudly spoken of in Middlemarch as a necessary
28657: “putting of two and two together.” With the reasons which kept
28658: Bulstrode in dread of Raffles there flashed the thought that the dread
28659: might have something to do with his munificence towards his medical
28660: man; and though he resisted the suggestion that it had been consciously
28661: accepted in any way as a bribe, he had a foreboding that this
28662: complication of things might be of malignant effect on Lydgate’s
28663: reputation. He perceived that Mr. Hawley knew nothing at present of the
28664: sudden relief from debt, and he himself was careful to glide away from
28665: all approaches towards the subject.
28666: 
28667: “Well,” he said, with a deep breath, wanting to wind up the illimitable
28668: discussion of what might have been, though nothing could be legally
28669: proven, “it is a strange story. So our mercurial Ladislaw has a queer
28670: genealogy! A high-spirited young lady and a musical Polish patriot made
28671: a likely enough stock for him to spring from, but I should never have
28672: suspected a grafting of the Jew pawnbroker. However, there’s no knowing
28673: what a mixture will turn out beforehand. Some sorts of dirt serve to
28674: clarify.”
28675: 
28676: “It’s just what I should have expected,” said Mr. Hawley, mounting his
28677: horse. “Any cursed alien blood, Jew, Corsican, or Gypsy.”
28678: 
28679: “I know he’s one of your black sheep, Hawley. But he is really a
28680: disinterested, unworldly fellow,” said Mr. Farebrother, smiling.
28681: 
28682: “Ay, ay, that is your Whiggish twist,” said Mr. Hawley, who had been in
28683: the habit of saying apologetically that Farebrother was such a damned
28684: pleasant good-hearted fellow you would mistake him for a Tory.
28685: 
28686: Mr. Hawley rode home without thinking of Lydgate’s attendance on
28687: Raffles in any other light than as a piece of evidence on the side of
28688: Bulstrode. But the news that Lydgate had all at once become able not
28689: only to get rid of the execution in his house but to pay all his debts
28690: in Middlemarch was spreading fast, gathering round it conjectures and
28691: comments which gave it new body and impetus, and soon filling the ears
28692: of other persons besides Mr. Hawley, who were not slow to see a
28693: significant relation between this sudden command of money and
28694: Bulstrode’s desire to stifle the scandal of Raffles. That the money
28695: came from Bulstrode would infallibly have been guessed even if there
28696: had been no direct evidence of it; for it had beforehand entered into
28697: the gossip about Lydgate’s affairs, that neither his father-in-law nor
28698: his own family would do anything for him, and direct evidence was
28699: furnished not only by a clerk at the Bank, but by innocent Mrs.
28700: Bulstrode herself, who mentioned the loan to Mrs. Plymdale, who
28701: mentioned it to her daughter-in-law of the house of Toller, who
28702: mentioned it generally. The business was felt to be so public and
28703: important that it required dinners to feed it, and many invitations
28704: were just then issued and accepted on the strength of this scandal
28705: concerning Bulstrode and Lydgate; wives, widows, and single ladies took
28706: their work and went out to tea oftener than usual; and all public
28707: conviviality, from the Green Dragon to Dollop’s, gathered a zest which
28708: could not be won from the question whether the Lords would throw out
28709: the Reform Bill.
28710: 
28711: For hardly anybody doubted that some scandalous reason or other was at
28712: the bottom of Bulstrode’s liberality to Lydgate. Mr. Hawley indeed, in
28713: the first instance, invited a select party, including the two
28714: physicians, with Mr Toller and Mr. Wrench, expressly to hold a close
28715: discussion as to the probabilities of Raffles’s illness, reciting to
28716: them all the particulars which had been gathered from Mrs. Abel in
28717: connection with Lydgate’s certificate, that the death was due to
28718: delirium tremens; and the medical gentlemen, who all stood
28719: undisturbedly on the old paths in relation to this disease, declared
28720: that they could see nothing in these particulars which could be
28721: transformed into a positive ground of suspicion. But the moral grounds
28722: of suspicion remained: the strong motives Bulstrode clearly had for
28723: wishing to be rid of Raffles, and the fact that at this critical moment
28724: he had given Lydgate the help which he must for some time have known
28725: the need for; the disposition, moreover, to believe that Bulstrode
28726: would be unscrupulous, and the absence of any indisposition to believe
28727: that Lydgate might be as easily bribed as other haughty-minded men when
28728: they have found themselves in want of money. Even if the money had been
28729: given merely to make him hold his tongue about the scandal of
28730: Bulstrode’s earlier life, the fact threw an odious light on Lydgate,
28731: who had long been sneered at as making himself subservient to the
28732: banker for the sake of working himself into predominance, and
28733: discrediting the elder members of his profession. Hence, in spite of
28734: the negative as to any direct sign of guilt in relation to the death at
28735: Stone Court, Mr. Hawley’s select party broke up with the sense that the
28736: affair had “an ugly look.”
28737: 
28738: But this vague conviction of indeterminable guilt, which was enough to
28739: keep up much head-shaking and biting innuendo even among substantial
28740: professional seniors, had for the general mind all the superior power
28741: of mystery over fact. Everybody liked better to conjecture how the
28742: thing was, than simply to know it; for conjecture soon became more
28743: confident than knowledge, and had a more liberal allowance for the
28744: incompatible. Even the more definite scandal concerning Bulstrode’s
28745: earlier life was, for some minds, melted into the mass of mystery, as
28746: so much lively metal to be poured out in dialogue, and to take such
28747: fantastic shapes as heaven pleased.
28748: 
28749: This was the tone of thought chiefly sanctioned by Mrs. Dollop, the
28750: spirited landlady of the Tankard in Slaughter Lane, who had often to
28751: resist the shallow pragmatism of customers disposed to think that their
28752: reports from the outer world were of equal force with what had “come
28753: up” in her mind. How it had been brought to her she didn’t know, but it
28754: was there before her as if it had been “scored with the chalk on the
28755: chimney-board—” as Bulstrode should say, “his inside was _that black_
28756: as if the hairs of his head knowed the thoughts of his heart, he’d tear
28757: ’em up by the roots.”
28758: 
28759: “That’s odd,” said Mr. Limp, a meditative shoemaker, with weak eyes and
28760: a piping voice. “Why, I read in the ‘Trumpet’ that was what the Duke of
28761: Wellington said when he turned his coat and went over to the Romans.”
28762: 
28763: “Very like,” said Mrs. Dollop. “If one raskill said it, it’s more
28764: reason why another should. But hypo_crite_ as he’s been, and holding
28765: things with that high hand, as there was no parson i’ the country good
28766: enough for him, he was forced to take Old Harry into his counsel, and
28767: Old Harry’s been too many for him.”
28768: 
28769: “Ay, ay, he’s a ’complice you can’t send out o’ the country,” said Mr.
28770: Crabbe, the glazier, who gathered much news and groped among it dimly.
28771: “But by what I can make out, there’s them says Bulstrode was for
28772: running away, for fear o’ being found out, before now.”
28773: 
28774: “He’ll be drove away, whether or no,” said Mr. Dill, the barber, who
28775: had just dropped in. “I shaved Fletcher, Hawley’s clerk, this
28776: morning—he’s got a bad finger—and he says they’re all of one mind to
28777: get rid of Bulstrode. Mr. Thesiger is turned against him, and wants him
28778: out o’ the parish. And there’s gentlemen in this town says they’d as
28779: soon dine with a fellow from the hulks. ‘And a deal sooner I would,’
28780: says Fletcher; ‘for what’s more against one’s stomach than a man coming
28781: and making himself bad company with his religion, and giving out as the
28782: Ten Commandments are not enough for him, and all the while he’s worse
28783: than half the men at the tread-mill?’ Fletcher said so himself.”
28784: 
28785: “It’ll be a bad thing for the town though, if Bulstrode’s money goes
28786: out of it,” said Mr. Limp, quaveringly.
28787: 
28788: “Ah, there’s better folks spend their money worse,” said a firm-voiced
28789: dyer, whose crimson hands looked out of keeping with his good-natured
28790: face.
28791: 
28792: “But he won’t keep his money, by what I can make out,” said the
28793: glazier. “Don’t they say as there’s somebody can strip it off him? By
28794: what I can understan’, they could take every penny off him, if they
28795: went to lawing.”
28796: 
28797: “No such thing!” said the barber, who felt himself a little above his
28798: company at Dollop’s, but liked it none the worse. “Fletcher says it’s
28799: no such thing. He says they might prove over and over again whose child
28800: this young Ladislaw was, and they’d do no more than if they proved I
28801: came out of the Fens—he couldn’t touch a penny.”
28802: 
28803: “Look you there now!” said Mrs. Dollop, indignantly. “I thank the Lord
28804: he took my children to Himself, if that’s all the law can do for the
28805: motherless. Then by that, it’s o’ no use who your father and mother is.
28806: But as to listening to what one lawyer says without asking another—I
28807: wonder at a man o’ your cleverness, Mr. Dill. It’s well known there’s
28808: always two sides, if no more; else who’d go to law, I should like to
28809: know? It’s a poor tale, with all the law as there is up and down, if
28810: it’s no use proving whose child you are. Fletcher may say that if he
28811: likes, but I say, don’t Fletcher _me_!”
28812: 
28813: Mr. Dill affected to laugh in a complimentary way at Mrs. Dollop, as a
28814: woman who was more than a match for the lawyers; being disposed to
28815: submit to much twitting from a landlady who had a long score against
28816: him.
28817: 
28818: “If they come to lawing, and it’s all true as folks say, there’s more
28819: to be looked to nor money,” said the glazier. “There’s this poor
28820: creetur as is dead and gone; by what I can make out, he’d seen the day
28821: when he was a deal finer gentleman nor Bulstrode.”
28822: 
28823: “Finer gentleman! I’ll warrant him,” said Mrs. Dollop; “and a far
28824: personabler man, by what I can hear. As I said when Mr. Baldwin, the
28825: tax-gatherer, comes in, a-standing where you sit, and says, ‘Bulstrode
28826: got all his money as he brought into this town by thieving and
28827: swindling,’—I said, ‘You don’t make me no wiser, Mr. Baldwin: it’s set
28828: my blood a-creeping to look at him ever sin’ here he came into
28829: Slaughter Lane a-wanting to buy the house over my head: folks don’t
28830: look the color o’ the dough-tub and stare at you as if they wanted to
28831: see into your backbone for nothingk.’ That was what I said, and Mr.
28832: Baldwin can bear me witness.”
28833: 
28834: “And in the rights of it too,” said Mr. Crabbe. “For by what I can make
28835: out, this Raffles, as they call him, was a lusty, fresh-colored man as
28836: you’d wish to see, and the best o’ company—though dead he lies in
28837: Lowick churchyard sure enough; and by what I can understan’, there’s
28838: them knows more than they _should_ know about how he got there.”
28839: 
28840: “I’ll believe you!” said Mrs. Dollop, with a touch of scorn at Mr.
28841: Crabbe’s apparent dimness. “When a man’s been ’ticed to a lone house,
28842: and there’s them can pay for hospitals and nurses for half the
28843: country-side choose to be sitters-up night and day, and nobody to come
28844: near but a doctor as is known to stick at nothingk, and as poor as he
28845: can hang together, and after that so flush o’ money as he can pay off
28846: Mr. Byles the butcher as his bill has been running on for the best o’
28847: joints since last Michaelmas was a twelvemonth—I don’t want anybody to
28848: come and tell me as there’s been more going on nor the Prayer-book’s
28849: got a service for—I don’t want to stand winking and blinking and
28850: thinking.”
28851: 
28852: Mrs. Dollop looked round with the air of a landlady accustomed to
28853: dominate her company. There was a chorus of adhesion from the more
28854: courageous; but Mr. Limp, after taking a draught, placed his flat hands
28855: together and pressed them hard between his knees, looking down at them
28856: with blear-eyed contemplation, as if the scorching power of Mrs.
28857: Dollop’s speech had quite dried up and nullified his wits until they
28858: could be brought round again by further moisture.
28859: 
28860: “Why shouldn’t they dig the man up and have the Crowner?” said the
28861: dyer. “It’s been done many and many’s the time. If there’s been foul
28862: play they might find it out.”
28863: 
28864: “Not they, Mr. Jonas!” said Mrs Dollop, emphatically. “I know what
28865: doctors are. They’re a deal too cunning to be found out. And this
28866: Doctor Lydgate that’s been for cutting up everybody before the breath
28867: was well out o’ their body—it’s plain enough what use he wanted to make
28868: o’ looking into respectable people’s insides. He knows drugs, you may
28869: be sure, as you can neither smell nor see, neither before they’re
28870: swallowed nor after. Why, I’ve seen drops myself ordered by Doctor
28871: Gambit, as is our club doctor and a good charikter, and has brought
28872: more live children into the world nor ever another i’ Middlemarch—I say
28873: I’ve seen drops myself as made no difference whether they was in the
28874: glass or out, and yet have griped you the next day. So I’ll leave your
28875: own sense to judge. Don’t tell me! All I say is, it’s a mercy they
28876: didn’t take this Doctor Lydgate on to our club. There’s many a mother’s
28877: child might ha’ rued it.”
28878: 
28879: The heads of this discussion at “Dollop’s” had been the common theme
28880: among all classes in the town, had been carried to Lowick Parsonage on
28881: one side and to Tipton Grange on the other, had come fully to the ears
28882: of the Vincy family, and had been discussed with sad reference to “poor
28883: Harriet” by all Mrs. Bulstrode’s friends, before Lydgate knew
28884: distinctly why people were looking strangely at him, and before
28885: Bulstrode himself suspected the betrayal of his secrets. He had not
28886: been accustomed to very cordial relations with his neighbors, and hence
28887: he could not miss the signs of cordiality; moreover, he had been taking
28888: journeys on business of various kinds, having now made up his mind that
28889: he need not quit Middlemarch, and feeling able consequently to
28890: determine on matters which he had before left in suspense.
28891: 
28892: “We will make a journey to Cheltenham in the course of a month or two,”
28893: he had said to his wife. “There are great spiritual advantages to be
28894: had in that town along with the air and the waters, and six weeks there
28895: will be eminently refreshing to us.”
28896: 
28897: He really believed in the spiritual advantages, and meant that his life
28898: henceforth should be the more devoted because of those later sins which
28899: he represented to himself as hypothetic, praying hypothetically for
28900: their pardon:—“if I have herein transgressed.”
28901: 
28902: As to the Hospital, he avoided saying anything further to Lydgate,
28903: fearing to manifest a too sudden change of plans immediately on the
28904: death of Raffles. In his secret soul he believed that Lydgate suspected
28905: his orders to have been intentionally disobeyed, and suspecting this he
28906: must also suspect a motive. But nothing had been betrayed to him as to
28907: the history of Raffles, and Bulstrode was anxious not to do anything
28908: which would give emphasis to his undefined suspicions. As to any
28909: certainty that a particular method of treatment would either save or
28910: kill, Lydgate himself was constantly arguing against such dogmatism; he
28911: had no right to speak, and he had every motive for being silent. Hence
28912: Bulstrode felt himself providentially secured. The only incident he had
28913: strongly winced under had been an occasional encounter with Caleb
28914: Garth, who, however, had raised his hat with mild gravity.
28915: 
28916: Meanwhile, on the part of the principal townsmen a strong determination
28917: was growing against him.
28918: 
28919: A meeting was to be held in the Town-Hall on a sanitary question which
28920: had risen into pressing importance by the occurrence of a cholera case
28921: in the town. Since the Act of Parliament, which had been hurriedly
28922: passed, authorizing assessments for sanitary measures, there had been a
28923: Board for the superintendence of such measures appointed in
28924: Middlemarch, and much cleansing and preparation had been concurred in
28925: by Whigs and Tories. The question now was, whether a piece of ground
28926: outside the town should be secured as a burial-ground by means of
28927: assessment or by private subscription. The meeting was to be open, and
28928: almost everybody of importance in the town was expected to be there.
28929: 
28930: Mr. Bulstrode was a member of the Board, and just before twelve o’clock
28931: he started from the Bank with the intention of urging the plan of
28932: private subscription. Under the hesitation of his projects, he had for
28933: some time kept himself in the background, and he felt that he should
28934: this morning resume his old position as a man of action and influence
28935: in the public affairs of the town where he expected to end his days.
28936: Among the various persons going in the same direction, he saw Lydgate;
28937: they joined, talked over the object of the meeting, and entered it
28938: together.
28939: 
28940: It seemed that everybody of mark had been earlier than they. But there
28941: were still spaces left near the head of the large central table, and
28942: they made their way thither. Mr. Farebrother sat opposite, not far from
28943: Mr. Hawley; all the medical men were there; Mr. Thesiger was in the
28944: chair, and Mr. Brooke of Tipton was on his right hand.
28945: 
28946: Lydgate noticed a peculiar interchange of glances when he and Bulstrode
28947: took their seats.
28948: 
28949: After the business had been fully opened by the chairman, who pointed
28950: out the advantages of purchasing by subscription a piece of ground
28951: large enough to be ultimately used as a general cemetery, Mr.
28952: Bulstrode, whose rather high-pitched but subdued and fluent voice the
28953: town was used to at meetings of this sort, rose and asked leave to
28954: deliver his opinion. Lydgate could see again the peculiar interchange
28955: of glances before Mr. Hawley started up, and said in his firm resonant
28956: voice, “Mr. Chairman, I request that before any one delivers his
28957: opinion on this point I may be permitted to speak on a question of
28958: public feeling, which not only by myself, but by many gentlemen
28959: present, is regarded as preliminary.”
28960: 
28961: Mr. Hawley’s mode of speech, even when public decorum repressed his
28962: “awful language,” was formidable in its curtness and self-possession.
28963: Mr. Thesiger sanctioned the request, Mr. Bulstrode sat down, and Mr.
28964: Hawley continued.
28965: 
28966: “In what I have to say, Mr. Chairman, I am not speaking simply on my
28967: own behalf: I am speaking with the concurrence and at the express
28968: request of no fewer than eight of my fellow-townsmen, who are
28969: immediately around us. It is our united sentiment that Mr. Bulstrode
28970: should be called upon—and I do now call upon him—to resign public
28971: positions which he holds not simply as a tax-payer, but as a gentleman
28972: among gentlemen. There are practices and there are acts which, owing to
28973: circumstances, the law cannot visit, though they may be worse than many
28974: things which are legally punishable. Honest men and gentlemen, if they
28975: don’t want the company of people who perpetrate such acts, have got to
28976: defend themselves as they best can, and that is what I and the friends
28977: whom I may call my clients in this affair are determined to do. I don’t
28978: say that Mr. Bulstrode has been guilty of shameful acts, but I call
28979: upon him either publicly to deny and confute the scandalous statements
28980: made against him by a man now dead, and who died in his house—the
28981: statement that he was for many years engaged in nefarious practices,
28982: and that he won his fortune by dishonest procedures—or else to withdraw
28983: from positions which could only have been allowed him as a gentleman
28984: among gentlemen.”
28985: 
28986: All eyes in the room were turned on Mr. Bulstrode, who, since the first
28987: mention of his name, had been going through a crisis of feeling almost
28988: too violent for his delicate frame to support. Lydgate, who himself was
28989: undergoing a shock as from the terrible practical interpretation of
28990: some faint augury, felt, nevertheless, that his own movement of
28991: resentful hatred was checked by that instinct of the Healer which
28992: thinks first of bringing rescue or relief to the sufferer, when he
28993: looked at the shrunken misery of Bulstrode’s livid face.
28994: 
28995: The quick vision that his life was after all a failure, that he was a
28996: dishonored man, and must quail before the glance of those towards whom
28997: he had habitually assumed the attitude of a reprover—that God had
28998: disowned him before men and left him unscreened to the triumphant scorn
28999: of those who were glad to have their hatred justified—the sense of
29000: utter futility in that equivocation with his conscience in dealing with
29001: the life of his accomplice, an equivocation which now turned venomously
29002: upon him with the full-grown fang of a discovered lie:—all this rushed
29003: through him like the agony of terror which fails to kill, and leaves
29004: the ears still open to the returning wave of execration. The sudden
29005: sense of exposure after the re-established sense of safety came—not to
29006: the coarse organization of a criminal, but to the susceptible nerve of
29007: a man whose intensest being lay in such mastery and predominance as the
29008: conditions of his life had shaped for him.
29009: 
29010: But in that intense being lay the strength of reaction. Through all his
29011: bodily infirmity there ran a tenacious nerve of ambitious
29012: self-preserving will, which had continually leaped out like a flame,
29013: scattering all doctrinal fears, and which, even while he sat an object
29014: of compassion for the merciful, was beginning to stir and glow under
29015: his ashy paleness. Before the last words were out of Mr. Hawley’s
29016: mouth, Bulstrode felt that he should answer, and that his answer would
29017: be a retort. He dared not get up and say, “I am not guilty, the whole
29018: story is false”—even if he had dared this, it would have seemed to him,
29019: under his present keen sense of betrayal, as vain as to pull, for
29020: covering to his nakedness, a frail rag which would rend at every little
29021: strain.
29022: 
29023: For a few moments there was total silence, while every man in the room
29024: was looking at Bulstrode. He sat perfectly still, leaning hard against
29025: the back of his chair; he could not venture to rise, and when he began
29026: to speak he pressed his hands upon the seat on each side of him. But
29027: his voice was perfectly audible, though hoarser than usual, and his
29028: words were distinctly pronounced, though he paused between sentence as
29029: if short of breath. He said, turning first toward Mr. Thesiger, and
29030: then looking at Mr. Hawley—
29031: 
29032: “I protest before you, sir, as a Christian minister, against the
29033: sanction of proceedings towards me which are dictated by virulent
29034: hatred. Those who are hostile to me are glad to believe any libel
29035: uttered by a loose tongue against me. And their consciences become
29036: strict against me. Say that the evil-speaking of which I am to be made
29037: the victim accuses me of malpractices—” here Bulstrode’s voice rose and
29038: took on a more biting accent, till it seemed a low cry—“who shall be my
29039: accuser? Not men whose own lives are unchristian, nay, scandalous—not
29040: men who themselves use low instruments to carry out their ends—whose
29041: profession is a tissue of chicanery—who have been spending their income
29042: on their own sensual enjoyments, while I have been devoting mine to
29043: advance the best objects with regard to this life and the next.”
29044: 
29045: After the word chicanery there was a growing noise, half of murmurs and
29046: half of hisses, while four persons started up at once—Mr. Hawley, Mr.
29047: Toller, Mr. Chichely, and Mr. Hackbutt; but Mr. Hawley’s outburst was
29048: instantaneous, and left the others behind in silence.
29049: 
29050: “If you mean me, sir, I call you and every one else to the inspection
29051: of my professional life. As to Christian or unchristian, I repudiate
29052: your canting palavering Christianity; and as to the way in which I
29053: spend my income, it is not my principle to maintain thieves and cheat
29054: offspring of their due inheritance in order to support religion and set
29055: myself up as a saintly Killjoy. I affect no niceness of conscience—I
29056: have not found any nice standards necessary yet to measure your actions
29057: by, sir. And I again call upon you to enter into satisfactory
29058: explanations concerning the scandals against you, or else to withdraw
29059: from posts in which we at any rate decline you as a colleague. I say,
29060: sir, we decline to co-operate with a man whose character is not cleared
29061: from infamous lights cast upon it, not only by reports but by recent
29062: actions.”
29063: 
29064: “Allow me, Mr. Hawley,” said the chairman; and Mr. Hawley, still
29065: fuming, bowed half impatiently, and sat down with his hands thrust deep
29066: in his pockets.
29067: 
29068: “Mr. Bulstrode, it is not desirable, I think, to prolong the present
29069: discussion,” said Mr. Thesiger, turning to the pallid trembling man; “I
29070: must so far concur with what has fallen from Mr. Hawley in expression
29071: of a general feeling, as to think it due to your Christian profession
29072: that you should clear yourself, if possible, from unhappy aspersions. I
29073: for my part should be willing to give you full opportunity and hearing.
29074: But I must say that your present attitude is painfully inconsistent
29075: with those principles which you have sought to identify yourself with,
29076: and for the honor of which I am bound to care. I recommend you at
29077: present, as your clergyman, and one who hopes for your reinstatement in
29078: respect, to quit the room, and avoid further hindrance to business.”
29079: 
29080: Bulstrode, after a moment’s hesitation, took his hat from the floor and
29081: slowly rose, but he grasped the corner of the chair so totteringly that
29082: Lydgate felt sure there was not strength enough in him to walk away
29083: without support. What could he do? He could not see a man sink close to
29084: him for want of help. He rose and gave his arm to Bulstrode, and in
29085: that way led him out of the room; yet this act, which might have been
29086: one of gentle duty and pure compassion, was at this moment unspeakably
29087: bitter to him. It seemed as if he were putting his sign-manual to that
29088: association of himself with Bulstrode, of which he now saw the full
29089: meaning as it must have presented itself to other minds. He now felt
29090: the conviction that this man who was leaning tremblingly on his arm,
29091: had given him the thousand pounds as a bribe, and that somehow the
29092: treatment of Raffles had been tampered with from an evil motive. The
29093: inferences were closely linked enough; the town knew of the loan,
29094: believed it to be a bribe, and believed that he took it as a bribe.
29095: 
29096: Poor Lydgate, his mind struggling under the terrible clutch of this
29097: revelation, was all the while morally forced to take Mr. Bulstrode to
29098: the Bank, send a man off for his carriage, and wait to accompany him
29099: home.
29100: 
29101: Meanwhile the business of the meeting was despatched, and fringed off
29102: into eager discussion among various groups concerning this affair of
29103: Bulstrode—and Lydgate.
29104: 
29105: Mr. Brooke, who had before heard only imperfect hints of it, and was
29106: very uneasy that he had “gone a little too far” in countenancing
29107: Bulstrode, now got himself fully informed, and felt some benevolent
29108: sadness in talking to Mr. Farebrother about the ugly light in which
29109: Lydgate had come to be regarded. Mr. Farebrother was going to walk back
29110: to Lowick.
29111: 
29112: “Step into my carriage,” said Mr. Brooke. “I am going round to see Mrs.
29113: Casaubon. She was to come back from Yorkshire last night. She will like
29114: to see me, you know.”
29115: 
29116: So they drove along, Mr. Brooke chatting with good-natured hope that
29117: there had not really been anything black in Lydgate’s behavior—a young
29118: fellow whom he had seen to be quite above the common mark, when he
29119: brought a letter from his uncle Sir Godwin. Mr. Farebrother said
29120: little: he was deeply mournful: with a keen perception of human
29121: weakness, he could not be confident that under the pressure of
29122: humiliating needs Lydgate had not fallen below himself.
29123: 
29124: When the carriage drove up to the gate of the Manor, Dorothea was out
29125: on the gravel, and came to greet them.
29126: 
29127: “Well, my dear,” said Mr. Brooke, “we have just come from a meeting—a
29128: sanitary meeting, you know.”
29129: 
29130: “Was Mr. Lydgate there?” said Dorothea, who looked full of health and
29131: animation, and stood with her head bare under the gleaming April
29132: lights. “I want to see him and have a great consultation with him about
29133: the Hospital. I have engaged with Mr. Bulstrode to do so.”
29134: 
29135: “Oh, my dear,” said Mr. Brooke, “we have been hearing bad news—bad
29136: news, you know.”
29137: 
29138: They walked through the garden towards the churchyard gate, Mr.
29139: Farebrother wanting to go on to the parsonage; and Dorothea heard the
29140: whole sad story.
29141: 
29142: She listened with deep interest, and begged to hear twice over the
29143: facts and impressions concerning Lydgate. After a short silence,
29144: pausing at the churchyard gate, and addressing Mr. Farebrother, she
29145: said energetically—
29146: 
29147: “You don’t believe that Mr. Lydgate is guilty of anything base? I will
29148: not believe it. Let us find out the truth and clear him!”

29154: SUNSET AND SUNRISE.
