29159: CHAPTER LXXII.
29160: 
29161: Full souls are double mirrors, making still
29162: An endless vista of fair things before,
29163: Repeating things behind.
29164: 
29165: 
29166: Dorothea’s impetuous generosity, which would have leaped at once to the
29167: vindication of Lydgate from the suspicion of having accepted money as a
29168: bribe, underwent a melancholy check when she came to consider all the
29169: circumstances of the case by the light of Mr. Farebrother’s experience.
29170: 
29171: “It is a delicate matter to touch,” he said. “How can we begin to
29172: inquire into it? It must be either publicly by setting the magistrate
29173: and coroner to work, or privately by questioning Lydgate. As to the
29174: first proceeding there is no solid ground to go upon, else Hawley would
29175: have adopted it; and as to opening the subject with Lydgate, I confess
29176: I should shrink from it. He would probably take it as a deadly insult.
29177: I have more than once experienced the difficulty of speaking to him on
29178: personal matters. And—one should know the truth about his conduct
29179: beforehand, to feel very confident of a good result.”
29180: 
29181: “I feel convinced that his conduct has not been guilty: I believe that
29182: people are almost always better than their neighbors think they are,”
29183: said Dorothea. Some of her intensest experience in the last two years
29184: had set her mind strongly in opposition to any unfavorable construction
29185: of others; and for the first time she felt rather discontented with Mr.
29186: Farebrother. She disliked this cautious weighing of consequences,
29187: instead of an ardent faith in efforts of justice and mercy, which would
29188: conquer by their emotional force. Two days afterwards, he was dining at
29189: the Manor with her uncle and the Chettams, and when the dessert was
29190: standing uneaten, the servants were out of the room, and Mr. Brooke was
29191: nodding in a nap, she returned to the subject with renewed vivacity.
29192: 
29193: “Mr. Lydgate would understand that if his friends hear a calumny about
29194: him their first wish must be to justify him. What do we live for, if it
29195: is not to make life less difficult to each other? I cannot be
29196: indifferent to the troubles of a man who advised me in _my_ trouble,
29197: and attended me in my illness.”
29198: 
29199: Dorothea’s tone and manner were not more energetic than they had been
29200: when she was at the head of her uncle’s table nearly three years
29201: before, and her experience since had given her more right to express a
29202: decided opinion. But Sir James Chettam was no longer the diffident and
29203: acquiescent suitor: he was the anxious brother-in-law, with a devout
29204: admiration for his sister, but with a constant alarm lest she should
29205: fall under some new illusion almost as bad as marrying Casaubon. He
29206: smiled much less; when he said “Exactly” it was more often an
29207: introduction to a dissentient opinion than in those submissive bachelor
29208: days; and Dorothea found to her surprise that she had to resolve not to
29209: be afraid of him—all the more because he was really her best friend. He
29210: disagreed with her now.
29211: 
29212: “But, Dorothea,” he said, remonstrantly, “you can’t undertake to manage
29213: a man’s life for him in that way. Lydgate must know—at least he will
29214: soon come to know how he stands. If he can clear himself, he will. He
29215: must act for himself.”
29216: 
29217: “I think his friends must wait till they find an opportunity,” added
29218: Mr. Farebrother. “It is possible—I have often felt so much weakness in
29219: myself that I can conceive even a man of honorable disposition, such as
29220: I have always believed Lydgate to be, succumbing to such a temptation
29221: as that of accepting money which was offered more or less indirectly as
29222: a bribe to insure his silence about scandalous facts long gone by. I
29223: say, I can conceive this, if he were under the pressure of hard
29224: circumstances—if he had been harassed as I feel sure Lydgate has been.
29225: I would not believe anything worse of him except under stringent proof.
29226: But there is the terrible Nemesis following on some errors, that it is
29227: always possible for those who like it to interpret them into a crime:
29228: there is no proof in favor of the man outside his own consciousness and
29229: assertion.”
29230: 
29231: “Oh, how cruel!” said Dorothea, clasping her hands. “And would you not
29232: like to be the one person who believed in that man’s innocence, if the
29233: rest of the world belied him? Besides, there is a man’s character
29234: beforehand to speak for him.”
29235: 
29236: “But, my dear Mrs. Casaubon,” said Mr. Farebrother, smiling gently at
29237: her ardor, “character is not cut in marble—it is not something solid
29238: and unalterable. It is something living and changing, and may become
29239: diseased as our bodies do.”
29240: 
29241: “Then it may be rescued and healed,” said Dorothea “I should not be
29242: afraid of asking Mr. Lydgate to tell me the truth, that I might help
29243: him. Why should I be afraid? Now that I am not to have the land, James,
29244: I might do as Mr. Bulstrode proposed, and take his place in providing
29245: for the Hospital; and I have to consult Mr. Lydgate, to know thoroughly
29246: what are the prospects of doing good by keeping up the present plans.
29247: There is the best opportunity in the world for me to ask for his
29248: confidence; and he would be able to tell me things which might make all
29249: the circumstances clear. Then we would all stand by him and bring him
29250: out of his trouble. People glorify all sorts of bravery except the
29251: bravery they might show on behalf of their nearest neighbors.”
29252: Dorothea’s eyes had a moist brightness in them, and the changed tones
29253: of her voice roused her uncle, who began to listen.
29254: 
29255: “It is true that a woman may venture on some efforts of sympathy which
29256: would hardly succeed if we men undertook them,” said Mr. Farebrother,
29257: almost converted by Dorothea’s ardor.
29258: 
29259: “Surely, a woman is bound to be cautious and listen to those who know
29260: the world better than she does.” said Sir James, with his little frown.
29261: “Whatever you do in the end, Dorothea, you should really keep back at
29262: present, and not volunteer any meddling with this Bulstrode business.
29263: We don’t know yet what may turn up. You must agree with me?” he ended,
29264: looking at Mr. Farebrother.
29265: 
29266: “I do think it would be better to wait,” said the latter.
29267: 
29268: “Yes, yes, my dear,” said Mr. Brooke, not quite knowing at what point
29269: the discussion had arrived, but coming up to it with a contribution
29270: which was generally appropriate. “It is easy to go too far, you know.
29271: You must not let your ideas run away with you. And as to being in a
29272: hurry to put money into schemes—it won’t do, you know. Garth has drawn
29273: me in uncommonly with repairs, draining, that sort of thing: I’m
29274: uncommonly out of pocket with one thing or another. I must pull up. As
29275: for you, Chettam, you are spending a fortune on those oak fences round
29276: your demesne.”
29277: 
29278: Dorothea, submitting uneasily to this discouragement, went with Celia
29279: into the library, which was her usual drawing-room.
29280: 
29281: “Now, Dodo, do listen to what James says,” said Celia, “else you will
29282: be getting into a scrape. You always did, and you always will, when you
29283: set about doing as you please. And I think it is a mercy now after all
29284: that you have got James to think for you. He lets you have your plans,
29285: only he hinders you from being taken in. And that is the good of having
29286: a brother instead of a husband. A husband would not let you have your
29287: plans.”
29288: 
29289: “As if I wanted a husband!” said Dorothea. “I only want not to have my
29290: feelings checked at every turn.” Mrs. Casaubon was still undisciplined
29291: enough to burst into angry tears.
29292: 
29293: “Now, really, Dodo,” said Celia, with rather a deeper guttural than
29294: usual, “you _are_ contradictory: first one thing and then another. You
29295: used to submit to Mr. Casaubon quite shamefully: I think you would have
29296: given up ever coming to see me if he had asked you.”
29297: 
29298: “Of course I submitted to him, because it was my duty; it was my
29299: feeling for him,” said Dorothea, looking through the prism of her
29300: tears.
29301: 
29302: “Then why can’t you think it your duty to submit a little to what James
29303: wishes?” said Celia, with a sense of stringency in her argument.
29304: “Because he only wishes what is for your own good. And, of course, men
29305: know best about everything, except what women know better.” Dorothea
29306: laughed and forgot her tears.
29307: 
29308: “Well, I mean about babies and those things,” explained Celia. “I
29309: should not give up to James when I knew he was wrong, as you used to do
29310: to Mr. Casaubon.”
29311: 
29312: 
29313: 
29314: 
29315: CHAPTER LXXIII.
29316: 
29317: Pity the laden one; this wandering woe
29318: May visit you and me.
29319: 
29320: 
29321: When Lydgate had allayed Mrs. Bulstrode’s anxiety by telling her that
29322: her husband had been seized with faintness at the meeting, but that he
29323: trusted soon to see him better and would call again the next day,
29324: unless she sent for him earlier, he went directly home, got on his
29325: horse, and rode three miles out of the town for the sake of being out
29326: of reach.
29327: 
29328: He felt himself becoming violent and unreasonable as if raging under
29329: the pain of stings: he was ready to curse the day on which he had come
29330: to Middlemarch. Everything that bad happened to him there seemed a mere
29331: preparation for this hateful fatality, which had come as a blight on
29332: his honorable ambition, and must make even people who had only vulgar
29333: standards regard his reputation as irrevocably damaged. In such moments
29334: a man can hardly escape being unloving. Lydgate thought of himself as
29335: the sufferer, and of others as the agents who had injured his lot. He
29336: had meant everything to turn out differently; and others had thrust
29337: themselves into his life and thwarted his purposes. His marriage seemed
29338: an unmitigated calamity; and he was afraid of going to Rosamond before
29339: he had vented himself in this solitary rage, lest the mere sight of her
29340: should exasperate him and make him behave unwarrantably. There are
29341: episodes in most men’s lives in which their highest qualities can only
29342: cast a deterring shadow over the objects that fill their inward vision:
29343: Lydgate’s tenderheartedness was present just then only as a dread lest
29344: he should offend against it, not as an emotion that swayed him to
29345: tenderness. For he was very miserable. Only those who know the
29346: supremacy of the intellectual life—the life which has a seed of
29347: ennobling thought and purpose within it—can understand the grief of one
29348: who falls from that serene activity into the absorbing soul-wasting
29349: struggle with worldly annoyances.
29350: 
29351: How was he to live on without vindicating himself among people who
29352: suspected him of baseness? How could he go silently away from
29353: Middlemarch as if he were retreating before a just condemnation? And
29354: yet how was he to set about vindicating himself?
29355: 
29356: For that scene at the meeting, which he had just witnessed, although it
29357: had told him no particulars, had been enough to make his own situation
29358: thoroughly clear to him. Bulstrode had been in dread of scandalous
29359: disclosures on the part of Raffles. Lydgate could now construct all the
29360: probabilities of the case. “He was afraid of some betrayal in my
29361: hearing: all he wanted was to bind me to him by a strong obligation:
29362: that was why he passed on a sudden from hardness to liberality. And he
29363: may have tampered with the patient—he may have disobeyed my orders. I
29364: fear he did. But whether he did or not, the world believes that he
29365: somehow or other poisoned the man and that I winked at the crime, if I
29366: didn’t help in it. And yet—and yet he may not be guilty of the last
29367: offence; and it is just possible that the change towards me may have
29368: been a genuine relenting—the effect of second thoughts such as he
29369: alleged. What we call the ‘just possible’ is sometimes true and the
29370: thing we find it easier to believe is grossly false. In his last
29371: dealings with this man Bulstrode may have kept his hands pure, in spite
29372: of my suspicion to the contrary.”
29373: 
29374: There was a benumbing cruelty in his position. Even if he renounced
29375: every other consideration than that of justifying himself—if he met
29376: shrugs, cold glances, and avoidance as an accusation, and made a public
29377: statement of all the facts as he knew them, who would be convinced? It
29378: would be playing the part of a fool to offer his own testimony on
29379: behalf of himself, and say, “I did not take the money as a bribe.” The
29380: circumstances would always be stronger than his assertion. And besides,
29381: to come forward and tell everything about himself must include
29382: declarations about Bulstrode which would darken the suspicions of
29383: others against him. He must tell that he had not known of Raffles’s
29384: existence when he first mentioned his pressing need of money to
29385: Bulstrode, and that he took the money innocently as a result of that
29386: communication, not knowing that a new motive for the loan might have
29387: arisen on his being called in to this man. And after all, the suspicion
29388: of Bulstrode’s motives might be unjust.
29389: 
29390: But then came the question whether he should have acted in precisely
29391: the same way if he had not taken the money? Certainly, if Raffles had
29392: continued alive and susceptible of further treatment when he arrived,
29393: and he had then imagined any disobedience to his orders on the part of
29394: Bulstrode, he would have made a strict inquiry, and if his conjecture
29395: had been verified he would have thrown up the case, in spite of his
29396: recent heavy obligation. But if he had not received any money—if
29397: Bulstrode had never revoked his cold recommendation of bankruptcy—would
29398: he, Lydgate, have abstained from all inquiry even on finding the man
29399: dead?—would the shrinking from an insult to Bulstrode—would the
29400: dubiousness of all medical treatment and the argument that his own
29401: treatment would pass for the wrong with most members of his
29402: profession—have had just the same force or significance with him?
29403: 
29404: That was the uneasy corner of Lydgate’s consciousness while he was
29405: reviewing the facts and resisting all reproach. If he had been
29406: independent, this matter of a patient’s treatment and the distinct rule
29407: that he must do or see done that which he believed best for the life
29408: committed to him, would have been the point on which he would have been
29409: the sturdiest. As it was, he had rested in the consideration that
29410: disobedience to his orders, however it might have arisen, could not be
29411: considered a crime, that in the dominant opinion obedience to his
29412: orders was just as likely to be fatal, and that the affair was simply
29413: one of etiquette. Whereas, again and again, in his time of freedom, he
29414: had denounced the perversion of pathological doubt into moral doubt and
29415: had said—“the purest experiment in treatment may still be
29416: conscientious: my business is to take care of life, and to do the best
29417: I can think of for it. Science is properly more scrupulous than dogma.
29418: Dogma gives a charter to mistake, but the very breath of science is a
29419: contest with mistake, and must keep the conscience alive.” Alas! the
29420: scientific conscience had got into the debasing company of money
29421: obligation and selfish respects.
29422: 
29423: “Is there a medical man of them all in Middlemarch who would question
29424: himself as I do?” said poor Lydgate, with a renewed outburst of
29425: rebellion against the oppression of his lot. “And yet they will all
29426: feel warranted in making a wide space between me and them, as if I were
29427: a leper! My practice and my reputation are utterly damned—I can see
29428: that. Even if I could be cleared by valid evidence, it would make
29429: little difference to the blessed world here. I have been set down as
29430: tainted and should be cheapened to them all the same.”
29431: 
29432: Already there had been abundant signs which had hitherto puzzled him,
29433: that just when he had been paying off his debts and getting cheerfully
29434: on his feet, the townsmen were avoiding him or looking strangely at
29435: him, and in two instances it came to his knowledge that patients of his
29436: had called in another practitioner. The reasons were too plain now. The
29437: general black-balling had begun.
29438: 
29439: No wonder that in Lydgate’s energetic nature the sense of a hopeless
29440: misconstruction easily turned into a dogged resistance. The scowl which
29441: occasionally showed itself on his square brow was not a meaningless
29442: accident. Already when he was re-entering the town after that ride
29443: taken in the first hours of stinging pain, he was setting his mind on
29444: remaining in Middlemarch in spite of the worst that could be done
29445: against him. He would not retreat before calumny, as if he submitted to
29446: it. He would face it to the utmost, and no act of his should show that
29447: he was afraid. It belonged to the generosity as well as defiant force
29448: of his nature that he resolved not to shrink from showing to the full
29449: his sense of obligation to Bulstrode. It was true that the association
29450: with this man had been fatal to him—true that if he had had the
29451: thousand pounds still in his hands with all his debts unpaid he would
29452: have returned the money to Bulstrode, and taken beggary rather than the
29453: rescue which had been sullied with the suspicion of a bribe (for,
29454: remember, he was one of the proudest among the sons of
29455: men)—nevertheless, he would not turn away from this crushed
29456: fellow-mortal whose aid he had used, and make a pitiful effort to get
29457: acquittal for himself by howling against another. “I shall do as I
29458: think right, and explain to nobody. They will try to starve me out,
29459: but—” he was going on with an obstinate resolve, but he was getting
29460: near home, and the thought of Rosamond urged itself again into that
29461: chief place from which it had been thrust by the agonized struggles of
29462: wounded honor and pride.
29463: 
29464: How would Rosamond take it all? Here was another weight of chain to
29465: drag, and poor Lydgate was in a bad mood for bearing her dumb mastery.
29466: He had no impulse to tell her the trouble which must soon be common to
29467: them both. He preferred waiting for the incidental disclosure which
29468: events must soon bring about.

29473: CHAPTER LXXIV.
29474: 
29475: “Mercifully grant that we may grow aged together.”
29476: —BOOK OF TOBIT: _Marriage Prayer_.
29477: 
29478: 
29479: In Middlemarch a wife could not long remain ignorant that the town held
29480: a bad opinion of her husband. No feminine intimate might carry her
29481: friendship so far as to make a plain statement to the wife of the
29482: unpleasant fact known or believed about her husband; but when a woman
29483: with her thoughts much at leisure got them suddenly employed on
29484: something grievously disadvantageous to her neighbors, various moral
29485: impulses were called into play which tended to stimulate utterance.
29486: Candor was one. To be candid, in Middlemarch phraseology, meant, to use
29487: an early opportunity of letting your friends know that you did not take
29488: a cheerful view of their capacity, their conduct, or their position;
29489: and a robust candor never waited to be asked for its opinion. Then,
29490: again, there was the love of truth—a wide phrase, but meaning in this
29491: relation, a lively objection to seeing a wife look happier than her
29492: husband’s character warranted, or manifest too much satisfaction in her
29493: lot—the poor thing should have some hint given her that if she knew the
29494: truth she would have less complacency in her bonnet, and in light
29495: dishes for a supper-party. Stronger than all, there was the regard for
29496: a friend’s moral improvement, sometimes called her soul, which was
29497: likely to be benefited by remarks tending to gloom, uttered with the
29498: accompaniment of pensive staring at the furniture and a manner implying
29499: that the speaker would not tell what was on her mind, from regard to
29500: the feelings of her hearer. On the whole, one might say that an ardent
29501: charity was at work setting the virtuous mind to make a neighbor
29502: unhappy for her good.
29503: 
29504: There were hardly any wives in Middlemarch whose matrimonial
29505: misfortunes would in different ways be likely to call forth more of
29506: this moral activity than Rosamond and her aunt Bulstrode. Mrs.
29507: Bulstrode was not an object of dislike, and had never consciously
29508: injured any human being. Men had always thought her a handsome
29509: comfortable woman, and had reckoned it among the signs of Bulstrode’s
29510: hypocrisy that he had chosen a red-blooded Vincy, instead of a ghastly
29511: and melancholy person suited to his low esteem for earthly pleasure.
29512: When the scandal about her husband was disclosed they remarked of
29513: her—“Ah, poor woman! She’s as honest as the day—_she_ never suspected
29514: anything wrong in him, you may depend on it.” Women, who were intimate
29515: with her, talked together much of “poor Harriet,” imagined what her
29516: feelings must be when she came to know everything, and conjectured how
29517: much she had already come to know. There was no spiteful disposition
29518: towards her; rather, there was a busy benevolence anxious to ascertain
29519: what it would be well for her to feel and do under the circumstances,
29520: which of course kept the imagination occupied with her character and
29521: history from the times when she was Harriet Vincy till now. With the
29522: review of Mrs. Bulstrode and her position it was inevitable to
29523: associate Rosamond, whose prospects were under the same blight with her
29524: aunt’s. Rosamond was more severely criticised and less pitied, though
29525: she too, as one of the good old Vincy family who had always been known
29526: in Middlemarch, was regarded as a victim to marriage with an
29527: interloper. The Vincys had their weaknesses, but then they lay on the
29528: surface: there was never anything bad to be “found out” concerning
29529: them. Mrs. Bulstrode was vindicated from any resemblance to her
29530: husband. Harriet’s faults were her own.
29531: 
29532: “She has always been showy,” said Mrs. Hackbutt, making tea for a small
29533: party, “though she has got into the way of putting her religion
29534: forward, to conform to her husband; she has tried to hold her head up
29535: above Middlemarch by making it known that she invites clergymen and
29536: heaven-knows-who from Riverston and those places.”
29537: 
29538: “We can hardly blame her for that,” said Mrs. Sprague; “because few of
29539: the best people in the town cared to associate with Bulstrode, and she
29540: must have somebody to sit down at her table.”
29541: 
29542: “Mr. Thesiger has always countenanced him,” said Mrs. Hackbutt. “I
29543: think he must be sorry now.”
29544: 
29545: “But he was never fond of him in his heart—that every one knows,” said
29546: Mrs. Tom Toller. “Mr. Thesiger never goes into extremes. He keeps to
29547: the truth in what is evangelical. It is only clergymen like Mr. Tyke,
29548: who want to use Dissenting hymn-books and that low kind of religion,
29549: who ever found Bulstrode to their taste.”
29550: 
29551: “I understand, Mr. Tyke is in great distress about him,” said Mrs.
29552: Hackbutt. “And well he may be: they say the Bulstrodes have half kept
29553: the Tyke family.”
29554: 
29555: “And of course it is a discredit to his doctrines,” said Mrs. Sprague,
29556: who was elderly, and old-fashioned in her opinions.
29557: 
29558: “People will not make a boast of being methodistical in Middlemarch for
29559: a good while to come.”
29560: 
29561: “I think we must not set down people’s bad actions to their religion,”
29562: said falcon-faced Mrs. Plymdale, who had been listening hitherto.
29563: 
29564: “Oh, my dear, we are forgetting,” said Mrs. Sprague. “We ought not to
29565: be talking of this before you.”
29566: 
29567: “I am sure I have no reason to be partial,” said Mrs. Plymdale,
29568: coloring. “It’s true Mr. Plymdale has always been on good terms with
29569: Mr. Bulstrode, and Harriet Vincy was my friend long before she married
29570: him. But I have always kept my own opinions and told her where she was
29571: wrong, poor thing. Still, in point of religion, I must say, Mr.
29572: Bulstrode might have done what he has, and worse, and yet have been a
29573: man of no religion. I don’t say that there has not been a little too
29574: much of that—I like moderation myself. But truth is truth. The men
29575: tried at the assizes are not all over-religious, I suppose.”
29576: 
29577: “Well,” said Mrs. Hackbutt, wheeling adroitly, “all I can say is, that
29578: I think she ought to separate from him.”
29579: 
29580: “I can’t say that,” said Mrs. Sprague. “She took him for better or
29581: worse, you know.”
29582: 
29583: “But ‘worse’ can never mean finding out that your husband is fit for
29584: Newgate,” said Mrs. Hackbutt. “Fancy living with such a man! I should
29585: expect to be poisoned.”
29586: 
29587: “Yes, I think myself it is an encouragement to crime if such men are to
29588: be taken care of and waited on by good wives,” said Mrs. Tom Toller.
29589: 
29590: “And a good wife poor Harriet has been,” said Mrs. Plymdale. “She
29591: thinks her husband the first of men. It’s true he has never denied her
29592: anything.”
29593: 
29594: “Well, we shall see what she will do,” said Mrs. Hackbutt. “I suppose
29595: she knows nothing yet, poor creature. I do hope and trust I shall not
29596: see her, for I should be frightened to death lest I should say anything
29597: about her husband. Do you think any hint has reached her?”
29598: 
29599: “I should hardly think so,” said Mrs. Tom Toller. “We hear that _he_ is
29600: ill, and has never stirred out of the house since the meeting on
29601: Thursday; but she was with her girls at church yesterday, and they had
29602: new Tuscan bonnets. Her own had a feather in it. I have never seen that
29603: her religion made any difference in her dress.”
29604: 
29605: “She wears very neat patterns always,” said Mrs. Plymdale, a little
29606: stung. “And that feather I know she got dyed a pale lavender on purpose
29607: to be consistent. I must say it of Harriet that she wishes to do
29608: right.”
29609: 
29610: “As to her knowing what has happened, it can’t be kept from her long,”
29611: said Mrs. Hackbutt. “The Vincys know, for Mr. Vincy was at the meeting.
29612: It will be a great blow to him. There is his daughter as well as his
29613: sister.”
29614: 
29615: “Yes, indeed,” said Mrs. Sprague. “Nobody supposes that Mr. Lydgate can
29616: go on holding up his head in Middlemarch, things look so black about
29617: the thousand pounds he took just at that man’s death. It really makes
29618: one shudder.”
29619: 
29620: “Pride must have a fall,” said Mrs. Hackbutt.
29621: 
29622: “I am not so sorry for Rosamond Vincy that was as I am for her aunt,”
29623: said Mrs. Plymdale. “She needed a lesson.”
29624: 
29625: “I suppose the Bulstrodes will go and live abroad somewhere,” said Mrs.
29626: Sprague. “That is what is generally done when there is anything
29627: disgraceful in a family.”
29628: 
29629: “And a most deadly blow it will be to Harriet,” said Mrs. Plymdale. “If
29630: ever a woman was crushed, she will be. I pity her from my heart. And
29631: with all her faults, few women are better. From a girl she had the
29632: neatest ways, and was always good-hearted, and as open as the day. You
29633: might look into her drawers when you would—always the same. And so she
29634: has brought up Kate and Ellen. You may think how hard it will be for
29635: her to go among foreigners.”
29636: 
29637: “The doctor says that is what he should recommend the Lydgates to do,”
29638: said Mrs. Sprague. “He says Lydgate ought to have kept among the
29639: French.”
29640: 
29641: “That would suit _her_ well enough, I dare say,” said Mrs. Plymdale;
29642: “there is that kind of lightness about her. But she got that from her
29643: mother; she never got it from her aunt Bulstrode, who always gave her
29644: good advice, and to my knowledge would rather have had her marry
29645: elsewhere.”
29646: 
29647: Mrs. Plymdale was in a situation which caused her some complication of
29648: feeling. There had been not only her intimacy with Mrs. Bulstrode, but
29649: also a profitable business relation of the great Plymdale dyeing house
29650: with Mr. Bulstrode, which on the one hand would have inclined her to
29651: desire that the mildest view of his character should be the true one,
29652: but on the other, made her the more afraid of seeming to palliate his
29653: culpability. Again, the late alliance of her family with the Tollers
29654: had brought her in connection with the best circle, which gratified her
29655: in every direction except in the inclination to those serious views
29656: which she believed to be the best in another sense. The sharp little
29657: woman’s conscience was somewhat troubled in the adjustment of these
29658: opposing “bests,” and of her griefs and satisfactions under late
29659: events, which were likely to humble those who needed humbling, but also
29660: to fall heavily on her old friend whose faults she would have preferred
29661: seeing on a background of prosperity.
29662: 
29663: Poor Mrs. Bulstrode, meanwhile, had been no further shaken by the
29664: oncoming tread of calamity than in the busier stirring of that secret
29665: uneasiness which had always been present in her since the last visit of
29666: Raffles to The Shrubs. That the hateful man had come ill to Stone
29667: Court, and that her husband had chosen to remain there and watch over
29668: him, she allowed to be explained by the fact that Raffles had been
29669: employed and aided in earlier-days, and that this made a tie of
29670: benevolence towards him in his degraded helplessness; and she had been
29671: since then innocently cheered by her husband’s more hopeful speech
29672: about his own health and ability to continue his attention to business.
29673: The calm was disturbed when Lydgate had brought him home ill from the
29674: meeting, and in spite of comforting assurances during the next few
29675: days, she cried in private from the conviction that her husband was not
29676: suffering from bodily illness merely, but from something that afflicted
29677: his mind. He would not allow her to read to him, and scarcely to sit
29678: with him, alleging nervous susceptibility to sounds and movements; yet
29679: she suspected that in shutting himself up in his private room he wanted
29680: to be busy with his papers. Something, she felt sure, had happened.
29681: Perhaps it was some great loss of money; and she was kept in the dark.
29682: Not daring to question her husband, she said to Lydgate, on the fifth
29683: day after the meeting, when she had not left home except to go to
29684: church—
29685: 
29686: “Mr. Lydgate, pray be open with me: I like to know the truth. Has
29687: anything happened to Mr. Bulstrode?”
29688: 
29689: “Some little nervous shock,” said Lydgate, evasively. He felt that it
29690: was not for him to make the painful revelation.
29691: 
29692: “But what brought it on?” said Mrs. Bulstrode, looking directly at him
29693: with her large dark eyes.
29694: 
29695: “There is often something poisonous in the air of public rooms,” said
29696: Lydgate. “Strong men can stand it, but it tells on people in proportion
29697: to the delicacy of their systems. It is often impossible to account for
29698: the precise moment of an attack—or rather, to say why the strength
29699: gives way at a particular moment.”
29700: 
29701: Mrs. Bulstrode was not satisfied with this answer. There remained in
29702: her the belief that some calamity had befallen her husband, of which
29703: she was to be kept in ignorance; and it was in her nature strongly to
29704: object to such concealment. She begged leave for her daughters to sit
29705: with their father, and drove into the town to pay some visits,
29706: conjecturing that if anything were known to have gone wrong in Mr.
29707: Bulstrode’s affairs, she should see or hear some sign of it.
29708: 
29709: She called on Mrs. Thesiger, who was not at home, and then drove to
29710: Mrs. Hackbutt’s on the other side of the churchyard. Mrs. Hackbutt saw
29711: her coming from an up-stairs window, and remembering her former alarm
29712: lest she should meet Mrs. Bulstrode, felt almost bound in consistency
29713: to send word that she was not at home; but against that, there was a
29714: sudden strong desire within her for the excitement of an interview in
29715: which she was quite determined not to make the slightest allusion to
29716: what was in her mind.
29717: 
29718: Hence Mrs. Bulstrode was shown into the drawing-room, and Mrs. Hackbutt
29719: went to her, with more tightness of lip and rubbing of her hands than
29720: was usually observable in her, these being precautions adopted against
29721: freedom of speech. She was resolved not to ask how Mr. Bulstrode was.
29722: 
29723: “I have not been anywhere except to church for nearly a week,” said
29724: Mrs. Bulstrode, after a few introductory remarks. “But Mr. Bulstrode
29725: was taken so ill at the meeting on Thursday that I have not liked to
29726: leave the house.”
29727: 
29728: Mrs. Hackbutt rubbed the back of one hand with the palm of the other
29729: held against her chest, and let her eyes ramble over the pattern on the
29730: rug.
29731: 
29732: “Was Mr. Hackbutt at the meeting?” persevered Mrs. Bulstrode.
29733: 
29734: “Yes, he was,” said Mrs. Hackbutt, with the same attitude. “The land is
29735: to be bought by subscription, I believe.”
29736: 
29737: “Let us hope that there will be no more cases of cholera to be buried
29738: in it,” said Mrs. Bulstrode. “It is an awful visitation. But I always
29739: think Middlemarch a very healthy spot. I suppose it is being used to it
29740: from a child; but I never saw the town I should like to live at better,
29741: and especially our end.”
29742: 
29743: “I am sure I should be glad that you always should live at Middlemarch,
29744: Mrs. Bulstrode,” said Mrs. Hackbutt, with a slight sigh. “Still, we
29745: must learn to resign ourselves, wherever our lot may be cast. Though I
29746: am sure there will always be people in this town who will wish you
29747: well.”
29748: 
29749: Mrs. Hackbutt longed to say, “if you take my advice you will part from
29750: your husband,” but it seemed clear to her that the poor woman knew
29751: nothing of the thunder ready to bolt on her head, and she herself could
29752: do no more than prepare her a little. Mrs. Bulstrode felt suddenly
29753: rather chill and trembling: there was evidently something unusual
29754: behind this speech of Mrs. Hackbutt’s; but though she had set out with
29755: the desire to be fully informed, she found herself unable now to pursue
29756: her brave purpose, and turning the conversation by an inquiry about the
29757: young Hackbutts, she soon took her leave saying that she was going to
29758: see Mrs. Plymdale. On her way thither she tried to imagine that there
29759: might have been some unusually warm sparring at the meeting between Mr.
29760: Bulstrode and some of his frequent opponents—perhaps Mr. Hackbutt might
29761: have been one of them. That would account for everything.
29762: 
29763: But when she was in conversation with Mrs. Plymdale that comforting
29764: explanation seemed no longer tenable. “Selina” received her with a
29765: pathetic affectionateness and a disposition to give edifying answers on
29766: the commonest topics, which could hardly have reference to an ordinary
29767: quarrel of which the most important consequence was a perturbation of
29768: Mr. Bulstrode’s health. Beforehand Mrs. Bulstrode had thought that she
29769: would sooner question Mrs. Plymdale than any one else; but she found to
29770: her surprise that an old friend is not always the person whom it is
29771: easiest to make a confidant of: there was the barrier of remembered
29772: communication under other circumstances—there was the dislike of being
29773: pitied and informed by one who had been long wont to allow her the
29774: superiority. For certain words of mysterious appropriateness that Mrs.
29775: Plymdale let fall about her resolution never to turn her back on her
29776: friends, convinced Mrs. Bulstrode that what had happened must be some
29777: kind of misfortune, and instead of being able to say with her native
29778: directness, “What is it that you have in your mind?” she found herself
29779: anxious to get away before she had heard anything more explicit. She
29780: began to have an agitating certainty that the misfortune was something
29781: more than the mere loss of money, being keenly sensitive to the fact
29782: that Selina now, just as Mrs. Hackbutt had done before, avoided
29783: noticing what she said about her husband, as they would have avoided
29784: noticing a personal blemish.
29785: 
29786: She said good-by with nervous haste, and told the coachman to drive to
29787: Mr. Vincy’s warehouse. In that short drive her dread gathered so much
29788: force from the sense of darkness, that when she entered the private
29789: counting-house where her brother sat at his desk, her knees trembled
29790: and her usually florid face was deathly pale. Something of the same
29791: effect was produced in him by the sight of her: he rose from his seat
29792: to meet her, took her by the hand, and said, with his impulsive
29793: rashness—
29794: 
29795: “God help you, Harriet! you know all.”
29796: 
29797: That moment was perhaps worse than any which came after. It contained
29798: that concentrated experience which in great crises of emotion reveals
29799: the bias of a nature, and is prophetic of the ultimate act which will
29800: end an intermediate struggle. Without that memory of Raffles she might
29801: still have thought only of monetary ruin, but now along with her
29802: brother’s look and words there darted into her mind the idea of some
29803: guilt in her husband—then, under the working of terror came the image
29804: of her husband exposed to disgrace—and then, after an instant of
29805: scorching shame in which she felt only the eyes of the world, with one
29806: leap of her heart she was at his side in mournful but unreproaching
29807: fellowship with shame and isolation. All this went on within her in a
29808: mere flash of time—while she sank into the chair, and raised her eyes
29809: to her brother, who stood over her. “I know nothing, Walter. What is
29810: it?” she said, faintly.
29811: 
29812: He told her everything, very inartificially, in slow fragments, making
29813: her aware that the scandal went much beyond proof, especially as to the
29814: end of Raffles.
29815: 
29816: “People will talk,” he said. “Even if a man has been acquitted by a
29817: jury, they’ll talk, and nod and wink—and as far as the world goes, a
29818: man might often as well be guilty as not. It’s a breakdown blow, and it
29819: damages Lydgate as much as Bulstrode. I don’t pretend to say what is
29820: the truth. I only wish we had never heard the name of either Bulstrode
29821: or Lydgate. You’d better have been a Vincy all your life, and so had
29822: Rosamond.” Mrs. Bulstrode made no reply.
29823: 
29824: “But you must bear up as well as you can, Harriet. People don’t blame
29825: _you_. And I’ll stand by you whatever you make up your mind to do,”
29826: said the brother, with rough but well-meaning affectionateness.
29827: 
29828: “Give me your arm to the carriage, Walter,” said Mrs. Bulstrode. “I
29829: feel very weak.”
29830: 
29831: And when she got home she was obliged to say to her daughter, “I am not
29832: well, my dear; I must go and lie down. Attend to your papa. Leave me in
29833: quiet. I shall take no dinner.”
29834: 
29835: She locked herself in her room. She needed time to get used to her
29836: maimed consciousness, her poor lopped life, before she could walk
29837: steadily to the place allotted her. A new searching light had fallen on
29838: her husband’s character, and she could not judge him leniently: the
29839: twenty years in which she had believed in him and venerated him by
29840: virtue of his concealments came back with particulars that made them
29841: seem an odious deceit. He had married her with that bad past life
29842: hidden behind him, and she had no faith left to protest his innocence
29843: of the worst that was imputed to him. Her honest ostentatious nature
29844: made the sharing of a merited dishonor as bitter as it could be to any
29845: mortal.
29846: 
29847: But this imperfectly taught woman, whose phrases and habits were an odd
29848: patchwork, had a loyal spirit within her. The man whose prosperity she
29849: had shared through nearly half a life, and who had unvaryingly
29850: cherished her—now that punishment had befallen him it was not possible
29851: to her in any sense to forsake him. There is a forsaking which still
29852: sits at the same board and lies on the same couch with the forsaken
29853: soul, withering it the more by unloving proximity. She knew, when she
29854: locked her door, that she should unlock it ready to go down to her
29855: unhappy husband and espouse his sorrow, and say of his guilt, I will
29856: mourn and not reproach. But she needed time to gather up her strength;
29857: she needed to sob out her farewell to all the gladness and pride of her
29858: life. When she had resolved to go down, she prepared herself by some
29859: little acts which might seem mere folly to a hard onlooker; they were
29860: her way of expressing to all spectators visible or invisible that she
29861: had begun a new life in which she embraced humiliation. She took off
29862: all her ornaments and put on a plain black gown, and instead of wearing
29863: her much-adorned cap and large bows of hair, she brushed her hair down
29864: and put on a plain bonnet-cap, which made her look suddenly like an
29865: early Methodist.
29866: 
29867: Bulstrode, who knew that his wife had been out and had come in saying
29868: that she was not well, had spent the time in an agitation equal to
29869: hers. He had looked forward to her learning the truth from others, and
29870: had acquiesced in that probability, as something easier to him than any
29871: confession. But now that he imagined the moment of her knowledge come,
29872: he awaited the result in anguish. His daughters had been obliged to
29873: consent to leave him, and though he had allowed some food to be brought
29874: to him, he had not touched it. He felt himself perishing slowly in
29875: unpitied misery. Perhaps he should never see his wife’s face with
29876: affection in it again. And if he turned to God there seemed to be no
29877: answer but the pressure of retribution.
29878: 
29879: It was eight o’clock in the evening before the door opened and his wife
29880: entered. He dared not look up at her. He sat with his eyes bent down,
29881: and as she went towards him she thought he looked smaller—he seemed so
29882: withered and shrunken. A movement of new compassion and old tenderness
29883: went through her like a great wave, and putting one hand on his which
29884: rested on the arm of the chair, and the other on his shoulder, she
29885: said, solemnly but kindly—
29886: 
29887: “Look up, Nicholas.”
29888: 
29889: He raised his eyes with a little start and looked at her half amazed
29890: for a moment: her pale face, her changed, mourning dress, the trembling
29891: about her mouth, all said, “I know;” and her hands and eyes rested
29892: gently on him. He burst out crying and they cried together, she sitting
29893: at his side. They could not yet speak to each other of the shame which
29894: she was bearing with him, or of the acts which had brought it down on
29895: them. His confession was silent, and her promise of faithfulness was
29896: silent. Open-minded as she was, she nevertheless shrank from the words
29897: which would have expressed their mutual consciousness, as she would
29898: have shrunk from flakes of fire. She could not say, “How much is only
29899: slander and false suspicion?” and he did not say, “I am innocent.”
29900: 
29901: 
29902: 
29903: 
29904: CHAPTER LXXV.
29905: 
29906: “Le sentiment de la fausseté des plaisirs présents, et l’ignorance de
29907: la vanité des plaisirs absents causent l’inconstance.”—PASCAL.
29908: 
29909: 
29910: Rosamond had a gleam of returning cheerfulness when the house was freed
29911: from the threatening figure, and when all the disagreeable creditors
29912: were paid. But she was not joyous: her married life had fulfilled none
29913: of her hopes, and had been quite spoiled for her imagination. In this
29914: brief interval of calm, Lydgate, remembering that he had often been
29915: stormy in his hours of perturbation, and mindful of the pain Rosamond
29916: had had to bear, was carefully gentle towards her; but he, too, had
29917: lost some of his old spirit, and he still felt it necessary to refer to
29918: an economical change in their way of living as a matter of course,
29919: trying to reconcile her to it gradually, and repressing his anger when
29920: she answered by wishing that he would go to live in London. When she
29921: did not make this answer, she listened languidly, and wondered what she
29922: had that was worth living for. The hard and contemptuous words which
29923: had fallen from her husband in his anger had deeply offended that
29924: vanity which he had at first called into active enjoyment; and what she
29925: regarded as his perverse way of looking at things, kept up a secret
29926: repulsion, which made her receive all his tenderness as a poor
29927: substitute for the happiness he had failed to give her. They were at a
29928: disadvantage with their neighbors, and there was no longer any outlook
29929: towards Quallingham—there was no outlook anywhere except in an
29930: occasional letter from Will Ladislaw. She had felt stung and
29931: disappointed by Will’s resolution to quit Middlemarch, for in spite of
29932: what she knew and guessed about his admiration for Dorothea, she
29933: secretly cherished the belief that he had, or would necessarily come to
29934: have, much more admiration for herself; Rosamond being one of those
29935: women who live much in the idea that each man they meet would have
29936: preferred them if the preference had not been hopeless. Mrs. Casaubon
29937: was all very well; but Will’s interest in her dated before he knew Mrs.
29938: Lydgate. Rosamond took his way of talking to herself, which was a
29939: mixture of playful fault-finding and hyperbolical gallantry, as the
29940: disguise of a deeper feeling; and in his presence she felt that
29941: agreeable titillation of vanity and sense of romantic drama which
29942: Lydgate’s presence had no longer the magic to create. She even
29943: fancied—what will not men and women fancy in these matters?—that Will
29944: exaggerated his admiration for Mrs. Casaubon in order to pique herself.
29945: In this way poor Rosamond’s brain had been busy before Will’s
29946: departure. He would have made, she thought, a much more suitable
29947: husband for her than she had found in Lydgate. No notion could have
29948: been falser than this, for Rosamond’s discontent in her marriage was
29949: due to the conditions of marriage itself, to its demand for
29950: self-suppression and tolerance, and not to the nature of her husband;
29951: but the easy conception of an unreal Better had a sentimental charm
29952: which diverted her ennui. She constructed a little romance which was to
29953: vary the flatness of her life: Will Ladislaw was always to be a
29954: bachelor and live near her, always to be at her command, and have an
29955: understood though never fully expressed passion for her, which would be
29956: sending out lambent flames every now and then in interesting scenes.
29957: His departure had been a proportionate disappointment, and had sadly
29958: increased her weariness of Middlemarch; but at first she had the
29959: alternative dream of pleasures in store from her intercourse with the
29960: family at Quallingham. Since then the troubles of her married life had
29961: deepened, and the absence of other relief encouraged her regretful
29962: rumination over that thin romance which she had once fed on. Men and
29963: women make sad mistakes about their own symptoms, taking their vague
29964: uneasy longings, sometimes for genius, sometimes for religion, and
29965: oftener still for a mighty love. Will Ladislaw had written chatty
29966: letters, half to her and half to Lydgate, and she had replied: their
29967: separation, she felt, was not likely to be final, and the change she
29968: now most longed for was that Lydgate should go to live in London;
29969: everything would be agreeable in London; and she had set to work with
29970: quiet determination to win this result, when there came a sudden,
29971: delightful promise which inspirited her.
29972: 
29973: It came shortly before the memorable meeting at the town-hall, and was
29974: nothing less than a letter from Will Ladislaw to Lydgate, which turned
29975: indeed chiefly on his new interest in plans of colonization, but
29976: mentioned incidentally, that he might find it necessary to pay a visit
29977: to Middlemarch within the next few weeks—a very pleasant necessity, he
29978: said, almost as good as holidays to a schoolboy. He hoped there was his
29979: old place on the rug, and a great deal of music in store for him. But
29980: he was quite uncertain as to the time. While Lydgate was reading the
29981: letter to Rosamond, her face looked like a reviving flower—it grew
29982: prettier and more blooming. There was nothing unendurable now: the
29983: debts were paid, Mr. Ladislaw was coming, and Lydgate would be
29984: persuaded to leave Middlemarch and settle in London, which was “so
29985: different from a provincial town.”
29986: 
29987: That was a bright bit of morning. But soon the sky became black over
29988: poor Rosamond. The presence of a new gloom in her husband, about which
29989: he was entirely reserved towards her—for he dreaded to expose his
29990: lacerated feeling to her neutrality and misconception—soon received a
29991: painfully strange explanation, alien to all her previous notions of
29992: what could affect her happiness. In the new gayety of her spirits,
29993: thinking that Lydgate had merely a worse fit of moodiness than usual,
29994: causing him to leave her remarks unanswered, and evidently to keep out
29995: of her way as much as possible, she chose, a few days after the
29996: meeting, and without speaking to him on the subject, to send out notes
29997: of invitation for a small evening party, feeling convinced that this
29998: was a judicious step, since people seemed to have been keeping aloof
29999: from them, and wanted restoring to the old habit of intercourse. When
30000: the invitations had been accepted, she would tell Lydgate, and give him
30001: a wise admonition as to how a medical man should behave to his
30002: neighbors; for Rosamond had the gravest little airs possible about
30003: other people’s duties. But all the invitations were declined, and the
30004: last answer came into Lydgate’s hands.
30005: 
30006: “This is Chichely’s scratch. What is he writing to you about?” said
30007: Lydgate, wonderingly, as he handed the note to her. She was obliged to
30008: let him see it, and, looking at her severely, he said—
30009: 
30010: “Why on earth have you been sending out invitations without telling me,
30011: Rosamond? I beg, I insist that you will not invite any one to this
30012: house. I suppose you have been inviting others, and they have refused
30013: too.” She said nothing.
30014: 
30015: “Do you hear me?” thundered Lydgate.
30016: 
30017: “Yes, certainly I hear you,” said Rosamond, turning her head aside with
30018: the movement of a graceful long-necked bird.
30019: 
30020: Lydgate tossed his head without any grace and walked out of the room,
30021: feeling himself dangerous. Rosamond’s thought was, that he was getting
30022: more and more unbearable—not that there was any new special reason for
30023: this peremptoriness. His indisposition to tell her anything in which he
30024: was sure beforehand that she would not be interested was growing into
30025: an unreflecting habit, and she was in ignorance of everything connected
30026: with the thousand pounds except that the loan had come from her uncle
30027: Bulstrode. Lydgate’s odious humors and their neighbors’ apparent
30028: avoidance of them had an unaccountable date for her in their relief
30029: from money difficulties. If the invitations had been accepted she would
30030: have gone to invite her mamma and the rest, whom she had seen nothing
30031: of for several days; and she now put on her bonnet to go and inquire
30032: what had become of them all, suddenly feeling as if there were a
30033: conspiracy to leave her in isolation with a husband disposed to offend
30034: everybody. It was after the dinner hour, and she found her father and
30035: mother seated together alone in the drawing-room. They greeted her with
30036: sad looks, saying “Well, my dear!” and no more. She had never seen her
30037: father look so downcast; and seating herself near him she said—
30038: 
30039: “Is there anything the matter, papa?”
30040: 
30041: He did not answer, but Mrs. Vincy said, “Oh, my dear, have you heard
30042: nothing? It won’t be long before it reaches you.”
30043: 
30044: “Is it anything about Tertius?” said Rosamond, turning pale. The idea
30045: of trouble immediately connected itself with what had been
30046: unaccountable to her in him.
30047: 
30048: “Oh, my dear, yes. To think of your marrying into this trouble. Debt
30049: was bad enough, but this will be worse.”
30050: 
30051: “Stay, stay, Lucy,” said Mr. Vincy. “Have you heard nothing about your
30052: uncle Bulstrode, Rosamond?”
30053: 
30054: “No, papa,” said the poor thing, feeling as if trouble were not
30055: anything she had before experienced, but some invisible power with an
30056: iron grasp that made her soul faint within her.
30057: 
30058: Her father told her everything, saying at the end, “It’s better for you
30059: to know, my dear. I think Lydgate must leave the town. Things have gone
30060: against him. I dare say he couldn’t help it. I don’t accuse him of any
30061: harm,” said Mr. Vincy. He had always before been disposed to find the
30062: utmost fault with Lydgate.
30063: 
30064: The shock to Rosamond was terrible. It seemed to her that no lot could
30065: be so cruelly hard as hers to have married a man who had become the
30066: centre of infamous suspicions. In many cases it is inevitable that the
30067: shame is felt to be the worst part of crime; and it would have required
30068: a great deal of disentangling reflection, such as had never entered
30069: into Rosamond’s life, for her in these moments to feel that her trouble
30070: was less than if her husband had been certainly known to have done
30071: something criminal. All the shame seemed to be there. And she had
30072: innocently married this man with the belief that he and his family were
30073: a glory to her! She showed her usual reticence to her parents, and only
30074: said, that if Lydgate had done as she wished he would have left
30075: Middlemarch long ago.
30076: 
30077: “She bears it beyond anything,” said her mother when she was gone.
30078: 
30079: “Ah, thank God!” said Mr. Vincy, who was much broken down.
30080: 
30081: But Rosamond went home with a sense of justified repugnance towards her
30082: husband. What had he really done—how had he really acted? She did not
30083: know. Why had he not told her everything? He did not speak to her on
30084: the subject, and of course she could not speak to him. It came into her
30085: mind once that she would ask her father to let her go home again; but
30086: dwelling on that prospect made it seem utter dreariness to her: a
30087: married woman gone back to live with her parents—life seemed to have no
30088: meaning for her in such a position: she could not contemplate herself
30089: in it.
30090: 
30091: The next two days Lydgate observed a change in her, and believed that
30092: she had heard the bad news. Would she speak to him about it, or would
30093: she go on forever in the silence which seemed to imply that she
30094: believed him guilty? We must remember that he was in a morbid state of
30095: mind, in which almost all contact was pain. Certainly Rosamond in this
30096: case had equal reason to complain of reserve and want of confidence on
30097: his part; but in the bitterness of his soul he excused himself;—was he
30098: not justified in shrinking from the task of telling her, since now she
30099: knew the truth she had no impulse to speak to him? But a deeper-lying
30100: consciousness that he was in fault made him restless, and the silence
30101: between them became intolerable to him; it was as if they were both
30102: adrift on one piece of wreck and looked away from each other.
30103: 
30104: He thought, “I am a fool. Haven’t I given up expecting anything? I have
30105: married care, not help.” And that evening he said—
30106: 
30107: “Rosamond, have you heard anything that distresses you?”
30108: 
30109: “Yes,” she answered, laying down her work, which she had been carrying
30110: on with a languid semi-consciousness, most unlike her usual self.
30111: 
30112: “What have you heard?”
30113: 
30114: “Everything, I suppose. Papa told me.”
30115: 
30116: “That people think me disgraced?”
30117: 
30118: “Yes,” said Rosamond, faintly, beginning to sew again automatically.
30119: 
30120: There was silence. Lydgate thought, “If she has any trust in me—any
30121: notion of what I am, she ought to speak now and say that she does not
30122: believe I have deserved disgrace.”
30123: 
30124: But Rosamond on her side went on moving her fingers languidly. Whatever
30125: was to be said on the subject she expected to come from Tertius. What
30126: did she know? And if he were innocent of any wrong, why did he not do
30127: something to clear himself?
30128: 
30129: This silence of hers brought a new rush of gall to that bitter mood in
30130: which Lydgate had been saying to himself that nobody believed in
30131: him—even Farebrother had not come forward. He had begun to question her
30132: with the intent that their conversation should disperse the chill fog
30133: which had gathered between them, but he felt his resolution checked by
30134: despairing resentment. Even this trouble, like the rest, she seemed to
30135: regard as if it were hers alone. He was always to her a being apart,
30136: doing what she objected to. He started from his chair with an angry
30137: impulse, and thrusting his hands in his pockets, walked up and down the
30138: room. There was an underlying consciousness all the while that he
30139: should have to master this anger, and tell her everything, and convince
30140: her of the facts. For he had almost learned the lesson that he must
30141: bend himself to her nature, and that because she came short in her
30142: sympathy, he must give the more. Soon he recurred to his intention of
30143: opening himself: the occasion must not be lost. If he could bring her
30144: to feel with some solemnity that here was a slander which must be met
30145: and not run away from, and that the whole trouble had come out of his
30146: desperate want of money, it would be a moment for urging powerfully on
30147: her that they should be one in the resolve to do with as little money
30148: as possible, so that they might weather the bad time and keep
30149: themselves independent. He would mention the definite measures which he
30150: desired to take, and win her to a willing spirit. He was bound to try
30151: this—and what else was there for him to do?
30152: 
30153: He did not know how long he had been walking uneasily backwards and
30154: forwards, but Rosamond felt that it was long, and wished that he would
30155: sit down. She too had begun to think this an opportunity for urging on
30156: Tertius what he ought to do. Whatever might be the truth about all this
30157: misery, there was one dread which asserted itself.
30158: 
30159: Lydgate at last seated himself, not in his usual chair, but in one
30160: nearer to Rosamond, leaning aside in it towards her, and looking at her
30161: gravely before he reopened the sad subject. He had conquered himself so
30162: far, and was about to speak with a sense of solemnity, as on an
30163: occasion which was not to be repeated. He had even opened his lips,
30164: when Rosamond, letting her hands fall, looked at him and said—
30165: 
30166: “Surely, Tertius—”
30167: 
30168: “Well?”
30169: 
30170: “Surely now at last you have given up the idea of staying in
30171: Middlemarch. I cannot go on living here. Let us go to London. Papa, and
30172: every one else, says you had better go. Whatever misery I have to put
30173: up with, it will be easier away from here.”
30174: 
30175: Lydgate felt miserably jarred. Instead of that critical outpouring for
30176: which he had prepared himself with effort, here was the old round to be
30177: gone through again. He could not bear it. With a quick change of
30178: countenance he rose and went out of the room.
30179: 
30180: Perhaps if he had been strong enough to persist in his determination to
30181: be the more because she was less, that evening might have had a better
30182: issue. If his energy could have borne down that check, he might still
30183: have wrought on Rosamond’s vision and will. We cannot be sure that any
30184: natures, however inflexible or peculiar, will resist this effect from a
30185: more massive being than their own. They may be taken by storm and for
30186: the moment converted, becoming part of the soul which enwraps them in
30187: the ardor of its movement. But poor Lydgate had a throbbing pain within
30188: him, and his energy had fallen short of its task.
30189: 
30190: The beginning of mutual understanding and resolve seemed as far off as
30191: ever; nay, it seemed blocked out by the sense of unsuccessful effort.
30192: They lived on from day to day with their thoughts still apart, Lydgate
30193: going about what work he had in a mood of despair, and Rosamond
30194: feeling, with some justification, that he was behaving cruelly. It was
30195: of no use to say anything to Tertius; but when Will Ladislaw came, she
30196: was determined to tell him everything. In spite of her general
30197: reticence, she needed some one who would recognize her wrongs.
30198:
