30202: CHAPTER LXXVI.
30203: 
30204: To mercy, pity, peace, and love
30205:     All pray in their distress,
30206: And to these virtues of delight,
30207:     Return their thankfulness.
30208: . . . . . .
30209: For Mercy has a human heart,
30210:     Pity a human face;
30211: And Love, the human form divine;
30212:     And Peace, the human dress.
30213: —WILLIAM BLAKE: _Songs of Innocence_.
30214: 
30215: 
30216: Some days later, Lydgate was riding to Lowick Manor, in consequence of
30217: a summons from Dorothea. The summons had not been unexpected, since it
30218: had followed a letter from Mr. Bulstrode, in which he stated that he
30219: had resumed his arrangements for quitting Middlemarch, and must remind
30220: Lydgate of his previous communications about the Hospital, to the
30221: purport of which he still adhered. It had been his duty, before taking
30222: further steps, to reopen the subject with Mrs. Casaubon, who now
30223: wished, as before, to discuss the question with Lydgate. “Your views
30224: may possibly have undergone some change,” wrote Mr. Bulstrode; “but, in
30225: that case also, it is desirable that you should lay them before her.”
30226: 
30227: Dorothea awaited his arrival with eager interest. Though, in deference
30228: to her masculine advisers, she had refrained from what Sir James had
30229: called “interfering in this Bulstrode business,” the hardship of
30230: Lydgate’s position was continually in her mind, and when Bulstrode
30231: applied to her again about the hospital, she felt that the opportunity
30232: was come to her which she had been hindered from hastening. In her
30233: luxurious home, wandering under the boughs of her own great trees, her
30234: thought was going out over the lot of others, and her emotions were
30235: imprisoned. The idea of some active good within her reach, “haunted her
30236: like a passion,” and another’s need having once come to her as a
30237: distinct image, preoccupied her desire with the yearning to give
30238: relief, and made her own ease tasteless. She was full of confident hope
30239: about this interview with Lydgate, never heeding what was said of his
30240: personal reserve; never heeding that she was a very young woman.
30241: Nothing could have seemed more irrelevant to Dorothea than insistence
30242: on her youth and sex when she was moved to show her human fellowship.
30243: 
30244: As she sat waiting in the library, she could do nothing but live
30245: through again all the past scenes which had brought Lydgate into her
30246: memories. They all owed their significance to her marriage and its
30247: troubles—but no; there were two occasions in which the image of Lydgate
30248: had come painfully in connection with his wife and some one else. The
30249: pain had been allayed for Dorothea, but it had left in her an awakened
30250: conjecture as to what Lydgate’s marriage might be to him, a
30251: susceptibility to the slightest hint about Mrs. Lydgate. These thoughts
30252: were like a drama to her, and made her eyes bright, and gave an
30253: attitude of suspense to her whole frame, though she was only looking
30254: out from the brown library on to the turf and the bright green buds
30255: which stood in relief against the dark evergreens.
30256: 
30257: When Lydgate came in, she was almost shocked at the change in his face,
30258: which was strikingly perceptible to her who had not seen him for two
30259: months. It was not the change of emaciation, but that effect which even
30260: young faces will very soon show from the persistent presence of
30261: resentment and despondency. Her cordial look, when she put out her hand
30262: to him, softened his expression, but only with melancholy.
30263: 
30264: “I have wished very much to see you for a long while, Mr. Lydgate,”
30265: said Dorothea when they were seated opposite each other; “but I put off
30266: asking you to come until Mr. Bulstrode applied to me again about the
30267: Hospital. I know that the advantage of keeping the management of it
30268: separate from that of the Infirmary depends on you, or, at least, on
30269: the good which you are encouraged to hope for from having it under your
30270: control. And I am sure you will not refuse to tell me exactly what you
30271: think.”
30272: 
30273: “You want to decide whether you should give a generous support to the
30274: Hospital,” said Lydgate. “I cannot conscientiously advise you to do it
30275: in dependence on any activity of mine. I may be obliged to leave the
30276: town.”
30277: 
30278: He spoke curtly, feeling the ache of despair as to his being able to
30279: carry out any purpose that Rosamond had set her mind against.
30280: 
30281: “Not because there is no one to believe in you?” said Dorothea, pouring
30282: out her words in clearness from a full heart. “I know the unhappy
30283: mistakes about you. I knew them from the first moment to be mistakes.
30284: You have never done anything vile. You would not do anything
30285: dishonorable.”
30286: 
30287: It was the first assurance of belief in him that had fallen on
30288: Lydgate’s ears. He drew a deep breath, and said, “Thank you.” He could
30289: say no more: it was something very new and strange in his life that
30290: these few words of trust from a woman should be so much to him.
30291: 
30292: “I beseech you to tell me how everything was,” said Dorothea,
30293: fearlessly. “I am sure that the truth would clear you.”
30294: 
30295: Lydgate started up from his chair and went towards the window,
30296: forgetting where he was. He had so often gone over in his mind the
30297: possibility of explaining everything without aggravating appearances
30298: that would tell, perhaps unfairly, against Bulstrode, and had so often
30299: decided against it—he had so often said to himself that his assertions
30300: would not change people’s impressions—that Dorothea’s words sounded
30301: like a temptation to do something which in his soberness he had
30302: pronounced to be unreasonable.
30303: 
30304: “Tell me, pray,” said Dorothea, with simple earnestness; “then we can
30305: consult together. It is wicked to let people think evil of any one
30306: falsely, when it can be hindered.”
30307: 
30308: Lydgate turned, remembering where he was, and saw Dorothea’s face
30309: looking up at him with a sweet trustful gravity. The presence of a
30310: noble nature, generous in its wishes, ardent in its charity, changes
30311: the lights for us: we begin to see things again in their larger,
30312: quieter masses, and to believe that we too can be seen and judged in
30313: the wholeness of our character. That influence was beginning to act on
30314: Lydgate, who had for many days been seeing all life as one who is
30315: dragged and struggling amid the throng. He sat down again, and felt
30316: that he was recovering his old self in the consciousness that he was
30317: with one who believed in it.
30318: 
30319: “I don’t want,” he said, “to bear hard on Bulstrode, who has lent me
30320: money of which I was in need—though I would rather have gone without it
30321: now. He is hunted down and miserable, and has only a poor thread of
30322: life in him. But I should like to tell you everything. It will be a
30323: comfort to me to speak where belief has gone beforehand, and where I
30324: shall not seem to be offering assertions of my own honesty. You will
30325: feel what is fair to another, as you feel what is fair to me.”
30326: 
30327: “Do trust me,” said Dorothea; “I will not repeat anything without your
30328: leave. But at the very least, I could say that you have made all the
30329: circumstances clear to me, and that I know you are not in any way
30330: guilty. Mr. Farebrother would believe me, and my uncle, and Sir James
30331: Chettam. Nay, there are persons in Middlemarch to whom I could go;
30332: although they don’t know much of me, they would believe me. They would
30333: know that I could have no other motive than truth and justice. I would
30334: take any pains to clear you. I have very little to do. There is nothing
30335: better that I can do in the world.”
30336: 
30337: Dorothea’s voice, as she made this childlike picture of what she would
30338: do, might have been almost taken as a proof that she could do it
30339: effectively. The searching tenderness of her woman’s tones seemed made
30340: for a defence against ready accusers. Lydgate did not stay to think
30341: that she was Quixotic: he gave himself up, for the first time in his
30342: life, to the exquisite sense of leaning entirely on a generous
30343: sympathy, without any check of proud reserve. And he told her
30344: everything, from the time when, under the pressure of his difficulties,
30345: he unwillingly made his first application to Bulstrode; gradually, in
30346: the relief of speaking, getting into a more thorough utterance of what
30347: had gone on in his mind—entering fully into the fact that his treatment
30348: of the patient was opposed to the dominant practice, into his doubts at
30349: the last, his ideal of medical duty, and his uneasy consciousness that
30350: the acceptance of the money had made some difference in his private
30351: inclination and professional behavior, though not in his fulfilment of
30352: any publicly recognized obligation.
30353: 
30354: “It has come to my knowledge since,” he added, “that Hawley sent some
30355: one to examine the housekeeper at Stone Court, and she said that she
30356: gave the patient all the opium in the phial I left, as well as a good
30357: deal of brandy. But that would not have been opposed to ordinary
30358: prescriptions, even of first-rate men. The suspicions against me had no
30359: hold there: they are grounded on the knowledge that I took money, that
30360: Bulstrode had strong motives for wishing the man to die, and that he
30361: gave me the money as a bribe to concur in some malpractices or other
30362: against the patient—that in any case I accepted a bribe to hold my
30363: tongue. They are just the suspicions that cling the most obstinately,
30364: because they lie in people’s inclination and can never be disproved.
30365: How my orders came to be disobeyed is a question to which I don’t know
30366: the answer. It is still possible that Bulstrode was innocent of any
30367: criminal intention—even possible that he had nothing to do with the
30368: disobedience, and merely abstained from mentioning it. But all that has
30369: nothing to do with the public belief. It is one of those cases on which
30370: a man is condemned on the ground of his character—it is believed that
30371: he has committed a crime in some undefined way, because he had the
30372: motive for doing it; and Bulstrode’s character has enveloped me,
30373: because I took his money. I am simply blighted—like a damaged ear of
30374: corn—the business is done and can’t be undone.”
30375: 
30376: “Oh, it is hard!” said Dorothea. “I understand the difficulty there is
30377: in your vindicating yourself. And that all this should have come to you
30378: who had meant to lead a higher life than the common, and to find out
30379: better ways—I cannot bear to rest in this as unchangeable. I know you
30380: meant that. I remember what you said to me when you first spoke to me
30381: about the hospital. There is no sorrow I have thought more about than
30382: that—to love what is great, and try to reach it, and yet to fail.”
30383: 
30384: “Yes,” said Lydgate, feeling that here he had found room for the full
30385: meaning of his grief. “I had some ambition. I meant everything to be
30386: different with me. I thought I had more strength and mastery. But the
30387: most terrible obstacles are such as nobody can see except oneself.”
30388: 
30389: “Suppose,” said Dorothea, meditatively,—“suppose we kept on the
30390: Hospital according to the present plan, and you stayed here though only
30391: with the friendship and support of a few, the evil feeling towards you
30392: would gradually die out; there would come opportunities in which people
30393: would be forced to acknowledge that they had been unjust to you,
30394: because they would see that your purposes were pure. You may still win
30395: a great fame like the Louis and Laennec I have heard you speak of, and
30396: we shall all be proud of you,” she ended, with a smile.
30397: 
30398: “That might do if I had my old trust in myself,” said Lydgate,
30399: mournfully. “Nothing galls me more than the notion of turning round and
30400: running away before this slander, leaving it unchecked behind me.
30401: Still, I can’t ask any one to put a great deal of money into a plan
30402: which depends on me.”
30403: 
30404: “It would be quite worth my while,” said Dorothea, simply. “Only think.
30405: I am very uncomfortable with my money, because they tell me I have too
30406: little for any great scheme of the sort I like best, and yet I have too
30407: much. I don’t know what to do. I have seven hundred a-year of my own
30408: fortune, and nineteen hundred a-year that Mr. Casaubon left me, and
30409: between three and four thousand of ready money in the bank. I wished to
30410: raise money and pay it off gradually out of my income which I don’t
30411: want, to buy land with and found a village which should be a school of
30412: industry; but Sir James and my uncle have convinced me that the risk
30413: would be too great. So you see that what I should most rejoice at would
30414: be to have something good to do with my money: I should like it to make
30415: other people’s lives better to them. It makes me very uneasy—coming all
30416: to me who don’t want it.”
30417: 
30418: A smile broke through the gloom of Lydgate’s face. The childlike
30419: grave-eyed earnestness with which Dorothea said all this was
30420: irresistible—blent into an adorable whole with her ready understanding
30421: of high experience. (Of lower experience such as plays a great part in
30422: the world, poor Mrs. Casaubon had a very blurred shortsighted
30423: knowledge, little helped by her imagination.) But she took the smile as
30424: encouragement of her plan.
30425: 
30426: “I think you see now that you spoke too scrupulously,” she said, in a
30427: tone of persuasion. “The hospital would be one good; and making your
30428: life quite whole and well again would be another.”
30429: 
30430: Lydgate’s smile had died away. “You have the goodness as well as the
30431: money to do all that; if it could be done,” he said. “But—”
30432: 
30433: He hesitated a little while, looking vaguely towards the window; and
30434: she sat in silent expectation. At last he turned towards her and said
30435: impetuously—
30436: 
30437: “Why should I not tell you?—you know what sort of bond marriage is. You
30438: will understand everything.”
30439: 
30440: Dorothea felt her heart beginning to beat faster. Had he that sorrow
30441: too? But she feared to say any word, and he went on immediately.
30442: 
30443: “It is impossible for me now to do anything—to take any step without
30444: considering my wife’s happiness. The thing that I might like to do if I
30445: were alone, is become impossible to me. I can’t see her miserable. She
30446: married me without knowing what she was going into, and it might have
30447: been better for her if she had not married me.”
30448: 
30449: “I know, I know—you could not give her pain, if you were not obliged to
30450: do it,” said Dorothea, with keen memory of her own life.
30451: 
30452: “And she has set her mind against staying. She wishes to go. The
30453: troubles she has had here have wearied her,” said Lydgate, breaking off
30454: again, lest he should say too much.
30455: 
30456: “But when she saw the good that might come of staying—” said Dorothea,
30457: remonstrantly, looking at Lydgate as if he had forgotten the reasons
30458: which had just been considered. He did not speak immediately.
30459: 
30460: “She would not see it,” he said at last, curtly, feeling at first that
30461: this statement must do without explanation. “And, indeed, I have lost
30462: all spirit about carrying on my life here.” He paused a moment and
30463: then, following the impulse to let Dorothea see deeper into the
30464: difficulty of his life, he said, “The fact is, this trouble has come
30465: upon her confusedly. We have not been able to speak to each other about
30466: it. I am not sure what is in her mind about it: she may fear that I
30467: have really done something base. It is my fault; I ought to be more
30468: open. But I have been suffering cruelly.”
30469: 
30470: “May I go and see her?” said Dorothea, eagerly. “Would she accept my
30471: sympathy? I would tell her that you have not been blamable before any
30472: one’s judgment but your own. I would tell her that you shall be cleared
30473: in every fair mind. I would cheer her heart. Will you ask her if I may
30474: go to see her? I did see her once.”
30475: 
30476: “I am sure you may,” said Lydgate, seizing the proposition with some
30477: hope. “She would feel honored—cheered, I think, by the proof that you
30478: at least have some respect for me. I will not speak to her about your
30479: coming—that she may not connect it with my wishes at all. I know very
30480: well that I ought not to have left anything to be told her by others,
30481: but—”
30482: 
30483: He broke off, and there was a moment’s silence. Dorothea refrained from
30484: saying what was in her mind—how well she knew that there might be
30485: invisible barriers to speech between husband and wife. This was a point
30486: on which even sympathy might make a wound. She returned to the more
30487: outward aspect of Lydgate’s position, saying cheerfully—
30488: 
30489: “And if Mrs. Lydgate knew that there were friends who would believe in
30490: you and support you, she might then be glad that you should stay in
30491: your place and recover your hopes—and do what you meant to do. Perhaps
30492: then you would see that it was right to agree with what I proposed
30493: about your continuing at the Hospital. Surely you would, if you still
30494: have faith in it as a means of making your knowledge useful?”
30495: 
30496: Lydgate did not answer, and she saw that he was debating with himself.
30497: 
30498: “You need not decide immediately,” she said, gently. “A few days hence
30499: it will be early enough for me to send my answer to Mr. Bulstrode.”
30500: 
30501: Lydgate still waited, but at last turned to speak in his most decisive
30502: tones.
30503: 
30504: “No; I prefer that there should be no interval left for wavering. I am
30505: no longer sure enough of myself—I mean of what it would be possible for
30506: me to do under the changed circumstances of my life. It would be
30507: dishonorable to let others engage themselves to anything serious in
30508: dependence on me. I might be obliged to go away after all; I see little
30509: chance of anything else. The whole thing is too problematic; I cannot
30510: consent to be the cause of your goodness being wasted. No—let the new
30511: Hospital be joined with the old Infirmary, and everything go on as it
30512: might have done if I had never come. I have kept a valuable register
30513: since I have been there; I shall send it to a man who will make use of
30514: it,” he ended bitterly. “I can think of nothing for a long while but
30515: getting an income.”
30516: 
30517: “It hurts me very much to hear you speak so hopelessly,” said Dorothea.
30518: “It would be a happiness to your friends, who believe in your future,
30519: in your power to do great things, if you would let them save you from
30520: that. Think how much money I have; it would be like taking a burthen
30521: from me if you took some of it every year till you got free from this
30522: fettering want of income. Why should not people do these things? It is
30523: so difficult to make shares at all even. This is one way.”
30524: 
30525: “God bless you, Mrs. Casaubon!” said Lydgate, rising as if with the
30526: same impulse that made his words energetic, and resting his arm on the
30527: back of the great leather chair he had been sitting in. “It is good
30528: that you should have such feelings. But I am not the man who ought to
30529: allow himself to benefit by them. I have not given guarantees enough. I
30530: must not at least sink into the degradation of being pensioned for work
30531: that I never achieved. It is very clear to me that I must not count on
30532: anything else than getting away from Middlemarch as soon as I can
30533: manage it. I should not be able for a long while, at the very best, to
30534: get an income here, and—and it is easier to make necessary changes in a
30535: new place. I must do as other men do, and think what will please the
30536: world and bring in money; look for a little opening in the London
30537: crowd, and push myself; set up in a watering-place, or go to some
30538: southern town where there are plenty of idle English, and get myself
30539: puffed,—that is the sort of shell I must creep into and try to keep my
30540: soul alive in.”
30541: 
30542: “Now that is not brave,” said Dorothea,—“to give up the fight.”
30543: 
30544: “No, it is not brave,” said Lydgate, “but if a man is afraid of
30545: creeping paralysis?” Then, in another tone, “Yet you have made a great
30546: difference in my courage by believing in me. Everything seems more
30547: bearable since I have talked to you; and if you can clear me in a few
30548: other minds, especially in Farebrother’s, I shall be deeply grateful.
30549: The point I wish you not to mention is the fact of disobedience to my
30550: orders. That would soon get distorted. After all, there is no evidence
30551: for me but people’s opinion of me beforehand. You can only repeat my
30552: own report of myself.”
30553: 
30554: “Mr. Farebrother will believe—others will believe,” said Dorothea. “I
30555: can say of you what will make it stupidity to suppose that you would be
30556: bribed to do a wickedness.”
30557: 
30558: “I don’t know,” said Lydgate, with something like a groan in his voice.
30559: “I have not taken a bribe yet. But there is a pale shade of bribery
30560: which is sometimes called prosperity. You will do me another great
30561: kindness, then, and come to see my wife?”
30562: 
30563: “Yes, I will. I remember how pretty she is,” said Dorothea, into whose
30564: mind every impression about Rosamond had cut deep. “I hope she will
30565: like me.”
30566: 
30567: As Lydgate rode away, he thought, “This young creature has a heart
30568: large enough for the Virgin Mary. She evidently thinks nothing of her
30569: own future, and would pledge away half her income at once, as if she
30570: wanted nothing for herself but a chair to sit in from which she can
30571: look down with those clear eyes at the poor mortals who pray to her.
30572: She seems to have what I never saw in any woman before—a fountain of
30573: friendship towards men—a man can make a friend of her. Casaubon must
30574: have raised some heroic hallucination in her. I wonder if she could
30575: have any other sort of passion for a man? Ladislaw?—there was certainly
30576: an unusual feeling between them. And Casaubon must have had a notion of
30577: it. Well—her love might help a man more than her money.”
30578: 
30579: Dorothea on her side had immediately formed a plan of relieving Lydgate
30580: from his obligation to Bulstrode, which she felt sure was a part,
30581: though small, of the galling pressure he had to bear. She sat down at
30582: once under the inspiration of their interview, and wrote a brief note,
30583: in which she pleaded that she had more claim than Mr. Bulstrode had to
30584: the satisfaction of providing the money which had been serviceable to
30585: Lydgate—that it would be unkind in Lydgate not to grant her the
30586: position of being his helper in this small matter, the favor being
30587: entirely to her who had so little that was plainly marked out for her
30588: to do with her superfluous money. He might call her a creditor or by
30589: any other name if it did but imply that he granted her request. She
30590: enclosed a check for a thousand pounds, and determined to take the
30591: letter with her the next day when she went to see Rosamond.
30592: 
30593: 
30594: 
30595: 
30596: CHAPTER LXXVII.
30597: 
30598: “And thus thy fall hath left a kind of blot,
30599: To mark the full-fraught man and best indued
30600: With some suspicion.”
30601: —_Henry V_.
30602: 
30603: 
30604: The next day Lydgate had to go to Brassing, and told Rosamond that he
30605: should be away until the evening. Of late she had never gone beyond her
30606: own house and garden, except to church, and once to see her papa, to
30607: whom she said, “If Tertius goes away, you will help us to move, will
30608: you not, papa? I suppose we shall have very little money. I am sure I
30609: hope some one will help us.” And Mr. Vincy had said, “Yes, child, I
30610: don’t mind a hundred or two. I can see the end of that.” With these
30611: exceptions she had sat at home in languid melancholy and suspense,
30612: fixing her mind on Will Ladislaw’s coming as the one point of hope and
30613: interest, and associating this with some new urgency on Lydgate to make
30614: immediate arrangements for leaving Middlemarch and going to London,
30615: till she felt assured that the coming would be a potent cause of the
30616: going, without at all seeing how. This way of establishing sequences is
30617: too common to be fairly regarded as a peculiar folly in Rosamond. And
30618: it is precisely this sort of sequence which causes the greatest shock
30619: when it is sundered: for to see how an effect may be produced is often
30620: to see possible missings and checks; but to see nothing except the
30621: desirable cause, and close upon it the desirable effect, rids us of
30622: doubt and makes our minds strongly intuitive. That was the process
30623: going on in poor Rosamond, while she arranged all objects around her
30624: with the same nicety as ever, only with more slowness—or sat down to
30625: the piano, meaning to play, and then desisting, yet lingering on the
30626: music stool with her white fingers suspended on the wooden front, and
30627: looking before her in dreamy ennui. Her melancholy had become so marked
30628: that Lydgate felt a strange timidity before it, as a perpetual silent
30629: reproach, and the strong man, mastered by his keen sensibilities
30630: towards this fair fragile creature whose life he seemed somehow to have
30631: bruised, shrank from her look, and sometimes started at her approach,
30632: fear of her and fear for her rushing in only the more forcibly after it
30633: had been momentarily expelled by exasperation.
30634: 
30635: But this morning Rosamond descended from her room upstairs—where she
30636: sometimes sat the whole day when Lydgate was out—equipped for a walk in
30637: the town. She had a letter to post—a letter addressed to Mr. Ladislaw
30638: and written with charming discretion, but intended to hasten his
30639: arrival by a hint of trouble. The servant-maid, their sole
30640: house-servant now, noticed her coming down-stairs in her walking dress,
30641: and thought “there never did anybody look so pretty in a bonnet poor
30642: thing.”
30643: 
30644: Meanwhile Dorothea’s mind was filled with her project of going to
30645: Rosamond, and with the many thoughts, both of the past and the probable
30646: future, which gathered round the idea of that visit. Until yesterday
30647: when Lydgate had opened to her a glimpse of some trouble in his married
30648: life, the image of Mrs. Lydgate had always been associated for her with
30649: that of Will Ladislaw. Even in her most uneasy moments—even when she
30650: had been agitated by Mrs. Cadwallader’s painfully graphic report of
30651: gossip—her effort, nay, her strongest impulsive prompting, had been
30652: towards the vindication of Will from any sullying surmises; and when,
30653: in her meeting with him afterwards, she had at first interpreted his
30654: words as a probable allusion to a feeling towards Mrs. Lydgate which he
30655: was determined to cut himself off from indulging, she had had a quick,
30656: sad, excusing vision of the charm there might be in his constant
30657: opportunities of companionship with that fair creature, who most likely
30658: shared his other tastes as she evidently did his delight in music. But
30659: there had followed his parting words—the few passionate words in which
30660: he had implied that she herself was the object of whom his love held
30661: him in dread, that it was his love for her only which he was resolved
30662: not to declare but to carry away into banishment. From the time of that
30663: parting, Dorothea, believing in Will’s love for her, believing with a
30664: proud delight in his delicate sense of honor and his determination that
30665: no one should impeach him justly, felt her heart quite at rest as to
30666: the regard he might have for Mrs. Lydgate. She was sure that the regard
30667: was blameless.
30668: 
30669: There are natures in which, if they love us, we are conscious of having
30670: a sort of baptism and consecration: they bind us over to rectitude and
30671: purity by their pure belief about us; and our sins become that worst
30672: kind of sacrilege which tears down the invisible altar of trust. “If
30673: you are not good, none is good”—those little words may give a terrific
30674: meaning to responsibility, may hold a vitriolic intensity for remorse.
30675: 
30676: Dorothea’s nature was of that kind: her own passionate faults lay along
30677: the easily counted open channels of her ardent character; and while she
30678: was full of pity for the visible mistakes of others, she had not yet
30679: any material within her experience for subtle constructions and
30680: suspicions of hidden wrong. But that simplicity of hers, holding up an
30681: ideal for others in her believing conception of them, was one of the
30682: great powers of her womanhood. And it had from the first acted strongly
30683: on Will Ladislaw. He felt, when he parted from her, that the brief
30684: words by which he had tried to convey to her his feeling about herself
30685: and the division which her fortune made between them, would only profit
30686: by their brevity when Dorothea had to interpret them: he felt that in
30687: her mind he had found his highest estimate.
30688: 
30689: And he was right there. In the months since their parting Dorothea had
30690: felt a delicious though sad repose in their relation to each other, as
30691: one which was inwardly whole and without blemish. She had an active
30692: force of antagonism within her, when the antagonism turned on the
30693: defence either of plans or persons that she believed in; and the wrongs
30694: which she felt that Will had received from her husband, and the
30695: external conditions which to others were grounds for slighting him,
30696: only gave the more tenacity to her affection and admiring judgment. And
30697: now with the disclosures about Bulstrode had come another fact
30698: affecting Will’s social position, which roused afresh Dorothea’s inward
30699: resistance to what was said about him in that part of her world which
30700: lay within park palings.
30701: 
30702: “Young Ladislaw the grandson of a thieving Jew pawnbroker” was a phrase
30703: which had entered emphatically into the dialogues about the Bulstrode
30704: business, at Lowick, Tipton, and Freshitt, and was a worse kind of
30705: placard on poor Will’s back than the “Italian with white mice.” Upright
30706: Sir James Chettam was convinced that his own satisfaction was righteous
30707: when he thought with some complacency that here was an added league to
30708: that mountainous distance between Ladislaw and Dorothea, which enabled
30709: him to dismiss any anxiety in that direction as too absurd. And perhaps
30710: there had been some pleasure in pointing Mr. Brooke’s attention to this
30711: ugly bit of Ladislaw’s genealogy, as a fresh candle for him to see his
30712: own folly by. Dorothea had observed the animus with which Will’s part
30713: in the painful story had been recalled more than once; but she had
30714: uttered no word, being checked now, as she had not been formerly in
30715: speaking of Will, by the consciousness of a deeper relation between
30716: them which must always remain in consecrated secrecy. But her silence
30717: shrouded her resistant emotion into a more thorough glow; and this
30718: misfortune in Will’s lot which, it seemed, others were wishing to fling
30719: at his back as an opprobrium, only gave something more of enthusiasm to
30720: her clinging thought.
30721: 
30722: She entertained no visions of their ever coming into nearer union, and
30723: yet she had taken no posture of renunciation. She had accepted her
30724: whole relation to Will very simply as part of her marriage sorrows, and
30725: would have thought it very sinful in her to keep up an inward wail
30726: because she was not completely happy, being rather disposed to dwell on
30727: the superfluities of her lot. She could bear that the chief pleasures
30728: of her tenderness should lie in memory, and the idea of marriage came
30729: to her solely as a repulsive proposition from some suitor of whom she
30730: at present knew nothing, but whose merits, as seen by her friends,
30731: would be a source of torment to her:—“somebody who will manage your
30732: property for you, my dear,” was Mr. Brooke’s attractive suggestion of
30733: suitable characteristics. “I should like to manage it myself, if I knew
30734: what to do with it,” said Dorothea. No—she adhered to her declaration
30735: that she would never be married again, and in the long valley of her
30736: life which looked so flat and empty of waymarks, guidance would come as
30737: she walked along the road, and saw her fellow-passengers by the way.
30738: 
30739: This habitual state of feeling about Will Ladislaw had been strong in
30740: all her waking hours since she had proposed to pay a visit to Mrs.
30741: Lydgate, making a sort of background against which she saw Rosamond’s
30742: figure presented to her without hindrances to her interest and
30743: compassion. There was evidently some mental separation, some barrier to
30744: complete confidence which had arisen between this wife and the husband
30745: who had yet made her happiness a law to him. That was a trouble which
30746: no third person must directly touch. But Dorothea thought with deep
30747: pity of the loneliness which must have come upon Rosamond from the
30748: suspicions cast on her husband; and there would surely be help in the
30749: manifestation of respect for Lydgate and sympathy with her.
30750: 
30751: “I shall talk to her about her husband,” thought Dorothea, as she was
30752: being driven towards the town. The clear spring morning, the scent of
30753: the moist earth, the fresh leaves just showing their creased-up wealth
30754: of greenery from out their half-opened sheaths, seemed part of the
30755: cheerfulness she was feeling from a long conversation with Mr.
30756: Farebrother, who had joyfully accepted the justifying explanation of
30757: Lydgate’s conduct. “I shall take Mrs. Lydgate good news, and perhaps
30758: she will like to talk to me and make a friend of me.”
30759: 
30760: Dorothea had another errand in Lowick Gate: it was about a new
30761: fine-toned bell for the school-house, and as she had to get out of her
30762: carriage very near to Lydgate’s, she walked thither across the street,
30763: having told the coachman to wait for some packages. The street door was
30764: open, and the servant was taking the opportunity of looking out at the
30765: carriage which was pausing within sight when it became apparent to her
30766: that the lady who “belonged to it” was coming towards her.
30767: 
30768: “Is Mrs. Lydgate at home?” said Dorothea.
30769: 
30770: “I’m not sure, my lady; I’ll see, if you’ll please to walk in,” said
30771: Martha, a little confused on the score of her kitchen apron, but
30772: collected enough to be sure that “mum” was not the right title for this
30773: queenly young widow with a carriage and pair. “Will you please to walk
30774: in, and I’ll go and see.”
30775: 
30776: “Say that I am Mrs. Casaubon,” said Dorothea, as Martha moved forward
30777: intending to show her into the drawing-room and then to go up-stairs to
30778: see if Rosamond had returned from her walk.
30779: 
30780: They crossed the broader part of the entrance-hall, and turned up the
30781: passage which led to the garden. The drawing-room door was unlatched,
30782: and Martha, pushing it without looking into the room, waited for Mrs.
30783: Casaubon to enter and then turned away, the door having swung open and
30784: swung back again without noise.
30785: 
30786: Dorothea had less of outward vision than usual this morning, being
30787: filled with images of things as they had been and were going to be. She
30788: found herself on the other side of the door without seeing anything
30789: remarkable, but immediately she heard a voice speaking in low tones
30790: which startled her as with a sense of dreaming in daylight, and
30791: advancing unconsciously a step or two beyond the projecting slab of a
30792: bookcase, she saw, in the terrible illumination of a certainty which
30793: filled up all outlines, something which made her pause, motionless,
30794: without self-possession enough to speak.
30795: 
30796: Seated with his back towards her on a sofa which stood against the wall
30797: on a line with the door by which she had entered, she saw Will
30798: Ladislaw: close by him and turned towards him with a flushed
30799: tearfulness which gave a new brilliancy to her face sat Rosamond, her
30800: bonnet hanging back, while Will leaning towards her clasped both her
30801: upraised hands in his and spoke with low-toned fervor.
30802: 
30803: Rosamond in her agitated absorption had not noticed the silently
30804: advancing figure; but when Dorothea, after the first immeasurable
30805: instant of this vision, moved confusedly backward and found herself
30806: impeded by some piece of furniture, Rosamond was suddenly aware of her
30807: presence, and with a spasmodic movement snatched away her hands and
30808: rose, looking at Dorothea who was necessarily arrested. Will Ladislaw,
30809: starting up, looked round also, and meeting Dorothea’s eyes with a new
30810: lightning in them, seemed changing to marble. But she immediately
30811: turned them away from him to Rosamond and said in a firm voice—
30812: 
30813: “Excuse me, Mrs. Lydgate, the servant did not know that you were here.
30814: I called to deliver an important letter for Mr. Lydgate, which I wished
30815: to put into your own hands.”
30816: 
30817: She laid down the letter on the small table which had checked her
30818: retreat, and then including Rosamond and Will in one distant glance and
30819: bow, she went quickly out of the room, meeting in the passage the
30820: surprised Martha, who said she was sorry the mistress was not at home,
30821: and then showed the strange lady out with an inward reflection that
30822: grand people were probably more impatient than others.
30823: 
30824: Dorothea walked across the street with her most elastic step and was
30825: quickly in her carriage again.
30826: 
30827: “Drive on to Freshitt Hall,” she said to the coachman, and any one
30828: looking at her might have thought that though she was paler than usual
30829: she was never animated by a more self-possessed energy. And that was
30830: really her experience. It was as if she had drunk a great draught of
30831: scorn that stimulated her beyond the susceptibility to other feelings.
30832: She had seen something so far below her belief, that her emotions
30833: rushed back from it and made an excited throng without an object. She
30834: needed something active to turn her excitement out upon. She felt power
30835: to walk and work for a day, without meat or drink. And she would carry
30836: out the purpose with which she had started in the morning, of going to
30837: Freshitt and Tipton to tell Sir James and her uncle all that she wished
30838: them to know about Lydgate, whose married loneliness under his trial
30839: now presented itself to her with new significance, and made her more
30840: ardent in readiness to be his champion. She had never felt anything
30841: like this triumphant power of indignation in the struggle of her
30842: married life, in which there had always been a quickly subduing pang;
30843: and she took it as a sign of new strength.
30844: 
30845: “Dodo, how very bright your eyes are!” said Celia, when Sir James was
30846: gone out of the room. “And you don’t see anything you look at, Arthur
30847: or anything. You are going to do something uncomfortable, I know. Is it
30848: all about Mr. Lydgate, or has something else happened?” Celia had been
30849: used to watch her sister with expectation.
30850: 
30851: “Yes, dear, a great many things have happened,” said Dodo, in her full
30852: tones.
30853: 
30854: “I wonder what,” said Celia, folding her arms cozily and leaning
30855: forward upon them.
30856: 
30857: “Oh, all the troubles of all people on the face of the earth,” said
30858: Dorothea, lifting her arms to the back of her head.
30859: 
30860: “Dear me, Dodo, are you going to have a scheme for them?” said Celia, a
30861: little uneasy at this Hamlet-like raving.
30862: 
30863: But Sir James came in again, ready to accompany Dorothea to the Grange,
30864: and she finished her expedition well, not swerving in her resolution
30865: until she descended at her own door.
30866:
