30868: 
30869: 
30870: CHAPTER LXXVIII.
30871: 
30872: “Would it were yesterday and I i’ the grave,
30873: With her sweet faith above for monument.”
30874: 
30875: 
30876: Rosamond and Will stood motionless—they did not know how long—he
30877: looking towards the spot where Dorothea had stood, and she looking
30878: towards him with doubt. It seemed an endless time to Rosamond, in whose
30879: inmost soul there was hardly so much annoyance as gratification from
30880: what had just happened. Shallow natures dream of an easy sway over the
30881: emotions of others, trusting implicitly in their own petty magic to
30882: turn the deepest streams, and confident, by pretty gestures and
30883: remarks, of making the thing that is not as though it were. She knew
30884: that Will had received a severe blow, but she had been little used to
30885: imagining other people’s states of mind except as a material cut into
30886: shape by her own wishes; and she believed in her own power to soothe or
30887: subdue. Even Tertius, that most perverse of men, was always subdued in
30888: the long-run: events had been obstinate, but still Rosamond would have
30889: said now, as she did before her marriage, that she never gave up what
30890: she had set her mind on.
30891: 
30892: She put out her arm and laid the tips of her fingers on Will’s
30893: coat-sleeve.
30894: 
30895: “Don’t touch me!” he said, with an utterance like the cut of a lash,
30896: darting from her, and changing from pink to white and back again, as if
30897: his whole frame were tingling with the pain of the sting. He wheeled
30898: round to the other side of the room and stood opposite to her, with the
30899: tips of his fingers in his pockets and his head thrown back, looking
30900: fiercely not at Rosamond but at a point a few inches away from her.
30901: 
30902: She was keenly offended, but the signs she made of this were such as
30903: only Lydgate was used to interpret. She became suddenly quiet and
30904: seated herself, untying her hanging bonnet and laying it down with her
30905: shawl. Her little hands which she folded before her were very cold.
30906: 
30907: It would have been safer for Will in the first instance to have taken
30908: up his hat and gone away; but he had felt no impulse to do this; on the
30909: contrary, he had a horrible inclination to stay and shatter Rosamond
30910: with his anger. It seemed as impossible to bear the fatality she had
30911: drawn down on him without venting his fury as it would be to a panther
30912: to bear the javelin-wound without springing and biting. And yet—how
30913: could he tell a woman that he was ready to curse her? He was fuming
30914: under a repressive law which he was forced to acknowledge: he was
30915: dangerously poised, and Rosamond’s voice now brought the decisive
30916: vibration. In flute-like tones of sarcasm she said—
30917: 
30918: “You can easily go after Mrs. Casaubon and explain your preference.”
30919: 
30920: “Go after her!” he burst out, with a sharp edge in his voice. “Do you
30921: think she would turn to look at me, or value any word I ever uttered to
30922: her again at more than a dirty feather?—Explain! How can a man explain
30923: at the expense of a woman?”
30924: 
30925: “You can tell her what you please,” said Rosamond with more tremor.
30926: 
30927: “Do you suppose she would like me better for sacrificing you? She is
30928: not a woman to be flattered because I made myself despicable—to believe
30929: that I must be true to her because I was a dastard to you.”
30930: 
30931: He began to move about with the restlessness of a wild animal that sees
30932: prey but cannot reach it. Presently he burst out again—
30933: 
30934: “I had no hope before—not much—of anything better to come. But I had
30935: one certainty—that she believed in me. Whatever people had said or done
30936: about me, she believed in me.—That’s gone! She’ll never again think me
30937: anything but a paltry pretence—too nice to take heaven except upon
30938: flattering conditions, and yet selling myself for any devil’s change by
30939: the sly. She’ll think of me as an incarnate insult to her, from the
30940: first moment we—”
30941: 
30942: Will stopped as if he had found himself grasping something that must
30943: not be thrown and shattered. He found another vent for his rage by
30944: snatching up Rosamond’s words again, as if they were reptiles to be
30945: throttled and flung off.
30946: 
30947: “Explain! Tell a man to explain how he dropped into hell! Explain my
30948: preference! I never had a _preference_ for her, any more than I have a
30949: preference for breathing. No other woman exists by the side of her. I
30950: would rather touch her hand if it were dead, than I would touch any
30951: other woman’s living.”
30952: 
30953: Rosamond, while these poisoned weapons were being hurled at her, was
30954: almost losing the sense of her identity, and seemed to be waking into
30955: some new terrible existence. She had no sense of chill resolute
30956: repulsion, of reticent self-justification such as she had known under
30957: Lydgate’s most stormy displeasure: all her sensibility was turned into
30958: a bewildering novelty of pain; she felt a new terrified recoil under a
30959: lash never experienced before. What another nature felt in opposition
30960: to her own was being burnt and bitten into her consciousness. When Will
30961: had ceased to speak she had become an image of sickened misery: her
30962: lips were pale, and her eyes had a tearless dismay in them. If it had
30963: been Tertius who stood opposite to her, that look of misery would have
30964: been a pang to him, and he would have sunk by her side to comfort her,
30965: with that strong-armed comfort which she had often held very cheap.
30966: 
30967: Let it be forgiven to Will that he had no such movement of pity. He had
30968: felt no bond beforehand to this woman who had spoiled the ideal
30969: treasure of his life, and he held himself blameless. He knew that he
30970: was cruel, but he had no relenting in him yet.
30971: 
30972: After he had done speaking, he still moved about, half in absence of
30973: mind, and Rosamond sat perfectly still. At length Will, seeming to
30974: bethink himself, took up his hat, yet stood some moments irresolute. He
30975: had spoken to her in a way that made a phrase of common politeness
30976: difficult to utter; and yet, now that he had come to the point of going
30977: away from her without further speech, he shrank from it as a brutality;
30978: he felt checked and stultified in his anger. He walked towards the
30979: mantel-piece and leaned his arm on it, and waited in silence for—he
30980: hardly knew what. The vindictive fire was still burning in him, and he
30981: could utter no word of retractation; but it was nevertheless in his
30982: mind that having come back to this hearth where he had enjoyed a
30983: caressing friendship he had found calamity seated there—he had had
30984: suddenly revealed to him a trouble that lay outside the home as well as
30985: within it. And what seemed a foreboding was pressing upon him as with
30986: slow pincers:—that his life might come to be enslaved by this helpless
30987: woman who had thrown herself upon him in the dreary sadness of her
30988: heart. But he was in gloomy rebellion against the fact that his quick
30989: apprehensiveness foreshadowed to him, and when his eyes fell on
30990: Rosamond’s blighted face it seemed to him that he was the more pitiable
30991: of the two; for pain must enter into its glorified life of memory
30992: before it can turn into compassion.
30993: 
30994: And so they remained for many minutes, opposite each other, far apart,
30995: in silence; Will’s face still possessed by a mute rage, and Rosamond’s
30996: by a mute misery. The poor thing had no force to fling out any passion
30997: in return; the terrible collapse of the illusion towards which all her
30998: hope had been strained was a stroke which had too thoroughly shaken
30999: her: her little world was in ruins, and she felt herself tottering in
31000: the midst as a lonely bewildered consciousness.
31001: 
31002: Will wished that she would speak and bring some mitigating shadow
31003: across his own cruel speech, which seemed to stand staring at them both
31004: in mockery of any attempt at revived fellowship. But she said nothing,
31005: and at last with a desperate effort over himself, he asked, “Shall I
31006: come in and see Lydgate this evening?”
31007: 
31008: “If you like,” Rosamond answered, just audibly.
31009: 
31010: And then Will went out of the house, Martha never knowing that he had
31011: been in.
31012: 
31013: After he was gone, Rosamond tried to get up from her seat, but fell
31014: back fainting. When she came to herself again, she felt too ill to make
31015: the exertion of rising to ring the bell, and she remained helpless
31016: until the girl, surprised at her long absence, thought for the first
31017: time of looking for her in all the down-stairs rooms. Rosamond said
31018: that she had felt suddenly sick and faint, and wanted to be helped
31019: up-stairs. When there she threw herself on the bed with her clothes on,
31020: and lay in apparent torpor, as she had done once before on a memorable
31021: day of grief.
31022: 
31023: Lydgate came home earlier than he had expected, about half-past five,
31024: and found her there. The perception that she was ill threw every other
31025: thought into the background. When he felt her pulse, her eyes rested on
31026: him with more persistence than they had done for a long while, as if
31027: she felt some content that he was there. He perceived the difference in
31028: a moment, and seating himself by her put his arm gently under her, and
31029: bending over her said, “My poor Rosamond! has something agitated you?”
31030: Clinging to him she fell into hysterical sobbings and cries, and for
31031: the next hour he did nothing but soothe and tend her. He imagined that
31032: Dorothea had been to see her, and that all this effect on her nervous
31033: system, which evidently involved some new turning towards himself, was
31034: due to the excitement of the new impressions which that visit had
31035: raised.
31036: 
31037: 
31038: 
31039: 
31040: CHAPTER LXXIX.
31041: 
31042: “Now, I saw in my dream, that just as they had ended their talk, they
31043: drew nigh to a very miry slough, that was in the midst of the plain;
31044: and they, being heedless, did both fall suddenly into the bog. The name
31045: of the slough was Despond.”—BUNYAN.
31046: 
31047: 
31048: When Rosamond was quiet, and Lydgate had left her, hoping that she
31049: might soon sleep under the effect of an anodyne, he went into the
31050: drawing-room to fetch a book which he had left there, meaning to spend
31051: the evening in his work-room, and he saw on the table Dorothea’s letter
31052: addressed to him. He had not ventured to ask Rosamond if Mrs. Casaubon
31053: had called, but the reading of this letter assured him of the fact, for
31054: Dorothea mentioned that it was to be carried by herself.
31055: 
31056: When Will Ladislaw came in a little later Lydgate met him with a
31057: surprise which made it clear that he had not been told of the earlier
31058: visit, and Will could not say, “Did not Mrs. Lydgate tell you that I
31059: came this morning?”
31060: 
31061: “Poor Rosamond is ill,” Lydgate added immediately on his greeting.
31062: 
31063: “Not seriously, I hope,” said Will.
31064: 
31065: “No—only a slight nervous shock—the effect of some agitation. She has
31066: been overwrought lately. The truth is, Ladislaw, I am an unlucky devil.
31067: We have gone through several rounds of purgatory since you left, and I
31068: have lately got on to a worse ledge of it than ever. I suppose you are
31069: only just come down—you look rather battered—you have not been long
31070: enough in the town to hear anything?”
31071: 
31072: “I travelled all night and got to the White Hart at eight o’clock this
31073: morning. I have been shutting myself up and resting,” said Will,
31074: feeling himself a sneak, but seeing no alternative to this evasion.
31075: 
31076: And then he heard Lydgate’s account of the troubles which Rosamond had
31077: already depicted to him in her way. She had not mentioned the fact of
31078: Will’s name being connected with the public story—this detail not
31079: immediately affecting her—and he now heard it for the first time.
31080: 
31081: “I thought it better to tell you that your name is mixed up with the
31082: disclosures,” said Lydgate, who could understand better than most men
31083: how Ladislaw might be stung by the revelation. “You will be sure to
31084: hear it as soon as you turn out into the town. I suppose it is true
31085: that Raffles spoke to you.”
31086: 
31087: “Yes,” said Will, sardonically. “I shall be fortunate if gossip does
31088: not make me the most disreputable person in the whole affair. I should
31089: think the latest version must be, that I plotted with Raffles to murder
31090: Bulstrode, and ran away from Middlemarch for the purpose.”
31091: 
31092: He was thinking “Here is a new ring in the sound of my name to
31093: recommend it in her hearing; however—what does it signify now?”
31094: 
31095: But he said nothing of Bulstrode’s offer to him. Will was very open and
31096: careless about his personal affairs, but it was among the more
31097: exquisite touches in nature’s modelling of him that he had a delicate
31098: generosity which warned him into reticence here. He shrank from saying
31099: that he had rejected Bulstrode’s money, in the moment when he was
31100: learning that it was Lydgate’s misfortune to have accepted it.
31101: 
31102: Lydgate too was reticent in the midst of his confidence. He made no
31103: allusion to Rosamond’s feeling under their trouble, and of Dorothea he
31104: only said, “Mrs. Casaubon has been the one person to come forward and
31105: say that she had no belief in any of the suspicions against me.”
31106: Observing a change in Will’s face, he avoided any further mention of
31107: her, feeling himself too ignorant of their relation to each other not
31108: to fear that his words might have some hidden painful bearing on it.
31109: And it occurred to him that Dorothea was the real cause of the present
31110: visit to Middlemarch.
31111: 
31112: The two men were pitying each other, but it was only Will who guessed
31113: the extent of his companion’s trouble. When Lydgate spoke with
31114: desperate resignation of going to settle in London, and said with a
31115: faint smile, “We shall have you again, old fellow,” Will felt
31116: inexpressibly mournful, and said nothing. Rosamond had that morning
31117: entreated him to urge this step on Lydgate; and it seemed to him as if
31118: he were beholding in a magic panorama a future where he himself was
31119: sliding into that pleasureless yielding to the small solicitations of
31120: circumstance, which is a commoner history of perdition than any single
31121: momentous bargain.
31122: 
31123: We are on a perilous margin when we begin to look passively at our
31124: future selves, and see our own figures led with dull consent into
31125: insipid misdoing and shabby achievement. Poor Lydgate was inwardly
31126: groaning on that margin, and Will was arriving at it. It seemed to him
31127: this evening as if the cruelty of his outburst to Rosamond had made an
31128: obligation for him, and he dreaded the obligation: he dreaded Lydgate’s
31129: unsuspecting good-will: he dreaded his own distaste for his spoiled
31130: life, which would leave him in motiveless levity.
31131: 
31132: 
31133: 
31134: 
31135: CHAPTER LXXX.
31136: 
31137: Stern lawgiver! yet thou dost wear
31138: The Godhead’s most benignant grace;
31139: Nor know we anything so fair
31140: As is the smile upon thy face;
31141: Flowers laugh before thee on their beds,
31142: And fragrance in thy footing treads;
31143: Thou dost preserve the Stars from wrong;
31144: And the most ancient Heavens, through thee, are fresh and strong.
31145: —WORDSWORTH: _Ode to Duty_.
31146: 
31147: 
31148: When Dorothea had seen Mr. Farebrother in the morning, she had promised
31149: to go and dine at the parsonage on her return from Freshitt. There was
31150: a frequent interchange of visits between her and the Farebrother
31151: family, which enabled her to say that she was not at all lonely at the
31152: Manor, and to resist for the present the severe prescription of a lady
31153: companion. When she reached home and remembered her engagement, she was
31154: glad of it; and finding that she had still an hour before she could
31155: dress for dinner, she walked straight to the schoolhouse and entered
31156: into a conversation with the master and mistress about the new bell,
31157: giving eager attention to their small details and repetitions, and
31158: getting up a dramatic sense that her life was very busy. She paused on
31159: her way back to talk to old Master Bunney who was putting in some
31160: garden-seeds, and discoursed wisely with that rural sage about the
31161: crops that would make the most return on a perch of ground, and the
31162: result of sixty years’ experience as to soils—namely, that if your soil
31163: was pretty mellow it would do, but if there came wet, wet, wet to make
31164: it all of a mummy, why then—
31165: 
31166: Finding that the social spirit had beguiled her into being rather late,
31167: she dressed hastily and went over to the parsonage rather earlier than
31168: was necessary. That house was never dull, Mr. Farebrother, like another
31169: White of Selborne, having continually something new to tell of his
31170: inarticulate guests and _proteges_, whom he was teaching the boys not
31171: to torment; and he had just set up a pair of beautiful goats to be pets
31172: of the village in general, and to walk at large as sacred animals. The
31173: evening went by cheerfully till after tea, Dorothea talking more than
31174: usual and dilating with Mr. Farebrother on the possible histories of
31175: creatures that converse compendiously with their antennae, and for
31176: aught we know may hold reformed parliaments; when suddenly some
31177: inarticulate little sounds were heard which called everybody’s
31178: attention.
31179: 
31180: “Henrietta Noble,” said Mrs. Farebrother, seeing her small sister
31181: moving about the furniture-legs distressfully, “what is the matter?”
31182: 
31183: “I have lost my tortoise-shell lozenge-box. I fear the kitten has
31184: rolled it away,” said the tiny old lady, involuntarily continuing her
31185: beaver-like notes.
31186: 
31187: “Is it a great treasure, aunt?” said Mr. Farebrother, putting up his
31188: glasses and looking at the carpet.
31189: 
31190: “Mr. Ladislaw gave it me,” said Miss Noble. “A German box—very pretty,
31191: but if it falls it always spins away as far as it can.”
31192: 
31193: “Oh, if it is Ladislaw’s present,” said Mr. Farebrother, in a deep tone
31194: of comprehension, getting up and hunting. The box was found at last
31195: under a chiffonier, and Miss Noble grasped it with delight, saying, “it
31196: was under a fender the last time.”
31197: 
31198: “That is an affair of the heart with my aunt,” said Mr. Farebrother,
31199: smiling at Dorothea, as he reseated himself.
31200: 
31201: “If Henrietta Noble forms an attachment to any one, Mrs. Casaubon,”
31202: said his mother, emphatically,—“she is like a dog—she would take their
31203: shoes for a pillow and sleep the better.”
31204: 
31205: “Mr. Ladislaw’s shoes, I would,” said Henrietta Noble.
31206: 
31207: Dorothea made an attempt at smiling in return. She was surprised and
31208: annoyed to find that her heart was palpitating violently, and that it
31209: was quite useless to try after a recovery of her former animation.
31210: Alarmed at herself—fearing some further betrayal of a change so marked
31211: in its occasion, she rose and said in a low voice with undisguised
31212: anxiety, “I must go; I have overtired myself.”
31213: 
31214: Mr. Farebrother, quick in perception, rose and said, “It is true; you
31215: must have half-exhausted yourself in talking about Lydgate. That sort
31216: of work tells upon one after the excitement is over.”
31217: 
31218: He gave her his arm back to the Manor, but Dorothea did not attempt to
31219: speak, even when he said good-night.
31220: 
31221: The limit of resistance was reached, and she had sunk back helpless
31222: within the clutch of inescapable anguish. Dismissing Tantripp with a
31223: few faint words, she locked her door, and turning away from it towards
31224: the vacant room she pressed her hands hard on the top of her head, and
31225: moaned out—
31226: 
31227: “Oh, I did love him!”
31228: 
31229: Then came the hour in which the waves of suffering shook her too
31230: thoroughly to leave any power of thought. She could only cry in loud
31231: whispers, between her sobs, after her lost belief which she had planted
31232: and kept alive from a very little seed since the days in Rome—after her
31233: lost joy of clinging with silent love and faith to one who, misprized
31234: by others, was worthy in her thought—after her lost woman’s pride of
31235: reigning in his memory—after her sweet dim perspective of hope, that
31236: along some pathway they should meet with unchanged recognition and take
31237: up the backward years as a yesterday.
31238: 
31239: In that hour she repeated what the merciful eyes of solitude have
31240: looked on for ages in the spiritual struggles of man—she besought
31241: hardness and coldness and aching weariness to bring her relief from the
31242: mysterious incorporeal might of her anguish: she lay on the bare floor
31243: and let the night grow cold around her; while her grand woman’s frame
31244: was shaken by sobs as if she had been a despairing child.
31245: 
31246: There were two images—two living forms that tore her heart in two, as
31247: if it had been the heart of a mother who seems to see her child divided
31248: by the sword, and presses one bleeding half to her breast while her
31249: gaze goes forth in agony towards the half which is carried away by the
31250: lying woman that has never known the mother’s pang.
31251: 
31252: Here, with the nearness of an answering smile, here within the
31253: vibrating bond of mutual speech, was the bright creature whom she had
31254: trusted—who had come to her like the spirit of morning visiting the dim
31255: vault where she sat as the bride of a worn-out life; and now, with a
31256: full consciousness which had never awakened before, she stretched out
31257: her arms towards him and cried with bitter cries that their nearness
31258: was a parting vision: she discovered her passion to herself in the
31259: unshrinking utterance of despair.
31260: 
31261: And there, aloof, yet persistently with her, moving wherever she moved,
31262: was the Will Ladislaw who was a changed belief exhausted of hope, a
31263: detected illusion—no, a living man towards whom there could not yet
31264: struggle any wail of regretful pity, from the midst of scorn and
31265: indignation and jealous offended pride. The fire of Dorothea’s anger
31266: was not easily spent, and it flamed out in fitful returns of spurning
31267: reproach. Why had he come obtruding his life into hers, hers that might
31268: have been whole enough without him? Why had he brought his cheap regard
31269: and his lip-born words to her who had nothing paltry to give in
31270: exchange? He knew that he was deluding her—wished, in the very moment
31271: of farewell, to make her believe that he gave her the whole price of
31272: her heart, and knew that he had spent it half before. Why had he not
31273: stayed among the crowd of whom she asked nothing—but only prayed that
31274: they might be less contemptible?
31275: 
31276: But she lost energy at last even for her loud-whispered cries and
31277: moans: she subsided into helpless sobs, and on the cold floor she
31278: sobbed herself to sleep.
31279: 
31280: In the chill hours of the morning twilight, when all was dim around
31281: her, she awoke—not with any amazed wondering where she was or what had
31282: happened, but with the clearest consciousness that she was looking into
31283: the eyes of sorrow. She rose, and wrapped warm things around her, and
31284: seated herself in a great chair where she had often watched before. She
31285: was vigorous enough to have borne that hard night without feeling ill
31286: in body, beyond some aching and fatigue; but she had waked to a new
31287: condition: she felt as if her soul had been liberated from its terrible
31288: conflict; she was no longer wrestling with her grief, but could sit
31289: down with it as a lasting companion and make it a sharer in her
31290: thoughts. For now the thoughts came thickly. It was not in Dorothea’s
31291: nature, for longer than the duration of a paroxysm, to sit in the
31292: narrow cell of her calamity, in the besotted misery of a consciousness
31293: that only sees another’s lot as an accident of its own.
31294: 
31295: She began now to live through that yesterday morning deliberately
31296: again, forcing herself to dwell on every detail and its possible
31297: meaning. Was she alone in that scene? Was it her event only? She forced
31298: herself to think of it as bound up with another woman’s life—a woman
31299: towards whom she had set out with a longing to carry some clearness and
31300: comfort into her beclouded youth. In her first outleap of jealous
31301: indignation and disgust, when quitting the hateful room, she had flung
31302: away all the mercy with which she had undertaken that visit. She had
31303: enveloped both Will and Rosamond in her burning scorn, and it seemed to
31304: her as if Rosamond were burned out of her sight forever. But that base
31305: prompting which makes a women more cruel to a rival than to a faithless
31306: lover, could have no strength of recurrence in Dorothea when the
31307: dominant spirit of justice within her had once overcome the tumult and
31308: had once shown her the truer measure of things. All the active thought
31309: with which she had before been representing to herself the trials of
31310: Lydgate’s lot, and this young marriage union which, like her own,
31311: seemed to have its hidden as well as evident troubles—all this vivid
31312: sympathetic experience returned to her now as a power: it asserted
31313: itself as acquired knowledge asserts itself and will not let us see as
31314: we saw in the day of our ignorance. She said to her own irremediable
31315: grief, that it should make her more helpful, instead of driving her
31316: back from effort.
31317: 
31318: And what sort of crisis might not this be in three lives whose contact
31319: with hers laid an obligation on her as if they had been suppliants
31320: bearing the sacred branch? The objects of her rescue were not to be
31321: sought out by her fancy: they were chosen for her. She yearned towards
31322: the perfect Right, that it might make a throne within her, and rule her
31323: errant will. “What should I do—how should I act now, this very day, if
31324: I could clutch my own pain, and compel it to silence, and think of
31325: those three?”
31326: 
31327: It had taken long for her to come to that question, and there was light
31328: piercing into the room. She opened her curtains, and looked out towards
31329: the bit of road that lay in view, with fields beyond outside the
31330: entrance-gates. On the road there was a man with a bundle on his back
31331: and a woman carrying her baby; in the field she could see figures
31332: moving—perhaps the shepherd with his dog. Far off in the bending sky
31333: was the pearly light; and she felt the largeness of the world and the
31334: manifold wakings of men to labor and endurance. She was a part of that
31335: involuntary, palpitating life, and could neither look out on it from
31336: her luxurious shelter as a mere spectator, nor hide her eyes in selfish
31337: complaining.
31338: 
31339: What she would resolve to do that day did not yet seem quite clear, but
31340: something that she could achieve stirred her as with an approaching
31341: murmur which would soon gather distinctness. She took off the clothes
31342: which seemed to have some of the weariness of a hard watching in them,
31343: and began to make her toilet. Presently she rang for Tantripp, who came
31344: in her dressing-gown.
31345: 
31346: “Why, madam, you’ve never been in bed this blessed night,” burst out
31347: Tantripp, looking first at the bed and then at Dorothea’s face, which
31348: in spite of bathing had the pale cheeks and pink eyelids of a mater
31349: dolorosa. “You’ll kill yourself, you _will_. Anybody might think now
31350: you had a right to give yourself a little comfort.”
31351: 
31352: “Don’t be alarmed, Tantripp,” said Dorothea, smiling. “I have slept; I
31353: am not ill. I shall be glad of a cup of coffee as soon as possible. And
31354: I want you to bring me my new dress; and most likely I shall want my
31355: new bonnet to-day.”
31356: 
31357: “They’ve lain there a month and more ready for you, madam, and most
31358: thankful I shall be to see you with a couple o’ pounds’ worth less of
31359: crape,” said Tantripp, stooping to light the fire. “There’s a reason in
31360: mourning, as I’ve always said; and three folds at the bottom of your
31361: skirt and a plain quilling in your bonnet—and if ever anybody looked
31362: like an angel, it’s you in a net quilling—is what’s consistent for a
31363: second year. At least, that’s _my_ thinking,” ended Tantripp, looking
31364: anxiously at the fire; “and if anybody was to marry me flattering
31365: himself I should wear those hijeous weepers two years for him, he’d be
31366: deceived by his own vanity, that’s all.”
31367: 
31368: “The fire will do, my good Tan,” said Dorothea, speaking as she used to
31369: do in the old Lausanne days, only with a very low voice; “get me the
31370: coffee.”
31371: 
31372: She folded herself in the large chair, and leaned her head against it
31373: in fatigued quiescence, while Tantripp went away wondering at this
31374: strange contrariness in her young mistress—that just the morning when
31375: she had more of a widow’s face than ever, she should have asked for her
31376: lighter mourning which she had waived before. Tantripp would never have
31377: found the clew to this mystery. Dorothea wished to acknowledge that she
31378: had not the less an active life before her because she had buried a
31379: private joy; and the tradition that fresh garments belonged to all
31380: initiation, haunting her mind, made her grasp after even that slight
31381: outward help towards calm resolve. For the resolve was not easy.
31382: 
31383: Nevertheless at eleven o’clock she was walking towards Middlemarch,
31384: having made up her mind that she would make as quietly and unnoticeably
31385: as possible her second attempt to see and save Rosamond.
31386: 
31387: 
31388: 
31389: 
31390: CHAPTER LXXXI.
31391: 
31392: Du Erde warst auch diese Nacht beständig,
31393: Und athmest neu erquickt zu meinen Füssen,
31394: Beginnest schon mit Lust mich zu umgeben,
31395: Du regst und rührst ein kräftiges Beschliessen
31396: _Zum höchsten Dasein immerfort zu streben_.
31397: —_Faust:_ 2r Theil.
31398: 
31399: 
31400: When Dorothea was again at Lydgate’s door speaking to Martha, he was in
31401: the room close by with the door ajar, preparing to go out. He heard her
31402: voice, and immediately came to her.
31403: 
31404: “Do you think that Mrs. Lydgate can receive me this morning?” she said,
31405: having reflected that it would be better to leave out all allusion to
31406: her previous visit.
31407: 
31408: “I have no doubt she will,” said Lydgate, suppressing his thought about
31409: Dorothea’s looks, which were as much changed as Rosamond’s, “if you
31410: will be kind enough to come in and let me tell her that you are here.
31411: She has not been very well since you were here yesterday, but she is
31412: better this morning, and I think it is very likely that she will be
31413: cheered by seeing you again.”
31414: 
31415: It was plain that Lydgate, as Dorothea had expected, knew nothing about
31416: the circumstances of her yesterday’s visit; nay, he appeared to imagine
31417: that she had carried it out according to her intention. She had
31418: prepared a little note asking Rosamond to see her, which she would have
31419: given to the servant if he had not been in the way, but now she was in
31420: much anxiety as to the result of his announcement.
31421: 
31422: After leading her into the drawing-room, he paused to take a letter
31423: from his pocket and put it into her hands, saying, “I wrote this last
31424: night, and was going to carry it to Lowick in my ride. When one is
31425: grateful for something too good for common thanks, writing is less
31426: unsatisfactory than speech—one does not at least _hear_ how inadequate
31427: the words are.”
31428: 
31429: Dorothea’s face brightened. “It is I who have most to thank for, since
31430: you have let me take that place. You _have_ consented?” she said,
31431: suddenly doubting.
31432: 
31433: “Yes, the check is going to Bulstrode to-day.”
31434: 
31435: He said no more, but went up-stairs to Rosamond, who had but lately
31436: finished dressing herself, and sat languidly wondering what she should
31437: do next, her habitual industry in small things, even in the days of her
31438: sadness, prompting her to begin some kind of occupation, which she
31439: dragged through slowly or paused in from lack of interest. She looked
31440: ill, but had recovered her usual quietude of manner, and Lydgate had
31441: feared to disturb her by any questions. He had told her of Dorothea’s
31442: letter containing the check, and afterwards he had said, “Ladislaw is
31443: come, Rosy; he sat with me last night; I dare say he will be here again
31444: to-day. I thought he looked rather battered and depressed.” And
31445: Rosamond had made no reply.
31446: 
31447: Now, when he came up, he said to her very gently, “Rosy, dear, Mrs.
31448: Casaubon is come to see you again; you would like to see her, would you
31449: not?” That she colored and gave rather a startled movement did not
31450: surprise him after the agitation produced by the interview yesterday—a
31451: beneficent agitation, he thought, since it seemed to have made her turn
31452: to him again.
31453: 
31454: Rosamond dared not say no. She dared not with a tone of her voice touch
31455: the facts of yesterday. Why had Mrs. Casaubon come again? The answer
31456: was a blank which Rosamond could only fill up with dread, for Will
31457: Ladislaw’s lacerating words had made every thought of Dorothea a fresh
31458: smart to her. Nevertheless, in her new humiliating uncertainty she
31459: dared do nothing but comply. She did not say yes, but she rose and let
31460: Lydgate put a light shawl over her shoulders, while he said, “I am
31461: going out immediately.” Then something crossed her mind which prompted
31462: her to say, “Pray tell Martha not to bring any one else into the
31463: drawing-room.” And Lydgate assented, thinking that he fully understood
31464: this wish. He led her down to the drawing-room door, and then turned
31465: away, observing to himself that he was rather a blundering husband to
31466: be dependent for his wife’s trust in him on the influence of another
31467: woman.
31468: 
31469: Rosamond, wrapping her soft shawl around her as she walked towards
31470: Dorothea, was inwardly wrapping her soul in cold reserve. Had Mrs.
31471: Casaubon come to say anything to her about Will? If so, it was a
31472: liberty that Rosamond resented; and she prepared herself to meet every
31473: word with polite impassibility. Will had bruised her pride too sorely
31474: for her to feel any compunction towards him and Dorothea: her own
31475: injury seemed much the greater. Dorothea was not only the “preferred”
31476: woman, but had also a formidable advantage in being Lydgate’s
31477: benefactor; and to poor Rosamond’s pained confused vision it seemed
31478: that this Mrs. Casaubon—this woman who predominated in all things
31479: concerning her—must have come now with the sense of having the
31480: advantage, and with animosity prompting her to use it. Indeed, not
31481: Rosamond only, but any one else, knowing the outer facts of the case,
31482: and not the simple inspiration on which Dorothea acted, might well have
31483: wondered why she came.
31484: 
31485: Looking like the lovely ghost of herself, her graceful slimness wrapped
31486: in her soft white shawl, the rounded infantine mouth and cheek
31487: inevitably suggesting mildness and innocence, Rosamond paused at three
31488: yards’ distance from her visitor and bowed. But Dorothea, who had taken
31489: off her gloves, from an impulse which she could never resist when she
31490: wanted a sense of freedom, came forward, and with her face full of a
31491: sad yet sweet openness, put out her hand. Rosamond could not avoid
31492: meeting her glance, could not avoid putting her small hand into
31493: Dorothea’s, which clasped it with gentle motherliness; and immediately
31494: a doubt of her own prepossessions began to stir within her. Rosamond’s
31495: eye was quick for faces; she saw that Mrs. Casaubon’s face looked pale
31496: and changed since yesterday, yet gentle, and like the firm softness of
31497: her hand. But Dorothea had counted a little too much on her own
31498: strength: the clearness and intensity of her mental action this morning
31499: were the continuance of a nervous exaltation which made her frame as
31500: dangerously responsive as a bit of finest Venetian crystal; and in
31501: looking at Rosamond, she suddenly found her heart swelling, and was
31502: unable to speak—all her effort was required to keep back tears. She
31503: succeeded in that, and the emotion only passed over her face like the
31504: spirit of a sob; but it added to Rosamond’s impression that Mrs.
31505: Casaubon’s state of mind must be something quite different from what
31506: she had imagined.
31507: 
31508: So they sat down without a word of preface on the two chairs that
31509: happened to be nearest, and happened also to be close together; though
31510: Rosamond’s notion when she first bowed was that she should stay a long
31511: way off from Mrs. Casaubon. But she ceased thinking how anything would
31512: turn out—merely wondering what would come. And Dorothea began to speak
31513: quite simply, gathering firmness as she went on.
31514: 
31515: “I had an errand yesterday which I did not finish; that is why I am
31516: here again so soon. You will not think me too troublesome when I tell
31517: you that I came to talk to you about the injustice that has been shown
31518: towards Mr. Lydgate. It will cheer you—will it not?—to know a great
31519: deal about him, that he may not like to speak about himself just
31520: because it is in his own vindication and to his own honor. You will
31521: like to know that your husband has warm friends, who have not left off
31522: believing in his high character? You will let me speak of this without
31523: thinking that I take a liberty?”
31524: 
31525: The cordial, pleading tones which seemed to flow with generous
31526: heedlessness above all the facts which had filled Rosamond’s mind as
31527: grounds of obstruction and hatred between her and this woman, came as
31528: soothingly as a warm stream over her shrinking fears. Of course Mrs.
31529: Casaubon had the facts in her mind, but she was not going to speak of
31530: anything connected with them. That relief was too great for Rosamond to
31531: feel much else at the moment. She answered prettily, in the new ease of
31532: her soul—
31533: 
31534: “I know you have been very good. I shall like to hear anything you will
31535: say to me about Tertius.”
31536: 
31537: “The day before yesterday,” said Dorothea, “when I had asked him to
31538: come to Lowick to give me his opinion on the affairs of the Hospital,
31539: he told me everything about his conduct and feelings in this sad event
31540: which has made ignorant people cast suspicions on him. The reason he
31541: told me was because I was very bold and asked him. I believed that he
31542: had never acted dishonorably, and I begged him to tell me the history.
31543: He confessed to me that he had never told it before, not even to you,
31544: because he had a great dislike to say, ‘I was not wrong,’ as if that
31545: were proof, when there are guilty people who will say so. The truth is,
31546: he knew nothing of this man Raffles, or that there were any bad secrets
31547: about him; and he thought that Mr. Bulstrode offered him the money
31548: because he repented, out of kindness, of having refused it before. All
31549: his anxiety about his patient was to treat him rightly, and he was a
31550: little uncomfortable that the case did not end as he had expected; but
31551: he thought then and still thinks that there may have been no wrong in
31552: it on any one’s part. And I have told Mr. Farebrother, and Mr. Brooke,
31553: and Sir James Chettam: they all believe in your husband. That will
31554: cheer you, will it not? That will give you courage?”
31555: 
31556: Dorothea’s face had become animated, and as it beamed on Rosamond very
31557: close to her, she felt something like bashful timidity before a
31558: superior, in the presence of this self-forgetful ardor. She said, with
31559: blushing embarrassment, “Thank you: you are very kind.”
31560: 
31561: “And he felt that he had been so wrong not to pour out everything about
31562: this to you. But you will forgive him. It was because he feels so much
31563: more about your happiness than anything else—he feels his life bound
31564: into one with yours, and it hurts him more than anything, that his
31565: misfortunes must hurt you. He could speak to me because I am an
31566: indifferent person. And then I asked him if I might come to see you;
31567: because I felt so much for his trouble and yours. That is why I came
31568: yesterday, and why I am come to-day. Trouble is so hard to bear, is it
31569: not?— How can we live and think that any one has trouble—piercing
31570: trouble—and we could help them, and never try?”
31571: 
31572: Dorothea, completely swayed by the feeling that she was uttering,
31573: forgot everything but that she was speaking from out the heart of her
31574: own trial to Rosamond’s. The emotion had wrought itself more and more
31575: into her utterance, till the tones might have gone to one’s very
31576: marrow, like a low cry from some suffering creature in the darkness.
31577: And she had unconsciously laid her hand again on the little hand that
31578: she had pressed before.
31579: 
31580: Rosamond, with an overmastering pang, as if a wound within her had been
31581: probed, burst into hysterical crying as she had done the day before
31582: when she clung to her husband. Poor Dorothea was feeling a great wave
31583: of her own sorrow returning over her—her thought being drawn to the
31584: possible share that Will Ladislaw might have in Rosamond’s mental
31585: tumult. She was beginning to fear that she should not be able to
31586: suppress herself enough to the end of this meeting, and while her hand
31587: was still resting on Rosamond’s lap, though the hand underneath it was
31588: withdrawn, she was struggling against her own rising sobs. She tried to
31589: master herself with the thought that this might be a turning-point in
31590: three lives—not in her own; no, there the irrevocable had happened,
31591: but—in those three lives which were touching hers with the solemn
31592: neighborhood of danger and distress. The fragile creature who was
31593: crying close to her—there might still be time to rescue her from the
31594: misery of false incompatible bonds; and this moment was unlike any
31595: other: she and Rosamond could never be together again with the same
31596: thrilling consciousness of yesterday within them both. She felt the
31597: relation between them to be peculiar enough to give her a peculiar
31598: influence, though she had no conception that the way in which her own
31599: feelings were involved was fully known to Mrs. Lydgate.
31600: 
31601: It was a newer crisis in Rosamond’s experience than even Dorothea could
31602: imagine: she was under the first great shock that had shattered her
31603: dream-world in which she had been easily confident of herself and
31604: critical of others; and this strange unexpected manifestation of
31605: feeling in a woman whom she had approached with a shrinking aversion
31606: and dread, as one who must necessarily have a jealous hatred towards
31607: her, made her soul totter all the more with a sense that she had been
31608: walking in an unknown world which had just broken in upon her.
31609: 
31610: When Rosamond’s convulsed throat was subsiding into calm, and she
31611: withdrew the handkerchief with which she had been hiding her face, her
31612: eyes met Dorothea’s as helplessly as if they had been blue flowers.
31613: What was the use of thinking about behavior after this crying? And
31614: Dorothea looked almost as childish, with the neglected trace of a
31615: silent tear. Pride was broken down between these two.
31616: 
31617: “We were talking about your husband,” Dorothea said, with some
31618: timidity. “I thought his looks were sadly changed with suffering the
31619: other day. I had not seen him for many weeks before. He said he had
31620: been feeling very lonely in his trial; but I think he would have borne
31621: it all better if he had been able to be quite open with you.”
31622: 
31623: “Tertius is so angry and impatient if I say anything,” said Rosamond,
31624: imagining that he had been complaining of her to Dorothea. “He ought
31625: not to wonder that I object to speak to him on painful subjects.”
31626: 
31627: “It was himself he blamed for not speaking,” said Dorothea. “What he
31628: said of you was, that he could not be happy in doing anything which
31629: made you unhappy—that his marriage was of course a bond which must
31630: affect his choice about everything; and for that reason he refused my
31631: proposal that he should keep his position at the Hospital, because that
31632: would bind him to stay in Middlemarch, and he would not undertake to do
31633: anything which would be painful to you. He could say that to me,
31634: because he knows that I had much trial in my marriage, from my
31635: husband’s illness, which hindered his plans and saddened him; and he
31636: knows that I have felt how hard it is to walk always in fear of hurting
31637: another who is tied to us.”
31638: 
31639: Dorothea waited a little; she had discerned a faint pleasure stealing
31640: over Rosamond’s face. But there was no answer, and she went on, with a
31641: gathering tremor, “Marriage is so unlike everything else. There is
31642: something even awful in the nearness it brings. Even if we loved some
31643: one else better than—than those we were married to, it would be no
31644: use”—poor Dorothea, in her palpitating anxiety, could only seize her
31645: language brokenly—“I mean, marriage drinks up all our power of giving
31646: or getting any blessedness in that sort of love. I know it may be very
31647: dear—but it murders our marriage—and then the marriage stays with us
31648: like a murder—and everything else is gone. And then our husband—if he
31649: loved and trusted us, and we have not helped him, but made a curse in
31650: his life—”
31651: 
31652: Her voice had sunk very low: there was a dread upon her of presuming
31653: too far, and of speaking as if she herself were perfection addressing
31654: error. She was too much preoccupied with her own anxiety, to be aware
31655: that Rosamond was trembling too; and filled with the need to express
31656: pitying fellowship rather than rebuke, she put her hands on Rosamond’s,
31657: and said with more agitated rapidity,—“I know, I know that the feeling
31658: may be very dear—it has taken hold of us unawares—it is so hard, it may
31659: seem like death to part with it—and we are weak—I am weak—”
31660: 
31661: The waves of her own sorrow, from out of which she was struggling to
31662: save another, rushed over Dorothea with conquering force. She stopped
31663: in speechless agitation, not crying, but feeling as if she were being
31664: inwardly grappled. Her face had become of a deathlier paleness, her
31665: lips trembled, and she pressed her hands helplessly on the hands that
31666: lay under them.
31667: 
31668: Rosamond, taken hold of by an emotion stronger than her own—hurried
31669: along in a new movement which gave all things some new, awful,
31670: undefined aspect—could find no words, but involuntarily she put her
31671: lips to Dorothea’s forehead which was very near her, and then for a
31672: minute the two women clasped each other as if they had been in a
31673: shipwreck.
31674: 
31675: “You are thinking what is not true,” said Rosamond, in an eager
31676: half-whisper, while she was still feeling Dorothea’s arms round
31677: her—urged by a mysterious necessity to free herself from something that
31678: oppressed her as if it were blood guiltiness.
31679: 
31680: They moved apart, looking at each other.
31681: 
31682: “When you came in yesterday—it was not as you thought,” said Rosamond
31683: in the same tone.
31684: 
31685: There was a movement of surprised attention in Dorothea. She expected a
31686: vindication of Rosamond herself.
31687: 
31688: “He was telling me how he loved another woman, that I might know he
31689: could never love me,” said Rosamond, getting more and more hurried as
31690: she went on. “And now I think he hates me because—because you mistook
31691: him yesterday. He says it is through me that you will think ill of
31692: him—think that he is a false person. But it shall not be through me. He
31693: has never had any love for me—I know he has not—he has always thought
31694: slightly of me. He said yesterday that no other woman existed for him
31695: beside you. The blame of what happened is entirely mine. He said he
31696: could never explain to you—because of me. He said you could never think
31697: well of him again. But now I have told you, and he cannot reproach me
31698: any more.”
31699: 
31700: Rosamond had delivered her soul under impulses which she had not known
31701: before. She had begun her confession under the subduing influence of
31702: Dorothea’s emotion; and as she went on she had gathered the sense that
31703: she was repelling Will’s reproaches, which were still like a
31704: knife-wound within her.
31705: 
31706: The revulsion of feeling in Dorothea was too strong to be called joy.
31707: It was a tumult in which the terrible strain of the night and morning
31708: made a resistant pain:—she could only perceive that this would be joy
31709: when she had recovered her power of feeling it. Her immediate
31710: consciousness was one of immense sympathy without check; she cared for
31711: Rosamond without struggle now, and responded earnestly to her last
31712: words—
31713: 
31714: “No, he cannot reproach you any more.”
31715: 
31716: With her usual tendency to over-estimate the good in others, she felt a
31717: great outgoing of her heart towards Rosamond, for the generous effort
31718: which had redeemed her from suffering, not counting that the effort was
31719: a reflex of her own energy. After they had been silent a little, she
31720: said—
31721: 
31722: “You are not sorry that I came this morning?”
31723: 
31724: “No, you have been very good to me,” said Rosamond. “I did not think
31725: that you would be so good. I was very unhappy. I am not happy now.
31726: Everything is so sad.”
31727: 
31728: “But better days will come. Your husband will be rightly valued. And he
31729: depends on you for comfort. He loves you best. The worst loss would be
31730: to lose that—and you have not lost it,” said Dorothea.
31731: 
31732: She tried to thrust away the too overpowering thought of her own
31733: relief, lest she should fail to win some sign that Rosamond’s affection
31734: was yearning back towards her husband.
31735: 
31736: “Tertius did not find fault with me, then?” said Rosamond,
31737: understanding now that Lydgate might have said anything to Mrs.
31738: Casaubon, and that she certainly was different from other women.
31739: Perhaps there was a faint taste of jealousy in the question. A smile
31740: began to play over Dorothea’s face as she said—
31741: 
31742: “No, indeed! How could you imagine it?” But here the door opened, and
31743: Lydgate entered.
31744: 
31745: “I am come back in my quality of doctor,” he said. “After I went away,
31746: I was haunted by two pale faces: Mrs. Casaubon looked as much in need
31747: of care as you, Rosy. And I thought that I had not done my duty in
31748: leaving you together; so when I had been to Coleman’s I came home
31749: again. I noticed that you were walking, Mrs. Casaubon, and the sky has
31750: changed—I think we may have rain. May I send some one to order your
31751: carriage to come for you?”
31752: 
31753: “Oh, no! I am strong: I need the walk,” said Dorothea, rising with
31754: animation in her face. “Mrs. Lydgate and I have chatted a great deal,
31755: and it is time for me to go. I have always been accused of being
31756: immoderate and saying too much.”
31757: 
31758: She put out her hand to Rosamond, and they said an earnest, quiet
31759: good-by without kiss or other show of effusion: there had been between
31760: them too much serious emotion for them to use the signs of it
31761: superficially.
31762: 
31763: As Lydgate took her to the door she said nothing of Rosamond, but told
31764: him of Mr. Farebrother and the other friends who had listened with
31765: belief to his story.
31766: 
31767: When he came back to Rosamond, she had already thrown herself on the
31768: sofa, in resigned fatigue.
31769: 
31770: “Well, Rosy,” he said, standing over her, and touching her hair, “what
31771: do you think of Mrs. Casaubon now you have seen so much of her?”
31772: 
31773: “I think she must be better than any one,” said Rosamond, “and she is
31774: very beautiful. If you go to talk to her so often, you will be more
31775: discontented with me than ever!”
31776: 
31777: Lydgate laughed at the “so often.” “But has she made you any less
31778: discontented with me?”
31779: 
31780: “I think she has,” said Rosamond, looking up in his face. “How heavy
31781: your eyes are, Tertius—and do push your hair back.” He lifted up his
31782: large white hand to obey her, and felt thankful for this little mark of
31783: interest in him. Poor Rosamond’s vagrant fancy had come back terribly
31784: scourged—meek enough to nestle under the old despised shelter. And the
31785: shelter was still there: Lydgate had accepted his narrowed lot with sad
31786: resignation. He had chosen this fragile creature, and had taken the
31787: burthen of her life upon his arms. He must walk as he could, carrying
31788: that burthen pitifully.
31789: 
31790: 
31791: 
31792: 
31793: CHAPTER LXXXII.
31794: 
31795: “My grief lies onward and my joy behind.”
31796: —SHAKESPEARE: _Sonnets_.
31797: 
31798: 
31799: Exiles notoriously feed much on hopes, and are unlikely to stay in
31800: banishment unless they are obliged. When Will Ladislaw exiled himself
31801: from Middlemarch he had placed no stronger obstacle to his return than
31802: his own resolve, which was by no means an iron barrier, but simply a
31803: state of mind liable to melt into a minuet with other states of mind,
31804: and to find itself bowing, smiling, and giving place with polite
31805: facility. As the months went on, it had seemed more and more difficult
31806: to him to say why he should not run down to Middlemarch—merely for the
31807: sake of hearing something about Dorothea; and if on such a flying visit
31808: he should chance by some strange coincidence to meet with her, there
31809: was no reason for him to be ashamed of having taken an innocent journey
31810: which he had beforehand supposed that he should not take. Since he was
31811: hopelessly divided from her, he might surely venture into her
31812: neighborhood; and as to the suspicious friends who kept a dragon watch
31813: over her—their opinions seemed less and less important with time and
31814: change of air.
31815: 
31816: And there had come a reason quite irrespective of Dorothea, which
31817: seemed to make a journey to Middlemarch a sort of philanthropic duty.
31818: Will had given a disinterested attention to an intended settlement on a
31819: new plan in the Far West, and the need for funds in order to carry out
31820: a good design had set him on debating with himself whether it would not
31821: be a laudable use to make of his claim on Bulstrode, to urge the
31822: application of that money which had been offered to himself as a means
31823: of carrying out a scheme likely to be largely beneficial. The question
31824: seemed a very dubious one to Will, and his repugnance to again entering
31825: into any relation with the banker might have made him dismiss it
31826: quickly, if there had not arisen in his imagination the probability
31827: that his judgment might be more safely determined by a visit to
31828: Middlemarch.
31829: 
31830: That was the object which Will stated to himself as a reason for coming
31831: down. He had meant to confide in Lydgate, and discuss the money
31832: question with him, and he had meant to amuse himself for the few
31833: evenings of his stay by having a great deal of music and badinage with
31834: fair Rosamond, without neglecting his friends at Lowick Parsonage:—if
31835: the Parsonage was close to the Manor, that was no fault of his. He had
31836: neglected the Farebrothers before his departure, from a proud
31837: resistance to the possible accusation of indirectly seeking interviews
31838: with Dorothea; but hunger tames us, and Will had become very hungry for
31839: the vision of a certain form and the sound of a certain voice. Nothing
31840: had done instead—not the opera, or the converse of zealous politicians,
31841: or the flattering reception (in dim corners) of his new hand in leading
31842: articles.
31843: 
31844: Thus he had come down, foreseeing with confidence how almost everything
31845: would be in his familiar little world; fearing, indeed, that there
31846: would be no surprises in his visit. But he had found that humdrum world
31847: in a terribly dynamic condition, in which even badinage and lyrism had
31848: turned explosive; and the first day of this visit had become the most
31849: fatal epoch of his life. The next morning he felt so harassed with the
31850: nightmare of consequences—he dreaded so much the immediate issues
31851: before him—that seeing while he breakfasted the arrival of the
31852: Riverston coach, he went out hurriedly and took his place on it, that
31853: he might be relieved, at least for a day, from the necessity of doing
31854: or saying anything in Middlemarch. Will Ladislaw was in one of those
31855: tangled crises which are commoner in experience than one might imagine,
31856: from the shallow absoluteness of men’s judgments. He had found Lydgate,
31857: for whom he had the sincerest respect, under circumstances which
31858: claimed his thorough and frankly declared sympathy; and the reason why,
31859: in spite of that claim, it would have been better for Will to have
31860: avoided all further intimacy, or even contact, with Lydgate, was
31861: precisely of the kind to make such a course appear impossible. To a
31862: creature of Will’s susceptible temperament—without any neutral region
31863: of indifference in his nature, ready to turn everything that befell him
31864: into the collisions of a passionate drama—the revelation that Rosamond
31865: had made her happiness in any way dependent on him was a difficulty
31866: which his outburst of rage towards her had immeasurably increased for
31867: him. He hated his own cruelty, and yet he dreaded to show the fulness
31868: of his relenting: he must go to her again; the friendship could not be
31869: put to a sudden end; and her unhappiness was a power which he dreaded.
31870: And all the while there was no more foretaste of enjoyment in the life
31871: before him than if his limbs had been lopped off and he was making his
31872: fresh start on crutches. In the night he had debated whether he should
31873: not get on the coach, not for Riverston, but for London, leaving a note
31874: to Lydgate which would give a makeshift reason for his retreat. But
31875: there were strong cords pulling him back from that abrupt departure:
31876: the blight on his happiness in thinking of Dorothea, the crushing of
31877: that chief hope which had remained in spite of the acknowledged
31878: necessity for renunciation, was too fresh a misery for him to resign
31879: himself to it and go straightway into a distance which was also
31880: despair.
31881: 
31882: Thus he did nothing more decided than taking the Riverston coach. He
31883: came back again by it while it was still daylight, having made up his
31884: mind that he must go to Lydgate’s that evening. The Rubicon, we know,
31885: was a very insignificant stream to look at; its significance lay
31886: entirely in certain invisible conditions. Will felt as if he were
31887: forced to cross his small boundary ditch, and what he saw beyond it was
31888: not empire, but discontented subjection.
31889: 
31890: But it is given to us sometimes even in our every-day life to witness
31891: the saving influence of a noble nature, the divine efficacy of rescue
31892: that may lie in a self-subduing act of fellowship. If Dorothea, after
31893: her night’s anguish, had not taken that walk to Rosamond—why, she
31894: perhaps would have been a woman who gained a higher character for
31895: discretion, but it would certainly not have been as well for those
31896: three who were on one hearth in Lydgate’s house at half-past seven that
31897: evening.
31898: 
31899: Rosamond had been prepared for Will’s visit, and she received him with
31900: a languid coldness which Lydgate accounted for by her nervous
31901: exhaustion, of which he could not suppose that it had any relation to
31902: Will. And when she sat in silence bending over a bit of work, he
31903: innocently apologized for her in an indirect way by begging her to lean
31904: backward and rest. Will was miserable in the necessity for playing the
31905: part of a friend who was making his first appearance and greeting to
31906: Rosamond, while his thoughts were busy about her feeling since that
31907: scene of yesterday, which seemed still inexorably to enclose them both,
31908: like the painful vision of a double madness. It happened that nothing
31909: called Lydgate out of the room; but when Rosamond poured out the tea,
31910: and Will came near to fetch it, she placed a tiny bit of folded paper
31911: in his saucer. He saw it and secured it quickly, but as he went back to
31912: his inn he had no eagerness to unfold the paper. What Rosamond had
31913: written to him would probably deepen the painful impressions of the
31914: evening. Still, he opened and read it by his bed-candle. There were
31915: only these few words in her neatly flowing hand:—
31916: 
31917: “I have told Mrs. Casaubon. She is not under any mistake about you. I
31918: told her because she came to see me and was very kind. You will have
31919: nothing to reproach me with now. I shall not have made any difference
31920: to you.”
31921: 
31922: The effect of these words was not quite all gladness. As Will dwelt on
31923: them with excited imagination, he felt his cheeks and ears burning at
31924: the thought of what had occurred between Dorothea and Rosamond—at the
31925: uncertainty how far Dorothea might still feel her dignity wounded in
31926: having an explanation of his conduct offered to her. There might still
31927: remain in her mind a changed association with him which made an
31928: irremediable difference—a lasting flaw. With active fancy he wrought
31929: himself into a state of doubt little more easy than that of the man who
31930: has escaped from wreck by night and stands on unknown ground in the
31931: darkness. Until that wretched yesterday—except the moment of vexation
31932: long ago in the very same room and in the very same presence—all their
31933: vision, all their thought of each other, had been as in a world apart,
31934: where the sunshine fell on tall white lilies, where no evil lurked, and
31935: no other soul entered. But now—would Dorothea meet him in that world
31936: again?
31937:
