31941: CHAPTER LXXXIII.
31942: 
31943: “And now good-morrow to our waking souls
31944: Which watch not one another out of fear;
31945: For love all love of other sights controls,
31946: And makes one little room, an everywhere.”
31947: —DR. DONNE.
31948: 
31949: 
31950: On the second morning after Dorothea’s visit to Rosamond, she had had
31951: two nights of sound sleep, and had not only lost all traces of fatigue,
31952: but felt as if she had a great deal of superfluous strength—that is to
31953: say, more strength than she could manage to concentrate on any
31954: occupation. The day before, she had taken long walks outside the
31955: grounds, and had paid two visits to the Parsonage; but she never in her
31956: life told any one the reason why she spent her time in that fruitless
31957: manner, and this morning she was rather angry with herself for her
31958: childish restlessness. To-day was to be spent quite differently. What
31959: was there to be done in the village? Oh dear! nothing. Everybody was
31960: well and had flannel; nobody’s pig had died; and it was Saturday
31961: morning, when there was a general scrubbing of doors and door-stones,
31962: and when it was useless to go into the school. But there were various
31963: subjects that Dorothea was trying to get clear upon, and she resolved
31964: to throw herself energetically into the gravest of all. She sat down in
31965: the library before her particular little heap of books on political
31966: economy and kindred matters, out of which she was trying to get light
31967: as to the best way of spending money so as not to injure one’s
31968: neighbors, or—what comes to the same thing—so as to do them the most
31969: good. Here was a weighty subject which, if she could but lay hold of
31970: it, would certainly keep her mind steady. Unhappily her mind slipped
31971: off it for a whole hour; and at the end she found herself reading
31972: sentences twice over with an intense consciousness of many things, but
31973: not of any one thing contained in the text. This was hopeless. Should
31974: she order the carriage and drive to Tipton? No; for some reason or
31975: other she preferred staying at Lowick. But her vagrant mind must be
31976: reduced to order: there was an art in self-discipline; and she walked
31977: round and round the brown library considering by what sort of manoeuvre
31978: she could arrest her wandering thoughts. Perhaps a mere task was the
31979: best means—something to which she must go doggedly. Was there not the
31980: geography of Asia Minor, in which her slackness had often been rebuked
31981: by Mr. Casaubon? She went to the cabinet of maps and unrolled one: this
31982: morning she might make herself finally sure that Paphlagonia was not on
31983: the Levantine coast, and fix her total darkness about the Chalybes
31984: firmly on the shores of the Euxine. A map was a fine thing to study
31985: when you were disposed to think of something else, being made up of
31986: names that would turn into a chime if you went back upon them. Dorothea
31987: set earnestly to work, bending close to her map, and uttering the names
31988: in an audible, subdued tone, which often got into a chime. She looked
31989: amusingly girlish after all her deep experience—nodding her head and
31990: marking the names off on her fingers, with a little pursing of her lip,
31991: and now and then breaking off to put her hands on each side of her face
31992: and say, “Oh dear! oh dear!”
31993: 
31994: There was no reason why this should end any more than a merry-go-round;
31995: but it was at last interrupted by the opening of the door and the
31996: announcement of Miss Noble.
31997: 
31998: The little old lady, whose bonnet hardly reached Dorothea’s shoulder,
31999: was warmly welcomed, but while her hand was being pressed she made many
32000: of her beaver-like noises, as if she had something difficult to say.
32001: 
32002: “Do sit down,” said Dorothea, rolling a chair forward. “Am I wanted for
32003: anything? I shall be so glad if I can do anything.”
32004: 
32005: “I will not stay,” said Miss Noble, putting her hand into her small
32006: basket, and holding some article inside it nervously; “I have left a
32007: friend in the churchyard.” She lapsed into her inarticulate sounds, and
32008: unconsciously drew forth the article which she was fingering. It was
32009: the tortoise-shell lozenge-box, and Dorothea felt the color mounting to
32010: her cheeks.
32011: 
32012: “Mr. Ladislaw,” continued the timid little woman. “He fears he has
32013: offended you, and has begged me to ask if you will see him for a few
32014: minutes.”
32015: 
32016: Dorothea did not answer on the instant: it was crossing her mind that
32017: she could not receive him in this library, where her husband’s
32018: prohibition seemed to dwell. She looked towards the window. Could she
32019: go out and meet him in the grounds? The sky was heavy, and the trees
32020: had begun to shiver as at a coming storm. Besides, she shrank from
32021: going out to him.
32022: 
32023: “Do see him, Mrs. Casaubon,” said Miss Noble, pathetically; “else I
32024: must go back and say No, and that will hurt him.”
32025: 
32026: “Yes, I will see him,” said Dorothea. “Pray tell him to come.”
32027: 
32028: What else was there to be done? There was nothing that she longed for
32029: at that moment except to see Will: the possibility of seeing him had
32030: thrust itself insistently between her and every other object; and yet
32031: she had a throbbing excitement like an alarm upon her—a sense that she
32032: was doing something daringly defiant for his sake.
32033: 
32034: When the little lady had trotted away on her mission, Dorothea stood in
32035: the middle of the library with her hands falling clasped before her,
32036: making no attempt to compose herself in an attitude of dignified
32037: unconsciousness. What she was least conscious of just then was her own
32038: body: she was thinking of what was likely to be in Will’s mind, and of
32039: the hard feelings that others had had about him. How could any duty
32040: bind her to hardness? Resistance to unjust dispraise had mingled with
32041: her feeling for him from the very first, and now in the rebound of her
32042: heart after her anguish the resistance was stronger than ever. “If I
32043: love him too much it is because he has been used so ill:”—there was a
32044: voice within her saying this to some imagined audience in the library,
32045: when the door was opened, and she saw Will before her.
32046: 
32047: She did not move, and he came towards her with more doubt and timidity
32048: in his face than she had ever seen before. He was in a state of
32049: uncertainty which made him afraid lest some look or word of his should
32050: condemn him to a new distance from her; and Dorothea was afraid of her
32051: _own_ emotion. She looked as if there were a spell upon her, keeping
32052: her motionless and hindering her from unclasping her hands, while some
32053: intense, grave yearning was imprisoned within her eyes. Seeing that she
32054: did not put out her hand as usual, Will paused a yard from her and said
32055: with embarrassment, “I am so grateful to you for seeing me.”
32056: 
32057: “I wanted to see you,” said Dorothea, having no other words at command.
32058: It did not occur to her to sit down, and Will did not give a cheerful
32059: interpretation to this queenly way of receiving him; but he went on to
32060: say what he had made up his mind to say.
32061: 
32062: “I fear you think me foolish and perhaps wrong for coming back so soon.
32063: I have been punished for my impatience. You know—every one knows now—a
32064: painful story about my parentage. I knew of it before I went away, and
32065: I always meant to tell you of it if—if we ever met again.”
32066: 
32067: There was a slight movement in Dorothea, and she unclasped her hands,
32068: but immediately folded them over each other.
32069: 
32070: “But the affair is matter of gossip now,” Will continued. “I wished you
32071: to know that something connected with it—something which happened
32072: before I went away, helped to bring me down here again. At least I
32073: thought it excused my coming. It was the idea of getting Bulstrode to
32074: apply some money to a public purpose—some money which he had thought of
32075: giving me. Perhaps it is rather to Bulstrode’s credit that he privately
32076: offered me compensation for an old injury: he offered to give me a good
32077: income to make amends; but I suppose you know the disagreeable story?”
32078: 
32079: Will looked doubtfully at Dorothea, but his manner was gathering some
32080: of the defiant courage with which he always thought of this fact in his
32081: destiny. He added, “You know that it must be altogether painful to me.”
32082: 
32083: “Yes—yes—I know,” said Dorothea, hastily.
32084: 
32085: “I did not choose to accept an income from such a source. I was sure
32086: that you would not think well of me if I did so,” said Will. Why should
32087: he mind saying anything of that sort to her now? She knew that he had
32088: avowed his love for her. “I felt that”—he broke off, nevertheless.
32089: 
32090: “You acted as I should have expected you to act,” said Dorothea, her
32091: face brightening and her head becoming a little more erect on its
32092: beautiful stem.
32093: 
32094: “I did not believe that you would let any circumstance of my birth
32095: create a prejudice in you against me, though it was sure to do so in
32096: others,” said Will, shaking his head backward in his old way, and
32097: looking with a grave appeal into her eyes.
32098: 
32099: “If it were a new hardship it would be a new reason for me to cling to
32100: you,” said Dorothea, fervidly. “Nothing could have changed me but—” her
32101: heart was swelling, and it was difficult to go on; she made a great
32102: effort over herself to say in a low tremulous voice, “but thinking that
32103: you were different—not so good as I had believed you to be.”
32104: 
32105: “You are sure to believe me better than I am in everything but one,”
32106: said Will, giving way to his own feeling in the evidence of hers. “I
32107: mean, in my truth to you. When I thought you doubted of that, I didn’t
32108: care about anything that was left. I thought it was all over with me,
32109: and there was nothing to try for—only things to endure.”
32110: 
32111: “I don’t doubt you any longer,” said Dorothea, putting out her hand; a
32112: vague fear for him impelling her unutterable affection.
32113: 
32114: He took her hand and raised it to his lips with something like a sob.
32115: But he stood with his hat and gloves in the other hand, and might have
32116: done for the portrait of a Royalist. Still it was difficult to loose
32117: the hand, and Dorothea, withdrawing it in a confusion that distressed
32118: her, looked and moved away.
32119: 
32120: “See how dark the clouds have become, and how the trees are tossed,”
32121: she said, walking towards the window, yet speaking and moving with only
32122: a dim sense of what she was doing.
32123: 
32124: Will followed her at a little distance, and leaned against the tall
32125: back of a leather chair, on which he ventured now to lay his hat and
32126: gloves, and free himself from the intolerable durance of formality to
32127: which he had been for the first time condemned in Dorothea’s presence.
32128: It must be confessed that he felt very happy at that moment leaning on
32129: the chair. He was not much afraid of anything that she might feel now.
32130: 
32131: They stood silent, not looking at each other, but looking at the
32132: evergreens which were being tossed, and were showing the pale underside
32133: of their leaves against the blackening sky. Will never enjoyed the
32134: prospect of a storm so much: it delivered him from the necessity of
32135: going away. Leaves and little branches were hurled about, and the
32136: thunder was getting nearer. The light was more and more sombre, but
32137: there came a flash of lightning which made them start and look at each
32138: other, and then smile. Dorothea began to say what she had been thinking
32139: of.
32140: 
32141: “That was a wrong thing for you to say, that you would have had nothing
32142: to try for. If we had lost our own chief good, other people’s good
32143: would remain, and that is worth trying for. Some can be happy. I seemed
32144: to see that more clearly than ever, when I was the most wretched. I can
32145: hardly think how I could have borne the trouble, if that feeling had
32146: not come to me to make strength.”
32147: 
32148: “You have never felt the sort of misery I felt,” said Will; “the misery
32149: of knowing that you must despise me.”
32150: 
32151: “But I have felt worse—it was worse to think ill—” Dorothea had begun
32152: impetuously, but broke off.
32153: 
32154: Will colored. He had the sense that whatever she said was uttered in
32155: the vision of a fatality that kept them apart. He was silent a moment,
32156: and then said passionately—
32157: 
32158: “We may at least have the comfort of speaking to each other without
32159: disguise. Since I must go away—since we must always be divided—you may
32160: think of me as one on the brink of the grave.”
32161: 
32162: While he was speaking there came a vivid flash of lightning which lit
32163: each of them up for the other—and the light seemed to be the terror of
32164: a hopeless love. Dorothea darted instantaneously from the window; Will
32165: followed her, seizing her hand with a spasmodic movement; and so they
32166: stood, with their hands clasped, like two children, looking out on the
32167: storm, while the thunder gave a tremendous crack and roll above them,
32168: and the rain began to pour down. Then they turned their faces towards
32169: each other, with the memory of his last words in them, and they did not
32170: loose each other’s hands.
32171: 
32172: “There is no hope for me,” said Will. “Even if you loved me as well as
32173: I love you—even if I were everything to you—I shall most likely always
32174: be very poor: on a sober calculation, one can count on nothing but a
32175: creeping lot. It is impossible for us ever to belong to each other. It
32176: is perhaps base of me to have asked for a word from you. I meant to go
32177: away into silence, but I have not been able to do what I meant.”
32178: 
32179: “Don’t be sorry,” said Dorothea, in her clear tender tones. “I would
32180: rather share all the trouble of our parting.”
32181: 
32182: Her lips trembled, and so did his. It was never known which lips were
32183: the first to move towards the other lips; but they kissed tremblingly,
32184: and then they moved apart.
32185: 
32186: The rain was dashing against the window-panes as if an angry spirit
32187: were within it, and behind it was the great swoop of the wind; it was
32188: one of those moments in which both the busy and the idle pause with a
32189: certain awe.
32190: 
32191: Dorothea sat down on the seat nearest to her, a long low ottoman in the
32192: middle of the room, and with her hands folded over each other on her
32193: lap, looked at the drear outer world. Will stood still an instant
32194: looking at her, then seated himself beside her, and laid his hand on
32195: hers, which turned itself upward to be clasped. They sat in that way
32196: without looking at each other, until the rain abated and began to fall
32197: in stillness. Each had been full of thoughts which neither of them
32198: could begin to utter.
32199: 
32200: But when the rain was quiet, Dorothea turned to look at Will. With
32201: passionate exclamation, as if some torture screw were threatening him,
32202: he started up and said, “It is impossible!”
32203: 
32204: He went and leaned on the back of the chair again, and seemed to be
32205: battling with his own anger, while she looked towards him sadly.
32206: 
32207: “It is as fatal as a murder or any other horror that divides people,”
32208: he burst out again; “it is more intolerable—to have our life maimed by
32209: petty accidents.”
32210: 
32211: “No—don’t say that—your life need not be maimed,” said Dorothea,
32212: gently.
32213: 
32214: “Yes, it must,” said Will, angrily. “It is cruel of you to speak in
32215: that way—as if there were any comfort. You may see beyond the misery of
32216: it, but I don’t. It is unkind—it is throwing back my love for you as if
32217: it were a trifle, to speak in that way in the face of the fact. We can
32218: never be married.”
32219: 
32220: “Some time—we might,” said Dorothea, in a trembling voice.
32221: 
32222: “When?” said Will, bitterly. “What is the use of counting on any
32223: success of mine? It is a mere toss up whether I shall ever do more than
32224: keep myself decently, unless I choose to sell myself as a mere pen and
32225: a mouthpiece. I can see that clearly enough. I could not offer myself
32226: to any woman, even if she had no luxuries to renounce.”
32227: 
32228: There was silence. Dorothea’s heart was full of something that she
32229: wanted to say, and yet the words were too difficult. She was wholly
32230: possessed by them: at that moment debate was mute within her. And it
32231: was very hard that she could not say what she wanted to say. Will was
32232: looking out of the window angrily. If he would have looked at her and
32233: not gone away from her side, she thought everything would have been
32234: easier. At last he turned, still resting against the chair, and
32235: stretching his hand automatically towards his hat, said with a sort of
32236: exasperation, “Good-by.”
32237: 
32238: “Oh, I cannot bear it—my heart will break,” said Dorothea, starting
32239: from her seat, the flood of her young passion bearing down all the
32240: obstructions which had kept her silent—the great tears rising and
32241: falling in an instant: “I don’t mind about poverty—I hate my wealth.”
32242: 
32243: In an instant Will was close to her and had his arms round her, but she
32244: drew her head back and held his away gently that she might go on
32245: speaking, her large tear-filled eyes looking at his very simply, while
32246: she said in a sobbing childlike way, “We could live quite well on my
32247: own fortune—it is too much—seven hundred a-year—I want so little—no new
32248: clothes—and I will learn what everything costs.”

32253: CHAPTER LXXXIV.
32254: 
32255: “Though it be songe of old and yonge,
32256:     That I sholde be to blame,
32257: Theyrs be the charge, that spoke so large
32258:     In hurtynge of my name.”
32259: —_The Not-Browne Mayde_.
32260: 
32261: 
32262: It was just after the Lords had thrown out the Reform Bill: that
32263: explains how Mr. Cadwallader came to be walking on the slope of the
32264: lawn near the great conservatory at Freshitt Hall, holding the “Times”
32265: in his hands behind him, while he talked with a trout-fisher’s
32266: dispassionateness about the prospects of the country to Sir James
32267: Chettam. Mrs. Cadwallader, the Dowager Lady Chettam, and Celia were
32268: sometimes seated on garden-chairs, sometimes walking to meet little
32269: Arthur, who was being drawn in his chariot, and, as became the
32270: infantine Bouddha, was sheltered by his sacred umbrella with handsome
32271: silken fringe.
32272: 
32273: The ladies also talked politics, though more fitfully. Mrs. Cadwallader
32274: was strong on the intended creation of peers: she had it for certain
32275: from her cousin that Truberry had gone over to the other side entirely
32276: at the instigation of his wife, who had scented peerages in the air
32277: from the very first introduction of the Reform question, and would sign
32278: her soul away to take precedence of her younger sister, who had married
32279: a baronet. Lady Chettam thought that such conduct was very
32280: reprehensible, and remembered that Mrs. Truberry’s mother was a Miss
32281: Walsingham of Melspring. Celia confessed it was nicer to be “Lady” than
32282: “Mrs.,” and that Dodo never minded about precedence if she could have
32283: her own way. Mrs. Cadwallader held that it was a poor satisfaction to
32284: take precedence when everybody about you knew that you had not a drop
32285: of good blood in your veins; and Celia again, stopping to look at
32286: Arthur, said, “It would be very nice, though, if he were a Viscount—and
32287: his lordship’s little tooth coming through! He might have been, if
32288: James had been an Earl.”
32289: 
32290: “My dear Celia,” said the Dowager, “James’s title is worth far more
32291: than any new earldom. I never wished his father to be anything else
32292: than Sir James.”
32293: 
32294: “Oh, I only meant about Arthur’s little tooth,” said Celia,
32295: comfortably. “But see, here is my uncle coming.”
32296: 
32297: She tripped off to meet her uncle, while Sir James and Mr. Cadwallader
32298: came forward to make one group with the ladies. Celia had slipped her
32299: arm through her uncle’s, and he patted her hand with a rather
32300: melancholy “Well, my dear!” As they approached, it was evident that Mr.
32301: Brooke was looking dejected, but this was fully accounted for by the
32302: state of politics; and as he was shaking hands all round without more
32303: greeting than a “Well, you’re all here, you know,” the Rector said,
32304: laughingly—
32305: 
32306: “Don’t take the throwing out of the Bill so much to heart, Brooke;
32307: you’ve got all the riff-raff of the country on your side.”
32308: 
32309: “The Bill, eh? ah!” said Mr. Brooke, with a mild distractedness of
32310: manner. “Thrown out, you know, eh? The Lords are going too far, though.
32311: They’ll have to pull up. Sad news, you know. I mean, here at home—sad
32312: news. But you must not blame me, Chettam.”
32313: 
32314: “What is the matter?” said Sir James. “Not another gamekeeper shot, I
32315: hope? It’s what I should expect, when a fellow like Trapping Bass is
32316: let off so easily.”
32317: 
32318: “Gamekeeper? No. Let us go in; I can tell you all in the house, you
32319: know,” said Mr. Brooke, nodding at the Cadwalladers, to show that he
32320: included them in his confidence. “As to poachers like Trapping Bass,
32321: you know, Chettam,” he continued, as they were entering, “when you are
32322: a magistrate, you’ll not find it so easy to commit. Severity is all
32323: very well, but it’s a great deal easier when you’ve got somebody to do
32324: it for you. You have a soft place in your heart yourself, you
32325: know—you’re not a Draco, a Jeffreys, that sort of thing.”
32326: 
32327: Mr. Brooke was evidently in a state of nervous perturbation. When he
32328: had something painful to tell, it was usually his way to introduce it
32329: among a number of disjointed particulars, as if it were a medicine that
32330: would get a milder flavor by mixing. He continued his chat with Sir
32331: James about the poachers until they were all seated, and Mrs.
32332: Cadwallader, impatient of this drivelling, said—
32333: 
32334: “I’m dying to know the sad news. The gamekeeper is not shot: that is
32335: settled. What is it, then?”
32336: 
32337: “Well, it’s a very trying thing, you know,” said Mr. Brooke. “I’m glad
32338: you and the Rector are here; it’s a family matter—but you will help us
32339: all to bear it, Cadwallader. I’ve got to break it to you, my dear.”
32340: Here Mr. Brooke looked at Celia—“You’ve no notion what it is, you know.
32341: And, Chettam, it will annoy you uncommonly—but, you see, you have not
32342: been able to hinder it, any more than I have. There’s something
32343: singular in things: they come round, you know.”
32344: 
32345: “It must be about Dodo,” said Celia, who had been used to think of her
32346: sister as the dangerous part of the family machinery. She had seated
32347: herself on a low stool against her husband’s knee.
32348: 
32349: “For God’s sake let us hear what it is!” said Sir James.
32350: 
32351: “Well, you know, Chettam, I couldn’t help Casaubon’s will: it was a
32352: sort of will to make things worse.”
32353: 
32354: “Exactly,” said Sir James, hastily. “But _what_ is worse?”
32355: 
32356: “Dorothea is going to be married again, you know,” said Mr. Brooke,
32357: nodding towards Celia, who immediately looked up at her husband with a
32358: frightened glance, and put her hand on his knee. Sir James was almost
32359: white with anger, but he did not speak.
32360: 
32361: “Merciful heaven!” said Mrs. Cadwallader. “Not to _young_ Ladislaw?”
32362: 
32363: Mr. Brooke nodded, saying, “Yes; to Ladislaw,” and then fell into a
32364: prudential silence.
32365: 
32366: “You see, Humphrey!” said Mrs. Cadwallader, waving her arm towards her
32367: husband. “Another time you will admit that I have some foresight; or
32368: rather you will contradict me and be just as blind as ever. _You_
32369: supposed that the young gentleman was gone out of the country.”
32370: 
32371: “So he might be, and yet come back,” said the Rector, quietly.
32372: 
32373: “When did you learn this?” said Sir James, not liking to hear any one
32374: else speak, though finding it difficult to speak himself.
32375: 
32376: “Yesterday,” said Mr. Brooke, meekly. “I went to Lowick. Dorothea sent
32377: for me, you know. It had come about quite suddenly—neither of them had
32378: any idea two days ago—not any idea, you know. There’s something
32379: singular in things. But Dorothea is quite determined—it is no use
32380: opposing. I put it strongly to her. I did my duty, Chettam. But she can
32381: act as she likes, you know.”
32382: 
32383: “It would have been better if I had called him out and shot him a year
32384: ago,” said Sir James, not from bloody-mindedness, but because he needed
32385: something strong to say.
32386: 
32387: “Really, James, that would have been very disagreeable,” said Celia.
32388: 
32389: “Be reasonable, Chettam. Look at the affair more quietly,” said Mr.
32390: Cadwallader, sorry to see his good-natured friend so overmastered by
32391: anger.
32392: 
32393: “That is not so very easy for a man of any dignity—with any sense of
32394: right—when the affair happens to be in his own family,” said Sir James,
32395: still in his white indignation. “It is perfectly scandalous. If
32396: Ladislaw had had a spark of honor he would have gone out of the country
32397: at once, and never shown his face in it again. However, I am not
32398: surprised. The day after Casaubon’s funeral I said what ought to be
32399: done. But I was not listened to.”
32400: 
32401: “You wanted what was impossible, you know, Chettam,” said Mr. Brooke.
32402: “You wanted him shipped off. I told you Ladislaw was not to be done as
32403: we liked with: he had his ideas. He was a remarkable fellow—I always
32404: said he was a remarkable fellow.”
32405: 
32406: “Yes,” said Sir James, unable to repress a retort, “it is rather a pity
32407: you formed that high opinion of him. We are indebted to that for his
32408: being lodged in this neighborhood. We are indebted to that for seeing a
32409: woman like Dorothea degrading herself by marrying him.” Sir James made
32410: little stoppages between his clauses, the words not coming easily. “A
32411: man so marked out by her husband’s will, that delicacy ought to have
32412: forbidden her from seeing him again—who takes her out of her proper
32413: rank—into poverty—has the meanness to accept such a sacrifice—has
32414: always had an objectionable position—a bad origin—and, _I believe_, is
32415: a man of little principle and light character. That is my opinion.” Sir
32416: James ended emphatically, turning aside and crossing his leg.
32417: 
32418: “I pointed everything out to her,” said Mr. Brooke, apologetically—“I
32419: mean the poverty, and abandoning her position. I said, ‘My dear, you
32420: don’t know what it is to live on seven hundred a-year, and have no
32421: carriage, and that kind of thing, and go amongst people who don’t know
32422: who you are.’ I put it strongly to her. But I advise you to talk to
32423: Dorothea herself. The fact is, she has a dislike to Casaubon’s
32424: property. You will hear what she says, you know.”
32425: 
32426: “No—excuse me—I shall not,” said Sir James, with more coolness. “I
32427: cannot bear to see her again; it is too painful. It hurts me too much
32428: that a woman like Dorothea should have done what is wrong.”
32429: 
32430: “Be just, Chettam,” said the easy, large-lipped Rector, who objected to
32431: all this unnecessary discomfort. “Mrs. Casaubon may be acting
32432: imprudently: she is giving up a fortune for the sake of a man, and we
32433: men have so poor an opinion of each other that we can hardly call a
32434: woman wise who does that. But I think you should not condemn it as a
32435: wrong action, in the strict sense of the word.”
32436: 
32437: “Yes, I do,” answered Sir James. “I think that Dorothea commits a wrong
32438: action in marrying Ladislaw.”
32439: 
32440: “My dear fellow, we are rather apt to consider an act wrong because it
32441: is unpleasant to us,” said the Rector, quietly. Like many men who take
32442: life easily, he had the knack of saying a home truth occasionally to
32443: those who felt themselves virtuously out of temper. Sir James took out
32444: his handkerchief and began to bite the corner.
32445: 
32446: “It is very dreadful of Dodo, though,” said Celia, wishing to justify
32447: her husband. “She said she _never would_ marry again—not anybody at
32448: all.”
32449: 
32450: “I heard her say the same thing myself,” said Lady Chettam,
32451: majestically, as if this were royal evidence.
32452: 
32453: “Oh, there is usually a silent exception in such cases,” said Mrs.
32454: Cadwallader. “The only wonder to me is, that any of you are surprised.
32455: You did nothing to hinder it. If you would have had Lord Triton down
32456: here to woo her with his philanthropy, he might have carried her off
32457: before the year was over. There was no safety in anything else. Mr.
32458: Casaubon had prepared all this as beautifully as possible. He made
32459: himself disagreeable—or it pleased God to make him so—and then he dared
32460: her to contradict him. It’s the way to make any trumpery tempting, to
32461: ticket it at a high price in that way.”
32462: 
32463: “I don’t know what you mean by wrong, Cadwallader,” said Sir James,
32464: still feeling a little stung, and turning round in his chair towards
32465: the Rector. “He’s not a man we can take into the family. At least, I
32466: must speak for myself,” he continued, carefully keeping his eyes off
32467: Mr. Brooke. “I suppose others will find his society too pleasant to
32468: care about the propriety of the thing.”
32469: 
32470: “Well, you know, Chettam,” said Mr. Brooke, good-humoredly, nursing his
32471: leg, “I can’t turn my back on Dorothea. I must be a father to her up to
32472: a certain point. I said, ‘My dear, I won’t refuse to give you away.’ I
32473: had spoken strongly before. But I can cut off the entail, you know. It
32474: will cost money and be troublesome; but I can do it, you know.”
32475: 
32476: Mr. Brooke nodded at Sir James, and felt that he was both showing his
32477: own force of resolution and propitiating what was just in the Baronet’s
32478: vexation. He had hit on a more ingenious mode of parrying than he was
32479: aware of. He had touched a motive of which Sir James was ashamed. The
32480: mass of his feeling about Dorothea’s marriage to Ladislaw was due
32481: partly to excusable prejudice, or even justifiable opinion, partly to a
32482: jealous repugnance hardly less in Ladislaw’s case than in Casaubon’s.
32483: He was convinced that the marriage was a fatal one for Dorothea. But
32484: amid that mass ran a vein of which he was too good and honorable a man
32485: to like the avowal even to himself: it was undeniable that the union of
32486: the two estates—Tipton and Freshitt—lying charmingly within a
32487: ring-fence, was a prospect that flattered him for his son and heir.
32488: Hence when Mr. Brooke noddingly appealed to that motive, Sir James felt
32489: a sudden embarrassment; there was a stoppage in his throat; he even
32490: blushed. He had found more words than usual in the first jet of his
32491: anger, but Mr. Brooke’s propitiation was more clogging to his tongue
32492: than Mr. Cadwallader’s caustic hint.
32493: 
32494: But Celia was glad to have room for speech after her uncle’s suggestion
32495: of the marriage ceremony, and she said, though with as little eagerness
32496: of manner as if the question had turned on an invitation to dinner, “Do
32497: you mean that Dodo is going to be married directly, uncle?”
32498: 
32499: “In three weeks, you know,” said Mr. Brooke, helplessly. “I can do
32500: nothing to hinder it, Cadwallader,” he added, turning for a little
32501: countenance toward the Rector, who said—
32502: 
32503: “_I_ should not make any fuss about it. If she likes to be poor, that
32504: is her affair. Nobody would have said anything if she had married the
32505: young fellow because he was rich. Plenty of beneficed clergy are poorer
32506: than they will be. Here is Elinor,” continued the provoking husband;
32507: “she vexed her friends by me: I had hardly a thousand a-year—I was a
32508: lout—nobody could see anything in me—my shoes were not the right
32509: cut—all the men wondered how a woman could like me. Upon my word, I
32510: must take Ladislaw’s part until I hear more harm of him.”
32511: 
32512: “Humphrey, that is all sophistry, and you know it,” said his wife.
32513: “Everything is all one—that is the beginning and end with you. As if
32514: you had not been a Cadwallader! Does any one suppose that I would have
32515: taken such a monster as you by any other name?”
32516: 
32517: “And a clergyman too,” observed Lady Chettam with approbation. “Elinor
32518: cannot be said to have descended below her rank. It is difficult to say
32519: what Mr. Ladislaw is, eh, James?”
32520: 
32521: Sir James gave a small grunt, which was less respectful than his usual
32522: mode of answering his mother. Celia looked up at him like a thoughtful
32523: kitten.
32524: 
32525: “It must be admitted that his blood is a frightful mixture!” said Mrs.
32526: Cadwallader. “The Casaubon cuttle-fish fluid to begin with, and then a
32527: rebellious Polish fiddler or dancing-master, was it?—and then an old
32528: clo—”
32529: 
32530: “Nonsense, Elinor,” said the Rector, rising. “It is time for us to go.”
32531: 
32532: “After all, he is a pretty sprig,” said Mrs. Cadwallader, rising too,
32533: and wishing to make amends. “He is like the fine old Crichley portraits
32534: before the idiots came in.”
32535: 
32536: “I’ll go with you,” said Mr. Brooke, starting up with alacrity. “You
32537: must all come and dine with me to-morrow, you know—eh, Celia, my dear?”
32538: 
32539: “You will, James—won’t you?” said Celia, taking her husband’s hand.
32540: 
32541: “Oh, of course, if you like,” said Sir James, pulling down his
32542: waistcoat, but unable yet to adjust his face good-humoredly. “That is
32543: to say, if it is not to meet anybody else.”
32544: 
32545: “No, no, no,” said Mr. Brooke, understanding the condition. “Dorothea
32546: would not come, you know, unless you had been to see her.”
32547: 
32548: When Sir James and Celia were alone, she said, “Do you mind about my
32549: having the carriage to go to Lowick, James?”
32550: 
32551: “What, now, directly?” he answered, with some surprise.
32552: 
32553: “Yes, it is very important,” said Celia.
32554: 
32555: “Remember, Celia, I cannot see her,” said Sir James.
32556: 
32557: “Not if she gave up marrying?”
32558: 
32559: “What is the use of saying that?—however, I’m going to the stables.
32560: I’ll tell Briggs to bring the carriage round.”
32561: 
32562: Celia thought it was of great use, if not to say that, at least to take
32563: a journey to Lowick in order to influence Dorothea’s mind. All through
32564: their girlhood she had felt that she could act on her sister by a word
32565: judiciously placed—by opening a little window for the daylight of her
32566: own understanding to enter among the strange colored lamps by which
32567: Dodo habitually saw. And Celia the matron naturally felt more able to
32568: advise her childless sister. How could any one understand Dodo so well
32569: as Celia did or love her so tenderly?
32570: 
32571: Dorothea, busy in her boudoir, felt a glow of pleasure at the sight of
32572: her sister so soon after the revelation of her intended marriage. She
32573: had prefigured to herself, even with exaggeration, the disgust of her
32574: friends, and she had even feared that Celia might be kept aloof from
32575: her.
32576: 
32577: “O Kitty, I am delighted to see you!” said Dorothea, putting her hands
32578: on Celia’s shoulders, and beaming on her. “I almost thought you would
32579: not come to me.”
32580: 
32581: “I have not brought Arthur, because I was in a hurry,” said Celia, and
32582: they sat down on two small chairs opposite each other, with their knees
32583: touching.
32584: 
32585: “You know, Dodo, it is very bad,” said Celia, in her placid guttural,
32586: looking as prettily free from humors as possible. “You have
32587: disappointed us all so. And I can’t think that it ever _will_ be—you
32588: never can go and live in that way. And then there are all your plans!
32589: You never can have thought of that. James would have taken any trouble
32590: for you, and you might have gone on all your life doing what you
32591: liked.”
32592: 
32593: “On the contrary, dear,” said Dorothea, “I never could do anything that
32594: I liked. I have never carried out any plan yet.”
32595: 
32596: “Because you always wanted things that wouldn’t do. But other plans
32597: would have come. And how _can_ you marry Mr. Ladislaw, that we none of
32598: us ever thought you _could_ marry? It shocks James so dreadfully. And
32599: then it is all so different from what you have always been. You would
32600: have Mr. Casaubon because he had such a great soul, and was so old and
32601: dismal and learned; and now, to think of marrying Mr. Ladislaw, who has
32602: got no estate or anything. I suppose it is because you must be making
32603: yourself uncomfortable in some way or other.”
32604: 
32605: Dorothea laughed.
32606: 
32607: “Well, it is very serious, Dodo,” said Celia, becoming more impressive.
32608: “How will you live? and you will go away among queer people. And I
32609: shall never see you—and you won’t mind about little Arthur—and I
32610: thought you always would—”
32611: 
32612: Celia’s rare tears had got into her eyes, and the corners of her mouth
32613: were agitated.
32614: 
32615: “Dear Celia,” said Dorothea, with tender gravity, “if you don’t ever
32616: see me, it will not be my fault.”
32617: 
32618: “Yes, it will,” said Celia, with the same touching distortion of her
32619: small features. “How can I come to you or have you with me when James
32620: can’t bear it?—that is because he thinks it is not right—he thinks you
32621: are so wrong, Dodo. But you always were wrong: only I can’t help loving
32622: you. And nobody can think where you will live: where can you go?”
32623: 
32624: “I am going to London,” said Dorothea.
32625: 
32626: “How can you always live in a street? And you will be so poor. I could
32627: give you half my things, only how can I, when I never see you?”
32628: 
32629: “Bless you, Kitty,” said Dorothea, with gentle warmth. “Take comfort:
32630: perhaps James will forgive me some time.”
32631: 
32632: “But it would be much better if you would not be married,” said Celia,
32633: drying her eyes, and returning to her argument; “then there would be
32634: nothing uncomfortable. And you would not do what nobody thought you
32635: could do. James always said you ought to be a queen; but this is not at
32636: all being like a queen. You know what mistakes you have always been
32637: making, Dodo, and this is another. Nobody thinks Mr. Ladislaw a proper
32638: husband for you. And you _said_ you would never be married again.”
32639: 
32640: “It is quite true that I might be a wiser person, Celia,” said
32641: Dorothea, “and that I might have done something better, if I had been
32642: better. But this is what I am going to do. I have promised to marry Mr.
32643: Ladislaw; and I am going to marry him.”
32644: 
32645: The tone in which Dorothea said this was a note that Celia had long
32646: learned to recognize. She was silent a few moments, and then said, as
32647: if she had dismissed all contest, “Is he very fond of you, Dodo?”
32648: 
32649: “I hope so. I am very fond of him.”
32650: 
32651: “That is nice,” said Celia, comfortably. “Only I would rather you had
32652: such a sort of husband as James is, with a place very near, that I
32653: could drive to.”
32654: 
32655: Dorothea smiled, and Celia looked rather meditative. Presently she
32656: said, “I cannot think how it all came about.” Celia thought it would be
32657: pleasant to hear the story.
32658: 
32659: “I dare say not,” said Dorothea, pinching her sister’s chin. “If you
32660: knew how it came about, it would not seem wonderful to you.”
32661: 
32662: “Can’t you tell me?” said Celia, settling her arms cozily.
32663: 
32664: “No, dear, you would have to feel with me, else you would never know.”
32665: 
32666: 
32667: 
32668: 
32669: CHAPTER LXXXV.
32670: 
32671: “Then went the jury out whose names were Mr. Blindman, Mr. No-good, Mr.
32672: Malice, Mr. Love-lust, Mr. Live-loose, Mr. Heady, Mr. High-mind, Mr.
32673: Enmity, Mr. Liar, Mr. Cruelty, Mr. Hate-light, Mr. Implacable, who
32674: every one gave in his private verdict against him among themselves, and
32675: afterwards unanimously concluded to bring him in guilty before the
32676: judge. And first among themselves, Mr. Blindman, the foreman, said, I
32677: see clearly that this man is a heretic. Then said Mr. No-good, Away
32678: with such a fellow from the earth! Ay, said Mr. Malice, for I hate the
32679: very look of him. Then said Mr. Love-lust, I could never endure him.
32680: Nor I, said Mr. Live-loose; for he would be always condemning my way.
32681: Hang him, hang him, said Mr. Heady. A sorry scrub, said Mr. High-mind.
32682: My heart riseth against him, said Mr. Enmity. He is a rogue, said Mr.
32683: Liar. Hanging is too good for him, said Mr. Cruelty. Let us despatch
32684: him out of the way said Mr. Hate-light. Then said Mr. Implacable, Might
32685: I have all the world given me, I could not be reconciled to him;
32686: therefore let us forthwith bring him in guilty of death.”—_Pilgrim’s
32687: Progress_.
32688: 
32689: 
32690: When immortal Bunyan makes his picture of the persecuting passions
32691: bringing in their verdict of guilty, who pities Faithful? That is a
32692: rare and blessed lot which some greatest men have not attained, to know
32693: ourselves guiltless before a condemning crowd—to be sure that what we
32694: are denounced for is solely the good in us. The pitiable lot is that of
32695: the man who could not call himself a martyr even though he were to
32696: persuade himself that the men who stoned him were but ugly passions
32697: incarnate—who knows that he is stoned, not for professing the Right,
32698: but for not being the man he professed to be.
32699: 
32700: This was the consciousness that Bulstrode was withering under while he
32701: made his preparations for departing from Middlemarch, and going to end
32702: his stricken life in that sad refuge, the indifference of new faces.
32703: The duteous merciful constancy of his wife had delivered him from one
32704: dread, but it could not hinder her presence from being still a tribunal
32705: before which he shrank from confession and desired advocacy. His
32706: equivocations with himself about the death of Raffles had sustained the
32707: conception of an Omniscience whom he prayed to, yet he had a terror
32708: upon him which would not let him expose them to judgment by a full
32709: confession to his wife: the acts which he had washed and diluted with
32710: inward argument and motive, and for which it seemed comparatively easy
32711: to win invisible pardon—what name would she call them by? That she
32712: should ever silently call his acts Murder was what he could not bear.
32713: He felt shrouded by her doubt: he got strength to face her from the
32714: sense that she could not yet feel warranted in pronouncing that worst
32715: condemnation on him. Some time, perhaps—when he was dying—he would tell
32716: her all: in the deep shadow of that time, when she held his hand in the
32717: gathering darkness, she might listen without recoiling from his touch.
32718: Perhaps: but concealment had been the habit of his life, and the
32719: impulse to confession had no power against the dread of a deeper
32720: humiliation.
32721: 
32722: He was full of timid care for his wife, not only because he deprecated
32723: any harshness of judgment from her, but because he felt a deep distress
32724: at the sight of her suffering. She had sent her daughters away to board
32725: at a school on the coast, that this crisis might be hidden from them as
32726: far as possible. Set free by their absence from the intolerable
32727: necessity of accounting for her grief or of beholding their frightened
32728: wonder, she could live unconstrainedly with the sorrow that was every
32729: day streaking her hair with whiteness and making her eyelids languid.
32730: 
32731: “Tell me anything that you would like to have me do, Harriet,”
32732: Bulstrode had said to her; “I mean with regard to arrangements of
32733: property. It is my intention not to sell the land I possess in this
32734: neighborhood, but to leave it to you as a safe provision. If you have
32735: any wish on such subjects, do not conceal it from me.”
32736: 
32737: A few days afterwards, when she had returned from a visit to her
32738: brother’s, she began to speak to her husband on a subject which had for
32739: some time been in her mind.
32740: 
32741: “I _should_ like to do something for my brother’s family, Nicholas; and
32742: I think we are bound to make some amends to Rosamond and her husband.
32743: Walter says Mr. Lydgate must leave the town, and his practice is almost
32744: good for nothing, and they have very little left to settle anywhere
32745: with. I would rather do without something for ourselves, to make some
32746: amends to my poor brother’s family.”
32747: 
32748: Mrs. Bulstrode did not wish to go nearer to the facts than in the
32749: phrase “make some amends;” knowing that her husband must understand
32750: her. He had a particular reason, which she was not aware of, for
32751: wincing under her suggestion. He hesitated before he said—
32752: 
32753: “It is not possible to carry out your wish in the way you propose, my
32754: dear. Mr. Lydgate has virtually rejected any further service from me.
32755: He has returned the thousand pounds which I lent him. Mrs. Casaubon
32756: advanced him the sum for that purpose. Here is his letter.”
32757: 
32758: The letter seemed to cut Mrs. Bulstrode severely. The mention of Mrs.
32759: Casaubon’s loan seemed a reflection of that public feeling which held
32760: it a matter of course that every one would avoid a connection with her
32761: husband. She was silent for some time; and the tears fell one after the
32762: other, her chin trembling as she wiped them away. Bulstrode, sitting
32763: opposite to her, ached at the sight of that grief-worn face, which two
32764: months before had been bright and blooming. It had aged to keep sad
32765: company with his own withered features. Urged into some effort at
32766: comforting her, he said—
32767: 
32768: “There is another means, Harriet, by which I might do a service to your
32769: brother’s family, if you like to act in it. And it would, I think, be
32770: beneficial to you: it would be an advantageous way of managing the land
32771: which I mean to be yours.”
32772: 
32773: She looked attentive.
32774: 
32775: “Garth once thought of undertaking the management of Stone Court in
32776: order to place your nephew Fred there. The stock was to remain as it
32777: is, and they were to pay a certain share of the profits instead of an
32778: ordinary rent. That would be a desirable beginning for the young man,
32779: in conjunction with his employment under Garth. Would it be a
32780: satisfaction to you?”
32781: 
32782: “Yes, it would,” said Mrs. Bulstrode, with some return of energy. “Poor
32783: Walter is so cast down; I would try anything in my power to do him some
32784: good before I go away. We have always been brother and sister.”
32785: 
32786: “You must make the proposal to Garth yourself, Harriet,” said Mr.
32787: Bulstrode, not liking what he had to say, but desiring the end he had
32788: in view, for other reasons besides the consolation of his wife. “You
32789: must state to him that the land is virtually yours, and that he need
32790: have no transactions with me. Communications can be made through
32791: Standish. I mention this, because Garth gave up being my agent. I can
32792: put into your hands a paper which he himself drew up, stating
32793: conditions; and you can propose his renewed acceptance of them. I think
32794: it is not unlikely that he will accept when you propose the thing for
32795: the sake of your nephew.”
32796: 
32797: 
32798: 
32799: 
32800: CHAPTER LXXXVI.
32801: 
32802: “Le cœur se sature d’amour comme d’un sel divin qui le conserve; de là
32803: l’incorruptible adhérence de ceux qui se sont aimés dès l’aube de la
32804: vie, et la fraîcheur des vielles amours prolongées. Il existe un
32805: embaumement d’amour. C’est de Daphnis et Chloé que sont faits Philémon
32806: et Baucis. Cette vieillesse-là, ressemblance du soir avec
32807: l’aurore.”—VICTOR HUGO: _L’homme qui rit_.
32808: 
32809: 
32810: Mrs. Garth, hearing Caleb enter the passage about tea-time, opened the
32811: parlor-door and said, “There you are, Caleb. Have you had your dinner?”
32812: (Mr. Garth’s meals were much subordinated to “business.”)
32813: 
32814: “Oh yes, a good dinner—cold mutton and I don’t know what. Where is
32815: Mary?”
32816: 
32817: “In the garden with Letty, I think.”
32818: 
32819: “Fred is not come yet?”
32820: 
32821: “No. Are you going out again without taking tea, Caleb?” said Mrs.
32822: Garth, seeing that her absent-minded husband was putting on again the
32823: hat which he had just taken off.
32824: 
32825: “No, no; I’m only going to Mary a minute.”
32826: 
32827: Mary was in a grassy corner of the garden, where there was a swing
32828: loftily hung between two pear-trees. She had a pink kerchief tied over
32829: her head, making a little poke to shade her eyes from the level
32830: sunbeams, while she was giving a glorious swing to Letty, who laughed
32831: and screamed wildly.
32832: 
32833: Seeing her father, Mary left the swing and went to meet him, pushing
32834: back the pink kerchief and smiling afar off at him with the involuntary
32835: smile of loving pleasure.
32836: 
32837: “I came to look for you, Mary,” said Mr. Garth. “Let us walk about a
32838: bit.”
32839: 
32840: Mary knew quite well that her father had something particular to say:
32841: his eyebrows made their pathetic angle, and there was a tender gravity
32842: in his voice: these things had been signs to her when she was Letty’s
32843: age. She put her arm within his, and they turned by the row of
32844: nut-trees.
32845: 
32846: “It will be a sad while before you can be married, Mary,” said her
32847: father, not looking at her, but at the end of the stick which he held
32848: in his other hand.
32849: 
32850: “Not a sad while, father—I mean to be merry,” said Mary, laughingly. “I
32851: have been single and merry for four-and-twenty years and more: I
32852: suppose it will not be quite as long again as that.” Then, after a
32853: little pause, she said, more gravely, bending her face before her
32854: father’s, “If you are contented with Fred?”
32855: 
32856: Caleb screwed up his mouth and turned his head aside wisely.
32857: 
32858: “Now, father, you did praise him last Wednesday. You said he had an
32859: uncommon notion of stock, and a good eye for things.”
32860: 
32861: “Did I?” said Caleb, rather slyly.
32862: 
32863: “Yes, I put it all down, and the date, _anno Domini_, and everything,”
32864: said Mary. “You like things to be neatly booked. And then his behavior
32865: to you, father, is really good; he has a deep respect for you; and it
32866: is impossible to have a better temper than Fred has.”
32867: 
32868: “Ay, ay; you want to coax me into thinking him a fine match.”
32869: 
32870: “No, indeed, father. I don’t love him because he is a fine match.”
32871: 
32872: “What for, then?”
32873: 
32874: “Oh, dear, because I have always loved him. I should never like
32875: scolding any one else so well; and that is a point to be thought of in
32876: a husband.”
32877: 
32878: “Your mind is quite settled, then, Mary?” said Caleb, returning to his
32879: first tone. “There’s no other wish come into it since things have been
32880: going on as they have been of late?” (Caleb meant a great deal in that
32881: vague phrase;) “because, better late than never. A woman must not force
32882: her heart—she’ll do a man no good by that.”
32883: 
32884: “My feelings have not changed, father,” said Mary, calmly. “I shall be
32885: constant to Fred as long as he is constant to me. I don’t think either
32886: of us could spare the other, or like any one else better, however much
32887: we might admire them. It would make too great a difference to us—like
32888: seeing all the old places altered, and changing the name for
32889: everything. We must wait for each other a long while; but Fred knows
32890: that.”
32891: 
32892: Instead of speaking immediately, Caleb stood still and screwed his
32893: stick on the grassy walk. Then he said, with emotion in his voice,
32894: “Well, I’ve got a bit of news. What do you think of Fred going to live
32895: at Stone Court, and managing the land there?”
32896: 
32897: “How can that ever be, father?” said Mary, wonderingly.
32898: 
32899: “He would manage it for his aunt Bulstrode. The poor woman has been to
32900: me begging and praying. She wants to do the lad good, and it might be a
32901: fine thing for him. With saving, he might gradually buy the stock, and
32902: he has a turn for farming.”
32903: 
32904: “Oh, Fred would be so happy! It is too good to believe.”
32905: 
32906: “Ah, but mind you,” said Caleb, turning his head warningly, “I must
32907: take it on _my_ shoulders, and be responsible, and see after
32908: everything; and that will grieve your mother a bit, though she mayn’t
32909: say so. Fred had need be careful.”
32910: 
32911: “Perhaps it is too much, father,” said Mary, checked in her joy. “There
32912: would be no happiness in bringing you any fresh trouble.”
32913: 
32914: “Nay, nay; work is my delight, child, when it doesn’t vex your mother.
32915: And then, if you and Fred get married,” here Caleb’s voice shook just
32916: perceptibly, “he’ll be steady and saving; and you’ve got your mother’s
32917: cleverness, and mine too, in a woman’s sort of way; and you’ll keep him
32918: in order. He’ll be coming by-and-by, so I wanted to tell you first,
32919: because I think you’d like to tell _him_ by yourselves. After that, I
32920: could talk it well over with him, and we could go into business and the
32921: nature of things.”
32922: 
32923: “Oh, you dear good father!” cried Mary, putting her hands round her
32924: father’s neck, while he bent his head placidly, willing to be caressed.
32925: “I wonder if any other girl thinks her father the best man in the
32926: world!”
32927: 
32928: “Nonsense, child; you’ll think your husband better.”
32929: 
32930: “Impossible,” said Mary, relapsing into her usual tone; “husbands are
32931: an inferior class of men, who require keeping in order.”
32932: 
32933: When they were entering the house with Letty, who had run to join them,
32934: Mary saw Fred at the orchard-gate, and went to meet him.
32935: 
32936: “What fine clothes you wear, you extravagant youth!” said Mary, as Fred
32937: stood still and raised his hat to her with playful formality. “You are
32938: not learning economy.”
32939: 
32940: “Now that is too bad, Mary,” said Fred. “Just look at the edges of
32941: these coat-cuffs! It is only by dint of good brushing that I look
32942: respectable. I am saving up three suits—one for a wedding-suit.”
32943: 
32944: “How very droll you will look!—like a gentleman in an old
32945: fashion-book.”
32946: 
32947: “Oh no, they will keep two years.”
32948: 
32949: “Two years! be reasonable, Fred,” said Mary, turning to walk. “Don’t
32950: encourage flattering expectations.”
32951: 
32952: “Why not? One lives on them better than on unflattering ones. If we
32953: can’t be married in two years, the truth will be quite bad enough when
32954: it comes.”
32955: 
32956: “I have heard a story of a young gentleman who once encouraged
32957: flattering expectations, and they did him harm.”
32958: 
32959: “Mary, if you’ve got something discouraging to tell me, I shall bolt; I
32960: shall go into the house to Mr. Garth. I am out of spirits. My father is
32961: so cut up—home is not like itself. I can’t bear any more bad news.”
32962: 
32963: “Should you call it bad news to be told that you were to live at Stone
32964: Court, and manage the farm, and be remarkably prudent, and save money
32965: every year till all the stock and furniture were your own, and you were
32966: a distinguished agricultural character, as Mr. Borthrop Trumbull
32967: says—rather stout, I fear, and with the Greek and Latin sadly
32968: weather-worn?”
32969: 
32970: “You don’t mean anything except nonsense, Mary?” said Fred, coloring
32971: slightly nevertheless.
32972: 
32973: “That is what my father has just told me of as what may happen, and he
32974: never talks nonsense,” said Mary, looking up at Fred now, while he
32975: grasped her hand as they walked, till it rather hurt her; but she would
32976: not complain.
32977: 
32978: “Oh, I could be a tremendously good fellow then, Mary, and we could be
32979: married directly.”
32980: 
32981: “Not so fast, sir; how do you know that I would not rather defer our
32982: marriage for some years? That would leave you time to misbehave, and
32983: then if I liked some one else better, I should have an excuse for
32984: jilting you.”
32985: 
32986: “Pray don’t joke, Mary,” said Fred, with strong feeling. “Tell me
32987: seriously that all this is true, and that you are happy because of
32988: it—because you love me best.”
32989: 
32990: “It is all true, Fred, and I am happy because of it—because I love you
32991: best,” said Mary, in a tone of obedient recitation.
32992: 
32993: They lingered on the door-step under the steep-roofed porch, and Fred
32994: almost in a whisper said—
32995: 
32996: “When we were first engaged, with the umbrella-ring, Mary, you used
32997: to—”
32998: 
32999: The spirit of joy began to laugh more decidedly in Mary’s eyes, but the
33000: fatal Ben came running to the door with Brownie yapping behind him,
33001: and, bouncing against them, said—
33002: 
33003: “Fred and Mary! are you ever coming in?—or may I eat your cake?”
33004: 
33005: 
33006: 
33007: 
33008: FINALE.
33009: 
33010: Every limit is a beginning as well as an ending. Who can quit young
33011: lives after being long in company with them, and not desire to know
33012: what befell them in their after-years? For the fragment of a life,
33013: however typical, is not the sample of an even web: promises may not be
33014: kept, and an ardent outset may be followed by declension; latent powers
33015: may find their long-waited opportunity; a past error may urge a grand
33016: retrieval.
33017: 
33018: Marriage, which has been the bourne of so many narratives, is still a
33019: great beginning, as it was to Adam and Eve, who kept their honeymoon in
33020: Eden, but had their first little one among the thorns and thistles of
33021: the wilderness. It is still the beginning of the home epic—the gradual
33022: conquest or irremediable loss of that complete union which makes the
33023: advancing years a climax, and age the harvest of sweet memories in
33024: common.
33025: 
33026: Some set out, like Crusaders of old, with a glorious equipment of hope
33027: and enthusiasm and get broken by the way, wanting patience with each
33028: other and the world.
33029: 
33030: All who have cared for Fred Vincy and Mary Garth will like to know that
33031: these two made no such failure, but achieved a solid mutual happiness.
33032: Fred surprised his neighbors in various ways. He became rather
33033: distinguished in his side of the county as a theoretic and practical
33034: farmer, and produced a work on the “Cultivation of Green Crops and the
33035: Economy of Cattle-Feeding” which won him high congratulations at
33036: agricultural meetings. In Middlemarch admiration was more reserved:
33037: most persons there were inclined to believe that the merit of Fred’s
33038: authorship was due to his wife, since they had never expected Fred
33039: Vincy to write on turnips and mangel-wurzel.
33040: 
33041: But when Mary wrote a little book for her boys, called “Stories of
33042: Great Men, taken from Plutarch,” and had it printed and published by
33043: Gripp & Co., Middlemarch, every one in the town was willing to give the
33044: credit of this work to Fred, observing that he had been to the
33045: University, “where the ancients were studied,” and might have been a
33046: clergyman if he had chosen.
33047: 
33048: In this way it was made clear that Middlemarch had never been deceived,
33049: and that there was no need to praise anybody for writing a book, since
33050: it was always done by somebody else.
33051: 
33052: Moreover, Fred remained unswervingly steady. Some years after his
33053: marriage he told Mary that his happiness was half owing to Farebrother,
33054: who gave him a strong pull-up at the right moment. I cannot say that he
33055: was never again misled by his hopefulness: the yield of crops or the
33056: profits of a cattle sale usually fell below his estimate; and he was
33057: always prone to believe that he could make money by the purchase of a
33058: horse which turned out badly—though this, Mary observed, was of course
33059: the fault of the horse, not of Fred’s judgment. He kept his love of
33060: horsemanship, but he rarely allowed himself a day’s hunting; and when
33061: he did so, it was remarkable that he submitted to be laughed at for
33062: cowardliness at the fences, seeming to see Mary and the boys sitting on
33063: the five-barred gate, or showing their curly heads between hedge and
33064: ditch.
33065: 
33066: There were three boys: Mary was not discontented that she brought forth
33067: men-children only; and when Fred wished to have a girl like her, she
33068: said, laughingly, “that would be too great a trial to your mother.”
33069: Mrs. Vincy in her declining years, and in the diminished lustre of her
33070: housekeeping, was much comforted by her perception that two at least of
33071: Fred’s boys were real Vincys, and did not “feature the Garths.” But
33072: Mary secretly rejoiced that the youngest of the three was very much
33073: what her father must have been when he wore a round jacket, and showed
33074: a marvellous nicety of aim in playing at marbles, or in throwing stones
33075: to bring down the mellow pears.
33076: 
33077: Ben and Letty Garth, who were uncle and aunt before they were well in
33078: their teens, disputed much as to whether nephews or nieces were more
33079: desirable; Ben contending that it was clear girls were good for less
33080: than boys, else they would not be always in petticoats, which showed
33081: how little they were meant for; whereupon Letty, who argued much from
33082: books, got angry in replying that God made coats of skins for both Adam
33083: and Eve alike—also it occurred to her that in the East the men too wore
33084: petticoats. But this latter argument, obscuring the majesty of the
33085: former, was one too many, for Ben answered contemptuously, “The more
33086: spooneys they!” and immediately appealed to his mother whether boys
33087: were not better than girls. Mrs. Garth pronounced that both were alike
33088: naughty, but that boys were undoubtedly stronger, could run faster, and
33089: throw with more precision to a greater distance. With this oracular
33090: sentence Ben was well satisfied, not minding the naughtiness; but Letty
33091: took it ill, her feeling of superiority being stronger than her
33092: muscles.
33093: 
33094: Fred never became rich—his hopefulness had not led him to expect that;
33095: but he gradually saved enough to become owner of the stock and
33096: furniture at Stone Court, and the work which Mr. Garth put into his
33097: hands carried him in plenty through those “bad times” which are always
33098: present with farmers. Mary, in her matronly days, became as solid in
33099: figure as her mother; but, unlike her, gave the boys little formal
33100: teaching, so that Mrs. Garth was alarmed lest they should never be well
33101: grounded in grammar and geography. Nevertheless, they were found quite
33102: forward enough when they went to school; perhaps, because they had
33103: liked nothing so well as being with their mother. When Fred was riding
33104: home on winter evenings he had a pleasant vision beforehand of the
33105: bright hearth in the wainscoted parlor, and was sorry for other men who
33106: could not have Mary for their wife; especially for Mr. Farebrother. “He
33107: was ten times worthier of you than I was,” Fred could now say to her,
33108: magnanimously. “To be sure he was,” Mary answered; “and for that reason
33109: he could do better without me. But you—I shudder to think what you
33110: would have been—a curate in debt for horse-hire and cambric
33111: pocket-handkerchiefs!”
33112: 
33113: On inquiry it might possibly be found that Fred and Mary still inhabit
33114: Stone Court—that the creeping plants still cast the foam of their
33115: blossoms over the fine stone-wall into the field where the walnut-trees
33116: stand in stately row—and that on sunny days the two lovers who were
33117: first engaged with the umbrella-ring may be seen in white-haired
33118: placidity at the open window from which Mary Garth, in the days of old
33119: Peter Featherstone, had often been ordered to look out for Mr. Lydgate.
33120: 
33121: Lydgate’s hair never became white. He died when he was only fifty,
33122: leaving his wife and children provided for by a heavy insurance on his
33123: life. He had gained an excellent practice, alternating, according to
33124: the season, between London and a Continental bathing-place; having
33125: written a treatise on Gout, a disease which has a good deal of wealth
33126: on its side. His skill was relied on by many paying patients, but he
33127: always regarded himself as a failure: he had not done what he once
33128: meant to do. His acquaintances thought him enviable to have so charming
33129: a wife, and nothing happened to shake their opinion. Rosamond never
33130: committed a second compromising indiscretion. She simply continued to
33131: be mild in her temper, inflexible in her judgment, disposed to admonish
33132: her husband, and able to frustrate him by stratagem. As the years went
33133: on he opposed her less and less, whence Rosamond concluded that he had
33134: learned the value of her opinion; on the other hand, she had a more
33135: thorough conviction of his talents now that he gained a good income,
33136: and instead of the threatened cage in Bride Street provided one all
33137: flowers and gilding, fit for the bird of paradise that she resembled.
33138: In brief, Lydgate was what is called a successful man. But he died
33139: prematurely of diphtheria, and Rosamond afterwards married an elderly
33140: and wealthy physician, who took kindly to her four children. She made a
33141: very pretty show with her daughters, driving out in her carriage, and
33142: often spoke of her happiness as “a reward”—she did not say for what,
33143: but probably she meant that it was a reward for her patience with
33144: Tertius, whose temper never became faultless, and to the last
33145: occasionally let slip a bitter speech which was more memorable than the
33146: signs he made of his repentance. He once called her his basil plant;
33147: and when she asked for an explanation, said that basil was a plant
33148: which had flourished wonderfully on a murdered man’s brains. Rosamond
33149: had a placid but strong answer to such speeches. Why then had he chosen
33150: her? It was a pity he had not had Mrs. Ladislaw, whom he was always
33151: praising and placing above her. And thus the conversation ended with
33152: the advantage on Rosamond’s side. But it would be unjust not to tell,
33153: that she never uttered a word in depreciation of Dorothea, keeping in
33154: religious remembrance the generosity which had come to her aid in the
33155: sharpest crisis of her life.
33156: 
33157: Dorothea herself had no dreams of being praised above other women,
33158: feeling that there was always something better which she might have
33159: done, if she had only been better and known better. Still, she never
33160: repented that she had given up position and fortune to marry Will
33161: Ladislaw, and he would have held it the greatest shame as well as
33162: sorrow to him if she had repented. They were bound to each other by a
33163: love stronger than any impulses which could have marred it. No life
33164: would have been possible to Dorothea which was not filled with emotion,
33165: and she had now a life filled also with a beneficent activity which she
33166: had not the doubtful pains of discovering and marking out for herself.
33167: Will became an ardent public man, working well in those times when
33168: reforms were begun with a young hopefulness of immediate good which has
33169: been much checked in our days, and getting at last returned to
33170: Parliament by a constituency who paid his expenses. Dorothea could have
33171: liked nothing better, since wrongs existed, than that her husband
33172: should be in the thick of a struggle against them, and that she should
33173: give him wifely help. Many who knew her, thought it a pity that so
33174: substantive and rare a creature should have been absorbed into the life
33175: of another, and be only known in a certain circle as a wife and mother.
33176: But no one stated exactly what else that was in her power she ought
33177: rather to have done—not even Sir James Chettam, who went no further
33178: than the negative prescription that she ought not to have married Will
33179: Ladislaw.
33180: 
33181: But this opinion of his did not cause a lasting alienation; and the way
33182: in which the family was made whole again was characteristic of all
33183: concerned. Mr. Brooke could not resist the pleasure of corresponding
33184: with Will and Dorothea; and one morning when his pen had been
33185: remarkably fluent on the prospects of Municipal Reform, it ran off into
33186: an invitation to the Grange, which, once written, could not be done
33187: away with at less cost than the sacrifice (hardly to be conceived) of
33188: the whole valuable letter. During the months of this correspondence Mr.
33189: Brooke had continually, in his talk with Sir James Chettam, been
33190: presupposing or hinting that the intention of cutting off the entail
33191: was still maintained; and the day on which his pen gave the daring
33192: invitation, he went to Freshitt expressly to intimate that he had a
33193: stronger sense than ever of the reasons for taking that energetic step
33194: as a precaution against any mixture of low blood in the heir of the
33195: Brookes.
33196: 
33197: But that morning something exciting had happened at the Hall. A letter
33198: had come to Celia which made her cry silently as she read it; and when
33199: Sir James, unused to see her in tears, asked anxiously what was the
33200: matter, she burst out in a wail such as he had never heard from her
33201: before.
33202: 
33203: “Dorothea has a little boy. And you will not let me go and see her. And
33204: I am sure she wants to see me. And she will not know what to do with
33205: the baby—she will do wrong things with it. And they thought she would
33206: die. It is very dreadful! Suppose it had been me and little Arthur, and
33207: Dodo had been hindered from coming to see me! I wish you would be less
33208: unkind, James!”
33209: 
33210: “Good heavens, Celia!” said Sir James, much wrought upon, “what do you
33211: wish? I will do anything you like. I will take you to town to-morrow if
33212: you wish it.” And Celia did wish it.
33213: 
33214: It was after this that Mr. Brooke came, and meeting the Baronet in the
33215: grounds, began to chat with him in ignorance of the news, which Sir
33216: James for some reason did not care to tell him immediately. But when
33217: the entail was touched on in the usual way, he said, “My dear sir, it
33218: is not for me to dictate to you, but for my part I would let that
33219: alone. I would let things remain as they are.”
33220: 
33221: Mr. Brooke felt so much surprised that he did not at once find out how
33222: much he was relieved by the sense that he was not expected to do
33223: anything in particular.
33224: 
33225: Such being the bent of Celia’s heart, it was inevitable that Sir James
33226: should consent to a reconciliation with Dorothea and her husband. Where
33227: women love each other, men learn to smother their mutual dislike. Sir
33228: James never liked Ladislaw, and Will always preferred to have Sir
33229: James’s company mixed with another kind: they were on a footing of
33230: reciprocal tolerance which was made quite easy only when Dorothea and
33231: Celia were present.
33232: 
33233: It became an understood thing that Mr. and Mrs. Ladislaw should pay at
33234: least two visits during the year to the Grange, and there came
33235: gradually a small row of cousins at Freshitt who enjoyed playing with
33236: the two cousins visiting Tipton as much as if the blood of these
33237: cousins had been less dubiously mixed.
33238: 
33239: Mr. Brooke lived to a good old age, and his estate was inherited by
33240: Dorothea’s son, who might have represented Middlemarch, but declined,
33241: thinking that his opinions had less chance of being stifled if he
33242: remained out of doors.
33243: 
33244: Sir James never ceased to regard Dorothea’s second marriage as a
33245: mistake; and indeed this remained the tradition concerning it in
33246: Middlemarch, where she was spoken of to a younger generation as a fine
33247: girl who married a sickly clergyman, old enough to be her father, and
33248: in little more than a year after his death gave up her estate to marry
33249: his cousin—young enough to have been his son, with no property, and not
33250: well-born. Those who had not seen anything of Dorothea usually observed
33251: that she could not have been “a nice woman,” else she would not have
33252: married either the one or the other.
33253: 
33254: Certainly those determining acts of her life were not ideally
33255: beautiful. They were the mixed result of young and noble impulse
33256: struggling amidst the conditions of an imperfect social state, in which
33257: great feelings will often take the aspect of error, and great faith the
33258: aspect of illusion. For there is no creature whose inward being is so
33259: strong that it is not greatly determined by what lies outside it. A new
33260: Theresa will hardly have the opportunity of reforming a conventual
33261: life, any more than a new Antigone will spend her heroic piety in
33262: daring all for the sake of a brother’s burial: the medium in which
33263: their ardent deeds took shape is forever gone. But we insignificant
33264: people with our daily words and acts are preparing the lives of many
33265: Dorotheas, some of which may present a far sadder sacrifice than that
33266: of the Dorothea whose story we know.
33267: 
33268: Her finely touched spirit had still its fine issues, though they were
33269: not widely visible. Her full nature, like that river of which Cyrus
33270: broke the strength, spent itself in channels which had no great name on
33271: the earth. But the effect of her being on those around her was
33272: incalculably diffusive: for the growing good of the world is partly
33273: dependent on unhistoric acts; and that things are not so ill with you
33274: and me as they might have been, is half owing to the number who lived
33275: faithfully a hidden life, and rest in unvisited tombs.
33276: 
33277: THE END
